column2: In cases of shipwrecks and other disasters to vessels at son, we so often hear from passengers of the bad conduct of ship's officers, and we so often hear from officers of the foolish action of passengers, that we cannot help calling special attention to certain facts developed in connection with the loss of the steamship Germania, which recently left this port for Hamburg.

A lad named JAMES I. RICE was brought before (Judge JONES, (of the Superior Court, Special Term, yesterday, on a writ of Habeas corpus, which was sued out at the instance of Counselor ALANSON NASH. From the statement of the latter it appears that the prisoner RICE, who is aged about 16 years, was indicated for robbery in the first degree about one year since.

The village of livington, on the Hudson, so often mentioned as the Summer abode of the fashion and galety of this City, has lately been severely visited by the unsparing hand of death. Four ladies, esteemed both in themselves and as the wives of most respected members of that community, have been taken away within the short space of a month.

Additional testimony for the defence was introduced yesterday, in the case of THOS. W. EGAN, accused of having prepared fraudulent pay-rolls while acting as United States Weigher, FRANK WEBB, recently arrested on a charge of being implicated in the alleged fraud, was pro-...

The Triton Sharpshooters' Company, HENRY DEIKER Captain, in connection with about 100 members of the NEW-YORK Schuetzen Batalion, P. HEMMER Major, yesterday celebrated a picnic with target shooting and a summer night's festival, at Funk's East River Park, foot of Sixty-third-street, East River.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--A special dispatch to an evening paper, dated pharnixville, Penn., says that the boiler in the pharnix Iron Company's works at this place exploded this morning, killing from ten to twenty workmen and injuring as many more, Five dead bodies have been taken from the ruins up to 10 o'clock A. M.

GUSTAVE BRUHAR, a German with no knowledge of English, and with little, probably of the dangers of the Metropolis, was out in the streets at a late hour of the night, with $500 in French gold secured in a belt around his waist, under his clothing, and a gold watch valued at $100 in his vest pocket.

HAVANA, Aug. 30.--Letters from the jurisdiction of Colon state that the insurgents left that quarter, going cast ward, and taking with them all the slaves of the San Antonio estate. Governor TRILLO, of Sagua la Grande, surprised the insurgents at Euerucijada, and killed twelve of them.

CHARLOTTETOWN, P. E. I., Aug. 30.--A general holiday was observed here to-day in honor of the visit of Prince ARTHUR. He held a reception at noon, at which five hundred persons were present. He then drove around the city with his suite, and was enthusiastically cheered by the crowds on the streets.

On the western shore of the Hudson River, near Weehawken, about opposite Sixtieth street of this City, the "National Stock Yard Company" have been preparing suitable grounds, convenient and commodious yards, and other necessary appliances for one of the largest cattle markets round about New York.

The fourth annual Convention of the Associations of the State of New-York will meet at Schenectady on Tuesday, Sept. 21, 1869, at 3:30 o' clock, and close on Thursday evening. Delegations from all the associations are expected, and the attendance of young men and others interested in the cause from cities and towns where no such organizations leave yet been formed is also urged.

The principal civil, military and naval officers of the Government have been invited to attend the Georgia State Fale, and the Macon Telegraph expresses the earnest hope that very many of them will accept the invitation, and thus learn that the people of the South are not only willing but most anxious to accept the situation to return practically to the union, and to invite cooperation in all industrial enterprises.

The Medical Department of the University of New-York, which was established in 1811 in the ??, on Broadway, in New-York City, removed in 1857 to No. 167 East Fourteenth-street, but the Fourteenth-street college buildings being destroyed by fire in 1866, the Finally continued their lectures in the North House of the New-York Hospital till the end of last term, some few weeks age.

The quantity sent by railroad this week is 108,500,13 tons: by canal, 8,693 tons: for the week, 117,103,13 tons, against 102,767 tons for the corresponding week last year. The trade, it will be seen, is almost entirely suspended by canal for the want of water to supply the City of Philadelphia.

A crowded house at Brady's Curriculum last evening witnessed a novel entertainment. The feature of the evening's performance was the contest between JAMES SMITH, of Philadelphia, the champion pedestrian of America, and JAMES ADAMS, ex-champion, who were to walk three miles while JAMES H. BOYLE, champion velocipedist, rode a velocipede five miles.

The charge of forgery against ANDREW H. ADAMS, of the firm of WADSWORTH, ADAMS Co., his examination, release, and subsequent re-arrest upon four distinct charges, are matters well known to our renders, especially to our merchants, who evince great interest in everything relating to the development of the case.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug, 30.--From 1,000 to 1,500 men from the coal fields north and south of this city arrived here to-day by rail and wagon. Their avowed purpose is to prevent the coalminers of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company continuing at work, They are now holding their second meeting, but have taken no ?? action so far. .

The first can was raised to its place on the track of the Elevated Railway in Greenwich-street yesterday. This car is the first of ten which are in process of construction for the company, and is a fair sample of the whole. In appearance it is not unlike those in use on our street roads, except that it is larger and more handsomely finished.
JAMES HYNES, of No. 21 First Street, when in Second-avenue, near Twenty-fourth-street was kicked by a horse, and so severely injured that he was taken to Bellevue Hospital in a critical condition.

The Commissioners appointed to lay out, open and grade Berrian-avenue, between Fordkam and williams Bridge, on the west side of the Harlem Railroad, held a meeting a few days ago, and appointed Messrs. PETER RURLEY, one of the Commissioners, and WILLIAM RUMBLE, Civil Engineer, a Committee to wait upon the Central Park Commissioners and submit the plans and profile maps of the new road for the approval of the latter.

Almost daily during the present summer notices have been sent to the Contral police office from some one of the precincts stating that a mad dog had been shot by a policeman, and almost invariably the dog was shot only after it linf bittem severa; other dogs. Twice during the past week it was announced that the dog had bittem two children before it was killed.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 30.--About 7 o'clock this morning a drove of ninety head of Texan cattle that had been landed from the International ferry-boat stampeded, and ran in every direction through the streets at a furious rate, goring and trampling everything that came in their way.

The Executive Committee of the Seven-teenth Ward--"old Democratic Forty"--met last evening at Frink's saloon, No. 56 Avenue A, for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee appointed to confer with the Tammany leaders and to urge upon them the importance of recognizing the German Democrats of the Tenth Assembly District.

The Elementary Principles of Sewing Machine Mechanism and Sewing Machine Stitches, wit a Glance at the history of the Sewing Machine, is the title of a neat and instructive pamphlet, or manual which is just offered to the public by Mr. J. BATTEY, of this City.

LONDON, Aug, 30.--Authentic details of the war in Paraguay have been received. No operations have been attempted by the Allies against the forces of LOPEZ in the mountains, nor have the Paraguayans offered any opposition to General PARTINHO'S march on Villa Reca.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 30.-- Seller LEMUS, the Cuban Envoy, has received no information from Cuba late than that already published. He speaks in hopeful terms of the struggle, and does not doubt the final success of the revolutionists.

HENRY LAYTON, charged with having circulated counterfeit currency stamps, was brought into the United States Commissioner's office, yesterday, on a motion for his discharge. His counsel claimed that he could not he held, from the fact that the stamps were not produced in evidence by the Government at the time of his examination.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 30.--Nearly 100 Negroes have come to this place from the neighborhood of Rutherford County, and report that they have been driven away from their homes by lawless white men. These negroes have been working on shares with the planters, and they, as well as planters, will lose heavily if they are not protected in sceuring the crop.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of yesterday you called for an answer to the question "Is Vaccination Dangerous" and invited some doctor to come forward with the reasons and proofs of its utility and safety. Allow me, therefore, to call the attention of these of "little faith" to the following remarks:

In the absence of further telegraphic dispatches relative to the reported matiny on board the United States frigate Sabine, the painful announcement made yesterday, that seven of the crew were hanged at the yardarm, may be reasonably doubted.

The news this morning from the coal region shows that the late "peace" was only a brief lull. The old struggle between the minors and the companies is renewed, and now the element of intimidation is invoked by the miners.

WHEELING, W. va., Aug. 30--The Haymakers of Lnsingburg beat the Battles of this city, to-day, in a game to six innings, by a score of 50 to 10. The game was called to enable the Haymakers to take a train.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30.--J. ROSS BROWNE denies that he denounced BURLINGAME'S mission, and awards due credit to BURLINGAME for his honesty of purpose, but thinks the Chinese Government will not move forward except under the pressure that is by the enforcing of treaty rights.

About 6 o'clock last evening a fire broke out on the fourth floor of No. 40 Vesey-street, the whole of which building is occupied by W. H. GRIFFITH, billiard-table manufacturer. The fire originated from a stove used for making glue, and the flames were confined to a portion of the floor where they began, but the building was so deluged with water that the stock was damaged to the amount of $5,000.
LONDON, Aug. 30.--The article in the Atlantic Monthly by Mrs. STOWE, on Lord and Lady BYRON, creates considerable excitement. The Telegraph comments editorially:

All the Governments of Europe, with the exception of Russia, have now adopted liberal constitutional political principles, A few years ago, Italy, which is now united under a constitutional parliamentary Government, was in the hands of a number of petty tyrants, the most despotic of whom was FRANCIS H. of Naples.

These clubs played the second game of a series on the Peconie's ground, Bedford, Saturday, which was won by the latter. Darkness prevented more than four innings being played. Messrs. CHAPMAN JONES and SOMERS, of the St. James, played remarkably well in their positions.

As an enterprise of great national importance, we certainly consider it highly desirable that means should be found for the completion of the water highway through Virginia, between the seaboard and the West--the James River and Kanawha Canal.

The new rule of the Board of Police requiring members of the force to appear in uniform at all times, except when at home, when attending, going to and returning from Divine service, and when absent from their precincts by permission of the Board, has scarcely been promulgated in General Order No. 574, dated on Saturday last, before the general inconvenience and dissatisfaction the measure evoked were plainly apparent.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--The Times of to-day says there is much aaxiety with respect to French intelligence. NAPOLEON was certainly ill. None spoke of any imminent danger, yet there was the utmost uneasiness in Parisian Society and on the Bourse. The panic was intense on Thursday, and has been so since, though the alarm is now subsiding.
The Chicago Times, whose right to be called Democratic none can dispute, propounds an inquiry which we hope to see frankly answered by some adherent of the same faith:

PROVIDENCE, T. I., Aug. 30.--The schooner L. S. Knight of Camden, from Philadelphia for Salem, with a cargo of coal, was fallen in with, abandoned, at 6 o'clock, A. M., of the 20th inst., between Baruegat and Maintinocock, sixty miles from land, by the schooner Funnic Blake, from Philadelphia for Providence.

When the screw steamer Delaware, Captain BENJAMIN C. SMITH, of the independent line between this city, New-London and New-York for this city, and was distant about three miles from Sands Point east, the Captain, who was at the wheel, heard a faint voice as of some one in distress.

The Seventh Ward Tweed Club held a meeting last evening at their headquarters, No. 68 as East Broadway, to promote the interests of ?? favorite, Hon. WM. M. TWEED, Supervisor, Senator and Street Commissioner.
A correspondent of the Chicago Evening Journal gives, in a letter daied Salt Lake City, Aug. 18, an account of an interview with BRIGHAM YOUNG, from which we quote the following:

A general election of county officers and members of the Legislature is to be held in California on the 1st of September. The election of Judges of the Supreme Court does not take place until the 20th of October.

Coroner KEENAN held and inquest yesterday in the case of THOMAS MACAULAY, late foreman of Metropolitan Engine Company No. 4, who died suddenly on Sunday evening, while visiting a friend at No. 300 Water-street. Death was found to have resulted from the rupture of an aneurism of the aorta.

We are happy to learn that the extraordinary telegram from Hong Kong, representing the Chinese Government to have refused to ratify the treaty negotiated with the United States, is not credited at Washington.

Is there no one interested in rendering our great cities fit to be inhabited by large masses of human beings? Somebody not afraid to act in the interest of the Public, who happened to be armed with the requisite means and authority, could find a magnificent field for his talents in New-York.

At the colored camp meeting held between Jamaica and Flushing on Sunday, there were present rival factions of colored men from Jamaica and Flushing, who engaged in a free fight at about 10 o'clock in the evening, using clubs and stones. During the melee a man named CHARLES JACKSON, of "The Alley," Flushing, had his head out open, his cheeks lacerated and his nose broken.

The President of a colored men's trade union in Macon, Ga., has written a letter to friends in Washington City, saying that they were fully organized and willing to aid their brethren there. The writer says the colored mechanics are well organized for protection throughout the State;

CURTIS,--Suddenly, at Catskill, on Sunday, Aug. 29, JOHN HENRY, only son of Charles C. and Ghariotto A. Curtis, aged 12 years. Funeral from his late residence, No. 504 Attantie-st., Brooklyn, on Wednesday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. COMINGS,--On Sunday morning, Aug. 29, of son gostion of the brain, LOUIS S., youngest son of George and Anna R. Comings, aged 13 months.
The will of CORNELIUS GRLNNELI., whose accidental death at the Isle of Wight on the 10th inst. was announced by telegraph, has been admitted to probate in the Surrogate's office of this City.

Detective TULLY, of the Central Office, yesterday afternoon arrested EMMA M. MORGAN on the charge of stealing about $300 worth of clothing and jewelry, the property of Dr. UNDERWOOD, the poolseller and noted sporting man. A portion of the stolen property was found in EMMA'S possession.

Agreeably to previous arrangement, the Board of Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction granted a holiday yesterday to the children under their care domiciled in the institutions on Randall and Hart Islands, for the purpose of paying a visit to the residence of Hon. WM. M> TWEED, at Greenwich, Conn.,

MORE DEMOCRATIC TESTIMONY.--The Citizen speaking of the system of "repeating by which HOFFMAN was elected Governor last Fall. says: "Repeating can be carried on even where there is no false registry, or, to state it more accurately, illegal ballots can this be deposited in place of legal ones.

Through a friend I have obtained access to the letters and documents upon which the charges against THOMAS I. YOUNG Supervisor of Internal Revenue for the Southern District of Ohio, were founded. I have had an opportunity to examine them all, and lnd the following as a condensation of their contents: THE FIRST LETTER.

In order to bring producers of country mild and consumers of this healthful article of human food more on an equal footing in regard to prices, and to avoid the extortionate commissions of several middlemen, a number of farmers and dairymen in Rockland County, near Poughkeepsie, and some prominent citizens in this City have formed an association to be called the "United States Condensing Company,"

A grand entertainment in honor of the Harvard and Oxford crews took place at the Crystal Palace, Sydenham, Monday evening, under the auspices of the London Rowing Club. All the Harvard crew were present but Mr. LORING, and Mr. WILLAN represented Oxford. Speeches were made by CHARLES DICKENS, THOMAS HUGHES and others.

An examination was commenced yesterday in the case of CHARLES S. and WASHINGTON ARTHUR, composing the firm of ARCHER BROTHERS, grocers and wholesale liquor merchants, at No. 171 West-street, who are charged with having prepared and sworn to fraudulent revenue returns. M. J. CONNOLLY, the complainant, testified:

WILLIAM VARLEY, alias Reddy the Black-smith, with be brought before Recorder HACKETT at the September term of the Court of General Sessions, commencing on Monday next, at which time a day will be fixed on the calendar for his trial.

The trustees of the College of the City of New-York will meet on Tuesday next. When the propriety of continuing the classical course of studies will be discussed, and, so far as that institution is concerned, probably settled.

About three years and a half since a young man named C. D. COON came here from Ypsilanti, Mick., having spent a part of his life more recently of Springfield, Ohio, and Buffalo, N. Y., where he was a searcher of records. He was accompanied by his wife, Mrs. SUSAN W. COON. The newcomer was a good clerk and an active business man, but found some difficulty in procuring a situation at first.

A freight train from Louisville for this place, through the negligence of a workman on the road, ran off the track, near Brownsville, this morning. smashing several cars and fatally injuring the fireman and engineer. A passenger train from Chattanooga, for this place, ran through a bridge near Cortland, Ala.,

Senator TRUMBULL reached Omaha yesterday from his California and Montana trip. He leaves for home to-day. A bridge on the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, near Newton, Iowa, was washed away yesterday, and an engine and seven freight cars plunged through the opening. The engineer, fireman and one brakeman were killed.

MCDONALD.--On Monday, Aug. 20, at his residence, ALEXANDER MCDONALD, in the 47th year of his age. His relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral at his late residence, ??., North River, on Thursday, Sept. 2, at 12 o'clock. His remains will be interred in Green-Wood Cemetary. MARX.--On Tuesday, Aug. 31, after a long and serious illness, Mr. MAX MARX.

There is every prospect of a speedy termination to the long and dangerous controversey which has arisen out of the English law relating to naturalization and allegiance. The rule that a British citizen can never divest himself of his allegiance is so manifestly untenable in days like the present,

Judge HOGEBOOM held a special term of the Supreme Court to-day to hear motions relative to the Receivership of the Susquehanna Railroad. Mr. HALE, of counsel for the Ramsey interest, asked for a postponement till to-morrow, owing to the illness of Judge ALLEN, who was to argue the motions on the part of the Railroad Company.

Don CHARLOS has abandoned Spain,and all attempts, for the present at least, and we suspect foreever, to provoke a popular rising in support of his pretension to the throne. He has gone to England, and thus ends the Carlist Mememount.

The official call for the assembling of the Republican State Convention in Syracuse, on the 29th of September, makes some changes in the apportionment of delegates, but they affect only two districts. The fourth district of Oneida will have three delegates, instead of four, as first published, and the third district of Onondaga is entitled to four instead of three delegates.

The Scene has changed again at Serauton. Eccentric as the movements of the miners generally are, their last turnabout has been unusually sudden. On Monday a riot was imminent. A thousand men and more had assemble from the surrounding coal fields to overawe those miners who were disposed to accept the Scranton Company's terms and go to work.

The five monitors, to which we alluded in our yesterday morning's edition, were ordered from Mound City, Ill., to this port. They were built up the river, or on the Ohio, and have never been down the Mississippi before. Their present names, as ordered by Ex-Secretary BORIE, are: Tempest, late Yuma; Iris, late Shiloh; Fury, late Umpliqua;

The International postal money order system is to be commenced between the United States and Switzerland to-day, the latter country being the first to enter into an arrangement with our Post Office Department, whereby money orders may thus be transmitted between this country and Europe.

The ship laborers of this port are on a strike and the trade of the port is at almost a standstill. Yesterday the Laborers' Society, numbering 3,700 persons, marched in procession through the streets, and their conduct was so disorderly that the military was called out to prevent a riot. The Mayor and several prominent citizens were very roughly handled.

The Assistant Treasurer of this City, Doubt-less with a laudable desire to oblige the public, his issued a notice that "Parties resident out of the City Choosing to assume the risk and expense of carriage both ways, may remit coupons by mail or express,

The following additional particulars have been obtained respecting the death of Dr. CARLTON GATES, of Yorkers, and the nature of his will. The value of Dr. GATEE' property estimated at $209,000. The family mansion and surrounding grounds, comprising between six and seven acres of land in one of the most desirable locations in Yonkers, and valued at $100,000,

The number of deaths in the city during the past week was 237, being an increase of 27 over the number reported in the previous week. There were 81 deaths of children under one year, 44 under two years. There were 137 deaths of children under five years of age. The proportion of the deaths

The Committee of New-York Bankers and Brokers, when here last week, applied to Commissioner DELANO for an order directing the United States District-Attorney for the Eastern District of New-York to discontinue the suits recently brought by him against certain bankers and brokers residing in Brooklyn,

The gas in an empty oil tank on a freight train of the Boston and Albany Railroad, at Newton, exploded last night, causing the death of SAMUEL PRESTON, the conductor, by burning. A brakeman was slightly burned. The car was set on fire, but the flames were extinguished by the Newton fire engines.

The basin of the Central Park fountain is not to be of bronze, but is an octagonal monolith seventeen feet diameter) of polished Westerly granite, supported upon sixteen polished Scotch granite columns, standing on an orDamental blue-stone plinth. The bronze capitals and bases

A. T. FARRISH CO. received this morning from Dowuleville a nugget of gold weighting 106 pounds, being almost, if not quite, the largest ever taken out in this State, and within a few pounds the largest ever found in the modern gold-mining. The value is about $25,00.

Lieutenant-Colonel C. H. CARLTON has been detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, by direction of the President. The Empress EUGENIE is now reported at Ajaccio, where she will remain a day or two. She will return to Paris early in September.

The St. John's Newfoundland, Telegraph, of Aug. 18, says it has been handed the following interesting letter from Captain BARTLETT, of the steamship Panther. This vessel, it will be remembered, was hired by Mr. WM. BRADFORD, an American artist, to convey himself and friends on a scientific expedition to the Arctic regions, and sailed from St. john's on the 3d of July.

The WORRELL SISTERS--SOPHIE., JENNIE and IRENE--give two performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, commencing with this evening, when they present the burlesque of "Lalla Rookh." The sisters, who have achieved a considerable share of popularity, will be sustained by a well-organized company of their

Our author in setting out makes a reflection--which may be said to have also the air of an insinuation--that he writes because he has something to sav; and certainly his book vindicates the boast handsomely enough.

A correspondent in Augusta, Me., writing at the close of last week, says of the crop prospects in that State: "An intelligent estimate can now be made of the crops for the year, which have been in the main harvested. The hay Crop,

Mazatlan, Mexico, advices to Aug. 20 have been received. Political affairs in Northwestern Mexico are quiet. LOZADO refuses to assist PLACIDO VEGA with men or arms. The Governor of Durango declares that he will oppose with all his power the formation of an independent Republic.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A notice (in one or two morning papers) of the case of the brokers, HART HALE, has a tendency to injure the commercial integrity of the merchants GEO. S. HART Co., by implying that they were in collusion with HART HALE

This Committee met at Apollo Hall last evening. Mr. EDGAR KETCHUM in the chair. On motion, each District Committee handed in the name of a delegate to the Executive Committee. Mr. HAW said that many of the District Committees were unorganized, and ought not to be recognized by the Central Committee.

The following bids for $300, 000 City Lunatic Asylum stock were opened yesterday at the Comptroller's office. The proceeds are to be devoted to the crection on additional accommodations for lunatics in this City. The stock pays 7 per cent. interest :

The Hartford Post closes an article in relation to Mrs. STOWE'S article on Lord BYRON in the September Atlantic with the following statements: "To this it is proper that we should add one or two statements that, so far as we know, have not been in print.

When the Viceroy of Egypt set forth on his visit to the chief European Powers there was a general flutter in the official circles of Constantinople. Here was the agent inviting honors which belonged to his chief. The Viceroy had long been suspected of a desire to throw off his allegiance.

A note from the American Legation contradicts the report which prevailed here on Sunday, that a dangerous conspiracy had been discovered on board the frigate Sabine, and announces the story utterly without foundation. A dispatch from Ajaccio announces that the Empress is indisposed,

Prince ARTHUR left Charlottetown in the gunboat Dart at 5 o'clock this morning, and arrived at Picton, by special train, at 2 o'clock. Great enthusiasm was manifested by the inhabitants along the line.

Coroner ROLLINS was engaged yesterday in making an investigation concerning the death of Mrs. BRIDGET WOODS, which is alleged to have resulted from violence received at the hands of her husband, JAMES WOODS. The parties to the tragic affair occupied one of a group of tumble-down shanties located on open lots in Fortieth-street,

At a late hour on Monday night a man named JOHN BOLAN was severely beaten by one THOMAS HARTIGAN, at a house near Mount Pleasant Perk, on South Eighth-street, Jersey City, HARTIGAN was taken into custody, and at the examination before Recorder MARTINDALE, yesterday, it appeared tat HARTIGAN had been trying for several days to induce BOLAN to fight with him, but,

In spite of all denials, STOKES of Tennesee is urging the general removal of Senator office-holders in his State. He has filed a list in the Post Office, and has one for the Treasury, which he hopes to have acted upon during this week. GERSHOM is recommended in place of HOPKINS, for Postmaster of Nashville.
The semi-weekly Central Park concerts are still kept up. That of to-day Will (weather permitting) take place at the north end of the Green, commencing at 4 P. M. The programme is as follows;

Yesterday, JAMES HARGRAVE, a native of England, but now residing in Cleveland, Ohio, appeared before Marshal TOOKER and complained that on the 10th of July last he bought, at the office No. 3 Hudson-street, a ticket by the City of Paris, and at the same time purchased, as he supposed, (pounds)50 in gold, giving therefore $325 in greenbacks.

Coroner ROLLINS held an inquest at the Eldridge-street Police Station, yesterday, in the case of JOHN LEONARD, 30 years of age, of No. 310 East Thirty-third-street, who was found lying helpless on the Bowery, near Canal-Street, on Monday night, and died soon after. It appeared that LEONARD came down town to visit some acquaintances, who are employed excavating at the site of the new Post Office.

The Great Western Railroad of Canada derives whatever importance or prosperity it possesses from its position as a link in the chain of American travel. It takes up its profitable traffic at the Suspension Bridge and lands it at Detroit, or vice versa.

On Saturday last the Bulletin contained a statement of the arrest of certain parties here who were charged with having kidnapped a man named CAHILL on board a ship in the harbor and sent him to sea. CAHILL, the man who is said to have been kidnapped, makes the following statement:
The British steamship China, from Liverpool, Aug. 21, and Queenstown, Aug. 23, reached this port last evening. Her advices are three days later.

A novel and important question under the stamp act was raised before Commissioner WILKINS on Saturday. Three seamen libelled the steamer Susan Ward for wages. In defence the Captain of the steamer claimed that the men wee acting under shipping articles, and that the time for which they were hired not having expired the men were not legally entitled to their wages.

Mrs. ELIZA N. BELLOWS, wife of Rev. Dr. BELLOWS, of this City, died at Northampton. Mass., on Friday evening, the 27th inst., at the age of 37, and her remains were brought to the City for interment. Yesterday afternoon the funeral services were held at the family residence in East Fifteenth-street.

The meeting of he Democratic State Central Committee at Albany yesterday, is made by the World an occasion for foreshadowing the action of the coming Convention. Our contemporary anticipates the unanimous re-nomination of the present State officers, with the addition of Mr. WRIGHT, of Ontario, for the vacant Canal Commissionership,

A few minutes before 7 o'clock this morning, boiler No. 20, on the south side of the north mill of the Phoenix Iron Company, at this place, exploded with terrific force, causing loss of life to those in the vicinity, an destruction to the neighboring property. The boiler was a double one, the steam boiler being uppermost, and underneath a smaller one, designated as a mud drum.

The Montreal Herald gives currency to a statement that Sir A. T. GALT, formerly Finance Minister of Canada, and in that capacity well and creditably known at Washington, did not accept knighthood from the British Government until he had made known his opinion in favor of Canadian independence.

A terrible fire has occurred at Cape May At 3 o'clock this morning the crowds of Summer residents in the several hotels were startled and terrified by the cry of fire and the sight of flames and smoke. The fire was discovered in the frame building on Washington-street, known as the "Japanese store," and occupied by P. P. BOYTON, pearl diver.

The regular weekly meeting of the Woman's Suffrage Association was held yesterday afternoon at the Woman's Bureau, in Twenty-third-street, the attendance being numerous, and made up almost exclusively of ladies. The exercises began at 3:30, Mrs. E. CADY STANTON presiding.

A grand fete was given at the Crystal Palace, at Sydenham, last evening, in honor of the harvard and Oxford boat crews, by the London Rowing Club. Mr. LAYTON, the President of the Club, occupied the chair. All the members of the Harvard crew were present except Mr. LORING, but Mr. WILLAN alone represented the Oxford crew.

The Humboldt Committee held its regular meeting yesterday, Messrs. KAPP, KUHNE, WARKER, FREY, AUFERMANN, HEIDENFELDT and STEINWAY being present. Mr. F. KLAMROTH, Secretary, read a communication from Mr. HERMANN SCHROETER, Secretary of the German Domocratic Union General Committee, stating that the later organization had resolved to take part in the procession on the day of the Humboldt Festival.

MR. DICKENS AND THE DANCING BEARS.--A Manchester paper says : A few days since a party of excursionists from Chatham had been spending the day in the vicinity of Mr. DICKENS' residence, Gad's-hill, near Rochester, when on their return in the evening they fell in with a couple of dancing bears which were going through their performances in the road in front of Mr. DICKENS' house.

An independent Convention, with independent nominations, are the immediate results of a movement which has been for some time in progress in San Francisco, and which aims at rescuing the city from the corrupt partisan combinations which have made it a New-York in miniature.

ALEXANDER, Corresponding Secretary. Mr. MARCUS OTTERBURG ADDRESSED THE MEETING ON THE NECESSITY OF THE GERMANS combining, irrespective of party, to get their political rights.

Two of GUSTAVE DORE's oil painting "Dante and Virgil crossing the frozen regions of Hell" and "Jeptha's Daughter," are now on exhibition at the Somerville Art Gallery, corner of Fourteenth-street and Fifth-avenue. They are the property of Mr. H. CARLTON ARYMAR, and are the first specimens of DORE's pencil ever brought to this country.

BENTON.--In Green Point, L. L. on Tuesday, Aug. 31, Mrs. MARY CATHERINE BENTON, wife of ?? Renton, in her 57th year. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited that and the funeral on Friday Sept., 3, at 4 P. M., from her late residence, Franklin st., between Java and India. Her remains will be taken to Hudson, N. Y.

Judge Carpenter, of the Superior Court, has, upon the complaint of EDWARD NORTON, OF Farmington, issued an injunction restraining the directors of the Connecticut Western Railroad from making contracts, or calling in installments of stock, or locating the road until the full amount of the capital stock of the road ($2,000,000) is subscribed.

The National Temperance Convention, which was called for the purpose of forming a Temperance party for political purposes, assembled at Farwell Hall, in this city, at 11 o'clock to-day. At the opening of Po the proceedings about 300 persons were present, probably 200 of whom were delegates.

The regular semi-monthly meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration was held at Castle Garden yesterday afternoon. The case of JABOB BINKLE, the emigrant who arrived in this City by the steamship Atlanta from Havre, and who was brutally clubbed by some policemen, was the subject of investigation.

With the Exception of a few days in August the present Summer has been a remarkably cool one, and in this immediate locality a very wet one. Yesterday, the first day of the Fall season, was exceedingly cool. the thermometer in the City standing many degrees below the average at this time for twenty years past.

After a long and parching drought, commencing on the 1st day of June, covering a period of eighty-nine days, we are at last having copious and refreshing showers. A ten-mile boat race was contested yesterday by JOHN BLEW and ROBERT PEACH, both oarsmen, who have already made a good record. The course was from the Battery to and around the Light-house at Robins' Reef and back, the distance being ten miles. On the start PEACH obtained the lead, but had to succumb to BLEW before the first mile had been gone over.

Of the whole number of emigrants landed this port, amounting to 21,302, 7,848 were Germans, the majority of whom arrived from the ports of Bremen and Hamburg. During the same period of last year 8,660 German emigrants were landed at this port, and about five years only 2,510.

The annual exhibition of the American Institute is to be held this year in the Empire City Stating Rink building, corner of Sixty-third-street and Third-avenue, which was yesterday opened for the reception of goods, and will remain so (Sunday excepted) until the 8th inst., when the exhibition season will begin.

Major-general HANCOCK having inspected all posts in his command, west of the Missouri River, will start on Monday to inspect all those posts in the command located east of the Missouri, in Montana and Minnesota. The estimates from well-informed sources place the number of bales of cotton that the South will raise this year at 3,000,000, and it is, we think, perfectly safe to calculate on 2,500,000 bales. And we think there are equally reasonable grounds to assert that the average price will be at least twenty-five cents per pound.

Mr. DICKENS has not resigned this peaceful mission. Nothing could be in better taste and feeling than his hearty speech at the banquet on Monday evening.

The oldest life insurance company in the United States dates no further back than 1813. The distinction belongs to the Mutual Life of this City, which was organized under a State charter in that year.

Constantinople, Sept. 1.--A messenger has left Constantinople with the Sultan's reply to the letter of the Viceroy of Egypt. It is reported that the Sultan expresses satisfaction with the Pasha's assurances of loyalty, but commands him to sell, or transfer to the Turkish Government, the Iron-clads and breech-loaders ordered in Europe,...

The Emperor to-day presided at a council of Ministers. Minister McMARON has arrived in Paris. In the Senate to-day Prince NAPOLEON made a speech on the Senatus Consultum. He protested his devotion to the Emperor and Prince Imperial, and give in his complete adherence to the proposed reforms, which he hoped were but the beginning of fresh reforms.

We present on another page this morning the schedule of the public debt as it stood on the books of the Treasury on the 1st of September inst., in which will be found the intelligent classification and ample details first introduced in the monthly Treasury reports by Secretary BOUTWELL last March.

The New-York Fruit Growers' Club will hold their regular meeting to-day at 1:30 P. M., in the hall Nos. 35 and 37 Park-place. Peaches, apples, plums, , will be exhibited and afterward distributed among the audience. Admission free.

The shoemakers here have struck for from twenty to fifty percent, higher wages. Many of the employers having taken full orders at the old rates. would lose heavily if they acceded to the demands now made, and refuse to do so. ASHTON ONENDON, Bishop of Montreal and Metropolitan of Canada, arrived here yesterday.

The German Cigar-maker who keep small stores for the sale of their Cigars have taken steps to organize against the interference of the internal revenue officers, who claim that they cannot be allowed to manufacture their cigars in the stores where they are retalling them.

An inquest was held at the Morgue yesterday, by Coroner ROLLISS, in the case of MIS. BiIRIDMET WOODS, who was alleged to have been beaten to death by her husband, JAMES WOODS, aided by her brother, OWEN CLARKE, in a shanty in West Fortieth-street, near Tenth-avenue, as already fully reported in the TIMES.
At 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon the lumber-yard of RUSSELL JOHNSON, at the corner of Broome and Tompkins streets, was fired by two children who had been carelessly playing with matches.

Last Week was the warmest of the season. The interest in regard to the crops has settled down under the fact that the Northwest is to aggregate an average harvest, and that its surplus of grain will be as large as usual. Minnesota has the most magnificent wheat crop ever known.

Work on the Ends bridge is being rapidly pushed forward. The shore p?? on the St. Louis side has been completed to a point above low-water mark, and the dredgeboats are now employed in preparing for the sinking of a caisson for the second pier. Which will be located about 300 or 400 feet from the shore.

Notwithstanding the time which has elapsed since the opinion of the Supreme Court of this State construing the statute relative to tax deeds, the Courts find themselves still harassed with litigation arising from a disregard of this opinion. In some counties lands are sold in quarter, half and whole sections, and in whole and half blocks.

The Board of Excise met yesterday afternoon, President HENRY SMITH in the chair. The Committee on Applications reported in favor of granting 725 new licenses in this City, 275 in Brooklyn, and 13 in Richmond County. The report was received and the recommendation adopted.

A terrible accident occurred at noon to-day on the Bangor and Piscataquis Railroad. A railroad construction train was barking over Black Island Bridge, four miles above Old-town, when the whole team, consisting of tow cars, the whole train, consisting of two cars, the engine and tender, broke through, plunging all on board into the river below.

To-day was observed as a public holiday in Halifax. Prince ARTHER attended a grand citizens' picnic in the grounds of the Duke of KENT, on the shore of Bedford Basin. A large number of persons were present, among them General DOYLE, Baron MIGUET and the officers of the French frigate semiramis.

The Philadelphia Press denies by authority the statement that Hon. R. C. GRIER, in consequence of failing health, will resign his seat as Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. The Justice is at present enjoying good health and has no intention of resigning his position.

FRANCIS I. A. BOOLE, so well known some years since as a prominent Democratic politician in this City, died yesterday at the Lunatic Asylum in Utica of softening of the brain. Mr. BOOLE's advent as an officeholder was as Councilman for a district located in the Eleventh Ward.

About 9 o'clock Wednesday evening Officer LANCASTER, OF THE Harbor Police, while patroling North River in a small boat, found 100 pieces of Muslin, valued at $800, secreted under Pier No. 50, at the foot of Morton-street. The muslin was delivered, yesterday, to the Property Clerk, at the Central Police Office, and was subsequently claimed as a part of a lot of goods stolen during Monday night from Pier No.39 North River.

At a late hour of Wednesday night. JOHN HESS and LUDWIG RENKING were in front of their residence, No. 354 West Fifty-third-street, and both very much intoxicated. A party of men happening to pass, irritating words were exchanged, and the matter coming speedily to blows, HESS was struck on the head with a stone thrown by one of the party, and fell to the sidewalk insensible.

LOCK HAVEN, Penn., Sept. 2--A meeting of the mill owners and others interested in the lumber trade, was held at Williamsport yesterday. Nearly every firm in the trade was represented' and an entire unanimity in the object of the meeting prevailed. It was resolved that but one-half of the usual stock of logs be cut and manufactured on the west branch for 187..

WASHINGTON. Aug. 2.--The little excitement of yesterday died away with the departure of the President last evening, and Washington to-day fell back to its Summer stupidity. The White House, so thronged yesterday morning, was deserted, the Departments were quiet, there were no arrivals at the hotels, and the small number of politicians whom the President brought here took their departure on the morning trains.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept.2.--Prince ARTHUR with Colonel ELPHINSTONE and Lieutenant PICKARD, left Richmond by a special train at 6:30 o'clock. Salutes were fired at several stations along the route. The party reached Hopewell at 10:20, where an address was presented to the Prince, who made a verbal reply. The Prince then took a carriage and rode some distance.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 2.--The Farmers and Merchants' Insurance Company of Quincy, Ill., has failed with more liabilities than assets. The excavations on the site of the new Post Office, at the lower end of the Park, are rapidly progressing. The night force set at work last Monday has been steadily engaged every night since. On an average thirty carts have been kept running, carrying out between 400 and 500 loads nightly.

The Ennadelphae is a society composed of Miss ANNA DICKINSON, the President; Mrs. ELIZABETH CADY STANTON, Mrs. ELIZABETH PHELPS, Miss SUSAN B. ANTHONY and Mrs. WILBOUR. The significance of the composite Greek word is "United Sisters." The object of the Society is to promote female suffrage and the welfare, mental and material, of women generally.

A young German named HEINRICH HENNING, 21 years of age, who boards at No. 12 Brunswick-street, Jersey City, was assaulted on Thursday, in the store of his employers, MILLENMAN SONS, No. 686 Greenwich-street, New-York, so severely that his injuries may prove fatal.

Captain Foss, of the ship Pacific, charged with shooting a man and a little girl on one of the docks, about two weeks since, was yesterday, on application of his counsel, JAMES F. MORGAN, admitted to bail in the sum of $5,000 by Coroner FLYNN.

An adjourned meeting of the Brooklyn Citizens' Reform Association was held at the City Salesroom, in Court-street, last evening, Mr. MORRIS REYNOLDS presiding. The following address was adopted : FELLOW-CITIZENS of KINGS COUNTY : A period has arrived in the history of your affairs as regards taxation, that demands your earnest solicitade and immediate action.

One of the few survivors of the generation which was in its prince when Sir WALTER SCOTT, CRABRE, WORDSWORTH and BYRON still flourished, arrived in this City yesterday. Sir HENRY HOLLAND, formerly physician to the Queen and Prince ALBERT, and at a much earlier date (1814) to the Princess of WALES, (afterward Queen CAROLINE,) is now on his eighth or ninth visit to the United States.

The examination in the case of CHARLES S. and WASHINGTON ARCHER, accused of having made fraudulent returns of sales, was resumed yesterday. M.J. Connolly testified: I took a memoranda of the returns made to the Assessor during the time I was in the employ of the ARCHER BROTHERS;

An inquest was held by Coroner KEENAN yesterday at No. 19 Washington-street, in the case of MICHAEL IRWIN, aged 10 years, who died from injuries received on Wednesday last in falling from the third-story window of the above-named premises to the roof of a shed below and thence to the pavement. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

The announcement of a trotting race between the two famous fast totters, Lady Thorn and Mountain Boy, for a piece of plate of the value of $2,000, given by the Association owning Prospect Park, attracted an assemblage of about 3,000 people only.

Partisan protests against the results of elections are too common to attract much attention. People generally look upon them as devices employed by an unsuccessful party to mitigate the mortification of defeat, and to throw a shadow of anxiety over the course of the victors.

Hon. THOMAS EWING, of Ohio, has written a fearfully long letter, (it would fill nearly six columns of the TIMES,) giving his views upon the present disturbed state of the country, for which he upbraids the Republican Party at great length and with much bitterness.

Teh entire destruction of the New Ironsides by ??re as she lay at League Island will be reelected with painful emotions by those who locked upon her as one of the noblest specimens of Philadelphia handicraft. As is the usual custom of the Government. what remained of the noble old craft was sold as it lay beneath the waves of the Delaware.

Justice DOWLING was engaged yesterday at the Tombs Police Court in examining a complaint of grand larceny against JOHN RILEY, a young man employed as a clerk by ALFRED COLVILL, a broker, at No. 50 Wall-street, who stands charged with having stolen ten $1,000 United States five-twenty bonds.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 8.--Five representatives of the Grand Lodge and Grand Encampment of Odd Follows of the State of Maryland, will leave hero by rail to-morrow to attend the annual meeting of the Grand Lodge of the United States at San Francisco.

A man named WILLIAM TUNBRIDGE was brought before Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday afternoon, having been arrested by Special Detective TAPLEG, of Collector BAILEY'S Revenue District on the charge of selling photograph cards of United States Treasury notes without a license.

It was provided at the late Memphis Commercial Convention that the next meeting of that body should be held at Louisville, Ky., on the 12th day of October next. A committee of twelve, of which Colonel BLANTON DUNCAN is chairman, were then appointed to make the needful arrangements.

Commissioner MANIERRE sat yesterday to hear complaints against members of the Police force for breaches of discipline and improper conduct. Many of the cases were of a character involving many disputed points, and the session was consequently protracted and at intervals quite exciting.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--The London Times to day has an editorial on the article in the Atlantic Monthly by Mrs. STOWE, in relation to Lord and Lady BYRON. The writer, after commenting on the character and Position of Lord BYRON, considers Mrs. STOWE'S story a faithful reproduction Mrs. STOWE'S story a faithful reproduction of Lady BYRON'S statement to her solicitors.

The Superintendent, Inspectors and Captains of the Metropolitan Police yesterday proceeded to Saybrook, Conn., by special car, to present to Hon. THOMAS C. ACTION, late President of the Board of Police, the testimonial, which has been described. The occasion was observed in the town as a general holiday, all the stores being closed.

A large and enthusiastic meeting of the Republicans of the Tenth Assembly District was held last evening at the Anon Rooms corner Stanton and Chrystie streets. The meeting was organized by the Chrystie streets. The meeting was organized by the election of J. M. PATTERSON, Jr., President, and WM. GLAZER, Secretary.

By Judge Monell. William K. Close rs. The National City Bank of New-York: case settled and filed in Clerk's office. By Judge Jones. Pioneer Iron Works rs William M. Kassou et al.; motion granted. Agnes Wright rs. James Jack; proceedings dismissed.

DETROIT, Sept. 3.--The propeller Boscobel, Captain ??, of the New-York Central line caught fire this morning below St. Chair. The boat was run upon the Canada shore, where she continued to burn, and will prove a total loss. The Boscobel was bound to Chicago, and had tem passengers, who were all saved, but they lost all their effects.

About one o'clock yesterday morning, EDWARD CARROLL, better known as the "Hoboken Clipper," was driving down Second-avenue in a carriage, and when near Thirty-second-street, was attacked by a party of men who only succeeded in striking him once with a knife and inflicting a slight wound on the lip when they were frightened off by the appearance of Officer HORSTMAN, of the Twenty-first Precinct,...

The Executive Committee charged with the preparations for the celebration of the Humboldt Centenary held its regular meeting yesterday afternoon, F. KUHNE presiding. The North German Consul. Mr. RONSING, informed the Committee that he would issue a call to the masters of North German vessels lying in this port to raise the North German flag on the 14th inst.

MADRID, Sept. 3.--The following news is official: Fifty-nine members of different Carlist bands in Catalonia have taken advantage of the amnesty proclamation and surrendered themselves. The journals of this city comment variously on NAPOLION'S refusal to see General PRIM.

Senator BROWNLOW has written another letter, warmly defending the course he took in the recent canvass in Tennessee, and declaring that in the event the General Assembly shall refuse to adopt the Fifteenth Amenment, which he does not believe, and shall elect a United States Senator bostile to the Government and the Administration, his "action in the premises shall be determined by his convictions of duty."

A copy of the Shanghao News Letter, brought by the last mail, contains the full text of certain addresses presented to Mr. J. ROSS BROWNE, one by the British and another by the American merchants residing in China. In these outpourings of condolence, disapproval is expressed of Mr. BURLINGAME'S mission,

On Wednesday afternoon next two picked nines of genuine Indians will play a game of ball, after the aboriginal fashion, at Jones' Woods. The contest will be of a singular character, and will, doubtless, be viewed with interest by many.

The protest against the legality and validity of the late election in Tennessee, adopted by the meeting of leading Stokes Radicals of the State, which was held in Nashville on the 26th nit., is as follows: PROTEST AGAINST THE LEGALITY AND VALIDITY OF THE LATE ELECTION IS TENNESSEE.

The National Academy of Sciences which convened here, as you are aware, on Tuesday, holds its third and last day's session to-day. Several valuable papers have been presented to the Academy during its session, among which was one especially noteworthy from Captains ERICSSON, the distinguished engineer of your City, on the "Retardation of the Earth's Rotation by Solar Influence."

ROCKLAND, Me., Sept. 3.--The vault of the Lime Rock Bank was broken into by burglars last night. They first picked the lock of the Western Union Telegraph office, adjoining the bank, and from thence made an opening of about eighteen inches in diameter through a brick wall into the bank vault.

The New-York Underground Railway is still a dream of the future, but we have the advantage of watching the experiment which is being made on the other side the Atlantic. The truth beings to dawn upon the minds of the London managers that their underground line will never pay the large profit once anticipated.

By the arrival of the brig Julia, at Boston advices have been received from Port-au-Prince to the 11th of August. The news is important. On the 10th of August the English war-steamer Britomart arrived at Port-au-Prince, from Gonaives, bringing two hundred refugees, consisting of women, children, old men, invalids and cripples.

The sudden advent of cool weather in this favored region has created a regular stampede among the summer visitors at the Highlands. At Fort Washington and the other landings on the Navesink River, the class of visitors have proved themselves no mere summer birds, for scarcely any of them have as yet deserted their nests.

At 9 o'clock last evening Officer DONOHUE, of the Fifteenth Precinet, while patroling his post, saw from the opposite side of the street a dark object of considerable size placed against, the wall of STEWART'S stable, in Wooster-street, just above Amity.

The Attorney-General has decided that the present Legislature of Virginia will be competent legislative body so soon as the new State Constitution under which it is elected and the action of the Legislature thereon has been approved by Congress,

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Sept. 1.--A terrible accident occurred about 11 o'clock last Monday night on board the ship Ann Eliza, now on the beach at Smith's Island, near Cape Charles, by which three men lost their lives and some five or six others were severely injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--It is understood that Attorney-General HOAR has written an opinion on the subject of the test elect as applied to the members elect of the Virginia Legislature, which has been forwarded by the Secretary of War to General CANBY for his instruction and guidance, and by whom it will be made public.

It is reported in Paris that the French Government refuse to send a representative to the Ecumenical Council. The health of the Emperor is said to be improving, although a dispatch from London says public opinion continues sheptical in regard to it. It is the impression that his real condition is co??aled.

The snow sheds on the railroad five miles west of this station caught fire last night. There being a stiff breeze blowing at the time, near a mile and a half of the structure was destroyed before the fire could be cheeked. Some seventy rails are reported badly bent, and most of the ties destroyed ; also, all the timber in the culverts is burned.

Yesterday a private exhibition was given by Mr. S. N. CARVALHO, at his studio, No. 765 Broadway, of his painting of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River. The painting, independent of its artistic merit, is of interest from the ?? that the sketched were taken by Mr. CARVALHO on the spot and while attached to the Fremont expedition as photographic artist.

Mr. JAMES OTIS, President of the North American Insurance Company, died at his residence in Twelfth-street, last evening, at 8:15 o'clock. He was somewhat injured about two week since by a severe fall, but had so far recovered as to visit his office.

PARIS, Sept. 3.--The health of the Emperor is improving. It is reported that the French Government has declined to send a representative to the Ecumenical Council. It is now said that Don CARLOS has returned to Paris.

Hon. STEWART L. WOODFORD delivered an elequent address at the dedication of the Soldiers' Monument in Salem, N. Y., on Friday. Seven years before on that very day the young men of the vicinity had left for the front, as members of the One hundred and Twenty-third Regiment. The orator said:

With the week that has just terminated the Summer season and its attendant dullness has come to a close. The Fall representations will be commenced tomorrow at almost all the theatres. Some new plays will be brought out, a very old drama will be revived, and many familiar faces will look down upon friendly audiences from behind the brightened footlights.

The boldest and most scientific feat yet performed at Niagara is promised before the season closes, by a daring fellow, who proposes to cross the river without the employment of any such safeguard as an "undershot" Velocipede, and, in fact, he will even dispense with the rope.

Search was professed to be made for these and other missing vessels among the Soonderbuns, but no trace of them was discovered, and it was taken for granted that both had gone down at sea.

New--York City, in the matter of taxation, is surely between the upper and nether millstone. With all the leeching and cupping it undergoes, the body corporate will never be, at this rate, too plethoric. Between a State, with its inflated valuation of civic property, bleeding it externally, and a corporation, never over--scrupulous, bleeding it internally,

THORNTON, of the United States steamer KearSarge, reports to the Navy Department his arrival at Tahiti, Society Islands, having sailed from the Chilian port of Talcahuano in April last, and reaching Nukahiva, one of the Marquesas group, on the 6th of June following, where he called upon the Governor,

Professor THEODORE WOOD, of Albany is the leader of a choir in this city, the church with which he is connected being one of the largest and most respectable in this vicinity. He has an army of acquaintances, who up to a recent period might also have been classed as friends in the city,

The Universe, a Catholic journal, declares that 200,000 Irish children are lost to the Catholic faith, in this country, every year. The Sunday school of the Church of the Puritans, Brooklyn, collected nearly $2,500, within four weeks, toward the erection of a new edifice.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 4.--RICHARD CARTER, foreman of the stone masons employed at Fairmount Park, was shot at and killed by JOSEPH SNYDER, a discharged workman. The weapon used was a seven-shooter. SNYDER was arrested by Captain LYON, of the Park Guard, despite his resistance and endeavors to use the weapon, two barrels of which were still loaded. CARTER was a married man.

The oil plant of Japan, called goma in the Japanese language, belongs like the ramie to the nettle family. The stalk is fibrous, but is not used. The plant grows to a height of four and five feet. It is an annual ; when in bloom, its blue flowers present a beautiful picture. It is a very rapid grower ;

At a late hour last night, JOHN FITZPATRICK, THOMAS DAILEY and CHARLES FOSTER, all quarrymen, came into the town of Yonkers to do some marketing. While returning home a quarrel arose between them, during which FOSTER was attacked by FITZPATRICK and DAILEY, and very brutally beaten.

LONDON, Sept. 4.--The Morning Post to-day has an editorial on Canadian matters. The writer says the consolidation and development of Canada are at hand. Immigration is increasing, the Government is active, and the relations with the United States are in a fair way of improving. People and money are the great desiderata.

Qucbee was the seene of one of the most disgraceful exhibitions yesterday afternoon that it has been its lot to witness for years. The ship laborers, after driving by force all Mr. CLARKE'S men from the ship Colonist, which they were engaged loading, tracked Mr. CLARKE in person through the street, hooting and yelling like savages, until he was finally obliged to take refuge in a store on Mountain Hill.

There is no foundation for the rumor that JUAREZ and his Cabinet will escort Mr. SEWARD from Acapulco to the City of Mexico. It has been arranged that the great statesman shall land at Manzanillo, and thence go to the capital in a stage or carriage provided for him by the Government, with an escort.

SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 3.--There is unusual delay in counting the vote in this city. The Independents have elected; SELBY, Mayor; HANNA, County Clerk: FREEMAN, Fire Commissioner; three Supervisors, and three School Directors. The Democrate have elected WHITE, Sheriff; HIGGINS, Recorder; KLOPENBERG, Treasurer; ROSENBELM, Assessor; BYRNE, District-Attorney, and MARKS, Harbor Commissioner. .

A series of anonymous statements are circulating by the Southern Press, professing to give an account of certain alleged cruelties perpetrated by Federal officers, at Camp Douglas, in the Summer of 1864. They are a mere repetition of ancient scandals, the falsehood of which was satisfactorily exposed at the time.

WERNBERG for the defence.

We learn that a suit involving the validity of the last will and testament of OLIVER MORSE, Esq., late of Monroe County, was tried last week before the Superior Court, involving some singular facts. More than thirty years ago Mr. MORSE was a merchant in Jones County, Ga., and failed in business, owing a considerable amount of money to merchants of Augusta, Savannah, Charleston and New-York.

To the Editor of the New--York Times: The "diffusion of knowledge" over the earth may be increasing at a very rapid rate, but I wish a little of it could be seen and made up of New--York. We are living in the eighteenth century, for all I hear to the contrary. A college Professor said to me yesterday : " What a grand thing that theory of NEWTON'S is."

For the first time since the assumption by the authorities of Philadelphia of that portion of the city known as Fairmount Park, the crime of murder was committed this morning. There is a very unpromising state of political affairs in the Cayuga and Wayne Senate District. Excellent reasons exist for the retention at home of Senator WILLIAMS. It has been understood that he would not be a candidate for reelection, and that the nomination would be conceded to Cayuga County.

Considerable excitement was caused among lager beer brewers and dealers yesterday in consequence of the arrest of several large wholesale proprietors and dealers, on the charge of having violated the tax law relating to the stamping of lager beer barrels and kegs.
