Two men, named RICHARD MARTIN and MATHEW WALSH, were arrested yesterday by Sergeant O'BRIEN and officers FINNERTY and O'BRIEN, of the Harbor Police, while in the art of taking off part of the crew of the bark Era, at present detained at the Quarantine anchorage in the Upper Bay.

The charge of temperature of the last few days has already has a marked effect on the vegetation of the Park and on the number of visitors. The lawns, which a week or two since were bright with the rich verdure of summer, are beginning to look brown and sere. The leaves of a few of the more tender trees and shrubs are falling.

The Secretary of State of Indiana on Thursday transmitted to Secretary FISH a certified copy of the joint resolution adopted by the Legislature of that State, accepting and ratifying the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution. Governor BAKER did not join in the certificate.

Were it and for the cold this would be a delightful time to visit the favored spot. But as it is the air is a little too bracing and almost irresistible tendency is to sit as close to the cheerful wood fire as possible. I am told that the cold season has come unusually early this year, fire having been found comfortable, if not absolutely necessary, ever since the 1st of August.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4.--The Buffalo Fire Department turned out in force to-night and gave a brilliant reception to the Northern Liberty Hose Company of Philadelphia. The streets were crowded with citizens. The line of march was illuminated with a fine display of fireworks. The visiting with a supper by Hose Company No. 11, of this city, whose guests they are.

Yesterday morning Chief of Police BRACKETT succeeded in arresting ANTHONY CORCORAN, the heartless wretch that shot ALICE FERGUSON, the water girl at the Nicollet House, on the 5th inst. Immediately after the shooting affair CORCORAN disappeared, since which time nothing had been heard of him until yesterday morning.

The great nugget recently sent down from the Monumental Mine in Sierra County has been deposited at the assay office to MARS LAWRENCE (formerly BELL'S) on California-street. Its original weight was 140 pounds, but a piece weighing 34 pounds became detached, and the nugget now weights 106 pounds.

Dr. NELATON, the Emperor's physician, contradicts, through the Paris Presse, the reports concerning the alarming illness of the Emperor, and says his recovery will be rapid if he takes the necessary rest. Prince NAPOLEON had an interview with the Emperor yesterday.
A clerk in one of the departments secured a promotion a few days since by a little trick which has probably not before been attempted.

The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place on Thursday, the 2d inst., at 3:30 P. M., NORMAN WHITE, Esq., Vice-President, in the chair. assisted by FRED. S. WINSTON and JAMES SEYDAM, Esqs., Vice-Presidents. Six new auxiharies were recognized: One in Michigan, one in Colorado Territory, and two in each of the States of Arkansas and Texas.

"The Mountains of Virginia" is a vague term in the popular geography of the State. Wherever is found a sulphur spring bubbling from a foot hill, or not even within the skirmish line of our great mountain ridges, we have advertised in the newspapers a "mountain resort," as if this elevation of figure could catch and cheat the imagination of the heat-burdened inhabitants of the lowland.

PARIS, Sept. 4.--The Emperor will not go to the Camp de Chalons to-day, as before reported. The Presse to-day says Dr. NELATON, the Emperor's physician, contradicts the alarming reports which are constantly arising in regard to the health of the Emperor.

[Mrs. BARTON, wife of the celebrated African traveler, has written a letter suggesting the idea that Dr. LVINGSTONE may probably be at this moment a prisoner in Central Africa. The same suspicion appears to be entertained by eminent geographers, and this fact gives to the following letter a peculiar interest:]

PORTLAND, Sept. 4.--At midnight last night both of Senator FESSENDEN'S physicians had given up all hopes of his recovery. He was gradually sinking, and appeared to be in a delirious stupor. He was taken on Tuesday morning with stoppage of the bowels, since which time the disorder has assumed a more violent form, ulceration having set in.

The Magnificent new clipper ship Java, Captain BASSETT, sailed from New-York, Jan. 16, for Yokohama, Japan, with a cargo of coal, and though several vessels which sailed after her have arrived, nothing has been heard of her. As Captain BASSETT was one of the most experienced and successful commanders in the country,

In pursuance of authority conferred by law, the Secretary of the Treasury, on the 25th day of June last, divided the coasts and boundary lines of the United States into sixteen Custom Revenue Districts, each district to be under the supervision of a designated agent. The Second Custom Revenue District was placed under the supervision of Colonel FRANK E. HOWE, with headquarters at No. 52 Wall-street in this City.

Coroner FLYNN was requested yesterday to hold an ante-mortem inquisition in the case of JACOB BERKLE, a German emigrant, who is now lying at the Hospital on Ward's Island in a critical condition, from injuries, said to have been received at the hands of Poundsman BUDDINGTON and Patrolman BELL, of the Fifth Precinet.

Last Spring citizens of Philadelphia were swindled to the amount of about 418,000, by means of forged warrants for the bounty paid by the city to soldiers during the war. The warrants were mostly for small amounts, and usually for less than $100. That the forgers realized so large an amount from their operations shows their industry, and that they remained undetected is proof of their adroitness.

It is estimated that the wheat crop of Ohio this year will amount to about thirty millions of bushels, or about double what it was last year. Corn will be one-third of a crop, or about thirty millions of ??. .

The leading journal a few days ago contained a letter from an English barrister in Spain, giving an account of his very narrow escape from a superstitious mob of people who had taken it into their heads that he was engaged in stealing children, who were to be killed so that their fat could be used to grease the telegraph which.
It is very doubtful which is the greater nuisance to the inhabitants of this City--a street well and smoothly paved, or a street left full of deep ruts and holes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4,-Secretary RAWLINS is much better to day, and it is expected that he will be able to get up on Monday. While he was in Connecticut last week he got wet and caught a cold, which produced a slight hemorrhage. In this condition he left for Washington. The travel In the cars did not serve him, and when he arrived here he had another bleeding attack worse than the first.

It again becomes our painful duty to chronicle a marine casualty, attended with loss of life. The following dispatch was received from our correspondent at St. Clair yesterday about noon: "The propeller Rosrobel, Captain HODGES, running in the New-York Central line, bound for Chicago, caught fire at 9 o'clock A. M., about there miles below St. clair.

yesterday morning the new singing school of the General Saengerband of New York, under the direction of Mr. LANCE. in the upper story of the Henry Clay House, corner First street and Avenue A, was opened. it is designed for the instruction of the children of members of the band, from 10 to 18 years of age.

CARACAS, Aug. 23.--Don GUZMAN BLANCO, formerly a Minister of President FALCON, gave a ball lately to the foreign ministers. While the festivities were in progress a mob attacked the house, crying, "Death to BLANCO." Their intended victim made his escape to the American Consulate, and tied thence to Curacoa.
There is a storm brewing in the East. No Oriental potentate who did not mean mischief would have written a letter such as that which we recently published from the Sultan to the Viceroy of Egypt.

PARIS, Sept. 5.--La Public (newspaper) states that the Emperor retired at a late hour on Friday night, was somewhat fatigued in the morning, and, consequently, did not preside at the Council of Ministers held on Saturday. To-day the weather is unfavorable, and the Emperor still feels some weakness;

PRAGUE, Sept. 5.--The celebration of the five hundredth anniversary of the birth of JOHN HSSE, commenced here yesterday. The city is crowded with strangers. Many English and French visitors are here, and a large number of Russian Sclaves have arrived to take part in the festivities.

I find the following in Harper's Weekly of Sept. 1: "Senator BROWNLOW has wirtten a curious letter in regard to the Tennessee election. It is curious from the moderation of its tone, and from its admissions.

Sergeant O'BRIEN, of the Harbor Police, while cruising Saturday night, boarded a canal-boat, where he found a barrel of sugar worth $12, of which he took possession and forwarded it to the Property Clerk at the Central Police Office as stolen property. LEVI W. BARNES, a resident of Boston, yesterday morning entered the restaurant No. 13 Park-place, and died while sitting at the counter, where he had just partaken of coffee.

The conservative papers in Virginia are greatly pleased at Attorney--General HOAR'S decision respecting the test oath. The Richmond Dispatch says that the President has never forfeited any of his pledges to Virginia, and it counsels the people to disregard polities and concentrate their attention and efforts upon their individual as well as State interests, and to get ready as rapidly as possible to pay their debts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--It has been named that Governor SENTER, in his recent interview with the President, assured the latter substantially that he could not convene the old Legislature of Tennessee, because of constitutional objections, and at the same time expressed his earnest belief that the new Legislature would ratify the Fifteenth or suffrage amendment.

FELLOW-CITIZENS: The time is rapidly approaching when the people of Mississippi are to be offered another opportunity of restoring civil government and returning the State to her normal position in the Union.

GOLDSBORO, N. C., Sept. 5.--A terrible conflagration occurred here last night, by which the Wayne House, Masonic Hall, a lumber-yard and ten warehouses were destroyed. Loss, $125,000. The offices of the Messenger and the Post newspapers were also destroyed. They will resume publication soon.

We have always foreseen that the demand for a redistribution of land in Ireland would be accompanied by an agitation for a similar purpose in England. The impossibility of a small farmer becoming the owner of the land he cultivates is producing its natural effects.

RICHMOND, Sept. 4.--The following is Attorney-General HOAR'S opinion, received this morning by General CANBY: ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S OFFICE, WASHINGTON, Aug. 28, 1869. To Hon. John A. Rawlins, Secretary of War: SIR: I have the honer to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of July 27, 1869,

About 7 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the stables of Mr. DEFOREST'S express, situated on Westervelt-avenue. Tompkiasville, S.I., caused by a man smoking a pipe. The flames spread with great rapidity, causing other buildings in the vicinity to ignite.

The death of Signor F. PALMO, at the advanced age of 85, occurred at his late residence in this City, No. 113 East Eleventh-street, at 7 O'clock yesterday morning. Signor PALMO was one of the oldest and most respected citizens of New-York, His name is universally known in connection with the history of operatic management is this City and throughout the country.

The full text of Attorney-General HOAR's opinion on the test oath, as applicable to legislators elected under the Reconstruction acts, satisfactorily disposes of a difficulty which, in General CANBY'S case, doubtless originated in a strict sense of duty, but for which there has not seemed to be any warrant in reason or law.

ARTHUR HUGH CLOUGH, whose untimely death deprived the world of one who would probably have been a great poet, left many papers behind him containing his opinions on a variety of subjects, and some verses not yet know to the public. These remains have been collected and edited by his widow.

Judge HENRY ADAMS BELLOWS, LL. D., of Concord, who has been appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of New-Hampshire vice Judge IRA PERLEY of the same city, whose term of office expired by the constitutional limitation of age, was born in Walpole, that State, in 1803.

The German Liederkranz Society of this City made its annual excursion up the Hudson River, to Dudley's Grove, yesterday. The small steamboat P. C. Schultz conveyed members of the Society and their friends from the foot of Barelay-street, at 8 A. M., to the foot of Christopher-street, where two barges were attached to her to which the passengers repaired.

Most of the pastors of the Brooklyn churches have returned, and resumed their ministerial labors yesterday. Rev. Dr. Scheuck, of St. Ann's; Rev. Dr. Hall, of Holy Trinity; Rev. Dr. Burgess, of St. John's; Rev. Dr. Drowne, of St. Paul's; Rev. Dr. Diller, and a host of other Episcopal rectors, were in their places,

Newport, at the southern end of Lake Memphremagog, is a flourishing village of 2,500 or 3,000 inhabitants. It is in everything a regular country village, although the railroad and steamboat lines give it a more lively air than most places of its size possess. The lumber business seems to be the most general and the most prosperous;

An unfortunate affair occurred last evening at Bradley's Hotel, corner of India and Commercial streets, by which a young man named PATRICK MURAY received fatal injuries. The connected story, condensed from the statements of those in the house at the time is as follows: Thursday morning MURRAY arrived alone from Halifax on board the steamer ??, AND ENGAGED BOARD AT THE Bradley Hotel.

ST. JOHN, N. B., Sept. 5. - The Governor General of New-Brunswick held a levee yesterday, at which four addresses, signed by many of the citizens, were presented. The levee was held at the Dejencur Skating Rink, and about 2,500 persons were present.

LONG BRANCH, Sept 5.--The weather here for the past week has been very wintry. Nearly all the Summer boarders have returned home. The Continental, United States, Metropolitan and Stetson House close to-morrow for the season. The last grand hop of the season took place at the Mansion House last evening, and was fully attended by the guests and visitors of the Branch.
The Special Chicago Express, which left New-York yesterday at 11 A. M., made extra-ordinary time between Syracuse and Rochester, as will be seen by the statement below.

We learn from a gentleman of our acquintance that he has received a letter from General LONGSTREET, wherein he alludes, with much feeling, to the position he holds in the estimation of his old bosom friends.

The Police Court was unusually crowded this morning, the principal attraction being MARTIN McGUIRE, charged with the murder of his wife, whose preliminary examination had been adjourned till to-day. McGUIRE came into Court looking rather better than he did on his first appearance there a week ago to-day, but rather pale and careworn.

We understand that senator FESSENDES was suffering but little pain at a late hour lass evening, but his physicians could not detect any change for the better. A gloom seemed to have been cast over the spirits of our citizens yesterday, and the general topic of conversation was in reference to his health.

SEPT. 5-In steamship Minnesota, form Liverpool. Colonel G. E. Church, Mane. E. L. Demorest, Mile. W. V. J. Demorest, J. N Young. Mrs. Young, bliss Minnie Young, Mrs. Powel, Master Wm. Powell, Master Frank Powell, Rev. Wm. Dymond, D. H. Ducker, Mrs. Ducker, Miss Ducker, Miss ltalley, Jos. Quinney, Colonel A. C. Chamberlain, Mrs. Chamberlain, R. W. Younge, Rev. J. Clizbe, D. S. Quinbev. rs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5.--Ex-Secretary SEWARD'S speech at Sitka has been published. He gives a complete review of the resources and productions of the new Territory, expresses sanguine hopes of the future prosperity of Alaska, and says the people need a Territorial Government.

The following is the Fire Marshal's report of fires for the month of August: In the City of New-York there were, during the month, sixty-four fires. Of these seven were caused by kerosene, ten by carelessness of occupants and employes, there were of incendiary origin, three were from spontaneous combustion, nine were of unknown origin,

The funeral of Ex-Alderman FRANCIS I. A. BOOLE took place yesterday from the Baptist Church in Sixth-street, near Avenue C. At 1 o'clock the remains were conveyed to the church, which was already thronged by the citizens of the Eleventh Ward and others.

The celebration of the five hundreth anniversary of the birth of JOHN HUSS was begun at ?rague, Prussia, last Saturday. The celebration, it is said, has a political rather than a religious ??, and in tendency seems to be Anti-German. The races at Baden-Baden, which began last Tuesday, have been well attended.

Mr. EDWARD FALCONER, the noted temperance advocate, who for the past twenty-five years has addressed Sabbath outdoor meetings in behalf of tectotalism in this City, Yesterday announced himself as an independent candidate for the Legislature, Ninth Assembly District.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 20. via Havana, Sept. 5.--Senor LERDO DE TEJADA has had some correspondence with the Prussian Minister in regard to a conspiracy which was attempted on the 20th inst. The latter congratulates JUAREZ on his success in frustrating the plot. The conspirators intended to seize a valuable conducta which was to pass through the capital on the 20th for Vera Cruz.
Last night, about 9:30, a serious affray occurred in South-street, near Grand-avenue, Hudson City, during which two men named BEHM and REID were stabbed, the former probably fatally.

The third and last day's session of the Academy was held yesterday. The meeting this year has called out some valuable and interest-fag dissertations and discussions. Among those who have been present, and have taken part in the meeting, are Professors HENRY, ALEXANDER, SILLIMAN, COULD, PARKER and HALL, and several officers of the army and navy.

Last evening, at the going down of the run, commenced the season of religious festivities regarded by a portion of the Jews as the Festival of the New Year, called Rosh-Hashono, or the "Feast of Trumpets."

This afternoon the first day's racing of the running meeting on the Fashion Course, L. L., will take place. The sport promises to be of an unusually attractive character, for among the contests is a four-mile heat race, new so rare on the American turf, between some first-class horses.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 3.--The Republicans of Clark County opened the campaign this evening with a large and enthusiastic meeting in the new and beautiful Opera-house in this city. Hon. PERRY STEWART presided, and after music by the Springfield Cornet Band introduced Hon. JOHN SHERMAN, who was received with applause, and addressed the meeting at length on the topics of the day. d:

JACOB BEKELL, Who, it was alleged was brutally ?? by officers of the Fifth Prediuet Police, was visited yesterday by coroner FLYNN and Deputy coroner SHINE, at the Emigrant's Hospital, ward island, and his statement of the affair take.

Commissioner DELANO has forwarded to Supervisor YOUNG, of Cincinnati, the subjoined copy of a letter from JOSEPH W. DWYER, Esq., who has charge, in his office, of all correspondence with Supervisors and detectives, relative to the accuracy of an article in the Cincinnati Enquirer, of the 29th ult., making certain complaints against General YOUNG'S official conduct as Supervisor of Internal Revenue in Southern Ohio:

About 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning fire was discovered in the rear of a row of frame dwellings, situated about two hundred yards northeast of the Pavilion Hotel, at New-Brighton, Staten Island. The alarm was promptly given, and No. Six engine, from New-Brighton, No. Seven engine, one truck and the bucket company,

WILKESBARRE, Sept, 4.--The miners and laborers employed along the line of the Delaware and Hudson Works held a meeting at Providence yesterday, and determined to resume work as soon as possible on the terms of the compromise.

Twenty years ago, or thereabouts, when the old Gowanus stages carried the visitor to Green-Wood-while its western entrance was yet incomplete and its present magnificent northern one still in the far future, and long are the location or extent of Central of Prospect Parks was even remotely contemplated,

The American war steamer Kansas arrived here from Rio Janeiro Aug. 29. The Kansas will sail for New-York on the 2nd of September. A shock of earthquake was felt here on the 29th ult. The Governor of St. Thomas gave a ball in honor of the marriage of the Prince of DENMARK.

From the San Francisco Bulletin, Aug. 23. The trial of Mrs. GEGGUS vs. The North American Insurance Company, District Court yesterday afternoon. The trial lasted three days, and the jury awarded a verdict of $10,214. 75 in favor of the plaintiff. The action was brought by Mrs. GEGGUS, widow of the late CHARLES GEGGUS, to recover the amount of his life insurance.

We rejoice to see that the world has begun to "build the tombs" and glorify the memories of the "prophets" whom it formerly persecuted and slew. Within the last few years, we have seen the development of a remarkable desire to commemorate the names of the world's great men, by holding festivals and erecting monuments in their honor.

Yesterday afternoon, at 3:30 o'clock the Police steamboat Metropolitan was cruising in the bay, when Sergeant O'BRIEN, who was in command, observed a small yacht floating through the Narrows bottom upward. he steamed for the yacht, and soon succeeded in securing and righting her.

The McMinnville (Tenn.) New Era learns from WILEY STEAKLEY and JOHN TEMPLETON (the men who killed CARTER,) the following par-particulars as to the cause and manner of the killing. CARTER had repeatedly threatened the life of STEAKLEY and Doc. CHARLES, a brother-in-law to TEMPLETON, because they had assisted in arresting CARTER in Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 5.--It was thought yesterday noon that Secretary RAWLINS was convalescent, but about 4 o'clock he began to fail. He rallied a little at 9 o'clock in the evening; at 11 o'clock, however, his pulse became very feeble, and he lay without any noticeable change until 8 o'clock this morning, when he called for and eat his breakfast,

A large number of the churches in this City and Brooklyn, closed during the heated term, were reopened yesterday. The cool weather of the last two weeks has driven back at least one half of those of our citizens who have been rusticating among the woods and mountains,
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 5.--A keg of patent powder exploded at Lake Sebago on Friday afternoon at the Portland Water Company's works, where three men were blasting,

PARIS, Sept. 5.--Queen CHRISTINA has gone to Vicky. It is rumored that she will endeavor to bring over General FRIM to the cause of Queen ISABELLA. The arrival of Don CAILLOS here is daily expected. MADRID, Sept. 6--Four thousand troops will sail on the 9th or 10th inst. for Cuba, and 6,000 more will follow in a few days.

The State election in Vermont takes place to-day. The Republican ticket is: For Governor General PETER T. WASHBURN; for Lieutenant Governor, GEORGE W. HENDEE; for Treasurer JOHN A. PAGE. The Democratic ticket is; For Governor, HOMER W. HEATON; for Lieutenant Governor, MORILLO NOYES; for Treasurer JOHN M. WERKS.

TIMOTHY CROLLY, who lives at No. 316 Seventh-avenue, accompanied by a friend named O'REILLY, entered a saloon on Sixth-avenue Sunday evening, and sat down at one of the tables, at the same time calling for beer. Soon afterward they were joined by a man named POWERS, who introduced to them a friend of his, whom he called PETER KEHOE.

The steamers Nautilus, Captain HODGES, and ??, Captain WATTSON, were noticed last as having arrived at Singapore. After receiving on board a full supply of coal, provisions, , for the completion of their voyage, proceeded thence to Shanghae and Hong Kong, (the latter port being that of their destination,) where they arrived on the 21st of June, all well.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--About noon today, a party of ruffians went into KEENAN'S liquor shop at the corner of Front and Arch Street, and after inquiring for KEENAN, asked, "Where is BROOKS?" Mr. JAS. J. BROOKS, a special United States Revenue Officer on duty here, who happened to be present, replied that he was the man, when one of the ruffians shot him with a revolver.

Our Georgia correspondent is not habitually an alarmist, or we might suspect exaggeration in the report he gives of the injury done to the cotton crop in that State. The damage caused by the excessive beat and drought of the latter half of August he describes as extended and irreparable.

HAVANA, Sept. 6.--On the 16th of August the insurgents, several thousand strong, commanded by General QUESADA, General CESPEDES being present, made an attack on Las Tunas, losing 250 killed. The garrison of Las Tunas consisted of 450 troops, of which 100 were killed and wounded. The fight lasted nine hours. The result is not stated.

MOSES MAYBAUM, who, it will be remembered, fled from Newark some four weeks ago, leaving behind him debts, it is alleged, to the amount of $40.000, surrendered himself to the authorities on Sunday night, and an examination a was commenced yesterday morning, but was adjourned on account of the absence of several witnesses.

Coroner FLYNN was notified yesterday that JOSEPH FRIEDLANDER, a native of Germany, aged 47, and the proprietor of a vinegar manufactory at No. 209 Third-street, was then in a critical condition from the effects of injuries alleged to have been inflicted by an unknown man and woman, who beat him over the head with the cover of milk cans.

Sir JOHN HERSCHEL, in his Outlines of Astronomy, estimates that the eccentricity of the earth's orbit produces a difference of terrestrial temperature of 23[degrees]. The earth being nearest the sun at our Winter solstice, the inhabitants of the northern hemisphere do not notice this difference;

PLYMOUTH, Penn., Sept. 6--A fire broke out this morning in the flue in the bottom of the Steuben Shaft, owned by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, in this place, and in a short time the whole breaker and outbuildings were in flames, and the hoisting apparatus, the only means of escape for the mines, destroyed.

"Prince or President" is not idle alliteration. It has been spring upon the Canadians by a plucky journalist at the Canadian London. apropos of the proposal of super-loyalists to make the boy Prince new visiting the Providers their king. The proposal itself is ridiculous.

We learn, by private letter form Paris, that Hon. JAMES W. GRIMES, of le??, has resigned his seat in the Unites State Senate, to take effect Dec. 1, and that he will not return to this county until next year.

Type-setting by machinery may be practicable. Reporting by machinery, which is talked of in some of the newspapers. is practically impossible, even though the words uttered be recorded. As a matter of fact. verbatim reporting is not feasible, nor, if feasible, would it be desirable.

FORT HARKER, Sept. 6. --Messrs. PHELIX P. CIRNOT, Wm. E. DODGE and NATHAN BISHOP, United States Special Indian Commissioners, reached Fort Harker Saturday evening, having left Melicine Bluff on the 23d of August. They had a council on the 21st ult., at which all the principal chiefs of the Camanche, Kiowa, Witchilaw and affiliated tribes were present.

General BUTLER, of Massachusetts, has been recreating himself from his professional and public cares in subjecting Mrs. STOWE's recent statement about Lord and Lady BYRON to the tests of legal analysis. General BUTLER's fame as a criminal lawyer is supposed, in Boston, to give a certain value to his newspaper cross-examination of Mrs. STOWE.

An examination was held yesterday, before Recorder ALDRIDGE, in Hudson City, in the case of ADAM REID, and the circumstances, as developed by the examination, were as follows: At about 8:30 o'clock on Sunday evening, Mr. GEORGE G. RAYNE, a resident of South-street, in Hudson City, while sitting in his house heard in the yard behind the cry of a boy for help.

Coroner FLYNN proceeded yesterday to hold a further examination in the case of JACOB BERKLE, the German who is now suffering from injuries alleged to have been sustained at the hands of Officers JACOBS and BUDDINGTON, of the Fifth Ward Police, the ante-mortem statement of the victim has already been published.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--Some time since Governor BOWIE received from the State Department at Washington a communication, which had been forwarded there by the Commissioners of Emigration at New-York, to the effect that seven convicts and paupers had sailed from Bermen for the United States, their passage being paid by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--A storm from the northeast began at 7 o' clock this evening. The fall of rain has not been great as yet, but it is hoped it will affect the Schuylkill River and put the water works in good condition.

COOKE--At Nassau, N. P., on Sunday, Aug ?? CAROLINE A COOKE, daughter of the its Manuel Arcon. and wife of John F. Cooke of Williamsburg, L. I. FOWLER -- At Franklin Furnace, N. J., on Saturday, Sept. 4. HENRIETTA LAURA, relief of the lats Colonel Samuel Fowler in the 43d year of her ago. Funeral from her late residence on Tuesday, 7th Inst., at 2 o'clock P. M.

Last week the Church Union newspaper, with which the public has been more or less familiar for some years past, was issued in sixteen-page form, neat, compact and full of good matter, with the imprint of Messrs. J. B. FORD Co., who are the recognized publishers of Mr. BEECHER, issuing regularly his Sermons and Lecture-Room Talks, and having in hand his coming great work, The Life of Jesus, the Christ.

Prince or President-Which; That is the coding question, The indications are that it will be the test question at the next general election in 1872. Continued British connection, independence or annexation-which of these have the fates in store for the Canadians?

The services commemorative of the New-Year were continued in the Jewish synagogues in this City yesterday, at all of which large congregations were present. The service comprised prayers of three kinds--that "of homage," to invoke the speedy approach of the kingdom of God, when all mankind will arrive at the true knowledge of their Creator, and unite in the worship of their Supreme Benefactor:

The rival crews of the Nissan Boat Club tested their skill as oarsmen yesterday on the Club course from the foot of Seventy-first-street. North River, the distance being three miles. The Two Crews were composed as follows: J. C. BABCOCK, Captain and how; H. A. TAPPIN, No. 2; G. S. WALSH, No. 3; J. MILLER, stroke Colors, white cap with red star in front.

There is said to be a panic in Germany on account of bad news received from France. The Parts Bourse was also excited yesterday, and to allay the alarm it was announced that the Emperor's health was satisfactory The ??? Morning Telegraph. in reviewing Mrs. STOWE'S article, says that the subject itself is too painful to be discussed, and regards the publication its Indiscreet on the part of the author and the publisher.

An inquest will be held to-day by Coroner FLYNN at Bellevue Hospital over the remains of at MICHAEL CONWAY, aged 36 and a native of freland, whose death was the result of compound fracture of the leg sustained a few days age.

The first regular meeting of the Board of Alderme after the summer vacation was held yesterday at 2 P. M. A seies of resolition complimentary to Mr. J. G. BENNETT, Jr. for his acheivement in erossing the Atlatie inthe yachis Heneulla and Dauatles, were adoped and Messrs COMAN, CUSHMAN. REPPER and MCMRATH were appointed committee to present them to him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.-At 7 o'clock this morning, Secretary RAWLINS was in a tolerably comfortable condition. He spoke to General JOHN E. SMITH and Commissioner PARKET with his customary earnestness on various subjects, and inquired whether they thought he would recover his health or again rise from his bed.

Trial trips were made on the new West Side and Yonkers Patent Railway in Greenwich-street yesterday, in which several stockholders of the Company and other invited guests participated. The first section of the road, from the Battery to Cortiandy-street, is completed, and posts for receiving the rails ar crected, and many of the rails are laid on the next section, from Cortlandt-street to Thirtieth-street.

It is one of theo traditions of the Elders that Time is money. If so, can any one toll why all the trains of our railway corporations, with double tracks, are not through trains? Why does any train stop except for wood or coal and water?
People who go to see "Formosa" will wonder rather at the squeamishness of the London critics that at the impropriety of the play. It is not worse than "La Traviata," and not no bad as "Camille."

The telegram this morning brings us the sad news of the death, yesterday, of General JOHN A. RAWLINS, Secretary of War. The health of this distinguished officer has long been failing, he having contracted during the war a bronchial affection which matured to the consumption that caused his death.

A regular meeting of the Eighteenth District Union Republican Association was held last evening, at No. 205 Lexington-avenue, Judge KELLY presiding. Mr. CHRISTOPHER PULLMAN, on behalf of a committee appointed to confer with the other organizations, relative to the Twenty-eighth-street Central Committee, reported that that Committee was fully organized.

On Saturday night an affray occurred at a raffle in the village of Little Neck, Queens County, between three men named respectively JOHN MINSHER, HENRY MILLER and POWELL NEMYER. The dispute arose about the number of the dice, when MINSHER excitedly drew a large knife and stabbed MILLER in the breast. NEMYER came to MILLER'S assistance, and before retreating shared a similar fate.

Not many days ago Mr. GEORGE PEABODY, then in one of the Southern cities, received at telegram from Boston, beginning with the starting words: "CHARLES SUMMER is drying," and proceeding with the request that Mr. PEABODY would immediately come to Boston for the purpose of seeing our Senator.

SATURDAY, Sept. 4. 1869--2 o'clock P. M. The Board met in their Chamber, number ?? City Hall, pursuant to special call signed by a majority of members. Present--Thomas ?? Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen O'Brien, Miller, Conner, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farley--9.

The paid Fire Department of Brooklyn promises to be in full operation this week. Steam engines have been purchased, tenders borrowed, horses bought, stalls erected for tile horses, full sets of harness provided, and everything is ready for starting in complete and regular order.

The election in this city takes place to-morrow. By an act of the last Legislature the old city officers are removed, and the election is for an entire new list, including Mayor, City Treasurer, Assessor, and a full City Council consisting of nineteen members.

The address of the Republican Executive Committee of Mississippi to the people of the State is a gratifying illustration of the liberality which actuates Southern Republicans. They have outgrown the taste for proscription, and frankly proclaim general amnesty and universal suffrage as the starting point in the canvass.
On the first Monday in this month the biennial election for members of the Cherokee Legislature was held.

Senator TRUMBULL has returned from his western tour much invigorated and benefited by the trip. The mountain breezes and the suns of the plains have bronzed his check to a very gratifying ruddy hue, and the elasticity of his step shows a decided increase of vitality.

PARIS, Sept. 6.--The Bourse is excited. Rentes opened to-day at 70f. 35c., a heavy decline since Saturday night. To-day the Commissaire of the Bourse, in order to allay the excitement, publicly announced that the health of the Emperor was satisfactory.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -The Morning Telegraph reviews chronologieally Mrs. STOWL'S article on Lord and Lady BYROS to-day. It says the subject is too painful to disceuss. It regards the Publication as the result of indispetion on the part of Mrs. STOWE and the Publishers.

The Inman steamship City of Washington, which left Liverpool Aug. 26, and Queenstown Aug. 27, reached this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by three days than that received by the steamship Rhein. The Union has the following: "It is by no paeans decided that M. BAROCHE is to represent France at the Ecumenical Council.

Lady BYRON told Mrs. STOWE that she wished to render her Ex-Lord's name infamous for the purpose of destroying the popularity of his works. The attempt has not only been an absurd failure, but has resulted in a sudden renewal of the popularity the poet enjoyed a half century ago.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 6. -- Much activity prevails among those interested in the Susquehanna Railroad election, which takes place to-morrow. Mr. FISK and others of his party are here. The impression is that the Ramsey interest will carry the election.

Some time in the early part of last month a respectable looking man, giving the name of WM. W. MORRIS, visited the stores of several leading wholesale firms in this City, and represented himself as having been authorized to purchase goods for Messrs. WOODS, YEATMAN CO., proprietors of the Cumberland Iron Works, near Erin, Tenn.

NATHANIEL JARVIS, Esq., the Commissioners appointed to distribute the fund of $200,000 among the private schools of the City, in pursuant of an act of the last legislature, has extended the time for making applications for shares of the fund until the middle of September, owing to the absence of many of the teachers, whose aid was necessary in filling out the blanks.
A daring attempt was made on Sunday evening to rob the trimmings and fancy goods store No. 50 Grand-street. The burglar gained an entrance by breaking open the rear door with a "jimmy,"

The World is still sensitive about the association of the names of PENDLETON and ??? with repadiation. We trust it may never be less so. In a period when the moral sousibilitions of journalists are much exposed and liable to be dulled, it is an encouraging sign that the World is so unwilling to have the opprobrious name of "repudiator" applied to its political favorites. .
The Board of Directors of the Norfolk and Great Western Railroad Company have been in session the last two days at the Exchange Hotel. Two very important subjects were discussed and acted upon.

While a City contemporary contends that, with few exceptions, "life insurance companies are nothing but mockeries, delusions and snares," notwithstanding the supervision exercised by this State and Massachusetts, the Pall Mall Gazette, speaking in behalf of England, calls for a system of Government inspection, "identical in all its essential features with that in use in [a part of] the United States.

In the matter of MARTIN LELAND, charged with forgery of city warrants of the City of Philadelphia, the prisoner was yesterday brought before Judge McCUNN on a writ of bubcas corpus. Mr. BLUNT, in his return to the writ. road the commitment and the following affidavit on which it is based:

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 6.--A fire broke out to-night on Carey-street, near Fourteenth, completely destroying the following premises: JOHNSON, HARWOOD ESTES' lumber-yard; G. W. CRANDALL Co.'s planing mill; BOYLE GAMBLE, saw works; GORSDORF'S file factory, and MASSIE HARVEY'S grocery and Honor store.

A serious affray occurred in Guttenburg on Sunday night last, during the course of which an old lady named CORRIGAN was kicked in such a brutal manner that the attending physician does not expect that she will survive. The particulars of the affray, which have heretofore been carefully suppressed, are as follows:

WEDNESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the China, close at the General Post Office at 6:30 A.M. No supplementary mail. THURSDAY. Mails for Havana and West Indies, via Nassau, N. P., by the Columbia. close at 2 P. M. Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Bremen, by the Hansa, close at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier, foot of 3d- st., Hoboken, to 1:45 P. M.

SEPT. 7--In steamship Russia, from Liverpol.--Dr. Marion L. Sims, Mrs. J. C. Lewis, Mrs. J. H. Weay, Mr. Farwell, Mr. R. Dickey, Mr. J. Swinburn, Mr. C. R. Adams, Mr. Louth, Mr. T. W. Bouton, Mr. Irwin, Mr. F. Muir, Mr. and Mrs. Smith and daughter. Mr. G. W. Farr, Mr. D. C. Winter, Mr. and Mrs. Grist, Mrs. Bateman and daughter,

The study of the classical languages and literature is to be continued in the City College. There was but one vote in favor of the abolition of the classical course, at the meeting yesterday of the Board of Education, acting as the Board of Trustees of the College.

PARIS, Sept. 7--Evening.--The Emperor will come to Paris to-morrow. La Presse says the condition of the Emperor has improved a little since yesterday. His strength has increased and pain has diminished; but it is not believed that he will be able to go but of doors to-day.

Though the big Indians of Tammany are still at sea as to most of the nominations for the Fall election, yet it appears from conversations with the most reliable of them, that after being frequently rubbed out and rewritten, the judicial state, for the higher Courts at least, has been almost, if not quite, completed. gh at first it.

The new basis of representation in Massechusetts Republican State Conventions allows on delegate from each town and each ward of a city, and one additional delegate for every two hundred Republican votes. If the State is fully represented, the Convention will consist of 1,089 members, about ?? less than last year. Boston, which has had 198 delegates, will now have but 92.

An adjourned meeting of the Board of Education, acting as the Board of Trustees of the College of the City of New-York, was held at the hall of the Board, corner of Grand and Elm streets, at 4 P. M. yesterday. President LARREMORE occupied the chair. Present: Trustees BRENNAN, DURYEA, WOOD, SHERWOOD, SANDS, SMYTHE, LEWIS and BELL.

The Pennsylvania horror, which for the moment challenges public attention, should not be allowed to pass without some consideration of the question--Is all done that might be done to mitigate the perils of mining and thrown around the miners the protection which science and careful supervision may afford?

Not very long ago Mr. HEPWORTH DIXON wrote a book to prove that the morals of the American people were falling into a sad condition, and in support of his statement he referred to the existence among us of Mormons and one or two other occentric seets. His object being to produce a "sensation," without much regard to other considerations, he neglected to inquire where the Mormons originally came from.

The lathers have lately sceeded form the Plasterers' Union, of which they forwed part. A meeting of the former was held Monday Dight, Mr. PETER SMITH in the chair, at Milleman's Hall, corner of Twenty-sixth-street and Seventhavenne, to hear the report of a Committee appointed to wait on the plasterers,

The Committee of Arrangements, representing the various amateur boat elbus of this City and vicinity, met at the Nassau Boat-club House, in West Thirty-fourth-street, last evening, to complete the preparations for the contemplated reception of the celebrated Harvard " "??." Mr. FORTMEYER temporarily presided in place of Mr. R. W. BRADY, of the Waverley Club.

Everything was in confusion, yesterday, at the Rink, and the exhibitors were busy endeavoring to get matters arranged for tile opening of the American Institute Fair this evening. Seven o'clock is the hour appointed for the initiatory exercises pertaining to this annual display. Not less than fifteen hundred applications have been made for space in the exhibition;

The death of General RAWLINS naturally awakens more or les speculation in regard to his successor. Among the prominent gentlemen talked of for the office, the name most dwelt upon is that of General DODGE, of Iowa, for eight years a member of the House of Representatives, and always prominent on the Military Committees.

From Our Special Correspondent. ALBANY, Tuesday, Sept. 7, 1869. The Albany and Susquehanna Railroad war still rages, and the end is not yet. Indeed, from present appearances, the belligerents have not reached the beginning of the end. The new election for Directors of the road, held in this city to-day, so far from settling the troubles and bringing about a lasting peace,

The Canard steamship Russia, which left Liverpool Aug. 28 and Queenstown Aug. 29, arrived at this port at a late hour Monday night. The steamship Holsatra, from Hamburg Aug 25 and Havre Aug. 28, reached the harbor about the same time. The news at hand by the these vessels is later by two days than that received by the City of Washington.

M. VICTOR CONSIDERANT, the eminent French writer on social science,--who, by the way, is now an American citizen,--has published an interesting essay on the national currency, in which a plan of reform, or, more properly speaking, of revolution, of the existing systems of the United States, is proposed and elaborated.

AVONDALE, Sept. 7, 8 P. M., SCRANTON, 11 P. M.--The great disaster foreshadowed in the dispatches of yesterday, has become a certainty. The miners of Avondale are yet entombed, and scarcely a hope remains that a single one of them will be found alive. At first it was supposed that 200 men were in the mine when the fire broke out, but later investigations have shown that the number was exaggerated.

The American Booksellers' Guide complains that people do not buy books any more: that they depend upon the newspapers for the substance of every new book. The writer intimates that a prominent publisher has suggested the expendiency of making editors of newspapers curtail their extracts, "as it is in this way that the majority of readers now get all they want of current publications without paying a cent for them.

The following letter from Chief Justice CHASE is published: NARRAGANSETT, Aug. 14, 1869. MY DEAR MR. BRIGGS: Your note of the 29th, after a rather long journey, reached me here yesterday. I should be very glad to see you and talk with you on any subject but politics. Dr. BAILEY used to say that of BUNYAN'S Pilgrims he represented Christian and I Hopeful. I am still hopeful.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-The remains of General RAWLINS were laid out in the parlor of General SMITH'S residence until between 3 and 4 o'clock this morning, and then placed in the burial case, which is of iron, highly polished and varnished. The coffin is trimmed with white satin, quilted in a beautiful manner.

Sir JOHN YOUNG, the Governor-General of Confederated Canada, rules over perverse politicians. When on a recent occasion, at Quebec, he enunciated the Bright-Gladstone doctrine of friendly separation from the parent country, timid Canadian critics took trouble to show that he did not mean what he said.

SUPERIOR COURT--SPECIAL TERM--SEPT. 7. By Judge McCunn. Simon Berg vs. Sigismund Lichtenstadler et al.; motion for Sheriff to pay over money granted. Solomon Manz vs. Philip Koehler et al.; motion for reference granted. Joseph C. Cook vs. Jared W. Post; motion granted.

The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Cushman, Connor, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGarth, Farley, McQuade--12. The minutes of the meeting held July twenty-six were read and approved.

There are, at this moment, 22,000 men, women and children starving in two English counties. They have been reduced to want to a strike among the nail-makers. They say that a good steady workman can only earn twelve shillings a week--say four and a half dollars,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--Information was received here to-day of the seizure of an expedition for Cuba, which attempted to getaway from Macon, Ga. It appears that the force was insignificant, consisting of only one small vessel, with probably not more than fifty or sixty men on board.

Miss KATE BATEMAN, whose success on the English stage has been reechoed and to general interest throughout this country for two years past, was, with her mother, among the passengers by the steamship Russia, which reached this port yesterday. Her engagement at Booth's Theatre will be commenced on Monday fortnight, and will extend over ten weeks, "Mary Warner" being the drama first produced.

The Humboldt Committee assembled yesterday afternoon, Mr. FRED. KAPP in the chair. Mr. W. AUFERMANN reported that the Park Commissioners had definitely granted the site opposite Fifty-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue for the erection of the monument.

The bank note printers' strike ended yesterday, those engaged in it having agreed to the terns of the compromise by which they are to receive all advance of five cents per hundred issues of ten-cent, Twenty-five-cent and fifty-cent postal currency, and of ten cents per hundred on fifteen-cent currency.

On Saturday night last two men entered the office of the Continental Life Insurance Company, at No. 26 Nassau-street, and while one of them engaged the attention of those in charge by talking on business matters, the other stole form the cashier's desk a tin box marked "J. K. FROST," and with it made good his escape.

Quite a demonstration was made yesterday by the young ladies of Mme. DEMOREST'S establishment, which was handsomely decorated for the occasion of her arrival from Europe by the Minnesola. Numerous and elegant baskets of fruit and flowers were presented, poetic sentiments were read, and "Home, Sweet Home" beautifully sung, accompanied by music.

Mr. BESSEMER, whose works are so famous for his steel manufacture, has made a suggestion in regard to lighting coal mines which seems worthy of attention. he purposes to light the mine as completely as a workshop, rendering lights in the hands of the miners unnecessary.

The Tweed-Belmont war becomes interesting. The disciples of Tammany lose no opportunity of proclaiming their hostility to the present Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, and their determination to instal Mr. TWEED in his place. The World retorts with quiet thrusts at Mr. BELMONT'S adversaries, of which this-referring to what the editor saw at the last Presidential election-is a fair example:

LONDON, Sept. 7.--Captain Sir JAMES ANDERSON has withdrawn from his connection with the French Cable Company. PAUL BAGLEY sailed to-day, on the steamer Aleppo, for America, to lay before President GRANT his correspondence with Mr. GLADSTONE and others on the release of the Fenian Prisoners.

There could be nothing more honorable to the wealthier class of our business men than the means they promptly adopted yesterday of showing their apprciation of the services and their respect for the memory of General RAWLINS. The distinguished officer had died poor, and, in the hast moments of his life he had referred to the prospects of the family he was about to leave behind hime.

The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education was held last evening, Dr. THORNE, President, in the chair. The report of the Committee appointed to investigate the method of doing business by the Board being the first order of business, Mr. RHODES moved that it proceed accordingly.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 8--12 A. M.--The canvass in Vermont has been one of the quietest known in many years, and the figures of the election show rather more than the customary reductions from the high figures of a Presidential election. Returns from thirty-three towns, casting about one-fourth of the vote of the State, give WASHBURNE, (Republican,) 6,691; HEATON, (Democrat,) 2,162.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--Mayor Fox has offered a reward of $1,000 for the arrest of the assassins of BROOKS. Mayor FOX visited him last evening, when BROOKS expressed his belief that he could not recover. While in this condition BROOK'S affidavit, or ante-mortem declaration, was taken, and upon the information thus obtained warrants were at once issue for the arrest of certain parties believed to be implicated in the attempted murder.

MADRID, Sept. 7.-ESTARTUS, at the head of a band of thirty Carlists, was yesterday defeated by a body of the national troops near the City of Gerona. ESTARTUS himself escaped and fled to the mountains, but many of his men were captured. This is the last Carlist band known to be on Spanish soil.

The money article of the London Times of Friday contains a statement relating to submarine telegraph cables, to the effect that in the last eighteen years 8,000 miles of light cables have been laid, none of which lasted longer than a year, and all successful working cables now are of the strong and heavy form.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In the Daily News for the 10th inst., my husband and I saw a paragraph quoted from your journal, as being addressed to you by one of your correspondents, with the signature "M." The paragraph concludes by inquiring, "Will any one explain the speech of Isabella in that noble but obscure play, "Measure for Measure." act it., scene 4:

On Friday last warrants were issued by United States Commissioner SHIELDS for the arrest of four prominent Ex-Internal Revenue officers on a charge of fraud. An affidavit was made by Assessor JOHN F. CLEVELAND, of the Thirty-second District, setting forth that he had been informed, and that believed, that SHERIDAN SHOOK, H. B. MATTESON,...

All the telegraph wires between New-York and Boston were prostrated this afternoon by a heavy storm. The business of the Western Union Telegraph Company was forwarded as far as the wires were working, and thence by special messenger over the break to the nearest telegraph station, so that in all cases dispatches have not been seriously delayed. It is expected communication will be completely restored early tomorrow morning.

The whole line of the New-Haven, Middletown and Willimantie Railroad, known as the air line to Boston, is under contract and progressing rapidly. It is proposed to have the road open from New-Haven to Middletown next Winter or early in the Spring.

The preparations for the celebration of the Humboldt centenary are under fair headway. The foundation for the monument was laid yesterday. The pedestal will be erected to-day or to-morrow, and the bust will be in readiness for the festival on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept 8.--The President today appointed General SHERMAN Secretary of War ad interim, precisely as General GRANT himself was appointed Secretary of War ad interim when Mr. JOHNSON sought the removal of Mr. STANTON.

Last night a meeting of the General Saengerburd, or Singing Societies, was held at Germania Assembly Rooms, Mr. B. HUNDT presiding. The annual report showed that sixteen societies, with 960 members, belong to the Association. The receipts were $1,604 56, the expenditures $922 88, leaving a surplus of $682 18. The election of officers resulted as follows:

A free burial society, to be known as the Darech Emuno, is to be set on foot in this City, for the purpose of providing decent interment for all Israelites with the die here inn straightened circumstances. A meeting will be held at 8 o'clock this evening, at the Synagogue Bual Jeshurun, No. 145 West Thirty-fourth-street, in order to effect a thorough organization of this proposed association. .

It appears upon inquiry in regard to the case of Mr. SHOOK, that in August, 1867, an assessment, or rather a pretended assessment, was made against the banking firm of J. B. ALEXANDER CO., No. 19 Nassau-street, for something over $7,000 for arrearages of taxes claimed from them as bankers.

The celebrated "Stevens Bailery" is still at the yard in Hoboken, where her keel was laid long ago. The ban of secrecy has not yet been removed from the work on this vessel, which, however is still steadily progressing. Our reporter visited the yard yesterday, and was enabled to gain a few facts in regard to the construction of this modern marine monster.

The Richmond State Journal contends that the election of United States Senators is among the acts requisite to reconstruction, and that, therefore, it will be not only the privilege but the duty of the Virginia Legislature to choose them at its preliminary session.

The regular meeting of the Kings County Republican General Committee was held at Washington Hall Tuesday evening, Mr. SILAS P. DUTCHER presiding. The following list of polling places for the primary elections on the evening of the 14th inst., has been resolved upon:

The ancient game of Laerosse, which was to have been played, yesterday, by picked nines of Canadian Indians, at Jones? Wood, was postponed on account of the very unfavorable condition of the weather. Nearly two hundred persons were present, who were entertained by several informal games. The game is played by nine players on each side.

The colonial system of England approaches a crisis for which neither the colonists nor the Imperial authorities are prepared. In the old Tory days the retention of colonies was supposed to be essential to the glory of the British Empire. The revolt of the thirteen, and their conversion into free and independent States. led to the adoption of a more kindly spirit in the treatment of those that were retained.

PARIS, Sept. 7--6 P. M.--The Emperor lies in the same condition. Yesterday's rumors with reference to his health were exaggerated. His position is one rather of stagnation than of convatescence. The weather militates against him.

At the meeting of the Board yesterday there were upward of twenty-seven charges against persons for violating the Excise law. The following cases were disposed of: Patrick Rrennan. No. 207 Nassaq-street. Brooklyn, license not revoked; H. Heins. No. 208 East Seventh-street, New-York. license not revoked; James Breslin, No. 13 Catherine-slip, license not revoked;

The second day's racing of the Fashion Course running meeting, which was announced for yesterday, was postponed on account of the unfavorable weather until Saturday. In donsequence the third day's racing will not take place until Monday, the 13th inst. For the Durdleraco, mile heats, the entries are Harry Booth, Lobelin and Simple Simon; Lobelin having the call in the belting.

The probability that Cuba will become, sooner or later, an independent State, and the clear possibility that she may become, in certain contingencies, a State of our Union, make the problem of her commercial future both to her and to us one of the highest interest and importance.

On account of the rain yesterday but little work could be done on the grounds of the new Post Office. the concrete will not be laid for a day or two. The advertisements on the fence, which have been gazed at by every passer-by for the last three days. were covered over yesterday with brown paper, their time having expired.

BARMY.--At Poughkeepsie, at the resulence of his son-in-law, Alanson Swain, on Thursday evening, Sept 2, NATHANIEL BARNEY, of Nantucket, Mass., the 77th year of his age. EDSON--At Elizabeth, N. J. on Monday, Sept. 6. HARRIET DE WOLF, daughter of J. H. and Frances E. Edson, aged 21 months and 17 days.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Sept. 8.--The Mississippi Valley Commercial Convention reassembled at 9 O'clock this morning. A permanent organization was reported as follows: President--WM. VANDEVER, IOWA, Vice-Presidents--R. R. Reynolds, Alabama; J. L Sharp, Tennessee ; Horace Reed, Wisconsin : Cyrus Alarich, Minnesota ; M. W. Delabay, Kansas ; Judge Sutton, Louisiana ; M. W. Beltzhoover, Pennsylvania ;

Last night the torch of the incendiary was applied with ?? effect to one of the central business ?? and a conflagration lighted, which before the flames could be checked, laid in ashes a large ??-yard, destroyed several the storehouses, and inflicted a loss upon the owners of the property and the insurance companies of between $100,000 and $200,000.

The following correspondence has passed between the Secretary of State and FREDERICK KAPP, Commissioner of Emigration: NEW-YORK, Aug. 20, 1869. SIR: I consider it my duty to inform you that the Government of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, on July 17, 1869, per ship Atlanta or Atlanta, from Bremerhaven,

Yesterday a complaint was made at the Mayor's office by a Mr. NICROSI, of Alabama, against JOHN DOWLAN. of No. 438 Broadway, for swindling him by means of the oroide-watch game. The amount lost was $90. It was subsequently recovered.

The difficulty with which the soldiers who survive the late war, and the widows and orphans of those who were killed or who died of disease contracted in the service, obtain the allowances set apart by the Government for these classes, are so great that in many instances pensions are never obtained.

At the regular weekly meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health, yesterday, an application recently received from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, requesting that several of the agents might be appointed by that Board as Sanitary Inspectors, without pay, for the purpose of visiting stables and cow-houses in the prosecution of the work of the institution, was denied.

The tire in the Dismal Swamp does not seem to abate. We were informed last week that it was confined to the undergrowth, but intelligence has reached us that it has got into the best timber. The fire commenced near Suffolk, and has burned a wide track clear through to near the northwest locks, a distance of nearly twenty miles, and it is still going south. The ground.

About a hundred of the master-printers of Germany recently met in the City of Mayence, which is the city of the inventor of printing, (GUTTEMBURG,) to take steps for obviating the difficulties which have lately existed between employers and their workmen; and we now learn from the German papers that they formed an association which all the master-printers of Germany and Switzerland are invited to join.
Mr. JOSEPH FRICPLANDER, of No. 209 Third-Street, died on Tuesday from the effects of a beating sustained on the 24th all. Coroner FLYNN ordered the arrest of Mrs. ALTOPHER.

The funeral of the late FERDINAND PALMO, formerly manager of the Italian opera in this City, took place yesterday, The remains were viewed by the friends of the deceased at the house in which he dwelt, No. 113 Eleventh street, near Fourth-avenue. They were in a plain coffin, which was placed in the drawing-room in which those who had known him assembled in the afternoon.

Prince ARTHUR has at last taken a short vacation from the series of public exhibitions which he has given, and departed for the hunting-grounds to shoot the moose which has probably been provided for him. The rest of a few days in the woods will be very pleasant after the round of dissipation in which he has indulged since my last letter.

During the month of August the amount of merchandise imported and paying duty was 222,817,933 pounds, exclusive of 30.000 tons of coal and salt. The exports for the same period were 12,577,563 pounds. The imports of liquors were: Wine, brandy and gin. 480,604, gallons: exports, 63,017 gallons.

For a few days past rumor has been current on the Eastern end of Long Island to the effect that JOHN CHAPLIN and son, of Orient, who left Black Rock, Conn., about a week ago, in charge of a sloop laden with mossbunkers, had been lost.

The Common Council of Jersey City held a protracted session, after three weeks vacation, on Tuesday evening. Among the important matters to which their attention was given was the consolidation scheme.

The following contributions have lately been made to the Central Park collection: By Captain CHARLE, M. PRE, of New -York, a pair of black swans. from London; by Captain NAPOLEON COLLINS. United States Navy, a bon of rare plants, from Siherin: by Hon. ALLEN MUNROE, of Syracuse, a bald eagle, from the Rocky Mountains;

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 8.--The National Republican Convention assembled to-day at noon. It is the largest meeting of the kind ever held in this State. Three hundred delegates are present, seventy-five of whom are colored. Nearly all the counties are represented. Judge SPEED, of Vicksburg, was chosen President, and the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

BOOTH'S THEATRE--An idle rumor was industriously circulated yesterday, on the Exchange, to the effect that Mr. JAMES FISK, Jr. owns a large controlling interest in Booth's Theatre. This is not the first time that such a statement has been put in circulation.

Coroner WHITE, of Hoboken, resumed the inquest, last evening, upon the body of an infant daughter of WM. BRADSHAW, of Hoboken. The child died on the 30th of August, under suspicious circumstances, and a post-mortem examination which was subsequently held by Dr. ELDER, revealed the fact that the stomach contained a considerable quantity of opium.

Dispatches received from Paris yesterday announce great improvement in the condition of the Emperor. He was present at a Council of Ministers at St. Cloud yesterday. A meeting was held in Limerick,. Ireland, yesterday, in relation to the Fenian prisoners, at which it was resolved that no "Tenant-right hill" will be accepted until the prisoners are at liberty.

On Tuesday afternoon, Mr. HENRY T. MOORE, the proprietor of Rutherfurd Park Hotel and Treasurer of the Rutherfurd Park Association, committed suicide by shooting himself in his hotel at Rutherfurd Park, New-Jersey, of which place he has for the last four years been a highly-respected citizen.

The argument upon the application for a perpetual injunction against the proprietors of the cattle yards at Communipaw, restraining them from continuing their business there, was begun before chancellor ZABBISKIE, at his chambers in Jersey City yesterday morning.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 8.--The terrible calamity at Avondale was proven to the most doubting at the dawn of morning, when the eastern gangway was penetrated; 1,200 feet from the bottom of the shaft, and the explorers came to a barricade that had been securely placed across the gangway. Tearing this down, a horrible sight was encountered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--The death of Senator FESSENDEN, coming as it does so close upon that of the Illustrious soldier whose body now lies in state at the War Office, has added to the feeling of gloom and sorrow by which the city is oppressed. Nowhere was the statesman more highly appreciated than here, among those with whom his public duties brought him in frequent contact.

The Union Republic Central Committee met last evening at Apollo Hall, corner of Broadway and Twenty-eight street. Mr. EDGAR FETOHVM occupied the chair. On, motion of CHARLES kITCHEL, of the Nineteenth District, a committee of three was appointed to draft resolutions expressive of the sense of the meeting in relation to the death of Secretary of War RAWLINS and Senator FESSENDEN.

While the country mourns the death of one of its most prominent officers, the Secretary of War, the intelligence of the decease of one of its leading statesmen, Senator WILLIAM PITT FESSENDEN, of Maine, is received. This has been foreshadowed by the bulletins of the past few days, which have represented his condition as critical and his death imminent;

JOHN S. AUGUR, of No. 364 Broadway, made a complaint Tuesday against Wm. W. MORRIS the man arrested on Monday charged with having swindled several merchants by false pretences. Mr. AUGUR testified that on the 24th of April last the prisoner came to the store of E. S. MILLS CO., at Nos. 51 and 53 White-street,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.-Advices from the Cuban forces have been received in this city up to the 20th ult. In these letters the friends of the Cubans have accounts of the several engagements which had recently taken place between the Spaniards and Cubans. The Cubans for some months have invested the town of Puerto Principle.

The firm of BOSWORTH, WHITE BELCHER, at No. 255 Canal-street, have at frequent intervals, for some time past, missed small quantities of goods from their store, though they could not discover the method of abstraction. As the aggregate value of these parcels of goods reached the sum of nearly $5,000, the members of the firm called on Captain JOURDAN, of the Sixth Ward Police, who detailed Detective WOOLDRIDGE to work up the case.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER, at No. 431 West Thirty-ninth-street, over the remains of THERESA BRAENIG, aged 3 years, who died from the effects of injuries sustained on Monday evening. It appeared that LOUIS ULRICH, aged 8 years, was standing on the stoop with the deceased, and for some cause ordered her to go away,

The Legislature, at its first convocation, is limited in its action to the election of its own officers, and the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment. That exactly suite the people of Virginia. More than that we never thought it prudent they should do. We would prefer that they should not even elect their permanent officers.

BROCK--CLOVER.--At the Church of the Messiah, Greenbush, N. Y., by Rev. Dr. Clover, HENRY BROCK to HELEN MARIA, daughter of the Rector officiating. FEARING--TRAVERS.--In Newport, on Wednesday, Sept. 1, by the Right Rev. Bishop Clark of Rhode Island. GEORGE R. FEARING to HARRIET daughter of William R. Travers.

On Tuesday morning, about 1 o'clock, fire broke out in the Allentown Iron Works, situated in the Sixth Ward, and superintended by SAMUEL LEWIS, Esq. The works were among the most extensive in this country, giving employment to about six hundred hands, and were owned principally by stockholders residing in Philadelphia.

In steamship Huntersville, from Sarannah--S. B. Swain, Mrs. J. F. Wheaton, Judins Cundenzahn and wife, Mrs. Clark and child, Mrs. Geo. F. Jackson, Mr. Chaig. In steamship San Sailrader, from Savannah.--H. Beckett, W. H. Munson, F. F. Putney, T. J. Mell, Mrs. Howard James and 3 children, Lieutenant,

The Rhinebeek Tribune publishes an abstract of the will of THOS. THIMO\PSON, late of Boston, which was admitted to probate in MAY. An appeal from the deeree was made, but the decision of the probate Court has been affirmed The amount of real estate as appraised is $518,-100, and of Personal property, 66,906; total, 585,006, which is regarded as a low estimate.

The trial of Mrs. ELLEN HARTMAN, charged with having caused the death of Mrs. LOUISE BOWMAN in the early part of August, was commenced yesterday in the Bergen County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice BEDLE presiding. Mr. and Mrs. HARTMAN made an effort to get the BOWMAN family out of a house which that family had hired from them.

A vessel is now lying near the Atlantic Docks, Brooklyn, which, it is asserted, is being rapidly fitted out for a Cuban privateer. She ?? when loaded, very little likely to present much of her hull above water, and as she is a swift craft is likely to prove an effective blockade-runner. Her armament consists of eight long 688 and a 100-pound Parrott gun at the bow.

CHARLES BROWN, the colored man who was shot by SAMUEL GASTON at the camp-meeting at Morrisville, on Sunday evening, died on Monday in consequence of his injuries. Coroner EARLY summoned a jury and held an inquest over the remains on Monday evening.

There appears to be a great lack of enterprise on the part of inventors and manufacturers in sending in specimens of agricultural implements to the Westchester Country Fair. Most of the other departments seem to be well filled. The display of vegetables, fruits and flowers is very fine. Considerable time was occupied yesterday in organizing the various committees.

It is stated that the Harvard crew were obliged to give up the use of milk altogether a week before the great race, in consequence of the prevalence of cattle disease in the counties of Kent and Surrey. This little incident assists as to realize the magnitude of the disaster which once more threatens England.

Yesterday Commissioner BOSWORTH listened to the complants against forty Police officers for offences of various kinds. Few of them possessed special interest. WM. LANG, of No. 3 Hester-Street, complained of Patrolman MICHAEL COLEMAN, of the Thirteenth Precinet, for having accosted him while standing at the corner of Hester and Suffolk Streets.

APROPOS OF WOMEN AND THEATRES. With a Chapter or Two on Parisian Line. By OLIVE LOGAN, (New-York: CARLETON.) Miss OLIVE LOGAN has republished in the volume before us the substance of various articles from her pen which have appeared in American magazines, and has added to the revised collection some half dozen papers having more or less relation to one of the two main topics indicated in its title.

Notwithstanding the circumstances which seemed to justify the suspicion that poison might have caused the death of the late Dr. CARLTON GATES, of Yonkers, the chemical analysis conducted by Professor DOREMUS failed to disclose any evidence of such a supposition.

Everywhere the working classes are intent upon the study of those great problems which vitally affect their own immediate interests, and are destined to modify the structure of all the older civilizations. The artisans of Europe are no longer content to leave their cause in the hands of any one who may volunteer to advocate it.

The groat moral controversy of which I wrote in my last, on Mr. BOUCICAULT'S boatracing drama at Drury Lane, is as lively as ever. The Manager of Drury Lane writes to stay that he takes mole money in one day for "Forinosa" than a whole week of the legitimate drama would bring into his treasury, and he does not see that there could be a stronger argument in favor of its propriety.

LONDON, Sept. 8.--The Morning Telegraph has an editorial to-day on the result of the recent international rowing match between the Oxford and Harvard crews. The writer says the merits of the two systems will be undecided until Oxford crosses the Atlantic and meets the American crew on American waters.

A Gorman ??an, (Dr. REYER,) who has has been engaged in studying the condition and prospects of the Suez Canal, has written an account of it much less flattering than the accounts we have lately received through French sources. He mentions two circumstances which render it doubtful whether the whole length of the canal will be navigable for large ships at the beginning of next November.

ENGLISH OPERA. The promise of Mine. PAREPA-ROSA and her associated to commence, during the present month, a series of representations of English month, a series of representations of English opera at the Theatre Francais in this City, has been given so much publicity. that it is only fair to the persons who made it to note, just now, that its very liberal fulfillment is at hand.

The American Institute Fair, at the Rink is assuming an appearance of order and regularity, and by the beginning of next week the exhibition will be well worthy of a visit. Sufficient may be seen already to repay one amply for the small outlay demanded for admission;

BROOK--CLOVER.--At the Church of the Messiah, Greenbush, N. Y., by Rev. Dr. Clover. HENDRY BROOK to HELEN MARIA, daughter of the Rector officiating. DAVIS--WASHBURN--At St. Martin's Trafalgar-square. London, Aug. 19, 1869, Miss ELIZABETH FLOY DAVIS to F. WASHBURN. Esq.
The Wisconsin Democracy have taken General ROSECRANS' advice and made short work with they cal " fossils of the party."
