Figures which come with a fair show of authority indicate an increase in the internal revenue of $25,500,000 for the year ending the 30th June, 1869, as compared with the receipts of the previous year.
There has been a rumor that the Pope had resolved to postpone the ?? Council, in consequence of the open opposition or studied coldness with which his invitations had been received.

The equalization of property in this State, in accordance with the following resolution, adopted by the Board of Equalization on the 8th inst., is given below : Resolved, That the valuations as now fixed by the Board of Equalization, and hereto annexed, and amounting to $1,860,120,770, be and the same are here.
MADRID, Sept. 8.--Slight disturbances have occurred in the city, owing to the removal of volunteers from posts which they have since the revolution. Several of the volunteers were wounded.

The Fire Commissioners have decided upon their rules and regulations preparatory to entering and men will be expected to devote their entire time to the work of the Department upon active operation this week if possible. From these it appears that both officers.

It has long been suspected, if not positively known, that the picturesque story of Sir ISAAC NEWTON having been led to the discovery of the law of gravitation by the fall of an apple, was as baseless as many of the other fine traditions of genius.

The Board of Supervisors of Kings County met at the Court-house, Brooklyn, yesterday, Supervisor OSBORN, President, in the chair. The Committee on Accounts reported in relation to the account of the Commissioner of Jurors for the year ending April 30, 1869,

The funeral services of the late JAMES H. CAFFERTY, the well-known artist and member of the National Academy, took place yesterday afternoon at No. 1,275 Broadway. A large number of the friends of Mr. CAFFERTY were present, Academy: M. FALKNER, J. G. BROWN. MR.
The Mississippi friends of Judge LEWIS DENT are at liberty to nominate him for Governor, if they choose ; and Judge LEWIS DENT is at liberty to accept the nomination, if he think proper.

It is with profound regret that we record the death of WILLIAM PITT FESSENDEN. Senator in Congress from the State of Maine. It would be difficult to name a man whose loss from the public councils would be more severely felt, whose high ability, large information and unquestioned integrity have made more beneficial impression upon public affairs. or who would be more sincerely mourned by the country.

We learn with satisfaction that Governor HOFFMAN has declined to be a party to the revolutionary project, commended by two or three Democratic journals, for defeating the action of our State Legislature last Winter in ratifying the Fifteenth Amendment.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 9.-General CANBY this morning issued his proclamation declaring the result of the late election. GILBERT C. WALKER will be installed as Provisional Governor on the 21st inst., and JOHN V. LEWIS Provisional Lieutenant-Governor on the 5th of October.
The last week in August, in England, was, it appears, worthy of a furious "heated term" in New-York--a steady, sultry heat, and never a drop of rain.

The funeral of the late Secretary of War took place yesterday from the War Department building in Washington. The remains were temporarily interred in a tomb in the Congressional Cemetery until their final disposition is determined on.

New-York is a City paralyzed in the hands of her rulers. The commerce of the world, floating through her grand water-gate, and up her beautiful bay, is lauded on wharves that would disgrace a coastwise village.

A new German steamship line will soon be established between the Prussian port of Stettin and the port of New-York. The preliminary steps of the undertaking have already been adopted, and in a few months two steamships of the line will begin their trips.

The most important news of the fortnight is the bombardment of the town of Gonaives by the revolutionary war steamers provide and Columbia, now called Grand Republic and Mount Organization. These war vessels bombarded Gonaives for two days but General CHEVALIER resisted the bombardment bravely.

The trial of Mrs. ELLEN HARTMANN, charged with having caused the death of Mrs. LOUISA BOWMAN, at Fort Lee, in the early part of August last, was continued before Judge BEDLE, in the Bergen County Oyer and Terminer yesterday.
The problem of swift and easy street locomotion probably will not be solved until steam or some similar motive power is applied to public and private vehicles.

BANTA.--At Hackensack. N. J., on Thursday morning, Sept. 9, 1869. ADELIA ZABRISKIE, wife of William S. Banta. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Saturday, Sept. 11, 1869, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from her late home, and at 2 o'clock from the First Reformed Church, Hackensack, without further notice.

In this City, yesterday, respect for the memory of the late Secretary of War was shown by the closing of the Custom-house, Sub-Treasury, and all other public buildings, with the exception of the Post Office. In the United States building on Chambers-street, no business was transacted, except what could not possibly be Postponed, and the United States Commissioners' Office was ostensibly closed.

Yesterday was the time appointed for the examination in the case of Ex-Collector SHERIDAN SHOOK. The accused appeared before Commissioner ?? at the hour designated for the examination. The District-Attorney asked for an adjournment, and the Commissioner, after much discussion, adjourned the ease to Saturday at 11 o'clock, when he said it must positively proceed.
BOSTON, Sept. S.--The application for pardon of DANIEL S. CURTIS has been unaulteously refused by the Committee on Pardons. He is imprisoned for an assault and battery.
A suit of somewhat novel character is now on trial before the United States Circuit Court. It is that of ALFRED TIPPETT against SAMUEL S. VAUGH and ASAPH WHITTLESEY, and is a civil suit for damages.

PETER B. SWEENEY, the great Tammany Sachem, and king-pin of the "Ring," arrived home yesterday in the steamer St. Laurent. His coming has been anxiously looked for by Democratic politicians of all grades in New-York, who found it impossible to prepare the "slate" satisfactorily in his absence.

HAVANA, Sept. 9.--General LESCA left the city at noon to-day for Sauga, with the new battalion of volunteers, four hundred strong. A detachment of two hundred spantards met the insurgents in Sevilla Bay and put them to flight.

Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday at the Morgue over the remains of JOHN HICKEY, who died on Wednesday from the effects of a kick in the abdomen, while another person was endeavoring to separate two women who were quarreling on the 2d inst. at No. 10 Roosevelt-street.

Sept. 9.--In steamship St. Laurent, from Hacre and Brest--Mr. Stucky, Mr. Thompson, Mr. Geiger, MR. Carlos, Mr. Barbeck, Mr. Phipps, Mr. and Mrs. Kayne, child and servant, Mr. and Mrs. Olstie, child and servant, Mr. Marzo, Mr. Dortlinger and son, Mr. and Miss Maxwell, Mr. Robbns, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Creners and child, Mr. and Mrs. Brankis, 3 children and servant,

The question of the loss sustained by cotton under the ordinary action of the atmosphere, is an interesting one to growers and cotton dealers, and experiments in reference to it will be viewed with attention. Our follow-citizen, JOHN H. HOLMES, Esq., cotton broker, BOYEL Co.'S wharf, has purchased a bale of new cotton, grown in Orangeburg County, in this State, classed full low middling, and weight 419 pounds.

SCRANTON, Sept. 9.--The assertion that 203 men were entombed in the mine was quickly demonstrated to be an exaggeration, but no one was prepared for the culmination of the great tragedy to-day, when it was finally, discovered that no more than 108 lives had been lost by the disaster.
The promulgation of Attorney-General HOAR's opinion on the test-oath question has been promptly followed by General CANBY'S proclamation announcing the result of the late election.

The Brooklyn Board of Albermen held a ?? meeting yesterday, President LERCEN it the chair. Mr. BERGEN said that the law Committee had prepared a report in reference to the judgment against the city. Obtained by Mrs. CATHAEINE COYLE, recently by the court of Appeals.

The bookmakers and booksellers evidently count upon a lively and remunerative Fall and Winter trade. Their preparations are certainly very extensive, and the promises they make are tempting in no ordinary degree.

In addition to the adoption of a resolution and the appointment of a committee looking to the obtaining of funds for the relief of the Avondale sufferers, the Board of Assistant Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution tendering to the Harvard Crew the hospitalities of the City on their return from England.

The Port Jervis Gazette says that on Saturday afternoon a large party of ladies and gentlemen of Honesdale, Engaged some passenger cars on the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company's Railroad, to take a trip up the road to Waymart, a distance of ten miles. In going up they had to ascend several planes by means of stationary steam power.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Hon. B. F. BUTLER, in his review of "The Byron Scandal," which appeared in your edition of to-day, after proclaiming the extreme puerility of Lady BYRON'S alleged motive for making her astounding charge against her husband,

WASHINGTON, Sept, 9.--The President to-day appointed General SHERMAN Secretary of War de facto, and issued a commission to him accordingly. This supersedes the ad interim appointment of yesterday, and is done so as to give the President time to consider the question of General RAWLINS' successor, and obviate the restrictions imposed by the act of June, 1868,

Mr. J. J. NOAH, late Revenue Supervisor for Tennessee, communicates to the Washington ?? a letter in which he shows that the internal revenue service, under the auspices of the present commissioner, has greatly improved and augment in the Governmental returns to a very considerable amount.

HALIFAX, N. S., Sept. 9.--The steamer Hornet has been released from custody. It is still believed she is intended for Cuba, and will receive arms and men at sea. Prince ARTHUR'S huntiag expedition was not successful. He bagged some small game, but saw no moose.

The demand for the direct representation of labor in the English Parliament gains strength every day. It is stimulated by the dissatisfaction with which the working classes regard the fruits of the past session.

The Detroit Post thinks that Captain ERICSSON, in his ingenious essay upon the change in the velocity of the earth's revolution, over-looked one very important element in the forces which tend to produce it.

The delegates of the German societies engaged in making arrangements for the torchlight procession in honor of HUMROLDT, hold another meeting at the Germania Assembly Rooms last night. Several additional Societies were reported as intending to participate in the procession, and several communications in reference so the matter were read.

Coroner FLYNN made further progress in his ante-mortem examination in the case of JACOB BERKLE, the German alleged to have been clubbed in the Fifth Ward Police Station. Several witnesses were examined.

Yesterday afternoon Sergeant SANDERS, of the Tenth Precinet Police, entered the Coroner's office, and in an excited manner informed Deputy Coroner SHINE that one MARY BOLAND alias Mrs. Charles Shay, was then lying in a dangerous condition at the promises No. 34 Stanton-street, kept by one Mine.

M. MAILLEFERT continues his submarine blasts on Ways Reff. Yesterday he exploded about twenty charges of 129 pounds of power each. He has been dredging the debris, and has already carried to shore some 300 tons of rock. The result of his explosions is not known, but he believes that about onequarter of the required amount of rock has been removed.

The Boston papers come filled with details of the great damage done in that city by a terrible gale on Wednesday evening. Certainly nothing equal to it has boon experienced there since the groat storm in 1851, when Minot's Ledge Lighthouse was destroyed, and by many it is contended that the gale on Wednesday was even more severe than that.

BOSTON, Sept. 9.--An extensive conflagration occurred in East Cambridge this morning, which destroyed the block of wood working factories on Otis, First and Second streets. The following are the owners, losses and insurance: F. GELDOWSKI, loss $100,000, insured for $80,000; WOODBURY Co., loss $10,000, insured for $20,000;

It is, in a word, to be abused when living and praised when dead. The eulogies lately pronounced upon Senator FESSENDEN only serve to give fresh force to the reproach that it is impossible for an eminent man to obtain justice until he is no longer in the world to hear its voice.

Colonel Whitely, of the United States Detective Squad. yesterday arrested JAMES CODBINGTON, aged 50, and GEORGE MERRIAN, aged 42, on the charge of uttering counterfeit twenty-five cent currency stamps. Upon-being searched $1,000 worth were found in their possession,

The Union General Democratic committee met last evening at Masonic Hall in Thirteenth-street. The hall was completely filled, even to overflowing, with the delegates. Among those prominent in thee meeting were NELSON J. WATERBURY; ANTHONY J. OLIVER, from the Corporation Counsel's office;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A stranger called on me a few days ago with a subscription book, handsomely bound and gilded, claiming to be the "agent for the Asylum for Widows and Orphans," and asking a donation. The name of GEORGE E. LOCKWOOD, trustee, No. 142 Broadway, was printed in the book.

On Thursday evening MARGARET ENRIGHT, chambermaid in charge of the third floor of the Metropolitan Hotel, locked the door of room No. 358, occupied by SOLON E. FARWELL, one of the guests. At 11 P. M. Mr. FARWELL entered the room, and at once discovered a man concealed under the bed.

The establishment No. 438 Broadway has become notorious for the number of its victims. Yesterday JOSEPH PAGE, of Ohio, and H. HOWARD, of California, complained that they had been swindled at this place by means of the envelope game, the first of $300 and the other of $68. An officer was sent with the complainants and obtained a return of the money.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 10.--The petition of EDWARD NORTON, of Farmington, for an injunction on the directors of the Connecticut and Western Railroad, forbidding them to make contracts on the ground that the full capital stock of the Company was not subscribed, was withdrawn to-day. Mr. NORTON having been a director in the Company

About 9 o'clock last evening, a fire was discovered in the rear basement of the five-story building Nos. 168, 170 and 172 Centre-street, occupied, with the exception of the first floor, by KAVANAGH DECKER, billiard-table manufactures. The flames soon ran through the inner portion of the building to the workshops on the upper floors and to the roof, completely destroying the building and its contents,

General B. F. BUTLER, the executor of the last will and testament of his brother, ANDREW J. BUTLER, filed in the Surrogate's office on the 10th of July a statement of the entire assets of his brother's estate, in accordance with the decision of the Court of Appeals.

The immediate completion of the Senatus Consuitum is demanded by the opinion Nationale, of Paris. The fears of a return of the Emperor's illness render it important that the Government should be settled, for without it a change of Sovereigns would produce revolution. The Emperor, accompanied by the Empress, was in Paris yesterday.

The steamship Donau, which left Bremen on Aug. 28. and Southampton on Aug. 31, reached this port last night. Her advice's are later by two days than those already at hand by the Russia. HARVARD AND OXFORD.

The steamship Henry Chauncey, which left Aspinwall, Sept, 2, reached this part yesterday, She brings the following

With the cool season will probably come the cabs which have so long been promised. We believe that the projectors of the undertaking are only waiting until their arrangements are properly completed before sending out the now vehicles for hire. They do not want to start until they are sure of carrying out their enterprise with success.

It appears that Dr. CUMMING has not been invited to attend the great Council at Rome. The Pope's two letters to Creeks and Protestants have been published in the London Times, and it seems that Protestants are only very affectionately argued to seek the true Church, and nothing is said about their attending the Council.

LONDON, Sept. 10.--JOHN BRIGHT, member of Parliament for Birmingham, says in a letter that the good harvest will tend to restore health to the general trade of the country; and when we have a sufficient supply of cotton, Lancashire will recover from her distressed condition. It is more cotton that we want, and not more taxes on imports.

About 9 o'clock last evening, the jewelry store of JAMES SOUTHWICK, No. 613 1/2 Broadway, became the scene of a drama and almost of a tragedy. Some rowdies entered the store, and began disarranging the stock in a very suspicious manner, so much so that SOUTHWICK resolved to put them out, and a scuffle ensued.

The steamship Eagle, Which left. Havana on Saturday, Sept. 4, arrived at this port yesterday. By the courtesy of her purser we are in prompt receipt of our Cuban letter and papers.

PARIS, Sept. 10.--The official papers announce that the condition of the Emperor is satisfactory. He has asked the consent of his physicians to go out into the open air. It is considered probable that the Empress will undertake her journey to the East in a short time.

Canada again disputes the billiard championship with the players of the States, and the victor in the forthcoming contest between DERBY and MELVIN FOSTER, must prepare to cross cues with C. The Republic is the title of a new evening paper which made its appearance among as on Thursday, under the auspices of WILLIAM H. HALLOUK as proprietor and Mr. ST. CLAIR KELWAY as editor. It is very neatly printed, and is pledged to everything that is good and against everything else.

At Weehawken, this morning, the market was dull and butchers hard to be delat with; nevertheless sales were effected, and at 11:30 the pens were pretty nearly cleared out. Weehawken ought to come out a first-class cattle market, under the able guidance of A. M. ALLERTON, whose genial manner does much to smooth difficulties, and he gets smartly along with the no easy task of pleasing every one, buyers and sellers,

Close upon the death of the distinguished Senator from Maine, the telegraph brings us intelligence of the death of JOHN BELL, at one time equally prominent with Mr. FESSENDEN in the councils of the nation. Mr. BELL was born at Nashville, Tenn., in 1797. He was, therefore, 72 years of age.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 10.--In the suit brought by the Attorney-General, at the suggestion of Governor HOFFMAN, in this district, to determine the legality of the election for directors of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad Company on the 7th inst., Deputy Attorney-General HAMMOND this morning applied to Judge JOHNSON, sitting at the Special Term in this city,

CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept, 10.--The frontier question between Turkey and Persia has been satisfactorily arranged. Formal ratifications will be exchanged by the two Governments as soon as possible. PARIS, Sept, 10.--It is reported that the Kedive of Egypt has submitted to the Sultan on all points, except in the matter of budget loans.

A regular meeting of this association (organized under the Auspices of the new General Committee) was held at No. 1.000 Third-avenue last evening, the President, CHAN. WATERS, in the chair. S.D. MOULTON presented the following preamble and resolution :

1. THE SUBJECTION OF WOMEN, BY JOHN STUART MILL. NEW-YORK: D. APPLETON CO. 1869. 2. WOMEN'S SUFFRAGE; THE REFORM AGAINST NATURE by HORACE BUSHNELL, New-York: CHARLES SCRHINER Co. 1869. SCRANTON, Sept. 10.--Although the excitement of the past four days has measurably subsided and business in all the towns is generally resumed, the mines are yet deserted, and probably none will be worked before Monday. The catastrophe is yet eagerly discussed. especially among miners who gather in groups in their hamlets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Letters from Cuba, via Key West, received yesterday, give the following account of the battle near Las Tunas: On the 16th ult. a reconnoitering party was sent out by General QUESADA, numbering three hundred men. On the afternoon of the same day, this force was attacked by largely superior numbers, but succeeded, with a loss of fifty-five in killed, wounded and missing.

It if apparent that Senator TWEED and the Tammany Regency are not to have things their own way this Fall without an effort. The meeting at Masonic Hall last evening represented some of the best blood and pluck of the old Democratic Party, and the orators could not have spoken in less flattering terms of the Tweed regime if they had been Republicans.

At the meeting of the Brooklyn Citizens' Reform Association, held at the City Salesroom, in Court-street, last evening, Hon. SAMUEL SMITH, Ex-Mayer, was elected President. Colonel THORP read an address on municipal abuses concerning Prospect Park. He said it was announced at first that the Park would not cost more than $3,000,000.

At 8 o'clock last evening, President GRANT, accompanied by General PORTER and Mr. CORBIN, his brother-in-law, visited the American Institute Fair, and soon became the observed of all observers. Matters were progressing rather quietly, there being a small number of visitors present just previous to the President's arrival

" The peril of the hour" in Ohio, according to tile Toledo Blade, is the multiplication of "Peoples' tickets" in the various counties and cities; a fusion of Democrats and Republicans going on with reference to local offices.

Some of the most graceful and appreciative tributes to the late Secretary RAWLINS have been rendered by the Southern Press. And they express the hope that the President will be as fortunate in selecting his successor as he was in choosing his faithful friend, whose loss the country now mourns.

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue recently decided that each society of Shakers is onti led to but a single thousand dollars exemption from income tax. The Society protests against this as unjust, and yesterday the question was argued before the Commissioner by the counsel of the Shakers,

Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. PORT JERVIS, Sept. 10.--this morning, at 12:30 o'clock, a terrific boiler explosion occurred at Sparrowbush, on the Erie Railway, three miles west of this place, by which four men were instantly killed. the locomotive, No. 239, was attached to a coal train westward bound. BANTA.--At Hackensack, N. J., on Thursday morning, Sept. 9 1869. ADELIA ZABRISKIS, who of William S. Banta. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Saturday, Sept. 11, 1869, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from her late home, and at 2 o'clock from the First Reformed Church, Hackensack, without further notice.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 10.--The city has relapsed into its condition of chronic dullness, presenting a remarkable contrast with the crowded streets and animated scenes of yesterday. The President and Cabinet will be mostly out of town until the 20th, and the preparation of the annual reports will not begin until the close of the present quarter on the 30th inst.

LONDON, Sept, 10.--The Times to-day has an article on the subject of Mr. SICKLES' note to the Spanish Government, in which it says: "It is hardly credible that America contemplates the recognition of Cuba. While Spain has little to lose except the island. Owing to the confusing prospect of the war, and its damaging effects on here commerce and finance, she admits she must ultimately consent to abandon Cuba.

After an absence of several weeks--nearly all the time on the Hudson--under the shadows of Fishkill Mountain, and in sight of that old Storm King, which seems one of the bulwarks of nature, I have returned to the shades of "The Beeches."

The way of reaching this beautiful sheet of water, which may in truth he called the twin sister of Lake George, is by following the Hudson from Luzernes to Schroon River, or by stage from Caldwell over a fine plank road through Warrensburg and Chester to this place.

The London Times, in speaking of the Irish land tonnre, announces that "the idea of peasant proprietorship is the most genial and picturesque of socialist dreams." Is this true! Is the possibility that those who till the land may own that land, only a "dream," a phantasy of "socialism?"'' If it be, then the deepest rooted of Irish grievances is be yond remedy.

The champion Eekfords yesterday played with the Actives, of Wappinger Falls, in this State, at the Union Grounds. The latter are young players, but showed some good work during the game, and were not beaten as badly as they expected to be, the score standing 31 to 8 in favor of the champions. LISBON, Sept. 11.--The regular mail steamer from Rio de Janeiro has arrived here, bringing dates from the hostile armies on the Parana to the 29th of July. The news is quite important. According to a Paraguayan account, a sharp engagement had occurred between the Brazilians and the Paraguayans, in which 200 of the former and 60 of the latter were killed.

The present month fairly inaugurates the regular season of drill and inspection of the National Guard regiments. Those members who have been fortumte enough to enjoy a vacation, have returned From the country, renewed in strength, and eager for the exercises of the drillroom and field day.

It is stated by the Hebrew National, a new weekly journal, published in London, that there are now living about 6,000,000 Israelites, nearly one-half of whom live in Europe. The following table exhibits the manner in which they are distributed among the different countries of the world:

The Pope himself is personally attending to nearly all matters of detail connected with the coming Ecumenical Council. He made a mee hit in his decision of a question which had puzzled the workmen engaged in making seats for the dignitaries who will attend the Council.

We learn from Mr. LYNCH, editor of the Gold Hill Daily News, a passenger on the train from the East, which arrived in this city this morning at 1:15 o'clock, that the fire on the Pacific Railroad, above Cisco, the night before last, was more serious than is generally supposed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--A few days since it was telegraphed from here that JNO. TYLER, Jr., son of Ex-President TYLER, had been consigned to a charity ward in Providence Hospital to be treated for drunkenness. Mr. TYLER now writes a card to one of the evening papers denying the statement.

The United States war steamer Algonquin, reported previously as having been sold by the Government to M. EVARISTE LAROCHE, (Charged' Affairs of Hayti,) in behalf of his Government, is to be delivered at the Navy-yard, Brooklyn, on Monday, to that gentleman. She is to be put under the command of an officer of the United States Navy, detailed for the purpose.

It has been very evident, the past season, that Niagara is losing some of its old prestige and Popularity as a watering place, and that its glories as such have departed--at least for a time. The patronage of late years does not compare with that of former years, considering the recent growth of all American watering places; but the people of the City have only themselves to thank for this.

If we correctly understand what occurred at the meeting of the Board of Health on Wednesday, It proposes to held a special meeting on Monday next to consider the propriety of Adhering to the determination formed about a month since to stop fat-boiling in the city on the first of October next.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 11.--The inquest began at 11 A. M. to-day in Shupp's Hall, Plymouth, Esquires WADHAMS and ENO acting as Coroners. A jury, consisting of Wm. J. Harvey, Charles Hutchison, Samuel Vanloon, James George, Martin McDonald and Thomas Patten, were all present, but the attendance of the spectators was much smaller than had been anticipated.

This finely-situated place of Summer resort, although well-known and frequented by those in search of pleasure or health from the West and South, has not, as yet, received the attention it deserves from the metropolitan resident. One of the advantages of St. Catharines is the facility with which it is reached from all parts of the country.

HAVANA, Sept. 11.--It having become known that suspected parties were about to mail letters for the United States, the mails by the steamship Missouri were detained, and the letters, which are supposed to contain rebel intelligence, were registered.

On Thursday last a room in the residence of Mr. JAMES AUSTIN, NO. 126 East Thirty-seventh-street, was entered and robbed of diamonds and other jewelry to the amount of about $3,000. Inspector DILKS was informed of the theft, and detailed Detective AVERY to work up the case.

CONOVER.--On Saturday, Sept. 11, at South Ambov, N. J., at the residence of her son-in-law, Captain P. V. De Graw, Mrs. CATHARINE S. CONOVER, of this City, in the 83d year of her age. Notice of funeral in Monday's papers. COX.--On Friday morning, Sept. 10, at his residence, New-Brighton, S. I., MARK COX, in the 45th year o his age.

The Ogden iron mine, located three miles from Ogdensburg, in the township of Sparta, Essex County, in New-Jersey, was on Friday the scene of a fearful catastrophe, resulting in the death of four of the men employed in the mine.

CHOY CHEW and SING MAN, our late Chinese guests, have got back to California, and tell a correspondent of the Chicago Tribune that "Now-York is a greater city than Chicago, and is a better place to sell first-class Chinese and Japanese goods. It has a groat trade and will keep growing larger for hundreds of years.

One door of the vault of the Rochester Bank, which burglars unsuccessfully attempted to rob on the night of the 1st, has a very curions lock. It was invented and made thirty -five years age by CHARLES DENNETT, one of the first directors of the Rochester Bank, who was a very ingenious mechanic.

H. B. MATTESON, one of the persons charged by Assessor CLEVELAND with having appropriated moneys belonging to the Government, voluntarily delivered himself up on Friday. He learned of the warrant for his arrest at his country residence in Chemango County, in this State, and immediately started for this City.

The Fair of the American Institute, at the Empire Skating Rink, in Third-avenue, which was thrown open a little prematurely to the public, is being rapidly put into exhibiting order, and has already been visited by a great many people. The Rink is so large that it takes a very large throng to made it appear full.
Chancellor WILLIAM CHAUVESET of Washington University. St. Louis, has resigned on account of ill health. he has held the position since the death of Chancellor JOSEPH G ?? in 1863.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 11--A terrible fire destroyed most of the business part of Martinsburg, Lewis County, on Friday morning. The fire was kindled by incendiaries, under the steps leading to the Good Templars' Lodge-room. The following property was destroyed : Lovejoy's Hotel, loss estimated at $13,000;

To the Editor on the New-York Times: From the telegraphic California reports of this morning, (Sept. 6.) in your paper, I fear I have been somewhat misrepresented in regard to my remarks at the Chicago Convention. I did not say that seven-eighths of the adult population died from drunkenness.

MY DEAR FRIEND: I thank you for your advice with regard to reduction f force in my Bureau. It is impossible to escape censure. The only way to do is to make up your mind conscientiously was to what is right, and then go on.

NASHVILLE. Tenn., Sept. 11.-- The funeral of Hon. JOHN BELL will take place to-morrow. At meetings of the Nashville Bar and of the citizens to-day, resolutions were passed eulogizing the deceased. The citizens' meeting was addressed by HENRY S. FOOTE, Ex-President JOHNSON and others.

MONTREAL,Sept. 11.--The La Crosse match for the championship of the Dominion, between the Montreal and Prescott Clubs, was won by the former in three straight games. The great breach of promise case of SOPHIA M. GRANGE against JAMES BENNING, for $60,000 damages, ended yesterday. The jury returned a verdict of $3,500 for the plaintiff.

A post-mortem examination of the body of Senator FESSENDEN was made by Dr. FOSTER, of this city, yesterday morning. Drs. PERLEY. of Bridgton, HORATIO SMITH, of New-York, Wood, GILMAN and DAVIES, of this city, and Dr. FESSENDEN, surgeon in charge of the Marine Hospital and brother of the Senator, being in attendance.

On Saturday morning last our community was thrown into a state of excitement by the report that J. K. BEAR, Agent of the United States Express Company, had not been seen since 7 o'clock the previous evening.

Green islands in a golden sea, With amethyst cliffs that melt away At every wash of the sleepy wave, White towering Alps that greet the day: And still through rents in the further space Glimpses of distant ocean bed, Burning with restless changeful light, And veined with flushed of glory spread, Far as the living are from the dead, Far as the blessed are from hell's night.

Mr. PENDLETON is still compelled to support himself on crutches. Among other things he said: " I cannot agree with Governor HAYES that the vexed questions of national politics are wisely and happily settled;

It is pleasant to see the charitable efforts for the relief of the families of the Avondale miners. Not only the municipal authorities but business associations and workingmen's associations have come promptly forward. The Stock Exchange and the God Room, as well as trade union and laborers' societies, have been touched by a common sympathy.

On the 8th inst. the seamen's boarding house kept by CONSTANTINE ADAMS, at No. 376 Water-street, was robbed, the occupants losing two silver watches, one gold watch, two gold chains, five breast pins, and some other articles, Valued at $320, besides $105 in American currency and English gold coin.
A dispatch from ST. Hyacinthe, Sept. 4, to a ?? Paper, Says: "Yesterday a man by the name of LOUIS PHENIX left his home at Milton, with the wife, to go to St. Dominique.

Our obituary yesterday recorded the death, in his 83d year, of JAMES FORNERI, LL. D, late Professor of Modern Languages in University College, Toronto. The career of the deceased Professor had been in some respects a remarkable one. The descendant of an ancient Italian family, he was educated, with a view to the office of the priesthood, in anticipation of the succession to valuable family living.

A report has been circulated that Major JOHN H. PRATT, the reputed Texas fugitive and assassin, whose case recently came before the United States and State Courts, in this City, in a very conspicuous manner, has temporarily taken up his residence in Europe.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11.--At the New England Fair to-day Dr. GEO. B. LORING delivered favor of the protection of industry as best calculated to promote the agricultural and other interests of the country.

This Association met last evening in Pryor's Hall, on Thirteenth -street, and formed a permanent organization, as follows: President, John Burt, Jr.; Vice -President, Henry Fox ; Second Vice -President, James Sullivan : Secretary, James E. Daniels; Treasurer, Dr. Stephen Clarks ; Sergeant -at -Arms, John Sullivan.

LONDON, Sept. 11.--The Land and Water (newspaper) hopes the Oxford crew will make a return much with the Harvards, and that the race will be as well fought as the last. A better contest cannot be expected.

Augusta C. Davidson vs. George L. Davidson; decree of divorce granted against defendant on the ground of adultery. SUPREME COURT-SPECIAL, TERM-BROOKLYN. Jno. W. Lane et al. vs. Chas. II. Bemans et al.: Eliza Strickland vs Joseph Strickhand; motion for alimony denied; no costs.

A brief telegram, received in this city yesterday afternoon, announced the safety of the steamer Cambridge, bound for this part form Bangor, for which serious apprehensions has been felt. From a passenger by the Cambridge, who arrived in this city by midnight from Portland with others of the Cambridge's passengers, we have been favored with a connected account of the terrific experience which passengers and crew were compelled to undergo.

Among the noted peculiarities of American speech, there are perhaps few that sound more oddly than the word dirt as many persons use it in connection with a thoroughfare. They call a road a " dirt road," leading a great many to suppose, at first, that they mean a road through which rubbish is to be earted,

At a meeting of the Board of Managers of the "Wilson Industrial School for Girls, held on Friday evening, the Building Committee reported that the new building recently purchased by them would be ready for occupation on the 20th inst. This building is situated on the corner of Avenue A and Eighth-street.

No one can fairly say that New-York is a dull city. As in most other thickly-populated towns, a walk through the streets is in itself an unfailing source of interest, and there are few who have not some favorite localities where they are pretty sure of finding occupation for a leisure hour.

State-street was not a little agitatated yesterday by the announcement that the paying Teller of the North National Bank had defaulted to a large amount. The offender is Mr. DANIEL E. SAUNDERS, Jr., and the story is the old one--that of speculation.

Yesterday was the second day of the running meeting on the Fashion Course, it having been postponed from the previous Wednesday on account of the unfavorable weather. The day was clear and pleasant, notwithstanding which the attendance was not large, being confined almost entirely to the regular habitats of the track and that class who make speculation on racing issue their legitimate business.

The Emperor, it is officially announced, is well. It is rumored that he may abdicate, and some think his son's majority will be proclaimed on his next birthday. The disturbances having been quelled at Madrid, the Government, it is said, has advised General PRIM that his speedy return home is not necessary.

The delegates of the German societies held another meeting at the Germania Assembly Rooms, last evening, to complete the arrangements for the torchlight procession of Tuesday next. Mr. STEFFEN presided, and a report of the Executive Committee was submitted, embracing the details of the procession.

About 5 o' Clock this morning, as an organgrinder, in company with his wife, was walking on the Erie Railway track. near Howell's Depot. passenger train No. 12 came along and ran over the man, killing him instantly and terribly mangling his body. His wife stepped aside in time to avoid being struck by the locomotive.

Commissioner STILLWELL received a complaint yesterday in which E. WOODWARD, GEO, MARSHALL and JAMES CODDINGTON were charged with having manufactured and issued counterfeited 25 cent notes. MARSHALL was taken as a Government witness. He testified that he had negotiated with WOODWARD for $1,000 worth of counterfeit stamps at 40 cents on the dollar.

Justice HOGAN issued a warrant yesterday at the request of the District-Attorney for the arrest of WM. HIGGINS, a liquor dealer at No. 3 Clark-street, on the complaint of MICHAEL BRADY, of No. 148 West Twenty-sixth-street, who accuses him of having, on the 3d of August, struck him on the head with a club, and also shooting him through the check with a pistol.

ROBERT COLLYER takes the following ehartable view of sleepy Summer congregations: "This may be one of those things in which nobody is to blame except as we are to blame for any other sickness. The preacher has written too many sermons, and the people have heard too many for ten months past.

It is said that Mr. JAMES FISK, Jr., propose a third rail from Albany to Saratoga, over the Rochester and Syracuse Road, to connect with the Susquchanna route, so as to give a broadguage connection with the West. If the Syracuse Company refuse his proposals, he intends to build a new road on his own account.

Notwithstanding the positive notice that the Postmaster will entertain no more personal applications for positions in the Post Office, a large number of place-seekers present themselves there daily, the average number being nearly seventy-five.
MADRID, Sept. 11.--The disorders have been quelled and the city and country are tranquil. The Government has advised General PRIM, therefore, that his speedy return is unnecessary.
The protected heat we have had, month after month, which was slightly abated by rains in the early part of last week, has at last culminated in a grand equipnoetial storm of wind and rain.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 11.--The stable belonging to ADIRE WELCH was burned at midnight last night. Loss, $2,500; without insurance. Eight horses and six mules perished in the flames. ADRIAN, Mich., Sept. 11.--The tennery belonging to W. H. STONE, in this place,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You speak often of these who think the five-twenties ought to he paid in lawful money, as repudiators. The acme of business integrity, I have always been taught to believe, is to live strictly up to contract. What was the contrast between the purchasers of the five-twenties and the Government? It was to pay the interest in coin.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11.--Senator FESSENDEN'S funeral took place at the First Parish Church at 10:30 o'clock to-day. The public offices were closed. The members of the Cumberland Bar, City Government, Eastern Star, and Machigonne Encampments, were present.

Taking the report of this week as an indication of the r?? in that direction, it may he safety averred that the building interest is looking up. For the week ending on Friday, there are sixty-one proposed new buildings reperted, against twenty-nine of the proceding week;

Work was commenced on the Lincoln monument at Springfield. Ill., on Thursday. Prayer was offered by Rev. Father HALE of that city, when, in the absence of Governor OGLESBY, Hon. JESSE K. DUBOIS made a written statement of the finances of the Association, showing that after all liabilities now contracted ($151,000) were paid, there would yet remain over %6,000 unexpended.

DENNIS EGAN, the keeper of a low drinking den in South Brooklyn, who was indicted on a charge of manslaughter in having, on the night of the 12th of April last, pushed JAMES HAGGERTY, while drunk, out of his bar-room into the street, thereby causing injuries from which HAGGERTY died in the Forty-third Precinet Station-house,

The Bay City (Mich.) Journal gives the following : "For a long time past a son of Mr. Ellis, at Bridgeport Centre, Saginaw County, has talked very strangely in regard to his mother, who died about ten years ago, asserting that she was buried alive.

The Oxford-Harvard beat race has been more than a boat race. It has been in every sense an international event, and touched the sympathies of almost every man, woman and child in this country, as from all we read it touched America at home.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11.--The sixth and last day of the Lexington races was well attended. The first race was for the Jockey Club purse of $600; three mile heats. Tow entries:

As usual, it is announced that the Maine election to-day is most important, as it is the first to occur since the Administration came into power. Regularly every four years the people of New-Hampshire, Connecticut, Vermont, California, Maine, Ohio and Pennsylvania, are told that their elections are most important because each is " the first" to pronounce authoritatively and decisively upon the success or the failure of the new Administration.

The law passed at the last session of the Legislature, permitting persons charged with crime to testify in their own behalf has now been in operation for four months, and its merits and demerits are exemplified in the practical workings of the latter over matters of public interest.

BONESTEEL.--At his residence at Copake, N. Y., on Thursday morning, Sept. 8, PETER BONESTEEL aged 13 years, a prominent lawyer of the Columbia Bar, and formerly of Hudson. BLEECKER.--On Sunday, Sept, 12, in the 14th year of her age, ANTONIA, youngest daughter of Anthony L. Bleecker.

Prince ARTHUR has once mere started on his tour through the New Dominion. He has had a brief rest of three days in the woods, during which he has shot nothing except partridges, and has not even heard a moose. The remainder of his journey through the Province of Now-Brunswick seems to be characterized with unseemly haste.

Hoboken has been the scene of another shocking affair. A murder has been committed, and the victim is a poor laborer named JOHN O'NEIL. The circumstances, as far as ascertained, are these: It appears that on the evening of tuesday last O'NEIL was in his room at the house of JOHN KENNEY, corner of Clinton and First streets, in company with EDWARD MASON, JAMES O'BRIEN. JOHN KENNEY and JAMES KENNEDY.
For a number of weeks past there have been displayed daily in our advertising columns several hundred announcements of the opening of as many academies and seminaries in this City and vicinity.

The evidence given before the Coroner's jury on the miners killed at Avondale does not satisfactorily dispel the dark stories which have been in circulation during the last few days. Our correspondent states that the testimony already produced is not so strong as that which will be forthcoming,

There may be plausible reasons for opposing the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment. But unless something can be found more plausible and true than the objections stated by Mr. PENDLETON to his Cincinnati friends, only ignorance or stupidity will be influenced by them.

About 7:30 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in Suydam-street, near Johnson, Williamsburg. It occurred in a row of five new two story frame houses, two of then unfinished, They were the property of Dr. SMITH, who occupied one of them.

SENATOR SUMNER AND TIIE ADMINISTRATION. WASHINGTON, Sept. 12.-There is good reason to believe that Senator SUMNER, who is to preside at the Massachusetts Republican State Convention, at Worcester, on the 22d inst., designs on that occasion to make an important and possibly very significant speech on the present condition of public affairs.

The Emperor, it is officially announced, is well. It is rumored that he may abdicate, and some think his son's majority will be proclaimed on his next birthday. A letter in the London Telegraph of yesterday says that Lord BYRON did not meet Mrs. LEIGH for a period extending over the time before his marriage with and separation from Lady BYRON.

The famous Harverd crew were expected to arrive in this City during yesterday. The day passed, however, without the arrival of the steamer City of Antwerp, on board of which Messrs. LORING and FAY embarked at Liverpool. Mr. W. BLAIKIE, the distinguished Ex-Harvard oarsman, and Mr. ELLIOTT, the Harvard boatbuilder, are passengers on the same vessel.
The annual election in Maine occurs today. The Republicans have nominated for Governor, General JOSHUA L. CHAMBERLAIN, who has, by annual elections, already held the office for three years.

The following letters, signed by the President and the Secretary of the Republican Central Junta of Cuba and Porto Riro, have been sent to General BUTTERFIELD, Treasurer of the Rawlins Fund: JUNTA CENTRAL REPUBLICANA DE CUBA Y PUERTO RICO, No. 71 BROADWAY, NEUVA-YORK, Sept. 9, 1869.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12.--The carillon of bells manufactured in France for St. Joseph's Cathedral in this city, having been mounted in the tower of the edifice, large crowds of citizens of all denominations assembled at the Cathedral and filled the neighboring streets to listen to the first performance of the bells,

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 11. - The inquest began at 11 A.M. to-day in Shupp's Hall, Plymouth, Esquires WADHAMS and ENO acting as Coroners. The following is the testimony of to-day: C. H. Wilson, M. D., sworn : The cause of the death of the men found in the mine was the inhaling of carbonic acid gas, producing asphyxia.
