According to a Paraguayan account, a sharp engagement had occurred between the Brazilians and the Paraguayans, in which 200 of the former and 60 of the latter were killed.

PORTLAND, Sept. 12.--The funeral service of Senator FESSENDEN took place at the First Parish Unitarian Church at 10:30 yesterday morning, Rev. Mr. BAILEY, the pastor; officiating, assisted by Dr. CARRUTHERS, the oldest settled minister in the city. The edifice was thronged, the crowd filling the vestibule and reaching into the street.

Yesterday being set apart, in accordance with the recommendation of the two General Assemblies of the Presbyterian Church which lately met in this City, as a day of prayer for the purpose of" obtaining the direction and guidance of the Holy Spirit in regard to the proposed union of the two Schools of the Presbyterian Church," there were special observances in the conventicles of that denomination.

OPERIATIC PROSPECTS. After having dwelt upon the gloomy prospect or being deprived of opera throughout those whole Winter, we now seem likely to be all but surfeited. English opera, as we have already had occasion to announce, can now be listened to at the French Theatre, where "The Puritan's Daughter" will be sung all this week.

The Central Park Meteorological Report for last week sets forth the following facts and figures: Barometer--Mean, 30.020 inches; maximum at 2. P. M., Sept. 6, 30.226 inches; minimum at 2 P. M., Sept. 8, 29.460 inches; range, .766 inch. ThermometerMean, 68.71 degrees; maximum at 2 P. M., Sept. 9, 79.2 degrees; minimum at 5 A. M., Sept. 10. 56 degrees; range. 23.2 degrees.

SILAS BOWEN, of Perry, was fatally burned at West Great Works, on Wednesday afternoon, by falling into a furnace for burning the waste of a saw mill. He was not missed and his fall was not witnessed. His body was discovered by another man who wheeled a load of edgings to throw into the furnace.

LONDON, Sept. 11. - The Times, in an article on the Turco Egyptian affair, trusts the controversy will have the effect to improve the relations of the Sultan and the Viceroy. The jealousy of the Porte was excited more by suspicion than by actions. The Viceroy having given assurances, and the Porte having conveyed warning, Turkey and Egypt may agree well.

LONDON, Sept. 11.--The Land and Water (newspaper) hopes the Oxford crew will make a return match with the Harvards, and that the race will be as well fought as the last. A better contest cannot be expected.

The Fenian Brotherhood held two meetings yesterday at the Fourth--street Headquarters. The Circles of the Manhattan district met to transact ordinary business, and the Executive Committee assembled by special call. General O'NEILL, R. MCCLOUD, P. J. MEEHAN, JAMES GIBBONS and E. L. CARY and others were present.

A new paper, entitled The College Review, has just made its appearance, and we are pleased to find in its contents the promise of success. It is introduced to the public by one whose name entitles him to a ready and respectful audience.

Lady PALMERSTON, whose death is reported in a cable dispatch to have taken place in London on Saturday last, was the daughter of Hon WILLIAM LAMB, the first Lord MELBOURNE, and Lady CAROLINE LAMB, the daughter of the Earl of BESBOROUGH. She was a sister of the second Lord MELBOURNE, the well-known Whig and Reform Premier, who died in 1848.

The gale of Wednesday was the most severe experienced since 1815, according to old and competent judges. It did great damage on Long Island, as well as in other places. A threemasted schooner, belonging in Boston, and laden with coal, bound for New-York, was grounded about seven miles off Mountauk Point.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 11.-A terrible fire destroyed most of the business part of Martinsburg, Lewis County, on Friday morning. The fire was kindled by incendiaries, under the steps leading to the Good Templars' Lodgeroom. The following property was destroyed: Lovejoy's Hotel, loss estimated at $13.000: insured for $4.500:

NASHVILLE. Tenn., Sept. 11.--The funeral of lion. JOHN BELL will take place to-morrow. At meetings of the Nashville Bar and of the citizens to-day, resolutions were passed eulogizing the deceased. The citizens' meeting was addressed by HENRY S. FOOTE, Ex-President JOHNSON and others. Mr. JOHNSON spoke of Mr.

The Fall regatta of the Shatemne Boat Club occurred on the Hudson, opposite this city, late yesterday afternoon. Hardly a breath of air was stirring, and the bosom of the Hudson was as smooth as glass. It was in single scull shells over a three-mile course. The entries were as follows:

We are inclined to think it about time that M. MAILLEFERT gave us something more substantial than rose-colored newspaper reports of his progress in blowing up the rocks in Hell Gate, known as Way's Reef. When he commenced at Pot Rock there was eight feet of water upon it.

A young man named HASTINGS, residing at No. 136 Mulberry-street, New-York, together with a few friends, entered the shooting-gallery of WM. BROWS, opposite the Bremen and Hamburg Hotel, on River-terrace,yesterday.

At a late hour on Saturday night, as HENRY C. WHIPPEY, of No. 144 Mulberry-street, was passing down Seventh-avenue, he was accosted by PATRICK DOYLE, who persisted in following him as far as Thirty-third-street, when he seized WHIPPEY, and through violence took from his person a handkerchief in which had been tied $17 in money.

PARIS, Sept. 12.--The Journal Officiel publishes the text of the Senatus Consultum, which is promulgated in the name of the Emperor, and is signed by ROUHER and countersigned by DUVERGIER. The following is a synopsis of the document:

The Board met in the Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to special call, signed by a majority of members. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Norton, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Connor, Hardy, McGrath, McQuade--S. On motion the reading of the minutes was dispensed with.

A man was yesterday morning found lying dead upon the track of the New-Jersey Railway, at the depot in Jersey City. Ills body was almost severed in two. It is supposed that he had fallen asleep on the platform of the midnight Trenton freight train,

Yesterday a party of friends of Mr. PENDLETON, returning from the fair, called at his residence, and were entertained by him. They wanted a speech. He asked to be excused, as there were Republicans present who would not want to her a partisan speech. As all wanted to hear him, he said, supporting himself on his crutches:

This week the Fall sales of country real estate really commence. One sale was made on the 2d inst. at Cranford, N. J., by Messrs. A. D. MELLICK, Jr., BR0. It was a decided success. The attendance was good, tho bidding prompt, and the prices quite satisfactory; but it was a little early, a trifle in advance of the regular opening.

LONDON, Sept. 11--11 A. M.- Consols open at 92 1/2 for money, and 92 7/8@93 for the account. The prices for American securities in New-York have not yet been published here, and the following prices are therefore given without reference to the condition of the home market. United States Five-twenty bonds, 1862, 83; 1865, old, 82 3/4; 1867, 81 3/4 ; Ten-forties, 75 1/2. Erie Railway Shares, 26 1/2, Illinois Central, 94.

We are now likely to have light thrown on the mysterious Paraguayan problem. General McMAHON, our Minister in Paraguay, is on his way to Washington, and it is already understood that the news he brings of the situation of affairs on the La Plata is quite different from the reports lately received through Brazilian channels.

PHILADELPIHIA, Sept. 12.-Considerable commotion has been caused in the Democratio Party hero by the resignation of S. GROSS FRY, candidate for City Treasurer. A meeting of the various candidates was held yesterday, at which it was determined that all should resign and take measures to form a new ticket.

MADRID, Sept. 11.--The disorders have been quelled and the city and country are tranquil. The Government has advised General PRIM, therefore, the his speedy return is unnecessary. The Imparcial newspaper, to-day, publishes a recent letter from Mr. FISH, the American Secretary of State, to Minister HALE, and comments favorably upon it.

Senator SHERMAN does not mistake the current of popular feeling when, in the Ohio canvass, he lays stress upon the questions of taxation and currency as those which call for immediate and intelligent attention. The influence of these questions upon the feelings and purposes of the people is not confined to Ohio.

VALMASEDA, the great hero of the Eastern Department of Cuba, the military prodigy of the Spanish forces, has his headquarters at Bayamo, and we are told by the Spanish Press that he is perfecting a base of operations on the River Canto. He has been engaged in this laudable task for upward of seven months--ever since his occupation of the blackened chimneys and charred remains of Bayamo.

During the session of the County Court in Richmond, Va., on Saturday, a misunderstanding between two prominent lawyers led to an exchange of epithets which were in turn followed by blows. The Court sternly ordered that they be committed to jail till Monday morning for contempt, but subsequently the sentence was committed to a fine of $25 each. The lawyers paid, apologised, and were speedily reconciled to each other.

An inquest was held by Coroner WHITE, in Hoboken, last evening, in the case of JOHN O'NEIL, who was found lying dead in the hallway of a house on the corner of First and Clinton streets, Hoboken, on Saturday morning last, under such circumstances that it is believed that he was murdered. The Coroner had a number of the boarders placed under $2,000 bonds to appear at the inquest.

A meeting of the Company recently organized for the purpose of constructing a ship canal between Newark and New-York, is to be held in a few days in the City of Newark, to elect a Board of Directors, $250,000 worth of stock having been subscribed.

About a week ago it was stated simultaneously in several of the morning papers, that the trustees of the Brooklyn City Hospital wore about to institute legal proceedings against the Union Ferry Company for the recovery of a sum of money estimated to be about $2,000,000 or $3,000,000, which amount it was alleged the Ferry Company owed to the City Hospital by virtue of their charter, which, it was claimed, provided that the surplus funds,

The lathers of New-York have heretofore been united in the same organization with the plasterers; but the somewhat diverse interests of the two branches of labor have caused antagonism between the members thereof, and it was thought better for the success of both that each should have a separate organization.

The defalcation of SAUNDERS, the paying teller of the North National Bank, continues to be a theme of fertile conversation in money circles. SAUNDERS, it is believed, has confessed to the extent of his iniquities. He turned over all his stock and accounts with the brokers to the bank authorities, and they, being settled, realized about $25,000 to the bank.

The loyal people of Maine have once more spoken, and their verdict is in favor of national honesty, quality and union. As was anticipated, the aggregate vote and the majority of General CHAMBERLAIN are somewhat reduced from lst year, but after a campaign in which so little public interest has been manifested, a Republican majority of 8,000 votes in a total of about 88,000 should be satisfactory.

Yesterday evening a meeting of the citizens of Yorkville (Nineteenth Ward) was held at the residence of JOHN FOLEY, Esq., No. 16 East Seventy-third-street, for the purpose of organizing an association, having for its object the establishment of a line of omnibuses on the Fifth and Madison avenues to Eighty-sixth-street.

OWEN HORAN, residing at Dykeman's Station, Harlem Railroad, was run over last evening by car No. 21, of the Ninth-avenue Railroad, at the corner of Twenty-sixth-street, and was seriously injured. he was taken to Mount Sinai Hospital. WALENSTINE LAWSON, residing on One Hundred and seventeenth-street, near Second, fell yesterday from a painter's scaffold. while at work, at the corner of One Hundred and Nineteenth-street and Second-avenue, and was severely injured. He was taken home.

At about 12:30 o'clock yesterday the milk stable of Mr. BOWRON, at Hunter's Point, was totally destroyed by fire. A load of hay being taken through the gateway came in contact with a jet of gas which set ?? to it. The Hames spread rapidly, and soon the stables and their controls were in rains. The fire extended to Mr. McMAHON'S stables, and they also were destroyed.

THOMAS H. BARRETT, of No. 6 Staple-street, and his brother WILLIAM, of No. 170 West Broadway, attended their father's funeral on Sunday afternoon, and subsequently returned to WILLIAM'S residence in company with two or three friends.

The Minnesota Republican State Convention, which was held in St. Paul on Thursday last, nominated the following ticket: For Governor, HORACE AUSTIN; Lieutenant-Governor, W. H. YALE; Secretary of State, HANS MATTSON; Attorney-General, F. R. E. CORNELL; State Treasurer, EMIL, MUNCH; State Auditor, CHAS. MCILRATH; Clerk of the Court, SHERWOOD HOUGH.

The new German Hospital, on the corner of Fourth-avenue and Seventy-seventh-street, a description of which has already been published in the TIMES, was formally opened yesterday for the reception of patients. At 3 o'clock in the afternoon about fifty ladies and gentlemen assembled in the dormitory of the first floor, and, after inspecting the building, they were addressed by Ex-Mayor GUNTHER, President of the Board of Directors, and Dr. KRACKOWIZER, Chief Surgeon.

Early on Sunday morning six one-story brick stores on Mariettastreet, and the large building known as the Norcross Corner, on the corner of Marietta and Peach-tree streets, were destroyed by fire. The loss is estimated at over $100,000; insurance, $560,000.

On Sunday morning about 3 o'clock, a man was assaulted and rebbed in Puntila-street, Jamaica, by two colored men, who stabbed him, nearly cutting his check off. The cry of "murder" was several times heard by ALBERT WILKINSON and brother, and GILBERT CREED, who armed themselves and proceeded in the direction whence the sound came.

The report of Admiral HOFF, in relation to what he terms the massacre of two Americans at Santiago de Cuba some time since and referred to in our telegrams from Washington, was, we have some reason to believe, the basis of the representations recently made to the Spanish Government by Minister SICKLES, of which erroneous accounts have transpired.

Between two of the highest of the Adirondack Mountains, at the bottom of a crevice thousand feet or more in depth, precipice walled and gloomy, has Avalanche Lake. Though thus sunken between Mounts McIntyre and Colden, (incorrectly known as Mount McMartin,) this lake is the most elevated of any waters in our State, probably higher than any lake cast of the Pacific ranges- 2,900 feet its surface is above tide level.

A correspondent who feels as though the Spaniards needed light to guide them out of their difficulties, sends us a paper setting forth the reasons why Count OTHO VON BISMARCK should be preferred to any of the names yet mentioned to wear the crown of Spain. The substance of his article is contained in the closing paragraph:

A special meeting of the Board of Health was held yesterday afternoon, President LINCOLN in the chair, to hear counsel on behalf of the "New-York Rendering Company," who claim exemption from the ordinance passed by the Board a few weeks ago directing fat-boiling establishments below One Hundred and Tenth-street to cease operations after the 1st proximo.

During the last two weeks we have seen one war begun, another ended and a third progressing. The one ended was in Banda Oriental, (Uruguay,) where a few restless men--by many believed to have been hired for the purpose--gathered a few hundreds of reckless fellow and declared war on the Government.

The arrival of the steamer City of Antwerp, with Messrs. LORING, FAY, BLAIKE and ELLIOTT on board, was confidently expected yesterday by their numerous friends. The vessel did not make her appearance, however, causing general disappointment. Numerous anxious inquiries in regard to the steamer were made during the day at the United States Barge office and at the Ship News office, but the invariable reply was "Not yet reported," in every instance.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have just heard through what I believe to be a credible source, that the United States sloop-of-war Albany arrived at the Lower Quarantine on the 16th of August last from Key West with no sickness on board, with the exception of a few cases of non-contagious complaints;

The dissensions which have broken out along the leaders of the Democratic Party are at least likely to furnish important contributions to the political history of the last few years. The gentlemen who have been intrusted with the secrets of management have taken to quarreling among each other, and the result is that some unlooked-for disclosures are being made.

The Board of Assistant aldermen met at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday, Mr. MONAGHAN in the Chair. Mr. PINCKNEY offered a resolution directing the Comptroller to furnish copies of all hills for work done on the Manual of 1868. It was referred to the Committee on Finance.

Captain Wm. TEWKSBURY, a well-known pilot, died yesterday of injuries received by a fall, a few days since, while repairing his house. The Boston fishing schooner Star of the Sea, with a crow of eight men, has not, been heard from since the sale on Wednesday, when she was in the bay fishing.

The application for the last will and testament of the late Dr. CARLTON GATES, of Yonkers, to be admitted to probate, came up before Hon. J. W. MILLS, Surrogate of Westchester County, yesterday. WM. ROMER, Esq., appeared as counsel for the legatees, and REUBEN W. VAN PELT, GEO. NORRIS AND THOMAS CAREY, Esqs., for Dr. W. GATES and Mrs. MARTHA GATES, parents of the deceased testator.

At length the Brooklyn Fire Department is about to go into active operation. Today the commissioners will issue a statement to the public, in which they will review the obstacles they have had to encounter. They set forth that among the obstacles there were the dilapidated condition of the old building and the worthlessness of the apparatus.

The preparations for the celebration of the centenary of the birth of HUMBOLDT, in this City today, have been completed on a grand scale. The following is tile official programme: Tile Executive Committee will meet at 10 o'clock A. M. at tile Committee Rooms, in the Liederkranz Building, Nos. 31 to 35 East Fourthstreet, to receive the invited guests. THE PROCESSION.

Prince ARTHUR and suite arrived here at 5:45 o'clock this afternoon, having ridden in carriages tile entire distance from Fredericton, 255 miles, in less than thirty-five hours, running time. A special relay of horses was provided in advance along the whole line. The roads were in a wretched condition, owing to recent rains.

The following is the will of the late HENRY KEEP, who left property worth about $1,000,000: I, HENRY KEEP, of the City of New-York, do hereby make, publish and declare this my last will and testament, in manner and form as follows: First--I order and direct that all my just debts and funeral expenses be paid as soon after my decease as can conveniently her done.

The dying establishment of A. DUMONT, at No. 850 Broadway, was damaged by fire yesterday morning to the amount of $250; insured. The fire was caused by some clothing which had been cleaned with benzine, and caught fire. The restaurant of PETER MINCK, at No. 102 West-street, was damaged to the extent of $100, some woodwork in the kitchen having caught fire from the furnace.

Recorder POPE held an examination in Hoboken, yesterday, in the case of JAMES HASTINGS, of No. 16G Mulberry-street, New-York, who is charged with shooting a young man, named HERMAN PARADISE, in a shooting gallery.

BLEECKER.--On Sunday, Sept, 12, in the 14th year of her age. ANTONIA, youngest daughter of Anthony L. Bleecker. The friends of the family, and of her grandfather Anthony J. Bleecker, are invited to attend the funeral at Trimty Church, on Tuesday, the 14th inst., at 2 P.M. CONOVER.--On Saturday, Sept. 11, at South Amboy. N. J., Mrs. CATHARINE S. CONOVER, of this City, in the 83d year of her age.

Among the curious phenomena of our climate none is so incredible and so mysterious as the rising of the springs in the very time when al theory would prove that our driest time should be just setting m for a long continuance. Yet, every where, are our long term of drought from dearth of rain has reached within sixty days of its termination, the springs,

An announcement in Thursday morning's issue prepared the public for an event, which, from the declining health of the venerable statesman for more than two years past, might have been expected at any time. A dispatch from Cumberland Iron Works, shortly after noon yesterday, brought intelligence that JOHN BELL died at 2 o' clock A. M. on that day.

A new theory accounting for the brettice in the Avondale shaft being fired so near the top has been advanced by J. W. HARDEN, mining engineer of Wilkesbarre, In a letter to be published in the Scranton Republican.

In connection with the recent refusal of Governor HOFFMAN to become a party to the alleged movement to defeat the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment, allusion to which was made in the TIMES a few days since, the following facts should be stated:

Coroner FLYNN made some progress yesterday in the case of JOHN HESS, who was fatally beaten on head on the 2d inst. with a stone by an unknown person. LUDWIG REULINGS, of No. 354 West Fifty-fourth-street, testified that he and deceased, on the day of the assault, had been drinking together a good deal.

Official Order Appointing a Governor and Lieutenant-Governor. The following was issued on Saturday: HEADQUARTERS FIRST MILITARY DISTRICT, STATE OF VIRGINIA, RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 10, 1869. SPECIAL ORDERS No. 194.--[Extract.]--4. The following appoitments to civil offices in the State of Virginia, Sept. 9. 1869, are hereby announced for the information of all concerned:
The State Fair closed yesterday, and Its success financially was complete. The Western Union and Atlantic and Pacific States Telegraph Companies have consolidated.

To-day Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER open the Fall season with their great sale at Shippan Point. The property has already been fully described in this column. It is worthy the attention of all interested in suburban sales. The terms are liberal, and the property the finest yet offered at public auction.

There must be some means adopted, with all possible promptitude, for inquiring into the management of our Lunatic Asylums, and the agencies by which persons are there incarcerated. Within the past year a very considerable number of cases have come to light in this City and vicinity, in which perfectly sane individuals had been confined, under false pretexts, in these asylums.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I was present last evening at the Cooper Institute to hear and see what CLAIR R. DEEVERE had to say and do in the matter of the spirits of the "mighty dead." The report yon publish this morning is crroneous when it avers that "the hall was almost filled." for the hall was not one-third full;

TUESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Plymouth, Cherbourg and Hamburg, by the Holsatia, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of 3d-st., Hoboken, to 1:15 P. M. WEDNESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the China, close at the General Post Office at 6:30 A. M. No supplementary mails.

At last the Brooklyn City Gas Light Company have laid gas pipes and erected lamps on both sides of the new extension over the Wallabout, from Flushing-avenue to the foot of Clymer-street, and on Saturday night they were lighted.

The tempest yesterday prostrated the telegraph wires, and communication in every direction was temporarily interrupted. The Emperor's health is bettor to-day. It is asserted that the Empress will set out again on her voyage to the East.

The returns come in slowly, and no aggregate has yet been made up. The vote in Portland is: Chamberlain, Republican, 1,799; Smith, Democrat, 829; Hichborn, Independent Temperance, 140. Chamberlain's majority, 830, Total vote, 2,768. Last year Chamberlain received 3,330 votes; Pillsbury, 2,314, Chamberlain's majority, 1,010.

Mr. SEWARD has given us, in the speech which appeared in yesterday's TIMES, the most intelligible notion of Alaska that has yet fallen under our eye, and we confess we rose from its perusal with a better conceit of our Russian investment than we ever had before.
The great Council of the Improved Order of Red Men will hold their annual session here to-morrow. Representatives will be present from Ohio, Pennsylvania, District of Columbia, Michigan, Tennessee,

General PRIM is in this city. While at Vichy he had a conference with the Spanish Ambassadors to England and France on the subject of communications received from Washington. It is rumored that the disposition of the people of the United States to interfere in the affairs of Cuba was denounced as an act of ingratitude to Spain, and the hope was expressed that Spain would reply energetically to the officious manifestations of the Americans.

The Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association is to have a new building. People who imagine that Brooklyn is a small, one-horse town, a mere adjunct of the City of New-York, containing no progressive men and little aggressive spirit, know very little about it; in fact, cannot have seen it. It is, indeed, what it is called, "the City of Churches," and is becoming mere so every day.

The East Side Association are about to erect, on the southeasterly corner of Third-avenue and Eighty-sixth-street, a large building, which will add greatly to the improvements now going on in the upper section of the City, east of Broadway.

The State Fair opens here to-morrow. The total number of entries are about 2,100. The display of stock is very tine. Many new and valuable agricultural implements are on the ground. All the officers of the Society are present. The indications are that the attendance will be very largo.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner FLYNN, in the case of JOSEPH FRIEDLANDER, the German who died a few days ago at No. 209 Third-Street, from the effects of an assault on the 17th ult. The following is an abstract of the testimony:

A new cable enterprise, under the Limited Liabilities act of Great Britain, is soon to place New-York in telegraphic communication with Aspinwall and Panama, with nearly all the West India Islands and with the Spanish Main.

"PATRIE" AT THE GRAND OPERA HOUSE. M. SARDOU'S drama of "Patric," which met with great respect at the hands of the scenic artists, and with much ill-treated at the hands of the actors at the Grand Opera House, some months ago, was reproduced at that theatre last evening. Brilliant scenery and costumes appeal, however, but to the eye, and until now no deeper impression has been made by any of the representations of the work.

The examination into the case of SHEBIDAN SHOOK, H. S. MATTESON, J. P. AHRAHAMS and W. E. BOARDMAN, charged with having exbezzied public moneys while acting as officers of internal Revenue in the Thirty-second Collection District, was commenced before United States Commissioner WHITE, yesterday afternoon.

The custom tailors are hard at work organizing shops for the benefit of their poorlypaid brethren, and the success which has hitherto attended their efforts induces them to believe that every shop in Now-York will be fully organized before Winter. Last night a meeting was held at No. 183 Varick-street.

Two weeks ago to-day the Active arrived. It was about 3:30 o'clock in the afternoon, and the fact was at once heralded that Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD and party were on board. In a few minutes boats were putting off from the shore, with officers and citizens to welcome our distinguished visitor to the land forever to be associated with his name.

The Daily News contains another letter from WILLIAM HOWITT on the charges against Lord BYRON. He says Lady BYRON had condemned herself by the breach of an honorable silence. Irreparable wrong was done BYRON by the destruction of the papers containing his justification of the case, and a solution of the question is impossible, except on defective ?? parte evidence.

The mechanics employed in the shops of the Central Railroad Company went on an excursion to Saratoga today. It was the largest affair of the kind ever gotten up here; the party filled thirty-five cars- Captain SHAW, of the London Fire Brigade, is in the city inspecting the fire apparatus and telegraph alarm.

"The world forgetting, by the world forgot." Some little time age, a member of the British House of Commons arrived in this City, with a letter of introduction to a gentleman then residing here. He delivered his letter, was afterward vaguely of as being Ill some where on the Hudson, and then suddenly disappeared His friends in England made inquiries after him but could gain no satisfactory tidings.

The funeral services of our lamented Senator, WILLIAM PITT FESSENDEN, were largely attended to-day at tile First Parish Church. The United States offices were all closed, as also those of the City Government and the Courts. The flags in the city and upon the shipping were placed at half-mast.

It is perhaps prematurely rumored that the authorities of the City of New-York intend sending to the London Exhibition of 1873 a series of models and diagrams illustrating the more important peculiarities of our metropolitan works and their maintenance and management.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: As the solicitors of the descendants and representatives of the late Lady NOEL BYRON, for whose family we have acted for upward of half a century, we request your permission to publish in the columns of the Times the following observations relative to an article which has just appeared in Macmillan's Magazine.

The centennial of the birth of the great man of science, whose fame no nation can claim, but whose memory our more demonstrative German fellow-citizens are naturally foremost in publicly honoring, was celebrated in this City yesterday by a grand procession in the morning. followed by the unvailing of the statue of HUMBOLDT at the Central Park, with appropriate ceremonies, in the afternoon, and by a torchlight procession and dinner in the evening.

On the 10th inst. Mr. CHARLES BRANDIS, of No. 1 Catharine-street, entered a gambling-house in the Bowery, and there lost the sum of $65 at a game of cards. Her then turned to leave the place, but was intercepted by JACOB W. HERMAN and IRA E. BRIDE, who exhibited pistols, and declared that Mr. BRANDIS should not go until he had surrendered all the money and valuables he might have in his possession.
The Prussian Government has taken very active measures for the enforcement of the law of military service upon the inhabitants of the territories lately acquired by Prussia.
The Fall season may be now considered as fairly opened. Yesterday, a particularly bright and auspiclous day, three large sales were male, and the result in each instance were very gratitying.

The Fall tortting meeting of the Prospect Park Fair Grounds Association commenced yesterday, and will be continued over Thursday and Saturday. The day was fine and pleasant, but the attendance was comparatively small, considering the liberal amount of money given by the Association to be trolled for.

SEPT. 14--In steamship Holsalia, for Hamburg,--L. C. Clark, wife, child and servant, Mrs. S. B. Clark, Miss Blanche Mevins, Edward Scheitlin, Edward Mertens, Emil Grisar and lady, Ad. Heyl, Alex. Mayer, Mrs. Bagaley, children and servant, Miss Josephine Campbell, H. J. Bang, Sr., and lady, Dewitt C. Sprague, S. H. Kimball, Miss Clara Kimball, Miss D. H. Wallace, Ernest Bartholdy,...

It would seem from an article which we quote from the Atlas, one of the favorite Tanimany prints, that Mr. TWEED'S friends have determined to change their base of opeartions: to abandon the campaign against BELMONT, which could come to nothing, and direct their batteries against the Democrats in the rural districts. who stand behind him.

Captain RUSSELL, of the whaling bark Thomas Winslow, reports that at 5 A. M. on the 8th of September he was compelled to lay to in a hurricane in latitude 38[degrees] 50', longitude 71[degrees] 40', 150 miles cast from Cape May. At 10 A. M., the wind blowing a complete hurricane, in a sudden gust the ship was thrown on her beam ends, with the mastheads under.

Since Saturday last the numerous friends and admirers of the Harvard crew have been eagerly looking for theo arrival of the Inman steamer City of Antwerp, having on board a portion of the gallant and famous crew.

A large meeting of sympathizers with the Fenian prisoners was held at Dundalk, Ireland, on Monday. Twenty thousand people,, it is estimated, were present. The reported proposal of Minister SICKLES to recognize the insurgents as belligerents, it is said, created much alarm, an sent the funds down to the lowest point they had touched for sixteen years.

The New York Society of Practical Engineering will meet this exiting in room no 24 cooper Institute Building. A carefuly prepared paper on water mater will be read, containing it is believed considerable information. new and of interest to the people. Inventors of water meters are invited to be present and exhibits their meters.

The $800,000 robbery of the Merchants' Union Express Company was again the subject of judicial examination yesterday, in the Supreme Court, before Judge CLARE. CONKLIN was found in the car bound and gagged, and the money gone.

The Board of Health listened yesterday to the conclusion of the argument on the question of exemption the "New-York Rendering Company" from the ordinance prohibiting all fat-boiling in the City below One Hundred and Tenth-street after Oct. 1 prox.

Among the spectators were prominent players from ill parts of the country, and quite a number from Canada, the noted ones from beyond the St. Lawrence being CYRILLE and FRANK DION.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11.-An excursion party from Cincinnati arrived here last night. Vice-president COLFAX reached Salem. Oregon, yesterday, en route to Callforina. He received a most enthusiastle reception. The San Pedro and Los Angeios Railroad is cotnpleted.

SEASON OF CONCERTS. The first concert of the season occurred at Steinway Hall last evening, and was quite numerously attended. About a dozen artistes, most of them favorably known to the general public, took part in it.
The Czar has recently taken a step of very great importance, in issuing an ukase abolishing the hereditary character of the Russian priesthood, which is a caste, comprising 700,000 families.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. H.--Last evening, about 10 o'clock, a watchman discovered three gangs of men, numbering in all about ninety, making for the wharves. In reply to questions they told the watchman that a Spanish steamer was to meet them and take them to sea, but did not state their destination.

JOHN C. JOHNSTON, aged 17, residing at No, 16 Essex-street, a clerk in the employ of Messrs. DAVIS RIKER, at No. 84 John-street, was arraigned before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs, yesterday, to answer a charge of having, on the 21st hit., embezzled $50, which he had on that day collected from JOSEPH WOLF, clerk in the American Agricultural Works, corner of Twenty-fourth-street and Tenth-avenue.

From sunset yesterday until the same hour to-day is observed among our Jewish follow-citizens as a most solemn fast, being "the Day of Atonement," the origin and institution of which may be found in Leviticus, where it is commanded that" an atonement shall be made for all the children of Israel from all their sins once a year."

LONDON, Sept. 14.--A heavy storm prevailed yesterday, not only throughout England, but on the Continent. Telegraph wires are or have been prostrated in every direction, and reports of marine disasters are constantly being received. The regular cable route to Valentia, Ireland, has been deranged, and messages to and from America were forwarded by way of Dublin.

Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the China, close at the General Post Office at 6:30 A. M. No supplementary mail. THURSDAY. Mails for Havana and West Indies, via Nassau, N. P., by the Columbia, close at 2 P. M.

SCRANTON, Penn. Sept. 14.--An adjourned session of the inquest began this morning at 10 o'clock. Even fewer persons were in attendance than on Saturday, there being never more than 100 in the hall. The miner were represented by E. L. MERRIMAN, and the Company by A. McCLINTOCK, and the examination was conducted exclusively by them.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--The Parisians are persuaded that the Emperor is recovering, although a marked alteration in his appearance is observable. There is great anxiety in regard to the Regency. By law the Empress is Regent during the minority of her son.

Captain ERICSSON desires us to remind the Detroit Post that his communication to the National Academy of Sciences related only to solar heat. Our contemporary has a apparently overlooked the very title of Captain ERICSSON'S essay, which is, Constancy of Rotation of The Earth Incompatible with Solar Influence.

The first term of the collegiate year of this College will commence to-day. The number of students is between 600 and 700, No change has been made in the course of study, the attempt to abolish the classics having failed, no member of the Board of Education voting for it except Commissioner SANDS. The new President of the College General ALEX. S. WEBB, will enter upon the discharge of his duties to-day.

LONDON, Eng., Sept. 14.--Mr. WASHBURNE, formerly United States Minister to Paraguay, has written a communication to one of the London journals on President LOPEZ, of Paraguay. He says his opinions have undergone no change.

There was a time when the name of GEORGE HUDSON at the head of a prospectus was sufficeent to make the fortune of a new company. He held leveas in Englan as if he had been a Prince of the blood Royal. Crowds of people waited outside his doors in the hope of winning his attention.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13.--A party, vouched for as reliable, writes to the Bulletin from San Buenaventura, that a document had been found on the beach at that place on the 30 of August, very badly mutilated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--The recent statement giving the receipts and expenditures of the Government for the past fiscal year, as shown by the books of the United States Treasurer, is confusing and unmeaning, unless explained by the further statement that the Treasure's figures include the entire workings of the Treasury, payments and repayments, the issue and redemption of all loans and the various classes of currency,

From the Atlas, (Organ of Mayor Hall.) THE BONE AND SINEW IN COUNCIL. The State Convention will meet in Syracuse just ten days from to-day, when, I suppose, the Democracy of the State will be fully represented by its leading men as well as by a goodly array of the bone and sinew, who carry out the views and programmes of those astute politicians.
Mr. SEWARD, during his stay in Alaska, visited many places of interest, of which he has given an account are extremely picturesque, and he is quite enthusiastic about the future of the country.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The State Fair has opened under the most favorable circumstances. The weather is delightful--a clear sky, bright sunshine and a fresh breeze to temper it. The booths are not yet complete. Those for the reception of manufactured articles progresses rapidly, and by tomorrow all will be in order.

The following telegram appeared in the Ecening Post on Tuesday: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.-A recent letter front Minister MOTLEY expresses dissatisfaction at the policy which he is instructed to pursue in regard to the Alabama claims.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 15.--A special from Little Rock, Ark., says the Republican members of the Legislature held a meeting, at which resolutions were adopted for the formation of a Liberal Republican Party, on the basis of universal suffrage and universal amnesty. A committee was appointed to solicit subscriptions and take other measures for the completion of the organization.

We have received the following communication: To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article in this morning's paper under the caption of "The Hell Gate Job," merits some attention from me as a citizen of New-York, feeling an interest that very naturally inspires an autochthon in the place of his nativity.

The verdicts of Coroners' juries very seldom combine justice and common sense in any remarkable degree, and we are sorry to say that the jury at Avondale will have not departed from the usual form. We give at length to-day an English version of Prince NAPOLEON'S recent speech in the Frency Senate on the Senatus Consultum. WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--Some time since A. J. APPELLATE, Lieutenant-Governor of Alabama, was appointed a Storekeeper in the Mobile Custom-house. Some objection being made to his holding both positions, he submitted the case to the Secretary of the Treasury, together with a statement of his reasons for wishing to retain the Government appointment.

An examination was held yesterday by Justice DOWLING at the Tombs in the case of PIERCE BUTLER, who was arrested yesterday. accused of complicity in the larceny of ten $1,000 United States Five-twenty Bonds from the office of ALFRED COLVILLE, at No. 50 Wall-street. The Cunard steamship Jara, which left Liverpool Sept. 4, and Queenstown Sept. 5, reached her dock in this City at an early hour yesterday morning. Her adviees are later by two days ?? those at hand by the City of Antwerp.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 15.--Ex-Lieutenant Governor SANFORD E. CHURCH is lying dangerously ill of pleurisy at his residence in this city. ROCHESTER, Sept. 15--Evening.--The physicians have just held a consultation in Governor CHURCH'S case. His condition has not changed since noon. To-night will be the critical period.

Yesterday was a quiet day. The sales of the previous day were very large, and it is best always after so busy a day, to take one of rest; accordingly yesterday nothing was offered. The auctioneers were busy closing up the sales already made, and preparing for others yet to come.

Dr. HARRIS, Sanitary superintendent, yesterday afternoon submitted to the Board of Health the monthly report of tests made at the laboratory of the quality of kerosene and burning fluid sold in different parts of the City. The Superintendent called attention to the fact that out of forty samples tested, ghteen were far below the required tests;

BASLE, Sept. 15.-The International Workingmen's Congress convened in this city yesterday. A large number of delegates are present. Congratulatory letters and dispatches from all parts of Europe and North America ave been received. A letter from the German workmen of New-York City, regretting their inability to send a delegate, and a communication from the National Labor Union of the United States, were read.

A Boston paper has a report from Washington that the Chinese Mission has been tendered to Ex-Governor MORGAN, of this State. Hon. GERSHOM B. WESTON, a prominent Massachusetts Republican, died in Duxbury on Monday, aged 70 years. He had repeatedly represented his town in the Legislature, and was a member of the last Senate.

The Glenham Hotel on Fifth-avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets, which is to be thrown open to the public tomorrow, has been elegantly fitted up. While it makes no pretensions to an elaborate exterior, the interior is unusually attractive and convenient. The building is six stories high, which basement, and contains 110 rooms.

MADRID, Sept. 15.--The journals of this city assert that the Government recently sent a circular letter to the Great Powers of Europe, respecting the note from Mr. SICKLES, the American Minister, on the subject of the recognition of Cuba, and that replies favorable to the rights of Spain have been received from England, France and Austria.

PARIS, Sept . 15.--Advices have been received from Paraguay to the 9th of August via Rio Janeiro. The Provisional Government had been established at Asuncion. It consisted of three members--M. M. REDUYA, SURAGA and VIVERELA. The Allies had commenced active operations. The Count D'EU had carried two Paraguayan fortifications and occupied Velenzuela.

Everybody remembers the tourists famous chapter on "The Snakes in Ireland," which consisted of a single sentence. "There are no snakes in Ireland." It is rather a sad application of the familiar jest to write, as we are obliged to do, under the head of "Shipbuilding in New-York." that at this moment but one new vessel is on the stocks in our great ship-yards.

The Board of Education met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, R. L. LARREMORE, President, in the chair. A number of nominations were received for teacherships in the evening schools of the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, Eighth, Eleventh, Twelfth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth,

The attendance on the fair-green has greatly increased since the forenoon. Stock owners and their pretty wives and daughters throng around the track anxious to see the performances of their favorites. The entries are numerous and well filled up. The gross number of horses entered is 211, divided into twenty-one classes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15--The Ecclesiastical Court, summoned for the trial of Rev. Mr. CHENEY. met at 2 o'clock, pursuant to adjournment, and at the suggestion of the Bishop adjourned till the 16th of November. The Iowa and Wisconsin State Fairs opened yesterday, but owing to the unpropitious state of the weather the attendance has not been very large. The entries at both fairs are greatly in excess of any former year.

The accounts we published yesterday of the celebration of the Humboldt centenary in all the principal cities of the country, as well as in other parts of the world, gave evidence not only of the fame acquired by the leading German savan of the century, but of the honorable appreciation of his labors in the cause of science.

A large meeting of those directly interested in cotton was held at Manchester on Tuesday evening. Among the resolutions adopted was one proposing to form an association to bring to the notice of Parliament the depressed state of capital and labor. The system of American imports and English exports was condemned.

The shipbuilding interest, once so flourishing in this city, when New-York was famous for turning out ships of superior model and speed, is now almost ruined. Our great shipyards, formerly the scene of bustle and industry. are now almost deserted, or are devoted to other purposes.

BOSTON, Sept. 15.--Twenty-six alleged Cuban Fillibusters, including GEORGE BROWN and HENRY HART, the leaders, were brought from New-Bedford to-day, and arranged before United States Commissioner HALLETT, charged with being engaged in a military expedition against Spain.

LONDON, Sept. 15.-The leading event at Doncaster to-day was the race for the St. Leger Stakes. Pretender was the favorite, the betting on him being oven at the start; but the race was won, after a close and exciting contest, by Pero Gomez, by a neck, Martyrdom second by threequarters of a length, and George Osbaldeston third-the latter beating Pretender, who was fourth, half a length. A Correspondent call attention to the danger of allowing carts of any kind on the principal drives in the Central Park, during the hours of the day when the roads are crowded with vehicles. One of the Park carts, crossing directly in front of a phaeton in which two ladies were driving, on Monday, caused an accident that might been a very serious one.

In pursuance of adjournment, the hearing on the writ of habeus corpus, issued in the case of HENRY FROTHINGHAM, detained in the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum as an alleged lunatic, came up before Judge MCCUNN, in the Superior Court, yesterday.

DUBLIN, Sept. 16.--The Synod has decided against the admission of ex-office members to future conventions. The Archbishop of Armagh died to-day, aged 68. TREYNE, a bailiff, was shot dead at Abbey lery to-day. The culprit, it is supposed, was a Fenian.

The Anti-Slarery Standard thinks there are many things requiring the President's attention, but that President GRANT "recreates excessively." "Rational recreation," it says, "in itself is good and sometimes very important. If he absolutely needs, and is likely to continue to need so much, he ought, in the present condition of affairs, to resign, that the country may have what it very much needs, a President in fact as well as in name.

PARIS, Sept. 16.--The Ganlois to-day states that the majority of the Prince Imperial will be announced for his next birth-day. March 16. The regular weekly statement of the Bank of France shows that the bullion has decreased 4,000,000 francs since last Thursday.

PARIS, Sep. 16.--Le Public reports that at the recent interview with General PRIM the Emperor renewed his declaration of absolute nonintervention in the affairs of Spain, and declined to accede to the request that France should make representations request that recognition of the Cuban insurgents as belligerents by the United States.

WILLIAM WILSON, HENRY WONDER, FELIX SANCHAS, (the murderer,) EUGENE RUSSELL, JAMES MURRAY AND HENRY SMITH were yesterday brought to this City from Sing Prison. Where they were confined. These men are pronounced confirmed lunatics, and having renamed in the State Lunatic Asylum for the period of their sentence, they were transferred to this county for disposition. ion.

Last Tuesday evening Detective MOORE arrested a young woman named SARAH MURRAY, employed as domestic in the boarding-house of Mrs. CAROLINE VILLEVERDE, No. 118 West Twenty-third-street, on suspicion of having stolen $1,000 worth of diamonds from her mistress.

The ball match yesterday between the Athleties of Philadelphia and the Champion Eckfords, resulted disastrously to the former. Three or four thousand Spectators assembled on the grounds, but were disappointed in their expectations of seeing an exciting and hotly-contested game.

The examination into the criminal charges recently made against SHERIDAN SHOOK, H. B. MATTESON, J. P. ALEXANDER and W. H. BOARDMAN, ex-officers of Internal Revenue of the Thirty-second Collection District, was resumed yesterday afternoon. WILLIAM H. ROGERS, receiving ?? of the Nassan Bank, was called as a witness for the prosecution.

The annual book trade-sale commenced at the salesrooms of LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co., Clinton Hall, yesterday at 9 A. M. The catalogue contained consignments from most of the principal publishing houses in the country. The bidding, as compared with last year, is considered higher and better in every way. Yet most of the works sold at less than half the retail prices set opposite to them in the catalogue. .

A regular meeting of the Union Republican General Committee (Twenty-Third-street) was held at their headquarters last evening, to hear the report of the Executive Committee on the time and places for holding the primary meetings for the election of delegates to the State Convention.

The response of the country in the appeal for the Avondale sufferers is as generous as universal. From all quarters money is pouring in, and we are told that from present appearances it is probable that the sum of $250.000 will be raised and forwarded within a month.

At an early hour yesterday afternoon Officer STROMBERG, of the Tenth Ward, was suddenly summoned by the occupants of the premises No. 30 Rivington-street, who implored him to see what was going on in the cellar. The patrol-man passed through the lager-beer saloon on the first floor, and groping his way down the kitchen stairs, saw smoke issuing from a dark store-room.

Now that PETER B. SWEENEY has returned from his European trip, the movements of the Municipal "Ring" will assume an importance and a decisiveness that they did not and could not possess during the absence of the great chief of that patriotie triumvirate whose decrees control the political destinies of this Metropolis.
