To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed with a great deal of pleasure an article which appeared a few days since in your paper, in reference to madhouses and the manner in which they were conducted.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 16,--The house of HENRY WILLETTS, on Limburg-street, was entered last night by burglars. Mr. WILLETTS' wife being aroused by the noise, called her husband, who sprang out of bed, and ran against the burglar and threw him. when he drew a knife and stabbed Mr. WILLETTS six times, killing him instantly.

While SAMUEL. ABRAHALL was driving a horse attached to a coupe down Broadway, about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the bolt fastering the whiffletree to the carriage came out, frightcning the animal, which dashed off at a rapid rate. After proceeding a short distance the cariage ran into a lamp post and was somewhat damaged, and the horse, breaking loose from the vehicle, ran upon the walk, throwing: down and severly injuring several persons.

The Police Commissioners met yesterday, but did little business, excepting the resignation of Sergeant JAMES C. PELL, of the City Hall Police, to take effect on Nov. 1. Sergeant PELL has been connected with the Police force for twenty-four years, and is a most excellent officer.

BRENTANO has just received from London a large supply of the last number of the Illustrated London News, containing full-page Illustrations of the great international boat race on the Thames, in which the Harvard boy showed so much pluck but lost the prize. The scenes represented are the start at Putney, and the finish at Mortlake.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16.--The Mexican residents to-day celebrated the fifty-ninth anniversary of the independence of Mexico. Salutes were fired from Fort Alcatraz and Mare Island Navy-yard. The national flag of Mexico was displayed beside that of the United States.

The British Colonist, published at Victoria, in its issue of Aug. 28, gives a full report of a banquet given to Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD by the prominent citizens of the place. Chief Justice NEEDHAM presided, and in proposing the health of their guest, delivered an eloquent address. Mr. SEWARD, in rising to respond, was received with load applause.

Interesting announcements are made by several local places of amusement. At the French Theatre, where the season of English Opera is progressing prosperously. "The Bohemian Girl" will be submitted for "The Purtan's Daughter" this evening, Mma. PAREPAROSA singing Arline, and Mr. NORDBLOM, a new tenor, effecting his debut in the latter work.

BRUSH--COOK.--On Wednesday. Sept. 15, by Rev. Win. H. Brush, JOSHUA M. BRUSH to NAME M. COOK, all of this City. BUCKNALL--ACKERMAN.--On Thursday, Sept. 16, at the Madison-square Presbyterian Church, by Rev. Wm. Adams, D. D., SAMUEL R. BUCKNALL, of this City, to JEANIE C., daughter of the late Jonathan C. Ackerman, of New-Brunswick, N. J. No cards.

The world is naturally somewhat chagrined at the termination of its little plan for nullifying the vote of this State on the Fifteenth Amendment, and so vents its spleen upon the Secretary of State, or rather upon the Assistant Secretary DAVIS, as the instrument of its disappointment.

With the present fruit season the auisance of sidewalk peddling has become greater than ever. The permanent peanut and popcorn venders who occupy a great part of the City sidewalks all the year round, are now reinforced by a largo body of fruit dealers who establish themselves with great complacency, not to say impudence, in the very localities where travel is most crowded and space is most demanded.

The people of Buffalo celebrated the centennial anniversary of the birth of HUMBOLDT by a meeting on Tuesday evening, at which Hon. MILLARD, FILLMORE presided. Mr. FILLMORE presided. Mr. FILLMORE opened the meeting with a brief statement of his interview with HUMBOLDT, his remarks being as follows:

JOHN McGUCKEN and ROBERT GOLDEN were arrested yesterday morning on the charge of having set fire to the house of Hose Company No. 1, at the intersection of North Second and Sixth streets, Williamsburg.

Messrs. A. D. MELLICK, Jr., BROTHER had a large and very successful sale yesterday at Bergen Point, N. J. The train started promptly at 12:15, and twenty-five minutes afterward landed its passengers at their place of destination. A ten minutes' walk brought the party to the place of sale, where a fine lunch was served, which, as usual, received full attention.

At a regular meeting of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday, Mrs. E. HERBERT was appointed Matron of the Idiot Hospital at a salary of $500 a year. A resolution was adopted, requesting A. P. BUTLER to examine the duration and residence in the county and pecuniary condition of each patient committed to the Lunatic Hospital, and the condition of their immediate relatives, and to report to Mr. KELLOCK.

The event of the week is the ultra-liberal speech delivered by Prince NAPOLEON in the Senate on Wednesday last. It has fallen like a bomb-shell in the ranks of those who would seek to make the reforms embraced in the Senatus Consultum final. The senation created by it has absorbed for the moment the interest attaching to all other political topics.

The meeting held in Manchester, England, on Wednesday evening, to consider the depressed condition of trade in Lancashire, is deemed of sufficient importance to be the subject of a cable telegram. Resolutions were passed urging public meetings in the principal towns of England and a Parliamentary inquiry.
SARATOGA, Sept. 16.--A fire occurred this evening in the Clinton House, an old wooden building opposite the Presbyterian Church,

Returns from 331 cities and towns give a total vote of 76,358, as follows: Chamberlain, 41,671; Smith, 30,708; Hichborn, 3,979; Chamberlain's majority over both, 6,979; Chamberlain's majority over both, 6,984. Hichborn's vote will not exceed 4,500 and Chamberlain's majority will be 7,500.

LONDON, Sept. 16.--The Times has an editorial article to-day on the Sickles not to the Spanish Government on the Cuban question, wherein it says: "It was generally believed that President GRANT would not interfere or allow interference in the Cuban question until Congress could vote upon it.

We publish to-day a remarkable narrative from the pen of a gentleman well known in mercantile circles in this City, who has just effected his release from the Lunatic Asylum at Bloomingdale, after an incarceration of three months, during the whole of which time he alleges he was of perfectly sound mind.

The circular of the New-York State and Lake Shore Grape Growers' Associations, announcing their annual Fairs for the exhibition of grapes and wines, have been issued. That under the auspices of the State Association will be held at Canandaigua on Tuesday and Wednesday, Oct. 5 and 6. Dr, JOHN A. WARDER, the distinguished pomologist, of Cincinnati, has been invited to deliver the annual address.

Hon. S. S. COX was serenaded last evening at his residence, No. 13 East Twelfth-street, by his friends, on the occasion of his return from Europe. The procession, preceded by Wallace's Band, arrived about 10 o'clock. "Home Again" was played, and then Mr. Cox, in answer to repeated calls, addressed the meeting.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16.--Santa Fe, New-Mexico, dispatches report a number of depredations by the Indians. Women and children have been murdered, and much stock driven off. Colonel GREEN had returned from his expedition to the White Mountains. He had killed and captured twenty-two Indians, and destroyed several camps and a large amount of property.

During the thirteen working days, from the 1st to the 15th inst., there were 2,012 applications for employment received at the Labor Exchange, of which 1,420 were made by males, and 592 by females. There were 2,151 orders of employers for laborers received, of which 1,520 were for males and 630 for females.

Coroner FLYNN held an inquest yesterday at his office, in the City Hall, in the case of THOS. H. BARRETT, the man who came to his death by a stab wound in the abdomen, inflicted by ELLEN R. UTT, at No. 170 West Broadway, on the 12th inst, as already reported. The following is a brief synopsis of the evidence:

It will be recollected that in May, 1859, the expedition under command of Captain McCLINTOCK, of the Royal Navy, discovered on the western extremity of King William's Island the record which first disclosed to the world the death of SIR JOHN FRANKLIN and his comrades.

In an address at the Humboldt celebration in Utica, Ex-Governor SEYMOUR, after remarking that it was eminently fit that the Germans should take the lead in such a demonstration, continued: "In no part of the United States, however, is this more appropriate than in the Valley of the Mohawk.

Hon. EDWARD RUFUS OLCOTT, who was recently found dead near Elliott City, Md., was a son of MILES OLCOTT, Esq., a prominent lawyer of Hanover. He graduated at Dartmouth College in 1825, was admitted to the bar, and commenced the practice of law in Haverhill. He afterward removed to Lowell, Mass., and from there to Louisiana, where he settled at Minden, Clairborne Parish, and became Circuit Judge.

ITHICA, N. Y., Sept. 16.-The entrance examination of tile Cornell University has been in progress here for the past three days. The numder of candidates has been nearly 400, and the entering class will be about 320, although the standard of admission was raised. The new students show a better state of preparation than last year.

The New-York State Homeopathic Medical Society, which has been holding its two days' semi-annual session at the Cooper Institute, concluded its labors on Wednesday evening. Among other business transacted was the formation of a Committee to raise funds with which to build a monument to the memory of Dr. H. B. GRAMM, the ploneer of homeopathy in this country, whose remains now rest in Green-Wood.

Much excitement and uneasiness has existed among our citizens for some time, owing to the fact being known that the General commanding the Department had received orders to take possession of, and hold for the use of the United States, all property within this Territory, not private individual property at or before thetime of the cession of this Territory to the United States by Russia.

The river piers, both on the East and North Rivers, have long engaged attention on account of their neglected condition. Already, however, many improvements have been made. Pler No. 35, foot of Franklin-street, which was at one time both shaky, dangerous and too narrow, is now being made safer and wider.

On Wednesday afternoon a young colored-man, named LEWIS CARTER, of Jamaica, was descending a well for the purpose of assisting in the removal of a pump, when a stone gave way under his feet, and he fell for some ten feet, finally catching hold of a three-inch beam. The stone-work of the well commenced caving in, followed by the soil, and soon the young man was entirely hidden from the light of the world.

A letter from Liverpool to the State Department at Washington states that contagion called murrain, or hoof and mouth disease, has broken out among cattle in several parts of England. Although not as fatal as the rinderpest, all are called upon to exercise great care to prevent its importation into the United States. Minister BURLINGAME and the Chinese Embassy, it is said, will leave Paris for Stockholm early next week.

ADAMS, CHANDLER Co., of No. 20 John-street, have on exhibition at their store a communion service, designed and manufactured by them expressly for Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER'S congregation in Brooklyn. It consists of two flagons, sixteen chalices and eight plates, all made of pure silver, with gold lining.

"Arkindale," one of the finest estates in Virginia, lying along the Potomac River, in Stafford County, and containing 2,338 acres, was sold by Messrs. TAYLOR, SUTTLE CONWAY, at public auction, in Alexandria, on Friday last. Mrs. A. M. FITZHUGH was the purchaser, at $21 per acre.

ALBANY. Sept. 16.--Some time since a warrant was issued to arrest a man named ADAM COLE, one of the most desperate characters in the country, charging him with an assault with a deadly weapon on a man named SMITH. Today Officer MALONE saw a man in a restaurant whom he thought was COLE, and while asking the proprietor who he was, COLE drew a revolver and rushed out on the street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16.--The delegates of the Pomological Society marched to Independence Hall this morning, and were introduced by T. E. MITCHELL to Mayor Fox, who formally welcomed them to the city in a few appropriate remarks, which were responded to by Hon. MARSHAL P. WILDER, of Boston. Richmond has been selected for the next meeting of the Society in September, 1871.

The little we know of the relative importance of what we do in this world, is a familiar theme for meditation in the closet and of exhortation from those pulpit, but it is a subject which never grows stale; which receives new and striking illustration every day in almost every reflecting man's experience.

BOSTON, Sept. 16.--Messrs. LORING and FAY, of the Harvard boat crew, arrived hero this morning. They speak in warm terms of the hospitalities they received in Now-York. The Boston Committee gave them an elegant banquet on the Fall River boat last night. No public reception will be extended here until the arrival of the remainder of the crew.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16.--Admiral HOFF arrived here last evening for the purpose of conferring with the Navy and State Departments on matters pertaining to his late command. It was only by the enforcement of the strictest sanitary regulations that he was enabled to preserve the health of the crew of even the flagship.

The oration of Professor AGASSIZ upon the character of HUMBOLDT, delivered in Boston yesterday, reminds us of an anccdote never yet put in print. A pompous Mayor of a Western city said to him that he had himself been deeply interested in natural science, but the pressure of business had prevented its pursuit.

The journey across country which Prince ARTHCR started upon last Thursday came to an end to-night. It has been an very pleasant trip, and, although the roads were bad, the long distance has been traveled with dispatch and without accident or delay.

In Jersey City, a few days ago, a well-known citizen was arrested and taken before Justice CHAMBERS, charged with having outraged a servant girl employed in his house. The complaint was made by his wife, who refused to live with him longer on account of his crime. The prisoner was held to bail in $1,000 to appear for examination.

ADAMS,--At Litchfield, Conn., on Monday, Sept. 13, ?? MARIA, wife of Charles Adams. Esq. ARMSTRONG.--On Wednesday, Sept. 15, of consumption. FRANCIS ARMSTRONG, aged 46 years. A true Christian, his end was peaceful. His funeral will take place from the Rose Hill M. E. Church, in 27th-St., on Saturday, 18th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M.

The New-York Oxygen Gas Company gave an interesting exhibition of their new oxygen gaslight at their works in West Forty-first-street near Eleventh-avenue, on Wednesday evening, in the presence of a number of friends and scientific men.

Yesterday was the second day of the Fall trotting meeting on the Prospect Park Fair Grounds' Association Course. Judging by the comparatively small attendance, the public Interest in the trotting contests on this course is sensibly decreasing; there were not over eight hundred people present, although a good programme was presented.

Secretary BOUTWELL arrived here on Wednesday evening from Boston, after a short sojourn in New-England, and took up his quarters at the Actor House. Yesterday he received calls from many prominent gentleman, among whom were General BUTTERFILD. HORACE GREELEY, GLORGE OPDYKE, THOS. E. STEWART, E. S. SANFORD and collector GRINNELLL.

The particulars of the recent attempt to murder Hon. G. W. HOLLISTER, Ex-United States Minister to Hayti, at his residence near Port-au-Prince, are given in a letter received at this port from Port-au-Prince, dated Aug. 9. On the morning of the 8th, Mr. HOLLISTER got into a dispute with a carpenter whom he had engaged to make repairs on his place, and finally struck the workman with a stick.

A serendae to Colonel MANUEL FREYRE, the Peruvian Minister, took place at the Gramercy Park Hotel last evening. Over 1,000 Cubans participated in the affair, assisted by many Americans. It was intended as an expression of gratitude toward and admiration for the Peruvian Republic, the ally and supporter of the Cubans in their struggle against Spain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16.--Arrangements have finally been made for reviving the defunct National Intelligencer by turning the Evening Express of this city into a morning paper, and issuing the sheet under the longitudinal title of Daily National Intelligencer Express.

ROCHESTER, N. Y. Sept. 17.--A serious collision occurred on the Central Railroad, at Lyons, this evening. The 5:30 train from this city ran into the rear end of a stock train, owing to the carelessness of a switchman, destroying the engine and disabling every passenger coach in the train. Several persons were injured, but no fatal casualties are reported.

Hon. FREDERICK A. TALLMADGE, a prominent citizen of this City, died yesterday at the residence of his daughter, at Litchlield, Conn. Mr. TALLMADGE was born at Litchlield, Aug. 29, 1792, and therefore at the time his death had just completed his 77th year.

The rainy weather yesterday prevented the attendance of a large number of visitors at the Fair. The steam machinery is not yet in operation, but it is expected that by Tuesday next everything will be in readiness to apply steam power to the various mechanical inventions that need it for displaying their capacities and modes of operating.

Attention has recently been directed, and not for the first time, to the city and harbor of Brunswick, Ga., as a point of first importance on the Atlantic coast, in view of its new railway connections, since the war, with the interior of Georgia and Alabama.

BOSTON, Sept. 17.--In North Bridgewater, last evening, JAMES ARMSTRONG fired at his father-in-law with a revolver and missed him, but wounded JAMES WELCH, a neighbor. He then fired another shot, killing his own wife. He fled, and at last dates had not been arrested.

The State Engineer and Surveyor's Railroad Report for the year 1868, but just published, abounds in information full of interest and importance. There are fitty-six different railways in operaion n the State, the aggregate longth of which is 3,053.95 unles, and which have been constructed and equipped at a cost of $208,185,782.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17.--The Women's Suffrage Convention, in session here, adopted the Constitution yesterday. The following officers were elected to the State Association: President, Mrs. H. M. TRACY CUTTER; Vice-President, Mrs. M. A. LONGLEY; Recording Secretary, Mrs. H. M. DOWNEY; Corresponding Secretary, Mrs. M. M. COLT; Treasurer, Mrs. L. H. CRALL;

In steamship Magholia, from Savannah.--A. H. McCann, E. B. Mundav, Mrs. Balley, Miss Mary Bailey, Mrs. Mary Rogers, Wm. Bailey, John Bailey, Mr. Starr, G. Coverdale, R. Whitfield, C. Lamb, Mrs. Raymond, Miss Raymond, Master Raymond, E. L. Holcombe, Jno. Savage, Colonel S. Simpkins, J. C. Hoxie, Mrs. Starr and 3 children, W. Ungleworth, J. Hay, S. Savage, P. Thompson.

The Emperor NAPOLEON, it is said, appeared in the streets of Paris Thursday. prince NAPOLEON the same day embarked from Calais in his yacht. The London Morning Standard, in an editorial, yesterday, diseredits the recent-reported San Buenaventura Franklin discovery. The remains of Lady PALMERSTON were interred at Westminster Abbey yesterday.

Having founded the Whig in the Spring of 1839, I have been its chief editor and publisher for term extending through thirty years--first at Elizabethton, next at Jonesboro', and for the last twenty years at Knoxville.

DUBLIN, Sept. 17.-In the Synod of Armagh a resolution excluding the laity from deciding question of doctrine and discipline has been rejected by a large majority. The synod has also rejected a resolution looking to the representation of minorities, and has adjourned until the both last.
ENGLISH OPERA AT THE FRENCH THEATRE. The performance of "The Bohemian Girl" at the French Theatre, last evening, was witnessed by an audience that filled the house in every part.

Time makes sad have with our most cherished illusions. What institution have we in this country more highly and universally respected than the tomato! His old name of love apple shows what a hold it has upon the popular heart. Who can believe this meek, innocent--looking, health--giving fruit, is the nurse of a reptile more venomous than the rattlesnake! Yet such is the report.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--The extensive flour manufactory of SIBLEY PENNYPACKER, corner of Twelfth and Bultonwood streets, was burned this morning. The building was owned by WILLIAM B. THOMAS, whose loss is $20,000; covered by insurance. One of the floors was occupied as an armory by Colonel THOMAS' regiment, and the muskets were all consumed.

The Fair is at its height. Pleasure parties throng the green. At 2 o' clock the horses came on the track, and the sight was one to gratify the most fastidious. The prize animals bore their honors with becoming dignity, and proved the discrimination of the judges.

Tile loss of Messrs. JUDD Co., a portion of whose linseed oil manufactory, at the corner of Cherry and East streets, was destroyed by fire on Thursday night, is as follows: On stock, $100,000; on machinery. $40,000, and on buildings,$40,000. The insurance is as follows: On stock, $170,000,; on machinery, $31,500, and on building, $38,500.

Apollo Hall, at the corner of Twenty-eighth-street and Broadway, has been frescoed and refurnished since last season, and last evening was thrown open to private view. The main hall is 165 feet in length by 60 in breadth, and has an extension 35 feet by 70, which can be used as a supper-room.
LONDON, Sept. 17.-The star Radical organ to-day states that the difficulty between the United states and Spain on the Cuban question is in a fair way of settlement.

QUEBEC, Sept. 17.--Prince ARTHUR, with the members of the Government, yesterday visited places of interest. The Party were everywhere received with enthusiasm. In the evening they attended a grand ball given by Lieutenant BELLEAU, complimentary to the Prince. The Prince will leave Quebee on Monday.
The late discovery of petroleum and sulphur in the parish of Calcasion, Mississippi, turns out to be a small affair so far as the oil is concerned, but a very large one in respect to suphur.

In our columns to-day will be found the details of a strange sort of commerce which is carried on in France, and, we presume, in all countries where the Latin Church prevails, which, like all other kinds of commerce, is subject to its own peculiar infestations of roguery.

The business of the week has closed. Today nothing will be done, and the market will be, as in old times, entirely quiet. Mondays and Saturdays, at one time, were considered as days of preparation and closing up, and on them no sales were attempted. Last Spring, during the great excitement, this rule was entirely ignored, and as important sales were made on these days as on any other.

HARTFORD, Sept. 17.--A stabbing affray occurred in this city about 10:30 this evening. A party of five negroes attacked two young white men, after some words had passed between them, and one of the latter, named ARTHUR ADAMS, was dangerously, and it is thought fatally, stabbed.

ARMSTRONG.--On Wednesday, Sept 15, of consumption, FRANCIS ARMSTRONG, aged 16 years. A true Christian, his and was peaceful. His funeral will take place from the Rose Hill M. E. Church, in 27th- St., on Saturday, 18th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M. BROWN.--At West Park, on the Hudson on Thursday. Sept. 16, JANE BROWN, widow of the late Edgar M .Brown. Notice of the funeral hereafter.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 17.--The case of David E. SAUNDERS, the defaulting teller of the North National Bank, came up to-day before Commissioner HALLET. The testimony taken showed the defalcation to be $132.000. Several brokers testified that they had bough stocks for the defendant on the usual margin.
It is the Atlantic and Pacific States Telegraph Company, whose two lines extend from San Francisco to Virginia City, Nevada, and Marysville, Cal., which has been absorbed by the Western Union.

A petition is shortly to be presented to Mr. PEABODY on behalf of the women of the South. Thousands of them are placed in circumstances of great privation, almost of actual destitution, and they appeal to the great philanthropist, not for money, but for "the opportunity to help themselves."

The Sixth Chamber of the Paris Correctional Tribunal, under the presidency of M. VIVIEN, was occupied on Aug. 20 and 27, says Le Droit newspaper, with a singular case of swindling. The two prisoners are JEAN CONSTANT DOUSSET, a merchant, and aged 45 years, and ANTOINE FRANCOIS D'ASSISES VIDAL, aged 37 years.
One of the Democratic papers of Pennsylvania accuses ASA PACKER of an offence which we venture to say was never made against any of his party before, and which is a new crime in American politics.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass, Sept. 17.--A free-trade meeting was held in this city, in Institute Hall, this evening. CHARLES MARSH, Esq., Cashier of the Pynchou bank, presided. The meeting was addressed at length by Professor Perry, of Williams College.
General CLANTON seems to be very much in earnest to develop the interests of Alabama by european immigration. He Proposes to open an office for that purpose in Montgomery,

SATURDAY. Mails for France, via Havre and Brest, per St. Laurent, and mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the City of Antwery, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail by the City of Antwerp closes on Pier No. 45 North River, at 1:40 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 17.--Congressman HOPKINS, representing the Madison District of Wisconsin, arrived in the city from the West this evening. He reports a very quiet feeling in political circles, and that the vote of the respective parties this Fall will probably fall off thirty-three per cent, through the apathy that prevails.

We present our readers to-day with a brief analysis of the last report of the State Engineer and Surveyor of this State, which has just been published in a volume of some 800 pages. It is chiefly remarkable, all things considered, for the fact that it reports no new lines and little or no progress in the railway department of this great State.

The friends of Mr. FROTHINGHAM. who has just been released from Bloomingdale Asylum, Claim, and we have no doubt with perfect truth--that there was no malicious intent in procuring his confinement. It is alleged-- and this is the point on which there are conflicting statements--that before his confinement he had given unmistakeable evidence of mental unsoundness.

Superintendent KENNEDY has issued a general order directing that on and after the 20th inst. the Police force shall wear the ;full Winter uniform, except gloves, including caps, belts and batons. Winter gloves will be worn after Nov. 1.

An important meeting of this organization came off last night at No. 267 Bowery, Mr. YOUNG, the President, in the chair. The minutes having been read and approved, the Committee appointed to organize mass meetings for the purpose of dehating on the Conspiracy and Eight-hour laws and the National Labor Congress reported progress, and will come a date for the holding of the same next Friday evening.

The new Board of Education have directed the public evening schools to be kept open during the coming season the same as heretofore and under similar regulations. The time fixed for opening these schools is the 1th of October proximo.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Public reference having been made to the claim of the family of the late Rev. B. B. HALLOCK upon the Erie Railway Company. It is only proper to say that his family, either jointly or individually, have made no claim whatever for compensation or damages for either the lost life or property.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 17.-During the session of the statistical congress in this city yesterday, Mr. CHADWICK moved for the collection of statistics respecting military service. with a view to the reduction of standing armies.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17.-At a meeting of the National Capital Executive Committee, a call for a Convention to be held here Oct. 20 was decided upon, and will be published in the promincut papers of the country.

The Board met in their Chamber, room member sixteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Connor, Hardy, Repper, McQuade--10. The minutes of the meeting held September thirteen were read and approved.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--Some light is now being thrown upon the Brooks shooting affair. JAMES APPLE, whose distillery had been closed by MR. BROOKS, was arrested to-day and committed without bail, charged with being implicated in the shooting.

Secretary BOCTWELL left this City for Washington on the 12:15 train yesterday afternoon. Several prominent gentlemen called on him during the morning at the Astor, among whom were collector GRINNELL, Postmaster JONES, General PALMER, THURLOW WEED AND Colonel F. E. HOWE.

INSURANCE AGAINST ACCIDENTS.--The Travelers' Insurance Company, of Hartford, the originator of accident insurance as practiced in this country, has achieved a success rivaling any of the older English companies. It has, we learn, paid over eleven thousand claims for death or injury by accident, thus disbursing over One Million Dollars, and its benefits are shared by all classes, rich and poor alike.

Coroner FLYNN yesterday proceeded to Bellevue Hospital to obtain the ante-mortem statement of WM. MADDEN, the man who was shot and seriously wounded in Broadway on Thursday evening by WM. J. HAMILTON.

The Philadelphia North American, in noticing the coal trade, says: "There is but little change to note since our last report, the market having continued dull at about the same rates. Eastern dealers show but little disposition to purchase, as their stocks are about as large as they are well able to carry, and are only doing a very small business.

The Board, at their meeting yesterday, exempted from the terms of the order compelling the Police force to wear their uniforms when either on or off duty, all those members employed and paid by public or private corporations. The following Sergeants were transferred: JOHN GUNNER, from the Twenty-seventh to the Nineteenth Precinct.

The German Democratic General Committee held a meeting last evening at Germania Hall, corner of Eighteenth-street and Third-avenue, about one hundred delegates being present. MAGNUS GROSS presented the report of the Executive Committee on the nominations for county officers at the coming election.

The inquest in the case of JOHN O'NEIL, who was injured in a drunken brawl on Monday, the 6th inst., in the house of JOHN KENNY, on the corner of First and Clinton streets, Hoboken, was concluded last evening before coroner WHITE.

The story of WILLIAM MADDEN, I young man who happened to be Walking down Broadway on Thursday evening, may be taken as an illustration of the excitements and perils which may be enjoyed by people of an adventurous disposition, without troubling themselves to go beyond the City limits.
Apropos of the Ecumenical Council that is to be, the following arrangements for the comfort of the foreign Prelates invited are guaranteed by a writer in La Liberte to be correct.

MADRID, Sept. 17.-The King of Itlay has given his consent to the selection of the Duke of GENOA as king of Spain. The strike of the workmen at Barcelona continues. It has assumed alarming proportions.

There is something of a rivalry between Professors ROMER and DOCKARTY, of the City College, for the office of Vice-President of the College. The dispute arises on a question of rank or seniority in Professorship. Professor ROMER has waived his right until the question is decided by the Board of Education, and Professor DOCKARTY is now acting as Vice-President.
PARIS, Sept. 17.--The Emperor yesterday appeared in the streets of Paris. Prince NAPOLEON embarked from Calais on his yacht to-day.
Judge BARRETT, of the Court of Common pleas, who returned from his European tour early yesterday morning, took his seat at Chambers yesterday, and will preside during the balance of the term.

Before Commissioner Bells. REDRESS SOUGHT BY AN ARABIAN. An Arabian, named Abraham Kassiney, made a complaint yesterday against another Arabian, named Solomon Akoun, alias Mustapha Bashaw, charging him with having opened a letter directed to his (complainant's) address, for the purpose of discovering the secrets it contained.

Dr. W. J. DAVIS, Ex-Professor at the University of St. Petersburg, has arrived in this country. Dr. DAVIS has been an extensive traveler in regions comparatively little known, among which are Thibet and the ranges of the Himalayas. His discoveries have led him to adopt some novel views respecting the origin and history of our race,

HAVANA, Sept. 18.--The schooner S. C. Dyer, from New-York, for Texas, put into the harbor of Matanzas in distress. She was detained by the authorities on suspicion of being a illlibustering craft, but has since been released at the intercession of the American Consul.

The annual book trade-sale was continued yesterday at the salerooms of Messrs. LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co., and was well attended by the trade. The bidding was exceedingly brisk, but the various publications offered did not command high prices. Messrs. CLAXTON, REMSEN CO.'S publications were sold for very low prices.
The steamship Weser, which left Bremen Sept. 4, and Southampton Sept. 7, reached this port late Friday night. Her advices are later by two days than those at hand by the Java.

In Broadway, yesterday afternoon, two ladies were knocked down within a very few yards of each other, by reckless drivers. In one instance a policeman, who was standing by, took no notice whatever of the stage which had caused the accident, and the by-standers picked up the victim,

Mr. FRANCIS ATWOOD, who was a farmer on New-Britain-avenue, and is worth about 15,000, was some months ago sent to the insane retreat in Middletown, the means employed to get him there being of a singular character, to say the least.

Many readers of our daily report of the proceedings in the United States Court, during the past week, may have wondered how the case of NANCY SLOAN vs. WILLIAM PENDERGEST, for breach of promise to marry, could have got into a Court supposed to be given exclusively to less sensational matters. But it got there in a perfectly legitimate my, and had just as much right there as any other.

Among the most interesting matters presented to the British Association for the Advancement of Science, at its last meeting, was the report of Mr. WM. FAIRBAIRN respecting the qualities of BESSEMER'S and HEATON'S steel.
Matters progress slowly at the Fair. Much to the disappointment of those who attend,

Great efforts have been made to keep what I am going to tell secret. I heard it pretty direct at the time, but doubted it. Since, however, I have received information sufficient to convince me that it is substantially true. It seems that theo Mormon girls, who have not yet " got religion," are very much opposed to polygamy.

Although the City of Brooklyn has been abundantly supplied with water, while other cities have been suffering, the Water and Sewerage Commission, appreciating the rapid increase of population and consequently the necessary increase of water resources, are preparing to meet such demand as the future may make upon them.

Professors LYMAN and NEWTON, of Yale College, who went abroad last Spring to purchase scientific works and apparatus for the various departments of this University, have returned to New-Haven. While in Europe Professor LYMAN bought $6,000 worth of physical and mechanical appliances for the Sheffield Scientific School.

The following letter was referred to by Colonel TODD, in his address at the celebration of PERRY'S victory at Put-in-Bay on the 10th inst: PROVIDENCE, April 24, 1869. General C. S. Todd: MY DEAR SIR: Your very kind favor of the 15th inst. I received and perused with heartfelt pleasure.

A cable dispatch announces that the Emperor of the French presided at a Council of Ministers yesterday. It is asserted on the authority of Le Public, newspaper, that no representative of the French Government will be present at the Ecumenical Council.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18,-Portage City, Wis., was the scene of a terrible tragedy on Thursday afternoon, It appears that two young men, named WM. H. SPAIN and BARNEY BRITT, had a quarrel, and after they separated SPAIN went home, procured a revolver, and on meeting BRITT again soon after, shot and almost instantly Idlled him, scarcely a word being exchanged.

" LA SONNAMBULA " AT THE FRENCII THEATRE, Tho curtain drew up at 8:20 last evening for the performance of "La Sonnambula" at the French Theatre, and the first appearance in this country of Miss ROSE HERSEE. The house was well-filled by a curious and attentive audience, prepared to be critical, but disposed to be generous.

LONDON, Sept. 18.-The Times calls to mind that the first anniversary of the Revolution in Spain has passed, and none of the evils laid to the charge of the Bourbons have diminished; they have rather increased. There is greater distress and confusion and less concord, efficiency and public security. The policy of the Government in the Provinces is reviewed and its action there contrasted with its action in the City of Madrid.

HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 18.--The Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Columbia County, to-day elected RICHARD F. CLARK delegate to the State Convention, and R. E. ANDREWS to the Judicial Convention. LOCKPORT, N. Y., Sept. 18.--At the Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Niagara County, held here to-day, CHARLES D. METZ, Esq., was chosen delegate to the Democratic State Convention.

The annual gathering at Salisbury Beach, just north of the mouth of the Merrimac River, took place on Thursday. It had its origin far back in the olden time, when the sturdy, industrious people of Salisbury, Mass., met annually on the beach to congratulate each other on the happy results of their labors for the season, and to return to Divine Providence their grateful thanks.

To the Commercial Editor of the Chicago Advance: Being very busily engaged in preparing the figures for my annual report, I have bee unable to give your paper on the resumption of specie payments but a hasty perusal. It deserves more thought and a better answer than I have time for.

An examination in the case of J. P. ABRAHAMS, an ex-revenue officer, charged with being implicated in the alleged embezzlement of public moneys in the Thirty-second Collection District, was called for before United States Commissioner WHITE yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock.

The Richmond Dispatch says it has the best reason for knowing that the construction of Attorney-General HOAR'S opinion in the Cabinet is that it present no obstacle to the election of United States Senators by Virginia.

The announcement that there would be a grand ball match yesterday afternoon between the champion Eckfords and the Matuals, for the benefit of the Avondale sufferers, was expected to have brought a very large crowd to the Union Grounds, but the unfavorable state of the weather dissappointed auticipations.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I am a woman, and hate argument ! Therefore, I will refer to you a point at issue between myself and a much wiser friend. The case is this: Strangers visit the City, and naturally expect to be entertained by acquaintances, who, in times past, have enjoyed the hospitalities of their distant homes.

The Summer is over and gone, and the flocks so long scattered by hill and seaside have returned or are returning to their City folds. The pastors, as is their wont, follow their flocks, and are resuming their labors within the walls of the sanctuary.

Coroner SCHIRMER was yesterday notified to hold an inquest at the Morgue in the case of a woman known only by the soubriquet of "Scotch Kate," long known to the Police as a most dissolute character, who died under somewhat suspicious circumstances in the basement of No. 20 Grand-street.

HAVANA, Sept. 17--The steamship Florida from Vera Cruz arrived this morning. She brings dates from the City of Mexico of the 12th inst. General ESCOBEDO had arrived at the capital. A new light-house has been erected at the mouth of the ?? River. It is announced that a new Cabinet will be formed by JUAREZ, with ?? IGLESIAS as Judge of the Supreme Court. Most of the old members will be retained. e retained.

By the arrival at this port of the French corvette D'Estres, in eight days from Port-auPrince, we are In possession of late and important news from that place. The City of Gonaives, after a siege lasting over twelve months, had at length fallen into the hands of the insurgents.

MADRID, Sept. 18--The Spanish Press has been in a complete ferment of excitement and indignation since the presentation of General SICKLES' notes to the Government. Some of the journals abuse the American Minister sadly. They say he was sent here solely because he was known to be a strong partisan of Cuban annexation. General SICKLES emphatically denies the assertion that his mission refers only to Cuba.

A meeting of the class of 1868 of Harvard College was held at the Fifth-avenue last evening, to take suitable action i regard to the recent death of their classmate, the late HENRY M. WHITMAN, of Cincinnati.

Yesterday was the third and concluding day of the fair Trotting Meeting at the Prospect. Park Fair Grounds Association. The Cuban revolution, however, disappoints the hopes of the Spaniards in its prompt suppression by ever and anon nullifying their fanciful predictions of its speedy annihil tion.

At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners, held yesterday afternoon, all the Commissioners being present, the following transfers of Sergeants were made: Richard Latty, from the Second to the Forty-second Precinct. Richard C. Castle, from the First to the Twenty-eight Precinct.
QUEBEC, Canada, Sept. 18.--P. P. HARRIS manager of the Quebec Branch of the Montreal Bank, and a broker named SANDERSON, have absconded, taking with them a large amount of funds of the bank :

On the 9th inst. an unknown woman was found at a place in Cherry-street, suffering from a severe contusion on the right eye and a knife wound on the right shoulder. She was subsequently taken to Bellevue Hospital in an unconscious condition, but died the same evening.

Among the questions to be dealt with by the forthcoming Ecumenical Council at Rome is the vitally important one of public education. In the "Apostolic letter" of July last the Pope admonished the faithful that "the Christian education of youth" was one of the subjects to be most "accurately weighed and determined."

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 18.--A terrible accident occurred to the night train from Charleston on the South Carolina Railroad before day light this morning. A large tree had fallen across the trestle at Congaree Swamp, and the engine and part of the train were precipitated into the swamp. The engine blew up, setting the cars and trestle on fire. About 600 feet of trestle was burned. None of the passengers were injured.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 18.--A letter is published from Mr. DAVID A. WELLS. Special Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Department, addressed to Mr. DUDLEY, American Consul at Liverpool, on the subject of devoting the surplus revenue of the Untied States to the reduction of the public debt.

The well-known line of steamers between England, India and China, in connection with the overland route, has met with another severe loss. The navigation of the Red Sea is attended with the greatest dangers, in consequence of the coral roofs and shifting sandbanks which stud the course large steamers are obliged to make.

THOMAS GRAHAM, one of the most eminent practical chemists of the day, and the author of several valuable scientific works, died in London yesterday, in the sixty--fourth year of his age.

On Thursday evening Sergeant James Stewart, Sergeant Wm. H. Denning and Private D. H. Carroll, of Company A, Fourteenth Rogiment, were presented with medals for correct drill and regular attendance. Captain Doyle is going to work in the right way to improve the efficiency of his command.

The Tammany Democracy held their primary meetings in this City last evening to elect delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which is to assemble at Syracuse on Wednesday next. A serious stabbing affray occurred in Newark-avenue, near South Fourth-sreet, Jersey City, about 10:30 o'clock last night. Three colored men named SAMUEL SHARP, SAMUEL SUTTON and JOHN BROWN were quarreling.

Evening.--Baron VON BEUST, the Austrian Prime Minister, is expected here. The Emperor did not attend the races at the Bois de Boulogne Le Public asserts that the French Government will send no representative to the Eenmenical Council.

Great satisfaction was felt throughout Spain last week when it became known that the Regent had yielded to the extraordinary pressure put upon him by all classes of society, and communicated the sentence of death which had been passed upon three Carlist leaders by the Council of War at Leon, one of them being the Canon MILLO.

The Master of the British Mint, THOS. GRAHAM, D. C. L., an eminent chemist, died on Saturday in London, in the 64th year of his age. It can discover no amelioration of the evils charged upon the Bourbons.

A terrible accident occurred to the night train from Charleston on the South Carolina Railroad before daylight this morning. A large tree had fallen across the trestle at Congaree Swamp, and the engine and part of the train were precipitated into the swamp.
BERTHA COHEN, aged 23, was struck on the head yesterday and severely injured by a brick which fell from the roof of her dwelling, No. 518 Third--avenue, as she stood in the yard.

Ex-President MILLARD FILLMORE has been appointed a delegate to the Commercial Convention, and will attend. He will organize the Convention, having been selected to do so.

It was rather a loose estimate that was made by one of the members of the Board of Education, at its last meeting, when he said that "from 15,000 to 40,000 children wore daily roaming through the City, who attended no place of instruction."

At 10 o'clock last night a fire occurred at the oil dock of LOMBARD, AYRES Co., at the foot of Sixty-fifth-street, North River. The engine-room was entirely consumed, together with a large quantity of oil. The loss of the firm is estimated at 10,000; insurance unknown.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W Simonton, Agent.

Yesterday morning we received a call from Mr. JOHN HITZ, the Consul-General of Switzerland, w ho left Washington some days since to visit the new Swiss settlement in Grundy County, which covers a tract of 9,090 acres of land. The Consul is well please with the progress of the colonists and their general condition.

The workingmen and their families will be interested to learn that the managers of American Institute at a late meeting decided to sell tickets to shops for mechanics, workingmen and workingwomen and their families, in packages of twenty-five, at thirty centers each ticket.

A man named CONNORTON, his wife, and a woman named McGINNISS, in poor circumstances, went to sleep on the floor of CONNORTON'S house, in the north-western part of the city, last night. This morning both of the women were found dead, but CONNORTON was insensible and breathing hard, caused by sleeping in a close room with a fire burning in a grate.

The prospects of Prince THOMAS, the young Duke of Genoa, and nephew of King VICTOR EMMANUEL, as a candidate for the throne, under the joint regency of MONTPENSIER, SERRANO and RIVERO, and improving. A marriage with the daughter of the Duke of MONTPENSIER is proposed.

Rev. BENJAMIN DORR, D. D., rector of Christ Church, in this city, died at his residence in Germantown at an early hour this morning. Dr. DORR had been in quite feeble health for about a year past, his nervous system especially being greatly prostrated.

Early in the Summer three human skeletons were found under a house at Parkville, Mo., under the following circumstances : A boy, son of the persons residing in the house, had borrowed an ax of a neighbor, which, instead of returning, he placed under a rock forming part of the wall of the building.

The political situation in Virginia is beginning to assume very lively interest. The installation of Governor WALKER, on Tuesday next, marks another step in the progress of practical reconstruction, and the assembling of the Legislature, two weeks hence, will put the State on such a political footing of her own as she has not occupied since 1861.

Yesterday morning, about 9 o'clock, a fire broke out in the blacksmith shop of JOHN DAGER, Seabury-street near Van Brunt, which was totally destroyed ; loss $400 ; insured. Two adjoining frame houses, belonging to FRANCIS B. CUTTING, were damaged to the extent of $800. The origin of the fire is unknown.

A riot occurred yesterday between the porters on a strike and others who refused to join them. Both sides were strengthened by their friends, and the riot threatened to become formidable, when the military appeared, and, charging into the crowd of rioters, dispersed them.

Much of what is stated as the course of the Administration on the subject of Cuban independence is mere matter of conjecture. All that is certainly known is the mediation through Minister SICKLES to the Spanish Government.

Last night, in an encounter between Corporal CHARLES H. SMITH, Company K. Seventeenth Infantry, and GEORGE SCULLATIS, policeman, originating in an attempt of the policeman to arrest SMITH for the disturbance of the public peace, the former was shot and instantly killed by SCULLATIS.
