Mrs. EMMA VARLEY, of No. 7 Chathamsquare, the wife of WILLIAM VARLEY, who has recently achieved considerable notoriety as "Reddy the Blacksmith," caused the arrest of MICHAEL VARLEY, a brother of Reddy's, yesterday, on a charge of felonious assault.

Tile recent revolution in the political affairs of the State has led to much speculation concerning the disposition to be made of our Immense State debt. With resources somewhat less than the tenth State in size and wealth in the Union, we have a State debt almost equal to that of the wealthy and populous Empire State, and only a trifle less than that of the great Mother of States.

The question of the proposed union of Washington and Jefferson Colleges was effectually settled by Judge McCANDLESS, of the United States District Court, at Williamsport, Penn., yesterday. The Court decided that an injunction restraining them from removing the College buildings and property should be granted, which leaves the Colleges separate as heretofore.
We have so often received news from Rio Janeiro that the backbone of Paraguay was broken, that this morning's tidings to that effect will only ?? fresh incredulity.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 20.-In his speech at Corinth on Saturday, Judge DENT said there were two parties at present in Mississippi. One was known as the " Bitter Enders" or "Extremists," the other as the National Republican Union Party.

A few days since a furniture maker living in a country town near Albany, N. Y., found himself in such poor health that he was advised by physicians to come West. He was an old man, and it seemed hard at his time of life to start out and make him a new home among strangers.

The State Fair, which began on Tuesday last and closed yesterday, attracted hither many people, variously estimated from 20,000 to 35,000. Though the display of animals and articles was very good, it was not so great as at some former Fairs held on the line of the New-York Central Railroad.

Brevet Brigadier-General ROBT. M. WEST, late Captain in the Seventh United States Cavalry, died near Fort Arbuckie, Idaho Territory, on the 3d inst. Professor CYRUS NORTHROP, the Yale Courant says, has formally declined the Presidency of the University of Alabama.

Two local political officeholders, named FRANK and STEPHEN KINNEY, were brought up for examination before United States Commissioner WHITE yesterday, on a charge of conspiring to defraud the Government.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20.-A party of eight persons, consisting of T. C. I. CHAFFE, his wife and wife's sister and five children, the youngest twelve weeks old, were found on the road near this city on Saturday in a most destitute condition. They were without money, starving and almost naked.

The reception of Prince ARTHUR at Quebec has had more the character of an English welcome than any which he had before received. The lack of general display in the streets, and the quiet, yet interested look of the crowds who thronged the road along which he passed have bad no parallel in the cities which he has hitherto visited.

Last evening, as the 6:30 mail train on the South Side Railroad was approaching Bush wick Station, the engineer observed a woman walking upon the trestle-work some distance ahead. He blew "down brakes." and continued to whistle, but the woman did not appear to notice it. When engine was within about twenty feet of her she turned around, and instantly threw herself down an embankment of some fifteen feet. .

The Albany Argus seems rather disposed to favor the adoption of the Judiciary article of the new Constitution, but for reasons of which all our readers may at once be able to see the force: "It given to the Democracy." says the Argus., the control for years of the Court of Appeals, through two Republicans (to five Democrats) are Kept on the bench.

Peterson Engine Company No. 31 held a large political meeting last evening at No. 139 Canal-street to indorse JOHN SCOTT as candidate for Police Justice in the Fourth (Essex Market) District, in place of Judge MASSFIELD. ANDREW CRONAN presided, and made a speech heartily indersing the candidate.

To-day three grand suburban sales will be made. At Great Neck, Queens County, L. I., Messrs JOHNSON MILLER have a sale of 500 elegant villa plots, also mansion house and numerous out-buildings. The grounds are very beautiful, the location excellent, as also the communication.

A report has recently been published by Mr. PAGE, an English engineer, relating to the practicability of opening the channel between Quebec and Montreal for steamers of a large size. In this report Mr. PAGE also calls attention to a letter on the subject from a competent authority, Mr. HUGH ALLAN, which contains some information likely to prove of interest to the general reader.

The members of the Forsyth-street Methodist Episcopal Church are subscribing liberally toward a land for the relief of the Avondale families, Persons desiring to contribute are requested to call upon R. H. GIBLETT, at No. 109 Canal-street. The subscriptions received at the St. Nicholas Hotel amounted to $233 82, Of this amount $151 32 was contributed by the employes of the house, the propprietors $50, amd guests the remainder.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 20.-Two large blocks in Medina were destroyed by fire yesterday morning. The following are the names of the losers: James Skinner, boot and shoe store, $1,500, insured for $1,000; John Parson, tin shop, $1,500; Fuller Godley, hardware store, $12,000, insured for $7,500;

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 20.-Private advices from Japan, received by the last steamer, are as follows: The Japanese currency was in a bad way, and much spurious money was in circulation. The paper currency was at a discount; trade was dull and business almost at a stand-still.

The number of pensioners now on the books of General LAWRENCE, the Pension Agent, is 5,863; number paid since Sept. 4, 2,943; amount disbursed, $209,863. Since General LAWRENCE has taken possession of the office he has made ten arrests,

The following returns of receipts have been made for August in the Fifth Collection District of New-Jersey: Transportation Companies.--New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company, $126,680; Jersey City Ferry Company, $48,702; Jersey City and Bergen Horse Railroad Company, interest on bonds, $24,000; Long Branch and Seashore Railroad, $24,737;

TUESDAY. Mails for Halifax, Bermuda, , by the City of Baltimore, close at the General Post Office at -- A. M. Mails for Europe, via Plymouth, Cherbourg and Hamburg, by the Allemannia, close at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P M.

The motion to appoint new receives of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad Company was made by the Attorney-General before Judge T. A. JOHNSON to-day. Messrs. JOHN K. PORTER and A. J. VANDERPOEL appeared as counsel for the Ramsey directors, and Messrs. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD,

LISBON, Sept. 20.-The mail steamer from Rio Janeiro has arrived, and brings important Intelligence. Dispatches received at Rio, from Asuncion, dated Aug. 15, report that the Allies have captured Ascurra and Piribebin. President LOPEZ has fled, and the Paraguayans can no longer continue the struggle. The Provisional Government has been installed at Asuneion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The following is a summary of our naval forces in the several fleets now on duty. This includes only the vessels actually on the various stations. It could at short notice be tripled, both as to ships and guns:
QUEBEC, Sept. 20. --Prince ARTHUR made a short tour around the harbor on Saturday.

WAVERLY, N. Y., Sept. 20--At 7:30 o'clock this morning the express train on the Pennsylvania and New-York Railroad, bound north, collided with the way train, standing on the track, at Athens, Penn., four miles from this place. One person was killed outright--WILLIAM MABEE, of Towanda, Penn., and another has since died.

BOYD -In this City, on Sunday morning, Sept. 19. ARCHIBALD B. BOYD, of Panama. N. G. aged 13 years. His friends and those of his brother, Hugh Boyd, are invited to attend the funeral from No. 25 Tompkins -place, South Brooklyn, on Tuesday, 21st inst., at 3 1/2 o' clock P.M. CONDIT. - At Saint Paul, Mmn. on Saturday. Sept. 18, JOHN S. CONDIT, late of Newark, N. J., aged 30 years.

A good young actress is as rate as a white eiephant or a dodo. Whether it be owing to projudico against the stage, to the opening of fresh a venues of employment for women, or to other and more occult causes, the number of young ladios coming forward in the dramatic profession who can be set down as realty belonging to the first rank soems year by your to become fewer and fewer.

The Democratic Union General Committee held a special meeting last night at Masonic Hall, Thirteenth-street, near Fourth-avenue, Supervisor SMITH ELY, Jr., in the chair. The business of the evening was the appointment of an Executive Committee of one from each Assembly District, and to take action in reference to the State Convention, which meets on Wednesday.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution requesting the City Representatives in Congress to vote for and urge the immediate recognition of the independence of Cuba. The Board adjourned to Thursday next at 2 P. M.

The September Term of the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminar for Westchester Country commenced yesterday at the Courthouse, White Plains, before Hon. J. W. GILBERT, Presiding Justice; Hon. ROBERT COCHRAN, County Judge, and M. B. SILLIMAN and D. K. CONKLIN, Esqrs., Justices of the Sessions.

A writer in the Portland (Me.) Argus Concludes a notice of the funeral of the late Senator FESSENDEN as follows: "Some thirty-five years ago--and perhaps more--DANIEL WEBSTER contemplated a journey to our Western States and Territories, which he had never visited.

M. THIERS' collection of engravings has been lately estimated at the enormous ?? of 800,000??. His mother-in-law, Mme. DOSNE, assisted him in discovering the precious curiosities which are now in his possession, and which form one of the finest cabinets in Europe.

The Twenty-second-street. Committee has taken action professedly to secure a united delegation to the State Convention. While this is very desirable, it is by no means the main object to be aimed at. It is not union at Syracuse we want so much as harmony in New-York. A united representation in Conventions is not as desirable as a consolidated party.

We have no inclination to take part in the family jars of the Tammany Democracy. It ;is no affair of ours, and we shall consider it no heart grievance if the quarrel with ;Mr. BELMONT is never composed--or if it results in driving that eminent chief into the arms of the real hand-paying party of the country. If he should take himself out of Tammany Hall he will not go alone:

The small grain crop of this year in the Northwest is now about all secured, and sufficient of it has been threshed to form some idea of the yield and quality. From reports in our exchanges and from other sources, we judge that the average yield to the acre will be about fifteen bushels, or not far from that of ordinary years.

Yesterday the Saturday Committee held a meeting with closed door, the subject under discussion being the unlsance occasioned by the operations of the New-York Rendering and other companies. WM. EVERETT, the engineer of the NEW-YORK Rendering Company, attended at the Board, as did also Mr. CARTER, the trustee of the Company.

Following the murder of the venerable SCHUYLER GATES at Kilbourn City comes a murder at Portage City and the lynching of the murderer. The sending of three persons into eternity by murder in the same vicinity is a matter of sufficient importance to create a wild sensation in any neighborhood, and such sensation exists at Portage and Kilbourn City.

Conventions have been the rage in Chicago during the present week. The "Western Woman's Suffrage Association" has been holding a meeting, which, though not largely attended, drew together quite a number of the notables engaged in the agitation, from different sections of the country.

The loss by the fire at Messrs. LOMBARD, AYRES Co.'s oil refinery, at the foot of West Sixty-fifth-street, is about $25,000. The ships Pacific, laden with 10,000 barrels of oil, and Cornwallis, having on board 1,765 barrels, were lying beside the pier at the outbreak of the fire.

The presence of Mrs. Dr. WALKER, at the Women's Convention, renews the recollection of an interview which took place between that somewhat remarkable person and General SHERMAN, at Atlanta, during the war, and several weeks after the city had been captured.

The recovery of the Emperor is said by a Paris correspondent of the London Times to have created a calm in the stormy debate which had begun between the party of the Empress and those friendly to prince NAPOLEON. It is a foretaste of what is to come, it says, when the Emperor does die.

An effort was made, we believe, at the last session of the Legislature, to enact a law forbidding the introduction of Texan cattle into this State. For some reason the effort failed. The high prices which have ruled for beef cattle of late have turned several hands of Texan scrub cattle toward California.

Forty men and several teams are now engaged in completing the new park known as Mount Morris-square, which will be finished in about six weeks, and for which the Central Park Commission appropriated $15,000. The walks on the west side are already graded, and work has been commenced on the hill, the ascent of which will be rendered easy be several paths sloping to the top.

The following particulars of an Indian massacre near Fort Buford, on the Upper Missouri, reach us from an authentic source: It is the usual custom for Indian traders to give the heads of the difference tribes a feast each year. On the occasion to which we refer, Mr. LARPENTER, whose trading post is at Fort Buford, had given a feast to a large number of Indians.

Last evening a number of the residents of the Nineteenth Ward assembled at Jackson Hall, No. 1,000 Third-avenue, to discuss the subject of needed stage and railroad communication between Yorkville and the lower end of the island. Mr. JOHN FOLEY presided. Remarks were made by several gentlemen, and at the conclusion the following memorial was adopted:

LONDON, Sept. 20.--The post this morning says it now appears that America has only made friendly representations to the Madrid Government in favor of the reasonable demands of the Cubans. It is probable the NAPOLEON suggested to the Regency that Spain should act considerately toward Cuba, and so disarm American influence.

The Sacramento Union furnishes the following report of lion. WILLIAM H. SEWARD'S speech in Salem, Oregon: The older States, situated eastward of the Missouri and below the base of the Rocky Mountains, have complete industrial, social and political systems, and fixed habits.

The National Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows of the United States will hold its annual Convocation, in this city, on the 20th inst. A few facts and figures relative to the organization may be of interest. In 1824 there were only six lodges comprising the entire Order in America, three of which were in the City of Baltimore, and one each in Philadelphia, New-York and Boston.

We have received the following communication by express from a party in San Buenaventura, who signs his name and is vouched for by a respectable firm in this city as an honest, reliable man. The communicaiton reads as follows: NEWS OF SIR JOHN FRANKLIN.

We have no desire to prolong the discussion of the repulsive story which has recently added to the seandalous literature of the age. But the claims of historical truth require that we should place on record the complete refutation of a narrative which was full of intrinsic improbabilities and contradictions,

DUBLIN, Sept. 20.-The Irishman to-day says no terms for Ireland will be acceptable without the release of the Fenlans. It is the verdict of the Irish people that England must set these men free or avow that her promise of a better Government for Ireland is a lie.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 20.--A suit has been entered in the United States Circuit Court against General JAMES B. STEEDMAN, Ex-internal Revenue Collector for this district, and his sureties, by the United States Distric-Attorney, for over 4600,000, which amount, after the adjustment of accou ts by the preper officers. is found to be due by STEEDMAN,as Tax Collector, to the Government.

Owing to the prevailing drought, our water supply has been materially lessened, and the pressure at the Croton Dam has decreased to such a degree, that in the residences on the more elevated portions of Manhattan Island the water cannot be forced up beyond the second story The water is lower than it has ever been;

The Central Park Commissioners, acting under the authority of a special law of the last Legislature, have defined the lines and filed the maps for the widening of Broad way from Thirty-second-street to Fifty-ninth-street.

The United States Convention of Universalists met, at 10 o'clock this morning, at the Church of the Messiah. Rev. J. G. BARTHOMER, of Auburn, was chosen President, and Rev. J. M. PULLMAN, of New-York City Secretary.
The following are the gross receipts of the different places of amusements, lines of railroad and stages and ferry companies, together with the amount of gas consumed during the month of August :

WILLIAM DALY has for some time been in the habit of returning to his home at No. 29 Frankfort-street, at a late hour of the night, intoxicated. He has also amused himself by knocking at the doors of the other occupants, thereby annoying them very much.

The Coroner's Jury in the case of the accident at Athens, Penn., yesterday, censure S. C. MEANS, conductor of the way train, for disobedience of orders, and JOHN RAHN, train dispatcher at Towanda, for running a fast train a few minutes behind a slow one.

Delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which is to assemble at Wieting Hall, in this city, at 12 M. to-morrow, are arriving in large numbers by every tram. This is the first time in six years that the Democracy have held their State Convention here, and the people of Syracuse manifest a laudable curiosity to see what improvement has been made in the representative men of the party since that time.

Nickel, about whose possible uses we heard so much in the days of the "new pennies," is, it seems, about to prove wonderfully serviceable for electro-plating. Means have been lately found for so depositing it on metallic articles as to make a more lasting and a far cheaper coating than silver, and one quito equal to silver in beauty.

At the afternoon session of the Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows, the Grand Officers presented their reports, and Standing Committees were appointed. The reports exhibit a gratifying condition of the Order everywhere, with the exception of the interior of the Southern States, where it is particularly bad.

The papers of this city publish a letter from the preacher-monk, Father HAYCINTHE, addressed to the Father-General of his order at Rome, announcing that he abandons his convent and ceases hence forth to preach in the Church of Notre Dame of Paris.

The remains of MICHAEL CASEY, the cartman who was drowned on Friday at the feet of East Sixteenth-street, were recovered yesterday and taken to his late residence, No. 403 East Eighteenth-street, where Coroner KEENAN will hold an inquest.

No department of the American Institute Fair is more deserving of attention than that under control of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, which occupies the northeastern angle of the rink. This Association was organized in 1864, and is now in the fifth year of its operations.

SEPT. 21--In steamship Allemannia, for Hamburg.--Baron Krause, Secretary of the North German Legation, Captain Kalinsky, Adolph Stavenow, L. Rhemheimer, H. Champenois, Emil Werner and family, G. T. Williams, Mrs. Anna Melchoir and child, Chas. Eliot, Mrs. Josephine Plummer, children and servant, Rev. Chas. Morningstar, Leopold Berheimer, Adolph Mark, Richard Kauffer and lady, Wm. Stone, Hiram Jenkins, Wm. Rapp, Z. R. Engel, F. Klewe.

CHARLES MURRAY and MICHAEL SMITH were arrested on Monday, by Officer HANTY, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, on a charge of having, on the 11th inst., stolen two flags and a quantity of wearing apparel, valued at $18, from the steamboat General McCullom, at Pier No. 1 North River.

Yesterday was a very busy day in the Real Estate market. The weather was bright, warm and pleasant; the roads were in fine condition, and everything was favorable for suburban sales, The sale made by Messrs., A. J. BLEAKER, SON Co., at West Bergen, N. J., was a great success. Perhaps 300 persons attended the sale, and they were of the ?? that are always welcomed.

The Committee to investigate the charges made by Senator SPRAGUE in reference to the disposition made of the Agricultural College lands granted to Brown University, met in Providence on Monday, but when they learned that the notification sent to Mr. SPRAGUE's office had not been forwarded to him, they adjourned to a future day.

The Board held a meeting yesterday afternoon. The resignation of Sergeant JOHN L., VOSBURGH, of the Thirty-second Precinet, to take effect on Oct. I, was received and accepted. Patrolman W. B. SMINCK, of the Twenty-seventh Precinet, was promoted to he roundsman, and assigned to the Seventh Precinet.

The revolt of Father HYACINTHE against the authority of the Papal hierarchy, of which the Cable brings us intelligence this morning, is an event which will produce a profound sensation throughout the Church. He is the most eloquent preacher of the Latin Church heard in France since the death of LACORDAIRE.

The Scotch have erected a national monument as Starling in honor of the heroic WILLIAM WALLACE, and the ceremony of "handing over" the monument was fixed for the 11th inst.--at which time it doubtless took place.

The Democratic State Convention meets to-day at Syracuse. The choice of delegates apparently has disappointed the Tammany Regency, who have not received the cordial support for their combination which they counted them when the electment baners.

The German Central; workingmen's Union, composed of delegate representing some seventy-three trade societies, has taken action to cooperate with the Workingmen's Union during the approaching campaign, and it has been decided that a mass meeting shall be called at an early day at the Cooper Institute.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner KEENAN, at the Founding Hospital, on Randail's Island, over the body of JOHN GARRETT, aged is months, who died from the effects of poison contained in a quantity of eye-water.

The gold piece given by King CHARLES I. to Bishop JEXON on the scaffold at Whitehall, has just been sold in London. It belonged to the estate of the late Mr. THOMAS BROWN, and was brought by Mr. WEBSTER, OF Henrietta-street Covent Garden, for the large sum of $345.

On Friday last three committees, one appointed by the Citizens' Association, of this City, one by the Chamber of Commerce, and one by the New-York Produce Exchange, held a meeting at the rooms of the Chamber of commerce to take measures for a thorough organization throughout the State of New-York, in order to effect a reform in the management of the canals, and to improve the canal trade.

THE STATUESQUE AT THE TAMMANY. One cannot have too much of a good thing. To the statuesque element supplied to the Tammany entertainment by a show of the fair proportions of numerous dancing girls, has been added the exhibition of Mr. JAMES MACE.

We have had occasion to comment favorably on the action of the new Board of Education in various directions. On one point, however, they have failed to meet public expectation, and that in regard to a want in our educational system which few intelligent men differ about.

The Park Commissioners announce that if the weather be fine there will be music by the Park Band at the north end of the Green this afternoon, commencing at 3:30 o'clock. The following is the programme:

The Pall Mall Gazette reviews the idea of a Chinese policy put forth by Mr. BROWNE, late American Minister to China. It says the sum of his argument is the opening of new markets to Christian traders. In point of fact there is nothing to show that the difficulties between foreigners and the Chinese are merely questions of interpretation.

The Croton Aqueduct Board yesterday opened the following bids, received for excavating, ditch making, embankment, laying twenty-inch and six-inch water pipe, and for furnishing stop-cocks and other castings for the High Service at Carmansville:

The Board met in their Chamber, Room number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Caddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Connor, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farrey--12.

The Supreme Judicial Court in session at Dover was occupied three days with the trial of the case of RICKER vs. FREEMAN--an action brought by the plaintiff against the defendant for injuries sustained eleven years ago, when the parties were school-boys of about 12 years of age.
The General Committee of the German-American School Association, of this City, held their regular monthly meeting at the Germania Assembly Rooms last night, Mr. WILLIAM WALLACK presiding.

AUGUST SCHNEIDER, alias August Miller, alias Louis Miller, was arrested yesterday by Detective DUNN, of the Sixth Precinct, on a charge of having passed a false check for $35 on the Bull's Head Bank, on EMMA GLOSSIND, No. 37 Centre-street, from whom he purchased some lards and received some change.

Right Rev. Dr. LYNCH, Bishop of Charleston, will ordain Rev. HENRY S. LAKE, now a deacon, to the priesthood, to-morrow (Thursday) at 8 o'clock A. M., in the Church of the Pauhst Fathers, corner of Fifty-ninth-street and Ninth-avenue, and not on Friday, as has been announced.

The Opening of the Race Course and Park which bear Mr. LEONARD JEROME'S name, was the beginning of a new epoch in the history of the American turf. In the first place, Mr. JEROME'S enterprise and liberality had rendered it possible for ladies to go and see a race, not only without risk of finding themselves disturbed or inconvenienced, but with the certainty of spending an agreeable day.

Commander M. F. MAURY has offered some explanations to the people of Cincinnati on this point. He recalls the early promise of the city, and contrasts it with its actual position. Once Cincinnati was the commercial focus of the Ohio Valley.

Mr. C. KOOPMANSCHAP, op San Francisco, is now in this City making arrangements for bringing to this country, in 1870, a supply of Chinese Laborers. After visiting the West he will leave, on Nov. 4, for China, to return in the Spring of 2870, bringing with hint as many Celestials as he may have contracted for.

The first case on the calendar of the Court of General Sessions yesterday was that of "Reddy the Blacksmith," otherwise WILLIAM VARLEY. Before 11 o'clock the Court-room became compactly filled in every part with spectators, largely composed of friends of the prisoner, who manifested intense interest in every little feature connected with the proceedings.

BROWN.--At Yonkers, on Monday, Sept. 20. MAXWELL, infant son of Edgar F. and Hannah K. Brown. CLARK.--At Yonkers, on Monday evening, Sept. 20. ANN, M., Wife of Hull Clark, aged 76 years. The relatives and friends Yonkers, on Thursday afternoon, at 31/2 o'clock. Carriages will be in waiting on the 2 o'clock train to Yonkers, or 2:30 train to Hastings.

The eleventh annual Fair of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society opened upon the Fair Grounds a short distance south west of the depot at Waverly yesterday morning. The exhibition of fruit and vegetables promises far to exceed to the display at any previous fair. The total entries of cattle number upward of twelve hundred. Many people visited the grounds yesterday.

The Engineer of the Board of Health will soon (probably to-day) present to that body a plan by which every street throughout the City may be flushed, daily, with water from the Hudson and East Rivers. The report will be accompanied by such details and estimates of the cost as will enable us to thoroughly understand the plan.

Rabbi H. Z. SNEERSOHN, of Jerusalem, lectured last evening in Room No. 14 Cooper Institute, on the Holy Land. The lecturer, who was dressed in Oriental costume, continued his remarks chiefly to the City of Hebron, the burying place of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. the lecture was nevertheless interesting and instructive.

Reports from Brazilian sources represent that the defeat of President LOPEZ at Ascurra was a complete rout, and that the struggle was ended. LA Patric, on the other hand, has different accounts, which while acknowledging that the Paraguayans have suffered a reverse, maintain that LOPEZ is still able and determined to continue the war.

The United Presbyterian Sabbath School Convention held its opening exercises last evening in the Seventh-avenue Church, below Thirteenth-street. Rev. J. H. ROBERTSON, of Mumford, addressed the large audience on the "Aim of the Sabbath School Teacher," which, he said, should be, first, to gather in scholars to the school;

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner ROOLINS, at No. 54 Barrow-street, over the body of SAMUEL MILLER, who died suddenly on Sunday soon after dinner, in consequence of a piece of meat lodging in his throat . A verdict of death Iron asphyxia was recorder.

The Pope has sent a communication to Cardinal MANNING in reference to the proposal of Dr. CUMMING to appear at the Ecumenical Council. The Pope refers Dr. CUMMING to the terms of the letter of invitation addressed to Protestants, and says he will find that it is an invitation, not to a discussion, but only to profit by the opportunity to return to the Church.

Yesterday afternoon the National Base-Ball Club. of Washington, played their return game with the Mutuals, at the Union Grounds, Brooklyn. The first match between these nines came off in Washington several weeks ago, when the Nationals beat the New-Yorkers by a score of 28 to 26. Yesterday the tables were turned.

Mr. CYRUS REDDING, in a letter on the Byron controversy, expresses the belief that the charge made by Mrs. STOWE never existed out of her own brain. He says Lady BYRON steadily refused to state the reason of the separation.

The journals of this city are still violent against the presumed unfriendliness of the American Government. Some of them urge an immediate declaration of war, if the Cubans are recognized as belligerents. The Ministry, after discussing the propriety of returning SICKLES' note unanswered, have decided to postpone their reply until the arrival of General PRIM.

Last evening the Apollo Dramatic Association gave a performance at SIEBERT'S Hall, East Eighth-street, the proceeds of which will be given to the fund for the relief of the Avondale sufferers. The programme was some what lengthy and difficult for an amateur company's first performance.

The long litigation in this suit has at last been advanced another and a very material step. The point around which the public interest centers has been decided. The Court has found an infringement by the respondent of the complainant's copyright.

WALTER OGILBY. A Novel, By the authoress of "Wau-Bun." Philadelphia: J. B. LIPPINCOTT Co., 1869. The author of this unpretending and pleasant story has many qualities essential to a good novelist, among which are a generous and ready appreciation of natural beauty and moral worth, an uncommon amount of information, and a keen sense of the ridieulous.

Speaking of one of Mr. SEWARD'S recent speeches, and of the supposed taste among the British-American colonists for annexation to the United States, the Toronto Globe says : "There is in the Pacitic colouies, as there always will be in every community on this continent, a few people who think that they could do better if annexed to the United States.

There is a great deal of sameness in our reports of the war. From latest accounts the Allies seem not disposed to venture into the interior beyond safe lines of supply of retreat. But for the convenience of the railway, the Brazilian Commander, Count D'EU, WOULD hardly have gone the thirty leagues he has traveled from the coast.

Prince ARTHUR arrived here on a special train at 11 o'clock this morning. He stopped fifteen minutes, and left for London, where he will arrive at 5 o'clock. Crowds assembled at the stations on the route, and greeted him with cheers.

SEPT. 21--In steamship Colorado, from Liverpool--R. W. Cooper, E. W. Prescott, C. S. Marshall, N. Hessler, Ries Beran, Thomas Beswick, H. D. T. Moore, Charles A. Rolfers, John Donnan, Samnel Donald, E. POWER, F. Walkins, Mr. Oakford, Willam Dumbull, Worthy Dumbull, J. W. Dickinson, M. M. Lloyd, J. P. Whitney, F. Balmacetta, Averasto Lamar, C. Robbins, John N. Beach, wife, 3 children and servant, Henry Neill, wife and child, Miss Schulz,

Major-General CRAWFORD lately received the degree of LL. D. from the University of Pennsylvania, of which he is a graduate. This honor will rest more gracefully and appropriately on General CRAWFORD'S shoulders than on those of some of the other military officers upon whom it has lately been conferred by sundry institutions of learning.

This morning a patent gas machine containing gasoline, located on the first floor of the premises No. 223 State-street, took fire through carelessness. The flames spread with great rapidity, setting the whole building on fire.

Another of those interesting companies, of young people which the Children's Aid Society periodically dispatch to the West, left the City yesterday in charge of one of the Society's officers. About fifty of the party were homeless boys from 12 to 16 years of age, who had been temporarily residing at the Newslays's Lodging House.

We give in another column the terms of an arrangement entered into last evening by the delegates of the several Republican primary organizations of this City. They promise harmony, and an end to the treachery which cost us our State ticket at the last election.

The speech of Senator SUMNER to the Massachusetts Convention, delivered yesterday and published in full this morning in our columns, consists of a general summary of that distinguished gentleman's opinions on the leading political questions of the hour.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The Times morning says ; "The Spanish have found their advantage in a bold display of patriotism and national courage. They met an imagined affront. with immediate dalliance, though their threatened adversary is ten times more powerful than themselves. General SICKLES is manifestly alarmed at the result of his proceedings, and has requested further instructions.

THURSDAY. Mails for Havana and West Indies, by the Missouri, close at 2 P. M. Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Bremen, by the Donan, close at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the prior foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P. M. Mails for Brazil, St. Thomas, Argentine Confederation Venezuela and the West Indies, by the North America, close at 1 P. M.

The immense ravages of the revolutionists as well as the Spanish troops, in Cuba threaten not only to render that rich and fertile island a protitloss possession to Spain' but to destroy its productive power for some time after the close of hostilities.

Two hundred California pioneers are expected in this City at 6:30 A. M. to-day. They left ?? at 6:30 A. M. last Thursday, in a special train of Pullman ears, via the great overland route. The entire distance traveled by them will be 3,187 miles.

There were no suburban sales advertised for yesterday, and it is very fortunate there were none. The weather was rainy and gloomy, and a disappointment would have been inevitable. Thus far everything has been very favorable. Each sale has taken place at the time advertised.

OIL, CITY, Penn., Sept. 22.--There is a large fire in the Standard Oil Works, near Pittsburg. It began about 9:30 o'clock this morning, and is still raging. All efforts to extinguish the fire have so far proved fruitless, and it is thought the entire works will be destroyed. The loss is not yet known. CINCINNATI, Sept. 22.-A frame house on Cemtral-avenue was burned last night.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22.--This morning, at 9 o'clock, the Council resumed its session. The Committee on Centennial Work report as follows: The year 1870 will be the centenary of the Universalist denomination in America. It is recommended, first, that the parishes pay off the outstanding debts. Second, That all the needed improvements and repairing of churches, or the building of new ones, he done in the course of a year.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The New-York financiers are at present exercised upon the high prices demanded for Gold, and for the use of Currency--the former acting upon the latter to the extent of its holding upon borrowed money.

Mrs. SCOTT--SIDDONS arrived in this City yesterday, by the steamer Scotia. Rev. Dr. McCLINTOCK and family returned from abroad yesterday, after an absence of about three months. The doctor is in good health and will at once resume his duties as President of the Drew Theological Seminary.
MADRID, Sept. 22.--The first subject of dismission before the Cortes on reassembling will

PARIS, Sept. 22.--The Journal des Debats tooks upon the religious situation as one fraught with serious consequences. It is said the coming Council at Rome will meet only to ratify the decisions of a most ultramontane committee. But the attitude of certain German and American Bishops, and the complaints of illustrious French ecelesiatics, show that the labors of the Council will not be so easy and direct as was anticipated.

Mr. FAGNANI'S much talked of pictures, theo " Nine Muses," were viewed on Tuesday at No. 82 Fifth-avenue, by a numerous circle of friends, and they are now announced at the same place for public exhibition. As most people are by this time aware, the pictures are portraits of young American ladies who are celebrated for their personal beauty, the costumes and accessories being of appropriate classical designs. Mr.

The Union republican general Committee (Twenty third--street) held an adjourned meeting last evening, at the hall corner of twenty-Third-street and broadway, Mr. John D. GRIDLEY in the chair. The report of Special committees being in order, Mr. JAMES W. CLEVE arose,

ST. JOHN, N. B., Sept. 22--Further investigations concerning the discovery of the selections of a Woman and child near Loch ??, leave no doubt that a double murder has been committed. A man named KANE is in custody on suspicion of being the criminal, and the bodies are supposed to be those of his wife and child.

A communication was presented to the Board of Health yesterday from the attorney and counsel, on the subject of tenement-houses. Mr. BLISS says that the first step toward the reform of the innumerable evils peculiar to tenement-houses, must be a more thorough knowledge of the tenement-house system, a thorough inspection of the system and more publicity on the subject.

LA JUIVE AT THE ACADEMY. The disposition of the public to sustain Grand Opera was last night clearly shown by the fact that in spite of the excessively unpleas ant weather, an audience more than respectable, both in numbers and character, assembled at the Academy of Music to witness the first representation of the new French company in :La Juive."

Dr. HARRIS, the Sanitary Superintendent, yesterday presented to the Board of Health the weekly record of results obtained under the supervision of the chemist in the laboratory of the Board with regard to explosive oils sold in this City and Brooklyn.

There are few classes of cases in law which require closer discrimination or greater care or accuracy than those which turn on the definition of words or phrases; and there have been many cases of great interest which involved nothing more.

SEPT. 22--In steamship Nevada, for Liverpool.--Rev. John Hurst and wife, Miss Hurst, Master Hurst, J. B. Monnot, Master G. F. Monnot, Miss Louisa Masters, E. F. Bradley, Geo. Banks, David Hopkins, Miss Marrian Taylor, Miss Kate Meredith.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22.--GEORGE PEABODY visited the Peabody Institute today during a meeting the trustees, and made an additional donation of $800,000 of Tennessee six per cent. bonds, and $100,000 Virginia State six per cent. bonds. This sum is designated by similar to and adjoining the present Institute, the site for which has already been purchased.
A meeting of the Commissioners took place yesterday, Commissioner GALWAY in the chair. A resolution recommending that the engineers of steamers be relieved from patrol duty was referred.

Our neighbors of Philadelphia profess to be law-abiding and humane people, and as the world goes, we believe they are; but we would like some of their wise men to reconcile such a reputation with the facts we are about to submit to their notice. Section 1 of their Amended Game laws reads as follows:

Inquiries at the Methodist Book Concern, in relation to the mismanagement of its affairs, disclose the fact that the frauds to which we alluded in Tuesday's TIMES were confined to employes of the institution, and in no respect compromise its heads.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the German Cigar Manufacturer's and Dealers' Union, was held at the Germania Assembly Rooms yesterday at 4 P. M. A. SCHEIDEMANTEL, C. NEWMEIER, PETER RADOW, JOHN FRANK and GUSTAV A. RATZ, were appointed a Committee to draw up a memorial to Congress, for the purpose of obtaining a change in the Revenue laws relating to tobacco.

Mrs. CATHARINE HALPIN, residing at No. 114 East Warren-street, while in a temporary fit of insanity, at 3 P. M. yesterday, assaulted her son EDWARD, 8 years of age, with an ax, inflicting ten wounds, any one of which was sufficient to cause death. The circumstances of the fearful tragedy are about as follows:

The Democratic Convention which met yesterday at Syracuse, renominated all the present Democratic State officers; W. W. WRIGHT for Canal Commissioner, and FORDIS LAFLIN for State Prison Inspector. It also bestowed a gratuitous kick at the Fifteenth Amendment.

The State Convention of the Democracy, after three sessions, the last one continuing late into the night, has closed its labors and its candidates and platform are now before the people. As I predicted, the proceedings were harmonious and excessively dull.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21.--The United States steamer Mohican returned from Siberia to-night with Professors HALL and ROGERS, of the United States Naval Observatory at Washington, who went North to observe the eclipse. The expedition was a decided failure. The steamer arrived in Plover Bay, July 30, and anchored in Emma Harbor.

The record of the Sir John Franklin expedition was found on the California coast by Mr. JAMES DALY, of the firm of DALY RODGERS, lumber merchants in San Buenaventura. Mr. DALY, walking on the beach, accidentally stumbled upon a battered leather bag, made of seal-skin and closely fastened, and in that the paper was found.

There is reason to hope that the taxables of this City will have half a million of dollars less to pay for the support of their public schools during the year 1870 than they have been accustomed to pay for several years past.

ALLEN.--At Dover, N. J., an Wednesday, Sept. 22, JABEZ L. ALLEN, aged 63 years. Funeral at 2 P. M. Saturday, 25th Inst., on arrival of 11:30 A.M. train from New-York. All friends are invited to attend the funeral without further notice of the late George Colgate. Notice of funeral hereafter. CLARK.--At Yonkers, on Monday evening, Sept. 20. ANN M., wife of Hull Clark, aged 76 years.

Four vessels have very recently left this port laden with firearms, and a fifth is upon the point of starting. Their cargoes consist of one hundred and twenty-five thousand Enfield and two hundred and twenty-five thousand Springfield rifles, which have been purchased from the United States Government, for account of the Porte, by his Excellency BLACQUE BEY, the Ottoman Minister at Washington.

FAULKNER--URMY.--On Wednesday, Sept. 22, at St. John's Chaped. New-York, by Rev. George B. Andrews, JOSIAH FAULKNER, Esq., of Wappinger's Falls, to Mrs. CATHERINE A. URMY, of New-York, No cards. San Francisco papers please copy. HAMILTON--COLEMAN.--On Wednesday, Sept. 22, 1869, at the residence of the Bride's parents, by Rev.

An article in the London Times of the 20th of August exhibits the vigilance of the English authorities to detect and avail themselves of any improvement in naval architecture, armament or nautical change of any description.
The Chief officer of the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, of London, Mr. EYRE M. SHAW, has written a letter to General ALEXANDER SHALER, of the Metropolitan Fire Department, of this City, in which he says:

SEPT. 23-- In steamship Ville de Paris, from Harre. Mr. Rucch and family, Mr. Nothean, Mr. Girod, Mr. Mareott and family, Mr. Eho and family. Dr. Holden and lady, Mr. Depierlis, Mr. Dannis, Mr. Worthington, Mr. May, Mrs. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson, Mr. Ward, Mr. Johnson and family, Mr. Brush and son, Mr. and Mrs. Bement, Mr. Virmondes, Miss Watson, Mr. Stewart and family,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The iteration by Mr. SUMMER of England's blame in recognizing a state of belligerency in bread of rebellion in this country seems to the womanish. How could a free Government withdraw its protection from subjects trading with a great country merely because a riot or rebellion was going on there?

The following letter from General ROSEGRANS appears in the Columbus (Ohio) State Journal: SAN RAFAEL, Cal., Sept. 11. 1869. MY DEAR GENERAL: Your favor of the 9th ult. is before me. Having been mislaid, it has remained unanswered till now.
The fourth annual State Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association of the State of New-York met here Tuesday afternoon. R. R. McBURNEY, of New-York City, was unanimously elected President.

SEPT. 23-In steamship Palmyra, for Liverpool.- R. C. Perkins, Jas. J. Ralston, Edward Patten, Miss Webster, Miss E. De Benkelaer, Edward Braggiotti R Thomas Scully, Alfred Pearson, Duncan A. McTavish, Mr. and Mrs. M. Fitzpatrick, Cornte Michel Dzieduszyeki, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Reushan. SEPT. 23.- In steamship North America, for St. Thomas and Brazil.

The French Minister of Foreign Affairs and Mr. BURLINOAME have completed arrangements for establishing improved relations between France and China on a basis of mutual conciliation. The French representatives in China have been instructed to follow the new policy.

The steamer Moses Taylor arrived from the North at a late hour on Sunday night, having on board Ex-Secretary SEWARD and party. Having made an extended tour through the seaports of Oregon, Washington Territory and Alaska, the excursionists return in excellent health and spirits.

The President of the Stock Exchange yesterday read to the Board a communication from a member of the large banking firm of VANDE-VENTER Co., of No. 17 Wall-street, announcing that they would not be able to deliver either the stock or the gold for able to deliver either the stock or the gold for which they had contracted.

General BUTLER'S speech to the Agricultural Association in Worcester, Mass., yesterday, totally lacks the point and spirit he generally manages to infuse into his public addresses, and is very tame and cautious.

At about 9:30 o'clock last night an oil train on the Erie Railway at Penhorn, N. J.,caught lire, and was destroyed, with 2,000 barrels of oil and a large amount of property that was situated near the track.

The Executive Committee of the National Capital Convention, to be held here on the 20th of October, with members of the Press and other citizens, held a meeting to-night. The Governors of the following States have responded to their invitations, and will send delegations:

United States Treasury Agent JOHN A. CLARVOE this morning arrested Captain LEONARD, a famous counterfeiter. Upon the prisoner were found between three and four thousand dollars in twenties, tens and fives upon national banks, and about $1,000 in twenty-five cent notes. The notes were well executed in the highest style of art.

For Sometime past it has been the custom of Mr. CHARLES M. ??. Assistant Treasurer of the Harlem Railroad Company, to proceed to the Fifth National Bank, in Third avenue, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh streets, two or three mornings in each week and procure considerable sums of money. y.

CARLOTTA PATTI CONCERTS. About ten years ago a French writer named D'ALEMBERT returned to Paris after a brief tour through the United States, and in a small volume of sketches offered to the public the results of his voyage.
We announced a few days since that some thirty gunboats were building in this port for the Spanish Government, to be used, as we apprehended, against the insurgent Cubans.

The Department of the Dwelling, in the southwesterly quarter of the Rink, is a most interesting portion of the American Institute Fair, and should be inspected by every householder. It is divided into groups, and comprises apparatus for warning, lighting and ventilating residences; implements for washing: Kitchen ware; building accessories,

To-day will be, as yesterday was, entirely quiet, for no sates will be attempted. The results of those made entirely satisfactory, and have encouraged owners of other places of suburban property to place them in the hands of the anetioneers.

Mr. SUMNER'S speech has received very general attention here. In official circles it is looked upon as an intimation that if any other course of action is pursued than that indicated in this speech, it will be at the peril of Mr. SUMNER'S displeasure.

An accident by which the lives of SEBRON HARGROVE and JAMES GILBERT were lost, and a considerable amount of property destroyed, occurred near Kingville to the night express train of the South Carolins Railroad about 4 o'clock Saturday morning.

The Times to-day has an editorial on the present situation of affairs in France. It says: "If the Emperor is now recovered his conduct cannot easily be accounted for. The new Constitution may be regarded as already virtually in vigor.

On the 18th of last month a desperate attempt was made by the enemies of the Government to get up a revolution in this city. The conspirators, it appears, bribed with money some forty or fifty soldiers of MONAGA'S division, and it was settled that on the evening of the day in question these soldiers should mutiny and kill their officers,...

Important dispatches have been received from Lord GRANVILLE in reference to the admission of British Columbia to the Confederation of Canada. He strongly urges upon Governor MUSOROVE and the Council the propriety and advantage of a union.

The clergymen in Salem, Mass., are preparing a memorial requesting the Governor to abstain hereafter from appointing a Fast Day. Chief Justice CHASE, it is reported, has recently invested $22,000 in a tract of land of forty acres and a handsome residence just outside of Washington.

The excitement in Wall-street on Wednesday, as already reported through our Money column of yesterday. was at fever heat through the forenoon on New-York Central and the other so-called Vanderbilt Railways. It was at white heat late in the day on Gold.

R. T. DANIEL, Chairman of the Conservative State Central Committee, publishes a card this morning stating that there is not "even the color of truth" in the newspaper statement that General CANBY ever intimated that the test oath would not be required if he (CANBY) could be made Senator.

AYMAR.--On Thursday, Sept 23, JULIA C. F. wife of William R. Aymar, in the ?? year of her ages. The relatives and friends of the ?? are requested to attend the funeral from her late residence. Waverley-st., between Oakland and Palisade ??., Hudson City. N. J., on Saturday. 25th inst., st 1 o'clock. ALLEN.--At Dover. N. J. on Wednesday. Sept 22, JABEZ L. ALLEN. aged 63 years.

We regret to announce the death of a well-known publisher, Mr. JAMES SADLIER, which took place at Far Rockaway, on Tuesday. The deceased was of the firm of D. J. SADLIER Co., the Catholic publishing house, and was about fifty years of age.

The book trade sale was concluded yesterday at the rooms of Messrs. LEVANT, STREBEIGH Co., in Clinton Hall. ROBERTS BROTHERS, of Boston, offered a consignment of photograph albums, which realized good prices. A quantity of elegant church services and prayer books offered by W M. RUTTED Co. realized fair prices. An elegant bible, hound in Turkey-red.

The large iron steam-propeller Rattlesnake ran on a rock at Hell Gate, at 9 o'clock A.M. yesterday, making a hole in her bottom. Her Captain was compelled to run her ashore at the mouth of the Kills, between Randall's Island and Westchester County, where she now lies submerged, loaded with coal from Philadelphia, bound East.

The Times, in an article on the cotton supply, says: "Mr. ASHFORD and Mr. BRIGHT, by different methods, arrive at the same end, namely, that nothing is wanted but cotton. More cotton would start the mills, dispel distress and silence the clamors against free trade.

JOHN FOGARTY, a cartman, residing in Fourteenth-street, Gowanus, and TIMOTHY MOHIDE, a laborer, residing in Twentieth-street, South Brooklyn, got into a guarrel on Wednesday afternoon, while both were at work on an excavation in Carroll-street, near Eighth-avenue, which resulted in MOHIDE'S beating FOGARTY to death with a shovel.

In the National Musical Convention to-day, L. H. SOUTHARD, of Baltimore, delivered an address on music as an element of worship. He protested against the adoption of vulgar or popular music in churches. He did not deem the music now in use adapted to cougregational singing, and consequently favoured organized choirs.

The steamer Guidion, hence for Little Rock, Struck a snag at Red Frok, Arkansas River, on Tuesday, and sunk in four feet of water. She had a valuable cargo on board, which will be lost. The boat will be raised again.

We are happy to observe that the Democratic Convention yesterday declared itself unconditionally against the adoption of the new Constitution. If any thing would justify rebellion, it would be doubling the terms of judges such as we find ourselves liable to be cursed with under the present system of selection.

The following is published as a correct statement of facts in connection with the recent defalcation: Mr. CHRISTIAN, Inspector of the Bank of Montreal, in the course of his inspection, found reason to apprehend irregularities of a serious character on the part of the Manager, Mr. HARRIS.

The trial of WALLACE McDANIELS for the murder of THOMAS E. CORWIN, at the Rosendale Hotel, near McComb's Dam, Morrisania, on the 22d of May last, was commenced in the Court of Over and Terminer at White Plains yesterday. J. C. DRYMAN, Esq., District-Attorney, appearing for the people, and CHAUNCEY SHAFFER And JOHN BATES, Esq., for the prisoner.

The nine Republican Assembly District Conventions of Kings County met last night for the purposxe of electing delegates to the Syracuse Convention to be held on the 29th inst. The following were chosen: First District.--State--Isaac, Beurne, C. r. Phillips. Judiciary--L. M. Peek, M. C. Earle, J. B. King.

The proprietress of a boarding-house at No. 97 Market-street, yesterday morning called upon Captain WARLOW, at the Madison-street Police Station,. and informed him that on Sunday three men, who had been temporarily boarding there, drove up to the door in a coach and removed from it to their rooms three bags,

The excitement in Wall-street yesterday was even greater than on the previous day, when the "street" was suddenly startled by the rapid descent in the price of Central Railroad stock, and the equally rapid advance in the quotations of gold.

Our readers are probably not aware that the harbor of New-York is at the present moment being made a naval depot by the Spanish Government, and that in this port a fleet of gunboats is now being completed for service in behalf of that nation.

General BENJAMIN F. BUTLER was the orator at the Worcester County Agricultural Society's Fair, at Worcester, Mass., which opened yesterday and continues to-day. His address was characteristic, and somewhat out of the customary line pursued by agricultural fair orators.

Our neighbors of Portage City are in a fair way to obtain notoriety fully equal to that of the new cities out on the plains. Last evening we gave the details of the murder of BRITT by SPAIN, and the subsequent lynching of SPAIN by the mob. This morning PAT. WILDRICK was taken from the Portage Jail about 1 o' Clock, and hung to a tree.

The Nationals of Washington suffered another defeat yesterday, this time at the hands of the Atlantics of Brooklyn. Their playing was much superior to what it was on Tuesday in the game with the Mutuals. The match was a fine exhibition on both sides, and for seven innings the result was doubtful.

A plan has been put forward in England, by several influential legal societies, for the amalgamation of the two branches of tile law as now practiced by barristers and attorneys. Such a scheme will probably convince the Tory Party that England is " Americanizing her institutions" with startling rapidity,

To the Editor of the Providence Journal: To-day, Sept. 22, I visited the Cove Foundry, for the purpose of witnessing the effective force of the Sturtevant Blower, and my attention was called, by Mr. McLAUGLIN,I well-borer, to the discovery of two beds of coal by him, in sinking a well for water in the foundry yard.

Soon after 6 o'clock A. M. Wednesday the Harbor Police found the body of a man about 70 years of age, having gray hair and whiskers, and wearing a dark sack coat and vest, and dark brown pantaloons, floating in the North River, off the Battery. It was towed ashore and taken to Castle Garden.

The Detroit Free Press rates the Postmaster-General in the most insulting terms for having promised to recommend Congress to allow Senator RAMSEY something beyond the pay of an ordinary Special Mail Agent, for his services in going abroad to negotiate a postal treaty with France.

The ladies of the Mount Vernon Association gratefully acknowledge the following contributions of articles of agriculture and furniture, at their valuation, received since the last publication: C. G. Crane, $7; Mr. Gould Son, $5; Gelliff Co., $20; N. N. Halsted, $43; Mrs. James S. Taylor, $39;
The Democratic Convention of this State, and the Republican Convention in Massachusetts, have assisted in shadowing forth the policy which the two great parties are prepared to submit to the country.

The delegates to the ninth annual Synod of the United Presbyterian Church assembled last evening in the Seventh-avenue Presbyterian Church, corner of Twelfth-street. Rev. W. W. BARR. of Philadelphia, presided. At its conclusion Rev. D. S. McHENRY, of Lansingville, N. Y., offered a prayer, and the retiring Moderator. Rev. J. J. BARR, called the Synod to order.

The September Term of the Pike County Peen.) Court opened at Milford on Monday, GEORGE R. BARRETT, President Judge of the Twenty-second Judicial District, presiding; GEO. T. HELLER and WM. WESTFALL, Esqs., Associates.

The twelfth anniversary of the Fulton-street Prayer Meeting was celebrated in the North Dutch Church yesterday at noon. This edifice was beautifully decorated with flowers, and was crowded with people.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to express to you the amazement which I, in common with many men if the all parties feel, at the unwanted attack of your correspondent "Chemung," upon the character, political and private, of TREMAN G. YOUNG-LOVE, Speaker of the Assembly.

The Kings Connty Board of supervisors, yesterday, resolved to award the contract for boiler and heating apparatus for the news extension of the Almshouse to FELIX CAMPRELL, for $20,638. The Country Treasurer was authorized to issue certificates of the country indebtedness for $100,000.
The long strike of the coal-miuers has become as completely a thing of the past as the Avondale disaster, which, with terrible emphasis, marked its culmination in the northern coalfield.

This was the third day of the meeting of the National Universalists' Concention. A woman's mass meeting was held at Dr. HARTZELL'S Church, at 8:30 this morning, to Organize a Universalist Association, and paise a Murray Centenary Fund. Three hundred names were appended to the list of membership.

In a brief conversation yesterday between two or three of our citizens and President GRANT, the address recently issued by the Republicans of this country was referred to, and some explanations were made to His Excellency respecting the character of those by whom it was put forth, and the purpose of the general movement of which it was an exponent and part.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In 1862 I was Captain of a party of about 200 men going to the gold fields of British Columbia, traveling the most northern route, and the first party who ever went that way. I have been written to by many young men wishing to go overland to Montana, and wishing me to be their guide,

The California Pioneer excursion party were confidently expected t arrive in this City yesterday, but did not make their appearance. It was ascertained that the programme of the excursion trip had been changed since the start at Sacramento on the 16th inst.,
The long strike of the coal-miuers has become as completely a thing of the past as the Avondale disaster, which, with terrible emphasis, marked its culmination in the northern coalfield.

The Department of Agriculture furnishes a summary of the crop reports. A summary is given showing the mean temperature and rain-fall of the several States for July and August, as contrasted with those months in last year.

The members composing the California Pioneer Association arrived in this City early yesterday morning, after a rapid and pleasant railway journey of 3,187 miles, commencing at Sacramento on the 16th inst. The most of them engaged rooms at the Astor House, but some few went to the Fifth-avenue Hotel.

Perhaps the reader may have lately noticed the following modest advertisement in several New-York papers: Wanted, a comfortable home for a gentleman, his wife and two young children; either a small furnished house at a low rent or cheap rooms with board;

There were over seventy complaints against policemen before commissioner BRENNAN yesterday morning. Patrolman GEORGE W. MCCELLOCH, of the Mounted Police, attached to the sub-precinct of Yonkers, was complained of by Roundsman WESTON for not properly patrolling his post for the space of three hours on the morning of Sept. 9.
The Gaulois asserts that France has sent a note to Prussia and Baden declaring that she will regard the annexation of the Grand Duchy by Prussia as a cusus belli.

Prince ARTHUR left by special train at 11:30 o'clock, with JOHN A. McDONALD, for Niagara Falls. There was an immense crowd at the station, which cheered loudly. The Guard of Honor escorted the party to the station.

The trial of WALLACE McDANIELS for the murder of THOMAS E. CORWIN, at the Resendale Hotel, was continued yesterday. the prisoner, on being placed on the stand in his own behalf, testified the Corwin came into the bar-room a short time previous to the fatal affray, and used abusive words to him, and attempted to injure him with a chair;

The Ninth Annual Synod of the United Presbyterian Church continued its session, yesterday morning, in the Seventh-avenue Presbyterian Church, corner of Twelfth-street. Rev. W. W. BARR, Moderator, occupied the chair. The Synod procceded to the election of a Moderator for the season of 1869.

This evening's Picayune says: "For some time past investigations have been going on in the Custom-house of the books as far back as June. It has been discovered that during KELLOGG'S administration of customs large frauds were perpetrated in a manner so bold and flagrant that it would be an insult to intelligent officials then in office to suppose they were not cognizant of the fact.

The City Council to-day appropriated $10,000 to arrange the fair grounds for the State Fair, to be held on the 2d of November. General CANBY had permitted his correspondence with prominent Virginians, relative to the test oath.

The Houston--street Railroad is to be opened on or about the 5th of October. Empowered by an act passed by the New-York State Legislature May 6, 1868. entitled "An act to authorize the construction of a railroad in Avenue C and other streets and avenues in the City of New-York," corporation,

The Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows was net in session to-day ,and the members are enjoying an excursion round the Bay by railroad, by the way of Alameda and San Jose. The Cincinnati "Red Stockings" reached Saeramento to-day, and will arrive in this city to night.

The Diocesan Convention of the Episcopal Church, which is now in session, excites some attention, more from its connection with the "Cheeny trial" than from anything else. That the diecese is High Church is evident from the voting, for the Convention has passed a resolutioon declaring the proceedings of the Excelesisatieal Court, which Judge JAMESON enjoined, as regular, and in accordance with the cannons in all respects.

The Thirtieth-street Methodist Church was filled last evening with an audience interested in the presentation of a testimonial to Rev THOMAS WALSH, whose son wasdrowned lately while on an excursion. The admission was by tickets, and about $500 were realized for the benefit of Mr. WALSH.

BARRY-PACKARD.--In Brooklyn, at the residence of the bride's mother, on Thursday, Sept. 23, by Rev. Father Francoisola, JAS. J. BARRY, U.S. Navy, of Baltimore, to LILLIE E. PACKARD, of Brooklyn. Baltimore and San Francisco papers please copy.

A most melancholy accident occurred on the Canada shore of the Niagara River, in the viemity of the Falls, at about noon to-day. A party consisting of one gentleman and four ladies, all belonging in Providence, R. L., stopped over here wide on their way home from Buffalo, and after viewing the sights on this side crossed over on the Canada side.

"LES MOUSQUETAIRES DE LA REINE" AT THE ACADEMY. The French opera at the Academy last night was a decided success. We could not truthfully say of the first performance of "La Juive" that it was everything that could be wished; but the first performance of "Les Mousquetaries de la Reme" very nearly deserves no less praise.

A team of horses attached to a wagon, belonging to HENRY BRESLIN, of No. 217 Second-street, yesterday can away, and in their flight ran over and knocked down LOUIS OGHT, aged 7 years, of No. 24 Clinton-street, instantly killing him. No one was in the wagon at the time.

Mr. GEORGE PEABODY said at the meeting of the Trustees of the Peabody Institute in Baltimore on Wednesday, that he was about to leave that city, probably for the last time. The next morning he went to Philadelphia, whence he will come to this City to pass a few days.

Pere HYACINTHE has left his convent and gone to the home of his parents, where he will await the decision of the Council. LONDON, Sept. 24.--The Times to-day, in an article on the letter of Father HYACINTHE, says : "It is to the Pope and his Jesuit advisers that we are indebted for HYACINTHE.

We quote from the Baltimore papers Mr. PEABODY'S letter making an additional gift of $400,000 to the Peabody Institute in that city: To the President and Trustees of the Peabody Institute of the City of Baltimore: GENTLEMEN: Among the objects of my present visit to my native land was my desire to see the workings and ascertain the success of the institute which bears my name and is in your charge.

The views of a United states Senator and especially one from Massachusetts on the present financial exigencies of our country will command great attention, and particularly as the time approaches for settling the issues of the next Congressional election.

A number of papers in other cities are still commenting upon the supposed defeat in the Keeknk Convention of a resolution calling for a removal of the capital. It happens that the resolution was not defeated, but was adopted almost unanimously.

When he infurmed the Magistrate that the prisoner had been charged with stealing a borse. The Court-martial appointed to try Lieutenant-Commander HENRY B SEELY, late of United States steamer Pawnee, on charges of maltreatment of seamen, began taking testimony in the case to-day. Rear-Admiral THATCHER presides. The case will probably occupy several days.

Speaking yesterday of "A Spanish Fleet in New-York," we used the following language: "They are built by a friendly Power to be used as a part of her coast guard, and in the present state of our relations with Spain we have no more authority to detain them than she would have to detain an American frigate which might casually touch for coal and water at Cadiz or Ferrol."

Referring to an editorial in yesterday's TIMES in relation to Spain, a correspondant writes: "I think there is a current error into which you fall in supposing that Spain has nothing to lose by war with us. In 1863 her shipping with foreign and colonial countries amounted to about 500,000 tons, and employed about 50,000 sailors, besides her coasting trade.

Father CHARLES LOYSON HYACINTHE, whose late independent course in Paris has excited such universal remark not only in the religious world but among all classes, was born at Orleans, France, in 1827, and completed his education at Pau.

A Committee of the Prison Association of the State of New-York is to meet in conference with the Wardens and physicians of the Sing Sing, Auburn, and Clinton Prisons at Sing Sing, on Saturday, Oct. 9, to prepare a memorial to the Legislature, recommending reforms in the conduct of the penal institution of the State.

The St. Louis Republican urges a now nomenclature in the matter of Pacific Railroads. It says the present names are so confusing that few persons besides railroad experts and newspaper folks can disentangle them-and even they sometimes get bewildered in the mazy labyrinth.

We publish this morning a decision in bankruptcy, which we think will be a surprise, and an unpleasant one, to some people. It involves the question of the effect of a voluntary assignment, without preferences, made by a debtor in failing circumstances.

The London Times, in an article on the recent letter of Father HYACINTHE, thinks that the Pope and his Jesuit advisers are responsible for his action, for had not the idea of a Council startled the Father from his quiet, he would have continued a inminary in the Church of which he is now considered a firebrand.

A telegram informs us that Lord WEST-BURY has been appointed Lord Justice of the Court of Appeals in Chancery, rice Sir C. J. SELWYN. People who remember the name which Sir RICHARD BETHEL made when at the Bar will not be surprised to learn that a liberal Government has rescued him from the comparative inaction in which he has lately been spending his days.

The tremendous struggle of the bulls and bears in gold culminated before noon yesterday amid scenes of frantic excitement, which, it is not too much to say, were never paralleled even in the Gold Room.

A report in favor of the act of consolidation of Hudson County into one great city was made yesterday by the Committee appointed to investigate the measure by the Hudson County Board of Freeholders. The committee state that the proposed measure would lessen taxation for every municipality, and push for ward improvements at a rate that would materially enhance the value of property.

MADRID, Sept. 24.--Since the return of General PRIM to Madrid, the language of the American Minister has been more conciliatory. LONDON, Sept. 24.--The Standard to-day says: "Whatever her legitimate claims to Cuba may be. Spain labors under a disadvantage in having to prosecute them in the face of the susceptibilities of the American people. While she is herself in a condition of revolution.

The Constitution and By-laws adapted by the Musical Convention designate that the name of the organizations shall he "The National Musical Congress," and provide that the active members shall he delegates from choral and other societies having a like object, the said societies being enutled to representation the rein upon the annual payment into the treasury of the sum of $100 for every ten encumbers of said society.

To-day, in accordance with the old custom, will be a day of test: no sales will be attempted, but the auctioneers will be busy perfecting their arrangements for the week to come, which promises to be a very busy one. A number of important suburban sales will be made, among them of our on Tuesday, by Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER, of 500 building lots at the Six Bonds.

An exhibition was made in Fifth-avenue, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth streets, last evening, of a new method for improving the light of street lamps, consisting of a small reflector of corrugated French plate glass. It was witnessed by Messrs. CONNOR and GEDNEY, of the Common Council; Mr. A. NEILL, a civil engineer, and others.

Yesterday a trotting match for $1,000 a side and a premium of $375 added by the Fair Grounds Association, between M. RODEO'S brown gelding Captain Gill and W. H. BORSHT'S brown gelding Old Put, came off on the Prospect Park Course.
BLAKSLEE Co.'s foundry at Sing Sing was destroyed by fire at 3 o'clock on Friday morning. A large frame building adjoining was slightly burned. BLAKSLEE Co.'s loss is about $5,000, fully insured.

The case of GRIFFIN, the engineer, on trial at this place for causing the Mast Hope disaster, was concluded last night. Intense interest was manifested in the proceedings throughout, and the Court-room was crowded.

The climax of folly and effrontery in the recent combination to advance the price and corner the supply of gold in Wall-street, was reached about noon yesterday. The whole gambling fabric, boastingly clamed to have been reared on thirty or forty millions, fell at the single flask of the telegraph form Washington ordering an extra sale from the Treasury of only four millions.
The steamship Columbia, which left Havana on Sept. 18, reached this port yesterday. Purser OSCAR CROCHERON has our thanks for the prompt delivery of out Cuban and Mexican cerrespondence.

The usual Saturday afternoon concert took place yesterday in the Central park. The attendance was as large as usual, notwithstanding the fact that the weather was somewhat threatening and that the autumnal winds are already beginning to strew the lawns with the dying treasures of the year.

Dr. DORR, late rector of Christ Church, has left, among other bequests to societies, the following: To the Selectmen of the town of Salisbury, Essex County, Mass., $500, in trust, to be invested in real estate, and the income to be applied to repairing and improving Point Cemetery.

Since the installation of the new Federal law officers in this City, rapid and energetic measures have been taken against United States offenders. Preliminary proceedings have been conducted in an exceedingly large number of cases, and where guilt has been conclusively established after a fair and impartial examination, the defendants have been promptly held to await the action of the Grand Jury.

The Atlantics and Stars had an exhibition game at the Capitoline Grounds yesterday for the benefit of the Avondale sufferers. As the match had not been previously announced, the attendance and the proceeds were small.

The news brought to us by the Atlantic Cable proves that the continued depression of trade in the cotton districts of England fairly alarms and bewilders the people. Lancashire is rapidly declining; everywhere mills are being closed or worked half-time only, and trained artisans are emigrating to this country in large numbers.

The appearance of the new Post Office grounds changes every week. Work now has progressed so far that to-morrow the foundation of the first pillar will be commenced, at the southwest corner. There are sixth-four of these supports to be built on the outer line, besides what will be necessary for the interior of the building.

A party of sixty immigrants arrived hero by the Orange and Alexandria train yesterday evening, direct from Sweden. They sailed from Gottenburg, via England, and arrived here in just nineteen days. This is the quickest trip ever made by emigrants. The destination of the party is Water Valley, Miss. Many of them are mechanics,

Major-General GEORGE H. THOMAS returned to the city yesterday, after an extended visit to Sitka and other military points in the North. As Commander of the Pacific Coast, he determined, soon after his arrival last Spring, to visit and inspect all the principal military posts of the North.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The statement published this morning that I have consented to let Dexter trot in a race, is wholly erroneous. I have never let one of my horses trot in a race, and have never thought of letting one of them trot in a race under any circumstances.

Governor MERRILL, of Iowa, is urged by some of the Western papers to appoint Gen. VANDEVER to fill out the unexpired term of Senater GRIMES. He was President of the Commercial Convention, at Keokuk, and is brought forward as one fully competent to urge the necessity of river improvements.

Sir PATRICK KEITH MURRAY, of Ochtertyre Bart., is at present on a visit to this country. He is the representative of one of the oldest and most honored families of Scotland, and is the direct descendant of PATRICK MORAY, or Murray, of Ochtertyre, in Perthshire, whose father was a son of Sir DAVID MURRAY, of Tullibardine, progenitor of the Duke of ATHOLE.

The failure of the Police to seatter the gangs of rowdies which hang about the street corners in various parts of Brooklyn is beginning to show that one important police duty is left unfulfilled, greatly to the discomfort and danger of respectable and law-abiding citizens passing to and from about their business after dark. The latest ease illustrating this condition of affairs is that which took place in Greenpoint of Friday night about 12 o'clock.

General MCCLELLAN and wife left the White Mountains on Tuesday, and stopped at Brattlbore, where he was serenaded in the evening at the Wesselhoeft House. A large concourse of citizens assembled to pay their respects to the General,

The Second Adventists, at their recent camp meeting at Springfield, Mass., reported an income for the Eastern branch of $20,000. During the year they have printed 2,000,000 pages of books and tracts. They have half a dozen missions among the freedmen and eighteen colored preachers. It was estimated that 5,000 Adventists were present from all parts of the country.

The Germans of the Sixth Senatorial District are hard at work to throw off the shackles of Tammany Hall at the incoming elections by an independent organization, in order to nominate their own candidates. The German independent central organization, which organized on Monday, last, numbers thus far over thirty clubs in this district, where the German--American vote is largely in the majority.

Much interest has been felt in the Senatorial Question in this County, from the fact that Chautauqua has conceded to us the nomination.
