Sept. 24, at Lebanon, N. H. JENNIE. daughter of Mrs. Caroline A. Harris, of this City.

The Times, this morning, in a leader on the Cuban question, says: "He must he a clever man who can determine the intentions of the United States with respect to Cuba. There are two parties in the States; one favors non-intervention, and the other approves of Minister SICKLES' course; and finally, there is President GRANT, who vibrates between the two.

The death of Lady PALMERSTON, known here some time back by telegraph, is noticed at length by the latest London journals. Many of the articles, by a curious choice of negative description, dwell at length upon what the deceased lady was not.

The Gaulois' statement that the annexation of Baden by Prussia would be considered a cause of war by France is denied by the Constitutionnel. The Spanish Government, it is said, intends to force the Bishops to take the date to the new Constitution.

Yesterday the Governor gave the final directions for the completion of the funding of the entire public debt of the State, including the Holford Bonds. Action upon these bonds has been delayed thus far on account of his desire to review the whole question before taking final action, as also on account of his illness of the last two weeks.

A dispatch from St. Paul says a deluge of water fell on Thursday and Friday nights, and the Mississippi River is again on the rise. All the bottom lands of the Minnesota River are overflowed, and the hay crop in that region, as well as in the large prairies, in rained.

The Strike of the miners in 1868 has been referred to and stated to have been a failure so far as concerned its ostensible object of procuring the enforcement of the Eight-hour law which the Pennsylvania Legislature had just enacted.

HENRY PLACIDE, the eminent American comedian, was born in Charleston, S. C., Sept. 8, 1799. His father, Monsieur ALEXANDRE PLACIDE, was an eminent patomimist and dancer on the tight-rope, (it was said that he was the instructor of the Count D'ARTOIS, the brother of LOUIS XIV., in that art,) a very graceful performer and estimable man.

The Government intends to compel the Bishops to take the oath of adherence to the new Constitution. It is officially announced that a reduction of five per cent. Is to be made in the salaries of all colonial officers.

A severe rain-storm, accompanied by high winds from the southeast, prevailed nearly all day yesterday. Beyond the blowing down of a few signs and shutters and the amputation of the limbs of some of the trees in the public parks no especial damage is reported in this City.

Mr. Senator SUMNER thinks the Cubans are in no sense entitled to be treated as belligerents, and that in reference to Spain "the true rule for us is non-intervention, except in the way of good offices.

The Brooklyn evening schools open, after a nine-months' recess, (nearly,) to-night. The session only lasts three months. These schools, seven of which are for white pupils and two for colored, are situated as follows: No. 1, Middagh-street; No. 2, Warren-street, near Smith; No. 3, Fifth-street, near South Fifth-street, E. D." No. 4, South Second-street, E. D.:

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, Genera Agent.

To-day opens a very busy week; the public have had quite a breathing spell; no sales have been attempted since Thursday last, and the people are now ready for another. The demand for tickets at the different auctioneers' offices, and the excellent attendance at the sales already made, prove how general the interest is in suburban sales,

A man named COLLINS, residing at No. 194 Delancey-street, was found at a later hour on Saturday night, on the railroad track in Goerck-street near Stanton-street, with a fractured leg, he having been run over by a Forty-second-street ear.

About five hundred people responded to the call for a meeting of those favoring the expulsion of the Bible from the schools. The meeting was disorderly. Resolutions favoring the expulsion of the Bible were presented, and a vote taken, so near a the that the Chairman could not decide by voices, and a division was called for.

In steamship India, for Liverpool.--Fred. Cyrus, Geo. Forbes, Adam Innes, Mr. Bunyan, Geo. Wood, Rev. Fred. Hall, W. Kalkman, Miss Burnside, Mrs. Jos. Kellv. Fred. Scholfield, Mary Ann Scholfield, W. H. Robertson, Wm. Hall, Patrick Trainer, and others in the steerage.

Professor CHARLES W. ELIOT is to be formally inaugurated as President of Harvard College on Tuesday, Oct. 12. Secretary BOUTWELL has tendered to C. C. ESTY, of Framingham, Mass., the position of Revenue Supervisor for the District of Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut. Mr. ESTY is at present Assessor for the Seventh District of Massachusetts.

The Ladies' Union Relief Association, of which Mrs. JOHN A. KENNEDY is President, is doing a good work among the deserving families of deceased soldiers in this City. As the cold weather approaches the demands for relief are continually increasing the number, and it is the purpose of the Association to hold a great fair, in December,

One of the effects of rust on cotton is to dry up the half-grown bolls and contract and harden the shell or case which covers the lint. It rarely occurs that this outer covering is so much hardened and contracted as to prevent the boll from cracking or opening a little.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A young man of good address and genteel appearance has, within a few months past, called upon the distressed friends of numerous persons whom the newspapers have announced to be missing from their homes, and representing himself to be a detective on the Police of this or some other city, has imposed false stories of the whereabouts of missing persons,

Dr. DORR, late Rector of Christ Church, has left, among other bequests to societies, the following: To the Selectmen of the town of Salisbury, Essex County, Mass., $500, in trust, to be invested in real estate, and the income to be applied to repairing and improving Point Cemetery.

The appointment of Mrs. PORTER, of Covington, to be Postmaster of Louisville, which has been whispered about in circles for six weeks more, is at last confirmed by our Washington dispatches. She was commissioned yesterday.

As so much interest and anxiety have been felt about the report of a mutiny on board the United States frigate Sabine, we take much pleasure in publishing an extract from a letter from Commander WALKER, to his wife, dated at Lisbon, Sept. 4.
The worthy citizens who consider they perform a heroic act in shooting or stabbing a fellow-creature unawares must be proud of their record this week.

The troubles around the Gold Room and to Wall-street, resulting from the explosion of a wicked conspiracy on Friday, are not yet over, perhaps, but so far as the outside public are concerned the measured of the mischief, it is hoped, has been taken.

Mrs. TILLINGHAST, who was injured by the accident yesterday, is better, and will recover. YATES, the absconding banker's clerk, was arrested by JACOB PFEIFFER, a United States Custom-house officer, while attempting to cross the bridge, and the money recovered.
The Combatants over the price of gold in wall-street have now had two days of rest and freedom from uproar, and will to-day be under better conditions than they have enjoyed for some time.

A large package, supposed to contain dry goods, and marked "NEWCOMB, ENDICOTT Co., Detroit, Mich.," was found on Saturday night, concealed in a sugar hogshead at the corner of king and Washington streets. It is supposed to have been stolen, and is now at the Greenwich-street Police Station-house.

JACOB McCABE, aged 27, a native of Ireland, and residing at No. 325 West Thirty-seventhstreet, was arraigned before Justice LEDWITH yesterday, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by Officer JONES, of the Twentieth Precinct, who had arrested him on a charge of having brutally outraged a woman named MARGARET MAHER, of No, 527 West Fortieth-street.

The lower class of New-York sports and rowdies generally, appear to have chosen Sunday mornings, and to have selected Laurel Hill and Cypress Hills, Long Island, for the scenes of their particular orgies, when all opportunities of gratifying themselves in the Metropolitan City seemed to be shut off.

MLLE. CAROLTTA PATTI. There is a real luxury in being able to say that a thing is good without adding any of those qualifications which the mingled duties of justice to the public an consideration for the difficulties of artists so commonly impose.
Mr. GEORGE WALKER, who went to Europe, in May, as an agent of Massachusetts to place its new loan upon the European market, has taken passage for home in the steamer of Oct. 12.

About 5 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the kindling-wood and meat-choping establishment of GRIER BUNDELL. Nos. 47 and 49 Varet-street, Williamsburg. The fire made quick work, aand soon the concern was inashes. The damage to the building, stock and machinery is estimated at about $15,000. The machinery is insured in the Merchants' Exchange Insurance Company for $1,500.

HENRY PLACIDE, one of the greatest favorites of the American stage, of whom more good has been said and writ and less evil than of any man, perhaps, in America, is now an invalid, living in great seclusion at his pleasant retreat at Babylon, on Long Island.

The order sent by the Secretary of the Treasury to-night for the October sales of gold and purchase of bonds further indicates the easy condition of the Treasury finances, and the confidence of the Administration in the continued success of its efforts to increase the revenue.

The First Ward Independent Social Club gave a picnic on Saturday at LANDMANN's Hamilton Park, in Third-avenue, near Sixty-sixth-street. Among those participating in the festivities was Wm. P. O'BRIEN. of No. 6 Pearl-street, who after dark became involved, as is supposed, in a quarrel with EDWARD BUCKLEY, of No. 16 West-street, and THOMAS DOWD.

In steamship City of Paris, from Liverpool. W. Hogan, Captain Huyshe, Captain Williams, M. J. Macdonald, P. Duffy, C. S. Burns, Rev. J. H. Eccleston, E. Baker, P. E. Mandel, J. w. Barstow, R. Suydam, Geo. Strawbride, F. de Armarod, Rev. T. Halpin, Mrs. Graves, Mrs. Lyons and infant. M. A. Collins and infant, Mrs. Downs, G. H. Mattield, wife and infant, M. Burns, Miss Burns, W. Cadman, Mr. Marsh and Wife Master Marsh,

The Republican Union State Convention is to be held in Syracuse on Wednesday, Sept. 29, to nominate candidates for the several State offices to be filled at the election on the 2d of November. The representation allowed in the Convention is one delegate from each Assembly District,

The grand structure of German unity is the central frame round which the policy of Europe for the moment turns. National unity is intrinsically a noble idea, and, wherever you find it, it appeals to all generous sympathies--unity America; unity in Italy; unity in Germany.

By the arrival at this port of the steamship Bienville, which lett Havana Sept. 21, we are in receipt of late news from Cuba. Purser A. T. ALEXANDER, of the Bienville, will accept our thanks for the prompt delivery of our correspondence and papers.

Yesterday afternoon, Dr. ALBERT T. SIMMONS, who was imprisoned by the Cubans several months age, and whose sufferings and the deliverance were noted recently in the TIMES, applied to commissioner OSBORN for an attachment against the Spanish gunboats now being built at this port as security for the damages claimed.

The Daily News to-day reports that the object of Lord CLARENDON'S visit to Paris was to announce to NAPOLEON an arrangement between Austria, Prussia. Russia and England to preserve peace and check the contagion of revolution in France in case of the contagion of revolution in France in case of the Emperor's death, but not to thwart German unity.

Advices from St. Domingo have been received up to the 9th inst. BAEZ had defeated the rebels who were besieging Azua. The news of the defeat of SALNAVE (BAEZ'S ally) was sorrowfully received by the latter's partisans.

Dr. C. F. HALL, one of the most successful of Arctic explorers, has returned home with a store of information concerning the fate of FRANKLIN'S party. He brings with him " the remains " of a young man who was one of the unfortunate explorers, and some articles which belonged to Sir JOHN FRANKLIN himself.

The Times, in an editorial on the relations of England and the United States, Says : " The progress and result of the negotiations on the Puget Sound question show that Americans and Englishmen keep sufficiently above the mists of national prejudices and apply the common principles of equity to the settlement of international disputes.

The London Times of yesterday, in an editorial, commends the spirit displayed in settling the Puget Sound question between the United States and England, and says that the Alabama and San Juan questions, the only ones now outstanding between the two countries, if left to the some arbitrators, could be settled on the principles of justice and equity without fear, favor or affection.

The machinery department of the American Institute exhibition this year is admitted to be the best that has ever characterized the Fairs given by this organization, and is well worthy of being closely investigated by visitors, especially such as have a talent for mechanism. The Rink, large as it is, being too small to admit of placing the various machines in the body of the

On Sunday last, the 19th, was road in the Romanist churches of this City a circular letter, apostolic, " under the ring of the lisherman," reciting the decree for the Council to be held on the day " consecrated to the immaculate conception of the Blessed Virgin, Mother of God,"

An explosion took place in the oil refinery of Mr. JOHN MAHONEY, at the intersection of Union-avenue and Fifth-street, on Bushwick Creek, yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock, caused by one of the employes recharging a still before it had been cooled after having been used, and this in disobedience to the positive orders of the proprietor.

Advices received by the Indian Department from Fort Stanton. New-Mexico, represent that the Mescalero Apache Indians are still on the war path. The citizens of San Jose, New-Mexico, report that a party of five or six of this tribe attacked four boys, who were herding sheep near that town, on the evening of the 10th of August.

To-day two large suburban sales will be made. Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER have their great sale at Rahway, N. J. The property consists of 500 choice building lots, situated on Leesville, Plainfield, Murray, St. George's, Jaques and Railroad avenues. Property in this city has of late found a ready market, at very fair prices, and from the class of persons who have applied for tickets to attend this sale, excellent results are anticipated.

The falsehood was telegraphed North from this city on Friday night that Secretary BOUTWELL refused to consent to the extra sale of gold until ordered by the President, and that the latter was persuaded into compliance by the appeals or prominent banking houses.

About 11:30 o'clock a fire was discovered in the subcellar at No. 10 Abingdon-square, running through to No. 77p Greenwich-street, filled with furniture on storage, belonging to different parties. The store on the first floor of No. 10 Abingdon-square is occupied by ROBERT TAGGET, plumber and gasfiltter, who owns the two buildings, which are five stories high, the upper part occupied as tenements.

The New-York Ecening Post advises the Methodists to sell out their "Book Concern." stop their official papers, and let their whole publishing business pass into private hands. We don't think this advice will be taken, and we doubt whether the Post really understands the matter of which it speaks.

HUIDEKOPER -- REYNOLDS.--At Meadville, Penn, on Tuesday evening. Sept. 21, by Rev., I. V. Reynolds, D. D., ARTHUR C. HUIDEKOPER, Esq., to MISS FRANCES L., daughter of Wm. Reynolds., Esq. JOHNSON -- WHITING.--At Zion Church. on Saturday, Sept. 25, by Rev. Dr. Stocking. WILLIAM JOHNSON, Esq., of Totues, England, to FRANCES HELEN, daughter of F. H. N. Whiting.

The Examining Board at the Naval Academy have admitted the following additional cadets: Frank White, of Maine; C. C. Chithean, of Ohio; E. B. Crocker, of Massachusetts; E. F. Hurd, of New-York; J. B. Culp, of Indian; J. E. Anderson, of Ohio;

An examination was held yesterday, by Justice DOWLING, in the case of JOHN W. GOULD, the Wall-street broker, who is accused of outraging the person of Mrs. ANNA MEAD, of No. 73 President-street, Brooklyn. The complainant was cross-examined at length by counsel for the defence, who sought to damage her reputation by a series of singular questions.

Yesterday the return of Dr. HALL. to NewBedford. Mass., was announced. To-day a telegram from St. Johns, N. F., notes the arrival of the Panther from the North, having on board the expedition of Dr. HAYES. It is rather a remarkable comcidence that these two noted Arctic explorers should return

Captains and Purseers of Vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibating the written authority of J. W Smionton, Genera Agent.

The market at Communipaw this morning was not overstocked, nevertheless Sales were slowly effected, butchers clamoring for a larger supply of prime Cattle and salesmen struggling for good prices, which were readily enough given for the small number of good Cattle on sale, while the inferior grades moved off very slowly.

SAMUEL BARTON, a farmer, aged 60 years, living on Gunpowder River, in Baltimore County, was found at his house, on Saturday morning, brutally murdered--his head nearly severed from his body. The suspected murderer is one WILLIAM BROWN, formerly of Terre Haute, Ind.

There is a superstition as widespread and as ancient as the human race that a fatality clings to the scene of murder, and the Burdell mansion, No. 31 Bond-street, has for years seemed to strengthen the illusion and clothe it in the robes of verity.

CORLIES.--On First Day evening, at Rahway, N. J. HANNAH S. CORLIES, in the 83d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral of the deceased from her late residence, Main st., Rahway, N. J., on Fourth Day, 29th inst., at 2 o'clock P.M., without further notice. DORRANCE.--At Bristol, Penn., on Sunday, Sept. 26 JOHN DORRANCE, in the 67th year of his age.

An application will be made at the next session of Parliament for a charter for the Union Pacific Railway, to be constructed from a point on Lake Superior, via the Red River, to a point on the eastern boundary of British Columbia, with power to improve the navigation leading to and from Rainv Lake and Lake of the Woods;

The telegram sent from Havana on Saturday last, relative to the surrender of General JORDAN and his troops upon the payment by the Government of a certain sum of money, was based upon official dispatches. It is reported that the insurgents in the neighborhood of Yaguaramas and Pais, and between Cienfuegos and Colon, are treating with the Spanish authorities relative to surrender.
A jury in the Supreme Court has awarded $17,950 damages to C. O. POLLARD against the town of Woburn, for permanent Injuries received by the plaintiff from a defein the highway.

If we read Governor HOFFMAN'S speech aright, his view of the way to pay one's debts is not of precisely the same pattern as Mr. PENDLETON'S at the kingston fair the other day: "I have read many learned essays on the question of 'How to pay the National Deby.'

Strawbridge, of Philadelphia; Hon. B. H. Fuller, of Alabama, and Hon. W. E. Rawson, of Albany, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Senator Henry Wilson, of Massachusetts;

Governor HOFFMAN delivered, on Friday, the address before the Union County Agricultural Society, at their annual Fair, in Kingston. We quote the following paragraphs from the report of the address published in the Albany Argus: Our country, not with standing the great dent which rests upon it, cannot fail to grow rich and prosperous, if our people will be economical.

"PROGRESS" AT WALLACK'S. Mr. ROBERTSON'S newest piece is also one of his best. The dialogue is smart and sententious, the characters are cleverly contrasted, the situations are possible and effective and the general result is altogether refreshing and unconventional.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: For the benefit of travelers I wish to expose a swindling operation carried on by the New-York Central Railroad, especially on the two roads between Rochester and Suspension Bridge. Passengers going West from Boston or Albany are not notified of a change of cars at Rochester.

The ruinous passion for speculation has been as prevalent in Austria of late as it is in this country. In descussing it he Schlesische Zeitung uses language which is peculiarly adapted to this locality at the present time.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair. A resolution was adopted to increase the salary of the third clerk in the Street Department to $3,500. Resolutions were also adopted to pave with Belgian pavement portions of Tenth, West Houston, Thirty-second and Thirty-first streets;

Our citizens have been somewhat agitated for two or three days by reports of a defalcation in the National Exchange Bank, which reports increased currency upon the announcement, Saturday, of the resignation of the Cashier, WM. H. COREY.

From the Roston Folio. The great nevelist prefaces his letter as follows: "you have not only my full permission to show this, but I beg you to show this to any one who has been misled into doing me wrong." We therefore take pleasure in presenting his statement to our readers:

Quite a number of patriots have lately shown a disposition to relieve the Secretary of State from all trouble in settling any little difference we may have with foreign States, by acting as volunteer diplomatists' Once or twice they have arranged to Alabama claims and it is not their fault if our negotiations with Spain are not prosperous.

Is woman so very much oppressed by our present social system, after all ? A correspondent of an evening contemporary undertakes to show that when she marries she had decidedly the best of the bargain. She possesses the absolute control over her own property,

In the TIMES of yesterday was a report of an affray which occurred at a picnic at LANDMINE'S Hamilton Park, on Saturday last, during which WILLIAM P. O'BRIRN was severely stabbed. A man named name EDWARD BUCKLEY, was arrested at the time on suspicion.

The United Presbyterian Church Synod resumed its session yesterday morning in the Jane-street Presbyterian Church, Rev. J. L. CLARK, Moderator, in the chair. A report was read from the Presbytery at Stamford, Canada, as to the state of the missionary work at that station. The report mentioned, among other things, that the people felt deeply the want of a cheap periodical.

The steamship Trade Wind, Captain MORRILL, hence on the 22d inst. for Belize, Honduras, went down at sea on the 24th. There were only three passengers on board, who with the crew took to the lifeboats. One of the boats in charge of HENRY ARNOLD, a colored pilot of Belize, with four persons, including two of the passengers, reached the Southwest Pass bar yesterday.

A letter, of 15th inst., from J. M. LEECH Esq., clerk of the Faculty of Washington College, to ROBERT M. LUSHER, Esq., agent of the Peabody fund for this State, announces that Mr. PEABODY has placed the bonds donated in the hands of a gentleman of high repute, for the enforcement and the employment of the proceeds for the benefit of the College.

The Massachusetts State labor reform convention is to be held in Worcester to-day The call says it is to he held for the purpose of nomination a State ticket, and adopting a platform and address. To-morrow the New-York Republican State Convention will be held in Syracuse, and the Mississippi Republican State convention in Jackson.

The eloquent speech delivered last Saturday at Harrisburg by Hon. COLUMBUS DELANO, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, contains an able and striking summary of that part of the Administration's work which has come under his own official notice. It confirms by facts and figures the declaration so often made in our columns,

At this season of the year nothing call bo more appropriate than for public moll to go and have a little homely talk in the agricultural districts. It tries the range of their own powers, and if they are gifted with the faculty of unbending, and can really fix their attention on the green fields without being drawn aside to the political stump,

The Trustees of the Avondale Relief Fund for Widsows and Orphans met to-day at Plymouth and adopted a plan for the distribution of the funds that reach them. After taking the oath required by the rules and regulations, the Trustees clected E. C. WADHAMS, President: H. GAYLORD, Treasurer and WILLIAM L. WILSON, Secretary and Disbursing Agent.

About 9 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the Hope Cotton Mills, in Alleghany City, owned by A. H. CHILDS Co., which destroyed the buildings entarely. The loss is about $150,000; insured for $115,000, mostly in Eastern companies. About three hundred employes are thrown out of work.

President GRANT is to be presented with an elegant set of eutlery, the gift of the workmen of the Lamson Goodnow Manufacturing Company, of Shelburne Falls, Mass. It is now on exhibition at Browne SPAULDING'S, on Broadway. As a specimen of taste, skill and "style" it does exceeding credit to the workmen.

On Friday night, about 11 o'clock a most horrible murder was committed in Baltimore County, the victim being Mr. SAMUEL BURTON, residing on the Hartord road, about one mile from the Copper Factory on the Gunpowder River, and eleven miles from this city. The alleged murderer is named WILLIAM BROWN, formerly of Terre Hante, Ind.,

The Providence Journal says very truly: "The way for us to obtain Cuba is to wait. This is the quickest way as well as the best, the most certain, the most honorable, the cheapest. A war with the feeblest Power on earth, a war with the Sandwich Islands, would cost us more than the price at which Cuba could be honestly bought."
The Schooner Cornelia, Capt. BAKER, R. A. MORGAN agent, arrived at New-London Saturday evening, from Hudson's Bay, Aug. 28, with 150 barrels oil. The bark Ansel Gibbs, of Fair haven,

Wall-street, yesterday resumed something of its ordinary appearance. The fever of the previous days seemed allayed, and men talked and acted with a cooler temper. Along the sidewalks, opposite the Exchange, were crowds of outsiders who appeared to be waiting for something to turn up, but their curiosity was not satisfied.

The now building of the National Military Asylum, located here, was dedicated yesterday. The building presents a fine appearance from the exterior. It is in the form of a cross, and when the wings are completed will have a frontage of 240 feet. The building will accommodate comfortably 500 information. The dedication was informal, the more imposing ceremonics being omitted on account
A steamer answering the description of the Cuban privateer Hornet has been seen for some days past hovering about the eastern shore of Long Island, between Montauk Point and Fire Island.

The trustees of the German Evangelical Lutheran church of St. Matthew, give notice that on the 1st October next they will commence to remove the bodies interred in the burning-ground of the church in Carmine-street, to the Lutheran Cemetery on Long Island.

The extraordinary rush of immigrants to this country during the three months ending June 30, of the present year, is worth nothing. The total number was 165,987--being a very large increase over the same period in previous years. The class of immigrants, too, is unusually good.

It was scarcely to be expected yesterday that anything like order could be brought out of the chaos into which financial circles have been plunged for several days past; indeed, since the night of Thursday of last week. The condition in which brokers found themselves on Monday night was anything but cheering.

PADUCAH, Ky., Sept. 28.--The frost this morning has done great damage to the tobacco crop in all the Kentucky purchase. About half of the crop, being still green, has been damaged in Graves, Ballard, McCracken,Christian, Calloway, Marshall, Logan and other counties. Parties are buying for an expected rise, and others who own from 100 to 400 hogsheads in the East have telegraphed not to put them on the market.

The ride from Washington to this city over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which I enjoyed yesterday, was extremely pleasant, combining as it does not only the most picturesque scenery, but abounding in what are now historic reminiscences connected with the late war.

The Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows adjourned sine die to-day. Vice-President COLFAX was present, and was introduced to the members. Grand Sire FARNSWORTH was presented with a diamond ring, set in gold, from the fillings of the "last spike." Grand Secretary RIDGELY was presented with a cane by the California brethren.

We suppose there will presently be some argument between our Government and that of Spain concerning the release o the thirty Spanish gunboats which are now being built at New-York and Mystic for the Cuban service, and most of which will be completed and ready to sail within a fortnight.

Whenever a broken rail throws off a train, or the enormous cost of maintaining permanent way is under discussion, there is a general outery against the poor iron of modern production, and a longing for the skill, science and honesty among manufacturers that used to make rails last twenty years.

The attendance of the American Institute Fair last evening was far greater than it has been at any time since the opening. The exhibition is now in the "full tide of successful operation," and has become an object of much interest not only to the residents of this City, but also to those of the rural districts, the latter of whom were present yesterday in great numbers.

The announcement made exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday of the latest, and in many respects the strangest, developments of the famous Burdell murder case, naturally stirred the public mind, and made that timeworn tragedy once more the theme of public remark.

The stockholders of the northern Pacific Railroad have been in session in this City, for several days past, and will probably continue to sit during the present week. Reports of the most favorable stamp were received from exploring parties who have just returned from a tour of survey, and it is proposed to commence building early next Spring.

Judge KINNE, of Otsego County, in this State, was found dead in his bed at his boarding-house, in Cooperstown, on Friday last. Judge KINNE was one of the leading citizens and oldest residents or Otsego County, being, at the time of his death, 71 years old.

The supply of Croton has not augmented to any great extent by the late rains. The decrease of water continues, and at this time there are hardly more than 500,000,000 gallons in the two reservoirs from which a supply can be drawn.

CHARLES DICKENS opened the Winter sessions of the Midland Institute at Birmingham, last evening, with a pleasant speech. After reviewing the history of the institution and offering advice for its future management, he touched upon other subjects. The present, he said, was a materialistic age. His political creed could be summed up in two articles.

Prince ARTHUR left Niagara Falls last night at 9 o'clock, sick, in company with the Governor-General. The hotels at the Falls were illuminated when they departed. They left Paris at midnight, and slept in the cars all night, and left for Long Point at 9 o'clock this morning.

The Boston banks will pay on Friday, Oct. 1, their usual semi-annual dividends, amounting in the aggregate to $2,250,000, an increase of about $150,000 ever the amount paid in April last. Other dividends, amounting to $1,137,065, will also be payable in that city on Friday; aggregate, $3,387,065.

Yesterday afternoon a meeting was held in the Mayor's office, of the Citizens' and Aldermanic Committees having in charge the fund raised in this City for the relief of the families of Avondale miners; Mayor HALL presided, and Marshal JOSEPH H. TOOKER acted as Secretary.

THOMAS FLANAGAN, aged 16, was arrested yesterday with ALICE WARD alias Weldon and MARY ANN ANDERSON, women of ordinary apperance, on a charge of swindling a number of actresses. It appears that a young man has been in the habit of calling at the residence of some well-known actress.

Supervisor PRESBREY reports to the Internal Revenue Office from Virginia, under date of Richmond, Sept. 27, that the cavalry squad under Captain BURNS are doing good service in the Fifth Virginia District. Collector WILCOX reports the seizure and destruction of thirteen illicit stills and the capture of several barrels of apple brandy and the arrest of twelve men.

The United Presbyterian Church Synod opened its fourth day's session yesterday in the Jane-street Church, Moderator Rev. J. L. CLARK in the chair. The Committee on the State of Religion submitted a report, which was recommitted.

In steamship Westphalia, from Hamburg.--H. Dollner, wife 2 children and servant, Louis Windmuller, wife and child, Joseph Lindenschmidt, wife and 4 children, G. D. Crommelin, C. F. Acker mann, wife, 4 children and servant, Francisca Wilckens, O. Witte and child, Aug. Konig. wife and 2 children, A. D. Schlessinger, Captain Chas. Watson,

Seldom has so disastrous a condition of affairs existed in Wall-street as that which the public have witnessed during the last few days. How much longer it will continue scarcely any amount of "information," special or general, would enable us to determine.

On Monday last Mr. THOS. H. FIELD, a retired merchant and resident of New-Rochelle, was killed instantly and in a most singular manner. It appears that Mr. FIELD had been greatly annoyed of late by trespassers, who entered his grounds almost nightly, and robbed his grapery of its choicest fruit.

A slimly attended meeting of representatives of the New-York State Fine Cut Tobacco Association was held at the Astor House yesterday afternoon, Mr. WILLIAM E. LAWRENCE presiding. A general and protracted discussion took place on the question of increasing the prices of manufactured to bacco, both in the Eastern and Western States.

Judge CARPENTER has decided not to grant an injunction restraining the Directors of the Connecticut Western Railroad from constructing for the building of the road. The decision is made after a full hearing on a petition of T. M. ALLYN, of Hartford, who claimed that the Company was not legally organized until $2,000,000 capital was subscribed.

Mr. GEORGE PEABODY sails this morning in the Scotia for England. He came on a visit to this county in the early part of the Summer on account of his failing health, which, unhappily, has improved but little during his visit. Mr. PEABODY'S generous gifts during this visit have already been made know.

Mrs. ANN LEWIS, of No. 243 Second-avenue, appeared befor Justice DOWLIN, yesterday, at the Tombs, and made a very grave and singular complaint against a man named JACOB COHEN, who had been arrested at her instauce.

Yesterday afternoon, at CAMP'S, JOHN DEERY, holder of the diamond cue, emblematic of the championship of American billiards, played his final game with MICHAEL PHELAN, winning by 26 out of 100 French caroms, and at 6:30 o'clock he took the train for San Francisco, where he expects to reside in future.

HENRY McKEON was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday on a charge of stealing a silver watch from the person of TIMOTHY MURPHY, at No. 24 Rose-street where the complainant was asleep, The prisoner was committed for trial.

The King of Portugal has publicity contradicted the rumor of his candidature for the throne o Spain. He says he was born a native of Portugal and will die an native. MADRID, Sept. 28. --The troubles at Barcelona have been quelled, and the city is tranquil. One hundred and twenty--six persons were arrested for complicity. Many escaped.

The London Times, in an article yesterday on the situation in France, considers the Emperor's illness a serious misfortune at the time the Government is being reconstructed, as NAPOLEON has need of all his powers at this crisis. It thinks the present peril aggravated by his enfeebled health, although, it says, "peril of some kind has been the prospect of the Government for the past two generations."

Close upon the heels of the sham Democracy that assembled in Convention here last night, come the delegates to the Republican State Convention, which is to convene here to-morrow. The people of Syracuse are fortunate in thus having an opportunity to compare the representatives of the two parties, and as a result of the comparison they will doubtless roll up a big Republican majority this Fall.
People are sometimes struck by the public spirit of members of Parliament, who serve their country without pay, and, indeed, are often considerably out of pocket in election expenses.

DEAR SIR: I take the liberty of addressing the following paper to you in order to secure that attention of the public which the subject fully deserves. You, to whom the foreign affairs of our country have been confided, seem to me the proper recipient of this letter; and I, a foreign-born citizen and American teacher of the law of nations, have a right, perhaps the duty, to discuss the subject.

SEASON OF FRENCH OPERA. If the artistes of the French company now singing at the Academy of Music had heeded a slightly altered version of a saying of ALEXANDER DUMAS, that the existence of a newspaper ought to begin with its second number, the impression as to their respective merit would have been decidedly different from that first

FREDERICK F. LOW, Ex-Governor of California, who was yesterday nominated by the President as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to China, to fill the position heretofore occupied by Hon. J. ROSS BROWNE, has already had some considerable political experience, having been a member of Congress from California in the Thirty-seventh Congress...

General ROBERT WILLIAMS friends have published a card in answer to that of Messrs. RIVES and PAXTON, on the Virginia Senatorial question. In this card they say, "General WILLIAMS, who is a native Virginian, and one of the few officers from that State who remained true to the Government during the late war, was some months ago approached by several leading men upon

The Times, in an article on the situation in France, says: "The coincidence of the Emperor's sickness and the reconstruction of the Government is a serious misfortune. The energies of the Emperor cannot be well spared at such a crisis. The reforms come, unfortunately, while the Emperor is incapacitated, and at a time when he is most required.

The sale made at Rahway, N. J., yesterday by Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER was another grand success. At 11 o'clock sharp, the train, consisting of eleven cars, and containing, perhaps, 700 people, started from the foot of Cortlaudt-street, proceeded without delay to its place of destination and landed its passengers before they had time to get tired.

BISHOP--FIELD.--At Grace Church, on Tuesday. Sept. 28, by Rev. Dr. Potter, DAVID WOLFR BISHOP to MARY FLORENCE VAN CORTLANDT, daughter of Benjamin H. Field. GALLAGHER--STONE.--At Trinity Church, Platisburg, N. Y., by Rev. William M. Ogden, GEORGE, GALLAGHER, of this City, to LUCY G., daughter of Roby G. Stone, of the former place.

BRANT.--At Jersey City, on Tuesday, Sept. 28, MARY H., widow of the late John C. Brant. Notice of funeral hereafter. BULKLEY.--On Monday, Sept. 27, MINNIE ADELE, daughter of Frederick C. and Fannie M. Bulkley, aged daughter of Frederick C. and Fannie M. Bulkley, aged 8 years and 8 months. Relatives and friends of the family, and these of her grandparents, Erastus Bulkley and Wm. H. Wilcox,

The liabilities of CLARK HOLT, of Rockville, a large manufacturer and President and Treasurer of the Tell and County Insurance Company, are much larger than supposed when his business irregularities and defalcations were discovered a short time ago. A full investigation indicates that they will reach a quarter of a million.

An interesting trial took place, yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge BEDFORD, the defendant, DAVID MARSH alias Henry Miller, being charged with forgery in the first degree. The crime was perpetrated nearly two years ago, and in this manner:

The steamer edaho, from Honolulu, has arrived, She brings advices to the 15th inst. Trade was good, and there was a steady demand for choice staple goods. The reports from the plantations were generally favorable, and the average yield was fully up to the expectation.

The declaration of the Trustees of the Avondale Fund is assuring. "The fund,', they say, "is specific, and is given solely for the aid and relief of those persons who survive the appalling death which involved husbands, fathers, brothers and sons."

The Minnesota Democratic State Convention for the nomination of a State ticket was held in St. Paul on Thursday, 23d inst. It was pretty well attended. The conflict of opinion upon some subjects, relating to parts of the platform and to some of the candidates, was sharp, but the results were acquiesced in. The full ticket nominated is as follows:

GEORGE PEABODY sailed for England yesterday in the Scotia. He went to the steamer quietly, accompanied by Mr. SAMUEL WETMORE, at whose residence he had been staying while in this City, and Mr. McALISTER, of Philadelphia. At the Cunard dock, Jersey City.
The Cunard steamship Cuba, which left Liverpool Sept, 18 and queenstown Sept, 19, reached this port last night, with two days later news than was hand by the Westphalia.

EUROPE. The Council of Ministers held yesterday at Madrid decided to propose to the Cortes to elect the Duke of GENOA King of Spain. The letter of the King of Portugal declining to be a candidate, is received by the Press with great enthusiasm. The accomplices in the recent mysterious murder, near Paris, of the TRAPPMANN family, have been arrested.

"MARTHA" AT THE FRENCH THEATRE. FLOTOW'S lively and melodious little opera was given last night, by the Parepa-Rosa troupe, to a crowded audience, who were quite taken by storm by the spirit and finish of the performance. The comic operas as sung by this company have been their most decided successes, and "Martha" is no exception to the rule.

The regular mail steamship from Rio Janeiro arrived at this port today, bringing advices from the hostiles armies in Paraguay up to the 22d of August. The news is highly important. On the 18th of that month the allied army attacked the forces of President LOPEZ, which were intrenched at Curuguaty.

The prospect of cheap fuel for the Winter is improving. At the auction sale of Scranton coal yesterday there were 90,000 tons disposed of at prices which, as compared with the figures made at the August sale, showed a very gratifying fail in the market rates,

To-day was the second of the Newmarket October Meeting. The Triennial Produce Stakes was won by Sir R. W. BULKELEY'S b. f. Martinique, beating Mr. BOWES' b. f. Toisson d'Or, second, and Mr. R. SUTTON'S b. c. Islam, third. Five started. The betting was two to one against Martinique, six to one against Toisson d'Or, and three to one against Islam.

The events of yesterday in financial circles may be summed up, before proceeding to tell the story of the day, in the following terms: The day opened bright and glorious as the Autumnal sun which gave it light. There were clouds to mar its brightness, it was true, but it was hoped -confidently hoped--that these clouds would be dissipated as the day waxed older,

The Delaware, Lackwanna and Western Railroad sold 90,000 tons of Scranton coal by auction at their office, corner William-street and Exchange-place, yesterday afternoon. There were a large number of speculators in attendance, the bidding being very close and animated.

It is evident that Judge DENT intends to cultivate sedulously the spirit which dictated his nomination. The scheme for making him the candidate of "The National Republican Union Party" was conceived in fraud; and his speeches as candidate are impregnated with fraud and falsehood.

M., for interment. BRANT.--At Jersey City, on Tuesday, Sept. 38, MARY H. widow of the late John C. Brant.

General ROSECRANS has not counseled in vain. His letter to the Ohio Democracy, declining the nomination tat had been tendered him, and setting forth the necessity for charge in the platform and tactics of the party, has imparted force and direction to Western opinion upon the subject.

Mr. GEORGE PEABODY sailed for England yesterday in the Scotia, as noticed elsewhere in our issue of this morning. There have been so many conflicting rumors in regard to the health of Mr. PEABODY, that we are glad to be able to state, by authority, that he certainly does not appear, on the whole, worse than when he arrived, early in June.

Secretary FISH was visited at his residence in this City yesterday by Dr. ALBERT F. SIMMONS, accompanied by his counsel, Mr. JOHN W. GRATTAN, who had a consultation with him in reference to the Cuban question, and made a demand for the damages the doctor has sustained by the agents of the Spanish Government.

The appointment of FREDERICK F. LOW to the Chinese Mission is received here with great favor. He did not seek the position, but has concluded to accept it. He entertains a liberal opinion on the subject of our relations with China, and has strong faith that the Chinese Government...

A legal document growing out of the gold gambling of last week, which will be found in another place--the application for injunction to Judge CARDOZO against the Gold Exchange--makes the extraordinary confession that forty millions of gold were bought and sold for the account of the plaintiffs, GOULD and SMITH, in a single day!

We observe that what was once announced by some papers as "The Cherbourg Horror."--meaning the reported mutiny on the Sabine, --is now more complacently styled by some of the same authorities "The Sabine Hoax." The change in title is easy; but the general tirade against the navy for its alleged tyranny, cannot be so easily compensated.

Hon. WILLIAM A. RICHARDSON, who has been Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and a probate Judge in Massachusetts, has, after several months' trial of both offices, concluded to resign the former. His salary as Judge is greater than that received as Assistant Secretary.

The Labor Reform Convention which met at Worcester, Mass., on Tuesday, will not carry with it the sympathies of the State, unless the tone of its deliberations undergoes a change. Mr. S. P. CUMMLNGS, of Danvers, opened the meeting by declaring that he was in favor of paying the national debt In greenbacks.

Paton, George Warren, Mrs. Ruxton, Mr. Howat, Walter O'Hirst, John N. Whiting, A. D. Valentine, Mr. Underwood, Mr. and Mrs. Badeau, daughter, son and child, Dr. William King, W. The through night freight train north on the Hudson River Railroad, on reaching Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth-streets, broke a coupling, and three cars loaded with petroleum were thrown from the track. The oil was fired by some accident, from the lamps of the train hands, and the destruction of the entire train seemed probable.

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has just decided on cases coming up from Philadelphia, that wholesale apothecaries and druggists, doing business as such under a regular license, must cease to sell liquors in quantities exceeding one half pint at one time, or pay the special tax required of a retail liquor dealer.

To-day will be another lively day for buyers of suburban property. Two large sales will be made. At Bayonne, N. J., Messrs. A. D. MELLICK, Jr., BROTHER will sell ninety building lots. The property has already been fully described in this column. It is very beautiful, convenient to New-York, and worthy the attention of all who are looking for country homes. The terms of sale are quite easy. Ten per cent.

The Board met in their Chamber Room, number seventeen City Hall, pursuant to special cal signed by a majority of the members. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Norton, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Connor, Hardy, Repper, McGrath, Farley, McQuade--14.

The NEW Jerusalem Church, on Cherry-street, below Twenty-third, was damaged by fire this morning early. The Church of United Brethren, in the Twentieth Ward, was also damaged by another fire, which burned a cabinet shop and damaged two dwellings.

The Convention at Syracuse yesterday adopted a platform on which the Republicans of the State will heartily rally. Its declaration in regard to the public debt contrast felicitously with the clumsy generalization by which the Democrats endeavor to disguise their policy of repudiation. Principal and interest, say the Republicans, "shall be paid in coin as the same matures;"

The Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of this diocese met yesterday morning in St. John's Chapel, Varick-street. The opening sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. BEACH, of St. Peter's. Dr. EIGENBRODT was elected Secretary, and EDWARD V. DELANCEY Treasurer.

The Indian raid in Wyoming, reported this morning, was palpably only the reckless sortie of a single band, and need excite no fear of general hostilities. They mustered but 100 warriors, and these, in their sharp fight with Company D. Second Cavalry, were worsted, five Indians being killed and many wounded.

It is reported here in official circles to-day that the recent note of Mr. SICKLES, the American Minister, has been withdrawn. LONDON, Sept. 29.--The Times Paris correspondent asserts that there is but little hope of a compromise between Spain and the Cubans.

The Republican State Convention met here at noon to-day, held two sessions, and finished its business before 8 P. M. The proceedings were harmonious, and the ticket nominated gives entire satisfaction to every member of the Convention, and cannot but be acceptable to Republicans throughout the State.

At the meeting of the Board of Health yesterday, Dr. HARRIS, the Sanitary Superintendent, reported that the tests of explosive oils by the chemist and his assistants, the past week, give one specimen of pure naphtha (" American Liquid Safety Gas,") and fourteen specimens which give off explosive vapor at a temperature below 80 Fahrenheit...

The prominent men of tile successful party in the recent election in Virginia have been divided in opinion upon the question whether it would be proper for the Legislature, which is to assemble on the 5th of next month, to choose United States Senators. They appealed to General CANBY, the military commander of the district. for his decision;

The news from Lisbon apparently confirms the report of Paraguayan disaster which the previous advices from Rio Janeiro brought. The advance of Count D'Eu seems to have resulted in driving LOPEZ to the interior with severe loss. If these later tidings are not exaggerated, the cause of LOPEZ has received a fatal blow.

The centennial celebration to-day was an imposing demonstration, surpassing anything ever attempted here. The city was literally alive with citizens and visitors. A procession was formed consisting of military, the City Government, engine companies and organizations of various kinds, a mile or more in length, making a maguiticent display.

The Mississippi Republican Convention at Jackson yesterday completed its nominations, and adopted a platform which we should judge from the brief summary given in our dispatches to be in most respects satisfactory.

The Republicans of this State will learn with regret that GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS deems himself constrained to decline the nomination for the office of Secretary of State, tendered him with cordial unanimity by the Syracuse Convention.

LONDON, Eng., Sept. 30.--Right Hon. EDWCARDWELL, Secretary of State for War, delivered a speech to his constituents at Oxford last evening on the subject of the policy of the Government toward Canada.

Mr. H. GAYLORD, Treasurer of the Avondale fund, acknowledges the receipt from citizens of New-York of $1,287 75. The receipt of $939 30, in addition to the $19,605 86 previously contributed for the Avondale sufferers, is acknowledged at the Mayor's office.

The City Supervisors of Brooklyn last evening reenacted the fraudulent programme of last year, in the matter of appointing in specters and canvassers for the forthcoming registry and election. Supervisor OSBORN presided. After long waiting the Special Committee on Appointments came in, and Supervisor HOWELL, its Chairman, presented the report with the list of appointments.
On Wednesday, SYLVESTER GREEN was arrested and taken before Justice COLE, at Morristown, charged with having committed an atrocious assault upon MICHAEL RILEY, at Succassunna Plains.

The Jefferson Club of the Twenty-second Ward is a well-organized body of substantial citizens, having permanent officers elected for the year and the Club holding its meetings weekly. The Republican Convention here has made the following additional nominations: For Auditor--H. MUSGROVE. For Treasurer--W. H. VASSER. For Attorney-General--J. S. MORRIS. For Superintendent of Public Instruction--H. R. PEASE.

Mr. E. HARRIS informs the Board of Health, in a communication on Washington Market, that the latter institution is "a disgrace to the City;" that the stench from the garbage and rotten fruit is intolerable, and that the air is so foul that "a piece of chemically-prepares paper, suspended in the market turned black in a few minutes."

Right Hon. JAS. MONCRIEFF, who, as will be seen by a telegram this morning, has been appointed Lord Chief Justice Clerk of Scotland, in the place of Hon. GEORGE PATTON, deceased, is the son of the late Lord MONCRIEFF, was born in Scotland in 1811. He passed his examination and was admitted as an Advocate in 1833, having been educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a report directing the immediate removal of all obstructions on Plers Nos. 14 and 15, North River, (New-Jersery Central Railroad Depot.) and instructing the Corporation Counsel to sue for the penalties incurred by the parties owning these obstructions.

The dealers in stocks paused yesterday in their flight, and asked each other what they were running away from. As no one could tell, the panie was arrested, and but for the failures of the previous day there would have been a considerable advance in nearly all securities.

FRIDAY. Mails for South Pacific, Central America, , by the Arizona, close at the General Post Office at 10:30 A. M. SATURDAY. Mails for France, via Havre and Brest, by the Ville de Paris, close at the General Post Office at 12 M.

The second annual Fair of the New-York State Grape-Growers' Association will be held at Canandaigua. N. Y., Oct. 5 and 6. The Association desire that the exhibition of grapes and wine on this occasion shall exceed in quality and variety that at their first Fair, in the Fall of 1868, which was pronounced to be the linest display

In indorsing unreservedly the course of General GRANT'S Administration, the Syracuse Convention has but followed the example of every Republican Convention that has yet been held. Not one has evaded the subject or dealt with it ambiguously.

The steamer City of Mexico has arrived from Vera Cruz with dates from the City of Mexico to Sept. 21. The Mexican Congress assembled the capital on the 16th inst., the anniversary of ?? independence. President JUAREZ delivered the opening speech.

Right Honorable EDWARD CARDWELL, Secretary of State for War, made a speech at Oxford, England, on Wednesday, in which he reviewed the policy of the Government toward Canada. There has been a heavy outflow of specie from the Bank of France during the past week. The amount on hand to-day is 9,200,000 francs less than on the corresponding day last week. The Empress left Paris at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon on her Eastern tour.

It will be within the recollection of our readers that a little more than a year ago some little public sensation was created by the announcement that the wife of a citizen in respectable position in the community had suddenly departed for Europe under the escort of a gentleman called by the title of "Colonel."

The commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday appointed JAMES WILSON guard at the Penitentiary in place of JOSEPH OGLE. THOMAS R. MURRAY was appointed clerk of the Free Labor and Intelligence Bureau. The Warden of Bellevue Hospital forwarded a request to increase the compensation of ambulance drivers to $30 a month, which was granted.

BUTTER. There is an absence of the usual active Fall trade, receipts are light and prices nominally maintained, but without some more animated demand must go lower. There are hopes of an increased Southern trade, or at least of business from some quarter, sufficient to keep the market along until November or later. Fine Fall State butter,

A dispatch received from Chicago, Ill., yesterday, conveys the intelligence of the death in that city on Wednesday of ISAAC V. FOWLER, EX-Postmaster of New-York. Mr. FOWLER was appointed Postmaster of the office in this City in 1858, by President BUCHANAN, and was then a leading Democratic politician;

Wednesday morning the body of a man was found floating in the water at the foot of Canover-street, Brooklyn. On being brought to the shore it was discovered that the deceased had his throat cut, as if with an ax or cleaver. He appears to have been about 25 or 30 years of age, and the body seems to have been in the water but a short time.

Collector GRINNELL has returned from Washington and is now contemplating a reduction of the force under him. Yesterday he was in consultation with Mr. MADGE, of the Treasury Department, at Washington, on the subject, and the result will probably be the abolition of several offices and the saving of salaries to the Government amounting to $25,000.

That the Cubans have a formidable privateer afloat in the vicinity of New-York is not a new thing to the readers of the TIMES, who for the past few weeks have been well advised concerning the whereabouts and movements of that craft. The Board of Directors of the East River Bridge Company met at the office of the Brooklyn City Our Company yesterday, Hon. HENRY C. MURPHY, presiding.

A communication from Mr. E. HARRIS, on the state of Washington Market, was presented to the Board of Health Wednesday. The structure was described as a disgrace to the City, as regards its appearance and on accoun of the noxious exhalations emitted from it.

The Fair of the Queens County Agricultural Society, held at Mineola, opened, as has been already announced, yesterday, and was continued to-day under most favorable auspices. The weather, which is always an important matter, was excellent, and the Fair green looked its gayest, thronged with thousands; not only Long Island, but New-York, and still more distant districts, sent up their quotas to enjoy the show, and to enliven the scene.

The movement for a third party in Arkansas has called out an address from the Republican State Central Committee, presenting at considerable length the reasons why no Republican should cooperate in it.

Yesterday was a very busy day in the real estate market. Two large ?? were made, and one of City property, at the Sales room. At Bayonne, N. J., Messrs. A. D. MULLICK, Jr., BRO had a particularly successful sale. The crowd was not so large as has attended some previous ones, but it more than made up in quality what it lacked in quantity.

The three-days' festival of the Germans-familiarly known as the Cansluller Volksfest--which terminated on Wednesday evening, was a most happy affair throughout. This festival dates back as far as the year 1820,

The Mississippi Democrats are emptying the vials of their wrath upon the head of Mr. ALCORN, the Republican candidate for the office of Governor. The worst they can say against him is that the was a secessionist at the outbreak of the war, and for a time rendered service on the rebet side.

STEWART COPS wholesale store, corner of Chambers-street and Broadway, and the matter was so thoroughly sifted that Justice DOWLING issued a search warrant yesterday, when Detective WOOLDRIDGE, of the Sixth Precinet, examined the residence of CHAS.

The Fall trade is upon as with a brisk beginning and bright prospects. This is a cheery fact, and more than an offset. Perhaps, for the anxiety and gloom which the Wall-street storm his brought to monetary circles. Save the dry-goods trade, which is affected through the price of cotton, by the fluctuations of gold, no branch of business seems to have felt the financial flurry.

The Southern Commercial Convention, to be held in Louisville next week, promises to be one of the largest and most successful assemblages of the kind ever held in this country. All the great centres of trade will be fully represented. and delegations have been appointed by the Governors of all the leading States in the Union.

The Screen, which the TIMES announced a day or two since as having gone on her trial trip, has returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It appears that the French propeller worked unsatisfactorily, and that he are she will be put on the drydock for the purpose of having her old propeller restored to its place, as it is said to work much better than new one.

A colored girl, known as MARTHA, has recently made a statement before the Grand Jury of Passaic County, charging Mr. CHARLES McNEIL, a man of considerable wealth-who took her from the Colored Orphan Asylum in this City-with revolting inhumanity toward her.

The Coroner gives the number killed at the Fair Ground on Friday, including two wounded, who have since died, at twenty. There is still one body at Weaver's undertaker's office that has not been recognized, and the head and some fragments of flesh of another body.

RICHARD BURNS, who was charged with being concerned in the murder of Mr. CRAFT, one of the prison keepers at Sing Sing, disappeared on Thursday of last week and eluded all efforts to discover his whereabouts until Saturday morning, when he was found secreted in an obscure corner of the bucket shop.
The potato crop of England will not be up to the average. It is estimated that half of the crop of Cumberland is diseased. Colonel HILL has been appointed Governor or Newfoundland.

Midnight.--A rain storm increased in violence about 9 P. M., and continues unabated, with every indication of another flood in that portion of the city submerged last July. The fire bells are now sounding general alarm.

The Saturday Review has an article on the subject of the relations between Spain and the United States on the Cuban question. The writer says the announcement that the Washington Government approves the communication of Mr. SICKLES, the American Minister to the Spanish Government, is only partially intelligible as long as the terms of that dispatch are unknown.
A few plain-spoken words may not be in appropriate to last week's panic in Wall-street. The present flurry is, happily, localized. We hope we are near the end of the troubles growing out of it.

Mr. CORNELIUS WENDELL was written to some time ago by a Western editor for some definite information relative to the Pomeroy-Randall-Legate letter. The following answer has been sent in reply : WASHINGTON, Sept. 21, 1869. To W. S. Burke, Esq., Editor Leavenworth Bulletin :
The people of the harvest of 1869 in the different ?? of the country through which the Grand Trunk ??, has just been received.

It is announced that JOHN DEERING, Jr., LE.B. will deliver, before lycoums and literary societies, during the coming lecture season his lecture on "Five Years in Washington: a Record of Personal Experience in Peace and War" giving remin?? of the persons and events that have marks the Capital so conspicuous during the last few years. .

Dispatches have been received at the Navy Department from Rear Admiral TURNER, commanding the Pacific Squadron, which give some interesting particulars of the natural phenomena during the recent eclipse in Siberia. The report is from Command or FRANKLIN, of the Mohican.

The New-England Labor Reform League commenced Its sessions yesterday and continued until this evening. The attendance has been small at all the meetings, and few of the "distinguished speakers" advertised to be present made their appearance. JOHN ORVISS, of West Boxboro, was chosen President,

The upholders of ancient customs always make a hard fight against the order of change, which is the order of the world. The sectarians still fight for their sects, refusing the broader and more humanizing ways of social progress.

The German element of the Tammany cohorts is yet restless and unsatisfied. WE hear that it is strenuously insisting upon the nomination of a German as Police Justice in a district where the "Ring" has made a different choice.
The Jewish temple Emanuel, on Fifth avenue, shows how far the Hebrews have adopted the modes and ideas of the age and the Gentile world in general.

Talking of the Water--supply of our great cities, are they to be always depending on the out-the-way rural rivers Great cities, as a general rule, have little foresight; and the periodical embarrassments and alarms of Philadelphia. New-York and other places show that a greatly increased population in town and county will make that supply a very difficult thing.

The case of Passed Assistant surgeon GREEN Seems to be discussed on all hands, and very unjustly, as an incident of the chronic dispute between staff and line in the navy. The Court-martial found that Surgeon Green had been guilty of the offence of disobeying a lawful order of his superior officer.

Lively excitement was caused in the vicinity of Printing House Square last evening by the appearance of a mad bull, followed at a respectful distance by a crowd of several hundred men and boys. The animal dashed rapidly and furiously through Nassan and adjacent streets, but finally came to a short halt in WallStreet.

The furniture, cotton and frame factories on Fourth, near Berry-street, were burned to-day. The loss is $200,000, which is partially covered by insurance. PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 3.--the shop of L. P. L. EMERSON, In Dexter-street, pawtucket, was burned Saturday night.
Reported Insubordination in the Cuban Army--The Americans the Victims of Spanish Cruelty and Cuban Assassins.

To-day the Tennessee Legislature convenes, and within ten days, probably, it will ballot for United states Senator. It is upon the whole, one of the ablest legislative bodies that has ever convened in the State, each party having, in the last canvass, put its "best foot foremost,."

The week now opening promises to be the busiest we have yet had this season. No sales will be made to-day, but during the next three days, through New-York, Brooklyn, Westchester County and New-Jersey property will be offered to keep busy for the rest of the week the auctioneers, their visitors and purchasers.
We are pained to announce the death of our estimable fellow-citizen, Rev. DOLPHES SKINNER, D. D., which took place at his residence at 6 o'clock this morning.

The operations of the Wall--street banditti would be had enough in their effect upon the financial credit of New--York abroad; but they are greatly aggravated by the manifest readiness of the local Judiciary to play into the hands of men for whom Sing Sing is the proper place of refuge.

Mr. PENDLETON, we understand. And the whole tribe of outspoken repudiators are not likely to be unisunderstood. But there are democrats who are so far ashamed of repudiation as to shrink from its open advocacy, yet whose partisan affiliations compel them to be its supporters.

Late advices have been received from Buenos Ayres. It seems that President LOPEZ, in evacuating Ascurra, removed everything, including his guns. During the pursuit 30,000 Allies attacked 3,000 Paraguayans. The latter fought desperately. The engagement lasted six hours. The paraguayans lost 2,500 men and all their archives and specie.

The basin in which the so-called fountain of Washington Parade Ground sputtered its brief Summer day, is now choked with dead leaves and other refuse, making the little water left in it slimy and pestilential.

Governor PILE'S address to the people or New-Mexico shows that this Territory is in a ruinous condition. With all its splendid attractions of "climate unsurpassed and unsurpassable, abundant mineral resources, and grazing qualities superior to all other portions of the Union," yet New-Mexico has had "no increase of population or wealth for ten years."

The general Railroad Convention, to the held at Oswego on Wednesday, will, according to present appearances, result in some important measures with regard to transportation. especially as relates to lines in the northern part of the United States and the southern part of Canada.
Prince ARTHUR, the Governor-General and the Royal party arrived here by the Great Western Railway at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Addresses were presented by the Corporation.

General S. Cooper, Alexandria, Va., DEAR SIR : You will please excuse the liberty which I take in trespassing upon your valuable time. I have recently been preparing for the Historical Society a paper upon the losses of the Confederate army from battle, wounds and disease during the civil war 1861-5.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I regret very much to see an article in to-day's TIMES in opposition to the Judiciary article of the New Constitution. I feel sure that you cannot have examined the new proposed Judiciary article carefully, or you would not permit so intelligent and powerful a guide of public opinion as the TIMES to give the weight of its influence to its enemies.

The Board met in their Chamber, Room number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the Chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Norton, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farley, McQuade--14. On motion the reading of the minutes was dispensed with.

As comments have been made in the newspapers affecting the Administration in connection with the recent gold panic, and much interest is felt on the subject, the Washington Agent of the Associated Press to-night called upon the President to ascertain whether there was any foundation for intimations or direct charges against the Administration.

At last New-York is about to be blessed with a "Home" for the poor little foundlings, and to the Sisters of Charity does the honor belong of taking the initiatory steps in this wise and humane movement.

Omaha dispatches say intelligence from the expedition under General DUNCAN, who with the Fifth Cavalry left Fort McPherson about ten days ago for the Republican River, has been received. The troops surprised a camp of fifty-six lodges, last Sunday, and drove them away, capturing a large quantity of camp equipage.

The San Francisco Times urges the formation of a National Historical Association, which shall not only seek to preserve complete and trustworthy accounts of events which affect the nation as a whole, but which shall extend its operation to the collection of materials for the history of each separate State.

The Journal Official announces that the Senate and Corps Legislaift have been convoked to meet on the 29th of November. Nearly all the journals express dissatisfaction at the fact that the Chambers have not been immediately assembled.

The deep green which still hangs over the Beeches, the hot sun above, and the lazy atmosphere around, no more denotes the stillness and quietude of nature than do the outward signs of commerce and business denote the quietude of business in the Ohio Valley, and yet both are in a very important sense deceptive.

The celebrated bill presented to the Nashville Railroad Company by Drs. D. W. YANDELL and BAYLES. of Louisvill, for curing JERRY BLACK's arm, has not been paid. The Company have notified the doctors that they decline to pay, and, accordingly, have returned the bill.

The banks in this city are moving on in the even tenor of their way, apparently as unconcerned as if New-York was not in existence. Although an actual stringency cannot be said to exist here, still money is not to be had simply by the asking; indeed, in tile common phrase of the day, it is "tight." Individuals, however,

The celebrated "Baron" HENRI DE RIVIERE, whose attempted marriage with a belle of Mobile and subsequent marriage with Miss BLUNT. the daughter of a wealthy Southern lawyer, together with certain guano speculations and shouting affairs, have acquired for him some notirety, was arrested al the New-York Hotel on Saturday night, just as he was going to dinner by Deputy Sheriffs LAWRENCE DELMAR and JOHN E. McGOWAN.
The efforts which are being made to assist the independence party in Cuba on the one hand, and to cripple them on the other, are fast producing complications of unusual public interest.

Among the new French works now attracting attention in Paris are; Les Peche's de Christine et d'Isabella d'Espague by PAULGRIMM; a week edition of Parisine, by NESTOR ROQUEPLAN; Les Dieux du Jour - Satires et Poesies, by FELIX DEBOURG;

The Albany Evening journal urges upon Mr. GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS the reconsideration of his-decision not to accept the Republican nomination for Secretary of State, "A sentiment most imperative," and the interest of the State are presented as superior to personal feeling.

The first performance of "Twelfth Night" will be given this evening at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, Mrs. SCOTT-SIDDONS acting Viola. "The Streets of New-York" will be performed at the Olympic, Mr. J. K. MORTIMER and Miss ELIZA NEWTON filling the principal parts.

The fortieth annual course of lectures of this College commenced last evening and will be continued until the middle of March, 1879, at the lecture room of the College of Pharmacy, in the University building. corner of Waverley-place and University - place. The lecturer on chemistry, by Professor C. F. CHANDLER, will be given on Wednesday evenings, from 7 to 9 o'clock,

The Woman's Club met yesterday at Delmonico's, for the first time since the adjournment, for the transaction of business, and though the stormy weather prevented a very large attendance, yet. considering this fact. It was full, and as gratifying in the interest manifested as in the number present.

The buyers of suburban property have a busy time before them to-day. Two large sales are to be made, and both of them of first-class property. At Linden, N. L. Messrs. A. D. MELLICK, JR. BRO. offer 230 fine building lots, nicely located, near the station and in a first-class neighborhood.

In Sunday morning's issue of the TIMES the last appearance of the Cuban cruiser Hornet, Prince Albert or Cuba, off Barnegat, on Thursday afternoon, was noted. Since that day no reliable information of her exaet location could be obtained, owing to the religious secrecy with which everything concerning that mysterious craft was kept.

The Southern Commercial Convention, which is to assemble in Louisville, Ky., on the 12th inst., promises to be very attended. So far as is ascertained, there will be present representatives from nearly every State in the Union.

Some time since a person was admitted to the King's College Hospltal ln this city, having met with a serious accident. He has since been identified as either KELLY or DEARY, one of the Fenian prisoners rescued from the custody of the Police at Manchester some time ago.

The Communipaw Market was dull and the sales small. The grades of Cattle were also poor, and though the gross numbers on sale were not heavy, yet, owing chiefly to stress of weather, the Cattle pens were rather fuller at 11:30 A. M. than was pleasing to salesmen. The same must be said of the Sheep market,

A correspondent of the Boston Courier, who has been "interviewing" Senator SPRAGUE. informs the public that the erratic Rhode island Senator "is giving his best thought to the pressing financial and Political economical questions of the hour."

The regular monthly meeting of the Sisters of the Stranger will be held this afternoon, at 4 o'clock, in room No. 45 Bible House. This society, during the Summer, rendered valuable aid to many persons whom the other charities of the City failed to reach.

The storms which have come to our relief within the last few days are very insignificant compared with disturbances which an officer of the English Navy bids as expect to-day. Private advices from Nashville indicate that the Senatorial contest will be closer between JOHNSON and ETHERIDGE than was anticipated. DORSEY THOMAS was elected Speaker of the Senate, and PERKINS of the House. The former is from the West, and the latter from Middle Tennessee.

A fair for the benefit of disabled Union soldiers, and of the widows and orphans of soldiers who fell by the late war, will be hold by the "Ladies' Union Relief Association," at the Apollo Building, entrance No 1,193 Broadway, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth streets, during the week commencing Nov. 8.

Some of the minor henchmen of Tammany were lately quite needlessly alarmed by the rumor that the Sachems intended to nominate an honest man for a municipal office, and they set to work after the fashion of the tribe to make impossible an event so unusual and untoward.

The election which takes place to-day in Jersey City, Hoboken and adjacent towns of Hudson County, new-Jersey, and the result of which is to determine the question of consolidating these cities, appears to call forth a very strong feeling both for and against the proposed scheme.

We are having rather "mixed" times in regard to political affairs. The saloons, brothels and kindred institutions have been "running" this city for some years past, being made use of as instruments by a "Ring" of able, but corrupt and unscrupulous politicians, who farmed out the fat offices to those within the circle--an operation with which you are familiar in New-York.

All the reports which have been received here of the progress of the Republican movement in Spain are confirmed. The town of Reus, nine miles from Tarragona, has declared for liberty. It is said that the Ex-King FERDINAND, of Portugal, has by this time accepted the Spanish crown;
