The Supervisors of Kings County yesterday authorized their Treasurer to issue certificates of indebtedness for, among other things, $15,000 to repair boilers in the county buildings, and $60,000 for a stone wall around the Penitentiary.

The Commissioners of Estimate and Assessment for the property affected by the laying out of the Southeastern Parkway or Boulevard leading from Prospect Park toward East New-York, met at the office of the Prospect Park Commissioners yesterday, Mr. NICHOLAS VAN BRUNT in the chair.

On the 16th alt. Mr. HENRY METZ quarreled with an unknown man in the street, and a struggle ensued During the melee MLTZ was struck on the head with a cart-rung, and was removed to his residence, No. 433 West Thirty-eight-street, in a critical condition.

The appearances yesterday would indicate that the financial flurry has passed over; that matters are settling down, and that business on the "street" will soon follow its accustomed routine. No new failures were reported, the settlements of the; business of week before last progressed favorably,

On the presentation of the following state of facts to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, that official promptly ordered the institution of immediate legal proceedings: A wholesale whisky firm in Kentucky was recently detected in the act of altering Government stamps on barrels of distilled spirits.

Some ingenious person has discovered a method of turning street dirt and sewage into gas. The Londoners have put in a claim to the inventor's services, but here is his proper field: let him come and make our mud into gas, and glory and fortune await him.

The above clubs played a game on Saturday last on the ground of the Endeavor Club, at East New-York, in which the Tribune boys were rather severely "scotched." J. OPENSHAW'S pitching was too much for them, they being unable to hit it from first to last. The play of MYERS and HALLORAN was what is termed "sharp," they carrying off the palm in fielding.

Member of Congress for the Fifth District, made a summary collection, a few days since of JAMES FISK, Jr. of $80,000 or $82,000, being the full amount of the cash balance of Mr. MORRISSEY, involved through his brokers by the failure and fight of FISK, Jr., from Wall-street on Friday week.

A London telegram says that in view of the present complications between the United States and Spain, the Prussian Government has dispatched vessels of war to the Antilles. This would seem to be a precautionary measure of an excedingly prudential sort.

Ex-Senator WADE, in a letter to the Ohio Republican Executive Committee, expresses his confidence in the success of the Republicans in the coming State election, and adds: "It is not possible that the people will desert an Administration, ?? far the most successful in our history."

"TWELFTH NIGHT" AT THE FIFTH--AVENUE THEATRE. Perhaps of all the exquisite Comedies of SHAKESPEARE, "Twelfth Night" is most perfect as a work of art, since there is name other of which it can so accurately be said that either the slightest addition or subtraction would impair its beauty.

Every where workingmen have lately been assembling together to consider their necessities, and the measures by which they may obtain comfort and relief. The Convention held a few weeks ago in Philadelphia was one of the most creditable of all these meetings.

The class of Chinamen taught by Mr. and Mrs. RAILSBACK, at the Five Points House of Industry, held one of their unique festivals in the dining room of the institution last evening. About forty were present, the entertainment consisted of songs by members of the class, with accompaniments upon instruments from the Flowery Land, speeches in Chinese and English and refreshments.

Not a rainy or muddy day--to say nothing of a pleasant day--passes in New-York, without the experience of some fresh annoyance to its citizens, by reason of the invasion of public rights by private persons. One such imposition is the practice of moving heavy safes into the upper stories of tall buildings during the busiest hours of the business day.

On Saturday night, an inoffensive, respectable man, while crossing Chestnut-street Bridge, met his death at the hands of some cowardly dastards, who stabbed him in the left breast, the knife penetrating to the heart and causing death in a few minutes. The murdered man was named JOHN HUGHES; he was about 48 years of age.

Considerable excitement prevailed in this city to-day over the arrival of the Legislature. To-night both parties went into caucus. The Spanish Cortes reassembled on Sunday last. It is thought that measures will be adopted suspending the constitutional guarantees, and investing the Government with extended powers, until the insurrections attending the Republican movement have been suppressed.

Croton water is flowing in to the reservoirs again, but who can tell how soon the supply may once more be exhausted? With a constantly growing City, it is evident that our present means may fail in any dry season. The new reservoirs will help us, but it will be some time before they are ready.

The Chicago Tribune publishes a full report of the speech of United States Senator MATT. H. CARPENTER, at the State Fair in Madison, Wis., on Friday last, "on the growth of monopoly in the carrying business."

The was a large attendance of visitors at the Fair last evening. In accordance with previous announcement, ERASTUS B. BIGELOW, Esq., of BOSTON, President of the Wool Manufacturers' National Association, delivered an address on the wool industry of the United States.

Within the past week six vessels have cleared from this port to Stein, (one of the principal ports on the Black Sea,) taking in the aggregate 13,707 barrels of petroleum. This is the largest weekly shipment from this port over before known, the usual number of departures averaging two vessels a month, and is regarded by the trade as a remarkable occurrence,

The Commissioners of the Board of Foreign Missions opened their sixtieth annual session at the Presbyterian Church, in this city, this evening. It is expected that 1,509 strangers will be present during the week. Dr. MARK HOPKINS, of Williams College, Massachusetts, presided. After the usual preliminaries, . S. P.

If any doubt existed in regard to the close relationship existing between the gold gamblers and the Democracy, it would disappear before the attempt to connect the president and his advisers with the great crime. That attempt was begun early, and has been again and again renewed.

How the credit of New-York may be expected to suffer even in our own country, from recent events in Wall-street, may be inferred from the tone adopted by the Press of Cincinnati, New-Orleans, and other important commercial centers.

There is a fine chance for a "local illustration," if any of the illustrated papers would choose to seize it, in the regular night work on the new City Post Office. The great calcium light gives a weird surrounding to the figures toiling at midnight within the inclosure, and the whole scene is not unlike that of the group of workmen around a great forge or furnace at night --the them of at least one

All the towns in this State, except Bridgeport, held elections for town officers on Monday. Returns have been received thus far from only fifty-two towns, communication with a large portion of the State having been cut off by the storm. Of the towns heard from, 28 elect Republican officers, 18 Democratic, and 6 are divided.

Supervisor EMERY yesterday seized BONNER'S distillery, containing eighty barrels of high wines and 3,000 bushels of grain. Parties were caught in the cistern room in the act of filling barrels with the tax-paid stamp upon them.

The special meeting of the New-York State Central Committee, which was called for yesterday, to take action with regard to the declination of Hon. GEORGE W. CURTIS, who received the Republican nomination for the office of Secretary of State, was held at the Lincoln Club Rooms, No. 37 Union-square.
WILLIAM WALLACE has obtained his honorary testimonial in Scotland, and it seems to be a sort of practical justice that SCHAMYL, the Wallace of the Eastern Caucasus, should be also remembered.

Several telegrams have lately been sent from Philadelphia to the London Times which were apparently intended to produce the impression in Europe that the United States Government were fully bent upon provoking war with Spain.

The sensation created in political circles by the admirable letter of LOUIS BLANC has been followed by another of a religious character, due to a communication addressed by the celebrated Carmelite preacher, Pere HYACINTHE, to the Superior of his order at Rome. The high political morality of the one document is even eclipsed by the lofty independence and truly Christian and apostolic spirit of the other.

The Board met in their Chamber-room number fifteen City ??. Present--Therris Ceman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the in lowing members: Aldermen Moore, Norman, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farley, McQuade--11.

The rise in the Androscoggin River at this point has been unprecedented and rapid. Several millions of legs have gone over the Falls this morning, belonging largely to S. R. BEARSE Co. and to the Lewiston Steam Mill Company. There is no damage to the cotton mills in this city, which are beyond the reach of any contingency.

The elaborate statement of the points at issue in our Chinese diplomacy which Mr. ROBERT HART makes. and which the Alta California publishes, derives its importance chiefly from the position Mr. HART occupies. He is the Inspector-General of Imperial Maritime Customers in China:

A serious disaster occurred at St. Anthony Falls, Minn., this morning from high water. A tunnel in course of construction under the bed of the river from Niccollet Island on the east bank of the river caved in,

Captain HALL, the well-known Aretic explorer, was yesterday charged by one WALTER BAYNE, before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, with the murder of a brother-in-law named PATRICK COLEMAN, on his return voyage a couple of years ago.

The promise made last Spring, at the time the chapter of the Hansom Cab Company was obtained from the State Legislature, that the Company's vehicles would be in running order by the 1st of October, has not been fulfilled.

The ladies who are so gallantly fighting the battle of their sex against a depraved and infatuated world reassembled on Monday after the Summer recess. The elements were propitions--the rain swept in wild gusts over the streets, and the storm-king was abroad.

Paris news says that Pere HYACINTHE is menaced with a sentence of major excommunication. The eloquent preacher at Natre Dame de Paris has never written anything more glowing and pathetic than the letter on this threat which we published yesterday.

Mr., CHARLES DELONG, Minister to Japan; Mr. SHEPPARD, United States Consul at Yeddo, and several Consuls of the United States, of Great Britain and of Belgium, in China and Japan, took their departure on the steamer china to-day.

To-day the Fall race meeting at Jerome Park is inaugurated with the match day. three of the six events being races of that description. The first is for $5,000, between two two-year olds, Mr. BELMONT'S ch. f. Finesse distance one mile.

It will be remembered that within a few days the United States frigate Secera and the monitor Dictator have been announced as under orders to proceed to the coast of Cuba. The TIMES is now enabled to publish lists of their officers. The following are. THE OFFICERS OF THE SEVERN.

The impetus given of late years to cotton cultivation in the East Indies is remarkable. The natives begin to appreciate the fact that it pays them better to produce cotton. which fetches 10d. a pound in the market, than the ?? millet of the country, which scarcely enables them to "keep body and soul together."

The Legislature convened at noon, with a full attendance. In the House a temporary organization was effected, with Wm. M. LANGLAN, of Rockbridge, as Speaker, and H. G. JONEE, of Albemarle, as Clerk, and adjourned till to-morrow, when permanent officers will be elected.

Speaking of a prominent Democratic orator now on the stump in Ohio, the Charleston Courier says that he "first was a temperance man, then, a Republican, then a Conservative, and now at last, he has come out entirely from among the Philistines, and become a thorough.

A meeting of this association was held at the rooms, NO. 45 Bible House, Astor-place, yesterday. The association was organized in January last, the object being to give medical and legal advice to all who may stand in need of them, and also pecuniary assistance.

The burglar of the period is just now unusually adroit and exceptionally industrious and successful. Only the other night he filehed $100,000 from the safes of a Norwich bank, and his recent operations in this City, although not so brilliant, have been continuous and remunerative.

A great independence meeting was held at Waterloo on Saturday, presided over by Mr. PARMLEE, Warden of the County. Hon. Mossrs. JOHN YOUNG and L.S. HUSTINGTON and Mr. LAFLAMME spoke in favor of Independence, and R. CHAMBERLIN and J. B. LAY against it.

Great activity prevails at the Industrial Exhibition preparatory to the grand opening to-morrow night. The exhibition will be a grand success. There is already a magnificent display of every variety of machinery, fancy goods, c.

The supply of Croton continues to increase with gratifying rapidity. At the time of the latest return from the fountain--head , yesterday, there was five feet seven inches of water in the Aqueduct, as against two feet seven inches a few days ago, and the height of water over the top of the dam was one foot with a continuous rise.

A correspondent writes that the keeper of Washington-square should not be held responsible for the fifthy appearance of the fountain-bed in that Park. The Croton Board employs a man to keep it in order, and the keeper has no control over it.
The tone of King WILLIAM'S speech at the coming opening of the North German Parliament, the Berlin journals say, will be entirely pacific. The French Emperor, it is said, will go to Compiegne.

The cold rain of Sunday and Monday was rather unfavorable for out-of-door sales, and the fear of damp ground, wet grass, bad walking over muddy roads, and consequent colds and sneezes, undoubtedly frightened off many who would have attended had the earlier days of the week been bright and warm, vet a goodly number did muster courage to visit the country, and the results of the sales are very gratifying.

The letter which we recently published, protesting against our liability to support foreign criminals, has attracted considerable attention. Other nations find it very convenient to get rid of their vagabonds and outlaws by giving them money to pay their passage to some foreign country.

A paragraph was recently published that Consul-General PLUMB had informed this Government of an apprehension that the Spanish authorities in Cuba would interfere with the United States mails. No such interference, however, has taken place, and therefore no case has occurred requiring any

Spain reconstructs herself slowly. She appears to be further removed from peace and order to-day than she was a year ago. The cable informs us this morning that martial law has been proclaimed in Andalusia and Catalonia.

The work at Hell Gate progresses slowly but to all appearances surely. The coffer Harn which the Government is building at Hailet's pomt will be complete in about a week, when the water will be pumped out for driluing opeearations. Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to ?? packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, Genera Agent.

The operators in gold and stocks experienced another day of quiet yesterday, and it now seems as if the financial flurry of the past two weeks had entirely passed over, but how long this state of affairs will continue it is impossible to say.

The Coroner's jury rendered the following verdict late last night: "P. L. DAVIS and twenty others came to their death by the exploding of the boiler attached to E. P. SINKER CO.'S portable engines at the Indiana Fair Grounds, which explosion was caused by carelessness and culpable mismanagement on the part of the engineer in charge, JNO. GALL, deceased."

There is at cast frankness in the method by which the Cincinnati Enquirer pushes its policy of repudiation. The World would have us believe that issues of that sort are introduced into platforms only for show. They are "mere dead formalism," it says. But the Enquirer insists that "the paramount issue is the national debt, and the form of its payment,"

The Cunard steamship China, which left Liverpool Sept. 25, and Queenstown Sept. 26, reached this port yesterday. Her advice's are later by two days than were those received by the City of Brooklyn. AFFAIRS IN FRANCE.

The Hartford courant of to-morrow morning will contain the following card from Mrs. STOWE: To the Editor of the Courant: Mrs. STOWE desires the friends of justice and fair dealing to publish for her this anhourncement: That she has kept silence heretofore in regard to the critleisms on her article on Lady BYRON for two reasons.

Down in Delaware they have discovered what they fondly believe to be a severer punishment than the whipping-post. It is doubtful if outsiders will share the delusion. A notorious thief was lately arrested at Milford, and a local paper exclaims: "What terror has the whipping-post to such black rascals at this?

In the matter of the habeas corpus in the cases of JAMES DOUGHERTY and HUGH MARKA, charged with shooting at BROOKS, the Philadelphia revenue officer, with intent to kill, Judge McCUNN, yesterday, issued write of habeas corpus and cerhorari.

The Woman's Suffrage Association yesterday discussed a resolution offered by Mrs. NORTON, to the effect that, in view of the approaching November election, the women should organize throughout the State, establish their own polio and vote on the candidates, independently of the men.

Official dispatches from Madrid change that Senior PAUL, a member of the Cortes, is in command of one of the Republican bands in the South. Communications between Madrid and Barcelona are interrupted.

But two sales were made yesterday, one at the Exchange Salesroom, by Messrs. E. H. LUDLOW CO., the other at the Commercial Exchange, Brooklyn , by Mr. J. COLE. The attendance was very good in both cases and the prices realized quite satisfactory. The prospects for a busy Fall season in City property are now very good.

JULES FERRY, one of the Deputies to the Corps Legislatif, elected recently from Paris, has called a meeting of the members of the Opposition, to take proper action with regard to the delay in opening the sessions of the Assembly.

In steamship Cuba, for Liverpool.--Sir Henry Holland, C. Appleton, Mr. Mason, Miss Julia Appleton, Miss Alice Appleton, Mr. Appleton's servant, James Huntington, A. Berger, Mr. and Mrs. F. Johnson and child, A. Vickers, Mrs. F. Weld and child, Mr. and Mrs. Austin Baldwin, Henry Green, Mrs. Dwight, Miss Dwight, Stanley Dwight. J. F. Cooke, M. Friedman, Mr. Beswick, Jas. T. Lee, E. Dexter, W. J. Rivington.

If there is one spot of earth in which all who speak the English tongue may be said to take a common interest it is the island of Juan Fernandez. The favorite tale of nearly every childhood is by most of us remembered through life with grateful affection, and the scene of its marvelous inceidents shares in our regard.

The Railroad Convention was called to order this morning in Doohttle Hall, at 10 o'clock, by Mayor PAGE, who stated that owing to the interruption to travel by the late freshet, many of the delegates had been unable to reach the city. He therefore proposed an adjournment until this evening at 7 o'clock, which was agreed to.

The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions resumed their session this morning. A special report from the Prudential Committee was read by Dr. WOOD, and referred to a special committee of seven, to report at the next meeting. Rev. Dr. CLARKE read a paper from the Prudential

JULES FAVRE, a Paris deputy elect to the Corps Legislatif, has called a meeting of the opposition to take action about the delay in opening the sessions of the French Assembly. A number of meetings are announced through out Ireland of those favorable to Fenian amnesty.

"Paterfamilias" asks us if there is any legal redress against express companies for the failure of delivery of personal baggage within a reasonable time after it is placed in their charge. On the general principle that for "every wrong there is a remedy." we should say there was legal redress in the case specified, there being probably a non-fulfilment of contract.

The steamship Alaska, from Aspinwall Sept. 28, bringing the regular mails, passengers and merchandise, reached this port yesterday. For the prompt delivery of our special correspondence we are indebted to the Purser. The Alaska's treasure list is as follows:

Coroner ROLLINS yesterday held an inquest at the Sixteenth Precinct Police Station House, in the case of PETER ROONEY, who was killed by the colored man, ROBERT FRY, during a fracas in Twenty-second-street, near Eighth-avenue, on Tuesday last.
The First Division National Guard made its Fall parade yesterday afternoon, and was reviewed by Governor HOFFMAN. The day was a clear and bracing one, and the display was a fine one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--A curious case was decided by the Internal Revenue Bureau to-day. Some time ago a question was submitted by the Virginia Internal Revenue officials whether sweet potatoes should be considered as grain or fruit.

Mails for Bermuda, by the Fah Kee, close at the General Post Office at 2 P.M. Mails for Havana and West Indies, via Nassau, N. P., by the Eagle, close at 2 P.M. Mails for Europe, via Bremen and Southampton, by the Union, close at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters, on the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P.M.

There ought to be little hesitation on the part of the British Government as to the proper course toward those Fenian prisoners whose release is still urged by public meetings in England and Ireland. While nothing can excuse deliberate murder and kindred crimes, such are not charged against all the Fenians in jail;

GEORGE YOUNG, Solicitor-General for Scotland, has been appointed Lord Advocate of Scotland in place of Right Hon. JAMES MONCHIEFF. The Pull Mall Gazette, in its financial article, says, The demand for mercantile accommodation and renewals in Manchester is greater at the present moment than it has been for the past twenty years."

As nearly as we can make out, from the conflicting reports, the Great Allied victory in Paraguay was the cover for the Allied evacuation of the country. It was the same device which prompts a grand lighting of camp fires or a terrible cannonade, under cover of which an army withdraws from its lines.

The movement in favor of peace and conciliation among the Republicans of West Virginia, which was inauguarted a few weeks ago in Ohio County, is repidly extending. General JOHN S. WITCHER, member of Congress from the Third District of the State, has indorsed it, saying that he believes the time has come when they can with perfect security repeal every proseriptive law upon the statute book:

The International Industrial Exhibition opened this evening with most imposing ceremonies. Nothwithstanding the recent storm and freshet prevented many articles intended for exhibition from arriving in time for the opening, the buildings were crowded to their utmost capacity, and the display of mechanical, agricultural and miscellaneous articles was of the most brilliant and extensive character.

BECKLEY.--In this City. on Tuesday evening, Oct. 5, at the residence of his son, Samnel M. Hackley, after it short illness. SILAS RECKLEY, of Canaan, Conn., to the 81th year of his age. His remains will be taken to the latter place for by terment. CONANT.--On Wednesday, Oct. 6, if typhoid lever, WILLIAM S. CONANT, aged 55 years, 5 months and 25 days.

Numerous charities are placed in an embarrassing position through the new litigation which was sprung up in regard to the disposition of the Excise Fund. The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund claim a large proportion of these moneys under a former act of the Legislature,

Negotiations, we are told, have been reopened between the Colombian Government and our own, for the construction of an interoceanic ship-canal across the Isthmus; and simultaneously we hear of revolutionary plots and projects to get possession of the narrow neck of land.

On Monday morning the Eastman tunnel, half a mile long, new being excavated for the purpose of making a water power on Nicolet Island, piereed a sunken water cavern in the island, below the level of the river. The gates at the head of the tunnel were closed, bit the rush of water could not be arrested.

The first lovely autumnal day we have yet been favored with was reserved for the opening of the Fall Meeting at Jerome Park. The weather was neither cold nor hot, but just touched the "happy mean" which wise men covet in all things, and too seldom enjoy in any. After so many days of clouds and storm, the bright sun was enough to tempt an anchorite from his cell.

In the House of Representatives to-day two resolutions were introduced, that the "iron-clad oath" be now administered to the members and temporary officers of the House, which were referred to the proper committee when it shall be appointed.

The accusation of murder brought against Captain HALL, the Arctic explorer, is founded on facts which the Captain has already voluntarily given in the newspapers. That he shot COLEMAN is not disputed, but where-as BAYNE, the brother-in-law of COLEMAN, declares that the shooting was reckless, and that COLEMAN had been "guilty of no act of insubordination,"

At the One Hundredth-street National Yards only 420 fresh Cattle were on sale, but it was fortunate that 531 were held from former markets. The great storm and floods have prevented getting stock through. Nearly all of these fresh Cattle were gathered up in Dutchess County, below the break on the Harlem Road. The farmers there jumped at a chance to get good prices, and they have done it.

King WILLIAM opened the Diet to-day with a speech from the throne. He said an unavoidable deficit in the finances rendered an augmentation of the taxes necessary. He announced that reforms would be introduced placing the Eastern provinces on a basis of self-government, and that new laws in regard to public education would be submitted.

The Mississippi regular Republican State Convention, which met in Jackson Sept. 29 and remained in session through the following day, nominated the following ticket for State officers: Governor--J. L. ALCORN. Lieutenant-Governor--R. C. POWERS. Secretary of State--JAMES LYNCH (colored.) Auditor-HENRY MUSGROVE.

When, several years ago, a violent controversy arose in England between the older life insurance companies and a number of new ones, it was claimed upon behalf of the latter that they could never result in injury to tile policy holders, because, f a young company were unsuccessful it could sell its business, that is, transfer its risks to some other more fortunate.

The savagery always dormant in great cities has again become active. The Metropolis has been furnished in one day with three murders and two suicides, all essentially barbarous and sensational. The affair in Cherry-steel, where a Chinaman murdered his wife and a fellow-countryman and then killed himself, was singularly marked by Eastern characteristies.

A few days since the TIMES foreshadowed a number of gratifying reforms as about to he introduced into the management of our public schools. Under the direction of the new Board of Education. Among other features mentioned were the reduction of expenditures of the coming year by about $500,000, as co apared with the preceding twelve month, and the Large increase of school accomadation.

The union Republican Central Central Committee, known as the Twenty-eighth-street organization, met last evening at No. 1,193 Broadway, to appoint the Union members allotted to them of the Committee of twelve provided for in the recent arrangement for the consolidation of the Union Republican organization in this City. Mr. NORMAN STRATTON.

several months ago some of the authorities of Baltimore were aroused to an extremely high pitch of virtuous indignation against the indecent dances in two of the city theatres, and summarily arrested the proprietors. Subsequently they were admitted to bail, and the cases have dragged along in the courts;

The Democrats of Mississippi, following the example of their brethren in other States, pretend to deplore the rejection of their overtures by the mass of the colored voters of the State. The fact is used by Democratic orators and oracles as a text for much indignant eloquence in regard to the perils of political parties based upon a division of races.

The quarterly report of Dr. HARRIS, Sanitary Superintendent of the Board of Health, shows the gratifying fact that the death rate during the past Summer in New-York has been less than in either of the preceding three years, and even that the total number of deaths is less than for the same period in 1866, 1867 or 1868.

The forms of another annual meeting of the stockholders of the Erie Railway corporation, for the election of Directors, are to be gone through next Tuesday. Heretofore seventeen Directors were elected every year. Now this trouble is saved by the compliant legislation at Albany last Spring, approved by Governor HOFFMAN,

Coroner FLYNN decided yesterday to postpone the inquest over the bodies of CHARLES ARCHOE, HENRY ACONG and SARAH ANN, his wife the details of whose tragical deaths have already been narrated in the TIMES. The reason for the postponement was because no good interpreter could be obtained for the examination of witnesses. Dr. SHINE occupied the forenoon by making the necessary post-mortem examination.

The action of the United States Officials in summarily seizing the Cuban privateer Hornet without any compliant being entered by the Spanish Consuls, is in entire harmony with the precedents of our history. It has always been held that the Government officers could libel and arrest, or the Secretary of State detain, suspicious cruisers merely on an affidavit or on any "probable cause."

The regular semi-monthly meeting of the Board of Education was held last evening, Mr. LARREMORE in the chair. A communication was read from Mr. J. W. GERARD, School Inspector of the Fifth District, calling attention to the expulsion of twenty scholars from School No. 50 on account of their parents not residing in this City.

Our Evening Schools are ones more quietly at work--so quietly in the midst of our more noisy agencies of progress, that they are scarcely noticed. But they are likely to be the most powerful of them all, and the most beneficial, making as they do the first movement in what will be an excellent change in the end.

The trading mind is always quick to seize absorbing events for speculative purposes and is generally forcible and just in its satire. A striking instance is that of the vendor who is a vertising his wares by means of the gold excitement. His wagon goes through the streets bearing a transparency wherein is pictured a number of sharks dashing about in troubled water,

JAMES FISK, Jr., was served yesterday with the writ of cupias issued against him on Monday by United States Commissioner SHIELDS, in the suit of JAMES BROWN CO., for the recovery of $2,500.000, alleged to have been lost an Wall-street gold speculations.

Yesterday was a very favorable day for out-of-town sales, and two firms improved it. At Newtown. Long Island, Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had a large sale of really very valuable and beautiful property. Perhaps, 400 persons attended, and they were of a very excellent class. There were very few "repeaters."
There was a great debate in the Madrid Cortes over the Government proposal to suspend the guarantees of the Constitution, CASTELLAR, ORENSE and SAGASTA made speeches.

Among other vessels driven ashore in the terrible storm of Sunday evening last was the sarah Elizabeth, a British bark, bound to this port from Buenos Ayres, with a very valuable eargo of hides and other articles. She was grounded near Gilgoe's inlet, on the Long Island shore, where she still remains.

The attendance of visitors at the Fair increases daily. On Wednesday the receipts for entrance fees were $1, 750, and yesterday they were in excess of this sum. The wool department has within a few days past received new and additional attractions.

The Republican State Central Committee met, according to adjournment, at the Lincoln Club Rooms, No. 37 Union-square, at noon yesterday. There were present, among others of the members, Hon. HAMILTON HARRIS, in the chair, Messrs. Thos. E. Stewart and Henry Smith, of New-York; O. B. Latham, of Seneca; James W. Husted, of Westchester; Benj. Field

There is non ore uncompromising opponent of the "Secom Empire." not oven excepting VICTOR HUGH, than LOUIS BLANG. He might have gone back to France long ago, and been certain of a career worthy of his talents, but while NAPOLEON is on the throne he prefers to earn his bread in London by acting as the correspondent of a French newspaper.

A special dispatch to the Press Herald shows that the Governor's message is not to go to the Legislature till Monday. This action causes much comment. The action of Legislature shows hasty action on sweeping bills to repeal all legislation since the war. One bill was passed to repeal ail laws passed in the years 1865-6-7 and 8.

The intrigue which has recently been set in motion against the President, if not absolutely without a parallel in political history, is certainly among the most unscrupulous which the present generation has witnessed.

The evening session of the Woman's Suffrage Convention yesterday assembled in Mercantile Library Hall. Over two thousand persons were in attendance,. The Convention was addressed by Mrs. JULIA WARD HOWE, of Boston, and Mrs. LIVERMORE, of Chicago. Miss ANTHONY also made a brief speech, which was well received.
The French Transatlantic Cable will probably soon find itself in difficulty. Permission to land it at Duxbury was accorded by the State Department, subject expressly to the revision of Congress.

Coroner FLYNN held an inquest yesterday in the case of the Cherry-Street tragedy. The only evidence elicited was that given by GEORGE ABQUNG, the solitary eye witness to the affair, as follows: I reside at No. 67 Cherry-Street; on Tuesday night. I returned home from Work, and, after having my super, went to the night School about 7 o'clock;

The case of EMMA DALZELL vs. AUGUSTUS S. DALZELL was up in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, again yesterday. A motion was made that the judgement of divorce granted in April last he vacated and defendant ordered to pay plaintiff $75 a week for the support of herself and children, and $730 for counsel fees.

Wednesday evening a steer broke out of a slaughter house at the corner of Forty-seventh-street and First-avenue, rushed to Thirty-sixth-street, back to Forty-seventh-street, and then down to Second-avenue and Forty-fourth-street.

In the case of JAMES DOUGHERTY and HUGH MARRA, charged with a deadly assault on BROOKS, the Philadelphia revenue officer, Judge McCUNN concluded to remand the prisoners, on the ground that it appeared satisfactory to him that a crime had been committed, indictments found for that crime, and a proper complaint made in Philadelphia against those men,

A special dispatch from Washington to the World says that: "Commissioner DELANO has received a letter from Supervisor PRESBURY, of Virginia, announcing that the collections on manufactured tobacco in that State from March to September, 1868, were $280,247 41,

The letter of Hon. ISRAEL T. HATCH, of Buffalo, in reply to the announcement made to him by a great number of his fellow citizens- Democrats and Republicans alike and utterly irrespective of party ties-that they have put him in nomination for the Assembly as an independent candidate, is full of interest. In accepting the nomination.

Rev. LEONARD W. BACON is out in a card charging the Christian Aid Society (City Mission) of Williamsburg with neglect of the poor. He asks its directors if it is their purpose for one more Winter to stand between the poor and their opportunity relief, and between the ignorant and ungodly of that district and the free gospel of Jesus Christ?

The Norwalk (Conn.) Bank lost by the recent burglary $32.984. The bonds stolen were the property of depositors of boxes, with the exception of $15,000 available securities held by the bank as collateral for discounted notes. The entire loss of the bank, actual and contingent, is, therefore, inside of $50,000, which is about the amount of its surplus.

The prophecy of SAXBY, the English naval officer, of a flood between the 5th and 9th of October, and from the 1st to the 30th of November, has produced lively antediluvian apprehensions among those who believe it. SAXBY made a similar prediction of floods to occur in December, 1862,

We are glad to hear that the irregularities which are said to have occurred in the Methodist Book Concern in this City, by certain employes of that establishment, are being officially investigated.

The South Pacific Railroad is completed to Lebanon. At last, after years of trial and repeated failures, the road has been pounded through the "hard pan" and the hard country from Little Piney to Lebanon, and now the directors and officers of the Company, with a numerous party of invited guests,

In the Senate, the protest of the Republican caucus against the legality of the body was taken up and read at length. If announces that the Republican members reserve to themselves the right and at any time to secede from the present Legislature and organize by themselves a legal and loyal Legislature. The Senate voted to lay it on the table.

The sidewheel steamer Tallapoosa arrived at the Navy Yard yesterday from Annapolis with three hundred and fifty marines, and a miscellaneous cargo. The Swatara yesterday moved over to the ordinance dock for the purpose of taking her guns on board.

A fire occurred here at 2:30 o'clock this morning, which destroyed a largo portion of the Seymour House, and burned to the ground two frame buildings of J. DOYLE, west of the Seymour House, on Whitesboro-street; also, the Stanwix Hall barns. The rear of SINK's new Opera House was scorched, but sustained no serious damage.

On Monday night this place was visited by a tremendous gale and the highest tide ever known. the marshes were completely covered. Thousands of tons of hay were destroyed, and thousands of cattle and sheep drowned. The dykes on the marshes are all gone, and the bridges all through the country swept away.

The Convention opened at 10:30 o'clock with prayer by Rev. Mr. BONTE. J. C. CHURCHILL, from the Committee on Credentials, submitted a report upon those received. On motion of Mr. FORT the report was accepted, with the understanding that the Committee report upon additional credentials as delegates arrive.

The accounts from Spain get worse instead of better. The insurrectionary party evidently gains in strength, and the latest telegrams inform us that communication between Madrid and Barcclona is interrupted. The belief prevails that the authorities conceal from the people the bad news which they receive from the Provinces.

In the Baltimore Presbytery, now in session in this City, the question of a reunion of the two branches of the Church is now undergoing animated discussion. J. CATNEL was run over and killed on the Northern Central Railroad yesterday, two miles from this City.

CONANT.--On Wednesday, Oct, 6 of typhoid fever, WILLIAM S. CONANT, aged 55 years, 5 months and 29 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 23 South 20th-St., Brooklyn, E. D., on Friday, Oct, 8. at 1 o'clock P. M.

In enumerating the present directors of the Erie Road, we yesterday included the name of Mr. W. B. SKIDMONE. That gentleman, we find, resigned the position last November. Rev. Dr. H. B. HACKETT has accepted the Chair of New Testament Exegesis in the Rochester Theological Seminary.

Mrs. BEECHER STOWE is determined to ride the whirlwind and direct the storm she has raised. She is now in her clement, and will further engage all her adversaries over the body of the unfortunate bard, who, like the Thracian in Rhodope, " was also illused by the women."

The jury, after hearin all the testimony, unhesitationgly rendered a verdict that the homicide was justfiable, as FRY had acted strictly in self--defence.

Notwithstanding all that has been written to the contrary, both in foreign and American journals, the relations and intercourse between the Spanish Government and our own are of the most friendly character, and have not been otherwise at any time since the incoming of the present Administration.

The Rapped assures its readers to-day that the Deputies of the Left will Proseed on the 26th of October to the Bureaus of the Corps Legislatif and sign a protest declaring that the Emperor has violated the Constitution, and that they consider themselves absolved thereby from their oaths of fidelity to him. elity to him.

Madrid dispatches state that the Cortes on Wednesday passed the bill suspending the constitutional guarantee during insurrection, after a great debate, in which CASTELLAR, ORENSE and SAGASTA made speeches. The Republican Deputies, it is said, now refuse to take part in the deliberations of the Chamber.

The case of WILLIAM VARLEY, otherwise "Reddy the Blacksmith." is now likely to be brought to a speedy termination. Yesterday the conspicuous male factor was arraigned before Recorder HACKETT, in the court of General Sessions, on the old charge of robbery in the first degree, which was made against him by LAWRENCE, GRAHAM , Or GRANAHAN, of Hudson City,

A quorum of the members of the New-York Chamber of commerce Intel at their rooms No. 63 William-Street, yesterday at 1 o'clock, Ex-Mayor GEO. OPDYKE, First Vice-President, in the chair. The period of service of the four delegates of the Chamber to the National Board of Trade having expired, authority was ronferred upon the chair to appoint their successors.

Dr. WILBERFORCE, Bishop of Oxford, has been translated to the Diocese of Winchester. Rev. Dr. MACKARNESS succeeds Dr. WILBERFORCE as Bishop of Oxford. The official report of the Bank of England, made public to-day, shows that the amount of specie in vault has decreased (Pound)362,000 sterling since the last report.

To-day was the third day of the racing at Narragansett Park. The weather was lovely, the course in perfect order, and the attendance larger than on either of the preceding days. The remaining heats in the race for 2:30 horses, which were postponed last night, were first trotted. Both heats were won by Surprise in 2:27 1/2 and 2:27 3/4.

At the session of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions in Pittsburg, Penn., on Tuesday, Rev. S. P. TREAT, D. D., Chairman of the Committee on Home Department, read his annual report, giving a detailed exhibit of the operations of that department during the year.

MILE. CARLOTTA PATTI IN BROOKLYN. Mile. CARLOTTA PATTI'S second concert in Brooklyn took place on Tuesday, and displayed the same characteristics of case and finish on the part of the artist, and of spell-bound attention and rapturous applause on that of the large audience, which we have noted before.

Yesterday, at noon, the members of the New-York Gold Exchange assembled in executive session to consider the report of the Committee of nine, which had previously declared in favor of establishing a new Clearing House for gold.

The telegraph reported on Tuesday morning that a man named JOHN S. ANDREWS had suddenly disappeared from Chicago, with $7,000 belonging to other parties. The Chicago papers show that JAMES F. ANDREWS in the person against whom the charge is made.

A New-Orleans dispatch to the Louisville Courier-Journal has a story of a counterplot in Cuba, or a plot within a plot, whose purport is that certain wealthy Cubans in the island, opposed to insurrection, are about to unite with the resident Spaniards in a "struggle for independence."

The Committee appointed by the Albany Common Council to confer with the descendants of General SCHUVLER with reference to the erection of a monument to the memory of the Revolutionary patriot, are expected to report soon. The Albany Argus hopes that a bronze statue, to be placed in the new City Park, will be decided upon.

Ex-President PIERCE died at 4:40 o'clock this morning. His disease was chronic inflammation of the stomach, attended with, dropsical effusion of the abdomen. The funeral has been fixed to take place on Monday noon, at St.
This afternoon the Eckfords and Atlantics play their second game for the championship on or the Union Grounds in Brooklyn. The reputation of these splendid mines will not fail to draw a great crowd.

The Commercial Convention which meets at Louisville next Tuesday will unquestionably, like its Memphis predecessor, do a good work in reconstructing Southern commerce, reviving Southern industry and developing Southern manufacturing and mining. Nor is this all. Beyond its material influence.

The recent railroad accident at Hopsick Falls, by which Dr. FOWLER and wife, of that place, and Mr. AIKEN, of Sand lake, lost their lives, and other parties were seriously injured, has in a measure been overshadowed by the events of the week. It was, however, a most tragic and heart-rending affair;

The following announcement of the assessment for State purposes, of property in Kings County, has been made to the Board of Supervisors of that county: "The Board of Equalization of taxes, in pursuance to chapter 312 of the laws of 18??, have fixed the aggregate valuation of property in your county at the sum of $154,491,259.

Deputies SIMON and MAGNIN support Deputy JULES FERRY in calling a meeting of the members of the Corns ?? to take action in regard to the delay in the convocation of the Chambers. Nearly all the journals deprecate the proposed manifestation of the Deputies of the Left on the 20th of October.

W. L. CHADWICK, Esq., our auctioneer, yesterday returned from Lincoln City, Nebraska and gives us the following particulars of the sales made under his superintendency: The sales commenced at Lincoln of the 23d ult., and continued three days. The sales were more largely attended than any previous ones, and the bidding was even more active than at the sales held last June.

An amusine wedding ceremony took place in Lawrence recently. The bride was from Maine, and was expected to arrive in town on the 7 o'clock train, and the services of one of our clergymen had been engaged to unite them the same evening.

The Ladies' Aid Society for the new German Hospital held a meeting at the Steuban House yesterday afternoon, Mrs. FRANCISCA KLEIN presiding. During the last two weeks $84 45 and a number of articles needed in the hospital were collected by the Society, their entire money collections amounting now to about $32,000.

The habeas corpus in the case of MCLAUGHLIN, the driver of the carriage in which the Brooks assassins escaped, was quashed this morning on the ground that the prisoner had not applied for the writ, nor did he desire its issue.

Who was not heard of Oberlin? On account of its position on the question of paces and sexes, as far as their education is concerned, perhaps no institution of learning in the world of its years has received such wide and terrible reproach and calumny as Oberlin College.

Mr. SEWARD and his party sailed on the steamer Golden City to-day. Through the courtesy of the officers of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company they will be landed at Manzamilo.

Prominent among the cities of the South which are rapidly recovering from the disastrous effects of the war is Savannah, Ga. Its Public spirited citizens appreciate and are now availing themselves of the unusual facilities afforded by its excellent harbor, and the commercial importance of the port is consequently being rapidly increased,
CORNELIUS DRISCOLL, of No. 358 Cherry-street, fell from his cart yesterday, at the corner of Ludlow and Canal streets, receiving a compound fracture of the leg. He was taken home by the Police.

On Monday about 10 o'clock, the stream north of the Hoosick tunnel, brook through the embankment and poured into the cut or excavation between the west end and the old Hanpt tunnel, So called, through which the water is conducted off into the Hoosae River.

To-day but one sale will be made. At Paterson, N. J., Messrs. A. J. BLBECKER, SON Co. will by order of the Dale Manufacturing Company, sell a number of building lots and a number of buildings and lots, many of the tenements well occupied. Maps and particulars may be had at the auctioneers' office, No. 77 Cedar-street.

The career of the Hornet is scarcely worth a line, except as affording a practical example of the course invariably pursued by this Government in relation to international questions. We do not allow privateers to escape from our ports, or to take coal and refit in them, and if England had adopted the same policy toward us was should have been spared much loss and she much danger.

Many complaints are made as to the concrete pavement which has lately been laid on Fifth-avenue. It is alleged by the residents on that thoroughfare that the new pavement does not at all answer the purpose for which it was intended; and that the laying of it has simply necessitated, in future, an additional expense for removing it, to be borne either by the property owners on the avenue or by the City at large.

The Trial of "the Blacksmith"--Tame Testimony of the Chief Wimens--?? Acquitted and Let Losse Once More. The Court of Genral Sessions was crowded with people again yesterday, for it was known that the trial of "Reddy the Blacksmith," whose proper name is WILLIAM VARLEY, was at length about to take place.

To-day is the first regular day of the Jerome Park Fall meeting, Wednesday being the extra or match day. The card to-day is mutually rich in racing sport, there being a hurdle race, a handicap dash of one mile and a quarter, a mile-heat race for three-year olds, and a mile dash for two-year olds.

The Thanksgiving Proclamation is not in any sense a State paper, but it is always made the vehicle of communicating an official summary of our national position in the last quarter of the year. The President on this occasion has nothing but causes of gratitude to which it is necessary to invite our attention.

The recent Peace Congress, which met at Lansanne to breathe out present threatening and prospective slaughter against the rulers of Europe, was closed by a speech from M. VICTOR HUGO. That eccentrics poet's address resembled his latest romance, in that it was partly retrospective, partly prophetic, and wholly delirious.

A year or two ago, the sum of $1,000,000 was left by Mr. ROOSEVELT to build and ennow a hospital in this City. The site chosen for the hospital is the block bounded by Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth streets and Ninth and Tenth avennes. The necessary excavations have already been made, and the corner stone of the new building will probably he laid within a few days.
Commissioner BOSWORTH yesterday sat to investigate charges against policemen. A large number of cases were tried, but were generally of a trivial character.

Republican nominations for the Senate have been made as follows: Fifteenth District, Truman G. Younglove; Eighteenth District, Morris Winslow; Nineteenth District, Daniel B. Goodwin; Twenty-first District, William H. Brand; Twenty-second District, George N. Kennedy; Twenty-fourth District, Orlow W. Chapman; Twenty-fifth District,

The sessions of the Church Congress opened at Liverpool on the 6th inst. Dean CHESTER urged the importance of a large-hearted and generous treatment of all non-conformists and Catholics. Several members of the Congress absenced themselves on account of a paper presented by MACKONOCHIE.

Both Houses of the Legislature to-day ratified the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments. In the House there were only six votes against them, and in the Senate only four against the Fourteenth and two against the Fifteenth,

On Saturday evening a thrilling adventure befell the messenger in charge of the car of the American Express Company on the night express train from Erie to this city. Shortly after leaving the former place he discovered to his consideration that the contents of the car were on fire.
A very interesting work has just been published in London called Mary, Queen of Scots, and her Accusers. Mr. HOSACK defends that unfortunate and most interesting Sovereign with warmth and eloquence.

The Position of the Cormen-Amercian population of this City, inrepest to the Republican and Democartie parties, is, to say the least, anomations. The latter absorber a large percentage of them into its ranks, and yet it is antagonistic to almost all the ideas of good government and pure representation. The review of the Second Division of the National Guard at the Prospect Park parade ground, Thursday, was a brilliant affair. The Division was under command of major-General WOODWARD.

The London journals continue industriously to discuss the Byron business. Nearly all the most respectable among them have expressed strong distaste for the subject, deprecating its agitation and implying that they, at least, would not be parties to it ; and have followed up such intimations by long and repeated essays on one side or the other, to which there seems just now little prospect of any termination.

HOLLISTER, late United States Minister to Hayti, had been appointed as representative of the latter Government to Washington, in place of Mons. E. LAROCHE, the present Minister.

The report of the Committee appointed by the Board of Education on Sept. 15 to examine the entire public school system, with a view to a reduction of expenses, has already been printed in our columns.

F. A. P. BARNARD, President of columbia College, resumed his duties-yesterday. He had been travelling in Europe with a view to procuring scientific improvements for this College. In a brief address he congratulated the students on the new system which was inaugurated last term.
The speech of Mr. SUMNER, made to the Massachusetts Convention, calls up a subject which, if it were possible, the nation ought to take counsel with itself upon.

The Constitutional Union General Committee met last evening at Masonic Hall, Mr. DANIEL B. NORTHRUP presiding. A committee of five was appointed to confer with the Executive Committee in regard to effecting subordinate organizations in the various wards of the City, after which various gentlemen were called upon to express their views on the purposes and objects of this general organization.

A new railroad, the Flushing and North Side Railroad, is just being completed from Hunter's Point to Flushing, and on eastward along the north side of Long Island, with a branch to College Point and Whitestone. The read is now in operation to Manhasset and to College Point.

The speech of Senator MORTON, at Cincinnati, is a powerful and masterly presentation of the issues at stake in the coming Ohio election, and , indeed, of the fundamental distinctions between Republican and Democratic policy the country over.

Mr. JAMES POLLOCK, Whose death securred on Thursday evening in this city, was an esteemed and valued citizen of San Francisco Ca; He arrived in New-York some two months since, being one of the first to take advantage of the New-Orleans Ponte across the continent, and was visiting relatives who reside here.

Yesterday Officer BUTCHER, of the Sixteenth Precinet, arrested JOHN MEANY for alleged complicity in the killing of PETER ROONEY, who was shot by the negro ROBERT FRY, and took him before Justice LEDWITH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by whom the prisoner was remanded for the action of the Coroner.

King WILLIAM opened the regular sessions of the Prussian Diet with a pacific speech. He said the deficit in the national finances was unavoidable, and that an augmentation of the taxes would therefore be necessary.

By the President of the United States: A PROCLAMATION. The year which is drawing to a close has been free from pestilence. Health has prevailed throughout the land. Abundant crops reward the labors of the husbandman. Commerce and manufactures have successfully prosecuted their peaceful paths.

The great Railroad Convention that was called to assemble in this city at 10 o'clock yesterday morning is not likely, from present appearances, to prove so large and imposing a body as was anticipated.

The President has received a dispatch from General AMES, commanding in Mississippi, saying, in effect, that he learns from the newspapers that dispatches have been sent to the President asserting that he will not permit a fair election In that State.

The Legislature of this year is, without doubt, one of the most important that has assembled since the war. Its action will be carefully watched and closely criticised. It meets at an important era in the history of the State, and it is capable of doing much good if governed by liberal, comprehensive principles.

The clipper ship Dreadnought, whose loss on the morning of July 4, off Cape Penas, north east of the Island of Terra del Fuego, was reported Thursday, was built at Newburyport, Mass., by CURRIER TOWNSEND, under the supervision of Captain SAMUELS, who commanded the yachi Heurictta in her famous race across the Atlantic two years ago.

The French and English Societies for the Abolition of Slavery have sent and address to Marshal SERRANO, the Regent of Spain, on the subject of human slavery. They ask him to use all his efforts to abolish slavery in Cuba, and refer him to his own speech, wherein he said that "slavery only exists in the civilized world as a Spanish institution."

The business of housebuilding this year has not been as lively as during the three preceding years. There have not been as many first-class stores erected, and the number of private residences of the higher order are also proportionately fewer. Builders say that materials are too high, and that the eight-hour movement has considerably increased the wages of the workmen.

Governor SENTER'S action in withholding his message provokes comment and suspicions. His private friends here, who deal largely in Tennessee bonds in Wall-street, have known its points on finance for some days, and have acted accordingly.

Quite an enthusiasm is apparent in England for the restoration of the old buildings. Lord GLARENDON, the present proprietor of Ken??worth Castle, is causing works of a rather extensive nature to be executed among the ruins of that palace, with a view of preventing its further decay.

As the tune approaches for the meeting of the great Council at Rome, the interest increases, and it becomes more and more a subject of discussion. The journals are filled with articles; but with a multiplication of words we are not yet much enlightened as to what is to be the scope or issue of this general reunion of Bishops.

In winding up the Albert Insurance Company, the vice-chancellor restricts the costs of receivership an other legal expenses, and declares that "a public company is not to be considered as a carcass to be preyed upon."

The Court of Appeals has just rendered a decision in the case of the people of the State of New-York, on the relation of JOHN J. BRADLEY against THOMAS STEPHENS, which is of importance to the City of New-York. The relators commenced an action in the nature of quo warranto,

The approach of Winter, with its long, dark evenings, renders timely one more allusion to a great need in most of our cities, and especially in New--York. It is that of evening occupation for the youth and rising manhood arcand as.

It has been announced that we are to have another new set of postage stamps. The issue now in use will, therefore, be shortlived. We suppose it is indecorous to criticise that which is already moribund; but we may safely say it is not because the present stamps are beloved of gods or men, that they are taken away from as in their youth.

A more gloriously beautiful day than was yesterday for the perfect enjoyment of racing. the "sport of kings," was never witnessed. An atmosphere bright, warm and genial characterized the second day of the Jerome Park Meeting, and tempted thousands to patronize the Course and enjoy the pleasing excitement produced by the contests of the noble thoroughbreds.

M. from her late residence, No. 117 East 34th St. FATMAN. --On Thursday morning. Oct. 7, after a short illness, at his residence, No. 86 Irving--place, JOSEPH FATMAN, in the 56th year of his age.

There will shortly be established, with headquarters in this City, and organization to be known as the National Cooperative Land and Labor Association, the principal business of which will be to obtain and register descriptive lists of the surplus lands in the South and West, with the prices and terms of sale,
Visitors to the Park have been greatly favored by the weather during the present season. Not a single concert has been postponed, and very few have been given under other than bright skies,

The steamer S. L. Fellon, belonging to the Wilmington and Baltimore Railway Company, ran on a rock or sunken pier during a dense fog on the Delaware River, while coming into the dock at Claymont. The passengers were transferred to the steamer Hancox, and continued their trip to the city.

The Scientific Congress of France has just held its thirty-sixth session at Chartres (Eure-et-Loir) Under the Presidency of M. DE CAUMONT. The proceeding s lasted eight days, and consisted of the discussion of different questions relating to the physical, natural, and medical sciences agriculture manufactures, archaeology, history, literature, and the fine arts.

The delegates to the Republican County Convention of Westchester assembled at Lafayette Hall, White Plams, yesterday, for the purpose of nominating candidates for county offices. Hon. JAMES W. HEUSTED was called to the chair, and the following-named gentlemen were selected : For County Treasurer, JOHN BERRIAN,

As the chilly nights come an, the ?? of the army of Station House lodgers reappear, and with them this have come many new recruits. These outcasts, constantly mereasing in number, and yearly becoming more abject and useless, present a difficulty with which the authorities will soon be forced to grapple.

The parade of the First Division on Wednesday was a gratifying one, though the attentive observer could scarcely fail perceiving certain irregularities that should be remedied. A little more attention to minor details will prove very beneficial in the future. In the first place the diversity of uniform in the staffs was especially noticeable.

In the case of HELENE STILLE against Baron HENRI DE REVIERRE, a report of which has already appeared in the TIMES, a motion was noticed for yesterday in the Superior Court, Special Term, to set aside the order of arrest here before granted against the defendant.

Secretary BOUTWELL arrived in this city to-day as the guest of the Union League. To-night he addressed an immense assemblage at Horticultural Hall. Upon being introduced he disclaimed being actuated by any partisan purpose in addressing his hearers, though appreciating the importance of the coming election.

The London Times, of yesterday, in an editorial on France, commends the moderation of M. KERATRY and his colleagnes, and considers it an evidence that the country can control its own destinics. The writer thinks the opposition now combines three great elements of strength--Union, method and patience.

At a meeting held at an early hour yesterday morning the Board of Police succeeded in filling the two vacancies among the Police Captains which have existed for some time past. The appointees are HENRY BURDEN and JOHN McDERMOTT, both in turn Sergeants at the Jefferson Market Police Court, Which has come to be considered the regular stepping stone to a Captaincy,

We notice that another man has come forward with a lock which he is anxious to have submitted to a thorough test in order to prove that it cannot be picked by the most expert burglar. It is time the public should understand that there is not, and cannot be such a thing as a burglar-proof lock.

This town was visited by a fearful hurricane last night, vessels, wharves, stores and fish-houses were smashed to atoms. Great quantities of fish and oil were destroyed. The steamer New-York narrowly escaped loss with all on a board.

This evening the large frame buildings in the rear of the University of Rochester, containing the laboratory, workshops, and the private mineralogical, zoological and other cabinets of Prof. HENRY WARD, and his plaster casts, monads and models, were destroyed by fire.

Mr. THOMAS EARLE, the keeper of the beacon light, at this port, did not like the looks of things at about 6 P. M., on Monday. The wind was blowing from the S. W., carrying the waves with great force over the lighthouse. He determined to leave it and go ashore over the bar. He made the attempt but the tide was too high, and he had to retrace his steps.

Mr. F. W. FARNAM, owner of the Excelsior Knitting Mills at Troy, is building a new free church for operatives, near Ida Hill, to cost about $40,000. A good mission is flourishing here. St. John's has been improved this Sumner at a cost of about $4.500. St. Paul's is building a new chapel in the rear of the church, with class rooms, library, sewing rooms, , at a cost of $35,000.

In one of the newspaper accounts of the damage caused by the recent flood, we were surprised to see the announcement that the shores of the Hudson River for thirty miles were "Strewn with lumber, pumps, apples-stores and hogsheads.

I do not believe that any intelligent person, who has had opportunity to know the influences that affect Congress, will deny my assertion that the most formidable influences controlling the United States Senate are the national bank lobby and that of the Union Pacific and other railroads.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A statement appeared in your paper of the 4th inst., in regard to the "Confederate losses in the late civil war," prepared by Dr. JOSEPH JONES, Secretary of the Southern Historical Society. According to the estimates made by the writer, the total number of deaths were about 200,000.

The other evening Baldwir's Hotel at Lake Mahopae, consisting of four large wooden houses, was burned to the ground. Early in July Thompson's Hotel at the same place, situated on the southern part of the lake, also a wooden structure, was burned in a few hours in open day and while filled wit guests.

The Spanish steamer Euterpe took her clearance from this port for Havana, yesterday, and in the afternoon, about 3 o'clock steamed down the Day. For some days she lay at Pier No. East River, expecting to be sent to seabut Capt. GILDERDALE, her commander. received no notice to leave.

The supply of Croton in the reservoir has happily increased to such an extent, during the past few days, that we may now safely dispel all : fears of a water-famine. This is due, of course, to the recent heavy rains.

The Ladies' Junta, like the Cuban Junta, is eager to try conclusions with the powers of despotism; and Mrs. NORTON is the Goicounia of the grand liberating enterprise. She would also join issue with impetuosity on the general election of the State, regardless of consequences. But there are dangers ahead.

As passage across the lower end of the City Hall Park is now forever stopped, our City authorities would add to the convenience of many thousands a every if they would facilitate crossing from Park-row to Broadway by means us still remain.

Things are not so bad as they seem. We are not going to be entirely overrun by the Mongolians very probably. the San Francisco Bulletin gives us, from the statistical returns of that port, the assurance that the influx is not at all alarming--that while, from 1858 to 1863. it amounted to about 8,000 yearly, it numbered from 1864 to 1858 about 3,000 per annum.

The following orders have been issued: DEPARTMENT OF STATE. Pursuant to the order of the President, this Department will be closed on Monday, the 11th inst., as a mark a of respect to the memory of Ex-President PIERCE.

One of the happy results of the successful completion of the Pacific Railway across this continent has been the opening up of a new country to foreign travel. Europe, and some portions of Asia and Africa, have been thoroughly explored by the intelligent,

The latest reports from General DUNCAN, on the Republican River, confirm the previous reports of his success against the Indians. The quantity of valuable material captured is much greater than at first reported. General AUGUR arrived at Cheyenne from Fort Fetterman on the 7th inst.

A suit of some interest, and one likely to consume considerable time, was commenced in the wayne circuit Court yesterday afternoon, it being the appeal of Hon. JACOB M. HOWARD from the decisoin of the Judge of Probate in the matter of the estate of ANTOINE BEAUBIEN, deceased.

The election for city officers in Newark takes place on Tuesday next, and the contest between the rival candidates is becoming lively and earnest with the approach of election day. The Republicans have nominated Mr. F. W. RICORD and the Democrats Mr. A. A. SMALLEY for Mayor to succeed Hon. F. B. PEDDIE.

At the Republican Senatorial Convention of the Twentieth Senatorial District, held here to-day, AUGUSTUS R. ELWOOD, of this village, was unanimously nominated for Senator. POTSDAM JUNCTION, Oct, 9.--Hon. ABRAM X.

The members of Independent Royal Arch Lodge, No. 2: Kane Lodge, No. 454; St. Nicholas Lodge, No. 351; and Prince of Orange Lodge, No. 16, F. and A. M., will meet at the St. Nicholas Hotel to-day at 4 o'clock P. M., to attend the funeral services of JOHN W. SHAW, late a sojourning brother of Pearl Lodge, No. 23, of Jackson, Miss., and act as escort to the depot.

The Journal Official has the following news: A very formidable riot broke out among the miners employed by the Compagnte du Chemin de for d' Orleans in the Department of Aveyron on Thursday last. The rioters attempted to drown the Chief Engineer of the Company in a neighboring river,

All application was made in the District Supreme Court to-day for mandamus compelling the Secretary of the Treasury and the First Comptroller to show cause why a certain employe of the Government should not receive the exact twenty per cent. compensation under the act of 1867.

A passenger has communicated to us the following account of the escape of the steamer New-York, of the International Line, under perilous circumstances, on her trip from St. John to Boston in the late storm: "The voyage as far as Eastport was pleasant as usual.

Some time during Friday night or more probably between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, four burglars easily gained an entrance into the office of the Dutchess County Mutual Insurance Company, in Poughkeepsie. They began work on the large safe, and soon succeeded in blowing it open with gunpowder.

Mr. G. W. CARLETON, the well-known publisher, has recently opened the Worth mansion, at the corner of Broadway and Fifth-avenue, as a book and stationery store. The property was purchased by Mr. CARLETON, a few months ago, who immediately proceeded to tear out the interior compartments and turn the whole of the lower floor into a grand salesroom, 100 foot by 30.

A meeting was held last evening at No. 214 Bowery to consider the plan of organizing a colony for settling in Kansas on the cooperative system. The advantages of the plan were set forth by one of the leaders in the movement, whose remarks were frequently applauded.
During the last session of the Legislature this popular Society was incorporated, the incorporate numbering many of our leading Irish fellow-citizens.

There has been rather a dearth of novelty at the City theatres during the past week, but as this is commonly the sign of prosperity and public satisfaction, we presume that neither managers nor audiences have anything of which to complain. The weather has been very favorable for the drama, as well as for the races,

The Prince left Kingston at 11 o'clock A. M. yesterday. An immense crowd on the wharf attended the departure. The steamer Bay of Quinle, filled with excursionists, accompanied the Prince to Gonaquete. At Brockville a large crowd gathered and an address was presented to the Prince.

We congratulate Philadelphia upon the possession of a sensible Judge. One of the persons implicated in the attempted assessiuation of Revenue Officer BROOKS, being brought before him on habeas corpus, was asked if he had himself applied for the issuing of the process, and, upon a negative reply being given, the writ was dismissed and the prisoner remanded.

The return game for the championship between the Eckfords and Atlantics was played yesterday afternoon at the Union grounds in the presence of a very large crowd of spectators, Both mines appearing an full force, an exciting match was looked for, and for the first four innings he playing was very close, the score standing four to three.

The Republican insurrection in Spain still continues, and the country is in a very unsettled condition. The Republicans are making very strong resistance in various parts of the country. Madrid is tranquil, but the Police authorities have advised the inhabitants of the city to arm themselves and their servants in order to defend their houses in case of a riot.

The settlement of the Irish land operation is the problem which now keeps every leading English politician in a state of suspense and anxiety. Mr. GLADSTONE has declined all engagements in order to devote his whole time to the long expected bill, and the Opposition Party find employment enough in endeavoring to hit upon compromises.

The last sickness of Ex-President PIERCE commenced in a mild form about five weeks since while he was stopping at this cottage at Little Boar's Head, at Hampton Beach. For several months before his health had been unusually good, he having risen from his severe sickness of last Fall and the early Winter with apparently renewed health and vigor.

Rev. J. HENRY SMITH yesterday delivered an address to the Sing Sing prisoners. in the chapel of the institution, which deeply impressed the listeners. The following is one of its most effective and affecting passengers ; Ten years ago three young men came ashore from a man-of -war lying off the cease of Massachusetts, They entered Boston.

The Harvard Boat Club held a meeting at Cambridge on Friday, and formally resolved that, whereas the boat-houses of the club are in such dilapidated condition that in the opinion of component judges they will fall to pieces this Winter, immediate actions is imperatively necessary.

Ex-Senator FRELINGHYSEN has taken the opportunity afforded him by a Republican mass meeting at Newark to make a few common sense remarks on the tendency of extremists to compel everybody else to accept their own doctrines. One man finds that if he drinks wines or spirits he invariably is led into excess.

Another of the advertising "attornies" in divorce suits has been distinguishing himself. A certain man of this City had a friend whom he was always asking to his house, and in whom he had "every confidence."

The last Carlotta-Patti Concert takes place at Steinway Hall this evening. At Wallack's, Tom Taylor's comedy of "An Unequal Match," will be acted for the first time in two years. The French Theatre will be opened for the season with "Sam," performed by Mr. F. S. CHANFRAU and a strong company.

The hour before dawn is the one of all others when the street lamps should be alight but in many parts of the City they are extinguished so early that the streets are left to darkness and to thieves during most of that period.

The French ship Malabar has been seized at Metatocino and brought to this part for violation of the Revenue laws. A meeting of leading citizens last night organized a California Immigrant Union, to promote European immigration to this coast.

The real feelings of some of the self-styled National Union Republicans in Mississippi may be inferred from the fact that the Jackson Clarion, one of Judge DENT'S most ardent supporters, finds it necessary to remind members of the party in the second Congressional District, who oppose the regular candidate for Congress,

The funeral of MARTIN, the Fenian, who died at the King's College Hospital, in this city, on the 5th inst., took place today, and was attended by 6,000 people. The father and mother, and other relations of the deceased, were present, wearing green, scarfs, and participated in the ceremonies.

The eminent merchant JOSEPH FATMAN who died at his residence in this City, No. 86 Irving place, on Thursday morning, after a brief illness, was buried yesterday. Mr. FATMAN was largely engaged in the tobacco trade. His strict probity, largeness of heart and genial manners won him the respect and love of all with whom he came in contact.

General ACERBI, one of the Thousand of the Sicilian expedition, and one of the most renowned among the faithful companions of GARIBALDI, has Just died in Florence. After having aided in tile conquest of rich Kingdoms he dies poor, leaving not even enough to pay the expenses of his funeral.

Admiral FARRAGUT has been in this city several days lying dangerously ill at the Sherman House. He took cold during an excursion on the Lake, which has resulted in congestive chills, and grave apprehensions are for his recovery.

Whatever may be the result of the Senaterial contest in Tennessee, its termination must afford relief to the adherents of ANDREW JOHNSON. Even the fecundity of Southern editors, in large-mouthed political diatribes, has failed to supply the necessary adulation, and his supporters fall back on the pet phrases of the candidate himself.

The friends of General JEFF. C. DAVIS were puzzled and pained at the appearance of an article in a California paper, some time since, charging that officer with various acts of maladministration, committed and permitted in his command on the Pacific coast.
