FOSTER.--On Saturday, Oct. 9. ROBERT C. FOSTER, son of the late James Foster, aged 34 years. The relatives and friends of the family, and also the members of Huguenot Lodge No. 331, F. and A. M., are invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 52 Union place. (new No. 203 4th-av.,) on Tuesday, Oct. 12, t 2 o'clock P. M., without further notice.

To Hon. Hamilton Harris and associates, Republican State Committee: GENTLEMEN: Absence in the interior of our State precluded a prompt response to the nomination you have seen fit to tender me. I improve the earliest moment to reply to your kind notification.

There seems to be no falling off in the popularity of country sales. At no time have they been better attended, or more satisfactory prices obtained than during the week just closed. The demand seems increasing as the season draws to a close, and it is fair to believe that every sale of really desirable property to be held between now and the 25th inst.,

The Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH will start on his journey to the East on the 24th of October. He will meet the Empress EUGENIE at Constantinople, and in company with Her Majesty and the Sultan will proceed, by way of Jaffa and Jerusalem, to Suez, to attend the opening of the Canal.

The New-York Association for the Prevention of Gambling has just issued an appeal to the public for material aid, with which to prosecute its laudable work. Since its organization it has done much toward decreasing the evil of gambling in this City.

Mr. WILLIAM L. MITCHELI., a prominent local politician, committed suicide at an early hour yesterday morning. by handing himself. The deceased for many years kept a wholesale and rental hour store at the corner of Wooster and Prince streets, and No. 722 Broad way, and was well known in the Eight and Fourteenth Wards.

In the Eastern part of the State--Washington County--during the fearful storm on Monday night the wind was terrific, and that did the greatest damage. In the central part of the State, on the Kennebee and Androscoggin Rivers and their tributaries, the chief damage was done by the flood.

The coal was removed from the steamer Cuba to-day. She had but ten tons on board, barely enough to steam eight hours, which is evidence that she came in in distress. A rumor that several Spanish gunboats are outside this port, waiting for the Cuba, created considerable excitement here, but proves to be with out foundation.

As it has been customary for the Governors of the Lastern States, except in Maine, to appoint the last Thursday in November as a day of thanksgiving, New-England people think that the President has designated too early a day for the National Thanksgiving.

A letter has been received in this city stating that on the 17th of September the Island of St. Thomas was visited by an earthquake which occured at 2:50 P. M. which shook the City of St. Thomas to its foundation.

Several negotiations have already been attempted between the Governments of the United State and Great Britain with the object of still further reducing the rate of ocean postage. We cannot say that these efforts entirely failed, for as our readers are aware, a twelve--cent stamp now carries a letter across the Atlantic,

Man's inhumanity to man doesn't pay, as the typical Yankee would express it; and now and then we find recorded satisfactory proof of it. The inhuman driver of an express wagon in Indianapolis the other day refused to take some of the wounded from the Fair grounds to the city unless he were plaid for It at an exorbitant rate.

Messrs. EDITORS: An article having appeared in the Canon stating "that Rev. JAMES KENT STONE, D. D., late President of Hobart College, at Geneva, has unquaitledly declared his renunciation of the tonets of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and his conversion to Catholicism,"

The first day for the registration of voters is appointed for to-morrow, throughout the Metropolitan District. After that time we may reasonably look for an increase in the applications for citizenship, though it is not probable the time of the Courts will be taken up to the same extent as last year, as the coming election is not of so much importance as was that of November, 1868.

The Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH of Austria will leave Vienna for the East on the 24th inst., and is to meet EUGENIE at Constantinople, when they, together with the Sultan, are to proceed to Suez, to be present at the opening of the canal. The fleets of the three Sovereigns will accompany them on their voyage to the Isthmus.

Next Tuesday evening the workingmen of New-York and its vicinity will hold a mass meeting in the large hall of the Cooper Institute and inveigh against the Couspiracy and Eight-hour laws, and endeavor to come to an understanding with regard to the candidates to be supported or rejected by them during the ensuing Fall campaign,

Mr. THEODORE L. MINIER, of Havana, the Republican candidates for Senator in the Twenty-seventh District, is Chairman of the Schuyler County Committee. He was cashier of the First National Bank of Havana under Hon. CHARLES Cook's Presidency for many years, and since the death of that gentleman has had the control and management of the bank.

FRANK KLEIN, a German, aged, 28, and a watchman at the New-York Restaurant, No. 734 Broadway, guarreled, yesterday, with, and struck the errant boy, CHARLES GRAMBJEIN, who became so enraged that he seized a bread knife and stabbed KLEIN in the shoulder, inflicting a serious wound.

There will be in attendance at the National Commercial Convention, which meets here on the 12th inst., delegates from all parts of the Union. The object of the assembly is to consult as to the best means of developing the commercial and manufacturing interests of the country, regardless of the interests of any particular section.

Chicago has the excitement of a firt-class mystery. This time it is the genuine article; no rapping spirit; no impalpable ghost; an actual defunct corpus on the edge of the public highway. Near the end of a street bridge, wedged in between piles, just clear of the water, the fascinating object was discovered.

There is at the Industrial Exhibition here the largest and longest wrought-iron beam ever rolled at a single heat in this country. It is seventy feet long, twelve fact nigh, and weighs 9,000 pounds. On Wednesday next the horticultural, floral and vegetable department will he opened.

The Albany Argus recognizes the necessity for some defence of Governor HOFFMAN and his collection with the "Erie Ring," but can offer nothing better in his behalf than very stupid abuse of tile TIMES. Our contemporary should remember that epithets do not obliterate facts.

Trade in the wholesale lines has been, in the main, more active, and on a steadier basis as to price, within the Last few days. The Breadstuffs movement has been checked by the break in the canal, which has had the effect of lessening the available supplies of Flour and Grain.

The depressed condition of American navigation interests, and the rapid transfer of the foreign carrying trade of the United States to ships and steamers sailing under the flags of Great Britain, Germany and France, is justly arousing Congress and the American people to the consideration of this grave national calamity.

A Salt Lake City telegram, dated the 8th inst., says : The Territorial Fair was held here during the last three days, There was a fine display of home manufactures. Among them were fine wagons and carriages, and a large assortment of cotton and woolen goods.

Yesterday morning a scow crossing St, Maurice River, from Point Chateau to Point Dore, upset, precipitating twenty men and the same number of horses into the water. Fifteen men and all the horses were drowned.

" AN UNEQUAL MATCH" AT WALLACK'S. One of the best houses of the season assembled last night at Wallack's theatre, to witness the revival of Mr. TOM TAYLOR'S comedy of " An Unequal Match." and the reappearance of Miss MADELINE HENRIQUES in a character to which on previous occasions she had given original and acknowledged effect.

Madrid advices report fresh disturbances in Valencia and at La Carolina and Gandesa, but in Aragon, Andalalusia nad Catalonia affairs look better for the Government. More troops are called for in Saragossa, and a movement in the capital is feared. The recent surrender to General BALDRICK is officially stated, and Deputies NOQUEEO and PALACIOS are said to have given in their submission to the Government.

Senator SUMMER, in his letter to the Transcontinental Railroad Convention, says: "The best and surest traveler is the sun; but the sun goes straight always." This will be news to astronomers. They have not hitherto given that respectable old luminary the credit of being much of a traveler himself. although he is surrounded by a numerous progeny who busy themselves in running a muck around their venerable sire.

The steamer Bristol, of the Fall River line, got ashore during the storm last night in Coddington Cove, four miles from Newport, but was expected to get off at high water without damage. Her passengers are all safe, and will be forwarded to New-York to-night on the steamer Providence.

The news thus received is later by five days than that at hand by the Deuisehland. For portions of it extracted from late continental files we are indebted to the courtesy of the Captain and Purser of the Silesia.

Is it not about time that the firing of cannon in public places in this City should be subjected to some restraint? As an expression of popular opinion or feeling it is in most instances absurdly unmeaning. Probably not a tenth of the crowd that assembled last evening in the City Hall Park know what the "saluting" was about.

Captain SHAW, the Chief of the London Fire Brigade, has lost no time in presenting a report on his observations in this country. He bears warm tribute to the hospitality with which he was received, but expresses had disappointment at finding so little to learn here.

In the Quarter Sessions this morning the Brooks case came up at the instance of the District-Attorney and by order of Judge LUDLOW.

Since Modern civilization means in a great degree the power of going fast, we don't see why Portland may not hope to join the race on the most favorable footing. By the route suggested at the Oswego Convention from that city to Chicago, through part of Canada, and thence to connect with the great upper thoroughfare to Puget Sound the usual passage between China and Europe would he shortened by over 2,000 miles.

Quite a respectable number of persons attended Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER'S sale at Garlstadt, N. J., yesterday. The day was pleasant, the lunch good, and the surroundings all very favorable. The bidding was fair, and the sale, though not as great a success as many that have been made this season, was yet satisfactory. It lasted until about 4 o'clock, when Mr. JOHNSON closed.

In accordance with the order of the Central Republican Junta of Cuba and Porto Rico, yesterday the normal celebration of independence took place in this City. The 10th of October, 1868, marks the commencement of the Cuban Republic, and is looked upon by the Cuban patriots as a day to be forever honored by them.

Mr. C. N. JORDAN, Cashier of the Third National Bank, was yesterday appointed receiver of the Gold Exchange Bank in place of Mr. AUGUSTUS L. BROWN. Mr. JORDAN at once set to work to endeavor to extricate the bank from the difficulties which surround it, but the complications are so great that it will be a work of some time, if indeed the business can over be satisfactorily adjusted.

The Providence Light Infantry, which will arrive here and be received by the Twenty-second Regiment on the 13th inst., is one of the oldest organizations in New-England, and the names of nearly all the prominent men of Rhode Island for the last half century are found upon its rolls.

The steam boiler in the box factory of ALBERT GOODWIN, in Lynn, exploded this morning, and, it is feared, fatally injuring ROBERT C. REEVES, of the firm of STACKPOLE REEVES, of India Wharf, Boston. The State Constable to-day seized about $5,000 worth of liquors, belonging to BURGEES FAXON, on Federal-street.

Yesterday morning an application was made before Judge CARDOZO to wind up the affairs of the British Commercial Life Insurance Company, doing business at No. 65 Wall-street. FRANCIS M. BIXBY was appointed receiver in the matter, and the motion now was to show cause why his appointment should not be made permanent.

Mr. KOOPMANSCHAP, the collie-labor contractor, left this City last evening for Louisville, Where he is to address the Commercial Convention on the subject of Chinese laborers, and the advantages to be derived from importing them for the labor market of the country.

Saturday evening JOSEPH BENGER A German, 23 years of age, who was a boarder in the house No. 206 West Thirty-fifth-street, kept by Mrs. MARY HUNT, entered the house, and, being intoxicated, began to abuse her. Presently he made an attack upon her with a large knife, which he snatched from the table, and inflicted a severe wound upon the arm near the shoulder.
Dispatches from Anbin, in the Department of Aveyron, have been received up to a late hour last evening. No new outbreaks had occurred among the miners, but the strike still continues.

Mr. CHARLES DICKENS has been making a speech at Birmingham on education, in the course of which he gave some very good advice to his hearers, especially with regard to the necessity of acquiring a habit of concentrating their attention on anything which happened to employ their time.

The remains of Ex-President PIERCE were removed from his late residence to Dorie Hall in the State House, at 11 o'clock, where they were open to the view of all who desired to see them. The procession from the house was composed of members of the Bar, citizens and friends, and twelve pall-bearers--members of the Bar.

A heavy rainstorm occurred yesterday afternoon, and the streets in the lower part of the city were flooded. Much damage is apprehended to the roads and bridges that were undergoing repairs of the damages resulting from the storm last week.

The lecture which Rev. Dr. PINNEY, recently from Africa, delivered last Sunday in the Baptist Church of Forty-second-street, and which he will continue this evening, suggests an innovation, which may, perhaps, be worth the attention of all clergymen.

A mass meeting of workingmen comprising the trades' unions and otker labor organizations in the City, was held at Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of bringing the united influence of these associations to bear on polities in the approaching campaign.

Last night the Italians, who regard the day an which COLUMBUS came in sight of America as the date of its discovery, celebrated the anniversary of that event by a ball, at which Mrs. ANGELINE PODISTA, an Italian lady of this city, 101 years old, led off in the grand march, and afterward danced ten sets.

The Supreme Court of the United states decoded in the case of CRANDALL vs. the State of Nevada (G Wallace. p. 39) that no one of the United States could impose a tax upon those who were obliged to pass through they territory of such State on their way to the National Capital.

The annual election of Directors of the Erie Railroad Company took place yesterday at the offices of the Company, corner Eighth-avenue and Twenty-third-street. Previous to the election the old Board met and passed a resolation referring the propriety of the law passed at the last session of the Legislature, relative to a classification of the directors hereafter to be elected, to a meeting of the stockholders.

The away of Tammany is still absolute. There are Democrats who rail against its tyranny and corruption, and threaten resistance when an election is far off. But when nominations are to be made they quietly subside, and on polling day they are found obeying Tammany's behest with merkness and fidelity.

The report in some of the newspapers of young HAMPE, who walked overboard from one of the Hoboken ferry boats, was a mistake, as the young gentlemen is now alive and in good health, his father having rescued him, with the assistance of Mr. PEER and Officer CARROLL.

On Saturday last the Government received information to the effect that preparations are being made for another raid into our country by the Fenian Brotherhood. The news, through it may be surprising to out readers, did not surprise the Government.

Captain General DE RODAS was taken sick yesterday, but to-day he is better. Several skirmishes have recently taken place in the Eastern Department, during which thirty insurgents were killed. The Spanish loss is not given.

The election for Mayor and city officers took place in Newark yesterday. The result, so far as obtained at midnight, was In favor of A. A. SMALLEY, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, in opposition to F. W. RICORD, Republican. Complete returns were received from the First, Third, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, Ninth and Tenth Wards.

The returns thus far received from Pennsylvania leave little or no doubt of the verdict of the people of that great Commonwealth in favor of Governor GEARY and the Grant Administration. On a lighter popular vote than last October, publican majority promises to be relatively oluphalic.

Monday last a colored man committed on outrage on a young lady, a school teacher, near Fort Washington, sixteen miles from the city, while she was on her way to, and within two hundred yards of the schoolhouse. When found by her friends she was lying on the ground, fearing to move lest the assailant should return, and finding her alone, kill her.

The three-year-old sweepstakes for trotting colts and fillies of the year 1866, named the Spirit of the Times Stake, was trotted for on Tuesday, the 12th inst., at Prospect Park. The subscription was $250 each, $100 forfeit, and there were seventeen subscribers.

The will of the late Senatro FESSENDEN, which was admitted to probate at the October Term of the Probate Court, is quite brief, covering but tow pages of foolseap paper, and was probably drawn by himself. If is dated Oct. 31, 1867, and was witnessed by ISRAEL WASHBURN, Jr., LEWIS B. SMITH and DAVID MOULTON. No bequests are made outside of his family.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having occasion frequently to consult a variety of works, I have, during a stay in New-York, been a frequent visitor at the Astor Library, and feel very grateful to its munificent founders. At the same time, I have become conscious that with its many and great merits, it is extremely detective in many branches of literature.

The Presbyterians in the United States are so numerous a body, and, what is much more than numbers, so generally educated and consistent, that their union or diversity cannot be a matter of indifference with the great public. Whether the ocelesyastical union of all Protestant bodies would really tend to the advancement of true religion, may be doubtful;

Governor SENTER has demolished the allegations and insiunations of his ??nemics by the tone and recommendations of his message to the Tounessce Legislature. It has been changed with insecurity: and he replies by urging upon the assembled legislators the immediate recognition of the principles and purposes which he professed prior to his election.
The chimerical proposition of the New-Orleans Picayune to exact gold, cash down, or the equivalent of gold, for cotton, is sharply rebuked and exposed by the Bulletin and Bes of the same city.

The way in which English women allow themselves to be duped by advanturecs from the East, whom they take to be Princes. was happily ridiculed by THACKBRAY in the Newcomes. Everybody who has read that charming story must remember "Rumman Lott," before whom English society prostrated itself, until Colored Newcome recognized in the "Prince" a discharged servant.

Salt River tickets are abundant, and the Democrats take their defeat cheerfully. The State Senate will stand: Republicans, 18; Democrats, 15. The Republicans concede the defeat of WATT in the First Senatorial District in the First Ward, but the returns will not alter the result. The House stands Republicans, 63; Democrats, 37. A majority on joint ballot of 29.

Dr. C. H. F. PETERS, the astronomer of Litchfield Observatory, Hamilton College, has already discovered eight asteroids and introduced them to the knowledge of the scientific world. These, with the dates of their discovery, are as follows: Feronia, No. 72, May 29, 1861; Enrydice, No. 75, Sept. 22, 1862; Frigga, No. 77, Nov. 12, 1862; Io. Nov. 85, Sept. 19, 1865; Thisbe, No. 88, June

The troops of the garrison of Madrid wore reviewed to-day by General PRIM. Government officials declare that the rebellion is dying out, but the Republicans contradict them, and maintain that it is increasing. The interruption of communication, renders it difficult to obtain information from the Provinces, but there is no doubt that the insurrection extends throughout the country.

A fight is reported to have taken place near Valentia, Spain, in which 250 of the combatants were killed and wounded. The Government troops are intrenched before the city, waiting for reinforcements before making an attack.

At One Hundredth-street market this morning the arrivals still continue short in consequence of the yet disturbed state of the traffic on the Erie Railroad, consequent on the breaks on that line. Fifty-eight car loads were expected this morning, and had not arrived at 11:30 A. M.; still larger consignments are known to be on the road awaiting transit. To-day the grand sale of Norwood property so prominently advertised by Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER will be held on the premises. The country is really very beautiful, the location healthy, the neighborhood good, and the property in many other ways quite desirable. It is but twenty-one miles from the City; about one hour's ride on the line of the Northern Rail-road of New-Jersey.

The NEW-YORK TIMES,--started in September, 1851,--has for many years been recognized as among the most successful, popular and influential newspapers in the country. It is still under the control and management of its original founders, who, with greatly increased resources and experience, will spare no pains to extend and strengthen its claims upon the confidence and support of the public.

Three hundred and fifty Mormons, prinetpally from England, arrived in Omaha on Monday, and left yesterday for Utah. Vice-President COLFAX left Omaha yesterday for home. General DIX has arrived from the West and will participate in the hunt to-day.

Hon. HORACE AUSTIN, Republican Candidate for Governor of Minnesota, recently challenged HOB. GEORGE L. Orts, his the Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee has declined it, assigning as a reason that " Mr. OTIS is a busy and honest practicing attorney," whose entire attention is demanded by the interests of his numerous body of clients in the Courts now sitting.
The news to-day is meagre. Lord DERBY'S condition is much worse to-day. He has been insensible for several hours.

An important Convention, looking to the reformation of our canal system and the correction of its abuses, is to be held in this City on Tuesday next, the 19th inst., at the instigation of the Citizens' Association. The most prominent individuals in the canal interests have been invited, and delegates from the Chamber of Commerce, Produce Exchange and Citizens' Association, of New York, will be in attendance. .

The Journal Official has the following: "Several public reunions have been announced to take place here, and disorders are threatened. The Government, however, will enforce the law authorizing the suppression of all public meetings of a character calculated to disturb public order."

Fighting is going on in the interior, and encounters with varying results are daily reported. President BAEZ is negotiating the sale of the Bay of Samana to the United States. Money is very scarce and trade dull.

The Republican triumph in Pennsylvania is rendered all the more satisfactory by the difficulties under which it was accomplished. To widespread a pathy was added the weakness incident to the hostility cherished by many Republicans to the present State Administration.

Apropos of the late troubles in Wall-street, the Chicago Times--a Democrat of the straightest seet--remarks: "As the national bank circulation is secured by Government bonds, the breaking of heavy banking houses in New-York, or in any part of the country, will not have such disastrous effects as like failures had under our old banking system."

The Scientific American, in its "Facts About the Croton Water Supply," which we elsewhere republish, gives some interesting statements regarding the storage reservoirs. It is clear from this article that if the original plan for these storage reservoirs had been consummated we should have had no trouble this year:

Last night the signal tower of the Mine Hill Railroad took fire, burning to death the watchman, OWEN FEENEY and his family, consisting of wife and two children. A Sister-in-law of FEENEY was also in the tower at the time. but escaped by leaping from a window. The fire originated in he lower part of the tower.

From the tone of the semi-official journals it may be gathered that the Government will yield to public sentiment in the operation of the speedy convocation of the Corps Legislatif, and that the manifestation organized by the Deputy for Finisterre will not be allowed to furnish a pretext for fresh political excitement.

The machinery department of the American Institute Fair has received many important additions since the last notice of that department appeared in the TIMES, and is well worthy of a visit by any one who desires to see the latest inventions in the line of mechanical apparatus. Prominent among the articles that will attract the attention of the visitor is Professor WIARD'S safety attachment for steam boilers.

The Terrible murders of seven persons which lately took place at Pantin, in France have been commented on as additional instances of the ferocity which sometimes exhibits itself among the French people. But it is due to justice in this case to notice that the names of those concerned in the fatal affair--as far as discovery has gone--are not French, but German.

We have received considerable information concerning the state of affairs upon the Isthmus of Panama from Mr. CHARLES E. PERRY, United States Consul at Aspinwall, who has just arrived from that port. Mr. PERRY says that business generally was very dull upon the Isthmus, and a further decline is even looked for.

One of the most important meetings of the Shipowners' Association of New-York, which has ever been held in this City, was convened at the Society's rooms, in Pine-street, yesterday afternoon. Everything that Californian call "so cheap" seems do dear when it subtracts one or two from the coin pile.

The visit of Dr. HAYES and Mr. BRADFORD to Greenland and Labrador has been a great success. The party reached Boston last Friday evening, much elated at finding themselves once more in a civilized land. Dr HAYES has made extensive explorations of hitherts unvisited places, and has made arrangements for another season.

Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS returns in greatly improved health, but seemed much pained to hear of the death of Ex-President PIERCE, in whose Cabinet he held the portfolio of War. Mr. DAVIS' family remain in Europe. The knowledge that Mr. DAVIS would arrive by Baltimore drew together a large crowd at the wharf on Saturday;

The regular night boat from the City of Providence brought the Providence Light Infantry, yesterday, on visit to their friends of the Twenty-second Regiment, National Guard. As the storm which occurred during the night had not subsided when the steatnor reached her dock, the reception ceremonies were some what delayed and curtailed.

The vacaney in the Cabinet created by the death of the lamented RAWLINS has at length been filled. Brevet Major-General WILLIAM W. BELKNAP, a volunteer officer of distinction during the war, and at present the Collector of the First Revenue District in Iowa, has received the honorable appointment, and is already on his way from Keokuk, Iowa, to enter upon the duties of the office which he has definitely accepted.

At a meeting of the American Social Science Association to-day, a communication was received from the New-York Prison Association, requesting a delegate to be sent to the International Congress on the subject of prison discipline. Mr. F. B. SANBORN was appointed to act in that capacity in conjunction with President ELIOT.

Medical men in all parts of the world have startling facts brought to their knowledge in reference to family affairs. It is fortunate for the peace of households that doctors, as a rule, set a gourd upon their tongues, and that it is deemed a breach of professional obiquette to disclose the secrets they learn in the course of their practice.

CHARLES AUGUSTINE SAINTE BEUVE, the eminent French literary critie, best known by his Causeriesdu Lundi, whose death in Paris yesterday is reported, was born on the 23d of December, 1804, at Boulogne-sur-Mer. His mother, a lady of English parentage, devoted herself to his early education, his father having died before his birth. He completed his studies at the College Charlemagne, in Paris, where he went at the age of fourteen.

One of the singular things about the Democratic Party, perhaps the most singular, is that it makes no attempt to take advantage of any weak points there may be in the enemy's position.

The subject brought before the notice of the authorities yesterday, by our correspondent "N. W.," is well deserving attention. Nothing is more common than to see stolen articles advertised for by the owners, with a pledge that the thief shall be rewarded and "no questions asked."

The Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction held their regular semi-monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, President BOWEN presiding. eleven graduates of Bellevue College were appointed district physicians, at a salary of $300 each per annum, for the purpose at attending to the medical wants of the poor of their respective districts, and affording them grataitons advice and treatment.

By an act of the last Congress the working force of the Federal Judiciary is to be increased by the appointment of an additional Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and a Circuit Judge for each of the nine existing Circuits.
The corner stone of the Reformed Church of Gowanns, at the corner of Third-avenue and Fifty-fifth-street, was laid in due form yesterday afternoon, by Rev. Dr. MANNING, pastor of the church.
Yesterday the Commissioners of immigration made then annual tour of inspection of the public institutions on Ward's Island.

"Distinguished foreigners" are very welcome to come here as often as they please, but surely it is just possible to have them forced upon our notice a little too much. When we have been told that Lord Lackpurse has arrived, and have been kept fully informed as to his movements for a week or two, is not that as much of his Lordship's affairs as we can reasonably be expected to take an interest in?

The fears entertained with regard to the result of Tuesday's election in Ohio, are shown by the latest information to be unfounded. Not only is HAYES reelected Governor, but both branches of the Legislature are Republican.

Dr. D. B. SIMMONS, late of Yeddo, Japan, gave an interesting account of Japanese earthquakes before the Geographical Society, at their rooms, Cooper Institute, last evening. He said the five islands which formed the Japanese Empire were of volcanic origin, craters being quite numerous in the mountains there at the present time.

During the week, ending on the 13th inst., there were 5,387 immigrants landed at this port, making a total of 216,610 since the beginning of the year. The same period last year gave only 179,165 arrivals. There was $10.767 50 received at Castle Garden. between the 6th and 13th insts., for communication of passengers.

Madrid dispatches report that Valentia still holds out. The insurgents there have proposed to capitulate, but surrender is demanded. The town of Bejar has revolted. Republican leaders PAUL and SALVOCHEA have fled to Gibralter and the latter on leaving Andalusia had 70 of his men killed.

A sad accident has happened in the St. Maurice River, with loss of life. The following are the particulars: A scow loaded with provisions, and which had on board thirty-eight men and six horses, started from the piles on Friday morning.

General TROWBRIDGE, of this city, has a report which was made by General BRAXTON BRAGG to General COOPER, in May, 1863, giving an account of operations in Kentucky and Tennessee during the previous Anima. The report never reached its destination, but was captured by troops under general TROWBRIDGE, among other military papers and stores.

Fire Marshal BRACKETT'S report for September self forth the following facts: In this city there were thirty four fires, of these four were caused by kerosene, ten by carelessness of occupants and employees, three by spontaneous combustion, two by children playing with matches, seven were of unknown origin, one was of incendiary origin, and the remainder originated form a variety of accidental causes.

Dr. A. W. HALL read a paper before the Polytechnic Branch of the American Institute, at the Cooper Institute, last evening, on the cause of auroral lights, in which he took issue with Professor LOOMIS and other scientists. who attribute these phenomena to electrical action.

The wide divergence of opinion among workingmen, not only as to what labor reforms are needed, but how they shall be obtained, is illustrated by an address in which " the new Democracy, or political commonwealth," formally protests against the assumption that the Labor Congress at Philadelphia fairly represents the most enlightened portion of the laboring classes.

A telegram to the Dispatch says Governor WALKER made an address to-day on the Fair Grounds at Danville. In the political portion of his address he said he felt nothing but pity for the opposition party in the late canvass, who were lad by a set of cormorants and carpet baggers, who had nothing at stake but their own selfish interest.

Some time ago ABRAHAM and JAMES VALK, large tea merchants in this City, petitioned to be declared voluntary bankrupts, but while the bankruptcy proceedings were pending, BENJAMIN VON BEIRAN, a creditor of the brankrupts, commenced a suit against them to a State Court to recover damages from them for alleged fraud, in converting $36,000 of his money to their own use.

Lord DERBY is much better to-day, and is still improving. The following dispatch concerning Dr. LIVINGSTONE was received here yesterday, under date of Bombay, Oct. 6: "A letter has just been received here from Dr. LIVINGSTONE, the great African traveler.

On Wednesday night three burglars effected an entrance to the store of JAMES OAKLEY, in Huntington, Long Island, blew open a safe and robbed it of $500. The noise awoke Mr. OAKLEY, who repaired to the apartment, and was instantly seized and mercilessly clubbed by the ??.

The good people of Montreal, on waking this morning, found themselves in the very heart of another Fenian seare. All sorts of rumors were afleat, bus of course Fenianism was in some way or other mixed up with most of them.

This institution is conferring great advantages on those receiving instruction within its walls. The general course of subjects taught embraces Latin, French grammar, geometry, bookkeeping, general history, German, political science, composition, Before the students are admitted they are required to pass a preliminary examination in the lower branches of school study.

This forenoon the warehouse building No. 349 Baltimore-street, a few doors east of Eutaw, was discovered to be on fire. The basement and first story were occupied by MOSES GUTMAN Co., wholesale and retail clothiers, whose stock is badly damaged by fire and water. The loss is estimated at $25,000, partially insured. 000, partially insured.

The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Saturday morning, at 11 o'clock, from the residence of her father, near Morristown, N. J. Carriages will be in waiting at the depot on the arrival of the 8 o'clock A.M. train from New-York.

The Brooklyn (E. D.) Young Men's Christian Association have elected the following officers, for the ensuing year: President--JOHN B. THOMAS, Presbyterian. Vice-Presidents--L. M. Palmer, Presbyterian; W. J. Combs, Baptist; J. H. Romer, Reformed; J. J. Hall, Episcopal; D. G. Paige, Congregational; J. A. Bradley, Methodist.

Washing on correspondents of Democratic papers have telegraphed that JEFFERSON DAVIS, during his say in Baltimore expressed himself in favor of the election of Judge DENT to the Governership of Mississippi. What also could be expected JEFF. DAVIS' Mississippi friends really nominated Judge DENT, and will control the Government of the State if the Dent ticket be successful.

The German Social Reform Society held a general meeting last night, when the reports of the last quarter were submitted, from which it appeared that the assets of the Society amount to $3,873 71. Five hundred and forty dollars were expended in aid of disabled members. A number of new members were initiated, which at present number 540.

Yesterday there were three large public meetings in the city. No disturbances occurred. The meeting of the Deputies of the Left, called by M. JULES SIMON, took place last night. Only seven members were present at the meeting. The ministers have gone to Compiegne to attend a council summoned by the Emperor.

Valencia still holds out against the troops. An official dispatch from that quarter, received to-day, states that the insurgents have proposed to capitulate, but the authorities demand unconditional submission. The town of Bejar, forty-five miles south of Salamanca, has revolted, and the inhabitants are flying from the place.

The difference between the registration figures of New-York and Brooklyn of this year and those of a twelve-month ago, are remarkable. In this City, there's a falling of 116,818, or sixty-seven per cent., while in the City of Churches there is a decrease of 25,501, or fifty-five per cent.
The Boston, Hartford and Erie Railroad intended as a short and direct road from Boston to the West and also to New-York City, has been building for a considerable time.
The steamship Columbia, which left Havana Oct. 9, reached this port yesterday. For the prompt delivery of our letters and papers we are once more indebted to the courtesy of the Purser.

At about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the upper story of PETER BALLENTINE SON'S extensive brewery on the corner of Rector and Front streets, Newark, N. J., was discovered to be on fire. The flames spread to the roof, and on account of the high wind which prevailed it was with great difficulty that they were prevented from doing further damage.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have seen in some of the New-York daily papers allusions to a reported speech of GEORGE DAVIS, Esq., of Wilmington, made in the proceedings relating to the steamship Cuba on Monday last, and from the character of these allusions I judge that the Press has been Imposed upon by a raise report.

Fat boiling without a permit being prohibited after the 15th inst., the conditions of the proposed permits were definitely settled Wednesday by the Board of health. No one is to be allowed to boil fate except when fresh from the animal and wholly untainted,

Yesterday was the third day of the Fall Race Meeting at Jerome Park, and the beauty of the Weather caused a large and Fashionable attendance. The track was heavy and holding, not having cried up after the heavy rain in the early part of the week.

Advices from Mazatlan to Oct. 4 have been received. Everything indicated that a revolution in Sinaloa was unminent. Troops had been stationed along the southern frontier of the State. The Government was buying up and manufacturing ammunition in large quantities. Desertions form the army were numerous.

The notable decrease of accidents in this City occurring from the explosion of Kerosene Oil, while in use as an illuminating agent, is a source of gratification. Within the past few weeks scarcely any of the frightful burning cases, of which we used to hear so frequently have been chronicled.

The Emperor NAPOLEON has ordered that the traveling expenses of the French Bishops of Quebec, on going to and returning from the Enamenical Council, shall be defrayed from the imperial exchequer.

It is evident from a letter which we published yesterday that the idea lately kindled into new life in England, of sending out emigrants in bodies to colonize particular districts, is destined to produce memorable results. The advantages of the system are numerous.
At Norwood yesterday, Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had a grand time. As fine a crowd as ever attended a suburban sale accompanied them on this excursion.

A dispatch from Schenectady say: "All the aqueducts have been repaired, but the rain which is still falling has increased the injuries at the culverts. It will be impossible to resume navigation by the 16th inst. The water is still rising in the Mohawk.

Illicit stills are as common in old Virginia as they used to be in 'Ould Ireland" in days when a drop of the "cratar," lawfully procured, was almost worth its weight in gold. The mountain sides, 'he glens, the heaths, the hogs were all dotted with stills--and so it is in Virginia at this hour.

President BAEZ says a St. Domingo dispatch, is again negotiating the sale of he Bay of Samana to the United States. An explanation follows: "Money is very scarce"--in the Baez treasury, of course. We hope that President BAEZ will have the negotiations all to himself.

United States District--Attorney PIERRE-PONT received a Telegram from Attorney-General HOAR on Wednesday last, requesting him to send Mr. B. K. PHELPS, Assistant United States District-Attorney, to Wilmington, N. C., to conduct the Government proceedings against the Cuban steamer Hornet.

EGBERT F. TEN EYCK, an actor connected with the Fifth-avenue Theatre, formerly a clerk in the United States Army Paymaster's office, was arrested at the above theatre on Wednesday evening, shortly after the performance, on a bench warrant issued from the United States Circuit Court.

The Convention of the Grand Commandery of Master Masons of Ohio began here to-day, and will continue until Wednesday next. The attendance is large. During the session important matters in the several degrees of Masonry will be brought up.

President GRANT, accompanied by General SHERMAN, Secretary COX, Postmaster-General CRESWELL, Secretary ROBESON and General F. T. DENT, left Washington this morning in a special car--Secretary ROBESON on his way to Annapolis, and the others to the Frederick County Agricultural Fair.

Governor SENTER submitted his message to the Tennessee Legislature on Tuesday. After a brief reference to the war, and the consequences thereof, he discusses the franchise question, declaring that the time has come for the removal of all inequality of privileges for political causes, and recommends prompt, and most efficient measures to restore all citizens to their rights and privileges.

The Special Congressional Committee on Commerce and Shipping held its first regular session at the Custom House yesterday morning. All the members of the Committee were present. Hon. JOHN LYNCH, of Maine, Chairman of the Committee, presided. There was a large attendance of merchants.

Pursuant to adjournment, the Gold Exchange met in Executive session, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of considering the report of the Committee of Nine, made at the meeting held a week ago, relative to the establishment of a new clearing House for gold, to be under the control of the members of the Gold Exchange.

News has been received from Central Asia that the Ameer of Bokhara has petitioned for the assistance of Russia against SHEERE AALI, of Cabool; that he has sent tribute to the Czar, and that his eldest son has gone to St Petersburg to seenye the succession to the Caliphate through the protection of Russia.

City Comptroller CONNOLLY has recovered his health sufficiently to enable him to attend to business. Mr. OSWALD OTTENDORFFER, proprietor of the New-Yorker State Zeilung, returned from Europe, on Monday, by the steamer Silesm. His health is greatly improved, and he hopes by exercising care to be able to preserve it.

The Tammany leaders propose to amuse the mass of the Democracy to-morrow evening and on the ensuring Monday, by allowing them to indulge in certain performances that may induce the belief among the unreflecting that the rank and file have something to do with the selection of persons to fill positions of trust in the City and County of New-York.

The walking match at the Skating Rink, which commenced Monday evening at 9:32 1/2, closed last evening. MCETTRICK being the winner. It has undoubtedly been the most interesting and attractive match that has ever been decided at the Rink.

At Harlem Flats yesterday several experiments were made, under the superintendence of the Metropolitan Fire Department, in order to test the merits of an invention by Mr. TODD, whereby it is claimed that fires may been extinguished in one fifth the ordinary time by the use of chemicals, with which the water from the trains, as it passes through an engine, is impregnated.

The Avenue C Railroad, running from the Greenpoint to the Jersey City ferries, is now completed, and will commence operations on Monday morning next. The depot is at Nos. 707, 709 and 711 East Tenth-street.

The dispatch which appeared in the Times on Saturday, announcing that an explosion had occurred at the Hossac Tunnel. is verified by further accounts which have come to hand. From these accounts we learn that on Saturday morning last the men at work at the east end were startled by hearing a tremendous explosion in the cascade ravine, situated about fifty reds from the entrance to the tunnel.

The Convention met at 10 o'clock. The first report presented was that which provides for the improvement of the Mississippi River and the tributaries. A memorial to be presented to Congress, and resolutions favoring the improvements, were read and unanimously adopted.

To-day will be entirely quiet both in the salesroom and in the country. The auctioneers have had a hard week's work and to-day will take a rest and prepare for the labor in store for them. Next week will be particularly lively and interesting; a number of very attractive sales will be made, among them some of the largest that have been made this season.

The World politely throws Mr. PENDLETON overboard. It compliments him, of course. It pronounces him a "favorite Democratic leader and able statesman;" attributes to him "brilliant personal popularity;" and yet again, referring to Ohio, declares him to be "personally the most popular man within its boundaries."
Hon. FREDERICK F. LOW, Minister to China, starts for Washington on Monday. The trotting match yesterday between Harvest Queen and Venture, for $10,000, was won by Harvest Queen in 2144.

At 10 o'clock on Wednesday night, when it was fully known in Columbus, Ohio, that Governor HAYES was reelected, an impromptu meeting of Republicans was held, and it was decided to celebrate the victory. A huge bonfire was built on the corner of High and State streets, and soon after a large crowd collected in front of the Committee Rooms, and loudly called for Governor HAYES.

JAMES SHERIDAN, aged 10 years, was kicked in the head yesterday by a horse and dangerously injured. He was taken to his home in Ninety-second-street, near Third-avenue. Yesterday morning an unknown man was badly crushed in Tenth-avenue, near Thirtieth-street, by being caught between a street car and a post. He was removed to Mount Sinai Hospital.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The sight of a good man struggling with adversity is a noble one. It exalts and purifies the beholder, and exerts a moral influence in every way salutary and beneficent. Conversely, when a man who has once been good seeks refuge from the strokes of adversity by deliberately becoming bad, he affords a spectacle fraught with sorrow and pain alike for gods and men.

Shall a circuit preacher be allowed to go to his appointments on a veloelpedel is the momentous question now being discussed by the methodist Recorder of England. The Recorder thinks he may, if his example does not load others to ride for pleasure on Sunday.

What was in all probability the last concert of the season was given yesterday at the Central Park. the blustering wind was sufficient to keep many away. and the attendance did not exceed 1,000 persons. Tents were dispensed with, and those who stopped to listen to the music kept themselves warm by promenading around the music stand.

About four years ago the State Legislature made an appropriation for the relief of the destitute and deserving blind in this City. Since then similar appropriations have been made each year. The last legislative donation for this humane purpose was fixed at $25,000, which sum was placed in the hands of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for distribution.

Captain KANE, of the steamer Rob Roy, brings information of the destruction by fire on Thursday night of the Louisiana State Seminary, near Alexandria. The library, apparatus and most of the furniture were saved. The loss is about $140,000, on which there was no insurance. The fire is believed to have been the work of an Incendiary.

HOLYOKE, a well-known writer in England on questions of interest to the working classes--we do not allude to his views on Christianity--has been making some practical remarks on cooperation and industrial partnerships. Of the former system, he says: "No workmen, 100 in number, ought to be without a cooperative store in any part of the country."

It is difficult for me to give you any adequate idea of the intensity of political feeling in Spain to-day. Mr. BUCKLE calls Spain "a torpid mass," but he never could have seen it at an hour like this, when every mind is full of coming events, when every cafe is a committee room, and every man a working politician.

The success of the Freedman's Savings and Trust Company, of Washington, is matter for congratulation of that institution. The amount of deposits, which reach nearly $1,500,000, is a highly respectable fact. And the establishment of branches throughout the principal cities of the country argues active business management.

For the past twelve months or more the nuisance caused by the noxious and foul exhalations omitted from the works of the New-York Rendering and other companies have occupied the attention of the Board of Health, with but little success in the way of improvement, as every action taken by the Board in the matter seemed to meet obstacles which effectual precluded any hope of an abatement of the nuisance.

A disgraceful shooting affair occurred at Taylorsville, Warrick county, Ind., on Sunday, resulting in the death of two, if not three persons. The difficulty was between a man named SPRINGSTOOR on the one side, and two others, named CLARK, on the other, in which HARVEY SPRINGSTOOR was killed, and his brother ABE so badly wounded that he died soon after.

The car shops of the Lake Shore Railroad were destroyed by fire yesterday. Passenger and freight cars, lumber, car material and tools were entirely consumed. The loss is over $300,000; fully insured.

A Madrid telegram reports the loss of life at the taking of Valencia as small, only two of the National troops being killed. The loss of the insurgents is unknown. No taxpayers or householders in the city, it is said, were engaged in the revolt. The capture of the city is reported to have had a quieting effect throughout the country.

The Medical Branch of the New-York University inaugurated its Winter's course of lectures last evening in the new building on Twenty-sixth-street, near the Bellevue Hospital. The opening address was delivered by Dr. JOHN W. DRAPER.

Mr. ALEX, H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, was long esteemed as a moderate politician. His election as Vice-President of the rebel Confederacy was supposed to be a partial anthlote to the ultraism of JEFFERSON DAVIS. In the matter of reconstruction, however, Mr. STEPHENS proves to be veritable extremist.

Prince GORTSCHAKOFF, of Russia, arrived in this city on Saturday. LEOPOLD, King of Belgium, has been invited to meet NAPOLEON at Compiegne. It is Probable that Marshal BAZAINE will be appointed Commander of the Imperial Guard.

The appropriation of $25,000 by the last State Legislature for the relief of theradigent blind of thus City, will prove a God-send to a numerous and worthy class of people, who have seareely any other means of living comfortably daring the approaching Winter season.

Father CHARLES LOYSON HYACINTHE, the most popular preacher in France, and whose name is now so closely connected with the religious questions of the day, arrived in this City yesterday. He came by the steamer Pereire, Captain DUCHESNE, from Havre, whence she sailed on Saturday, Oct. 9. touching at Brest the same day, and reached this port at six o'clock yesterday morning, making the passage in eight days and sixteen hours,
The new Fish market, adjoining the Fulton Ferry, was opened last night to a numerous assembly of invited guests, and had the appearance, for the time being, of a brilliantly-lighted banquet ball.

The Metropolitan Board of Health would seem, from certain proceeding at its last session, to have again broken faith with the public by still further perpetuating the nuisances of fat melting and bone boiling in this City. Pledge after pledge has it given for several months past that these pestilential nests should be removed, but its promises have all been forgotten.

Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER'S great sale at Railway, N. J., yesterday, was, as their sales usually are, very successful. At the time appointed a goodly number of very respectable appearing persons bud assembled; indeed, under the admirable arrangements and precautions, none others could attend, and not one incident occurred to may the pleasures of the day.

How is the vote on the new Constitution to be counted in New-York and Brooklyn? We presume our readers will be surprised to hear that there is any doubt about it. An examination of the act under which the vote is to be taken, however, will show that there is a good deal of uncertainty in the matter.

Much complaint having been made of the oppressiveness of the tax regulations upon the distillation of brandy from apples, peaches and grapes, exclusively, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue has, upon a proper presentation of the facts, ordered an additional exemption in relation to such distillation.

The Italian residents generally, and a large proportion of other nationalities, yesterday celebrated the anniversary of the discovery of America by COLUMBUS, by a procession and appropriate exercises in the City Gardens.

A gentleman who arrived here to-night direct from Wilmington, N.C., says the United States Commissioner, Collector of the Port, and Prosecuting Attorney have no doubt the Hornet will be condemned and dismantled. When the Hornet was capture, she had on board only ten tons of bad coal.

The annual election for officers of the New-York Gold Exchange was held yesterday, previous to which the report of the Treasurer was presented. The balance, April 1, 1869, was $96, 722 89; the receipts amounted to $133,352 38; the balance in the Now-York Gold Exchange Bank is $1,022 65; cash in hands of Treasurer, $3,091 09; loans on Government bonds at par, $110,000.

That honest and industrious artisan, "Reddy the Blacksmith," yesterday appeared for the second time at the Central Police Office, demanding that his picture be withdrawn from the Rogues' Gallery, where it was placed after his late return from California.

Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD arrived at Manzanilla on the 7th inst. He was received on landing with salutes from the forts, and was met by the Governor of the State of Collma, who in the name of President JUAREZ warmly welcomed the distinguished quest to Mexico.

We observe that the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelly to Animals has began the inspection of horses belonging to hack-drivers who apply for licenses. This is well. Many of the horses thus employed are atterly unfit for work, and it is an act of benevolence to prevent their misuse.

DIETZ--In Harlem, on Saturday, Oct. 16, FANNIE MYER, wife of John G. Dietz. The Friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, in 129th-st., near 7th-av., on Tuesday, the 19th inst., at 4 o'clock P. M.

The meeting of the special Congressional Committee on the Decay of American Commerce, has adjourned to be reopened in Boston. Much information was presented to them by our prominent merchants and shipbuilders, as to the causes of this national misfortune...

Last Friday morning JOHN A. DEYO, aged 15, an employe in the Cosmopolitan Hotel, in Chambers-street, was shot in the head by JAMES NOLAN, a porter in the same hotel. Coroner KEENAN yesterday held an ante-mortem examination. It appears that NOLAN came down stairs with a revolver in his hand when DEYO requested permission to look at it.

A meeting of the State Temperance Committee, called to consider the action of the two political parties at their recent State Conventions and the duty of the temperance voters of the State, was held at No. 172 William-street, on Friday last.

Ponchon and family, Mr. Poirtz, Mr. Brati, Mr. Gallatin, Mr. Blanoy and wife, Mrs, Bain and daughter, Mr. Baldwin, Mr. Rocheran, Mr. Seguin, Miss Arnouns, Miss Noble Jones, Mr. Rosellus, Mr.Recd and wife, Mr. Avel and wife, Mr. Johnson and wife, Mr. Mann and wife. Senator SPRAGUE, the Knight of the Rueful Countenance, is still wearing the willow for his country. On Saturday he uttered another of his popular series of lamentations over the destinies of the nation. It seems that we give no attention to the people of other countries--the last fault that we should have thought could be found with us--and that we do not compare favorably with our competitors in trade.

A case just advanced a stage in Iowa calls for a passing word. The Supervisors of Leo Country, In that State, refused to collect the taxes due the United States in respect to certain railway bonds. They were arrested for contempt, and discharged by a State Judge on the ground of no jurisdiction.

The Chicago Tribune gives some apposite Illustrations of the comparative expensiveness of Republican and Democratic State Governments. What can be achieved in the way of reckless extravagance, we of New-York have already experienced. But the Tribune leaves New-York out of the question as too bad a case for the purposes of comparison.

The loss of life in the fighting which preceded the capture of Valencia was trifling. Of the national troops only two were killed, and seven wounded. The losses suffered by the insurgents are unknown. It has been ascertained that no taxpayer or householder in Valentia took part in the revolt.

In accordance with a resolution of the Joint Committee from the Chamber of Commerce and Produce Exchange, passed some time ago, a convention of the friends of the canals is to be held in this City, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, to-day. S. S. GUTHRIE, President of the Buffalo Board of Trade, has appointed the following delegates :

Mr. BONNER'S very striking and successful principle of publishing the first and best stories of the greatest living writers has just been newly illustrated. Already he had introduced his world of readers to Dr. TYNG, HENRY WARD BEECHER and a number of other distinguished clergymen, who have each given, through the columns of the Ledger, their only work of fiction.

The greatest Catholic display ever witnessed in Montreal took place yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the translation of the relies of St. SENO from Bonsecour's Church to the Bishop's Palace. Over 30,000 people joined in the procession.

The Tammany Ring having disinherited a late favorite son who was a member of the last State Senate, the ex-favorite rebels and declares he will offer again for the place as an independent Democratic candidate. Professing to be certain of election, he only regrets that he was thrown out by the Ring because it will cost him $23,000 to be returned. It would be pertinent,

Compared with last year, at this length of time before the November election, there is very little doing in the Courts of Naturalization. The Supreme Court, so far as we can learn, is doing literally nothing. For the week ending last evening. (Oct. 18,) there have been naturalized in the Court of Common Pleas 398, and in the Superior Court, 103. Total, 501.

The lawless condition of parts of Indiana is as ?? as it is disgraceful. The hanging and shooting of men by vigilance committees indicates an absolute state of barbarism. The RENO brothers, who were taken from prison by a mob who would not wait for the action of law upon he charge of express robberies, were murdered in cold blood, to the horror of everyone who road of the case.

In the House this morning, a communication was received from General CANBY, thanking them for the privilege of the flour voted him yesterday. The resolution relatives to the recent elections in the North, introduced yesterday, was tabled.

It is proper enough that Mr. ADOLPH SUTRO should use his utmost endeavors to carry out the project for the tunnel which bears his name, provided he appeals for aid to the quarter most immediately concerned. Therefore, his address recently delivered, at Virginia City, to the citizens of Nevada, is not to be objected to.

CHARLES WILLIAM ELIOT, the successor of Rev. THOMAS HILL, as President of Harvard College, was formally inaugurated at Cambridge today. There has probably been no change in the administration of the College, from the day of its foundation down to the present time, which has excited such general, serious and various comment as the last.
Returns from all the counties have been received at the Republican headquarters in this city, a few only of them unofficial. The result will vary but a few votes R. D. HARRISON, Chairman...

To the Editor of the New-york Times : Permit me to say a word with respect of an infamous and unfounded charge against me, recently preferred by a poor, ignorant woman, instigated thereto by others. The charge has been dismissed on the testimony of the complainant herself.

The Tammany Ring held their County convention at the Wigwam last evening, which was filled with delegates comprising a full representation of all the wards. Mayor HALL, was called on to preside, and made one of his characteristic speeches, in which he tickled the vanity of has hearers by telling them that he had that day been comparing a first of delegates to the Tammany convention with a list of members of the Union League,

ALLYN.--Suddenly, on Tuesday, Oct. 19, TIMOTHY C. ALLYN, of this City, aged 40 years. The remains will be taken to Hartford, Cenn., for interment. COWAN.--On Tuesday, Oct. 19, EMILY E. COWAN, oldest daughter of Amer and Anna M. Cowan, of consumption.

The Mutuals and Atlantics played their return game yesterday, at the Union Grounds, in the presence of many spectators, in spite of the weather, which made standing uncomfortable. In the first game the Atlantics were victorious, but yesterday they were outplayed by the Mutuals and defeated. The match was rather a singular one, as the score shows, the Atlantics being "Whitewashed" for six innings in succession.

Minister WASHOURNE has applied for more money. He cannot keep up the French Mission on the salary allowed by Congress. Therefore he must have $15,000 gold for "contingent expenses." It would be interesting to have hoard the opulent of Representative WASHBURNE on that proposition. When in Congress he had an exeacdingly keon scont for appeals of this kind.

The Journal Office contains the following appointments: Marshal BAZAINE to be commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Guard; General DE FAILLY to be Commander-in-Chief of the Third Army Corps, headquarters at Nancy, vice Marshal BAZAINE, . It is officially denied that there is any foundation for the rumors of changes in the Ministry.

CLARK---SCRIVEN.--On Wednesday, Oct. 6, at the Parish Church of Withecombe Raleigh, Exmouth, Devonshire, England, by Rev. Henry Hussey, inoumbent, ALFRED CORNING CLARK, youngest son of Edward Clark, Esq. and grandson of the late Ambroso L. Jordan, of New-York, to ELIZABETH SCRIVEN youngest daughter of the late George Seriven, and nicce of Dr. Samuel r. Percy, of New-York.

Some of the English journals pay a well deserved tribute to remarkable man who died a few weeks age--Mr. THOMAS WATTS, of the British Museum Library. His short, squat figure will be remembered by any one who has over had occasion to use the reading room of that institution.

"AS YOU LIKE IT" AT THE FIFTH-AVENUE THEATRE. The delicious comedy, whose every scene carries as away into green Roll's, by sylvan shades and sparkling waters, and whose almost every line is freighted with melodious philosophy, was repeated at the Fifth-avenue Theatre, last night, for the purpose of enabling Mrs. SCOTT SIDDONS and Mrs. CLARA JENNINGS to change the parts they had essayed on the previous evening, and to appear respectively as Cella and Rosalind.

Mr. GLADSTONE'S extraordinary run of ecclesiastical patronage--only equaled in extent by that oxerelsed by Lord PALMERSTON during his tonure of power---seems likely to involve him in serious trouble. During the earlier part of his political career his undisguised sympathy with the ultra High Church movement made him the subject of a deep-rooted averaton on the part of the Evangelicals, from the effects of which he suffered long and seriously. his appoint.

The undersigned, being convinced of the necessity of an American Woman Suffrage Association, which shall embody the deliberate action of the State organizations, and shall carry with it their united weight, do hereby respectfully invite such organizations to be represented in a delegate Convention, to be held at Cleveland, Ohio, Nov. 24 and 25, A. D. 1869.

A well--Known contributor to the Atlantic Monthly calls attention to the waste of public money which goes on in and around Congress. He condomns the pictures under the dome and elsewhere, in common with most other critics who have any cultivated taste to boast of.

The Republican insurrection is considered almost at an end, but precautions against failure outbreaks are considered necessary. Previous to the final attack on Valcuein the Government forces lost many men killed and wounded in skirmishes with the insurgents.

The Diario de la Marina to-day published three important documents, incorporated in their passage through the island, which, if true, prove that the Republican rising in Spain is the work of the Cuban insurgents. An additional detachment of troops was to-day sent to the seat of war.

The effort of Tammany to revive the waning love of the Germans for the Ring by falsifying an occurrence in a Police Station House, has resulted in disastrous failure. A German emigrant, taken very much ?? to a Station House, had managed to give himself while there some severe cuts and bruises.

A more unpleasant day than yesterday for a country sale can scarcely be imagined, Cold, raw windy dusty and generally disagreeable, yet despite all these drawbacks, live car loads of gentlemen and Indies accompanied Messrs. A. D. MELLICK, Jr., BROTHER to Newark, Arriving at the Broad--street Station, a number of large six-horse stages were in waiting, which, being soon filled, carried the excursionists to the top of the had overlooking Newark, known as Clinton-place.

The Republicans of the Fifth District of Erie County have nominated LYMAN OATMAN for member of Assembly. The Democrats of the Third District yesterday nominated Hon. ISRAEL T. HATCH, who was previously nominated by some 200 merchants of Buffalo to look after the canal interests of the city. The Republican candidate in that district is A.H. BLOSSOM.
The congressional Committee of Inquiry on American Shipping met to-day in the rooms of the Board of Trade, About twenty leading shipbuilders and merchants were present., FRANKLIN W. SMITH,

An extraordinary emigration party was made up a little while ago in the County of Mayo, Ireland. Three children, aged respectively 11, 6 and 4, agreed to start from their native village and make their way to Chicago! Their father had sent them a ticket to lake them from Liverpool to New-York, and armed with that and the sum of ten shillings, they set out on their travels. The poor children, we are told,

The Cuba was Ilbeted to-day, and the United State Marshall boarded her and demanded the surrender of the ship into his hands. Commodore HIGGINS declined to surrender his ship except to an officer of the United States Navy, and under a direct order from President GRANT.

Not so far from it, perhaps, as some others, the current Atlantic is still not at its best mark, Mr. PARTON has an interesting paper "The Small Sins of Congress;" Dr. HOLMES a poem measuring BONAPARTE and HUMBOLDT; Mr. TUCKERMAN a pleasant article on "The Old Bankers of Florence;"

The strike on the Erie Railroad still continues, and with the exception of the Susequehanna shop, the men seem as determined as over to hold out until the discharged men at Port Jervis are reinstated.

The pulpit has not yet properly apprehended the improvements which outerprising lawyors have introduced into the laws regulating marriage. In a sormon delivered on Sunday last, the preacher warned the unmarried portion of his congregation to be careful how they selected their partners in life.

Among the institutions regarding whose management the State Commissioners of Public Charities offter suggestions, in their late report, the two "Houses of Refuge" at New-York and Rocheser are specially interesting.

Brothers-in-law and cousins are not always a comfort in the family, but pugilists at least know how to turn the relationship to account. Hero is "JEM MACK," that hero of a hundred fights, carrying his cousin LEOPOLE about the country merely to knock him down for the amusement of the public.

The friends of GEORGE PEABODY, Esq., will be gratified to learn of his safe arrival in England on the 8th inst. A letter written by him off Liverpool on that day, was received by one of his relatives here yesterday, in which he states that though feeble his general health continues much the same as when he left.

General HICKENLOOPER and T. D. JONES, Esq., of Cincinnati, General BUCKLAND, of Fremont, and the members of the McPherson Monument Association, met at Clyde, on the 15th inst., surveyed the cemetery grounds, and selected the site for the location of the monument.

We print as valuable, because coming from reliable Spanish sources, the subjoined facts in regard to recent operations in Cuba: DISTRICT OF CUBA. On the 26th of September the column under General JUAN SA EZ IZQUIRDO, 202 men strong, and a detachment of artillery with two guns, attacked Generals MARMOL and JORDAN and Brigadier FONSECA, who had encamped on the borders of the Canto River, between Canto-Abajo and Palma-Sorlane.

The gunboat Prince Alfred, stationed at Goderich, has been pleased in readiness for active service. Orders were received here last night directing the Toronto Field Battery to proceed immediately to Goderich to man the Prince Alfred. One-half of the battery left here this morning.

Another member of the British aristocracy has come to grief--Lord CHARLES G. A. HAMILTON, the heir of the Premier Peerage of Scotland This young gentleman is now only in his 22d year, but by dint of strenuous efforts he has managed to run himself "over head and cars" into debt.

Some months age the General synod of the Reformed Church issued an invitation to all ?? denominations in the country to ?? delegates to meet in council for the purpose of devising means of uniting the various churches and extending the Gospel throughout the world. The circulars issued by the Synod met with a cordial reception, and a numerous gathering is looked for.

Mr. HENRY DE BERGH, who is aiming at a truly good work, whatever may be said in ridicule of it, might sometimes do a good turn to that ill-fated creature, the turtle. The method of outting it up before it is quite dead is said by those who are in the secret, to be bad enough. but its features are its last hours arrive,

The tendency of very common and very simple matters to surround themselves, in the course of ages, with a kind of mystery, after several generations have talked a good deal about them, without clearly understanding them, has been very well illustrated in the case of the carrying trade.

Certainly Mr. BOUCICAULT is the neatest hand at concocting an advertisement now extent. He is worth the attention of proprietors of bitters, scents, healing ointment and life-giving pills. They ought to hire him to prepare "catch" paragraphs. When "Formosa" was produced he managed to get up a discussion on is alleged indecency, but, unfortunately, people soon saw through the trick.

The discovery of a conspiracy to surrender the barracks at San Mateo, Spain, to the Insurgeuts is reported; and the Captain of the garrison, who was implicated, has been arrested. Before the attack on Valencia the national droops suffered severe losses in skirmishing.

A protest just published in Havana, and signed by over 3,000 of its citizens, scene, to express the largely prevalent sentiments of the Spanish and native residents of the Island with considerable accuracy. It has always been doubled by Impartial observers whether much of the Importance of the insurrection was not due to the efforts of persons who wither sought politics notoriety here,

A violent snowstorm set in here about 7 o'clock this morning and continued until noon. Although the snow melted fast, there are new about three inches on the ground. The snow came from the north, where it began last night, and has prevailed in Illinois, Missouri and Kansas.

Our article of yesterday on "Republican Nominations for the Legislature" has elicited explanations and qualifying statements from friends of some of the gentlemen therein named, With regard to two only correction seems necessary.

The exercises of the twentieth anniversary of the American Bible Union commenced yesterday morning at the Baptist Mariners' Temple, corner of Henry and Oliver streets, and will be continued to-day. In the forenoon the annual election of officers took place, resulting in the reelection of last year's list with a few alterations in the Boards of Managers.

Most people remember the startling announcement of a "triple alliance" which was made not long ago by a " special correspondent." The powers contracting the alliance were represented to be England, France and Spain, and the nation threatened was our own. The story was intrinsically improbable, and it was soon contradicted with much ridicule in France and England.

BARKER--TOUSLEY.--On Wednesday, Oct. 20, at Passaic, N. J., by Rev. John A. Mckenn, GEORGE A. BAR??, of New-York, to EMMA A., daughter of Charles Tuesday, Esq., of Passaic, N. J. No cards. BONNER--CLARK.--On Wednesday, Oct. 220, by Rev. Henry Ward Boocher. DAVID BONNER, of New-York, to Miss MARIE ADELE CLARK, daughter of Allen Clark, Esq., of Brooklyn.

A fearful tragedy was enacted yesterday afternoon, at a locality beyond the Mission, in which a young and very pretty girl was shot and killed by a ferocious lover,, who afterward lodged a bullet in his own brain.

The immigration of foreigners to this country is becoming more organized than it has been. The Germans and Scandinavians have been for a good white coming and settling in societies or companies throughout the West as recently in Missouri,

The Directors of the Gold Exchange Clearing House held a meeting yesterday afternoon, and considered various amendments to the plan which had already been submitted to them. While they were debating the various modifications a message was sent in to the Chairman by Mr. C. N. JORDAN, the Receiver of the Gold Exchange Bank,

The Board held their usual meeting yesterday, President LINCOLN in the chair. Dr. STONE moved that the chemist he directed to report to this Board some sample test by which the Board can ascertain the purity of their kerosene. Adopted.

We said yesterday that MATTREW P. BEMUS, net with standing his notorious record, has been renominated for the Assembly by Republicans of the First District of Chautauqaua County. He is one of the two who alone, of all the supporters of the Hodges Tax-levy, have obtained even a partial indorsement by their constituents.

A review of the Imperial Guard will be held on Sunday next, when a demonstration in favor of the Emperor is expected. The Radical voters propose to summon the Deputies from Paris to resign their seats in the Corps Legislatif on the ground that they have not fulfilled their duties.

At 11 o'clock last evening Office GAMBURNS, assisted by two other officers, made the arrest of a desperate couple, whose names are JOHN SMITH and ROSE PRINCE, at the house No. 28 Broome-street, Noward, and lodged them in the station House.

The first rain of the season fell to-day and is prevailing through-out the coast. A large force of men and teams are employed on they California and Oregon Railroad, and the road is expected to be completed to Chico on Feb. 1.

In accordance with an invitation of the General Synod of the Reformed Church, a numerous delegation met at the Washington-square reformed Church, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of devising me us for uniting the various churches and spreading the Gospel.

The good results of the October election in Pennsylvania and Ohio should not be diminished in the State of New-York in November. The indersement of the Administration of General GRANT by 8,000 in Ohio and 4,500 in Pennsylvania, on a comparatively light popular vote, is most emphatic.

An impression seems to be gaining ground that America has reason to fear the competition of British India in cotton manufacture. A contemporary in Philadelphia expresses this fear in a forelble manner, but its theory seems to have no facts to rest upon. .

An inquest is to be held to-day by Coroner KEENAN in the case of PATRICK MCGUINNESS, aged 70, who is alleged to have met his death through injuries sustained at the hands of JOSEPH R. JAMES, aged 33. The deceased and JAMES were both occupants of the same house, No. 540 Ninth-avenue, and had a drunken quarrel on Monday night.

The Republican mass meeting last evening, was a great success. There was a vast assemblage, animated by more than ordinary enthusiasm; the speeches were spirited and effective; and the resolutions adopted have the genuine ring.

The following letter from Mr. HENDERSON GAYLORD, of Plymouth, Penn., gives interesting information concerning the Avondale Relief Fund, of which he is the Treasurer. It is proper to say that the letter is a reply to one asking for information concerning the fund, and especially as to what subscriptions remain uncollected:
