The Erie Railway strike was a very trivial affair. The men engaged in three shops belonging to the Company demanded to be paid on the 15th of every month. Mr. FISK promised that this should be done. When the 15th of October came two shops out of the three were left unpaid.

Yesterday was quite a busy day; two large sales of suburban property were made, and two small sales of City property at the Exchange Salesroom. At Boscobel, on the Hudson, Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had a large and very satisfactory sale.

A review of the French Imporial Guard is announced for Sunday next, when a demonstration favorable to the Emperor is untlerpated. The dissatisfaction of the ulta Radical voters of Paris with the Opposition Deputies and their manifesto may take the form of a demand for their resignation.

JOHN REAL, who killed Police officer JOHN SMEDICK, was seen in company with one of Sheriff O'BRIEN'S deputies at the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, on Monday afternoon at about 2 o'clock. A meeting of members and friends of the Western Branch Young Men's Christian Association will be held at the rooms No. 285 Hudson-street, this evening at 8 o'clock, for the purpose of reorganizing.

It was rumored some weeks age that the Tammany Ring, in the preliminary distribution of the spoils, had given the nomination of the Judge to succeed Judge CLERKE in the Supreme Court to Messrs. FISK and GOULD, and soon after it was reported that these worthies had had an attack of virtue, and were going to renominate Judge CLERKE, an upright and able officer, who has already been nominated by the Bar.

Mr. TIMOTHY C. ALLYN, an insurance agent at No. 30 William-street, boarding with his wife and child at the Gramerey Park Hotel, on Tuesday afternoon killed himself accidentally, it is supposed, while alone in his room.

This morning JOHN COLLINS, conductor on the Girard-avenue Passenger Railway, was shot and cut in the head with a hatchet, at the corner of Twenty-fourth-direct and College-avenue. His injuries are serious. The supposed assailant. JOHN SWIFT, has been arrested and locked up.

The National Capital Convention meet in this city to-day. Hon. JOHN D. CATON, of Illinois, was chosen permanent President, with fifteen Vice-Presidents. Judge JAMES H. BIRCH, of Missouri, offered a resolution providing for a committee to prepare an address providing for a the country upon the subject of removing the Capital,

The other day the Mayor of New-York granted the use of the City Hall for the purpose of celebrating what some one with unconscious irony what some one with unconscious irony called the anniversary of Cuban "independence." The casualties on that occasion were as serious as on almost any of the Cuban "battle fields," for a good many work nerves were shaken, and one man had his arm shot off.

Whatever poetry may have been associated with Alaska in imaginative souls must vanish before the matter-of-fact representations of General THOMAS. It is not flattering to our national vanity to he told that a territory for which we paid a good round sum is absolutely worthless.

On the American Institute grounds yesterday, a trial of two self-supporting fire ladders and escapes was made. The operations were begun by the owners of the Fielding apparatus, which 's a very large affair. It consists of three ladders, the largest of which hinges on a heavy oaken base, and is elevated by means of a winch The two smaller fit into this. and are arranged to work with pullers.

At 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the trial of DAVID BURKE, the alleged murderer of THOMAS CANE, at Hunter's Point, on the night of the 25th of October, 1868, during the great petroleum fire, commenced in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer, Justice BARNARD presiding.

A meeting of the National Executive Committee of the Union League of America was held yesterday at the St. Nicholas Hotel. There was a good attendance of members. Governor NEWELL, of New-Jersey, presided in the absence of Governor GEARY. The Secretary, Mr. BAKER, of New-York, read a report of the arrangements for the elections in Mississippi and Texas.

The machine shops in this village wear a Sunday aspect. The sound of the hammer is searcely heard, and quiet reigns supreme. Only four or five men are at work, as the discharged employes, among whom are included nearly all the men in the shops, have not been reinstated, although the men think their prospects are brightening daily.

An Omaha dispatch to the Tribune says: "A report has been received at the Department headquarters from Colonel DUNCAN, who recently commanded the expedition of the Republican River. There is no further doubt that the surveying party of twelve men, under NELSON BUCK, were murdered by the Indians, on the Republican River, in the latter part of August or early in September."

The following persons were arrested to-day, charged with having in their possession and selling counterfeit tobacco revenue stamps: FREDERICK BANNASCH, Ex-Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue; Captain T HOMAS W. ROACH, Ex-Detective of the Revenue Department, and Lieutenant JOHN H. STONE, late United States Whisky Inspector, and at present a special detective.

President SALNAVE arrived unexpectedly in this city on the 6th inst., and was received with much enthusiasm. He abandoned his army before the City of Aux Cayon and returned hither by land. His fleat act was to appoint a new Ministry. He named General CHEVALIER Minister of War; General AILMAND, Minister of Finance:

The Charleston (S. C.) News says that many of the most valuable coast and Sea Island plantations will, next season, be devoted to the growth of the finer kinds of upland cotton. The planters expect to make more money to the acre than by continuing the growth of Sea Island.

From time to time the attempt to force questionable publications into notoriety attracts the attention of the authorities. Week after week the pictures become more showy and daring, until a last the Police are ordered to seize the dirt heap. Kill one of these demoralizing sheets and it very soon reappears in another shape.

The convention of delegates from the various Boards of Trade, and of individuals throughout the State interested in reforming the canal management and improving the canal trade, was hold yesterday at the rooms of the Citizen's Association, No. 813 Broadway, in this City, pursuant to the call made Sept. 17 last, by the Joint Committees of the Association, the Chamber of Commercc, and the New-York Produce Exchange.

The inaugural address of the President of Harvard College, which we presented yesterday, will interest that large body of our readers who have sympathy with the modern reforms in education. Mr. ELIOT is, we believe, the youngest Harvard President who has over occupied that honorable position.

A dispatch from Dublin of yesterday announces the death of Right Hon. JOHN EDWARD WALSH, H. D, Master of the Rolls in Ireland. Dr. WALSH was born in 1810, and was educated at Trinity College, Dublin. He was admitted to the Bar in 1839, was made Queen's Counsel in 1837. Attorney-General for Ireland in 1869, and Maser of the Rolls the same year.

Rev. Dr. ALEXANDER H. VINTON, of St. Mark's Church, in this City, has accepted a call to Emanuel Church, In Boston, until lately occupied by Bishop HUNTINGTON, This call had been previously made in the Spring, but was declined by Dr. VISTON, who wished his congregation to move up town.

The New-York Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting yesterday at 1 o'clock, to consider an invitation which had been received by the President from the Khedive of Egypt, through his agent in Paris, that the Chamber be represented at the Inauguration of the Suez Canal Hon. Wm. E. DODGE presided,

To the Editor of the new-York Times: My attention has been directed to an article in the TIMES of the 12th inst., headed "The Hornel as a Pirate," in which occurs the following: "The counsel for the privateer. Hon. GEORGE DAVIS, is represented as 'boiling over with Cuban enthuslasm and sympathy,' which is probably the explanation of his opening speech being somewhat wild and sensational."

Pere HYACINTHE, accompanied by a French gentleman, who noted as his interpreter, visited BRADY's gallery, corner Broadway and Tenth street, yesterday morning, and had several excellent photographs of himself taken.

Following out the suggestion of Justice INGRAHAM in his charge at the commencement of the present term of the Oyer and Terminer, the Grand Jury are now hearing testimony relating to the subject of the recent gold speculations. Messrs. FISK and GOULD have been subp??naed to appear before and be examined by the Jury to-day.

Dispatches from Madrid report that the insurrection at Bejar has been suppressed. The troops had and dispersed it, killing, wounding and capturing many of the rebels. Among the killed is Senor GUILLEN, a Deputy to the Cortes. Four men have been executed at Seville for causing an accident to a railroad train full of troops.

The remarks we made recently with reference to the outrages committed on ladies in cars and stages, have awakened a response which sufficiently proves how far the evil had extended. We shall publish shortly some of the letters which have been addressed to us, but the perpetrators of those offences need not wait till then to desist from their cowardly and disgusting practices.

The second annual National Convention of railway conductors of the United States, in session yesterday, was called to order at 10 o'clock yesterday morning by Mr. JAMES MARSHALL, President of the Association of the New-York and Harlem Railroad, who Introduced Rev. Dr. TRIMBLE, of this city, who invoked the Divine blessing upon the deliberations of the Convention.

St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, is the oldest in that city, the Nostor of churches and Bishops, For more than forty years it was the only Episcopal Church in the city, and was organized when there were not more than a hundred houses in the region now the terminus of the Brooklyn city railroads and the Union Ferry.

The Cabinet met this morning and were in session a couple of hours. This extra meeting gave rise to considerable speculation, but it transpired that the cause of it was the fact that the business of a regular meeting of yesterday was not concluded, and the members met to-day to finish what was before them.

The Republican ratification meeting at Cooper Institute last evening was a grand success. The recent glorious victories in Pennsylvania and Ohio have given new life to the Republicans of this City, and they came together last evening imbued with a confidence and enthusiasm that afford the best assurance of victory in November.

The College Building is now on fire. The flames on the roof, which is of tin, are thought to extent from end to end. Engines are at work. The building contains the Lane College, Young Men's Mercantile Library, Chamber of Commerce, and several stores and offices.

A ??--in this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 20, Mrs., widow of the late Caleb Angevine need 50 years. Funeral from the Church of the Holy Communion, corner of 90th-st. and 6th-av., on Friday, Oct. 22 at 12 o' clock. relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. Remains will be buried in Green-wood Cemetery.

The Canal Convention yesterday resulted in an organization for the protection of what may be termed the honest commercial interests of the State, as against the Jobbers who grow fat at its expense. Corrupt officials and rascally contractors is made for prosecuting them when the requisite evidence shall be obtained.

MARY SOMERVILLE is a name which the Sorosis may well be proud of--as proud as the Germans are of Baron HUMBOLDT. This phenomenon of her sex, in her eightieth year, lately published an abstruse and admirable work on Molecular and Microscopic Science, reviewing and criticising the most recent researches and discoveries of the philosopheres in the world of nature.

Dr. WATERBURY, of the Presbyterian Church, were elected Presidents to preside at the different sessions of the

Some one has written a book on Monarchs Retired from Business. He might add to it all affecting chapter on diplomatists out of employment. Their lot is a hard one. Nothing is go unpleasant as to be a great man one day and a nobody the next.

SATURDAY. Mails for German States, via Hamburg, by the Toutonia, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the City of Antwerp, close at 12'M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on Pier No. 45 North River, to 1:30 P. M.

The Gold Exchange Bank commenced yesterday morning to pay twenty-five per cent. of all ascertained claims of creditors against the institution, and succeeded by the close of business hours in satisfying the demands to this extent of all but nine of the parties whose money had been locked up in the vaults since the 24th of September.

This case, in which HELENE C. STILLE is plaintiff, and Baron HENRI DE REVIERE is defendant, came up for hearing yesterday before Judge JONES, of the Superior Court, on a motion on behalf of defendant to discharge the order of arrest under which the defendant had given bail.

ATHERTON.--On Thursday morning, Oct. 21, ALMIRA STUART, wife of Henry L. Atherton. Funeral from the residence of her son-in-law, George H. Forstor, No. 4t West 22d-st., on Saturday, 23d inst., at 3 o'clock P. M. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend. BUTLER.--At Detroit, Mich., on Sunday morning,

During the meeting of the Presbyterian Synod to-day the literature and music of Sabbath Schools were denounced as unfit to be taken into the Church, and resolutions were adopted urging Christians to use their efforts to enforce a rigid observation of Sunday laws, and to refuse their votes to persons who violate these laws.

A Powerful section of Irish citizens here recently protested against the Democratic nominations and policy. Now the German Democrats are loud in expressions of dissatisfaction. To estrange both classes is an act of ingenuity which the Democratic managers can scarcely hope to equal very often.

Madrid dispatches report the departure of 8,000 troops on Wednesday for Havana. Captain-General DE ROADAS has informed the Home Government that the Cubans and the insurgents in Spain have all along been acting in concert. The Republican leaders captured in arms are to be shot, and several have already been executed.

Undismayed by previous discomfitures, the organs of the Gold Ring have renewed their attempts to identify the President with the recent transactions of FISK and GOULD. From one infamy they have descended to another.

By an act of the Legislature passed March 17, 1857, section 17, in relation to extortionate charges by railroad companies, it was provided in relation to the Hudson River Railroad Company, that it should be entitled to charge passengers at the rate of two and one-half cents per mile for the distance traveled thereon during the months of December, January,

This has been an exciting day in Knoxville. The Legislature met in Joint convention at 12 o'clock, and, with overcrowded gallerion commenced balloting. On the first Ballet JOHNSON received 45; ETHERRIDGE, 26; FLETCHER, 12; NEIL BROWN, 7; PEYTON, 6; EWING, 4; M. BROWN, 2; NELSON, 1.

The exodus of Roman Catholic Bishops still goes on. During this week a considerable number of well-known prelates from different parts of the country have sailed from this port. It is probable that Father HYACINTHE himself will be glad to join in this pious pilgrimage to Rome if his present persecution lasts much longer.

The Erie Railway strike is still in progress, and the men confident as ever of success. The Company show no signs of yielding or the men either. The report that a portion of the Long Dockers had resumed work was discredited in part--some reports say two-thirds of them were at work while others say not over thirty or forty have resumed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed in coming from Court to-day that the "Tammany Ring" has seized the only white marble building we have in our Park, and appropriate the same to party purposes. They have conspicuous signs on the feast side of the building,"

Boats were moving freely on the Eric Canal last evening. The Fish Creek feeder has been ordered to be advertised and let by the Canal Board. WALPOLE, N. H., Oct. 21.--The WALPOLE and Westminster Bridge across the Connecticut was carried away last night, the old pier, built thirty-eight years ago, having crumbled.

The River Improvement Convention, embracing about coodelagates, was permanently organized, with Governor MERRILL, of Iowa, as Permanent Chairman, and Governor MARSHALL, of Minnesota, Governor FAIRCHILD, of Wisconsin, and others as Vice-Presidents.

It is rumored that the National Guard will be reorganized at once. The Emperor will come, to Paris on the 25th inst. The Ministers will remain at Compiegne until the 24th, when they will return to Paris. It is officially stated that the Ministerial programme will soon be made public.

Referring to our article of yesterday on the Tammany nomination for the Supreme Court Judge, a correspondent suggests an explanation which adds to the infamy of the affair. Judge BRADY, he remarks, has several years yet to serve in the Court of Common Please, where he has won respect and confidence by the faithful discharge of ardnous duties.

Advices from Hayti to the 5th inst. have been received here via St. Thomas, News had reached Port-an-Prince of an engagement between SALNAVE'S two steamers, the Salnave and the Alexandre Petion, and the rebel steam ers Quaker City and Florida, in the neighborhood of Cape Haytien.

The Howard Mission and Home for Little Wanderers is located in the Fourth Ward of this City. It is surrounded by a region in which the population exists at the rate of 230,000 to the square mile, and where there is an average of less than two dwelling houses to each grog shop, dance-houses or other establishments for the propagation of wrotchodacss.

A very fashionable and very numerous assemblage filled the Presbyterian Church in Forty-second-street, near Fifth-avenue, last evening, when Mr. JOHN NELSON PATTISON, the distinguished composer and planist, was united in mutrimony to Miss ADELAIDE MANGAM.

The poor blind people of the City, who have lived all the year in anticipation of the comparatively trifling but to them by no means insignificant addition to their slender means of subsistence, afforded by the act of the Legislature appropriating #25,000 for their relief this your, began to rather Monday at the Bureau of Charities and Correction, to make their applications in proper form,
The sessions of the Cortes have been resumed. A resolution thanking the army for their efforts in quelling the recent Republican ?? was unanimously adopted yesterday.

The trial of MORROW and DOUGHERTY, charged with the attempted assassination of BROOKS, began this morning before judge LUDLOW. Several witnesses were examined, but nothing new was citied up to the recess.

There is yet one more chance for people who have never visited Jerome Park to enjoy a good day's amusement. On Saturday there will not only be some sharp contests between first-rate horses, but an absolute nevelty will be introduced, and one that ought to he alone sufficient to tempt thousands of spectators to the Park.
The American Christian Missionary Society's Convention concluded its labors to-day.

The following exhibit shows the gross receipts of the different, theatres, railroads, stages and ferries for the month of September, together with the amount of gas consumed during the same month. The telegraph returns are for the month of August:

AYRES--EVANS.--On Wednesday, Oct. 20, at Christ Church, Tarrytown, N. Y., by Rev. J. S. Spencer. assisted by Rev. John Purvis, Mr. J. S. AYRES, of Port Austin, Mich., to Miss ANNIE E. EVERS, of the former place. No cards. Detroit papers please copy.

Yesterday was another very busy day at Plainfield, N. J. Messrs, A. D. MELLICK, JR., BRO, had on extensive and very successful sale. Between three and four hundred persons went down in the special train. At the village depot a number of earnings were in waiting to carry the guests to the place of sale, where they were joined by a goodly number of local buyers.

The American Bible Union yesterday received reports on the circulation of the revised Scriptures in Spain, China and this country. Addresses were made by Rev. Dr. MILLER, of Elizabeth; Rev. Mr. LORRIMER, Mr. MACDONALD and others.

The United States Consul at Gibraltar reports the arrival there on the 2d inst. of the brig Rush, of New-York, bound to Malta. In a gale on the 15th of September, her master, named JOHN PETTY; mate, JOSEPH W. CONKLLNG, and a seaman named HENRY PETERSON, were washed overboard and lost.

Perhaps it is necessary, in a certain dogree, that passengers to and from the Fulton Forry should keep in dally exercise their facultion of caution, readiness, resolution and physical agility, in attempting to got from one side of South-street to the other.

At this season of the year it is well to look to one's steps in walking along the streets. We cast out no insinuations against the paving. Everybody expects to trip up occasionally on the heavy flags which are pitched down on the sidewalk, and left to find their own level. But the approach of cold weather heralds in a new peril.

At the grand plaza of Prospect Park, on Flatbush-avenue, yesterday afternoon, not less than fifteen-thousand persons witnessed the unveiling of the statue of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, erected by the dollar-subscription fund raised by citizens without regard to party connection. The statue is of bronze, about nine feet high, and represents the figure of the late President standing, with the folds of a cloak draped about him;

No doubt the belief of New-York--at least of a great majority of its people--is that man is a soldier and life is a tight, or, at any rate, something of which peril is a natural and necessary ingredient, and that, in a Christian community, one should largely rely on Providence.

The fresh assaults of the gold gamblers and their organs upon General GRANT, this time dragging in the name of Mrs. GRANT, attract renewed attention here, not only for their matte, but for their shameless audacity.

The Judicial vote is light and so far favorable for the Democrats. The steamer Sterra Nerada, hence Sept. 16, for san Luis Obispo, went ashore on the 17th during a heavy for near Pledres Blancos, a few miles south of Monterey. Her passengers were saved.

United States Deputy Marshal CHRISTIE was recently ordered to serve a summons on JAMES FISK, Jr., informing the latter that he had been selected as one of the Grand Jurors of the United States Circuit Court, now in session. Numerous efforts were made to find the redoubtable speculator, but without success.

Vermont has ratified the Fifteenth Amendment. The vote was taken by yeas and nays in each House, and was unanimous in the Senate. In the House there were twelve votes against it, but Colonel DICKEY, of Bradford, the acknowledged tender of the Democracy, and their candidate for Speaker, voted yea, as did also Mr. BISHOP, of Bolton, bitherto slaunch and faithful in the ranks of the old line Democrats.

An interesting question connected with the rights of the New-York, Housatonie and Northern Railroad Company and the Boston, Hartford and Eric Railroad Company, as regards the location of their tracks through the village of Danbury, came up for adjudication before the Board of Railroad Commissioners a few days since.

It is reported that Captain-General DE RODAS has informed the Rome Government that the rebels in Cuba have all along had native relations with the Republican insurgents in Spain, and that arrangements have been made between them for mutual encouragement and assistance.

Mr. GLADSTONE's decision, that to comply with the numerous memorials for the release of the Fenian prisoners would be contrary to the duty of Government, as guardian of the public security and peace, is much to be regretted for many reasons.

The cry for a reduction of taxes is echoed on all sides. There are those who advocate a continuance of the present fiscal system, professedly with a view to a more rapid reduction of the debt; but the fact that the same journals champion the tariff, with all its enormities, suggests the possible presence of other motives.

The trial of ANTOINE MAURER for the murder of JOACHIM FUERTER in the month of March last was commenced in the Rock-land County Court of Oyer and Terminer, at New-City, before Judge TAPPAN, on Tuesday, and was concluded yesterday.

The steamship America, from Hong Kong, brings the following news: Nothing had been heard from the ship Flying Scud, which left Yokohama on the 17th of August last. It is known that she encountered a typhoon, and it is feared that the ship and all hands are lost.

To-morrow (Saturday) is the extra and final day of the Jerome Park Fall Meeting, and the American Jockey Club, in order to wind up the racing season of 1869 with tolut and success, have issued the most attractive programme of a day's sport of the entire meeting.

From the doings of the Louisville Convention, some southern journalists are deriving strange lessons. From things commercial they pass to things political. Business intercourse they make a foundation for a partisan compact, with a resuscitated Democracy as its ultimate result.
The most noticeable fact in European politics at the present moment is the preponderating influence of liberal ideas and the rapid advance of liberal reforms.

Facing the National Academy of Design, and on the corner of Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue stands the elegant new building created by the Young Men's Christian Association of this City. This edition, although hardly completed as yet internally, will at once attract attention as being one of the few buildings of which New-York has the right to feel proud.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The concrete pavement put on the Fifth-avenue, between Thirteenth and Nineteenth streets, is already almost worn out. It has been patched up two or three times already between Thirty-third and Thirty-sixth streets, and needs to be fixed again.

The activity of the work on the new Post Office grounds is unabated. More room is now needed for storing material, and the north fence is to be moved seventy feet further up to inclose the required space, the City authorities having granted permission for such additional use of the Park. Yesterday the extension was commenced by setting up new fence posts.

It is said that the ultra Radicals are visiting the workshops of Paris, and urging the men to take part in the demonstration on the 26th inst. The workmen in the Provinces have also been notified of a general uprising on that day. The Radical Press are opposed to the demonstration.

But the most remarkable proof of suddenly-developed anxiety for the municipal good is the army of scrapers and sweepers crowing streets that have not been visited by either for nearly a twelvemonth. The canard about the indictment of General BUTTERFIELD and Mr. CORBIN, on the testimony of JAY GOULD, was telegraphed here this morning, and created considerable stir until it was contradicted. There have been numerous reports afloat of the resignation or removal of BUTTERFIELD, but nothing has transpired to give any foundation for them.

The Brooks case was resumed this morning. Mr. BROOKS testified to the facts of the assault. He recognized MORROW as being in KEENAN'S store previous to the assault, and believed JAMES DOUGHERTY to be the man he saw struggling to get into the carriage at the door when he reached it in pursuit of his assailants.

We had occasion, some time ago, to notice the finding of the Court of Inquiry in the case of General DYER, Chief of Ordnance. It was natural to suppose that even the most bitter and prejudiced of General DYER'S opponents world be satisfied with the decision of a Court whose investigation was so thorough and exhaustive, and the position and personal character of whose members placed it above the suspicion of partisanship.

The combinations against ANDREW JOHNSON last night united, and his fate was evident when the Legislature met to-day in Joint Convention. HENRY COOPER, of Davidson County, was elected United States Senator, to succeed Mr. FOWLER, on the first ballot. The vote stood, HENRY COOPER, 55; ANDREW JOHNSON, 51.

General KRYZANOWSKI, Supervisor of Georgia and Florida, reports under date of Oct. 12, that Jackson and Washington Counties, in Florida, are under the control of an armed mob, which has risen to prevent the execution of the Revenue laws.

The trial of the officers of the steamer Cuba was continued before the United States Commissioner to-day, and the Court adjourned until 10 o'clock to-morrow. The only witness yet examined was GORDON, who said he belonged to the United States Detective force.

It is stated that the large amount of traffic drawn to the Pacific Railroad has so taken away business from the Panama route as to render is improbable that the letter line can ever again enjoy prosperity. This is a change which might have been foreseen. The Panama route, as the Philadelphia American points out, depended.

The election yesterday resulted in the choice of Mr. ROBERT F. MORRISON, (Democrat,) for Judge of the Fourth District Court; Mr. McKINSLEY, Independent and Republican, Judge of the Twelfth; W. D. SAWYER, (Democrat,) Police Judge of San Francisco.

The side-wheel steamer Gettysburg has gone out of commission and her crew has been transferred to the Vermont. It is said that the Gettysburg is to be sold. The Tallapoosa arrived at the Navy Yard on Thursday night, from Boston, after having towed the Monongahcia to Portsmouth. Thursday night, from Boston, after having towed the Monongahcia to Portsmouth.

Had VICTOR HUGO ever stopped at Bryan, a station on the Union Pacific, and passed the night in what is called a first-class hotel there, he would have done one of two things-i.c., become an atheist or abandoned the following dogmas of his philosophy: "The faith in an inn is one of the roots of man's trust in providence;"

There are twenty Spanish gunboats now lying in the Delamater Basin, between Thirteenth and Fourteenth streets, North River, five more having been sent around from Mystic, Conn., this week. they left that place on Monday, but being delayed on the route by the heavy wind on the sound, that night, did not arrive here until Wednesday.

The old stone mill at Newport and the "Written Rock" of Deighton have now got a formidable rival in another archaie puzzle dug up the other day near Syracuse, in this State. It is in the shape of a stone man, ten feet long, soulptured from Onondaga Gypsum. " "What is it" Dr. BOYNTON, the geologist, thinks it is the work of some of the early Jesuit missionaries from France;

As a Financial exploit and a matter of business carried to a satisfactory conclusion, without blunderings or catastrophies, the Boston Peace Jubilee, or its memory, deserves very great credit--to say nothing of the overflow of gratified feeling it produced among the New-Englanders,

Another beautiful custom is springing into existence--perhaps we should rather say is undergoing revival. A man could once be married in peace if ho chose--now that last consolation is denied him. The "interviewers" have got at all the sextons, and the moment it is hoard that a wedding is coming off, away go the gentlemen of the Press.

No sales will be made to-day. A little rest is needed, for during the past few days the auctioneers have been pretty hardly worked. On Monday, though, they commence again. The first sale of the week will be made on that day by Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER, consisting of 250 very fine building lots at Homestead Station, N. J., on the line of the Northern Road.

A Rock Island dispatch says the Redman House, in that city, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The house and furniture were valued at $100,000 and were insured for $15,000, as follows: Hartford, $5,000; Home, of New-York, $5,000; Security, of New-York, $2,000; and the rest in a Chicago company. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I beg to express to you my gratitude for the excellent article in yesterday's TIMES on the subject of the re?lection of Justice CLERKE. I do not believe that members of the Bar will always remain careless or indifferent to such emphatic appeals to their courage and professional honor as your article conveyed.

The "Woman's Parliament" has held its preliminary meeting. Its object, we are told, "is to crystallize the intelligence and influence of woman into amoral and reformatory power." This is a process of crystallization which will be now to natural philosophers, but let us not be too particular.

Yesterday morning Justice BARNARD sentenced DAVID BURKE, the man convicted in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer, on Thursday, of murder in the first degree, in having taken the life of THOMAS CANE, at Hunter's Point, on the night of the 25th of October, 1868, to be hanged on the 10th day of December, 1869, between the hours of 10 and 2 o'clock.

The Emperor of China, so the story goes, has refused a State reception to the English Prince who is known as the Duke of EDINBURGH. This will probably save the young gentleman from the necessity of giving presents. The English people will be glad to hear it. When the Royal Duke was in Australia he gave away a few trinkets, and applied to Parliament for money to reimburse him.

Rev. G. A. HUBBELL, pastor of the Warren-street Methodist Church, Brooklyn, has been studying "The Romish Crusade against our Public Schools," and has prepared a discourse on the subject, which, owing to its thoroughness of review and its fair statement of facts, is of unusual importance. He says they have already commenced the crusade, and all the means in their power will be used to bring it to a successful termination.

During the coming month of November the series of political elections for the present year will be closed. During that month elections of more or less importance are to be held in the States of New-York, New-Jersey, New-Hampshire, Massachusetts, Illinois, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Mississippi, Maryland and Texas.

The leading ship and engine works on the Mersey are those of the Messrs. LAIRD at Birkenhead. ELDER Co. at Glasgow, or of the Thames Company at London, they deservedly rank with the first building works of the kingdom.

Coroner KEENAN proceeded to Bellevue Hospital yesterday, and held an ante-mortem examination in the case or JOSEPHINE WEISS, the young woman who was on Friday evening stabbed by her lover, HENRY VASQUEZ, at the No. 99 Crosby-street, as already reported in these columns.

A fire broke out in the crockery warehouse of Messrs. VAN HEUSEN, CHARLES Co., on James-street, in this city, last night. It was a bad fire to control, yet the firemen managed to confine the flames to the burning building. The loss is estimated at $30,000. There was an insurance of $20,000 on the building, and $30,000 on stock.

The recent reply of Right Hon. Mr. GLADSTONE to the President of the Limerick Amnesty Association, on the subject of the course of the Government toward the imprisoned Femans, has caused considerable dissension. The London Amnesty Association has protested against the sentiments of the Premier.

Services to take place at the residence of Frederick Zittel, son-in-law of Henry Bodge, No. 232 02d-st., between 2d and 2d avs., on Monday, Oct. 25, at 4 o'clock P. M. The opening by private enterprise of a new market in this City, recalls attention to the long-vexed question of reform in our market system generally. For how many years it will be necessary to agitate for this reform it is impossible to say.
If ever the custom of suing railway companies becomes general, there will in a reform in the treatment of passengers greater than all the remonstrances of letter writers could effect in a century.

The inadequacy of the accommodations of the Five Points House of Industry has been long felt, and during last Summer it was determined to tear down the western portion of the building, take in all the spare ground that belonged in the institution, and creet, in place of the old building, a lofty and substantial structure that would afford the increased accommodations desired.

The Congressional Select Committee on American Navigation Interests, which has just held sessions in this City, Boston and Portland, Me., visited Fall River, Mass., on Friday, and there adjourned, to meet in Philadelphia on the first Tuesday in December. We learn that the questions before the Committee were finally narrowed down to three distinct propositions, one or all of which will probably be recommended to Congress.

The examination of the persons charged with circulating counterfort tobacco stamps was continued to-day. It was shown that two of the party, a few weeks since, were in New-York with $8,000, furnished from Richmond to buy counterfelt stamps. ROCHE and BANNASCHE, the two principal men, were to-day committed to jail.

A contributor to Appletons' Journal has lately written two articles for its columns, in which he comments with feeling and taste upon the late Mr. HENRY KEEP'S unfulfilled purpose to devote a million of dollars to the promotion of artistic taste in the community. Th this end, says the writer in question, Mr. KEEP intended to build an odifice on a grand scale for the permanent exhibition of works of art.

BY ALGERNON CHARLES SWINBURNE. By the waters of Babylon we sat down and wept, Remembering thee, That for ages of agony hast endured and slept. And wouldst not see. By the waters of Babylon we stood up and sang, Considering thee, That a blast, of deliverance in the darkness rang, To set thee free.

The military is collecting in Paris in view of the threatened irregular meeting on the Corps Legislatif on the 26th inst. An imperial manifesto is expected. The Orleanists are active. It is thought that the crisis may restore ROCHER to the Cabinet.

To the Editor of New-York Times: Many residents of the Fifth-avenue are a thousand times obliged to you for speaking against the imposition of spending so much money for a pavement of no earthly use. It will not inst. three months. It was laid on the Fifth-avenue in August, and has already been repaired two or three times.

ROBERT HART, Inspector-General of the Imperial Maritime Customs at Pekin, writes that J. ROSS BROWNE'S addresses to the British and American merchants at Shanghae, (leaving aside what he said about Mr. BURLINGAME,)are reasonable and truthful matters of fact and to the point.

Considerable stir was occasioned among the directors of the Farmers' and Butchers' National Bank of Somers, at Somerstown, Westchester County, in consequence of the mysterious disappearance of their cashier, Mr. MORUIS HILL, who was traced to New-York, but all their efforts to discover his subsequent movements were unsuccessful.

The chapter of accidents in the past two days has been unusually large, and it affords illustrations of nearly every variety of carelessness and neglect by which human life is constantly sacrificed in our cities and towns. A woman was seriously injured by falling through a coalbole in Vandewater-street.

Lord STANLEY remarked the other day that Cooperation was a "good thing," and be predicted "its success," But Cooperation has a deeper political significance than the speaker probably imagined, and is likely, in the immediate future, to receive an extent of practical application which he scarcely dream of.

Before Judge Benedict, MOTION TO DISCHARGE. The United States vs. John C. Layion.--This was a motion for the discharge of the prisoner, who is held for issuing and passing counterfeit money. The motion was based upon the alleged insufficiency of the warrant of commitment--that no crime was charged in it, and that no limit was set to the time for which the prisoner could be held by the Marshal.

To the Editor of the New - York Times: It is now more than a year since I asked you to allow me, through your columns, an opportunity of explaining to the friends of this society in America some of the work which we have accomplished. Since that time our work, has become more largely known in the States, partly through the accounts of travelers, partly through the efforts of individual gentlemen.

The Clerk of the Court said: "OWEN HAND, you know that heretofore you were indicted for the crime of murder to which you pleaded not guilty.

A meeting of fifty or sixty ladies took place yesterday morning at PACKARD'S Rooms, No. 037 Broadway, for the purpose of organizing a Woman's Council, with affiliating branches in other cities, which will each send delegates at certain periods of the year to the Woman's Parliament to be held in this City.

Supervisor ISAAC J. OLIVER was surprised at his residence in Thirty-eighth-street on Friday evening by a party of friends, who came to present him with a gold-headed cane, as a token of their regard and esteem for his straightforward and upright conduct as a man, a citizen and an officeholder.

Hon. THOMAS EWING, of Ohio, while arguing a case before the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday, fainted from nervous exhaustion, and, though partially recovering, is now lying in a dangerous condition at the Capital.

Highwaymen stopped the Los Angeles stage yesterday near that city and robbed the express and passengers of a large amount. The mail, which contained several hundred thousand dollars in greenbacks, was untouched.

The election of Mr. COOPER is variously commenced on by the Press. The Appeal regards it as probably the best selection that could have been made after Mr. JOHNSON. The Sun says the action of the Legislature in electing Mr. COOPERS and the means resorted to accomplish it, have elected Mr. JOHNSON Governor, and Senator hereafter.

At 5:45 o'clock this morning a severe shock of earthquake was felt here, preceded by a rumbling noise and vibrations. It lasted about twenty seconds. Houses shock violently, every body awakened, and many rushed from their houses in alarm, but no material damage was done.

The regimental inspections are now progressing in he First Division, and the result is an interesting one, in view of the fact that upon them depends the future fate of many an organization. So far the inspections have been satisfactory, though owing to the multiplicity of parades, a falling off in the attendance of the rank and file has been observable.

The snow and ice steamer Sully was sunk thirty miles below St. Joseph, in the Missouri River, yesterday. The boat was valued at $15,000, and was insured in the Eton, Monongahela and another Pittsburg Company for $10,000. mpany for $10,000.

The prosecution in the Brooks case has closed, reserving the right to call the witness who was spirited away and cannot be found. The defence will try to prove and alibi. The Court refused to admit the affidavit of NEIL McLAUGHLIN, driver of the carriage, to Mayor Fox, on which the indictments were found against the prisoners.

Paris dispatches state that the military is collecting in Paris in anticipation of the demonstration on the 26th inst. NAPOLEON is expected to issue a manifesto. The Orleanists are reported active, and it is thought ROUHER may be restored to the Cabinet. Name of the Opposition Deputies, it is now sail, will go to the Chamber on the 20th.

A cable dispatch from London brings the intelligence of Lord DERRY'S death, which from his serious illness, had been daily expected. He died yesterday, in the 71st year of his age. EDWARD GEOFFREY STANLEY, K. G., , Earl of Derby, was born March 29. 1799, at Knowsley Park, Lancashire, and educated at Oxford University, where he took the Chancellor's prize for Latin verse.

The Republican state Central Committee of Maryland have published a statement showing the wasteful expenditure of the public money by the last Legislature of that State. The facts and figures are given, and the items of expenditure are succinetly stated.

Every now and then a dark story makes its appearance with reference to the betrayal and ill usage of young girls who arrive among parties of immigrants at Castle Garden. Such a case is now occupying the attention of the Police. An irish girl was engaged as a servant by a woman named JACKSON.

Whether the negroes of Louisiana like the importation of large bodies of Chinese or not, they must submit to the infliction. There are five shiploads of Celestials now on their way to the State, and they have agreed to do any kind of work which happens to come first.

In the report he advances opinions quite contrary to those upon which we have hitherto felicitated ourselves.

JOSEPH MESSNER, convicted some time since of the murder of has wife, was taken into the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday afternoon and received his sentence to be executed. The prisoner looked remarkably well, and it was the remark of the attendants at court that he had improved in appearance since his trial.

About 11:30 o'clock last evening, a lamp in the bands of MONICA CAMPBELL, a married daughter of ADAM HERWIG, who resides with her father, exploded, mattering the burning contents over her clothes. The garments worn by the unfortunate woman were soon a mass of flame, and losing all presence of mind she ran screaming into the drinking room connected with the establishment.

The steamer Continental, hence yesterday for the Colorado River with troops for Arizona, has returned, the Commissary Department having neglected to provide rations for the soldiers. The Seminary building, near Alexandria, was destroyed by fire last Friday morning between 1 and 3 o'clock. No lives were lost, and the students generally saved their baggage. They found temporary shelter among the hospitable citizens of Alexandria, and some of them are now on their way home up or down the river.

BELKNAP, the new Secretary of War, was tendered a dinner by his friends in Krokuk, Iowa, on Saturday evening, Oct. 16, and responded to the teast in his honor as follows: MY FRIENDS AND FELLOW-TOWNSMEN; I can command no words to express fully my gratitude for this undeserved greeting.

We are glad to learn that "An Old Subscriber" has never been subjected to the annoyances which we described in an article on the "Despots of Daily Life." His milkman, for instance, will not only sell two dollars' worth of tickets, but is "a gentleman in his conduct and appearance."

In reference to these concerts the Boston Traveller says in regard to the Pianos used at them: "The plane used on the occasion was a grand, from the world celebrated manufactory of the Messrs. STEINWAY SONS of New-York. These instruments are well known in this city, and take rank among artists as being the best manufactured in the country.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you allow me to call the attention of your readers to the bonevolent work which I have in charge in Washington and vicinity, designed for the proper education of freemen ?? and teachers and other men of position and influence among the colored people of the South . This work originated, in connection with my efforts in Washington, before the close of the war.

Deputy United States Marshal INSLEE, of Port Huron, with another Internal revenue officer from this city, went to Chicago recently armed with a bench warrant from Judge DRUMMOND, of that city, and proceeding to Joliet, where LEVI J. NORTH'S cierus had just gone into Winter quarters, arrested W. H. C. SHEPARD, GUSTAVUS SHEPARD and CHARLES H. HASKINS, proprietors thereof, on a charge of smuggling sixteen horses fram Canada.

On the night of the 17th of last August the premises of BARTON, ALEXANDER WALLER, dealers in cutlery, at No. 68 Beckman-street, were entered by burglars, who carried off 143 dozen pocket knives, valued at $1,400.

It is natural that a large percentage of the whisky produced in the State should concentrate here to be exported to other markets. The firms engaged in the business now number between sixty and seventy, all of whom are doing an active business.

Proceedings have been instituted in the United States District Court against W. M. SMALLWOOD, late Postmaster at New-Orleans, and his sureties, for the alleged defalcation of over #19,000, the proceeds from the sale of internal revenue stamps, of which his account was short. Quarantine from all ports ceases to exist here from to-day.

JAMES REESE, aged 35, and a vagrant, died suddenly yesterday in the stable left in the rear of NO. 46 Wall-street, Body removed to the Morgue. A mad dog was killed yesterday by Officer MUSGROVE at No. 166 South-street.

It is quite evident that the day is near at band when the principles which have long governed the Episcopal Church in this country will be adopted in England. The voluntary system will obtain supremacy, and the laity will be allowed an equal voice with the ?? in deciding questions of church discipline and management.

At 7:45 o'clock last night flames were discovered in the rear portion of he extensive range of old buildings situate on lots Nos. 247 and 240 West Twenty-eighth-street, and occupied as stables by the Dodd City Express Company.

At 5:45 o'clock this morning a severe shock of earthquake was felt here, proceeded by a rumbling poise and vibrations. It lasted about twenty seconds. Houses shock violently, everybody awakened, and many rushed from their houses in alarm, but no material damage was done.

WILLIAM EDGAR LAWRENCE is the Democratic candidate for the Assembly in the Third District of Westchester County. The Democrats of the Second District of Stephen County have nominated JOHN WOOD, of Greenwood, for member of Assembly, and JACOB B. WALCOTT, of Corning, for School Commissioner.

Personal independence in politics is eminently proper, but when it divides Republican councils and materially assists to give one MICHAEL. NORTON the opportunity to misrepresent a respectable constituency in the State Senate, our admiration for the generally desirable quality is apt to wane.

At a late hour on Saturday night SAMUEL R. BRICK, a resident of Stapleton, Station Island, jumped on board a Third-avenue car, and he found his entrance to the interior impeded by THOMAS BRADY and two unknown men. The three jostled Mr. BRICK in a suspicious manner, and he soon found that his gold watch, valued at $200, had been abstraeled from his vest pocket.

A change of performance will be had at Niblo's this evening, "Oliver Twist" being noted instead of "East Lynne," "Formosa" will be performed at the Bowery for the first time. At the New-York Circus two Cuban acrobuts, ESPINOZA and RODRIGUES, will make their first appearance in this country. No change of performance is advertised elsewhere.

The organs of Democracy take the failure of ANDREW JOHNSON to get buck to Washington as a defeat of their party. they announce the result with much "regret." They wanted JOHNSON in the Senate to plague his impeachers, to bully the Administration and to preach repudiation.

Mr. D. J. MORELL, M. C., perhaps the largest iron manufacturer in Pennsylvania, has published a letter in opposition to repeal of the duty on bituminous coal, His arguments are disingenuous and easily disposed of.

The action of the Administration with regard to General BUTTERFIELD is just and judicious. The President is not indifferent to the accusations preferred against that officer, and yet not willing to accept as conclusive the statements of men who have proved themselves unworthy of belief.

ABEL.--On Sunday, Oct. 24, JULIA ABEL, in the 28th year of her age. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral services at the residence of her uncle, Mr. Hiram Miller, No. 8 Charlton. st., this (Monday) evening at 7 o'clock, without further notice. The remains will be taken to Peekskill for interment.

A fire broke out in the crockery warehouse of Messrs. VAN HEUSEN, CHARLES CO., on James-street, in this city, last night. It was bad fire to control, yet the firemen managed to confine the flames to the burning building. The loss is estimated at $30,000. There was an insurance of $20,000 on the building and $30,000 on stock.

The list of candidates put in nomination by the Republicans and Democrats throughout the State--as published in Saturday's TIMES--has enabled our readers to compare the relative character and standing of the representatives of the two great parties who claim their support at the coming election.

A committee of the Ladies' Union Relief Association met last Friday at Police Headquarters. Inspector JAMISON, Captains WASHBURN, ALLAIRE and ETEARNS formally offered their services to the Association as representatives of the late Union army, to assist them in their forthcoming fair.

We all know that a search after justice in New-York is beset with difficulties. A man has to grope his way about in very nasty corners, and after all he finds that he has been pursuing a shadow. But, although a Judge is generally assumed to be a marketable commodity here, the suitors in his Court do not, as a rule, attempt to interfere with his personal freedom.

An immense demonstration in favor of amnesty to the Fonians was made to-day. Large processions formed in various parts of the city, and headed by hands of music and bearing flags and banners inscribed with significant mottoes, marched to Hyde Park.

The heavy ram of Saturday last caused disappointment to thousands who had anticipated with cagerness the enjoyment of witnessing the grand steeple chase announced to come off at Jerome Park on that day, the last one of the season of 1869.

The annual Fair of the Maryland State Agricultural Society, suspended for several years, will be again opened on Tuesday next, and will be reinaugurated by a grand parade of the Maryland National Guard, consisting of ame regiments of infantry, several of cavalry and two batteries of artillery, with Governor BOWIN and staff.

In the editorial correspondence of the Macon (Ga.) Messenger from Louisville we had the following allusion to GENERAL BUCKNER: General S.R. BUCKNER, too. is here. His property in Kentucky has been restored to hi, and be intends to make Louisville his residence.

Insteamship City of Brussels, from Liverpool.--C. E. Hart, R. E. Veigt, J. Pierce, J. P. McJames, R. A. Johnson, S. S. Burton, E. Hoz, F. Reis, W. H. Fairall, Dr. A. Matthewson, Mr. Nash, wife and 3 children, T. W. Stoddard, Mr. Wolf and wife, A. De Grelff, Mr. Lusey and wife, T. E. Wolls, C. T. Barlow, T. S. Hibbard, G. M. Lorimer, Mr. Ricketts, J. Carbuit, J. Easter, Mr. Suitoras,

At 11 o'clock A. M. of Thursday, the Sheriff' of Hamilton County served a writ of attachment upon the proprietors of Thayer's circus, and seized the whole property. The writ was issued at the suit of CLARY REILLY, of New-York, who had a claim against them for printing, amounting in all to $2,926.

It has been said that this was ANDREW JOHNSON'S last chance, and if beaten now he would be likely to retire from public life altogether. But he is not likely to do so, especially should Parson BROWNLOW, who is in feeble health, not live to complete his term.

The week just closed has been by far the busiest of the season. Sales were made every day except Saturday, and on Tuesday and Wednesday two large pieces of Westchester County property were offered, more valuable than has been sold under the hammer for a long time.

A number of our friends who have recently visited Upper Red River give us the most glowing account of the condition of the crops in that section. They tell us of wide fields of cotton that gleam like snow in the sunshine of glorious Autum days, and of the merry souge of the harvesters, which are heard all the live-long day.

Lord DERRY has passed away almost simultaneously with the principles which he had endeavored to perpetuate in the Government of his country. He lived long enough to see the system which he had spent nearly half a century in defending finally rejected by the people.

A letter has just been received here by a member of one of the legations, from Nassau, N. P., stating that on the 16th inst. the steamer Lillian, which escaped from Cedar Keys some weeks ago as a Cuban privateer arrived off that port, but remained some miles out beyond marine jurisdiction, and sent in a small boat with a request to have coal sent out.

Retreachment has not been applied to the navy, say the slanderers of General GRANT. They allege that under JOHNSON the current naval expenses were largely reduced, while under GRANT economy was "at once set aside."

We ought not to refuse to hear both sides, even on such a subject as that of the treatment of ladies in street cars and stages. From the tone of some letters we have received, it appears clear that Indies are not the only persons who fee themselves ill used. It is quite possible, we are assured, for the man to be the victim instead of the " unprotected female."

There is some expectation that the Supreme Court may deliver an opinion in the Yerger case to-morrow, and the belief seems to prevail that it will be adverse to the power of the military tribunal to try and punish the criminal.

SALNAVE'S war steamers sailed recently with provisions for Cape Haytien, which is besieged by the rebels. while on the way they met the rebel steamers Quaker City and Florida. A sharp fight ensued, the details of which have not yet been received. Both sides claim the victory.

In the superabundant attention which has been given to the subject of the political and social rights of the colored people, we have been in danger of losing sight of their rights as free inborers, This is not for want of discussion on the "labor question."

Yesterday being Pere HYACINTHE'S first Sabbath in America, great anxiety prevailed among those interested in his movements as to how he would spend it. At an early hour in the morning visitors could have been seen lounging round the doors and vestibules of the Fifth-avenue Hotel, watching eagerly for the appearance of the preacher-monk,

Thirty-five citizens of Augusta, Ga., who served in the rebel army, obtained "liberal subscriptions" for a "most magnificent banquet:" to be tendered to JEFF. DAVIS when he passed through that city on his journey from Charleston to his home in Mississippi.

THE WEBER PIANO THE PIONEER ACROSS THE CONTINENT. The enterprise of San Francisco was shown yesterday in the receipt overland of two of the celebrated Weber Pianofortes, by the agent, EDWARD F. PIEROE.

A San Francisco paper has found out that the Pacific Railroad is not an unmixed good. It has been the means of introducing sharper competition into almost every department of trade and local interests have thereby been injured. Some manufactures in San Francisco have already been compelled to discharge half their hands.

Notwithstanding the rumored suppression of Fenian demonstrations in England, an immense amnesty meeting was held in Hyde Park, London, yesterday. Fifty thousand people, it is estimated, were present. Several inflammatory speeches were made, and an immediate release of the prisoners demanded.

The Fair of the American Institute is every day becoming a more assured success. The receipts up to last Saturday amounted to $11,000, while at the corresponding period last year they were but $37,000.

We have more than once alluded to the decreasing number of the State's poor in Massachusetts, but it may be well to remark that this decrease seems to be constant, without regard to the season of the year. On the 1st of October the whole number of inmates supported by the State at Tewksbury, Monson and Bridgewater, was but 1,467, whereas at the same date last year it was 1,601, and in 1867, 1,684.

About 8 o'clock P.M. the crowd of visitors at the Maxwell House were startled by the announcement that an attempt had just been made to assassinate ANDREW JOHNSON in his room. A thousand stories were told.

ROBERT HART, Inspector--General of the Imperial Maritime Customs at Pekin, writes that J. ROSS BROWNE'S addresses to the British and American merchants at Shanghae, (leaving aside what he said about Mr. BURLINGAME,) are reasonable and truthful matters of fact, and to the point.

A Life Insurance Policy of the National Life Insurance Company, for $5,000, has been placed in the hands of Ex-Mayor C. GODFREY GUNTHER, for the use of the German Hospital and Dispensary, by Mr. JACOB COHN. Sunday night about 10 o'clock an unknown man felt into the East River from Pier No. 40 and was drowned.

BOWNE--At Flushing, L. I., on Seventh day, Oct. 23, JOHN W. BOWNE, in the 79th year of his age, The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, on Third day morning, at 11 o'clock. CHAPMAN.--At Bridgeport, Conn., on Sunday, Oct. 21, TIMOTHY P. CHAPMAN, aged 49 years. The funeral will take place at his late residence, on Wednesday afternoon, at 3 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It has been charged by the Methodist Press that up to the date of my transfer from the Maine to the New-York Conference, in May last, I avowed myself a "thorough Methodist in doctrine." I have already branched this charge as false and slanderous, and I now put the brand on it again.

The Times, in his obituary article on the late Lord DERBY, says: "No one can be a. Watesman without a statesmanlike temperament. With this the Earl of DERBY was never end wed. He was too impulsive to resist the temptation of making sallies on enemies both in and out of season.

The conviction is growing that in the present state of parties the selection of a King is impossible. The Cortes is as much divided in opinion as the Cabinet; and unless a compromise is effected, the establishment of the monarchy will be hopeless.

Rev. Mr. SPURGEON, the well-known Baptist preacher, used to be famous for his comic sermons and lectures: but increasing years, corpulency and a wife and children have a little sobered him. The other day, however, he came out in his old character.

Increased efficiency in the ' collection of revenue, and rigorous economy in expenditures, were prominent features of the platform on which General GRANT was elected. The Republican Party pledged itself to promote these objects, and General GRANT was chosen to accomplish them.

The complaint concerning the inadequate payment of our foreign Ministers is being very generally discussed, and we observe that as a rule it meets with little sympathy, One or two journals express regret that American diplomatists receive no preparatory training, and assert that it is rare for an able man to be sent to any foreign Court.

Motions were made in the Supreme Court Chambers yesterday, before Judge CARDOZO, in two cases, entitled "The Eric Railway Company vs. Mr. CALER C. NORVELL." and "FRREDERICK A. LANK vs. The Same." These suits were commenced some time ago to recover damages for an alleged libel, published in the Money article of the NEW-YORK TIMES on the 29th of April.

Early in the last session of the Legislature Senator TWEED introduced a bill under which sectarian schools might be supported by taxation, and thus brought into direct competition with the common schools. Under such a law it is quite apparent that the latter must he soon destroyed.

The Officers' Association of the gallant old Sixth Regiment New-York Veteran Cavalry held their fourth annual reunion at Delmonico's last evening. At the business meeting the following officers were elected for the ensuing year; President, Colonel GEORGE E. FARMER; First Vice President.

The fears of a revolt at Paris on the 26th are diminishing. The Government is taking every precaution to guard against any disturbance of the public peace. Marshal BAZAINE has been authorized to use his cannon without mercy if need be. PARIS, Oct. 25.--The Emperor arrived at the Tuileries to-day.

Yesterday afternoon two strangers entered the jewelry establishment of ADAMS , No. 825 Broadway. One of them professed a desire to purchase some silverware, and was taken to the rear of the store by a clerk, leaving his companion in the front.

Judging from the tenor of some of the letters we have received regarding our remarks on Judge BRADY'S nomination by the Tammany Ring, especially of that of "Vindox," appearing in our issue of Saturday, many members of the Bar seem to be in a sort of haze as to the nature of the transaction in which Judge BRADY is now asked to share.

The "humors of an election" in England are only properly appreciated when an official investigation is made into the circumstances under which a sent was won. Such an inquiry has been going on in the borough of Bridgewater. Mr. BAGEROT, the editor of the Economist, (London,) and author of an excellent work on the English, Constitution, was a candidate for that constituency.

The London Times prints Mr. LANGE'S explanation of the report that a French vessel of experiment had stuck in the mud of the Suez Canal, and was extricated by being forced back again. He says the vessel was the heavily armed Egyptian corvette Latif, of 300 horse power, which turned back, as a matter of course because, on the 11th of September, the Bitter Lakes were not yet open.

DR CORDOVA AT STEINWAY HALL. Mr. DE CORDOVA delivered at Stein way Hall last evening the first of the series of three humorous lectures with which in each successive year be delights a friendly public. Mr. DE CORDOVA'S habitual material, and the use he puts it to, are not unfamiliar.

A number of clergymen in Massachusetts are signing a petition for presentation to Governor CLAFLIN, praying him not to issue a proclamation for Thanksgiving unless he can initiate measures which will command a better observance of the day as a season of fasting. humiliation and prayer.
The following communication from the New-York Association for the Advancement of Science and Art has been sent to the Board of Education: To the Honorable Board of Education:

JOHN CONINGTON, Professor of Latin at Oxford University, England, whose death on Sunday is reported in a London dispatch, was the son of Rev. RICHARD CONINGTON, of Boston, Lincolnshire, and was born at that town on the 10th of August, 1825. He was fitted for Oxford at Rugby, and was at the University from 1843 to 1847.

The decree of the Constitutional Cortes, establishing unrestricted liberty of religion in the colonies of Cuba and Porto Rico, was to-day promulgated in this island, and has gone into effect as the law of the land. The document is exceedingly liberal in its terms.

The Board of Alderman and the permanent Water and Sewerage Board of Brooklyn have acquired a knowledge of chemical analysis which elevates them to a lofty standard as inspectors of water works and examiners of the water consumed by the people of the "City of Churches."

The Police Commissioners yesterday decreed that the resolution requiring all policemen, from the 1st of November next, to reside in the county in which they do duly should not take effect until the 1st of May next.

After one of the most fierce and exciting contests that has perhaps over characterized a Senatorial race in this country, the fight was ended to-day in ANDY JOHNSON'S defeat. The result is considered an event of more than ordinary significance, considering the peculiar relation of parties in Tennessee at the presant time.

MARGARET RILEY died yesterday at No. 287 Mott-street, from the effects of injuries sustained on the 24th inst. by a fall down stairs. Coroner FLYNN held an inquest. Verdict in accordance. JOHN BURKE, a man under arrest for intoxication, died suddenly yesterday at the Tombs. Coroner FLYNN obtained a verdict of death from intemperance.

The author of Alton Locke and Westward Ho! has been writing in vindication of the true "rights of women." but he is particularly careful to guard himself against the suspicion of putting any faith in the "female clubbists" of New-York.

The fears of a revolt to-day in Paris, it is said, are growing less. Every precaution has been taken to guard against any disturbance, and Marshal BAZAINE has been directed, if need be, to use his cannon without mercy. NAPOLEON arrived at the Tuileries yesterday. The Prefect of Police had issued a proclamation warning all good citizens to preserve order and not expose themselves to danger by a needless curiosity.

Can nothing be done to stop this incessant sacrifice of life by the explosion of kerosene lamps?? Within the last week we have reported five or six cases of men and women who have been terribly burned by such accidents. It is the old story: the lamp explodes, a woman's dress catches fire, she runs from room to room, and at last falls down in a dying state.
President GRANT has pardoned ANDERSON, PATTERSON and ELSOM, who were convicted here in 1868 of conspiring to defraud the revenue, and sent to the Albany Penitentiary.

In the days when ROBERT T. HAWES and AZARIAH C. FLAGG held the strings of the City's purse, a regulation of the Comptroller's office required every person holding a position by appointment in any department of the City Government, to make an affidavit at the end of the month,

Yesterday Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had quite a successful sale at Homestead Station, N. J. The train was well filled; not quite as many persons attended as have been present at some of the previous sales, but what they kicked in quantity was more than made up in quality. The bidding was good, and the prices realized quite satisfactory. The party returned to New-York at an early hour. pleased and satisfied.

The first day's session of the Social Science Congress will be held to-day in the lecture room of the Historical Society, corner of Eleventh, street and Second-avenue, where the subsequent sessions will also take place. There will be an afternoon meeting at 8 o'clock, and an evening meeting at 8 o'clock.

A couple of evenings age Mr. BRICK, of Station Island, was robbed of his watch on a Third-avenue oar. The thief who took it was arrested and brought up before Justice LEDWITH. But the complainant suddenly declined to prosecute, alleging as a reason that his watch had been returned to him.

The Fair of the American Institute, at the Rink, Third-avenue and Sixty-Third-street, will positively close on Saturday next, leaving only five days more in which those who desire to inspect the collection of articles of utility or art that go to make up this exhibition, can satisfy their curiosity.

CHARLES ADAMS, Jr., is the Republican candidate for Councilor in the Seventh District of Massachusetts. General JAMES L. ALCORN calls upon his Democratic opponents in Mississippi to select some champion to meet him at Jackson, on any day they may appoint, to discuss his personal record from 1861 to 1865, and over after to hold their peace.

An Associated Press telegram last evening briefly informed you of the horible affair which was enacted near hero, at Ponckhockie, Saturday night. I have gleaned the fullest particulars, and they are indeed horrible. THE MURDERER AND HIS VICTIM.

A series of fires occurred here Saturday night and Sunday morning. The most serious were the complete destruction of St. Andrews's Church, and the partial destruction of the Unitarian Church and the drug manufactory of Messrs. KERRY BROTHERS.

The Erie Railway difficulty has not even yet reached a settlement. JAY GOULD promised the men that they should be paid regularly on the 15th of each month, unless hindered by unforeseen circumstances beyond control. In a telegram, sent to the Port Jervis men on Saturday last, embodying the terms of settlement, he announced that payments would be regularly made on that day if convenient.

The Grand Jary still has the case of the alleged Wall-street conspirators under consideration. But little additional testimony was taken yesterday, the jury adjourning at an early hour. It is understood that the prosecuting authorities find some difficulty in bringing the acts of the "Bulls" within the operation of the letter of the statute.

The city is entirely tranquil. The government has taken great precautions to guard against disorder, but no manifestation is likely to occur. PARIS, Oct. 26--6 P. M.--The city has remained perfectly tranquil up to this hour. The threatened demonstration has not been made, and no disturbance whatever has occurred.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : The following article appeared in to-day's edition of the World : GRANT'S STOCK SPECULATIONS. Yesterday afternoon our reporter called on GEORGE E. STONE, of the firm of STONE, NICHOLS STONE brokers, No. 52 Wall-street.

General FRANCIS C. BARLOW started for Washington, on Saturday last, for the purpose of tendering his resignation as United States Marshal for the Southern District of New-York to the President in person. It is understood that he retires from the position because he found that it greatly interfered with his private law practice, and because the duties of the office were not congenial to his taste.

All but four counties in Ohio have been heard from officially. Governor HAYES' majority will be about 8,000. The temperance candidate for Governor did not receive more than 700 votes in the outire State. The distillers in Kentucky are to hold a Convention in Lexington on the 3d of November.

Mr. LEONARD JEROME may justly be congratulated on the brilliant success which has attended his suggestion of an extra day's sport, in which a steeple chase should be the distinguishing and most attractive feature.

About four inches of snow fell here this morning. At Walkarion, Port Elgin, and at other points north and west, about two feet of snow have fallen, and it is still snowing along the lines of the Great Western and the Grand Trunk railways. The fall is very light and railway communication uninterrupted.

In the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday Mr. BRINCKERHOFF, the Civil Engineer, surrendered his place to Mr. HASTINGS, formerly of the Boston Navy Yard. Mr. BRINCKERHOFF is a Democrat and his successor a Republican. The following changes have also been made; DANIEL HERRICK, to be foreman of teamsters, vice JACOB D. STRAUT, removed; JOHN WALKER,

A few minutes before 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon, a most desperate attempt was made to commit robbery and murder. It appears that a laborer, named JAMES LILLIES, has been for some time a depositor in the Citizens' Savings Bank, corner of Canal-street and the Bowery, and had the misfortune to lose has bank book.

Advices received to-day by the tobacco warehouse men, from Indiana, Illnois, and Northern Kentucky, state that all the tobacco beused and not cured or protected by Bros, has been badly damaged by freezing. It is impossible to state what amount ot damage has been sustamed, but it will be great.

Yesterday was a very busy day at the Exchange Salesroom. A larger crowd assembled than have been gathered together within its walls for several months. It seemed, indeed, very much like the old enthusiastic days of last winter, when the room was filled with earnest, anxious bayers.

ARNOLD--BLEECKER.--At the church of the ?? on Tuesday, Oct. 20, by Rev. .Samuel D. Dennison, D.D., JOHN WILLIAM SCHMIDT ARNOLD to ADRLINE CLINTON, daughter of the late John Rhinciander Bloocker, all of this City.

Yesterday afternoon one of the boldest burglaries committed in Queens Country for a long time was perpetrated in the dwelling of JOHN ROBINSON, of Flushing. White the family was at dinner a bold thief metered their apartments.

The following plans for new buildings were approved during the week ending Tuesday, Oct. 20, 1869: Two second-class dwellings southwest corner Tenth-avenue and Twentieth street, 20X37 feet three stories. ANDREW EWALD and B. LANG, owners.

BOORMAN.--On Tuesday morning, Oct. 30, Mrs. MARY WELLES BOORMAN, widow of the into James BOORMAN, in the 85th year of her age. Notice of funeral hereafter. CARPENTER.--HATHR CKCRLIA. only daughter of Abram and Harrief Carpenter, aged 3 years and 7 months.

A very successful free trade meeting was held this evening. It was addressed by G. G. CLARKSON, President of the Rochester Reform League; Professor PERRY, Rev. Dr. SHAW and MAHLON SANDS, Secretary of the New-York Free Trade League.

The funeral of JOHN W. FARMER, the well-known philanthropist of this City, took place yesterday afternoon from the Embury Methodist Episcopal Church, corner of Herkimer-street and Schenectady-avenue, Brooklyn. There was a very large attendance of the friends
