TAYLOR, Chief of the Division of Statistics, under the authority of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, gives a most interesting and gratifying illustration of the results of the present administration of the Revenue Bureau. e compatison is made with the months of July,

In the case of HELENE C. STILLE against Baron II. A. DE RIVIERE, the plaintiff has filed her complaint in the Superior Court. The larger portion of this document is a reiteration of her afidavlts published in connection with the order of arrest which has been vacated by Judge JONES.

The Paris correspondent of the London Daily News. writing on Oct. 14, says: "SAINTE BEUVE, the well-known critic, publicist and poet, lies dead in the little room that served him for bed-chamber and study in his modest lodging hard by the Luxembourg.

Mr. BERGH was lately challenged to put an end to pigeon shooting if he dared, and his "humanity" was made, as usual, the theme of many feeble witticisms. Yet the ideas which he is trying to instill into the community are rapidly gaining force in England.

The Bohomians are at a discount in Lausame also-being slighted by the body of cosmopolite Congressmen who lately met in that city. and who, in resolving that the Polish and Oriental Democracy should be brought into fraternity with that of the West, left out the Czechs by a marked vote.

A correspondent writes to a contemporary to relate a remarkable evidence of "practical Christianity." He went to church on a wet Sunday, and upon coming out, with the prospect of getting wet through, was offered an umbrella by a lady whom he had never seen before. "She had carried two to church, thinking somebody might be unprovided with one."

In steamship Scotia, from Liverpool.--G. Rosenean, B. Remhaidt, J. M. Ganson and lady, J. B. Haggin, lady, 3 children, nurse and governess, Miss Haggin, Mrs. A. M. Sicors, J. H. Irwin and lady, Miss Irwin, L. M. Dobson, Miss Brooklyn, J. M. Rice and lady, R. Watson and lady, P. Anderson, lady, 2 children and 2 nurses, Mrs. Clark, Miss M. O. Mailey,

This organization hold a meeting at NO. 41 First-avenue on Monday night, Mr. F. V. DURING presiding, when the following nominations were indorsed: Nelson W. Young for Corner, John R. Brady for Judge of the Supreme Court, Charles Goepp for Judge of the Superior Court, Michael C. Gross for judge of the Marine Court, Frederick W. Loew for Judge of the Common Pleas Court.

One of the recommendations of the Committee of the Lausanne Congress of Peace and Liberty was the establishment of syndics, to arbitrate between employers and workmen--a good idea, and one that comes home to the business and bosoms of a great many.

The Empire Fire Extinguishing Company gave their second experiment of extinguishing fire by means of carbonic acid gas at the Battery yesterday, and it was a complete success. A frame building about fifteen feet square and twenty-five feet in height, was erected, filled with tar barrels, cotton soaked in kerosene, and fine shavings saturated with the same material.

The booksellers have reached their busiest season. Every week brings fresh announcements and new issues, and both in such bewildering profusion as to reader a simple repetition of their titles a matter of considerable labor. The most important publications announced yesterday, came from the presses of LITTLE, BROWN Co.,

The "Ides of October" have come and gone, and still LOUIS NAPOLEON is Emperor of the French. Predications of fatal days for his dynasty have a habit of turning out mere moonshine. A little while ago the Orleanists scattered their gold with a liberal hand, and a successful rising was confidently anticipated. The hour same, but not the man.

The papers read at the opening session of the Social Science Congress yesterday were all of a high order. The programme for to-day's session in the lecture room of the Historical Society, is even of a more interesting character than that of yesterday.

The concrete pavement in Twenty-second street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, has been put down since that in Fifth-avenue, and has been subjected to much less wear; but is already rivals that in the more-used thorough fare in raggodness.

There may be a sort of fanciful propriety--if nothing else--in sending as English Minister to Madrid the famous Mr. LAYARD, who had so much experience in grabbing and guessing among the rains of some other ancient monarchies of the elder continent.

The Committee appointed by the Irish Republican Horace Greeley Campaign club Issued an address yesterday to the Irishmen of New-York City and State, in which they say: "Countryment who still Eager in the Democratic ranks, we appeal to you no longer to deserve the reproach which these words, from a man who never bowed to Democratic dictation, conveys.

On Monday evening, as already announced, General BUTTERFIELD, forwarded his resignation as Assistant united States treasurer to the Secretary of the Treasury, having previously notified the latter of his action by telegraph.

The Coolie trade has long been carried on with many of the tragic incidents which used to characterize the traffic in slaves. The horrors of the "middle passage' are renewed again and again in the transportation of these unfortunate emigrants.

At midnight of Monday Patrolman LAWRENCE McDONALD, attached to the Sixth Ward Police, was relieved from post duty, and entered the basement saloon kept by DIKDRICK M. KERR, at No. 203 Bowery. Being in full uniform, McDONALD called for lager, and he and the inmates became somewhat intexicated, whom the officer made insulting over?? to one of the women, which she rejected.

The Voz de Cuba, a Liberal journal, lauds the decree establishing religious freedom. It expects the most beneficial results for the country from this great measure, believing that under it the Catholic religion will revive, and that Atheism, now so prevalent, will be annihilated.

At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning a disturbance took place in Elizabeth, N. J., which culminated in a riot and almost in murder. Some young rowdies were expelled from Arnold's Hall, where the ball of the Tentonia Singing Society was in progress. They returned in a few minutes with a mob of sixty of seventy ruffians, and rushed into the hall.

The Council of Censors of Vermont have concluded their labors, and have called a State Convention, to be held on the second Wednesday in June, 1870, to act upon certain amendments to the State Constitution. Which they have promulgated. These proposed amendments forbid special legislation;

The Trustees of the Avondale Fund for the relief of widows and orphans, met yesterday at Plymouth, E. C. WADHAMS, President, in the Chair. The Treasurer gave security in the sum of $50,000 and the assistant Treasurer in the sum of $10,000 for the faithful performance of their respective duties.

The workmen at the Ere Railway shops in Jersey City struck again it noon yesterday, but returned to work at 3 o'clock, upon the conclusion of negotiations with. Mr. GOULD. The strike was occasioned by the arrival of committees from Port Jervis, Susquehanna and Buffalo, and Its object was to have at the men reinstated in work at the shows in Susuehanna and Port.
The Yorger case has thus far brought before the Supreme Court at Washington only a question of practice, but it is none the less a question of importance and interest to the public.

The Howard Mission and Home for Little Wanderers, No. 49 New-Bowery, sent a deputation of children and teachers to the Fair of the American Institute, by the courtesy of its managers, yesterday afternoon.
The Commission which is to report finally upon the Central and Union Pacific Railroads is now writing the report, and it will be ready for submission in about a week.

The English journalists mount their pulpits and deliver solemn discourses concerning the recent gold panic in this City. It is always pleasant to point the moral which does not tell against ourselves.

The celler dam at Hailett's Point, which the Government has been building, is now finished and ready for drilling operations, which will commence in a few days. The rock is to be excavated to the depth of twenty-five feet. and When chambers to be run out under the point for the purpose of biasing it away.

He has been deemed a lucky man on whom the powers that be confer the office of United States Marshal for the Southern District of New-York. Office-hunters have coveted it as a prize to be fought for, and have pursued its possessor with envy and detraction.

The store in which was the Post Office, the barn and carpenter shop of GEORGE ELLIOTT, in the town of Row, were destroyed by fire last night. Two hundred pounds of gunpowder and a barrel of kerosene in the store exploded. No person was injured. The loss is $1,200.

An exhibition of the practical use of the now Longbridge steam brake was made on the Brie Railway yesterday afternoon. The exhibition was under at the request of the managers mud judges of the American institute. The brake is designed for steam cars, and is constructed in such a train at pleasure, without the aid of brakemen.
We publish this morning letters from our own correspondents at Madrid, which supply the public with information far more trustworthy than they are in the habit of receiving through other channels.

Paris was reported entirely tranquil yesterday, and no disturbance occurred. The Emperor drove through the streets in an open carriage in the afternoon. Marshal SERRANO, it is reported, threatens to resign the Spanish Regency in case of a rupture between the Unionists and the Progressists.

HENRY O'NELL, the laborer who fell on Monday at the old building corner of Greenwich and Morris streets, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital from the affects of the injuries, his skull being fractured. An inquest will be held to day by Coroner KRENAN.

Mr. DAN NOBLE has just undergone his third trial for the Royal Insurance bond robberies. He has been tried twice in this county, on both of which occasions the jury failed to agree upon a verdict. The place of trial was then changed to Tioga County and a special term of Court convened at Cawego last week, with Judge MURRAY presiding, for the purpose of disposing of the case.

The North American Review for October is just out, and contains articles on "The Genesis of Language." "The Writings of Mr. ROWLAND G. HAZARD." "Indian Migrations," "Civil Service Reform," " The Coast of Egypt and the Suez Canal," "Paraguay and the Present War," and the usual variety of "Critical Notices."

BOYNTON to IRENR, daughter of Ira Smith, Jr.,all of Brooklyn. HODGSDON--SMITH.--At West Brighton, S. I., on Tuesday, Oct. 26. by Rev. Mr. Seymour. Captain DANIEL B. HODGSDON, U. S. R. M., to GEORGIA M., daughter of Captain George B. Smith.

The business of life insurance, relying as it does not only upon an expressed popular necessity, but intelligent criticism and appreciation by the public, as singularly open to misrepresentation. The opponents of the system charge that the premiums are too high, that the accumulations which are necessary to meet the policy-amount insured are insufficient.

F. MASTERMAN, formerly members of the United States Legation in Paraguay, who were imprisened by order of LOPEZ,

The weather here is winterish. The ground was covered with snow this morning. OSWEGO, Oct.27--A snow storm with high wind prevailed here last night. The schooner Australia, laden with barley, from Toronto, went ashere one and a half miles below the city. The cargo is damaged.

The Yale Navy--its history, its condition, its record of triumphs and defeats--surely this is a twice??old late, and one this has not improved with the to long of late years. And yet yet this an rent ?? venerable the me has, within a few weeks, been adapted to new variations of so lively and pleasing a character that all the sons, patrons, requsintances and well-wishers of Yale will gladly give ear to them.

Information has been received at the Coast Survey Office of a very marked earthquake wave having been recorded on the self-registering gauge in San Francisco on Friday last at 5 o'clock P. M. From this the occurrence of a violent earthquake in some distant part of the Pacific Ocean may be inferred, of which news will doubtless reach here before long.

Major-General GEORGE H. THOMAS was given a very handsome reception last evening by a number of the officers of his old staff and command. So far as the General as concerned, the matter was a complete surprise. The old here was on his way home form the East, and stopped while route at the Tremont House.

Ex-Governor CLIFFORD has been reelected President of the Board of Overseers of Harvard College. GEORGE W. COOLERY, for several years District-Attorney of Suffolk County, died in the Insane Asylum at South Boston yesterday. RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 27.--The Presbyterian Synod of Virginia meets here to-morrow.

The Grand Division Sons of Temperance of Eastern New-York convened in annual session at Lyric Hall, No. 727 Sixth-avenue, yesterday, at 10 A. M., G. W. Patriarch EDWARD CRUMMRY, of Poughkeepale, presiding. The proceedings were opened with prayer by the Grand Chaplam, Rev. S. P. M. HASTINGS, of New-York, after which over 100 newly-elected representatives to the grand body were initiated in due form.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: How many of your reader have a definite idea of Iowa How many know that it is larger than all of New-England except Maine, larger than New-York or Pennsylvania, and more fertile than all of them put together. How many know that she has more coal than Pennsylvania, and more liable land Hear any other State in the Union. .

A large and enthusiastic meeting of the Republicans of Brooklyn was held in Continental Hall, Washington-street, last evening, Hon. STEWART L. WOODFORD presiding. After the applause with which the speakers were greeted as they took their seats on the platform had subsided, General WOODFORD came forward.

A very worthy performance of "Faust" was given by the German artists. last evening, at the French theatre. which seems destined, we should say, to have occupants of every other nationality but that to which it was dedicated.

The Pairic in, its issue to-day, asserts that a widespread conspiracy has been discovered in the Turkish Provinces of Albania and Herzegovina, in connection with the revolt at Cattaro, in the Austrian Province of Dalmatta. Several arrests of persons implicated have been made by the authorities, and a large amount of arms and ammunition seized.

Besides the names by which they are known to all the world, the principal Italian cities, like our own, have titles drawn from some local characteristic. Thus we have Firenze la bella, or Florence the beautiful; Roma la clerna, or the Eternal City: Venezia la gala, the lively or gay city; Genoa la superba, and Milano la ricca, and so on to the end.

The Chinese residents of the city commenced last evening on I-street, above Third, their annual clearing out of devils. The musicians were after the cloven-footed gentry straight from the word go, creating racket sufficient, as far as an inexperienced outsider can judge, to raise the biggest devil in the city.

In accordance with the previously arranged, Dr. ELIOT announced the next business in order to be the reading of a paper by FREDERIC KAPP, Esq., Esq.,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your comparative statement of internal revenue collections for the quarter ending Sept. 30, 1868 and 1868, a typographical error occurs seriously prejudicial to the officers of this district, and which I beg to correct.

Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P. M. Mails for Bermuda, by the Fah Kee, close at 2 P. M.

According to the Paris Patric, the Dalmatian revolt has ramifleations in the Turkish Provinces of Albania and Herzegovina, where arrests have been made and arms and ammunition seized. The Austrian and Turkish authorities will act together in suppressing the insurrection. The Honduras Ambassador to the Court of St. James, JEAN DE FRANCISCO MARTIN, died on the 26th inst. in London.

JEAN DE FRANCISCO MARTIN, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Honduras, died in this city yesterday. Rev. Mr. TEMPLE publicly expresses his regret at the anxiety and excitement caused by his promotion to the Bishopric of Exeter.

A distressing story of a "servant's revenge" comes from a quiet part of Berkshire, England. Lieutenant-Colonel HICKIE had a nurse in his family named ELIZABETH BARRY. She was discharged from his service, and threatened to have her revenge. One day during the absence of Colonel HICKIE and his wife,

We were visited last evening with the first snow storm of the season, accompanied by a sinking of the themometer to a point quite winterish. The full of snow was not over an inch, hut it still remains on the ground not much affected by the sun's rays. This sort of weather is somewhat unusal in this section, as generally at this time we are enjoying a beautiful Indian summerlike season.

Nearly forty years age sixty acres of land of a medium quality, situated in a backward English county, were purchased by a cooperative association. The shareholders were fifteen in number, and each put $3 (?15) into the concern. The landlord advanced $100 to start the affair.

The steamship Columbia, from New-York 21st just., arrived here this morning. Senior CASTANON, editor of the Voz de Cuba, yesterday challenged Seflar GILPI, editor of the Prensa. GH. PI has refused to fight.

Tammany gathered together its followers last night to ratify the Democratic nominations. There was the usual torehlight procession, with the hands, the guns and the big boll, and in point of numbers and enthusiasm the meeting was not inferior to most of the gatherings of the faithful in years past. Mayor HALL presided, and after he had spoken,

The more we examine the tone of the London papers on the gold panic the less creditable does it appear to the character or honesty of the English journalists. The story of the crisls lost nothing by its journey across the Atlantic. The English papers are not above putting imaginative touches to their news.

BOORMAN.--On Tuesday morning, Oct. 26, Mrs. MARY WELLKS BOORMAN, widow of the into James Boorman, in the 85 year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectuflly invited to attend the funeral, Without further invitation, on Friday, the 29th inst. At 10 o'clock A.M., from her late residence, No. 13 Washington-square.

The New-York Association for the Encouragement of Science and Art has written to the Board of Education an important letter on the subject of physical instruction. For many years men of thought and progress have been lecturing on this theme, and the schools have been very slow to profit by their suggestions, But the change must come.

A fire was discovered in the ante-room of the Senate Chamber in the Capitol this afternoon, which caused damage to the extent of $200. Had this fire occurred at night, the whole building would probably have been destroyed.

Mr. FERNANDO WOOD is quite overcome when he thinks of the corruption for which the Republican Party is responsible. He "was shocked, positively shocked." so he told a meeting the other night, with his tongue in his check. He is such a child of nature. And yet by this time his sensibilities ought to be somewhat deadened. He has seen a great deal in his time,

The operators of the Franklin Telegraph Company, who instituted a strike on Tuesday for an advance of twenty-five per cent, on their salaries, held a meeting yesterday morning at No. 11 Brad-street, twenty-one operators being present, and elected officers for their organization.

Some leading colored citizens of this State, whose names are printed below, have issued an appeal to the people for an extension to the colored men of the right to suffrago. They say: What we ask of you is the recognition of our manhood. We are taxed as men, conscripted to defend our country when in peril as men, punished for any infraction of law at leas, as ?? as other men. n.

Judge HENRY COOPER is elected United States Senator from Tenncasea for six years from the 4th of March, 1871. Judge COOPER is a native of Maury County, but removed to Bedford, where he was married in 1850. He was subsequently elected to the Legislature from that Floterial District, in a holly contested canvass, by a majority of 500.

The litigation in the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad war come up in a new shape on Monday before Judge JOHNSON at Rochester. Mr. BANKS, the receiver, presented a position stating that he had been put to very great expense in repairing the damages caused by the recent freshets; that he had no resources except about $50,000 in bank,

List of Americans registered at the office of BOWLES BROTHERS Co., No. 12 Rue de la Paix, Paris, for the week ?? Oct. 14, 1860: New-York--J. Sherwood, Jr., M. D. Wilber, Mrs. M. D. Wilber, Miss G. L. The community was startled Tuesday morning by news that a member of the Junior Class in the University of Vermont, DONALD MANN, had committed suicide by hanging himself in his room. It appears that nothing was seen of MANN by his college mates since last Saturday afternoon, and on Tuesday morning, immediately after prayers, the door of his room was broken open by order of the President.

The recurrence yesterday of a runaway bull accident seems to call for some additional precautions on the part of the drovers or the Police, or both. It is especially necessary in view of the fact that not only is the presence of the animal far from agreeable to eyes courageous persons, but that he is usually made the occasion of a grand hunt by an armed and reckless crowd of pursuers.

The Commissioners of Emigration met last night in University-place, near Twelfth-street, Mr. VERPLANK in the chair, and present Messrs. Winston, Leutrel, Bissenger, Smith, McElroy and O'Gorman, Commissioners.

The most destructive conflagration that has recently occurred in this City broke out about 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the premises of DAVID CLOSE, first floor of No. 110 Fulton-street. This building and No. 114, adjoining, were of brick, six stories high, very old and dry, and having open communication on the two upper floors.

We have heretofore copied statements concerning the appearance and explosion of a large meteor in Stewart County, followed by the fall of a number of meteoric stones. Yesterday we were favored with one of these stones, which fell in the yard of Mr. E. BARLOW, about eleven miles southwest of Lumpkin.

In the meetings of the Social Science Association now holding in this City may be discerned the beginning of an institution which is destined to acquire no small influence in the community. Meetings of this kind have been common of late years in other countries, but with as the idea is still only partially developed.

Senator THAYER, of Nebraska, who is now here, in a conversation with the President, called his attention to the late speech of Judge DENT, in which the latter is reported to have declared that the President has assured him that he was privately in favor of his election, but dared not express himself publicly because of the opposition of the Radicals.

Amid the general wreck of what were once "Democratic principles," the main plank remaining to which survivors cling, seems to be the repudiation of the public debt. Thus platform of the party is usually labeled somewhat speciously.

WM. F. WHEELER, United States Marshal at Helena, Montana Territory, has forwarded to Secretary COX a report of the United States Grand Jury of the Third Judicial District of Montana Territory in regard to robberies and murders committed upon citizens there by predatory bands of Indians within the past few months.

The State Executive Committee of the National Union Republican Party forwarded to-day, to the Secondary of War, affidavits and other official communications, substantiating the statement made some weeks ago in a dispatch to President GRANT by A. C. FISK, Chairman, to the effect that General AMES did not intend to hold a fair election.

The Dartmonth Alumni hold their usual festival this year at DELMONICO'S IN Fifth-avenue, on Thursday, Dec. 2, at 5:30 P. M. The following gentlemen compose the Committee of Arrangements: Hon. David E. Wheeler, Hon. Cyrus P. Smithy, Ex-Mayor of Brooklyn Horatio W. Twombly, Walter Gibson, General Charles A. Carleton, J. Wyman Jones, Edwin T. Rice, Professor Alopheus B. Crosby, Hon. The letter which we have published from Mr. STONE, of the firm of STONE, NICHOLS STONE, thrown some light upon that business of "interviewing" which has lately helped to tower the character of the Press, A reporter went to Mr. STONE and asked him whether he had read the attack upon him in the Saturday Review.

The new Governor of Virginia, in a late agricultural address, very earnestly urged the young men before him not to imitate those who had forsaken their "paternal acres" and gone to the large cities. This same point was enforced by our own Governor. HOFFMAN, and by Ex-Governor SEYMOUR, in their recent addresses on similar occasions.

Yesterday Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had a very successful sale at Cresskill, N. J., About three hundred people were present, and not with-standing a clareless, chilly day, the bidding was very spirited. At the lots were sold, and owing to a new feature introduced, which gave five of the best lots to the five largest purchasers, the ?? was very close.

Mr. GLADSTONE has written a letter to the Dublin Council in which he expresses his satisfaction that the city approves of his action and that of his colleagues in the last Parliament in regard to the Irish Church question.

The death of Mr. SPOFFORD, of the old firm of SPOFFORD TILESTON, which occurred yesterday at his country seat, in Westchester County, removes from the business circle of New-York one of its oldest merchants, and one who for half a century has been identified with the growth and prosperity of the City.

In addition to the twenty Spanish gunboats now in the Delamater Basin, at the foot of West Thirteenth-street, five more will arrive on Saturday from Mystic, Conn., where they have been built. They come to get their machinery and engines put on board, and to be fitted out according to Mr. DELAMATER'S contract with the Spanish Government.

The Boston Advertiser says that in consequence of recent occurrences in banks of that city, the Bank Examiners have decided to add to their regular investigation an inquiry by circular of individual depositors, as to their correct balances, the answers to which will furnish a meat valuable check upon the possibilities of error or fraud in the interior management of the banks.

The old chronicles make a grand show with the migrations of the Cambyses, Tamorianes and Ghongis-Khans; but these are, after all, less worthy of historic admiration than that swarming of over four millions of foreigners into the single part of New-York, in about the space of ten years.

ALEXANDER -- DICKERSON. -- At Madison. square Chruch, on Thursday, Oct. 28, by Rev. Dr. Adams, Mr. CHAS. A. ALEXANDER to the Mrs JULIR A. DICKKERSON, second daughter of the late R. H. Winslow, all of New - York. BRITTON -- STILLWELL. -- At the Madison.square Chruch, on Thrusay, Oct. 28, by Rev. T. Ralston Smith, D. D., CHANNING M. BRITTON to ISABEL, second daughter of J. E. Stillwell, M. D.

A Woman's Suffrage Convention assembled in the Opera House in force this forenoon, and Rev. N. J. BURTON of this City, was called on to preside. Prayer was offered by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. After singing by the HUTCHINSON Family, Mrs. CAROLINE M. SEVERANCE, of Boston, read a long essay.

"SHE WOULD AND SHE WOULD NOT." COLLEY CIBBER'S farcical comedy, which reminds one in title, but not otherwise, of a quaint style of nomenclature n fiction that is coming once more into vogue, was revived on Wednesday at the Fifth-avenue Theatre. "She could and She Would Not" is one of the dramas which, it is common to say, are full "hustle;"

A suit has just been settled in our Superior Court, of a kind that always deeply interests a community. A widow brought an action against an Insurance Company to recover $10,000, the amount of a policy upon the life of her into husband. The Company set up for defence that the policy was rendered vold by the suicide of the insured.

Is it not time some one gave a good legislative shake to that rotten old legal tumbledown, the usury law? Every one knows it is practically a dead letter; or, if he doesn't , he had only to wall till he tries to borrow money on anything less than trouble security. It remains purely, by vis inertia, a foreign substance festering in the body of the Commonwealth.

The following letter on National Taxation and Finance, has been addressed to the Secretary of the Treasury by Mr. NATHANIEL SANDS, of this City: NEW-YORK, Oct. 24, 1869. Hon. Gorge S. Boulwell, Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, D.C.:

The Department of Agriculture has just issued a preliminary report of the condition of the crops, It says: The great agricultural lesson of the season inculcates the necessity of draining and thorough culture.

The Condition of the sewers in this City is plainly seen to be very serious by all who are competent to form a practical opinion on hygienic questions. Almost every houscholder has good reason to know that the drains are not well "trapped," from the number of rate which overrun his house.

Messrs. A.D. MELLICK BROTHER yesterday sold the Pilot estate at Orange, N. J. This was a peremptory sale, and a very desirable property. The consequence was an attendance of about 150 and a very respectable party. Although the entertainment was enlivened by a know squall, it seemed to have no effect upon the bidding, which was etremely spirited, and the competition manifested was quite lively.

Senator THAYER'S version of his conversation with the President with reference to the Mississippi election, was scareely needed to disprove the protensions to Executive favor which have been paraded by Judge DENT and his friends.

Two days remain for the registration of voters preliminary to the State election on Tuesday next. To-day and to-morrow are the only days on which the Boards of Registry will sit in the several election districts of this City and Brooklyn; and the opportunity should not be unglected by these who would secure a full and honest vote.

The Operators of the Franklin Telegraph Company, who had been on a strike since Tuesday noon, held a meeting yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Communications were received from operators in St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, and other cities, expressing their approval and sympathy, and offering material aid

The Western papers continue to discuss with animation the propriety of removing the capital, and in each great city there is at least one journal which has succeeded in proving that there alone can a suitable site be found for the headquarters of the Federal Government.

Any one disposed to underrate the importance of immigration to this country cannot do better than reflect a little over the suggestive facts contained in Mr. KAPP'S paper read before the Social Science Association. Two of his statements were of themselves sufficient to demonstrate the vital interest which the subject Possesses.

A special dispatch from Carbondale, III., says that the steamer Stonewall, which left St. Louis Tuesday evening for New-Orleans, heavily laden with passengers, and horses, mules, bay other freight generally, took fire last night when near Neely's Landing, and despite all efforts to save her was burned to the water's edge.

Superintendent KENNEDY, in his usual election order, directs the Police to do certain things, and among others, to "protect persons who may be placed at each poll as challengers in the decorous performance of that duty." He leaves his subordinates to determine as to what shall be considered a decorous performance.

One of LEECH'S early drawings was called "the cow with the iron tail," The sketch represented a milk dealer drawing his supplies for his customers from the parish pump. People in these days are very glad to got 'milk" adulterated with nothing worse than water. As for getting it pure, pace an "Old Subscriber," it is almost out of the question.

It is very gratifying to find, as the canvass in this City proceeds, that the attitude of independent German--Americans becomes more decided. With the exception of that section which has delivered itself over, bonded hand and foot, to Tammany and the Ring, they are refusing longer to be identified with principles, the triumph of which in this City has done it incalculable harm.

It is all very well for Mr. GLADSTONE to "refuse" to release the Fenian prisoners, but if he supposes the question comes to an end there, he is greatly mistaken. One immense meeting has already been held in London, and now the Dublin Amnesty Association have avowed their determination to continue the agitation until their work is accomplished.

The Nation calls attention to the dishonesty and corruption which exist in Chicago, and which have lately been illustrated afresh in the case of the "Assessor on the South Town" This official's term of office expired in 1869, hut for reasons of his own he desired to keep it until 1870. It is his duty to assess the taxable proper.

BOORMAN.--On Tuesday morning, Oct. 26. Mrs. MARY WELLES BOORMAN, widow of the late James Boorman, in the 85th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, on Saturday, the 30th inst. at 10 o'clock A. M., from her late residence, No. 13 Washington-square.

Sargeant, D. C. Winter.

ELIZO O'KEEFE, residing in Twelfth-street, near Avenue A, was brought before United States Commissioner SHIELDS by Detective ABNER R. NEWCOMER, yesterday, on the charge of perjury. The letter officer deposed that the accused was the widow of a Union soldier, named THOMAN O'KEEFX, who was killed in the war, and that she had been drawing pension as such, under oath, after having married a second time to one FITZSIMMONS.

Mr. BRTOON RICHARDSON, of Yonkers, delivered an address last evening at the American Institute Fair on "The Culture and Manufacture of Silk." A large and very attentive audience was present. Mr. RICHARDSON began by alluding to the antiquity of silk manufacture, is introduction into ancient Rome, into Persia, Greece and elsewhere, from China, the Chinese being the first to wind and weave it.

The sessions of the American Social Science Association, which have been hold at the lecture soon of the Historical Society, in this City, for the last three days, closed last evening, Five important papers were rend before the Association yesterday, but want of space forbids more than brief abstracts of their contents.

A few days since a respectably-attired individual called at the store of Messrs. BROWNE SPAULDING, jewelers, and selected a fine watch and chain, intended, as the represented, for presentation on the part of a club in the country to their President, and directed those gentlemen to forward at once by express the package, valued at $268, to Adams.

A serious collision occurred last evening upon the Hudson River, just of Chambers-street. The Pavonia ferry-boat called the Delaware, and the Morristown, of the Hoboken line, then moving in opposite direction, were about to pass each other when they collided.

FERNANDO WOOD has furnished the latest proof that the Democratic opposition to Tammany is merely a political confidence game. After denouncing the corruption of that organization for years, he haslgone back to the feet of the Sachems at the moment when they are most corrupt. He has justified the belief in his political dishonesty which always prevailed.

J. RILEY WEAVER, United States Consul at Brindist, Italy, and a daughter of Bishop SIMPSON, were married inst. night, at the Methodist Episcopal Church, at Twentieth and Spring Garden Streets. Among the guests were the President, Mrs. GRANT and daughter NELLIE, Generals DENT and EATON, Senator CATTELL, Mayor Fox, and other notables.

AN ORDINANCE TO DIVIDE THE CITY OF NEW-YORK INTO CONVENIENT ELECTION DISTRICTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION EIGHT, ARTICLE THREE, TITLE THREE, OFACT OF THE LEGISLATURE PASSED APRIL FIVE, EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND FORTY-TWO. (Containing all Amendments to Aug. 1, 1869.)

About 10 o'clock last night the breaker of the Upper Lehigh Coal Company, situated about seven miles from White Haven, was burned to the ground. Labor on the works had been stopped for several days, with the exception of pumping, and the belief is expressed that the fire was the work of an incendiary.

A very large meeting of colored citizens was hold last evening at Zion Church, Bleecker-street, to lake into consideration the subject of sending delegates to the National Labor Convention, at Washington. A series of seven resolutions was submitted by the Committee appointed at the former meeting.

The proposition to put a tax on dogs is made in some quarters, for the benefit of the nation at large. It is estimated that there are six millions of dogs in the United States. Levy a tax of one dollar on each of those animals, and you have an annual income equal to the currency interest on $100,000,000 of the national debt.

The advertisements for stolen property which are allowed to make their appearance in one or two City papers are clearly contrary to the law, and ought to be suppressed. We may see the effect of them from a case which came before the Magistrate at Jefferson Market on Wednesday.
The bark Water Witch, of Montreal, with scrap iron, from Kingston for Cleveland, foundered off South Bay, Lake Ontario, on Sunday morning. The crew came ashore in the small boats.

The Dublin Fenian Amnesty Association, at a business meeting held in that city last evening, unanimously adopted resolutions expressing regret at Mr. GLADSTONE'S refusal to release the Fenian Prisoners, and declaring their determination to continue the agitation and to form local associations throughout the country.

One of the numerous cases in which WILLIAM McGARRAHAN is plaintiff, and by which he hopes to establish his claim to a valuable tract of land in California, was before the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia to-day.

The steamship Morro Castle, Which left Havana Oct. 23, reached this port yesterday. By the courtesy of Purser R. W. ALBERT we are in prompt receipt of our letters and papers. The Situation--Troops From Spain--Retregression--Spanish Connivance with the Revolution--Personal.

EVAN EVANS, who arrived from Wales on Monday last, will preach. At 3 P.M. the same elergyman, and also Rev. HOWELL HOWELL will deliver sermons.

The trustees of the Cooper Union have now completed the comprehensive scheme for the free technical education of workingmen, originally contemplated by the trust deed of Mr. COOPER, by the establishment of a permanent course on "Machinery and Mechanical Engineering."

One noticeable result of that old civic independence, which made the Middle Age history of Italy so hereto or so picturesque, is the diversity of dialects in that country. Strangers would he apt to think that the poetry of DANTE, PETRARCH and ALFICRI--to say nothing of the Crusean Academy--must have made the standard Italian a common speech.

VON VLECK gave an expose of the manner in which so-called spiritual mediums perform the tricks by which they decolve the public into the belief that they, the mediums, are in actual communication with spirits. After showing that he rould produce the my serious rappings of the Fox girls, which he explained was done by contraction of the meseles.

A dispatch from Corrlane, Utah, says: "The passenger train which ran off the track near Evanston, yesterday evening, was run into by the second section of the train filled with Mormons, and DAVID SHIELDS, JOSEPH THOMAS, JOHN TUSTIN and PHILIP DELL were killed. Some other passengers were wounded."

The Circuit Counts of the United States have always been Courts of great importance, but that importance has very much increased of late, and will continue to increase, for the tendencies of the times have thrown and will throw more and more business into the Federal Courts. of all the Circuits.

Charlotte suffered severely by a fire which broke out yesterday morning about 3 o' clock, in the business portion of the village, resulting in the destruction of a considerable amount of property. A long wooden block two stories high, occupied for various business purposes and tenements, situated on the street parallel with the dock, was the scene of the fire.

A mass meeting of workingmen was held in the large hall at the Cooper Institute last evening. Mr. J. M. BOBOSE called the meeting to order, and introduced Mr. JAMES E. TAYLOn, of the Stone Cutters' Society, as Chairman. Mr. JOHN ENNIS, of the Plasteres' Union, was the first speaker.

The Minister form Honduras,. Suffer GOMEZ, leaves the United States on the next Isthmus steamer. This gentleman formerly represented Nicaragua and San Salvador in Washington, of which latter State he was tw100 Secretary of State.
The murder of JOACHIM FUERTER near the station in this village, in March last, has been a prolific source of anxious conjectures and surmises since the first discovery of the traces of that crime.

After the termination of the Church Congress in Liverpool, which is claimed as a great triumph for Ritualism, I thought the best thing I could do was to see what was going on in Birmingham. The next Church Congress is to be held at Southampton--but Birmingham will always be the centre of important movements.

The monthly meeting of the trustees of the Children's Aid Society was held at the rooms of the Society, No. 19 East Fourth-street, on Wednesday evening, HORATIO ALLEN, Esq., in the chair. The work of the Society has been going on prosperously. During the previous month 122 boys, 19 girls, 18 women and 15 men were provided with homes and employment.

Some old author-TACITUS, we believe--says it bodes no good to the people when the rulers of men meet in conference. If such were the case, the peoples of Europe should be rather down-hearted to see such a fraternizing of the crowned heads as has taken place latterly--the King of Prussia crossing the Rhiue to shake hands with NAPOLEON, the Hapaburg Archduke going to meet the Carignans in Milan,

We some time since referred to the victory won at Cherbourg by a crew of the United States steam frigate Sabinc, under Lieutenant-Commander BARTLETT, of this city. It seems that they may be regarded as the champion earsmen of the Tagus as well as of the English channel.

About 2 o'clock P. M., Thursday, a man Claiming to represent JAMES DONALD Co, of Teneust Hill Oil Works, entered the office of VERMILYE Co., and expressed his desire to open an account with them, at the same time presenting a check on the Chatham Bank, corner of John-street and Broadway, and also a draft on Albany for $1,350.

The Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH of Austria was received by the Sultan last evening. The shipping in the borbor was decorated, buildings illuminated, and much enthusiasm manifested on the occasion.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: For some months we have endured in silence the persecution waged against us, and made no response to untruthful, nonsensical, expurie statements, conscious that time would bring our vindleation.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The residents upon Fifth-avenue are justly indignant about the wretched covering which has been plastered over the pavement. but they would have mush less cause of complaint if the street was properly swept and the dirt carted away.

The Times has an editorial on American finances, wherein the writer comments on Secretary BOUTWELL's advocacy of paying the national debt in gold, and considers the very necessity of such an advocney roff of the strength of the repudiators. Mr. SOUTWELL's appeal for paying the debt will earn him glory and patriotism.

The Dominion Cabinet has been reconstructed as follows: Premier and Minster of Justice, Sir John A. Macdonald, K. C. B.; Minister of Militia, Sir George E. Cartiel, Bart.; Minister of Finance, Sir Francis Hincks, K. C. B., C. M. G.; Minister of Customs, Hon., S. L. Thley, C. B. ;

The steamboats of the Mississippi have long possessed an unenviable notoriety all over the world. They are associated in the popular mind with every description of lawlessness. Mismanagement, and reckless disregard of human life. The wildest story of sitting on safety valves and heating the hollers until they burst, still finds ready credence if the scene of it is laid on a Mississippi steamer.

The proposition to relieve Hell Gate by cutting a canal through Astoria, which has been suggested by various parties at different times, has been taken up by the late engineer of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Mr. VANDERBILT. He has matured a plan by which such a canal could be constructed for less money and in less time than would be required for the removal of the rocks in Hell Gate channel.

A special dispatch from Quincy, III., to the Tribune is to the effect that "Pet" MCKAY, a highly-esteemed and beautiful young lady in that city, aged 18 years, walked out on the railroad bridge and pianed her cloak to a brace of the bridge and leaped into the river. Her body has not been found.

At the recent meeting in Madrid, Spain, composed of representatives of the different political parties, complete disunion is said to have existed. General PRIM had to use every effort to prevent a rupture both on the Church and King questions. The Opposition is now stated to be divided, but the final selection of the Duke of GENOA for the throne is regarded as probable.

He has long been the lending citizen of the ?? that bears ?? name, has served the public as Justice of the Peace and Associate Justice.

Superintendent KENNEDY has issued the following order: OFFICE OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF METROPOLITAN POLICE, No. 300 MULBERRY STREET, NEW-YORK, Oct. 30, 1869. To the Captains of Police: The Police telegraph instrument after sun down on Nov. 2d inst. will be used exclusively in transmitting election returns.

The preliminary report of the Department of Agriculture on the state of the crops makes the starting declaration that the actual reduction in value the past season ?? from the "alternate drowing and according " of farm crops, has been not less than $300,000,0001 The importance, not only to individual prosperity but to the national resources, of better draining, and, in general, more careful culture, is very obvious.

California Continues in the path of progress. The total value of her exports for the first nine months of this years does indeed compare unfavorably with the corresponding period of 1868. This is to be accounted for chiefly by the diminished value of agricultural products, the quantity of flour sent out, for instance, having been nearly as great as before, wile the total value is $700,000 less.

General B?? still retains possession of the office of Assistant United States Treasurer, and has heard nothing as yet in regard to the appointment of a successor, being also unaware of his alleged indictment by the Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

The corner-stone of the new hospital founded by the munificent bequest of JAMES H. ROOSEVELT, was laid yesterday. A prayer was offered by Rev. THOS. DE WITT, an address delivered by Rev. JOS. T. DURYEA, and the ceremony of placing the stone was performed by Dr. EDWARD DELAFIELD, who is to be the President of the institution.

The general depression which has overcome the marine of the United States does not we are happy to say, weigh upon the navy of Yale College, which is now in a restored and flourishing condition. "The boat house," says our correspondent "Epsilon," "is in good order and condition," and there are "fifteen serviceable boats, four shells, three gigs, two barges, two double souls and four single souls."

It seems that we are about to have a railroad war of greater or loss dimensions in this city shortly, between the Central Pacific and California Pacific Railroads. As we are informed, the former company made an agreement verbally with the latter several months ago, promising to give it the privilege of coming into the city with its track at any point it chose to select,

The Patric, in its issue today, says that the military subdivisions of Nancy, Tours and Litle are to be abolished. The headquarters of the old district of Nancy will be at Metz. There is much excitement in literary circles this city to day. M. BIETHE, the Prefect of the Police, has forbidden the representation of a new drama, which had passed the censorship.

The Sierra Nerada left this port in charge of Captain J. C. BOOERT, on Saturday last, Oct, 16, with 124 tons of freight and 42 passengers, bound for San Luis Obispo and way ports. THE PASSENGERS. Among the passengers on board was Governor WOOD, of Illinois, together with his wife, two sons, and brother-in-law.

The trial of Rev. C. C. TATE, at Trinity Church, has its curious and almost funny phases as well as its most serious characteristics. It was decided yesterday that lawyers should not be allowed to participate in the arguments or discussions.

The third annual Sunday School Jubilee, in aid of the Home of the Aged and infirm of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in Philadelphia, took place last evening at the Academy of Music. Long before the commencement of the exercises the building was crowded in all parts.

The dispatch from Salt Lake should quiet the demand for the adoption of a storm Anti Mormon policy by the General Government. The system is in danger from influences which are at work among the Mormons themselves : and these influences will gather strength if there be no Federal interference to counteract them.

Captain-General DERODAS has pardoned MACGREGOR. AGRICAN has been sentenced to be shot. The rebels in Santa Espiritu, and the Spanish troops in the district of Cinco Villas, number 5,000 in each place. Generals ESPINAR and LA TORRE will salt from Havana for Spain to-morrow.

After all, that spire of the Old Dutch Church in Fulton-street is not so very far gone; and we hasten to state the fact for the assurance of all "Kuickerhockers" and others who love the ancient landmarks. There is a great place of the belfry left, and a careless passenger would suppose the whole of it was still towering above him.

HILDERBRAND, the nuterions outlaw, stating that he had come to the conclusion that he could no longer keep up a war against the whole country, and begging to be "let alone." He promises that he will never more molest anybody, and in future net like an honest and Peaceable man.

This society of amateurs of the noble game of ?? has recently commenced a handicap tournament in which not only the strongest. players, but also several of the second and third-class players take a part. In this contest the honor of victory is the main object, the prize striven for being a minor consideration.

To-morrow being the second anniversary of the death of Governor ANDREW, his remains will be removed from their temporary resting-place in Mount Auburn, to Hingham, his native town, where a burial spot has been appropriated for the purpose.

Taking the weather into consideration, yesterday was fortunately an "off-day" for owners, buyers and reporters, and the auctioneers had consequently a capital time to prepare for the exertions of the ensuing week. The season for suburban sales is about drawing to a close, Next Wednesday, however, Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER have an absolute sale of sixty-one valuable lots in the village of Astoria, L. I.

The British Government is applying the screw very gently with the view of attaching British Columbia to the Canadian Confederation. Earl GRANVILLE, the Colonial Secretary, has addressed a dispatch to Governor MUSGROVE, of British Columbia, in which the advantages of the union are earnestly and not unfairly stated.

The following are special dispatches to the Cincinnati Commercial: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 27--A large and brilliant meteor passed over this city at 9 o'clock this the ring. A large train of flame followed it, and it omitted a strong odor of sulphur.

A most heartrending accident occurred last night, about 11:30 o'clock, in PORTER DUNHAM's "sample room" saloon on Third-street, between Jefferson and Green. The statements made in regard to the matter are to the effect that W. SCOTT GLORE, EDDIE BENSINGER and JIM HOCKER, the latter a salesman in DEPPEN's clothing house, were all standing at the counter together, BENSINGER paying Mr. DURHAM,

At the Woman Suffrage Convention to-day, Mrs. Dr. LOSIER, of New-York, road an essay on the health of women, and addresses were made by Mrs. PAULINE W. DAVIS, of Providence, R. I., Mrs. CECELIA BURLEIGH, of New-York, and WM. LLOYD GARRISON. The attendance was good.

About 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon THOMAS JACKSON, residing at the corner of Morris and Washington streets, became involved in a quarrel with ARCHIBALD DOUGLAS, of No. 85 Greenwich-street, in the liquor saloon of THOS. BRANAGAN, at No. 2 Washington-street, over a matter of political manufacturing in the First Ward. Both men became much excited,

The Shanghae News Letter, just at hand with other Chine and Japan Journals, received by way of San Francisco, Comments on the question of Chinese emigration. " We are glad to see." it says,"by the last Pacific mail papers, that in every part of the United States the question of Chinese immigration is being earnestly discussed,and that our fellow countrymen are already clearing their made from their hazy Rations of this Empire.

There have been several preliminary meetings of the members of the different parties in the Constituent Cortes to-day, to discuss the question of the chance of a monarch. At that of the Unionist Deputies every member save two voted against the Duke of GENOA.

The Trustees of the New-York Hospital have, it appears, abandoned their idea of creating a receiving house at the corner of Twenty-ninth-street and Ninth-avenue, the cost of the same being more than was anticipated. The ground purchased for the erection of the building is to be let on lease.

It is evident, from the comments of the London Times, as reported by cable this morning, that the relations of parties here on the question of national faith is understood abroad. The Decomacratic Party is rightly associated in the foreign mind with the policy of repudiations while the Republican Party is as clearly identified with the maintenance untarnished of the nation's honor.

Owing to the expectation of an order from Washington for the release of BOGART, the Ex-Assistant Paymaster, his mother was in waiting for him all day Thursday with a carriage, designing to convey him once more to the lap of luxury; but the anxiously-looked-for order did not arrive, and the patient lady had to retire surely disappointed.

SATURDAY. Mails for Europe via Liverpool, by the City of Brussels, close at the General Post Office at 1 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on Pier No. 46, North River to 1:30 P.M. Mails for France via Havre and Breat, Per pereire, close at the Post Office at 11:30 A.M.

BERRY--MOTT.--In Southpost, Conn., on Thursday, Oct. 23, at the resident of the bride's parents, by Rev. Edward Wall, LLOYD W. BERRY to ELLA MOLT, daughter of G. Molt, Esq. BOYD--CUTTER.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 28, by Rev. N. M. Gaylord. FRANK L. BOYD to KAHE B. CUTTER, both of Boston.

For a long time the officers of the Government have been aware of the existence in Southern Ohio or Indiana of a gang of counterfeiters, and a special detective has been engaged in an endeavor to discover their retreat.

Complaints are appearing in several journals with reference to the Democratic "demonstration" in Union-square on Wednesday evening. One correspondent writes to say that he received a severe flesh wound from a rocket stick; another states that his sick child was rendered worse by the noise and confusion which were kept up until nearly 11 o'clock.

The Proprietor of a boarding house in the eastern part of the city took a poor sick man off the street, day before yesterday, and gave him food and shelter, and provided him with medical attendance, for charity. Yesterday the illness culminated in a beautiful crop of small pox pustules, that broke out over the entire surface of the man's body,

The last day for registration is here: to-night at 9 P.M. the lists will be complete' and no man who fails to record his name before that hour, can lawfully vote on Tuesday next. Let every citizen who reads this statement at his breakfast table this morning and who has neglected to register, do so before going to his business;

The British bark Strathspey, house Sept. 13, for Queenstown, with a cargo of wheat, encountered a cyclone Sept, 24, In latitude 27:15 north. longitude 123 west, sprang a leak and was abandoned on the 25th, Within three minutes after the Captain and crew left the vessel, she went down stern foremost.

The Times, in an article on the Irish land question, says: "It is not our business to satisfy the Feuians. They would not be satisfied if Ireland was doubly confiscated for their benefit. It is our business to do justice between two classes constituting the bone and sinew of Ireland, whose interests are identical, and extirpate the most ancient root of Irish wrongs.

We have received a communication from Hon.S.S.Cox, in answer to our strictures on his Brooklyn speech. Mr. Cox says: "You predicate an editorial on a wrong report of my speech in Brooklyn. that report astounded me as much as it seems to have astonished others. I never said that 'the national debt is now $10,000,000 more than it was just after the war."

In steamship Peceire, for Harre,--Wm. De Laucey Ward. Mrs. M. Ward, Miss Ward, Rev. E. Sorin, Mr. Vauller, Mr. Mayer. Mrs. E. Swift, A. S. Peabody, S. L. Post, Mark H. Wentworth, Miss F. Wentworth, Miss Susie Wentworth, Mr. and Mrs. Murphy and 6 children, E. Murphy C.C. Thompson, c. M. Thompson, Mr. Poirler and servant, Mrs. P. D. Michon, F. A. Brush, C. P. Bromley,
The steamship America, which left Bremen Oct. 10 and Northampton Oct. 19, reached this port yesterday. Her advices are later by two days than those at hand by the Scotia.

A few minutes after 13 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the extensive planing and moulding mill situated at the foot of Fifty--third-street, East River, owned and occupied by OGDEN CARPENTER. The buildings were wholly of wood, and occupied four full lots. They were entirely destroyed.

Yesterday afternoon a party of fifty gentlemen, composed of the Commissioners of Emigration, the German Consul of New-York and other notables, visited Ward's Island on an inspection tour, concluding their trip with a sumptuous entertainment and the usual complement of speeches.

Mr. TENNYSON' S new poem on "The Quest of the Holy Grail" is in type, and may be expected to appear before Christmas. Anything to make money. A manufacturer in the north of France is making pocket handkerchiefs upon which is to be represented the murder of the KNICK family by TRALPMANN, They will be called "Madras de Paulin."

The Turner Society (association of German gymnasts) of this City have sent the following appeal to the different Turner Societies of this State, for the Support of General FRANZ SIGEL, the Republican Candidate for Secretary of State at the coming election:

New Street cars, to be used without conductors, have been recently introduced into Chicago and Hartford. An effort is made to have them used in other cities, and the experiment is about to be tried in Philadelphia. It is said that the system has been in use in New-Orleans during several years.

The dreadful fate of the janitor in Liberty-street, who, with his family, was burned to death of Friday night, is what might happen any time to hundreds of others, who, like him, live in the top floor of large buildings. The homes of these guardians of valuable property are placed in the very places where they are exposed to most danger.

Fire broke out this morning on the Fourth and fifth floors of store No. 68 Federal-street, occupied by the New-England Type Foundry, office of the Railway Journal, and S. P. BALDWIN, dealer in paper and twine. The printing office of the Journal was not injured. The type foundry was damaged to the amount of $5,000 to $9,000;

The annual Fair of the American Institute for 1869 closed just evening with grand eclat. Long before the time announced for the closing exercises crowds of people began to till the rink, so that by 8 o'clock there could have been no ness that four thousand visitors at the exhibition.

The writer of the article on this subject, in yesterday's TIMES, was in error in stating that the iron Age was first iron sailing vessel constructed in this country. It appears that an iron brig called the Norcity was built by the Atlantic Works in 1868-9, being launched Jan. 23, 1869.

The introductory lecture of a course by a Professor WILLIAM G. PLYMPTON, on Mechanical philosophy and Mechanism, was delivered last evening, in the large hall of Cooper Institute. On the platform were Mr. PETER COOPER, Hon. CHARLES P. DALY, ABRAHAM, S. HEWITT and others of the Committee. Mr. HEWITT introduced the lecturer, and gave a brief explanation of the object to be attained.

Detectives QUINN and CASEY, of the Eighth Precinct, arrested CHRISTIAN OWEN a cigar manufacturer, last night, near his place of business, No. 242 Grand-street. The charge against the prisoner is that of forgery.

The season is over at the Central Park ; the last concert of the year has been given, and for the next nine months the nymphs and dryads will have the Park pretty much to themselves. Few intrusive visitors will disturb them.
The recent operations in gold in Wall street developed a rather singular case yesterday, before Justice DOWLING, at the Tomba Police Court.

There are many who have thought that the new Judiciary article was scarcely worth saving, because it does not at once abrogate the principle and practice of electing Judges. A review of the subject and a closer examination of the article itself, however, will lead to a different conclusion.

About fifty ladies met yesterday at Room No. 12, Packard's building, for the purpose of constituting themselves a Woman's Parliament, and perfecting all arrangements for the future proper management of the concern.

The journeymen watch-case makers of this City will meet to-morrow evening at CARBERRY'S, corner of William and Ann streets, to consider an advance of prices, and to devise the best means of ameliorating their condition generally. There are in this country 294 of these craftsmen--100 in New-York and Brooklyn, 100 in Philadelphia, 20 in Boston, 10 in Cincinnati, and 4 in Newark, N. J.

The Democrats of the Second District of Monroe County have nominated RICHARD H. SCHOOLEY, at present City Clerk of Rochester, for members of Assembly. In the Third District, HENRY W. DAVIS having declined the Democratic nomination, the District Committee have tendered the nomination to ALEXANDER P. BUTTS, of Sweden, and he has accepted it.

It is well understood that Queen VICTORIA has strong opinions upon various social abuses and misfortunes. She has, in fact, several times thrown off her reserve of royalty for the purpose of remonstrating publicly with those who are responsible. The great mass of poverty in London is always a sad attendant upon the glories of that great city, but much of it is kept out of sight.

There seems to be some chance that the political difficulties in Spain may be adjusted at last. The preponderance among the Monarchical party in favor of the Duke of Genoa disposes of the numerous discussions as to the other

United States Commissioner SHIELDS commenced and examination in the case of T. CULLAM, D. BUCKSER and W. MONDAY, jointly charged with having removed a large quantity of unstamped tobacco to a place other than a bonded warehouse.

Old and new comedies have alternated during the week at Wallaok's and the admirers of "The Heir at Law" and "The School for Scandal," of "Caste" and "The Unequal Match" have had the best Possible opportunity for in dulging their tastes.
The accounts of the burning of the steamer Stonewall in the Western papers received last night give very little of interest not contained in the full reports telegraphed by the Associate Press.

The examination in the case of CHARLES S. and WASHINGTON ARCHER, wholesale grocers and liquor merchants, charged with making false revenue returns, was resumed before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday.

The pleasure-seeking public, who have so long and patiently suffered the stifling atmosphere which pervades our theatres and other places of popular amusement, will be glad to learn that the Metropolitan Board of Health proposes to afford them speedy and permanent relief.

A sleeping car attached to the express train on the Oswego and Syracuse Railroad, due here at ?? o'clock this morning, was thrown from an embankment two miles this side of Fulton by a broken rail. II. II. VAN SLYCK, of New-York, had his right collar bone broken and sustained several scalp wounds. JOHN VAN WAGGONER, conductor, was seriously injured internally.

Secretary FISH arrived in this City from Washington yesterday forenoon, In the afternoon he had quite an extended consultation.

AGNEW.--On Saturday, Oct. 30, WILLIAM AGNEW, in the 85th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral. without further invitation, on Monday, Nov. 1, at 13 o'clock M., from his late residence, No. 24 East 21st-st. CLOW.--On Thursday morning, Oct. 28, ZILPHIA, wife of Christopher Clow, aged 51 years, 2 months and 23 days.

The bulk of intelligent medical men have come to the conclusion that while our knowledge of the nature of disease have been gradually increasing, our power over its effects is not keeping pace with it.

The Hebrew National, a new Jewish journal published in London, gives the statistics of the Jews in the world. There are 6,000,000 Jews in the world, one-half of when live in Europe. America contains 260,000.

The British soldier is feeling the evil effects of being swathed in the antique habiliments of a time-honored military fashion. Of 22,000 patients, chiefly from India, admitted to the military hospital at Netley, there were 1,633 suffering from heart disease, caused, it is admitted, by the present cumbrous style of accoutrement.

In connection with the handsome and commodious new fish market in South-street, which has just been completed, an abuse exists which should be remedied. It appears that each member of the Association occupying the market house, some twelve in number, has the convenience of a water closet, the droppings from which, of course, fall into the slip in the rear of the market house.

The New-York Gencalogical and Biographical Society, which began his career under such favorable auspices, shows already the promise of a great future. There are now upward of sixty members, and the nu?eleus of a valuable library has been formed. .

For some time past respectable persons passing down Frankfort--street after dusk have been installed by a gang of young rowdies who assemble nightly about the corner of Gold-street. Last Sunday evening two gentlemen were proceeding down that street to their lodgings, when these candidates for Sing Sing attacked them, utterly unprovoked, with the most disgraceful abuse.

The weather has become unusually cold during the last few days, and overcoats are generally worn. Business of all kinds has improved, and the storekeepers anticipate a brisk trade during the Winter and Spring.

In the TIMES was previously published an account of the trial and conviction of DAVID BURKE for the murder of THOMAS CANE, at Hunter's Point, on the 25th of October, 1868. We also give a graphic report of the testimony of the deemed man, in which he denied the intent to stout and pleaded self-defence.

At 7:15 o'clock last night a fire broke out on the third floor on No. 62 Church-street, and occasioned considerable loss before it was extinguished. The third and fourth floors and occupied by G. JARETZKI CO., shirt manufacturers; loss $2,000; insured. The second floor, occupied by STEPHEN BREESE, commission merchant; loss $2,000. The first floor by M. BACHMAN, cloths: loss $1,000.

A rumor prevails in Paris that the Emperor is again indisposed. General FLECRY has gone to St. Petersburg to enter upon the duties of French Ambassador to Russia. Father HOSELE, elected Bishop of Rottenburg, but not yet confirmed, has been summoned to Rome by the Pope, it is supposed on account of his action at the Fulda Conference.

The inspections in the First and Second Divisions are still progressing in this City and Brooklyn. General McQuade having had his time fully occupied during the week. Since our last summary the following regiments have made returns:

The weekly record of the progress of work on the new Post Office shows no diminution of energy or labor performed over previous weeks. The making of the north fence toward the City Hall has given more room on the ground for storing material, which will necessarily accumulate. Four ponderous derricks are now in constant use in excavating an lowering stone for the wall,
We cannot afford to treat with indifference, even if we would, the advances made by the communities of Europe in the path of political and social reform.

The interests of intermers under the Internal Revenue laws will be materially affected by recent decisions of our United States courts, as to the payment of the costs of prosecuting the cases. In small cases those costs are often enough to absorb or at least to materially diminish the informer's share.

The Central Park will shortly be embellished by another statue from the atelier of J. Q. A. WARD. It will be placed near the Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Tenth-street entrance. It represents a private of the Seventh Regiment N. G. in regulation uniform and overcoat.

It is an indisputable fact, that, in proportion to its general military excellence and soldierly capability, the American army is probably less accomplished in marksmanship than any of the armies of the leading powers. And the truth is equally applicable to the regular army and the militia.

This evening a very large and enthusiastic meeting of leading Citizens of Detroit was held at the City Hall to listen to addresses by Professor PERRY, of Williams College. General BRINKERHOFF, of Ohio, and MAHLON SANDS, of New-York, Secretary of the Free Trade League, Hon. RICHARD HAWLEY was called to the chair.
In the case of MICHAEL GILFOIL, who obtained a writ of mandamus, as already published in the TIMES, from Judge CARDOZO, of the Supreme Court,

A few days ago, a public writer, who has himself contributed largely to American literature, complained in a melancholy spirit of the scanty encouragement which is given to native authors. The same cry is repeated in another quarter with respect to artists.

Some of the Democratic speakers in the present canvass have discovered certain wonderful mares' nests. Unable to deny that the present Administration reduced the national debt during the first seven months of its holding office by the enormous sum of $57,000,000;

Another of the representative men of this City, long and favorably known in business and political circles, is dead. WILLIAM J. PECK died at his residence, No. 248 West Fifty-second-street, in this City, yesterday (Sunday) morning, in the 48th year of his age. Born, reared and educated in this City, he was closely identified with its singular and remarkable growth and prosperity.

JOHN LEONARD, of No. 7 Hubert-street, was found yesterday morning in Church-street, dear Worth, with his leg broken, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital. The Police do not appear to know how the injury was received. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning an attempt was made to fire the dwelling No. 30 Hamilton-street by building a fire under the stairs, but it was fortunately discovered and extinguished before any damage was done.
An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner ROLLINS in the case of THOMAS FIERY, lately employed on the Fourth-avenue Railroad as a conductor, who, an Friday evening last, while intoxicated,

Several gentlemen have organized a Social Science Society, which will meet daring the Winter every Monday evening at Plimpton Hall. A. portion of the time on each evening is set apart to allow strangers an opportunity to take part in the discussion, and we understand that workingmen and women are particularly invited to attend, for much attention will be paid to labor questions.

A writer in the London Telegraph says he examined, a couple of years ago in the Doge's palace at Venice, a very old manuscript map of the globe on which he saw marked the two lakes of Nyanza, said to have been recently discovered by SPEAK and BARKER.

The withdrawal of ERASTUS C. BENEDICT removes the only obstacle to the undivided support of Judge CLERKE by the Republican Party. There can now be no difficulty in uniting Republican votes with the votes of Democrats who are opposed to Tammany rascality; and the united strength should be sufficient to keep Judge BRADY where he is.

At a meeting of the City Council of Charleston, S. C., on Thursday, a motion was made that the report of a committee in favor of paying $3,000 to Major CORBIN, for legal services to the Board, be adopted, and was deciared by the Mayor, the presiding officer, to be passed. Loud calls for the yeas and nays were made, and a Scene of confusion ensued.

The regular monthly terms of the law courts commence to-day--the first Monday--though it is not expected that much will be done until after the election of Tuesday. Presiding Justice CLERKE, and Judges SUTHERLAND and CARDOZO of the Supreme Court, are announced to held the General Term.

The unvailing of the Vanderbilt bronze at the Hudson River Railroad Depot, St. John's Park, on Nov. 10, will be the occasion of an ovation to the distinguished financier such as is seldom offered to citizens who have attained honors and distinction wholly in the walks of private life.

ALFRED of England, in presenting the young Mikado of Japan with a diamond snuff box, felt himself under the common sense necessity of tolling the Asiatic that it was meant to held imperial goodies--not snuff for the nose; which shows that the Prince was rather ashamed of that old European custom.
