But a short time age the Sierra Nevada, a vessel heavily laden with passengers and cargo, struck on a reef, and in a few minutes afterward she went down. Every soul on board was saved--first by the coolness of the Captain and good discipline of the crew, secondly by the proper supply of boats on board. Contrast this story with the loss of the Stonewall.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I was on board the train on my way from New-York to Binghamton, on the 26th alt., when the cars were thrown off the track with great violence. The train was running with fearful speed down the steep grade approaching the Susquehanna Depot.

The funeral of our lamented fellow-citizen, Mr. PAUL SPOFFORD, took place at his late residence, No. 4 East Fourteenth-street, yesterday, at 1 o' clock P. M., in the presence of a numerous assemblage of relatives and friends. The exercises were opened by some remarks by the pastor of the family, Rev. Dr. MURRAY, and the singing of the familiar hymn, "Nearer, my God, to Thee."

The hostility of the Democracy to the nomination of Mr. GREELEY for the Comptrollership needs no explanation. His preminence in the Republican Party, his energy and effectiveness in party warfare, and the known purity of his personal character, are facts which sufflelently explain the persistent misrepresentation to which he is subjected by avowed opponents.

Senor ARDANAZ, in his budget, just submitted to the Cortes, announces that the financial deficit for the current year amounts to 520,000,000 reals. He looks forward with hope to the ensuing fiscal year, extending from January, 1870, to January, 1871, his estimates for which show, as before reported, a ?nrplus in favor of the Treasury.

This distinguished gentleman [Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS] arrived on the steamship Cuba last night, as was announced in our morning edition, but with other passengers, in accordance with a barbarous regulation which late oppressions have brought into existence here, just as they are being abolished, or, at least, modified by the most tyrannical of Governments, was not permitted to land until this morning.

The remains of Hon. JOHN A. ANDREW, the war Governor of Massachusetts, were this morning transferred from Mount Auburn to Hingham and deposited in the Hingham Cemetery. Proviously to putting it into the hearse the excelient was opened and the body found to be in an excellent state of preservation, considering the length of time which has elapsed since its burial, the day being the second anniversary of the decease of Governor ANDREW.

To-night and to-morrow morning will be selected for the disclosure of "astounding facts" concerning various candidates to be voted for at the State election. These eleventh-hour revelations of hideous inquity on the part of divers and sundry persons, always trap more or less of the unwary, especially those of an undecided turn of mind, who want something "definite" to guide them.

National issues are only indirectly involved in the contest which to-morrow will decide. The result will neither change the policy of the Administration, nor affect the relative power of parties in Congress. And yet, for national reasons, a Republican triumph is of more than trifling importance.

The fire of Friday morning in the Licking County Infirmary offers a deplorable commentary on the letter of Mr. BRACE, which we printed on Saturday, respecting the miserable treatment suffered by lunatics in those County Asylums.

The sales for last week were quite large, and the results as satisfactory as during any previous one. Several were made in New-Jersey, and one at Flatbush, L. I. The attendances were generally good, and despite the cold, unpleasant weather, the people were interested, remained out of doors patiently, listened to the auctioneer good-humoredly and bought quite promptly.

The Mechanics' Institute Exhibition closed last night. The receipts were over $61,000. The Institute medal was awarded to the Pacific Rolling Mill Company. KOOPMANSCHAP has returned to this city. He will forward a hundred Chinamen next week to work on the Memphis and El Paso Railroad.
The Times, in an article on the Irish land question, says: "It is not our business to satisfy the Fenlans. They would not be satisfied if Ireland was doubly confiscated for their benefit.

Le Public (newspaper) says the report that the Emperor is suffering from a relapse of his former illness is false. On Friday the Emperor experienced some rheumatic pains, but on Saturday they had disappeared, and the Emperor was quite well. No meeting of the Ministerial Council has been held at Compiegne since the Emperor's return.

Intelligence from the Control Department is to the effect that a body of insurgents, while operating on the Cienfuege and Villa Clara Railroad, obstructed the track in such a manner as to cause a freight train to be run off. They then carried away the freight into the interior, and burned a bridge, thus cutting off communication between the two cities.

Secretary BOUTWELL'S bulletin of the public debt for Nov. 1, which will be cut to-morrow morning, will show another handsome decrease of debt, amounting for the month of October to over seven millions of dollars. The following are the principal features of the statement:

The Central Park meteorological report for last week sets forth the following facts and figures: Barometer, mean, 29.951 inches; maximum at 9 P. M., Oct. 25, 30.366 inches; range, .758 inch. Thermometer, mean, 40.1 degrees, maximum at 12:15 A. M., Oct. 24, 59.7 degrees; minimum at 5 A. M., Oct. 27, 30.2 degrees; range, 29.5 degrees.

LAFONTAINE tolls an amusing story of a cobbler who get a hundred crowns from a benevolent banker, and was so worried with the care of it, that he ran basic and returned it, for a quiet life. It is hardly to be expected that Mrs. General GAINES should follow the philosophy of that son of Crispin;

The tactics which have been employed by a section of the Democrats during the pending contest will not be altogether forgotten by the public when the election is over. The weapons of detraction and slander have been intrusted to hands even more unserupulous than those which are usually employed by the advocates of corruption and repudiation.

The regular mail steamer from South American ports has arrived. She brings dates from Rio Janeiro to Oct. 8. The session of the Brazilian Chambers had been prorogued. After a month's rest, during which extensive preparations were made,

We don't see that Dr. VAN VLECK can effect so very much good by his exposure of the regueries or dexterities of the DAVENPORTS, HUMES and other spiritualists. A great many persons like to have a faith in jugglery, and will be disposed, like the man HORACE speaks of,to complain that the doctor in curing them has removed their pleasant hallucinations.

Many persons have been prophesying about electricity as a motor for machinery and vehicles; and these notions have been in a remarkable degree realized by the magnetic artifice which sets so many sewing machines going. And the advance is made by Professor GAUME of this City, who has invented a battery, with magnets and armature, which can work a force pump.

We should be sorry to cast ridicule upon those advocates of "woman's rights" who restrict their demands within bounds which all the world is disposed to respect. Let women have an equal chance with men in all callings or professions--let inequalites of the laws be redressed.

"Murder will out" is a maxim which is not always sustained by facts, but there are probably few instances in which a murderer does not carry about with him "the worm that dieth not" in his own breast. The other day a man was hanged in England for killing his wife near twenty years before.

A handicap tournament, confined exclusively to members, has been in course of play at the Brooklyn chess Club since Saturday, the 23d inst. The players being divided into three classes, the first class gives the advantage of pawn and first class vies the advantage of and the knight to the third class.

AGNEW.--On Saturday, Oct. 30, WILLIAM AGNEW, in the 83th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral. without further invitation, on Monday, Nov. 1, at 12 o'clock M., from his late residence, No. 24 East 21st-st. BARRY.--At Oregon City, Oregen, on Monday, Oct, 4, MERCEIN BARRY, in the 33d year of his age.
A large audience assembled in the hall of the Cooper Institute last evening to listed to a lecture from OLIVER DYER, Esq., his subject being "What Swedenbourg Teaches as the Way to Escape Hell."

About 3 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in some rubbish under the stairs on the outside of the buildings Nos. 82 and 84 Canal-street, on the rear. No. 82, a small two-story frame, occupied by CAROLINE DIERS, was damaged about $500, but was insured for $1,500 in the Star Insurance Company.

On Friday last a young woman named ELLEN--, in a fit of jealousy, attempted to stab her lever, WILLIAM COX, the bag master of the receiving ship Vermont. Suspecting him of being unfaithful to her, ELLEN visited the Brooklyn Navy Yard that day, and going on board the ship, found WILLIAM in company with two young women.

Once more the old question comes up, How will the ex-soldiers vote? It is a question already answered this Fall in Ohio and Pennsylvania, and to-morrow it will be answered in New-York. General GARFIELD, in an eloquent speech delivered just before the Ohio election, said:

TUESDAY, Mails for Europe, via Southampton, Cherbourg and Hamburg, close a the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken to 1:45 P.M. Mails for Halifax, Bermuda, , by the City of Baltimore, close at--.

A gentleman who came down on the North Missouri Railroad yesterday informa us that several prairie fires were counted near the road, within a distance of six miles between Cairo and Moberly, as the down train passed. No estimate of the damage done could be made, but the fires seemed destructive to farms.

An election in Texas, under the reconstruction acts of Congress, has been ordered on the 30th of November next. After mature deliberation, the Committee have concluded that a State Convention is unnecessary at this time, and if held in the peculiar attitude of our political affairs would be productive of evil rather than good.

Italy reserves the right to set aside decisions of the Ecumenical Council not in accord asce with the laws and the spirit of the age. The Budget just submitted to the Spanish Cortes shows a deficit for the current year of 520,000,000 reals, but the estimates for the next fiscal year show a surplus in favor of the Treasury.

How many persons are knocked down by reckless drivers every week in this City alone! Not one-tenth of the cases get into the papers. The sufferers are carried home, and the relatives see "no use" in making their fate known to the public. On Friday evening a child, 7 years old, was killed by horse and wagon.

A propos of the question of debt-reduction versus taxation, it has been stated that had Great Britain continued as highly taxed as it was twelve years ago, a good deal more than half of her larger debt would have been paid. Since 1855 the rate of British taxation has been reduced by an annual sum equal to $125,000,000 in gold.

The rain must suspend cotton picking, but will be very welcome to the sugar planter, as in sonic places fears were beginning to be entertained for the seed cane. Grinding, too, was checked for want of water. Cotton picking has been pushed very vigorously throughout the State, planters giving it their undivided attention;

During the past week at Newton. L. L, the house of GEORGE BAKER was entered, chloroform administered to the family, and the bedchambers robbed of goods worth $500, consisting of jewelry, clothing and silver ware. The house of SAMUEL RIKER was entered and robbed in a like manner of goods to the amount of $400.

People are at present inclined to think that, instead of being two retiring and sequestered, the Chinese have grown too forward and presuming. Our citizens have been making a sort of outery on the Pacific seaboard, and wishing John Chinaman would stay in his own country; and now we perceive by the Shanghai news, that the Emperor of Austria thinks them too familiar by half.

Another squabble, resulting in attempted murder, occurred in the First Ward Saturday evening. About 9:30 o'clock THOMAS POWERS, proprietor of the saloon no. 61 Beaver-Street, got into a dispute with one THOMAS MAHER, Whereupon the barkeeper, HENRY FOLEY, took up the matter, and made an assault upon MAHER, cutting him severely on the head.

Pere HYACINTHE had the satisfaction of spending a quiet Sabbath yesterday. No visits from persons desirous of: knowing whether he prayed or not bored him from early morn until night. He arose at 5 A. M., dressed himself in the garments of an ordinary American gentleman, and went to early mass at the Catholic Church in Wet Twenty-third-street.

The steamer Idaho arrived to-day with Honolulu advices to Oct. 20. The labor question is creating much excitement and numerous meetings have been held. The planters favor the importation of Chinese. The commercial and laboring classes urge the encouragement of European immigration.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of Saturday says there will be a sufficient Republican majority in the West Virginia House of Representatives, and a large Republican majority in the Senate. Dr. TRUE, of Maine, says that the rattlesnake has not crossed the Androscoggin River, and that there are no poisonous reptiles or insects cast of that river.

The snow storm which begun on Friday continued through Saturday. It has been very severe at Lincoln. Eighteen inches fell at Mooshead Lake and down in Piscataquis County one foot. The stages are leaving Dexter on runners. Some eight or ten inches fell here, but it has mostly melted. The weather is now clear and cold. d.

The morning train from this city, which left here, on the Oswego and Syracuse Railroad, at 6-20 this A. M., had attached to the rear end the sleeping car from New-York, and on reaching a point one and a half miles north of Fulton, while running at the usual rate of speed, the sleeping car left the track,

The proofs are conclusive that wholesale frauds have been committed upon the registry in various parts of the City; the Sixth, Fifteenth and Twenty-first Wards having been especially chosen as fields for the operations of repeaters. In each the registration is suspiciously large, and in the Twentyfirst is greatly in excess of the vote cast for Governor in 1868.

A change of programme will be made at Wallack's Theatre this evening, and Mr. THOM TAYLOR'S comedy of "Still Waters Run Deep" will be acted there for the first time this season. At Niblo's, Miss LOTTA will commence a brief engagement. She will appear in "Little Nell," Mr. FELIX A. VINCENT, Mr. EDWARD COLEMAN and Miss KATE NEWTON filling the other characters in the play.

An Omaha dispatch says that parties from Salt Lake report that several Mormon dignitaries connected with the Zion Cooperative Association, have been publicly excommunicated by the Mormon Church. Considerable excitement prevailed among their friends.

CHARLES KUPPEL, of No. 4 First-avenue, was brought before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday on the charge of selling unstamped Turkish tobacco. The complaint was made by a newly-appointed detective, named SAMUEL ADLER, who testified that he noticed the tobacco in question in defendant's store, and that he bought some of it, at the same time in forming the defendant that he was liable to arrest.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM--NOV. 1. Cases argued at January, April and June Terms, At January Term before Presiding Justice Clerke, Judges Sutherland and Barnard Hoffman vs. Hoffman; judgment modified with costs to the pliantiff; order to be settled by Sutherland, J. Walsh vs. Sexton, (argued at the April term before Clerke, P. J., and Ingrabam and Peckham, J. J. Judgement reversed and new trial ordered, costs to abide the evebt; opinion by Peckham J.

Secretary BOUTWELL writes the following reason to a Boston gold broker for not selling gold hero: " I found upon inquiry that the receipts of gold at tile Boston Custom House do not exceed the payments.

The last rail of the New-York and Oswego Midland Railroad, completing the line between Oswego and Norwich, chenango County, was laid at 6 o'clock this evening, near this city, One hundred guns were fired in honor of the event.

This case came up yesterday in the Superior Court, before Judge FITHLAN, for argument. As already reported in the TIMES, the plaintiff seeks to restrain the defendant from paying certain appropriations out of the City funds on the ground that the Board of Supervisors by which the appropriation was made was illegadly constituted, he, the plaintiff, not being present as a member of such Board, by reason of not having received the proper notice.

The 1st of November schedule of the public debt of the United States shows a further reduction of the principal of the debt of seven millions three hundred and fifty thousand dollars since the 1st of October.

Sunday evening, about 6:30 o'clock, some adroit speak their entered the house of Mr. DAVID H. McALPINE, No. 9 West Twenty-ninth-street, by the basement door, which had been carelessly left ajar, and noiselessly made his way up stairs past the family, who were gathered in the basement at dinner.

ELLAS SHUNTZ was before United States commissioner SHIELDS for examination, yesterday afternoon, on the charge of smuggling $10, 000 worth of human hair into this City. The information which led to the arrest of the accused was given by his sister, who is a manufacturer of hair.
General WOOL was quite seriously injured by a fall while walking on the piazza of his residence at Troy on Saturday, but was somewhat more comfortable on Sunday. his health has recently been failing.

The Rubican arrived in port at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, from New-Orleans. among the passengers there were J. H. LYONS, second engineer, and LOUIS YOUNG, head cook of the Stonewall, and one or two others of the survivors of the late catastrophe. It is still the prevailing opinion that about 230 persons perished, and it is feared that quite a number were burned to death on the boat.
To vote the Tammany ticket to-day is to assist in plunging this City into the horrible quagmire of tar and sand which will surely overwhelm us if the concrete pavements are perpetuated and extended.

At 4 o'clock this morning an Erie Railway freight train laden with petroleum. cotton and tobacco, eastward bound, when about one mile west of this station, ran off the track wing to the breaking of a truck One of the oil car's took fire through some ??-explained cause. and almost Instantaneously the whole number of oil cars were enveloped in one sheet of flame.

The Republican platform represents the American and progressive spirit by which this country has been built up, which has carried it through many periods of difficulty and danger, by which the dissolution of the Union was prevented, and in which lie the hopes of a safe and glorious future.

"They say", declared a Democratic speaker at the meeting of that party in Brooklyn, last week, "that you have been so selfish as to appropriate all the canvassers. Well, I'm glad of it. Fight them with their own weapons."

The City Chamberlain yesterday paid out 25,652 09 interest received on public moneys, making the sum of $159,124 of received from this source during Mr. SWEENEY's term of office. The Common Council yesterday passed resolutions of condolence with the family of the late WM. J. PECK, for many years a member of the Board of Aldermen. This was the only business transacted.

The united States steamer Resaca sailed to-day for Panama. The Alta California and the San Francisco Times have been consolidated under the name of the Alfa California The San Francisco Times. The Western Pacific Railway Company have completed the Oakland Ferry landing.

Look out for fraudulent tickets! The enemy is desperate, and will shrink from no device that seems to afford a chance of success. We hear of tickets prepared for Republican use by pretended friends, with the view of defeating or electing particular candidates by the use of fraudulent lists.

The stockholders of the Hudson River Railroad Company held a meeting yesterday, at the office, corner of Thirtieth-street and Tenth-avenue, to ratify the consolidation agreed upon between the officers and directors of the two companies.

(Continuing all Amendments in Aug. 1, 1869.) The Mayer, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New-York, to Common Council convened, do ordain as follows:

Nov. 1--In steamship City of Paris, from Liverpool.--Mrs. Ashton. Miss Ashton, Mrs. Syms, Wm, Shaw, Wm. Smith. Miss Coore, James Jackson, Mrs. Holingshead, child and servant, O. H. Henrick, T. F. Thompson J. Humphreys, Mrs. Hall and 2 children, John Smith, E.W. Henry, T. A. Hampton, Mr. Hanson, Mrs. Battersly, Wm. Russell, Mrs. E. Canter, E. Martin, Robert Smith, John Bestwick, Miss II.

Sir RICHARD GROSVENOR, the Marquis of Westminster, died yesterday, aged 74. DUBLIN, Nov. 1.--A meeting was held at Limerick, last night, to discuss the fixity of land tenure. During the evening the proceedings were violently interrupted by person who shouted for amnesty to the Fenians, and, making a rush for the platform, took possession of it.

General FRANZ SIGEL, who leads the Republican State forees to-day, will undoubtedly run ahead of his ticket, and, with a fair election and a full polling of the Republican strength, he may be elected triumphantly to the position of Secretary of State.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Why should Judge CLERKE be retained in the Supreme Court of this district? The proofs of his fitness for the place have been quietly and steadily accumulating for more than forty years of extensive professional experience in our midst.

A fatal shooting affray occurred yesterday morning at Tate's Creek, eight miles from Lexington, between RYLAND TODHUNTER and JOSEPhH ROBINSON, two neighboring farmers. It seems that some' fox hunters bad torn down the fences separating the farms, and TODHUNTER'S mules entered ROBINSON'S cornfield.

Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER and lady, yesterday, visited the Brooklyn Navy-Yard. They devoted the most of their time to the receiving ship Vermont. ROBERT D. BOGART, who was handed over to United States Marshal DALLON on Friday last, has given bail in the sum of $15,000 to appear of trial to December.

ARCHER--LE ROY.--On Sunday, Oct. 31, 1869, at the residence of the bride's parents, Mount Vernon, N. Y., by Rev. Charles Seymour, GEORGE E. ARCHER, of Youkers, N. Y., to Miss HATTIE A. LK ROY, of Mount Vernon, N. Y. No cards.

Not in New-York alone are the German-Americans battling for reform. The agitation in which they are engaged has become national in its character. In nearly all our great cities they are uniting for one purpose--to secure honest, capable and responsible government.

The people of New-York will to-day indorse by their votes the Administration of President GRANT, if all who approve and rejoice in the economy, retrenchment and reform which have characterized its course, from the day of his inauguration until now, do their duty at the polls. For a full Republican vote throughout the State assures a Republican victory.
There are doubtless some Republicans who have forgotten that a registry law is not of much use unless people take the trouble to comply with its provisions, and make a proper record of their names.

The anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association, of Brooklyn, E. D.. was held in Christ Church. Bedford-avenue, Inst evening. Among the clergymen present were Rev. Dr. SOUENCK. of St. Ann's; Rev. Dr. CARROLL, of Lee-avenue Reformed Church; Rev. Dr. LEONARD;W. BACON, of the New-England Congregational Church, and others.

The registration frauds have been more extensive than we believed from the proofs at hand yesterday. At least 25,000 names are illegally upon the Doll-lists, and nearly all of them will be voted upon unless the officials and challengers do their whole duty to-day, and do it fearlessly.
The Republican journals throughout State exhibit a stronger assurance of victory and the Democratic journals more fear of defeat, than we are accustomed to look for.

In the Lower House of the Legislature to-day, Mr. WHITE offered a preamble reciting the following clause of the Constitution of Tennessee: "No Senator or Representative shall, during the time for which he was elected, be eligible to any office or place of trust, the appointment to which is vested in the Executive or the General Assembly, except to the office of a trustee of a literary institution."

The first meeting of the Club at the Casino Espanol was held on Saturday evening. Dr. BAXERES commenced to make a political speech, but the audience refused to listen, and hissed him from the tribune.

STEPHEN C. MILLER, editor of the Pulaski Democrat, died here on Sunday morning. Captain STEPHEN CORNELL, of the Revenue cutter Chase, died at Ogdensburg on Sunday morning. He was a resident of that village.

TUESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Southampton, Cherbourg and Hamburg, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:15 P. M. Mails for Halifax, Bermuda, , by the City of Baltimore, close at 11 A. M.

The Marquis of Westminster, Sir RICHARD GROSVENOR, died on Sunday in London, at the age of 74 years. A meeting in Limerick, Ireland, to discuss the land question, on Sunday night, was broken up by persons who shouted for Fenian amnesty, rushed on the platform and broke the furniture.

Bids were opened at the Treasury Department to-day for building new revenue steam cutters. The bids and bidders were as follows, and where two or more bids appear for the same class of vessels, they are for vessels of different motion, and where the engines are different. The following are for wooden vessels:
There was a very good attendance yesterday at the Exchange Salesroom. The attraction was the Supreme Court sale by Mr. J. MCGUIRE. The bidding was good ; the sale amounted to $60,000.

The examination in the case of FRANK WEBB, formerly engaged in the Weighmaster's Department, under General EGAN, was resumed before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday. The accused was charged with being a particeps criminis in the alleged preparation of fraudulent pay rolls.

A fire was discovered in the carriage factory of SHEPHERD TITUS, No. 27 Grand-street, Brooklyn, E. D., about 6:30 o'clock last evening, and the place was totally destroyed, involving a loss of $12,000; insured for $3,500. The flames extended to B. VATH'S milk depot, No. 29 Grand-street, which was damaged to the amount of $500.

An informal meeting of the New-York and Brooklyn watchcase makers was held at CARBERRY's corner of William and Ann streets, last evening, for the purpose of devising means for advertising the interest of the operatives. JOS. DUNCUFF was appointed President pro tem. and JONATHAN BLOOM Secretary.

BIRCH.--At Boston, on Monday, Oct. 25, WILLIAM N. BIRCH, of New-York, in the 70th year of his age. BROWN.--On Sunday, Oct. 31, PHENA BROWN, relict of Hori Brown, in the 82d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are repspectfully invited to attend her funeral, without further invitation, on Wednesday. Nov. 3, at 10 A. M., at the residence of her son. J. G. Brown, No. 212 6th-av.

While the critics of the Administration are deeply immersed in statistics showing how many drives General GRANT takes, how many dinners he eats, and how many cigars he smokes, another class of statistics, from another source is from time to time put before the public, also bearing on the same question of the "President's policy."

Another act in the Joslyn-Fisk drama was enacted yesterday in the Tombs Police Court, before justice DOWLING, when CHARLES C. ALLEN, a broker, was arraigned to answer a charge of perjury made by JAS. FISK. Jr., and JAY GOULD. The following affidavit was presented:

THE PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY OF NEW-YORK. The Philharmonic Society have now arranged the programme for their twenty-eighth season. It will consist of SIX concerts and eighteen public rehearsals, all at the Academy of Music.

An unusual number of American travelers are taking Vienna on their way to Italy and Constantinople. Among the recent visitors at the American Logation, have been Rev. Dr. VERMILYE, THEODORE ROOSEVELT, and Senator FENTON and daughter, of New-York, and Hon. MORTON MCMICHAEL, of Philadelphia, and son. Senator FENTON left on Wednesday for Venice and Rome.

Steinway Hall was filled with a large audience last evening to hear the eloquent blind preacher, Rev. Dr, MILBURN, deliver his lecture on the subject of his experiences in search of sight. Governor HOFFMAN, who presided, made a few remarks as to his warm personal friend a few remarks as to his warm personal friendship for and sympathy with, Mr. MILBURN,

The organ which the Messrs. ODELL. of this City, have just completed for the new rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association was tested, in presence of a select few, Monday evening, by distinguished organists of this City. The result was highly gratifying to the audience assembled, and adds another leaf to the laurel wreath which the firm named have deservedly won in their particular sphere.

Hon. CHARLES A. WICKLIEFE, formerly Governor of Kentucky, died at the residence of his son-in-law, Judge WILLIAM M. MERRICK, in Howard County, Md., on Sunday evening last. He belonged to a family several members of which have been prominent in political life in Kentucky and in the nation, but none of them were more distinguished than himself.

Another warning against the careless carriage of petroleum on railways On Monday an Erio freight train fan off the track, an oil car caught fire, and the whole train--fourteen ears--was soon a sheet for flame. " The scene presented by the conflagration was grand and fearful.

Theopinion delivered by Chief Justice CHASE in the case of THORINGTON vs. SMITH HARTLEY, is important not only by reason of the special point at issue, (namely, wheather a contract for the payment of Confederate notes by parties residing within the Confederate States can be enforced in United States Courts, andif so, on what terms,) but also in consequence of the general remarks of the Court on the political status of the Confederate Government.

The bill providing for a Constitutional Convention in Tennessee having passed both Hones of the Legislature, the friends of ANDY JOHNSON assembled in Greenville on Saturday last and nominated him for the Convention. He was the chief mover in putting the bill brought, and intends to figure largely in remodeling the affairs of Tennessee by virtue of this Convention.
The new Prussian Ambassador to France has arrived in Paris. The Montmartre Cemetery, Paris, was crowded with people. The Police were present, but their interference was not deemed necessary.

Brief dispatches by cable announced the loss of the whaling schooner Susan N. smith, of Boston, In August last. Captain JOB. P. ROUNSEVILLE, master of the vessel, has arrived in this city and is now stopping with his brother-in-law, JAMES L. CHAPMAN, Esq. From him we have a full narrative of the terrible occurrence, which is one of the most remarkable cases of shipwreck on record.

The eastward movement of fleur and grain through Ruffalo with 1858, shows an increase of 17,900 barrels of flour, and a decrease of 5,755,482 bushels of grain. The following shows the imports of flour and grain into Buffalo, by lake and Grand Truck Railway, for the mouth of October,

Although the Republicans make the handsome gain of twenty thousand in the City and five or six thousand in kings, as compared with last November, (Presidential vote,) the Republican counties come up, as a general remark, badly, the result mainly, no doubt, of a light popular vote, but in art of local divisions or personal preference on the Senate and Assembly tickets.

No one can carefully study the statement of the Phonix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford without being struck by the remarkable stops of progress made by the Company during the three years there exhibited. Ninety-seven per cent., one hundred and fifty per cent, advance in policies,

A letter appeared recently in our columns from Mr. KAPP, one of the Commissioners of Emigration, which deserves more than a passing attention. Mr. KAPP is very favorably known among our citizens as an historical scholar, and one of the most intelligent and public-spirited of the German Republican leaders.

The Board met in their chamber, number fifteen City Hall, Pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Connor, Repper, McGrath, Farley--9. The minutes of meeting held October Twenty-eight were read and approved.

Our telegrams inform as that "paris is still tranquil." The manifesto lately issued by the "Left," and incorporated in our own correspondent's letter yesterday, shows that ther never was probability of that popular rising which was announced for the 26th October.

BROWN.--At Nyack, on Sunday, Oct. 31, JULIA J., wife of Samuel Brown, of this City. Her relatives and friends are invited to attend her funeral at St. Peter's Church, Perth Amboy, N. J., on Wednesday, Nov. 3, at 2 o'clock P. M. BROWN.--On Sunday, Oct 31, at Newburg, N. Y., Mrs. HELEN M. BROWN, rellet of the late J. W. Brown, in the 32d year of her age.

A Correspondence of the Rural New-Yorker addresses the following communication to that journal; "There is a singular and wide-spread disease among cal?? prevailing in Monroe county, and perhaps other sections of western New-York. It is rarely futal as yet, but troublesome.

The quiet little settlement at the foot of the Palisades, opposite Yonkers, known as Bombay Hook, was the seene of a terrible tragedy during the small hours of yesterday morning JOHN DICKEY, an employe in McNEIL'S factory for preparing sausage cases, and his wife, lived comfortably, and, to all appearances, happily together there in a small house. ey had a few boarders.

A gentleman has left at this office a sample of an article which he purchased within a few days as a superior quality of tea. Being an old tea drinker, and compelled to use the article medicinally, his attention was attracted a few days since by the appearance of some tea at a store in the city, put up in neat packages and marked with a well-known brand.

Yesterday the salesroom was deserted The election occupied the attention of most persons, and consequently no sales were attempted. The one advertised by Messrs. A. J. BLEECKER, SON Co., was postponed; due notice will be given of the time when it will be made.

Reports reached us on Saturday morning of the burning of the Licking County Infirmary, at an early hour on Friday morning, and that ten of the inmates perished. They were locked in their cells, and the fire progressed so rapidly that no assistance could be rendered them. Later intelligence from Union Station states that the main building was not burned.

The Philadelphia Inquirer prints a letter from Mr. GEORGE WILKES, editor of the Spirit of the Times, to a friend in that city, in which, after alluding to consultations with Dr. SEQUARD in relation to his own health, Mr. WILKES says: In my conversation with SEQUARD I learned something which you may possibly and to be of value.

The French steamslup Ville de Paris, from Havre, Oct. 21 and Brest Oct. 23, reached this Port Yesterday morning. By the courtesy of Captain SURMONT, we are in receipt of late Continental papers. In the afternoon the steamship Cimbria from Hamburg Oct. 20 and Havre Oct. 23, (With papers due to the Ceurtesy of Captain HAACY.) arrived here; and during the evening the Cuba, from Liverpool Oct. 23 and Queenstown Oct. 24, touched her dock.

Cooper, wife and infant, Owen Sheridan, Mr. Hasbuck and wife, Dr. Edwin E. Denby, Captain McGill and wife, A. J. Hughes, Jno. C. Langen, P. C. Hill and wife, Mr. Corn and two infants,

This morning about 2 o' clock the rooms of the National Bank, at Greencastle, Ind., were entered by burglars by means of an " outsider" and crowbars, and attempt made to open the fire--proof vault, but were discovered before they had succeeded in the attempt. They secured about $25 worth of stamps, which were not in the vault.

A frightful accident occurred at Rolling Praitie on Monday last, which, as near as we can learn, happened as follows: A number of bands were engaged in threshing wheat at the farm of Mr. BROWN, the machine being set in the barn. JOHN NICHOLS, a son-in-law of Mr. BROWN, and son of Mrs. CLARK, of New-Carlisle, was stationed in the barn left to pitch sheaves down to the feeder.

At length the report of the Commissioners of the Union and Central Pacific Railroads has been made public be Secretary Cox, and we have official estimates of the condition and prospects of these great transcontinental highways of travel and traffic.

This Society, established but a few months ago held it regular meeting yesterday afternoon at Room No. 45, Bible House. The report for the past month was read by Rev. Dr. DEEMS, showing the Society to be in a satisfactory condition and doing a vast amount of good among the poor and needy.

The joint delegation appointed at the yearly meetings of the Friends to visit the Indian tribes, have submitted to the Indian Bureau some suggestions as "to what they consider the best means of improving the Indians. The delegation, which consisted of BENJAMIN HALLOWELL., of Baltimore, FRANKLIN HAINES,

Yesterday afternoon JOHN W. DRAPER CO., sold at auction a quantity of goods seized by Government officers, which a Mormon some time since attempted to land here without paying duty. He was accompanied by his last wife and an array of trunks which excited suspicion.

A sweepstakes tot of an interesting character between five horses came off yesterday on the Fashion Course. It was for a stake of $1,200, with six entries, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, but only the following five started--W. SAUNDERS' b. g. Western New-York; M. RODEN'S b. g. HORNDECK'S s. g. W. H. Taylor: and W. BROWN'S g. m. Lady Hamilton.

The petition for winding up the European Life Insurance Company of London, and which has been dismissed, illustrates the defects of the English system of legal supervision on behalf of the policy holders. Some shareholders asked that the Company be wound up, as not being able to pay its debts.

The Byron controversy is ended. Whatever Mrs. STOWE may have to say further can only be said in self-defence. Nothing that Lady BYRON can have said or written to Mrs. STOWE or others in later years can destroy the effect of her own letters, written to Hon. AUGUSTA LEIGH on the eve of the separation, while she was staying with Lord BYRON in Piccadilly, and subsequently.

The second meeting of this Society, organized some two weeks since for the purpose of affording assistance to such indigent and unfortunate Belgians as should apply for aid, was held last evening at Room No. 24 Cooper Institute. President LAMARCHE in the chair.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner ROLLINS at No. 24 Avenue A, over the body of CASPER SCHELLENBERGER, a German, who committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor. The deceased has a surgical operation performed on one of his legs about two years ago, since which time he suffered considerable pain, and frequently spoke of seeking a suicide death.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

The first is told as follows in the St. Paul (Minn.) Press of Oct. 29: "Some years since a lady who had been a teacher, married a missionary and went to India. Among other acquaintances, she met a gentleman connected with the British Army. In her possession were pictures of several friends and acquaintances in this State, which she exhibited to this gentleman.

A letter has been read from Captain WASHINGTON, of the Submarine No. 13, in which that officer attempts to exculpate himself from the serious charges preferred against him in reference to his conduct during the recent disaster to the Stonewall.

We are called upon this morning to make the painful announcement of the death of the venerable Rev. HEMAN BANGS, which took place yesterday at his residence, No. 90 Howe-street, after an illness lasting many weeks. Rev. Mr. BANGS had reached the advanced age of 79, and has been for many years past one of the foremost preachers of the Methodist Church in the New-York East Conference.

Mr. MARETZEK'S season began at the Academy of Music last night when " II Trovatore" was sung to a fine house and amid tumultuous applause. The performance as a whole may be said to have been characterized by tolerable discretion and tremendous emphasis, we do not remember to have heard the more salient passages of this uproarious work given with greater force and determination.

Yesterday morning, at about 6 o'clock, Mr. S. DUNNING, messenger of the American Express Company, running on the steamer Andy Johnson, upon opening his safe, in which money packages had been deposited the evening previous, found that he had been robbed of all intrusted him.

There are few in the City of Churches that have any vital faith in the $7,500,000 bridge. To forecast its benefits, or even its creation, is to talk buncombe. Nothing of it yet exists, say Brooklynites, except on paper.

It has been found necessary to station an additional number of watchmen over the ??, at the foot of Thirteenth-street, to guard against incendiaries, a number of suspicious-looking Cubans having been noticed lately loafing around the docks. ks.

The carvers of this City and vicinity held a mass meeting at the New-York Casino, Nos. 51, 53 and 55 East Houston-street. last night. Mr. HUGH HOENAK, who presided, stated the object of the meeting to be the reorganization of the Carvers' Association of this City. Dr. DOUAI, editor of the Arbeiter Union, said the times were getting worse and worse for the workingmen of this country.

The following is the essential part of Mr. GLADSTONE'S reply to the various associations which have pleaded with him for the release of the Feman prisoners: "These proceedings, i.e., the public meetings for demanding the liberation of all imprisoned Fenians, have varied much in their character. Loyal and peaceable persons have taken part in them in large numbers under the influence of feelings which deserve every respect.

The steamships Eagle, from New-York, and Yazoo, from Philadelphia, have arrived here, the former last evening, and the latter this morning. Admiral POOR, United States Navy, accompanied by American Consul PLUMB, have exchanged visits with Captain-General DE RODAS.

Rev. SAMUEL P. HALSEY was duly installed pastor of the Wall about Presbyterian Church, Franklin-avenue, Brooklyn, last evening. Rev. T. DE WITT TALMAGE preached the sermon from the text, "Walk about Zion; and go round about her; tell the towers thereof."--Psalm xlviii, 12, 10.

A Florence newspaper, Dltalic, extracts from the "Annales de la Medeciac et de la Chirurgie Etrangere" the following extraordinary history. The Italian paper, for reasons easily to be gathered, does not give implicit credence to this statement, nor lend it the editorial sanction:

BANGS.--At New-Haven, on Tuesday evening Nov. 2, Rev. HEMAN BANGS, in his 80th year. Friends are invited to attend the funeral services at the First M. E. Church, New-Haven, on Friday, 5th inst, at 2 o'clock P.M. CLISBY.--At Macon, Ga., on Monday, Nov. 1, J. H. RANSOM. son of Joseph and Celletta Clisby, aged 5 years. CORLIES.--On Tuesday evening, Nov. 2, LYDIA L. CORLIES, widow of the into Joseph W. Coriles.

I have next to nothing to write, as the trip down the coast has been almost wholly devoid of any event. The weather is hot, and on Monday night we had plenty of thunder and lightning. Mrs. FRED SEWARD was sick all the way down, and did not once appear at the table. Mr. SEWARD is in famous health and spirits, and has enjoyed the whole trip greatly.

Tuesday evening a man of respectable appearance applied for lodging at the Manhattan House, No. 29 Centre-street, having paid for which, he retired to his room. The next morning he did not appear, and the door of the room remaining locked during the day, at 8 o'clock last evening, the landlord suspecting something wrong, forced it open.
Unlike the great October elections in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Iowa, the November elections, both East and West, last Tuesday were comparatively destitute of national political significance.

The attendance at the salesroom yesterday was very light. The sales announced were quite attractive, but the election excitement probably interfered, and there were but few of the regular visitors present. Messrs. A. J. BLEECKER,

Mr. CHARLES S. SPENCER denies that he was responsible for the secret assassination of the "Judiciary article," but he admits that to that article he was opposed. Republicans in the country are satisfied with their Judges, he says, and do not wish to change the conditions under which they are elected.

When the World's reporter put into the mouth of Mr. S. S. Cox the extraordinary assertion that the national debt is now larger than at the close of the war, that gentleman indignantly repudiated the statement, and characterized as "a sham" the reporting which rendered its publication possible.

The Police Commissioners Yesterday dismissed the following patrolmen for various offences: Edward V. Adams, First Precinct; Maurice Scanlan, Seventh Precinct; Terence Shea, Tenth Precinct; John J. Kelly, Fourth Precinct; Andrew Hendry, Eight Precinct;

General PRIM to-day presented to the Cortes the members of the reconstituted Ministry. He explained that the question of the royal candidature was the cause of the Ministerial crisis, and added that the attitude of the Unionists hindered a solution of the question He declared that the Government would remain faithful to the principles to the principles of the revolution.

Mr. BERNARD SMYTH, Recover of Taxes, gives notice that in order to accommodate the large number of persons who have to pay taxes and are desirons of escaping the penalty which will be imposed on all who have not paid on the 1st of December next, he will receive checks to his order inclosed in an envelope with the tax bills, in payment of such bills.

An interesting conference of Congregational ministers of New-York and Brooklyn, and lay delegates from the several churches, was held in the Bedford Congregational Church, Rev. Mr. HUTCHINGS, pastor, Clove Road, near Pacific-street, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The multitudinous articles which were on exhibition at the American Institute Fair, are fast being removed, and the Rink begins to wear a bare and desolate look. Workmen are busily employed in taking down the ponderous machinery, the operation of which has been regarded with interest and satisfaction by thousands during the past month, and by Friday night it will be all removed.

The Brooklyn Board of Education met yesterday afternoon, Dr. THORNE in the chair. A petition from a number of citizens of the Ninth Ward asking for a new primary school, was referred to the Committee on Schoolhouses, The Finance Committee reported bills amounting to $85,993 29, which were ordered to be paid. Primary School No. 8 was changed into Grammar School No. 32.

ELIZABETH BARRY, who was arrested for stealing Colonel ?? child, was brought up for examination before the local Magistrates. She was hooted by the crowd who gathered outside the Town Hall, and an attempt to hiss her was also made in the Court itself, but of course was speedily checked.

The proceedings of this assemblage of chess amateurs have considerably increased in interest by the entrance of several more competitors for Caissan honors. Among others may he mentioned Messrs. DELMAR and TURNER, the former the victor in several tourneys, and the latter a distinguished representative of Western chess.

We regret that we are compelled to announce that Major-General JOHN E. WOOL is seriously ill and that grave apprehensions are felt in regard to his recovery. The old hero's physical powers have for some time back been undergoing a gradual prostration, and this, coupled with the accident which he suffered on Saturday afternoon last, has caused great uneasiness among his relatives and near friends.

The Parliament of Ontario was opened this afternoon by Lieutenant-Governor HOWLAND. In his speech he refers to the abundant harvest, the activity in manufactures and railway enterprises, the increased and increasing demand for labor and the success of the measures taken to promote immigration.

Senior ANTONIO MARIA DE ZEA, the Spanish Consul to Portland, who has been discharging consular duties in this City since the commencement of the Cuban rebellion, returns to his original post, and Senior BALBINO CORTES assumes the office by appointment from Spain.

The centenary of Universalism in this country was commenced last evening at Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, fifth-avenue, corner of Forty-fifty-street. There was a very large attendance. Mr. TLATT presided, and on opening the meeting congratulated them on their large attendance.

The first annual session of the New--Jersey Association of Congregational Churches began last evening at the Congregational Church in this city. The Association is composed of twenty-two churches, principally from the south of the State of New-York.

Have the advocates for restricting the negro vote by a property qualification ever contemplated the necessity of imposing an educational test upon the white citizens of this Union? If their only desire,

Under a new arrangement with the Kansas Pacific Railroad Company, J. HUGHES Co. will commence running a tri-weekly line of four-horse coaches between this city and Cheyenne Wells, to connect with trains on the Union Pacific Railroad, commencing on the 10th mst. On the 20th ult. the mail line coach from Tueson, Arizona, while on the way to Santa F6 was fired into by Indians when near Mesilla.

The deposits at the Branch United States Mint in this city during the month of October were 89,000 ounces of gold and 57,000 ounces of silver. Of the silver 28,000 ounces were received from Japan for recoinage. The amount coined during the same period was $1,670,000. Governor HAIGHT has designated Nov. 18 as Thanksgiving Day.

The Young Men's Christian Association of St. James' English Lutheran Church, East Fifteenth-street, between Second and Third avenues, announce that they have arranged for a course of lectures, as follows: Nov. 4., Rev. JNO. G. MORRIS, D. D., of Baltimore; subject, " Young Men in History."

The clergy and laity, ladies and gentlemen, of the City and vicinity will meet to-day in the Reformed Church, on the corner of Fifty-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street. Rev. Dr. SCHAFF, who has just returned from Europe, will present the results of his mission in behalf of the Evangelical Alliance to Great Britain, France, Holland, Germany and Switzerland.

The story of the tragedy enacted in the first hour of Tuesday morning on the New-Jersey shore, nearly opposite Yonkers, was briefly told yesterday morning, burdened with the version of the affair given by the murderer, which, it now appears, was false.

We are indebted to Mr. GILMER, a former resident of this city, for the information of a terrible railroad accident which occurred yesterday on the Union Pacific Railroad, between Evanston and Wasatch.

The Troy Times of last evening says that Major-General WOOL passed a quiet and painless night, and yesterday morning there was no apparent change in his condition, certainly none for the worse. The distinguished patient is fully conscious of his situation, and realizes the fact that at best he has but a short time to live.

In the month of December, 1861, HENRY WILLETTS, then Treasurer of the county of Westchester, absconded, and was at the time a defaulter to the amount of $180,000. His sureties, consisting of Darius Lyon, Robert R. Oakley Elisha Crawford, Harvey Heustis, William H. Heustis, Caleb Martine, James Hatfield,

About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a young lady of this city, MISS PET MCKAY, committed suicide by jumping into the river off the railroad bridge. The particulars of this sad occurrence, as obtained from Mr. WM. WOOD, an employe on the bridge, are as follows:

The Senate was the prize the Democracy played for on Tuesday, and,--though the result is still doubtful,--they seem to have won it. Should the official returns show a tie in that body, of sixteen Republicans to sixteen Democrats, as is not improbable, the casting vote of the Democratic Lieutenant-Governor, the President of the Senate, will settle the matter so far as concerns the nominations of Governor HOFFMAN.

Owing to the leave of absence granted by the King of Portugal to Senor MIGUEL MARTINS D' ANTAS, his Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at Washington, the Consul-General in the United States, A. DACUNHA PENEIRA DE SOTTO MAION, has been appointed Charge d' Affaires from Portugal.

The annual meeting of the Governors and Supervisors of the Woman's Hospital of the State of New-York, was held at the Institution in Fiftieth-street, yesterday afternoon. Mr. A. R. WETMORE presided, and prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. GREEN, of Boston, Short addresses were then made by Rev. W. H. MILBURN, (the blind preacher,)

In Steamship Scotia, for Liverpool--MISS C. B. Smith, General W. B. Franklin, J. W. Goddard, J. Hargreaves, Miss Gibbs, MR. Eisennman, Mr. and Mrs., Joshua Lippincott, Mr. and Mrs. Lindley Smyth, Mr. and Mrs. Hofland and maid, F. Benj. Kett, F. Amoran, Mrs. Wm. Tannenbeck and child. D.S. Schanck,

The Liberal Christians of Harlem have just completed a chapel, with rooms for social purposes, and a parsonage adjoining, making, altogether, a very unique and attractive establishment. It is in the Romanesque style of architecture, and cost about $27,000. The Chapel will seat 350 persons, and is a very tasteful affair.

THURSDAY. Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Bremen, by the steamship Rhein, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier, foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P. M.

SUMNER M. BOLTON, of the Eleventh Maine Infantry, at the battle of Bermuda Hundreds was hit by a ball over the right eyebrow, which penetrated the orbit and destroyed the sight. The wound was probed, but no ball could be found, so it was allowed to heal up.

A Council of French Ministers met at Compiegne yesterday. The Paris Constitutional of yesterday says the Dalmatian insurrection attracts a good deal of attention from the British Government at Present. The same paper says that Count BISMARCK'S influence of German politics has diminished considerably.

The meeting of the Women's Suffrage Association was held yesterday at the rooms of the Female Medical College, No. 187 Second-avenue, on account of the dangerous illness of Mrs. PHELPS, at whose residence it is ordinarily held. Miss ANTHONY, who has been attending conventions at Providence and Hartford, reported that the "work goes bravely ??" in the East.

In the Supreme Court, General Term, yesterday, the case of the People of the State of New-York vs. The Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey was argued before Presiding justice CLERKE and Judges SUTHERLAND and CARDOZO, Ex-Judge PARKER, of Albany, appeared in behalf of the Attorney-General of this State, and Mr. DIMMICK for the railroad Company.

The members of the American Institute met last evening in Room No. 24 Cooper Union, Hon. HORACE GREELEY in the chair. The most important part of the proceedings was receiving the report of the managers of the Fair just closed. By this report it appears that the gross receipts amounted to $59,216 87; the expenses paid and estimated were $44,216 07, leaving a balance of $15,000 to be turned ever to the Institute.

The Honsesmiths' Association of the City of New-York met last evening at the hall corner of Twenty-Sixth-street and Seventh-avenue, JOHN McCANN, Vice-President, occupied the chair. An election of officers to serve the ensuring six months took place, with the following result : GEORGE LINTON, President; HENRY ABLETOR, Vice-President;

The steamship Enterpe, which left this port for Havana, some time since, bearing arms and inunitions of war for the Spanish man-of-war, reached this port on her return from that city yesterday. Her voyage to Havana was successfully accomplished,

The correspondent of the Post writes as follows from Rome, concerning the expected action of the Council: "The dogmatic definition of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary will encounter no obstacle. The Pope earnestly desires the consolidation of this dogma. The erection into a dogma of the necessity of the temporal power is not considered possible by its most ardent champions.

An interesting lecture was delivered last evening in the St. James Latheran Church in East Fifteenth-street, by Rev. JOHN G. MORRIS, D. D., of Baltimore. He commenced by saying that the young men of the age are the prop of the Church and of the State. They are to be the future conservitors of commerce, literature and religion.

It cannot be too distinctly understood that the responsibility for Tuesday's defeat rests with Republicans outside of the City. In the City the part did its duty: there were unity, energy, and a success which is manifest in a largely reduced Democratic majority. The apathy and indifference which ended in disaster attached mainly to our country friends.

On Monday evening next Mr. JOHN LESTER WALLACK will make his first appearance this season in ROBERTSON'S now comedy "home". The public of New-York are greatly indebted to Mr.WALLACK for the taste, energy and liberality with which he has kept up theatrical standards in the Metropolis at a height never surpassed,

Government Detectives have recently made frequent raids on the lottery dealers in this City, arresting the on the charge of no paying a special tax on their business. One of the very latest cases is that of HARLOW E. SILL, the alleged proprietor of a "policy" shop at No. 292

"What to do with the Indian" has become a pressing problem, now that civilization has found a grand highway between the Atlantic and the Pacific, along which already pours a mighty stream of travel and traffic Our new and intimate relations with the red men will no longer suffer us to continue our Podsnappian policy of "waiving them nay."

Lake Quinsigamond, rendered famously the yearly contests between the boatmen of Yale and Harvard, was to-day the scene of another race, interesting chiefly to sporting men, The crews of the Neptune hoat of Boston and the Stephen Salisbury. Jr., boat, of Worcester, tried their muscle over a six-mile course for the championship and a stake of $500 a side. mpionship and a state of $500 a slde.

JOSEPHINE CLIFTON, a homeless woman, having made two attempts to drown herself in the North River, near Desbrosses-street, was yesterday committed to the care of the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction. Officer McSALEY, of the Sixth Ward, arrested PETER PISCT, an Italian, whom he accused of having assaulted CORNELIUS SHAY,

A report having been circulated that Governor WARMOUTH had itsued $10,500,000 in bonds, of which there is no official record, the Governor publishes a statement that all the bonds issued have been duly recorded by the Treasurer, and concludes as follows:

The following letter is published in the Austin (Nevada) Reveillee: ARGENTA, Saturday, Oct. 23, 1869. EDITOR REESE RIVER REVEILLE: On my arrival I was surprised to understand it was reported that the suspension of the First National Bank of Nevada was from my use of the bank's funds in speculation in gold in New-York--all of which is false.

A new church, just finished by the Fourth Unitarian Society, in One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street, near Fourth-avenue, was dedicated with appropriate services last evening. Rev. T. W. CLARKE, pastor, opened the services in a short address, inviting all liberal Christians to join in making this a refuge.

The county Press has teemed for a week or two with rumors of the failure of several large capitalists and property-holders in San Francisco, and to-day we have a dispatch from Treasure City which connects the name of ALVINA HAYWARD with these rumors, and states that the report in relation to him had caused a short run on the branch of the Bank of California, in which institution he is a stockholder.

Before the war the State of Virginia had made very considerable progress in the organization of her agricultural interest by means of a system of societies and clubs, which, having for its foundation neighborhood associations of ten or a dozen farmers, contemplated the grouping of these into county societies, and these again into district societies; and, comprehending and crowning the whole, the State Society.

The preliminary meeting for taking into consideration what measures should be adopted for making successful the proposed World's Conference of the Evangelical Alliance, was held at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, in the Reformed Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth street. Hon. WM. E. DODGE, presided. A large auditory, composed in great part of ladies, was present.

Advices from Cattaro state that the troops, after a battle which lasted four hours, defeated the rebels and captured a strong position which had been occupied by them near Lisie. The population of two districts had surrendered to the Austrian authorities.

Last evening the Reform Club met at Plimpton Hall, and its purposes were enlarged upon by Mr. IRA B. DAVIS. He announced the alarming fact that Christianity and all human institutions thus far are a failure, and it is necessary to institute an entirely new order of things.

A Madrid dispatch says Admiral TOPETE insists on tendering his resignation as a Cabinet officer, but the Regent declines to accept it. A new Cabinet may become necessary. The Cortes has again adjourned. The contemplated meeting between the Emperor of Austria and the King of Italy, according to a London dispatch, is to take place in the latter part of this month, at Brindisi, in Italy.

Commander Cox, of the English man-of-war Philomel, died yesterday The steamer Washington, from St. Nazaire, has arrived at this port. JACMEL, Oct. 24, ria HAVANA, Nov. 4.--General CHEVALIER, President SALNAVE's Secretary of War, after besieging the town of Jacmel for a fortnight, was compelled to raise the slege and march on the revolutionary forces of General BRUCE, who was advancing on the City of Portaa-Prince. General BRICE had alread captured the town of Miragoane.

About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a middle-aged man, named PETER FERDON, a Vagrant, crept under one of the archways at the furnace at the Union-street dock, in Poughkeepsie, for the purpose of sleeping there till daylight. The place is a resort for vagrants who have nowhere to go, because it is warmed by steam pipes running through it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The United States law relating to steambonts requires a steamer like the Stonewall to have at least three good metallic lifeboats, besides life-preserving apparatus. The penalties for not complying with the law are very heavy, besides which the Government has appointed a large number of Inspectors at good salaries to see that it is complied with, and who are subject to heavy penalties for not doing their duty.

Hon. JOHN CHURCHILL, Chairman of the Sub-Election Committee charged with the investigation of the South Carolina cases, arrived here last night, and the Committee will meet to-morrow to determine whether, under the circumstances, they are obliged to comply with the order of the House.

The remains of Ex-Governor CHARLES A. WICKLIFFE, of Kentucky, reached here this morning, and left at 3 o'clock this afternoon for Bardstown. In respect to his memory the Courts adjourned. and the members of the Bar passed the usual resolutions of regret and sympathy. A letter from Southern Kentucky says:

The Anniversary Committee of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, have issued the following circular in relation to the approaching anniversary: 1. The General Missionary Committee will meet at the Mission Rooms, No. 805 Broadway, New-York, on Thursday, Nov. 11, 1869, at 10 o'clock in the morning.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It was the boast of the Roman matron when asked to exhibit her jewels, to point to her children, and with equal pride the parent Society in this country announces so frequently the birth of similar institutions in the United States, the offsprings of its own good example.

While a party of priests and others were returning from a land meeting in Cavan they were attacked by persons lying in wait on the roadside, and were brutally beaten. One has since died from his injuries. The assault is generally considered an Orange outrage, and a Coroner's jury has brought a verdict of murder against seven Orangemen implicated in the affair.

The Williamsburg Chess Club, although a recent organization, counts among its members some celebrated chess players. Among others may be mentioned Major WERNICH and Baron VON FRANKENBERG, both of whom obtained prizes in the tournament recently held at the Cafe Europe.

With all the talk of labor organizations in New-York about corrupt politicians, they seem to fail when their announced principles are put to the cost. They remain given over to the very politicians when they denounced before election day.

On Wednesday night the depot of the Long Island Railroad Company at Hunter's Point was entered by thieves, who on being detected by the watchman, seized him, and after binding and gagging him, placed him in the water closet, and one of them remained on watch.

Yesterday the petition of the California Pacific Railroad Company (Valley Railroad) for the requisition of certain lands in this city, and the right to cross the tracks of the Central Pacific Railroad Company, came up for hearing in the Sixth District Court, on the question of granting the prayer of petitioner for the immediate possession and use of the premises mentioned in the petition.

Admiral TOPETE insists upon tendering his resignation as one of the Cabinet. The Reagent refuses to accept it, but the Admiral firm in his determination to withdraw. It is probable that the whole Cabinet will resign, and that General PRIM with form a new one.

A Circuit Court was opened yesterday by Judge BARNARD for the purpose of trying one of the notorious suits known as CHAMPLIAN BOWEN et al. vs. NELSON CHASE et al. There are about four actions pending, all depending upon the same questions of law and fact, and all arising out of the provisions of a certain will alleged to have been made b Mme. JUMEL a short time prior to her death.
There was a time when a double murder like that which was committed on the banks of the Hudson last Tuesday, would have sent a painful shock throughout the community.

The exhibition of the new organ in the First Reformed Church, Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, E. D., took place last evening. The vocal performances were volunteered by the accomplished choir of Christ Church, in the same avenue, and the selections, which were from Rossini, Auber, Handel, Weher, Hayde, Hosse and Mendelssohn, were rendered with marked ability.

An alternation occurred on Wednesday at Yonkers between RICHARD BRODERICK, a teamster, and PETER WHALEN, a hatter, which resulted in BRODERICK being stabbed twice in the abdomen and right arm. The injured man was carried to his home. His wounds, although f a serious character. It is believed will not proved fatal. WHALEN fled immediately after committing the assault.

BOND-HAZARD.--At Enfield, Conn., on Wednesday, Nov. a, E. W. BOND, of Springfield, Mass, to FANNY, daughter of the late A. G. Hazard. HYATT--HARDING.--In Brooklyn, at the residence of the bride's father, on Tuesday, Nov. 2, by Rev. H. M. Storris, HENRY A. HYATT of Cincinnati, to Miss NELLIE M. HARDING, of Brooklyn, late of Cinnati.

The City of Nashua recently purchased a steam fire engine, and the location of the steamer caused some feeling between the different sections of the city. This morning the steamer's house was discovered on fire. The house, the engine, two hose carriages, with the hose, and a hook-and-ladder truck were totally destroyed.
Hon. THOMAS F. BOWIE, at one time quite a prominent politician of Maryland, died at his residence in Upper Marlborough, Prince George's County, that State,

Considerable interest is already felt by the Bar of this City as to the man whom Governor HOFFMAN will select to fill the seat on the Bench of the Court of Common Pleas, to he made vacant by the transfer of Judge BRADY to the Supreme Court.

The colored citizens of Baltimore and the State of Maryland are celebrating the anniversary of Emancipation with great enthusiasm. The procession is several miles in length, and is composed of number of benevolent societies in full regalia, on horses and in carriages, trade associations on platform wagons and on foot,

Nov. 4--In steamship Cambria, from Glasgow.--Mr. Duke. Rev. R. C. HALL, Mrs. Cerdell, Mrs. Thos. Perteous, Mrs. Nulands, Captain John Sunith, Rev. Bishop Falconer, Mr. and Mrs. Crannage, Miss Dunlop, Mrs. Fawns, Mrs. Ewing, Miss Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Silver, D. Mossman, Chas. McKay, Dr. John Graham, Peter Tayler, Allen Moore, Mrs. John Leggatt, John Duff, John Cashill, Miss Moore, Mr. Thuna, Mrs. W. P. Cowan, Miss Jane Walker,

The prize fighters are in trouble here. ALLEN and BACK US refuse to accept MURRAY, of St. Louis, as final stakeholder. BILL CARROLL came here last night for the purpose of selecting some one who would be satisfactory to both parties. McCOOLE insists upon MURRAY, and the difficulty threatens to break up the McCoole-Allen fight.

JOHN C. HALLEY, Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue in Oakland, is supposed to have absconded by the last steamer to Panama. He is a defaulter to the Government in the sum of $1,600. The report of the Montgomery-street Extension Commissioners will soon be published. The damages apparaised aggregate $2,000,000.

The Conservative Republicans of the Fourth District of Texas have nominated General HORACE BOUGHTON, formerly of this State, for Congress. His ancestors were among the earliest settlers of the valley of the Genesee. He distinguished himself early in the war as an officer of the Rochester regiment, which went to the first Bull Run 1, 000 strong and came out reduced to 200.

Are the Spaniards correct in claiming an early flate for the revolution inaugurated at Yara, or is this merely a lull before the storm? The Spanish element is more sanguine of success than at any time within the past ten months; not only the authorities, but also the public at large are confident of an early termination of the war.

A regular meeting of the Chamber was held yesterday afternoon, Ex-Mayor OPDYKE in the chair. J. L. HALSEY, CHAS, SMITH, E. M. WRIGHT and LUTHER KOUNTZE were elected members of the Chamber. Mr. LATHROP, whose term of office as member of the Arbitration Committee had expired, was unanimously reelected.

The Discret News, published at Salt Lake City, and the official organ of BRIGHAM YOUNG, prints in its Issue for Oct. 26, the following notices: To whom it may concern: This certifies that WM. S. GODRE, E. L. T. the Church of Latter-day Saints on Monday, the 25th day of October, 1869, by the High Council of Salt Lake City, for harboring and spreading the spirit of apostacy. .

CORLIES.--On Tuesday evening Nov. 2. LYDIA D. CORLIES, widow of the late Joseph W. Corlies.

The Committee of the Preshyterian General Assembly, O. S., which has been in session for some time past investigating the affairs of the Theological Seminary, closed its labors last evening. The longstanding disagreement between Rev. Dr. LORD, Divinity Professor in the North Western Theological School, and C. H. McCormick, has been brought to an end by a compromise satisfactory to both parties.

We believe the Judiciary article of the proposed new Constitution was lost on Tuesday mainly through the indifference or hosmtility of Republicans; and that this indifference or hostility was mainly the fault, as we have intimated once or twice before, of the Bar.

The salesroom yesterday presented quite a bright appearance. The contrast between it and the previous day was very marked. The election excitements had evidently passed over, the attendance was good, the bidding brisk and the prices obtained very satisfactory.

Hon. HENRY SMITH, of the Board of Supervisors, was presented with a handsome Maltese Cross, last evening, by a large number of members of the Lincoln Club, of which he was the founder. The presentation took place at the Lincoln Club Rooms, at Union-square, being preceded by a very choice collation. Nearly one hundred well-known gentlemen were present on the occasion.

A bill has passed its second reading, in the Tennessee Assembly, providing in its first section-- "That hereafter it shall he lawful to contract for any rate of interest, provided that the rate of interest be in writing, and expressed in the face of the instrument creating the principal debt or obligation."

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner FLYNN, at Bellevue Hospital, over the remains of EDWARD CALLAHAN, aged 19, a plumber, who died from lockjaw caused by his thumb being cut off, on the 26th ult., by a circular saw. Verdict in accordance.

Midnight.--The great philanthropist, whose name is familiar on both sides of the Atlantic, is dead. He expired at his residence in Eaton-square, this city, at 11:30 o'clock to-night. He had returned to London only a short time ago from the South of France, whore he had gone in the hopes of regaining his health. The news of Ins death is received here with profound regret.

State Fairs and commercial Conventions are becoming much more common than ever they were before, and we regard the circumstance as one of the most promising of all the "signs of the times." The special industries of each district are brought into prominence, and the inventor or the ingenious artisan enlarges his opportunities of finding profitable markets.

Too little importance is generally ascribed to the beautiful and efficient science of life insurance by the great mass of the responsible public. Admiral TOPETE has positively refused to withdraw his resignation, and it has been reluctantly accepted. The Democrats and Progressists are holding a joint conference to discuss the situation and adopt common course of action. The critical condition of affairs creates much public anxiety.

The Privy Council of England, by an order dated July 30, 1868, made a change in the rules previously adopted to prevent collisions at sea. The Court went out hunting yesterday at Compiegne. The Emperor was not present. One of the electoral meetings held last night was dissolved by the Police. HENRI ROCHEFORT, the editor of the Lanterne, set out from Brussels yesterday on his return to Paris.

SUPERIOR COURT--SPECIAL TERM--NOV. 5. By Judge Flihian. Samuel Kidd et al. vs. William P. Shaw et al motion granted and commission issued. Nathan Mestler vs. Mansah Mestler; motion granted and cause referred. George Hubert vs. Bernard McIntyre; judgement for defendant on the demurrer, as frivolous, with leave to defendant to answer within ten days, on payment of costs.

This morning, at 10 o'clock, ground was broken on the Fremont and Elkhorn Valley Railroad. A large force of graders were on the ground, and immediately went to work. Ten miles of this road will be completed this year. MEMPHIS, Nov. 5.--Messrs. DENT and ALCORN closed the canvass in Mississippi at Holy Springs yesterday.

The Democracy of Kings County are playing a desperate and shameless game. They chose their own partisans for election officers last Tuesday, and manipulated the ballot boxes with a characteristic indifference to the rights of Republicans and the decencies of a political contest.

The Steamship Eutorpo, which arrived in this harbor a few days ago from the West Indies, with several cases of yellow fever on board is still detained at Quarantine, and will remain there for some time. Those on board having yellow fever were in the best possible way of recovery yesterday morning, and the Captain is so well that he has been able to move about and take charge of his vessel.

The Ladies' Aid Society for the election of German Hospital, corner of Fourth-avenue and Seventy-seventh-street, held a meeting at the Steuben House yesterday afternoon, Mrs. FRANCISCA KLEIN presiding. In consideration of the hospital being finished now, and having been put in use lately, they resolved to take out a new charter and to form a society for providing poor sick persons in this City with medical treatment.

We noted the other day the remarkable decision of Chief Justice CHASE concerning the validity of con tracts made in Confederate currency--whether such contracts could be enforced in the Courts of the United States and, if so, whether the contracts were payable in Confederate Treasury notes (which are now cheap) or in United States money.

An expedition, composed of troops and volunteers, recently left this city by sea and land to surprise a strong body of rebels at Cienaga de Zapata. No news has yet been received of the result. The Diario doubts the success of the movement,

The dangers arising from collisions at sea have very largely increased both in number and in the damages which they cause, in these later years. The English Wreck Register for 1865 gave the number of collisions in the seven previous years as 2,344, which is nearly one for every day in the year.

An examination was held before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, in the case of FREDERICK WHITTON, charged with passing counterfeit money. Assistant District-Attorney PURDY appeared for the Government.
