Madrid dispatches report that the opposition to the Duke of GENOA for the throne of Spain is daily gaining strength. The Democrats and Progressists had a meeting yesterday to discuss the situation, which is regarded as critical. The resignation of Admiral TOPETE has been reluctantly accepted.

The greatest salvage case on record in our American Courts has at last been decided, and for the last two days our lawyers have been busy dividing the large amounts by them received among their numerous clients, most of whom, we are glad to state, belong to the numerous class of ?? and stevedores.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to geliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent. News packages for the Journal of commerce, Times, Tribune, World, Sun, Express, Evening Post, Commercial Advertiser.

Tuesday's elections show that the prohibitionists people made good their threat to have a hand in State politics whenever they could; and their work is visible from Massachusetts to Minesota. So far, however, as can now be seen, their main achievement has been to damage their own cause.

HENRY WILLIAMS and JEROME JACKSON, both colored, quarreled in Grand-street, at an early hour yesterday, about tobacco, and JACKSON was stabbed in the neck by WILLIAMS. The wound was a severe one, and after it had been dressed at the Eighth Precinct Station House the injured man was conveyed to his home by his friends. WILLIAMS was committed to await the result of the injuries.

The following is a list of plans for new buildings submitted to the Superintendent of Public Building since our last report: Plan No. 1, 132--One five-story brick tenement house, 25 by 54, on Ninety-second-street, north side, 75 feet west of Third-avenue; owner, F. J. GETS.

The Utica Observer claims for GEORGE SANFORD, the Democratic candidate for Senator in the Nineteenth district, a majority of eight votes. Five of these votes were cast for GEORGE H. SANFORD. Hon. CHARLES J. FOLGER, Republican, reelected Senator in the Twenty-sixth District, ran about 500 ahead of his ticket in Ontario County.

The notorious saloon of HARRY HILL , No. 16 West Houston-street, was last evening the scene of a disgraceful affray, during which the proprietor received two severe stab wounds. It appears that NELLIE SMITH and JENNIE COLLINS, two of the abandoned women who frequent the place, have on several late occasions created a disturbances in the saloon, and in each case were ejected from the premises.

The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-Place, on Thursday, the 4th inst., at 3:30 P. M.: JAMES LENOX, Esq., President, in the chair, assisted by WILLIAM, JAMES SUYDAM and A. ROBERTSON WALSH, Esqs., Vice-Presidents. .

Yesterday was the anniversary of the day of the famous (or infamous) Gunpowder Plot, when, about 300 years ago, a lunatic, denominated GUY FAWKES, thought he would be doing God's service by blowing up the House of Parliament with all its loyal contents.

The merchants of Liverpool, having long age distanced the merchants of New-York in the establishment and successful working of ocean steam lines, are now rapidly running ahead of London, which, with its out port of Southampton, once had the lead in ocean steam navigation.

A terrible gale, with rain and select, has been prevailing here since early this morning, and it is feared that much damage has been done on the Lake. The bark Plymouth, from Hamilton, Canada, loaded with wood and staves, was wrecked on the breakwater this afternoon. Her crew were saved on a raft.

Yesterday, Fire-Marshal BEACKETT submitted his monthly report to the Commissioners of Police, from which it appears that in October, in this City, there were fifty fires--of these: Four were caused by kerosene; eleven by care lessness of ocenpants and employes; two by children playing with matches; eight were of unknown origin;

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER over the remains of CORNELIUS SHAY, who died from the effects of injuries sustained through violence, as proviously reported, CHRISTOPHER McGUIRE, a bartender at No. 500 Pearlstreet, being accused of the assault, though subsequent developments proved his innocence.

The directors of the Central Underground Railway held a meeting yesterday, at which Mr. WILLIAM A. WHITBECK, one of the directors, who has lately returned from Europe, made the following interesting statement : The aggregate length of underground railways in operation in London is about ten miles.

The political news today is not important. To-morrow will be recognized as a holiday in London, and the Exchange will not be open for business. Queen VICTORIA will visit the city to open a new bridge and viaduet.

It is about time for us to look over our Pacific Railway investments, and see what we have done, what remains to be done, and what lessons the experience may teach us. There was a rippling sensation in home and foreign money markets some time since in reference to Pacific Railway securities, but it has died away.

Mr. MULLETT, Government Architect, on his recent brief visit to this City, expressed himself well satisfied with the progress of the work on the new Post Office. The Superintendent's report for October shows that during that month 23,243 cubic yards of dirt were removed, 1,205 cubie yards of concrete laid, and 6,666,900pounds of wall built.

The safe of the Dorchester Insurance Company at Neponset was broken open last night by burglars, and a large amount of money taken. The safe was opened by drilling through it and then blowing it open with gunpowder. As near as can be estimated, the loss will amount to $20,000 or $30,000.

The official report of the recent attack on the mail and the murder of Colonel STONE by the Indians at Apache Pass, Arizona, states that the attack was made after night, and was a complete surprise. The Indians were led by white men.

DONIZETTI'S well-known opera of "Lindadi Chamounix" afforded an opportunity last night for the reentrance of Miss KELLOGG, and for Signor RONCONI to appear in one of those original characters in which he first made his great reputation. Ex-President JOHNSON gave a banquet to the members of the Legislature at the Staley House to-night. Governor SENTER, Senator FOWLER and the members, and other distinguished citizens were present. It was one of the most agreeable entertainments ever given in Nashville, and everything passed off pleasantly.

BOOTMAN.--On Thursday, Nov. 4, ELIPHALET BOOTMAN, in the 66th year of his age. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from St. John's Chapel, (Varick-st.,) on Saturday afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock, without further notice. The remains will be taken to Newburg for interment.

There was a very fair attendance at the salesroom yesterday. But two sales were made, amounting in all to $93, 420. The four-story house and lot, No. 29 Park-avenue, sold for $53,000. The other sales were unimportant. To-day the auctioneers and regular attendants will have an interval of rest; no sales will be attempted, and the echoes of the cheerful basement will not be disturbed.

The following anecdote of Admiral FARRAGUT, we believe, has not appeared in print. While at New-Orleans the officers of the Susquehanna, probably desirous of going North, represented the ship as greatly in need of repairs. A board of survey was appointed to examine and report on her condition.

Postmaster-General CRESWELL is still anxious to carry out the changes in the present letter delivery system which he proposed some time ago. Ills plan is to so perfect the delivery of letters by carriers that even business men with prefer to receive their mails in that way rather than by sending to the Post Office.

A meeting of the promoters of the scheme for a Woman's Parliament was held at Packard's Rooms, corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, yesterday afternoon. Most of the leading ladies in the woman's suffrage movement were present. Gentlemen were vigorously excluded from the meeting, but it is understood that the necessity for forming a permanent organization was warmly urged.

It is remarkable that of the past events which stand forth prominently in our recollection, disasters and crimes should be among the chief. The year of "the panic," of "the great fire," of "the famine," of the "awful murder," are move distinetly recognized by those occurrences than almost anything else, excepting, of course, such as those in which we have borne a personal share.

The other day a lecture was delivered in Brooklyn on the present mode of dress, with special reference to evil effects of tight lacing. It is said that more than six hundred young ladies assembled to hear this discourse--a striking testimony to the interest of the subject, and perhaps to the ability of the lecturer, who was a lady.

The dispatch we publish this morning anounces that the Belgian Government has made the desired concession to an American company for laying a new ocean cable from Ostend to some point on the Atlantic coast between Maine and Georgia.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Nov. 6.--The books of the Treasury this afternoon showed the coin balance to be $112,669,101 75, in which are included $31,463,320, the amount of outstanding gold certificates. The United States frigate Albany, Captain WATCH commanding, left the Navy Yard for the West Indies on Friday night. When passing the Battery she run into the United States School shin Saratoga. The latter vessel sustained but slight damage, but the Albany had her rigging so severely damaged that she had to put back for repairs.

HAVANA, Nov. 6.--The regular mail steamer from Vera Cruz arrived at this port to-day, bringing dates from the City of Mexico up to the 29th of October. Governor SEWARD had arrived at Guadalajara. He was everywhere received with enthusiasm. He was expected to arrive at Mexico on the 4th Grand preparations were making to receive him.

The unmitigated nuisance which has been plastered over the pavement of Fifth-avenue can no longer be tolerated by the people residing along that thoroughfare, even on the pretence of an experiment. It has been thoroughly tested and found altogether wanting in every particular essential to a good roadway, except that of a temporary smoothness.

The crowd in attendance to-day was much greater than yesterday. All through the day yesterday and this morning visitors were pouring into the City. The hotels and boarding-houses literally swarm, and there are few private residences that have not had their hospitality pat under requisition.

The Sags in London were yesterday placed at half mast, and many building in the city raped in mourning, as a mark of respect to the memory of the late GEORGE PEABODY. Queen Victoria opened the new bridge and viadnet in London yesterday, with State ceremonies, in the presence of a great concourse of people. The houses were decorated, and the day observed as a general holiday.

An English paper says that photographic portraits can now be printed with printers' lnk. They are as permanent as a printed text, and so easy of production that 12,000 may be produced from a single plate in one day. The death of the eminent critic, SAINTE BEUVE, makes the second empty seat in the French Academy.

M. in the green room, and swept all before it. The block was owned by KEELER MCALPINID who lose $20, 000, and have an insurance for $15, 000. RAPALJE, seed merchant,

A young clergyman in Philadelphia recently made himself a brilliant momentary reputation, by preaching two of Dr. CHANNING'S sermons as his own. Bishop GREEN, of Mississippi, is lying ill at the residence of a friend at Lynehburg, Va.

Ireland is becoming the experimental arena of English politics. The principle applied to the settlement of the Church question will, at no distant day, be revised with reference to the English and Scotch establishments, and the future of the voluntary association which new represents Protestant Episcopacy in Ireland will have a material influence on the destinies of the State Churches in the sister Kingdoms.

LONDON, Nov. 6--The death of Mr. PEABODY occurred so late on Thursday evening (11:30) that the fact could not be widely published until to-day. His death is universally regretted. Flags flying at half-mast, buildings draped in various parts of the city and other evidences of mourning attest the public sorrow.

An examination was held before United States Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday, in the case of J. H. SCHROEDER and ISIDORE M. BON, jointly charged with complicity in smuggling cigars into this port. Testimony was given by JOHN A. ALLARAU to the effect that he smuggled about 20,000 unstamped Havana cigars into this City,

There was a trot at the Union Course yesterday. between HOWE'S bay gelding and T. JACKSON'S black mare Topsey. The day was line and the track in capital order. In the pools, the bay gelding had the call at about two to one. The attendance was good.

In the gold cases, wherein the property of JAS. FISK, Jr., was attached, and reports of which have already appeared in the TIMES, additional lis pendens have been filed, covering not only the Opera House property, but also some leasehold property the same block. ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 6.--Governor HOFFMAN last night, in the course of his speech, in response to a serenade by the "Jacksonians," said : "I notice that most of the Redial papers in Albany and New-York are asking 'What will they do with it'--that is, with the victory.

United States Marshall HARLOWE has appointed FOSTER SWIFT, M. D., physician to the United States prisoners and witnesses detained in custody in this City, in place of E. B. DALTON, M. D., resigned on account of ill health.

A reliable gentleman, officially connected with one of the prominent railway lines of the country, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, direct from Salt Lake. He informs us that there is trouble in the Mourn on brotherhood, and that four of the most able and influential elders have been excommunicated for giving expression to an indorsing utterness adjudged by the great lawgiver of the Mormons to he heterodoxical and schismatic.

THE OPERA AT THE ACADEMY. Mr. MARETZEK'S Italian Opera Troupe has been very successful thus far, the attendance having been numerous and fashionable, and the new singers quite up to the mark of public expectation. Among the strangers, the new tenor, M. LEFRANC, has produced the most decided impression, his at de poitrine having thrown his audience into transports of approbation when ever heard.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The TIMES of the 30th ult., contains an excellent article on "Wines," which represents the case of wine production in general more correctly and impartially than we frequently find it.

"Home" (its first performance) and " A Regular Fix" will be given, with the cooperation of Mr. LESTER WALLACK, at Wallack's Theatre. " Poor Humanity" will be acted for the first time by Mr. W. HOLSTON and the regular company at the Olympic. At the Fifth-avenue Theatre "Much Ado About Nothing" will be rendered.

Senior JOSE MORALES LEMUS, the Cuban Envoy to this country, arrived in this city yesterday from Washington. He received a large mall from the Cespedes Government by the last steamer, and thus is possession of late news from nearly every jurisdiction of the island claimed by the revolutionists. s.

The are twenty-five Spanish gunboats at the Delamater Iron Works, at the foot of west Thirteenth-street, to which will be added five more this week. They are to leave Mystic to-day of to-morrow. Where they were built, and will be towed hither to receive their machinery and be fitted out according to the terms of the contract.

The revival of several of the agricultural societies in this State and the success of their exhibitions this Fall are favorable auguries of a rapid recuperation. During the month of October fairs were held at Danville, Lynchburg, Wytheville, Lexington, Staunton and Leesburg, all, I am told, well attended, and the display at each was very satisfactory.

About 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning Officer WILLIAM FLANNERY, a married man, aged 30, a native of Ireland, and a member of the Eleventh Precinct Police, left the Station House on his way home. As he passed No. 115 Columbia street FLANNERY noticed Miss CAROLINE MYERS, aged 17, endeavoring to get into the house, she having been accidentally locked out.

The Albany Journal cellbends that Mr. SPRINGSTEED, Republican, has: been fairly elected to the Assembly from the First District of Albany County. Whether he will be counted out remains to be seen. If not the Democratic majority will be fourteen.

At a meeting of the Free Trade League of this city, held last evening, Professor PERRY spoke on the subject of "Freedom in Trade." DETROIT. Nov. 7--A meeting of the advocates of protection to home industry was held in the City Hall last evening.

During the week just closed the market has not been very well supplied. The most of the sales of City property have been made by order of referees or trustees, being these of obligation rather then choice, showing that property owners who can use their own discretion are not disposed to risk their real estate in the market at this season.

The Secretary of the Navy has received intelligence of the death of the venerable Rear-Admiral CHARLES STEWART, f the "Ironsides" Constitution frigate fame, which occurred at Bordentown, N, J, yesterday at 3 o'clock. Admiral STEWART was 92 years of age, and had saved 71 years, having entered the navy as a Leiteunant on the 9th of March, 1798.

Skilled detective, on Saturday, arrested in this city and Troy the parties implicated in the extensive express robbery on the Central Railroad, between this city and Fonda. One of the parties arrested is CHARLES B. CONKLIN, the baggageman, who was once before arrested in NEW-YORK AND discharged upon a writ issued by a judge of that City.

The regular mail steamer from Vera Cruz arrived at this port to-day bringing dates from the City of Mexico up to the 20th of October. Governor SEAVARD had arrived at Guadalajara. He was every where received with enthusiasm. He was expected to arrive at Mexico on the 4th. Grand Preparations were making to receive him.

The Archbishop of Paris, in a pastoral letter on the Ecumenical Council, maintains that the French Concordat is opposed to any settlement of the question of the infallibility of the Pope without discussion. The Spanish Unionists and Progressists are in a state of inharmony on more questions than the selection of a Sovereign--the oath to support the Constitution,

The card of the Pacific and Atlantic Telegraph Company of the United States, published in another column, sets forth that to-day the Company will signalize the opening of their new offices in the City and Chicago, by reducing the rate for messages between the two places from $1 75 to $1 50.

There is a rumpus in the "Camp of Israel." and the "Saints" are troubled. But it bodes will for the dawning freedom of thought and of conscience among this deluded and fanatical people. The editors and proprietors of the Utah Magazine have just been excommunicated from the " Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints." For attempted fee expression of thought on purely secular matters.

The joy with which a decisive victory has inspired the Democrats of New-York is not wholly free from misgivings. The mass of them shout and are happy. They picture to themselves absolute control of profitable offices, of all the avenues to legislation, of the treasury of the State, and the vast expenditures of which this City is the scene. The prospect renders them almost wild that exultation.

Hon. HORACE GREELSY delivered a temperance lecture last evening at Botame Hall, No. 08 East Broadway, before the Standard Division of the Sons of Temperance. There was a large audience. Mr. GEO NEALEY occupied the chair.

On Tuesday next, the 9th inst., one of the most heartless crimes recorded in the criminal annals of our State will be expiated on the gallows at Concord. JOSHUA L. BROWN, the murderer of Mr. and Mrs. THOMAS BROWN, an aged couple who resided in Harapton Falls, N. J., about six miles from Exeter,

We took occasion the other day to refer to the spirited and persistent way in which the Jersey City Times had been urging upon the National Guards the importance of taking up target practice in carnest, with the view to improve the present low standard of marksmanship.

Detectives HURLBERT and KIRKE, of the Troy Police, arrested two notorious burglars in this City last night, on a charge of having, on the night of the 4th inst., feloniously entered the residence of Hon. JOHN S. FLAGG, Ex-Mayor of Troy, and stealing therefrom a quantity of diamond jewelry, valued at $3,000.

The advent of cold weather is a time of peril to this City. As statistics show, there is then always a large increase in the number and destructiveness of conflagrations. This year, during the last week in October, there were twenty-six alarms of tire, four human lives were destroyed, and property valued at $300,000 was consumed.
The Inman steamship City of Brooklyn, from Liverpool Oct. 28 and Queenstown Oct. 29, arrived at this port last evening. Her news is later by three days than that at hand by the Donau on, Friday last.

The delegates of this association held a meeting at No. 10 Stanton-street yesterday afternoon, Mr. CHARLES WELTZ presiding. The proceedings of the Convention of the International Tailors' Protective and Benevolent Union of the United States and Canada held at Pittsburgh, Penn., in August last, which have been published as a pamphlet, were read by Mr. ROBERT BLISSERT in English and Mr. JACOB MORSTADT in German.

Two electoral meetings were dissolved yesterday by the Police. Both assemblages dispersed quietly, offering no resistance to the officers. HENRI ROCHEFORT has arrived in Paris. Last night he addressed an electoral meeting. He is nominated as sole candidate for the Corps Legislatif from the First Ward of Paris.

Superintendent KENNEDY received through the mail yesterday a copy of the following circular, the person sending it stating that the document had been extensively circulated throughout the Union. The letter is a curiosity in its way: OFFICE OF NOYES Co., NO. 63 WALL-STREET, NEW-YORK, 1869.

A dispatch from Washington this morning announces the death of this distinguished veteran at his residence at Bordentown, N. J., on Saturday afternoon. Admiral STEWART was among the last of those heroes whose names form the connecting links in the great epochs of the country's history. He was born in Philadelphia, on the 25th of July.

The free letter delivery system goes into effect about the 15th of November. The city has been divided into seventeen districts, and a portion of the letter carriers will be furnished with horses. There were seven murders and suicides in this city during the past week.

The following letter in regard to a further reduction of postage between the United States and Denmark, Sweden and Norway explains itself, Colonel JOHNSON is chief engineer of the Northern Pacific Railroad. It may be well to say that this subject of cheaper postage promptly received the attention of Minister ANDREWS on his arrival at Stockholm,

A report became current in Jersey City yesterday afternoon that the entire body of brakemen employed on the freight trains of the Eastern Division of the Erie Railway struck on Saturday night. the cause of the strike is said to have been in consequence of the discharge of three of the brakemen on Friday, and substituting in their places three men not belonging to that organization.

The death of Mr. PEABODY occurred so late on Thursday evening, (11:30,) that the fact could not be widely published until to-day. His death is universally regretted. Flags flying at half-mast, buildings draped in various parts of the city and other evidences of mourning attest the public sorrow.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You are quite right, in your paper of this morning, in saying that Joc Elliott is a horse, rather than a colt-I mean in point of speed--after he has trotted a mile in 2:191/2, being a quarter of a second faster than the famous Flora Temple over trotted a mile.

There is so much of sensational oratory and " disjointed thinking " among the members of Congress during the session, that a scientific audience is always somewhat sur. praised to flnd a prominent member of that body showing any very strong appreciation of science or a disposition to respect its laws.

The train which left Omaha at 10 A. m. Monday consisted of two baggage cars, two passenger cars and two Pullman palace cars--made up in the order in which we have mentioned them--the baggage cars in front and the Pullmans in the rear of the train. In personal appearance Mr. PEABODY resembled a professional rather than a business man. Mr. PEABODY's great interest in education doubtless partially arose from the fact that he was taken from school at the early age of 11 years, and was thus deprived of what in that day was known as grammar school instruction.

The Massachusetts State Police say they seized the stock in the Boston lager-beer saloons last week, because the proprietors were extending their business to the sale of sprits and wine. Governor FAIRCHILD'S MAJORITY IN Wisconsin is about 10,000.

It may be recollected by the readers of the TIMES that on the 28th of October a carbolic acid tank exploded at an establishment in South Brooklyn, where some experiments were in progress for the rendering of wood self-preservative a for street paying purposes, and that thereby two persons were killed--MARTIN VOORHIES and MICHAEL GEOGHAN.

The ratification of the Burlingame Treaty with China will have an important effect upon our commerce with that nation, and upon our own laws and customs in those parts of our country into which the Chinamen have made their way.

On Thursday last Rev. NATHAN HATHAWAY, of Bristol, received a letter dated Providence, and purporting to come from Deacon JOHN A. WOOD, in which he was invited to come to this city to supply a vacant pulpit on the following Sunday. Mr. HATHAWAY replied that he would come on Saturday morning, and requested his correspondent to meet him at the depot.

A manifesto was expected from Ex-Queen ISABELLA to-day, announcing her abdication of the throne in favor of the prince of the Asturias. But at the last moment a telegram was received from Paris countermanding, by order of the Queen, the publication of the document.

The Democrats of the Nineteenth Senatorial District are now claiming two more votes for GEORGE SANFORD than they did at first, and the Utica Herald seems to look upon the case as almost hopeless, saying that the official canvassers will be called to decide upon controversies over come disputed votes, and their action will give the certificate to one or the other of the claimants.

Why all this delay in the appointment of a successor to General BUTTERFIELD? There never was a clearer case against any official. He has acknowledged that he speculated in stocks. There is, to put it very moderately, some ground for supposing that he was privy to the scandalous plot which sent gold to 160, and threw the trade of the country into confusion for days together.

A Paris dispatch says, an unknown man was arrested at Compiegne, on Sunday, who was found to be armed, and who declared that it was his intention to assassinate the Emperor. There is much anxiety felt in Paris as to the condition of the King of Italy, as no advices were received from Flrence yesterday.

The following is Pere HYACINTHE'S reply to an address and invitation to visit Boston, tendered him through the Evangelical ministers of this city and vicinity: " I am very sensible of the high honor paid me in the greeting from the clergy whom you represent; I am touched by your expressions of Christian sympathiesy and affection.
No further dispatches have been received to-day from Florence. There is much anxiety to know the condition of King VICTOR EMMANUEL.

The Government dam at Hallett's Point is completed, and the work of excavating it has commenced. A Burleigh steam drill is to do the boring for blasts, and already several tons of rock have been removed. The work is under the charge of Mr. PIERCE.

Dr. JOHN H. GRISCOM lectured last evening at the Presbyterian Church, (Dr. CROSRY'S,) corner of Twenty-second-street and Fourth-avenue on the "Sanitary Influence of Sunlight." That was the second of a course of lectures delivered under the auspices of our Young men's Christian Association of the Presbyterian Church.

McLEER has been thus cheated out of the Street Commissionership, and GOODRICH and AMMERMAN out of thier seats as Assmeblymen,

Our people will be delighted to learn that we are to have another private market larger than either of the others that have been opened during the past year. The dilapidated rookeries in the lower part of the town have been a prolific source of plunder to the "Ring" which governs the City, and cause of shame and humiliation to the citizens long enough,

PIKE, the Hampton murderer, will be executed in the State Prison, in this city, about 11 o'clock to-morrow. The Executive has declined to interfere with the sentence, and the prisoner has given up all hopes, and is now preparing for his final doom. The scaffold has arrived, and will be erected to-morrow morning.

The Old Admiral lies dead in his counrty hoem on the banks of the Delaware. The thime was when the death of CHARLES STEWART--the "Old Ironsides" of our navy--would have been an event of natinal gloom, and men would have looked upon the sinking flag, and listed to the sad booming of the minute gun as though the greatest embodiment of American seaman--hip and valor had passed away.

Intelligence received at a late hour last night from a reliable source reached us of the enlisting of another Cuban expedition being now in progress in this City, Philadelphia and Baltimore. We cannot say, as yet, whether the expedition is being formed under the auspices of the Cuban Junta or not,

The Social Science Club met at Phmpton Hall last evening, Mr. CHARLES MORAN, President, in the chair, and debated the question, "Can Government Regulate the Hours and Wages of Labor by Legislation ?" Mr. R. L. DcGDALE opened the discussion.

A meeting of the citizes of the Tenth ward was held last evening in Allen-street, Mr. S. CRAMER in the chair. Speches were made by Messrs. L. C. ROCHESTER and W. DONOHOE denouncing the frauds perpetrated at the last election, and before the meeting adjourned 375 names were registered of citizens of the Ward who voted for Mr. JACOB COHEN for Supervisor.

Unsolicited advice is rarelywell received, and we suspect that the "good counsel" which the World has addressed to Governer HOFFMAN is hardly that which he contemplated in his Albanyspeech. He gave a general warrantyas to the honesty of the Democratic legislators elect.

The Governors of thirty-one States have united with the President in recommending Nov. 18 as a day of thanksgiving and praise. A disappointed negro woman in Mobile poisoned a family of five of her own color. one day last week, and one of them died. She now meditates upon her dark crime in prison.

ITALIAN OPERA. The blithe and melodious little opea of the Riccis, "Crispino e la Comare," was sung last evening at the Academy to an audience genuinely delighted with the performance. Miss KELOGG deived in her fine vein of comic talend with the happiest effect, and Signor RONCONI convulsed the house by unexpected and original strokes of humor.

A shooting affair occurred in this city this afternoon between BALTHAZAR LIED, a member of the City Council from the Fifteenth Ward, and Rev. WILLIAM SCHMITT. The latter, who was a minister in the Lutheran Church, quit preaching some three months ago and opened a lager-beer saloon. He was visited by Councilman LIED, and they spent some time in social chat and drinking.

The managers of the Eric Railway seem to be in constant trouble with their employes. Search has one difficulty been settled are a new one presents itself. Of course it is not only injurious to the road financially, but the success of the strikers in each instance serves to eneourage them to take this method to settle their wrongs.

Yesterday morning six of the officers of the steamship cuba, which was recently detained at Wilmington, on the charge of being a privatcer, were taken over to Brooklyn and delivered into the enstody of United States Marshal DALLON, for the purpose of a waiting their trial before the United States Circuit Court, Eastern District.

The unvailing of the Vanderbilt bronze takes place at the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad, erected on the site of St. John's Park, to-morrow. at 10 A. M. Bishop JANES will offer the opening prayer, Mayor Hall will deliver an address, an ode by WM. ROSS WALLACE will be reelted, and Rev. G. QUENNELL, will pronounce the benediction.

Yesterday afternoon the Atlantics and Eckfords played their final game for the championship at the Union Grounds, both nines appearing in tall force for the contest. The cold day was unfavorable for brilliant playing, and the number of spectators was small in comparison with what a mild afternoon would have brought out.

The Board met at 2 P.M. yesterday, Mr. MONAGHAN in the chair. A resolution from the other Board increasing the salary of the third clerk in the Bureau of Street Improvements to $3,500 per annum was concurred in.

The Lake House and Noyes' Block were destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is $75,000, mostly covered by insurance. One man, J. P. FISK, was fatally, and nine others more or less injured, by the falling of a wall. The employes of the hotel lost all their clothing, and the guests a considerable amount of theirs.

A gale of considerable severity, accompanied with flurries of snow, has prevailed here since Saturday night, and several disasters have occurred to the shipping on the lake. The schooner Annexation is ashore at Sackett's Harbor, and is going to pieces. The Schooner Heather Belle, with barley, for Toledo.

BELL.--Suddenly, on Monday, 8th inst., Mrs. NANCY BELL, in the 78th year of her age. funeral from the residence of her son-in-law, James H. White, No. 221 Madison-St., near Jefferson, this (Tuesday) afternoon at 31/2 o'clock. Her remains will be taken Wednesday morning to Darien, Conn., for interment. r remains will be taken Wednesday morning to Darien, Conn., forinterment.

Hon. O. BASCOM, of Whitehall, Canal Commissioner, died, at his residence in that village, yesterday morning at 4 o'clock. He had been ill about three weeks, his sickness having been induced by exposure consequent upon the discharge of his public duties during the late breaks in the Champlain Canal.

On Saturday afternoon, an accident occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, at Chatham, N. J., which resulted on the injury of two brakemen and a heavy loss to the Company. A freight train from the West was rounding a curve, when the engineer discovered that a train of empty coal car had run off the track, about one hundred yards ahead.

An unknown man. while prowling about Compiegne yesterday, was taken into custody. Upon being searched he was found to be armed. He admitted that his intention was to assassinate the Emperor. He has been taken care of.

The following general order was issued to-day: NAVY DEPARTMENT, Nov. 8, 1869. Tile Department has the melancholy duty of announcing to the Navy and the Marino Corps the death of Rear-Admiral CHARLES STEWART, the oldest and one of the most distinguished of its officers.

The official returns of the election in Hudson County, show that John Kennedy, the Demoeratie candidate for County Clerk, received 6,854 votes; Cassedy, Independent, 6,474; newkirk. Independent, 542. For Sheriff--Andrews Mount, Republican, 7, 593; Patrick Harrington, Democrat, 6,177.

Yesterday large numbers of peoplw visited Bay View Park, to witness the two hundred into race between WILLIAM WALSH and NEIL MOWRY, for a stake of a $1,000 a side a championship gold medal presented by Mr. SILAS SELECK, the proprietor.

The immense drawback frauds which were reported exclusively in the TIMES of Sunday, were first revealed in the following manner: About six weeks ago a man named WILLIAM COHEN, or KOHN, residing in Brooklyn, visited District Attorney PIERREPONT's office for the purpose of giving information in regard to the offence, in which young BLATCHFORD is,

To the Editor of the New - York Times: Allow me to correct some of the remarks of your Liverpool correspondent in your paper of 6th November, regarding the Cunard line of Atlantic steamers. After securing the contract from the British Government to carry the mails between Liverpool, Halifax and Boston, Hon. SAMUEL CUNARD arranged with ROBERT NAPIER, of Glasgow, to build for him four steamers, each of 900 tons.

The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was held yesterday, Mr. BERGEN presenting. A resolution providing that the Street Commissioner be directed to advertise for bids for furnishing the city with registered bonds instead of bonds with coupons, as at present, specifications to be obtained at the Comptroller's oilice. was adopted.

No sales were made at the salesroom yesterday. To-day, at the Exchange Salesroom, Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER have a sale of fifty choice building lots, adjoining the city of Brooklyn, being part of the block bounded by East New-York and Utica avenues and Furnald-street;

Referring to the verdict of the Corner's Jury in the case of ARCHIBALD DOUGLASS, killed by Officer JACKSON, the Evening Post says: "Considering that, according to all the evidence, the man DOUGLASS was shot when he was running away, the verdict is certainly surprising, Common men would have said that JACKSON had clearly committed murder.

Notwithstanding the wintry temperature yesterday, there was a large assemblage of trotting habitues on the Fashion Course to witness three races announced to come off, but one of which ended in a forfeit after the horses had scored. This was a match for $500 between JOHN MURPHY'S gray gelding Jocko, owned by Mr. CROW,

The election has come and gone, and you have heard the result. In this city we had quite a lively time among those who interested themselves in contests between the two factions. The Democrats were particularly busy, and cast a large proportion of their vote: while the Republicans, entirely disgusted with both "Tings," staid largely away from the polls.

The bank robber at Wolfboro' was a very bold and skillfully planned crime. The loss in available funds will reach about $25,000. The national bank and savings bank wee both in the same apartment, and both were plundered. Hon. JOHN M. BRACKETT, President of the discount bank, and Treasurer of the savings institution, lost $3,000 of his private funds,

No decision has yet been given by the Supreme Court in the legaltender case which was argued last Winter. Numerous letters have been received here within the last few weeks, from various parts of the country in reference to the probable action of the Court,

The failure of the house of A. BININGER Co., wholesale Honor dealers, No. 02 Liberty street, established in 1776, was announced yesterday, and created much excitement in business circles. This firm occupied the same position in the line of its special business as that of A. T. STEWART Co. in dry goods It was the oldest house of the kind in this country.

A Special meeting of the city Council of Charleston, S.C., was held on Thursday night last to hear and try the charges against Alderman T.J.MACKEY, for his conduct on the Thursday Night previous. After the witnesses for the procecution, and some of those for the defence had been heard,

A special dispatch to the Gazette from Charlottesville says: "JOHN HENRY SALMON his been arrested and is now in jail for the murder of his mother and brother. The suspicious circumstances are that the blood which was on his shoo was wiped off his hand, and the preventing by himself of the arrest of a negro man, last seen at the house,

A Columbus (Ohio) correspondent of the Washington Chronicle gives the following copy of a note received by him from Hon. C. L. VALLANDIGHAM: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 11, 1860. My DEAR SIR ; Your polite note of this evening I have this moment received. I would with pleasure confer with you briefly, as you request,

Three years ago a law was enacted entitled "An act for the better protection of seamen in the Port and Harbor of New-York." This law provided that a Board of five Commissioners should be appointed, of which the New-York Chamber of Commerce, Board of Underwriters, American Seamen's Friend Society, New-York Marine Society and Port Society were each to appoint one member,

A special messenger to General SULLY, the Indian Superiutendent, reports that the deaths among the GrosVentre Indians from small pox number 500, or half of the entire tribe. They are committing suicide by blowing their brains out with revolvers.

Any one who contrasts the recent history of Cuba with that of the Central and South American Republics, formerly under the dominion of Spain, will deeply regret the mismanagement which has characterized the insurrection intended to accomplish Cuban independence.

The following correspondence between Hon. THOS. McELRATH, Appraiser at this port, and the Secretary of the Treasury, has been handed us for publication: OFFICE OF THE APPRAISER, PORT OF NEW-YORK, NEW-YORK, NOV. 4, 1869.

A grand banquet was given by the Cuban Club in the City of Kingston, Jamaica, on the evening of the 11th ??; in commemoration of the declaration of Cuban independence. Cards had been issued to a number of Jamaica residents, and a large and enthusiastic company assembled.

A small audience assembled at Irving Hall, last evening, to witness the efforts of a Mrs. HARRIET TACK A BERRY, of Cleveland, as a spiritual medium. The lady is of a prepossessing appearance, and seemed to take it very coolly when it was announced that she was to be favored with the presence of her husband, who was drowned some nine years ago.

Tahiti advices to Oct. 16 have been received. The French gunboat Dentre Castorcux and the ship Nation's Hope has arrived from Sydney. The Tahiti Cotton Company, about six months ago, sent the bark Margaret Cander. Captain BLACKETT, to the Gilbert Islands for a cargo of coolies.

The subject of lighting the streets, alluded to by Mr. ROOSEVELT at the late meeting of the Association of Science and Art, is a very important one, especially as regards crowded crossings where cars run, and most especially at the crossing near the ferries. Here the gas lamps and other twinkling lights rather embarrass the sight, in the midst of the vehicles;

There is probably no class of men that deserve more active, practical, common sense sympathy, and receive less, than sailors. Many of them are bad in almost every sense of the word, and it would be strange if, with their surroundings, they were not;

The medical officers of tile navy are carrying on their part of the war between line and staff in the service with extraordinary vigor. Before us lies a circular which they have addressed to their civilian brethren' the physicians of the country, asking" the name of very physician in the State" on a petition to Congress in their behalf.

The body of Admiral STEWART arrived here at 8 o'clock this evening, from Bordentown, by steamboat, and was taken to Independence Hall by a guard of marines and sailors. It will be exposed to public view from 9 A. M. until 3 P. M. to-morrow, when the funeral will take place.

The argument upon the motion for a receiver and an injunction in the case of the Tennessee Railroads was continued to-day before Judge SWAYNE. The case was opened on behalf of the United States by Judge MATTHEWS in an able argument of three hours, in which the several propositions of law relied upon in support of the motion were fully set forth.

The troops which arrived from Spain yesterday will leave to morrow for Manzanilla. The steamer City of Merino sailed this after noon for New-York, and juniala for phlladelphia. HAVANA. Nov, 9.--The United States steamer Tusearora arrived to-day from Key West.

WEDNESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Queenstown and Liverpool, per steamship Cuba, close at the General Post Office at 9 A. M. Supplementary mail, for paid letters only, close at 10 A. M., on the clock, Jersey City. Mails for Havana and Mexico, via Sisal and Vera Cruz, by the Cleopatra, close at 1: A. M.

Captain JOHN T. WASHINGTON is a grand nephew of General GEORGE WASHINGTON, and was horn in Jefferson County, Va., in the year 1810--his birthplace being within three miles of the old Washington homestead. Here he resided during his earlier years.

The vote in New-Hampshire to-day on the question of a State Constabulary is very light, but the indications are that the proposition is defeated. This city Concord, Dover and other populous towns have given large majorities against the project.

NATILANIEL JARVIS, Esq., the Commissioner appointed by the Board of Education to distribute the fund of $220,000 which was smuggled into the Tax Levy at Albany last Winter, to be divided among the sectarian schools of this city, has made his report to the Comptroller, who is to disburse the fund.

The association organized for the purpose of building the new market on the North River, at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, to which we alluded yesterday, is composed of business men of ample means, and doubtless the enterprise will be sucessfully carried through. The company was formed under the Building act and proposes to apply to the next Legislature for a charter to run the establishment as a market.

The Board of Health held what they called a special meeting yesterday in place of the regular meeting, which should occur to-day, the public and Press being left to their own sagacity to find out the fact. The fat-boiling nuisance,-which the Board has been treating with so much leniency of late, was expected to come prominently before them,

The resolutions passed by the Erie brakemen now on strike at Port Jervis show that their real ground of compliant is a want of good faith on the part of the management. They declare that they have been dealt with unfairly, that the Company has violated its pledges by discharging men without assigning any cause, except that they lately tried to get an advance of wages.
F. Flake, Esq., Editor Flake's Bulletin, Galveston, Texas: SIR: In reply to the interrogatories contained in your communication of the 23d inst., received this morning. I am instructed to inform you:

We briefly recorded in our last issue tile fact that the stone building at the Infirmary had been consumed by fire, and that a number of persons had perished in the flames. There is little to add by way of particulars to the terrible truth already announced. There were ten insale persons in the building, confined n cells, at tile time it took fire.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am a member of the New-York Bar, and am compelled to make the humiliating confession that there was never a truer statement written than those contained in your editorials on the Judiciary and the Bar.

The execution of JOSIAH LETTLE PIKE, for the murder of THOMAS BROWN and his wife, two aged person, at Hampton Fall, May, 1868, took place this forenoon, according to previous arrangements, in the jailyard in this city. Only the few person allowed by law were present. On the scaffold PIKE made the following Speech.

Steamers Niagara, Blakeman, Norfolk, City Point and Richmond, Old Dominion Steamship Co.; Charleston, Berry, Charleston, H. R. Morgan Co.; Volunteer, Jones, Wilmington, N. C., Lorillard Steamship Line; Virgo, Ruikley, Savannah, Murray, Ferris Co.; Glances, Walden, Boston, W. P. Clyde; Colorado, (Br.,) Williams, Liverpool, Williams Guion. Ship California, Wellcomb, San Francisco, Sutton Co.

The City Council of Baltimore has authorized the City Register to issued $300,000 of city six per cent. bonds, wherewith to pay the remainder of the floating debt of the city existing at the time of the adoption of the new constitution. Of this debt, $1,700,000 were funded some time ago.

The extensive series of arrests recently made by Colonel WIITLEY and his subordinates, of the United States secret service, in the way of persons accused of being engaged in certain unlawful operations for the inanufacture of tobacco revenue stamps and United states coin, culminated yesterday in new discoverles.

In regard to the delay in the appointment of Assistant Treasurer at Now-York, which is referred to in the editorial columns of the TIMES of to-day, it is proper to state that from the hour General BUTTERFIELD'S resignation was received, there has been no other intention that to supply his place as soon as a fit person could be found.

Nov. 9-In steamship climbria, for Plymouth, cherbourg, London and Hamburg.--Right Rev. Bishop Bacon. Rev. M. Godwin, Mrs. Alex. Foster and Children, Miss. Sarah E. Foster, Miss Annic Foster, John Foster, W. Foster, Fred. Foster, Mrs. L. Wertheimer, children and servant, Miss Ehiso Hoffmann, Miss Matilda Wertheimer, Miss Caroline Wertheimer,

Monday evening, HENRY CONWAY, who is an engraver, 29 years of age, visited Mrs. MARY EMMA FORT, at No. 60 Sixth-avenue, for the purpose of bringing his suit for the lady's hand to final decision. Seven months ago he spent his time and substance in assisting her to procure a divorce from her husband, and it would now appear that he was not working unselfishly.

The New- York Society of Engineering discuss railway accidents this evening at the Cooper Union, (rooms of the Geographical Society) A paper proposing new plans of railway construction. by which, it is claimed, comparative immunity from accident can be secured, will be read. .

Considerable excitement was created among the railroad men here to--day by the presence of JAY GOULD and MCHENRY and a number of others interested in the Eric and Atlantic and Great Western Roads. Negotiations have been carried on all day, and although they have been private, yet enough is known to justify the statement that they have been of a highly belligerent character.

The Superintendents and Managers of that excellent institution, the Five Points House of Industry, again make their annual appeal for help to enable them to give a Thanksgiving dinner to the inmates of the house. During the year there have been 1,506 persons cared for in the institution;

The following is the complete report of the Committee appointed by secretary BOUTWELL to investigate the Government bond purchases for the Sinking Fund and special account, TREASURY DEPARTMENT, Nov. 9, 1869. SIR : We have received your communication of the 1st inst.,

The Board of Supervisors, sitting as a Board of County Canvassers, met at noon yesterday to canvass the votes cast at the late election. Mr. FOX was elected Chairman. The returns from the Seventh. Tenth and Thirteenth Wards were then taken up, read by Mr. TWEED, and partially canvassed.

The unvailing of the Vanderbilt bronze takes place at the new depot of the Hudson River Railroad, to-day at 1 P. M. Bishop JANES offers the opening prayer, Mayor HALL makes an address, an ade by WM. ROSS WALLACE will be sung, and. Rev. G. QUENNELL will pronounces the benediction.

About 2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in a barn at the corner of First and Schuyler streets, in the First Ward, The building was destroyed and four horses perished in the flames. A boarding house kept by WM. T. SHEPHERD also took fire and was partially destroyed.

FOR STORE.--There is no more attractive window on Broadway at this season of the year than that of WARNOCK Co., dealers in hats, caps and furs. There is new on exhibition at this popular establishment a magnificent display of rare and beautiful goods, well worthy of a long journey simply to look at them. Those in want of the choicest furs in the market should examine this immense stock before purchasing elsewhere.

A post-mortem examination was made yesterday by Drs. SHEPARD, MOORE and KORF, on the body of Mrs. ELIZABETH BAKER, who was at first supposed to have met her death by accidentally falling into a water barrel on Saturday last. Subscquent developments, however, led to the suspicion that it was the result of foul play, and an examination was the result.

The General Council of the Lutheran Church assembled this morning. Rev. Mr. LEIST presented a reply to the question asked by the Minnesota Synod concerning the declarations of the General Council on the four points;

The strike of the brakemen on the Eastern Division, Erie Railway, has assumed no new phase, the condition of things being much the same as yesterday. Last evening Admiral FISK'S special deputies were on duty, but their fighting qualities were not called in requisition, as the strikers did not interfere in the running of trains, as was apprehended by the Company's officers.

EVERARD.-- On Monday, Nov, 3. at ?? JULIA EVERARD, mother of James Everard, a native of the City of Dublin, Ireland, aged 67 years. Relatives attend the friends of the family are respect fully invited to attend the funeral from the residence at be son James, No. 205 East 32d-st., on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The inaugural banquet of the Lord Mayor of London took place to-night at Guildhall. The members of the ministry, the foreign Ambassadors, and a large and distinguished company were present. Mr. GLADSTONE replied to the toast to Her Majesty's Ministers. On rising he was loudly cheered.

The United States steamer Saginaw, from Mexican ports, and the steamer Golden City, from Panatna, have arrived. The first train from the East arrived at Oakland last evening, and was greeted with firing of cannon, illuminations and a general jubilee of the citizens.

The Fair of the Ladies' Union Relief Association for the care of disabled soldiers and their families was opened, under pleasant and encouraging auspices, at Apollo Hall, corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth-street, on Monday evening. There was an ample attendance of ladies and gentlemen on the occasion.

CADMUS--CHRISTOPHER.--On Monday, Nov. 8, 1869, at Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Port Richmond, Staten Island. by Rev. John Coyle, DAVID V. P. CADMUS, of Newark, N. R. to MARIETTA CHRISTOPHER; of West Brighton, Staten Island. DOOLITTLE--HART.--On Thursday, Nov. 4, by Rev. Dr. Ewer, JAMES R. DOOLITTLE, Jr., of New-York, to Mrs. CLARA M. HART, nee Matteson, of Springfield, Ill. No Cards.

JOSEPH DRAIN, a laborer, 16 years of age, residing at No. 197 Navy-street, and Wm. F. PARCELLS, an engineer, 41 years of age, and resulting in Baltic-street, near Fifth-avenue, were arrested at a late hour on Monday night while passing along the Hunterfly road, near Bergen-street, on suspicion of having been engaged in some dishonorable work.

This was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening before the Young Men's Christian Association connected with the Spring-street Presbyterian Church. by Rev. Dr. AIRMAN. Among the requisites to manliness, he said, was a healthy physique, as not the least important. A liberal course of reading was also a necessity to the development of manliness.

No suit has been commenced by General BUTTERFIELD against any morning paper in this City for an alleged libel on his character, in charging that he "used the news of the battle of Chancellorsville to promote private stock operations in wall-street," as was stated by the New-York correspondent of the Philadelphia Ledger.

At the Liverpool races to-day the Waterloo Plate, handicap of sixty sovereigns, for three years old and upward, one mile and a quarter, was won by Mr. J. V. MORGAN'S b. f. Antias, by Prime Minister, out of Alma, by Platcatcher, three years; Mr. HODGMAN'S b. m. Problem, by Newminster, out of Triangle, 5 years, second;

The result of the vote for Senator in Oneida County, the Nineteenth District, was officially declared yesterday as follows: For DANIEL B. GOODWIN, Republican, 9,612; for GEORGE H. SANDFORD, Democrat, 9,638. SANDFORD'S majority, 26. The Democrats of Rome rejoiced greatly yesterday over the result of the vote for Senator in the Nineteenth District.

The inaugural banquet of the Lord Mayor of London, came off last night at Guild Hall, in that city, and the members of the Ministry, Foreign Ambassadors, and many distinguished guests were present. Mr. GLADSTONE, in reply to the toast to "Her Majesty's Ministers," made quite an extended speech, in which he alluded particularly to Irish affairs.

The trail of an action for limited divorce, or separation from bed and board, was commenced yesterday in the Supreme Court, Special Term, before Mr. Justice BARNARD. He had three associated on the Bench. The title of the action is BEATTEA BISSELL by her guardian, vs. JOHN BISSELL.

Nov. 9.-- In steamship Westphalla, from Hamburg.--F. Wolff and wife, Mrs. Wallace and daughter, L. Alexander, wife and child, Sophle Ramberger and 2 children, Lilly Graeffe, Hermine Muller, Benedict Vikar Pens, F. Pfarrer-Hundt. Laura Wieener, Henry Lundt, Mrs. N. B. Sandford, Mrs. Stelton, Mrs. Carl Schurz, 2 children and servant, G. Netter,

A Mormon temple is to be erected in this City within the coming year. A Committee, at whose disposal the requisite funds will be placed by the Mormons in this county, has been appointed to choose a suitable site and to make the necessary arrangements for the edifice.

The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, parament to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members. Alderman Moore, Nortan, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Connor, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farley, McQuade--15.

GREGORIO DOMINQUES, Consul from Ecuador to New-York, was arrested yesterday, and taken before Justice WALSH, charged with receiving bonds of the Western Union Telegraph Company, which were stolen from Mr. WILLIAM HUNTER, of Fort Greene-place. The bonds were identified by Mr. HUNTER, and the Consul offered no defence.

The Commissioner appointed by the Board of Education to distribute the fund of $220,000, inserted in the City Tax Levy last Winter, among the sectarian schools of the City, has made his report. Against the manner in which the Commissioner, Mr. NATHANIEL JARVIS, Jr., has discharged his duty there is nothing to be said; but against the appropriation itself there is much to be said.

The frequenters of the Academy of Music are to listen this evening to Signer LEFRANC and to Mme. DE BRIOL in "H Trovatore." Concert goers will have an opportunity of attending a very interesting concert at Steinway Hall, and of welcoming back to the Metropolitan stage a songstress whose accomplishments and personal history are equally familiar themes.

The London Times, in speaking of insurance companies' failures remarks, "the truth of the matter is that the unsound proportion of insurance business, whatever that may be, is due to excessive competition.' The observation is a perfectly just one, and applies to this country as well as to England, and to fire as well as to life insurance.

The Officers' Union of the Mercantile Library Association enjoyed its fourth annual dinner at the Grand Hotel, corner of Broad way and Thirty-first-street, last evening. Hon. LYMAN H. TREMAINE presided. Prominent among the invited guests were Hon. Horace Greeley. Pere Hyaetnthe, Hon. John Bigelow. ssrs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your editorial lecture to Prohibitionists is about what might be expected from a politician who reasons only from a party standpoint. The same counsel in kind used to be given to Abolitionists, but by persistent, determined devotion to their convictions they helped in working out the problem of liberty for the enslaved.

The Prospect Park Commissioners met in their rooms. corner Court and Livingston streets, last night, Hon. J. S. STRANAHAN presiding. Bills amounting to $28,511 87 were reported by the Auditing Committee. and ordered to be paid. The financial statement for October was presented by Mr. TAYLOR, Comptroller of the Park, showing expenditure amounting to $101,684 35, leaving in the treasure a balance of $43,935 87.

Mr. STEPHEN TOBERTS, fothis City,in answer to the challenge allunder to in tyhe TIMES of friday, as having been put forward by WATERS, BALCH Co., of Troy, paper boat manufactures, who took the first medal at the late Fair, Ins sont us a letter, in which he says: " What Mr. WATERS calls a paper boat is two-thirds wood.

Commissioner DELANO'S action louching income returns shows that he is rapidly mastering the details of the business of his Bureau. Quick to discover faults in the administration of the law, and possessing the requisite decision and firmness to apply the requisite decision and firmness to apply the remedies, the Commissioner is proving himself an excellent executive officer.

The counsel for ADAM VAN ALLEN, cashier of the First National Bank, charged with fraudulent use of revenue stamps, have waived a further examination before commissioner PARKER, and given bail for the appearance of their client at the next term of the United States Court, which meets at Auburn on Tuesday next.

The first of the star coarse of lectures was last evening delivered at Steinway Hall by this Kate FIELD. The subject was "Out in the woods" and was descriptive of a season among the Adnoadacks. The lady said she was induced to make a summer sojourn in the Adirondack region in consequence of having read Rev, Mr. MURRAY's description of discharges and the adventures there likely to be met with.

A private letter from Fort Garry says: Upon hearing that the Canadinn Government had appointed a Governor for the now colony of Winnepeg, the half breeds organized to prevent his entrance into that settlement, and hearing of his approach a formidable band of bunfflo-hunters went down to Pembina to prevent His Excellency from crossing the line.

Lieutenant WILMER HAWLEY, now of General THOMAS JORDAN's staff of military instructors, but formerly of Company B. Seventeenth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, Colonel LANSING, has reached this city, and is bound for Macon, Ga., but expects to return with an expedition.

Commodore HIGGINS, of the Cuban war steamer Hornet, who is at the Plerrepoint House, Brooklyn, indignantly denies that any anterior motive contrary to Cuban interests dictated his entry into the port of Wilmington, and demands an investigation of the charges.

A pleasant reception was held at the rooms at the Eastern Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at No. 473 Grand-street, last evening. There was a goodly number of ladies and gentlemen present. After a variety of entertaining exercises a collation was enjoyed. The organization is in a very prosperous condition, numbering about 150 members.

A salute of thirteen guns was fired at noon yesterday at the Navy Yard, in honor of the memory of Commodore STEWART. The Tallapoosa arrived yesterday from Washington, and it is taking in stores. She will take to Washington a couple of two-winged propellers.

The New-York Liberal Club met last evening at No. 23 Third -avenue . This Club, it appears, has been organized with a view to afford "men of advanced ideas" an opportunity to afford "men of advanced Rleas" an opportunity to enlighten the darker portion of the world on all matters which appertain to their prosperity here and happiness hereafter.

Following so hard on the death of RearAdmiral STEWART, the tidings of the death of General WOOL, another veteran of our service, comes upon the country with peculiar significance and solemnity. Like STEWART, his fame is that of an elder generation, and shares in the rising glories of American military annals.

Harver's Weekly contains the opening chapters of a new serial story by WILKIE COLLINS, author of "The Moonstone," "No Name," "The Woman in White, "and other novels that have attained wide-spread popularity in this country and in England. The new story is entitled "Man and Wife,"

The semi-annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the New-York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled, was held at their office, No. 97 Second-avenue, on Tuesday last. Present, John C. Green, President; John David Wolfe, Vice-President; Jonathan Sturges, Treasurer; R. M. Hartley, Corresponding Secretary; Otis D. Swan, Recording Secretary;

A pleasant reunion of the members of Colonel THOMAS WENTWORTH HIGGINSON'S old command, the Thirty-third Regiment United States Colored Troops, took place yesterday at the Astor House. The following officers were present: Colonel T. W. Higginson, Lieutenant-Colonel C. T. Trowbridge, Major H. A. Whitney, Captain J. S. Rogers, Geo. D. Walker,

The General Freight Agents' Association met at the Galt House this morning w. d. SHINN, President, J. T. TUCKER, Secretary. The attendance of delegates is very full and business of much importance is under consideration.

MARY E. WHALEN, aged 50 years, committed suicide yesterday by hanging herself. Sixty cmigrants from North Carolina, consisting of men, women and children, passed through Baltimore last night for Iowa and other Western homes.
The city is entirely tranquil. There were several electoral meetings yesterday, and last evening a demonstration was made in favor of HENRI ROCHEFORT. In no case was there any public disturbance.

In consequence of a communication appearing in the Sun newspaper from one PHILIP GOLDMAN, in which certain defamatory charges were made against THOMAS SHELLS, a Deputy Tax Commissioner, a complaint for libel was made on Tuesday. before Justice DOWLING, against GOLDMAN by Mr. SHELLS, who made the following affidavit:

The Lord Mayor's dinner is an occasion on which it becomes necessary for the Prime Minister of England to make a long speech without saying anything. The City of London has, in its time, made great sacrifices on behalf of the Government--more than once it has melted down all its plate in order to provide some ready money for impoverished monarchs.

Hon. HENRY J. CULLEN, Jr., of Brooklyn, denies, in a note to the Albany Argus, That he is a candidate for Speaker of the Assembly, and says that he intends, in common with the rest of the Kings County delegation, to present the name of the Holt. JOHN C. JACOBS, of Kings.

To-day will be a very busy day in real estate matters. There important sales are announced. At Staten island Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER will sell the very beautiful property which has for some time past been extensively advertised. To no locality on the continent has nature been more prodigal of such gifts as render that lovely ?? especially titted for the dwelling place of man;

The veteran General WOOL died yesterday morning in Troy, at 2:30 o'clock, at the age of 86 years. He was the last of the old heroes who connect us with the early military history of the Republic, his first training having been received in the war of 1812, and his full glory in the conflict with Mexico.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I beg to inclose you the names of forty-two subscribers to the $1 "Peabody Monument," and hope to send you others: Wm. S. Woodward, Rev. C. W. Homer. J. B. Trevor, Chas. A. Lamont, M. A. Wheelock, E. s. Munroe, E. P. Scott, Geo. Howard Marvin, Gco H. Massett, S. F. Massett, Ed. White, F. H. Wirg, E. E. Parkins, Chas. Stokes, J. W. Gillesp,

The appointment of the Hon. CHARLES J. FOLGER to the Assistant Treasurership, in this City, terminates the anomaly of General BUTTERFIELD'S continuance in office, after damaging imputations had been attached to his official conduct. The public were at a loss to understand why an officer who had deemed it necessary to resign should be retained in a position which requires,

A terrible tragedy occurred in the town of Stephentown, Rensselaer County, Friday afternoon. From the accounts received it appears that BENJAMIN CRISSEY, a resident of that town, and a notorious loafer, entered the house of Mrs. DODGE, a widow woman residing about two miles from the stone bridge.

The formal opening of Swarthmore College took place this afternoon, when a large number of its friends were conveyed thither by the Westchester Railroad. The building is a massive stone structure, four stories in beighth, 350 feet front by 50 deep with the main building, and 80 feet deep containing a dining and lecture room.

Many ladies, with a few of the other sex, assembled at No.937 Broadway yesterday afternoon, to take part in the exercises of the weekly meeting of the Woman's Sulfrage Bureau. Mrs. WILBUR called the meeting to order, and was elected "Chairman" pro tem. Mrs. NORTON said that since the Association demanded suffrage for the sake of power,

JOHN S. BLISS, who is under indictment for an alleged bounty fraud, and who was a partner of the notorious L. N. BROWN, the abscending fraudulent bounty agent, has three charges pending against him before three United States Commissioners--BETTS, OSBORN and SHIELDS--one before each, for other alleged bounty frauds.

NOV. 10--In steamship Cuba, from Liverpool.--A. G. Lathrop. Commander Wnkirkland, Mr. Bockwith. W. Kennedy, Mrs. J. F. Sheafo, Miss March, Captain Crossman, J. H. Sheaf, C. C. Lane, Cors. Scott. J. Coldwell, J. P. Howard, Mr. and Mrs. Johnson. Miss L. Lyman, J. B. Lyman, F. Lyman, J. V. Carpenter, Mrs. J. V. Carpenter, James Sterrill, II. J. Fairchild, E. J. Jaffiray, Thomas Drew, W. Clarke.

The funeral of the late Admiral CHARLES STEWART, United States Navy, took place in this city to-day. His remains were brought here on Tuesday evening, by a special train from Borden town, N. J., and were escorted from Walnut street landing to Independence Hall, in Chestnut-street, by a guard of twenty marines and eight sailors, commanded by Captain J. G. CORBIN, Lieutenant-Commander ROWLAND and Lieutenant MEADE.

In the Cortes yesterday President RIVERO paid marke respect to General STICKLES, the American Minister, by visiting him in the diplomatic gallery. During the sitting, Deputy MAZAVEDDO asserted that the fillibusters had headquarters in Paris and London, with ramifications in Madrid;

MME. BISHOP AT STEINWAY HALL. Mme. ANNA BISHOP reappeared at Stein way II all last evening, and sang in the presence of a numerous audience, some elements of which were suggestive, as were the artists themselves, of the middle ages.

Returns from sixty-one towns, on the question of the adoption of a State Constabulary act, give 2,963 year to 5,875 nays. It will be defeated by at least two to one. Among the returns received are the following: Concord, five wards, 212 for, 514 against; Manchester, 413 for, 788 against; Conway, 2 for 38 against; Laconia, 56 for, 55 against;

The ladies of the Five Points Mission have made preparations for their usual Thanksgiving Dinner. Their buildings have been greatly enlarged and their work extended during the year. They come forward on this, their nineteenth Thanksgiving anniversary,

In the suit brought in the United States Circuit by JAY GOULD and FREDERICK A. LANE against CORNELIUS S. BUSHNELL for prosecuting the Erie Railway Company to compel them to pay dividends on their preferred stock, as appears by the orders published in our law columns on Sunday, our report of the decision of Judge BLATCHFORD was quite correct.

There is still considerable excitement in Ireland on the question of the imprisoned Fenians. Dispatches from Dublin today state that last evening during a meeting of the Dublin Ammesty Association and the Ammesty Committe, a number of men broke into the rooms of the latter, smashed the lamps, destroyed the furniture, purloined the records and committed other outrages.

Five human skeletons were exhumed yesterday by the workmen engaged in digging the foundations for the new Post Office. The skeletons were found about eight feet below the surface, near the Park-row side of the Post Office plot. They crumbled to pieces very easily on being exposed to the air, and most of the bones were carted off;

In this Spanish Cortes at Madrid on Tuesday Deputy MAZAVEDDO said that the Cubans had headquarters in Paris and London, and made a business of disseminating intelligence to injure Spain, He wanted action taken. Minister BECERRA replied that Spain would protect her honor anywhere, and added, that late reports from Havana showed that the insurrection was diminishing.

BENEDICT.--On Wednesday morning, Nov. 10, SETH WILLISTON BENEDICT in the 66th year ??. The friends of the Friday morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock. from his late residence, No. 77 West 45th-st. The remains will be taken to Norwalk for interment on the 12 1/4 o'clock train. EVERARD.--On Monday, Nov. 8 at midnight JULIA EVERARD, mother of James Everard, a native of the City of Dublin, Ireland, aged 67 years.

The Board met in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--James A. Monahan, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Assistant Aldermen Healy, Lysaght, Bryan Reilly, Robinson, Hill, Hampson, Welch, Calkin, Hoffman, Pinckney, Daly, John Reilly, Haughton, Creiger, O'Neil, Cunningham, Roberts--19.

The following resolution was passed at the last meeting of this association, it being determined to stop the sale of unseasonable game in this City: Resolved, That the sun of $1,000 out of the funds of the Club,be placed at the disposal of the Executive Committee, with power to disburse the same at its discretion, for the services of informers and detectives,

The race over the Baltimore Club Park, mile heats, best three in five, which was postponed after the fourth heat yesterday, resulted as follows: The fifth heat was won by Goshen, in 2:37 1/2 the sixty by Arian, in 2:38 1/2; the seventh by Moses in 2:38 Moses, having won two heats yesterday, was declared the winner of the race.

At the Liverpool races to-day the Sefton Handicap of five sovereigns each, two forfeit to the fund, with 100 added, for three-year olds and upward, was won by Mr. J. SAXON'S b. g. Plenipotentiary, three years old, by Masjid, out of Mary, by Idle Boy;

Notice having been given that application would be made to the Supreme Court at Chambers, on the 10th inst., for the appointment of Commissioners of Estimate and Assessment for the widening of Broadway from Thirty-second to Fifty-ninth street, about a score of persons gained access to Room No. 13, situated in the upper part of the new Court House.

A letter received at the Indian Bureau, from Captain POOLE, United States Indian Agent, dated Wheatstone Agency, Dakota Territory, Oct. 28, reports that in consequence of the intoxicating liquors brought to that Agency and sold or given to the Indians for some days previous, more than the usual amount of drunkenness had prevailed,

Everything here is being turned to psyturvy to prepare for the approaching State Fair, which opens on the 16th inst. Everybody is more or less excited about the "coming event." Hotels are having India-rubber attachments fastened to all their appurtenances, from their rooms and beds to their knives, forks and plates,

Coroner WHITEHILL commenced an inquest last evening on the body of MARY ELIZABETH BAKER. lately residing at the corner of Washington-avenue and Warren-street, Brooklyn, who died in a mysterious manner on the night of Nov. 6.

Mrs. TACKABERRY, the Cleveland medium, repeated her seance at Irving Hall last evening before an audience of about 150 persons. A Committee, consisting of Messrs. MATTHEWS, YOUNG and BEACH, was selected from the audience to tie the lady's hands behind her, and seal up her mouth with court plaster, after which she was seated in a cabinet concealed from the audience, when she answered,

The six young lions, three of which are male and three female, which arrived in the Park last week, have been accommondated with a temporary cage at the north end of the animal's room upon the first floor. They come from Caffraria, are two and a half years old, and still return the tiger marks upon them which all cub lions possess, but which disappear with age.

BRIDGET GERDY, an emigrant, recently obtained a warrant from Justice HOGAN for the arrest of PATRICK GUINNESS, on a charge of seduction, presenting a requisition therefor from Mr. FRED, KAPP, one of the Commissioners of Emigration, As soon as the accused was arraigned before the Magistrate on Saturday, his counsel asked for an examination, which was granted yesterday,

CLAUSEN--CHRISTENSEN--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Nov. 10, at the residence of the bride's brother, the Consul of Denmark, by Her. O. Juni, Mr. JOHANNES CLAUSEN to Miss EMILIE CHRISTENSEN, both of Denmark. No cards. CAMPBELL--TAYLOR.--At the residence of the bride's further, on Tuesday, Nov. 9, by Rev. T. B. Smith, Mr. STEVEN J. CAMPBELL, of Greenburg, to Miss PHEBE J. Taylor of Mount Pleasant. N. Y.

The evidence yesterday on the trial of Rev. T. B. SMITH for murder, developed some new facts which were brought out in the testimony of Dr. BURLINGAME which are considered damaging to SMITH'S case. The more important testimony was of the fact that Mrs. SMITH'S neck had a livid appearance--an appearance violence infected.
Major--General WOOL died at his residence, in presence of his family, Hon. J. who has been with him for upward of forty years. He died almost without a struggle. His age was 86 years.

The monumental bronze statue erected in honor of Commodore CORNELICS VANDERBILT, on the Hudson-street front of the Hudson River Railroad Depot, was unvailed at 1 P. M. yesterday in the presence of a vast multitude of people, with interesting attendant exercises.

W. KEMPTON and JOHN RIPON, who where recently arrested near Prince's Bay, Staten Island, on a charge of counterfeiting internal revenue stamps. were before Commissioner JONES, Brooklyn, yesterday, for examination. The last-named prisoner waived examination, and was held to await the action of the Grand Jury.

The of Commerce have appointed a committee to draft a memorial, urging congress to grant additional subsidy to the pacific mail steamship Company to enable it is perform semi-monthly trips to Japan and China;

On Saturday evening the unusually quiet village of Wauwatosa was the scene of a bold and successful robbery. The victim is Mrs. OLIVER HARWOOD, an old and esteemed resident of the place. It appears that about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening a hurried rap was heard at the door, which was responded to by Mrs. HARWOOD.

The original pacific Railway line, chartered by Congress, was to extend from the Missouri River to the waters of the Pacific Ocean at Sacramento, about 1,830 miles. The two or three corporations engaged in building it were not expected to go beyond this point, water transportation between Sacramento and San Francisco being abundant.

The adjourned meeting of the General Assemblies of the Old and New School Presbyterian Churches, which met in New-York last May, convened in this city to-day. The Old School Assembly met in the First Church, and was opened with prayer by the Moderator, Rev. W. M. JACOBUS.

The laying of the corner stone of the new St. John's Church, at Clifton, S. L. toll place yesterday afternoon, with appropriate services. Right Rev. Bishop POTTER officiated, assisted by Rev. Drs. GODDARD and ABERCROMME, who delivered brief addresses. Among other elergymen present were the rector of the church, Rev. J. C. ECCLESTON, D. D., Rev. Dr. OGILBY
