The appointment of Hon. CHAS. J. FOLGER to be Assistant Treasurer at New-York, which was finally determined by that gentleman's acceptance last night, is received here with very general favor. His integrity and independence of character are well known and highly appreciated. His political status, though fully understood, has not especially entered into the case.

The statue or group designed in honor of Commodore VANDERBILT was opened yesterday, under circumstances which will be found fully described in another column. The "moral" of such an event as this is so obvious that we shall not waste the time of our readers in exphtiating upon it. Perhaps it is easier to overrate than to underrate its import.

The Commissioners of Emigration met yesterday afternoon, Mr. WINSTON presiding. A communication was received from on emigrant agent at Buffalo, complaining that attaches of the Erie Railway Company made misrepresentations to an emigrant family composed of nine persons.

The evidences we daily receive that Georgia is recovering from the prostration of the late war are exceedingly gratifying. Georgia used, in the days of the rebellion, to be called "the keystone of the Confederate arch;" and the implied analogy between it and the "Keystone State" of the North is obvious.

Once in a while our columns record an arrest for carrying concealed weapons; but almost every day there is an accident occasioned by firearms intended only for self-protection. The Court of Special Sessions last week sentenced a man to the Penitentiary for one month, and to pay a fine of $50.

The Book Concern and Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church are now in full possession of their new quarters in the line building at the corner of Broadway and Eleventh-street. The two institutions occupy one-fourth of the building lately put up by JAMES McCREERY Co., and occupied by them as a first-class drygoods store.

The state of affairs in this Island is, to say the least, more unsettled than it has been for the past six months. There is undoubtedly, loss excitement among the masses and more confidence in the Cities of Havana, Matanzas and Cardenas, but the remainder of the island is in a state of ferment, not even excepting the Vuelta Abaio region.

It was rumored, yesterday, that Commodore HIGGINS and the officers of the Cuba, or Hornet, made a visit to the headquarters of the Cuban Junta for the purpose of demanding an investigation into the charges recently made against them through the Press.

At the meeting of the Commissioners of Charters and Correction. yesterday, the superintendent of the Free Labor Bureau reported that between Oct. 24 and Nov. 6 be had received 422 applications for male help, and 1,299 for female help.
The lovers of art in Brooklyn will before long have their ardent wishes gratified, by the erection of a handsome straeture adjoining the Academy of Music in Montague-street, by the Art Association.

The fifty-sixth anniversary of this Society was held yesterday in the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, and was well attended. The annual report, which was read, showed the Society to be increasing in usefulness and efficiency in the relief of cases of sickness and distress, so common in this City. .

The watchcase makers of this City met last evening at the corner of Ann and William streets, and took preliminary steps toward a permanent organization. Mr. DUNKIRK acted as temporary Chairman, Mr. BLUME as Secretary, and Mr. LUDLAM as Treasurer. About forty case makers were present representing sixteen different shops in New-York and Brooklyn.

Two petitions, one from New-York and one from Boston, have been sent to the United States Government at Washington, signed by nine-tenths of the merchants of those cities engaged in the trade with Hayti, asking for the recognition of the revolutionists in that island as belligerants.

It is now said that, after all, the dogma of the infallibility of the Pope will not be forced on the Ecumenical Council. Reports from Rome, apparently based on good authority, state that the Pope delares that he must be assured of an imposing majority of the Bishops in favor of the dogma;

As the ferry boat Winora, of the Fulton Ferry line, was entering the slip on this side of the river, at about 5:30 P. M. yesterday, the pilot lost his presence of mind, and used his bell so clumsily that the engineer was unable to tell whether to "stop her" or "let her go."

The principle of "aggregation"--one of the most peculiar social foatures of the times--is at work everywhere, and it is now going with a rush into the hotel business. We are to have another "palatial" earavanservi in our midst, on the site of the Lafarge House--a most mighty,

There would seem to be a purpose, more or less defined, on the part of a portion at least of the Democratic Party in this City, to make the questions of the sectarian distribution of school money and of reading the Bible in the public schools distinct political issues.

Afternoon.--ALEXANDRE AUGUSTE LEDRU-ROLLIN, ex-Minister of France, who was compelled to seek safety in England in 1848 on account of a conspiracy against NAPOLEON, is expected to arrive here to-day. It is reported that he will be promptly arrested if he enters French territory.

The strike of the brakemen in the employ of the Eastern Division of the Eric Railway Company seems to be spreading. The report among the men in Jersey City, yesterday, was that the men engaged along the line west ward as far as Cincinnati were prepared to join in and would do so this morning, if not before.

The following letter explains itself: NORTH ATLANTIC FLEET, UNITED STATES FLAGSHIP POWHATAN, FIRST RATE, HARBOR OF HAVANA, Nov. 3, 1869. Hon. G. M. Roberson, Secretary of the Navy: SIR: In compliance with the Department's circular letter of Sept. 28, 1869,

The old Bancroft House, on the corner of Broadway and Twentieth-street, having passed into new hands, has been thoroughly renovated. It is painted, papered and frescoed throughout, and with accommodations for 200 guests is one of the pleasantest hotels in the City.

It is as well that those, of whatever party, who are ?? as to the cansequences of the passenge of the State Government into Democratic hands, should understand clearly that even if Democratic politicians were all that politicians should be, no real change for the better in the condition of our affairs can be looked for, as long as the Judiciary remains unreformed. as long as the Judiciay remains unreformed.

The heirs of JOHN CAMPBELL, the possessor in 1783 of three hundred acres of land, which now embraces the commercial centre of Louisville, are about instituting a suit for this property, of which they claim they are the rightful owners.

In sympathy with the funeral of GEORGE PEABODY, which takeo place in London tomorrow, Mayer SHURTLEFF has directed that the bells be tolled half an hour at noon, and that the flags be at half-mast on the public buildings.

The Old Schoo Presbyterian Assembly met again this morning. After devotional exercises, the matter of the election of Professors for the Danville Seminary was taken up. The following candidates were elected:

Subjoined are the names of thirty-nine additional subscribers to the $1 "Peabody Monument" fund, to be erected is Central Park. The sums collected have been paid into the hands of JOHN BLOODGOOD, Esq., banker, No. 22 William-street, Treasurer problem., who will he happy to receive other subscriptions from all parts of the country:
A cable message from Madrid, dated the 8th November, informs us that cries of "Viva Republica" were raised in that city on the occasion of the funeral of "the patriot RIEGO."

Representatives of the colored men engaged in different occupations in this City met at Zion Church, Bleecker-street, last evening, to select delegates to represent the colored workingmen at the National Labor Convention, to be held in Washington on the first Monday in December.

The Albany Journal asserts that Mr. SPRINGSTED was really elected to the Assembly from the First district of Albany County, and that the returns were so altered as to give Mr. MURPHY a majority. And the Journal adds: "A Legislature elected by frand will need control stonger than that of Governor HOFFMAN to keep it honest."

The engine of the train on the Harlem Railroad due in this City at 9:20 o'clock last night, near Woodlawn Cemetery, above Fordham, at the junction of the New-Havan and Harlem Railroads, was thrown off the track and overturned. One of the firemen was crushed beneath it and killed. The engineer was dangerously injured.

BRUSH-WHITLOCK.--In this City, at the Washington square Retormed Church, on Wednesday, Nov. 10, by Rev. M. S. Hutton, D. D., CLINTON E. BRUSH to ELIZA T., daughter of Wm. S. Whitlock, all of this City. BURR--LOTT.--On Wednesday, Nov. 10, 1869, at No. 52 South Oxford-st., Brooklyn, by Rev. Dr. S. D. Burchard. S. BURCHARD BURR to MARIA S. LOTT, daughter of the late Engelbut Lott, of Flatbush,
In the Supreme Court, Special Term, before Judge BARNARD, yesterday, a case was called on for trial which presents some phases of New-York City life in an exceedingly Indierous aspect.

The board of Managers of the ladies Depository is just now renewing its appeal in the public for support and encouragement. This institution was founded in 1833, for the purpose of assisting respectable females to obtain employment, and this its office at 376 Broadway. It is entirely number the control of ladies, whose object is purely that of assisting those who are loss for.

Yesterday bids were to have been opened and contracts awarded by the Croton Aqueduct Department for laying 650 feet of iron pipe from Manhattan to Ward's Island, but on account of the absence of one of the members of the Board the further consideration of the subject was deferred.

While our canals and their conduct are oxciting not only general interest but violent partisanship; while every phase of their commercial and political management is earnestly discussed, it is strange that the realquestion upon which their success and asefulness depend is so generally disregarded.

J. Glancey Jones, Ex-United States Minister to Russia, is at the St. Denis Hotel. Hon. C. H. Sherrill, Washington; Commander W. H. Buhler, of the United States Navy; Hon. Z. Pratt, of Prattsville; Hon. D. B. Saunders, of Massachusetts; J. Ahern. of Baltimore; E. Whaley, of St. Paul, and O. B. Craig, Esq., of Baltimore, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT. No. 202--James D. Bennell and Seth Turner vs. Finley F. Fowler.--Appeal from the Civenit court for the Northern District of Illinois.--The billin this enuse was filed by Fowler to obtain an accounting and injucntion against Bennett and Turuer for an alleged infringement of two reissued letters paten, obtained by him for "improvements for elevating bay and other like purposes."

The Monumental City is to have a monument to GEORGE PEABODY. Governor HOFFMAN has appointed Colonel LESTER R. FAULKNER, of Livingston County, Aid in his Staff, in place of Colonel WILLIAM KIDD of Rochester, resigned.
Time develops mystery and solves many a doubt; so it has in relation to the figures served up by the canvassers at the recent election in the City of Brooklyn.

At the regular meeting of the "Medico-legal Society." at the College of Physicians and Surgeons last evening, Dr. FINNELL submitted a rate specimen of a fatty heart taken from the body of a colored woman who recently fell in syncope, while shouting under great excitement at a religious meeting, and died in a few moments.

Coroner FLYNN held an inquest yesterday, at the Beekman-street Police Station, in the case of GEORGE JESSUP, his wife LETITIA, and his two children JOHN and WILLIAM, who, it will be remembered, were suffocated by smoke from a fire on the second floor of the premises No. 63 Liberty-street, which occurred on the night of the 29th ult.

The Tammany Ring are encountering a good deal of difficulty in making up a state for the Municipal election that shall satisfy the hosts of aspirants for Aldermanic and Judicial honors, and prevent the running of bolting candidates.

Last night the great Atlantic and Great Western Railway case began in the Court of Common Pleas, Judge W. W. BOYNTON. The parties interested represent the first and second mortgage bondholders against JAY GOULD and the Eric Railway.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The editor of a notorious paper once compatred himself to Saint Paul and SOCRATES. I thing the Prohibitionists have about as much right to compare themselves to the Anti-Slavery men.

An Omaha dispatch says the Indians (convicted of murder) who escaped on Tuesday night have been recaptured. Little Wolf and Horse-driver attempted to commit suicide yesterday afternoon. They are both in a critical condition. Blue Hawk has not been recaptured.

The Board of Trustees of the College of St. Francis Xavier met yesterday morning at the College buildings, No. 49 West Fifteenth Street. Rev. JOHN PABST was appointed President of the Board. The election of Professor took place with the following result.

The following order has just been promulgated: HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY, ADJUTANT-GENERAL'S OFFICE, WASHINGTON, NOV. 10, 1809. GENERAL ORDERS NO. 7t.--The General of the Army with profound regret has to announce the decease of one of the very few remaining veteraus of the war of 1812, Major-General JOHN E. WOOL. of the United States Army, which occurred at his residence at Troy, N. Y., at an early hour this morning.

At the meeting of the American Geographical and Statistical Society last evening. Mr. GEO. GIBBS. of Washington, D.C., read a paper upon the "Physical Geography of the Northwestern Boundary of the United States."
The following interesting correspondence in relation to the Eight--hour law explains itself: NEW--YORK, Oct. 21, 1869. Hon. George S. Boutwell, Secretary of the Treasury, Washington, D. C.:

M. CATACAZY, the newly-appointed Minister from Russia to the United States, passed through Paris recently on his way to Washington, and must by this time have arrived at his post. Some facts have come to my knowledge in connection with the career of this diplomat which it way be useful to you to know on the other side.

The following plans for projected buildings have been received by the Superintendent of Public Buildings, and the customary permission awarded, during the week ending Nov. 8: Nov. 3, No. 1,169--One brick store, iron front, No. 372 and 374 Hudson-street, 50 by 85, five stories; owner, Mr. LOEWENBEIM.
The British Government has ordered a man-of-war to convey the remains of the late GEORGE PEABODY to this country. Rev. Dr. TEMPLE has been elected by the Chapter of Exeter, Bishop of the Diocese.
The investigation before Surrogate MILLS, in this case was resumed yesterday, when S. E. LYONS, Esq., of counsel for the legatees, reviewed the testimony which had been adduced by the contestants.

The bronze statue of the late Bishop BROWNELL, of this State, presented to Trinity by GORDON W. BURNHAM, of New-York, and erected in the College grounds, was publicly unvailed this afternoon in the presence of a large concourse of spectators.

Cooper Institute was crowded last evening by an audience composed in great part of ladies, the occasion being a welcoming ovation to Rev. Father McMARION, who was lately released from prison, in Canada, after an incarceration of two years.

The TIMES is to--day endled to publish full and ?? particulars of the great Custom House drawback frauds, concerning which we have given several exclusive reports during the past few days. The enormous extent of the brauds the during and unscrupulous manner in which they were accomplished,

The public ceremony of unvailing the soldiers movement at Fairmount Cemetery, New-York, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon. The monument is of granite, forty-two feet high, and weight thirty-five tons.

The privileged growler--we mean, of course, WENDELL PHILLIPS--draws, in the Anti-Slarery Standard of this week, what it pleases him to regard as the moral of the late elections--namely, that "we are floating away from the keen and angry devotion to the one great question of the negro."

This institution celebrated its twenty-second anniversary last evening. An able address was delivered by Dr. GOUVERNEUR M. SMITH, in the large hall of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

The boiler in MENDERSON'S large planing mill and sash factory at Covington, Ky., exploded this morning. The wildest rumors of loss of life were afloat until late in the afternoon. Fourteen men were in the shop at the time of the explosion. J. WORLING, the engineer, was killed.

BONNER.--At Columbus, Ga., on Tuesday, Nov. 2. LIONEL T. BONNER, of Brooklyn, aged 40 years. The funeral will take place at his late residence, No. 6 Hanson--place, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon, at 3. o 'clock . His friends, and those of the family, are respectfully invited to attend.

An accident occurred at the Nineveh Tunnel, on the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad, last evening, at about 6:30 o'clock, resulting in the injury of the engineer, a brakeman and two or three passengers. The particulars are as follows, briefly: The passenger and freight train which left Oneonta at 1:46 P. M.

The case of ROMAINE MULLIGAN and JAMES CALDWELL, charged by Mr. KORN with being implicated in the drawback frauds, came before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday for examination. Mr. A. H. PURDY, Assistant District-Attorney, appeared for the Government. He requested an adjournment, in consequence of the absence of Judge PIERREPONT.

A special meeting of the Board of Education was held at its rooms, corner of Grand and Elm streets yesterday evening, the main object of the session being the consideration of the Educational Tax Budget for 1870. The President, R. L. LAEREMORE, Esq., occupied the chair, and there were present Commissioners Brennan, Lewis, Wood, Sherwood, Sands, Duryea, Bell, Smythe and Gross.

One would be inclined to say, on reading the striking and lucid exhibit of Mr. BOUTWELL, published in our columns yesterday, that the new fiscal year, beginning July 1, 1869, has opened under happy auspices. Comparing the receipts and expenditures of its first quarter with those of the same period in the year preceding, the saving effected under the new Administration is very manifest.

It is quite evident that if we do not wish the present discussion of the employment of the school fund to flame out into a wrathful religious controversy, fed by the fires of sactarian hate, we must conduct it from the start in the most candid and dispassionate way. There is no telling to what angry pass this question may lead us.

"Sheridan." cried the conductor, as we came to a full stop after a ride of four hundred and odd miles westward from the Missouri River. And Sheridan it was; so we get out in the prairie town which the other day sprang up, an apparition of civilization amid the solitudes of the Great American Desert.

In the superior Criminal Court of Middlesex County yesterday, ALBERT S. JOCELYN, of Lexington, convicted of rape, was sentenced to the State Prison during life. One hundred and thirty-five men were discharged from the Navy Yard yesterday. They were attached to the Constructor's Department. The Engineer's and the other departments are to be cut down.

The following rather singular tradition which exists among the Papago Indians respecting Montezuma, their founder, and the deluge, has, we believe, never yet appeared in print; at least not in its present shape. It was related by Captain Con Onan, an aged an intelligent member of the tribe, and was taken down from his lips by an interpreter for Judge HENRY T. BACKUS, of Arizona Territory, and formerly of this city.

The New-Jersey Railroad Company have recently erected at their terminus in Jersey City, opposite Cortlandt-street, a large building that is used for a purpose hitherto unknown to railroad managers. It is a "stable," or cleansing house, for sleeping cars. The building is about 200 feet in length, with three tracks upon which trains can be run in, and a long platform running through its entire length.

An inquest was held by Coroner LANG, of Newark, yesterday and last evening, upon the lady of JAS SUERMAN, of No. 30 Oxford-street, who died on Wednesday morning from the effect of injuries received. It is supposed, at the hand of lus stepsister, HONORA ROBINJSON. Mrs. ROBINSON. BRIDGET ROGERS, another stepsister of ?? deceased, and her husband, EDWARD ROGERS, were arrested and are still in custody.

The case of the United States es. E. B. WARD, Which was commenced in the United States Circuit court on Tuesday. Judges WITHEY and WILKINS presiding, and has occupied the attention of that court since was concluded yesterday afternoon, with a verdict for plaintiff for $68,090 50.

A correspondent of a contemporary calls attention to a little circumstance in connection with the coroner's jury which was empaneled to inquire into the death of the man DOUGLAS, shot by JACKSON, the Deputy Sheriff. The names of the jurymen are JOHN G. BYRNES, GEORGE Y. MACOMB, FRANCIS REYNOLDS, JAMES McCABE, THEODORE HILBECH and HENRY L. FRASER.

The Board met in their Chamber. No. 15 City Hall, pursuant to adjo??nment. Present--Thomas Coman. Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members : Aldermen Moore , Cuddy, Ward , O' Brien, Repper, Coulter, Me??rath, MeQuatie--9. The minutes of meeting held November eight were read and approved.

Last night the Chinese pupils, numbering some thirty young men and boys, together with about a dozen Cubans, who attend evening school at the Five Points House of Industry, were entertained at a sociable by Rev. S. P. HALLIDAY, superintendent of the institution. They were all neatly dressed, and looked quite intelligent. A number of visitors, including several ladies, were present.

The Tahiti Messenger, the official journal of the French Protectorate in the Society Islands, publishes a detailed account of the tragedy on board the French coolie ship while becalmed off Byron Island. When the revolt occurred there were about ?300 Kanakas on board, who were on deek, receiving presents.

Mr. GEORGE COOK, aged 52 years, a well known auctioneer, doing business at No. 108 Liberty-street, committed suicide yesterday by cutting his throat. The misguided gentleman left his home, No. 215 East Thirty-fourth-street, in his usual health and spirits, and arrived at his office at 9 o'clock.

The fifth day's racing over the Chickasaw Jockey Club Course began with a race for the De Soto Stake, for three-year olds, two miles; subscription, $100, half forfeit; the Club to add $600. Ten entries. The race was won by Mr. BABCOCK'S Helmbold, beating General BUFORD'S versailles in 3:44, 3:46.

The Assemblies met in their respective churches. In the Old School, a member who formerly strongly opposed a reunion, prayed that the hopes of its friends might all be realized and the fears of others utterly disappointed. The official report of the New School Assembly was read, showing that every Presbytery had voted affirmatively.

Death seems to be busy with the veterans in this changeful Autumn weather. On Tuesday the Old Admiral was put to his rest in the city of his birth. While the muffled drums were heating the "long-rolling salute as they were wont to do." Our reporter tells us, "whenever the gallant old seaman stepped upon his quarter deck," the oldest soldier of our wars was dying at his home in Troy.

The great Earl was burred yesterday with all possibly privacy. The Quern wished to send her representative to the funeral; the Lord Lieutenant of the country and the authorities of Liverpool, one half of which, like several whole towns in Laneashire, belongs to the Earldom, wished to pay a tribute to his memory, but all proposals were firmly deeilned by Lord STANLEY, the new Earl.

The following petition, which speaks for itself, was drawn up yesterday, and is now lying in the rooms of the Shipowners' Association of New-York for signature: To the Honorable the Senate and Representatives of the United States, in Congress assembled: The undersigned shipowners and others respectfully represent that prior to 1861 there was established a lighthouse on Body Island,

Yesterday afternoon Special Deputy Collector HUCKEL and Surveyor GOODRICH, acting under authority received from Secretary BOUTWELL, repaired to the shipyard of Messrs. NEAFID LEVY, and there took possession of the ram Atlanta, for an alleged violation of the Neutrality laws. Deputy Collector HUCKEL placed a Custom House officer on board,

Suits were entered in the Circuit Court to-day by ANDREW PARK, WM. G. CLARK, WM. T. CANSLY and LOUIS C. GURNER against FRANKLIN A. DICK, who was Provost Marshal of this Department under General HALLECK,

The discoveries of fraud in the Brooklyn section. ??? come thicker and faster, and take a variety of shapes. The City Canvassers discovered that the returns from the First District of the Twenty-second Ward has been tampered with in such a manner as to elect WALSH,

Whereas, information has been received at this Department that portions of the County of Sumter, in said State, are infested by hands of lawless and unprincipled men, who, under pretext of suppressing illicit traffic in cotton, have willfully and maliciously set fire to and consumed the storehouses of citizens,

Coroner BATHGATE yesterday held an inquest at the Metropolitan Police Station, Freemont, on the body of THOS. HAMMOND, the fireman in the employ of the Harlem Railroad Company, who came to his death the previous evening by the accident to the train due in the City from Chatham at 9:20 P. M.

The Bishop of Orleans, France, declares that he will abide by the decisions of the Ecumenial Council, whatever they may be. The letter of the Archbishop of Paris, issued Nov. 7, opposing the adoption of Papal infallibility by the Council without discussion, is reported to have been instigated by NAPOLEON.

BEECHER--SNOW.--On Wednesday, Nov. 10. at the residence of the bride's mother, by Rev. Dr. H. E. Montgomery, HENRY CLAY BERCHER to FRANCES GERTRUDE SNOW, daughter of the late George M. Snow. BRADLEY -- SWEENY. --On Tuesday, Nov. 9. by Rev. Charles H. De Luynes, JOHN J. BRADLEY to Miss M. J. LOUISE SWEENY.

One sultry day, while SHERIDAN, seated upon a log by the roadside, was attentively observing the passing column, a pail of a ice-water near him attracted the notice of a trooper trudging along on toot. Wiping the perspiration from his bronzed forehead with his coat-sleeve, he brusquely uncosted the Gentral, omitting even the customary salute:

There have recently arrived in New-Orleans, from the West, about 1,000 skilled German laborers, who have at once been sent to the Teche and other portions of the State, where their labor is so greatly needed. The cost of transporting these laborers, we learn, is but $12 per head, the railroad (Illinois Central) charging $6 to Cairo, and the steamers $6 from Cairo to this point.

The Bremen bark Cupido, Captain LEITHOFF, with pertroleum, from New--York to Danzing, burned to the water's edge at the latter city yesterday. where she had just arrived. The loss is heavy. ROCHESTER, Nov. 12.-- BAMBER'S brick block, on Monroe--avenue, was partially destroyed by fire last e evening. The loss is about $10,000, on which there is but a slight insurance.

The agony of suspense that has held this part of the country for the last four days is now some what relieved. The absolute mystery that has surrounded the murder of the three children in the town of Eden is partially cleared up by the return of the mother, Mrs. CLARK, though her appearance is almost as mysterious as washer disappearance.

Following closely upon the death of ROBERT J. WALKER comes the intelligence from Washington of the deceased of another old and honored politician in that city. AMOS KENDALL died yesterday in the eighty-first year of his age. AR in the ease of Mr. WALKER his death had been expected for some time, still the news will for a moment thrill the public pulse,

One lesson may be learned from the election returns in this city, and it is a lesson which, we presume, will not be lost on our local political managers of either party. It is that there is an "irrepressible conflict" between the two leading portions of our population. The milesian element is bitterly hostile to the Tentonie element, and the latter reciprocate the feeling with equal, if not greater, intensity.

Commissioner MANIERRE yesterday examined a number of charges against policemen for neglect of duty and violations of the rules, none of which were of any public interest. There were several cases of alleged improper conduct, which were adjourned. Of those tried the most important was that of Officer JOHN HARRIS, of the Fifteenth Precinct.

On last Saturday, Mrs. W. H. LWELS, who lives on the Metairei Ridge, left her home baout P. M. , in order to visit Greenville. When she returned, towards disk, she discovered that her two sons, aged 6 and 8 years repectively, accompanied by a white boy, some 15 years of age, and a dog, had gone, as it was supposed, along the swamp for a walk.

Coroner SCHIRMER was yesterday summoned to No. 162 East Twenty-eighth-street, by the Police, to investigate a terrible and most shocking mystery. It appears that the tenants occupying these premises, which are in a most respectable neighborhood, near St. Stephen's Church, have ever since their entrance been annoyed by a noisome odor, especially on the lower floors.

The annual meteoric shower of falling stars may be looked for between midnight and sunrise to-morrow morning. Astronomers are preparing to take scientific observation of the phenomenon. It is not probable that it will be much of a shower this year.

The delay in the announcement of the new Government loan for the purchase of the telegraph lines has a tendency to depress the price of Consols. Kelly, the Feaian-His Identity with Martin in the Manchester Hospital.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe that a telegram from Brest claims for the fine steamer the "quickest ocean passage on record," viz.: eight days, sixteen hours and thirty-five minutes, (apparent time,) from Sandy Hook to Brest.

A certain native living in Koolan has been sick, and , apprehending that his end was near at hand, sent into town for a coffin, so that his friends might, be prepared to give him proper burial. In due time the coffin arrived, upon seeing which grave doubts arose in the sick man's mind as to whether it would fit.

Thursday evening Sheriff ANDREWS, of Chatauqua County, N. Y., called upon Captain WALSH, of the Fourteenth Precinct, and desired the arrest of a man known to him as LUKE EGAN, who had committed a burglary in that county, and for whose arrest a reward of $1,000 was outstanding.

Comptroller CONNOLLY and his clerks yesterday took possession of the handsome and spacious offices prepared for them in the new Court House. The offices are located in the northwest corner of the building. They comprise four rooms on the basement floor and three on the floor above. In the large room on the basement floor are located the Bureau of Arrears and the Clerk of Street Openings.

In the Superior Court, before Judge Jones, yesterday, the case of RICHARD JAMES vs. WILLIAM W. STREW was decided. The plaintiff in this case, who was colored janitor of the Metropolitan Gas Company's office, corner of Forty-second-street and Broadway, used the defendant for slander in calling him a thief.

Dispatches were received by the Paris insurance companies, yesterday, announcing the complete loss of the American steamer Leight, in the Mediterranean. Later advises, however, show that she was an English vessel. She encountered a severe hurricane off the harbor of Oran, Algeria, and was driven upon the rocks and totally destroyed.

AN ORDINANCE TO DIVIDE THE CITY OF NEW-YORK INTO CONVENIENT ELECTION DISTRICTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION EIGHT, ARTICLE THREE, TITLE THREE, OF ACT OF THE LEGISLATURE PASSED APRIL FIVE, EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND FORTY-TWO. (Containing all Amendments to Aug. 1, 1869.) The Mayor, Aldermen and Commonally of the City of New-York, in Common Council convened, do ordain as follows;

The reported sailing of a naval expedition for San Domingo, which appears in some of to-day's New-York papers, is largely sensational, and is denied here on official authority. The Albuny, which left New-York on Wednesday, was under orders to join the West India Squadron, which she will do after having landed General BABCOCK, special agent of this Government at the Island of San Domingo.

It is probably known to but very few of the present citizens of our State that Wisconsin has the high distinction of having given Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, Ex-President of the Ex-Confederate States, his first public whipping. It should be remembered that Master JEFF, was educated for the army at the expense of the Government he so ungratefully betrayed, and entered the service as a loan, lank, imperious,

Officers of various insurance companies of Massachusetts held at private meeting in Worcester on Thursday, to discuss plans of improvement in the present mode of conducting the insurance business. The New-Hampshire Democrats will hold their State Convention in Concord on the 5th of January.

Presbyterians residing near the southwest corner of the Central Park will be pleased to learn that a new house of worship will be opened on Sabbath morning next in Fifty-sixthstreet, near Broadway. This edifice has been built by the Central Presbyterian Church, and will accommodate about five hundred people.

List of American registered at the office of BOWLES BROTHERS , No. 12 Rue de la Paix, Paris, for the week ending Oct, 28, 2869: New-York-Mrs. GIDEON T. Tucker, George Wilkes, Mrs. Alex, Rumrill, Miss Sarah E. Rumrill, Miss Jennie B. Rumrill, Mr. and Mrs. Henry May L. Browning W. W. Leland, E. M. Hilchcock and Wife, C. B. Hackley and wife,

It is quite evident that the art of paving streets has not yet been brought to the point of perfection, but the experiments which have recently been made give us reason to hope for great improvement on the old foundations for artificial thunder, which still make our streets such a badlam of deafening sounds. But for streets where heavy traffic is carried on, nothing has yet been devised to take the place of stone.

An Indianapolis special and private dispatch from Senator MORTON denies the telegraphic report from Washington in reference to a conversation with President GRANT and Seccretary BOUTWELL about Cuba. A special dispatch from Jacksonville says: "The heirs of the late General MCCONNELL, who was murdered in February last,

A private letter from S. J. BROWN, Esq., son of Hon. JOSEPH R. BROWN, dated Lake Traverse, Nov. 1, gives us the not unexpected news of the death of JOHN OTHERDAY, the well-known Sioux Indian, who was instrumental in resening sixty-two captives from the Sioux massacre of 1862. His death occurred on the 29th ult., of a disease called "Indian Consumption."

"FRA DIAVOLO" AT THE ACADEMY. AUBER tried and failed three times before making with his fourth effort a success and beginning in La Bergere Chalclaine, that long series of triumphs which it took nearly fifty years to span, and which had scarcely ended with, as a septuagenarian. The ?? rested from this labors with still undiminished powers.

The primary meetings of the Republican Party of this City have been appointed to be held on Monday evening next, when delegates are to be elected to the Convention to make nominations for Aldermen, Assistant Aldermen, Police and Civil Justices for the December election. There appears to be a total apathy in the party with reference to the primaries as well as to the candidates who may be put in nomination.

The strike of the brakemen in the employ of the Erie Railway Company, upon its Eastern Division, promises to lead to a similar action on the part of the engineers. It will be recollected that these were first impelled to strike by the fact that they were obliged to run their trains with green brakemen.

It will be remembered that on the 9th of October last the office of the Dutchess County Insurance Company at Poughkeepsie was entered by four burglars who get away with a large amount in bonds and securities, and that upon their arrived here all but one escaped, and none of the stolen property was recovered.

The Cuban Junta have received a communication from commandor HUGGINS, late commander of the Cuba. In which he hilly, answers the charges recently made agaisnt him. He elses his communication as follows:

Captain C. F. HALL was on Change yesterday, was promptly introduced by the President to many of our merchants, and then, formally, to the Chamber. In the course of his remarks in response, Captain HALL said: My old friends of my old home, Cincinnati: I teel unable to respond, satisfactorily to myself, to the sentiment of my old friend, your President, Mr. GANO.

The obsequies of the late GEORGE PEABODY, took place this afternoon. The funeral procession formed at the mansion of Sir CURTIS LAMIPSON, in Eatonsquare, the residence of the deceased. It consisted of a hearse and five mourning coaches.

Colonel SCHOFIELD, Assistant Inspector-General of the Department of Missouri, has arrived from Camp Supply, Illdian Territory, which he left on the 3d inst., and reports all the Arrapahoes at their reservation near Fort Sill. Colonel SCHOFILED does not believe tile reported death of SANTANA. No news of such an event had reached Camp Supply when he left.

GEORGE FRANCIS TRAIN has commenced a suit against the Kansas Pacific Railway Company, in which he claims the sum of $300,000. He has also brought a suit against the Union Pacific Road. In which he says that he is entitled to recover a similar amount. The cases came before the Supreme Court yesterday,

Some important developments have been made in the "Comsteek" lode, in Nevada, and there is much excitement in mining stock circles. Nearly all descriptions of silver mining stock have advanced. A memorial to Congress, asking aid for the Sutro Tunnel, has been signed by all the Nevada State officers and by many prominent citizens.

During the recent political canvass in Ohio under the auspices of Mr. PENDLETON, one of the points dwelt upon by Democratic orators was the unhappy and miserable state of the country. A party out of power is under the hard necessity of saying this, however much the facts may be against them.

Yesterday was a quiet day in the real estate market. The previous day was an unusually busy and exciting one ; four sales were made in the salesroom, one in Brooklyn and one on Staten Island, and, as is generally the case after so very severe a day, the one following was very dull.

In reporting on class "H," of tile articles exhibited at your late fair, consisting of minerals, chemicals, , I have the pleasure to state that though the variety was not great in point of numbers, yet there were exhibited several specimens of minerals and their metallic products of very great interest;

From the Springfield (Ill.) State Register. STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS first came to reside in Sprinfigeid, M., some time in April, 1837. He had already served one term in the Legislature, and had then recently been appointed by President VAN BUREN, Register of the Land Office or that place. At the date above mentioned, he was a little, active, wiry fellow, about five feet, and weighed not more than 110 pounds.

Sing Sing State Prison has long been overcrowded; and, as the result, escapes have been constantly effected, attempts at escape have been constantly made, and are foiled only with considerable trouble and expense, while discipline under any circumstances is not what it ought to be.

To-day the first block of Maine granite will be laid on the concrete foundation, which will be the commencement of the new Post Office building proper. The work so far has been preparatory, and has been pushed with remarkable energy enabling the builder to begin upon the main structure sooner than was anticipated.

The members of the bar and officers of the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday held a meeting in the office of the Clerk of the Court, Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON acting as Chairman, and D. W. MIDDLETON, Esq., Clerk of the Court, as Secretary.

Mr. BERNARD CASSERLY, the Superintendent of the Emigrant Landing Depot, has written a letter in which he says, regarding the charge against Commissioner KAPP, for signing a blank order in the case of BRIDGET GERDY, that the course of Mr. KAPP is that followed since 1847 by such men as Gulian C. Verplanck, Edwin D. Morgan, Cyrus Curtiss, Andrew Carrigan and Elijah F. Purdy.

Advices from Alexandria state that the great bed of rock in the Suez Canal at lsmailia, seventy-five miles south of Port Said, which has hitherto been a hindrance to dredging, will be at once blasted out. This rock is eighty fect thick.

The fourth Convention of the New-York State Base Ball Association was held at the Assembly Chamber, at Albany, on Thursday, no less than forty odd clubs being represented. The utmost harmony prevailed. Mr. R. DENNIS, of the Auburn Club, was chosen President, and Messrs. STERLING , of Brooklyn, and VAN HORN, of New-York, Vice-Presidents.

The conspirators who planned the Brooklyn election frauds have overshot their mark. They plotted to secure victory to a corrupt and grasping Ring, and in their eagerness to make sure work of it they have roused public indignation to an extent' which renders complete exposure certain, and merited punishment at least probable.

About 8 o'clock last evening a tire broke out in the drying room of LORILLARD'S tobacco factory, No. 69 Wooster-street, in such proximity to the boiler room that it was probably caused by the furnace. The engines were promptly on hand and quickly extinguished the flames, but the drying room being filled with tobacco, the damage by water was very great.

From the Cleveland Herald. In the midst of publishers' quarrels and charges of meanness made against each other by rival publishers, it is pleasant to note one act of generesity by a great publishing house, which has not found its way into the papers.
The following order has been issued General MCDOWELL: HEADQUARTER DEPARTMENT OF THE EAST, NEW-YORK CITY. Nov. 11.

Within a few weeks, in at least four instances, great disasters have been happily averted by the presence of mind of a few individuals. In a Western city a closely-packed audience was enjoying an opera.

The Treasury and Post Office Departments were closed to-day in respect to the memory of ROBERT J. WALKER and AMOS KENDALL, and of course there was no business transacted at either of these branches of the public service.

At a medical lecture in the Pennsylvania Hospital this morning a class of thirty--nine ladies were present, with 140 male students. The first case examined was that of a boy, with typhoid fever, and this case was followed by cases of lead palsy, (male,) hysteric palsy, (female,) bloody vomiting, (female,) and hear disease, (male.)

At the assembling of the Superior Court in Lawrence yesterday morning Judge WILKINSON charged the jury in the case of LEONARD CHOATE, on trial for setting fire to the slaughter house and barn of JOSEPH ACKERMAN on the night of the 16th January last, and occupied about an hour.

Captians and purpose of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W Simonton, General Agent. New packages for the Journal of mmerce, Times, Tribune, World, Sun, Express, Evening post, commercial Advertiser, staats Zeitung and New-Yorker Demokrat, should also do delivered only to the same ??.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER in the case of the infants found dead in a chimney in the basement of the premises No. 162 East Twenty-eighth-street, as fully narrated in yesterday's TIMES. MARY HOLLINGSHEAD, who occupies the lower portion of the house, testified that she had no knowledge of the remains.

Rev-ALBERT BARNES, the well-known Biblical Commentator, is to publish Scenes and Incidents in the Life of St. Paul. Rev. JOHN HICKS, D. D., Senior Presbyter of the Diecese of Vermont, died at Burlington on the 4th inst.

MATTHEW ARNOLD lays down as a fundamental principle in the management of schools that three things should be inculcated--a love of simplicity and equality, a high sense of honor, and a feeling of humanity.

Colonel WHITLEY, Chief of the Secret Service, made some further progress yesterday in the counterfelt tobacco and match stamp case, which he has had on his hands for several weeks. JOHN RIPPON, the man arrested at Princess Bay, and whose residence in Fort Green-place, in Brooklyn, was found to contain a press and other materials for the manufacture of counterfeit coin and revenue stamps, was induced to make a confession a few days ago.

A wholesale onslaught upon the banks of New-York and Brooklyn has just been averted by the prompt arrest of two gentlemen, who have been for a long time preparing for a very extensive campaign in the way of "raising the Wind."

Organization for the promotion of class interests is rapidly spreading among the various ranks of artisans. Like other divisions of society, they have discovered the strength which results from combination, and the wisdom of that policy which makes the welfare of the individual identical with the welfare of the mass.

The ceremony of laying the foundation stone of the main building of the now United States Post Office and Court House, took place early yesterday afternoon, in a quiet and unostentatious manner, under the direction of the Superintendent, Hon. CALVIN T. HULBURD; the builder, Mr. T. T. SMITH; master mason, MICHAEL LYDDAN, and master rigger,

It has been already published that a man arrested as LUKE EGAN, and as being the man who was concerned in a burglary in Mayfield, Chatauqua County, was hurried off by Superintendent KENNEDY on Friday morning before a habeas corpus could be served on him.

Italian opera has enjoyed a week of abundant prosperity. "Crispine," "It Trovatore," "Fra Diavolo" and "Linda" have drawn houses of uniform excellence, and as every one seems to have determined that the season shall be a "pyramidal" success, we presume there not need be no doubt of it.

Last night another monster demonstration in favor of HENRI ROCHEFORT was held in the streets. The people were not disturbed by the Police. The garrison of the city will be immediately augmented by two regiments of cavalry.

SUPERIOR COURT - SPECIAL TERM - NOV. 13. By Judge F. J. Fithian. Rebecca Baird vs. Third-avenue Savings Bank ; the judgement in favor of the defendant, if any has been entered, must be set aside and a new trial granted, costs to abide event, unless defendant stipulate to correct the verdict nune pro tune, so that the same be entered and recorded by the clerk as and for $65 47,

In steamship Leo, from Savannah.--Miss Jeannie Woodruff, Geo. H. Birer, W. J. Wilson, F. H. Gore, B. E. Wright, T. M. Williams, E. F. Goddard, D. H. Smith, Captain E. T. Merrill, L. Herz. Mrs. E. Johnsan, Mr. Landry.

It is reported that the spanish Government to-day received a dispatch from Florence stating that the entire Italian Cabinet approve of the candidature of the Duke of GENOA. Senor ORENSE, one of the Republican Deputies, who was recently arrested, has been unconditionally released. He had gone to France.

In this age of inventive genius, it is impossible to aver to what lengths we are to go in the matter of improvement, so far as pertains to everything connected with our social well being. One after another there come up for public attention new applications of scientific principles to the wants of the community.

A gentleman called at the Witness office yesterday to inform us that his brother had gone to confession last Saturday, in order to get the necessary certificate to present at the parish church to enable him to get married.

BRENTANO received yesterday, by the English steamer, a royal supply of the now London magazines, and the counters in his little Broadway store are fuller and more attractive than ever. In the fresh lot are London Society, The Cornhill, Temple Bar, Tinsley's, Cassell's and the Sunday Magazine-the English edition of course, and not the reprint-for November, with the October number of All The Year Round.

Mr. RAILSBACH, of the Five Points House Industry, after making a thorough examination of a single block of tenement houses in the Sixth ward, writes that he found in the block 551. families, comprising 2,527 persons, of whom 1,241 were adults and 1,206 children. Most of the families have but one room, and the aggregate amount of rent is about $60,000.

The true story of that San Domingo affair, which haws been suddenly revived and which has occupied public attention to some extent during the past few days, is substantially the one, we are led to believe, already recounted in these columns by our Washington correspondent.

Yesterday a special meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health was held, at when the following report was submitted by the Sanitary Superintendent, Dr. ELISHA HARRIS: The Board of Health already is fully aware that its medical officers and its Sanitary Engineer are of opinion that the entire premises and appurtenances of the rendering dock are inherently and persistently offensive to the smell, and are the sources of very offensive odors, which,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your edition of this morning there appeared a communication signed "H," and while the article is but a weak attempt to detract from the credit so justly earned by Captain DUCHESNE and his gallant steamer, it will be well to lay before your readers a true statement of the case.

Alluding to the statement in our Washington dispatches on Friday that a package of $10,000 in fractional currency sent from a Newark national bank to the Treasury Department for redemption was found to be $2,000 short, the Newark Advertiser says:

One would have supposed that the questions. relating to the proper enlistment of men into the United States Army had been all disposed of in the various habeas corpus cases which have come before our Courts within the last few years.

The Now-York Genealogical and Biographical Society met last evening at Mott Memorial Hall, Madison-avenue, Dr. HENRY R. STILES presiding. Several donations to the library were received. Two life members,four resident and two corresponding members were elected, and eight new names were proposed for membership.

Many important reforms have been introduced into the office of the United States District-Attorney in this City since Judge PIERREPONT assumed charge. The complaints formerly so frequent that parties were arrested on warrants without knowing the cause of their arrest are no longer made.

Correspondence of the Cleveland Leader. BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, Monday, Nov. 9, 1869. A terrible tragedy occurred here last night, by which Father JOHN COVENEY, a Catholic priest of this place, lost his life.

To-day was the sixth of the meeting of the Chickasaw Jockey Club. The Club stake, $1,000 or a goblet, dash, of four miles, for all ages, subscription, $50, pay or play the second horse to receive $100, was won by Carrie A therton, who beat Corsican, Killy Free and Crossland. Time, 7:59.

At the last term of the Court of Appeals, a decision was rendered in the case of WILLIAM KEEFE us. The People, which was argued at the preceding term of the Court. The prisoner was tried at the November Term of the Criminal Court, 1865, upon an indictment for the murder of JOHN ABRAHAMS, which occurred in this City in the month of June, 1865.

"With Mr. PEABODY'S country we are not likely to quarrel." These were Mr. GLADSTONE'S words at the Lord Mayor's banquet on Tuesday last. That they were not intended as empty compliments is proved by the honors which were paid to Mr. PEABODY'S memory on Friday.

DOROTHEA D. FAY, a very respectable-looking female, appeared against EDWARD BURNS, agent for KELLY Co., No. 416 Sixth-avenue, at the Court of Special Sessions yesterday morning, and charged him with assault and battery. The defendant keeps a furniture store, and sells to people who are anxious to furnish houses, allowing them to pay for it by monthly installments.

The Diario, (newspaper,) this morning, has an editorial article wherein it says that " the existence of any anti-Spanish element in Cuba is abnormal and transitory. The enemies of Spain could not remain there. There are but two elements of population--Spanard and foreigners."

The difficulties of the Erie Railway Company with its employes are unending. The strike of the old brakemen promises, now more than ever, to be successful. The agitation in favor of a strike by the engineers; unless the old brakemen be restored to their places, is gaining ground.

The tournament at the Brooklyn Chess Club will probably be concluded at the beginning of next month. Upward of 160 games have been already contested; the total number, if all were played, would be 342, expressed by the algebraie sign 19--1x19-2x2. There being nineteen players, and each having to play two games with every other player,

Some time age a trunk containing clothing valued at $2,468 was stolen from the baggage room of the Erie Railroad, at the foot of Chambers-street, and the efforts to discover the thief and recover the property were not successful until yesterday, when one JOHN PATTERSON was arrested by Detective BLACKWOOD, of the Ninth Precinct, as the guilty party.

Another preliminary meeting of the Women's Council was hold yesterday afternoon, corner of Broadway and Twenty-second-street. Mrs. Dr. ANNA DINSMORE presided, and the subject of organizing their councils in all parts of the country was discussed with much spirit as well as wisdom and ability.

Two additional regiments of cavalry are to be added to the garrison at Paris. Another large demonstration was made in that city on Friday night in honor of ROCHEFORT, but the people were not disturbed by the police.

G. B. STEBBINS, of Detroit, denies making the assertion, as charged by Professor PERRY in his speech on Monday night, that population of England to pauperism. He says he simply quoted from the New-York Times. He did not make the statement on his own authority.

At a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners, held yesterday, it was ordered that the following resolution, adopted some years ago, be anew promulgated in a general order of the Superintendent: Resolved, That the Captains of Police be required to give their personal attention and supervision to the orders for investigations into the characters, habits and associates of applicants for appointment in the Police force, which may be referred to them;

NOV. 13--In steamship Ville de Paris, for Hanre and Brest.--Mrs. E. N. Crosby and family, Mrs. Naef, Miss Merritt, G. Merritt, D. Merritt, Mr. Roel, A. Guesnard, Mrs. Steinhart, Mrs. Walden Pell, Mr. Aubert, Mrs. Hutton and maid, J. W. Kohlsaat, Miss Anderson, Miss E. E. Vernon, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Palmer, 2 children and 2 maids, W. Whitehouse, S. S. Whitehouse, E. Stern and servant, Hon. Elliot C. Cowdin, D. Mendez,

The inquest in the case of JAMES SHERIDAN, who, it is alleged, came to his death by the hands of his step-sister, ROSANNA ROGERS, was resumed at Newark, N. J., yesterday by Coroner LANG. The first witness called was Mrs. HANNA ROBINSON, step-mother of deceased, widow.

The annual nuisance of target company parades is just now in full force, searcely a day passing without the appearance of one or more of these burlesque commands in our streets. With very few exceptions, these organizations are the exact opposite of a military body. Composed mainly of boys, and "officered" by ambitious striplings,

BUCKNAM.--At Port-au-Prince, Hayti, on Thursday, Oct. 28, after a short illness, EZRA BUCKNAM, in the 64th year of his age. His remains will be brought home for interment at the earliest opportunity. COOK.--Suddenly, on Friday, Nov. 12, GEORGE Cook, of this City, in the 53d year of his age.

Steamship Agamemnon, (Br.,) Middleton, Marseilles Sept. 25, Genoa 28th, Leghorn Oct. 9, Naples 11th, Messina 15th, Palermo 19th, and Malaga 26, with fruit, , and 2 passengers to Alfred Booth. Experienced very light casterly winds up to Nov. 7, lat. 35 17, lon. 58 15, and from thence had very strong gales from N. W. to W. S. W.; Nov. 4, lat, 35 11, lon. 62, exchanged ensigns with a American frigate, bound E.
From Le Follet. The season has arrived when we must discard the light and airy materials of Summer wear, and adopt the more appropriate, though not less elegant warmer textures.

More than 600 Americans attend the German Universities. The squadron of the Cent Gardos, composed of 13 officers and 218 men, costs the French War Department $60,000 a year. Halt the squadron is in personal attendance on the Empress and half on the Emperor.

More interesting particulars were obtained yesterday concerning the great scheme by means of which the National Treasury has been depleted of nearly one million dollars as fraudulent drawback claims. It appears that a fast fellow named HUGO A. SUMMERS, now dead, was the first to perpetrate the frauds on the Government through the connivance of dishonest Custom House clerks.

It is a fact well known to the readers of the TIMES from publications repeatedly made in these columns, that an investigation of certain gigantic frauds perpetrated against the Government by the managers of lottery and policy establishments in this City, has been carried on for several weeks past by Assessor DOTY, of the Sixth District.

By the discovery of the calcined bodies of three infants in the chimney of a house in a respectable quarter of the City, a nest of murder has boon disturbed. The matter will give rise, of course, to a very searching inquiry; but while a full investigation must be made, we regret that the name of a former occupant of the house has been dragged into the case at this early stage.

Mrs. HAMMOND, better known as Belle Boyd, who became widely known during the war in consequence of her efforts to benefit the Southern Confederacy, and who has lately been giving readings in California, was yesterday taken to the Asylum at Stockton, having through sickness and mental excitement become insane.
A fire occurred last night in NO. 25 Suoth Howard street, The first story of the building was occupied by RUTHRAUFF, ALGER CO., boots and shoes; loss' $20,000; fully insured.

Our readers will remember that in the month of'April last a man, giving the name of FRANCIS E. PINTON, an alias borrowed from a gentleman residing in Brooklyn, in whose regiment be had served during the war, committed a very daring robbery in the Park Bank.

From the Troy Times of Last Evening. The last sad solemnities are over, and all that was mortal of JOHN E. WOOL has been deposited in Oakwood. Those who have united in paying the last sad tribute of respect to the dead hero have finished their task, and he has been left alone in the companionship of the dead.

The second Committee of Conference to reconsider the disagreement between the Senate and House upon the Convention bill, reported this morning that they could not agree. Propositions were then made in both Houses instructing the Committee to report a compromise providing that the Convention shall be composed of seventy-five members, instead of fifty, as proposed by the Senate, and one hundred, as proposed by the House.

The regular mail steamer from Rio Janeiro, which arrived to-day, brings the following news from Paraguay: One hundred and thirty-three Brazilian soldiers had been surrounded by President LOPEZ'S force at Curuguaty. The Prince D'Eu had started from Rosario with a portion of his army to attempt their release.

In the suit of BEATRICE BISSELL vs. JOHN B. BISSELL, for a limited divorce. Judge BARNARD yesterday rendered the following decision: This is an action for limited divorce on the ground of abandenment, under subdivision 3, section 51. article 4, title 1, chapter 8 of Part 2 of the Revised Statutes.

In an interview with Senator CLARK, of New-Hampshire, last week, we were favored with several incidents illustrative of the character of our departed townsmen. At the time that the death of Senator FOOTE was announced in the Senate, speeches expressive of the public loss were made, among them one of great beauty and pathos by Mr. FESSENDEN.

By advises from Hawaii we learn that the Volcano of Kilauea is again in action. The "Old South Lake," which our readers will recollect, has been for some time nothing but a "big hole in the ground," is again filled with lava.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The current number of the Galaxy contains an article on the English universitites, generally so just and correct as to make one regret all the more that it should be marred by some passages in which the writer has either exaggerated or generalized too hastily.

The strike of the brakemen upon the Eric Road is virtually disposed of. The men expected corporation from the engineers, but this they have so far failed to receive. Most of the engineers entertain the proposition far from favorably.

Miss RYE, bringing with her a batch of ten grils and seventy children immigrants, arrived at Quebee, by the steamship Hibernian from Liverpool, on Tuesday. The ten girls, with the exception of two who come to families in Montreal, proceed to Upper Canada. The seventy children, the majority of whom are females, are nf an average age of seven years.

The large frame building known as the Republican Wigwam, corner Lako and Market streets, was destroyed by fire last evening. Total loss, $40,000; insurance about f31,000. The fire is supposed to have boon the work of an incendiary.

Several of the churches on the eastern side of the city have been imposed upon, within the past few months, by a pretender named FONDA, who insiuantes himself into, the confidence of good people for the worst of motives.

The defenders of the coal monopoly deny that any benefit to consumers of Nova Scotia coal would follow a repeal of the duty. Let us see whether this logic will hold water. The price of any natural product to the consumer depends, first, upon the cost of its production, and, secondly,

A notice has been issued by the Central Pacific Railroad Company to its agents--a copy of it being posted at the ticket office of the passenger depot in this city--directing that on and after Nov. 1 all freight charges and ticket rates payable in currency will be receivable only in currency.

The Troy collar makers and laundresses, after a long contest with their employers for higher wages, established a "Cooperative Laundry," with the view of competing with their late masters. They failed, however, in getting sufficient work to keep the laundry in operation, and at last determined to establish a manufactory for the purpose of making enough collars and cuffs to keep the laundresses busy.

HIGGINSON--GRACIE.--At Christ Church, in Elizabeth, N. J., on Thursday, Nov. 11, by Rev Stevens Parker, JAMES J. HIGGINSON to MARGARET BETHUNE, daughter of the late Archibald Gracie. HOFFMYER--CLARK.--On Thursday, Nov. 11, at the residence of the bride's parents, by Rev. A. A. Reinke, of the Moravian Episcopal Church, JOS. A. HOFFMYER to ISABELLA CLARK, daughter of Abin. B. Clark.

A superbly-illuminated catalogue has just been issued by Mr. THEO. E. BALDWIN, (successor to the firm of BREWSTER BALDWIN,) carriage builder of this City, the plates of which are said to have cost $10,000. Every style of carriage is handsomely pictured for the information of purchasers.

JOHN POXLEY, who was arrested in this city for having burglar's tools in his possession, proves to be an escaped convict from sing Sing with a four years' unexpired term to serve. He has boon sent back in charge of a New-York officer.

The time has arrived for the primary meetings of the Republicans in this City. But our reporters have already informed the public that there is a total already informed the public that there is a total apathy in the party with reference to the candidates. The Republicans have "about come to the conclusion that it is useless to go to he polls."

A new hospital for the above class of diseases has been opened and put in working order by Dr. H. KNAPP, formerly Professor in the University of Heidelberg. it is incorporated under the name of "The New-York Ophthalmic and Aural Institute." Gurdon Buck, M. D., A. C. Post, M. D., F. S. Winston, C. H. Loutrel, A. D. F. Randolph, N. J. Waterbury.

Last evening in the new Catholic church at College Point, Rev. Dr. FARLEY, of Jamaica, preached a sermon in which, after sketching the history of the Church, he said the Catholic Church is as firm to-day as it was eighteen centuries ago, and the sterms and winds of heresy, infidelity and sectarianism cannot move the rock on which it is erected.

Mr. ALEXANDER DELMAR, who mistakes notoriety for fame, and who will have the former if he cannot have the latter, has Joined the Washington staff of your contemporary, the World, and is engaged as secondary appendage to the celebrated " arithmetic man" employed on that paper.

If anybody knows what has become of the great Cab Company, which was long ore this to have had our streets swarming with cheap' well-appointed Hansom cabs,--or of the stil1 more celebrated Underground Railroad Company,

Advices received by the mall steamer from Rio Janeiro, which arrived here yesterday, confirm the previous reports of the important advantages gained by the Allied army in Paraguay. The Paraguayan troops were demoralized and deserting in large numbers.

PATRICK CAMPBELL, of No. 519 First-avenue, last evening, was amusing himself by beating his wife, and FRANK KEARNEY interesting to protect the woman, was turned upon by CAMPBELL, who dealt him a blow on the head with an ax. The Police arriving at the moment,

During the Summer just closed good work appears to have been done by the Geological survey in the Lake Superior region. Professor BELL'S party have all returned to their Winter quarters, after having experienced many of the hardships and privations incident to the life of the first explorers in the distant wilderness.

Our citizens were startled yesterday morning by the intelligence of the sudden and altogether unexpected death of Mr. WYLLYS WARNER, Secretary of Yale College, which occurred at Chicago Thursday morning.

The tone of Brooklyn Democratic politicians is now despondent. The work which they overdid has had to be undone in large measure, partly through fear of the terrible threats that are made in various quarters, intimations of vigilance committees, District-Attorney MORRIS and his threatened indictments and convictions, and the last fear of losing the support of earnest, honest and respectable Democrats at the next election.

The venerable and beloved citizen named above aled this morning, after a protracted illness, at the age of 81. The present generation or our city will remember him only as the milldlooking white-haired Christian gentleman, conspicuous in every good work and deed of benevolence, but old men among us call him to mind as one of the most conspicuous figures in the stormy party times of forty years ago.

In accordance with the announcement on Friday, the Bishop of London to-day delivered the funeral sermon on' the late GEORaE PEABODY. at Westminster Abbey. The interior was still hung with the drapery of mourning.

FRANCIS LYON, a boy 13 years of age, was arraigned before Justice DODGE yesterday, charged, with two others who are not yet arrested, with assaulting JAMES CLOONAN Wednesday night, in Twenty-sixth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, knocking him down and rifling his pockets of a watch and a small sum of money.

For some time past JOHN SMITH and MARY, his wife, both natives of Ireland, and aged about 30 years, have resided in the lodging house of PATRICK WARD, atNo. 37 Blulberry-street, Botll were habitual drunkards and frequently dlsturbed the house By their quarrels.

The hull of the frigate Augusta-a vessel that had a short but conspicuous career in the war of the colonists against the mother country -has at last been exhumed from the mud of the Delawaro. The exposure of this relic of thee revolution deserves more than a passing notice.

A few minutes past 9 o'clock this morning, the eastern-bound train on the Western Prcific Railroad, composed of eight cars, including one sleeping car, collided with the Alemeda Ferry train of four cars, near San Leandro. Both trains were going at the rate of twenty miles an hour.

At 12:30 o'clock this morning fire was discovered on the second floor of the four-story brick building, No. 175 Greenwich-street, and before the flames were extinguished the entire building with the contents had been materially damaged by fire or water. The first floor was occupied by A. P. CLARK, dealers in boots and shoes, the second floor by J. G. WOODS, printer, and the upper floors by S. HARRISON, cigar maker.

The Erie strike, instead of being "trampled out" by the warlike demonstrations of the managers, backed by their subsidized parties of roughs, seems to be extending and growing more formidable. The engineers of the road, who at first stood wholly aloof from the brakemen, now fear that they may be gradually drawn into the vortex, despite their own efforts.

There was a large assemblage of Latter-day Saints at the Free Church (Mormon) in Brooklyn, E. D., yesterday afternoon, on the occasion of a sermon by Elder THEODORE CURTIS of Salt Lake City, who arrived here on Saturday night.

On Sunday night last Mlle. SAGRINO, a performer on what is called the flying trapeze, began an engagement at the Varieties Theatre. We understand that she is about 18 years of age, of foreign birth, and the wife of HERCULES LIBBEY, a cannon ball manipulator, now performing at the same theatre.

About 9:30 o'clock last night, DAN NOBLE and THOMAS SMITH happening to meet on Lakestreet, near the Arbor and being both under the influence of liquor, had a war of words for a few minutes over a misunderstanding which occurred between them several months since, when they agreed to go inside the Arbor and flight it out.

The friends of St. Barnabas' House will do well not to forget its needs for Thanksgiving Day. It is hoped to provide on that day, as in former year, a dinner for the hundreds who attend the schools, and the many worthy poor who surround the mission.

A question of great importance in the practice of criminal law has boon at last decided by the Court of Appeals. It is nothing more than whether the greater includes the less in indictments for murder, and it came before the Court in the case of KEEFE V8. The People; the appellant,

The TIMES of 6th of July last gave a comprehensive history of the negotiations on the Alabama claims question, which embraced the correspondence from the time Mr. ADAMS reopened the discussion in December, 1867, down to Mr. REVERDY JOHNSON'S letter of February 17, 1869, in which he defended the convention against the criticisms it had provoked at home.

Nov. 14--In steamship City of Mexico, from Vera Cruz, $c.--A. T. Halsey, wife, 2 children and servant, G. A. Hawley, Felixe lierrera, Am. Campoa Diaz, Ed. Berron, Ernest Fischer, Alonzo Fernandez, J. Church. In steamship Maqnolia, from Charleston.--Charles Appleton John Riley, J. J. Buokalen and lady, Mrs. J. A. Smith, E. O. Adams, E. Hopkins, M, Carrington, 2 Sisters Mercy, and 4 in the stecrage.

Hon. JOHN SHERMAN of Ohio, has written the following reply to an invitation to attend the Georgia State Fair at Macon.: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Oct, 26, 1869. time an answer to your invitation to attend the Georgia Sate Fair at Macon, on the 16th of November next, with he sincere hope that I might be able to accept it;

As a Hibernian Society, returning from a funeral, was passing through Chatham Square Yesterday afternoon the ranks of the procession were broken by the driver of car No. 178, of the Third-avenue line, who attempted to go on without waiting for the Hibermans to straggle over his track.

The St. Paul Pioneer admits that the latest official and corrected returns for Governor of Minnesota give Judge AUSTIN, Republican, 359 majority. Four counties remained to be heard from, which will increase this majority.

The arrival hero from New-York of the steamer Algonquin, lately purchased for this Government, has inspired SALNAVE and his party with fresh hope, as they will now be enabled to prosecute the war with greater vigor, and may probably retrieve in a measure the disasters of the lasttwo or three months.

The Bishop of London, yesterday, deliverd the funeral sermon on the late GEORGE PEABODY, at Westminster Abbey, as previously announced. The edifice was filled by an immense congregation, who listened to the discourse with deep emotion.

AN ORDINANCE TO DIVIDE THIS CITY OF NEW-YORK INTO CONVENIENT ELECTION DISTRICTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION EIGHT, ARTICLE THREE, TITLE THREE, OR ACT OF THE LEGISLATURE PASSED APRIL FIVE, EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND FORTY-TWO. (Containing all Amendments to Aug. 1, 1869.)

At the Academy "Norma" is to be given to-night by Mme. BRIOL, Miss LOUISE C. TREUER and Signorl MASSIMILLIANI and COLETTI. The season here is prospering finely, and we trust the attendance on this occasion will be up to the encouraging standard of last week.

When will the English Government have done with its pettiness on the Fenian amnesty question Y What a contrast does it present to the prompt, broad, bold policy of this Republic toward its rebels, and how little to justify the difference!

The sales for the week just closed were not equal to the previous one. Considerable property was offered, but a large proportion of it was not sold. Some of the most desirable lots actually changed hands, but very many that were put up remain on the hands of the owners. The auctioneers did their utmost, but just now there is but little disposition shown to buy.

A commotion of no ordinary character has prevailed hero for a few days past, growing out of the magnitude of the claims, In the shape of bonds and mortgages, and other Indebtedness of the Atlantic and Great Western Railway, and for the satisfaction of which an order of Court Is asked for the sale of the road,

A resolution was unanimously adopted by the Louisville Convon'tion requesting Ex-Precident FILLMORE to appoint a delegation of six persons to attend the Russian Expostion In 1870. This suggestion came from Europe.

In the Circuit Court this morning, the jury in the case of JOHN H. WELLS against the Rensselaer and Saratoga Railroad Company, rendered a verdict in favor of plaintiff for $5,500 damages. The case has occupied the attention of the Court the past three days, and was submitted to the jury at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, who remained out all night.

On Thursday last seven cane fields in the vicinity of Las Cruces wore burnt. Since that time four Chinamen were discovered in the act of firing another cane field. They were seized and immediately executed. The settlement of Taguayaben, which was defended by thirty volunteers, has been captured by the iusurgents and burnt.

The Califonia Immigrant Union hns advertised for proposals for building an immigrant depot capable of accommodating from 500 to 1,000 boarders. The California Legisiature will occupy the new Capitol building in Sacramento during their next session.

Last evening Hon. C. C. LIGH lectured before Neptune Sons of Temperance, No. 3, at their hall in Grand-street. He said that the temperanco cause had many opponents; among them were appetite, habit, the doctors, the rumsellers and our legislators.

The proceedings in the Constituent Cortes on Saturday were interesting and important. One of the Porto Rico Deputies asked Senor BECERRA, the Minister for the Colonies, what the course of the Government would be toward the island that was peopled by 600,000 faithful Spaniards.

The manifesto of the Opposition members of the Corps Legislatif is published, and is signed by twenty-eight Deputies. They say that the demand by the people of the right to govern themselves means an inevitable transformation, the necessity of which is each day proved to be more and more imperative.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. MONAGHAN in the Chair. Mr. PINCKNEY presented a resolution directing the Comptroller to inform this Board of the number of leases of wharves, piers and slips made by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund during 1869, the names of the persons to whom such leases, were given, and the terms of such leases.

It is only the old story repeated for the hundredth time, when we are told that " Mexico is once more on the eve of a revolution." That unhappy "sister republic" is always either in the midst of a revolution, or on the brink of it. Anarchy seems to be its chronic state, and a little relief in the way of tranquillity and order is an unexpected blessing.

The annual meeting of the Missionary Society of the M. E. Church was held at St. Paul's Church yesterday at 10:30 o'clock A. M. Rev. Dr. HARRIS made a statement of the finances of the Society, from which it appeared that the total receipts during the past year have been 2612-726 71, and the expenditures $624,779 40.

The announcement which we publish this morning, from our own correspondent at St. Petersburg, foreshadows a now and startling complication in European politics. The statement is that a proposal has breen submitted by Prince GORTSCHAKOFF to the French Minister for an Alliance, offensive and defensive, between Russia, France and Austria.

The Alabama Legislature met to-day. The Governor's Message was read In bota Houses. It is very conservative. He combats the calls made for martial law, and says there has been no necessity for it; sets forth the general peacefulness of the people and the advantage offered In this State for emi gration; favors a reduction of taxes, and a limit to the Indorsements by the State for railroads.

Owing to the death of General BUTTERFIELD'S father yesterday, no business was transacted at the Sub-Treasuror's office. Senator CHAS. J. FOLGER, the new incumbent, appeared at the Treasury building in the afternoon for the first time, but remained there a short time only. Ho will probably not assume his official duties for a day or two.

The discussion between free traders of the ultra sort, and protectionists of the kind akin to monopolists, proceeds on the bypothesis that there is no middle ground which can be consistently occupied. The free traders represent all who demur to the legislative acceptance of their abstract principle as virtually in favor of protection for its own sake, and a high tariff as its legitimate result.

Yesterday morning WM. KEANE, aged 24, living at No. 173 Dolancoy-street, a feeder in the Herald pressroom, was fatally wounded in the head by a man named JAMES LEE. The two men had been on a spree together, all of Sunday night, and became somewhat intoxicated by daylight yesterday.

The United States Fire Department of this place turned out at 10 o'clock this morning for a parade, and presented a fine appearance. It consists of a steamer, two hand engines, four hose trucks and a hook and ladder wagon.
