The will of General WOOL: has not yet been opened. It is understood, however, that he has left property to the extent of $650,000, most of which is in available moans. It is said he has bequeathed to his nephews ad nieces a large part of it. His homestead, library, paintings, , valued with a bequest of $35,000, at about $100,000, he leaves to his nephew and namesake, JORN WOOL GRISWOLD.

The Board of County Canvassers of Kings County resumed their business yesterday, and canvassed the returns from the Eleventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth, Fourteenth, Fifteenth and Sixteenth Wards. As on former days, there were numerous frauds detected in the form of measures, in all cases made so as to reduce the vote for WALTER for Sheriff, and McLEER for Street Commissioner.

The Republicans of the Twenty-second-street organization, last evening, elected delegates to the Judiciary, Charter and Ward Conventions. There was no opposition in any of the districts. The delegates elected will meet at their various headquarters as follows:

Coroner BATHGATE, yesterday, resumed his investigation relative to the accident on the Harlem Railroad, which resulted in the death of THOS. HAMMOND, the fireman, on Thursday night last. The conductor and brakemen of the train were examined, without cholting any new facts.

The Social Science Society, last evening at Plimpton Hall, elected the following officers for the term ending in May next: B. F. LEE, President; W. B. SCOTT, Vice-President; CHARLES MORAN, Treasurer; W. L. ORMSBY, Recording Secretary, and R. L. DUGDALE, CorrespondIng Secretary.

The Committee of Home Industrial School NO. 5, No. 244 West Thirty-third-street, are preparing to give a Thanksgiving dinner to the little ones under a their fare. They ask the charitable to the good cause in which they are engaged. Donations in money and food, also in clothing, will be thankfully received and carefully disbursed.

The heavy and startling defalcations young EDWARD B. KETCHUM, not four years are still fresh in the recollection of the business community. How he laid deep schemes for own aggrandizement, involved himself in a tangle of "irregularities," and finally brought ruin to his firm and disgrace upon his head, need not be repeated here.

The schooner John Atwood, of Provincetown, which reached this port yesterday from Baracoa, on the northeast of Cuba, in twentyone days, brings a story of an outrage perpetrated by the military at the latter place. She reports that having obtained the proper clearances from the authorities at Baracoa on Oct. 25, she took a pilot n board and got under weigh.

The American Institute of Architects begins its third annual Convention at the rooms of the Now-York Chapter, No. 935 Broadway, at 3 P. M. to-day, when the annual address will be delivered by the President, RICHARD UPJOHN, Esq. Tho sessions will continue to-morrow, at 11 A. M., 3 P. M. and 8 P. M., at the last of which the closing address is to be delivered by E. L.

In the Shaker habeas corpus case of SARAH ANN BARBOCR of New-Dorp, Staten Island, against Illegal restricting of her child, MARION S. D. BARBOUR, which was issued last July and returnable before Judge MILLER, of this city the Court to-day rendered its decision, awarding the child to the custody of the mother and deciding that the Shakers illegally held and restrained her.

The death of Mr. BUTTERFIELD, which occurred at his home in Utica on Sunday evening, was not unexpected. Some two years age he was stricken with paralysis at the Aster House in this City, and had never recovered from the shock. Had he lived until Thanksgiving Day he would have been 68 years old.

The country is once more on the eve of a ??solution, owing to the discord existing among the Ministers. LERDO'S ambition knows no bounds, and he will not permit either the Ministers of his tool, the President, to inaugurate or carry out any measures of which he may disapprove. That he is the most talented of all cannot he gainsaid; but he is also the most unscrupulous.

ANDREWS.--On Sunday evening, Nov. 14, THOMAS ANDREWS, formerly of Hudson City, N. J., in the 45th year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family, and the veterans of the Seventh Regiment, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, 17th inst., at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 135 West 44th-st. BRENNAN.--On Monday, Nov. 15. HANNAH BRENNAN, the mother of Timothy, Owen W. and Mathew T. Brennan.

Spain moves at last. The Government has gradually arrived at the realization of the truth that slavery is dead, and that the nation which trics to keep it alive only invites misfortune. Tile Minister for the Colonies told the Cortes on Saturday that the Government proposed to treat Porto Rico as a Spanish province, and was willing to abolish slavery, and allow indemnification to slaveowners for losses incurred.

A meeting of the Equal Rights Association of Brooklyn was held at tile Academy of Music in that city last evening, the audience numbering one thousand persons or more. The Brooklyn Equal Rights Association is a society recently organized to " promote the equal civil and political rights of all American citizens without distinction of race or sex."

An executive session of the Gold Board was held yesterday afternoon, Mr. J. F. UNDERHILL in the chair, to consider the expediency of allowing the Gold Exchange Bank to resume its ancient connection with the bank, and to hear the report of the Committee to whom the subject was referred at a previous meeting. Mr. R. L. EDWARDS, of the Committee, (who are, as well, the directors of the new Clearing House,

J. C. BUELL, cashier of the Second National Bank in this city, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the head. The cause is supposed to have been mental depression, resulting from losses during the late panic.

The Western Branch of this Association, having its rooms at No. 285 Hudson-street, held its regular were made from the different committees, such as the Library, Boarding-house, Church, Devotional Exercises and Lecture Committees.

The Grammar Schoolhouse, in Newton Centre, was destroyed by lire this morning. It is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary. It cost $10,000, and is insured for $25,000. LAWRENCE, Mass., Nov. 15.-The extensive leather board factory of HAYDEN BALCOM was destroyed by fire yesterday. Also the braid mill of WEBSTER MILLER, in the same building. Loss $30,000; mostly insured.
A number of the leading ladies in the Roman Catholic parish of St. Anthony will open a Fair this evening at the Sullivan-street Church, of which Rev. Father JOACHIM is pastor.

The now chapter of Alabama correspondence which we published yesterday morning, with its letters from Secretaries SEWARD and FISH, Lord CLARENDON, and Messrs. THORNTON and REVERDY JOHNSON, brings the history down to thE negotiations in train under Mr. MOTLEY.

A litigation in the Superior Court, in Ciicinuati. has recently resulted in affirming the judgment of a lower Court against a fire insurance company for the amount of a disputed claim. The Company set up as their principal defence the violation of a provision inserted in the policy which they issued, to the effect that the best endeavors of the owner should be used at and after a fire to save the property insured.

The Inman steamship City of London, which left Liverpool on Nov. 4, and Queenstown on Nov. 5, and the Helvetia, Liverpool Oct. 30, and Queenstown Nov. 1, reached this port yesterday. The City of London brings news later by three days than was at hand by the Main.

In the hour before dawn of Sunday, when the sleep of laboring life is most profound, a monster stole to a stairway which was the sole means of exit for scores of men, women and children occupying a vast tenement house in this City.

" NORMlA" AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Chiefly to give Mme. BRIOL a suitable opportunity to exhibit her powers as a dramatic singer, "-Norma" was presented last night at the Academy, with results, so far as that lady is concerned, that may justly be styled very satisfactory, while they cannot be pronounced great.

In the Court of General Sessions yesterday Judge BEDFORD, in the case of Commissioners of Charities and Correction vs. WM. E. VAN HAUTEN, appellant, rendered the following decision : This is an appeal in bastardy from an order of filiation made by JAMES E. COULTER, one of the Aldermen of the City of New-York, on the 31st day of August, 1869.

There is a probability of a conflict of a serious character between the United States and State authorities in Philadelphia. Last week Supervisor LITTON, of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seized a distillery in that city. On Saturday he was arrested by the sheriff under a warrant charging him with having forcibly invaded the premises seized, without warrant of law.

Begardous' Fine Art Gallery, No. 1,153 Broadway, was opened to private view last evening. The gallery is not a very extensive one, but it contains already about one hundred paint-lugs by native artists, with several pieces of sculpture by KUNTZE, PICKETT, MANLY and RICHARDS.

The following unsafe buildings have been reported to the Superintendent of Public Buildings during the week ending Nov. 15: Nov. 9, Nos. 318, 126 Chrystie-street; front and south side wall badly bulged; rear wall badly bulged and cracked, and in a very dangerous condition. Nov. 12, Nos. 319, 636 Sixth-street; front wall badly cracked and out of plumb;

The case of ALEXANDER HENDERSON us GEORGE II. BUTLER has been again revived. It will be remembered that about the first of June last, a certain article appeared in WILKES' Spirit of the Times, Commenting in severe terms upon ALEXANDER HENDERSON, manager and halfowner of the LYDIA THOMPSON Burlesque Troupe.

The Kings County Board of Supervisors met yesterday morning and signed the warrants for the collection of the taxes in the various wards of Brooklyn and county towns. The collection of taxes commenced yesterday.

Yesterday, at Edwardsville, in the County of Madison and State of Illinois, about twenty milles distant from St. Louis, WILLIAM BELL suffered the extreme penalty of the law for the murder of one HERMAN WENDELL, of that coucty, on Saturday night, Nov. 21, 1868.

On the 25th of October last, a case containing $7,000 worth of diamond rings was stolen from the store of BISHOP REIN, in the Fifth-avenue Hotel Building. Quite recently an officer of Police from this City, named PIKE, went to Boston and there identified a man, giving the name of LEVISION, as one of the gang who committed the diamond robbery.

A terrible boiler explosion occurred In STORMS' paper mill at Catskill village at 11:30 this A. M. The building was completely demolished and several lives were lost. It is impossible to tell at present the full extent of the disaster. It is known that Mrs. GEORGE BRADOW, the wife of the engineer, was Instantly killed.

At Washington Market, yesterday, prime beef was selling at $13 50 per cwt., and inferior quality as low as $8 per cwt.; excellent mutton at $7 to $9 per cwt., and fat lambs at $8 to $14 per ewt.; pork, by the carcass, at 131/2c. per pound; poultry of all sorts, such as chickens, 25c. to 28c. per pound; turkeys at 22c., 25c. and 28c. per pound; ducks at 22c. to 25c. per pound;

If we consider the predictions or the threats of the Democratic Press since the elections, there is by no moans an inviting future before the residents of this City. We have enjoyed, as all call testify, the luxury for a few years past of an honest and thorough administration of various important branches of public trust.

In the Spanish Cortes at Madrid, on Saturday, Colonial Minister BECERRA, in reply to a Deputy from Porto Rico, who asked how the Government proposed to treat the island, said "that the treatment of the colonies would be such that the people would be proud to call themselves Spaniards."

The Presbyterians yesterday celebrated the union of the old and new school Churches by a joint communion at Central Church in the afternoon, and a joint meeting at the Walnut-street Church In the evening. BOSTON, Nov. 15.-Colonel ALFRED W. JOHNSON, a well-known citizen of Belfast, Me., died suddenly last night at the St. James Hotel of lung disease. Ho was going South for his health.

An examination in the case of FRANCES A. HOWARD, alleged to have assisted in he drawback frauds while acting as a clerk in the office of Internal Revenue at Washington, was commenced before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday afternoon. Judge PIEREPONT conducted the prosecution, being assisted by Mr. PURDY.

A new and original swindle was practices upon the pupils of Public School No. 4, in Jersey City, a few days ago. A distinguished-looking gentleman, tall, dark-complexioned and of philanthropic men, visited the school, and introduced himself as Rev. Mr. WHEELER, of Charleston, B. C., asking the principal to assist him in the good work of educating the negroes of the South.

The late Commercial Convention at Louisvillo took very strong ground in favor of the project proposed by tile Mediterranean and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of this City. T. CLARK, Esq., the special delegate of the Board of Directors, received flattering attintions from the Convention, and his statement of the purposes entertained by the Company was indorsed by the entire assemblage.

On Saturday night Major H. A. PERRINE, station master and freight agent of the Camden and Amboy Railroad, at Jamesburg, was run over and killed, near the station, by a mail train. The locomotive had become detached from the train and ran up to the station in advance.

Further particulars of the disaster on the Western Pacific Railroad, this morning, have been received. Eleven dead bodies, recovered from the wreeked cars, have been taken to the dead house in Oakland. It is estimated that twenty persons were wounded.

A dispatch from Alexandria announces the arrival of the Emperor of Austria at Port Said. The Empress EUGENIE is expected to reach that place to-morrow. The weather at the isthmus is very fine. LIVERPOOL, Nov. 15.--The Baz?ltan, a new vessel, constructed expressly for the Suez Canal traffic, should to-day for Port Said.

The special train for the Georgia State Fair reached hero at 4 o'clock this morning, all well. Governor BULLOCK boarded the train at Dalton. The guests upon the train breakfasted at the National Hotel, at the Governor's expanse, and loft soon after breakfast with Hon. SLMON CAMERON, Hon. G. W. WOODWARD, General HORACE CAPRON, Colonel J. W. FORNEY,

The following telegraphic communication has passed between the students of Princeton and Union Theological Seminaries in reference to the recent union of the Old School and New School bodies of the Presbyterian Church: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13, 1869. Princeton to Union. Greeting: We are now one in name as in heart. God bless you and help us with our united ranks to press on with vigor for His greater glory.

Steinway Hall, Fourteenth-street, was comfortably filled last evening on the occasion of a lecture by WENDELL PHILLIPS, who took for his subject "The Question of To-morrow," The lecturer commenced by alluding to the custom hitherto adopted of speaking, only on certain subjects, on the Lyceum.

The work of completing the Spanish flotilla, now lying at the Dolamater Iron Works, is proceeding rapidly, and there is every prospect of the vessels' completion by the first week in December. Moored in tiers, side by side, in the Delamater basin, the little craft present a busy scene.

The promise of the new Administration to ferret out, check and punish fraud in high places, is in a fair way of fulfillment. On Friday morning the examination in the case of the drawback frauds, which occurred under the last Administration, is to be resumed before Commissioner OSBORN.

The bitterness of spirit which stern conflict engendered is dying out among the Southern Republicans. In Alabama, as in Arkansas, the Governor has promulgated opinions which indicate the rapid growth of generous sentiment, and the prevalence of a disposition to obliterate as quickly as possible all that remains of proscription,

Bishop DUPANLOUP has published a letter, addressed to the clergy of his diocese, deprecating the idea that the present is a favorable opportunity for claiming the infallibility of the Pope. He blames such journals as L'Univers and La Civilla Cattolica for their inconsiderate haste in discussing so delicate a question in anticipation of the deliberations of the Council.

A meeting was held last night at the Fifth-avenue Hotel to make arrangements for the celebration of the centennial anniversary of the birth of BEETHOVEN, which occurs Dec. 17, 1870. Judge BRADY presided. Messrs., C.A. Stewart, Dr. Doremus, A. H. Green, F. E. Howe, Dr. J. P. Thompson, Henry Clews, D. Lyding Suydam, H. B. Fry,

For a couple of months past the columns of the TIMES have contained reports of the many burglaries committed in queens County. From JOHN ROBINSON, in Flushing. F. W. BRAGARD and O. F. OSTRANDER, in Newtown, more than $12,000 worth of property was taken.

Pending the result of the examination of Mr. S.T. BLATCHFORD'S case by the United States law officers, Collector GRINNELL himself has also been investigating the matter. Though saying but little he has not been idle in ferreting out the extent of the alleged frauds, and is determined, in addition, to carry his vigilance into certain other departments of the Custom House.

The Journal de Debats asserts that Queen ISABELLA has definitively abdicated the throne of Spain. Le Temps says: "Everything is impossible in Spain now--as Republic, because the Republicans are insufficient; a monarchy, because no party is strong enough to appoint a King.

Baron WERTHER, the new Prussian Minister to France, was received by the Emperor at Compiegne yesterday, when expressions of a mutual desire for the maintenance of the present amicable relations were indulged in. The Emperor spoke particularly of the development of a good understanding between Prussia and the German confederation on the one side and France on the other.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I was exceedingly gratified on perusing the article in your issue of the 8th inst., headed "How fires are caused and how their danger may be lessened." No better service can be rendered by our leading papers than to occasionally remind the public of the serious consequences likely to result from the careless use of combustible materials as well as fire.

London, Nov. 16.--According to a new arrangement the Government will dispatch Her Majesty's ship Monarch from Portsmouth, on Friday, the 26th inst., with the remains of the late GEORGE PEABODY. The Monarch will remain at Spithead for a few days until she is joined by the American vessels from the Mediterranean Squadron,

"LONDON" AT THE FRENCH THEATRE. The second performance of the new sensational drama of "London; or, Lights and Shadows of the Great City," was enjoyed at the French Theatre, last evening, by a numerous audience. The work, in spite of a compliccation of incidents, is an interesting one, and its purity of tone gives it a value distinct from recent pieces of a similar order.

Miss EDITH O'GORMAN, whose fortunes and misfortunes are Sister THERCHA of the Catholic Convent in Hudson City, has formed the subject of many paragraphs in the new-papers, lectured in Jersey City last evening on the "Roman Catholic Clergy." She had delivered two lectures before her appearance last evening,

There can be no doubt that the honors paid to the remains of Mr. PEABODY are in part in tended as a compliment to this country. Her Majesty's steamer Monarch will bring the body to these shores, in company with some vessels from the French fleet, and a detachment of American ships from the Mediterranean Squadron.

During a fencing scene at the Gaiety Theatre last night, one of the rapiers struck a kerosene lamp which exploded, setting fire to the scenery. The flames communicated to the auditorium, and before all in the building had time to escape the premises were enveloped in flames.

At injunction has been obtained by a part of the directors of the Montclair Railway. Restraining the Delaware, Lackawanna and West in Railroad Company from entering into an agreement to construct a railway from Caldwell to Newark.

An application for an injunction has been made in the Supreme Court to restrain Colonel EMMONS CLARK, of the Seventh Regiment, from approving of the section of the Fourth Company in expelling ARTEMUS B. JOHNSON for non-performance of duty on June 26, 1838, the latter claming that he had been transferred to the Fifth Company on June 5, 1868,

JOHN W. LALOR, a clerk in the Naval Office, and FREDERICK G. A. KEEVER, or Kuhune, a Custom House broker and employe, were brought before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, on the charge of obtaining goods by false representations. It was alleged that the accused entered the house of Mr. DUVERGER, at No. 124 East Tenth-street,

Sir FRANCIS HINCKS has secured his devoted seat in the House of Commons, but his victory is not one to be proud of. If he is not a hardened politician he must have regretted his return to Canada. When the announcement was first made that he was again to take an active part in Canadian politics,

An adjourned a special meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education was hold yesterday. The Board proceeded to select and adopt the books hereafter to be used in the schools, as follows: DAVIS' Elementary Algebra. MCGUFFEY's Spelling Cards.

The cases of HENRY WARD, of No. 2 Parkrow; EMMERSON, of No. 206 Broadway, and E. W. HULZ, of No. 180 1/2 Greenwich-street, who were separately charged with carrying on the business of lottery dealers without paying special Government tax, were called before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday for examination.

The salesroom yesterday presented quite a brisk appearance. The attendance was one of the largest obtained this season, and composed of a class of persons who will compare favorably with those of last Fall, when the real estate excitement was at its height and buyers were plenty.

The trial of the Pawnee Indians, Yellow Sun, Little Wolf, Horse Driver and Blue Hawk, charged with the murder of EDWARD MCMURTY, was completed in the United States District Court at Omaha, on Tuesday. The American Institute of ?? convened in third annual session at the rooms of the New-York Chapter, No. 225 Broadway, at 3 o'clock P. M. yesterday. There was a large attendance of Fellows of the Institute, many of whom came from distant eitles. tics.

The TIMES has just come into the possession of some very starting and important information regarding an investigation new being made on the part of the Treasury Department at Washington for the purpose, it is alleged, of discovering certain frands supposed to be conaceted with the issurance of the new fractional currency.

The Perian Coterie gave a masquerade ball at the Central Park Garden last evning. The evening's entertainment began with a grand march at 11 o'clock, In which some hundred couples took part. Turk and African. shepberdess and brigand, African and Yankeo, Spanish cavalier and Scotch lassie.

WILLIAM CARROLL was brought up for examination before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, on the charge of attempting to create a revolt and mutiny on board the ship Florence J. Lockwood, during the last voyage of the vessel between Wilmington and this City.

The latest intelligence regarding the Winnepeg war represents that Governor MCDOUGALL is now encamped in Dakota Territory. His family will return to Canada, but the Governor and his staff will a wait events at Fort Garry, where it is said there is a party in his favor, consisting of the employes of the Hudson Bay Company and some Scotch and English settlers.

There is continued excitement in Hartford and Erie stock and bonds, and to-day transactions on the street have been very heavy, the stock selling down to 9 3/4 and the bonds to 46 3/4. Parties who borrowed money on the stock and bonds have been notified for additional collateral, but reply that they cannot put up any more margins,

It is hard work to break down any system which politicians have found handy for purposes of corruption. We have not only to fight against the corrupters, but the corrupted, and the still more numerous class which is quite willinng to be corrupted if any one will make it worth their while.

As the Sultan has finally decided not to be present at the evening of M. DE LESSEPS' great work, the Viceroy will be able to exercise his hospitality in his own way, and will receive the credit of the undertaking. France will be represented by the Empress, who, in her steam yacht L'Aigle, will lead the way at the grand opening procession.

The New-York Historical Society celebrated their sixty-fifth anniversary last evening at their hall in Second-avenue. The venerable Dr. DEWITT presided over the large and cultivated audience that was in attendance despite the unfavorable night.

ANDREWS.--On Sunday evening, Nov. 14, THOMAHANDREWS, formerly of Hudson City, N. E., in the 45?? year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family, and the veterans of the Seventh Regiment are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, 17th inst. at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No, 136 West 44th-st.

If it has been a matter of surprise that so many of the great Midland Counties of New-York have remained for a whole generation since the introduction of railways in this State without proper facilities to trade and travel, it is gratifying to know that their wants are soon to be amply supplied. The fact is of almost, if not quite, equal importance to the City of New-York.

We are enabled this morning to give further particulars of the outrage perpetrated upon the American schooner John Alwood in the port of Baracoa, Cuba, of which we made brief mention yesterday. The consignee of the vessel in Baracoa was Sefior ALAYO, the American Consul at that port.

The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Common, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Alderman Moore, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller Cushman, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath, Farley, McQuade--13.

Mr. HENRY BERGH, President of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, sends us a note, in which he says that "the season being near when the 'sport,' as it is termed, of tying fowls to stones and other wise, and shooting at them on a wager,
A meeting in the interest of colored workingmen was held met evening at Bethel Church, Sullivan-street, which was addressed by AARON A. BRADLEY, of Georgia, and Mr. TROOP, of this City.

A large cotton factory on Spruce street, near Schuylkill, was burned last night. The loss is estimated at $80,000. The building was occupied by ALEXANDER BULFORD, HAGUE Co., BRIERLY Co., and DALTON JOHNSON, manufacturers of cotton goods.

About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon HENRY EASTON Collector of Customs for Cobourg, during a temporary it of insanity, shot himself with a rifle. The ball passed through his heart, causing instant death.

The public were apprised of the arrest, last Sunday morning, on board of the steamer Great Republic, of the notorious Colonel, J. IL. ALEXANDER, who has been obtaining large sums of money in various places by palming himself off as a Government agent, and who it is believed is really possessed of many important secrets of powerful Rings formed for the purpose of defrauding the United States revenue.

In the matter of the habeas corpus of JOHN CRAWFORD, alias Lake Eagan, the alleged burglar of Mayfield, Chatauqua County, this State, which was to have come on for argument yesterday before Judge CARDOZO at his private chambers, Room No. 13 in the upper part of the new Court House, we are credibly informed that nothing was done beyond the traversing of the return made by superintendent KENNEDY.

The following awards for damages have been made in the matter of widening Laurens-street, from Canal to Amity-street, and extending the said street from Amity-street to the Fifth-avenue: Frederick H. M. Newcomb, $31,208; Joseph W. Kellogg, $8,000 ; A. Manel, $9,300 ; Michael Murphy, $21,511 ; unknown owners, $6,797; Nicholas Serf, $487;

It is reported that Mr. A. T. STEWART has purchased nearly 2,000 acres more adjoining his original purchase at Hempstead Plains, making the entire tract about 9,000 acres. Brick clay and potters' earth have been found in large quantities on the land, and will doubtless prove very valuable.

The loss of HEYMAN, COHNFELD Co., importers of feathers, at No. 8 Greene-street, by the fire on Monday evening, is fully $10,000. There was the following insurance on their stick: Williamsburg City, $2,000; Grocers, $2,500; Yonkers and New-York., $2,500; International, $2,000; Greenwich, $3,000; Bowery, $3,000; Hamilton, $2,000;; Franklin, $3,000; Phoenix; $5,000;

The Freedmen's Burean, so far as its organization as a physical and material help to the colored race and white refugees was concerned, expired by limitation of law on the 31st of December, 1868; but the educational work and the bounty claims business for colored soldiers was continued by the same law which terminated its material functions.

While the large number of speeches and essays which have been attered and written in England upon the Irish land question do not suggest any very clear method of its settlement they do prove that no time is to be lost in giving this one more installment of justice of Ireland.

There are many who have believed that because but little was said in the newspapers or elsewhere of the progress made by the Pneumatic Propelling Company, in the construction of an engine and tanks that would answer every requisite purpose, therefore the project had fallen through.

The Emperor gave audience to Baron WERTHER, the newly-appointed Ambassador from Prussia, at Compiegne yesterday. Much good feeling was manifested. M. WERTHER, in presenting his credentials, assured the Emperor that the Prussian Government desired to preserve the present amicable relations with France.
The Cunard steamship Russia, which left Liverpool, Nov. 6, and Queenstown, Nov. 7, reached this port yesterday. Her advices are later by two days than those at head by the City of London.

The canvassers of Kings County yesterday completed the canvass of the returns of the city wards, excepting the returns which were regarded as fraudulent. These were returned to canvassers for correction. The returns from the Third District of the Twentieth Ward, notwithstanding the intimation of fraud in the matter of the votes for member of Assembly,

EASTON--BURNET.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Nov. 17, 1869 by Rev, Isaac M. See, BENJAMIN C. EASTON to Miss MAGGIE G. BURNET, both of Brooklyn No cards. GLAE--FLOOKS--At Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Nov. 17, at the North Reformed Dutch Church by Rev. W. T. Enyard, FRANK A. GALE to ANNA FLOOKS. No cards.

The London Times, in its money article of yesterday, in speaking of American securities, informs its readers that a people in debt complain of Its burden, forgetting the benefits it brought them, and intimates that the heavy annual payment to foreign holders is more dangorous to their popularity than when made to holders at home.

The sale of thirty-five acres of land, with ?? thereon, on Central Park avenue, advertised to be made yesterday, was adjourned with Thursday, 25th inst. To-day being a holiday, no sales will be attempted. On Saturday Messrs. A. J. BLEECKER, SON Co. will set at the Exchange Salesroom, by order of the Hanover Coal Company, 1,428 acres of land, ten miles from Richmond, Va. nd, Va.

This Board yesterday directed the Corporation Counsel to take legal measures to have Canal-street, on the north side, between Molt and Mulberry streets, widened and straightened. So as to make it correspond with the remaining portion of the street.

The annual festival of tile above school was held Tuesday afternoon and evening at their rooms over the New-York Port Society's Mission, corner of Water and Dover streets. In the afternoon a most luxurious dinner was fur. nished for over ninety children, gathered into this school from the miserable habitations of the Fourth Ward.

Tuesday night Patrolman UNDERHILL, of the Fourth Precinet, while on post, was told by some of the wretched denizens of the tenement house No. 64 Frankfort-street, that a family in one of the rooms required attention of some sort. Sauntering into the building to ascertain what was amiss, he was piloted to the room of one IRA CUNNICK.

Yesterday morning Hon. CHARLES J. FOLGER, the new Sub-Treasurer, was formally installed into office In the Rotunda of the Treasury building. General BUTTERFIELD Introduced Senator FOLGER to the clerks and employes of the office with a few appropriate words, in which h thanked his subordinates for their fidelity in their official duties.

A heavy fall of snow commenced this forenoon. PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 17.-The snow storm changed to a violent rain with a gale of wind in the night. It is now clear and quite warm. ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17.-Tho weather turned cold last night and froze sharply. The mercury now stands at 340. The storm prostrated the telegraph lines in nearly all directions.

The Kings County Canvassers have completed their work, and have, much against the will of the majority, given a small majority to ANTHONY WALTER for Sheriff. This was not done on the score of any respect for the claims of justice, but from fear of the excited condition of the public mind.

Signor ALFARO, the Secretary of War of the Cuban Junta, honored the Navy Yard with a visit yesterday. He inspected the receiving-ship Vermont very closely. It may be remembered that he was placed under arrest at the time of the Ryan Cuban expedition. The Severn left the Battery yesterday for the West Indies.

Five steamers have sailed for Havana since Sunday, carrying from three to four thousand volunteers, well armed and equipped. The Republican Committee here have remonstrated with General PRIM against the sending of Republican prisoners to Cuba. PRIM replied that he would consult his colleagues on the subject before taking final action.

The day set apart for a general expression throughout the nation of gratitude to the Giver of every good and perfect gift, will be marked this year by no innovation upon the established manner of observing it. The custom of coming together in the several States once in every twelvemonth and giving thanks for the blessings that we enjoy is time-honored among us;

A regular meeting of this Board was held last evening, President LARREMORE in the chair, and nine members present. NOMINATION OF SCHOOL INSPECTORS. Mayor HALL sent in a communication containing a list of names nominated by him for School Inspectors in pursuance of the law creating the new Board of Education.

If the great structure between the Mediterranean and Red Seas fails to restore the sceptre of trade to Middle Europe, plucked from it by VASCO DE GAMA, the opening of the Suez Canal insures other results that far outweigh this commercial supremacy.

The funeral of a relic of the village days of New-York takes place to-day from the cathedral in Mulberry-street. Mrs. HANNAH BRENNAN, who died on Monday last, in the 84th year of her age, came to New-York in 1790, when 4 years of age, and has resided here continuously from that time until her death.

Collector GRINNELL issued the following order yesterday: COLLECTOR'S OFFICE, Nov. 17, 1869. To Merchants, Shippers and all others concerned: Notice is hereby given, that under recent instructions from the Treasury Department the system of cording and sealing packages of merchandise shipped from this to Pacific ports, by way of the Isthmus of Panama, will be abolished on and after the 20th inst., (sailing day of the steamer Alaska.)

An inquest on the body of WILLIAM KEANE, who was shot by JAMES LEE, at the Bank Coffee House, No. 398 Grand-street, on Monday morning, was held yesterday by Coroner KEENAN and a jury of seven men, at the Police Station corner of Delancey and Attorney streets.

The Times, in its money article to-day, referring to the movement of American bonds to Europe, observes that it is necessary to recollect that a people liable for debt are apt to complain of its burden, forgetting the benefits it brought them.

One more kerosene horror" is added to the long list-this time the conflagration of a Milwaukoo theatre, with several persons burned to death, fifteen or twenty others badly burned, and still others mahned in the madness to escape from the building. We are now approaching the end of the year, and the regular period for colleeting statisties.

The New-York Liberal Club, a non-political organization, held its fifth regular meeting last evening at No. 23 Third-avenue. Mr. HENRY WEHLE presided, and in a few prefatory remarks alluded to the Vanderbilt bronzes, which he considered a public imposition, and the unvalling of which was an attempt at deffication of the money bag.

In the General Term of the Supreme Court, Justices CLERKE, SUTHERLAND and CARDOZO presiding, a motion was made yesterday morning by D. T. WALDRON, Esq., to strike from the rolls of attorneys and counselors of the Court the names of ORSON A. HOUSE and EDWARD D. GEBHARD.

The Metropolitan Board of Health met yesterday afternoon. The Sanitary Committee reported in favor of continuing the investigations in regard to adulterated milk. The Superintendent reported on the special street-cleaning work done by the Board during the past summer, the total expense of which was $3,547 54.

No further information was obtained yesterday in relation to the alleged national currency frauds beyond what has already been published in the TIMES, excepting the fact that the Treasury Commission has completed its investigation into the operations of the National Bank Note Company, of this City. The investigation has been secretly conducted, under the supervision of Mr. GUTHRIE, of Treasurer SPINNER'S Department, having commenced on Wednesday, the 10th inst.

There was a large assemblage of the leading patrons of the racing and trotting turf present yesterday at BARKER and HAMBLIN'S auction mart, corner of Broadway and Thirty-ninthStreet, to witness the extensive sale of trotting and race horses advertised, belonging to Messrs. ECKERSON and WELDON.

The leading players of the Brooklyn Chess Club visited the Williamsburg Chess Club on Tuesday evening, by appointment, to inaugurate a short match by consultation. Messrs. WERNICH, VON FRUNKENBERG and J. KENFF were selected to represent Williamsburg, and Messrs. BRENZINZER, GILBERG and MERIAN were the champions for Brooklyn.

The brig Nautilus, Captain TURNER, which arrived from Tahiti yesterday, making the quickest trip on record-67 days for the round trip-news is resolved by a business house in this city of one of the most thrilling tragedies ever enacted on the hign seas.

Sanitary Superintendent HARRIS' report of the results of tests of explosive oils sold as kerosene, , in this City during the past three weeks, submitted to the Board of Health yesterday, states that of thirty-seven samples examined, thirty-six gave off explosive vapor far below 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

Today was devoted to the religious ceremonies in connection with the opening of the canal. The solemu blessing of the canal was given by Pere BAUER, the Almost of the Empress EUGENIE. He preached a sermon, in which he congratulated the world on the success of this grand enterprise, and thanked the Khedive, who, he said, had immortalized his namo and reign by his cooperation In one of the greatest undertakings on modern times.

Mr. SEWARD left Guanajuato on the 8th and Queretare on the 10th inst., and is expected here on the 14th. Harmony has been restored in the Cabinet. LERDO DE TEJADA and ROMERO have been reconciled. IGLESIAS has been appointed Minister of Justice.

The clearing away of the morning's storm and the bright pleasant evening filled Steinway Hall with an exceedingly large audience, whom the continuance of the army weather might have debarred the pleasure of hearing Miss OLIVE LOGAN.

Mr. STEPHEN SPRINGSTED, the Republican candidate for member of Assembly in the First District of Albany, has published a letter in which he says that the vote of Rensselaerville and Borne, as officially recorded by the town clerks Immediately after the election, stood 476 for him and 791 for MURPHY, the Democratic candidate.

The French steamship Lafayette, which left Havre Nov. 4, and Brest Nov. 6, and the German Steamship Hamonia, from Hamburg Nov. 9, and Havre Nov. 6, both reached this port yesterday. Captains ROUSSEAU and MEIR will both accept thanks for late continental papers, and also for their prompt delivery of our correspondence, selections from which are printed below.

Complaint was made against MICHAEL STECKELDERG, of NO. 15 Cedar-street, before United States Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday, in which the former was charged by Collector ISAAC HARVEY with violating the section of the Internal Revenue law relating to the branding of cigar boxes with the manufacturer's name.

JOHN S. BLISS was held to bail by United states Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday, to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of defrauding au ex-Union volunteer, named THOMAS MEHN, out of $100 bounty money. The accused is already under indictment on a similar charge.

The trial of ROBERT BERRY, in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge BARNARD, on the charge of murdering JAMES DONNEGAN, was resumed yesterday. After counsel on both sides had summed up, the Judge charged the jury, and they retired about 11:30 o'clock in the forenoon.

It was a happy thought to ordain our day of Thanksgiving in this gracious Autumn weather. The year has done its work. We have gathered the fruits of the generous Spring and the laboring Summer. The farmer turns from well-filled barns to thank the Providence that gave him rain and sunshine--a seedtime and a harvest.

The Institute of Architects met, according to adjournment, at the Rooms of the New-York Chapter, No. 925 Broadway, at 11 o'clock A. M., yesterday, the Vice-President, R. M. HUNT, Esq., in the chair. After preliminary business was transacted, the first of the prepared papers was read.

Our New-Hampshire exchanges do not, in general, evade the conclusion that the issue distinetly made in the recent special election, was one of absolute "prohibition, against "Hcenses"--the Temperance question raised also in Maine, Massachusetts, Ohio and Minnesota.

All the newly-elected members of the Legislature have been admitted to seats. The seats of Messrs. PORSKAUER and MAYO, (Democrats,) from Mobile, will be contested by their opponents in the Senate. Mr. PENNINGTON (Republican) introduced a resolution requesting Congress to remove all the disabilities of the Fourteenth Amendment.

The Indian Peace Commission met here to-day, Messrs. STUART of Philadelphia, DODGE, of New-York, BRANOT, of Pittsburg, FARWELL, of Chicago, and BISHOP, of Connecticut, being present. Excuse were received from Messrs. TOBEYs, of Boston, and LANE, of Indiana.

At the meeting of the Women's Suffrage Association, at Packard's Building, corner of Broadway and Twenty-second-street, yesterday afternoon, Mrs. WILBOUR urged upon every member to assist in sustaining the meetings, either by speaking themselves, or by having their ideas expressed by others.

"IL POLIUTO" AT THE ACADEMY. The performance of "H Poliuto" last evening at the Academy rose in merit decidedly above public expectations, and justified enthusiasm such as is not frequently witnessed. Signer LEFRANC'S impersonation of Poliutus has obviously been most carefully studied, and this tenor's fine lyric powers are brought to hear in executing his conception with admirable effect.

A report has been received from Vula Nueva giving an account of an explosion of a locomotive which was standing at the depot. Engineers and several others were wounded. The steamship Columbia, from New York, arrived this morning. The Rosarita and Flora Plantations, near Clenfuegos, have been burned.

The morning's papers give the details of great military preparations now making to guard against disorders during the elections on Sunday. The journals publish a communication from LEDRU ROLLIN, in which he withdraws as a candidate for the Corps Legislatif, assigning as his reason for this step that he does not desire to cause division in the Liberal Party.

The improvements of civilization are accompanied by disadvantages. For every benefit of science there is a new danger. So in the German legend, sixty of the magic balls hit, three missed; and the erratic three caused tragedy.

The Society of the Army of the Tennessce met at 1:30 o'clock today. The meeting was called to order by Genoral G. M. DODGE, First Vice-President. Generals SHERIDAN, WEITZEL, WILSON, MEREDITH and CORSE, of other departments, were present, and upon motion were invited to take seats upon the stage. As they appeared they were greeted with applause.

THURSDAY. Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Bremen, by the steamship Donau, close at the General Post Office at 10 A. M. Mails for Havana and the west Indies, by the Eagle, close at 10 A. M. Mails for Bermuda, by the Fah-Kee, close at 10 A. M.

Thirty-five policemen were yesterday arraigned before Commissioners BOSWORTH and MANIERRE for various infractions of the rules and acts of misconduct, the most serious of which were cases of alleged intoxication. JOHN McKNIGHT, of the Thirtieth Precinct, was charged with entering the Station House under the influence of liquor.

He puts the amount of the State debt as follows: Ante-war bonds, $8,378,200; Post-war bonds, not a special tax, $8.836,855.

As the law which imposes a tax on incomes expires by limitation with the present fiscal year, it will devolve on the present Congress to determine whether the taxation of incomes shall cense with the present law, or be continued, and become henceforth a permanent feature of our system of taxation.

A committee of the Faculty of the Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania, have just submitted a report in which they define the position of the women medical students of that city, in view of the discussions brought about by the recent scene in the Pennsylvania Hospital, where a number of women present at a clinical demonstration were insulted by the male students in attendance.

The Society of the Army of the Tennessee met again at 11:20 o'clock this morning. General SHERMAN and SHERIDAN appeared upon the stage, and were greeted with cheers. The hall was well filled were made by the Corresponding and Recording Secretaries and Treasure.

ACKLEY--CAHOONE.--On Tuesday, Nov. 16, by Rev. Dr. DeWitt, OLIVER S. ACKLEY to SUSAN V. CAHOONE, daughter of the late Rev. Wm. Cahoone, all of this City. BANE--STONE.--On Wednesday, the 17th inst., at the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, by Rev. E. Roney, LEON BANE, of New-York, to Miss EMILIE STONE, of New-Orleans.
Dates from Rio Janeiro to the 27th ult. have been received. According to the latest accounts from Paraguay President LOPEZ had transferred his headquartors and seat of Government to San Joaquin.

Mr. COWPER, the English Consul at Trinidad, is charged with connivance with the Captain of the brig Echo in comnutting an act of barratry in selling the brig's cargo without notifying her consignee. The action causes much comment among the merchants, and legal steps have been taken to procure justice.

BIRCH.--On Thursday, Nov. 18, SARAH, Widow of Edward Birch, a native of Convetry, Warwickshire, England, in the 75th year of her age. We sat and watehed her bosom heaving. And Sofetly bent to hear her breathing And there were toars, sobs and sighing, For our dear mother was slowly dying.

A violent gale prevailed in this vicinity yesterday, and serious damage was done at Chatham and on the line of the Hariam Railroad. The mail tram on the Harlem Road, which lott Chatham for New-York at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, was blown from the track by the power of the gale, near Boston Corners,

The association of young men known as the "Literary Cluster" held their third annual ball at Appollo Hall Inst evening. The night certainly was all that could be desired, and a goodly company of young and old tripped the "light fantastic" to the witching music of Wallace's Band. Mr. JACOBS is President of the Society.

Telegrams from Ismalia, on the Suez Canal, dated the 17th inst., announce the arrival at that point of the procession of vessels, headed by the Empress EUGENIE'S yacht L'Aigle, after passing through the first part of the canal. At the ?? west part the depth is said to be nineteen feet, and varies generally from twenty-five to thirty feet in other portions.

The premises No. 64 Orchard-street, ocenpied as a bakery by MARKS LEVY, were damaged yesterday morning by fire to the extent of $200, in consequence of the bursting of a kerosene lamp. Mrs. ELIZA ALEXANDER, an aged lady, living at No. 79 Sheriff-street, yesterday fell into the East River, at Pier No. 51, but was reseued in an exhausted condition by the bystanders.

While PATRICK MURPHY, of No. 145 Fourth-avenue, was riding up town last evening in a Forty-second-street cross-town car, in company with his wife and children, an unknown man, fashionably dressed, who sat near them, managed to cut the strap of a leather satchel which Mrs. MURPHY carried on her arm, and escaped with it from the car before the larceny was discovered.

BAOON ,of Williamsburg, and became the guest of Rev. Dr. BACON. at whose house he was called upon by the clergymen of the city, collage Professors, and a number of prominent citizens.

The Evening Post objects to our statement of the free traders position in relation to the tariff and the movement for its reform. What we alleged was that the free traders, in public discussions, insist upon the acceptance of their dogma, and characterize as "virtually in favor of protection" all who demur to its feasibility or justice.

Rev. O. H. TIFFANY, D. D., formerly of Chicago, now of New-Brunswick, N. J., leetured last evening at the Thirtieth-street Methodist Episcopal Church, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, on "Sham and Shoddy, or the Pretences of modern Life." This, he said, was a singular age, a fast age, and people nowadays were fast and singular people;

The Coroner's jury impaneled to ascertain the causes of the death of sixteen persons killed by the railroad accident on Sunday morning, met at Alameda last evening. After hearing the testimony of several witnesses they adjourned until Wednesday night.

A railroad accident occurred near this city at about 6 o' clock yesterday morning, which might have been attended with serious loss of life, but for the presence of mind of the engineers and the superior strength of the Pullman cars. A freight train was started out from this city, going east ward. It is alleged that the conductor started out on his own responsibility,

The verdict of acquittal, rendered yesterday, in the case of Rev. ISAAC B. SMITH, has been generally expected by those who have watched the testimony, and the manner in which the prosecution has been conducted. The evidence was singularly clear on some points which were not made public before the trial.

Commenting upon the article which we recently published in relation to transportation by railway and canal, the Buffalo Express says: "Neither the narrowness nor the thinness of the stratum of water in the channel of the Erie Canal offers any insuperable obstacle to the use of propelling wheels, as the experience of those who have carefully experimented with steam canal boats and tugs will testify.

A match took place yesterday afternoon at the Union grounds, Williamsburg, between the Eckford and Mutual Clubs. There was quite a large attendance of spectators. The ground was rather slippery, in consequence of the late heavy rains. Much interest was shown in the match, and the good players were frequently applauded.

The call for the Virginia Republican State Convention, to be held in Richmond on the 24th inst., announces that the Convention is to be held for the purpose of extending and perfecting the organization, and promoting the power and influence of the Republican Party in the State ; to deliberate and decide upon what course of action shall be pursued by the organization in the future;

The firm of JACOB STINER CO., of this City, treated their employes to a fine dinner yesterday, at BANGS' restaurant, on Broadway. The venerable head of the firm and his son and sonin-law sat at tho head of the table, along which were ranged over 100 men employed in the various stores of the firm.

MARTIN GERMAN quarreled with his wife CATHERINE, yesterday, at No. 39 Elm-street, when he seized a hatched and struck her several times on the head, causing severe and dangerous scalp wounds. The wounded woman was attended by a physician, and removed to Bellevue Hospital. The husband was arrested and locked up in the Sixth Ward Station House.

The Emperor gave a reception yesterday at Compiegne. He was cordial in his manner toward Mr. WASHBURNE, the American Minister, and paid him constant attention, which is much commented on in political circles.

The letter of General SHALER, which we published on Wednesday, shows that the Fire Commissioners are endeavoring to improve the system they have organized and efficiently administered. General SHALER has, however, slighly misapprehended the position we assumed.

When, on the last day of the year 1868, the career of the Freedmen's Bureau, in its original shape and with its original functions, ended by limitation of law, a great part of its most useful work, namely that of education and of securing the bounty claims of colored soldiers, remained untimshed.

A Fenian demonstration was made at Waterford last night. There was a torchlight procession, in which nearly 5,000 men took part. The bands played Fenian airs, the streets were crowded with spectators, an extra Police force was on hand, but did not interfere with the proceedings, and there was no disturbance.

The work of retrenchment is still going on at the Navy Yard. Sixteen men were discharged from the equipment department on Wednesday, and there is a gradual reduction going on in all the departments day by day. The Guerriere, first-class war ship, went into the dry dock on Wednesday for thorough repair.

The sixth annual Fair of the State Agricultural and Mechanical Society has just closed, having been open three days--the 10th, 11th and 12th instants. Five Fairs had been held when the war came upon us, and this is the first one since the war. In has been in a high degree successful; more so in the attendance and enthusiasm manifested than in extend of the material on exhibition.

Yesterday the contract of many of the First Nine of the Cineinnati Club with the Club expired. In the evening a meeting was held, and a settlement was had. Mr. A. B. CHAMPION, President of the Club, then presented each of the members of the nine, on behalf of the Club, with a landsome donation, in acknowledgement of their uniform good couduct and fidelity as the representatives of the Club upon the field.

The Albany Argus gives the following review of the Albany number market for the week ending Nov. 16: "We have had, since our last report, a firm and active market. The shipments have been large, but have been checked by want of vessels. stocks are steadily thing off.

HENRY VAN TAN yesterday assaulted ANDREW SMITH in Hudson City with an ax, and but for the timely interference of a stranger would have inflicted serious injuries. SMITH had enraged VAN TAN by throwing a stone at his dog. The assailant was taken into custody and held for trial.

The nomination of the Duke of GENOA to the throne has up to the present moment received the support of 181 Deputies to the Cortes. An accusation has been fled In the Supreme Tribunal of Justice against the Bishop of Havana.

An adjourned meeting of shipbuilders and ship writes who held yesterday at No. 470 Grald-street, at which Mr. THOMAS STACK president. A report was submitted by a committee appointed at a former-meeting to give their views on the race series of our merchant marine and prepare a plan of proceeding for the Association.

Private letters received to-day report that a fire had taken place at Fort Bully, Dakota, and destroyed Government property to the amount of $1,000,000. The entire post narrowly escaped destruction. AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 19.-About 6 o'clock yesterday morning,

The cable told as yesterday that the French Minister to Russia has announced to his master an intended visit of the Czar to Paris this Winter. That there is something afloat between France and Russia is becoming more and more certain. Emperors do not usually travel from a long distance to meet each other merely to talk about the weather, or to ask after the progress of their aliments.

A Western paper says that President GRANT has been ever since his manguration in correspondence with General BELKNAP, with a view to his acceptance of some important post at Washington, and that his appointment as Secretary of War came Directly from him after consultation with General SHERMAN.

A few persons attended at the salesroom yesterday. Two small Supreme Court sales of City property were made, one by Mr. Jos. MCGUIRE and the other by Mr. E. F. RAYMOND. It would probably assist some of these sales if they were advertised a little mere extensively.

A few days since since, as already reported, a man named either JOHN CRAWFORD or Lake Eugan was taken into custody by Captain WALSH, of the Fourteenth Preemot. LAKE EAGAN was charged with having committed a burglary in Mayfield, Chautanqua County, this State.

Advices received by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue show that the squad of cavalry, which has been aiding the revenue officials In breaking up illicit distillerices in Virginia, is doing good service. in Botetourt and Craig Counties, in the Sixth District, several stills were found, the distillers were arrested and held for defrauding the Government, and about 800 gallons of brandy were seized.

The capacity of the Brooklyn Water Works will probably soon be increased. The great conduit, which stretches back four and three quarter miles on Long Island, is capable of issuing forty million gallons daily, but the various ponds which supply it can issue but twenty million gallons during the twenty-four hours.

In the Senate to-day a bill was introduced b the Senator from Selma, to vecate the municipal offices in Mibile. The bill athorizes the Lieutenant-Governor, Speaker of the House and Attorney-General to appoint the Mayor and Aldermen of Mobile, to hold for three years.

The funeral of Hon. NATHANIEL NILES, who died at his residence in this City, on Tuesday last, took place yesterday morning, from St. Francis Xavier's Church, West Sixteenth-street. Vicar-General STRAUS and Rev. Father MOYLAR officiated at the ceremonies, and among the pall bearers were ROYAL PHELPS, JNO. C. HAMILTON, J. W. BEEKMAN and GORDON HAMMERSLY.

Sometime between the evening of Nov. 17 and yesterday morning, the store of J. M. DOUBLEDAY, umbrella manufacturer, at No. 22 Wooster-street, was entered by burglars, who evidently gained admission in the first instance by the use of false keys, as there were no marks of violence upon the street doors, which were found locked as usual.

-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 19--BIRDSAY CURTIS., who was injured by the accident on the Harlem Railroad near Boston Corners, on Wednesday, died yesterday from the effects of his injuries. Coroner ALLEN, of Chatham, hold an inquest on the bodies of MCBRIDE and CURTIS, at the depot at Boston Corners.

The audience was not large. After a few general remarks about progress, the lecturer proceeded to give her impressions and reflections on first visiting Salt Lake City.

Mr. BACON'S familiarity with the discourses of the distinguished monk, and his personal acquaintance with him since he came to America,

It is rumored to-day that two members of the tiers parli will enter the Ministry with M. OLLIVIER. He has had an audience with the Emperor. They will have a consultation onl Sundaynext. A grand banquet will be given here on the 6th of December, in nonor of the returned French exiles.

The change in the method of shipping goods to California, made by the late order of the Collector, is regarded with much favor. The matter was first brought up by Mr. GRINNELL some time ago, before the Congressional Retrenchment Committee, of which Senator PATTERSON, of New-Hampshire, was Chaiman,

A regular monthly meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Union was Held yesterday afternoon to take steps to secure the permanent possession of the building now occupied as the headquarters of the Union, at No. 48 Bleecker-street.

There is a scarcity of seamen for the United States service at present, so much so that great difficulty is experienced in finding men to enlist. In consequence of this the Secretary of the Navy has issued an order providing for the payment of a bounty to men willing to enter the naval service.
The steamship Morro Castle, from Havana, Nov. 13, via Nassau, N. P., reached this port yesterday. Purser R. W. ALBERT has our thanks for the prompt delivery of our correspondence and papers.

A very high-falutin and imaginative stump speaker, addressing a large village audience, remarked "Every mountain has sent forth its rill and every valley its stream, and lot the avalanche of the people is hero." Without the simile, I would observe that a great crowd of people is here from apparently every part of the United States.

We certainly thought that the character of this review, and the common courtesies of literature, would have protected us from the illiberal ins?? that have been based on the opportune appearance in our pages of Lady BY RUN'S letters to Mrs. LEIGH. They do it in admirably, but did it never occur to the critics who affect surprise at the circumstance, that this sort of fitness in one of the ordinary results of truth?

The Archbishop of Canterbury is seriously Ill. The Times calls attention to the new regulations made by the American Government economizing the use of coal in the navy, and says they deservo attention in England, although our expenditure of coal has never boon so lavish as that which provoked the interference of the American Navy Department.

On the subject of the French Cabinet, a Paris dispatch gives currency to a rumor that two members of the "Tiers" Party may be appointed with M. OLLIVIER. The latter has had an interview with the Emperor, and another consultation will take place on Sunday. A banquet to the returned French exiles is to he given in Paris, Dec. 6.

Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, of No. 185 Chnton-Street, made an affidavit on the 15th inst, before the Magistrate, to the effect that Dr. AUGUST WEDEKIND had obtained from her, on the 12th inst.,

JOHN H. ARNOUX, for some time past one of the officers attached to the Tombs Police Court and for many years a patrolman in the Eighteenth Precinct, died at an early hour yesterday morning at his residence, No. 312 East Twenty-fourth-street, in the forty-seventh year of his age.

The Workingmen's Union held a meeting last evening, at No. 267 Bowery, NELSON W. YOUNG Presiding. Reports of the condition of several Unions were read. Everything seemed to be progressing satisfactorily. A letter was read from ERNEST VAN BREIZER, Belgian Consul to the United States, asking for the aid of the Union in the collecting of documents and information in reference to the working classes.

Notwithstanding reports to the contrary, Mr. FOLGER meditates no changes among the clerks and employes of the Sub-Treasury at present. He has constant applications for positions, by friends and others, but he has determined to remove no one now under him, unless necessity requires it.

This Society held their regular monthly meeting at the Steuben House last night, Mr. S. HERZBERG, presiding, Five law cases of poor Germans were taken care of by the Society. A resolution, condemning the detention of witnesses, without indemnity, for weeks and even months, as a barbarism, was adopted.
BENJAMIN LAVINE was arrested with two others, on the 20th of August last,

About 8 o'clock this morning a portion of the large, new, stone front building on the southeast corner of Olive and Fifth streets, fell with a terrible crash, burying from nine to thirteen men at work in the basement. At this writing, six men had been taken out of the ruins, one of whom (NAPOLEON EASTON) has six ribs broken,

EUGUNE B. TUNISON, who pleaded guilty. in the United States Circuit Court, Eastern District, to the charge of stealing letters and pack ages from the Post Office, and pardoning their contents, was brought up for sentence yesterday.

A clerk in the Custom House, who has known SAMUEL T. BLATCHFORD for a period of sixteen years, reported to one of Collector GRINNELL'S Secretaries, yesterday, that he had seen the fugitive drawback conspirator in Nassaustreet, near the Sub-Treasury Building, at about 10 o'clock in the morning.

Coroner FLYNN held an inquest yesterday in the case of JOHN McGRATH, who died at No. 60 Watts-street, as was supposed, from the effected of chloroform administered by Dr. MARVIN S. BUTTLES, of No. 41 St. Mark's-place.

A private letter from Jamaica, W.I., under date of 25th October, States that consul GREGG declares that the report of his speeches at the cuban banquet, as furnished by the Jamaica Press, was incorrect. Mr. GREGG asserts that he simply expressed his belief that Cuba would secure her freedom, and that,

There are forty-seven sea-going ships now at this station, with an average tonnage of one thousand tons each. The largest vessel of the fleet Is a Russian frigate, which draws seventeen feet and two Inches of winter. The buildings In lsmailia are tilled with guests and other visitors, and the surrounding plains are covered with the tents of the native tribes,

HENRY CONWAY, the young man in the employment of BALL, BLACK , jewelers, Broadway, who, it will be remembered, was indicted for having on the 8th of November last, at No. 66 Sixth-avenue, feloniously assaulted Mrs. MARY EMMA FORT, yesterday received the sentence that he deserves.

The Society of the Army of the Tenncssee and the Society of the Cavalry of the West have just hold their annual reunions at Louisville. They found themselves made heartily welcome in that city, with overgreens and flags and flowers decorating their meeting-halls. and the spectators of their gathering hardly less enthusiastic than the participants.

BIRCH.--On Thursday, Nov. 18. SARAH, widow of Edward Birch, a naive of Coventry, Warwickshire, England, in the 75th year of her age. We sat and watched her bosom heaving, And soitly bent to hear her breathing, And there were toars, sobs and sighting, For Our dear mother was slowly dying. The relatives and friends of the family, also those of her souls.

As before stated in the TIMES, the public indignation of the defrauded electors of Kings County knows no diminution, but instead of cooling down into indifference, is every day gathering fury for a storm. The conversation in public and private inevitably turns to this theme, and from angry and shapeless expressions of dissatisfaction and disgust, is fast moulding itself into form for practical Business.

The steamship Union, which left Bremen Nov. 6 and Southampton Nov. 9, reached this port yesterday. her advice's are later by two days than those at hand previously. ENGLAND.

There is now being built at the Novelty from Works, in this City, a life-preserving ear, a model of which was on exhibition at the late Fair of the American Institute, which, if fully equal to the performances of what is claimed for it, is a decided advance on the present mode of getting up railroad carriages.

Winter, with all its rigors and its season of enjoyment to the votaries of skating, will soon be upon us, and we therefore give, in anticipation, an account of the preparations that, are being made for it in and around this City. Probably no outdoor recreation has attained so great and rapid a popularity among all classes of the community as skating.

The area wall of the new Post Office is nearly completed. Three piers of Mane granite are in position, and the stone for the rest arrives every few days by vessels. The centre area is gradually getting lower, the digging there not being pushed rapidly.

The Dalmatian insurrection has not been suppressed as has been reported. New of the capture of a d?? by the Austrians, is received. The Suez Canal is pronounced a success by dispatches received at Paris. The ?? has arrived at Suez without accident, on the impeiral yacht ??.

We believe we speak the plain facts in the case when we state the FRANK SEARCY wounded two men the night they made their first attempt to hang him. They demanded admitance to the house, which was refused them by SEARCY.

We believe that the town of Nottingham, in England, has earned the distinction of being the first where a considerable body of female voters have had the privilege of exercising the electoral franchise. The occasion was the election of municipal officers, and the result has not been so satisfactory as could have been wished.

We spoke some days ago of the question of the liability of banks for the loss of valuables which depositors have been in the habit of leaving in their strong rooms for safe keeping. It is quite a striking circumstance that the same question has recently arisen in Australia

Justice HOGAN proposed to go into an examination yesterday in the case of Dr. AUGUST WEEKEND, who is accused of having extorted the sum of $1,000 from Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, of No. 185 Clinton-street, under threats of accusing her of poisoning her husband.

The Italian Opera Company has continued during the week to float on in what some ?? statesman called "the full tide of successful experiment." In "Norma" on Monday, Mme. BRIOL made a favorable if not very profound impression, and Signor?? MASSIMILIANI effected his reappearance as a faithful and hard-working Pollio. llio.

The case of Deputy Sheriff JACKSON, who is now confined in the City Prison, awaiting his trial for murder, in having shot ARCHIBALD DOUGLAS upon the 29th of October last, during a political quarrel, in the First Ward, was laid before the Grand Jury of the county by District-Attorney GARVIN, last week, and an indictment for murder has been found by that body.

The revolution in the South has at length resulted in the triumph of the insurgents. SALNAVE'S hopes, so far as the suppression of the insurrection in this part of the country was concerned, depended upon the success of the military operations undertaken by his chosen and trusted Generals, VICTORINE CHEVALIER ad VIL LUBIN.

Another meeting for celebrating the centenary of the birth of LUDWIG VON ?? the renowned musical composer, occurring next year, by a musical festival in this City, was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel last night, Rev. Dr. J. P. THOMPSON presiding.

When people speak of the "Fifth-avenue belle," we all know what is meant. The young lady in question is one of the most ornamental of her species. In appearance she is the highest conceivable product of care and thought in external adornment.

ALLEN.--?? Houghtenville. N. J., on Saturday, Nov. 20, NELL??. wife o E. M. Allen and only daughter of B. F. Libby. Esq.. formerly of New-York. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her into ?? on Monday, Nov. 22. at 2 1/2 o'clock. Trans leave from foot of Cortland-st. at 1 o'clock.

All operations in the Park have ceased for the season, with the exception of gathering up the fallen leaves and carting them to the compost heap. The boats have been removed from the lake, and houses have been prepared for the swans and other water fowl.

A large and enthusiastic mass meeting and torchlight procession took place last evening at the junction of East Broadway and Grand-street, in favor of the nomination of OTTO H. COOP for Alderman of the Sixth Aldermanic District. The demonstration was gotten up under the auspices of the Independent Workingmen's Association.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20.--The Committee which a short time since examined the case of Captain WASHINGTON, who was charged with passing the the steamer stonewall, while she was burning, without stopping his boat, have reported that after duly weighing the evidence they conclude "that Captain WASHINGTON committed a grave error,

The shoemakers employed by GRAFF BROTHERS, Nos. 18 and 20 Springfield - avenue, have again quit work at the command of the Knights of St, Crispin. At the time of the last strike Messrs . GRAFF paid the men an advance of twelve and a half cents a pair on all hand --sewed work,

Rev. J. W. KRAMER, of Calvary Church, Summit, N. J., has accepted the charge of Grace Chapel, New-York. The Methodists and Congregationalists of Colliusville, Conn., united in Thanksgiving service last Thursday.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 18.--a magnificent meteor was seen this evening at this place, about twenty-five minutes before 7 o'clock. It came in sight about fifteen or eighteen degrees below and south of the zenith, and passed slowly to the west, and disappeared about eight of ten degrees from the horizon due west, or a little north or west.
This body, disclaiming all connection with the so-called "Pantaloonaties" of the Woman's Suffrage Association, held its regular ?? meeting at Packard's Building, in Broad way, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.-- The seizures reported at the Internal Revenue Bareau to-day were as follows : 29,000 cigars seized in the Twenty-second Pennsylyania District ; 163,000 pounds of tobacco seized in the Fifth Kentucky District.

About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire was caused in the water closet in the rear of No. 123 Cedar-street, occupied by WILLIAM FOGARTY as a boarding house. The fire originated from the leakage of gas ; and when the firemen opened the doors to get access to the flames an explosion of the gas occurred

Professor BREHM'S work on the natural history of birds is being translated by Professor RYMER JONES, Messrs. CASSELL will issue it in serial form with colored plates. A movement is to be set on foot in Edinburgh for the purpose of erecting a statue in that city to the memory of the late Rev. Dr. CHALMERS.

The case of the Erie Railway Company vs. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, in which a motion for a jury trial was denied a few days since, was yesterday before Judge INGRAHAM on an examination of the defendant before trial. In the complaint it is alleged that in February and March, 1868, several actions were commenced

The predicted value of the Pacific Railroad as a means for the profitable development of mines of useful metals, is beginning to be realized. Our dispatches note that copper ore, from districts in Nevada contiguous to the Central Pacific, is to be forwarded by that road to Sacramento or San Francisco for reduction.

Yesterday afternoon complaint was made at the Newark Street Commissioner's office of the dangerous condition of an excavation made by the Aqueduct Board in Astor--street. It was stated that, on the morning of Thursday last, a party, numbering seventeen persons, riding in a large wagon, had been precipitated into the hole, many of them being injured by the fall.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS--NOV By Judge Ingraham. Miles vs. Briggs; motion granted. In the matter of the petition of Samuel D. Roberts; see memorandum for counsel. Paine vs. Paine; motion denied with leave to renew on other papers.

While two little boys were picking cinders out of an ash barrel in front of premises No. 11 University-place, yesterday morning, they discovered the mangled head of a man. The Fifteenth Ward Police were notified, who took possession of the ghastly object and notified Coroner ROLLINS of the fact.

SAN FRANCISCO, NOV. 18.--The verdict of the Coroner's jury on the Western Pacific Railroad accident of Sunday last, was that the collision was the result of the ignorance and incompetency of BERNARD KANE, the switch tender at Sampson Station.

"M. T.," of Providence; initials which at once suggest the former pastor of our Memorial Church, contributes to Zion's Herald this interesting reminiscence of the late Ex-President PIERCE: Your readers know that Mr. PIERCE was a member of the United States Senate from New-Hampshire, and that he resigned his seat after a short term of service, and came home.

We have a telegram from Ottawa which enables us to announce that Messrs. DUNKIN, MORRIS and ALKINS have been sworn in as Privy Councilors, Mr. DUNKIN taking the place of Minister of Agriculture, Mr. MORRIS that of Minister of Inland Revenue

Every morning as the eminently respectable citizen of this Metropolis makes his way down town, no matter how early a departing train or urgent business may call him forth, he meets the ubiquitous ragpicker, male or female, but especially the latter, bent double beneath a bulky bag, with an iron hook in hand, poking among the garbage of ash barrels and boxes and the heaps of ?? in the streets.

At 6 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the white lead works of ANDERSON, DOUGLAS PIERCE, Nos. 93 and 95 Furman-street, Brooklyn, which resulted in the loss of $20,000 worth of property, and the lives of THOMAS WALLACE, the janitor of the building, his wife and boy, 5 years old.

NEWBURG. N. Y., Nov. 20.--The hurricane was disastrous in its effects here. It was the heaviest blow experienced in thirty years. A meeting was called yesterday afternoon in the Board Room of the Stock Exchange by the subscribers to the "fund to erect a monument ?? Central Park in memory of GEORGE PEABODY."

The revolutionists and seccessionists of Cuba seem to have arrived at their "last ditch," or very near it, since they have taken to the strategy of burning their sugar farms and plantations. Very few people, likely to prosper. would resolve to burn the house over their own heads by way of mending matters.
