ROBERT H. GOLDSBOROUGH, who was convicted of murder at the last session of the Sussex County Court of Sessions and confined in the jail at Newton, awaiting the exception of a sentence to the gallows on the 10th prox., escaped from the jail on Wednesday night.

A skull, with horns attached, of immense proportions, found on the Merced River, in Mariposa County, by Captain NETHERWOOD and Mr. DUNSCOMB, while at work in their mining claim abut six weeks ago, is an interesting relie of the " early inhabitants" of California.

Considerable discussion is now going on in the Seventh Regiment relative to the time observed by that command in the manual of arms. Captain, Allison, an energetic and enthusiastic officer, is a warm champion of fast time, similar to that maintained in the cadet battalion at the West Point Military Academy.

BROWN-STONE FRONTS. Three first-class dwellings, north side of Thirty -ninth-street, past of Park-avenue, 16 2/3 by 56 feet, four stories; E. H. COBURN, owner, Three first-class dwellings, (Brunswick stone fronts,) east side of Madison-avenue, south of One Hundred and Thirty-third-street, 20 by 43 feet, three stories; LEANDER BLACK, owner.

The Grand Jury which has had the gold conspiracy under investigation, though failing to find indictments against any of the parties, have nevertheless deemed a portion of the evidence taken before them worthy of being given to the public for its information.

LONDON, Nov. 20--A double se??lling match occurred on the Tyne at Newcastle to-day, between KELLY and SADLER on one side, and RENFORTH and TAYLOR on the other. The former won by a length. It was a very excluding and well contested race, and was witnessed by a great crowd of people.

It is currently reported in reliable quarters, that it is proposed to select a site upon the upper end of the island, in the vicinity of Fort George, for a pleasure ground, designed for uses similar to these of the Prospect Park Association of Brooklyn.

The Arizona Mines, Oct. 23, notes that ?? WHEELER, United States Topographical Engineer, is making a survey of the great American Desert west of the Colorado and south of the White Pine ?? region. On the 23d of September his party was on the Muddy, a stream that enters into the Rio Virgen, a short distance-sixty miles-north of callville.

Some time ago WM. Y. TAYLOR, at the instance of MARY JANE KEATING, was convicted of seduction, the result of which was imprisonment and fine, the first of which he served in the County Jail and for the second pleaded insolvency.

The Fair held for the benefit of the Ladies' Union Relief Association terminated on Monday evening. The success of the enterprises is a fitting reward for the patriotic energy, perseverance and kind-heartedness of these good ladies. Their untiring energy since the first year of the war, in assisting our soldiers, cannot be too highly appreciated.

The question of the appointment of the nine Circuit Judges is becoming very interesting here, and is engrossing the attention of a different, and, I may say, better class of men than that which usually participates in the pressure for office. This is because the class of talent called for is of a different, and of a higher order, but more especially because of the serious nature of the considerations involved in the selections.

JEFFERSON DAVIS has settled down again on his native heath with as little notice as he received on his first landing from abroad. He has gained the last finishing touch to the realization of his old wish to be " let alone." He is as safe now as any mole from public pros ecution or private molestation.

Honolulu advices to Nov. 2 have been received. Large meetings had been held to consider the subject of coolie immigration. Resolutions strongly condemnatory of the importation of coolies were passed. Reports had been received of earthquakes of the Keomar coast.

It would seem as if the "Triumvirate" has resolved never to put an end to the war ; the news from up North is totally devoid of all interest - and even this uninteresting kind is scarce. LOPEZ is reported to have taken refuge in the woods beyond San Estanislao, with a force estimated between 3,000 and 4,000, chiefly old men or young boys, badly armed and even still worse off for provisions.
A week of very brilliant performances commences with to-night. No opera will be given this evening, but the first representation of "William Tell," to-morrow, will atone for the privation.

A heavy gale of wind prevailed here yesterday, which was more servere in its effects in this Immediate vicinity than that of last Wednesday, and the destruction of property in the surrounding country has been great. In this city, the spiro of the Presbyterian Church was partially blown over, and a poltion of it was carried some distance.

M. EUGENE FORCADE, whose death on Saturday evening. Nov. 6, is announced to-day though a comparatively young man, (he was only 19.) may fairly be called one of the oldest journalists in Europe. He established in Marseilles, has native town, one of the best known of French provincial newspapers, the Semaphore, when he was not more than 17 years of age,

The opinion of our eastern contemporaries is that the Anti--confederates will have a majority of from five to seven in the new House of Assembly of Newfoundland. The City of St. Johns returned 6 Anti--Confederates, Ferryland 2, Placentia Bay 3, while the last named constituency also returned 4 Confederates, and Burgos and La Poile 1--making 20 members altogether elected as far as heard from.

The small propeller Belle Seen was burned to the water's edge off Port Washington last night. Nothing has been heard of her crew, but it is presumed that they escaped in a lifeboat. There were no passengers on board.

The California Immigrant Union will soon appoint agents to the principal cities in Europe. Another in mine has been discovered a few miles northeast of Sun Bernardino. The ore is pronounced superior to the Sun Jacinto. The line of the Virginia City and Truckee Railroad was inaugurated yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19.-Advices from Arizona state that the expedition under Colonel BARNARD, recently repulsed by the Indians, was reinforced from Camp Bowie, and assumed the aggressive. The savages have concentrated their forces, and a battle is imminent.

The large and increasing attendance of "street boys" at the Sunday evening meeting held at their lodging houses is gratifying to who take an interest in the homeless youths of this City. An impression prevails that the boys have a disposition to ridicule everything which smacks of religion; and yet the audience...
NEW CASTLE, Del., Nov. 20.--Five men, named EDWARD SMITH, ANDREW CHAMBERS, GEORGE JACKSON, JAMES GORDON and JOSEPH DARMS, were publicly flogged in the jail yard, at this place, to--day.
There is no change in the market; it remains as it has been for some little time pastvery sluggish. It seems, indeed, quite impossible just now to get up any feeling of activity.

In the Cortes yesterday, Admiral TOPETE Presiding, the members of the Republican minority presented a protest declaring that there was no truth in the reports that they were implicated in a conspiracy with the insurgents in the Island of Cuba.

Advices from Alexandria. Just received, contain the gratifying intelligence that the Suez Canal is a success. The Imperial yacht Aigle, with Her Majesty the Empress on board, has arrived at Suez without accident.
The Lecture Committee of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association have arranged for a course of lectures, chiefly scientific, by men distinguished in their several departments.

A terrific tornado occurred hero on the 18th inst. Heavy winds arose about 5 o'clock in the morning, increased in violence, and almost totally destroyed a portion of the city known as Lower Georgetown. Houses were demolished in almost every direction.

AN ORDINANCE TO DIVIDE THE CITY OF NEW-YORK INTO CONVENIENT ?? DISTRICTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION EIGHT, ?? THREE, TITLE THREE, OF ACT OF THE LEGISLATURE ?? APRIL, FIVE, EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND FORTY TWO. (?? All Amendments to Aug. 1m 1869.)

The Republican Deputies in the Spanish Cories, at a session of that body on Saturday, tented the reports that they were implicated in the Cuban insurrection. Spain continues to forward reinforcements to her army in Cuba. Another detachment of volunteers sailed for Havana last week.

A man and wife, bearing the surname of KOCH, attempted, yesterday, to commit simultaneous suicides, at the foot of Fourth-street, in Hoboken. The parties were advanced in years beyond the prescribed three score and ten, and had grown tired of life.

Prince METTERNICH, who went to Vienna recently, has returned to his post in this city as Envoy Extraordinary from Austria. His stay at Vienna was shortened on account of tho political situation here. Tile Prince was incorrectly reported to have arrived at Ismailia a day or two ago.

An unknown man, supposed the be French, was found yesterday in Second-avenue suffering with an apoplectic fit. He is 40, years of age, has black hair and mustache, and was dressed in pepper and salt pantaloons and west, black frock coat and silk bat. He was sent to Bellevue Hospital.

By a letter received from Painesville, yesterday, we learn that on Thursday night the grave of Mrs. CARPENTER was desecrated by some body snatchers from Cleveland. The circumstances attendant on the death of Mrs. CARPENTER were so sad and terrible that it seemed as though no other sorrow could have been added to the nursery of the doubly orphaned children.

Yesterday morning a gang of Fourth Ward rowdies, headed by JAMES GIBBONS and "Scotch Level," made their appearance at the foot of Fifty-eighth-street, East River, and presented their pistols at the head of the keeper of the Charity Hospital boat, and demanded that he should release one ANDREW COAKLEY, one of the boat's crew, a prisoner committed to the care of the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction.

A meeting of the Committee appointed to collect funds for the erection of the Jewish Hospital on Lexington avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh streets, was held at Temple Emanuel yesterday afternoon. BENJAMIN NATHAN, Esq., presided, and JULIUS J. LYONS acted as Secretary.

Rev. Pt. FREEL, of St. Charles Borromeo's Church, Breeklyn, preached last evening at St. ?? (R. C.) Church, Eight-street, on "The ?? of the Pope." He took for his text the thirty-first and thirty-second verses of the twenty-second chapter of Lake: "Simon, Simon, behold Satan has desired to have you and to ?? you, as wheat; but I have prayed for thee that thy faith fail not, and then being once converted ?? thy brethren."

This morning our citizens were startled by the report that a young man named TAYLOR LEWIS MORGAN, a student in the Freshman Class of the University, and a brother of Rev. THOMAS J. MORGAN, of the Theological Seminary, had committed suicide. The body was found about 7:30 o'clock this morning. He was found lying with his head against in pillow, and a revolver with two chambers empty, lying on the floor a short distance off.

A telegram from Ottawa, dated Nov. 18, published on Friday morning, states on what is termed" good author Ity, that there is no truth in the report from Washington that the Government of tile Dominion had threatened retaliatory measures If the present restriction on commercial intercourse was continued by the United States."

The case of Dr. AUGUST WEDEKIND, accused of having extorted money from Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, of No.185 Clinton-Street, was contioned yesterday before Justice HOGAN. Coremer KEE. AN was present at the request of the Magistrate.

On Wednesday the Post recorded the fact that three vessels were reported ashore at Gross Point, twelve miles from this city, and to-day further details have been obtained of the disaster to the schooner arrow, which went ashore at that point on Tuesday night, in the great storm.

LIFE OF GERARD HALLOCK, THIRTY-THREE YEARS EDITOR OF THE NEW-YORK JOURNAL OF COMMERCE. Illustrated in Biography, Professional Writings, Correspondence, Controversies, New-York: OAKLEY, MASON Co., 1869.

A few of the faithful and some strangers were found with curiosity enough to lead them to attend what is called a" Spiritualist Conferonce," held in the hall, corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon.

Mr. ANDREW BOYD, of Albany, is engaged in the task of preparing a catalogue of all books and pamphlets, portraits and medals, in short of everything over published concerning President LINCOLN. Inasmuch as the various works published at his death alone exceed 400 in number, it is evident Mr. BOYD'S undertaking will be no light one.

There are signs of a disposition to "push things" a little too fast in the matter of resumption, and of an equally--marked disposition in another quarter to urge upon Congress further issues of an inconvertible currency. The West complains of hard times as a result of inadequate banking facilities.

ALLEN.--At Houghtenville, N. J., on Saturday Nov. 20. NECLIR, wife of E. M. Allen, and only daughter of B. F. Libby, Esq., formerly of New--York. The relatives and funeral from her ?? residence on Monday, Nov. 22, at 2 1/2 o'clock. Trains leave from loot of Cortlandt--st. at 1 o'clock.

The supplementary elections for members of the Corps Legislator from this city began to-day, and are progressing quietly. Up to this hour (3 o'clock P.M.) there has been no disturbance in any quarter of the city. The Emperor left Compiegue this morning, by special train for Paris, and arrived at the Taileries at noon.

A shocking affair occured on L-street, be tween Twentieth and Twenty--first streets, last evening. Some three or four years since at man named MITCHELL, a shoemaker, residing in this city, 'had a falling out with his wife, which resulted in their separation. Mrs. MITCHELL going to Austin, Nevada.

By the kindness of Captain B. F. SMITH, we are enabled to place before our readers the following particulars of an extensive fire at Fort Sully, which he received by private letter: On last Sunday, at about 4:30 o'clock in the afternoon, a fire broke out in the Quartermaster's storehouse.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your notice of the Empire Skating Rink yesterday you were in error when you stated that the Poultry Show would continue from the 1st to the 12th of December. It closes on the 9th, and the Rink will be ready for skating as it was last year, by the 12th of December.

Wisconsin gives Governor FAIRCHILD 8,181 majority as appears from the official figures. This is nearly double his majority two years ago. Hon. WILLIAM W. SNOW, elected to the Assembly from Otsege County, is dangerously ill.

The undersigned, as representatives of the ST. JOSEPH AND DENVER CITY RAILROAD COMPANY, have the honor to offer for sale the FIRST MORTGAGE BONDS OF THE ST. JOSEPH AND DENVER CITY RAILROAD COMPANY, on their line of railway, which connects St. Joseph with Fort Kearney by rail, amounting to $1,500,000. All that can be issued.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When the first Junta was organized in the City of New-York, the chief object of its existence was to distribute rellabte information in this country concerning the state of affairs in Cuba, by which public opinion would be guided and the sympathies of our people aroused in favor of the patriot cause.

" The Nine Muses" of signor FAGNANI continue through laudatory and adverse criticism, to attract the public to the somerville Art Gallery. As just recogmtion rather than a flatiering compliment of American female beauty, these picture, apart from the striet consideration of their artistle merits, are full of interest, and, wherever they are taken, will be sure to attract much attention.

A cause which needs little argument to commend it to public sympathy is in need of help. We refer to the Orphan Asylum of "St. Vincent de Paul," which is intended for the benefit of all bereaved and helpless children, without regard to distinctions of race or creed.

Few questions of domestic policy, at this time, present higher claims on the attention of the people and their representatives than that involved in the civil service reform advocated with such zeal and good judgment by Hon. Mr. JENCKES, of Rhode Island.

The first of the elaborate views of Indian policy to be presented for Congressional information and guidance, next month, comes to us from General HAZEN. General HAZEN 'S reputation as an old Indian campaigner, and the very wide experience he has had in Indian management since the war, invest his opinions with unusual interest and importance.

General ELI S. PARKER, by invitation, delivered a eulogy on the late General J. A. RAWLINS, Secretary of War, at the annual reunion of the Army of the Tennessee in Louisville. Alluding to the promptness with which the North sprang to arms at the assault on Fort Sumter, he said:

Coroner KEENAN consulted with Dr. ELISHA HARRIS, Sanitary Superintendent of the Board of Health, yesterday, in relation to the case of MICHAEL GALLER, who died last summer, and is now buried in the Lutheran Cemetery,

A Convention of delegates from the several district association in South Carolina of survivors of the Confederate army was held in Charleston on Thursday, to form a State Association. General J. B. KERSHAW presided, and on taking the chair expressed his regret that his "gallant comrade, General WADE HAMPTON, the representative man of South Carolina in this connection," was not present to act in his stead.

BATH, Me., Nov. 22.--The new hall in Boothbay Harbor, owned by Dr. RICE and occupied by the Masonic Lodge, was burned on Saturday morning. The loss to the Masonic Lodge is $600; to Dr. RICE, $2,000. DENVER, Colorado, Nov. 22.--About 2 o'clock this morning a fire was discovered in the store-room of Mrs. CADY.

A terrible accident, accompanied with great loss of life, occurred at 9:05 this morning, on the Western Pacific Railroad, in Alameda County, one and a half miles south of Brooklyn Park Station. The regular morning train for Stockton, being behind time, came in collision with a passenger train of six cars that had left Hayward for Alameda at its regular hour.

The first of a series of lectures to be given on successive Monday evenings in the Yorkville Presbyterian Church, East Eighty-sixth-street, was delivered last evening by Rev. DAVID MITCHELL. These lectures are got up by the Church for the benefit of the residents of that quarter, and several eminent speakers have been engaged who will treat upon various interesting and instructive topics.

We find in the Richmond Whig the following letter from Judge JOHN W. JOHNSTON, one of the United States Senators elect from Virginia: ABINGDON, Wednesday, Nov. 17, 1869, His Excellency Governor Walker:

A meeting in aid of the temperance cause was held at the M. E. Church in Seventh-street last evening, which was addressed by professor S. GRAHAM , of England, and others. Professor GRAHAM said that many people argued that dronkards should be advised, but that respectable people who only take their wine moderately didn't need any pledge.

The Second Teachers' Institute of the Baptus Sunday School Union commences its sessions to-day (to continue three days) in the Calvary Baptist Church, Twenty-third-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. The afternoon sessions commence at 2:30, and the evening sessions at 7:30. To-day Rev. Tilos. D. ANDERSON, D. D., delivers the introductory address; Rev.

The immense fancy dry goods store of R. H. MACY, on Fourteenth --street, extending through to Sixth--avenue and to Thirteenth-street, and covering more than half an acre of ground, is now the largest establishment of the kind in this country, an addition of large proportions having just been completed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22.-A locomotive, tender and three cars of the easetward-bound train on the Western Pacific Railroad were thrown from the track near San Landros by a defective rail. The fireman was the only person injured. The damage was soon repaired, Large quantities of opium were seized to-day by the revenue officials, the property of Chinese passengers of the steamer Japan.

The battles of the rebellion were but the culmination of that contest between national and State sovereignty which has long existed, though it has confined itself mainly to the legislative halls and the Court rooms of the land.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 22.--The Goodman, Miss. Star, speaking of the affray in which General BARRY was shot at Durant last Monday, says that the trouble originated in STEVENS, the hotel keeper, ordering a crowd of colored men out of his house, who bad followed General BARRY to his room, and during BARRY'S speech STEVENS, In reply to the statements made by BARRY, told him he lied.

Yesterday Morning at about 7 o'clock, an explosion occurred in the Country jail at Hudson City, N. J., which shattered and nearly destroyed the rear wall. The time had been set upon for the removal of six prisoners from the jail to the state Prison at Trenton.

PARIS, Nov. 22. --The Emperor yesterday attended the Theatre Francals. The supplementary elections for the Corps Legislatif have terminated. HENRI ROCHEFORT is elected from the First Circonscription, CREMILUX from the Third, and ARAGO from the Eighth. In the Fourth Circonscription no candidate had a definitive majority, and a new election will be ordered. The city is tranquil.

The annual meeting of the Liberal Christian union, of Brooklyn, was held last evening in the Unitarian Church of The Saviour, corner Pierrepont and Monroe streets, Brooklyn. Mr. C. P. GERBISH, President of the Union, presented the annual report for the past year, setting forth the work performed by the Union, and the necessity for energetic action to enable them to be of more good.

It was never supposed that, in the distribution of official patronage, General GRANT could satisfy all the demands of political faction. The war had multiplied enormously the number of offices to be filed, while the reduction of the army had greatly increased the number of applicants for them.

BOSTON, Nov, 22.--The Boylton National Bank, corner of Washington and Boylston streets, was entered between Saturday and this morning, and a clean sweep made of all the valuables on deposit in the outer vault, mostly botonging to private individuals.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day an opinion signed by chief Justice CHASE was read in the case of the Adams Express Company against the Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria Railroad and others.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22.--Captain E. W. GOULD a highly intelligent and prominent steamboat captain and owner, publishes a letter to steamboat owners, suggesting that a convention be held at St. Louis, on the first Wednesday in January, with delegates representing all the interested steamboat stock in the West and South, for the purpose of securing such Congressional legislation as will secure the separation of the law regulating navigation on seas, lakes,
Events soon pass from the public recollection in these days. but probably our readers have not quite forgotten the Spanish gunboats, about which there has been so much controversy.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 22.--Much interest is manifested in the Railroad Convention at East Saginaw to-morrow. A large attendance is anticipated. The Convention is called to secure a railroad to meet the Northern Pacific at the head of Lake Superior via the Straits of Mackinac.

It was about 8:10 o'clock in the morning when a terrible sound shook the vicinity of Fifth and Olive streets-a sound of a great crashing and failing, that in a moment started into been attention and alarm all the people in the streets or houses for many squares around. It was a sound that as soon as heard translated itself, and from mouth to mouth the announcement spring, a great building has fallen.

Yesterday morning Deputy Collectors S. T. BLATCHFORD, who is charged with the perpetration of gross frauds in the Drawback Department of the New--York Custom House, presented a verbal resignation, through a friend, to Mr. GRINNELL, who accepted it.

The Constitutional Union General Committee met at Masonic Hall at 8 o'clock last evening, and was called to order by DANIEL D. NORTHROP, the Chairman. In view of the fact, however, that in consequence of the holding of several ward nominating conventions of the party at the same hour, the attendance was rather limited, it was deemed advisable to adjourn the meeting until after the December election.

Governor MERRILL. of Iowa, has addressed the following reply to a letter from a Prouncment citizen of the State asking the appointments of a person the ?? thought suitable and worthy: MY DEAR SIR: Your letter of the ?? inst., inquiring whether it was my intention to appoint a United States Senator to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Hon. J. W. GRIMES

At Common paw this morning the trade in live stock was lively, and the supply and demand equal. Sales of good beef Cattle were readily effected at remunerative prices. Some prime Ohio Steers sold as high as 10 1/2c. ?? lb. There were no sales of Sheep, but, nevertheless, stock holders looked hopefully toward the future, as they had good animals on sale. Prices quoted were as follows: Prime Bullocks, 16 1/2c. ?? lb.;

FORT SCOTT, Kansas, Nov. 22.-A large number of men interested in railroad corporations are in attendance at the Cherokee Council. now in session at Talequah. Several parties interested in the Osage land business are there, trying to induce the Indians to part with their land.

CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 22.--The State Tomperauce Committee held a meeting hero to-day. The returns of the vote on the Constabulary act were examined, and the result is not discouraginug. The proposition to run au independent ticket at the coming State election was considered, and action upou it was postponed to a sub. sequent meeting.

JAMES GANNON was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday, on a charge of rescuing a convict. JOHN E. HYATT, a keeper in the Penltentiary on Blackwell's Island, made affidavit that on Sunday forenoon he noticed a signal from the pier foot of Fifty-first-street,East River, and supposing it was the physician, manned a rowboat with a convict crew.

Nov. 22--In steamship France, from Liverpool,--Mrs. Benj. Baugh, Maurice Moore, C. H. Williams, G. Watton, K. D. Wide, Chas. Possing, J. R. Hatton, Bernard Graghty, H. G. Atkinson, Henry M. Mason, Mrs. O'Neil and 3 children, Mr. and Mrs. Williams and child, Mr. and Mrs. Haucock and child, Mr. and Mrs. Thos. Wood and child, Miss Kate Rimmer, Mrs. and Miss Burrows, Miss M. Casey.

Evacuation Day will Do celebrated next Thursday by a military parade and review. The line of march will be the same in part as that of the American troops when they entered the City eighty-three years ago.

Yesterday afternoon a Spaniard, named PAUL BOUTINE, called at the Mayer's Office, and complained to Marshal TOOKER that he had been robbed of $1,400 in the saloon of CHARLES BUSH, No. 2. New Chambers-street.

A fearful accident occurred at the mine of Jesus Maria, in the State of Guanajuato, on the 9th ult. While some of the men were engaged at work in the said mine an immense mass of rook. over a hundred thousand pounds weight, fell upon them. The news of this terrible accident soon spread all over the town of Mineral de la Luz.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 22.--A train of cars from New-Orleans for Louisville ran off the track on Friday morning near Bolivar. The ladies' car was turned down an embankment, demolishing it and injuring a number of persons.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. - The burning of the propeller Belle, of Milwaukee, near Port Washington, on Saturday night, has already been printed, with no information of the crew. Yesterday the brig C. J. Hutchinson arrived at this port, having on board as the survivors of the disaster, Captain C. N. MAYERS, first mate, of Milwaukee ; Second Engineer GEORGE WALL, of Milwaukee ;

At the Morris and Essex Railroad depot, at Hoboken, last evening, at about 6 o'clock two gangs of men were engaged in shifting the positions of a number of freight cars, when those being shifted by one gang unexpectedly collided with those being moved by the second gang. Four of the latter, who stood between the moving cars, were caught between the bumpers and three of them terribly crushed.

United States District-Attorney PIERREPONT has just rendered an opinion in regard to the Revenue law concerning bankers. The matter was referred to him some time age by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, since which time be has heard arguments, pro and con, on the subject.

Rev. LEONARD W. BACON delivered a lecture on "Father Hyaeinthe, his life and eleguence," in the New-England Church, Williamsburg, last evening. Among his large and appreciative audience were Actifed Rev. Dr. Wells, Rev. Dr. Haskins. Rev. Mr. Jocelyn, Rev. Mr. Murphy, Jonathan s. Burr, Esq., J. M. Stearns, Esq., and other well-known gentlemen.

Board of Alderman. At the meeting of this Board yesterday resolutions were adopted to pave Fifth-avenue, from Fifty-ninth to Ninetieth-street; Thirty-seventh-street, from Sixth to Seventh-avenue, and Forty-third-street, from Madison to Fifth-avenue, with Nicolson pavement, and to pave Howard-street, from Broadway to Mercer-street with Seeley's improved pavement, notwith standing the Mayor's ??, and Seventh-avenue from Fourteenth street to Seventy-ninth street with Stafford pavement.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.-The citizens of Peabody met at their Town Hall this evening, to see what action should be taken in regard to tile funeral obsequies of the late GEORGE PEABOD. A set of resolutions was offered by Hon. B. C. PERKINS expressive of the emotions of sorrow, veneration and love awakened by the death of the philanthropist of the age, and adopted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.-The State Department has received information that the 300 Americans, who were induced to ship on board the steamer Lillian, for Cuba, have been landed near Nassan, N. P., and the Lillian has been captured and held at Nassau on charges of having violated the Neutrality laws.

Yesterday afternoon a woman of elegant appearance, who chooses just now to be called MARY SMITH, was arrested at the corner of Broadway and Tenth-street, on a charge of picking the pocket of Mrs. FANNY A. HINCKLEY, of No. 17 West Twenty-eighth-street.

Pursuant to adjcurment the habeas corpus case of JOHN CRAWFORD alias Luke Eagan, who ws charged with being a fugitive from justice from Chatauqua County, this State, came before Judge CARDOZA again yesterday.

The rumor that Collector GRINNELL intends to change the system of carting goods from wharves and vessels to the Appraiser's office is premature. The present mode of conveying the goods, though subject to many objections, does not offer many opportunities for fraud.

The New-York Mutual Benevolent and Protective Society of Operative Painters had a meeting last evening at Demilt Hall, corner of Twenty-tiiird-street and Second-avenue. Mr. BARR, a delegate from the Brakesmen's Union, of Port Jervis, appealed for aid on behalf of the men at present on strike, against what he considered the oppreasions of the Erie Railway Company.

The name and face of SAMUEL W. SETON, who died at his residence in Union-square on Saturday morning, at the age of 81 years, have been familiar to be public school children of this City for three generations past, and will be remembered with tenderness by thousands of all ages and both sexes in the City.

Yesterday was not a very brisk day, yet one good sale was made, the results of which were very satisfactory to the owners and auctioneers, and should be to the purchasers. At Rahway, N. J., Messrs. JOHNSON MILLER had quite an extensive sale.

TORONTO, Canada, Nov. 22.--A Special dispatch from St. Paul. Minn., to the Globe, says: "A messenger from Pembina reports that Governor MCDOUGALL will not send his family to Canada. He is building quarters, and will await the reaction in favor of Canadian authority, which is anticipated. Governor MCTEVISH is very ill, and cannot take the field in person, which is greatly to be regretted.

A meeting of the pastors of the Prosbyterian churches of this City took place at the Univeraity-place Church yesterday, at 12 1/2 o'clock, when for the first time since the reunion the ministers of the Old and Now Schools met together for private consultation upon the interests aud welfare of their several charges and for social converse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.-But one thing has been determined reference to the new appointment for Judges, and that is that Attorney-General HOAR will be appointed to fit the present vacancy on the Supreme Bench. It is expected that Justice GRIER will resign early in December, and that both vacancies will be filled at the same time.

It is said that the firm of LOCKWOOD Co., who have been busily engaged ever since their failure in the endeavor to provide a resumption of business, have so far succeeded that they will resume in a very few days, with, probably, some changes in the management of the firm.

The Fair for the benefit of the new Catholic Church of the Epiphany, in Second avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets will close this evening. It is being hold in the basement of the new edifice, and is well worthy of a visit. Funey articles of various kinds are to be had in profusion and at moderate prices.

The extensive manufactory at Belleville, N. J., Known as the Belleville ! Print Works, was sold Saturday, by the Sheriff of Sussex County, to satisfy mortgages amounting in the aggregate to $229,523, Mr. H. J. GARDINER, the holder of the principal mortgage (of $193,779) purchased the property for $15,000, subject to his own and two light mortgages held by other parties.

?? ?? writes of the Pastroal ?? Society Church of the Holy trinity, that " a ?? sprain entirely disables me from traveling, so that I shall be unable to fulfill my engagement at Trenor Hall on Tuesday evening.

BATES--KEYSER.--On Wednesday. Nov ?? the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Dr. Agent age, DANIEL, BATES to HESTER, ?? Keysou, Esq., all of this City. HALL--DE LA MONTAG??--In Brooklyn Thursday, Nov. 18, by Rev. Samuel ?? Wm. R. HALL o Mrs. ?? LA ?? No cards.

The representatives of about seventy German business firms in this City, met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the Merchants' Exchange and News Room, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine-street, for the purpose of taking initial steps toward the founding of a German bank in this City.

The Book Committee of fifteen traveling preachers appointed by the General Conference of 1868, "to attend to the publishing interests of the Methodist Episcopal Church," have been engaged, for the past forty days, (in connection with a sub-committee previously appointed,) in Investigating the alleged frauds in the Methodist Book Concern.

Mr. MULLETT, Supervising Architect of the Government arrived in the City yesterday, from Boston, and left again in the evening for Washington. During his brief stay he was in consultation with Postmaster JONES and Judge BLATCHFORD respecting the interior arrangements of the new Post Office and Court House.

WILLIAM TELL TO-NIGHT. This evening ROSSINI'S noblest composition to be attempted at the Academy, and from the pains taken with the east and rehears als, and considering the importance to the success of the season that this should be veritable red-letter night, we have hopes that "William Tell" will be sung ands acted in a really creditable manner.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W Simonton, General Agent.

MADRID, Nov. 22.-The port of Manila has been visited by a violent earthquake, which extended throughout the Phillppine group. The shocks were very severe. In Mauila eight persons are known to have been killed, and many were injured. The loss of property was very great.

Judge CLERKE yesterday morning granted a mandamus in favor of JOHN FOLEY, enjoining the Board of County Canvassers from counting the vote case at the last election for HENRY SMITH for Supervisor, on the ground that the law passed last Winter makes all votes cast at such election for SMITH null and void.

Sharplay, of Philadelphia, are at the Astor House; W, Bodisco, secretatyi of the Russian Legation and Hon, H. Risley, of Washingtonare at the clarondon Hotel: Hon, D. K. McCurthy, of syracuse,

BENEDICT.--At West Norwalk, ?? ??, Nov. 21 ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? in the 86th year of his age. Friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral from the Congregations Church. New ?? on Tuesday morning, 23d inst., at 11 o'clock. BOLES.--At Northampton. Miss., on Friday, Nov. 19, 1869. JANE ?? RIVINGTON BOLES, daughter of William and Susan R. BOIES, aged 8 years and 19 months. .

SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 22.--The steamer Japan, which arrived to-day brought the following general news: The Duke of EDINBURGH reached Pekin on the 8th of October in the capacity of a private gentleman, and with but few attendants. Mr. WILLIAMS, the Secretary of the American Legation, left Pekin on the 5th of October for Europe, via Shangha.

The County Canvassers met yesterday morning and adjourned to this morning. Errors were found in the Twenty-second ward returns, which were sent back for correction. It is understood that the result of the canvass will be declared on Wednesday.

Leading Philadelphians have organized a branch of the American Social Science Association for their city. HENRY S. FORTE has become weary of tarrying in Tennessee. and now intends trying his fortunes in Mississippi. The coal trade in Middle Georgia is looking up. one hundred and fifty cars on the Western and Atlanta Railroad cannot supply the demand at Atlanta.

The elections in Paris concluded yesterday. Like the first day, yesterday was quite undisturbed. M. ROCHEFORT has been returned from the First District of Paris, M. CREMILUX from the Third, and M. ARAGO from the Eighth. Mr. BURLINGAME, with the Chinese Mandarins, has returned to Berlin.

At an early hour yesterday morning a fire broke out in the stand of GALLAGHER LANE, No. 405 Fulton--row, West Washington Market extension, which spread with great rapidity, and before the flames were extinguished caused considerable damage to the occupants of the crowded locality.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The Spanish gunboats complication will soon assume a new phase, which will bring the matter to a point where its final and speedy disposition will be apparent. As has been stated heretofore in this correspondence, the detention of the gunboats to the present moment has been on an executive order of the Navy Department, which has kept an armed surveillance over them.

Mr. WM. M. TWEED is our authority for stating that the Meetropolitan Fire Department is to bo reorganized by the next Legislature. Each company will bo allowed twenty-five men, instead of twelve, as at present, and the number of companies is to be increased to fifty.

BELFAST, Me., Nov. 22.--The gale of Saturday was very severe on the Penobscot River. In this city the wharves of HENRY MCGILVERY were destroyed, and tile frame of a vessel was demolished. CONDON'S wharf was ontirely carried away. The schooner John L. Tracy, (of St. George,) from Cambridge, Md., with a load of ship timber, was driven ashore and much injured.

The examination in the case of HARLOW E. SILL, of No. 272 Mott-street, charged with doing business as a lottery dealer without a revenue license, and also with not paying the Government tax of five per cent. on gross receipts, was resumed before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday.

It begins to be reported that the Democratic chiefs have decided not to abolish the Commissions which now manager the more important portion of our municipal affairs, but to make some such change in their organization as will submit them to the control of the Mayor.

The letter from Dr. DAVID LIVINGSTONE, the African explorer, to Lord CLARENDON, alluded to several days ago in the cable dispatches, has been made public. It is dated, "Near Lake Bangweolo, South Central Africa. July, 1868." Dr. LIVINGSTONE says, regarding his previous reports:

" At Omaha the fever of speculation has a good deal ?? a way; for that has an elephant on its hands. A great bridge is building over the Missouri shore, and the Union Pacific Railroad will put their shops on the other side; so it is Council Bluffs, and not Omaha, which is looming up for the future."--Letter Veteran Observer, Times, Nov. 13.

To-day a convocation of the Episcopal clergy of Long Island will be held at St. George's Church, Flushing, to discuss matters concerning the welfare of the new diocese of Long Island. Bishop LITTLEJOHN will preach the sernon.

The counting of the gold in the Sub-Treasury vaults commenced yesterday noon. Mr. FOLGER and General BUTTERFIELD were represented by Mr. F. D. TAPPEN, President of the Gallatin Bank, and the Government by Messrs. BIGELOW, MOORE and GUTHRIE.

The nearer we get to the bottom of the election frauds in Kings County, the more clearly it appears that they were not committed by a few "roughs" and sporting sine who had bet heavily on CUNNINGHAM for Sheriff, and FUREY for Street Commissioner, as the Brooklyn Eagle and the World would have us believe, but by the lenders of the Democratic Party.

In steamship Silesia from Hamburg.--Edward Well, Julius Molter, wife, 2 children and servant, Dr. Max Schuler and wife, Kunigunde Sonntag and 2 children, George Gunther, Cacellie Kirsting and child, Emilie Steinert, Mrs. Dannet and daughter, Miss James, Stilmann Witt and wife, colonel W. H Witt, wife child and servant Sarah Korn, Franz Day, Rosa Harrington, .

It is understood that the managers of the camp meetings held by the Methodist Episcopal societies of New-York and vicinity, contemplate abandoning the old camp grounds in the woods near the village of Sing Sing, having ??elocated a grove at the extreme easterly portion of Davenport's Neck, known as Leland's Point, in the town of New-Rochelle.

The absorbing sensation and topic of conversation yesterday, was the announcement that the Federal law officers in this City had been directed to prepare a formal libel against the thirty Spanish gunboats, and to take other measures to compel their detention at this port until such time as their character and ultimate use had been fully ascertained.

Collector GRINNELL has received additional startling information regarding the perpetuation of moist stupendous frauds against the National Government on the Part of numerous mercantile firms in this City.

A Japanese Prince and suite arrived by the China steamer yesterday. He is sent as a special Commissioner by the Emperor to inquire into the condition of the Japanese laborers on the sugar plantations in the Sandwich Islands. A heavy gale from the north has prevailed here and numerous wreeks are reported.

The concert to-morrow evening, in aid of the Dramatic Fund, presents attractions which should yield more than usual assistance to a very meritorious organization. The annual appeal in behalf of the Fund always occurs under suspices which entitle it to marked favor.

This organization held a meeting last evening at No. 458 Pearl-street. Mr. THOMAS H. MARTIN, the Chairman, stated the object of the meeting, which was to take measures to prevent, at the December election, such outrageous frauds as were perpetrated by the Democratic Party in the Fourth and Sixth Wards at the November election.

A meeting was held last evening in the Theatre of the Union League Clubhouse to take steps for the establishment in this City of a Metropolitan Art Museum. A memorial from American citizens in Europe, suggesting the importance of such a museum, was referred some months ago to the Art Committee of the Union League who issued the call for the meeting last evening as the best means of bringing the subject before the public.

ANDREW MORN, a resident of South Carolina, who recently arrived in this City, Yesterday gave bail before Justice DODGE, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, in the sum of $1,000, to appear before the Court of General Sessions to answer a serious charge made against him by Mrs. CHARLOTEE LOZIER, of No. 323 West Thirty-fourth-street.

CORONER FLYNN was notified yesterday to hold an inquest in the case of DENNIS AHEARN, a native of Ireland, 54 years of age, who was admitted to the hospital about two months ago on a permit from GEO. KELLOCK, Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, and who died there on Monday night.
The Sultan protests against the act of the Viceroy of Egypt in proclaiming the neutrality of the Suez reports that the Egyptian steamer Laly has been aground two days off that port.

An order has been issued by General SHALER for the parade of two brigades of the Metropolitan Fire Department on Evacuation Day. Engine Companies Nos. 7, 10 an 12 , and Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, will constitute the First Battalion, under the command of Major RHODES.

Officer IRWIN, of the Fifth Precinct, was walking very late, on Monday night, along the Second-avenue, attired in citizen's clothing, when he noticed two suspicious looking men loitering about near the vicinity of East Thirty-fifth-street. Suspecting they were up to no good,

About the 1st of March Last Mr. PRITCHETTE landed in Huaheine from an English bark, in which he had taken passage from sydney to california. He sailed again for san Francisco in the ill-fated English brig Rona, which foundered at sea on the 2nd of May.

Vashti belongs to the curious category of books that at first thought, at least, disgust us because they are no worse. Of course, as a rule we want books as good as they can possibly be; but there are occasional exceptions, and this is one of them. St. Elmo was deliciously amusing, and Vashti, despite many sparks of the same fire, is unconscionably dull, and herein is the heart of the mystery.

BEARE.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 23, THOMAS M. BEARE. Notice of funeral hereafter. BLEAKLEY.--At his residence, Verplanck's Point, N. Y., on Thursday, Nov. 18, William Bleakloy, Ex-Sheriff of Westchester County, N. Y., aged 61 years, 6 months and 6 days.

The Government forces arrived before Maracaibo about the 23d ult. The troops under PULGAR's command seeing this, at once revolted and hoisted a white flag. PULGAR, alarmed for his safety, took refuge with fifteen of his adherents on board the British war ship Cherub, then in port.

The examination in the case of JOHN W. LALOR and F.J. J. KEHNER, charged with foreibly extorting goods from a Frenehman named EDMUND DURANGER, residing at No. 124 West Tenth-Strect, under pretence that tey were masggled, was commenced before United States Commissioned SHIELDS yesterday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me, through your columns, to avail myself of the occasion which the robbery of the Boylston Bank, in Boston, offers, to call the attention of the public to the safety for securities offered by the Safe Deposit Company of New-York, nos. 142 and 146 Broadway, corner of Liborty-street, established for the sole purpose of their safe-keeping, and the first of its kind in the world.

The controversy between the Union Pacific and Central Pacific Railroad Companies, concerning the possession of the road between Ogden and Promontory Point, the settlement of which was initiated by the act of Congress of last Spring, which fixed the point of junction at Ogden,

The proposal to hold an International Congress on prison discipline, and to urge upon the different Governments a more humane system in the treatment of convicts, was brought before a joint Committee yesterday evening, composed of the following gentlemen: Jas. J. Barclay, Hon. Jos. R. Chandler and Dr/ A. J. Dart, of the Philadelphia Prison Society, and Theodore Dwight, Dr. Francis Lieber and Dr. Wines, of the New-York Prison Association.

A Fair to aid in the establishment of an Inebriate Asylum in this city, under the auspices of the ladies of Baltimore, opened here to-night at the Maryland Institute. The three Commanderies of Knights Templar of this city were present in full regalia; also an immense crowd.

Canadian papers publish the warrant of Queen VICTORIA, assigning to the several provinces comprising the Dominion the following seals: For the Province of Ontario--Vert a sprig of three leaves of maple slipped, or on a chief argent the Cross of St. George.

The city is entirely tranquil. Ministers BOURBEAU and LEROUX have been reelected Deputies. The Emperor has decided to remain in Paris for the present. LONDON, Nov. 29.--The Times, in an article on the political situation in France, says: "The hopes which were lately raised of the formation of a Ministry under OLLIVIER have vanished.

A decision has been rendered in the New-York Superiro Court in the case of PATRICK O'TOOLE the younger, by his guardian vs. The Managers, , of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Dehnaquents to recover $10,000 by the plaintiff. This, it will be remembered,

The examination in the case of the lottery dealer named HARLOW E. SILL was resumed before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday. General JACKSON, Assistant District-Attorney, conducted the prosecution, Mr. CHAS. S. SPENCER being present for the defendant.
The second annual Fair of this Society, to open on the 1st of December next, and to close on the 9th of December, though only the second exhibition of the Society, promises to be a very fine affair.

Every step in the proceedings of this Government toward Spain and its rebellions colony is interesting and important as involving principles of international law. This body of law, as we have often remarked, is made up year by year by the practice of the leading nations, and the decisions of their Courts.

The public have had some experience of reports of that class which are intended to " whitewash" culpable persons. Whenever a revelation is made which injuriously affects a powerful interest, political, commercial or social, a short and single plan is tried of hushing up the whole affair.

The examination in the case of Dr. AUGUST WEDKIND, charged with exterting $1,000 from Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, on a chreat to have her arrested for peisoning her lusband, was resumed at 2 P. M. yesterday before Judge HOGAN.

Professor FREDERICK L. RITTER delivered the second of his course of lectures on the History of Music, last evening, at Weber's Rooms, Fifth-avenue and Sixteenth-street, before a very select audience. The subject of the discourse was "The great epoch of Catholic Church music and the Madrigal, from the latter part of the fourteenth century to the death of PALESTRINA, in 1594."

The Bishop of Havana, who was recently arrested at Cadiz, was brought to this city to-day under guard. He will have an examination immediately. In compliance with a resolution adopted by the Cortes calling for information, the Government has been obliged to submit for examination documents which implicate Spanish republicans in a conspiracy with the insurgents or Cuba.

Collector GRINNELL erred, we think, when he accepted the resignation of BLATCHFORD--one of the prime actors in the drawback frauds, and a fugitive from justice. A man who has betrayed the trust reposed in him, and conspired with others to defraud the Government he was paid to serve, should not have been allowed to "resign" the position lie had forfeited.

At the Exchange Salesroom yesterday one of the ?? attended that have been gathered it better within its walls for many weeks. The ?? was stormy and very uncountable yet attractions offered were sufficient out quior a large number of persons.

WILLIAM TELL AT THE ACADEMY More than a year has passed since the death of ROSSINI. Yet until yesterday none of those grand operas, among which "William Tell" is at once the most brilliant and the most profound, has been fittingly brought before the New-York public.

By the President of the United States of America. A PROCLAMATION. Whereas, By the proclamation of the President of the United States of the twelfth day of June last, the levying of discriminating duties on merchandise imported into the United States in French vessels from the countries of its origin was discontinued;

A large and influential meeting of gentlemen, prominent in our banking and trading circles, was held yesterday at the office of Mr. JOHN BLOODGOOD, No. 22 William-street, for the purpose of organizing an association, having for its object the erection of a national monument to GEORGE PEABODY. Mr. W. H. NEILSON presided.

An interesting case came up before Justice WALSH in the Brooklyn Police Court yesterday afternoon, involving the rights of an orphan girl and the disposition of $10,000 in real and personal property left to her by her father, the late JOHN PHILIP BORN.

This morning, in THOMAS Co.'s pork house. EDWARD WELCH missed his footing and fell into a vat of boiling Water. and DENNIS QUINLAN, in trig to resene him, was drawn in head foremost. Both were horribly scalded. QUINLAN died this evening and WELCH cannot survive.

The body of PETER WEDENHOUSE was taken from the Fifth-street ruins late last night. Two or three more bodies are believed to be in the rains. A young man named BARNETT was publicly excommunicated from the Walnut-street Presbyterian Church last Sunday for abstracting money from the weekly collections. He confessed to having purloined about $1,000 since last February.

A lecture was delivered last evening, by Rev. Dr. HOWARD CROSBY, on the above subject, at the Fortieth-street Presbyterian Church. He reviewed the history of the Nile, and commented upon its importance in contributing to the prosperity of the country by irrigating the land.

Another reprimand has been administered by the Bishop of Orleans to the ultramontane editors, who presist in urging the dogmatic definition of the infallibility of the Pope. The London Times, in an article on the political situation in France, says the hope of a new Ministry under OLLIVIER is dissipated,

Thirty hundred and ninety-eight pounds of well-dressed flesh, or thirteen members of the Fat Men's Association met at the Revere House last evening to arrange matters for a ball to be given by them next month at Irving Hall.

About 150 Bishops have already arrived here. Many of them are from America. PARIS, Nov. 23.--The Bishop of Orleans reprimands M. VEUILLOT, the editor of ultramontane organs here, for the publication of articles in favor of the infallibility of the Pope.

In steamship Hammonia, for Hamburg.---R. Martin and lady, H. G. Fraser, Chas. von Roggenbach, Ferd. von Loehr, H. Leboucheur, S. M. Giddings, J. L. Taylor, B. Simon, Oscar Strassburger, S. Hirschbach and son, L. F. Dommerich, Hch. Muller, H. Truitt, Mrs. Jackson Matthews, J. G. Adolph, Rich. McClure, George Graaff, and others in the steerage.

The third of the "Star Course of Lectures" was delivered at Steinway Hall last evening before is large audience. Rev. JOHN HALL, D. D., was the lecturer, and "Switzerland" his theme. The lecturer said that he objected to talking "Guide Book," and should not, therefore, enter into such details as could be found in Murray.

The City of Washington, from Liverpool Nov. 11 and Queenstown Nov. 12, reached this port yesterday. During the evening the Silesia, from Hamburg Nov. 10 and Havro Nov. 13, arrived. By these steamers we are in receipt of news later by three days than that already at hand. For recent Continental papers we are once more indebted to the courtesy of Captain TRAUTMANN. of the Silesia.

The long and dark evenings of Winter are almost upon us, and as usual at this particular season, the classes which prey upon society are showing great signs of activity They are never asleep. but their opportunities vary, and now is the time when they being to look out for their richest harvests.

The tragedy at No, 63 Liberty Street, on the 29th ult., when the janitor, WILLIAM JESSUP, his wife and two children were burned to death was before commissioner BRENNAN yesterday on a charge of neglect of duty against Officer CORNELIUS MARTINEAU, of the First Precinct, who, it will be remembered,

COLGATE.--BLAKE.--On Tuesday evening, Nov. 23, by Rev. Dr. Storrs, of Brooklyn, ABNER W. COLGATE to GUARLOTTE ELIZABETH, daughter of Stepten M. Blake, of this City. EDMONSTONE--WORDEN.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Nov. 18, 1869, by Rev. H. Paddook, ALFRED EDMONSTONE, of New-Haven, Conn., to Miss FLORENCE A. WORDEN, of Wappingers Falls, N. Y.

The facts in the matter of BLATCHFORD'S resignation are represented in behalf of the Collector to be these: When the alleged friends were first brought to the attention of the Collector and Judge PIERRE PONT, they both agreed that one affidavit which implicated Mr. BLATCHFORD came from such a doubtful and tainted source that neither of them could net upon it officially.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--The sailing of Her Majesty's screw steamship Monarch, with the remains of the late GEORGE PEABODY, has been postponed until Friday, Dec. 2. JAMES PLM C0., merchants of Dublin, well known in American trade, are bankrupt.

TORONTO, New. 24.--A special dispatch the Globe from St. paul, Minn., says: "A gentleman from Fort Garry arrived at St. Paul yesterday. He says the English half-breeds and whites take little or no part in the demonstration. The insurgents are chietty French half-breeds. A system of passes has been adopted, and street suveillance is exercised.

The first of a match of three games was commenced last week, and owing to the lateness of the hour was postponed to Tuesday evening. The game had reached the twenty-seventh move on the previous evening of play, and much interest was felt by both of the contending parties, and by chess players in general, as to the final result.

Yesterday morning Inspector DILKS, of the Central Police Office, received a dispatch from the Chief of Police of Charleston, S. C., stating that one CHARLES CAHN had absconded from that city, after committing a forgery for $10,500, and was presumed to have come to New-York. Detective TIEMANN was immediately sent in search of the fugitive, and in a short time found and arrested him at the Metropolitan Hotel.

The interest and excitement in regard to the stupendous drawback frands still continues unabated in official cricles. According to Distriet.--Attorney PIERREPONT they are of greater magnitude than at first supposed, being considerably over instead of under $1,.000,000.

AT 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon Marshal HARLOW and Deputy Marshal WINSLOW visited the establishment of CORNELIUS H. DELAMATER, at the foot of West Fourteenth-street. They entered the office and were introduced to Mr. REYNOLDS, the Superintendent of the iron works, to whom Marshal HARLOW read the following attachment, of which he had Curty copies, one against each gunboat, numbers occupying the places of their names:

Tuckey, Andrew Jaynes, Mrs. R. Cunningham and daughter, Mrs. S. Rosenbaun and family.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--There is a good deal of talk and excitement here over an issue, which has just been made, to compel the recognition of mixed schools. On Monday the daughter of Rev. SELLA MARTIN was admitted to one of the schools on an admission ticket signed by Professor VASHON, a colored school trustee.

The Commissioners of Emigration met last evening at the Society Library building in University-place. There were present Mayor HALL and Commissioners O'GORMAN, WINSTON, BESSINGER, SMITH, KAPP, MCELROY and VERPLANCK, GULIAN C. VERPLANCK, the President, Occupied the chair.

King and man servant, B. G. Haines, A. B. Bigelow. W. H. Irwin, General Geo. W. McCook, Mr. King, Miss L. Haydon, Miss Louise Dalton, W. Williams. J. J. Jarves, Charles Fairehild, Mr. and Mrs. J. Aldrich, Hon.

At the regular weekly meeting of the Fire Commissioners yesterday, District Engineer RHODES Submitted a report showing that the engines in his command were frequently delayed in getting to work at fires because of the hydrants being out of order or obstructed, and giving a list of thirty-one hydrants which are unserviceable from these causes.

Yesterday was about as disagreeable a day as could well be desired by the bluest of all blue individuals, and the salesroom presented quite as gloomy an appearance as the day. A few disconsolate persons were present, comparing ideas and prophesying all sorts of things for the future, yet all agreeing on one point, that it is useless to expect any activity in the real estate market until after the 1st of January.

Mr. SEWARD'S trip from the Pacific Coast through Mexico is proving a sort of triumphal march. It rarely fails to the lot of public men during their lives to be the recipients of such an ovation of gratitude from all classes of citizens in a foreign State as the Ex-Secretary is receiving in Mexico. At a dinner given Mr. SEWARD at Column, on the 12th ult., many toasts were proposed and speeches made.

MEMPHIS, Tenn, Nov. 24.-- A terrible affair occurred near Tiptonville, Tenn., on Sunday. A party of masked men went to the house of WAT. JONES, a planter, for the purpose of disarming the negroes working for him. JONES having intimation of their coming, determined to resist, as the negroes had been peaceable and well-disposed, and made the proper means for a defence.

The tables are turned, Messrs. GOULD, FISK, LANE and their fellow conspirators of the Erie Ring are no longer masters of the situation. The law, in the hands of honest judges, is proving too much for them.

Latest dates from the South American Republics are Chili 17th, Bolivia 9th and Peru the 27th of October. CHILI. Congress is still in session. The bill authorizing Government to raise a loan of $4,000,000 for the construction of the railroad from Chilian to conception and Talcahuano has passed the Second reading, and it is thought it will pass both Chambers.

The shares of the French Cable Company declined 5s. in London, on the announcement of the leasing of one of the Angle--American Cables to a German Company. General DULCE, recently the predecessor of General DE RODAS, as Captain--General of Cuba, died on the 23d inst. in Madrid.

The usual monthly sale of Scranton coal took place yesterday at the rooms of the Delaware, Lacka wanna and Western Coal Company, No. 26 Exchange-place. The bidding was exceedingly brisk, but the prices of last year were not maintained, and the various kinds of coal sold yesterday were disposed of at a great reduction of prices as compared with last month's sale.

It is a little singular that St. Paul, Minn., the centre of a region greatly depressed by the low price of wheat, should come forward with an explicit declaration in favor of the resumption of specie payments. The people there evidently regard an irredeemable circulation as worse than any possible results from a resolute effort to restore the gold standard.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 24-The National Woman Suffrage Convention was called to order by Mrs. LUCY STONE BLACKWELL. Delegates were present from sixteen States, among them were Mrs. Celia Barlelgh, Mrs. Myra Bradwell, Judge Bradwell, A. J. Davis, Mary F. Davis, Henry B. Blackwell, A. J. Boyer, J. J. Bellvile, Mrs. E. F. Crain, Mrs. E. D.

In May last, CHRISTOPHER GRAHAM, on No. 66 University-place, fluished a side-saddle for Mr. TOWNSEND CONNOLLY, which he sent to that gentlemen's stable, at No. 217 East Thirty-fourth-street, where it was received by WILLIAM H. WILLIAMS, a negro, who lived over the stable, but was not in Mr. GRAHAM sent the bill of $110 to Mr. CONNOLLY, and was surprised to be answered that it had never been received.

In the TIMES of yesterday we gave an account of a fire which occurred in Flushing, L. I., on Tuesday morning, on the premises of ROBERT SMITH. It was at the time supposed that the fire was the work of an incendiary, and Officer SMITH set himself at work to discover the criminal.

PORTO RICO, Nov. 11, via HAVANA, Nov. 24. --The island is perfectly tranquil, and the prospect for good crops is brilliant. In January next, the duties on certain articles imported to the island, which have for some time past been admitted free, will be reimposed.

In an article on the recent highly important letter from Dr. LIVINGSTONE, the African explorer, the last London Spectator shows the value of his discoveries, and the facts which they have proved. It says: "But our delight at the prospect of seeing Dr. LIVINGSTONE again in the flesh must not be allowed to overshadow the intense interest attaching to his discoveries.

The power of foreseeing things which will never happen is not so rare as some enterprising writers appear to suppose. They exercise it with rather uncommon ingenuity and patience, and its is probable that they really confound it with the genuine gift of prescience, or they would never have the courage to go on inventing starting predictions in the teeth of repeated failures. .

The foundation of a Museum in this City for the collection of works of art has often been talked about, but at length there is a prospect that the design will be put before the public in a practical shape.

The fire which broke out Tuesday evening in the elevator at the top of the six-story brewery of DAVID JONES, Nos. 627 to 635 Sixth-street, was confirmed to the roof, but the whole lower part of the building was flooded by water, causing great damage to stock.

CARACAS, Nov. 7, via HAVANA, Nov. 24. The town of Maracaibo has capitulated, and there is great rejoicing in Government circles. The insurgents abandoned their leader, General PULGAR, who made his escape General ZULUCTA, commanding the rebel advance, joined the Government forces.

The litigation that has been going on for the last year or two against the unscrupulous usurpers who, by means of a conspiracy which for holdness and imquity has no parallel on record, have gained possession and control of the Erie Railway, is about to culminate in a thorough exposure, and, it is to be hoped, a merited punishment of the guilty parties.

A meeting of the New-York Liberal Club was held last evening at its rooms. No. 23 Third-avenue, Mr. HENRY BURLEY presiding. A letter addressed to the Secretary was read from Mr. A. R. RUESSLER, United States Geologist, Washington, in which he claimed for Maryland the right to be considered a gold mining region.

The Police Commissioners yesterday afternoon held a protracted meeting. all the members present. The following officers, who have been Acting Sergeants, were made full Sergeants, and detailed for duty in the precincts where they now are: Thomas Byrnes, Sixth Precinct; William D. Sminck, Seventh Prescient; Henry A. Hudson, Eighth Precinct;

BARTLETT.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday evening, Nov. 23, HARRIET S., wife of Jonas Bartlett, in the 56th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, No. 150 Union-St., on Friday, 26th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M.

DE CORDOVA delivered a lecture last evening at the Cooper Institute on "Our New Clergyman." He gave an amusing account of the peculiarities of th people of Turmpdale, and the advent among them of Rev. Mr. Trot, who was received in the most enthusiastic manner by those who were tired of their former pastor.

The suggestion that we throw out some days ago, that the Custom House investigations, conducted by the new Administration, would probably result in new and starting disclosures, or more than confirmed by the news published in our columns yesterday morning.

ENGLISH OPERA. The performances of the Richings Opera Troupe, which have attracted to the Grand Opera House audiences that have filled it every night since the season was commenced, brought before the public yesterday "La Sounambula." Although a representation by artists of the Same company was being given simultaneously in Brooklyn, there was a sufficiency remaining for the acceptable interpretation of BELLINI'S charming work.

Mr. WILLIAM M. TWEED having caused it to be announced in positive terms that the Fire Department is to be reorganized in a certain way, we may assume that he has been invested with the dictatorial powers in State affairs that he has long been supposed to exercise in City concerns.

To-day is the eighty-sixth anniversary of the evacuation of New-York by the British. The event will be celebrated by a parade of the First and Second Divisions National Guard, State of New-York, and a portion of the Fire Department. The line of march for the military will be partly over the same route that the American troops took when they entered the City.

The official announcement, this morning, of the adoption of the new Judiciary article of our State Constitution, will be most welcome. It will be especially gratifying to the large and varied business interests which have suffered from lax administration of the law, and, indeed, to all owners of associated wealth.

A telegram from Madrid this morning announces the death of General DULCE, in the 60th year of his age. He had been in feeble health for many years previous to his death. His predominant quality was personal courage. and to this he owned the first step in the career which culminated in the attainment of the highest position under the Spanish Government outside of the Kingdom.

In commenting on the Patti Concert in Boston, the Traveller says: "The Piano used by Mr. RITTER was a Steinway Grand. The instrument is a new one, and its many brilliant qualities were the theme of commendation from all. No better instrument has ever been heard in the Music Hall, or Indeed in any other hall, for that matter.

Hon. WILLIAM I. BOREMAN is urged for President of the Senate of West Virginia. The Cleveland medical students who attempted to steal the body of Mrs. CARPENTER from the cemetery in Gamesville, Ohio, have given bounds to appear for trial in February. The case against them is now said to be rather weak.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday, at the Metropolitan Bank, at 2 o'clock P.M. The reports of the Secretary and Treasurer, covering a period of nine months, (from Feb. 1 to Nov. 1.) were submitted, and officers and trustees were chosen for the ensuing year. The Trustees are: B. J. Howland, Howard Potter, Horatio Allen, Theodore Roosevelt and Alexander Van Rensselaer.

The regular weekly meeting of the Woman's Suffrage Bureau was held yesterday afternoon at the Packard Institute. Although but a few of the "faithful" were present, the meeting nevertheless was one of the most spicy and interesting that has been held.

The second session of the Institute of the Baptist Sunday School Union we held at Calvary church, Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon, at 2:30. C. B STOUT, of New-Brunswick, delivered an address on "Sunday School appliances and how to use them." in which he advocated a greater variety of lessons, and the use of maps, blackboards,

Full details have appeared in the TIMES of the adroit robbery of the store of JACOB H. FREY, No. 787 Broadway, of diamonds worth $710, in October last, and of the arrest of one GEORGE WILSON, hose name first appeared as Charles H. Wilson, by Detectives REILLEY and CORKEY, of the Fifteenth Precinct.

We learn that the County Board of Canvassers have finally determined that 25,964 votes were cust in this City for the Judiciary article of the amended Constitution, and 65,599 votes against it, making the majority against the article in this City 39,635.

The editorial allusion to Brooklyn politics and politicians in yesterday's TIMES was the cause of intense excitement in "Ring" circles at the City Hall and Court House yesterday all day. The members of the "Ring" had an idea that the small concession they made in counting in ANTHONY WALTER as Sheriff by a nominal majority was ample atonement for the flagrant frauds they committed upon the electors all over the city.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25.--The Woman Suffrage Convention last night, rescinded the order adopted in the afternoon session, tabling the Constitution proposed for the national organization. Mrs. LIVERMORE announced that she had received a letter from HENRY WARD BEECHER, consenting to the President of the proposed national organization ;

The connection of Messrs. FISK and GOULD with the Erie Railroad is not a story in itself, but rather a series of stories, each incredible enough to deserve admission into a new collection of Arabian Nights' tales-if we may be permitted to mention a work to which Mr. McHENRY has conscientious objections. One little episode of the main

No sales were made yesterday. To-day, at Centreville, Bayonne City, on the line of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, a sale will be made of twenty-live splendid building lots and two houses and lots.

Printing House-square, so rarely the theatre of starting events itself, whatever its mission may be to scatter broadcast the tidings of them wen they occur elsewhere, was yesterday afternoon the scene of one of the most lamentable tragedies (for there is but little hence for the life of the victim at this hour) which has taken place in the city for many Months.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25.-In the House, yesterday, a bill repealing the law allowing negroes to hold office and sit on juries came up on its second reading, and, without discussion, was tabled by a vote of 41 to 30. The bill repealing the law imposing penalties on common carriers making a distinction on account of race or color was passed on its third reading.

The anniversary meeting of the managers of the "Society for the Relief of Poor Windows with small Children'" was held yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the University-place Church. Mrs. W. P. GRIFFIN presided, and opened the meeting by reading a chapter from the Scriptures.

The Convention just held at Cleveland the purpose of organizing what is called a "National Women's Suffrage Association" deserves to be treaded in a serious spirit, chiefly for the reason that its own deliberations were free from the extravagance and buffoonery which usually brig ridicule upon meetings of the same Kind.

BARTLETT.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday evening, Nov. 23 BARRLETS., wife of Jo?? Bar?? year of her age. The relatives and friends of the ?? are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, NO. 150 Union-st., on Friday, 26th ?? at 1 o'clock P. M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--The heads of the several Departments, to wit, the Treasury, War, Navy, Interior and Post Office, have laid before the President their annual reports in a state of entire or partial completion, so that, he can obtain them the data and information required to complete his message.

AUBURN, N. Y., Nov. 25.--The second day of the centenary Convention of the Universalists of the State brought additional delegations to the city of both clergymen and laymen. The attendance was large throughout the day, and great interest was manifested in the proceedings.

The report that an alliance was in contemplation between France and Russia has been much discussed in England and France. The public journals of both countries consider such an alliance by no means 80 improbable as a weekly contemporary here insisted that it was last week; and on tile general question they express views almost identical with these put forward by ourselves. The following is from the Pall Mall Gazelle of Nov. 9 :]

Evacuation Day was celebrated, yesterday, with the customary pomp of parade, by the firemen and ?? of the City. In earlie times this was one of the great municipal days: but with the grand events of recent history more freshin remebrance, Evacuation Day has been quite stricken from the calendar of holidays. and trade does not pause a moment in its channels to do it honor.

The Democratic leaders in Brooklyn are excited by our exposures of the part which they have taken in the recent election frauds. The TIMES, says our reporter, is "the cause of the most intense excitement in 'Ring' circles at the City Hall and Court House."

No. 269.--Joseph W. Parish et al. vs. The United States.--Appeal from the Court of Claims.--Parish Co. contracted with Surgeon Magruder, at Louisville, in December, 1863, to furnish ice for the use of the United States General Hospitals to the West, including the Division of the Mississippi, and other Departments of the Gulf upon the Mississippi and its tributaries, for the year 1864.

Mr. H. L. HALL, the only agent of the National Association, for publishing literary and musical works for the blind, in the raised letters, is in this city soliciting subscriptions for that establishment. The benevolent object of this Association is to provide, by subscriptions and legacies, for this great want, by printing and furnishing music and other books in the raised character, at the actual cost or less, and to the ?ligent blind without charge.

In a letter to one of his constituents Speaker BLAINE says that there is no foundation whatever for the rumors that the State Department is negotiating another reciprocity treaty with the British Provinces. The power to do so in the ?? instance belongs to the House of Represcutatives.

Yesterday two trots took place at Union Course, Long Island. The day was fine and the attendance fair. The track was very heavy. The first event was a stake mile boats. The entries were Kate McGowan, Red Rover and Soger.

In Union Hall, Cooper Institute yesterday evening, Hon, WILLAM PARSONS lectured for the bebotit of the new Catholic Church, Port Jervia, Rev. J. NILLA, Pastor, is subject was "Irland and its Gennus, as represented in its romantic history and legondary tales."

Mr. FOLEY, who ran as a kind of People's candidate for Supervisor at the last election, has taken legal steps to contest the right to HENRY SMITH, present Supervisor--who claims to be reelected--to sit in that Board. On his application Judge CLERKE has granted a mandamus directing the Board of County Canvassers to give the certificate of election to Mr. FOLEY.
