The following is the vote of New-York County as officially made known yesterday by the Board of Canvassers: Secretary of State--Homer A. Nelson, 79,476; Franz Sigel, 36,897. Comptroller--William F. Allen, 77,800; Horace Greeley, 38,650.

A meeting of horticulturists and others was held yesterday afternoon, in the lecture room of the American Institute, Cooper Union building for the purpose of taking steps toward organizing a fruit growers' club.

Yesterday, although announced as "opening day" of the Fair, was not so by any means. A great deal had been done, it is true, to reduce order out of the inextricable confusion of the day before, but a great deal remained to be done, and if any one desirous of compiling a book called the "Curiosities of Cursing" had established himself at any one of a hundred places in the building and on the grounds,

CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 25.-Special Treasury Detectives SALMON DUTTON and DAVIS CROMLEY, of New-York, traced on from Baltimore to Philadelphia and thence to this city, a couple of fractlonal currency counterfeiters, and arrested them on the arrival of the morning train in this city to-day.

On Sunday afternoon last there was gathered at the Second Baptist Church, (colored,) on; West Main --street, an unusually large congregation to hear the funeral services of BEN TAYLOR. A good part of the congregation of the First Baptist was present, and the crowd in the church was grearter than it ever had been before.

The City Mission held their monthly meeting on Wednesday evening in the Fourth-avenue Presbyterian Church. Several of the missionaries gave accounts of their going about from house to house, and of their labors in tenement houses, hospitals, chapels, industrial and Sunday schools, , showing gratifying results.

The German woodcarvers, who during the past few years have been very successful in their operations in enforcing for all of their members good wages, are again preparing for a strike. The Carvers' Association, which numbers about one thousand members, has taken action to commence the strike on Saturday in case the employers should persist in their demand that the men shall work on Saturdays until 6 o'clock P. M. instead of 5 P. M.

B. F. THOMPSON, a young man about 25 years of ago, was arrested on Saturday, charged with the murder of his brother, JOHN L. THOMPSON, a man about 40 years of age, who lived on the west side of the river, about two miles from the city. The younger brother, FRANK, boarded with the elder, living as one of the family.

BUFFALO, NOV. 25.-CLAUDE BRENT, a bookkeeper In the Union Iron Works in this city, while shooting at a target with friend yesterday afternoon, was accidentally shot, and it is feared, mortally wounded. The ball from his friend's rifle passed through his right breast and lung, and out of the back, between the shoulder blades.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 25.--The Republican State Convention to-day adopted an address to Congress. It sets forth that the election in Virginia was a Confederate triumph, achieved by intimidation and fraud, Republican meetings being in some instances broken up by mobs;

The collection of "stamped orders" from the Mercantile Library order boxes was discontinued on the 1st instant. Hereafter, members who desire to have books delivered at their residences will send their orders by mail.

Those who sympathize cordially with the Cuban struggle for independence,-and they are very many among our pooplo,-cannot but admit that the insurrectionary cause is now fast losing ground. Whether the present aspect of the Cuban situation may not be only one of those tidal ebbs which even successful revolutions undergo,

MISS BATEMAN AT BOOTH'S THEATRE, This is the last night of Miss BATEMAN'S engagement at Booth's Theatre, and, with the exception of the malince to-morrow, the last opportunity for the present to see not only that accomplished actress, but the play of "Mary Warner," a domestic drama of a common-place type, yet so ?? titled to the idiosyncrasies of Miss BATEMAN as to have proved of singular attraction.

A Committee of Port Jervis workers now in this City, arranging with the heads of various trades' organizations here to obtain means of support for the employes of the Erie Railway Company, until the existing difficulties can be settled in the interest of the men, have made the subjoined statement of the causes of the trouble and how it at present stands.

A great want of proper places of amusement for sailors in tile port of New-York has long been felt, and it is to supply this want that the " Marine Temperance Society " holds a weekly meeting every Wednesday evening in the New-York Port Society's Mission, corner of Water and Dover streets.

The Veterans of the war of 1812 met yesterday at Military Hall, No. 193 Bowery, for the purpose of reviving old memories of the last war with England, and taking measures to secure from Congress pensions for their services in that three years conflict. General H. RAYMOND was in the chair, and colonel ABM. DALLY was Secretary.

A meeting of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Ward Citizens' Association was has last evening at Masonic Hall, Eight-six street, between Third and Fourth avenue Mr. JOHN FOLEY presided, and in his opening remarks said he had to report progress so far as the railroad on Madison-avenue was concerned.

OMAHA, Nov. 25.--VINCENT COLVER, the special Indian Commissioner, has just arrived from sitka, performing the journey in twenty-two days, and touching at all the principal points. He traveled over 3,000 miles along the coast of Alaska, and found the Indians to the number of Over 70,000.

We insert a narrative of DANIEL SAMSON, first mate of the ship Catherine, Captain ALEXANDER, with a cargo of railroad iron for Quebec: "We sailed from Genoa on the 22d day of July, 1869, with a crew of twenty-one men, including the first, second the third mates. Their names were: First mate, DANIEL SAMSON, of Genoa; second mate, JOHN DONOVAN, of Queenstown, Ireland; third mate, WILLIAM H. BELL, of Limerick, Ireland;

A Madrid dispatch says the Republican Deputies in the Cortes have issued a manifesto, in which the Provisional Government is accused of provoking the revolutionary movement. The intention to return to the Cortes to defend the right of the people and endeavor to establish a federal republic is also expressed.

There is probably no spot in England so full of interest as Westminster Abbey, and certainly none about which so much has been said and written. One feels, in approaching the subject, as if commencing a very trite story, yet our foreign tour would be quite incomplete did we not visit, may thoroughly study, this great English monument. For the nation's life is chronicled here-- " not theirs only, but ours also."

According to special call, a meeting of the stockholders of the Wells, Fargo Co. ' Express wan hold at noon yesterday, at the Company's offices, on Broadway, below Wall-street. The small room used for the meeting was densely packed, and considerable interest was manifested in the questions brought forward.

MADRID, Nov. 25.--The proposed new Constitution for Porto Rico, a synopsis of which has already been made public, was read in the Cortes yesterday. All the Republican Deputies who recently left their seats in the Cortes, will return this week.

A meeting of citizens of both political parties was held at the residence or Mr. JAMES A. BRADLEY, No. 37 South Ninth-street, Brooklyn, E. D., last night, to receive the report of the Committee appointed at a meeting held at the residence of W. J. COOMES, Esp., on the 17th inst., to propose a definite plan of action relating to the late election frauds, and to take such action thereon as may be deemed advisable.

The Teachers' Institute of the Baptist Sunday School Union met yesterday afternoon at Calvary Church, at 2:30 o'clock. The exercises were opened as usual by singing and prayer, after which several addresses were made. E. R, OLIN, Esq., spoke upon the importance of gathering the children into the Sunday School where they can enjoy the benefits of religious instruction.

The statutes of this State expressly authorize the Supreme Court "to suspend any director of a corporation whenever it shall appear that he has abused his trust . " And also" to remove such officers upon proof of gross misconduct."

The Eighty-sixth anniversary of the evacuation of the City of New-York by the British troops at the successful close of the Revolutionary war, when the American colonies became states "by the grace of God free and independent," was yesterday celebrated with more than usual enthusiasm.

PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 25.--The General Synod of the Reformed Churches in the United States met in triennial session in Christ Reformed Church last evening. This morning's session was wholly taken up with organization. In making out the roll, when the name of Iowa classes were called, two sets of delegates presented credentials.

BROWN-STONE FRONTS. Six first-class dwellings, north side of Forty-ninth-street, cast of Third-avenue, 19 1/2 by 44 feet, two stories; JOHN MOLLOY, owner. Three second-class dwellings, north side of Fifty-eight-street, west of Avenue A, 20 by 55 feet, four storeis; JAMES GILMORE, owner.

M. EMILE OLLIVIER left Paris for Saint Tropez the day before yesterday, leaving the Ministerial problem still unsolved. He address to the determination which I communicated to you in a former letter, not to take office until after the assembling of the Legislative Body, and a test vote showing the force upon which he canrely in the Chamber.

LONDON, Nov. 25.--The Shipping Gazette has an editorial on American Finances. It thinks a return to specie payments could soon be effected in the United States, and no debtor class would suffer by it . The South is generally well supplied with cash. Southern buyers are the mainstay of the Northern market.

The success which has thus far attended the efforts of the management of the South Side Railroad of Long Island, to give suitable accommodation to the public, has impressed upon their minds the necessity of an extension of their line, and it has been determined to extend the road from its present terminus at Patchogue to Bellport.

A suit has been commenced in the name of the Erie Railway Company against the plaintiff in the suit the particulars of which were published yesterday, and his attorneys, and against certain parties unknown, in which all the defendants in the elder suit, except the Erie Railway Company.

The effect of the late action by the Unites States District-Attorney against lottery dealers, for alleged revenue frauds, has been such as to prompt the mangers, middlemen and shopkeepers engaged in lottery schemes in this City to make correct returns of their gross Receipts.

The compressed air safety brake, invented by AUGUSTE DE BERGUE, of France, was exhibited yesterday on an excursion train upon the Erie Railroad to several members of the Press and other invited guests. This brake has been in use for two or three years in Europe, and has been tested on the engines of the Erie Company for six months Dust.

Within the past week an agent of the Junta visited Boston for the double purpose of obtaining men and money in aid of the cause, and of endeavoring to ascertain the tone of public sentiment with reference to the departure of an expedition from this port. Although judiciously careful in his statements, yet from his conversation it was learned that the work of aiding the rebellion was going bravely on.

At an early hour last evening a party of bold burglars broke into the unoccupied house No. 2 Bond-street, by forcing open the basement door and, going through the building to the roof, passed over theo intervening houses to No. 8 Bond-street, which they entered by breaking open the scuttle.

From the quiet manner in which the building of the New Post Office goes on, no one would suspect that much was being accomplished. But the progress from week to week continues at about the same rapid pace with which the work was started. The main supports of the structure are now well under way, nine of the pillars having already been laid.

In response to the inquiry of the Tribune as to "when the Brooklyn bridge will begin to be more than the (very faint) shadow of things hoped for." It may be stated that the caisson of the bridge is now in process of construction at Greenpoint, L. I., where a large force is employed in the Work.
It would afford real pleasure to your correspondent to be able to give you some flattering advices with regard to a country in whose success all Americans are so deeply and sincerely interested.

A meeting of the scceders from the Republican Convention yesterday took place this morning at the office of the State Journal, the Republican organ. Sixty members were present, about one-half of the original Convention.

The harbor is full of ice. Palais harbor is closed, and the Provincial and Gulf ports steamers have gone into Winter quarters. Four vessels and the mail steamer Peruvian have yet to leave for sea. The Steamers plying between here and Montreal have been laid up.

This week has boon a dull one, owing to the prevalence of the worst kind of weather imaginable. A portion of the time it was almost impossible to be out, and even, for one day at least, the ladies had to forego their favorite employment of shopping.

An address of General HAMPTON at the Georgia State Fair, though somewhat florid in style and factitious in sentiment, is, nevertheless, extremely interesting. As he has himself turned the sword into the plowshare and the spear into the pruning-hook, so he heartily commends the pursuits of agriculture to all his late comrades in arms;

A great amount of ignorance has been enlisted in writing down Alaska. The latest authentic account which we have is from VINCENT COLLYER, who has just returned from that country. He says that the Islands of St. Paul and St. George are alone worth the price paid for the whole Territory.

The Eighth Assembly District German Republican organization met at the Tenth Ward Hotel, corner of Broome and Forsyth streets, last night, to ratify the nomination of FRANCIS V. EURING, the candidate for Police Justice of the Fourth Judicial District, and appointed Committees to nominate the remaining candidates of the district at the coming charter election.

Commander SANDS, Superintendent of the Naval Observatory, to-day transmitted to the Secretary of the Navy a copy of the letter of Commander GIBSON, in relation to the meteoric shower of Nov. 13 and 14, which he observed at the Pensacola Navy Yard.

Senior JOSE LEMUS, Vice-President of the so-called Cuban Republic, who has figured quite prominently at Washington of late, as the Envoy of the insurgent party under CESPEDES, is now very busily engaged in preparing a complaint against the Spanish gunboats. He first determined to appeal as a complainant against the vessels after consulting United States District--Attorney PIERREPONT in regard to the matter.

In consequence of the critical condition of Mr. ALBERT D. RICHARDSON, who was shot on Thursday evening in the Tribune office by DANIEL MCFARLAND, as already fully reported in these columns, Coroner KEENAN proceeded to the Actor House yesterday morning and took the ??-morten statement of the victim to this shocking tragedy.

THE ITALIAN OPERA. The third representation of "William Tell" at the Academy of Music last night, was far better than the first. The nervousness incident to an initial performance was no longer perceptible, the artists knew precisely what to expect from each other

The following graphic resolutions were adopted at a meeting of the Sixth Ward Democracy, on Thursday night; Resolved, That we hall with honest pride the result of our labors during the recent election campaign in the development of a foul conspiracy, iniquitous frauds and the pointing of public indignation and scorn on their authors and abettors.

--All hopes for the safety of the schooner J. B. Martin are given up. She was lost, it is believed, on the 4th inst. while entering the Straits, and had no time to get into Lake Huron before the gale struck her. The vessel belonged to Milwaukie and bad ten persons of that place on board.

Mrs. MARGARET PERRY and her daughter, of Carrollton, Ill., have been held to bail, each in the sum of $5,000, on a charge of infanticide. It is charged that they murdered an illegitimate child of Miss PERRY. The mother, Mrs. PERRY, is a daughter of the late Governor CARLIN, of this State.

The Athenaeum says that a collection of Mr. DISRAEL'S speeches is about to be published. The Prussian Chamber of Deputies have missed a motion extending the trial by jury to political and Press offences. A velocipede race, from Paris to Rouen, seventy-eight mike, was won by an Englishman, against eight competitors, in ten and a hail hears.

Colonel JONES, Superindent of Indian Affairs for Idaho, reports to tile Indian Bureau concerning the assembling of the Nez Perces Council, at their reservation on the 18th lust., when the chiefs of the whole tribe were present, the non-treatyparty then outnumbering the treaty party.

Our town has been visited by a terrible tornado, which lasted from midnight of Wednesday until sundown to-day, spreading devastation in every quarter. A large portion of our town is in ruins, and many of the inhabitants are to-night utterly homeless. Many persons were injured by flying fragments of houes.

The World is dishonest in its controversies. What it cannot answer, it perverts; what does not suit its purpose, it mistakes. Thus it reprepresents the TIMES as having attempted the exculpation of Collector GRINNELL'S acceptance of BLATCHFORD'S resignation, although no further back than Wednesday last we condemned that acceptance as inexcusable.

On Wednesday night an incendiary set fire to a building in Connersville, Ind., used as the Winter quarters of the Forepaugh Menagerie. By order of the Superintendent of the menagerie, all the animals were let loose, which act in the end proved needless, as the fire was arrested before much of the building was burned.

BEARE.--On Tuesday, Nov. 23, at his residence, No. 345 West 14th -st., New-York, THOMAS MARSTON BEARE. His relatives and friends are invited to attend his funeral at the Church of the Annunciation, 14th st., near 7th-av., on Saturday, 27th inst., at 1 o'clock P. M. BURROWS.--Suddenly, at Brooklyn, on Friday, Nov. 26, CLARINE. A. DAYTON, wife of Jereme Barrows, in the 50th year of her age.

The efforts of a few enterprising citizens for two years past to provide a first-class railroad from Hunter's Point along the north side of Long Island, are likely to be crowned with success. The road is now completed as far as Flushing, College Point and Whitestone

Mr. OLIVER DE FORREST GRANT, President of the "Grant Locomotive Works" at Paterson, N. J., died on Thursday last. He was among the most enterprising and highly-esteemed citizens of Paterson. A meeting of Ithe employes of the locomotive works was held yesterday

The new house of worship of the Plymonth Baptist Church, Rev. ISAAC WESTCOTT, D. D., Pastor, on Fifty-first-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, will be dedicated to-morrow with Interesting services. In the morning, Rev W. H. FELIX, of the Pilgrim Baptist Church, delivers the sermon.

It is one of the droll rotributions which the whirl of time brings about that the very amendment of our Neutrality acts, which is now apparently to be used against the Spanish Government in favor of their rebellious colony, was originally inserted at the request of that Government against their South American Provinces.

The Secretary of the Navy, in his forthcoming report, will recommend a total reorganization of the navy, the sale of all the old and worthless vessels of the Isherwood class, and the construction of some new and more serviceable ships.
EDWARD C. WESTON, son of C. T. WESTON, aged 13 years, was drowned in a skating pond to-day.

We have heretofore collated from the report of the Comptroller of the Treasury, and other reports made to the Legislature, statements showing that the liabilities of the State were over $40,000,000. With but little regard to the indebtedness of the past, let us see how we will stand in the immediate future.

A full dress promenade concert of the Seventh Regiment will be given at the Academy of Music, on the evening of Dec. 16, and premises to be an exceedingly brilliant affair. It will commence at 8 o'clock, and from 10 to 1 o'clock there will be dancing. The band will number 100 periormers.

The next public union meeting under the auspices of the New-York City Sunday School and Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church will be held in the Seventh street Methodist Episcopal Church, on Monday evening next. W. W. CORNELL, Esq., President of the Society, will occupy the chair.

The Legislature met this morning after an adjournment of two days. The business in the Senate was unimportant. In the House, Mr. MAGEE, a Democratic member from Mobile, and but recently seated, was expelled on the ground that during the war he had been a County Commissioner.
Dr. ALBERT DAY, Superintendent of the New-York State Inebriate Asylum, near this city, was suddenly attacked last night by E. S. BIAKELY, an inmate of the institution.

In the General Synod of the Reformed Church, after divine service and a great deal of routine business was disposed of, an election was held for a place of meeting for the next General Synod. Cincinnati, Ohio, and Fort Wayne, Inc., were put in nomination.

On Thursday evening last GEORGE SIPP and PATRICK MADONEY were in the saloon no 120 Greene-street, known as "Dutch FRED'S," and being noisy and disorderly, the proprietor called in Officer O'BRIEN, of the Eighth President, who took MALONEY by the collar, and leading him from the saloon, started with him for the Station House.

Yesterday the Police Station in Newark was crowded with persons who came to report burglaries of their stores, and others who, hearing of the alarming number of robberies that had been perpetrated, were there to learn particulars. Mr. COHEN, of No. 46 North Canal-street, reported that his clothing store was entered and that a quantity of clothing was carried away.

The Livery Companies, who are the modern representatives of the ancient trades, guilds of the British metropolis, have lately identified themselves with a movement whose rapid development is matter of interest to artisans of all nations. GOVERNOR GEARY, of Pennsylvania, has issued his warrant ordering the execution of Dr. PAUL SHOEPPE, found guilty of the murder, by poison, of Miss MARIA M. STEINNECKE, of Carlisle, the execution to take place on Wednesday, Dec. 22.

There was a reunion of the prominent members of the Tiers Parti this forenoon to discuss the proposition of interpellation. A resolution blaming the Ministry was adopted. the electoral meetings recommence in Paris to-day. Troops have been dispatched to Alby, in the Department of Tarn, to quell disturbances reported there.
The steamship Weser, which left Bremen Nov. 13 and Southampton Nov. 16, arrived at this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by two days than that at hand by the Java.

On Wednesday evening last, LYMAN ALLYN, an aged boarder at Taylor's Hotel, in Jersey City, was found dead sitting in his chair in his room. His death was duly reported on the following morning, but there were circumstances developed yesterday which surround his life and death with peculiar interest.

General WILLIAMS C. WICKHAM, President of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, returned yesterday from New-York, where, we learn, he has completed the contract for the completion of his road to the Ohio River.

On Wednesday the cigar boat was brought out for a trial trip between this city and New-York. The vessel was manned by the owners, the pilot and another person. They started from here on Wednesday morning. As soon as the boat got under headway it sped like an arrow, and was sailing at the rate of about eighteen miles an hour.

The graduating exercises of the Senior Class of Grammar School No. 41, in Greenwich-avenue, took place yesterday afternoon. The school room of the department was haudsomely decorated with flags and flowers, and the scholars appeared in their gayest colors.

CONRAD METER, the man who has been in confinement in the County Jail for several months past, awaiting the execution of the death penalty upon him for the crime of murder, has at length penetrated the formidable array of stone walls and iron gratings which stood between him and the outer world and is now a fugitive from justice.

The case of GEO. F. GODSOE and ANNIE R. GODSOE, and CHARLES H. LOWELL and SARAH E. LOWELL, all charged with polygamy, were before the Superior Court to-day. LOWELL plead guilty, and the others, who were on ball, not guilty. By consent of counsel, the jury, by direction of the Court, brought in a pro forma verdict of guilty, the facts in the cease, all that the jury could try, being admitted.

SAN FANCISCO, Nov. 27.-The Giant Powder Mills, situated in the suburbs of this city, exploded last night. Two white men were killed and one wounded; eight Chinamen were also Injured. The building was blown to pieces, and the glass in the neighboring houses shattered.

BOSTON, Nov. 27.--MARY JEFFERSON, of Boston; MARY J. HARRIS, of Philadelphia, and GALVIN R. HEDDEN, late of New-York, are under arrest and held for examination, charged with pension frauds. The allegations are that Mrs. JEFFERSON has drawn pensionas a soldier's widow, having been twice married since the death of her first husband, and that the other defendants made oath that she was still a widow.

The last two days of the Fair have been mainly devoted to the tournament, wherein certain adventurous young gentlemen, more or less representing Richard Coeur de Lion, Fergus Melvor, the Black Prince, dressed very fantastically, armed with a lance and mounted on excellent horses, rode rapidly round a circus, endeavoring, with and without success, to carry off several rings suspended at intervals around the arena.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Though I am not one of the Fifth-avenue butterflies you speak of in your paper of Sunday, Nov. 21, I am very well off, and would be delighted to do anything in the world to help the poor girls you speak of.

Rev. Mr. STEBBINS, of San Francisco, declines the invitation to accept the pastorate of the Church of the Unity, in this City. Rev. J. S. B. HODGES, of Grace Church, Newark, has been elected to two rectorships in New-York State.

The United Presbyterian is getting alarmed at the state of religion in New-England. The Methodists, Baptists and Congrogationalists have lately been holding conventions in Connecticut, and they say: "New-England, which once led the world, is lagging behind, and the great West and Northwest are outstripping her in all the lines of moral and spiritual progress.

CHARLES STUDE, a German, 'residing at No. 135 First-avenue, was arrested yesterday morning and arraigned before Alderman COMAN, on a charge of committing a felonious assault upon JOHN COCHRANE, of No. 221 First-avenue. The prisoner and the complainant had a quarrel, when STUDE drew a revolver and fired twice at his opponent, one of the bullets taking effect in Mr. COCHRANE'S arm.

LONDON, Nov. 27.-Dispatcbes from Cork, Dublin and Tipperary, report that there have been several Fenian demonstrations in various parts of Ireland to-day. At Tipperary and Clonmel the proceediugs were riotous. Fenian songs were sung by the mob while marching in procession, and several houses on the line of march 'were stoned and riddled.

The annual Fall parade of the First Division on Thursday was a very good one, and the appearance of the several commands was, III general, a satisfactory one. Those Brooklyn regiments participating in the parade also made a good show, and they evinced a degree of progress and efficiency that will redound to the credit of the commanding officers.

To-day. (Wednesday,) at 2:30, a special train departs for Compiegne with the guests invited to the Emperor's fete. The ladies are in a minority, but the unusual beauty, grace and charm of those selected would more than compensate for any deficiency in numbers.

It is but a few days since the public were startled to find that a convict, but recently pardoned out of the New-Jersey State Prison. had been appointed a policeman and assigned to duty sin the Twenty-eighth Precinct. Yesterday the Police Commissioners were engaged in the consideration of another and still more flagrant case of the same character.

This Board met at noon yesterday, Mr. JOHN FOX in the chair. Mr. ELY said he had two communications to present in relation to the votes cast for Supervisor, and he moved they be read. Mr. TWEED said the Board had no power to go behind the returns of the canvassers.

The week just closed has been a little more active than the preceding one. A few enles of considerable interest were made, and the results, all things considered, were very satisfactory. This must not be taken as a sign though that any general activity has commenced. Until after the 1st of January but few sales of any importance, except forced sales, will be made.

The Government have received dispatches from Hon. Mr. MCDOUGALL relative to a the Winnipeg insurrection, which confirm the reports already received. Mr. MCDOUGALL expresses a belief that the agitation will die out as soon as proper explanations are made to the half-breeds.

In DICKENS' last Christmas story, No Thoroughfare, M. Obenreiser often reverts to the smallness of this world, and its incapacity to keep asunder those whom any bond of interest has once united. Rather, according to him, the tendency is to reunite the separated, even though in the most unlikely places and under the most improbable circumstances.

The Trustees of Dartmouth College held a meeting in this city on Monday, and among the business transacted was granting leave of abscenco for three months to the President of the institution, Rev. ASA D. SMITH, D. D. Since his labors commenced, six years ago, the funds of Datmouth College have increased more. than $200,000, mainly through the efforts of Dr. SMITH.

HENRY M. DUNN, who was bitten by a dog in August last, was taken with hydrophobia on Thursday, and, after intense suffering. died yesterday. ALEXANDER MCCONNELL, who was kicked in the abdomen a few days since by LORENZO MURPHY, died last night. MURPHY is under arrests.

We are authorized by Mr. LEWIS B. BROWN, one of the principal men engaged in the project, to say that the report of the engineers removes every obstacle that had been supposed to be in the way, and that the present indications are that ground will be broken for the new underground railway as early as February next, and that the work will be completed in two years from that time.

A ease now pending before the Police Commissioners should teach public officials of all grades a lesson they greatly need. A man who committed perjury to obtain a position was appointed a policeman upon the recommendation of five politicians of local prominence who certified to his good charactor.

Mr. ISAAC C. PRAY, a cultured and genial gentleman, well known in literary and theatrical circles, died at his residence, No. 23 Irvingplace, yesterday morning. Mr. PRAY was born in Boston in 1813, and since 1836, when he first came to this City, won conspicuousness as a journalist, a playwright, an elocutionist and an actor.

At the weekly prayer meeting of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, on Friday evening last, near the close of the services, Rev. Mr. BEECHER beckoned to some one in the audience After considerable urging in this manner a woman arose, one of strange appearance and attire. Her features were strong and wild-looking, and her eyes large and dark.

The brief anticipatory notice our Washington Correspondence has given of the Navy Department report, shows of that this will be an important document. For example, we are told that it will recommend the total reorganization of the navy, with the "sales of all the old and worthless vessels of the Isherwood class" and the construction of new and serviceable ships to supply their places.

Yesterday afternoon MORRIS VERLOSKY and RACHEL SEREKEN, residing at No. 77 Bayard-street, had an altereation at that place about some clothes, which ended in VERLOSKY'S drawing a large knife, with which he attacked the other, cutting her in two places on the right arm, and making a severe wound two inches long on the right side of her mouth.

There is now in process of construction in Hoboken, under the supervision of General GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN, a steam floating battery which promises to be one of the most remarkable constructions of the age. The incipienoy of the enterprise dates beyond 1841, when Commodore STEVENS, who started it, first submitted his plans to the Federal authorities and asked Congressional approbation toward its construction.

About 4 o'clock yesterday morning JACOBROUX, conductor of Third-avenue car No. 49, getting into a dispute with ALBERT GARDNER, a passenger, drew a pistol and assaulted GARDNER with it, inflicting some severe eats on the head, and split one of his ears. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am daily asked whether the real estate market is not dull or flat, and whether prices are not on the decline, to all of which I have unhesitatingly answered No. We compare the sales being made from day to day with the general run of sales during past years.

Last evening Rev. J. T. KENDRICK lectured at Neptune Hall, No. 405 Grand-street, on temperance. He argued that if alcohol had been necessary for man, God would have provided it for him at the Creation, and that as alcohol is produced by the decay of vegatable matter it cannot give health or strength or sustain the life of animals.

M. LESSEPS, the chief engineer of the Suez Canal, has publicly denied the unfavorable reports which have been recently circulated about that great enterprise. He calls attention to the fact than in ten days no less than fifty vessels sailed safely through the canal and back.

The Vice Consul at Barcelona, under date of the 3d of November, reports to the Department of State information of the loss by foundering at sea of the bark Nellie Ohapin, of Boston, on a passage from Newport, England, to Genoa.

The Park-avenue extension and other tranduient movements in the City of Brooklyn at the present time constitute the basis of much discontentment and uneasiness. The people living along the line of Park-avenue are not aggrieved on account of the proposition to extend or open up Park-avenue, merely, but in relation to the manner in which it is proposed to be done.

The last rail of the Bangor and Piscataquis Railroad was laid at Foxcroft Friday afternoon. The road will be open to regular traffic about Dec. 15. A movement will be made the coming Winter to extend the road beyond the present terminus. Navigation is about suspended here.

There can be no use in disguising the fact, even if it were possible, that a profound anxiety pervades the business community in regard to the coming year. The long-predicted " shrinkage." which has been so often falsely prophecied that people have come to doubt its over occurring, seems at length really to have begun.

A desperate character named COOPER, who had been whipped by a party of " regulators" in Pulaski County, caused the arrest of some of his neighbors whom he accused of administering the chastisement. Saturday morning was fixed for the trial, COOPER and his friends entered Somerset, county seat, armed to the teeth.

Late advices have been received here from the Philippine Inslands. A formidable reactionary conspiracy had been discovered at Manila. Many arrests were made. The principal person implicated committed suicide when he found the scheme had been frustrated.

Judge KELLY, the upright and useful Magistrate, has been on the Bench twelve years, having been twice elected in the face of adverse political majorities in his district. He is now renominated, and is urged to accept by a number of our best citizens. Judge KELLY prefers to devote himself to his private duties, and to his position as President of the Fifth National Bank.

The officers and trustees of the Steuben Monument Association, of this City, who were incorporated in 1860, but whose aims were delayed by the war, held a meeting at the Steuben House yesterday afternoon, Mr. CHAS. MOHRING presiding.

The Committees appointed by the Common Councils of the several cities of Hudson County, New-Jersey, which assented in September last to consolidation, assembled Saturday and took preliminary steps toward securing desirable amendments to the Charter.

Persons passing through William-street on Saturday morning could not have failed to observe a large gathering of able-bodied, respectable-looking men, clad evidently in their holiday clothes, and the majority of them carrying small portmanteaus or waterproof bags standing about in the vicinity of No. 60, between Pine and Cedar Streets.

At a little before 1 o'clock yesterday morning, as Officer AXT and Private Watchman WALDMAN were passing through Bowerystreet, Newark, N. J., they heard the cry of "Watch! Watch!" issuing from the Inger-beer saloon of a German named HESSE. Officer FISHER immediately proceeded to the house, No. 32 Bowery-street,

The stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, last night ratified a contract with C. P. HUNTINGTON, W. H. ASPINWALL, PLINY FISK and their associates, of New-York, for the completion of the road. The gentlemen named and their associates in the contract were elected directors for the ensuing year, with JOSEPH R. ANDERSON and General WICKDAM.

Last Friday night burglars effected an ontrance into the premises of HOWE FERRY, No. 76 Bowery, from the collar of the building, to which, it is presumed, they gained access during the day unobserved, and secreted themselves until alter the house was closed at night.

A melancholy accident occurred on the New-Jersey Railroad, at the Hackensack bridge, last evening. A passenger, whose name is unknown, was unable to find his ticket when the the conductor called for it, on the train that left New-York at 6:30 o'clock, and was informed that he must Day his fare or be put off the train.

About 7 o'clock last evening an affray occurred at the corner of Avenue A and Thirteenthstreet, during which JOHN BIGLEY, of No. 526 East Fourteenth-street, was assaulted by WILLIAM MCKENNEY and JOHN MCKENNEY, both of No. 535 East Thirteenth-street, who used blunt instruments of some kind, and beat him so badly about the bead that he was taken to Bellevue Hospital in a precarious condition.

The document just produced from the archives of the State Department, to the chagrin and discomfiture of Peru, in her complaint against the Spanish gunboats ought certainly to operate by the way of estoppel, because it is direct and positive in terms.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 29.--The troubles on the Mississippi are increasing. The citizens of Water Valley were very much alarmed last night at the reported threats of the negroes to burn the town. A committee of citizens went to Grenada for groops, and Governor PENNIBACKER sent them late night.

It having been reported that the waters of the basin between Piers Nos. 22 and 23 East River, where the Fulton Market Fish mongers' Association keeps its fish, were deleterious to the health of the fish, and consequently to that of those consuming them, Mr. GEO. W. BLUNT

The information which we were enabled yesterday to lay before the public will doubtless excite considerable interest in all parts of the country. It is true that we have no reason to be excessively anxious for the settlement of the questions arising out of the Alabama claims.

M. MAILLEFERT'S contract to remove Way's Reef and other rocks at Hell Gate expires to-day, and General NEWTON will soon have the work surveyed and report the result to Washington. What MAILLEFERT has accomplished by his blasting at that point during the last three months cannot be known accurately until the soundings have been made.

A complaint was made yesterday before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by JOHN H. BAKER, No. 141 Sixthavenue, in which it was stated that on Oct. 5 JAMES DONALDSON called on BAKER, saying that he had a cash customer for a diamond ring and gold watch and chain worth $275, which BAKER desired to sell.

The examination in the case of JOHN S. BARTON, charged with having bribed two weighers white acting as agent for a Water-street mercantile firm, was before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday. A motion was made by counsel for the defence, for the adjournment of the case for several days.

A mass meeting of the Clothing Cutters' Protective Union of this City was held at the Germania Assembly Rooms last night, Mr. HENRY SCHAEFFER presiding. A preamble and resolutions were passed, stating that the object of the meeting was to reorganize the association, to invite clothing cutters not belonging to it to join it,

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

A large crowd of persons, principally Germans, assembled yesterday morning at the Co??oner's office, in the City Hall, in order to witness the proceedings in the GALLER-WEDEKIND case, now so mysterious in all its bearings. Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, wife of MICHAEL GALLER, whose remains are now undergoing analysis to determine the cause of his death, was also present, and appeared to take a deep interest in the proceedings.

MR. HACKETT'S FALSTAFF. The disposition so frequent with Americans to discourage or get rid of whatever is no longer now or youthful, is no unnatural characteristic of such a country. To be young and frosh and comely, is usually also to be energetic and strong, and the genius of America has stretched forth her hands to grasp the qualities for which, in the Republic's tende rer years, there has been the most need.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28.--Paymaster W. G. MARCY, of the Mare Island Navy Yard, is a defaulter in the sum of $140,000, according to estimate. He has turned his property over to the Government, but it will by no means cover the amount of the defalcation.

BONNER--SEWELL--On Thursday, Nov. 25, at All Saint's Chapel, Quebec, Canada, by Rev. E. W. Sewell, assisted by Rev. G. V. Honsman, GEORGE T. BONNER, of New-York, to ISABEL GRACE, daughter of the late William S. Sewell, of the former place.
At the regular meeting of the Board of Assistant Alderman, yesterday, Mr. PINCKNEY said he saw by the public prints that the Board hold a meeting on Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--Mr. BURLINGAME, several weeks ago, authorized a gentleman who has just returned from Europe to make the statement that the constant reports of the dissatisfaction of the Chinese Government with his mission originate in China among those who are opposed, on commercial and other grounds, to the policy of that Government.

BOSTON,Nov. 29.-Counterfeit United States ten dollar bills have just made their appearance in this city, and are excellent imitations of the genuine. In Peabody, on Saturday evening, NATHANIEL LORD, a well-known citizen of the town, was knocked down on the road and robbed.

PARIS, NOV. 29.--The sessions of the Senate and Corps Legislatif were reopened to-day with great ceremony by the Emperor, who delivered the opening speech from the throne. It was hoped that the Empress might possibly return in time to take part in the ceremonies, but she has not yet reached Paris. The Emperor said: "It is not easy to establish regular and peaceful liberty in France.

CONNOR.--On Sunday, Nov. 28, after a lingering illness, MARY, relict of Thomas Connor, aged 54 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her into residence, No. 78 Lexington-av., on Wednesday morning, at 9 1/2 o'clock. DAVIS.--In this City. PHEBR DAVIS, in the 77th year of her age.

Mrs. EMMA SANDBURGER was engaged in pouring oil into a lamp over a fire at her residence, No. 147 Henderson-street, Jersey City, last evening, when some of the oil, dropping upon the stove, ignited. The flames communicated to the can containing the oil, and this exploded. A second afterward her clothing was in flames.

At 12:40 o'clock on Monday morning nearly all of the sky was remarkably clear. Between 3 and 4 o'clock the heavens were suffused with the red and scarlet variety of the Aurora Borealis. The planet Jupiter shone forth in the West, while the silvery Sirius appeared about one hour west of the meridian, and the moon a short distance above the eastern horizon.

The Emperor of the French yesterday delivered the customary speech on the reassembling of the Senate and Corps Legislatif. The agitation of the past two months is ascribed to "subversive passions " and the " excesses of the Press and of public assemblages," by which society was menaced and freedom compromised.

The new building of the Young Men's Christian Association, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third street, was thrown open last evening, for a private view, to the donors of the fund and a few friends who had been specially Invited. The formal opening of this institution will take place on Thursday evening next.

A petition was yesterday presented to tale Board of Police Commissioners, signed by several hundred citizens of the Sixth Aldermanic District, which is the Thirteenth Ward, praying for the removal of all the Election Canvassers and Inspectors of the ward, in the interest of the purity of the forthcoming municipal election.

The Now-York News Company, of which Mr. DAVID P. RHOADES is President, have published a neat little pamphlet containing, beside their trade list, which appears to embrace all literature, explicit directions to news agents all over the country as to rules and methods to bo observed in starting and carrying on news depots.

HENRY SCHOULDER, a journeyman tailor, formerly residing in this City, but now of Union Hill, N. J., stands accused of bigamy. It seems that while he had a wife and family residing in this City, he became enamored of a pretty flower girl residing at Union Hill, named AMANDA DELTZ, whom he met in the course of his journeyings in this vicinity.

A fair number of persons assembled at the Exchange yesterday to attend the sale of the Valentine estate, located at Yonkers, N. Y. The bidding was not very brisk, nor was very much interest manifested; the results, though, were moderately satisfactory.

The case of the newly-appointed Police man EDWARD BRANIGAN, of the Seventh Precinct, who has been seven times arrested for crimes and misdemeanors within the past three years, has naturally created considerable sensation, succeeding as it did so closely a similar case in the Twenty-eighth Precinct.

A running match for $1,000, mile heats, between two well-known racehorses, Mr. J. ECKERSON'S ch. h. Mature, five years, by Star Davis, dam Katonah, and Mr J. HINCHMAN'S ch. c. Boaster, four years, by Eclipse, dam Vanity, came off yesterday on the Paterson Race Course, New-Jersey. n the Paterson Raco Course, New-Jersey.

LOUIS RIELLE is a young man about 24 years of age, was born at Red River, from poor, but respectable parents, and is of pure French origin. Thirteen years ago his education was placed under the care of a Bishop, who sent him to the best classical college in Montreal-that same college where General DIX, of the United States, and several other great scholars have been educated.

At the election in Mississippi to-day the proseriptive clauses of the proposed State Constitution are separately submitted. In the Texas Constitution there are no clauses of this kind, it being very liberal in Its character.

Rev. JAMES McCOSH, D. D., President of Princeton College, lectured in the Central Presbyterian Church. at Newark, N. J., last evening. His subject was " The Association of Ideas and its Influence on the Training of the Mind." Hesaid that law ruled in mind as it did in matter, and its reign linked our feelings one to another.

Prince Louis de Bourbon, of France, is at the Union-place Hotel. Senator Starkweather, of Connecticut; General Cadwalader, of Philadelphia; General Cleary, of Washington; Hon. James S. Parker of Massachusetts; Hon. W. E. Taylor, of Binghamton; Hon. W. E. Chandler, of Washington; Commander M. P. Williams, of the United States Navy, and Hon. E. A. Rollins, Philadelphia, are at the Astor House.

General LUBIN, on his march from Jacinel to this city, took possession of Fort Bigoton, four miles from hero, and hold it for SALNAVE. General CHEVALLIER, who Joined the revolutionists at the same time that LUBIN professedly did, had taken possession of all the towns and fortresses on his line of march up to Leogane, fifteen miles from this city, and was about to join his forces with the other revolutionary leaders.

Corner CHASE yesterday morning commeneed his inquest over the remains of CORELIUS STAILL, who was stabbed and killed on Sunday morning, during a barroom fight, at No. 31 Bowery, in New-York. Louisa Hesse testified that she was the wife of the proprietor of the saloon and boarding house at No. 31 Bowery street;

The announcement is made this morning in our telegraphic news columns of the death of this noted and once unrivaled cantatrice GIULIA GRISI was born at Milan, in 1812, and was the daughter of GAETANO GRISI, an officer of engineers in the armies of the first French Empire.

Last week we gave a short notice of this coming exhibition of poultry and small animals. The entries last evening, including all sorts, were 1,000 in number, and this includes many rare birds and animals. The premiums are to be a warded on Monday next, and all sales must be effected through the Treasurer.

The funeral of Mr. BARROW BENRIMO took place yesterday at the residence of his brother, No. 243 WestTwenty-second-street. The services were conducted by Rev. J. J. LYONS, according to the forms of the Jewish faith.

Last evening our Israelitish fellow-citizens commenced the celebration of the Feast of Dedication, instituted 2,034 years ago. Eight candlesticks with candles are placed in the Synagogues and dwelling houses, and one candle is lighted and dwelling houses, and one candle is lighted on each day of the feast, which concludes on the 7th of December.

In thunder, lightning and in rain, the State Fair closed to-day. Very few beside the exhibitors interested in the awards of the prizes and the officers of the Society were present, and many of those who were thoroughly drenched would gladly have sacrificed their chances of fame, if by doing so they could have done away with their wetting.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 29. --A bill was introduced in the House to-day to pay the principal and interest of the State bonds and stocks in

Sunday morning, about 1 o'clock, Officer RYAN, of the Eighteenth Precinet, saw a man coming out of the bakery, no. 285 Third-avenue, who field at his approach, but whom he captured after a chase of several blocks. It appeared that the prisoner, who gave his name as THOMAS JORNSON, had entered the bakery by foreing open a side window;

Among the letters published in the volume giving the official account of the reunion of the soldiers of the Armies of the Tennessee, the Ohio the Cumberland and Georgia, which took place in Chicago, in December, 1868, is the following; UTICA, Dec. 12,1868.

[OFFICIAL.] SATURDAY, Nov, 27, 1869--3 o'clock P. M. The Board met in their Chamber, No. 16 City Hall, pursuant to a call signed by a majority of the members. Present-James A. Monaghan, Esq., President, in the Chair, and the following members:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.-The Census Committee held a long session to-day, but did not reach any conclusion. From the expressions during the discussion it seems very probable that the Committee will decide to include in their bill the matter of the basis of representation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 29.--W, H. WISE an express messenger on the Cleveland and Pittsburg Railway, shot himself through the Head this afternoon, while the train was entering the Cleveland depot. He left a note stating that "whisky and friends" was the cause of the deed.

Senator SUMNER is to deliver his great speech on the question of " Caste" at Plymouth Church. Brooklyn, next Thursday evening, and on Friday evening he will repeat it at Steinway Ball in this City. These are the only occasions on which the speech will be made in these cities, and without doubt the orator will have crowded houses.

ANDREW J. CLARK was arrested yesterday on a charge made by Mme. HERMINE GONZALES, No. 10 Union-square, that on the 10th of January last, CLARK came to her pretending that the could by for her the house No. 186 Fourth-street, for $14,000 by paying $3,000, and that $500 were required to bind the contract.

On the evening of Monday, the 22d inst., WILLIAM MORRIS, a guest of the Fifth-avenue Hotel, going out for a stroll with six $100 bills in his pocket, met a gaudily-dressed woman of enticing appearance in Broadway, whom he accompanied to a house in Fourth-avenue, between Ninth and Tenth streets, and on coming out discovered that he had been robbed of every dollar.

Prince LOUIS DE BOURBON, whose romantic marriage at the Jefferson Market Police Court some time age excited such attention and so much flutter in the fashionable circles of this City, is again here with his fair Cuban bride, He has been traveling quietly and unostentatiously through various parts of the United States, and purposes remaining here during the Winter.

Mississippi and Texas, the only two states now "out in the cold," hold their elections today to decide whether they will come into the brotherhood of the Union once more. Compared with this question, the fortunes of the local candidates are less important.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Within the past few days I have seen several letters in your paper concerning the practical working of the present system of discipline in Columbia College. If I mistake not these letters have all been written by Alumni.

The good ship Scottish Bride, two months out from Bordeaux, which arrived at this port Sunday, was freighted with the story of a large marine monster, which the Captain, as there is no duty on such merchandise, was enabled to unfold without delay, and made manifest (without the assistance of the Custom House officials) to a wondering reporter yesterday, as followeth:

Mr. ADAMS should write another chapter on Erie. If our Judges continue the present contest as they have begun it, they will furnish material for his use, of a more interesting character than any hitherto available.

A large meeting of public school teachers and citizens was held in Grammar School No. 50, in Twentieth-street, yesterday afternoon, to give public expression to the loss which the public schools and the community have sustained in the death of SAMUEL W. SETON, late Superintendent of Public Schools, a biographical notice of whom has already appeared in the TIMES.

General DUGAN, the Conservative candidate for Congress in the Third "District of Mississippi, has withdrawn in favor of Hon. S. B. STEERS of Columbus. There was much opposition to DUGAN as a Conservative candidate.
The iron-clad Roanoke, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, is being thoroughly overhauled and its machinery put in order, so as to be ready for service at very short notice.
District-Attorney PIERREPONT has not as yet been informed by the Washington authorities what action will be taken by the National Government on the Cuban complaints against the gunboats.

The removal of the wreck of the steamer Scotland from one of the channels in the Lower Bay, is about accomplished. The work was undertaken by the Neptune Submarine Company several months ago on a contract to clear away the hulk by sections, one half of which was removed to the required depth by the middle of Summer.

Mr. PETER B. SWENEY is the acknowledged Chief of the Tammany Democracy. He is supposed to know, if any recognized loader does, what the partly mean by their opposition to the Grant administration of the Government, and what their future issues are to be before the people.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29.-In the General Synod of the Reformed Church, to-day, theCommittee on Minutes of the District Synods continued their reports. Various items were referred to special Committees. The presence of Rev. Dr. STORK, the Commissioner from the Lutheran General Synod, was announced.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--A special dispatch from St. Paul says a letter from Pembina received on Saturday night states that the insurgents are arranging to hold a council of representatives from the different districts,

These two champions, to whom will, without doubt, be awarded the prizes in the Brooklyn Chess Club Tournament, played their second game on Saturday evening. Mr. DELMAR, who was successful in the, first game, had to succumb in the present one, but not without a gallant contest.

It has long been a matter of surprise to the general public and of humiliation to Masons, in New-York, that while their Order in other cities has had its headquarters at Halls which have reflected credit upon the liberality and dignity of its members, and added architectural beauty to the cities themselves, the Metropolis of the country,...

At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad, held in this city a few days ago, a resolution was adopted that no officer or employe of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad shall have or hold any interest in any other railroad, express company, transporation company, manufactory, coal mine,
The following particulars of the serious earthquake at Manila, alluded to in our telegrams, were forwarded by a correspondent, and appeared in an extra of the Hong Kong Daily Press of Oct. 14:

One of the most daring and successful bank robberies over committed in this section of country, was prpetrated in this village this morning at about 3 o'clock, on the National Bank of Port Jervis, by which over $50,000 in currenoy, bonds and securities belonging to the bank, and individuals who had placed their bonds in the bank for safe keeping, was stolon, the burglars successfully making their escape.
West Hoboken was yesterday morning the scene of a melancho?? suicide.

Considerable discussion is now being had among the members of the Metropolitan Police Mutual Aid Association, in consequence of an appeal recently made for a subscription for the pecuniary benefit of their President and Secretary, Messr. W. H. LEFFERTS and HENRY WHEELER.

ALBERT D. RICHARDSON was married at the Astor House, yesterday afternoon, to Mrs. MCFARLAND or Miss SAGE--which she resumed since her divorce. A few of his personal friends among whom were HORACE GREELEY, Mr. FROTHINGHAM and others, witnessed the ceremony, which was performed by Revs. H. W. BEECHER and O. B. FRONTHINGHAM.
To-day seems the time. in the affairs ofan Isthamian Canal, "which, taken at its flood," may lead on to the increased fortune of the American people.

CHAPMAN.--At Flushing, on Friday, Nov. 26 1869, MARY H., only child of Wm. H. and A. E. Chapman, aged 2 years, 11 months and 9 days. CONNOR.--On Sunday, Nov. 28 Ratter a lingering illness, MARY, reliet of Thomas Connor, aged 54 years. The relatives adn friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 476 Lexington-av., on Wednesday morning, at 9 1/2 o'clock.

Hon. THOMAS B. BRYAN, who has been awarded the certificate of election as delegate from Du Page County to the Illinois Consitutional Convention, has refused to accept it, saying his opponent was fairly elected, and that the informalities which led to the rejection of a number of votes for that gentleman do not alter the fact that he was really the choice of a majority of the people.

The remains of an unknown man, aged 35 years, were found yesterday in the East River near the foot of Errome-street. The skull was crushed, but it could not be ascertained whether the injury had been inflicted before death or after. Coroner FLYNN ordered a post-mortem examination to determine that point, and the body was sent to the Morgu.

Preparations for the execution of DAVID BURKE. convicted at the last term of the Queens County Court, Oyer and Terminer, of the murder of THOMAS KANE, on the night of the great oil fire at Hunter's Point, Oct. 25, 1868, and sentenced to be hung on the 10th of December, are progressing at the County Jail, North Hempstead.

JOHN DORSEY, of Williamsburg, recently convicted at Northampton of wife-murder, was yesterday sentenced to imprisonment for life. BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 30.-Captain MCLELLAN, of the brig George Burnham. at Holmes' Hole, committed suicide yesterday morning in the cabin of his vessel, by shooting himself. No cause is assigned for the act.

Nov. 30-- In steamship Silesia, for Hamburg.--MRs. Chas. H. Wilmerdings and family, John R. Wilmerdings, Mrs. Harriet Rues, R. J. Lang, lady, infant and nurse, Miss Emma Ware, R. C. Dixly and lady, J. C. Burrage and wife, Misses Helen, Emma Ruth and Martain Burrage, W, H. Glenney, Jr., Mrs. Stetson Miss Wellington, H. Schoonmaker, C.A. Shourds and lady, H Critterndren, Mrs. Edw. H Abbot.

The Albany and Susquehanna Railroad case was further postponed till to--morrow on the urgent appeal of the counsel for Messrs. GOULD and FISK, Judge BARNARD telegraphed to Judge SMITH requesting a postponement, stating that DAVID DUDLEY FIELD was engaged before him in the Vanderbilt suit, and that one suit or the other must be postponed.

Governor BROWNLOW is out in a published call upon Jos, A. MABRAY, the present publisher and proprietor of the Whig, a Conservative organ, to run as candidate for the Constitutional Convention, the avowed object of which is the removal of the entire Republican Judiciary and the amendment of the Constitution on a Democratic basis.

Rev. Dr. PRICE, of Wales, preached his last sermon, before his departure to Europe, in the Laight-street Baptist Church, last evening. The Doctor's mission to this country was as a delegate from the Baptist Churches of England to solicit aid for the Spread of the Gospel in Ireland, and in which mission he was successful to a very flattering degree.

The Evening Post sensibly talks of "revenue reform in the West," and truthfully chronteles the progress which the demand for a revision of the tariff on the revenue principle as distinguished from the "protection," which signifies monopoly, is making in that section.

The following points were made yesterday by Mr. W. M. RAMSEY, in his argument before the Superior Court for the plaintiff, in the matter of enjoining the School Board from expelling the Bible from the schools. To show themselves entitled to the relief prayed for, the plaintiffs must establish two proposttions: first. that religious instruction in the con:

The grounds of the new Post Office have ceased to present the busy scene which has attracted the notice of every passer-by since the work commenced. Unluckily, for manypoor laborers at least, Uncle Ssm's appropriation for the building has nearly given out, and the working force has consequently been greatly reduced within a few days.

Superintendent KENNEDY yesterday issued the following order: OFFICE OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF METRO POLITAN POLICE, NO. 300 MULBERRY STREET, NEW--YORK, Dec. 1, 1869. To Captain of Police: GENERAL ORDER, No. 591.-- You will, on Tuesday, Dec. 7, order the whole of your command on duty at sunrise, except those detailed by the Superintendent for that day.

Yesterday Mr. THOMAS W. MCELRATH, late Appraiser of the Port of New-York, formally turned over the Appraiser's Department to his successor, General GEORGE W. PALMER. About 3 P. M., the officers, clerks and other employes of the Department assembled in one of the cargo-examining rooms of the United States Public Stores, on Greenwich-street, to witness the ceremony.

The following is a complete resume of the operations of the Sinking Gund since it was first instituted: Between the 11th of May and the 25th of November there was paid for United States six per cent. bonds, on account of the Sinking Fund and for the fund held subject to order of Congress, interest and premium paid thereon, $89,282,270 13.

The following letters were sent from this City, yesterday, to Governor GEARY, of Pennsylvania: NEW-YORK, Nov. 30, 1869. His Excellency John W. Geary, Governor of the State of Pennsylvania: MY DEAR SIR: I commend to your most earnest consideration the inclosed letter from Professors DOREMUS and HORSFORD in relation to the testimony which is said to have warranted the conviction of Dr. SCHOEPPE for the crime of muder.

EDWARD SCHAUM, the alleged murderer of the CORNELIUS STAHL, who, it will be remembered, was stabbed at Mr. AESSE'S house, No. 32 Bowery-street, Newark, N. J., on Sunday morning last, at 1 o'clock, was arrested yesterday afternoon, at 3:30, by EDWARD BROCKLEHURST, of the Newark detective force, at Reddy the Blacksmith's in Chatham-square.
About one hundred ex-Union soldiers, the victims of HERMAN'S swindling scheme, have commenced proceedings before the Court of Claims, at Washington, for the recovery of their bounty money.

WILLIAM H. FURNESS, aged 45, a native of BOSTON, committed suicide yesterday at GAYER's restaurant. No. 736 Broadway, by swallowing morphine. He came to this City in August last, and on talking a room at the restaurant stated that he was partner in a liquor brokerage firm down town.

There is nothing either now or surprising in the discovery that Judge BARNARD is not peculiarly sensitive to public opinion. It is quite possible that he moves in a little world of his own, where an independent standard of morals has been conveniently invented, and where he is probably regarded as one of the brightest ornaments that over adorned the Judicial Bench.

The sitting as well as the standing capacity of the large hall in the new buildings of the Yound Men's Christian Association was well tested by the large and brilliant audience assembled there last evening. The occasion of this gathering was the grand concert given to celebrate the formal opening of their hall to the public.

Yesterday, on motion of District-Attorney PIERREPONT, HARLOW E. GILL was held by United States Commissioner SHIELDS in his own recognizance to a wait the action of the Grand Jury. The same disposition was made of several similar cases.

Yesterday morning a man giving the name of CHARLES HART, a well-known character, entered the jewelry store of BROWN SPAULDING, at No. 570 Broadway, and requested permission to look at some gods. One of the clerks, Mr. GEORGE H. BEHAN, exhibited several articles, and finally had his suspicions aroused by the singular conduct of HART.

In the Supreme Judicial Court, to-dau, a decision was given in the case of THOMAS KENSHAW vs. ALBERT H. KELSEY in favor of the plaintiff. This was an action for rent of a plantation in Mississippi, leased during the war, by a citizen of Mississippi to a citizen of Massachusetts, and for corn used on the plantation. The defendant had begun to cultivate a crop when he was driven off by the guerrillas.

This case was again called on yesterday at the opening of the Supreme Court, General Term, before Judge BARNARD. The room was filled with an unusually largo audience, anxious to hear farther expected developments, but to the surprise of all tile case came to a very sudden, unexpected termination for the time boeing.

JESSE T. REYNOLDS, a lawyer and claim agent of Watertown, Jefferson County, was arrested to-day and brought before United States Commissioner FROTHINGHAM, of this city charged with forging pension papers. In one case, it is charged he had drawn for two years the pension of a deceased person.

It seems that the business of forging naturalization papers is still kept up in this City, notwithstanding the lack of any particular occasion just now for manufacturing votes. Probably the Democratic politicians are anxious to "keep their hand in," as the saying is, against the time when their services will be more especially needed by the "Ring."

General WILSON said that the friends of DAVIS strenuously denied that he was disguised as a woman, and he therefore detailed the proofs with considerable minuteness. Lieutenant DICKINSON states that DAVIS had a black mantle wrapped around his head, through which could be seen the locks of his hair.

LONDON, Nov. 30--The Times, referring to the possible cession of San Domingo to the United States says: " From the present aspect of affairs we should be disposed to expect the completion of a treaty to that effect. Such a bargain would be beneficial not only to the parties concerned, but to Europe and the world. The Americans stand to lose but little, while they might gain a great deal.

A movement was set on foot some seventeen years ago, by prominent members of the Methodist Episcopal Church, for the establishment of a Metropolitan Church in Washington. The church was built at a cost of $200,000, of which sum $140,000 have been already raised by subscription,

For this season of the year yesterday was really a surprising day. At the Salesroom a large number of persons assembled, and of a very excellent class. The building was spirited, the prices obtained very good, and there was a general appearance of interest which was pleasing and encouraging to the auctioneers, and argues well for the coming season.

In the case of WILLIAM HEATH and JAMES M. ELLIS vs. JOHN F. UNDERHILL, President, and others, officers and members of the Arbitration Committee of the New-York Gold Exchange, argument was yesterday had before Judge LOEW, in the Court of Common Pleas, on an order to show cause why the injunction herebefore issued against the defendants should not be continued in force.

PARIS, Nov. 30--In the Corps Legislatif to-day the Opposition submitted interpellations on the prorogation of the Chambers last September, on the action of the authorities in the Aubin and Ricamerie affairs, and in the troubles of last June in Paris. Deputy RASPAIL submitted an interpellation on the assassination of citizens, and demanded the impeachment of the Ministers.

The National Board of Trade opens its session this morning in Richmond,-and, not less from the high character of its members, and the moral significance of its place of meeting, than from theo variety and value of the topics it is to discuss, its proceedings will have an importance hardly equaled by those of any similar gathering during the last ten years.

The total loss by the fire in Topeka, Kansas, on Sunday night, was $75,000. The French steamship Pereire, from Havre Nov. 10, and Brest Nov. 20, and the Cuuard steamship Scotia, from Liverpool Nov. 20, and Queenstown Nov. 21, both reached this port yesterday. The latest news at hand by these vessels is later by two days than was received Saturday by the City of Brussels.

The rumor that the Prince DE LA TOUR D'AUVERONE, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, has resigned, is again in circulation in Paris. The recent speech of the Emperor of the French is regarded by the London Morning Telegraph as liberal in promise and in tone.

There can be no doubt that the staus of Georgia will be--as our Washington correspondent has intimated--"one of the first matters to receive the attention of Congress." Nor is there much room for doubt as to the result.

The Christian Convention of Passaic County, called with a view to the system atization of Christian work among all classes of people, held its first session last evening in the First Baptist Church, in Paterson. The body of the church was well filled with an assemblage which included representatives from nearly every Protestant congregation in the country.

The adjourned examination in the case of Dr. AUGUST WEDEKIND, accused of levying black mail on Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, was resumed yesterday by Justice HOGAN, at the Tombs. The room devoted to examination was crowded by those interested in the proceedings, which proved quite as interesting as those on previous days.

The great storm is over and we have mild weather again. The marine losses along the lakes have been heavy--much larger than during any storm we have had for years. A heavy body of snow fell just north of us, and so drifted as to cover up the fences. Here there was about six inches. The western part of this State and Iowa have a covering of from twelve to eighteen inches on a level.

At the regular meeting of the Fire Commissioners yesterday. Mr. MEYERS, of the Special Committee to meet with the Mayor and Comptroller, reported having done so, and that those officers coincided with the action taken by the Board of Estimate of the Fire Department.

Yesterday was the second day of the great Supreme Court sale of the Lorillard estate, made at Fordham Park, N. Y., by Messrs. A. J. BLEECKER, SON Co. The day was much more favorable than the previous one, a little cool and blustery, but dry and clear. The attendance was excellent, not quite so large as on Tuesday, but of the same class of earnest, desirable persons.

The Legislature of Some Carolina met day before yesterday, and are new pretty fairly organized. The general complexion, both as to race and politics, is very nearly the same that it was when the body adjourned, after a four month's session. late last March.

According to recent statistics, the United States still continue, by the remittance of bonds, to pay for an excess of importations from Europe at the rate of many millions sterling per annum. The principal financial writers of New-York and Philadelphia from time to time urge their readers to consider how long this is to go on.

All day yesterday Mr. RICHARDSON'S condition appeared to be hopeless, and he was very much exhausted. Seeing this one of his physicians administered a little brandy, which stayed on his stomach for nearly as hour. It revived him somewhat, and another dose was given him.

Rear-Admiral ROWAN, commanding the Asiatic Squadron, writes to the Navy Department from Yokohama, Oct. 2, giving an account of the severe crippling of the United States steamer Idaho in a typhoon on her way to Hong Kong on the morning of the 20th September.

The will of the late JOHN W. FARMER, who was pretty generally known to the public in connection with the souphonses that he established for the benefit of the poor, has been offered for probate, and a contestant has appeared in the person of the special guardian of the children of Mr. FARMER, who, it seems, were disinherited by the will.

AVERELL.--Suddenly, at Greenpoint, on Tuesday, Nov. 30, MARGARET A. AVERELL, wife of Thomas J. Averell, and daughter of the late Robert Dodge, in the 34th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence in Union-av., near Meserole, Greenpoint, on Friday, at 1 P. M. The remains will be taken to Cypress Hills Cemetery for interment.

In the House, to-day, a colored man was elected Engressing Clerk. The Democrats voted for him against a white man. A large number of bills were reported from committees. MESSNER has had little hope of any other result and has known nothing of the efforts made to save his life. He will not, therefore, be disappointed.
