BRADLEY, No. 31 South Ninth-street, last evening, for the purpose of perfecting the ?? of the association of citizens for the prevention and punishment of frauds at elec??, Judge THOMPSON presiding. ding.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday afternoon, Mr. A. A. LOW announced that the Executive Committee reported back the bill with respect to the appointment of a commission by the President to take charge of harbor encroachments, and recommended its reference to a special committee to report on the expediency of its passage.

The somewhat protracted trial of the breach of promise case wherein LUCY ODELL was plaintiff and ANDREW J. ITSELL was defendant, was concluded in the Circuit Court on Monday, the jury bringing in a verdict in favor of the plaintiff for $800 damages.

The Board of Health notified Coroner FLYNN, yesterday, that Mrs. LAURA A. KEUGER had died at No. 375 Fourth-avenue from the effects of chloroform. An inquest was accordingly held over the remains, and the following evidence elicited:

According to the regular weekly statement published to-day, the amount of bullion on hand in the Bank of France has decreased 1,300,000 francs since last Thursday. PARIS, Dec. 2--8 P. M.--Up to this hour the city has been perfectly tranquil. No political or popular demonstrations whatever have been made.

Captain ERMATINGER, of Montreal, has been summoned here to undertake a special message to Red River to endeavor to conciliate the half-breeds. The Indian question is attracting much attention. A tribe between Fort William and Red River is reported unfriendly.

SALNAVE seems to be preparing for the worst. He is concentrating his forces and putting up cannon whenever there is an available place in the city, in defence of himself. The palace is surrounded with cannon, also; and it is said it is SALNAVE'S intention to pull down the buildings and houses in the neighborhood of the palace the better to protect his position.

It is believed that the arguments in the case of the thirty gunboats, which will be made before Judge BLATCHFORD to-morrow, are likely to result in their release. The motion for their discharge will be made by Messrs. STOUGHTON CRAIG, counsel for the claimants, but will be contested by District-Attorney PIERREPONT.

To say that there was a large gathering present at the dedication of the new building of the Young Men's Christian Association last evening, would be superfluous. The large hall and every room adjoining was crowded almost to suffocation. The main features of the building have already been published in the TIMES.

WILLIAM DOUGHERTY, charged with manufacturing and selling champague at No. 59 Division-street, without paying the special Government tax, was arrested by Deputy Marshal CROWLEY, yesterday afternoon, while in the act of applying for a registered letter at the Post Office.

The following statement, issued by General WALKER, of the Burean of Statisties, shows the aggregate value of imports into each customs district of the United States during the fiseal year ended June 30, 1869:

The vote, as far as heard from, gives the following majorities for ALCORN: Wilkinson County, 2,000; Noxubee, 2,751; Jefferson, 1,513; Yazoo, 2,000; Marion, 2,000; Adams, 2,475; Warren, 3,763; Copiah, 366; Claiborne, 1,650; Marshall, 600; Hinds, 1,500; Lowndes, 3,500; Lauderdale, 572; Clarke, 400--again in thirteen counties of more than 13,000 over last year's Radical vote.

The Superintendent of Buildings' report to the Board of Fire Underwriters shows that during November thirty-two buildings, reported as unsafe previous to that date, have been made safe, and that thirty buildings, reported as unsafe before that date, have still to be repaired or taken down.

A singular attempt to commit suicide occurred last evening, between 5 and 6 o'clock, upon the North River. ROBERT LUNON, a newly-arrived emigrant, sprang into the water from the ferry boat Morristown, just after she had left her slip at the foot of Barclay-street, in this City.

ARTHUR.--On Thursday, Dec. 2, EDWARD H. ARTHUR, President of the Union National Bank, in his 64th year. Funeral services on Sunday next, at Calvary Church, at 1 o'clock P. M. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend without further notice. AVERELL.--Suddenly, at Greenpoint, on Tuesday, Nov. 30, MARGARET A. AVERELL, wife of Thomas J. Averell, and daughter of the late Robert Dodge, in the 34th year of her age.

BEACH--ANDREWS.--At Westport Conn., on Tuesday, Nov. 30, by Rev. J. Eaton Smith, assisted by Rev. Dr. Short, Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, of New-York to CAROLINE B. ANDREWS, of Newark, N. J., on Wednesday, Dec. 1, 1869, by Rev. J. S. B. Hodgez, D. D., at the residence of the bride's parents, JOHN.,. BOCKEK, Jr., of Brooklyn, N. Y., to MATTIE L., eldest daughter of Erastus W. Rolf.

Hon. B. F. HOPKINS, Congressman from Wisconsin, who has been seriously III for some time past, but who had become convescent last week, had a relapse Monday last, with a partial stroke of paralysis, completely prostrating him. There is but little hope of his recovery.

The stockholders of the James Mill, at Newburyport, have authorized the Directors to sell the machinery and real estate whenever they deem it best. The United States steamer Tallapoosa sailed to-day for New-York.

DEC. 2--In steamship Holsatia, from Hamburg,--F. J. Hotop, wife, 2 children and servant, G. Sessebirg, Caroline Reimers, Doris Kione, H. Leewenberg, Mrs. McGilvery and 2 children, R. Wagner, John Benkendorff, L. H. Hinek, Carl Richter, Augusta Bombard and 2 children, Franz Heisterberg, Geo.

The question is frequently asked, "What is being done about the East River Bridge" There is no secret about the fact that the Executive Committee of the Company have lost no time in getting to work on the construction of the caisson for the Brooklyn side of the river, after they were authorized by the directors.

A fire broke out at a late hour last night in the Commercial Eievator, owned by MERRIAM CO., and partially destroyed the machinery and contents. The building contained between fifty and sixty thousand bushels of grain, a large portion of which was damaged by water and smoke.

The interest in the Bible question before the Supreme Court does not abate. Citizens throng the Court Room, and the floor and galleries are crowded. Judge MATTHEWS, for the defence, began his argument yesterday, and at the noon recess to-day he had spoken four hours.

The advocates of immediate resumption overlook one obstacle, which may well be pronounced insurmountable. There are, undoubtedly, valid reasons against the adoption of the measure they recommend, arising out of the present condition of trade and industry, and the tendency of any marked disturbance of values to produce widespread embarrassment and ruin.

Three and a half miles of the snow sheds of the Union Paclfle Raliroad were completed this week, and the Company expeet to finish seven miles by the ist of February, eovering all the deep euts, thus placing the road out of all danger of interruption from drifting sbow.

The work on the great railroad bridge over the Ohio is so far advanced that the engineers are confident on being able to open it for the passage of regular trains by Dec. 15. Construction trains, however, will be able to pass several days sooner. The 400 feet span now rests on its permanent bearings, and is in every respect satisfactory to its engineers.

This exhibition, though only the second of the Society, is a most admirable one. The fish ponds are arranged and prove a most charming addition to the show. J. H. STACK, of Bloomsburg, N. J., exhibits in this line. He has brought specimens of trout of different ages and development.

The time of the Senate was consumed in discussing a bill to give negroes equal privileges on railroads, Mr. WORTHY, Democrat, advocated an amendment to the bill providing that the common carriers be forced to provide equally comfortable, but separate apartments,

Very soon after Congress meets, it will be called upon to take into consideration the popular grievance in regard to coal. New-England, New-York and New-Jersey are at issue with a few mining and railroad corporations who, by keeping the market at an exorbitant rate, are able to obstruct industries and to add another to add another to the many ills which to poor have to bear.

The Second course of scientific lectures before the American Institute, will be held in the great hall of the Cooper Union, commencing on Friday, Dec. 17. 1869, and continuing each Friday until Jan. 28, 1870. The lecturers are President WHITE, of Cornell University; Professor J. L. MORSE, of Salem, Mass.

A meeting for forming a general co-operative society, and for creating a mechanics' institute in this City. was held at the Steuben House last night, Mr. R. BLISSERT presiding . A circular drawn by a committee, and inviting the workmen of this City to join in the enterprise, was read and recommitted.

Professor CLARK, of Scenery Hill, Washington County, Penn, sent the paragraph to Professor AGASSIZ, and received the following reply:

We hope we shall not be suspected of uttering an ungenerous taunt when we say that South Carolina is not exactly in a position to talk about "pledging its last dollar and man to the Government" in case of war.

The funeral of the late ISSAC C. PRAY, of this City, the leading characteristics of whose life were presented in the TIMES a few days ago, took place yesterday afternoon from St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, in East Eighteenth-street.

The following are the projected buildings, plans for which have been approved, for the week ending Dec 2 1867: BROWN AND OTHER STONE FRONTS. Four first-class dwellings, Ohio stone fronts, south side Forty-?? and north side Forty - Fourth-?? west of seventh-avenue,

The Philadelphia Post publishes the subjoined copies of letters received by the committee having to charge the arrangements for a mass meeting in that city in favor of free Cuba: FROM SENATOR ROSCOE CONKLING. UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 27, 1869.

On Monday evening last there glided into the harbor and anchored quietly one of the most formidable from-clad ships of war afloat, merely on a trial trip. The name of this vessel is the Miantonomoh, and it is needless to say that she is manned by American sailors. She lies at anchor off the Battery.

The latest advices from our Havana correspondent confirm the position we have already been compelled to take regarding the years may exist situation of affairs in Cuba. The so-called "war" is carried on with the torch, not the rifle, and the whole insurrection drags on in a line of policy at once aimless and idle.

An enthusiastic mans meeting of the citizens of the Eighth Judicial District. in favor of the election of THOMAS A. LEDWITH as Police Justice, was held last evening at Kellor's Sixteeth Ward Hall, No. 263 West Seventeenth-street.

Tile Alumni of Dartmouth College residing in this City and vicinity, who number between one and two hundred, and who have organized themselves into a society called the "Dartmouth College Association of the City of New-York," celebrated their sixth anniversary by a dinner at DELMONICO's last evening.

The seventh regular lecture of the Parker Fraternity course was delivered in Music Hall last evening, by WENDELL PHILLIPS, on "What we ask of Congress." Mr. PHILLIP'S lecture was substantially as follows: LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: I am to speak to you to-night on "What we would ask of Congress."

The case arising out of the building of the Onondlaga, of which we give a report this morning, involved one interesting question and suggested another still more so. It seems that her builders contracted with the Government first to build simply an iron-plated vessel, and were afterward directed by the Secretary of War to put over the iron plates a wooden covering and an outside thinner iron plating.

This morning at 7 o'clock there was a fire-damp explosion at the Empire Mine, at Wilkesbarre. When work was suspended last night those in charge neglected to close the doors opening into the slope, and fire-damp accumulated where least expected, Five men were injured.

There is published this morning a list of the state central committee of the walker party, just organized. In it are the names of gentlemen heretofore Whigs, Republicans and Democrats, including Hon. A. H. H. Stuart, of staunton; Franklin Stearns, Judge H. H. Marshall, Charles J. Carrington,

A young man named BENJAMIN SMITH, residing in Newark, appeared before Justice HILDEBRAND, of the city, yesterday, and charged a window named JENNIE BROWN, with having robbed him of $38. On Tuesday evening BROWN accompanied the accused to an unoceapied house in Newark, and during his stay was relieved by her, as he alleges, of the amount stated.

In part influenced by the gross frauds perpetrated in New-York City and Brooklyn, the cry was raised last Winter by certain interior journels, "Divide the State and let the river counties set up for themselves and work out their own salvation." The recent election experience has renewed the agitation which had subsided for a time.

A few nights ago a broker's office, on Montgomery street, was robbed of $5,700 in gold. It was ascertained that the robbery was committed by parties from Chicago, brought here for the purpose, and one of whom was arrested while on his way to the cars with his share of the plunder.

A numerous and highly intellectual audience was present at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, drawn thither to listen to a discourse on "Caste," the orator of the occasion being Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, United States Senator from Massachusetts. A very large proportion of the audience was made up of ladies.

General T. B. HAMILTON has been appointed to the office of Assistant Appraiser of the First Division, rendered vacant by the promotion of General PALMER. General HAMILTON is a young man, and served with distinction in the Union army during the late war.

The shooting of Mr. ALBERT D. RICHARDSON by JAMES McFARLAND, on the 25th ult., in the Tribune counting room, culminated yesterday morning in the death of the wounded man. The precarious condition of Mr. RICHARDSON during the last two or three days of his life prepared the public mind for his death, as the physicians had already given up all hopes of his recovery.

We are in receipt of the following letter from an old friend in Southern Utah. It doubtless is conclusive as to the fate of the three missing men of the Powell party. We hope to learn more particulars before long: ST. GEORGE, Utah, Nov. 11.

The great Supreme Court sale of the Lorillard estate closed yesterday. The attendance was, as on the previous days, very good; there was no falling off in interest or attention; the bidding continued as prompt as at first, and the prices obtained were quite as satisfactory. The sale amounted to more than any other one made this season;

The Board of Trade reassembled this morning. The Committee appointed to invite Governor WALKER to attend the session of the Board found the Governor just leaving the city, but were informed that he would visit the Board on his return, in a few days. He tendered his thanks for the courtesy extended him.

There are twenty candidates for chess honors in this tourney. The successful players thus far are Messrs. B. LISSNER, J. LISSNER, J. MASON and VON FRANKEN BERG. Many amateurs of chess would have participated in the proceedings but for the fact that three other tournaments are in progress, namely, the Brooklyn Club, the New-York Club, and the Williamsburg Club tournaments.

[OFFICIAL.] WEDNESDAY, Dec. 1, 1869--2 o' Clock P. M. The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esquire, President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Miller, Cushman, Connor, Hardy, Repper, Coulter, McGrath-Farley, McQuade--14.

The fifty-sixth anniversary of this institution was held in the chapel of the Asylum building in Twentieth-street yesterday afternoon. A large number of the directors and patrons of the Asylum were present. There was also present one of the original founders of the institution. Mrs. GOLDSMITH, formerly Miss LEGGETT, now 90 years of age.

The attention of the War Department has been fately attracted to the fact that the Utah Mormons have been engaged for some time in cellerting a formidable camp in the vicinity of Salt Lake City, numbering about fifteen thousand men. It is said that this movement was undertaken for the purpose of being prepared to resist the entrenchment of any legislative acts which may be made against polygamy at the approaching session of Congress.

In the Superior Court, Special Term, before Judge FITHIAN, yesterday, in the suit of WILLIAM B. LANCTON vs. ALBERT SPEYERS, a motion was made to vacate the attachment heretofore issued against the property of the defenderty with intent to defraud his creditors.

There is never any knowing how much to believe of reports of coming insurrections in Ireland. A slight outbreak of local discontent is sometimes magnified into a national rising, and vague rumors of the country-side are caught up and talked about as if they were events, not words.

A clue has been discovered to the whereabouts of SAMUEL T. BLATCIIFORD, the fugitive Ex-Deputy Collector, and of some of his prominent confederates in the drawback frauds, which, if cautiously and expeditiously followed up, is likely to eventuate in their arrest.

An additional Postal Convention has just been concluded by Postmaster-General CRESWELL with the General Post Office Department of Great Britain, establishing on and after the 1st of January next, a reduced rate of letter postage of six cents between the United States and the United Kingdom.

During my professional attendance on Mr. PEABODY, for the last four weeks, I have had various short but interesting conversations with him on general subjects, and to-day a more lengthy one. I note down some of his remarks for future reference:

Mrs. "ABBY SAGE" McFARLAND resided in this city more than a year. Upon her arrival, she presented letters of introduction to Hon. ALBERT G. PORTER, of the distinguised law firm of HARRISON, FISHBACK PORIER, and engaged his services to procure a divorce from McFARFARLAND, her husband.

The Erie, the New-York Central, and the Pennsylvania Central Railway Companies have agreed upon a tariff of rates for the carrying of freight during the coming Winter months, subject to difference in classification by Western roads.

It is unnecessary to dwell upon the deplorable state into which our shipping trade has sunk. We are all compelled to acknowledge that a traffic which is of the most honorable and profitable kind to any nation engaged in it, has with us dwindled away until it scarcely corresponds with the position of a fourth-rate Power.

The difficulty arising out of the landing of the French telegraph cable on American shores his, according to a telegram from Paris, been adjusted in an amicable manner. Carlist conspiracies have again been discovered in Spain, a Madrid dispatch says, and several arrests have been made, and measures taken to prevent a fresh outbreak.

On Thursday evening last SAMUEL G. DOUGHTY, a retired merchant, who has boarded for some time at the New-York Hotel, Broadway, was noticed to be in a very nervous and excitable condition. To relieve himself of the nervousness, he has been occasionally in the habit of using morphine, although without any direct medical advice.
The Albany and Susquehanna Railroad suit is progressing slowly. Several witnesses have been examined in relation to the proceedings at the election for directors. held in Albany in September.

St. Johns, Cambridge, Eng., has 377 students. A statue of the Earl of DERRY is to be placed in the Carlton Club at London. Mr. SPURGEON has been suffering from a light attack of smallpox, but is fast recovering.

Yesterday some six hundred packages of tea were forwarded from this city to New-York by railroad, in one consignment. This is sand to be the largest shipment made to one firm since the opening of the railroad.

In the General Synod of the Reformed Church, the subject of the revision of the Hymn Book was deferred until the next meeting. District Synods were authorized to annex the selection of hymns to their respective liturgies. A new District Synod was constituted, consisting of the Westmoreland, Clarion, St. Paul's and West Now-York Classes.

W. H. H. WISE, a messenger for the American Express Company, on the Cleveland and Pittsburg Railroad, shot himself in his own car, between Euclid-street and the Union Passenger Depot, at 2 o'clock P. M., Monday, as the train was approaching Cleveland.

In the Board of Trade, this morning, Mr. MONROE, of Dubuque, had the floor on the unfinished business of yesterday, being the resolution for a double-track railroad from the centre of the source of grain and produce in the West to the Atlantic seaboard. He showed that a double-track road,

Governor BULLOCK'S letter, which we elsewhere print, demonstrates the reasonableness of the position assumed by the Republicans of Georgia, and the moderation and justice of the course now urged upon Congress. The new Constitution of that State, as prepared by a Republican Convention, and ratified by Republican ballots, is remarkable for its liberality.

However difficult it has been for the representative of any Power to open negotiations with the Emperor of China, upon a direct and personal basis, there can e no doubt that the United States have been accorded the preference in this respect. Mr. BURLINGAME'S mission is the first even quasi diplomatic recognition of that nature ever made by the Chinese Court.

The bids on the thirty-two iron columns for the cellar of the new Post Office were opened yesterday noon, and the contract awarded to the Messrs. CORNELL at $3,6033 40. There were fourteen separate bids, the highest of which was something over $8,000. The columns must weight 6,362 pounds each.
Important dispatches from the Home Government in reference to the Northwest are expected to-morrow. The English Cabinet meets only once a week-on Saturdays.

The steamer Colorado sailed for Panama. to-day, with $614,000 in treasure, of which amount $427,000 is for England, $10,000 for France, $144,000 for South America, $17,000 for Central America and $15,000 for Panama.

THE DISCOVERY OF THE GREAT WEST, By FRANCIS PARKMAN. Boston: LITTLE, BROWN Co. The author of this book is already favorably knows to the public for his researches into several hither to introdden fields of American history. The present volume is in reality the third of a series in which the early attempts at colonization by the French and English, or the adventares of discoverers are carefully traced.

The denizens of the Fifth Ward of Brooklyn, while cooking their early breakfasts, yesterday morning, were somewhat astonished at hearing the tread of an army under their windows, and the rather unusual sounds peculiar to the deploying of armed forces.

At Jackson, Ark., last week, H. C. LEWIS, formerly a Deputy United Studies Marshal, was shot and killed by Deputy Sheriff WARD, who was shot and wounded by LEWIS. Whisky was the cause. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--PHILIP FLANNIGAN has been found guilty of murder in the second degree, for killing Colonel SEYBERT in September last. The jury had been out since Wednesday.
By the arrival today of the steamer Continental, from Mexican ports, advices were received from Mazatlan to Nov. 24. Political affairs in Mexico were quiet, and business unusually dull.

Authentic reports that have reached as of Dr. DAVID LIVINGSTONE'S explorations in Africa promise most important results. The long-standing reporach of georgraphers, that they knew less of the grand equatorial continent than the telescope has revealed of the moon, is apparrently wiped off.

ELIZABETH MOTT, a native of this country and 30 years of age, was found dead in her room at No. 100 Allen-street, on Thursday night, under very peculiar circumstances. When found she was lying in bed, and a stab wound in the breast indicated foul play, which was to some extent confirmed from the fact that a large and terrible looking knife lay beside her.

The bill to ratify the lease of the Nashville and Northwestern Railroad by the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad was amended, but no final action was taken.

The facts connected with the recent arrest of church burglars at Hudson City are singular and interesting. A Newark detective some two weeks ago noticed two men entering the city over the turnpike bridge. One of these GOTTLIER MULLER, was known to be a notorious burglar.

A destructive fire occurred this morning, consuming four entire blocks and three-fourths of two other blocks. The fire originated in the clothing establishment of COHEN BROTHERS, at the corner of Strand and Fremont streets.

After months anxious suspense the long looked--for "coal boat rise" has at last come, and the largest shipment ever sent from this city is about to be forward to southern ports, unless the twelve foot rise at Oil City should interfere. Forty--three steamers will start out from Pittsburg, towing barges containing atleast 4,600, 000 bushels of coal, and perhaps 5,000,000 bushels.

A few days ago, as already published in the TIMES, one HERMANN ALBERT, aged about 35 years, was brought before Mr. Justice INGRAHAM, at the Supreme Court Chambers, on a writ of habeas corpus, and his discharge from the Lunatic Asylum on Black well's Island was asked on the ground that he was not a lunatic in any proper sense of that word, ant that his detention there was illegal.
Dispatches from Rome announce that a Pre-Synodal Conference was held yesterday, when a Papal allocution was delivered and oaths were administered to the officers of the Ecumenical Council.

A meeting of the Board of Trade was held to-day, at which a committee of five was appointed to urge action on the subject of a ship canal from Pittsburg to Lake Erie. A committee was also appointed to take measures toward the construction of a railroad via the Connellsville Road to Uniontown,

The election of Aldermen, Assistant Aldermen, Police and Civil Justices and School Trustees for this City, takes place on Tuesday next. The candidates of the different parties have already been published, and those of our readers who continue to take any interest in City politics have had a chance to examine into their qualifications for the positions to which they have been nominated. When I first studied geography, the spot where I now sit was marked on the map of Missouri Territory with a gray peppering of dots and labeled, "Great American Desert." As the years rolled on, I notice each succeeding edition of the atlas reduced the size of the peppered spot, until now, with the Norwegian Maelstrom, the Great American Desert has about reached the vanishing point.

Senator SUMNER delivered his famous lecture on "Caste" last evening at Steinway Hall to a large and intelligent audience. The appearance of the gentleman on the platform was the signal for loud applause. His lecture was substantially the same as that delivered at Brooklyn on Thursday night,

The Appeal's Little Rock special says: "Judge YANCEY, of the Chancery Court, has released all the officials of the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad, who were arrested for contempt for refusing to obey a process, on the ground that the Judge who had issued the injunction had no authority to issue it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your answer to your correspondent N. T. D.'s question as to how she can reach the poor girls whom she wishes to help, you refer her to the Police, to the doctors and to clergymen generally.

The selections for the new Circuit Judgeships have not positively transpired, but the indications are that in the circuits named below the gentlemen mentioned have been determined upon: For the circuits comprising the States of Michigan, Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee, Judge BALLARD, of Louisville, now United States District Judge for the District of Kentucky ;

As I interpret the address and resolutions of the majority of the Convention that appointed you committee.

Among the numerous branches and small local roads leased by the Erie Railway Company under the management of the present Board of officers, is the Newark and Paterson Railroad, a short line--limited as to its capacity and its prospect of profits--running, as its name indicates, from Newark to Paterson.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having read your admirable article in the TINES of the 1st inst., under the heading of "The Georgia Imbroglio," I feel constrained to inflict upon you this letter, for the purpose of expressing, in my own behalf and that of the Republicans of our State, thanks for the correct and forcible presentation of our case to the country.

The establishment of ESHER Co., No. 148 Duane-street, was, on Sept. 13, entered by burglars, who forced an entrance through the roof, and stole about $14,000 worth of silks, The goods were removed to the Sixth-avenue, where they were stored in the cellar of Mr. PALITZ, pastry cook, who supposed they were preserved fruits. The bronze medallion of Commodore VANDERBILT, which was privately exhibited and briefly noticed in the TIMES, on the occasion of Captian DE GROOT's dinner to the Press at the Astor House, is now on public exhibition at the store of F. P. FREEMAN, No. 391 Breadway, where it attracts much attention. As a work of art it has rare excellence and will well repay a close inspection.

On Thursday evening the North German brig Der Fleiss, Captain YULLIE EHRENREICH, with a cargo consisting of 1,531 barrels of naphtha, destined for Bilboa, Spain, anchored off Tompkinsville, S. I., awaiting favorable weather to proceed to sea. The Captalu yesterday morning,

This most interesting exhibition is now in successful operation. Messrs. HAMILTON KIRKHAM exhibit numerous French birds. Their two coops of La Fleches are pre-eminently beautiful. The raven-black plumage of these birds is beautifully set off by the crimson of their bifureated combs. The three coops of Crevecoaeurs are just as admirable both in respect to size and coloring.

A large number of policemen were tried yesterday before Commissioner BOSWORTH, and some of the cases involved matters of public interest. JAMES F. AITKEN, of the Fourteenth Precinct, was arraigned on a charge of neglect of duty while stationed at the Fourth Election District of the Fourteenth Ward, in failing to report to the Police Commissioners that the Inspectors had abandoned their posts.

At the sitting of the Corps Legislatif to-day, HENRI ROCHEFORT rose and demanded that the National Guard be ordered to guard the Hall of the Corps Legislatif in future, for the protection of the members. The demand took the Chamber by surprise, and created an extraordinary sensation.

Just now we seem to be flooded with propositions for new Bureaus in Government. There is hardly a trade or, at all events, a general interest in the country, but wants a Bureau in the Administration. The engineers demand a Bureau, and a pamphlet has just been published "On the Necessity of a Bureau of Mechanics."

The proceedings of this tourney will terminate to-night. The players who have taken a decided lead among the nineteen combatants, of which it is composed, are: F. E. BRENZINGER, who won 27 games, lost 5. E. PELMAR, who won 25 games, lost 6, F. PERKIN, who won 27 games, lost 8, CHADWRK, who won 22 games, lost 9. C. A. GILBERG, who won 23 games, lost 11.

W. breezes and fine weather ; laden with a portion of the cargo of the ship Figlia Allessandra, from Marseilles for New-York, which put into Bermuda in a very crippled condition, being actually lashed together with chain and hawsers. Last night a fire broke out in the stable belonging to the old Monsam House and extended to the adjoining building, which was known as Jenkins' shop, and thence to the Monsam House and Danes' block, which was occupied by N. DANES, grocer; Miss WELLS, milliner; DANES BONNER, lawyers,

St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, located on Sussex, between Washington and Warren streets, in Jersey City, was wholly destroyed by fire at an early hour yesterday morning. When first discovered by a daughter of H. G. VoLKERT, the flames were confined to the first floor of the southeasterly tower of the building, and had the proper means for extinguishing them been at hand, comparatively little damage would have been done. The fire companies,

The Cincinnati, Wilmington and Zanesville Railroad was sold yesterday, under a foreclosure of the mortgage for $1,004,000. The road extends from Morrow to Zanesville, a distance of 131 miles. Included in the sale were sixteen locomotives, sixteen passenger, 171 box and cattle, and seventy-two coal cars; also @200,000, and of real estate.

Tennessee has not yet fully reaped the harvest of political strife which the passions of the war have sown. It was hoped by many that when the right of suffrage was restored to all the citizens entitled thereto, there would be an end of bitterness and strife.

SUPERIOR COURT--GENERAL TERM--DEC. 4. CAUSES ARGUED AT APRIL TERM. Before Chief Justice Barbour and Justices Jones and Freedman. William E. Hoy et al. re. William Reaue; judgment reversed and now trial ordered with costs to the appellant to abide the event. Opinion by Jones, J.; concurring opinion by Fithian, J.; dissenting opinion by Barbour, C. J.

Some time ago we took occasion to chronicle the opening in London of a dining room for the poor on the model of the celebrated Cafe California of Paris. Its establishment originated with an enterprising importer of Australian beef, who, findding that a popular projudice existed against his meat in the ancooked state, resolved to try whether the national palate could not be reached by undertaking the cooking himself.

The first of the popular concerts at the Hall of the Young Men's Christian Association was given yesterday afternoon, Mr. GEORGE W. MORGAN, Mr. J. W. HILL and Mrs. JENNIE KEMP??ON taking part therein. The hall was well killed; about three-fourths of those present being ladles. Judging from the attendance yesterday these concerts are likely to prove a success.

While it is very questionable whether a distinct organization for the defence of prisoners on trial would answer the purpose, or, indeed, would be free from objectionable features, some method of curing present evils in connection with such unfortunates is certainly called for.

A new stage in the Ramsey-Erie suit has been taken. Mr. RAMSEY, through his counsel, Messrs. PECKHAM TREMAINE, of Albany, ask judge MURRAY to again summon before him the Erie delinquents, to show cause, on the 10th of December next, at Delhi, Delaware County, at the Chambers of Justice MURRAY, why the several others of suspension, granted by him, enjoining them from acting as Directors, should not continue and remain in full force.

JOHN SHIELDS, aged about 70 years, committed suicide this evening by cutting his throat with a razor. He had shown symptoms of insanity of late. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--A petition, signed by 20,000 persons, was forwarded to Washington to-night, to be presented to Congress on Monday, asking the recognition of the Cuban rebels as belligerents.

The total vote here foots up 2,175. The count of the canvassers will not be known until to-morrow. REID, a negro, is believed to have been elected Clerk of the District Court. Austin, Williamson and Bell Counties have gone nearly unanimous for HAMILTON and HAYNES.

The want of a homeopathic hospital in this City has been felt for a long time by the believers in that system of treatment, and at last there is promise that the need, will be supplied. As a means of placing the claims of the hospital before the people, and also to obtain funds, a Hospital Inaugural has/been arranged for the 14th inst., at the Union League Club Theatre.

Dr. W. A. HAMMOND, formerly Surgeon General United States Army, delivered an interesting lecture, yesterday afternoon, before the clinique at Bellevue Hospital Medical College, on puerperal mania. This is the first instance in this country where a clinique has been held for the treatment and illustration of the different form of insanity,

At No. 937 Broadway, in room No. 12, of emblematic adornments, the above-named body held, yesterday afternoon, what was supposed would be its final meeting, anticipative of a full fledged Parliament. The apartment occupied by the Woman's Association is the same in daily use by Mr. PACKARD'S anatomy class,

It is much to be regretted that the friends of the late Mr. A. D. RICHARDSON have taken a course which leaves writers on alternative but to discuss the exceedingly painful circumstances connected with his death. Had those friends been well advised, they would have refrained from the attempt to canonize Mr. RICHARDSON,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In reply to the question, "How can ladies hear of poor young girls who need help" a friend suggests that the "New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor" is the best possible agency by means of which to gain such information. This institution divides the City into sections, employing a visitor in each.

The Democratic Convention to nominate delegates to the State Convention met this forenoon. Hon. JOHN PRATT was recommended for the Supreme Bench. After the business of the Convention was transacted, it adjourned to the Opera House, and at 2 o'clock Hon. D. W. VOORHEES was introduced by Colonel JOHN S. WILLIAMS.

At last we have the official statement from the managers of the Second National Bank of the losses by the defalcation of the late cashier. The footing of known losses to the bank shows $177,000, to which must be added so much of $90,000 unauthorized discounts, in which the late cashier was interested, as cannot be collected from the estate of the deceased and from his associates on the discounted paper.

The death of ELIZABETH WOOD, at No. 100 Allen-street, which was considered a mysterious one, was fully investigated yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER, and ascertained to be a case of suicide. It appears that the deceased had been an invalid, and had on several occasions remarked that her life was irksome, as she was exceedingly poor and destitute, and thought that death would be a relief.

General LESCA is sick, and General CARBO is ordered to relieve him of the command of the troops in the Chico Villas District. A Spanish war-steamer arrived from Cadiz yesterday with a battalion of troops; also the family of Captain-General DE RODAS.

The London Globe publishes the following among many things that are not generally known, "Wine becomes 'corked' in the process of decanting, not from contact with the cork while in the bottle; it is the upper portion of the cork where the mouth of the bottle clips it, that decays. If we knew that a certain cork was had,

A short time ago the officers of the Wells-Fargo Express Company opened negotiations for the purchase of the good will of the Pacific Express Company of California, which included a valuable exclusive contract over the Central Pacific Railway. The terms demanded for the good will were $5,000,000 of Wells-Fargo stock at about the middle of November the proposed arrangement was submitted to the stockholders for acceptance, and adopted by a large vote.

Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday, at No. 320 Washington-street, over the remains of WM. THOMAS HYDE, aged 3 years, who came to his death by being scalded on Thursday. He was playing in the room with a wagon, and accidentally stumbled into a pail of hot water that had been carelessly left standing on the floor.

The plans for the new bridge proposed to be constructed over Bushwick Creek, connecting First-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, with Franklin-street, an improvements gently needed, were presented at a meeting of the Aldermen of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, held at the office of Alderman GEO. H FISHER, No. 27 Broadway, on Friday afternoon. The four plans offered were as follows:

General TERRY is confined to his house in Atlanta, Ga., by Illness. One young man in Michigan has accepted a challenge from another to roll a log for a wager of $50. Fifteen thousand acres of coal and mineral land in Grant and Mineral Counties, West Va., have just been sold for $225,000.

The motion in the case of the Spanish gunboats was to have been heard yesterday morning in the United States District Court, Southern District, before Judge BLATCHFORD. The counsel were present on both sides, but Judge PIERREPONT applied to have the motion lie over to Wednesday next, saying that he was ready on behalf of the Government, but,

To-day is the first day this week that the President found himself sufficiently relieved from the press of business to receive visitors; consequently the rush to the White House was very great. The President's time was almost wholly occupied up to 3 o'clock in receiving his callers.

Major-General Woodward, commanding the Second Division, has issued a circular, in which he announces for the information of his command, that in order to obtain an authoritative decision in the matter of "tax exemptions," and to save all expense to the members of the command, he caused a suit to be brought on his own account, as a test case, against the Board of Assessors.

At the session of the National Board of Trade to-day the question of the resumption of specie payments was taken up. Mr. HOSTIE, of Charleston, S. C., did not think that this was the time for specie payment.

The Supreme Court, General Term, bas been adjourned to the 13th inst., at which time there will be a large number of decisions rendered, and a report will be made by the examiners appointed at the November Term to examine students for admission to the Bar. The next regular General Term of this Court will commence on the 1st Monday of January next.
Among the good works which the Board of Health has quietly but energetically pressed forward during the past year, has been the improvement of the homes of the cellar population of this Metropolis.

The mercury to-day indicated 2?? above zero. A snow storm prevails this evening. Dispatches have been received here to-day announcing the condition of the canal as follows: At Amsterdam the ice in the canal is firm; but few boats are there. At Fonda the ice in the canal is two inches thick, with but one boat frozen in.

The Asiaties which G. H. WARNER, President of the Society, exhibits are of many distinct breeds and varieties--dark and light Brahmas, buff, white and partridge Cochins, white and gray Dorkings, Crevecocurs, Houdans, La Fletches, Sultans, Sebright and game bantams. In aquatic birds he exhibits Rouen and Aylesbury ducks and Toulouse geese.

M. GUIZOT, in a letter to a member of the Corps Legislatif, advises the members of support the parliamentary empire. Prince METTERNICH, the Austrian Ambassador, is at Vienna to receive his instructions regarding the questions at issue between Prussia and Austria.

The friends of McFARLAND are taking measures to raise a subscription to defray the legal expenses of his defence, a prominent merchant heading the list. Mr. CHARLES S. SPENCER has been engaged as one of the counsel in the case.

A terrible accident occurred about 6:45 o'clock last evening, at the Giant Powder Works, situated about five miles from the City Hall. The works, of which BANDMANN, NIELSON Co. are the agents, were started over a year since. The grounds, lying between two hills, consist of about an acre of land, around the whole of which was an eight-foot fence.

Oh, sadly fall on hill and lea The shadows of the weary day; And, wafted from the wailing sea, A low long murmur seems to say, To Say: "Shine on, then golden sun; Thine hour will soon be done! Ah! well-a-day!"

Rev. Dr. BANCROFT has been elected rector of Christ Church, Brooklyn, L. I. Andover Theological Seminary has seventy-seven students. Professor THAYER has returned from Europe. Rev. J. B. WAKELY, an English clergyman, is preparing a history of the WESELYS.

A new Declaration of Independence has just been made at a public meeting in San Francisco--a declaration of independence of China. "We pledge ourselves," reads this portentous document, which is now before a Committee for revision, " to a system of nonintercourse with these Chinese coolies," and, moreover, "to use every exertion sanctioned by our laws to eject them from the State."

ZACHARY TAYLOR HOCKLINBERRY, who is to be executed on Tuesday next, at Butler, for the murder of ANNIE McCANDLESS, has made an addition to the confession previously made by ??. This addition embraces ten closely-written usage of note paper, and is in the same rambling style which characterized his first confession.

The disturbance in the saloon of THOMAS DONOHUE, corner of Twenty-third-street and Second-avenue, on Friday afternoon, was yesterday the topic of conversation in all Democratic circles.

The Junction City, Kansas, Union says: "CHAS. BROWN, who has been a captive for three years among the Cheyenne Indians and who has just escaped, states that there are in the hands of that tribe more than twenty white boys and girls, captives;

Apropos of the approaching half-yearly payment of interest by the Savings banks, may not something be said of the desirability of some more liberal system of treatment toward depositors The practice of these banks varies, and some do offer terms to their customers to which little exception can be made.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The new communication with the upper part of the City from the Battery will, it appears, soon be opened. Probably are this the frames of some carriages are already in course of construction. I Would, through your columns, gladly suggest an improvement in their style.

JOHN J. ECKEL died yesterday morning in the Albany Penitentiary, where he was serving out a term of imprisonment for having defrauded the Government by manufacturing whisky illcitly. The remains are to be interred to-morrow in Green-Wood.

This association, recently established for the practice of the game of chess, consists already of twenty-four members, and counts among its members Major WERNICH and the Baron VON FRANRENBERG, both of whom distinguished themselves in the last tournament, which was held at the Europa Chess Rooms. A special meeting of the St. Nicholas Society was held last evening at the hall of the Historical Society, corner of Second-avenue and Eleventh-street, for the purpose of listening to an address by the President, Hon. JAMES W. BEEKMAN.

Mrs. ELEANOR F. BISHOT, whose domestic troubles have recently been made public in a suit brought by her for a diverce from her husband, yesterday appeared before Justices DOWLING and KELLY, in the Court of Special Sessions, charging WILLIAM L. SWETT, a dry goods merchant in Boradway, and a policeman named PATRICK J. BROPHY, with conspiracy.

Le beau saison--when is it not le bean saison for somebody ?--has not departed. It has only intrenched itself behind plate windows and in Summer-tempered rooms. The gay light colors have only been taken in as a gardener takes his geraniums in from frost. Fashion's year only keeps perpetual Spring. This December in costly warerooms He robes spangled with daisies and hedge roses.

Fire Marshal BRACKETT'S report of fires during the month of November has just been presented to the Board of Police. Among other things it notes that in this City there were sixty-eight fires. Of these nine were caused by kerosene, sixteen by carelessness of occupants and employes, one by defective fine, four by overheated stoves, five were unknown, one was of incendiary origin, and the remainder originated from a variety of accidental causes.

About 6:30 last evening an unknown man suddenly dropped dead in the City Hall Park. He was first observed by PETER CONWAY, of No. 653 Water-street, who immediately gave information to the City Hall Police.

The cases of malpractice which have frequently to be recorded, and the loss of life which often occurs from delayed or unskillful treatment of accidents or disease, suggest the question whether surgery and medicine ought not to form some part of popular education.

JAMES HORNER, a Democratic fledgling residing in Ablngdon-square, is a candidate for Alderman in the Ninth Ward, and being anxious to inform the public of the fact, yesterday hired a truck, and , decorating it with a placard bearing his name and aspiration, sent it through the streets.

WILLIAM H. CURTIS, a well-known actor, attached to the Boston state many years, died yesterday, at the age of 60 years. AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 5.--WEBSTER REED, a young unmarried man, was drowned yesterday, while skating at Madison.

The residents of Brooklyn Heights were suddenly aroused about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a rumbling as of thunder, quickly followed by a tremendous crash which appeared to come from toward the river front, and which proved to be the fall of two four-story brick building on Furman-street, foot of Cranberry-street.

Rev. O. B. FROTHINGIIAM, yesterday, referring to the part that he and Mr. BEECHER had taken in the marriage of Mr. RICHARDSON, said be had nothing to say to the newspapers that had abused him, but to his congregation-his friends--an explanation was due. ALBERT D. RICHARD-

ASHTON.--On Saturday, Dec. 4, ARTHUR ASHTON, only child of J. Hubley and Hannah R. Ashton, aged 4 years, 2 months and 4 days. Funeral services at the residence of his aunt, Mrs. Devoo, No. 324 East 15th-st., at 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon, the 6th inst. The remains will be taken to Washington for interment on Tuesday morning, Dec. 7.

Congress meets the country in a time of profound peace. The skies are free from a single cloud. The President has done his duty. It has bee an even, easy Administration, Without ostentation or sensation,--only honest, assiduous work.
M. GUIZOT has written a letter to a member of the French Corps Legislatif on the political affairs of France. He advises, the members to support the parliamentary empire.

We have noticed that a diploma was awarded at the Georgia State Fair to Dr. C. B. LEITNER, of Geneva, for a fine specimen of South American cotton. Dr. LEITNER yesterday left a boll of this cotton with us, and it is really a variety that deserves attention. The boll is much larger than any cotton boll we ever saw before.

The constitutional guarantees, which were suspended some time ago as a measure of public safety, have been restored. MADRID, Dec. 5.--The Carlist Chief POLO has been convicted of treason and sentenced to death. Rumors of a Carlist insurrection continue to circulate.

The week just closed has been, for this canson of the year, remarkably brisk and attractive, and real estate men, who of late have not been the most agreeable companions imaginable, Suddenly gained cheerful and smiling countenances, pleasant to behold.

A quorum of both Houses of Congress will undoubtedly respond to the roil call to-morrow. The arrivals up to Friday were so scattering that it did not seem as though the meeting of Congress was so near, but the arrivals by the trains of last night and those to to-morrow morning will increase the numbers to at least two-thirds of both Houses.

The Central Pacific Railroad has completely rebuilt the snow sheds which were burned near Cisco, and has considerably extended the shedding beyond the aid limits. The aggregate shedding is about thirty-five miles in length, and protests the road through the deep snow belt of the Sierras.

In a recent lecture at the Kentucky Military Institute Rev. Dr. HENDERSON said that having seen the statement, which has been widely published, that the first words of Professor AGASSIZ in his opening lecture to the Harvard course were, "I do not wish any one to come to my lectures who believes the Book of Genesis given in the Bible,"

The extensive flooring and planning mill of Messrs. WM. and GEO. CARSON, was burned this morning. Nothing but the brick walls or the extensive three-story building remains standing. The mill was to have been sold by the sheriff soon. The assignee had sold the stock.

Hon. C. H. Tucker, Chairman of the Aldermanic Convention of the XIth Assembly District: SIR: From reliable sources we have ascertained that there have been registered in this district on Friday and Saturday, the names of 1,500 fraudulent voters, mainly repeaters.

SAMUEL T. BLATCHFORD, the alleged fugitive draw back conspirator, was brought to this City, yesterday, by Colonel WHITELEY, Chief of the Secret Service Division, the latter having found him at Montreal, Canada. The clue to his whereabouts was given to District-Attorney PIERREPONT several days ago,
The steamship Hansa, which left Bremen Nov. 20 and Southampton Nov. 23, arrived at this port yesterday. Her news is later by two days than that hand by the Russia.

The fact of the Danish question having been again revived, and of the consequent interchange of diplomatic notes between the Cabinets of Berlin and Vienna, will probably appear to the general reader a remarkably uninteresting piece of intelligence.

Pere HYACINTHE has written a letter from New-York to EMILE DE GIRARDIN, in which he says: "I offer up prayers that the cause of liberty may triumph and bear fruit in Europe as it does in this noble country. That, with the triumph and fruitfulness of Christianity, is the sole safety of the present, the sole hope of the future.

We observe that some changes of programme are to be made at the City theatres this evening. At the Academy of Music a final performance of "William Tell" is to be given. At the Grand Opera House an English version of "The Huguenots" will be rendered for the first time. Mr. WALLACK will present "The Wonder."

HARTLEY, Secretary of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, cautions the public against a tall man (name unknown,) of fair complexion, respectable appearance, a cast in the eye, a fluent talker, from 60 to 65 years of age, who professes to be a retired Methodist clergyman.

A SIGN OF THE TIMES.--New-York is growing so last that our leading merchants find it necessary to keep places of business in different locations. Thus, Mr. E. A. BROOKS, leader of fashions in ladies', gentlemen's and children's boots and shoes, (long established at No. 575 Broadway,) has just opened a handsome store at No. 841 Broadway, near Fourteenth-street.

The Empress EUGENIE has arrived in Paris. The elections for members of the Corps Legislatif in the districts of Paris in which there was result in the recent elections, began yesterday, and were undisturbed.

A collection of $1,000 was taken up in Plymouth Church, yesterday, for crecling accommodations for an evening school for street boys, about to be established in the basement of the Bethel connected with the church. Mr. BEECHER took the occasion to deny the assertion that Plymouth Church is an aristocratic institution.
In this full of the political tempest between the November elections and the bustle of Congress, Mr. VOORHEES has taken an opportunity to make a speech "to open the coming Gubernatorial campaign."

Every careful reader of history has observed how often it has happened that some private contention has come to represent public interest and safety-as it were, merging its individual significance in the larger sphere of its public importance.

RICHMOND, Va. Dec. 6.--At the session of the National Board of Trade to-day a delegate from the Louisville Board was received. The Executive Council recommended Buffalo, N. Y., as the next place of meeting. HAMILTON A. HILL, of Boston, was reducted Secretary of the Board.

The municipal election--or rather the balloting farce which passes for an election in this City--takes place to-day. The polls will be open, or at least the law declares that they shall be open, from sunrise to sunset, which to-day will be from 7:11 o'clock in the morning till 4:32 in the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6.--It was a blue Monday morning that dawned to-day, "with weeping skies overhead and reeking streets underneath." Rain had fallen steadily all night, and the reception which the elements gave to the assembled wisdom was cold and gloomy;

Chicago paid $728,001 12 internal revenue tax in November. Chicago has laid twenty and a half miles of Nicolson pavement this year. The Chicago Post alludes to the Congressional Globe as "that expensive machine for grinding out immortal oblivion."
The Inman steamship City of Paris, which left Liverpool Nov. 25 and Queenstown Nov. 26. arrived at this port yesterday, with news later by three days than was brought by the Hansa. FRANCE.

The first mercantile vessel which passed through the Suez Canal on its way to Bombay was wrecked in the Red Sea. This is not encouraging. It illustrates the truth of the remark we made some weeks ago, that although the canal might be a success in itself, it did not at all insure a good passage up the Red Sea.

The following contracts for laying crosswalks were awarded by the Croton Department yesterday: At the intersection of Broadway and Sixth-avenue, to MICHAEL GAVIN at $1,014; across Fifth-avenue, at One Hundred and Thirty-first and One Hundred and Thirty-second streets, to MICHAEL GAVIN, at $760 50;

The first downright snow storm of the season set in yesterday morning. Since Friday, about 4 A. M., when there was a good sprinkling of the Wintry down, we have had several premonitions of tile advent of this decided storm in the few showers of sleet and rain which have fallen. The Report of Secretary COX proves to be a digest or synopsis, in the main, of the sub-reports of departments and districts, drawn up, as far as practicable, in the spirit, if not the language, of subordinates. Of course its main interest centers in General SHERMAN'S Report, which reviews the whole status of the army.

The report of Mr. ROBESON consists of a careful and very lueid review of the condition of the navy as the present Administration found it, of its progress in efficiency since the 4th of March last, and of its needs and prospects. It is to be regretted that he did not in-

The Postmaster--General's Report presents a mass of statistics, many of which are important and all interesting. The income and expenditure show improvement: the revenues were $18,344,510 72, and the expenditures $22,730,592 65, an increase of the former over 1868 of 12.59 per cent., while the latter has only increased 4.25 per cent.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 6.--The General Assembly to Kentucky met at Frankfort to-day and elected H. P. LESLIE, of Warren County, President of the Senate, and J. H. BUNCH as Speaker of the House. The Governor's Message was then read.

Mrs. R. J. BENNETT has commenced suit as a taxpayer and owner of property against the Mayor, Comptroller, Chamberlain, Board of Supervisors, WM. C. ROGERS, EDWARD JONES and J. JARVIS JONES. In her complaint she says the taxes of last year were unusually heavy, and the estimated amount for next year is still more burdensome;

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 6.--A special dispatch from St. Paul, Minn., to the Globe says: The latest intelligence from Fort Garry indicates that the insurrection is dying out. Only about fifty insurgents are under arms. The remamder have disbanded and a portion of hem had left for the Plains on a Winter buffalo hunt.

CLARK.--On Sunday, Dec. 5, Mrs. SUSAN CLARK, aged 77 years and 7 days. The relatives and friends of the family, and these of her sons-in-law, Samuel L. Caverly, Jacob Hyatt and John W. Ritch, are respectiully invited to attend the funeral from the First Baptist Church, corner of 5th and South 5th-sts., Williamsburg, on Wednesday, Dec. 8, at 11 o'clock A. M.

"THE HUGUENOTS" AT THE GRAND OPERA HOUSE. The massive strains of MEYERBEER'S grandest opera were said to have been wedded to English words for the first time at the splendid theatre in Twenty-third-street last night. The statement should, perhaps, be qualified so far as to describe "The Huguenots" as a whole, since

Yesterday, at the meeting of he Brooklyn Aldermen, Alderman THORNE moved that the resolution of Alderman WHITING, offering $1,000 as a reward for the arrest and convietion of all parties concerned in the late electron frauds, which was laid on the table under the rule at the last meeting, be adopted.

The Report of the Interior Department opens with a statement of public land sales: the total is 7,666,151 acres, or 1,010,409 more than last year; the cash receipts were $4,472,886, an increase of $2,840,140, and the expenses were $453,816.

Yesterday was a bleak, dismal, uncomfortable day. A severe storm lasted from morning until night, and the day was in all respects just the kind to keep within doors all who were not obliged to go out. The attendance at the salesroom was very slim. There was but one sale, and that of not much importance.

A sense of gratitude and pride may well be awakened in any nation which is invited to contemplate so bright and hopeful a review of its affairs as that which President GRANT is providentially enabled to lay before us. His Message is one of good news throughout.

The death of this well-known clergyman, for some time expected, is at last announced. JOHN ORSENIGO was born in Italy, emigrated thence and entered the Roman Catholic priesthood in this country. For many years he faithfully discharged the du ties of his office as co-adjuster of the late Dr. CUMMINGS, at St. Stephen's Church, in this City.

NASHVILLE, NOV 6.--The House adopted to-day a resolution to adjourn on the 22d inst. to the 1st of January next, and passed to a first reading the bill providing for the funding of the State debt, due and accruing, between this and 1875, together with the notes of the Bank of Tennessee.

To the Senate and House of Representatives: In coming before you for the first time as Chief Magistrate of this great nation, it is with gratitude to the Giver of all Good for the many benefits we enjoy. We are blessed with peace at home, and are without entangling alliances abroad to forbode trouble; with a territory unsurpassed in fertility,...

JEFFERSON, Texas, Dec. 6.--Bowie, Davies and Cass Counties give DAVIS 612 majority, GRAFTER, for Congress, is 1,000 ahead. The Legislative and County officers in Bowie and Cass Counties are Radical, and in Davies County Conservative. All the votes case are for the Constitution. Half the whites did not vote.

WILLIAM E. BOGART, an old man who has been in custody for the past week, on a charge of swindling, was arraigned on fresh charges before Judge MANSFIELD yesterday. One affidavit alleged that he bad obtained $100 from a good woman named RODDY MACKAY, residing in Port Washington, on the false pretence that he had charge of $40,000 worth of goods smuggled from Liverpool, and belonging to her son,

AN ORDINANCE TO DIVIDE THE CITY OF NEW-YORK INTO CONVENIENT ELECTION DISTRICTS, PURSUANT TO SECTION EIGHT, ARTICLE THREE, TITLE THREE, OF ACT OF THE LEGISLATURE PASSED APRIL FIVE, EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND FORTY-TWO. (Containing all Amendments to Aug. 1, 1869.)

PARIS, Dec. 6.--The political programme of EMILE OLLIVIER, and his partisans, has been adopted with some reservations by thirty-seven Liberal Deputies, who are forming into a separate party. On the basis of this new party the formation of a parliamentary ministry under OLINIER will be possible.

It is stated in letters received in Paris from Madrid, that General PRIM decidedly favors the Republican Party. The Ministerial crisis in Italy still continues, and it is said that the King has requested General CIALDINI to form a new Cabinet.

Before the Medical Society of the County of New-York, last evening, Professor T. GILLARD THOMAS read a paper on the "Induction of Premature Delivery as a Prophylactic Resource in Midwifery." A petition was presented for signature soliciting the restoration of army surgeons to the rank held by them under General Orders United States Army issued in 1863.

By the steamer De Solo, just arrived from Havana, the following letter has been received in this City, viz.: MACURIJES, Nov. 29, 1869.--On the 1st of next month 400 volunteers from the first battalion of Matanzas will leave for the Aldama's sugar estate, where they will be quartered to guard the same; staff and headquarters at Santa Rosa, which is a magnificent plantation.

To-day the election for manor City officers is held in the Metropolis. In the various districts Aldermen, Assistant Aldermen, Police Justices, Civil Justices and School Trustees are to be chosen. Boxes were yesterday distributed also for Mayoralty ballots. It is said that the friends of Mayor HALL, in order to make assurance doubly sure, and take a bond of the voters,

Coroner KEENAN held an inquest yesterday in the examination room attached to the office of the Board of Coroners, in the City Hall in, in the case of ALBERT D. RICHARDSON, who came to his death by a would inflicted by DANIEL MCFARLAND. The proceedings attracted a large assemblage of people, who evidently came to see the prisoner more than anything else.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W Simonton, General Agent. News packages for the Journal of mmerce, Times, Tribune, World. Sun, Express, Evening Post, Commercial Advertiser.

SENATE.... WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 6. At 12 o'clock punctually the Senate met, when the session was opened by prayer by Rev. Dr. NEWMAN, Chaplain of the Senate, who supplicated Divine blessings upon the different Departments of the Government upon the President of the United States in his private and public capacity,...

Mr. DAVID HARRISON, of Fayette, Miss., has patented an invention designed not only to obviate loss of time to fast or express railway trains by stopping to take in water and fuel, but also to enable anything, such as mails, express packages, , to be supplied to trains while running at full speed.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Hayti, Nov. 24, ria HAVANA, Dec. 6.--The revolutionary army now hold possession of the whole of Northern Hayti, including the ports of Mole St. Nicolas, Port de Paix and Cape Haytien. Cape Haytien was taken by assault on the 13th of November ; the followers of SALNAVE took refuge in the American Consulate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5.--The Special Commissioners from Japan to the Sandwich Islands, sailed for Honolulu to-day to investigate the condition of their countrymen on the plantations in the Islands, and, possibly to draft a treaty with the Hawaiian Kingdom, to be submitted to the Government of Japan on their return.

The annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the Colored Orphan Asylum was held yesterday. The following officers were chosen for the ensuing year: Mrs. AUGUST TABER, First Directress; Mrs. W. H. ONDERDONK, Second Directress; Miss S. S. MURRAY, Secretary: Mrs. CHAS. LEMDON, Treasurer; Mr. O. K. HUTCHINSON, Superintendent;

There have been within the last three years three legal contests of great importance in this City between the Government and importers, the last of which was brought to a close in the United States District Court on Saturday, and resulted as each of the others had, in the failure of the jury to agree upon a verdict.

The formal opening of the new rooms of the Hudson River (Unitarian) Conference and the New-York Young Men's Christian Union, at No. 5 Clinton-place, was made the occasion last evening of a very pleasant reception in which about 300 ladies and gentlemen participated. The Message of the President of the United States was transmitted by the Atlantic Telegraph last night and is pubblished this morning. Tile Pall Mall Gazette, in its comments on the reference to the Alabama claims, says: "The Americans are ready to accept an apology in lieu of all the damages they demand.

Mr. WILLIAM P. LEIGHTON, of Black Hawk, died last night from drinking a small quantity of a strong solution of Cyanuret of Potassium. He was at work in the Polar Star Mill, and contrary to his usual custom, left the engine room and came into the new mill to warm his midnight lunch upon the stove and eat with the other men. ter placing his ketrie on the stove.

We have given some space to the feathered portion of the exhibited creatures at this show, and a brief notice of the rabbits. Yesterday evening the dogs particularly attracted our attention. The entries in this class are nearly 200. F. BUTLER, New-York, is the largest contributor, he having sent in no less than seventy-five specimens.

A mail train on the Pennsylvania Central Railroad, while standing this morning at the station, was run into by a freight train, and three conches, two freight cars and the engine smashed. A brakeman on the freight train named BENJAMIN SANDSBURY was killed, and HENRY MEKIN, a peddler, mortally wounded. .

The state of trade and manufactures in England, the lack of work in large districts, the war between employers and employed, the rapid increase of pauperism and crime, are subjects of serious and even alarming interest.

The London journals, or some of them, published President GRANT'S message yesterday morning, and the pall Mall Guzette, in its comments on that part which speaks of the Alabama claims, says the Americans are willing to accept an apology in hen of damages, but England can do no more than she has done.

An order has been issued by Admiral GODON to the workmen in the NAVY Yard, to get the Roanoke in readiness for service immediately--meaning within five days. The consequence is that workmen in all the departments necessary to complete the preparations of this vessel for sea, are at work night and day to accomplish the task specified by the order.

After the announcement had been made to ECKEL that he must die, we are informed that, at the suggestion of a prominent citizen, ECKEL'S partner in crime, CALLICOTT, had an interview with him, for the purpose of drawing from him any disclosures he might feel disposed to make in regard to the murder of Dr. BURDELL.

NICHOLAS M. MELADY, who murdered his father and stepmother about nine months age, was hanged this morning at 8:30 o'clock. It is said he left a written confession of his crime. WILLIAMSPORT. Penn. Dec. 7. JOHN FIELDS, who murdered his brother-in-law, GEORGE MATHEWS, in Cascade Township,

The trial of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad suit was resumed this morning. William C. Van Atisne, bookkeeper in the railroad office, was examined as to the proceedings of the election and as to the transfer of stock made by the Ramsey Party.

OFFICIAL. MONDAY, Dec. 6, 1869--2 o'clock P. M. The Board met in their Chamber, number Fifteen City Hall. pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Cuddy, Ward, O'Brien, Cushman, Connor, Repper, McGrath, Farley--10.

The election for minor offices in this City passed off very quietly yesterday except in one of two of the wards where party spirit ran high. The result was, in nearly all the districts, a cut-and-dried certainty. Beyond the candidates of the factions and their immediate adherents very little interest was manifested in the event by our citizens generally.

The annual tournament of the New-York Cness Club, which commenced last Wednesday, has continued with unabated interest to the present time. Fifty-two games have been contested with the following result: J. Ware, Jr., won seven games, lost none; B. Lissuer won three games, lost two; James Thompson won four games, lost two;

About 5 o'clock this afternoon, white the building of the Commercial Exchange Association was being lit up, a large chandelier in the upper hall fell, allowing an immense rush of gas, which took fire, and in a few seconds the whole structure was in flames.

H. R. HARDING was elected Mayor of Cambridge, yesterday, by 377 plurality, over WELCH. At Chelsea, Mayor FORSYTH was reelected without opposition. The preliminary examination of FRANK E. murder and robbery of NATHANIEL LORD, in Peabody, resulted in fully committing them for trial.

The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education, held last evening, was presided over by Mr. E. J. WHITLOCK, in the absence of Dr. THORNE, President. From the report of the Finance Committee it appeared that bills amounting to $52,412 95 were to be paid.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee held its regular meeting at No. 9 Court-street, Brooklyn, last evening, JAMES B. CRAIG in the chair. Mr. J. I. BERGEN, from the Finance Committee, reported that the collections last year had been greater than previous years, and that the finances were in excellent condition. The balance on hand is $5,000,
WEDNESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Queenstown and Liverpool, by the Scotia, close at the General Post Office at 8 A. M. Mails for Porto Plata, San Domingo, Samana, , by the Tybee, close at 2 P. M.

The Red River packet steamer Richmond struck a sawyer twelve miles below here on the 2d inst., and sunk. The steamer is a total loss. She was one of the best boats in this river trade. A small part of her freight was saved by a passing steamer. No lives lost.

Contrary to al established customs, business at the Salesroom yesterday was decidedly brisk. Election day is generally very quiet. It is presumed that some few buyers, at least, are interested in the success of some ticket or individual, and that on that day they will use their time and efforts to secure the election of the persons whose friends they are.

The Court of Magistrates in Pawtucket was crowded on Saturday morning by eager spectators, to listen to the examination of HIRAM A. BRIGGS, charged with mingling arsenic with gingerbread and sweet bread, with the intent to poison ALMIRA BRIGGS, her two daughters and a grandchild.

The snowy mantle which covered the City yesterday morning was hailed with gladness by thousands, who availed themselves of its presence to indulge in the luxury of sleigh riding. Union-square presents at this time a vast change from its former appearance; dry goods, jewelry and banking establishments occupy the buildings formerly used as residences,

Nearly an hour was spent at the opening of the House to-day, in a scramble by the members of several of the Committees to secure the reference to their respective bodies, of the several portions of the President's Message referring to legislation, particularly those parts wherein important recommendations are made.

Yesterday the quartz numbers of the Columbia Mining Company at Unionville struck, on account of the reduction of wages, New men were set at work, but were driver off by the strikers. Five of the strikers were arrested by the Sheriff, but they were instantly rescued by their friends.

The Philadelphia Day publishes the following extract from a letter written by an officer of the United States steamer Triana, and dated Savannah River, Ga., Nov. 21, 1869: "We left Hampton Roads on Saturday, Nov. 13, to convoy the Dictator to Key West, Fla. On Saturday night and Sunday we encountered a fresh gale from the eastward.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. Mr. LESTER WALLACK repeated, at his theatre, last evening, two performances which have always been part of his repertory, but which had not been applauded this season. He acted Viscount de Ligny in "The Captain of the Watch," and Woodcock, in that character's "Little Game."

Dr. McCOSH desires to contradict the statement which has appeared in some newspapers, that since his accession to the Presidency Princeton College has received more than $400,000, this being an exaggeration. He says, also, that there have been mistakes in some papers as to the names of the supposed donors.

Important news reached Lieutenant-General SHERIDAN'S head-quarters to-day concerning Indian depredations in Montana Territory. It appears the Blackfeet Indian, who are very numerous in that Territory, have left their reservation, organized into mounted parties, and are robbing and murdering white citizens in the most shocking and barbarous manner...

Mr. J. H. BEADLE, editor of the Utah Reporter, published at Corinne, Utah, was in the city yesterday. Mr. BEADLE is the man who received such a severe pounding at the hands of the "Saints" of Brigham City four weeks ago, from the effects of which he has not yet fully recovered.

A letter from Laramie Dec. 4, says: "The Indian troubles in Wyoming are quito alarming. Bands of Sioux are roving through the Territory, robbing and murdering. The mail party that left Fort Laramie was driven in by the Indians.
JAMES S. PIERCE, an old resident of Suspension Bridge, jumped off the Suspension Bridge into the Rapids, this afternoon. Intemperance and pecuniary embarrassment prompted the suicide.

The members of the Commercial Exchange, undaunted by the destruction of their hall, met to-day at MICHENERS Co.'s store, on Arch-street, and resumed business. Their hall will be rebuilt immediately, the insurance being sufficient to replace it.

The second annual Convention of the NewJersey Woman's Suffrago Association met last evening at the Opera House in Newark, and was attended by a crowded auditory. It will continue throughout the day, to-day, closing with the session this evening.

Hon. JAMES POLLOCK, Director of the United States Mint, reports to Secretary BOUTWELL that the deposits of bullion at the mint and branches during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1860, were as follows: Gold, $31,463,249 76; silver, $1,790,453 49; total deposits, $33,253,703 25.

The present year seems destined to be marked in the history of our city as an era of disastrous fires. The chimeshad scarcely ceased their farewell to 1868, and their welcome to 1869, before the bells sounded the alarm for the terrible fire at Broad and Cherry streets. This was succeeded within a fortnight by the conflagration in the Burd buildings, at Ninth and Chesnut.

At a meeting of the Board of Health yesterday the Attorney reported twenty-two eases of violation of Tenement House laws,twenty-four cases of non-compllance with ordinances, and three cases of violation of ordinances. Suits wore ordered to be commenced in all these cases.

The Ecumenical Council was opened yestorday in Rome by Pope PIUS IX. The streets leading to the Vatican, notwithstanding the rain which fell at intervals, were crowded by the people, as the Pope, at the head of a procession of 700 Bishops, proceeded to the hall of the Council.
