The Harrison boilers, 100-horse power, and the Root boilers, advertised as 120-horse power, were placed in the American Institute Fair to operate the engines. The Harrison boilers were reported by the Superintendent of Machinery as the only boilers that were tight and able to perform the work allotted to them.

A dispatch from Los Angeles says the ship Orion, from New-York for San Francisco, went ashore on Yuigo Shoal, near San Diego, on the night of Dec. 6. She was rescued by the steamer Oriflamme, and towed into the harbor of San Diego, leaking badly. She will probably discharge her cargo.

Dr. HARRIS, Samtary Superintendent, yesterday submitted to the Board of Health the bimonthly report on chemical tests of the cheapoils for lamps, which shows that of the forty samples examined during the last two weeks not one was of the standard required under the Health Ordinances.

The report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office equals any of its predecessors in careful elaboration and compass of topical interest. The text embraces thirty-five separate heads, with the usual appendix of statistical tables.

The Wheeling and Parkersburg packet Rebecca ran Into Pier No. 4, at Parkersburg, last night, and sunk immediately. Thirteen lives wore lost. All the passengers are reported to be saved. The lost are supposed to have been dock hands. No further particulars have as yet been received.

The Secretary of the Treasury recommends to Congress the repeal of laws which allow shares of fines, penalties and forfeitures to officers of the Government or to informers, and the recommendation is earnestly seconded by the President in his Message.

The New-York Liberal Club held its regular weekly meeting last evening, at No. 27 Third-avenue. A paper was read by Captain C. B. DAHLGREN on Nevada and her mines. He says there are 150 good quartz mills in the State, with 2,300 stamps. The whole production of silver in the last ten years has amounted to $15,000,000.

The commissioners of Emigration met yesterday afternoon, Mr. WINSTON presiding. Current bills, amounting to $17,741, were ordered to be paid. The charges against the Erie and Hudson Railroads were referred to the Committee on Grievances.

The National Base-Ball Association met at the rooms of the Lowell Club this morning at 11 o'clock. The Convention was called to order by the Second Vice-President, J. R. ROGERS, of Pennsylvania. Recording Secretary C. E. COON, of the District of Columbia, and Treasurer N. N. BOGERS, of Massachusetts, were present. The other officers were absent.

The sugar harvest will be generally finished throughout the State by the last of this week. Below the city a few planters may grind a little longer, but the great majority on the coast and the bayous will have their sugar all in the coolers or perguries by Monday next. The yield will not much exceed that of last year.

The triumph of the revolution is almost complete in the South, all the principal towns in this part of the country having, within the last eight or ten days, given in their adhesion to the Government of President DOMINGUE.

A bold and successful diamond robbery was perpetrated in this city this evening. About 6 o'clock a thief entered the jewelry store of W. H. WILLIAMS, No. 488 Broadway, under pretence to buy, but really for the purpose of theft.

Last Spring a widow named STINGLER, who resided about fifty miles from Rochester, N. Y., was importuned by a neighbor to trade her small cottage and few acres for forty acres of land in Wisconsin, one hundred miles west of Milwaukee. He represented the land to be fertile-on the line of a railroad, and near a large village.

The message of Governor HAIGHT to the California Legislature is published to-day. He congratulates the people on their general prosperity since the close of the last session of the Legislature; commends the present school system; says that an efficient militia is indispensable to the proper enforcement of the laws and to the maintenance of public order:

Dec. 9. -- The ceremonies yesterday attendant on the opening of the sessions of the Ecumenical Council lasted five hours.

While machinery has been for a long time in use in most other branches of manufacture, until quite recently cigars have been made altogether by hand, the process requiring a skill which can be attained only by two or three years' apprenticeship.

A distinguished lawyer, Mr. MURRAY HOFFMAN, has recently given it as his opinion that the term of office of Mayor HALL, who was elected in 1868, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mr. JOHN T. HOFFMAN, extends to the 1st day of January, 1871, or in other words, for the full term of two years from the day of his election.

The expected release of the Spanish flotilla at Delamater's Iron Works did not take place yesterday. As twenty of them are now completed and requiring only provisions and fuel to render them ready for sea, their departure may be looked for at an early date in case of their release.

The question of the validity of divorces obtained in another State has been brought prominently before the public by recent circumstances. It may not be without interest to see what have been the rulings of our Courts on the subject.

The State Senate to-day passed, on its first reading, a bill providing that no person shall be indicated for an act committed while serving as a soldier during the late war, and dismissing all pending prosecutions of the kind.

Workmen have commenced to move back the fence around the new Post Office grounds, leaving a plank sidewalk six feet wide. Superintendent HULBURD stated at the outset that the fence would be drawn in during December, and he has fulfilled his promise to the accommodation of the public.

JOHN KING, aged 35, committed suicide last night at the New-York Hotel, by shooting himself through the temple. He came to this City from Fort Smith, Ark,m and was a lawyer by profession. He was reported to have indulged considerably in strong drink.

There is now on exhibition at the rooms of the State Board of Agriculture. or Headquarters of the Geological Corps, a section of the lemur or thigh bone of an animal of the mastodon species, the fossilized remains of which were recently discovered in Union County.

This association of chess players organized a tournament on Wednesday of last week, to which they invited the members of every chess organization in New--York, Brooklyn and vicinity of the Metropolis. Many distinguished amateurs participate in the proceedings.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Ever and anon the newspapers have a fling at Mr. SEWARD'S northern investment, yet I do not observe a corresponding willingness to accept the good points of the purchase. Of course every one acknowledges its advantages in timber, minerals. furs and fishes.

Yesterday afternoon the library of Rev. JOEL PARKER, D. D., consisting of about 300 volumes of theological works and current literature, was sold at auction by BANGS, MERWIN CO. There were few noticeable books in the collection with the exception of nine volumes of the Critici Sacra, printed in 1696. and a fine copy of the paraphrases of Erasmus, bound in stamped hog skin, and bearing date 1522.

About 1,000 men are at work on the railroad at the Pass of Del Mocha, near Orizaba....The yield of the Sonora mines is bountiful. The manufacturing interest is increasing in prosperity. The Macias insurrection has ended. The ususal number of pronunciamientos were issued by the insurrectionits....A very brilliant

The grading and track laying of the Delaware, Lackawana and Western Railroad is partially completed west of the Passaic River to Singack, and a locomotive will soon be placed upon the road to assist in the completion.

This morning MICHAEL CANN was shot and instantly killed by JAMES GALLOWAY, at the house of the latter, No. 176 William-street, Federal Hill, in this city. The shooting originated in reports circulated by CANN in regard to GALLOWAy's wife. They had been partners for some time in the fishing business.

The Times, this morning, has an editorial article on the Alabama claims. The writer hopes that the American Goverment will appoint such men as GEORGE TICKNOR CURTIS and WILLIAM M. EVARTS to state the facts and law of he case. The Times thinks good results would certainly follow so wise a selection.

Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD and party arrived in this city on the 15th ultimo, and were received at the railroad station by President JUAREZ and his Cabinet, and a Commission of the notables of the city. On the 18th of November Hon. THOMAS H. NELSON. The United States Minister to Mexico,

MICHAEL F. BARRY, a patrolman of the Ninth Precinct, was placed on trial yesterday before Commissioner MANNERRE for not preventing the outrage at No. 1 Christopher-street during the registry on Friday, the 3d inst. WILLIAM C. CARPENTER, the Inspector who was the victim, testified that between 5 and 6 o'clock.

Mrs. GALLAGHER, No. 117 Charles-street, was seriously burned last evening by the explosion of kerosene oil in a can. Mrs. HOPPER, the wife of a Baptist minister in Irvington, was assaulted by a man unknown to her a few days ago.

During the remarkable clearness of the sky Thursday evening and Friday morning, many meteors were seen here and there to speed across the heavens. The number counted from 9 o'clock in the evening to 5 in the morning was thirty.

In the case of JOHN KING, the Arkansas lawyer, who died in the New-York Hotel on Thursday evening, from a pistol shot wound in the temple, said to have been inflicted by his own hand, De. WM. SHINE, deputy for Coroner FLYNN, denied yesterday that he held an inquest over the remains of deceased, as was confidently stated by the proprietor and clerks of the hotel, and the officer on duty there.

Rome, Dec. 10.--The Pope delivered an allocution before the assembled Bishops. He expressed his satisfaction in being able to open the Council on the day which had been fixed, and at finding that the Bishops came in such numbers to aid the Holy See, helped by the Holy Spirit.

Typhoid fever is raging in Utica. Eastern chestnuts are sold at seventy-five cents a pound in San Francisco. Wisconsin expects to have eight or nine Congressmen under the new apportionment. It new has six.

" PIPELE" AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC FERRARI'S comic opera of "Pipelo" was produced for the first time in America at the Academy last night. The work has been comparatively little heard of here, and some suspicion that it was of a slight and flimsy character may have possessed the public mind and led to a paucity of interest, which for a new opera in a successful season is somewhat unusual. This did not, however,

Evening.--The Corps Legislatif had another stormy session to-day. An Opposition Deputy demanded the impeachment of M. FORCADE, the Minister of the Interior. Scenes of violence followed, such as have never before been witnessed in the Chamber. The sitting was adjourned a mid great excitement. The French official Yellow Book has just been published.

GEO. BRENNER, a native of Germany, aged 21 years, and a barber, committed suicide yesterday morning by swallowing poison. It appears that for some time BRENNER was employed in the barber shop, No. 4 Market-street, and occupied a room on the upper floor of the premises, No. 8 Eldridge-street.

A few weeks ago we stated that Mr. MORRIS S. HILL, the Cashier of the Farmers' and Drovers' National Bank of Somers, in Westchester County, had absconded, and left the books in a state of confusion, preventing the officers of the bank from ascertaining the true condition of the institution, but it was supposed by outsiders that Mr. HILL was a defaulter.
The first of the trials of the Justices of the Peace in Hudson County, N. J., who were indicted for malfeasance in office, was held in the Hudson County Court of Sessions yesterday.

BARNES.--On Thursday, Dec. 9. MARY, wife of John Van Cleve Barnes, and daughter of the late Richard Vaughan, aged 27 years. Funeral from the residence of her father-in-law Daniel Barnes, No. 351 West 20th-st., on Sunday, the 12th inst., at 1 3/4 o'clock.

It will be remembered that a few weeks ago a man named BARTON M. JOHNSON was arrested and arraigned before Justice HOGAN on a charge of having sold two $5,000 United States bonds, alleged to have been stolen, to Messrs. CAROLIN O' BRYAN, BRYANT and JOHN H. HAND. The accused was held for examination to take place on Monday next.

There was a large attendance of skaters at MACMILLAN'S Open Rink, corner Fifth--avenue and Forty--fifth--street, yesterday, through but few of the participants were ladies. The ice was in very fair condition, not with standing the softening tendency of the weather during the day, and those who took advantage of the occasion enjoyed fine sport.

Were the effects of the ill-feeling so often exhibited between tugs and ferry boats plying on the East and North Rivers confined to their officers and owners, we should not feel called upon to discus the matter. But the public has an interest, and a very large one, in this animosity.

The French "Yellow Book" has just been published in Paris. It regards the condition of France as favorable, and says her relations with foreign countries are more amicable since the Conference on the Greek and Turkish question.

Judge HITCHCOCK, who has been appointed a receiver of the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad, by the County Court of Common Pleas in Summit County, Ohio, is a resident of Pamsville, Ohio. He succeeded to the Common Pleas Bench of his subdivision after the election of Hon. B. F. WADE to the United States Senate, now nearly twenty years ago.

The St. Nicholas Hotel in Broadway, between Broome and Spring streets, was supplied with gas from private works located at No. 61 Mercer-street, at th rear of a four-story trick building used as a laundry for the hotel. Yesterday afternoon, about 3 o'clock, there was an explosion of the material used in the manufacture of this gas.

Several persons in Havana have received letters from General GOICOURIA, demanding sums of money of from $2,000 to $10,000. He requests that the money be forwarded to him, without delay, in care of the American Consul at Nassau. These letters have been delivered to the Spanish authorities in Havana. An incendiary proclamation, dated Havana, Dec. 10, was received by the steamer Columbia from New-York.

The report of Lieutenant GEORGE WHEELER, of the Corps of Engineers, who, with Lieutenant LOCK WOOD, led the exploring party sent out a few months ago by General ORD to discover a route through the White Pine country to the Colorado River, to which reference has been made in our San Francisco dispatches and

The attacks which are being made upon Mr. PEABODY, for his alleged "sympathy with the aristocracy of England throughout our civil war," are not only unjust, but reveal an utter Ignorance of Mr. PEABODY'S true character, as well as of the facts of his life. We shall take an-other opportunity of proving this assertion.

Last evening CHARLES L. WOODWARD was sitting by the grate in his basement at his dwelling, No. 303 East Thirty-fourth-street, when he was suddenly startled by the report of a pistol, and the whiz of a bullet over his head.

One branch of Congress, the House, was in session to--day, and when it is stated that the Census bill was the only topic of discussion, it may be inferred that the proceedings, however important, were dull and uninteresting. The only ripple of me??ment which disturbed the gravity of the body was when Mr. FERNANDO WOOD solemnly

At about 10 o'clock last night, a young German named JOHAN SCHMIDT shot himself with it pistol, on Bloomfield, between Ninth and Tenth streets, in Hoboken. He was taken to St. Mary's Hospital in an insensible condition, where he soon afterward died.

Special Agent GAYOR made a complaint before United States Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday, charging a Post Office carrier named JAMES R. HOBBY, Jr., with having embezzled several letters intrusted to his care for delivery.

The adjourned motion for the discharge of the Spanish gunboats now lying at the foot of Thirteenth--street, on the North River, came on yesterday at the United States District Court, before Judge BLATCHFORD.

Dr. CARPENTER presented a report of his Deep Sea explorations before the English Royal Society, which is full of valuable scientific discoveries. A small crinoid was brought up, from a depth of 300 fathoms, of a class supposed to have no living representative.

SATURDAY Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, by the City of Paris, close at the General Post Office at 10 A. M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on Pier No. 45 North River to 11:30 A. M. Mails for France, via Brest and Havre, by the Pereire, close at 9 A. M.

A day or two since Mayor BEACH had a narrow escape from death by poison. He was slightly unwell, and called upon his physician. Dr. SEYMOUR, to prescribe for him. The doctor prepared a powder, and directing that it should be taken with some syrup, laid it upon his desk.

It is believed that Father HYACINTHE will depart for Europe to-day in the steamer Pereire. P. Diez de Rivera, of the Spanish Legation, and Dr. A. Van Cortlandt, of New-Rochelle, are at the Albemarle Hotel. General John A. Green, of Syracuse; Hon. G. D. Lord, of Rochester; Hon. J. F. Bagley, of Detroit; Hon. John Lyneh, of Portland; Hon. C. D. Skinner, of Oswego ;

CALVIN CHISHOLM, of Nova Scotia, and LOUIS WILSON, a Swede, left here in a whale boat on Monday for the Isle of Shoals, and nothing having been heard from them since it is supposed that they have been drowned.

The appointment by the President of Hon. GEORGE A. PEARRE, of Cumberland, to be United States Judge for the Circuit composed of Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina, was an act which will meet the warmest public approval, and which will reflect the greatest credit upon General GRANT. In discharging the delicate,

The Spanish engineers and a number of officers of the war steamer Pizarre visited the gunboats at DELAMATER 'S basin, foot of west thirteenth -street, yesterday. It was intended to take some of them up the North River on a trial trip, and steam was got up for this purpose on board of six of them; but owing to the lateness of the hour, the trip was postponed until to-morrow.

In steamship Pereire, for Havre and Brest--Rev. Pere Hyacinthe, A. Ruben Hoise, Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Singer, Mrs. Carr and son, Mrs. Thos. T. Davis, C. A. Singer. Misses Sadie and Josie Singer and servant, Mrs. Brooks and family, Mr. and Mrs. Kayne,

A meeting of holders of the bonds of the State of Tennessee was held yesterday at the office of REUBEN MANLEY CO., No. 64 Broadway, to devise ways and means for securing the payment of the interest now due on the bonds. J. J. DONALDSON, President of the Bank of North America, Presided, and Mr. A. D. WILLIAMS acted as Secretary. At least $12,000,000 worth of bonds were represented.

The Ohio Republican State Central and State Executive Committees had a meeting in Columbus on Thursday. Among the resolutions adopted unanimously was the following: Whereas, At the late State election the Republican Party achieved a signal triumph in the election of its candidates for State officers and a majority of the members of the General Assembly,

At the annual election of Greenwich Lodge, No. 467, F. A. M., held on Friday evening, the following officers were elected and appointed for the ensuing year; SIMEON T. BROW, Master; M. B. Abrahams, Senior Warden; Chas. H. Van Norden, Junior Warden; Wm. H. Lefferts, Treasurer; Wm. B. Shoue, Secretary; Wm. S. See, J. J. Taylor and B. F. Burnham,

A ball will be given at Irving Hall on Thursday night next, for the benefit of the fund set aside by the Grand Army of the Republic for the relief of disabled soldiers, sailors and widows and orphans. This ball will be conducted under the auspices of Post Cameron, No. 79, an announcement which will satisfy all that the arrangements will be of the most complete and satisfactory nature.

There is, to anybody who knows anything of the facts, something very amusing in the trouble which the Courts and the Legislature find in dealing with the "concealed weapons" problem. The Recorder and City Judge charge the Grand Jary about it every year in the most solemn manner,

It has happened this year that an unusual amount of critical attention has been bestowed upon the business of life insurance, both here and abroad. The failure of some English companies has led to a close examination of their methods of government, and the discussion about them has widened until it embraced the personnel and management of all companies of whatever grade.

The steamship Deutschland, which left Bremen Nov. 27, and Northampton Nov. 30, arrived at this port yesterday. Our special correspondence from France and England, published know, supplies intelligence later, by two than was at hand by the Cuba.

Father HYACINTHE took his departure yesterday for France by the Steamer Pereire. He left the Fifth-avenue Hotel at 9 A. M. for Pier No. 50, accompanied by Mr. DARLING and two members of the Societe Francuis de Bienfaisance. He was cordially welcomed on board by Captain DECHESNE, and spent nearly an hour on deck with his friends before the signal for departing was given.

That all pervading and mysterious organization, the Post Office Department, presents in itself a strange epitome of human life, its wants and its feelings, its motive power and even its faults. From the dry figures of the annual report, spring pictures of humanity in every phase, and beneath every sky.

Mr. WARD presented a petition of the Chemung County (New-York) Medical Society, for an increase of the rank of the Naval Medical officers. Mr. STARK WEATHER presented a petition of the citizens of New-London, Conn., that coal be admitted free of duty.

The sessions of the Ecumenical Council have been adjourned until after Epiphany. Much opposition is expected on the reassembling of the body, but His Holiness is said to be sure of the cooperation of the American Bishops.

At the regular meeting of the Genealogical and Biographical Society last evening. Mr. AUGUSTES MAVERICK read a paper on the late Hon HENRY J. RAYMOND. The name RAYMOND, he said, was of French origin, but the genealogical record of the family in this country could only be traced back about 80 years.

There is a charity in this City that hourly repeats the divine command, " Suffer little children to come unto me ." and every night gathers to his sheltering arms hundreds of homeless little vagrants who come hungry and are fed, filthy and are made clean, tired and are given rest. Knowing no creed nor clime in extending its beneficence, it looks only to see the actual need of its snecor before it acts.

The American ship Crescent City, which left Savannah, Ca., for this port on the 30th of October last, laden with cotton, sprung aleak at sea and was abandoned, as it was evident she could not be kept afloat.

The Treasurer's office of Erie County was entered by burglars at 2 o'clock this morning, the safe blown open with nitro-glycerine and the contents abstracted. The loss has not yet been ascertained. The safe is a perfect wreck. The Court House building was badly damaged.

The plaining mill of JOHN S. THOMAS, on the corner of Compton-avenue and Chestnut-street, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is $25,000, insured in the following companies: $1,000 in the Maryland Fire, of Baltimore; $1,000 in the International, of New-York; $2,500 in the Globe Mutual $2,500 in the American Central, $2,500 in the Commercial, and $2,500 in the Citizen's.

The past week has been an interesting one at the opera houses. On Monday, the Richings Troupe produced the "Huguenots." with considerable splendor, against "William Tell," at the Academy. Some of the singing in the "Huguenots" was curiously bad, yet the work was so well placed upon the stage and the deserts of Mrs. RICHINGS-BERNARD in the production so

The House made very little progress on the Census bill today, the best portion of the session having been consumed in disputing and skirmishing on the franking privilege question. About twothirds of the bill has been finished; but at the present rate of progress it will not be ready to go to the Senate before Wednesday unless night sessions are held.

The defence in the case of JOHN T. BARTON, accused of bribing United States Weighers to make false returns in merchandise, were ready to proceed with an examination before Commissioner OSBORN, yesterday, but an adjournment for one week was asked by Assistant the case. His motion was allowed.

There are indications here of some important events about to transpire. SALNAVE'S soldiers, and every man and youth--and even women--he can press into his service, are at work on the fortifications of the city. Earthworks are being thrown up, and cannon rapidly placed in position.

Three days since in this city, at his house on Jackson-street, died AH POV, a Chinese merchant. The disease which baffled the skill of Chinese doctors and carried him off was a lingering consumption. He was born at Canton, and at an early age entered upon mercantile pursuits. He came to this country and continued his native avocation. He died at the age of 59 years.

Some time in the month of August, 1869. Mrs. MCFARLAND appeared in the town of Martinsville, and, calling upon Attorneys HARRISON SHIRLEY, made known her residence in Morgan County, town of Mooresville, and engaged their services to assist Messrs. PORTER, FISHBACK HARRISON in procuring her a divorce.

With the setting in of Winter the public and private charities of tile City once more attract, as they should, the attention of its public-spirited and philanthropic people. Few, however, of our citizens are probably aware that theo institution we call the NewYork City Almshouse has now come to comprise no less than twenty different institutions, established on Manbattan,

The natural discontent of mankind with its present condition, which, in its proper action, is an important spur to effort for improvement and progress, leads the foolish to endeavor to pry into the secrets of the future instead of going to work to make a future for themselves.

About eighty physicians, chemists and jurists held a meeting this afternoon at Medical Society Hall, for the purpose of reviewing the case of Dr. PAUL SCHOEPPE, under sentence of death and execution on the 22d inst. at Carlisle, for the murder of Miss STEINECKE.

The election in this county, we contest candidly, has passed off as quietly as any election we have ever seen; in fact we are free to say more so, and we attribute this happy result to the forethought of General REYNOLDS in prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquors in the immediate vicinity of the polls.

ADAMS.--On Saturday, Dec. 11, JNO. S. ADAMS, of the firm of Best Adams. Funeral services to be held at his late residence, No. 32 West 15th-st., on Sunday, Dec. 12, at 4 o'clock P. M. His friends are respectfully invited to attend with out further notice. BENNETT.--On Friday evening, Dec. 10, GRACIE, youngest daughter of Webb and Jane M. Bennett, aged 9 months.

The Ecumenical Council has adjourned until after Epiphany, and much opposition, it is said, will be made to its reassembling; but the Pope expects to be supported by the American Bishops. France is reported to have made known to the Council that infallibility is inopportune religiously revived, and places that country politically otherwise than according to the Concordat, and frees her from obligations then accepted .... The Board met again yesterday at 11 A.M., Mr. HARDY in the chair. Protests were received from JOHN A. STEMMLER, candidate for the office of Civil Justice in the Seventh District, alleging that gross frauds have been perpetrated in the Nineteenth Election District of the Nineteenth Ward, and asking that the returns from that district be thrown out:

The increased temperature of Friday night and Saturday morning rendered the ice as soft as a new cheese and quite put a stop to all skating. On MACMILLAN's pond a few persons asaembled during the afternoon, and made an attempt to glide over the frozen surface, but it was found that the ice had melted for nearly an inch in depth, and that skating was quite out of the question.

Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning flames were seen issuing from one of the six two-story frame buildings, Nos. 814, 816, 818, 820, 822 and 824 First-avenue, and owing to the combustible character of the houses they were all totally consumed. They were owned by a Mr. VOLKENSBURG, whose loss is estimated at $8,000. Nos. 814 and 816 were unoccupied.

Black cashmere suits are considered in more refined style than even velvet this Winter. The material is far finer than any quality known of late years, as may be judged from the cost, which is $3 to $7 a yard, six to eight quarters in width.

It is quite clear that the Tipperary election has fallen like a bombshell in English political circles. The papers are full of it. Our London contemporaries think that the Tiperary voters, in returning a Fenian to Parliament, are flying in the face of Providence Here is Mr. GLADSTONE with his elaborate

The Chronicle in commenting on president GRANT 'S message, says it has broken down all hope of reciprocity, and renders annexation more desirable. It admits that annexation is impossible unless the whole Dominion asks for it, and believes independence will become the popular ery.

The Committee appointed by the Ten Hour Labor State Convention in September last have approved a bill for presentation to the Legislature, and petitions are now in circulation in the manufacturing districts urging its passage.

Yesterday afternoon Detective JAMES IRVING, of the Central Police, sailed for Europe on the steamer City of Paris, and that fact be coming known, caused inquiries to be made as to the reason of his voyage. inspector DILKS declared that he was only going as a witness in a civil suit in England, which was a consequence of an accident to a lady passenger which

WILLIAM DELONG, a young man, the son of a clergyman of this city, shot himself at Whitney's Point, a few miles from this city, yesterday, while in a sleigh returning from a hunting excursion. The shooting was accidental.

The arrangements for the first of a series of full-dress promenade concerts to be given by the Seventh Regiment are now complete, and the Music Committee announce that the concert will take place on Thursday evening next at the Academy of Music, when the band will number 100 performers. The tickets are limited to 1,200, each admitting a lady and gentleman, with 200 extra ladies tickets.

The following appeal has just been issued of the Republican electors of the Seventh Assembly District of this City: To the Republican Electors of the Seventh Assembly District: A reorganization of the Republican Party of this City is about to take place, under the sanction of the last State Convention, with a view to secure greater harmony, parity and efficiency in the party.

Some of the obscure followers of Tammany are so mortified to think that a few of the Ring nominations were defeated, that they are crying lustily for a new election. They appear to think that if SWEENEY or TWEED should only see fit to order a new election it would have to be held, and they promise themselves to organise repeaters enough next time to make a clean sweep of all the offices.

A somewhat remarkable discovery of human and animal remains has been communicated by Professor CAPELLISI, of Bologna, to the Guzetta delt Emilia. The Professor, on his return from Demark, whither he had gone to be present at the International Prehistoric Congress, was rendered so zealous by what be had heard there that he was induced to make many excursions in the neighborhood of Spezzia.

Returns from sixty-one countries give DAVIS 9, 077 majority. Twenty of sixty-one counties voted the Hamilton ticket. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 11.--Leave to bring in a bill looking to the encouragement of immigration was obtained in the Kentucky House of Representatives on Tuesday in the Senate.

Mr. DAVID HARRISON, of Fayette, Miss, has patented an invention to enable cars to be run with safety at great speed, and to give sure warning of their approach to a station, and to permit the ready ascension of steep grades. The adaptation of locomotive and track to the ascent of heavy grades is accomplished by placing toothed rads on the inner sides of the ordinary

STANTON PECKHAM, City Treasurer, of Newport, R. I., died on Friday morning. The Legislature of Georgia will meet in regular session in January. Eighteen families from Barbour County, Ala., are on their way to Texas. The Newburyport (Mass.) Herald boasts of a subscriber who has taken it uninterruptedly for fifty-two years.

We understand that the corporation of Yale College, at their last session, determined to raise the annual charge for tuition in the academical department to $30, after the present collegiate year. It is expected that this addition to the income of the College will enable the corporation of meet some pressing wants and make some of the advances in the means of education which are demanded,

Judge MONDELET gave a decision this morning that CALDWELL'S arrest in Ontario on a warrant issued by a Quebec Magistrate was legal. CALDWELL was then brought before Judge COURSOL. his counsel put in a plea that COURSOL had no right to try the cash; but that he tried in the province where he was arrested.

The arrangement with respect in the German-American telegraph cable, referred to yesterday, is that the concession from the North German Confederation of all telegrams for America not otherwise expressly directed by the sender to be sent by some other route, as well as the right to carry German and English messages, will be effected by a German -English Company shortly to be formed.

At Packard's building, yesterday, the organists held, as usual. their weekly meeting, the dancing bipeds being done by two or three reporters, (male) who, after a few cursory glances auto the tabooed procinets, were whisked out, sans ceremonie. Mrs. CHARLES PIERCE, of Boston, was present, and inaugurated business by demanding the reading of the minutes of the previous Saturday.

United States Commissioner SHIELDS received a complaint yesterday against two longshoremen, THOS. REDDEN and THOS. ROGERS, who were accused by Police Sergeant EDWIN O'BRIEN of stealing sails from the anchor Ahoy, a Government vessel. The property was represented to be worth $100. The accused claimed that they bought it on Staten Island for $35.

The Spectator to-day has an editorial on American affairs. The writer says that President GRANT'S programme, as announced in his recent Message to Congress, of peace, retrenchment, reconstruction and honesty, must enhance the position of the United States. Her way of paying debts was the last to be quarreled with....The Times,

The news which was telegraphed to us from England yesterday we had already given to the public more than a fortnight ago. We are now told that Lord CLARENDON will soon reopen negotiations for the settlement of the Alabama claims, but the information which we were enabled to give our readers is all that can be safely trusted.

M. DE LESSEPS has been appointed to the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor. Mr. HAYMAN succeeds Dr. TEMPLE as headmaster of Rugby. EUGENIR is said to be writing a journal of her Eastern tour. The Earl of DERBY left a fortune of ?? 100,000 a year.

WILLIAM WINTER IS a young man possessing in his own right and income of about $13, 000 per annum. He is by some considered insane, and by others, and those who know him best, as only a half idiot. It appears that he is defective in mental capacity, and that this misfortune has continued from childhood.

The consolidation of the Kingdom of Italy has proved to be a more difficult and protracted process than the violent struggle which attended its birth. With component parts so conflicting and so diverse, none of which has had influence enough to impress its distinctive characteristics upon the rest,

Rev. G. C. HEPBURN has assumed charge of an Episcopal Church on Fulton-avenue, Brooklyn, L. I. Rev. G. W. FREEMAN has accepted the appointment, from the Baptist Mission Society, of General Missionary along the line of the Pacific Railroad from Omaha to Sacramento.

Mr. JACOB LORILLARD, of this City, intends to found a Swiss village near Fordham Park, in Westchester County, eleven miles from the City Hall. The carrying out of this design will prove highly advantageous to a class of community that, hitherto, have been compelled to put up with insufficient accommodations at very high rents.

Steamship Deutschland, (N. G.,) Neynaber. Bremen Nov. 27, and Southampton 30, with indse, and 243 passengers to Oclrichs Co. Has had light westerly winds with rough sea the entire passage; Dec. 10, 211 miles east of Sandy Hook, passed steamship Weser, hence for Bremen.

This important case, new on the calendar of the Supreme Court for trail during the present week, will doubtless attract considerable attention. Dr. ABRAHAMS died in this City about a year ago, leaving a large estate, the greater portion of which he willed to various public charities, most of them prominent Jewish institutions.

A letter from Captain HALL, of the ship Orion, says nothing about the vessel being ashore, but that three men and two boys are all he can master to man the ship, the rest of the crew being down with scurvy. The vessel is short of provisions, and is leaking slightly.

A large mass meeting was held by the German independent organization of the Fourts Judicial District, (Tenth and Seventeenth Wards.) at the Harmony Rooms, No. 143 Essex-street, yesterday afternoon, Mr. HIGH GORSCH presiding, in order to give expression to their indignation at the frauds committed by Tammany Hall in the district at the late charter election. Yesterday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock tire was discovered in the basement under the office of the Excelsior Iron Works, owned by GEORGE R. JACKSON, BURNETT CO., and situated at Nos. 340-352 East Fourteenth-street, being 150 feet front by about 50 feet deep, and three stories high.
The Inman steamship City of Brooklyn, which left Liverpool on Dec. 2 and Queenstown on Dec. 3, reached this port yesterday. Her advices are later by three days than those at hand by Deutschland.

We differed so widely from Governor WELLS while the contest in Virginia was in progress, that we may now with greater freedom appland the wide, just, and eminently generous position he has assumed with regard to the admission of that State and the treatment of those of its citizens who still labor under political disabilities.

The tone of the President's Message and of the opening debates in Congress sufficiently indicate the future policy of the Republican party--if we may call that a policy which is rather an accident or the natural consquence of foregone events.

At St. Ann's Catholic Church, yesterday, Rev. THOMAS S. PRESTON discoursed on the "Catholic View of the School Question." The reverend gentleman remarked that he proposed to address them upon a question which agitated the community considerably at the present time, and which certainly was at all times a question of great importance for a nation and a republic situated. as this is. s.

The ice bed has been put in perfect order and everything is ready for freezing weather at the rink. The ice will be formed gradually over every part of the bed so as to freeze the earth solid for a sufficient depth to prevent the warmth from acting upward on the base of the ice,
At a late hour Saturday night Patrolman CANAVAN, of the Second Precinet, found a man asleep in a doorway of a store at the corner of Ann-street and Park-row, and arousing him told him to go home.

Our Washington correspondent confirms the impression, which we derive from various other sources, that the present session of Congress will be marked by a business-like spirit not always observable in former years. In the words of the old saying, we have too often been trented with great cry and little wool. This session we hope to see a change.

The municipal election to-morrow promises to be unusually liverly, there being four regular tickets in nomination, the Republican headed. Mayor SHURTLEFF, the Demcerats supporting BALDWIN for Mayor, the Labor Reform. CHASE, and the Temperance men JOHNSON.

The full dress promenade concert of the famous Seventh Regiment, National Guard, to take place at the Academy of Music next Thursday evening, promises to be a most brilliant affair. The band will number 109 performers;

The Republican Convention to nomination a candidate for senator in the Twenty-Sixth (Hon. CHARLES J. FOLGER'S) District, is to be held in Geneva on Friday next. The special election will take place on the 28th inst.

BALMER.--On Saturday, Dec. 11, ELLEN MARIA BALMER, daughter of James and Jane Balmer, aged 11 years. The relatives and friends of the family, and also those of her uncles, John and Joseph Fraser, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her parents, No. 28 Bond-st., Brooklyn, on Monday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

Whatever happens in Hayti is of interest to us here, for it is certain that during the present session of Congress important action will be taken by this country regarding the island of which Hayti forms part. But, meanwhile, there is a Indicrous feature in the lilliputian contests forever going on there, which gets the better of its graver aspect.

The real estate market has been exceedingly dull during the past week, except on election day, (Tuesday,) when an unusual amount of life was exhibited at the Exchange Rooms, and quite a large number of sales was effected, especially of Prospect Park lots in Brooklyn, disposed of by MALLORK BLACKWELL.

It is strictly accurate to say that the reception of the President's Message by Congress has been marked by a spirit of hearty concurrence and general satisfaction such as has not been exhibited since the last Message of Mr. LINCOLN. It has brought back the days of happy accord, and completed harmony between Congress and the Administration, which result must inevitably be felt throughout the country.

Rev. JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, D.D., preached last evening in the Tabernacle, corner of Thirtyfourth-street and Sixth-avenue, on " The Council at Rome, and its relation to the whole Church." The doctor began by saying that the Council at Rome was not in any proper sense an Ecumenical Council. but a Latin Council, inasmuch as the Greek Church bears no part in It.
The steamship Alaska, which left Aspinwall Dec. 3, reached this port yesterday. She brings the specie referred to in the subjoined TREASURE LIST.

There can no longer be any doubt that the rumor of a projected alliance between Russia, France, and Austria has engaged the serious attention of every Cabinet and Court in Europe. The report was dismissed with an "uninformed sneer" by one of our contemporaries when we published it on the authority of our correspondent at St. Petersburg.

Yesterday afternoon Rev. FREDERICK EVANS, late of Hyde Park, was installed as Pastor of the the Laight-street Baptist Church, which has long been without a regular pastor. After singing aad prayer, Rev. Dr. SHEDD delivered a a sermon on the text-" Thou Art the Man."

Saturday morning JAMES BOCKLIN, a lamplighter, found the dead body of a female infant on the corner of Seventy-eigth-street and Second-avenue. The body was removed to the Morgue where Dr. WOOSTER BEACH made a post mortem examination which showed that the infant was of full size and had been born alive and with healthy organs.

The public scarcely need to be reminded that the Homeopathic Hospital inaugural takes place at the Union League Club Theatre on Tuesday evening next. Artistic talent of the highest order will aid to make the occasion one worthy of being participated in. Miss KELLOGG, who has volunteered for the occasion, by special request will also sing "Home, Sweet Home."

A dispatch from Paris says that the Pope has issued a decree, providing that in case of his death the Ecumenical Council shall be dissolved and none but Cardinals take part in the choice of a successor. The Ecumenical Council has adjourned until after Epiphany, and much opposition, it is said, will be made to is reassembling;

The December Iron Works, at the foot of West Thirteenth and Fourteenth streets, yesterday were the scene of great excitement and bustle. At an early hour in the morning the Spanish contractors, headed by captain ARRAGON, came to the premises to superintend the out-fitting and towing of the eighteen vessels from the wharf to the stream.

FAIR HARVARD: A story of American College life. Now-York: G. P. PUTNAM SON. London: S. LOW, SON MARSTON. 1869. This book purports to do for Harvard what tom Brown did for Oxford. We shall take occasion to print out certain differences between the English university system and our own,

T. M. MAHON, who was recently elected President of the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad, publishes a card to-day, warning all persons against buying bonds of, paying money to, or making contracts with any of the old officers or directors who now have possession of that road.

"Pipele" is to be sung at the Academy of Music this evening. "Ernestine" and "Trying It On" will be acted for the first time at Wallack's. "Don Caesar De Bazau" will be rendered, with the afterpiece of "A. Poor Goose," at the Fifth avenue Theatre. At Booth's, "The Merry Wives of Windsor" will be given.

All the newspapers of this City have stated, with some particularity, the singular circumstances attending the recent alleged suicide at the New--York Hotel, and De. WILLIAM SHINE, the deputy of Coroner FLYNN, has been brought into some notoriety in connection with the official irregularities accompanying the affair.

Rev. Dr. O. B. FROTHINGHAM preached yesterday morning on "The Foes of Society." These he divided into two groups, hot blooded and cold blooded. placing the passionate people. lawbreakers and rowdies among the first mentioned. and the upper class Pharisees, leaders of society, self-righteous people, among the latter class.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: We desire to inform the public through your columns that the statue now on exhibition at Wood's Museum is a plaster cast taken from the original by C. F. OTTO. an artist of Syracuse, without our knowledge and consent.

Some thirty days ago General W. T. CLARK, late Adjutant-General of McPHERSON, during the war, and now member of Congress from TEXAS, came to this City and stated to Mr. J. P. LINDSAY that unless he could secure a printing press the Republican Party would be defeated in the State of Texas.

The real estate market continues exceedingly dull. There were no public sales at the Exchange Rooms yesterday, and private negotiations were difficult and unprofitable. To-day there will be a little more life. JAMES M. MILLER sells some valuable property in Westchester County, and three lots on Seventy-sixth-street,

The New-Jersey Central Railroad Company has for some time past been driving piles and filling in soil from the Jersey City shore toward the centre of the Hudson River, with a view to the construction of a long pier.

The case of BARTON M. JOHNSON, who is under arrest on a charge of having had felonious possession of a quantity of stolen United States bonds, was yesterday examined into by both Justice DOWLING and Justice HOGAN, they having separate cognizance of the case.

The progress of the work at this chamel of the harbor is watched by the commercial part of the community with much interest. Al Hallett's Pont the Government is pushing matters in good earnest, as an inspection of the work there shows. The coffer dam grows deeper every day, the rock being removed at the rate of about 2,000 enble feet per month.

A fire broke out in the blind factory of Massrs. NILES LONGHEAD Co. last night. The building is a total loss. One hundred thousand feet of lumber adjoining were burned to ashes. The value of the building, stock, machinery and lumber was $35,000. Insurance $25,000 in home companies.

If "hard times" are at hand, as many believe, it must be remembered that we have had very little of them for many years. To our own surprise and that of the world, we finished a tremendous civil war without anysevere financial disasters.

The following is the vote of Boston to-day for Mayor : SHURTLEFF. 11.293 ; BALDWIN, Democrat, 4,197 : CHASE, Labor Reform, 197 ; JOHNSON, Temperance, 312 ; majority for SHURTLEFF, 6,587. The City Council will be largely Republican...EDWIN WALDEN,

Dec. 13, Mrs. LUCINDA C. COBB, relict of the late Ebenezer D. Cobb, of New-York, in the 72d year of her age.

The Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH opened the Reichsrath to-day with a speech from the throne. He favored a conciliatory course in dealing with the Dalmatian insurection; dwelt upon the peaceful appearance of European affairs with satisfaction;

HENRY ERBEN has just completed an organ for the Baptist Church at Yonkers, and presented to that church by Messrs. COLGATE and TREVOR. The cost of the Instrument is about $10,000, and it possesses all the qualities for which the Erben organs are noted.

A boy named McGAVERNER was terribly beaten and stabbed on Saturday night, by two rutilans named GERVIN and HICKS, and was left in an almost lifeless condition on a cellar door. No cause is assigned for the assault.

The reception of the remains of the late GEORGE PEABODY on board the Iron-clad Monarch took place on Saturday. Although it was intended that the proceedings should be privately conducted, they were attended by an interesting demonstration of respect.

The case in which WILLIAM WINTER applies for a substitution of trustee of his estate, was again before Judge BARNARD yesterday on a continuance of the motion. The case has been frequently before the courts in litigations of various forms, continuing through years, and presenting some features out of the ordinary course of legal proceedings.

The Union Republican General Committee met at the corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway last evening, Mr. JOHN R. GRIDLEY in the chair. The Finance Committee reported favorably on the annual report of IRA O. MILLER, Treasurer, which was unanimously accepted and ordered to be placed on file.

The gols panie and gold frauds of September last are to be investigated by the House Banking committee, which owes to Congress and the people a thorough exposure of the iniquity. The inquiry institated by the Grand Jury here enede in smoke.

Yesterday morning the investigation in the case of GEORGE L. CHAMBERS, of Astoria, charged with the malicious shooting of JOHN MYERS, Jr., ?? the 24th of September, came up for examinator before Justice SNEDEKER, in Jamaica.
There is a pleasant prospect for Winter. Not only have we more than the average number and variety of thieves to cope with, but our chosen protectors are turning against us.

Some four weeks ago Messrs. H. G. STEBBINS SON moved from No. 44 Broad-street to No. 50 Exchange-place, selling their lease on the building and their old office furniture to W. E. GRAY Co. The new occupants at once moved in and commenced business as brokers, and apparently very successful ones.

The remains of the late Mr. PEABODY were removed on board the British man-of-war Monarch, on Saturday, at Portsmouth, and were consigned to the care of Captain COMMERELL, the commander of the vessel, by Mr. MOTLEY, the United States Minister, in behalf of the relatives and executors of Mr. PEABODY.

We have been favored by the politeness of HERR ALBERT HUG, one of the strongest chess players of the City of Mannheim, with one of three games played by correspondence between that city and Barmen, which lasted nearly a year and was recently concluded.

On Saturday the New-York Harbor Police met with some parties in small rowboats loaded with various rigging articles, near Staten Island, and on inquiring where they got those things, learned that they had bought them from a tugboat they pointed out to the officers. The tugboat was identified as belonging to the Navy Yard.

Yesterday the Supreme Court at General Term rendered a decision in the case of the People vs. JOHN REAL, who was tried and convicted in February last, in the Oyor and Terminer, for the murder of Officer SMEDICK, Judge BARNARD presiding.

Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning the heavens were overspread here and there with the brilliant red variety of the northern lights. The auroral light mingling at times with the morning twilight produced a grand effect. It is confidently expected that sooner or later the wonderful auroral exhibitions of 1835 will yet again recur.

WILLIAM HIGGINS, a passenger on board of the steamer Alaska during a voyage between Aspinwall and this port, appeared before United States Assistant District-Attorney PURDY yesterday for the purpose of securing the prosecution of the JOHN McCORMACK on a charge of larceny on the high seas.

A special dispatch from Houston, Texas, says: "Returns from eighty-seven counties received show that HAMILTON'S (Conservative) majority in forty-five counties is 9,970. DAVIS' (Radical) majority in forty-two counties is 12,332. DAVIS, in thirty-five counties, is 72 ahead. There are forty counties to be heard from.

The Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair. The only resolutions adopted were to lay the Nicolson pavement in Thirty-ninth-street, from Third to Lexington-avenue, and in Fifty-Fifth street, from Fifth to Sixth-avenue. The Board then adjourned.

The trial of WM. DICKEY for the murder of his wife and THOMAS CAHOUN at Bombay Hook, was commenced in the Bergen County Court of Oyer and Terminer at Hackensack, N. J., before Judge BEDLE yesterday. The murders were committed on the night of the 6th of November last, in the house of the prisoner, near Closter Landing, opposite Yonkers.

"DORA BELLA." , AT WOOD'S MUSEUM. Wood's Museum was last night the scene of a crowded house and of much excitement. The attractions may be said to have been three-fold, and to have consisted of the the Blondes, the Wild Animals and the Stone Man.

EUGENE HENRY CHARFOURNIER, a native of France aged 34, has for some months occupied a room at No. 10 Laurens-street. He was in the employ of TIFFANY Co., jewelers, in Broadway. He was last seen alive by his associates on Saturday afternoon, and failed to make his appearance yesterday.

Its is evident that the recommendation of the President to continue the income tax for three years longer, at a reduced rate, will form the subject of a warm contest, both in and out of Congress. Journals which very seldom hold the same opinions agree in denouncing what they cal the most obnoxious of all imposts.

The sixty-fourth annual meeting of the New-England Society in the City of New-York, for the election of officers and transaction of business, was held last evening at Delmonico's at 7:30 o'clock, ISAAC GREEN PEARSON presiding. Tho Treasurer's report was submitted, and showed that the funds of the Society amount to $32,321 59.

Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday at No. 117 Charles-street over the remains of Mrs. MARGARET GALLICKER, who died from the effect of injuries caused on the 10th inst. by the explosion of a can of burning fluid, known as "Union Oil," while filling a lamp. The oil was obtained on the corner of Greenwich-avenue and West Twelfth-street, from a Mr. RAPPELYE.

Letters received here from well-informed persons abroad show that Mr. BURLINGAME has been triumphantly successful in his negotiations with the European Powers. His great struggle was in England, where an established plicy had to be abandoned by lier Majesty's Ministers to meet his views.

The examination in the case of JAMES R. HOBBY, Jr., a mail carrier, charged by Special Agent GAYLOR, of the Post Office Department, with embezzlement and secreting letters, was conducted before United States Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday.

A good deal of discussion is being had throughout tile State upon the question of when the new Judiciary article of the Constitution goes into effect. In the course of it a doubt has even been raised as to whether the article has been adopted at all, owing to various alleged irregularities in the mode by which its confirmation has been arrived at.

The Bishops congregated in Rome have brought a great number of addresses and presents to the Pope. The reported loss of extraordinary sums of money upon altered securities by banks and bankers illustrates a species of fraud of frequent recareence within recent years. It is not at all probable that this the last development of the sort which our capitalists will be called upon to contemplate, for there is a large supply of stolen bonds on the market.

The trial of SAMUEL GASTON, in Bucks County, Penn., for the murder of WM. BROWN, a colored man, at a negro camp meeting on the west bank of the Delaware, oppostite Trenton, commenced in the Court of Oyer and Terminer on Friday last, and was concluded on Monday night.

Louisville claims a negro child with ten fingers on each hand. There is talk of a union of all the railroads between Boston and Bangor. A great many "well-known citizens" of Boston die. The boot, shoe and leather trade of NowEngland are about to organize a Board of Trade.
An adjustment is about to be made of the great Howland will case, which will enable the executors to proceed as soon as practicable to the payment in full of all the legacies given by the will.

The Cold spell on Monday and last evening revised the skating amusement on some of the open rinks, and the capitoline and fifth-avenue rinks were yesterday patronized by numerous votaries of this fascinating outdoor recreation.

The theatre of the Union League Club was filled with a fashionable audience of ladies and gentlemen last evening on the occasion of the inaugural ceremonies of the Halmemann Hospital, an institution recently organized in this City, located in East Fifty-fifth-street, and under the management of homeopathists.

Rome, Dec.14.,--The Bishops have brought a great number of addresses and presents to the Pope from the faithful in all parts of the world. It is officially stated that since 1859 the Holy See has received 100,000,000 francs from the contributions of Peter's pence....The Empress EUGENIE has written a letter to the Pope expressing her regret at not being able to visit His Holiness.

A gathering of the friends of female suffrage is in session in this city. The meeting this morning was called to order by S. S. FOSTER, and Judge HENRY CHAPIN was chosen President. JULIA WARD HOWE made an address on the general subject of "Women Suffrage."

The Spanish gunboats in the North River are fully manned and every possible means is being taken to get them ready for sea. Yesterday the engineers for the vessels signed a contract "for service on board steamships of the Spanish National Navy." It is printed both in English and Spanish.

To-day the Senate discussed, without definite action, the Omnibus Railroad bill. It proposes to issue State bonds to the amount of several millions of dollars, for which the State is to hold the indorse to the extent of several millions more the bonds of several other roads,

The National Convention of Petroleum Refiners met yesterday morning, at 10:30 o'clock, at the Merchants' Exchange and News Rooms, in Pine-street, for the purpose of considering and acting upon such matters as might come before them affecting the general interests of the trade. In effecting a temporary organization, Mr. O. H. PAYNE, of Cleveland, was called to the Chair.

Governor HOFFMAN is expected in town this week, when the question as to who is to fill the vacancy on the Bench of the Court of Common Pleas, caused by the transfer of Judge BRADY to the Supreme Court., will be definitely decided. There are many aspirants for the place, some of them tit and others totally untit--the latter class far outnumbering the former.

Yesterday morning the long-anticipated Convention for reapportioning the basis of representation in future Congressional and Senatorial Conventions, was convened in Jamaica. Suffolk County was represented by six delegates, headed by H. A. REEVES, M. C.; Queen's County was represented by eight delegates, headed by STEPHEN TABER, Ex-M. C.;

Mr. MORRIS S. HILL, late Cashier of the Farmers' and Drovers' National Bank of Somers, Westchester County, was brought before Justice E. P. FERRIS, at White Plains, yesterday, on a charge of having embezzled $30,000 belonging to the bank.

A new monthly journal is announced to be published by the Young Men's Christian Association. At the Convention of the Associations of the United States and British Provinces, held in Portland last May, a resolution was passed authorizing the General Executive Committee to provide for the publication of such a periodical, the first number of which will appear in January,

Late intelligence from the Eastern Department has been received in this city, giving accounts of several skirmishes which lately took place between the troops and the insurgents near the towns of Santiago de Cuba, El Cobre and Holguin.

No doubt these new postage stamps will be a novelty--especially it they stick. This little point has been a good deal neglected lately. A postage stamp is not of any great use unless it will adhere to an envelope, but the Post Office authorities have altogether overlooked that small matter.

The case of CALDWELL, who was committed for extradition, has been again before the Court. Judge COURSOL ruled that the decision of Judge MONDELET, on the application to him for a writ of habeas corpus, was final, so far as he (Judge COURSOL) was concerned, and therefore he dismissed the motion for the prisoner's discharge.

A Very important order and injunction relating to the lottery business has just come to light. It emanates from a Justice of the Supreme Court of this City. having been granted on the 6th Inst. The Complainant in the matter is Hon. JOHN MORRISSEY. Copies of the order and injunction have been served on many of the managers,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your journal of Saturday contained a pungent article entitled " The Public Indictment of the Bar," which, like others that have lately appeared, none too early or too fearlessly called public attention to dangers of the gravest character connected with our judicial administration, and to facts not at all flattering to the legal profession.

For some time past the officers connected with the United States Secret Service Division have been quietly engaged in the task of discovering the whereabouts of a certain gang of counterfeiters concerned in the manufacture and sale of revenue stamps.

In the Bergen County Court of Over and Terminer, Judge BEDLE presiding, on Monday the trial of WILLIAM DICKEY for the under of his wife and her alleged paramour was commenced; but an adjournment was necessitated by the absence of witnesses.

The Evening Journal mentions a rumored defalcation of some $50,000 at the Howard National Bank. The defalcation was discovered during an official examination of the affairs of the bank by the Government Commissioner.

The most zealous advocate of continuing the burdens upon materials for shipbuilding can have no reply to the starting facts which are brought to bear upon the subject. It is not only that the shipping interest has been almost destroyed, but that no new legislation tending to relieve it can effect the purpose except slowly, and after a considerable period.

An unknown man, about 48 years of age, threw himself in front of the Washington train on the New-Jersey Railroad, near Metuchin, on Monday afternoon. The locomotive was reversed when the conductor became aware of the evident intention of the man to commit suicide,

At the close of the disastrous campaign of 1866, the dismemberment of the Austrian Empire appeared to the complete. Her Italian possessions and her power and influence in Germany were cut off forever, and among all the fifteen constituent nationalities of her remaining provinces scarcely one was sincerely interested in the reconstruction of the shattered State.

The steamship Rapidan, from Havana Dec. 8, reached this port yesterday. by the courtesy of Purser OSCAR CROCHERON, our special correspondence, later by six days than that already received, came duly to hand.

Officers MOORE and MOOREHEAD this morning attempted to arrest WILLIAM . alias Snibbs, ARNOLD and LEONARD HARTMEN, professional thieves, who drew their revolvers and resisted. MORE was shot through the shoulder, and MOOREHEAD in the head. The wound of the latter is dangerous.

The Committee on Supplies of the Board of Education have been engaged for the last two days in opening and examining bids for supplies to the Board for the coming year. There were sixty bidders altogether, or three times as many as list year. The average prices were ten per cent. lower than last year.

The Society of the Sixth Army Corps, which was formed last Summer in this City, met yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, and organized itself into a permanent body. MajorGeneral H. G. WRIGHT presided as temporary Chairman.

The Hospital for Incurables, on Blackwell's Island, is a most worthy institution, in which many unfortunates, of both sexes, are yearly provided with the bare necessities of life. At present there are upward of one hundred inmates, many of them paralytics or rhenmatics.

The merchants of Paterson having determined to test the legality of the increase by the Eric Railway Company, of charges for transportation of freight under "terminal express," have placed in the hands of their counsel, General Thos. De. HOXSEY, about three hundred bills, upon each of which an action will be commenced to recover a penalty of $100 for each extortion.

GEORGE P. BARLOW, of Florida, was found dead in bed at the Terra Haute House this morning, having committed suicide be taking laudanum. He left the following letter: DEAR FATHER: Tell by younger brother to beware of the dissipated course which has caused my death Yours ever. (Signed) GEORGE.

The long-expected nomination of Attorney-General HOAR to the vacancy on the Supreme Bench was sent to the Senate to-day. Judge HOAR'S distinguished abilities are universally conceded, and his elevation to the Supreme Bench is received with profound satisfaction by all, and by none more than by those who have business with the Attorney-General's Office.

The report of the Commissioner of Agriculture is completed. In the opening the Commissioner says the year has been one of vicissitude; of mingled constancy and change: of general fruitfulness and local blight; of general sun and fructifying rains, with periods of drought and inflictions of destroying tempest and deluging flood.

To the Editor of the New-York Tuners: When the Free Trade League denounces everything that bears the name or semblance or protection, the TIMES blames its extreme course. and counsels moderation and compromise. When the league does so far modify its views as to adopt those of Commissioner WELLS, the TIMES not only does not praise it, but actually blames Mr. WELLS in advance for being indorsed by it.

During the night of the 12th inst. the saloon No. 732 Broadway was entered by burglars, who used false keys, and their escape with a coat, cap, fur collar. Detective REILLEY of the Fifteenth Precinct after considerable labor, found the coat with one CUDLIP, No. 521 East Twelfth-street, where it had been pawned by TIMOTHY OAKS.

Sugared pop-corn poisoned a man in portland, Me. Ontario's share of the Dominion debt is catimated at $5,849\0,000, and Quebec's share at $4,660,000. First cousins in New-Hampshire have five days in which to marry. The law forbids them after the 21st.

EDWARD PRATT, the Quartermaster of the Anchorhoi, who was arrested by the Harbor Police the other day on the charge of being implicated in defrauding the Government and subsequently discharged for want of evidence, upon returning to the Yard was discharged from his position.

The attention of Colonel FRANK E. HOWE. special agent of the Treasury Department, was first directed to the frauds practiced at the Appraiser's Department in this City in the udervaluation and underweighing of imported sugars by receiving a personal letter from Secretary BOUTWELL, dated on the 20th of July last, in which mention was made of certain complaints made by several Philadelphia and Boston sugar merchants.

General SHERIDAN, on taking the chair at the annual reunion of the Army of the Cumberland, in Indianapolis on Wednesday, was greeted with round after round of applause. When quiet was restored he said:

Professor YOUMANS delivered the fifth of the series of lectures being delivered before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New-York, at Steinway Hall, last evening. Previous to the lecture Mr. G. SCHMITZ, organist to st. Patrick's Cathedral, performed a voluntary on the organ. The Professor said he proposed to consider the unity of the universe on the side of thought.

A special meeting of the members of the Chamber of Commerce was convened at 1 o'clock yesterday, for the purpose of considering the reports submitted to the last meeting on the subjeet of the decline of American commerce. At the request of the Chairman, Hon. WM. E. DODGE, a communication from the New-York Association for the Resuscitation of American shipping Interests, was read by the Secretary.

The Prospect Park Commissioners in their last annual report recommended that the City Park of Brooklyn be improved by being changed into a public market where the produce of Long Island might be brought for the accommodation of the people, so as to avoid the necessity of making pilgrimages to New-York to purchase the cereals that pass their own door on the way thither.

The Cunard steamship Siberia, which left Liverpool Dec. 4 and Queenstown Dec. 5, arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices are later by one day than those at hand by the Ville de Paris on Tuesday. A Paris dispatch announces that M. BERTHEMY is about to return to his post as Minister Potentiary of France to Washington. n.

Flynn, vice Y. B. Knight, removed; Messenger, $800 per annum, I. C. Lane, vice J. A. Flynn, promoted: Clerk, First Division...

To-day was the first approach to a field-day in the House that we have yet had. Repudiation, flat-footed and undisguised, came to the surface where it was to have been expected--in the ranks of the Democratic Party.

The G. T. Trimble Association, composed of these who graduated from Public School No. 7 while JOHN W. KETCHUM was Principal--that is, from 1856 to 1846--held its second-annual meeting yesterday. Owing to the very end weather, the attendance was small. It was decided to have their annual dinner on or about the last Tuesday of January, and probably at the St. James Hotel.

The officers and members of the Seventh Regiment, National Guard, gave a full dress promenade concert and hop, last evening, at the Academy of Music. Despite the storm and fog, the affair was a decided and grand success, as is usual with the Seventh, the arrangements for the concept having been made on the most lavish and extensive scale.

At the Exchange, yesterday, several sales were made of City and Brooklyn property, at what was generally regarded as rather low figures. The premised No. 346 West Twenty-sixth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, with four-story house in front and three-story house on the rear of the lot, and a yard between the two, were sold by WM. KENNELLY for $14,600.

During the entertainment at the Adelphi Theatre Comique Saturday evening, one of the WATSON BROTHERS, gymnasts, fell while performing their feat called "The Three Flying Men." To the Editor of the New-York Times: In 1865 and 1866 all honest men desired individual as well as national economy, and as a general thing a return to specie payments; and in those two years, when gold wont down to frown 25 to 28, the great mass of prudent business men sold and bought mostly for cash.

Dr. HALL, rector of the church, conducted the services, and delivered a brief address to the relatives and friends in attendance. A meeting of the workingmen of the City was held last evening at the masonic Hall, Thirteenth-street, for the purpose of considering the question of cheap labor. Mr. NELSON W. YOUNG presided. Resolutions were adopted strongly protesting against the importation of Chinamen into the country by the American Immigrant Society, to the injury of the working classes, and calling on Congress to take measures for is prevention.

In the case of SEYMOUR F. SMITH, bankrupt, Judge HALL, of the United States District Court, yesterday decided that the making of a general assignment without preferences by an insolvent debtor was an act of bankruptcy ;

On the 7th of December last, Messrs. HENRY WILSON and CHARLES PHILLIPS were arrested by United States Detective NETTLESIHP, of Newark, charged with selling liquor, at No. 20 Bank-street, Newark without license. They were held to bail in $1,000 each for trail.

Corner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday, at No. 227 West Twenty-first-street, over the remains of SIMON FLEIG, a German, who died yesterday under very peculiar circumstances. He was locked up for intoxication on Tuesday night by the Twenty-ninth Precnet Police, and in some unexplained manner had his neck broken.

General BUTLER's letter in defence of the policy of proscription is an exceedingly able and adroit specimen of special pleading on a subject in which any special pleading, however able and adroit, is altogether out of place. That he is very caustic upon Mr. GREELEY, is quite certain ;

The case of Patrolmen TREADWELL W. REMSEN and JAMES HANNIGAN, of the Twenty-second Precinct, charged with highway robbery upon the person of GEORGE W. WELLS, as previously reported, came up again yesterday before Commissioners BOSWORTH and MANIERRE to hear testimony for the defence.

In the Corps Legislatif today Deputy ESTANCELIN expressed admiration for the Orleans Princes and regretted their continued banishment. M. FORCADE DELA ROQUETTE, Minister of the Interior, protested against these remarks. M. ESTANCELIN denounced the policy of the Government with much warmth.

The Army of the Cumberland Society was called to order at 10 o'clock this morning, by the Chairman, General SHERIDAN. General FULLERTON, from the Committee on Finance, reported a resolution favoring an investment of the funds in Government bonds, which was adopted.

Dr. OLIVER, an Englishman of prominence, was shot and killed at 7 o'clock this morning by GEORGE AYERS, of Fauquier, who charged him with having seduced his daughter while visiting his house some months ago.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday. Mr. COMAN in the chair. The resignation of JAMES O'BRIEN (the present Sheriff) as a member of the Board from the Fifteenth District, was accepted as and a resolution was adopted designation RICHARD CROCKNER to ?? the vacancy caused by Mr. O'BRIEN'S resignation.

Hon. NATHANIEL G. UPHAM, who died on the 11th inst., at his residence for many years, in Concord, N. H., was born in 1801, and graduated in 1820 at Dartmouth College, from which he received the degree of LL.D. At the age of 27 he was named one of the Judges of the Superior Court of his native State.

The two Houses of the Legislature met at 12 o'clock to-day, in joint session. On the first ballot for United States Senator, STEVENSON received sixty-six votes; MCCREERY, fifty-nine; FINLEY, ten, and BECK, one. The joint session then adjourned till 3 o'clock P. M., to give MCCREERY'S friends time for consultation.

A tremendous shock was caused by an explosion of the glycerine magazine of the Roberts Torpedo Company, containing hall a ton of glycerine. The cause of the explosion is unknown. P. H. BROPHY, the agent, and another man, who was near the magazine at the time of the explosion, were instantly killed.

Repudiation was very emphatically repudiated in the House yesterday, and that, too, by Democratic members. Mr. MUNGEN, of Ohio, stood solitary and alone in his advocacy of a Republic, and the rights of its creditors. His Democratic associates, or the more prominent of them, lost no time in discarding the heresy, and pledging their party to the honest payment of the debt.

At the recent banquet at tho City of Mexico in honor of Mr. SEWARD, sentiments were interchanged which show a much more cordial feeling on the part of Mexico towards the United States than seemed to exist a very few years ago.

Another case of public frauds was yesterday exposed in which an old and honored Government officer, of highly respectable family, is charged with being the guilty party. The person under suspicion is Mr. GEORGE F. DUNNING, a resident of Brooklyn, for the past ten years an all ache of the Sub-Treasury, and more recently acting as Superintendent of the Assay Office.

Reports from Oregon indicate that the taxes are being collected much more easily this year thanusual, because money is abundant. It is pleasant to read this of Oregon. The Cleveland Herald reports that the Democratic leaders in that State are endcavoring to secure the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment through the votes of the Hamilton County independendent memebers of the Legislature.

News has just reached here from private sources that Colonel DENNIS, Surveyor-General, has succeeded in raising and arming a force of 200 Swamp Indians, and a number of their English half-breed relations. Governor McDOUGALL has also raised a force of Sioux at Portage and La Prairie, under Canadian officers.

The only sales at the Exchange yesterday were of Mulberry-street property by order of the Supreme Court, under the direction of D. R. INGRAHAM, Jr., referce. Two lots, each having a four-story brick house in front and threestory brick house in the rear, brought $8,000 over and above a mortgage of $25,000, which was assumed by the purchaser.

The Picayune, in a compilation of Mexican news, lately published, had a paragraph announcing that the banner of CORTEX, the renowned conqueror of the Aztecs, had been discovered in the municipal palace at Tlascala. This is no discovery.

The charge of highway robbery preferred by GEO. W. WELLS against Patrolmen TREAD-WELL W. REMSEN and JAMES HANNIGAN, of the Twenty-second precinct Station, came on yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder HACKETT.

WILLIAM II. WHIMSTER, whose name has become notorious in connection with the great drawback frauds, surrendered himself to the officers of the law yesterday morning. For some time past he has been a fugitive form justice, several sharp allache's of the Marshal's office having sought in vain to capture him.

Every item of news must nowadays be made tributary to sensationalism. Eflect is everything. If an ordinary business failure occurs, it is magnified into a serious disaster. If half a dozen failures, all of them of the common class. can be grouped together, they are paraded as a sign of "the coming crash."

The Considerable Convention closed its sittings at Albany on the 28th of February, 1869.
