Our correspondent "Angelico," at Florence, writes: "The American colony here in Florence is once more well established, come back for the Winter season from the four winds of Europe and America. Our Minister and Mrs. MARSH have not yet returned after their prolonged absence, but are soon expected.

From figures furnished by the State Comptroller, it seems that the assessment of real and personal property in all the counties of California, for the current fiscal year, aggregate $258,040,335, if no mistake has been made in addition. The Alta figures out a net gain over the previous year of $21,105,880.

One hundred and seven counties heard from give DAVIS a majority of 1,128. The counties to hear from have an aggregate white majority of 2,000. The vote for Governor is so close that it will require the official count to decide. The Conservatives claim a majority in the Legislature on a joint ballot.

An indictment against DANIEL McFARLAND, the assassin of ALBERT D. RICHARDSON for murder in the first degree, was presented yesterday by the Grand Jury in the Court o General Sessions. The prisoner will be arraigned to answer some day next week, but there is no immediate prospect of a trial being had in the ease.

Christmas is drawing nigh not under the most cheerful circumstances that could be imagined. People generally are anxious to retrench their expenditure rather than to launch out into extravagence. There will be fewer costly presents given away this year than usual.

CORNELISON.--At Bergen, N.J., on Thursday, Dec. 16, ALETTA, wife of Dr. J.M.Cornelison. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, on Monday, the 20th inst., at 2 o'clock.

Early in the year 1857 there was published in the Republican a thrilling narrative entitled "The La Paz Sufferers," telling of the capture of a number of American citizens by the Mexican authorities and their brantal treatment. The article was copied from a Mexican paper shortly after the release of the captives from bendage.

In 1868 the whalers commenced to arrive on the 1st of October, and during that month twenty-eight vessels arrived, reporting 946 barrels sperm, 19,515 barrels whale oil and 254,500 pounds hone. Total value at Consular prices, about $365,000.

A large number of the members of both Houses of the Legislature paid a visit to Mrs. JAMES K. POLK yesterday afternoon, in compliance with a resolution adopted by both Houses of the General Assembly. They formed in procession at the Capital at 4 P. M., about 100 in number, and marched two by two to the residence, corner of Union and Vine streets.

The President's Message has been well received here among all classes. There is not, of course, an entire unanimity in regard to all his recommendations, but, on the contrary, a sharp dissent from some of them. The questions of the most interest are those relating to finance, and there continues to be a degree of feverish anxiety in the public mind in relation to the future.

Several schooner loads of granite have arrived for the pillars of the new Post Office, and the masons will go to work again next week setting them. About a hundred men are now engaged on the grounds. At the north end a huge pile of stone for the concrete to be laid over the entire area has been accumulated.

The "Marseillaise" is to be restored to the military bands of France. Prince CORSTCHAKOFF, Chancellor of the Russian Empire, is seriously ill. English marriage notices read, "A marriage is arranged to take place," Attempts are being made to raise a subscription for a statue to RAPHAEL, at Urbino, Italy.

When I speak of the West, it is of the Central West, for the West, in literal meaning, is beyond the Rocky Mountains. The Central West may be defined as that whole region which lies in the Ohio Valley and on the Central Mississippi, comprehending about twelve States, and in the next census will be found to have nearly half the population of the United States.

To attempt to refund our debt abroad, without reforming our loose habits at home, implies the continuance of the heavy taxation which was never before paralleled in time of peace and has been justly compared to the consuming of the seed corn which should be reserved for future sustenance and growth.

The particulars of the wreck of the Anchor line steamship Grecian, Capt. NICHOLS, are as follows: She was bound to New-York from Palermo, in Sicily, with a cargo of fruit and marble, and made the land on the evening of the 13th of this month near Jones' Inlet, Long Island. During the night a heavynortheaster spring up which drove the vessel ashore.

Had he contented himself with journalism, he would have made his paper far more conspicuous, far more representative of American journalism, even, than it has become.

For some time past there has been a great deal of speculation as to the character of the work going on beneath Broadway, between DEVLIN Co.'s clothing store, opposite the City Hall, and the new Post Office grounds.

When Mr. ASHELY was nominated Governor of Montana, all but his adhereuts felt that a grievous mistake had been committed. The President, having at length arrived at the same conclusion, has offered the only atonement in his power by putting Mr. ASHLEY aside and appointing General POTTS in his place.

The movements of the German labor and trades' unions are growing in importance from day to day, and their operations are continually extending, as will be seen from a project which has been set on foot lately. It is the projected erection of a Workingmen's Hall or Institute on a grand scale,

The First Battalion of Havana Volunteers has gone to Vuelta-Abajo to relieve the Second Battalion, whose term of active service has expired. Two men charged with taking part in the assassination of two volunteers, were executed yesterday, in the town of Laguinillas. The Spanish man-of-war Isabel sailed to-day for New-York.

A fearful accident occurred in the Briggs mine yesterday, about 3 o'clock. A stall, we believe the third from the bottom, gave way, and fell on the one below, when it, too, gave way, and with both their loads of rock fell upon a new one just being put in. Several men were under it, and three were Instantly killed and four severely wounded.

Yesterday LAWRENCE BUCKLEY, a teacher in the Public School in Twenty-seventh-street, between Second and Third avenues, was arraigned before Jurstice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on a charge of brutally assaulting JAMES H. DE WITT, one of his pupils, aged 14 years, whose parents reside at No. 417 East Twenty-fourth-street.

ALBERT CARRICHER, a resident of Charleston, S.C., Who is temporarily in this City, and stopping at the Westchester House, corner of Bowery and Broome-street, on Thursday evening ventured into the street with $2,000 in United States bonds in his pockets. He met a strange woman in the street and accompanied her to her room No. 141 Bleceker-street, and with this large amount of money upon him, went to sleep in this questionable company.

The metropolis, and all England except a few warm nooks on the seacoast, are bound in icy fetters. The steeple chases at Croydon have been postponed from day to day, as no one will risk his horse's legs or his own neck in such weather. Sporting and sight-seeing London poured out as usual...

The German-American School Association held its regular monthly meeting at Liederkranz Hall, No. 35 East Fourth-street, last night. It was resolved that an election of delegates in the several ward school clubs be ordered by the President for next year.

From an interesting paper prepared by Professor EDMUND ANDREWS, President of the Chicago Historical Society, on "The Geology of Lake Michigan," we give the following synopsis: He had long been convinced that sufficient indications existed on the lake shore to determine the distance of the drift period. Lake Michigan had its currents like the ocean, one passing northerly. and the other southerly.

The designs of the new postage stamps having been finally selected, the National Bank Note Company of this City is now preparing to engrave the plates from which to print them. The Company intends to have the smaller denominations ready for the public by February, if not sooner.

Judging from post experience the present inroad of April into December is not guaranteed to be successful any length of time, on which we venture to talk of furs. The extravagant sets of Russian sable brought to this market may be dismissed with a glance at their cost--from $800 to $8,000 a set.

The steamship Rhein, which loft Bremen Dec. 4, and Southampton Dec. 7, arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices are later by two days than those at hand Thursday by the Liberia. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am an incredulous person, and make it a rule never to believe anything that cannot be explained, therefore would respectfully ask your aid in solving a solution of the problem below.

Mayor PUTNAM received information yesterday from Admiral THATCHER, stating that H. S. WILLIAMS, Esq., one of the Directors of the Eastern Railroad, a personal friend of the late GEORGE PEABODY, has received a dispatch from London announcing the departure of the frigate Monarch for Portland. Mayor PUTNAM has teletraphed to London in regard to the matter,

PATRICK COLTON, a barkeeper in the porter house on the corner of Chatham and Roosevelt streets, died yesterday from the effects of a pistol-shot wound in the head, inflicted by himself in such a manner as led to the supposition that he had committed suicide.

The season of Italian opera which began on Wednesday, Nov. 3, with "H Trovatore," ended on Friday with "II Ballo in Maschera"-- Signer VERDI thus having the honor of both opening and closing the Iyric campaign. It is generally admitted that the season has been an agreeable disappointment.

Maine began this century with a population of 150,000; she had in 1868, according to Governor CHAMBERLAIN'S annual address, 650,000. In the meantime she has had great losses. Her chief industry lies nearly prostrate. Her stalwart lumbermen went by regiments to the war and to glorious graves.

It has been the peculiar function of M. OLIVER--EMILE OLLIVIER to act as the political barometer of modern France. On his election, in 1857, as Deputy for the Third District of the Seine, he represented the furthest advance of national Liberalism, and the most emphatic protest of popular freedom.

About one-third of all the young men in the City of New-York between the ages of 15 and 30 may almost be said to be strangers within our gates, aspiring and enterprising youth, who have come here to seek their fortunes with very little appreciation of the obstacles and discouragements with which they must contend.

Spear, Edward Jones, Augusta J. Rumsey, Logan Spitz, John W. Farner, John Bergen, Jacob Boell, Eliza N. Bellows, N. Parker Haven and Walter Reid.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your editorial this morning under the head of "Promoting Panics," is timely, and a very correct statement of things as they exist, and I thank you for it. The journal of Commerce also speaks in the same strain this morning.

The passage of a French Telegraphic Cable bill such as that before Congress, will by no means settle the questions upon which the United States are at issue with the French Government. The Senate bill of last February distinctly laid down the principle that no cable should be landed respecting which this country should not exercise control at this end,

The City of Brooklyn has among its residents same members of the New-York Fat Men's Association, and many others of note, who are understood to be candidates. The more prominent of these is FRANK SWIFT, the gigantic contractor, the owner of Barren Island, the builder of the quarantine island. the collector of defunct horses and other animals, , , weighing 251 pounds.

Another terrible mining accident occurred at 5 o'clock this morning at Stockton, near this place. A coal mine caved in, filling the shaft and tunnel with enormous masses of earth, carrying two large houses down with it, and choking the entrance to the mine.

The money order department of the New York Post Office, presents daily a busy scene. People have begun to appreciate this very convenient and safe system of transmitting money to any part of the country, and the business of the department is continually increasing. Last week the amount paid out was $94.223 24, and the amount received for transmission, $13,833 33.

JUDGE MURRAY, at Delhi, on Friday, heard a motion by Mr. RAMSEY, counsel, in his suit against the Erie Railway Company, to confirm the orders, heretofore granted, of suspension of injunction and for the appointment of a receiver, thereby vacating the stay of proceedings granted by Judge BALCOM. Messrs. R. W. PECKHAM, Jr., and HENRY SMITH appeared for the plaintiff, and Messrs. D. FIELD and T. G. SHEARMAN.

A special dispatch from St. Paul says that the editor of the St. Paul Press has received a letter from a prominet Canadian at Pembina, stating that Governor McDOUGALL has not called on Canada for troops, but relies on the loyal people of the Territory to quell the outbreak, and thinks they will do it without bloodshed.

It is generally admitted that grosser frauds were perpetrated in the making out of the returns of the recent charter election than on any previous occasion. In every case in which the contest was at all close, the returns were a Mered, or kept back altogether.

The proprietors of the Excelsior Iron Works say that the complaints regarding the action of the firemen on the occasion of the late fire in their establishment have boon investigated, and are proved to be erroneous; that they are entirely satisfied with the manner in which the fire was handled and checked.

At Lowville, in Lewis County, HIRAM C. POWERS was yesterday convicted of murdering RICHARD SHAW, and sentenced by Judge MULLIN to be hanged on the 4th of February. The condemned man approached his victim while he was sitting in the sacred circle of home, surrounded by his innocent and happy family,

Another meeting was held for establishing a German bank of discount in this City, at the Merchants' Exchange and News Rooms, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine-street, yesterday afternoon, Mr. JOSEPH SELIGMANN presiding.

The Committee on Protests of the Board of City Canvassers met at 11 A. M. yesterday, Mr. FARLEY in the chair. The case of JOHN A. STEMMLER vs. JOSEPH MCGUIRE, in which STEMMLER claims to have been elected to the Civil Justiceship of the Seventh District, was called.

The regular mail steamer from Vera Cruz arrived here to-day, bringing dates from the City of Mexico to the 10th inst. The ovations to Ex-Secretary SEWARD continued. On the 3d, Senor ROMERO gave a grand dinner in his honor at which speeches were made by Messrs. ROMERO, SEWARD, FREDERICK SEWARD and others.

The trial of MUNROE, for murder, came to a close last evening. After a painstaking charge from the Judge, the jury deliberated for two hours, and brought in a verdict of guilty, accompanied with a recommendation to mercy. The prisoner's fortitude quite forsook him as he heard the verdict pronounced by the foreman.

One THOMAS MURPHY has applied for a divorce in Chicago, saying that the was married "in fun" to JULIA FOGARTY, in Whitehall, N. Y., on the 10th of November, 1865, and that the lady in the case, failing to see the fun of the thing, has prosecuted him for non-support, he never having lived with her.

Our correspondent in Egypt writes that M. DE LESSEPS, of Suez Canal fame, was married on the afternoon of NOV. 25, at Ismailia, by Monseigueur BAUER. Almost the only spectator outside of family connections, was Captain RIES of the Norwegian frigate North Star.

Water-color paintings do not seem to find favor with American picture buyers, perhaps because so few really good specimens find their way to this side of the water. There is also an impression that water colors are of a transitory nature and soon fade.

Mr. DICKENS has labored hard to convince the world that at this time of year there is only one unfailing test of a man's character. If he is a good man, he will give away a large quantity of presents. If he is a very bad one, he will despise all the amenities of the season, and avenging ghosts will scare him out of his wits on Christmas Eve.

District-Attorney MORRIS of Kings Connty. and the Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, who have been in-sessIon for six weeks, yesterday brought indictments into Court against sixty persons for being concerned in the recent election frauds. About 245 yesterday afternoon, our citizens were deafened and applied by a coneussion which shock every building to its foundations, prustrated men in the streets, shaltered windows and dears and seamed veritably the "crack of doom." In an instant the streets were filled with people, looking about in wild alarm for the cause of the disaster, which was indicated by a spiral column of smoke rising from the northwestern part of the city.

What has become of the San Francisco "Avitor?" Secretary BOUTWELL is to lecture before a Lyceum in Boston on the 29th. It is understood he will speak upon the financial question. The farmers of Minnesota and of Northern and Central Iowa still hold their wheat, and must do so until Spring.

One of the most brutal murders that ever occurred in Western New-York was committed at this place last night, Dr. ANDREW MEAD, a resident of this county for the past fifty years and a very respectable and influential man, was murdered and robbed in his store, between 7 and 8 o'clock. MEAD was between 70 and 80 years of age.

Major RHEA, formerly of the Memphis Avalanche, will leave tomorrow by the Pacific Railroad with 300 Chinese laborers for the Southern States. The party expect to reach New-Orleans by the 10th of January. The Chinamen are under a contract for three years....It is feared that this will be a dry Winter.

The initial passage of the Suez Canal--the severest test to which it can ever be submitted--has ended in complete success, and the last of the series of celebrating fetes took place last night in the shape of a grand ball here, at the Viceroy's palace of Kasr-el-nil.

Cardinal PANTINI, a native of Rome, died on Saturday at the age of 72 years. This leaves sixteen vacancies in the College of Cardinals, none of which, It is said, will be tilled while the Ecumenical Council is in session....The Ecumenical Council will reconvene on Wednesday, Jan. 6, 1870.

Sixty persons were indicted by that body on Saturday for participation in the frauds.

The public will learn with satisfaction that another Important step has boon taken In regard to the Alabama claims negotiations. It was recently announced In the TIMES that this Government had proposed the transfer of the negotiations to Washington, as a preliminary to the reopening of the question, and the London papers on Friday last, referring to this statement, announced that if Mr. MOTLEY proposed this transfer it would be accepted.

I have just been four hours in St. Peter's, assisting at a great solemnity, one of 20,000 spectators, I should think. The High Mass on Advent Sunday has always been celebrated in the Sistine Chapel, but that room could not hold even a fraction of the Bishops now in Rome, unless everybody else was to be excluded. Perhaps a rehearsal, too, was convenient.

An exceedingly large audience greeted the woman's rights champions in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening. Mrs.BURLEIGH called the meeting to order, and Mr. BEECHER said if he supposed the effect of this agitation would be to make woman unwomanly, why we had men enough, such as they were.

The first annual hall of the "Fat Men's Association of the City of New-York" took place at Irving Hall last evening. The Association now numbers-between 150 and 200 members, and considerably more than a quorum were present at the ball.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair. A resolution was adopted to pay the Chief Justices the same salaries as that now received by the City Judge, the Clerks $5,000 each per annum, and the Police Court Clerks $4,000 each from the 1st of January, 1870.

We published in the TIMES a few days since an account of a trial which took place before Judge CARDOZO, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, between Mr. SAMUEL P. WHITE and State Senator MATTOON, in which the former sought to recover of the latter the sum of about $3,000,

The trial of GEORGE S. CHAMBERS, who accidentally shot and killed JOHN MYERS, Jr., at Astoria, L. I., Sept. 24 last, took place yesterday before Justice SNEDEKER, and resulted in a verdict of "excusable homeide." The accused who was ably defended by Mr. J. D. TOWNSEND, was honorably discharged.

There were no public sales of real estate at the Exchange yesterday. POTTER BROTHERS have sold at private sale a house and grounds at Fort Washington for $80,000; also, two lots on Forty-fifth-street, near Fifth-avenue, for $42,000, and one lot one lot on Forty-fourth-street for $16,000.

Cincinnati will open its soup houses for "customers" on Christmas. The Petersburg Index estimates the peanut crop of Virginia last season at 500,000 bushels. The New-England Society of St. Louis starts with seventy-five members.

This morning the locomotive "Annapolis," of the Reading Railroad, exploded near the crossing of the Reading and Trenton Railroad, killing the engineer. JOSEPH NAGLE, and injuring three other men, one of whom will lose an arm. The locomotive was a very old one.

Mayor HALL is announced to deliver a lecture on "The Prism of Charity," on the 30th inst., with special reference to the wants of the Mount de Chantal Visitation Academy, near Wheeling, West Virginia--an institution organized for the education of young ladies, but which is compelled by the impoverished condition of the Southern people to seek assistance from the more prosperous North.

The delay in the admission of Wirginia to representation in Congress-the doubt which delay suggests whether, without furtehr conditons, the State will be admitted at all--cannot be contemplated without mortification and regret. A fortnight ago, everything pointed to a different conclusion.

The Indian fight on the 18th of November, in the canyon on the north side of the Guadeloupe Mountains, 200 miles south of Fort Stanton, must not be regarded as indicating general Indian hostilities, or as weakening in any way the force of those pacific assurances from our officers which were lately presented to Congress.

The nomination by the President of Hon. EDWIN M. STANTON as Associate Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court, and his Prompt confirmation in the Senate, without reference, by a vote of forty-six to eleven, have combined to form a tribute alike graceful and well merited to honorable public services and conspicuous ability and worth.

The case of JOHN REAL, who was convicted and sentenced to be hang for the murder of Policeman SMEDICK in July, 1868, and to whom the General Term have denied a new trial within the last few days, came up again yesterday before the same Court, Judges CLERKE, INGRAHAM and SUTHERLAND on the bench.

The President today-transmitted to the Senate a voluminous document in reply to the resolution calling for information with regard to Cuba. The correspondence between Spain and our State Department, laid before the Senate on Monday, gives a luminous, as well as voluminous, idea of the actual relations between the two countries up to the present time. That they will, as we anticipated, vindicate the course pursued by our Government hither to, cannot be doubted.

To steer between the Seylla and Charybdis of boarding on the one hand and comfortable and inexpensive housekeeping on the other has long been the aim of people of moderate means in American cities, and particularly in New-York. We all know what the conclusion is in theory, and how rarely that conclusion becomes practically operative in theory and fact.

Within the last month there has been much agitation on Long Island, and especially in Suffolk County, in favor of a repeal of the game law or modification of the law so as to exempt a part of the island from Its provisions. A petition is extensively circulated in behalf of the measure.

This interesting contest is still steadily progressing--116 games have already been lost and won. The most successful champions are up to the present time Captain MACKENZIE, who has won twelve, without the loss of a single game ; Mr. WARE, President of the Boston Chess Club, who has scored sixteen against five which be lost ; Dr. BARNETT with twelve won and four lost, and Mr. B. LISSNER, who has won eleven and lost seven.

Last evening the sale of pictures contributed for the benefit of the Artists' Fund Society took place at BARKER THEALL'S Gallery, No. 845 Broadway, in the presence of a very large gathering of artists and patrons of the fine arts.

The Vice-President called the attention of the Senate to the requirement of the law for filling the vacancy occasioned by the death of Mr. FESSENDEN as one of the Regents of the Smithsonian Institution. The law provided that this vacancy should be filied in the same manager that committees are appointed.

On Monday night a young man named RICHARD E. KELLY arrived in New-York from New-Concord. Ky. He was en route to Poughkeepsie to attend Eastman College. He came ?? the Pan Handle route. On reaching Jersey City he took from his bootleg the sum of $230 and placed it in his pantaloons pocket.

Ex-Judge STRONG continued his arguments, opposing the motion made by Mr. SHEA, counsel for the alleged Lunatic, mrs, CAROLINE C. ALLEN. to have counselor PRITCHETT published for contempt of court.

The first-class steam frigate Benicia, under the command of Captain NICHOLSON, arrived at the Navy Yard yesterday for the purpose of taking in the balance of her crow, and her stores and supplies. She will leave here immediately for China.

A large Republican meeting was held in Madrid yesterday. A period is to be listed beyond which the advocacy of the candidature of the Duke of GENOA for the Crown shall cease. A reconciliation between the Montpensiers and Ex-Queen ISABELLA is spoken of which may lead to the crowning of the Prince of ASTURIAS, with the Duke of MONTPENSIER as Regent....

The claim of CHARLES BURRILL to be compensated for furnishing men to the Boston quota during the war has been partially considered in the Board of Aldermen, on a proposition to pay him $25,000 in full of all demands.

A bill now before the Kentucky Legislature contemplates extending the limit of the rate of interest that may be charged by agreement on loans of money to ten per cent, per annum. At a previous session the subject of conferring similar privileges exclusively upon certain cities was debated.

The United States steam frigate Powhalan after a five years cruise, returned to this port yesterday afternoon, direct from key west, and is now anchored off the Navy Yard. She is commanded by Commodore MCDOUGALL., and was built at the Norfolk Navy Yard in 1850.

The case of RUSH C. HAWKINS vs. GEORGE BLISS, Jr., the facts of which have already been fully reported in the TIMES, was yesterday brought to a conclusion by a verdict the jury took occasion to censure "the manner in which the business has been transacted, especially on the part of the defendant."
It commenced snowing at noon to-day, accompanied by violent wind, which has increased in fierceness up to this hour, 8 P.M. Snow is now falling very fast, and forms into almost impassable banks.

After 1870 the treaty becomes terminable by a year's notice from either side, and a powerful agitation is at present going forward in France, by one party for its renewal,

A special meeting of the Brooklyn Board o Education was held last evening to consider what action should be taken with reference to the lease and proposed purchase of the Bache mansion in Concord-street, between Fulton and Washington streets.

Ex-Chieftain Peter L. BUCHANAN, of the New-York Caledonlan Club, delivered one of a series of lectures before the Club last evening, his subject being the "History of the Scottish Freemasons," Among the various theories of the origin of Masonry, the true one, he said, was that it originated among the Romans, where an origanization of practical masons followed the army and erected fortifications and walled camps.

ITALIAN OPERA--EXTRA NIGHT. An extra performance is given this evening by Mr. MARETZEK'S company, at the Academy. "William Tell," the success of the season is to be sung, with Signor LEFRANC in his great part of Arnoldo. We advise all who have not witnessed that admirable performance to embrace this final opportunity.

AUGUSTE MICHEL MARIE ETIENNE, Count Regnault de Saint-Jean d' Angely, General and Senator of France, was born in Paris July 29, 1794. He was the son to the Count REGNAULT who distinguished himself in the parliamentary era of the Republic and the First Empire.

Yesterday morning a German, named WM. MILLER, was brought before Justice QUARTERMAN charged with stealing $150 from BERNHARDT HARFLIE while engaged in a brickyard in College Point. After a chase of some two months Officer SCHMIDT succeeded in trapping the offender by giving him to understand that there was a letter for him from Europe containing money.

The case of JOSEPH H. RAMSEY vs. The Erie Railway Company and others, was argued yesterday at Binghamton, on the motion to set aside the order of suspension injunction and order appointing a receiver.

Racina, Wis., has just found homes for twenty little children from Boston. The Philadelphia Ledger takes its stand in opposition to charitable fairs. Pear festivals are becoming fashionable in Boston and vicinity. Some of the ladies think the work misspelled.

The Board of Health yesterday ordered that the cow stables of Brooklyn as inspected and their condition reported to the Board. It appears that the milk from the country is pure and sweet, while that coming from the crowded city limits is largely diluted with water.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate a House joint resolution for extending the recess over the holidays from the 22d inst. until Jan. 10. The subject was laid on the table until the expiration of the morning hour, when it was concurred in by yeas 27, nays 22. The recess, therefore, extends till Monday, Jan. 10.

In 1825, when a vote of welcome to LAFAYETTE was proposed in Congress, the only voice raised in opposition to it was that of a representative from Ohio. Mr. SCHENCK is anxious to eclipse the act of his jaundiced predecessor. He has followed the line taken by others, and attacked Mr. PEABODY for supposed sympathies with the rebel cause.

Me. WILSON G. HUNT has presented to the Mercantile Library a splendid painting of President GRANT. The portrait is half length life size, and is considered by the friends of the President a most faithful likeness. It was painted by Mr. N. B. KITTELL, of this City, who received from Mr. HUNT a commission to paint it for the Mercantile Library in May last.

The case of GEORGE MORONEY vs. The British Commercial Life Insurance Company came up, yesterday, before Judge INGRAHAM, of the Supreme Court, on a motion to vacate an order made by Judge CARDOZO directing reinsurance of the defunct British Commercial Life Insurance Company in the Continental Life Insurance Company of this City.

THE SEASON AT BOOTH'S. We may be permitted, viewing the artistic worth of the performance, to call attention to the fact that Mr. HACKETT'S embodiment of Falsta?, in "The Merry Wives of Windsor," is to be applauded at Booth's during this week only.

One of the fortunate circumstances attending the commencement of our new Post Office was that the preliminaries had escaped from the crowd of plunderers who lie in wait for spoils to be gathered from such enterprises.

HAMILTON for United States Senator. Chicago papers find that it interests their readers to explain why a man is not divorced.

This Board held a meeting yesterday afternoon, General JAMES BOWEN, President, in the Chair. It was reported that the new fever hospital on Black well's Island was now ready for occupation, and the Board resolved to ask the Committee on Medical Examination for instructions regarding the transfer of patients to the new hospital.

Last Saturday evening, after the physicians in attendance on Mr. A. S. BROWN, who was severely hurt on the railroad, had left for the night, a man of respectable appearance appeared at the door of the house and inquired for Mr. BROWN, introducing himself as Dr. HADLEY, of Boston.

The action of a recent Convention held at Muscatine, Iowa, was menacing, and its speeches were quite warlike The difficulty in question may be described as follows: During the late rebellion certain counties in Iowa, under an enabling act of the Legislature, issued bonds in aid of the construction of railways.

At a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday, the Detective Squad attached to the Central Department was constituted the Thirty-fifth Precinet of the Metropolitan Police District, and JAMES J. KELSO was appointed its Captain. Captain KELSO has been connected with the detectives for many years...

A large fire occurred last night on Prado-street, which is generally supposed to be the work of an incendiary. An inflammatory proclamation has been circulated in the city, calling the Havanese to fly to arms and aid the insurgents fighting in the interior.

Governor BULLOCK has issued a proclamation summoning all persons elected to the General Assembly of the State of Georgia by the proclamation of General MEADE, June 25, 1868, who are qualified, to appear in Atlanta on the 10th day of January next...

LITTLE EM'LY AT NIBLO'S An adaptation by ANDREW HALLIDAY of DICKENS' David Copperfield was presented, on Monday evening, at Niblo's Garden, and has since drawn excellent houses. "Little Em'ly" is a piece of the jerky and fragmentary sort, which is almost inevitable when the attempt is made to dramatize a long novel and to get in a great many characters.
A telegram from Governor PEASE, dated Austin, Texas, says: "DAVIS, for Governor, is 400 ahead, exclusive of the Counties of Milan and Navarro, which if allowed to vote, would elect HAMILTON."

ANDREW WILSON. Jr., has mangurated the some what per??ons undertaking of selling country property on a large scale in the month of December. His first sale took place at Madison, N. J., yesterday, and notwithstanding at the disadvantages of the season, the enterprise may be safely pronounced a perfect success.

At the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HACKETT, Patrolmen TREADWELL W. REMSEN and JAMES HANNIGAN, convicted on Tuesday last on a charge of grand larceny preferred by GEORGE W. WELLS, were sentenced.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

The Bishop of Havana has disappeared from Madrid, and is believed to have gone to France with another Bishop who declines to recognize the government, the Regency or the revolution....Bullion In the Bank of France increased 6,900,000 francs during the past week. A Paris dispatch says the present session of tho Corps Legislatif will be adjourned to-day.

Governor CHAMBERLAIN, of Maine, has issued the following general order: STATE OF MAINE, AUGUSTA, Dec. 18.1869 GENERAL ORDER NO, 6--The fleet conveying the remains of GEORGE PEABODY being expected in Portland land harbor, the State Government is desirous of tendering every expression of respect proper upon the occasion, and will officially participate in the services which may be had.

At 11:55 o'clock Wednesday night while Officer MICHAEL GRIFFIN, of the Second Precinct, was patrolling John-street, from Broadway to Cliff-street he was suddenly started by the report of a pistol behind him, and the whiz of a bullet close by his car.

At the weekly meeting of the Kings County Supervisors yesterday, the salary of JAMES GARDNER, Deputy County Treasurer, was increased from $1,000 to $2,000 per annum from Jan. 1, 1870.

The only business transacted by this Board yesterday was to fix the salaries of the Clerk of the Board of Assistant Aldermen and the Deputy Clerk of the Board of Aldermen at the same sum as that now paid the Clerk of the Board of Aldermen.

The confirmation by the Senate of LEWIS B. WOODRUFF as United States Circuit Judge for this district, is an honorable tribute to his ability as a lawyer and his character as a man. Members of the profession may have had other preferences while the claims of candidates were yet undetermined by the President.

Her power of modulating her voice requires, however, further cultivation. her readings last evening consisted of selections from N. P. WILLIS' Poems. oetils.

About 6:30 this evening a man named PRES. BARKER, charged with the seduction of ELIZABETH MCQUIGG, was shot and killed by her. Immediately after the shooting she gave herself up to Esquire MATHEWS. Her brother, JOHN MCQUIGG, was also arrested , charged with the same crime. Both were committed to jail. An inquest is now being held over BARKER'S body.

The new Grammar schoolhouse just completed in Eighteenth-street, near Ninth-avenue, was formally opened yesterday afternoon with appropriate exercises. The structure is a substantial four-story brick building, costing $100,000 and capable of accommodating over 1,500 scholars.

There was a large meeting at Room No. 24 Cooper Institute, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of organizing a colony to locate in Colorado Territory. HORACE GREELEY presided. Mr. N. C. MEEKER detailed the advantages of Colorado as a place of location for colonists.

Since the Bishop of Chicago, Right Rev. JAMES DUGGAN, has become it is said, insane, the Metropolitan Bishop of the province, Archbishop KENDRICK, of St. Louis, has been endeavoring to select a proper person to succeed him.

Yesterday afternoon JOHN A. CROZIER, a one-armed soldier, attacked JOHN RIORDEN with a knife and stabbed him in a horrible manner, inflicting no less tan thirteen wounds. An alleged criminal intimacy between RIORDEN and CROZIER'S wife was the cause of the assault. RIORDEN will die. CROZIER is in jail.

Messrs. JOHN H. DRAPER Co. concluded the Custom House sales yesterday by his using of a large amount of goods seized by the revenue officers, consisting of laces, cigars, ribbons, wine and jewelry. The sale took place in their auction room, No. 112 Pearl-street, and was well attended.

CHAMBERS BROTHERS' elevator at Muscatine, Iowa, was burned last night. The loss is $30,000, and the insurance is $24,000. There were only a few hundred bushels of grain in the elevator....The stores of J. B. DUNN Co., and ADAM STONE, at St. Charles, Minn., were burned last Monday. The loss is $18,000, which is nearly covered by insurance.

The ship Harrest Queen, Captain HENRY AJNSSEN, of the Black Ball line, has just made a remarkably short voyage for SanFrancisco and back by the way of Liverpool. She left New York Jan. 25, 1869, arriving in San Francisco May 19, a passage of 114 days.

The Ways and Means Committee is not likely to do much more with the Tariff bill until after New Year's. What it has accomplished to this date can be told in a short Paragraph. Pig iron is put at $7 instead of $9 per ton, and scrap iron at $6 instead of $8, and the number of articles under the last head is considerably reduced.

The readers of the TIMES will remember that about two months ago Dr. AUGUST WEDEKIND was arraigned before Justice HOGAN, on the complaint of Mrs. ELIZABETH GALLER, who accused him of having extorted $1,000 from her by threats and intimidation. After due examination the prisoner was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 24.--The City Council has authorized Mayor SHURTLEFF to petition the Legislature for an act providing that after the year 1870 the Board of Aldermen shall consist of sixteen members, one from each ward, to be elected on the general ticket, and the Common Council top consist of three members from each ward.

The NEW-YORK TIMES discusses the necessity for reform in the management of our State Prisons. It is informed that "Governor HOFFMAN is sufficiently impressed with the importance of the subject to be willing to recommend anything that may be necessary--even an amendment to the Constitution--to take this whole class of officers out of the political arena."

The brokers who frequent the Custom House Rotunda, and who pretend to be the thermometers of the state of business there, declare that there has not been so little done in that spacious beehive "for years" as during the past ten days. Steamers, they say, come in slowly, and with limited cargoes, Importers are not buying; their stock on hand does not go fast enough; foreign merchants fear failures here;

From the Scientific American. The time is coming when in many portions of the United States the steam plow will be permanently adopted. If, in a country of small farms like England, it can be made so useful as to render profitable lauds which, without it, can only be worked at a loss, how much wider is its scope on our broad plantations, wide prairies, and river bottoms which are devoted to grain production.

The world-renowned violinist, OLE BULL, arrived in this City by the Russia on Thursday, and his thousands of admirers will be glad to learn that he is in excellent health and looking as finely as ever. A pleasant little episode occurred on the passage, in which his wonderful musical genius and his equally famous love of his native land were agreeably combined.

Day by day the political echoes of the year are becoming fainter. The Legislatures and Parliaments of the world have entered on a brief interval of repose, and the advent of the period sacred to peace and good will has reduced the nations to that happy state in which there is no history, and consequently no news. Spain alone, anxious and distribute, continues to contribute her quota of current rumors.

A young and beautiful German girl, about 16 years of age, met with a sad and sudden death last night, on the Harlem Railroad, a short distanco north of the Morrisania Depot. It appears that the Harlem train going north, and the NewHaven 8:2n down passenger train-the latter being behind time and running under a high rate of speed-pased each other there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--"Mr. STANTON is dead." "Impossible! " "When !" " How !" were the exclamations and responses with which people greeted each other as they left their breakfast tables this morning, for the places of their daily duty. It did, indeed, seem impossible that the bright morning, with Its bracing atmosphere, should bring such a great sorrow where there was only room for joy and happiness.

A gentleman who is now a resident of East Boston states that after an unsuccessful sojourn in California of several years, he took passage in a bark bound to New-York. She touched at Panama for provisions and water, and having procured these, her Captain proposed to sail the next day.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 24.--The Montgomery Opera House was burned this afternoon. The building was owned by JAMES MONTGOMERY, of Chicago, and was valued at $40,000, and insured for $10,000. The west room was occupied as the Post Office. The mail and office fixtures were saved. C.O. COMSTOCK'S billiard room, in the basement, was damaged to the extent of $3,500; ho was not insured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--The political turmoil and confusion has given place to the usual holiday excitements, and, with the exception of the national calamity, alluded to elsewhere, there is very little of public importance to chronicle. To-day and yesterday the Capitol was deserted.

The case of WADE vs. THAYER, in which the plaintiff sought to recover $10, 000 damages for hurts received by him in the Western Hotel at the hands of two of THAYER's employes, came up for trial before Judge REED in the District Court on Thursday, was partially heard and continued until yesterday, and finished last evening. Rev. JAMES KENT STONE, D. D., late President of Hobart College, has himself settled all controversy as to his religious status in two letters which he has published, but which we have not seen beyond the reference to them made by the Gospel Messenger (Episcopal) of this week.

A correspondent raises a question in reference to the length of the terms of the County Judges elected at the last election, in view of the adoption of the new Judiciary article. It may be of interest to consider what is to be effect of that article upon all our Courts, and how the change is to be made from the old system to the new.

A recent series of letters from one of the English mechanics imported by Mr. GOLDWIN SMITH to work at Ithaca, contained some good suggestions. Among others, was one upon the value of skilled labor in this country.

Coroner BATHGATE held an inquest yesterday at Morrisania on the body of a Bohamian girl, between 15 and 16 years old, named ANN WOTAPKE, who was struck and instantly killed by a train of the New-Haven Railroad, about 8 o'clock on Friday evening. The deceased came to this country about eight months ago, and for the last fortnight was in the employ of Mr. JOHN WIRTH, of Morrisania.

Mr. BENJAMIN FITCH, a retried New-York merchant, now residing at Darien, Conn., has established at that place a home for soldiers and orphans of soldiers engaged in the late war, which is deserving of public notice.

The joyful festival of Christmas tide has come and gone, leaving the world better, it is to be hoped, for the devotions which commemorate the founding of a pure religion, and the innocent pastimes and household rejoicings which characterize a universal holiday. Santa Claus has been on his annual round, and swept away again with his prancing team into the region of fancies and dreams.

We learn that an unfortunate accident occurred at Greene, in Coventry, last night, but which might almost be called fortunate, so many persons were put in mortal jeopardy, and yet escaped with unimportant hurts.

No pillow for Thy head, Thy swaddling-clothes Thy only coverlet:--It was that we might lore Thee. Hadst--with the glorious band, That in Thy presence stand Waiting Thy will--Thou come, O dearest Lord!

The deaths from small pox last week numbered twenty, a slight increase over the number the preceding week. There is also an increase is the mortality among the colored population, the deaths amounting to fifty-two, lacking but little of being one-half the total mortality. This is a very heavy death rate.

It just occurs to us, at this stage of the proceedings for annexing all or part of San Domingo, to inquire what the people of that Island think about it. We admit, however, that in our recent real-estate transactions we have never particularly consulted the wishes of the people living on the ground we aimed to buy.

TORREY--FAEKLER.--On Wednesday, Dec. 15, at the Catholic Apostolic Church, by Rev. D. M. Fackler, JOHN TORREY, Jr., of New-Jersey, to MARYS., daughter of the afficiating clergyman. JUDSON--JUDSON.--On Thursday, Dec. 23, at the residence of the bride's parents, by Rev. Wm. Hogarth

TUESDAY. Mails for Europe, via Southampton, Cherbourg and Hamburg, by the Westphalia, close at the General Post Office at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters at the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P.M. s for Halifax and Bermuda, by the Etna, close at-.

A Montreal paper gives a starting account of the condition of the agricultural population in the Province of Quebec. It states that, while the habitans are emigrating at the rate of tens of thousands annually, farm servants may be hired for 6 a month and board ; and there are very few localities in which able-bonded men can earn on the average two shillings a day ;

On Saturday evening the Southern and Western trains were detained at Trenton two and a half hours. The Western train leaving New-York at 9 o'clock P. M. was detained at Trenton, repairing a hot Journal under one of the care.

The radical journals of to-day state that seventy-four noncommissioned officers and soldiers of the Paris garrison have been arrested for having formed a republican and socialistic society..... It is now asserted that the Ministry will resign to-morrow. The city is full of rumors as to the names of the successors, but they cannot be traced to any reliable source.

The collision on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Thursday afternoon, mentioned briefly in our columns yesterday, was one of the most frightful accidents that over happend on that road. The facts appear to be these: The trains colliding were the "Cincinnati Express" coming west, due here at 4:45 P. M.

Last night, a bout 12:15 o'clock, Mr. DANIEL STRONG, aged 69 years, died from the effects of a lose of corrosive sublimate taken through mistake. About 4 o'clock in the afternoon he went up stairs at his home and found a vial of something he knew not what. He inhaled some of it and then knew not what it was.

A special telegram to the Tribune, from St. Paul, says: " The declaration of independence of the Provisional Government of Rupert's Land and the Northwest Territory, was received from Red River to-day. It was signed by JOHN B. RUCE, President, and LOUIS RIELLE, Secretary.

Private dispatches received in this City from London announce the wreck of Mr. GEORGE M. LORILLARD'S yacht Meteor, near Tunis, Northern Africa, on the 13th inst., and the safety of all hands. Rumors to this effect have been current in the City for several days, and much anxiety has been felt by the friends of the party who sailed in her in the Summer.

Coroner VOLHARDT. of Hudson City, was notified last evening of an accident that occurred on the Erie Railway at Penhoar, an oil depot, a short distance west of the tunnel, on Saturday evening. Three laborers employed at the oil works, CHARLES DENNY, WM. HOWE and another, whose name was not reported,

The following resolutions, offered by WM. C. BRYANT, were unanimously adopted by the Union League Club Saturday night: We the members of the Union League Club of the City of Now-York, having learned with profound grief the death of EDWIN M. STANTON, the greatest War Minister of modern times, to whose energy and lofty patriotism the ultimate success of the national hosts is owing as much as to any other individual man ;

Mr. GLADSTONE'S political cross is the Irish question. He may carry it by the help of a bayonet, but the burden will be none the easier. The worst law is martial law. There is a widely accepted belief in natural depravity as the normal condition of the Irish people, and it is easy enough to find a "policy" for such a condition. We have something like it in our Indian countries.

Rev. WM. AIKMAN delivered, yesterday morning, at the Spring-street Presbyterian Church, the last of his series of discourses on the Family Relation. Ills subject was" Employers and Employed." After setting forth the reciprocal relation which these two classes held toward each other, he spoke of the dilatoriness which sometimes characterized employers in

Yesterday morning, Captain LEE, Chief of Police, received a telegram from Inspector DILKS, of New-York, giving a description of three young girls, who had left that city for St. Louis, under circumstances leading to the belief that they had been seduced a way from home from evil purposes, and requesting their arrest on be-half of their relatives.

At a meeting of the Juridical Society, a few evenings ago, a paper was read on the so called Alabama question, in which it was proposed to submit all the points at issue between the two countries to the most learned statesmen and lawyers of the various countries of Europe.

Mad dogs are raging in New-Orleans. Peoria, III., is overrun with rats. And yet Peoria looks askant at the Chinese. Montreal has subscribed $6,000 for a statue of the Queen. Chinamen are to dig the Cape Cod Canal when it is dug.

We have of late been giving some extracts from our exchanges, showing the immouse amount of emigration that is now coming into our State, but we cannot fine room to keep it up. We see from nearly all our exchanges that the number is on he increase, and bids fair to continue all Winter. .

The new enapel of the Seventh-avenue Methodist Episcopal Church near Flatbushavenue, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday. The edifice is built of brick, with a brown-stone front, and is two stories high, ninety-eight feet in length, and fifty feet in width. The cost of the chapel, including furniture, is about $60,000. The windows are of stained glass;
We publish further expressions of Republican opinion in favor of a large and immediate reduction of taxes. All the journals from which we quote are influential in their respective neighborhoods,

The steamship China arrived this morning from Hong Kong Nov. 19 and Yokohama Dec. 2. She brought a heavy freight and a large number of passengers, including 520 Chinese and Japanese. General VAN VALKENBURG, late United States on the China.

General AMES has ordered the Legislature to convene on the 11th of January. The following officers, elected at the late election, are appointed provisional officers until their installation: JAMES L. ALCORN, Governor; JAMES LYNCH, (colored,) Secretary of State: HENRY MUSGROVE, State Auditor; JOSHUA S. MORRIS, Attorney-General.

The other day Captain CHASE, of Jewell's Island, an old gentleman about 80 years of age, started from home for Portland in his sailboat, accompanied by his little grandson, about 8 years old. When about half-way between Overset and Pumpkin Knob the little boy felt cold and his grandfather told him to go forward to the cuddy and warm himself.

Great confusion and excitement was caused during the morning service in St. James' Church yesterday, by the evergreen decorations taking fire near the organ, from the gas jet. The congregation sprang from their seats and rushed for the doors in such wild alarm that many would have been trampled or crushed to death, had not Detective MAHONY, of the Fourth Pre-

In many of the churches in Brooklyn yesterday, sermons were preached in which the people were warned of the fearful consequences to young men of drinking intoxicating liquors at New-Year's receptions, and the ladies were admonished to expunge the viper from their tables on the 1st of January, 1870.

BERRY.--In New-York, on Sunday, Dec. 26, BERTINETTE, wife of Robt. W. Berry, of Hackensack, N. J., and daughter of General James S. Hatfield, of Hoboken, N. J. Relatives and friends of the family, also those of her father, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from Christ's Church, Hackensack, on Wednesday, 29th inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock P. M. Train from New-York leaves foot of Chambers-st. at 12 M.

The Dalmatian rebels, it is reported at Vienna, have laid down their arms....A Republican Society has been discovered among the soldiers of the Paris garrison, and seventy-four of them have been arrested. ....The reported reconciliation between the Ex-Queen ISABELLA and the Duke of MONTPENSIER is denied in a Madrid dispatch....

The contest for the Speakership of the next Legislature is becoming quite spirited as the time draws near for the meeting of the General Assembly. There are quite a number of candidates in the field among the Republicans, of which we may mention McVEAN, of Caddo, said to be the choice of Governor WARMOTH;

Mayor BRUSH has issued a proclamation calling upon the citizens generally to take action on the death of Hon. E. M. STANTON, a former member of the Bar in this city. He requests business houses to be closed and the city bells to be tolled between 12 and 1 o'clock on Monday.

On the 6th March last, five young German artists of this City started a social club, desigDating It as the Palette Art Association. New members were quickly enrolled, and it was deemed better to form a cosmopolitan art society, than to indulge twice a week in desultory conversation and unlimited tobacco and lager beer.

About 3 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear of NO. 166 1/2 Bowery, occupied by A. MEYERS, confectioner, whose loss is $2,000, but covered by insurance. E. KRUCEMAN, toys and picture frames, in No. 166, was damaged $5,000. The building, which is owned by 1. TOBIAS, will require $1,000 for repairs.

Detective DUSENBURY, of the Central Police, arrived in this City, yesterday, from Cincinnati, having in custody a merchant of that place, named DAVID JOSEPH, whom he had arrested there by virtue of a requisition from Governor HOFFMAN, which was based upon an indictment obtained by a complaint made by H. B. CLAFLIN CO.

Senor JOSE M. LEMUS, "Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Cuba" at Washington, has received by special messenger official news from the Oaban leaders on the island, of their military operations between August and Oct. 4.

The funeral services of the lamented Dr. F. J. RANDALL, Inspector of the Metropolitan Board of Health, were held yesterday afternoon, at his late residence No. 367 Broome-street. His late associates, the Inspector and Executive officers of the Board, attended in a body, wearing crape upon the left arm.

Among the merciful institutions of this City none deserve a more hearty recognition than the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Mr. HENRY BERGH, the magnificent founder of the Association and the steadfast laborer in its wide field, together with

Rev. BIRON STOW, one of the oldest, Baptist clergy men of Boston, for a long time pastor of the Bowe-street Church, died suddenly of apoplexy, yesterday morning, at his home in that city. Mr. STOW was born on the 16th of June, 1801, in Croydon, Sullivan County, N. H.

A meeting of the holders of Tennessee State bonds was held yesterday afternoon at the office of THOMAS DENNY CO., No. 39 Wall-street, at which, it is estimated, $12,000,000 of bonds were represented. Mr. J. J. DONALDSON, President of the Bank of North America, presided, and Mr. A. W. WILLIAMS acted as Secretary.

This case, about which so much has been said, and of which the TIMES has recently published extended reports, came up again yesterday before Judge CARDOZO at the Supreme Court Special Term, on the motion made by Mr. GEO. SHEA, as counsel for Mrs. ALLEN, for an order to have Mr. GEO. E. PRITCHETT punished for contempt of Court.

JOHN R. WILDER, of Westwood Village, to-day attacked his wife with a hatchet, inflicting fatal injuries upon her. WILDER then went to an adjoining room and discharged simultaneously two gun-barrels of buckshot into his head, blowing the top completely off.

At the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HACKETT, JOSEPH VASQUES was arranged for the murder of JOSEPHINE VEESE on the 31st of October last. He pleaded "not guilty." Mr. J. H. ANTHON, who appeared for the prisoner, made an application for the issuing of a commission to examine witnesses now residing in the Island of Cuba.

A special dispatch to the Tribune from St. Paul, of this day's date, says letters have been received from Pembina to the 16th inst. The discomfiture of failure of Colonel DENNIS, of MCDOUGALL'S staff, to enlist and arm the Indians, saved the lives of MCDOUGALL and his suite.

At 5 o'clock last evening a young lady named MORAN, residing at No. 1,569 Indiana-avenue, was walking on that thoroughfare, only a few yards from home, when a ruffiian seized her by the throat and tore off her gloves, pulled two gold rings from her fingers, and snatched from her hands her pocket book, which contained a small sum of money.

A terrible accident occurred yesterday afternoon at the slaughter house of SHOENEMAN Co. JAMES BROWN, an Irishman, 48 years old, was the victim. He was employed as engineer at the establishment, and it is supposed that while he was oiling the machinery an ever coat which he wore became caught in the belting, and he was thus drawn around with great velocity.

MILLER sells, under a foreclosure of mortgage, four lots of land, with a brewery thereon, situated on the south side of Fifty-eighth-street, about 300 feet west of Third-avenue; and 2 lots on Fifty-eight-street, near Lexington-avenue, on one of which is a brown-stone front dwelling house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27--The following additional advices from China were received by the steamship China: At the time Sir RUTHER FORD ALCOCK, the British Charge d'Affaires, left Pekin for Shanghae, the French Minister was preparing for his departure. New translations of the Burlingame credentials show that he was accredited to the Western Nations as lesser States and had no plenipotentiary powers.

With two exceptions, all the conspicuous persons implicated in the great drawback frauds conspiracy have been taken as Government witnesses. The latest addition to the number is SAMUEL. T. BLATCHFORD, the fugitive Deputy Collector, who was proved by the testimony of his confederates in the fraudulent claim scheme to be a prominent actor in the affair.

The Troy Times learns by a special dispatch from Whitchall the particulars of a horrible affair in Washington County yesterday. EZRA GREGORY, a Dresden farmer; shot LEWIS LOUGREY, a neigh boring farmer, through the head, killing him instantly.

The cordial reception given to General HURLBUT, our Minister Resident in the United States of Colombia, is a felicitous omen for the renewal of negotiations with that country touching the Darien Canal.

The Commissioners of the Metropolitan Board of Health are just now actively engaged in preparing the annual report of the operations of the year just closing, for presentation to the Legislature of 1870. This report is in the hands of a Committee of the Board for compilation. while the statistical matter which will be presented therewith is being prepared by the clerical force of the office.

The general prosperity of our people is marketed in no way more decidedly than in the evidences of thrift which may be observed in every section of this City in the creation of new building, and in the transformation of certain localities where old-style houses are being torn down to make place for architectural piles more costly in character,

The Operative Painters met last night at Demilt Hall, and refused to readmit some members who had continued at work for low wages while the Society was on a strike. A letter was received from Mayor HALL, with some tickets to be given away to the members, inviting them to his lecture, "The Prism of Charity."

In the Corps Legislatif to-day the election of ISAAC PEREIRE, formerly Director of the Credit Mobilier, was annulled by a vote of 130 to 31. He was a Government candidate for Deputy form one of the districts from this city. The determination of the election cases was the last act of the extraordinary session of the Corps Legislatif.

Monaghan, Esq., President, in the Chair, and the following members: Assistant Aldermen Healy, Lysaght, Bryan Reilly, Robinson, Bill, Hampson, Welch, Calkin, Holfman, Pinckney, Daly, Gibney, John Reilly, Pettit, Haughton, Cregler, O'Neil, Jackson, Roberts--20.

It is quite evident that the trouble in the British possessions adjacent to Minnesota is much mere than the riotous opposition to authority which they early dispatches represented it to be. Nor is it a strictly local quarrel, which this country can afford to view with indiference.

The funeral of the late Physician-in-Chief of the Seaman's Retreat, Stapleton, Long Island, dr. THOMAS C. MOFFATT, whose somewhat sudden death, at the age of 45, caused so much regret and sorrow among the members of his family and many friends, will take place on Wednesday, the 29th of December.

The Chinese appear to have settled their affairs with England on a durable basis. The revised treaty between the two Powers does not seem objectionable in any way, so far as we can judge from the telegraphic summary. Many concessions have been made to foreign trade, two new ports are to be opened--as we understand,

A report was circulated yesterday to the effect that a defalcation had been discovered in the Merchants' Exchange National Bank. No. 2?? Broadway. Upon inquiry in the proper quarter it was ascertained that a Committee of the Bank Directors was in session, and it was admitted that there was a "difficulty," but how great the alleged defalcation was not stated.

The following changes have taken place in the Custom House since the 15th inst.: P.A. Van Bergen, transferred form Eight Division to Chief Clerk of Seventh Division. $2,000; W. G. Lee, Special Inspector for thirty days, at $4 per day: S.T. Bulkly, Special Inspector for thirty days, at $4 per day; John Piatt, Special Inspector for thirty days, at $4 per day ;

Admiral JOHN R. TUCKER, of the Peruvian Navy, still tarries in Petersburg, Va. There was $400,000 in Virginia's Treasury on Friday. Ex-Secretary STANTON made his will in July. Dr. SEARS has returned to New-Orleans from Texas.

Our Washington correspondent communicates the intelligence that the people of that city are "getting pretty thoroughly aroused" on the subject of the International Exhibition. This is well: and if the said people will only keep on getting pretty thoroughly aroused until 1872, for which year the exhibition in question is fixed,

This Board met at noon yesterday, President ROACH in the chair. An immense quantity of routine business was transacted, after which the following appointments of Court Clerks were made: Marine Court--Lawrence Clancy, reappointed. First District Court--John M. Costa. Second District Court--Max Moses.

The sale of leases for stalls in the new Avenue C Market was continued yesterday with greater success than was experienced last week. Each stall has a fixed rent, and bids are received for the lease over and above this amount. About eighty stalls have been disposed of thus far at premiums ranging from $5 to $400, and the remainder will be sold on Wednesday at 12 o'clock.

The owners of property on the Sixth-avenue, above Forty-second-street, and the side streets 200 feet each way, held a meeting last evening at the Howard Rooms, corner of Forty-second-street and Sixth-avenue, for the purpose of taking advice and remonstrating against the assessment levied for laying the Nicolson pavement on the Sixth-avenue, from Forty-second to Fifty-ninth-street. The meeting was not large,

The heaviest earthquake ever experienced in Eastern California and Nevada occurred about 6 o'clock last. evening. The shock was felt with more or less severity at Sacramento, Marysville, Grass Valley, Nevada City, Lowa Hill, Stockton, Chico, Truckee and other neighboring towns.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the first column of the editorial page of the TIMES, under the head of ''Terms of the New-York Times," I find the remark in regard to regiestered letters: "The system is an absolute protection against losses by mail."

The case of EDWARD LORD and THOMAS DAVIS, charged with picking the pocket of JULIA BRIGGS at Wood's Museum on Christmas Day, as previously reported, was again before Justice DODGE yesterday, and the accused were committed for examination.

Yesterday afternoon some children playing at the foot of Thirty-third-street, East River, rambled upon an old dirt scow moored there, Upon this decrepit and deserted vessel they found a large glass jar which contained the perfectly-formed body of an infant.

Monthly report No. 3, series 1869-'70, of the Bureau of Statistics, now in press, exhibits the trade of the United States with foreign countries during the month of September, 1869, and the nine months ended the same, compared with the corresponding periods of 1868. The Seventeenth Assembly District Union Republican Association met last evening for the last time previous to reorganization, at the Wigwam in Forty-ninth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues. Resolutions were passed unanimously complimenting GEORGE P. RADFORD, Preisent ;

HANNAH A. C. LAWLER, of No. 192 Bleecker-Street, made a complaint yesterday before Justice DODGE, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, in which she stated that on the 22d inst, a boy named JOHN CAMPHELL came to the store with a note for Mrs. MORRIS, which he delivered to an attendant at the counter,

The body of an unknown man, that was discovered by some boys in the woods at Orange Mountain, near the estate of General McCELLAN, on Sunday the 12th just., was surrounded with a mystery that has recently been cleared to a suspicion of murder.

The Spanish gunboats, thirteen in number, which left DELAMATER'S Yard on Christmas Day and dropped down to Quarantine, as already reported, have not yet left the port, nor is it probable that they will depart before Thursday next. They lie at another around the Spanish war steamer Isabel Ualolica, off Stapleton Landing.

The weather and tides have delayed the Government soundings at Shelldrake Reef, where M. MAILLEFERT has been at work. Way's Reef has been surveyed, but the plotting has not been completed by which the result can be known. M. MAILLEFERT'S friends are confident of his having made good progress, and will make every exertion to have his contract extended.

JEROME BRADLEY, who is already committed by both Justices DOWLING and HOGAN, in default of $100,000 bail, on a charge of having had felonious possession of a large number of valuable stolen bonds, was yesterday again arranged before Justice HOGAN to answer the charge of forgery.

Last evening, about 7 o'clock, JOSEPH BARNADO, an Italian, living at No. 14 Roosevelt street, caused the arrest of one of his countrymen, who had threatened to kill him. White on his way home, after taking this precaution, when passing the corner of Baxter and Leonard streets, BARNADO was assaulted by another Italian, known in the neighborhood as "Fashi," who plunged a knife into his check, and instantly fled, escaping for the time.

Considering the inclement weather, quite an audience was present at the temperance meeting given under the auspices of the National Temperance Society at St. Paul's M. E. Church, last evening. Biship JANES presided. The pastor, Rev. dr. RIDGAWAY, rad a portion of the Seriptures and offered up a prayer.

G. S. CODY, Sheriff of Culpepper County by military appointment, has been tried by a military commission for embezzling about $10,000, and sentenced to five years in the State Penitentiary....A disturbance occurred on Christmas night between some white and colored men.

The extraordinary session of the French Corps Legislatif was closed yesterday, and the regular session opens to-day. There is one circumstance in connection with the death of public men in this country to which we ought by this time to be well accustomed. It is the melancholy state of dependence in which they are compelled to leave their families.

At Communipaw Market this morning trade was down from 1/2e. to le. ?? lb., according to the grades. That is, prime Cattie fell 1/2e. ?? lb., and inferior lots were fully ie. lower ?? lb. than during last week. Sheep also were slack, both as to prices, sales and quality. In a general way trade was depressed; the holiday's supplies hold out still in retail markets, and little fresh stock has come to hand.

The most destructive fire occurring here in many years took place this morning, breaking out at 2 o'clock, and continuing late into the morning. Seven large brick stores in South Salina-street, owned by GIFFORD, HAMLET CROUSE, were burned or crushed by falling walls.

The American Theatre, Walnut-street, above Eighth, was the scene of great excitement on Saturday night last. The building was crowded almost to suffocation, and hundreds who applied for admittance were turned away. The programme was carried out without the slightest accident to mar the pleasure of the thousands who were enjoying the performances, until about 10 o'clock, when through the house the cry of fire was raised.

GUSTAVUS ASPLAND, of No. 7 Second-avenue, appeared yesterday before Justice DODGE at the Jefferson Market Police Court and stated that Sunday night he was in company with NELSON NELSON and LEONARD ROTH, and that while in the saloon corner of Spring and Mereer streets, they robbed him of his watch. The accused, who had been arrested, demed their guilt, but were committed for trial.

A dense for hung over the City yesterday morning, and in the thickest of it several collisions occurred in the rivers and the habor. The ferry boat Morristown, of the Hoboken line, when near the middle of the river, collided with a sloop. Both of the vessels were somewhat damaged. A youth on board of the ferry boat.
The holidays are passing very tranquilly....JOSE CRESPILES and JOSE RUBO, convicted of attemptig to incite a rebellion among the Catalan volunteers, were sentenced and garroted on Christmas Day.

A row, and remarkable case of stabbing, took place Christmas, at 7 o'clock In the evening, on Broadway, near Eighth-street. JERRY HOGAN was found lying there, with a knife buried to the hilt in his left temple. He was unable to speak, and was thought to be dying.

The statement has been published that the Mexican Commission now in session in this city has virtually decided that it has no jurisdiction over franchises purchased by American citizens of the Mexican Government.

The Isabel Catolica and her charge still ride to their anchors on the quiet bosom of New-York Harbor; nor does there appear to be the slightest chance of their departure at this side of New Year's Day. Coal is the immediate demand, as the Spaniards purpose buying 20,000 tons in New-York for consumption on board of their war steamers on the Cuban station.

The family of Governor McDOUGALL arrived here to-day from the north. They left Pembina last Saturday, and will await the arrival of Governor McDOUGALL, who is expected to reach St. Paul next Friday en route to Canada.

The terms of union for the Republican Party of the City and County of New-York, agreed upon at the instance of the State General Committee last Summer, and ratified by the Republican State Convention, have been thus far carried to Success. To-night the programme will be completed by the election of delegates in the various Assembly Districts, who are to constitute the new Union General Committee.

New-Haven is to have a Sunday paper. A little pleasant weather would be an agreeable change. The Texas packers are now busily engaged in putting up beef and sending it to New-Orleans. The dividends from Massachusetts manufacturing stocks are smaller than usual.

Our Washington correspondent transmits important intelligence respecting an alleged "compromise" arrived at by Virginia Republicans, in council at Richmond. To avert the threatened exaction of the test oath from the members of the new Legislature, it is proposed to lay before Congress a bill providing for some further action by the Legislature as preliminary to complete readmission.

A telegraphic correspondence between Mr. JAMES G. BENNETT, Jr., and Mr. ASHRURY, held during the past week, has resulted in an acceptable arrangement for an ocean race between their respective yachts, the Dauntless and Oambria, both schooners. e race will take place on the 4th of July next, starting from old head of Klusale, Ireland,

Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE'S final contribution to the Byron controversy will be giver to the public on the 8th of January. The volume will make quite a bulky book of 430 pages, ant the title as now decided upon is as follows Lady Byron Vindicated : Being History of one Byron Controversy from 1816 to the present time The last skeets of the volume will not leave the printer's hands for several days,

Hon. GEORGE S. BOUTWELL, Secretary of the Treasury, returned before the Mercantile Library Association, in Music Hall, this evening, on the "Transition Period of the United States," A fair audience business men, particularly those interested in finance.

Dr. THOMAS CLARKSON MOFFATT, late physician-in-Chief of the Seaman's Retreat, Stapleton, Staten Island, was buried yesterday. In the morning the coffin bearing his remains was borne from his residence in the Retreat grounds to the First Presbyterian Church, located near them, and of which he was for a number of years an elder.

Yesterday morning Officer WALKIN SHOW, of the Broadway Squad, captured a burglar in the cellar of the boarding house of Mrs. FISSUX, No. 8 West Fourteenth-street, where he was concealed under a large trunk.

Imporant ant intelligence reached your correspondent to-night from a reliable source in Richmond, concerning a new movement regarding the admissionof Virginia. It is to the effect that since the adjournment of Congress there have been repeated efforts made to harmonize the two wings of the Republican Party in regard to the admission of the State.

The difficulty and delay anticipated in the transmission of the outgoing foreign mails, owing the refusal of the steamship lines to transport them at the reduced rates proposed to be paid by the United States Government, will not, after all, be so great as was thought.

At a meeting of the Police Commissioners held yesterday afternoon the new Thirty-fifth Precinet was established, to be bounded by the Bowery and Broadway, Bleecker and Houston streets, the territory to be taken out of the Fourteenth Precinet.

Governor PALMER declines to commission Mrs. MYRA BRADWELL. of this city, a Notary Public, for the reason that an official bond would be necessary, and being a married woman, she is legally incapable from giving the bond required.

THURSDAY. Mails for Bermuda, W. I., by the Fah-Kee, close at the General Post Office at 2 P. M. Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Bremen, by the Rhein, close at 12 M. Supplementary mail for paid letters on the pier foot of Third-street, Hoboken, to 1:45 P. M.

An examination was held before Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, in the case of ROBERT MARTIN, charged with counterfelting a plate for printing disbursing officer's checks, the kind used by the National Treasury Department.

I doubt that there are eleven millions of Spiritualists in America; but there must be a large number interested in the subject, in one way or other, so much as to wish to know what progress England is making in the science of the supernatural. I have, therefore, from time to time, given such facts as have come to me. Little is said publicly on the subject.

A petition memorializing Congress not to reduce the present tariff on iron has received the signatures of many of the iron manufacturers of this city and other points of the State. The iron men here have invited Dr. WM. ELDER, of Philadelphia, to visit St. Louis and deliver an address on the interests involved....

EDWARD PERRY, the junkman, suspected of having kitled THOMAS HAYES, late watchman at HARBECK'S stores, in Furman-street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday night, finding that he was closely tracked by the Police and that escape was impossible, surrendered himself to the authorities at Jefferson Market yesterday morning, and was subsequently taken to Brooklyn and handled over to the authorities there.

Count DARU and LOUIS JOSEPH BUFFET, leaders of the "Left Centre." have declined seats in the new Cabinet, and it is reported MM. TALHOUET and SEGRIS, members of the "Right Centre." M.
