Long before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, every seat and almost every standing place was occupied by the large audience presebt t the last of the two holiday concerts given by this Association. The popularity of these concerts cannot be questioned, but it is far from being solely due to " popular prices."

At the regular meeting of the Fire Commissioners held yesterday, a report was received from District Engineer SULLIVAN, stating the scarcity of street hydrants in his districts, and designating sixty-eight localities where they are needed.

It will be remembered that when the late Mr. DEVLIN became City Chamberlain. the City funds were transferred, under a mandamus of the Supreme Court, from the Park Bank to the Broadway Bank. While the matter was in litigation. the Park Bank retained the funds of the City, then amounting to $4,000,000, about forty days beyond the time when the Broadway Bank was appointed to receive the deposits.

It is to be hoped that the Congressional Committee, now in session in this City, will promptly and decidedly condemn the scheme to stop the work, of late so rapidly progressing, on the new Post Office. it is well under stood here from what sources this project to change the site have come.

Tuesday night a young woman was found disabled in the street, and, being taken to the Seventh Precinct Station House, it was discovered that she had taken laudanum, with the intention of ending her life. After she had been relieved of the drug.

Yesterday the House Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, of which General FARNSWORTH is Chairman, and Messrs. ADAMS, BOYD, FITCH, TRIMBLE and FERRY are members, assembled at the Astor House, room No. 41, for the purpose of considering what is understood to be a proposition to change the site of the new Post Office and United States Court building to a location further north, but within the limits of the City Hall Park.

General PUELLO, a St. Domingo man, who holds the rank of a Field Marshal in the Spanish army, and commands the Central Department at Puerto Principe, has made up his mind (on paper at least) to attack the insurgents.

J.P. COOPER, Justice of the Peace, held an inquest on Tuesday, at Rutherford Park, N. J., to inquire into the cause of the death of LOUIS MILLER. From the evidence it appeared that the deceased was driving across the Erie Railway track about 7:30 A.M., when the express train No. 12 came along.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday. The only business transacted was to refer to a Committee the resolution giving the Second avenue Railroad Company power to use portions of Sixty-second and Sixty-third streets, near Second-avenue. The Board then adjourned.

A special dispatch from St. Paul to-day, states that the cause of Governor McDOUGALL'S retreat from Winnedeg was the result of an interview between McDOUGALL and DONALD G. SMITH, of the Hudson Bay Company The colony, for a time, reverts to the control of that Company.

No meeting of the Women's Suffrage Burean was held this week. Desirous of ascertaining the reasons of its adjournment, our reporter visited Miss ANTHONY in the afternoon to get her views on the subject. She was hard at work as usual, exceedingly agreeable and free to speak about the matter.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your edition of this morning I find, in the annual report of the Emigration Commissioners, mention again made of the disastorus passage of the ship James foster, Jr., some twelve months since.

Another and more formidable raid on the managers, dealers and middlemen engaged in lotteries is contemplated by the Federal law officers, who believe that the best method for collecting the revenue tax on the business is by inaugurating criminal proceedings against the offenders.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30.--Several shocks of earthquake were felt in Virginia City last night and this morning. Some of them were quite severe, and the people were considerably alarmed....The steamships Oriflamme and Pacific collided off Santa Barbara on the night of the 28th inst.

The article which we published on the 30th November last, announcing the intentions of the United States Government in reference to the renewal of the Alabama negotiations, has attracted some little attention in England, and we lay before our readers to-day the comments of two of our leading contemporaries on the subject.

WASHINGTON. DEC. 30.--Mr. VINCENT COLYER, of New York, yesterday handed to President GRANT a memorial, signed by a number of the property holders and business men of Victoria, to be followed by another, which will contain the names of all the British merchants and others at Victoria places, in favor of the transfer of British Columbia in the United States.

The steam yacht Anna, ostensibly owned by GEO. W. BROWN, of the firm of BROWN PHILLIPS, No. 155 South-street, but really owned by the Cuban Junta, left her dock at the foot of Division-avenue, Brooklyn, E. D., on the morning of the 29th inst., at 10 o'clock, having cleared for Nassau.

CONCORD, N. H., DEC. 30--A two days session of the New-Hampshire Woman's Suffrage Association began in Eagle Hall today, Mrs. NATHANIEL WHITE, of Concord, President. There were about one hundred persons present, among them many Shakers. The records of the convention held last year were read.

WASHINGTON H. HARRINGTON, a ?? burglar, went into the office of LORILLARD Co., in Chambers-street, yesterday, and presented a subscription paper for the benefit of the family of HENRY JOHNSON, who was said to have been a gentleman and good officer.

The property which the German cabinet makers are acquiring at Astoria for the purpose of building up a town, within easy communication with the factories is the City where they are employed, is undergoing a rapid improvement. Section one is already in possession of its property, and during the past three weeks has been employed in laying out the streets;

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. MONEGHAN in the chair. A resolution to increase the salary of the Third Clerk in the Bureau of Street Improvements to 83,500 per annum, was concurred in, notwithstanding the Mayer's veto. A resolution was adopted to pay ALGERNON S. SULLIVAN 84,000 for legal services in the case of McVEANY vs. CULKIN.

At a meeting of the belly makers last evening it was reported that a member had been discharged from Steinway's manufactory for trying to induce a fellow workman to join the Society. It was resolved to pay him full wages until he obtained another situation

The new Ministry in France has not yet been consolidated. The Prince DE LA TOUR D'AUVERGNE, ex-Minister of Foreign Affairs, and M. GRESSIER, ex-Minister of Public Works, have been made Senators....The lunatic asylum at Tulle, France, was burned on Wednesday. No lives were lost.

The following new buildings have been proposed since our last report: Five first-class dwellings, north side of One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street, between Fourth and Madison avenues, 17 1/2 by 42 feet, three stories, brown-stone front. LAWBENCE DALY, owner.

The Tammany Hall General Committee met at the Wigwam in Fourteenth-street last evening, Grand Sachem TWEED in the chair. There was a very large attendance of the tribe. The Chairman rattled off a few words in the Indian dialect on taking his seat

The New-Jersey State Convention of Public School teachers commenced its sessions at Norristown on Wednesday. A large number of teachers, representing every county in the State, were present, and the discussion of questions concerning the instruction of pupils was participated in by the members with the deepest interest.

JOHN CAMPHELL., of No. 101 Perry-street, was thrown yesterday morning when crossing Mereer-street at Fourth-street, by stepping on a rope training from a truck, and his head striking on the curbstone, he received a concussion of the brain.

Mr. JOHN B. McKEAN, who for nearly seven years past has occupied the important position of Clerk of the Supreme Court Circuit, Part 1., has tendered his resignation and it has been accepted, to take effect on the first of the ensuing month.

In the Seventh District the following ticket was elected by the Republicans on Wednesday night, (instead of that reported yesterday,) receiving 618 votes to 298 for the Thomas E. Stewart Company's ticket: President, Colonel Frederick A. Conkling; First Vice President Andrew Kinnis: Second Vice-President, William Mertan; Recording Secretary

The position of affairs is but little changed. The Captains of the British and French men-of-war in port have intimated to SALNAYE that if, on the approach of the insurgents, he attempted to use any measures in defending his position in Port-au-Prince which placed the lives and property of foreigners in jeopardy, they would land their men and resist him.

The Police Commissioners held another protracted meeting yesterday, in which the time was mostly consumed in undoing what they had done the day before. JOSEPH NICHOLSON, of the Eighteenth precinct, who on Wednesday was made an acting Sergeant and assigned to the Fifteenth Precinct, was reduced to patrol duty and sent to the Fifteenth.

Mr. CHARLES CALLENDER, the Superintendent of National Banks, who has been investigating the accounts of EDWARD J. OAKLEY, Cashier of the Merchants' Exchange National Bank, states that the amount of the discrepancy will not exceed $100,000.

The case of JOHN REAL convicted in the cyer and Terminer in February last of the Murder of Policeman SMEDICK was before the General Term of the supreme Court again yesterday. The court was composed of Presiding Judge CLERKE and JUDGE SUTHERLAND and CARDOZO.

The first number of the new series of The Christurn Union comes before the people full of life and promise, and more fortunate than most new enterprises. palpably conquers success at the start. It bears both the sugury and the fruits of success on its face; every page of it shows skill and power--of power not expended in a first effort, but with reserves behind.

The following names constitute the roll of new delegates to the Kings County Republican General Committee, excepting in the cases of contested elections: First Ward--Edwin A. Studwell, George Meritt, Edwin M. Esterbrook, Ludovie Bennet, Mortimer C. Earl.

Some of the country papers are still talking of cutting the State in two and leaving New-York City out in the cold. The reason they give is that they want to escape contamination, or think New-York is going from bad to worse and want to cut loose from it before it gets worse.

It is rumored that a plot to burn or otherwise destroy the Spanish gunboats lying at anchor off Staten Island, similar in character to that described in the TIMES a week of two ago, has been laid and will be carried out as soon as possible.

The opening services of the Classon-avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, of which Rev. JOSEPH P. DURYEA, D. D., is pastor, took place last evening. The new and commodious edifice was filled by an enthusiastic congregation. This is one of the ?? churches of Brooklyn. .

On and after Saturday next a change will he made in the postal arrangements between this country and France. Heretofore the rate on letters to that country direct has been fifteen cents per quarter once, and on letter for Italy, Switzerland, Holland and Belgium, twenty-one cents per quarter ounce. Prepayment was optional, as also on letters sent to France via England.

On Christmas evening Collector GRINNELL gave a dinner at his residence in this City, to Hon. F. A. Low, United States Minister to China. Among the invited guests were Hon. EDWARDS PIERREPONT, United States District Attorney, DENNING DUER, Esq., Judge BLATCHFORD. J. P. LINDSAY, Esq., Colonel FRANK E. HOME

The agitation for abolishing the franking privilege is taking a somewhat more definite shape than heretofore. Hon. JOHN HILL, Congressman from the Fourth District of New Jersey, has distributed a petition to both Houses among his constituents, and the same is being extensively signed.

In the Supreme Court, General, Term yesterday, the case of BOLLES, Receiver, vs. DUFF et al. was decided, before Judges CLERKE, SUTHERLAND and INGRAHAM. Judge SUTHERLAND held that the orders of the 10th and 14th of June should be vacated, on the ground that they must presume them to have been made under a misapprehension of the proceedings on April 20

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 30.-JOHN G. WALKER, the gentleman having in charge the Chinese under contract to work on railroads in Texas, in a communication to the Republican, says: "A marked characteristic of the Mongolian race is suspielon and want of contidence.

When the Drainage act was first passed by the Legislature and ratified by the voters of Flushing, its measures were imperfectly under-stood by the great body of citizens. The general impression was that it empowered the six Commissioners, composed of the first citizens of the town irrespective of party, to drain the meadows and low lands adjoining the villages of Flushing.

The report of United States Marshal HARLOW only dates bark to the 1st of May last, the time when ex-Marshal MURRAY retired from his office, The report shows that there were 173 monitions, 532 capiases, 119 admiralty monitions and 49 civil capiases served by Deputy Marshals during the past eight months, and also that 500 criminal arrests were made in the same period.

A veteran officer of the Custom House, who first reported for duty in its dusky interior thirty-seven years ago under the reign of "Jackson the Great." while speaking recently of the growth of New-York commerce, put the whole subject concisely in a single sentence, "When I came here, the Custom House was a one-horse concern; now, Sir, we drive four-in-hand."

Mrs. CAROLINE KRIETZ, of No. 330 East Eighteenth-street, made a complaint before Justice DODGE. yesterday, stating that she had been robbed of a single diamond stone, worth $100, which had been set in an earring. ALEXANDER BERHARD, a dentist, living at No. 207 East Forty-first-street, called upon her professionally, she said, and she is certain that when he began work both earrings were perfect.

CADWELL--TAULMAN.--At the residence of the bridge's grandparents, on Wednesday, Dec. 22, by Rev. Wm. Adams, D. D., of this City, ELISHA J. CADWELL, of this City, to CORNELIA, eldest granddaughter of Peter H. Taulman, Esq., of Piermont. CHADWICK--DUDLEY.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 28, by Rev. John E. Cookman, Mr. JOSEPH P. CHADWICK, of Keyport, N. J., to Mrs. R. A. DUDLEY, of Keyport, formerly of New-York.

PARIS, Dec. 30.-The new Ministry has not been constituted. The matter is still one of general Speculation and newspaper comment. The Prince DE LA TOUR D'AUVERNE, the ex-Minister of Foreign Affairs, and M. GRESSIER, the ex-Minister of Public Works, have been appointed Senators... There has been unusually heavy outflow of specie from the Bank of France this week.

The Republican primary elections on Wednesday evening for the choice of delegates to the new General Committee, and of officers of the district organizations, passed of, as a general thing, harmoniously. Efforts were made in two or three districts to bring in Tammany repeaters for the purpose of carrying one or the other of the rival tickets.

During the present year there were 408 admiralty, revenue and internal revenue suits instituted in the United States District Court, of which 180 met with final disposition. There were 47 law and equity suits also instituted.

Mr. WARDWELL. Superintendent of the Penitentiary, has issued the following special order: SUNDAY, Dec. 29, 1869. PRISONERS: When I desire to inflict any punishment on you, I have only to turn to the Various prison books on my table, and I can see at once any and all modes of punishment possible for any man to conceive of.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 30. Two two-story brick buildings on Main-street were burned last evening. They were occupied by JAS. F. SNOW, dry goods, whose stock, valued at $15,000, was badly damaged by water, insured for $5,000 in various offices; the store owned by SYLVANUS photograph ?? stock cutirely destroyed, insurance unknown; TODD'S picture frame factory, loss $500. no insurance. ce.

In the Times of yesterday we gave an account of the action of Postmaster-General CRESWELL with regard to the transmission of foreign mails, the steamers heretofore carrying them having refused to accept the reduced rate to be paid for ocean postage after he 1st of January, 1870.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Certain French and English papers contain a notice of an intended marriage of Mrs. ABRAHAM LINCOLN to a Baden Count, which is one of the basest lies ever invented and told, and evidently fahricated to injure the reputation of the lady.

O'Brien, Miller, Hardy, Repper, Farley McQuade--10. The minutes of meeting held December twenty-seven were read and approved.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Wish you and with many others I say let the taxes be reduced-and especially the income tax. The article signed "Clerk" in your paper Last week was worthy of consideration. It makes a vast difference with a man whether his income is derived from his salary, from his labor or from the interest of his bonds.

We reprint to-day a paragraph on the Alabama claims which appeared in the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 30th ult., and seems for many reasons to deserve attention. The NEW-YORK TIMES has from its birth been distinguished among its contemporaries in the Empire City as being at once reasonable and respectable.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The Governor's Message is completed and nearly all in type. It will make about six columns of the Argus, and will be furnished to the Press simultaneously with its delivery to the Legislature. The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor are also nearly ready for delivery, and will also be furnished in advance.

The alleged frauds in the levying of assessments for the improvement in certain streets in Hoboken was, it was thought, to have received the consideration of the Common Council of that city at its special meeting last evening. That body convenced, however, only for the purpose of authorizing warrants for the payment of the members of the Police force, and as soon as it had completed this business adjourned.

On the 1st of January next an important act passed at the last session of the Dominion Parliament, with the view of preventing Canada, being made an asylum for thieves and swindlers, comes into operation.

GRAND ORGAN CONCERT. A full description of the new organ for Dr. TYNG'S Church was given to the readers of the TIMES yesterday morning. The instrument, with its varied resources and grand effects, was exhibited before an exceedingly numerous audience last evening. It so large an organ there are, of course, many defects.

A meeting of the petroleum oil exporters was held at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Merchants' Exchange, in Pine-street, for the purpose of receiving a report from the Committee recently appointed to arrange for the sale and purchase of petroleum. Mr. BURLACE occupied the chair, and Mr. BRINSLEY was appointed Secretary.

We await with no little interest too developments of the Ecumonial Council at Rome-with none the less interest because the precise character of its developments is still uncertain. The more fact that a convocation of this kind has taken place but once in many conturies, gives the event at unusual importance.

A telegram was received from Albany yesterday, by Messrs. CHITTENDEN Co., of this City, stating that an attempt had been made to swindle a Troy bank by a men who deposited a certified check on a bank in this City, purporting to be drawn by that firm. A similar attempt was made to defraud the New-York State National Bank at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--The Appropriation Committee, at their meeting to-day, had under consideration some of the appropriation bills, and after a short discussion, adjourned to Tuesday next. The Committee have nearly finished the Legislative and Executive, the Pension and the West Point bills, and will at an early day present them to the House.

The City of New-York still an experimenter in street pavements, and from the less y view of a majority of its throughfares the stranger would inevitably conclude that the experiments had almost universally resulted is failure. Probably no metropolis with the pretensions and wealth of New-York is so wretchedly paved.

The Albany has gone out of commission, and her crew is transferred to the Vermant.

Navigation on the Hudson River is now, open between here and Albany-a very rare occurrence at this season of the year. A propeller made the passage through yesterday without encountering any formidable diffeulties. All the wider places, such as the bays at Poughkeepsie, Newbarg, Haverstraw and "Tappan Zee," were almost entirely free of ice,

The recurrence of New-Year's Day brings with it all those feelings of good will towards our fellows, the expression of which we New-Yorkers have crystallized into custom; and it is to be hoped that the salutation upon the lips of all today will be a prophetic one-A Happy Now Year.

During Tuesday night the Savings bank in Rockville ws entered by burglars. The robbery was unusually bold and daring. A visit was first made to the residence of Mr. L. BISSELL, Treasurer of the bank, and from his pocket keys were taken which gave the seamps ready admission to the bank building and safe.

The first number of the new monthly of the Young Men's Christian Association made its appearance yesterday. In shape and size it resembles Appletons' Journal, and has on its first page an excellent engraving of the new building in Twenty-third-street.

The Brooklyn Fire Commission was organized on the 22d of May, under an act of the Legislature, which passed last session, but did not get actively at work until the 15th of September, when the voluntary system was merged into the paid department. The Commissioners are engaged in preparing the first annual report to the Legislature,

New-York Legislature met. 8.--Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS died at Culpeper, Va., aged 67. Major-General LOVELL H. ROUSSEAU died at New-Orleans, 51 years of ago.

There is no probability of the departure of the Spanish flotilla for Cuba before Tuesday or Wednesday. Its detention is owing to the Spanish Naval commissioners' desire to have the vessels thorughly finished in every little detail are they go to sea, and not, as has been alleged, by Mr. DELAMATER'S objection to their going to sea before he is paid.

The State Military Associaton will hold its annual session this year at Albany, on the 18th inst. Judging from the previous achievements of this organization, the present year will not bring with it any decided advantage to the National Guard.

The surrounding neighborhood is suffering from extreme excitement regarding the appearance of no less than ten cases of trichiniasis, which are likely to terminate fatally. The circumstances are as follows: About ten miles south of this town, in DcKalb, are the following persons, working on Mr. MALONEY'S farm: Mr. GROVIER, wife and tow little girls aged respectively 9 and 7 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.-A number of gentlemen connected with the newspaper Press of Richmond and Petersburg, Va., arrived in this city this morning, at the invitation of the journalists of Washington. The visit has been in contemplation for several Weeks and every preparation was made for extending to them a cordial reception.

Yesterday was a very quiet day in almost every branch of business. The active country demand for dry goods, plantation supplies and fancy goods, has almost entirely ceased, and country buyers have returned home to enjoy the holidays. However,

Bondon gets very dull just before the holidays. Everybody goes not of town that can age. The English gather in their country houses at Christmas, and invite all their friends. Cap tains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port re requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associate ?? Press, only to paries exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Sinonton, General Agent.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway bridge over the Hackensack River, on the Salt Meadows, is nearly completed. Construction locomotives are running from tile constructing bridge at Rutherford Park to the Hackensack. A great portion of the road-bed of the branch Is made at Clifton, running through THOMSON'S farm to Paterson.

JAN. 1--In steamship City of Washington, for Liverpool.--Miss Emma Wilson, Mrs. Alien, A. Platt, W. J. Stillman, Rev. H. C. Hayden, G. T. G: alman, Captain Dawson, H.M.S.; Nathan Bidwell and wife, Isaac C. Bateman, Mrs. Emma Boyd, Thomas Stainbridge, G. Henry, Robert and Henry Bidwell Leander Hook, J. C. Rogan, Thos. Marshall, Nicholas Little, J. Simpson.

The advent of 1870 was greeted with the customary salutations from New-Yorkers yesterday, and received the honors due to the natal day which marks on the century's dial the allotted age of three score years and ten.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. .-Chief of Police CAIN was yesterday committed to the Parish Prison for twenty-four hours for contempt of Court, in the Seventh District, for allowing Governor YARMOETH the use of the Metropolitan Police to prevent Auditor WICKLIFF from reoccuping his office in the Mechanics' Institute, from which he had been ejected by order of the Governor.

The Board of Supervisors met at 9 A. 31. yesterday, Mr. ORISON BLUNT in the chair. On motion, a ballot for President was taken, and Mr. WM. M. TWEED, having received nine votes, he was declared to be duly elected.

Inundation have occurred at Pisa from the overflow of the Arno. A collection of over 1,100 Chinese books has been given to the British Museum. The English Parliament meets again Feb. 8. Signor VERDI expects to finish his new opera is three months.

Things theatrical may be described as being just now in a state of simulated coma, or, more idiomatically, as "laying back for a spring." All awfull stillness prevails, like the quiet which went before the night of Vesuvian horror that saw the streets of Pompeli run tire and the morning that saw it one vast silent tomb.

MARTIN McGUIRE, the man who murdered his wife at their residence, corner of Washiugtonstreet and Retreat-avenue, on the 22d of last August, committed suicide last night by hanging himself in his cell at the county jail on Pearl street. He was discovered hanging dead by ANDREW FENN, son of the jailer, this morning, when ho went to let him out to wash.

The streets during the night dividing the last day of the old year from the first of the new, were unusually lively. Very rarely indeed have the streets at a late hour of the night been more crowded with drunken and boisterous men.

From the annual report of the Itahan School, it appears that during the past year the average attendance has been 256. There are 317 names on the books. Owing to the widening of Worth-street, and the consequent, removal of many families of Italians, the number of scholars attending the Evening School sessions has lately some what decreased.

The Long Islnud Historical Society, although young in years, is strong and manly, as an institution organized and built up for the purpose of preserving the annals of Brooklyn and Long Island, and of all the world beside. It is not exceeded by any society of the same kind in the country.

The work was given for John to "go ashore," and at once these was a deafening clamor and a confusion of tongues.

At a late hour last evening JOHN FULLARD, DOMINICK FEENEY and GEORGE BRUCE were taken into custody in Jersey City for having brutally assaulted Officer LYNCH. FULLARD had insulted a female, and she complained to LYNCH.

Rev. Dr. SAMUEL OSGOOD denies the story that he has joined the Episcopal Church, but says he has discontinued his connection with the Unitarian organization, on the score of objecting to sectarianism in any form. The last scene in the drama--the drama ?? let us rather say the travesty, the extravaganza, the burlesque which SALNAVE has for two years been enacting in the Island of Hayti, has come to an end.

Bishop MARIAN, of the Methodist Church, has promised to write a history of Methodism in Missouri. Rev. H. KINGSBURY, of New-York, will supply the pulpit of the Presbyterian Church, in Rome, N. Y., for six months.

On the 5th day of October last, DANIEL LINK, of this city, tiled a very matter-of-fact-sort of a bill against SOPHIA E. LINK, praying, according to the formula in such cases, for a divorce on the ground that his wife had willfully deserted him for the space of more than two years, although he had treated her kindly and affectionately, and in all respects bad conduted himself as a good, true and virtuous husband.

HAVANA, Jan. 1,--Intense excitement prevails hero in consequence of the announcement in the Havana journals of this evening that the revolution has terminated. According to the published statements, the editors of the journals have seen a copy of a circular signed by the members of the Cuban Juuta in New-York,

Yesterday was one of the most remarkable New-Year's Days we have seen for a great many years on the pemsula of Manhattan and its neighborhood-calm, soft, moist, like some days In the poetical Indian Summer or in the opening spring.

POUGHKEEPSIE. Jan. 1.--A terrible tragedy occurred at Sleepy Hollow, near Tarrytown, about 2 o'clock this afternoon. A man named V. W. BUCKHOUT shot his wife, a New-York merchant named ALFRED RANDALL, and a son of the latter named CHARLES RANDALL. Mrs. BUCKHOUT was shot through the temple; ALFRED RANDALL through the heart, and CHARLES RANDALL in the side.

All the State and City Courts commence new terms on Monday, the 3d inst. There will be no Supreme Court Circuit, for the reason that there are only four Judges of that Court for the present. Judge SUTHERLAND will take his seat in the Court of Appeals. There will be a General Term held by Presiding Judge INGRAHAM and Judges BARNARD and JOHN R. BRADY. Judge CARDOZO will hold Chambers dur.

Dr. Max Lilienthal, Rabbi Mound-street Temple, Cincinnati, Ohio: DEAR SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 14th inst. in relation to the Divorce laws of the State, and suggesting the propriety of my recommending their amendment to the Legislature.

The topic of town tall yesterday, partionlarly among the club men of the Metropolis, was the assault made by Mr. H. L. BATEMAN upon r. HIRAM CRANSTON at the Manhattan Club House on New Year's eYe. JOHN TAYLOR, aged 82, and a, native of England, was caught in the machinery of HOLBROOM'S soap factory, in West Twenty-fourthstreet, on the 22d ult., and had both legs fractured. Death ensued on Friday, and Coroner FLYNN hold an inquest.

The footing up of the year's business in Chicago shows receipts of merchantable commodities, including grain and lumber, of the value of $415,652,000, against $397,552,000 for the year 1868-an increase of $18,100,000. The manufactures of the city amount to $58,000,000, against $63,000,000 for the preceding year-a decrease of $5,000.000.

A good many years ago some trouble connected with a bank at Northampton caused the directors to engage the legal services of Hon. RUFUS CHOATE. The case was heard in Chambers at Boston, Chief Justice SHAW presiding.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. .--The Colored Society celebrated the anniversary of the issuing of the Emancipation Proclamation, and called upon Governor WALKER, Who made them a speech, in which he roverted to the occasion which they celebrated, and told them they were his peers before the law and vested with the same rights and privileges.

The climate of New-York and the contigu ons Atlantic seaboard has long been a study of great interest. We have just experienced a remarkable instance of its peculiarity The Hudson River, by a singular freak of temperature, has thrown off its icy mantle and opened its waters to navigation.

In our telegraph columns yesterday was an item dated Toledo, Iowa, Dec. 27, giving a brief account of the suicide of DENTON CAMERY, Deputy Treasurer of Tama County. The circumstances are to a great extent inexplicable. and have excited much interest In the locality in which the event took place.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Many thanks for giving us a poop behind the scenes. I say "us," not in an editorial sense, but meaning us, young ladles. It was a now revelation to hear what "faun" went on in the Gold Room and the Stock Exchange on Friday. I think we know now why so many men have so little conversation.

The diplomatic explanation in the Paris Journal Officiel, with respect to the examination and control by the French Government of dispatches by the Transatlantic cable, is more ingenious than candid.

The three young girls who came here from New-York, and were rescued by the Police from dens of infamy, have found a temporary home more suitable than the calaboose, in which they had been domielled for several days.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: For many years your newspaper has been our household guest, and I have learned to place great confidence in its prevailing sentiments of Justice and common sense, and for that reason am induced to apply to you on behalf of the school for girls, known as the "Head School," in Twelfth-street.

The cadet corps of the gymnastic school of the Turnverein of this City had their annual parade, under the direction of their instructor, Captain HERMAN BENNECKE, at Turner Hall, in Orchard-street, yesterday afternoon. They are about 100 in number, from 11 to 17 years old, and comprise three companies.

The most singular case of child abduction that ever came to our hearing was related to us last evening by the afflicted and half-crazed mother, who has been in our city for the last four days. The scene of the occurrence is dated in Washington City.

Great excitement was created in this village this (Wednesday) morning, by the discovery, on opening the Sehoharie County National Bank, that burglars had been at work the night before, and bad succeeded in obtaining an entrance to the bank and appropriating and carrying away everything of value therein.

A heavy southeast rain storm prevailed all last night and the greater part of to-day. As a consequence, the flood tide is very full. Reports from the south state that the down track of the Hudson River Railroad is badly washed near Cruger's, so that no trains can pass over it.

Very few public sales have taken place at the Exchange Rooms during the week past, and those chiefly by order of the Supreme Court. It has been almost impossible to negotiate private sales although there has been no decline in the prices demanded.

An unknown man, about 50 years of age, apparently intoxicated, walked off an East Boston ferry boat last evening and was drowned. PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 2.--General GEORGE F. SHEPLEY took the oath of office yesterday as United States Circuit Judge.

General H. L. BURNETT, the attorney for the Western distillers, had an interview yesterday with Commissioner DELANO relative to an extension of the time allowed for the fermentation period.

For the first time, almost in a generation, the State Capitol is to witness, on Tuesday next, the assembling of a Legislature composed of a clear working majority of Democrats in both Houses, backed up by a Governor and an entire Cabinet of State officers of the same political faith.

The orders of the Secretary of the Treasury for gold sales and bond purchases for the month of January, given to-night, show that he will continue his policy in a modified shape, the sales of gold authorized being but $4,000,000,

The colored people of Nashville yesterday celebrated the anniversary of the proclamation of freedom. After parading through the streets, they assembled in the Capitol and organized a convention. About 2,500 participated in the Convention.

There is a certain mystery banging about the conduct and disappearance of Rev. Mr. PEARCE, a Methodist clergyman of West Hampton, L. I. On Tuesday, last week, in seeming good health, he left his home for Moriches, and after purchasing a large trunk at that place, borrowed a horse and buggy of a friend, for the purpose of returning home, which he did.

Taken as a whole, the Woman Sufirage Convention just held at Concord seems to have been one of the most reasonable and influential meetings ever yet called in behalf of this cause. The Convention was all wrong, as usual, and perhaps as a matter of course, in its political premises and dogmas.

New Year's was bright and pleasant in Boston. Hon. D. W. VOORHIES is confined to his bed with inflammatory rheumatism. Twin brothers, 17 years of age, have just been sent to the Massachusetts State Prison for five years for burglary in Springfield.

A Liverpool merchant addresses to us a letter which we commend to attention as the judgment of a capable and distant observer upon some aspects of our financial problem. His difference with ourselves in regard to taxation and resumption refers rather to forms of expression than to essential points of the argument on either side.

The cry still is, REDUCE THE TAXES! The trading class is literally a unit in favor of reduction. The farmers are compelled, by falling prices,to pray for it as a measure absolutely necessary.

A terrible tragedy occurred last evening in a house of assignation in the Fourteenth Ward, where a man killed his paramour and himself, both the man and the woman expiring soon after their admission to Bellevue hospital.

The new legal tender notes of the denomination of fives, twenties and fifties will be ready for general circulation the early part of next week. "As the days begin to lengthen the cold begins to strengthen," says the old maxim, which has failed to come true thus far this season. The days began to increase in length on the 23d ult.. and the gain up to the end of the year was four minutes.

Mr. ANDREW WILSON, Jr., has entered on one of the largest real estate movements ever undertaken in Westchester County. On Saturday that gentleman gave a sumptuous dinner to a number of his friends at the residence of THOS. R. HAWLEY, Esq., on the White Plains road, near Mamaroneck, and there and then presented his plans for the coming season.

APPLEBY.--On Saturday, Jan. 1. WILLIAM APPLEBY, in the 76th year of his age. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend his funeral at the Church of the Holy Martyrs in Forsyth-st., between Hester and Canal sts., on Tuesday, the 4th, at 1 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Cuban Janta of this City have read with the almost indignation the telegram forwarded to the Associated Press from Havana, under date of yesterday, stating that the editors of Havana journals affirm that they have seen a circular signed by the members of this Janta, ordering the Cubans to lay down their arms.

The speech of Mr. SEWARD at the dinner recently given him by Minister LERDO, the Premier of the Cabinet of JUAREZ, is remarkable as a vivid picture of the condition of American republicanism, in the year 1861.

Considerable excitement was created yesterday by the strange actions and loud cries and exclamations of a woman who was being taken in an express wagon to the Poorhouse. She attacked the officer who had her in charge with great ferocity and desperation, scratching his face, pulling his hair, and calling for help.

From a controversy which is at present being waged in England between the advocates and opponents of trades' unions, some interesting facts may be gleaned regarding the general effect of these organizations upon trade, and the extent to which they are likely to modify the existing relations between labor and capital.

It is remarked that not one-tenth the number of field hands are seen upon the streets this Christmas as were any former since the war. They are far less roving. They are getting more settled, and finding out that yearly changes from one plantation to another do not pay.

The French Cabinet is not authoritatively announced, but is forecast in the official paper of M. OLLIVIER, La Liberle. Of the Ministry thus given, four of the members are Senators, and six are members of the Chamber of Deputies.

There is no reason why the South should not have a university of as high a grade and character as exists in any Portion, either of this Union, or in England or Germany. We have the intelicot, and we certainly have the material for its creation.

A grand barbecue was held hero to-day, for the entertainment of the poor of Syracuse. It was provided by JOHN GREENWAY. Thousands of persons from the surrounding country came to town, and the streets have all day worn a holiday appearance.

Returns from the Senatorial election in the Twenty-sixth District show the election of ABRAHAM V. HARPENDING, the Republican candidate, by a majority of several hundred votes. Though this result is not at all surprising to us, it is a great disappointment to the Democracy.

On this, the first business day of the new year, we present the readers of the TIMES. with a comprehensive review of the business of the past year, and what is better, with a statement of the outlook for 1870, as obtained from the lips of prominent merchants in each branch of business All of the gentlemen visited gave a free expression to their opinions, and the reasons which led them to the conclusions formed.

In his lecture Wednesday evening Mr. BOUTWELL declined to discuss any of the prominent business questions which now interest the country. It was evidently not his purpose to invite discussion, nor to provoke criticism on any of the points touching the future financial policy of the Government.

A retrospective view of the racing season of the year just closed, and a dispassionate observation of the most prominent events which have distinguished it, may not be without interest to the turfman at the present time, the running of the past season exercising no little influence on that of the coming year.

MARTIN MCGUIRE, the man who murdered his wife at their residence, corner of Washingtonstreet and Retreat-avenue, on the 22d of last August, committed suicide last night by hanging himself in his cell at the county jail on Pearl street.

The cartage business of the New-York Custom House for years has been a source of annoyance to the Collectors of the Port. During the administration of Collector SMYTHE trouble arising from mismanagement of the cartage business became notorious, was the subject of Congressional investigation and newspaper comment.
The steamer China sailed to-day for Hong Kong and Yokohama. She carried $693,000 in treasure, of which $645,000 was for Hong Kong, $10,000 for Shanghae and $38,000 for Yokohama.

The difficulty which we pointed out some time ago of making a Spanish Regency under MONTPENSIER acceptable at the Tulleries, will be found emphasized by this morning's telegrams. Queen ISABELLA is stated to have alleged that the barrier to her reconciliation with her brother was the well-known aversion of NAPOLEON III. to such a step.

We surrender to-day a large portion of our space to Mrs. STOWE'S vindication of her narrative concerning Lord BYRON and Mrs. LEIGH. We regret to be compelled at the outset to state our opinion that the reputation which will suffer most by this new "revelation" is that of Mrs. STOWE herself.

ALBANY, Jan. 3.-The Democratic caucus for Speaker of the Assembly, this evening, resulted, as every one anticipated who watched the progress of the canvass during the day, in the complete triumph of the Tam. many Ring. Yesterday at the Exchange Salesrooms was nn exceedingly dull one, no property being publicly disposed of. Some valuable real estate, however, is advertised to be sold dining the week. Attention is called to the advertisement of "Derby Farm," Aiken, S. C., now offered for sale by the proprietor.

The famous "cable" paragraph in President GRANT'S Message has atleast found a responsive echo in the sympathies of our countrymen and countrywomen in Paris, however it may affect the Parisians in general and outrage the sensibilities of the French authorities in particular.

Mayor HALL has determined, it appears, to take some action in regard to the pneumatic tube which is being run from DEVLIN'S building beneath Broadway: Yesterday he sent over one of his employees, with a written order, directing the person in charge of the works to admit the bearer to the tube and allow him to make such an inspection as he might deem necessary.

St. Paul, Minn., has just built a stone bridge across Bridal Veil Creek. Chicago telegraphed to San Francisco that no leading Eastern papers were published on the day after Christmas. Bourbon Connty. Ky., has contributed nearly $50,000 to the real estate and building fund of the Kentucky University.

A public meeting was held last evening at Ittner's Hall, Tremont, Westchester County, for the purpose of protesting .against the enormous amount of taxation which had been levied during the recent year, and to adopt measures of reform.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 3.--The action of the Ways and means Committee in reducing the tariff on pig iron from $9 to $7 per ton has brought out a savage howl from pig iron producers, though scarcely any of them aver that they cannot still make pig from at a good profit.

Another meeting of taxpayers, owning property on Sixth-avenue, between Forty-second and Fifty-ninth streets, opposed to the assessment for the Nicolson pavement now laid on the avenue, was hold last evening at the gas fitting establishment of A. MEAD, corner of Sixth-avenue and Forty-seventh-street. A number of gentlemen were present representing some eighty lots.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3.--The General Assembly met at 10 o'clock this morning. The Senate organized by electing E. J. HALL (Republican) Clerk, and B. T. CHURCHILL (Democrat) Sergeant-at-Arms. The House partially organized by electing A. J. CUNNINGHAM, (Reformer,) of Hamilton County, Speaker.

LEWISTON, Mo., Jan. 3.-A furious rain storm commenced yesterday and continued till 10 P. M.. causing considerable rise in the streams. Culverts are washed away on both of our railroads, so that no trains have gone out this morning. A remarkable display of auronal light was observed at 3 o'clock this morning. The light was vivid pink.

A few days ago two Police officers of this City were tried and convicted in the Court of General Sessions of the crime of robbing a Kentuckian in the street, at a late hour of the night, of the sum of about $430 in greenbacks. Two or three days after their conviction they were sentenced by Recorder HACKETT to the State Prison for five years each.

In accordance with the annual custom, there are prayer meetings being held every day this week in all the Evangelical Christian churches of this City and vicinity, the general purport of which is to further the Christianization of tho entire world.

An important question often comes up in regard to our charitable associations. "How shall they best be supported?"--by endowment from the State or by private and annual assistance ! There is clearly a right that all charities of a general nature should expect some help from the public Legislature.

Without formality or ostentation, Hon. D. D. T. MOORE, editor and proprietor of the Rural New-Yorker, presented, New-Year's Day, twenty of his employes with paid-up life insurance policies in the Farmers' and Mechanics' Life Insurance Company, in amounts of $500, $1,000 and $2,000, respectively, the whole insurance aggregating $18,000, at a cost to the liberal employer of nearly $5,500.

A man calling himself Colonel HOUSTON KING was brought before Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday afternoon, on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the Government. The story which was told about him by the officers having him in custody was of a very extraordinary character. It appeared that in July last he visited General HINOKENLOOPER, District Attorney at Cincinnati.

The customary address of the French Emperor to the Corps Legislatif at the beginning of the year was delivered on Saturday. The recent political concessions were alluded to as circumstances which augmented their prerogatives without diminishing his authority.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 4.-The steamer Norwich left Rondout yesterday, and reached tins city last night. Her officers report having experienced no difficulty, the river being open for the entire distance. Between this city and Athens there is some floating ice, but not enough to hinder the passage of boats.

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The resignation of the Spanish Cabinet, in consequence of Italy's refusal to permit the candidature of the Duke of GENOA, is announced. It is reported that Admiral TOPETE will return to the Ministry.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 4.--At a caucus of the Republican members of the Senate to-night, Hon. W. W. BOLSTER was nominated for President on the first ballot, and in the House caucus REUBEN FOSTER was nominated Speaker.

The new orders in regard to carting have been signed by Mr. GRINNELL, and they will be acted upon immediately. The new orders seem to meet with the approval of merchants and importers.

Recent occurrences in England, by which the interests of stockholders and others in some public companies have been seriously compromised, are leading to very general discussion as to the general management of such companies, and the prevention of similar irregularitios.

Coroner FLYNN held an inquest yesterday in the case of GEORGE BAUMAN and Mrs. ANNIE ALMEJO, nee McNAMARA, who died on Sunday night by pistol shot wounds inflicted by BAUMAN, as already reported in the TIMES.

Postmaster JONES has posted up a printed notice, for the information of all who seek positions in the Post Office, to the effect that no more vacancies will be occasioned, unless by natural causes or removals for neglect of duty.

Mr. JAMES W. MOORHEAD, charged with perjury on complaint of one D. G. SCOFIELD, was honorably discharged by Commissioner SHIELDS, yesterday, on motion of Assistant District-Attorney JACKSON, there being no witnesses produced by the complaint to substantiate the charge.

By the arrival of the brig Jane from Portau-Prince direct, full particulars have been received of the capture of Port-au-Prince by the revolutionary forces under General BRICE. On the 48th of December General BRICE, of the southern division of the army of the revolutionists, succeeded in landing one-half of his forces in boats in the immediate vicinity of Port-au-Prince.

By a telegram received yesterday afternoon from Absecom, N. J., we learn that the schooner Ida Smtth was driven ashore on Peck's Beach during the gale on Monday night. She is light, and will be saved.

HENRY WARREN, Engineer of one of the Spanish gunboats, known as No. 20, visited the United States District Attorney's office yesterday, for the purpose of making a complaint against the Captain of the vessel. He charged the latter with placing him under an armed guard of four Spanish sailors, in order to prevent him from going on land.

The Newark Common Council was formally organized last evening. A large crowd witnessed the ceremonies. After the Council bad been called to order, and prayer had boon offered, the Council proceeded to ballot for a Chairman. Five ballots resulted In a tie vote.

PWEED'S resolution to reseind the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment was called up at the opening of the Senate this morning, immediately after the reading of the journal. Senator WOODIN, of Cayuga, opened the discussion in a very able legal argument on the right of the present Legistature to reseind the action of a previous Legislature on this subject.

The Chamber of Commerce met at 1 P.M. yesterday, WM. E. DODGE, the President, in the chair. In opening the proceedings Mr. DODGH congratulated the Chamber on the improved prospects of commerce for the year upon which we are now entering, and expressed the hope that commerce would soon be disengaged from its present embarrassment.

MR. EDWIN BOOTH AS "HAMLET." Mr. EDWIN BOOTH is undoubtedly the best Hamlet seen in this country, by the present generation, and perhaps the best America has produced. We wish, in saying this, that it signified more. It is, however, undesirable that satisfactory representatives of this arduous character have been very few among us,

A case of much interest, not only as regards the amount in litigation, but also as to the prominence of the parties most interested, came before the Supreme Court at Chambers yesterday, Judge CARDOZO presiding. It is entitled ELAZABETR R. BOWNE vs. HERMANUS B. DURYEA and others. The defendant DURYEA is a well-known lawyer of Brooklyn.

The Plesant Parlors at No. 49 East Twenty third-street were filled yesterday afternoon with a large gathering of ladies and gentlemen, called together to organize a City and County Association in aid of the cause of woman sufrage. AIKEN. for an injunction to restrain the presentation of the drama of "Mary Warner" upon the stage of the Chicago Museum.

The value of statements relating to assets as a test of life insurance solvency is undoubtedly, as a correspondent alleges, subject to very important qualifications. The bare statement of amount insured and amount accumulated of itself proves nothing.

Governor CLAFLIN, of Massachusetts, will send in his Message on Saturday. The New-Haven Police arrested a student on Wednesday for breaking a street lamp. The Boston Advertiser suggests that if you want to find a live-long Friend, you had better got introduced to a Quaker.

The Irish journals report that during the Parliamentary election in Longford, which was bitterly contested and attended with great excitement, the supporters of MARTIN, the Fenian candidate, and the friends of NUGENT, came into collision at Gullet Hill, near Longford.

A meeting of the Privy Council was held to-day, at which it is understood the Red River difficulty was discussed. The Government will await the result of the negotiations of Vicar THIBAULT and Colonel DE SALABERRY. An effort will also be made to obtain a statement of the claims of the insurgent leaders to form a basis for settlement.

The mercantile agency of DUN. BARLOW Co. has issued its annual circular of the failures of the year just past, and gives, on the whole, an encouraging view of the commercial situation. The failures, it will be noticed, have been considerably in excess of those of the proceeding twelvemonth;

There is not an unprejudiced man or worman in New-York who is not ready to declare that the streets of the City are in a disgraceful condition the whole year round. A change of season only brings with it a change of the nuisances with which we are afficted If it is not snow, it is mud.

There is such a thing as true and conscientious allegiance to party, and there is also a spurious device for using "party" as a sort of bludgeon to knock down friends and foes with, on the least provocation. In the latter kind of tactics the Tribune is, and always has been, unrivalled-indeed, no one has ever contested the field with it.

The strike of the operators of the Western Union Telegraph Company still continues, the situation remaining unchanged. The operators express a determination not to yield until their alleged grievances are redressed, while the Company are equally resolute not to yield to the demands of the strikers.

The Bricklaysrs' Union No. 2 met at Demit Hall last night. The annual report of the Treasurer was received, showing the following figures: Total receipts, $4,680 52; total expenditures, $4,595 67, leaving a balance on hand of $84 85.

The Ways and Means Committee had a long session to-day, but nothing of importance was transacted. They discussed the miscellaneous articles and arrived at no decided conclusion on anything, the effort being made to have the tax on iron again put back to the old figure,

Governor BURBANK, of Dakota Territory, forwards to the Indian Office a report announcing the killing, Nov. 3, of three Arickarees, two women and one man, and the wounding of a young girl by the Sioux, supposed to belong to the Grand River agency.

The attempt to organize the new Republican General Committee last evening was a failure. Long before the hour appointed for opening the meeting an excited crowd was present, anxious to get into the Committee room, but failed in so doing until 7:30 o'clock.

Yesterday afternoon Coroner FLYNN proceeded to examine the three witnesses detained by the Police in the case of JAMES LOGAN, (No. 2,) who was shot on Wednesday morning in West Houston-street, by JERRY DUNN. These witnesses very justly complain that they were treated by the Eighth Ward Police more like actual criminals than credible witnesses for the people.

Both Houses of the Legislature met at the usual hour this morning, and after a brief session, adjourned over to Tuesday next, at 11 A. M. This long adjournment is partly to give Speaker HITCHMAN time to make up his Committees, and partly to enable the Democratic lawmakers to attend the "Americus Club" ball in New-York to-night.

Yesterday was the Feast of tile Epiphany, known to our ancestors as the Feast of Lights and Twelfth Night. In oldnu times this feast, which closes the holy season of the Nativity, was celebrated with much religious pomp during the day, while the night was abandoned to merriment, all constitutional authorities abdicating for the time and giving place to to the kings and queens of misrule.

Mr. HARDENBERG, Senator from the Fourteenth District, appeared and took the oath of office. A message was received from the Assembly, stating that they had concurred in the resolution relative to the Fifteenth Amendment. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. BOWEN--For a canal bridge at Albion, Orleans Connty.

The demand made by JOHN L. BROWN, manager of the street cleaning contract, for an increase in the compensation for cleaning the streets to $1,000.000 per annum, was based upon the assertion that the present price of $498,500 is not sufficient to keep the streets in a clean condition.

For several months past negotiations have been in progress between several small railway companies, whose charters have been obtained but whose tracks have not been laid, for a consolidation and for extension to New-York.

It must be presumed that the Governors of the New-York Hospital do not appreciate the very strong feeling which exists upon the maintenance of a hospital in the lower part of the City. Otherwise it is difficult to account for their intention to sell or lease the remainder of the old site, and do away with the hospital wing still in use.

The post was, in our opinion, correct as to the indication of the Tammany "beginning" at Albany. There is every reason to believe that the power of the Tammany Ring will roll over and crush all that bas been most honest, efficient and enlightened in our Municipal government.

BARTON.--Suddenly, in Brooklyn, on Thursday morning, Jan. 6, LOUISA, wife of Richard O. Barton, aged 52 years. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, corner Skillman-st. and Willonghby-av., Brooklyn, to-day (Friday) at 3 o'clock P. M. Her remains will be taken to Troy for interment.

The following new buildings have been proposed since Jan. 1, 1870: BROWN-STONE FRONTS. Five first-class dwellings, north side of Seventy-first-street, 110 feet east of the Boulevard,l 26x50, three stories, basement and cellar; J. W. OGDEN, Jr., Owner.

An attempt was made yesterday by E. H. LUDLOW CO. to break the silence of the Exchange Rooms by a public sale of real estate, but the result was a discouraging, failure. Two lots on he east side of Lexington-avenue, 25.5 feet north of Fifty-fourth-street, were put up at $7,500, but received no bids and were withdrawn.

A body of instruments is reported to be moving towards the Cauto Abajorigion, in the Eastern Department. The reported object of these expeditions is to destroy the cane fields.

A great part of the centre area has already disappeared, although but few men have been digging there, and in sic weeks the excavation will be about complete.

At the close of the lecture and entertainment in the Reformed Church, Bedford-avenue, Williamsburg, last night, Rev. Dr. PORTER, the pastor, on returning home, found his house in possession of about 150 friends and their wives.

Until now, any carman could cart Custom Honse merchandise if he could get the job and give bonds.

Both Houses of the Legislature of Minnesota met in the Senate Chamber to-day. Governor MARSHALL delivered his annual Message. He recommends that five hundred acres of the internal improvement lands be appropriated to pay all railroad bonds.

AHRENS.--On Friday morning, Jan. 7, Mrs. CATHARINE AHRENS, aged 76 years, 1 month and 23 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her nephew, F. Baker, No. 411 State-st., Brooklyn, on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

Our people have celebrated the holidays pretty extensively. An immense amount of money has "changed hands" in procuring articles in the present-making line. The Governor elect passed through this city Monday night going to Alabama. The General is boldly outspoken. he says, emphatically, he is Southern in all his feelings. In his administration though, he will not go back on the negro nor carpet-bagger. he has no resentments against the body of the white people who refused to support him inthe recent election.

It is a very hard Winter. There have been heavy gales, deep snows in the north, great floods in the midland and west.

The resolutions adopted by the Republicans of New-Hampshire at their State Convention in Concord, on Friday, are as follows: The Republicans of New-Hampshire, in delegate convention assembled, hereby renew and reaffirm their allegiance to the principles of liberty, equality and impartial suffrage, which underhe our republican institutions, and are the hope of the oppressed in every land .

We have heretofore spoken of tile merits of Mr. ALEXANDER WUST'S pictures. A year or two ago, shortly after his return from Europe, Mr. WUST exhibited a number of paintings of Norwegan scenery, which were much admired, and which brought high prices.

It has been stated that the largest sum subscribed in this City to the fund for the benefit of the family of the late Mr. STANTON is $1,000, and that that was from a Democrat. The facts do not bear out the statement. Mr. A. T. STEWART gave $5,000, and twenty other gentlemen, all Republicans, $1,000 each.

Corner FLYNN impaneled a jury yesterday in the case of JAMES LOGAN No. 2. who died on Thursday night by a pistol shot wound, alleged to have been infracted by JERRY DUNN, alias "Hawkshaw," on the morning of the 3d inst.

The sculptor TENERANI is dead. Mr. A. CLINT has been elected President of the Society of British Artists. A Miss GARRETT has passed her examinations for the M. D. degree of Paris. The Belgian Moniteur publishes a decree creating Post Office Savings Banks.

CAMPBELL charges the conductor and a man named BRERETON with assault and battery in so ejecting him. The case was tried in Paterson, N. J.,on Friday.

The first of the annual course of free lectures on Science and Art was delivered last evening at the Cooper Union by Professor EBELL, his subject being animal life and the general principles by which the laws of the animal kingdom are governed.

The case of MARVIN R. CLARK, petitioner against his wife SARAH ESTHER CLARK as respondent, came up yesterday in the Supreme Court Chambers before Judge CARDOZO. Mr. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER appeared for the petitioner, and Mr. COMPTON for the respondent.

At first the statement was treated as a simple canard circulated for the fun of the thing, though it now appears that the movement is really believed to be on foot.

There is but little new to chronicle in relation to the strike of the operations of the Western Union Telegraph Company. All the indications point to an early abandonment of the movement, notwithstanding that a majority of the men on strike profess to be determined to hold out to the last unless the Company comply, with their demands.

The regular mail steamer from Vera Cruz arrived here to-day, bringing advices from the City of Mexico to the 1st inst.... Governor SEWARD was still at the Capital, but expected to leave for Vera Cruz on the 10th.... Secor ZARCO, the editor of the Siglo, and a prominent politician, is dead.

The great dramatic event of the week has been the admirable production of "Hamlet" at Booth's Theatre. So sumptuous a revival is highly honorable to the management, and constitutes an important era in the history of Metropolitan art. As we have suggested before, the costumes adopted are significant rather of originality than of demonstrable correctness.

AHRENS.--On Friday morning, Jan. 7, Mrs. CATHINE AHRENS, aged 76 years. 1 month and 23 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her nephew. F. Baker, No. 411 State-st., Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. Wm. C. DAVIES was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday on the complaint of Colonel THOMAS B. VAN BUREN, of No. 52 Wall-street, who stated that the prisoner obtained $5 from him under pretence of being a distant relative, and destitute of means to proceed on his journey home. The surviving patriots of the war of 1812, residing in this State, met here to-day. Quite a number were present and many sent letters regretting their Inability to attend. General RANNEY, of St. Louis, presided.

Rev. GEO. PEARCE is the oldest missionary in India. He has labored there for forty-three years. Rev. E. K. FULLER, of New-York, has accepted a call to the Second Baptist Church in New-London, Conn. There was a singular and unfortunate scene occurred this morning at the State House. Mrs. JANE P. THURSTON, of Portland, had caused notice of a sale of the State of Maine, its rights, appurtenances, , to be posted up un the doors of the State House, and a little before 10 o'clock she ascended the Speaker's rostrum and proceeded in a manner worthy of HENRY BAILEY in his palmiest days to sell the State.

A new floating church for seamen has just been completed under the auspices of the Protestant Episcopal Church missionary Society of the Port of New-York, and will be opened today with appropriae services. It is known as the "Church of our Saviour," and lies moored in its permanent position at the foot of Pike-street, East River.

A fire occurred this morning in ELLIS HAZELTINE'S flouring mill, in North Water-street, causing damage to the amount of $15,000; insured. PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8.-A- fire occurred this morning at No. 712 Chestnut-street, on the seeond floor, occupied as a packing room of the dollar store on the first floor. The stock is ruined.

It is now ascertained that the total loss by the burglary at the Glen's Falls National Bank on Thursday evening will not exceed $23,000. The burglars failed to observe a package of $8,000 which was in the upper portion of the safe, and left it untouched.

The delegates elected at the primaries held on the 31st of December of constitute the Democratic Republican General Committee for 1870, met at Tammany Hall last evening to organize by the election of officers. Grand Sachem TWEED called the meeting to order, and, on motion of "Big Judge" CONNOLLY, was made temporary Chairman.

Sergeant WILLIAM H. LEFFERTS, President of the Metropolltan Police Mutual Aid Association, has submitted his annual report for the twelve months ending Jan. 8, 1870, from which it appears that the sum of $22,433 was collected from members, and duly paid over to the families of twenty-three deceased members.

The owner of a steamboat on the San Joaquin River made a written contract with a farmer to transport 500 tons of wheat from Paradise City to Stockton, at $2 per ten. The farmer failed to deliver the wheat according to contract, and the steamboat according to contract, and the steamboat man sued for 1,000, and claimed the entire sum as due him.

Captain-General DE RoDAS has issued a proclamation, generally complimentary to the behavior of the citizens and army. He says the sickly season has passed without diminishing the strength of the army. The insurgents took the offensive twice and were twice repulsed. The insurrection after that was confined to th mountains.

The Cigar Makers are still on strike. One firm, however, has given in to the demands of the Society, and will resume work at the old rates on Monday. The men who are out of work receive $7, single men, and $10 married men, per week. The Workingmen's Union passed a resolution last night to give them aid in money, if necessary.

Some months ago, JAMES MARTIN and LARRY SMITH, aged about 9 years, were found in the night time in the store of GEORGE BRACKELS, No. 318 Greenwich-street, with burglars' tools in their possession, and it being evident that, small as they were, they had made a forcible entry into the premises, they were taken in custody, but were discharged next morning by Alderman O'BRIEN, acting Magistrate at the Tombs Police Court.

For a week past we have been saying at regular intervals of four and twenty hours that there were no sales at the Exchange yesterday. During the entire week there was not a single public sale effected, and the dullness was shared by the entire market. This exhibits a marked contrast with the Spring week of last year, when operations were exceedingly brisk even for a lively season.

Congress meets again next Monday. The first subjects which will be considered with sufficient interest to thoroughly absorb all the olements in both Houses, are finance and taxation. The Ways and Means will, within a week, report a readjusted tariff,--or rather, an amended tariff, whereby it will be proposed to reduce taxation from that source about $25,000,000 to $30,000,000.

Rev. J. M. STURTEVANT, Jr., acting pastor of the Congregational Church, worshiping at Rutgers Institute, preached yesterday morning from the words "In the last days perilous times shall come," (2d Timothy, iii., 1.) It was, he said, strange that Paul, writing in the days of persecution, when Christians were constantly exposed to scourging, imprisonment and death, should point forward to these later times as the perilous ones.

A fire broke ut last night in Willis block, on Pennsylvania-street. PHYPP BROTHERS, jewelers, and the Empire Sewing Machine Company were the principal sufferes by water. Their loss is not large. The damage to the building is small. MEMPHIS, Jan. 9.-- An incendiary fire last night destroyed the store of CARROL Co., in Front-row. Loss $10,000; fully insured in locate companies.

Yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock, while the tugboat Jonatha Chase, Captain DALTON, was returning to the City, after having towed the bark Mendota as far as Quarantine, when off Robins Reef Lighthouse, tire was discovered breaking out from around the steam chimney. The men made all efforts to extinguish the fire, but the wind was blowing so strong they were unable to stop its headway.

"The Martvrs" was the subject of a lecture last evening by Rev. WILLIAM P. MORROGH, D. D., pastor, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Fourteenth-street, near Avenue A. The church was filled to repletion. The proceeds of the lecture are for the benefit of the poor under the care of the Confraternity o St. Vincent de Paul, and the sum realized for this charitable object must be large.

That is the question of the day, and it is one which must be quickly, plainly answered--yea or nay. Front the Lynchburg (Va.) News. We learn that on the night of the 31st of December last the house of Mr. GEORGE SHEPHERD, in Russell County, was visited by three men in disguise, who demanded of Mrs. SHEPHERD that she deliver to them the money known to be in her possession.

The great billiard match between Messrs. DECRY and DION, for the champion diamond cite and 1,000, took place last night at Mechanics' Pavillion before a large audience. The excitement among billiardists for several days past showed that the game would be closely contested, and consequently but little odds were offered, although DION appeared to be the favorite.

In the case of BIRDSALL vs. JOSLYN, et al., a motion was made before Judge FREEDMAN, in the Superior Court, for leave to issue a commission to examine GEORGE WASHINGTON, JAMES K. POLK, both colored, and several other parties in the State of Louisiana. The action was brought by the plaintiff to recover $185,000 for damages caused to him by the defendants converting 800 shares of the express stock of WELLS, FARGO Co.

An order has been received at the Navy Yard, directing that fifty sailors be enlisted for one year to do the ordinary labor of the yard, arid that they be paid $30 per month besides rations. The men already enlisted under this order are above middle age. The Government deems it just to confer such favors as it may have at its disposal upon old United States tars and marines.

It is reported from Washington that Attorney-General HOAR will transmits to the Sepato to-day, in obedience to the resolution calling for his opinion of July 29, 1869, as to whether the act of February 22, 1867, to establish and protect national cemeteries, is competent to vest in the United States exclusive jurisdiction over lands acquired for that purpose.

Some excitement prevailed among certain classes in this City yesterday, a rumor having spread like an unseen infection that the remains of JAMES LOGAN NO. 2 were about to be removed to their final resting-place. BUFFET, Minister of the Finances, replying to an address from the great financial societies, declared that they must conform strictly to their statutes to avoid such misfortunes as that of the Credit Mobilier.

According to the decision of Justices BADGLEY and MONOK yesterday, the prisoner CALDWELL was remanded back to jail that he might be brought before Mr. Judge of Sessions COURSOL this morning, for further examination under the new warrant issued against him on the deposition of MERCIER, of New-York, who charges CALDWELL with forging signatures to a bill of exchange.

St. Ann's Free Church for Deaf Mutes and their friends, Eighteenth-street, near Fifth-avenue, has, through its sisterhood and brotherhood, undertaken a mission work in the chapel on the south side of Eighteenth-street, near Eighth-avenue. The brotherhood of the parish has assumed the rent of the room and other expenses, amounting to between $600 and $700 a year.

The Message which Governor CLAMIN communicated to the Legislature of Massachusetts on Saturday is noteworthy from the fact that the topics which it discusses and the recommendations which it makes are such only as are of direct interest to the people of the Bay State. He congratulates them upon the fact that the past year has been one of unusual health and abundant prosperity,

By the China, which arrived Sunday morning from Japan, we learn that a most important step has been taken by the Mikado, which goes far towards insuring a now era of peace and progress in that country. This is the pardoning of STOTSBASHI, the late Tycoon or Shogoon, and Prince AIDZU, who was the head of the nothern party in the late civil was in Japan.

The Spanish Ministerial crisis has terminated in the appointment of Senor RIVERO, the President of the Cortes, to be Minister of the Interior; Admiral TOPETE, to be Minister of Marine, and Senor SAGOSTA to be Minister of Foreign Affairs ....M. OLLIVIER, the French Premier, promises to keep justice clear from politics, so that decisions will have all the more weight.

Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER took for the text of his discourse, last evening, the story of Zaceheus, the Roman tax collector, of small stature but large means, who climbed a sycamore tree to get a sight of the Saviour as he passed through the streets of Jericho. Zaccheus was a man of bad repute among the people who paid taxes in those days, but on better acquaintanco was found to possess some admirable qualities.

On Monday morning the Ama, a lo, dark steamer, came into our harbor and attracted but little attention. She reported that she had been driven in by a stress of weather, and desired to coal before proceeding on her voyage to Nassau. This was easily accomplished, and the Anna was fully prepared to leave the next day, when Captain SOMERS the commanding office

The Spanish frigate Gerona will soon sail for Venezuela for the purpose of watching the steamer El Rayo. The El Rayo was formerly the R. R. Ouyler, and was sold by citizens of the United States to the Colombian Government. A rumor prevails that she has been sold to the Cuban insurgents.
