To the Editor of the New-York Times : In most of the daily morning papers of this City issued on the 6th lust., there appeared what purported to be a statement of General MARTINDALE, which was to be used on a motion to be made in the Susquehanna Railroad case, at Albion, in the County of Orleans, on the 20th inst., to vacate the judgment of Justice E. DARWIN SMITH, entered therein.

The ninety-fourth session of the Legislature of New-Jersey commences at Trenton, at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The majority of both houses being Democratic, an organization will be without difficulty effected, but according to usage, the business of the session, which is of more than usual importance this Winter, will be deferred until the second week of the session.

The Spring campaign is already the subject of gossip and candidates are talked over. It is universally agreed that Governor JEWELL will again head the Republican ticket and, few doubt, lead it to victory. His great popularity is conceded by his opponents, who frankly admit he will be a difficult man to beat.
EDGAR--GOODLOE.--At Lexington, Ky., on Wednesday, Jan. 5, by Rev. Nathaniel West, Mr. JAMES EDGAR, of Detroit, to Miss MARY GOODLOE, daughter of Judge W. C. Goodloe.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to inform "A Boston Merchant" that check books " perforated like sheets of postage stamps" have been used for many years by London bankers, and are used by some persons in New-York. I presume any regular New-York dealer in check books will make them to order. Of course they cost more than ordinary checks.
The disappearance of the three children of JACOB WEBLE from their home la Wynockie, N. J., still remains a profound mystery to the grief-stricken parents and the people in that vicinity.

On Sunday afternoon Hon. JOHN HUYLER, who received injuries in an affray in the streets of Hackensack on the 20th ult., died at his residence in that village from their effects. Mr. IIUYLER had for thirty years been one of the most prominent among the citizens of Bergen County, and his death occasioned sorrow throughout the entire county.

The population of the City is variously estimated from 800,000 to 1,000,000. About one-half were born in the United States, and tho other half are from foreign countries, of forty different nationalities.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 10.--COTTON active at 24 1/4c. @24 1/2c. for Middling; sales, 8,200 bales; receipts, 9,561 bales; exports, to Barcelona, 836 bales. FLOUR firm at $5 25@$5 75@$6 25. CORN firmer at $1 05. OATS, 70c. BRAN. $1 25. HAY--Prime, $27 50.

At Communipaw Market, this morning, the cattle were quite as good as these quite last week, yet the average prices were fully 1/2 c. ?? 1b. lower than on said sale days. Trade was lively and general satisfaction prevailed. The Texan cattle on sale also showed rater better handling than is generally the case with those same wild animals.

The week opened yesterday with a silent day at the Exchange Rooms. To-day, however, we have the promise of several sales of desirable property. A.J. BLEECKER, SON CO. will oiler the louse and lot No. 51 West Forty-fourth-street.
This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair. A resolution was adopted to pay J. R. FELLOWES$1,200 for legal services in the case of WEST vs. The Corporation of the City of NowYork.

This noble institution for the relief of such as have diseases of the spine or hip Joint, is steadily moreasing in public favor. Yesterday afternoon being the day of the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees, the occasion was em braced to give to the children fine collation and some presents.

Some weeks ago the gas works of the St. Nicholas Hotel in the rear of the hotel, on the opposite side of Mercer-street, were very seriously damaged by fire, together with the laundry of the hotel adjoining.

The delay in the admission of Virginia may humiliate that State and certainly does entail upon it cruel injustice; but it also operates injuriously upon the reputation and prospects of the Republican Party. Congross, in defining the conditions of restoralion, exacted all the guarantees which could be reasonably required; and it virtually promised restoration ns a result of compliance.

The Arbeiter Union held its first meeting last evening under its now constitution. It was resolved to tax each member of the different trades' organizations five cents, in order to raise a fund to support strikers.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday, President BERGEN in the chair. The report of the Law Committee, recommending the amendment of the city charter, was made the special order for next Monday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10.--A special dispatch to the Chicago Tribune, dated Fort Abererombie, Jan. 5. via. St. Cloud, Jan. 10, says : "Advices received to-day from Red River state that the Canadians taken prisoners have not been sent across the lines but are yet in jail.

BANTA--On Monday, Jan. 10, SILVIA BANTA, in the 76th year of her age. The friends of her family are invited to attend the funeral at the Moravian Church, Staten Island, on Wednesday next, 12 o'clock. BRIGGS.--At Westchester, on Sunday, Jan. 9, EUSTATIA, wife of Peter Briggs, Jr., aged 37 years, 11 months and 18 days.

An adjourned meeting of the Convention of Ministers and Laymen of the Churches of Brooklyn was held at the rooms of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association yesterday afternoon, Rev. WM. I. BUDINGTON, D. D., in the chair.

The recent discussions in the public journals on the difficulties concerning natal rank have led to the inquiry, What is this "executive officer" who seems to oppose a principal obstacle to the proper adjustment of these difficulties.

The other day, on the invitation of one of the old champagne firms near Epernay, Messrs. DEUTZ GELDERMAN, of Ay, a party of Americans started from Paris to celebrate the baptism of a new brand of that wine which In compliment to General GRANT has been denominated "The President's Cabinet." The title thus given, be it noted, has no sort of political significance.

A typographical mistake in the TIMES of Saturday last in the report concerning the accidental poisoning of a lawyer named BUELL, led some of our readers to infer that RUSHTON'S drug store was the establishment responsible therefor.

Hon. ALEXANDER H. H. STUART is editing a Virginia paper. A clergyman in Ohio has sued his congregation for $95 back salary. Miss MAY CAPERS has won a doll in a Charleston Pair, and is more lively than ever.

The Message of Governor MCCLURG, of Missouri, contains one point of special politcial significance. It takes open ground in favor of enfranchising the blacks and of removing the disabilities ot the disfranchised whites. But the Missouri Democrat assumes as it seems to us, a sounder position than the Governor's. Governor McCLURG proposes that these two measures shall be submitted to the people of Missouri next Autumn:
Yesterday afternoon, soon after the bids for the Treasury gold had been announced in the Gold Exchange, an unusually stormy scene occurred within the precincts of that arena dovoted to noise.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

Professor ABNER S. BRADY Opened his rink at Jersey City, lately known as Brady's Curriculum, last evening, for skating purposes, About 2,000 ladies and gentlemen were present, perhaps two-thirds of them on skates. The sheet of ice, covering 92,000 square feet, was as level and smooth as a mirror.

A large and enthusiastic temperance meeting was held last evening, at the Presbyterian Church in Fourteeuth-street, near Seventhavenue. In the absence of WM. E. DODGE, Prosident of the National Temperance Society, inder whose auspices the meeting was held lastevening, Dr. McELROY, pastor of the Church, presided. After prayer by Rev. Dr.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Secretary BOUTWELL to-night delivered a lecture for the benefit of the charity fund of the Graud Army of the Republic, Department of the Potomac, at Lincoln Hall, which was filled with ladies and gentlemen.

It was erroneously announced that the Fourth Regiment N. G. S. N. Y. (Veteran Zouaves) would be formally disbanded last evening. The regiment will not be disbanded until next Monday night. The regiment will be mustered out owing to its inability to recruit the minimum number of men allowed by law.

The state of mind in which many people seem to be, about "the decline of America commerce," or more accurately of the American carrying trade, is becoming very eurious. Everybody is agreed that it has declined and is declining, and that it ought to be revived. Everybody says, too. that the reason is that we cannot build ships as cheaply as Europeans.

Readers who are gifted with memories mast have noticed that two of our arguments against the total and summary abolition of the income tax have been quietly evaded by writers on the opposite side of the question In the first place, the Tribune, which opposes the reduction of taxes, has not shown how the Government is to make up the deficiency of fifty millions which the repeal of the income tax would cause.

Fashionable circles on the cast side of town were startled and agitated on Saturday and Sunday by the announcement of an elopement extraordinary. Gossip said the guilty couple were of high respectability and moved in very good society.

The New-York Marine Society, established Jan. 8, 1770, held its annual meeting and celebrated its one hundredth anniversary yesterday afternoon. The meeting was held at Kolb's Hotel, No. 120 Pearl-street, and the occasion was one of great interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10.-The President this afternoon transmitted to the Senate, in Executive Session, the Samana Bay lease and the San Domingo annexation treaties-the terms of which have been fully alluded to In these dispatches-together with a brief special message on the subject.

The proposed changes in the Customs cartage is the subject of much comment, and argu months pro and con are quite numerous. The community at large seem to favor all changes of the old system which tend to break up the numerous "Rings " which have so long controlled all matters in the Custom House for personal ends.

The following is the statement, complete of the funds stolen from the Glenn's Falls National Bank : United States five-twenty bonds, 1867, coupon, three of $1,000 each, $3,000 ; two of $500 each, $1,000; eight of $100 each, $800, and one of $500, of 1862, five-twenty, $500; $18,000 United States legal-tender notes, $50s, 8100s, $500s and $1,000s.
PARIS, Jan. 10-Evening.--A quarrel has arisen between Prince PIERRE BONAPARTE and the writers of the Marseillaise, in consequence of a bitter and slanderous attack made in that paper on the Prince.

The Union Republican General Committee organized last evening without an exhibition of opposition from any source. All sections of the party coalesced in the nominations, and an organization was effected in the utmost harmony.

The Young Men's Democratic (Tammany) Committee held its first regular monthly meeting for the year 1870, at Tammany Hall last evening. Mr. JOEL A. FITHIAN, President of the Committee, occupied the chair.

The resignation of the French Ambassaders at London and Berlin is ascribed, in a private dispatch to Washington, to lack of sympathy with the new French Ministry. A change in the French War Department is anticipated....A demand for the arraignment of Baron HAUSSMANN, on what charge is not stated, has been made in the Corps Legislatif....The Government has resolved not to exempt LEDRU ROLLIN and TIBALDI from the amnesty....

The friends of the Republican Party throughout the country will rejoice over the reunion of the Republican General Committee of this City, Which was accomplished last evening in the most orderly manner imaginable.

On Sunday evening a serious if not fatal affray occurred at Upper Tuckahoe, in the town of East Chester, Westchester County. JOHN BROPHY entered the grocery store of JAMES SPOLLAN and asked for a box of matches, and a box or package of the ordinary kind was handed to him. BROPHY said they were not the kind he wanted, and described those he desired. Mr.
The most intense excitement prevails at Tremont on account of the homicide committed there on Saturday night, the deceased having been a general favorite among a large circle of accouaintances.
The reassembling of Congress was signalized by a resolute, simultaneous, and well nigh successful effort in both Houses to bring Virginia squarely into the Union without further delay.

The Newark Board of Trade met last night in their rooms on Broad-street. A. communication from the National Board of Trade was read, calling the attention of the Newark Board to the resolutions relative to statistical compilation contained in the report of the National Board of Trade. Which was laid on the table.

The "nipping air" of Sunday night put many of the skating ponds in order again, and yesterday the balls were up everywhere except at Central Park. At McMILLAN'S pond in Fifthavenue, which has had the best success in freezing this season, the skating was prime, and the ice well patronized.

The veteran organization of the Seventh Regiment held a meeting last evening at Delmonico's. The Secretary announced the accession of sixty-seven new members, and over forty candidates under consideration.

ALBANY, Jan. 10.--Speaker HITCHMAN has been quite ill for the last twenty-four hours with on attack of dysentery. He is better, however, this evening, and, it is said, will be in his place to-morrow and announce the Assembly Committees.

Reported expressly for the NEW-YORK TIMES by Davie W. Lewis Co., Commission merchants. BUTTER--The receipts for the week were 9,091 pkgs.; exports are lighter, and there has been more trade at about last week's prices. We note sales of few fancy Delaware Dairies at 43 c., and a line of Chenango Dairies at 41 1/2c.;

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 10.--The Constitutional Convention assembled at the Court House in Nashville at 12 o'clock to-day. The Convention was called to order by Hon. A. O. P. NIOHOLSON, who read the proclamation from Governor SENTER announcing the vote for and against the Convention, and stating the Convention had been called by the people, the vote being 50,520 for, and 10,020 against.

The New-York Association for the Protection-of American Shipping Interests hold a meeting last evening, in Room No. 24 Cooper Institute, Mr. DANIEL COGER in the chair. About twenty persons were present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--General SHERIDAN has submitted to the Secretary of War a report from Captain CHARLES W. RAYMOND, of the Engineer Corps on the Yukon River, Alaska, made gin accordance with special orders from General WHIPPLE, commanding the Military Division of the Pacific.

Some time has elapsed since we submitted this plan question to the public, and events since then have done very little towards clearing a way the difficulties which surround it. We have used the belt opportunities for gaining information which are open to us, and the result of it all is that we can hear of no facts which prove that the insurrection is making any progress.

The animal meeting of this Society was held on Saturday evening at its rooms on Fifteenth-street, WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT, the President, in the chair. The reports of the Treasurer, the House Committee and Art Committee were read.

The Senate was called to order by the Vice-President, who laid before that body several communications. BILLS AND RESOLUTIONS. A large number of bills, , were introduced, including a resolution by Mr. CORBETT in lavor of including the annexation of British Columbia in the subjects for negotiation with Great Britain.

The excellent exhibit of our finances under this Administration raises the question, whether we should use the surplus to pay off the national debt, or whether we shall better meet the expeetations of the people by applying our abundance to a material reduction of taxation!

A meeting of the managers of "The Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamon in the City and Port of New-York," was hold last evening in the Sunday School room of the Church of the Ascension, on West Eleventhstreet, near Fifth-avenue. There was a large attendance of members, and considerable important business of a strictly private nature was transacted.

From the Lancaster (Penn.) Intelligencer. We were shown a curious specimen of a water fowl, by our friend Dr. S. S. WEIST, of Schecneck, which be captured in this county; he has prepared it very carefully.

CHURCH GLASS is a Kentuckian. The thermometer at Quebee on Saturday morning marked 16[Degrees] below zero. The Attica Atlas has new typo, and is now legible. Some of the boys in Brown University serenaded Senator SPRAGUE on Monday night.

The Board met at their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the Chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Cuddy, Reilly, Hughes, Miller,

During the morning of yesterday the "Street" was filled with rumors to the effect that the Gold Exchange Bank had suspended, and that there was a great deal of trouble generally in relation to the gold brokers and speculators in gold.

Notwithstanding the exertions of Sanitary Superintendent HARRIS and his indefatigable corps of Inspectors, there does not yet appear to be any material diminution of smallpox cases in this city. It is not epidemic, nor need any fears be entertained that it will become so;

Off cape Lookout, at 10 A. M. Jan. 9, the Captain of the steamship Champion, which arrived here yesterday, reports that he saw a schooner in the breakers on the shoals, with signals of distress flying. Bore down on her and sent off one of his boats to board her. After a hard row of three hours succeeded in reaching her.

Yesterday the men on strike in Albany. Troy and other cities returnd to work, having previously abjured their connection with the League. The leaders of the movement in this City are making desperate efforts to obtain the sinews of war, and last evening delegations from their number waited on various labor organizations and demanded pecuniary aid.

Nearly two hundred old sailors and marines presented themselves at the Navy Yard yesterday, ready to enlist in the corps of "ordinary men" to perform general labor in the yard The fifty required were selected and are now in the service.

The flight of Rev. HORACE COOKE, pastor of the Seventh-street Methodist Church, with MISS MARTRA JOHNSTON, still continues to absorb a large share of public attention, and although nothing further has been heard from the fugitives themselves, certain additional facts in reference to the parties have been brought to hight, which cannot fail to be of interest to the readers of the TIMES.

The successive failures of contractors to remove the deep rooks at Hell Gate have induced the Government engineers here to undertake the work themselves, and proceed with it surely. until that whole channel is made the sate and navigable entrance to our harbor on that side which commercial interests have long required.
The case of EDWIN PERRY, charged with murdering THOMAS HAYES, the night watchman, in Furman-street, Brooklyn, on the night of Dec. 28, 1869. came up for trial yesterday, before Judge PRATT.

It is a fact, scarcely less strange than true, that the United States holds within its limits the principal wheat market of the world, and that this is to be found at a point where but thirty years ago there was only a straggling town of 8,000 or 10,000 people, and where now flourishes a city of over 100,000 inhabitants, rightly rejoicing in the soubriquet of the "Fair White City of the Lakes."

Yesterday the Exchange Rooms resounded once more with the energetic calls of rival auctioneers, and sales were made at three stands simultaneously, a large crowd having gathered to see the unwanted spectacle. The principle sale was that of MULLER, WILKINS Co., who disposed of a large amount of property on Second-avenue and Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth streets. Under the direction of Sheriff O'BRIEN.

ABBOT.--At Orange, N. J., on Monday, Jan. 10, MARY WADE, infant daughter of Abiel and Alice M. Abbot. BRYANT.--At Hempstead, L. I., on Monday, Jan. 10, Mr. LLOYD BRYANT, aged 70 years. The funeral will take place from his residence at Hempstead, this Wednesday, at 10 1/2 o'clock.

It is often difficult through the medium of a newspaper to present the facts of a case in controversy so as to enable readers to see exactly the legal right of a given case, but some propositions are so manifest that they need but be stated to be understood.

The German Liederkranz Society of this City held their annual meeting at their hall, Nos. 31, 33, and 35 East Fourth-street, last night, Mr. WILLIAM STEINWAY presiding. Mr. ERNEST STEIGER, the Secretary, made a report showing that the Society, entering now its twenty-fourth year.

When the people of the United States resolved to suppress insurrection, they did not also intend to pursue conquered States with undying hostility. "Prove your loyalty," they said to these communities. "and we shall be glad once more to see you standing side by side with us in the Union."

HAMLET AT BOOTH'S THEATRE. We are requested to call attention to the fact that the performance of "Hamlet," at Booth's Theatre, now begins at 7:45 instead of * as here-tofore. The tragedy is proving, as it deserves to be, highly attractive, and will probably keep the stage for weeks to come.

The brig Timothy Field, with a Cuban crew, 2,000 maskets and eight held pieces--10 peunders--sailed from this port for a rendezvous with the Anna, on the evening of the 3d inst. Clearance was asked for her at the Custom House on the 1st ultimo, but the Collector refused to give it. until the United States Marshal should first visit, the brig and decide whether she was capacitated for carrying an expedition of listen or not.

KEYES, at $5,894 60; Sixty-third street, from Third-avenue to Lexington-avenue, to W. A. CUMMING, at $5,865 55;

A meeting to the East River Association was hold, yesterday, at No. 40 Burling-slip, for the purpose of taking measures to improve and render safe the navigation of the East River. Mr. JAMES R. TAYLOR, President, presided, and Mr. GEO. W. BLUNT acted as Secretary.

The foothold in the West Indies which has long been an object of quest by the United States is now in a fairway of attainment. The Babcock-Gautier treaty for the session of San Domingo is before the Senate, with the chances in favor of its ratification.

It will be remembered that the Thirty-second Collection District, embracing the lower wards of this City, was, for two or three years, the place of receptacle or whisky sent from the west, both bonded and free; and it was generally believed that extensive frauds were being committed during this time on the revenue.

Speaker HITCHMAN, notwithstanding his recent severe Illness, was in his chair at the opening of the Assembly this morning, and immediately after the reading of the Journal announced the Standing Committees. Mr. JACOBS was then called to the chair and the Speaker retired for the day.

There is now a good prospect that the telegraph difficultiess will pass off without any serious disturbance of the public business or convenience. The Western Union Company has shown itself master of the situation. Three operators in New-York returned to work on Monday, and, for aught we know, others may have followed suit yesterday either here or another places.

The called informs us this morning that an arrangement for the consolidation of the Public. and English companies is "progressing favorably." We are sorry to hear it. The creation of a monopoly is never to the interest of the public.

The first meeting of the Legislature of New-Jersey for the present year was held at Trenton yesterday. Throughout the day and evening the halls of the Senate and the Assembly chamber were so crowded that it was with great difficulty that standing room could be obtained.

The Members of parliament for Birmingham have addressed their constituents in the Town Hall to-night. Mr. BRIGHT made his first appearance on the platform since his entrance into the Cabnuet, and he met with an cutlmsiastic reception. Mr. BRIGHT said, on the subject of the Irish Church, his constituents had spoken lond enough for all to hear and for all to understand.

Coroner KEENAN was notified yesterday that CONRAD OESTREICHER, a German, aged 31. and lately residing at No. 55 Rose-street, had expired in Bellevue Hospital at a late hour on Monday night from the effects of a stab wound.

The Union Republican Association of the Thirteenth Assembly District met last evening at the corner of Eighteenth-street and Eighth-avenue. The constitution and by-laws for the past year were readopted, and a committee of five was appointed to aid in carrying them out.

The annual election of the Board of Directors of the Ninth National Bank took place yesterday at the office of the bank, No. 363 Broadway. Unlike the generality of bank elections, when there is usually little or no opposition, there was a hard contest for the controlling power of the bank funds.

The contest of yesterday over the admission of Virginia was productive of good results already apparent. The Reconstruction Committee met this morning and took up the bill referred by General PAINE yesterday.

The surveys on M. MAILLEFERT'S rocks at Hell Gate by the Government engineers have been greatly delayed by the recent unfavorable weather. It is said that thus far they have found no soundings less than eighteen feet and that the average depth is nineteeen fect, which shows good work for Professor MAILLEFERT.

A State Temperance Convention of 133 delegates, representing about forty towns, met here to-day, and organized an independent political party, with Rev. L. O. BARROWS as their candidate for Governor, and Colonel H. O. PIERCE, of Hillsboro, for Railroad Commissioner.

A premature explosion of a blast occurred about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Fleetwood Park Race Course, now being constructed in the town of Morrisania, and resulted in two persons, named OWEN BRADY and JOHN COURTNEY, being very seriously injured.

Don GREGORIO DOMINGUEZ, the ex-Consul-General of Ecuador, who died at his residence in Sixteenth-street day before yesterday, was a prominent character in the celebrated Chilian-Peruvian bond affair, in which JOHN GRAHAM and ANTONIO MILLAN are the leading contestants.
The Bricklayers' National Convention reassembled this morning. A special committee was appointed to draft a set of resolutions having reference to the strike of the telegraph operators.

The Speaker of the Assembly continues seriously ill at his rooms, in the Delevan House, and Mr. JACOBS presided again to-day in his place. The only incident of the day worthy of note in the Lower House, was the passage of the act authorizing free liquor in the City of New-York from now till the 1st of May, or until the Democracy shall have recognized or abolished the Excise Commission.

At the regular meeting of the Shipowners' Association, at No. 52 Pine-street, yesterday afternoon, a communication was read from the counsel to the Association with regard to the Quarantine regulations, In which he says: "It would, in my opinion, be utterly futile for the merchants to ask to materially alter the law relating to quarantine at this session.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: For one I thank you for your article of to-day, headed, "Does a Fee License Counsel to Defend Dishonesty " You might have used the word "promote" instead of "defend" and sailed closer to the truth.

Mr. KELLY, of Pennsylvania, is in one way or another closely identified with the monopolies of his State,--he is, in fact, as much interested in them as if he were a paid spokesman on their behalf. Under these circumstances It is amusing to hear him accuse Mr. WELLS of being the advocate of the Foreign "steel interest."

Captain HALL, the Arctic explorer, has received the following letter from the Secretary to the Bremen Committee of the German Polar Expedition; BREMEN, Dec. 20, 1869. To Captain Charles Francis Hall, Arctic Explorer. New-York:

MR. FECHTER AS RUY BLAS. On Monday evening Mr. CHARLES FECHTER made his first appearance on the American stage at Niblo's Garden as Kay Blas. The event, while it had been looked forward to with much curiosity--as was indicated by the great throng in attendance--had not been heralded or magnified by any of those subtle moans where with managers .

A meeting of much importance to the cigar manufacturing interests of the United States was held yesterday afternoon, at No. 170 Water-street. The meeting elected officers for the ensuing year. Mr. HIRSCH being reelected President, Mr. JACOBI Vice-President, and Mr. STRATTON Secretary.

The annual ball of the M. T. Brennan Coterie took place under brilliant auspices at the Academy of Music last evening. There was a very select and distinguished number of ladles and gentlemen in attendance. A host of Metropolitan celebrities was present, including Justice Dowling, the President of the

A rumor having gained circulation in this City and vicinity to the effect that the Inebriates' Asylum, established on Ward's Island about eighteen months ago, was being managed unfairly, and would doubtless soon collapse bocause of the failure of the system, a TIMES' reporter was yesterday dispatched to the institution for tile purpose of learning what the managing physician had to say about the matter. Dr.

Many of me Hartford clergymen express disapproval of Sunday evening sacred concerts. And now St. Louis has erected " a palatial business edifice." What American structure won't be " palatial" by and by. The Boston Atheneum wants the city to give them the site of the Coliseum for a new building for tho fine arts, to which its colleotion may be transferred.

Detectives FARLEY and SIMINGTON yesterday arrested in this city a young man named WM. R. ANDERSON, who was formerly an agent for the John Hancock Life Insurance Company, of Rochester, N. Y. The arrest was made upon a warrant issued by E. W BRYAN, a Police Justice of that city,

Both Houses again devoted the chief part of the session in each to the case of Virginia, and it is due to Congress to say that it is the very sentiment of the injustice of the delay which is now forcing the consideration of the question of admission in both Houses every day.
The girl MARTHA JOHNSON, whose abduction by Rev. HORACE COOKE has been the theme of public scandal for the past few days, has been found, and is now in the custody of the Police.
The full text of the treaty celebrated between the United States of America and the Dominican Republic for the incorporation of the second with the first is as follows:
COOK.--At West New-Brighton, S. I., on Tuesday evening, Jan. 11, after an illness of only four hours, A LICE E., oldest daughter of Benj. F. and Helen M. Cook, in the 20th year of her age.

Petitions were presented for a line of firstclass steamships between Norfolk, New-York and the Mediterranean ports. RESOLUTION S. Mr. CONINIG presented the resolutions of the Legislature of New-York withdrawing the assent of that State to the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment.

About half the buildings of the National Rubber Company at Bristol were consumed yesterday by fire, along with their contents, involving a loss of between $250,000 and $300,000 fully covered by insurance in the different companies given below. The fire was caused by the explosion of the middle heater owing to the expansion of highly rarifled air,

The Gold Exchange was very quiet yesterday, and not a ripple of excitement disturbed its serenity. The absence of members was noticeable, and explained by the fact, that they were settling the affairs of the day before, which had been interrupted by the temporary suspension of the Gold Exchange Bank;

To the Editor of the New-York Times : In your issue of Dec. 24 I saw an item signed "Missionary." This missionary sold his keepsakes for bread. My family have lived for days at a time on potatoes, not a mouthful of another kind of food In the house, not even meal enough to make a bowl of gruel, though some were sick in bed and the others invalids.

The Marseillaise newspaper was published in mourning yesterday, and contained the following leading article printed in large type: The Murder Committed by the Prince Pierre Napoleon Bonaparte upon the Citizen Victor Noir--The Attempt to Murder Made by the Prince Pierre Napoleon Bonaparte upon the Citizen Ulric de Fonvielle.

The Board of Education held its first meeting for 1870 at 4 o'clock P. M. yesterday,. Present ; Commissioners Larremore, Bell, wood, Sherwood, Sands. Lewis, Smythe, Duryea and Breonman. R. I. LARREMORE, Esq., was reelected President of the Board, and after being conducted to the chair returned thanks for the honor conferred upon him.

The Melbourne Argus reports a horrible massacre at Fiji. A Mr. LATTIN, who, it is said. was formerly a storekeeper in Melbourne, had shipped about 280 natives on board the French bark Moreu. Their ultimate destination was is believed, Queensland; but it seems that the Islanders rose en masse and mercilessly killed every white man on board with the exception as the mate. They then jumped overboard.

NOIR, gives his version of the fatal ??, in which the Prince is represented to ?? been violent and insulting from the first, and ?? have been the assailant by striking M. NOIR in the face, and, at the same time,

The investigation instituted by Coroner BATHGATE relative to the killing of young MILTON L. CARPENTER, Of Tremont, at a saloon, in that village, was concluded yesterday, when the jury rendered a verdict to the effect" That the said MILTON L. CARPENTER died of compression or congestion of the brain and fracture of the skull, which were superinduced or effected

It will not be the fault of the Governor, or of the Press. which has already so freely and fully commented on the Governor's Message, if the question of Prison Discipline shall fail to be thoroughly investigated, and our prison systes made to conform more nearly to the spirit of the age.

CLERKS APPOINTED. The Clerk announced the following appointments: Journal Clerk, CHARLES R. DAYTON of Suffolk County; Assistant Journal Clerk, FRANK B. BROWN, of Steuben; Deputy Journal Clerks, CHAS. J. GAYLORD, OF Dutchee County; GEO. BREAK, OF Monroe County;

At the meeting of the Board of Excise yesterday thirty-one new applications for licenses in New-York and nine in Brooklyn were granted. Only one case of violation of the Excise law was tried. HENRY SIEFKE. of No. 18 Sixth-avenue, being the defendant.

The Legislature of New-Jersey met in the State House at Trenton yesterday. The session was a very short one, and but little business was accomplished. THE SENATE. The Senate convened at 10 o'clock A. Mr, and after the reading of the minutes, the following bills were introduced by title and will be referred to the proper committees when they are appointed:

From the American Gold Register, compiled by Mr. J. C. MERSEREAU, the Registrar of the New-York Gold Exchange, it appears that the daily gold clearings at the Gold Exchange Bank during the year 1869, were as follows for the months named: January, 31,231,000,000;

The smallpox question came again before the Board of Health yesterday, through the report of Dr. HARRIS, made in pursuance of the resolution of the Board passed at the previous session, in which he says that he never informed any member of the Sanitary Committee that the prevalence of smallpox in this City could be traced to Quarantine.

The Castleton; Vt., National Bank was broken open on Monday night and robbed of $6,400. The front door was blown open, it is supposed by nitroglycerine. BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Jan. 12.--The Valley Railroad, fourteen miles in length, between Great Bend, Penn., and this city, has been completed, and an engine passed over the road this afternoon.

The decline of trade in Buffalo, of which so much has been recently said, seems to be regarded as an abnormal rather than a natural event, incident to the development of the railroad system. There is really no difficulty in explaining it, heavy as the falling off is from 72,000,000 bushels of grain, received in 1863, to only 56,000,000 in 1869.

ABRAHAM KEHER and his son MORRIS, of No. 133 Norfolk-street, who were arrested by the Tenth Ward Police on suspicion of being implicated in the murder of CONRAD OESTREICHER, are still in the custody of the Police, as Coroner KEENAN has determined to postpone the inquest until Saturday.

A sale of Mulberry-street property was made at the Exchange yesterday by JOSEPH MCGUIRE, under the direction of GRATZ NATHAN referee. The property consisted of two lets, Nos. 35 and 37, together measuring about 49x103.4 on one of which was a four-story brick building, with store on first floor, and on the other a three-story house,

Wendell Phillips, of Boston, is at the St. Dennis Hotel. Hon. J. N. McCallough, of Pittsburg; Hon E. B. Phillips, of Chicago; Hon. As II. Holley, of Eakeville; Hon. H. B. Norton, of Norwich; Eom. T. Roessle, of Washington; Dr. O. E. Herrick, of Key West; Hon. John Cooper, of Mount Verfion; Dr. J. S. Delevan, of Albany. and General A. B. McCalmont of Pennsylvania, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Collector Casey.

The announcement that Hon. LOUIS B. WOODRUFF, recently appointed Circuit Judge for the Second United States District, would take the oath of office yesterday morning, attracted an immense crowd of spectators who were anxious to witness the ceremony.

The reception tendered by the Morton Commandeer of Knights Templar of this City to the New-Haven Commentary No. 1, of New-Haven, Conn., and St. John's Commanders No. 4. of Philadelphia, Penn., which took place at the Metropolitan Hotel, last evening, was an elegant affair.

Hon. WILLIAM McDOUGALL arrived yesterday and had an interview with the Governor-General and members of the Cabinet. MONTREAL, Jan. 12.-Two men, named SHEA and MURPHY, living at Port Hood, Cape Breton, after some rough play proposed to fight a duel, and, calling friends to act as seconds, they stood up with pistols.

At the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, before Judge LEDWITH, the charge of conspiracy to obtain $115,000 worth of bonds on the North Carolina Railroad by misrepresentations, preferred against BENJAMIN F. SAWYER, Mayor of Hudson City, SAMUEL ROPES and J. J. BONMAN, by CORNELIUS C. CAMPBELL, was resumed.

It is very clear that the Tribune does not know what it moans when it treats of financial questions. It opens an old bag stuffed with various crotchets, and gets itself so muddled among them that it can scarcely toll one front the other.

Preparations are now in progress for the speedy dispatch of the vessels which are to form a part of the expedition to the Isthmus of Darien, hence the workmen at the Navy Yard are being quite busy. The vessels which are to participate in the expedition are the Nipsie, expected to arrive from Washington to-morrow, and the United States storeships Guard and Saratoga.

On inquiry at the Western Union Telegraph Office this morning it was ascertained that all business was closed up last night south of Washington before the closing hour, and that Company to-day is prepared to receive messages for all points, excepting Goldsboro, Raleigh and Newbern. N. C., and several small offices,

Yesterday a number of the leading members of the American Jockey Club had a capital day's sport at Jerome Park in match and sweepstakes pigeon shooting. This was the second occasion on which they had assembled at Jerome Park for the enjoyment of this attractive sport, and so popular has it become among the members that it is proposed to hold weekly reunions for its practice during the season.

BILLS REPORTED. By Mr. MURPHY--Repealing the Westchester County Common Pleas and General Sessions of the Peace act; also, prescribing jurisdiction and to provide for filling vacancies in Courts of Sessions; also, for the relief of MARY BRADLEY. By Mr. M. NORTON-Amending the Metropolltan Excise law.

A fire broke out this evening, at 8 o'clock, in the rear of Nos. 105, 107 and 109 Madison-street, occupied by SHERWOOD Co., manufacturers of school furniture; loss $6,000; insurance $5,000. S. E. MORSE Co., manufacturers of printers' furniture, lose $20,000; insured for $10,000. Other parties occupying the same building lose about $10,000; insured for $4,000. The aggregate loss is about $40,000;

Honolulu advices to the 22d of December, state that the Austrian frigate Donan, Admiral VON Prrz commanding, arrived on the 20th from Yokohama. She encountered a heavy cyclone and suffered serious damage, losing her, rudder and sternpost, and sustaining other injuries.

The Senate assembled this morning in an economical mood, which. showed itself in a proposition from one of the Democratic members to cut down the number of clerks of committees heretofore employed by that body.

Captain DURFEE, with the officers and crew (twelve in number) of the late brigantine Baltimore, (formerly the Karnale,) of Liverpool, arrived at St. Georges in two of the boats of ship on Sunday last. The Baltimore sailed from New-York on the 20th of December for Havre. On the 23d a terrific gale was experienced west, with a heavy cross sea, which caused the ship to leak.

Yesterday was a most propitious one for the ceremonies which tools place on the University Gronnds of old Prlnceton College. It was the commencement day of the Spring term of 1870, and also the day designated for tile dedication of the magnificent new gymnasium in Nassau Hall, just completed for the college.

Utica, N. Y., Jan. 13.--The fifth annual Convention of the American Dairymen's Association, which has been in session in this city since yesterday morning, adjourned this afternoon. The annual address was delivered by Professor G. C. CALDWELL, of Cornell University. Addresses wore also made by Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR, Hon. J. STANTON GOULD,

From the official report of the Judges at the Eleventh Exhibition of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association. BURGLAR--PROOF SAFE.--In his efforts to produce a burglar--proof safe, the inventor has evidently made a long stride in the right direction.

It is announced that the negotiations between the Northern Pacific Railroad Company and JAY COOKE Co. have been concluded by a contract under which that firm acquires a largo interest in the franchise of the road, and undertakes its fiscal agency.

A Committee of the Tammany Reform Benevolent and Protective Association met at Masonic Hall, East Twelfth-street, last evening, to ascertain the number of persons who have expressed a desire to join the organization. The reports received from the members of the Committee were most flattering, and augur well for the success of the movement.

The regular monthly meeting of the Amercan Phonographio Society was hold on Wednesday evening, at Pakard's Rooms, No. 937 Broadway. The President, Mr. JAs. E. MUNSON, presided. The principal business of the evening was the election of officers for the ensuing year. The following were chosen: President, Mr. JAS. E. MUNSON; Vice-President, Mr. R. L. Dugdale;

The Novena of the Nativity is now calling the faithful to the Churches at Rome; and overflowing as the city is with its sacerdotal population, worshipers are not wanting. The Sacri Cronzi, as the church bells are poetically called, are sounding, and the Holy Sacrament is exposed for adoration in many of the churches.

The Erie Railway strikers are fighting over now the same ground which they contested with the Company some months ago. It was then a struggle for regular and punctual paymcnt of wages. It is the same now. They then gained their point. The Company agreed to pay the men at Long Dock on the 12th of each month; the 12th came, but no money, and the men quitted work.

Governor DURKEE, of Utah, continues dangerously ill at Omaha. The City of Boston is talking of a popular loan, in sums of $50, $100, $500 and $1,000. A Massachusetts farmer has been sent to jail for two months for cruelly beating his horse. Olympia,,Washington Territory, organized a New-England Society, and celebrated Forefathers Day with a dinner and a ball.

The following is a list of new buildings proposed since the last report and for the week ending Thursday, Jan. 13, 1870: BRICK AND STONE FRONTS. Four first-class dwelling, north side of One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street, 310 feet east of Fifth-avenue, 18.9X48; three stories, basement and cellar; fronts, brick and brown stone; JOHN SCHRIGER, owner.

It is quite probable that one of the first measures recommended by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will be a prohibition of the consolidation of rival ocean telegraphic cable companies, without the previous assent of the Government which has granted rights and privileges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13.-The discussion on Virginia in both Houses to-day revealed no new features, though it seemed to define more clearly than ever the increasing sentiment in favor of practical unconditional admission. In the House, Mr. FARNSWORTH gave notice that he would move the previous question tomorrow at 8 o'clock, and an evening session for debate was therefore agreed upon.

In steamship City of Mexico, for Havana.--J. E. Alexandre, J. Briggs, L. W. O'Bannon, Dr. Skelton, U. S. Consul to Mexico; J. M. Prioz, J. W. Smith, F. Campz, O. Rosecranz, G. H. Reynolds, J. O. Palace, Juan T. Gongalez, Mrs. C. Unkenstein, J. Gilchrist, E. M. Troth, G. Vonhoffman, Gabriel Ancianz, E. Williams, B. Tarantese, J. Arschamm, Mrs. Eaton, Mr. Gatey, M. Mark, M. Llorence.

The city is still greatly excited. During the night the disturbances continued, but there were no serious conflicts. Several policemen were wounded by stones thrown, and one was dangerously stabbed while attempting to quell the disorder. A Magistrate was struck on the head with a stone and knocked down. Many other outrages were also committed.

An ex-bank clerk named WM. F. VELTMAN, formerly a resident of Staten Island, now residing in Brooklyn, and a stock speculator named WM. LEITH, were arrested by Deputy Marshal JURNEY yesterday, on a charge of being Jointly Implicated in a conspiracy by means of which the Fourth National Bank was defrauded of $7,000.

The Constitutional Convention was, to-day, again engrossed in the introduction and reading of propositions to amend the State Constitution, many of which wore similar to those offered yesterday. Among those offered to-day were the following:

Despite the recent dramatic scene in Congress, when, by concerted action, the Democratic members fell upon poor MUNGEN, and made him the scapegoat for the greenback heresy, the Indiana Democratic State Convention stands by the doctrine of repudiation.

A few days since we published a translation of an article from the Now-York Staals Zeitung covering a letter from Professor GNEIST, of Berlin, in which it was asserted that the Dr. PAUL SCHOEPPE, of Carlisle, Penn., convicted of the murder of Miss STEINNECKE, was the same party who was convicted of burglary and forgery, together with his father, some years since in Germany.

Later letters and papers received here from St.Thomas and Turk's Island give some further interesting particulars regarding the annexation feeling and excitement on the Island of San Domingo. LUPERON and CABRAL had fulminated another proclamation, this time addressed specially to the Washington Cabinet and the United States Senate.

The Following Custom House Changes have occurred since Jan, 3. Storekeepers, at $4 per day--Thomas Hagan, Vice E. Van Wart, removed; John Edwards, vice n. G. Williams, promoted; John Drew, vice J. T. Walton, resigned.

At length the Brooklyn Fire Commissioners have concluded to promulgate a list of Fire Signals for the use of the Department in both Eastern and Western Districts. The locations noted by the numbers appear to be all well chosen. There is hardly one of them that is not in a centre of manufactures or population, or both.

The excitement in Paris over the recent tragedy continues, and the troops are held in readiness to quell an outbreak should any occur. It is said the Government will withdraw the demand for the arraignment of M. ROCHEFORT, and will propose a law providing for trial by jury for political offences.

The directors of the Cleveland and Pitts burg Railroad held a meeting in this City yesterday. The following were present, C. H. Andrews, Jay Gould, J. H. Devercux, Peter B. Sweeny, Hugh Smith, Henry Harley, James Fisk, Jr., L. B. Rucker, George W. Cuss and Thomas A. Scott.

Mr. WILLIAMS presented a petition of J. Ross BROWNE, late Minister to China, representing that by reason of extraordinary expenses connected with the office during the nine months held by him, he had been subjected to a loss of about $12,000, and asking for relief.
A special dispatch from Ottawa to the Leader says the Minister of Marine advertised to-day for six swift-sailing schooners, to be used as a Marine Police on the coast .... It is not improbable.

"SURF" AT THE FIFTH-AVENUE THEATRE. Miss OLIVE LOGAN'S play of "Surf" was enacted, for the first time before a New-York audience, at the Fifth-avenue Theatre on Wednesday. "Surf" is described on the bills as a "new and original local comedy." It is a mixture of farce and melodrama rather than a comedy, and its originality is, to say the least, open to question.

The Directors of the Norfolk and Great Western Railway to-day met to consider the proposition of responsible persons in Now-York to build the entire road from Norfolk to Bristol, Tenn., and appointed a committee to proceed to New-York at once and close the contract.

FRIDAY. Mails for Havana (via Baltimore) by the Cuba, close at 6 P.M. Mails for Europe, via Derry and Liverpool, by the Nestorian, (from Portland, Me.,) close at 1 P. M. Only letters specially directed so sent. SATURDAY. mails for Europe, via Northampton and Bremen, by the Main, close at 11:30 A.M. Supplementary mail on pier foot of Second-street, Hoboken, to 1:30 P.M. Mails for Havana, by the Rapidan, close at 2 P. M.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, President REILLY in the chair. A resolution from the other Board, directing the payment to J. B. FELLOWS of $1,200 for expenses incurred in the suit of THOS. C. WEST vs. The Mayor, , was concurred in.

Within the past month an article was published in the Boston Times which had a most unparalleled history. The writer, who is a steady go-to-meeting citizen, it seems, had his mind filled with his subject before going to bed, and determined to submit it to paper at the first opportunity.

The student of French history will see in present events one of those shadows of destiny which Christian men are wont to call "special interpositions of Providence." How often has a slight, everyday, commonplace incident changed the fate of a nation! The grandest events are merely transpositions of the commonplace.

The made in which prisoners are now treated in this City is, we believe, without any parallel among civilized nations. Not only is every one professing to come from a newspaper office allowed to badger and cross--question the man--as was done in the Police themselves now act as Grand Inquisitors.

The Kentucky presses Association met at Lexington yesterday. Mr. RAUCK, of the Lexington observer Reporter, delivered the address of welcome. Mr. W. N. HALDEMAN, of the Louisville Courier-Journal, was elected President for the ensuing year.

A correspondent of the Portland Press says Mrs. SARAH POTTER, of Wales, Me., seems to have been peculiarly unfortunate. When about 9 years old the bone of one of her arms was split. Three years later she suffered from a compound, longitudinal fracture of the arm, the bone being "broken off and split to pieces," to use her own language.

Montgomery, Ala., Jan. 13.--The Legislature has been engaged entirely on local bills. In the House several members expressed indignation at the introduction of a resolution authorizing the appointment of a clerk to put in legible and sensible shape bills for engrossing.

The Police Commissioners yesterday noon transferred Sergeant THOS. KILLILEA, of the Thirty-second Precinct, to the Jefferson Market Police Court, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sergeant MICHAEL O'CONNOR. The following additional transfers of Sergeants were also made:

A committee of the Directors of the Samuel Miller Orphan Asylum, consisting of Mr. JOHN G. MEEM, Mr. GEORGE D. DAVIS and Mr. C. W. BUTTON, will visit Baltimore, Philadelphia and other cities, at some early day, with the view of making inspections of such institutions in those places, their construction and arrangements of health, comfort, amusement and instruction, preparatory to the commencement of their asylum here.

JOHN ]iROHIIY, who was shot at Upper Tuckahoe on Sunday night last, by JAS. SPOLLAN, in front of the latter's store, died about 8 o'clock yesterday in great agony. The deceased was sensible to the last moment, but constantly suffered so much pain that hno never communilcated to his wife a statement of the circumstances under 'which the fatal shot was fired.

The troubles at Atlanta over the organization of the Legislature seem to have degenerated into a Bullock and anti-Bullock fight. Numerous dispatches were received here to-day on the subsect, including one or more from General TERRY, asking instructions as to his action under certain circumstances.

This is the cry which Senator SUMNER now echoes, undeterred by the fear that he will be proclaimed a "traitor" because he dares to diverge from the policy which is laid down by the Secretary of the Treasury. The truth is that the demand for a reduction of the taxes has now reached a point at which no Government could afford to disregard it.

The annual meeting of the Union League Club, for the election of officers for the ensuing year, took place last evening. Several hundred members were present on the occasion. There was a movement made to elect an independent ticket, but it proved to be weak and futile. The ticket itself included a few names which were not on the regular ticket.

The discussion at the last meeting of the Superintendents of the Poor of Kings County was rather more interesting than usual. It was very gratifying to observe how full of sympathy the Superintendents were for the suffering poor, and perhaps not so gratifying to the poor tax payers to anticipate a raid upon them for new appropriations to replenish the Superintendents' treasury..

A sale of tour lots on Forty-fifth-street, 100 feet west of Tenth-avcnune, -was made at theo Exchange yesterday by MULLER, WILKINS Co., under the direction of HNRY BENTZ. receiver. The two westerly lots were ocupied by brick buildingss, a three-story factory, 40x50 feet, standing on the rear of both lots; a threestory house, 25x40 feet, on the front of one, and a two-story stable and office on the other.

The Arion Society gave the first of its carnival festivals of the season at the Germauia Assembly Rooms last night. The large hall of the building was well filled with ladies and gentlemen, every one of the latter wearing, as is usual on such occasions, a clown's cap.

A little light was shed on the illicit whisky operations alleged to have been carried on by the proprietors of the distillery at Nos. 102 and 104 Hester-street, yesterday, during the examination of the case before Commissioner SHIELDS, Assistant District-Attorney PURDY produced a Government witness named PATRICK KEARNS.

A meeting was held at the Produce Exchange at 1 o'clock P. M. yesterday, to take into consideration the propricty of sending delegates to represent the produce dealers of this City at a Convention of the Commercial Union of the State of New-York, to be held at Rochester on Wednesday next.

The importance of statistical science, as applied to social and material development, has long been recognized, but its practical application is still imperfect as to results and partial as to locality. The efforts of the State of Ohio in this direction are among these to which attention may be advantageously directed, the occasion being offered by a voluminous report by Hon, ISAAC R. SHERWOOD, Secretary of State Just Published.
Judge RICHARDSON has written a letter declining the Presidency of the Hartford and Erie Railroad....In the House to-day, Mr. FITZGERALD, Of Boston, introduced a bill to abolish the State Police....

The excitement in regard to the recent extensive seizure of whisky distillers in Colector BAILEY'S district, on suspicion of defrauding the Government, continues unabated. The examination of the several cases is being made as rapidly as possible, but the result will not be announced until it is completed.

The National Bricklayers' Convention last evening elected the following officers: Vice-President EDWARD O'ROURKE: Secretary, S. J. BURROWS: Treasurer, WALTER B. DODSON. This morning a Committee was appointed to report on the telegraph operators' strike, and report a resolution indorsing the action of the operators, pledging them moral and material support.

The second anniversary of the De La Salle Catholic Association last evening at Steinway Hall was largely attended. The Association which is of a purely literary character--was established upwards of two years ago, under the direction of the Christian Brothers, with the object of bringing the Catholic young men of the City together in the debating class, and by the...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to express the sense of satisfaction which, I am quite sure, will be entertained by all impartial persons upon reading the very able criticism on Mr. FECUTER'S acting, which you published yesterday. The justice and fairness exhibited by your critic has often impressed me, in common, doubtless, with many other of your readers.

In the days when reconstruction was a thing unsettled, and not yet among the " fixed facts" of history, every American was his own reconstructionist-had a plan and a panacea for political ills better than those of any of his neighbors.
A meeting was held at the Southern Hotel last night to consider the subject of removing the National Capital to the Mississippi Valley, and was well attended, many prominent citizens being present.

The second of Professor DoOULES' lectures before the Young Men's Christian Assooiatioll was fully as well attended as the first. Every seat and every standing-place was monopolized, and, from all indications, the course must prove an exceedingly attractive one. After a prelude on the organ by Signor mora, Professor DOREMUS stepped to the front of the platform.

The Erie Railway strikers at Long Dock were yesterday assured of the support and cooperation of their fellow workers all along tile line of the road. Mr. HILL, who was sent to the Convention at Binghamton on Thursday morning, returned yesterday morning. He brought with him two delegates sent by the Convention, with authority to take whatever action in the Premises they should think best.

Mr. MITCHELL has, with a persistence which entitles him to the thanks of NewYork and Brooklyn, reintroduced his Gas bill of last session. Whether it will be attended by a better fate than on the previous occasion, remains to be seen.

The Senate met this morning at 10 o'clock. Senator COLLIER, who took the oath on the 10th inst., having made application to withdraw his oath, setting forth that it was made under misapprehension and party pressure, was allowed to withdraw, and by vote of the Senate his name was dropped from those roll.

At about 7 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the rear of the stable No. 122 West Thirty-sixth-street, which totally destroyed the building and burned up two horses valued at $300 each, and a wagon worth $150 belonging to WM. CONNOLLY, the occupant, a milkman, doing business at No. 166 West Thirty-sixth-street, and who had no insurance upon the property.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Excuse me for asking a little space in your columns for another communication,, which I promise shall be the last on this subject. I had no intention at the outset of entering into any protracted discussion regarding the conveying of the foreign malls.

Despite all that working correspondents may write, there is very little to be said, oven at this late day, concerning the arrangements for the Peabody obsequies. The authorities of Peabody and Portland, at least, have been prompt enough in their action, but the final order of exercises cannot be determined upon! until the arrival of the funnerla fleet and Mr. GEORGE PEABODY RUSSELL. /This. much, however, is known:

Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 125 Thompson st., on Saturday afternoon, at ?? o'clock. CANNON.--On Friday, Jan, 14, at Spingler House, New-York City, JOHN M. CANNON, Notice of funeral services hereafter.

Mr. DRAKE presented a petition in favor of the abolition of the franking privilege. He declared himself not only in favor of the proposition, but wished to incoporate with it another reform by discontinuing the immense publications of public documents, and thereby lessening the expenses of the Government.

No further danger of outbreak being apprehended, the troops collected from the neighboring garrisons have been ordered back to their posts, GREGO and the other conspirators against the life of the Emperor, who were tried and sentenoed to transportation in 1804, are to be comprised in the general amnesty to political offenders.... Out in Michigan they callan enterprising settler a railroad yes" man, as he is pretty certain to vote in favor of new railroads. In Boston just now it is the fashion to have " Dickens parties." In Minnesota hasty-pudding festivals are the correct thing. The Massachusetts Radical Peace Society is to hold a meeting in Boston on Wednesday, 26th inst.

The popefle Parthenia, Captain J. WESLEY TRYON, bound from Saybrook to New-York, when off Madison, about 9 o'clock Thursday morning, blew out one of her flues, severely sealding the engineers, JOHN DIBBLE and ALLEN TRYON. The latter is a brother of captain TRYON.

The County Clerk has issued a circular calling the attention of all concerned to the State law of April 30, 1869, which provides that all Notaries Public who were appointed at any time during the year 1868 by the Governor, with the consent of the Senate, shall hold office until and including the 30th day of March, 1870, and no longer.

The present agitation among the piano makers, of whom there are about 1,500 employed in this City, is exciting considerable attention among the working classes and all those interested in the labor movement. The House closedthe great debate on Virginia to day at 4:15 o'clock, when the voting began on the several amendments to the main bill of the Reconstruction Committee. The discussion to-day was very striking. Early in the debate General LOGAN made a brief but eloquent speech in favor of the bill; FITCH, of Nevada, and STEVENSON, of Ohio, did the same;

The following is the full report of Mr. BONNER'S speech, at the opening of the new Gymnasium at Princeton, N. J., on Thursday : I expected to be called upon for a speech. In fact, I was notified that I should be : and what is somewhat unusual with speechmakers, if their own statements are to be credited, I have come fully prepared for the occasion.

Commissioner BRENNAN, yesterday, tried fifty-three policemen, charged with various infractions of the rules for the government of the force. The great majority of theo cases were of the usual trivial character, and none of them developed any matters of general public interest.

The following is the text of Judge LEDWITH'S decision in the case of Mayor SAWYER, of Hudson City, and others, recently acquitted by him of charges of conspiracy to defraud: Having heard all the testimony in this prosecution, I have concluded to discharge all the parties accused, as the complainant has failed to establish his allegations of fraud or attempted fraud against the parties charged.

The following letter from Dr. HARRIS, the Sanitary Superintendent, is designed to allay needless anxiety induced by exaggerated rumors concerning the prevalence of smallpox amongst us: METROPOLITAN BOARD OF HEALTH, Jan. 14, 1870. Rumors and anxieties concerning smallpox, many of which are exaggerated and erroneous, make it our duty to give full information in regard to the character and extent of its prevalence.

A reception was given to the Federal Judges of the Second Circuit Court Districts,. last evening, at the residence of Mr. E. W. STOUGHTON, on .Fifth-avenue. A. large number of distinguished people were present on the occasion, including Judges WOODRUFF, BENEDICT the United States Supreme Court, ex-Attorneythe United States Supreme Court, ox-AttorneyGeneral EVARTS, District-Attorney PIERREPONT, Mr. D. D. FIELD, Assistant District-Attorney PURDY, and others.

The American Church Union, New-York branch, held its annual meeting Thursday evening its rooms, No. 1,155 Broadway. The attendance embraced many prominent Episcopalians, both clergy and laity. The following officers were unanimously elected for the ensuing year :

On Sunday last, in the prime of life and the midst of usefulness, our fellow-townsman, FREDERIC A. COE, breathed his last after an illness which was short and sudden. Mr. COE was born at New-Hartford, Oneida County, in this State in September, 1816, and at the time of his death was in his fifty-fourth year. His father, who survives hi, was the Presbyterian minister at that place.

The usual monthly meeting of the NewYork City Sunday School and Missionary Society was held yesterday afternoon, at the Book Rooms, No. 805 Broadway. Mr. W. W. CORNELL presided, and Mr. JAS. H. PELTON officiated as Secretary. The report sof the missionaries were of great interest.

There is hope for Virginia. The House yesterday, by a narrow majority, adopted Mr. BINGHAM'S resolution providing for the unconditional admission of the State. The preamble subsequently passed without a division. And as a substitute for the pending bill, the whole was finally carried by a vote of 148 to 49, the majority embracing eighty-four Republicans.

At the usual weekly prayer meeting of the congregation of Plymouth Church last evening, Rev. Mr. BEECHER opened the conversation by announcing that he had received during the past week, as he usually does, a large number of letters upon all sorts of subjects, and it was worthy of observation that many of them-very many of them-began much as if one mind had dictated the sentences. For instance;

Promptly on its reassembling, Congress has taken up the question of another reduotion of the army. The problem presented is the difficult one of diminishing numbers without impairing efficiency; or that of steering between the Seylla and Charybdis of crippling on the one hand and crowding on the other.

The steamer Eagle, which left Havana Jan. 8 and touched at Nassau, N. P., reached this port last night. Our letters and papers reached us, as usual, promptly, thanks to the courtesy of Purser HUERTAS.

The bark Silver Cloud, 128 days from Australia, and the ship North Star, 110 days from Hong Kong, both supposed to have been lost, arrived to-day.... The evcavation of the Sutro Tunnel has now reached lve hundred feet, and the work is being vigorbusly pushed....The Superintendent of Indian Affairss of Oregon, has returned to Salem, after a comparatively unsuccessful attempt to place the Snake Indians on the Government reservation.

The Methodist of this week prints the following in relation to the irregularities in the Methodist Book Concern: "A sub-committee of three of their number, appointed by the Book Committee, devoted nearly a month to the examination of the irregularities brought to light by the assistant agent, and when the Book Committee met, on Nov. 4, made a report of results as far as ascertained.

The annual report of the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction was received and ordered to be printed. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. WOOD-To punish homicide and other irjurics by the careless handling of firearms. By Mr. CAULDWELL-To amend the Morrisania Trustee act.

The annual meeting of the Methodist Episcopal Sunday School Union was held at No. 805 Broadway yesterday afternoon. VicePresidents JOHN TRUSLOW and E. H. BROWN in turn presided. An interesting report was read by Corresponding Secretary J. H. VINCENT, from which it appears that the Union controls 16,193 schools, with 182,869 officers and teachers, and 1,170,219 scholars, the average attendance of scholars being 561,747.

All the facts in this case having been already published in the TIMES, to dwell upon the details would be productive of no good. The whereabouts of Mr. COOKE are still a mystery, and his present residence is only known to his intimate friends. Mrs. CooKE yesterday removed from her late residence, the parsonage of the church, and is now with her mother in Williamsburg.

The Benecia has been ordered to leave on the 25th inst. The United States gunboat Yantic has been ordered to take part in the expedition to the Isthmus of Darien. The old store ship Relief has been selected as the rendezvous for the "ordinary seamen," many of whom will have to be discharged to make room for first-class seamen whose labor will be more valuable to the Government.

A agreeable reunion of the members of the Tabernacle Church, corner of Broadway and Sixth-avenue, was held last evening, with the object of promoting mutual acquaintance and friendships. To add to the interest of the event several new productions of the well-known artists, ssrs.

The official investigation into the irregularities alleged to have been discovered In the revenue returns of several distillers and whisky dealers in the Thirty-second Collection District, is still being conducted at Collector BAILEY'S Office, but no result is likely to be arrived at for sometime.

The unusual spirit exhibited in the sale of cal estate at the Exchange Rooms, in the early part of the week, gradually dwindled down until yesterday, when the auctioneer's voice was alent again. A few individuals gathered there, is usual, but soon dispersed, without having accomplished anything in the way of trade, unless among themselves. The indications for next week are not very promising, although a few ales are announced.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent. News packages for the Journal of Commerce, Times Tribune, World, Sun, Express, Evening Post, Commercial Advertiser, Stoats Zettung and New-Yorker Demokrat, should also be delivered only to the same parties.

It will be satisfactory to his American admirers to know that Mr. DICKENS' forthcoming story is to appear in this country simultaneously with its publication in England. Messrs. FIORDS, OSGOOD CO. have arranged for advance sheets of the serial Illustrated installments of which will, when begun, be regularly found in Every, Saturday.

For several days Past a warrant has been out for the arrest of EDWARD J. OAKLEY, late Cashier of the Merchants' Exchange Bank, on a charge of embezzlement, The warrant was issued by Commissioner SHIELDS, on an affidavit made by Assistant District-Attorney PURDY, in which OAKLEY was accused of embezzling moneys belonging to the Merchants' Exchange National Bank, and of having thereby violated a law of the United States.

Early this morning KEATING'S planing mill, on Portland-street, was destroyed by tire. A large quantity of lumber was burned. The upper stories were occupied by carpenters, builders, , who lost everything. The total loss is estimated at 30,000.

The annual festival and public reception of the Eighth Ward Colored School took place yesterday at No. 185 Spring-street. This school is composed almost entirely of colored children, of whom about 150 were present. An unusually large number of visitors were present, besides many of the children's Parents.

In 1869 the Onondaga salines produced 6,804,295 bushels of boiled salt, and 1,857,942 bushels of sun-made salt-a total of 8,662,237 bushels, of fifty-six pounds each. The total revenues were $86,757 60, of which $46,546 51 was disbursed for the pumping and distribution of the salt water, the improvement and repairs of the State property and machinery, and the supervision of the manufacture.

At a meeting of friends of the project to remove the national capital from Washington to St. Louis, held in the latter city on Thursday evening, the following letters were read ; WASHINGTON, Dec. 29, 1869. Mr. L. U. Reavis : DEAR SIR : Yours came to hand duly. I have done nothing on the address; time had been engrossed.

The stockholders of the Newark and Paterson Railroad Company are said to have sob on foot a movement for the appointment of a receiver, who is to be empowered to commence suits against the directors of the Erie- Railway Company for not fulfilling the terms of the contract made by them when they leased the road.

An: advertisement in another column relates to valuable property for sale in the immediate neighborhood of Aiken, S.C., which offers to the Northern capitalist a rare opportunity for investment. Two pamphlets have been published recently, setting forth the unrivaled advantages of Aiken as a Winter resort for invalids.

The jury in the case of Dr. SHATFORD, on trial for murder in producing abortion on the body of a girl named THEODOSIA PATTERSON, last night brought in a verdict of not guilty. On the announcement of the verdict the crowd in attendance broke forth in vociferous applause, which took the Court some time to suppress.

The annual meeting of the Board of Trade of Boston was held on Wednesday, and the following report was submitted from the Committee on Tariff Legislation: The Committee of the Boston Board of Trade appointed to consider "the question of the Customs Duties," and to report to the Board the principles and qualifying conditions which, in their opinion. should govern the tariff legislation of the country," beg respectfully to report.

Public affairs are "tranquil" again in France....The Government authorities, it is said, extent to prosecute the proprietors of the Reforme, a revolutionary organ, for recent violent attacks upon them. Two provineral journals, it is reported, are also to be prosecuted.

From the advance sheets of a new sensation book by GEORGE ELLINGTON, published by subscription, we excerpt the following outline sketch of MORRIS PHILLIPS, of the Home Journal. The author, treating largely of society, people and fashionable life in New-York, deems the Home Journal and Mr. PHILLIPS appropriate subjects for discussion in his work.

While a number of men were engaged this afternoon at plumbing in the new building erected last Summer by the Gas Company of this village, and using an open fire in their work, an explosion of escaped gas took place, slightly injuring some of the workmen, and causing a damage to the building of about $2,500. The shock was at first thought to be an earthquake.

An inquest was commenced yesterday by Corner FLYNN in the case of GEORGE STOLL, the German who died at No. 124 Delaucey-street, from the effects of a stab wound received on the 24th ult. Dr. LOUIS BOPP,...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am glad that your attention, as well of that of Mr. Commissioner WELLS, has been turned to the present demoralized state of labor. You may remember that I called your attention to it more than a year ago, as the most serious feature of our present situation.

The New-York Bridge Company applied a day or two since to the Harbor Commission, for leave to deposit the earth dredged from tile bottom of the East River, on the Brookiyn side, near the Fulton Ferry, in the new grounds being made on tile northwest side of Blackwell's Island, where the Commissioners of Charities and Correction are now carrying on operations of great benefit to Hell Gale navigation.

A panic occurred in Music Hall last evening which might have resulted seriously. About 9 o'clock, during the exhibition drill of the Montgomery Guards, a seat in the gallery, upon which several persons were standing, gave way, and during the excitement consequent thereupon theory of fire was wickedly raised.

A few days since MATHEW CLARK, of South Hampton, received from Messrs. H S. FRENCH $180, the proceeds of some pork sold by CLARK for Mr. GEORGE WHITTAKER, of South Hampton. He remained in the village until near night when he started for home in company with two men from Scuttle Hole, a village about two miles from Sag Harbor.

BROPHY.--In this City, on Friday, Jan. 14, at his father residence, no. 20 Market-st., JOSEPH, eldest son of Michael and Rosanna Brophy, in the 21st year of his age. God takes the good, too good on earth to stay, And leaves the had, too bad to take a way. The relatives and friends are requested to attend the funeral this day, at 2 o'clock.

At a meeting of the telegraph strikers on Friday, Mr. IRA DEWITT, one of the members present, stated, in a few pointed remarks, his belief that as an organization they were beaten, and that the best thing they could do would be to retreat in as good order as possible and repair the breach.

The Brooklyn election frauds have come before the public once more, and in a new aspect. It was expected that a beginning would have been made on some one of the cases in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge PRATT, last Friday,

Further particulars of the explosion on board the propeller Parthenia, on Thursday morning, while on her trip from Saybrook, Conn., to New-York, represent the occurrence as attended by scenes of unusual distress and suffering. The first and second engineers, ALLEN TRYON and JOHN DIBBLE, were both scalded so badly that they died in a few hours.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Saturday, Jan. 7, 1870. On Tuesday, the 4th of January, several citizens of Eau Claire and the neighboring towns witnessed the following remarkable meteorological phenomenon: About 10:30 in the evening a light exactly resembling the aurora borealis in its pale milky color, appeared nearly due east, about fifteen or twenty degrees above the horizon.
