It is stated with some appearance of authority that sermons will be preached t several of the churches this morning on the "clerical scandal" which has recently given active employment to some of our contemporaries. We should be glad to believe that the statement was untrue, but there are ministers of religion who for the sake of notoriety would hold up their own mothers as dreadful examples.

The discussions which are continually agitating the whole body of our laboring classes are bringing forth some now and startling allocations from the side of the employers. It is said by the latter that the phrase " the rights of labor" is receiving a very different interpretation from that which formerly attached to it;

The workmen lately discharged from the service of the Erie Railway Company held three meetings in Jersey City yesterday, at which over 300 were present, and in which the latest movements in the progress of the strike were fully reported.

Miss NADEJSDA LEVITSKASA, formerly prima donna of the Russian Opera Troupe, and ALEXANDER RAJOSINE, appeared at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning to answer a charge of grand larceny, preferred against them by Count DIMITRE AGRENESS SLAVIANSKY, proprietor and manager of the company.

LEO BALSKY, a Russian by birth, aged 35 years, and formerly proprietor of a notorious private post office in Amity-street, has resided for some time in the premises No. 23 Bleeckerstreet, near Mott, with his mistress, ELLEN KNICKERBOCKER, a woman well known in the neighborhood.

ROBERT COPELAND, one of the men charged, with defrauding the Fourth National Bank of $7,000 by means of fraudulent entries, voluntarily appeared before Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, and gave ball In $5,000 to appear for examination of Monday next.

In the Circuit Court, the case of JOHN SEILER against PETER C. WARD was tried and resulted in a verdict for plaintiff for $3,000. The wife of SEILER became attached to WARD a few years since, and the preference thus shown grew into an intimacy which is alleged to have been criminal.

The rains for several days past have been quite general throughout the Pacific States, and the prospect for the crops are most favorable. There is no longer reason to apprehend danger to the growing grain from a want of rain.... The ship Chieftain has been placed under the Salvador flag and her name changed to the Clotilde .... JACOB

A variety of operations whereby money is extorted, are usually grouped under the popular designation of "blackmail." The smaller and less injurious developments of this system are recognized as a misdemeanor by the common law; but the larger descriptions stalk unscathed through the few enactments that bear upon them.

The Government detectives are on the track of CALDWELL, who is supposed to be in the hands of his friends in the vicinity of Prescott. DEVLIN, his counsel, went to Prescott last night, and a Government. dectective was sent to watch him, it being believed that he went up to help CALDWELL in evading arrest.

Rev. E. P. INGERSOLL has accepted the call, previously declined, from the Middle Reformed Church of South Brooklyn, Salary $5,000. Indianapolis has three free churches within its limits. Rev. E. B. FAIRFIELD, LL.D, has left the Baptist Church and joined the Congregational.

The buildings in Trinity-place, now used as Appraisers' stores, have a superficial area of 26,000 square feet, and are rented by the Government, from private parties, for $73,000 per annum; an increase of $31,000 over the rental of last year, when $42,000 was paid. Two stories have been added to these buildings, it is true; but the ground area is no more than before.

THE WEEK'S AMUSEMENTS. Fow dramatic events in a generation provoke so much discussion as has the advent in New-York of Mr. FECHTER. We rejoice in this since discussion in art, like free speech in politics, tends to the evolution of truth. The rank heretofore claimed in these columns for Mr. FECHTER will be, we venture to think, generally acknowledged as his style and peculiarities become more familiar.

The arrangement is finally settled between the directors of the Companies, and it only requires to be coutirmed by the shareholders.

Forty years ago, when the region of Unionsquare was a mere suburb, and the Park Theatre was in its glory, and the old Bull's Head Tavern stood on the present site of the Bowery Theatre, the City of New-York did not possess a prison intended for the exclusive custody of persons committing offences against the criminal laws of the StatE.

O. GREY, when considerable evidence was obtained, though of an unimportant character. Indeed the testimony was simply amusing for its want of purpose,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--Neither branch of Congress was in session to-day, and consequently the Capital was almost entirely deserted. The only evidence of legislative life about the building was in the three or four Committee rooms where sessions were held, delegations heard, and witnesses examined.

In an interview yesterday with Messrs. KIRTLAND and HAMMOND, of the firm of UNDERHILL Co.. No.106 Duane-street, those gentlemen confirmed the report of Mr. J. A. UNDERHILL'S defalcation. In the morning the creditors of the firm, numbering forty, met at the office in Duane-street to learn something with regard to the affair, and to arrange for an investigation of the matter.

Ex-Justice RICHARD KELLY, late of the Yorkville Police Court and of the Court of Special Sessions, was made the recipient of a handsome and valuable gold watch yesterday morning. The presentation was made in the Justice's private room at the Tombs, and was a great surprise to Mr. KELLY.

In the Court of Inquiry to-day, the council for the defence filed the following plea against the jurisdiction of General RUGER, General HAINES and Major GOODFELLOW, composing the Board of Inquiry: The ineligibility of the undersigned to a seat in the Legislature of Georgia under the Reconstruction acts of the Congress of the United States,

A special dispatch from St. Cloud, of the 14th, says: Dr. SHUFFER had arrived there from Pembina the same evening, and reports matters as in a very serious state at Fort Garry. The French, under REILLE, are masters of the situation.

The Canard steamship Java, which left Liverpool, Jan. 1, and Queenstown, Jan. 2, reached this port yesterday, with tow days' later news than was at hand by the City of Paris. The farewell address of the London Morning Herald is printed in the last number of that journal, dated Dec. 31. The first issue of the paper was sent forth in November, 1780.

The vast part played by railroad companies in the complex mechanism of modern commerce has at length boon brought before the eyes of law-makers. The recent messages of the Governors of New-York, Wisconsin, Massachusetts and Minnesota are remarkable for the high ground they take in reference to State supervision of such corporations.

WILLIAM GODWIN, and perhaps some one before him, said that a man is never in greater danger of missing the world's applause than when he has taken the greatest pains to deserve it. This may sometimes be true in art, because pains in it are often expressed by minuteness, and this is commonly accounted the antithesis of genius.

The Legislature to-day ratified the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments. The election for United States Senator will occur on Monday. B. G. EGGLESTON, the candidate for Governor last year on the Radical ticket; R. N. FLOWER, of Mississippi, and Major-General AMES are the prominent candidates.

The Pennsylvania Temperance State Central Committee has issued a call for a State Convention to be held in Harrisburg, Feb. 8. Country papers are asking their readers to repeat the following rapidly: "And she stood in the arbor welcoming him in."

Some months since we published a statement to the effect that Miss GRAY, a milliner of Fort Edward, had become the fortunate heir to $19,000,000, which her lover, a young Englishman, had willed to her upon his dying bed. The main fact in the case--the heirship--is true;

In the case of CONRAD OESTREICHER, whose death was due to a stab wound sustained on the 2d inst., Coroner KEENAN held an inquest yesterday. The accused, ABRAHAM KEHER, and his son MORRIS were arraigned at the same time. MARY OESTREICHER, sister of the deceased, whose house she kept at No. 55 Rose-street, identified the body of her brother.

Between 4 and 5 o'clock this morning a stone wall 100 feet long and 30 feet high, in the rear of a building on Third-street, west of Elm-street, fell towards the Third-street building crushing In the kitchen. A woman named HERRE, who was making a fire, was caught and held by the falling stones until liberated by her husband. Her leg was broken.

The people of Newton, Sussex Co., N. J., are greatly excited over the sudden death of EDWARD PALMER, a resident of that place. As already reported, it was suspected that PALMER came to his death at the hands of his wife and a man named BROWN, with whom Mrs. PALMER is said to have had a guilty intimacy.

Less than a score of years ago, the cost of opening a street in New-York City, from river to river, was about $3,000. The same legalproceedings are taken now, as then, yet the cost under the Tammany " Ring" is ten times as great. Tne new drive or boulevard, for instance; was projected some time ago.

To-morrow evening the Fourth Regiment will be mustered out of the State service, in accordance with the orders issued from General Headquarters, the command not being able to present the minimum number of men for inspection.

GENERAL ORDER No. 1.-A sub-district, to consist of the counties of Warren, Taliaferro, Wilkes, Lincoln, Columbia and Glasscock, in Georgia, is hereby constituted, and Brevet Major JACOB KLINE, Captain Eighteenth United States Infantry, is assigned to Its command, with headquarters at Barnett Station, Warren County.

A large and enthusiastic mass meeting of Republicans was held here on Saturday, and attended by nearly every Republican member of the Legislature and a large number of prominent Republicans in various sections of the State and of this city.

1870 IS an old story with you, so I will spare you any moralizings upon it. In a patriotic point of view 1876, with its centenary of independence, will be more interesting, I will resorvctho observations I purposed making for that occasion, or, if you prefer, will postpone them to the year 1000, and wish you now a happy new year-what there is left of it.

The proceedings of the Council of the Vatican are daily becoming more interesting as the forces of the liberal opposition begin to stand distinctly apart from the Ultramontane supporters of the contemplated dogma of papal infallibility.

The much-talked-of game of billiards between JOHN DEERY, of California, the present champion, and CYRILLE DION, champion of Canada, for $1,000 and the diamond cue, came off at the Mechanics' Pavilion, in this city, last evening.
For the past two days the weather has been extremely cold. The thermometer stood at 10? below zero yesterday morning, with a flue west wind blowing. THE CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 15--The Legislature to-day ratified the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments. The election for United States Senator will occur on Monday. B. G. EGGLESTON, the candidate for Governor last year on the Radical ticket; R. N. FLOWER, of Mississippi, and General AMES are the prominent candidates.

The Latter Day Prophet has addressed the following words of comfort to the modest friend of the Mormons in this City: SALT LAKE CITY, U. T., Jan. 5, 1870. Hon, George Francis Train, New-York: DEAR SIR: * * * We read of you and your progress with considerable interest.

Canada, in spite of its proverbial slowness, may be said to have made remarkable progress in railway enterprise. Less than twenty years ago there wore not ten miles of railroad in operation throughout the whole of what is now known as the Dommion, but since 1852,2,500 miles have been added, several lines are in course of construction and others are projected, including the Intercolonial, which, if not the most important, will certainly be the longest.

A number of drunken loafers, congregated before HOIILUND'S drinking saloon in Hudson City, became'involved in a desperate fight last evening over some Inconsequential matter. Two of them, JOIIN LANNIOAN and FRANK WOOD, fought over the matter, and were punishing one another badly, when WooD dealt his opponent a blow with his fist which sent hm reeling insensible to the ground, and then took to his heels. No policeman was about.

There was a great discusslon in the Senate yesterday on the affairs of the Interior and the general domestic policy of the Government. At the conclusion of the debate the Senate passed a vote of confidence in the late Ministry ... In the Corps Legislatif yesterday, M. KERATRY moved that the debate on the arraignment of Deputy ROCHEFORT be postponed until the 24th inst.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The event of the past week has been the substantial admission of Virginia back into the Union, from which she practically seceded nine years ago. Congress took hold of the subject very promptly on the first day of its reassembling, and its grip of the subject had not lessened in either House, until on Friday evening the House of Representatives passed the bill of unconditional admission.
A special dispatch from St. Cloud, of the 14th, says: Dr. SHUFFER had arrived there from Pembina the same evening, and reports matters as In a very serious state at Fort Garry.

Services were hold last evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, In behalf of the Italian Church Reform Commlsion, which ,were attended by an overflowing congregation. Right Rev. Bishop CoXE, of Western New-York, delivered a discourse, in which he gave some account of the reform movement in Italy, and made an appeal in its behalf.

HAVANA, Jan. 15--The Gaceta to-day publishes dispatches from the interior announcing the surrender of insurgents in large numbers. The Spanish troops in the Central Department are on the march to attack the insurgents. The Spanish mail steamer which sailed to-day took a memorial signed by thousands of Spaniards, requesting the Cortes to defer the granting of liberty and reforms in Porto Rico.

A discourse on this subject was delivered at the Madison Square Church, last evening, by Rev. Dr. ADAMS, by request of the directors of the Union Theological Seminary. The speaker took for his text, Matthew ix., 37-38, viz.: "Then health He nnto His disciples, The harvest truly is plenteous, but the Iaborers are few; Prny ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that He will send forth laborers Into His harvest."

EUROPE. In the French Senate, on Saturday, a great debate is reported to have occurred on the general domestic affairs of the Government, and a vote of confidence in the late Ministry was passed. In the Corps Legislatif it was moved that the debate on the arraignment of ROCHEFORT be postponed to the 24th inst.

The now and elegant little Chapel of St. John's Church, situated at the corner of Seventh. avenue and Douglass-street, Brooklyn, wa8 duly opened with divine services yesterday. Among the clergymen who took part in the exercises xvllll the rector, Rev. ROBERT H. TURRY, Rev. Messrs. SPAFFORD, NEWTON, BAKER and PAIGE.

COGSWELL.--On Saturday morning, Jan. 15, HENRY COGSWELL, aged 65 years and 8 months. His friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this (Monday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 140 8th-av. CROLIUS.--In Brooklyn, on Sunday, Jan. 16, WILLIAM I. CROLIUS, in the 88th year of his age.

Our readers must have been struck with the touching letters to this journal from missionaries; and country clergymen which our article on the inadequacy of their salaries has called forth. If any one will carefully examine the dry statistical pages of Commissioner WELLS recent report, he will find the figures relieved by some similar communications from teachers and salaried persons.

From the Charleston News, Jan. 11. The Orangeburg News says emphatically that were farmers do not get what hands they want this year "'tis their own fault." Much land has been sold to colored men, who are building and settling upon it; but this does not hinder farmers from contracting with these very men. A gentleman in the county has rented lands to families all around him.

Three fires occurred yesterday morning. The first was in the three-story frame building No. 461 Tenth-avenue, owned by JOHN MCINTYRE, and occupied by RABB BAILEY as a grocery. Damage to stock, $400; insured. PETER WHITE'S blacksmith and wheelright shop, No. 463 Tenth-avenue, was also injured by the flames. Loss $100. The fire is supposed to be of incendiary origin.

Review of the Pnst Veelh. So far as public sales are concerned, the past week has exhibited more hfe in the real .estate market than the preceding one, but the aggregate of recorded transfers, as they have apPcared in the columns of the TIMES from day to day, is much smaller.

The Iowa Senatorial contest has at last been decide. The locality claim has again been put aside. The contest was narrowed down to the personal qualifications and popularity of Messrs. ALLISON and WRIGHT. The latter has for several years been on the Supreme Bench of the State, residing at Des Moines.

It was expected the Salem Water Pipe case would be argued m the United States District Court yesterday, but owing to the death of a daughter of Judge LOWELL, the case was postponed until next Wednesday. General BUTLER is one of the counsel.

That the Eric Company, by an artful contrivance made with Mr. McHENRY and others, got a lease of the Atlantic and GreatWestern Company at the end of 1868, and that the payment of all rent has been evaded, are but too well known by those most interested. When tile lease was made, the character of the Erie managers was not so well developed, and Judge BARNARD had not granted so many Injunctions by scores.

We predicted some months ago, atthe outset of the Erie Railroadstrike, that the affair would be a lasting and determined one; and the event has justified ouraugury. Indeed, with the reputation of the Company what it is, With "Erie" a byword in men's mouths, it was not to be supposed that even genuine measures of conciliation would be received with trust and confidence by indignant emPloves.

The following is the full account of the recent horror at Long Swamp, reported in the TIMES Friday morning: The true name of the man was FREDERICK STAUD. He had lived at Long Swamp about six years, and is supposed to have brought with him, as well as amassed since coming here, considerable money It has

The Central Park meteorological report for last week sets forth t following facts and fig. ures: Barometer-Mean, 30.105 inches; maximum at 2 P. M. Jan. 14, 30.512 inches; minimum at 2 P. M. Jan. 13, 29.844 inches; range, .668 inch. Thermometer-Mean, 3-1.40. maximum at 4 P. M. Jan. 13, 520; minimum 7 A. M. Jan. 9, 170; range, 35o. Jan. 14, rain and hail from 8:30 P. M.

The costs in the trial of the Directors of OVEREND, GURNEY CO. were over $5,000 a day. Eight theatres in London are managed by ladies. Mr. GLADSTONE has just completed his 60th year, and Mr. DISRAELI his 64th. The village of Sardon, in France, has been entirely destroyed by fire

The Congressional Temperance Society hold a meeting to-night at the Metropolitan Methodist Church. The house was densely crowded with ladies and gentlemen. After singing by the choir, and prayer by Rev. Dr. NEWMAN, Senator WILSON, President of the Society, read the following recommendation of the Soniety:

NO. 11. The first race meeting over the Prospect Park Course was held in the last week in June, shortly after the Jerome Park Spring meeting. It was given under the auspices and management of some of the leading members of the American Jockey Club, but the amount of success it met with will hardly induce its repetition another season.

The conclusions reached and reported last week by the "Committee on Tariff Legislation" of the Boston Board of Trade are remarkable, not so much in themselves-for the same results had been already arrived at by many thinkingmen-but rather by reason of the lesson they convey.

The beautiful church of which Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG is pastor was well filled last evening by an audience anxious to hear something about the missionary work in the far West. The usual Episcopal form of evening prayer was read by Rev. Mr. AMES. It was announced that Rev. Mr. TYNG would be unable to be present, owing to his having been suddenly summoned to speak at the rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association.

Mrs. THOMAS SHAW, of this city, received a letter from Mrs. GEORGE PEABODY RUSSELL, of Salem, stating that she had received a cable dispatch from Sir EDWARD LAMSON, one of the executors of Peabody estate in England, informing her the flect was at Madeira Jan. 1, and that GEORGE PEABODY RUSSELL confirmed the report that three of the vessels would coal at Bermuda.

An adjourned meeting of citizens was held last night at the Southern Hotel, to take action in relation to the removal of the national capital to the Mississippi Valley. Mayor COLE was called upon to express his views, but declined on account of indisposition.

Rev. THOMAS PRESTON, of St. AHE'S Church, Eighth-street, lectured last evening at the Cooper Institute on the "Catholic View of the Public School Question." The lecture was announced to commence at 8 o'clock, but fully two hours previously the large space fronting the building was besieged by an Immense crowd, excitedly striving for a position near the door, In order to be able to obtain a good seat when the gates were thrown open.

Said SIDNEY SMITH: "When a country 'squire hears of an ape, his first feeling is to give it nuts and apples; when he hears of a dissenter, his immediate impulse is to commit it to the county jail, to shave its head, to alter its customary food, and to have it privately whipped.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : "Vindox," I observe from his letter in your paper of this date, wishes to withdraw from the discussion raised by his vague statements on the subject of the conveyance of the ocean malls. Before he does so finally he will, however, I trust, enlighten the public on the point referred to by me in my former letter to you, viz.:

The Tammany politicians are at Albany, putting to knife the Police Board, and making war generally upon our City civilization. In one single particular this Tammany tribe show an instinct for the fitness of things. They still call themselves by their old Indian name.
From the Evening Express. The Press is an immense power for good or evil; and just now its days of evil seem to prevail. "The lie travels its league while truth is putting on his boots."

The second anniversary of the Sabbath School of the Meothodist Episcopal Chapel iu East Eleventh-street, was celebrated yesterday afternoon. This Mission is under the care of the City Sunday School and Missionary Society of the Methodist Church, of which Mr. W. W. ConNELL is President.

The short session" which the Democracy boasted at the opening of the Legislature they were going to exhibit to the admiring gaze of the people, seems likely, from present appearances, to turn out, like the other boast of their Governor about au "honest Legislature," to be only a pretence to win a little favor in advanuce.

There is a proposition before the Legislature or Maine to put a tax on insurance business done by companies "not located within the State." The Eastern Argus objects to that proposal-and, In our opinion, with great justice. Any sort of tax on insurances is a tax on thrift and forethought, and, therefore, tends to discourage the very qualities which are most useful in a community.

Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD has everywhere mot with a cordial reception from the Mexicans, across whose country he has recently been traveling. Two gentlemen of his party arrived in this City Saturday, and have furnished us with an interesting account of the journey of the distinguished statesman from the Pacific Coast to the Gulf. Mr. SEWARD ana party,
In the Legislature, to-day, the Senate passed a bill repealing the clause in the Sunday law prohibiting theatrical am usements on the Sabbath.

Last year a young man who had but recently returned from California, was employed in the City Treasurer's office as temporary clerk. He did his work so well that he was again employed this season, and placed in a most responsible position, the duty of paying interest on the city debt being Intrusted to his charge.

General C. H. SMITH assumed command of the Department of Louisiana on the 7th inst. Bishop CHASE, of New-Hampshire, is very ill, and probably cannot live many days. The thermometer marked eighteen degrees below zero at Burlington, Vt., on Friday morning last.

The regular mail steamship from Rio Janeiro arrived at this port today, bringing later intelligence from Paraguay. Tile dispatches previously received, announcing the flight of LOPEZ and the termination of the war, are fully confirmed. It seems that LoPEZ did not retreat towards Bolivia.

There is less novelty to refer to after a review of the programmes of the City theatres than usual. Two changes of bill, however, call for note. At the Bowery, the new pantomime of "Buck, Buck, how many Horns," will be produced for the first time.

The Arion Singing Society rehearsed theo opera "Der Frelschuotz," by CARL MARIA VON WEBER, at the Academy of Music, last evening. They will perform the opera under the direction of nMr. CIARLES BEnRGIANN,their musical director, with splendid decorations at the Academy of Music, of this City, on the 21st and 29th inst., and at the Academy of Music of Brooklyn ontho24th inst.

From the Trenton (N. J.) Gazette. It does, we confess, seem somewhat unfair that a generation that did all the fighting for the preservation of tile Union should also do all the paying. It seems no more than just that,

During the past two weeks Admiral BUCHANAN, of the late Confederate Navy, visited our city, while on a pleasure tour through the South. While in Savannah a most unexpected, but pleasant, occurrence took place. It was at the Gulf Railroad office.

The strikes which are continually heard of in almost every class of industry have rendered it very desirable, on behalf of those interests, that some exposition of their results should be offered. The opinion is frequently expressed that, as a rule, strikes have been successful.

It becomes our painful duty to chronicle another one of those chilling horrors and deeds of blood resulting in the taking of life, and the bereaving of friends and home, which have been but too common in some portions of our State and upon our border for two or three years past. In this instance it was a double tragedy, enacted, it would appear, with atrocious premeditation and deliberate purpose.

A committee appointed by both branches of the Legislature has addressed the following letter to General TERRY: We, the undersigned Committee appointed at a meeting of both Houses of the General Assembly, irrespective of party, having objected to and protested against the manner of the organization of said General Asssembly as illegal and unconstitutional,

Hon. ISRAEL WASHBURNE, of Livermore, Me., is dangerously ill. He is 83 years of age. The Democratic Party in Georgia bewails that it has no leader. A Chicago paper complains that two distinguished Senators not unfrequently make up in acrimony what they lack in enthusiasm.

The third in the sones of temperance meetings which are being hold in the different churches of this City, was attended by a large audience at th Calvary Baptist Church in Twenthird-street last evening. The meeting was presided ovr by Mr. B. F. JESSUP, who explained that the object of these meetings was to bring the subject of temperence before the churches and before the youth of the land.

The revolution in the State of San Luis Potosi is increasing. The Governor of the State and the members of the Legislature are still hold prisoners, and some Federal Generals have joined the insurgents. The officer commanding the Federal troops in that State reports that his forces are not strong enough to operate against the usurpers.

The now Post Office, now in process of Crection at the lower and of the City Hall Park promises to be an oranment to the City, and a triumph for the archteet, from whem we have obtained the following details with regard to it The style of the building is Renaissunce, of the French school. It will be carried up there storics in the walls, a fourth story being former in the roof.

The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was hold yesterday afternoon, President BERGEN in the Chair. The Board proceeded to consider the special order of business, being the report of the Law Committee proposing certain amendments to the city charter, which was presented to the Board on tile 27th of December, 1869.

Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Saturday night, an affray took place in the liquor store of MIATTHEW CONNOLLY, No. 136 North Fifth-street, Brooklyn, E. D. between the proprietor and a man named THOMAS KENNEDY, a resident of North Sixth-street, near Seventh.

The will of the J.C. CALHOUN, son of Commodore CALHOUN, involving property to the amount of $50,000, has been refused probate by surrogate HULSE, at Newburg. The matter has been a subject of considerable interest, not only in a legal point of view, but on account of the social standing of the contesting heirs, and the very peculiar features presented in evidence.

The year 1869 has not been remarkable for any great interruptious in the domain of labor. There has been a very general uniformity in every department of industry throughout the land. And not only has this been true of theo United States, but, save with few exceptions, it has been true also of European countries.

A lively discussion was held yesterday in the Preachers' Meeting, at No. 805 Broadway, on the financial condition of the M. E. Book Concern and the report of the Investigating Committee. Resolutions of inquiry were introduced by Rev. Mr. TAYLOR and Rev. Mr. BULKLEY, who, together with Drs. CURRY, HARRIS and HOLDICH, and Rev. Mr. WOODWORTH and others participated in the debate.

Washington, Jan. 17.--The Senate was the point of interest and importance at tho Capitol to-day, and the Virginia question was of course the subject which throw life and excitement into the generally dull and dignified proceedings of that branch of Congress.

The Senate met at 7:30 o'clock P. M. BILLS NOTICED. Mr. BRADLEY gave notice of a bill to amend the act to prevent encroachments on the grounds attached to St. John's College at Fordham,Westchester County. Mr. GRAHAM gave notice of a bill to regulate passenger fares on railroads, and to prevent exorbitant charges when passengers omit to purchase tickets. Mr. GRAHAM also gave notice of a bill to limit the capital stock of railroad companies.

In the case of HANLON vs. The Board of Supervisors of West Farms, Judge TAPPEN issued an order restraining the Receiver of Taxes of West Farms from collecting $65,200 for work on Madison and Berrian avenues. To this an order to show cause was issued, and the argument to continue the injunction came up yesterday at the Court House, in Brooklyn, before Judge TAPPEN.

A very important lawsuit is now in progress, involving the title to a large amount of land and buildings thereon, bounded on the south by a line running east and west, near Wolcott's Bridge, from the creek to the foot of the mountains, and on the north by what is termed the "Lower Bridge," or "Pancake," including pearly two hundred aeres of valuable property.

The trial of ELLEN REBECCA UTT, indicted for murder in having killed THOMAS H. BARRETT, on the 12th of September, 1869, was began yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge BEDFORD and a jury. The case was opened by Colonel FELLOWS, the Assistant District-Attorney :

Some additional facts in regard to the alleged Hester-street distillery frauds were gleaned, yesterday, from an affidavit made by MORITZ SCHLESINGER, of No. 95 Clinton-street. Deponent asserts that he was in the employ of the owners of the place, embracing HOFFMAN, RAYMOND and two others, during October, November and December, 1868; that he was engaged to gauge spirits;

ANDERSON.--On Monday, Jan, 17, at the residence of his son-in-law, Dr. Edwin Lewis, in Jersey City, ALEXANDER ANDERSON, M. D., late of this City, in the 95th year of his age. His relatives and friends, those of his son-in-law, the members of the Historical Society and of the Academy of Design, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from Trinity Church, New-York, on Wednesday, 19th inst., at 1 o'clock.

In the Corps Legislatif, today, the debate on the arraignment of Deputy HENRI ROCHEFORT was opened. From the beginning of the sitting the Chamber was crowded with spectators, and all the Deputies were present. M. ROCHEFORT occupied his usual scat, and all the members of the Cabinet were present on the Ministerial bench.

Saturday night JOHN MULLEN, of No. 459 Fourth-avenue, was in the liquor store No. 445 Fourth-avenue, drinking with JAMES HAYDEN and some others, and some words passed between them of an angry character.
The steamships Cleopatra and France have arrived here from Vera Cruz. Among the passengers by the former were Secretary SEWARD and his party. They are all well.

The second in a course of four lectures before the Lee Literary Association was delivered last evening at the Bleecker-street Universalist Church, by Rev. Dr. E. H. CHAPIN, on the subject of "Building and Being." The continual process of construction which is going on throughout the universe, he said characterized men and communities as well as material things and it behooves us to see to it that we are built on the right plan.

Sanitary Superintendent HARRIS has just received the report of the Water Side Sanitary Inspector; Dr. JUDSON, in regard to the ship John Bertram. This vessel, which is of 778 tons burden, arrived at quarantine on the 10th inst., after a voyage of 103 days from Hamburg, more than half of which had been spent in battling the contrary winds of the North Sea.

List of Americans registered at the office of BOWLES BROTHERS CO., No. 12 Rue de in Paix, Paris, for the week ending Dec. 30, 1869; New York--G. F. Bassett, W. T. Mortimer, L. E. Chittenden, W. Lusk Webster, Misses Lusk, J. A. Bain, J. M. Baldwin, Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Witherbee, Miss J. W. Roe, G. W. Partridge, jr., S. r. Saxton,

The steamship Weser, which left Bremen Jan. 1 and Southampton Jan. 4, reached this port yesterday. Her adviees are later by two days than those at hand by the Cuba. The London Times publishes a lengthened reply to Mr. BENNETT'S letter to Mr. ASHBURY, printed in that journal on Nov. 3.

Here are some notes from the "short and simple annals of the poor" in this City, enough to give one the heartache to read: Mrs. A makes vests at eighteen cents apiece for a whole-sale house. She can earn $8 a month by working fourteen hours a day, including Sundays.

Another disastrous fire occurred in Chatham village last night, destroying five buildings and involving a loss of over $40,000. The fire broke out in the building on the corner of Park-row and Railroadavenue, occupied by John Van Buren, and owned by Burrows and Birge, and known as "Military Hall."

The Committee of fifty appointed by the Club on Nov. 23 met at the Club room, No. 109 East Fifteenth-street, last evening, and presented a constitution and a list of officers for the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Official information received this evening by General BEDFORD. from Lieutenant SUMNER HAYS, Company E, Eighth United States Infantry, at Spartanburg, states that his command of ten men, while assisting the Revenue Assessor, seizing whisky stills and capturing prisoners, was attacked, had three horses killed, several men wounded d the command driven into Spartanburg Village.

OLE BULL was presented with an elegant and costly silver pitcher by the members of the Young Men's Christian Association, after the concert at their hall on Saturday. The gift bore the following inscription: "To OLE BULL, from the Y. M. C. A., as a token of their friendship and admiration. New-York,Jan. 15,1870."

There are many persons extant who still cherish the old-fashioned idea that when the State Legislature is in session the time has arrived for the reform of serious abuses. We could all suggest a variety of measures which would be certain to promote good government, and assist in raising the character and improving the position of the State.

The anthracite coal trade is very dull, and comparatively few colleries are at work. The supply of coal at all the great centres is reported up to the demand, and at Elizabethport considerably in excess of the supply of vessels necessary for its distribution.

As the time for the decision of the staff and line dispute in the navy approaches, the contest increases in bitterness. The report of the Naval Board assembled to consider the subject will shortly be laid before Congress; and, meanwhile, no stone is left uuturned by either party to help its cause.

The New-York Cooperative Clothing Manufacturing Company met last evening at No. 10 Stanton-street, and made some amendments to their Constitution. The Operative Painters last night received a delegation of the Eric Railway men, who are out on strike; who came to ask their sympathy.

Employment, was furnished for 304 male immigrants and 339 female immigrants by means of the Castle Garden Labor Exchange during the two weeks ending on Saturday. There were 457 applications for situations made by males, and 377 by females, a total excess of nearly 100 over the number of orders received from employers. The average rate of monthly wages for both males and females was $9.

The first real estate transaction on the Island of Manhattan, which has been recorded, was made many years ago, when the worthy representative of the Dutch States-General-the good PETER MINUIT-purchased the entire island from the Indians for the moderate sum of sixty guilders, or about $24. Since that time there has been a "steady advance in prices and a marked increase in the number of transactions."

A meeting of the friends of this (Methodist Episcopal) organization was held at the Eighteenth-street M. E. Church, Rev. Mr. DEPEW presiding. A large audience was present. Mr. W. K. PEYTON, Treasurer of the Society, gave an account of its operations for the past year.

The Supreme Court of those United States mot this morning pursuant to adjournment. The Attorney-General addresed the Court as follows: ADDRESS OF MR. HOAR. MAY IT PLEASE YOUR HONORS: Since your last adjournment the emblems of public mourning have been again displayed in the Capitol of the nation under circumstances which press upon the attention of this Court with a peculiar and touching solemnity.

We have more than once, within a few months, alluded to the fact that 1870 was the centennial of the first celebration of the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth, and the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the occurrence of that great event.

At the regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sunday School teachers last evening, at the Presbyterian Church corner of Twentysecond-street and Fourth-avenue, Rev. H. CLAY TRUMBULL, of Hartford, delivered an address on "The Church and the Sunday School."

There was but little change yesterday in the aspect of affairs in reference to the strike of the mechanics in the employ of the Erie Railway Company at Jersey City. The men held two meetings at Washington Hall, at which considerable business pertaining to a thorough organization was transacted.

The President of the Brooklyn Chess Club visited, on Saturday last, tile Europa Chess Rooms, and as much curiosity was manifested to witness a game at chess played blindfold by him against a really strong player, Major WERNICH,, the champion of the Williamsburg Chess Club consented to break a lance with him, the former having tile board and men before him.

A meeting was held by a number of Germans at Dramatic Hall, in Livingston-street, near the Court House, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, Dr. PONCE M. NICHTERN presiding, in favor of the repeal of the Excise law.

A single Supreme Court sale took place at the Exchange yesterday under the direction of GRATZ NATHAN, referee, JOSEPH McGUIRE acting as auctioneer. The property sold consisted of a lot in Harlem, on One Hundred and Twenty-first-street, between Second and Third avenues, 21.4 feet by 140 feet, with nine two-story brack houses thereon.

Among the best of all the publications issued from the weekly press in England are those designed for the young and for the working classes. They are illustrated in a most liberal and beautiful manner, and are full of interest for old and young. Chatterbox, the Friendly Visitor and the Cottager Artisan are excellent examples of these productions, and a supply of them has just been received by Mr. BRENTANO.

Since the reduction of the postage on foreign letters, there has been a marked increase in the sale of stamps at the New-York Post Office, although the system has been in operation but two weeks. This is especially the case with stamps for letters for Great Britain.

Some fifty brokers went into executive session at the Gold Room yesterday, in our suauce of a special call, to consider how far the authority of the Executive Committee, in the matter of appropriating money, should be extended.

The articles in the Mace-Allen prize fight were signed at the Clipper office in this city yesterday by JEM MACE in person for himself, and by FRANK BURNS on behalf of TOM, ALLEN. The articles stipulate that the fight shall be for $2,500 and the championship of America, and shall take place within 60 miles of New Orleans.

At about 8:30 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the room of JACOB HINCK, on the top floor of the three-story frame building, No. 67 Mulberry-street. The adult occupants hastily fled down stairs, forgetting two small children who were left in the front room adjoining that one where the fire was.
A heavy rain storm, accompanied with thunder and lightning, set in at noon to-day. CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 17.-During the thunder storm last night the mercury stood at 420. Today it is down to zero.

COTTON firm at 24 1/4c.@24 1/8c. for Middlings; sales 3,350 bales; receipts 11,669 bales. Exports--to Amsterdam, 1,820 bales; to Barcelona, 1,120 bales. FLOUR, $5 37 1/2@$5 87 1/2@$6 25. CORN easier, at $1 05. OATS, 70c. BRAN, $1 30. HAY $30. PORK, $29. BACON scarce and firmer, at 14c.@16 1/2c.@17 1/4c. LARD firm at 17c.@171/2c. for tierce, and 17 3/4c.@18 1/4 for kcg.

Captain ANDREW E. WARNER, a highly respected citizen of this place, died yesterday at the age of 84, Captain WARNER served with distinction in the war of 1812. He was at one time Grand Master of the Grand Lodge, I. O. of O. F., of Maryland,

The excitement in Paris yesterday, arising from the proceedings of the Corp Legislatit regarding Deputy HENRI ROCIIEFORT, was intense. The Chamber was crowded, and a great gathering of the people about the hall increased as the debate progressed.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair, The Street Commissioner was directed to cause the immediate removal from Tompkins-square of all the sheds used by the Concrete Pavement Company.

A meeting of this association was held at the Century Clublast evening,ex-Governor MORGAN presiding. Two tickets of officers of the association were presented, and after some discussion a committee was appointed to draw up a third ticket, which they did, presenting the names of JOHN TAYLOR JOHNSTON for President, and General DLX, WM. C. BRYANT and D. HUNTINGTON for Vice-Presidents.

To the Proprietors of the Lchigh Crane Iron Company, Allentown Iron Company, J. B. Moorhead Co., and Thirteen Others: GENTLEMEN: I have been favored with a copy of the following petition, addressed to the Congress of the United States, and presented Jan. 12 in the House of Representatives by Hon. W. D. KELLY:

The extravagant and profligate expenditure of the public money by the Democratic Board of Superintendents of the Poor of Kings County has at last reached a point that excites apprehension and alarm, even on the part of the leaders of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn.

By those arrival at this port of the brig Rapid in 16 days from Miragoano, advices from Hayti direct to the 2d inst. have been received. The news by the last arrival from St. Maro, of the capture of Port-au-Prince by the revolutionists, is fully confirmed. SAGET hold quiet possession of Port-au-Prince.

ALBERT NAST, formerly a bookkeeper in the employ of a lead pipe company at the corner of Sixth-vaenue and Thirty sixth-street, was arrested in Albany on Saturday and brought to this City, where he was arraigned before Justice BIXBY, of the Yorkville Police Court, on a charge of embezzling $2,000 from his employer.

A large number of petitions were present ed for the abolition of the franking privilegeone by Mr. CARPENTER, who said for every such petition he received twenty applications for pub lie documents to be mailed under frank.

The news of the approaching visit of a very great personage is being broken to by degrees. It might have proved too much for our nerves if it had been proclaimed in a sudden or unfeeling manner, and we cannot be sufficiently thankful to those who have considered our weakness, and made the necessarv allowances for it.

The Circuit Court appointed to be held for the County of Orleans commenced its session at Albion yesterday morning, Judge TALCOTT presiding. A motion was noticed for argument at this Circuit on the part of Messrs. FISK, GOULD Co., in the

There was a great demonstration last night on the Boulevard Montmartre by the friends of M. ROCHEFORT. The crowd was dispersed by the military without a conflict, and the Boulevard occupied by the troops till after 3 o'clock this morning. The Police wore also very active all night. There was considerable disorder, and many arrests were made. At this hour (1:30 P. M.) the city is quiet....

The usual weekly meeting of the Framers' Club of the American Institute was held at Room No. 21 of the Cooper Institute, yesterday afternoon. Mr. N. C. ELY, Knoxville, Tenn., wrote that he had lands that will grew tea. Dr. SMITH made an interesting discourse on the value of bones for manure. A Mr. LACE had slaughtered two pigs, nine months old, which dressed 415 and 391 pounds.

In the case of JOHN J. MORROW vs. JAMES W. WALKER, the plaintiff recovered a judgement against the defendant in the Superior Court, and on execution being issued and returned unsatisfied, an order was made for the examination of the judgement debtor respecting the possession or disposition of his property.

The Exchange was comparatively busy yesterday, a considerable crowd having been brought together by the announcement of important sales of City property. ALLEN disposed of thirty-fourlots adjacent to each other, on First-avenue and Forty-eighth andForty-ninth streets, which brought in the aggregate the sum of $CO,150. Eight of these lots are on the avenue,

The Voz de Cuba, in an tio editorial yesterday, protested against the petition recently forwarded to Spain in favor of certain reforms, claiming that such reforms would he a movement backward, adverse to liberal inetitutions, and probably productive of discord among the Spaniards.

A public discussion on the tariff question took place last night at Masonic Hall. The meeting was large, embracing all classes, including many of the most prominent and intelligent persons of this city. Speeches were made by Hon. JOHN HOGAN, Colonel COLEMAN, G. N. Fox, Hon. DAN. MORRISON, S. R. SHERRICK, President of the Board of Trade; Hon. CHAUNCEY J. FILLEY, GEO. B.

The New-Jersey Senate met in the State House, Trenton, at 10 A. M. yesterday. The President announced the following Committees: On Judiciary--Hopper, Nixon and Little. Education--Rice, Bettle and Bird. Railroads, Canals and Turnpikes--Edsall, Bettle and Laskill. Municipal Corporations--N.D. Taylor, J. W. Taylor and Wiley.

An Association has been organized under the name of the "Metropolitan Museum of Art," for the purpose, as expressed in the Constitution of the Association, of establishing in this City "an institution in which our whole people shall be freely provided with ample facilities for the study of select examples in every department of the fine arts, and for the cultivation of pure taste in the application of art to manufactures and to practical life."

In compliance with a resolution of the Senate, the Secretary of the Treasury has transmitted to that body the report of H. H. MCINTYRE, late special agent of the Treasury Department for Alaska. The report gives a detailed description of the. general features of Alaska, including climate and resources of all kinds, as well as a description of its inhabitants. The following is an abstract:

Elgin, Ill., now fines any person retailing pork not inspected by the City Physican. Chicago complains of a scarcity of fifteen cent scrip. General PILLOW has taken to his bed in Memphis. Tenn., sick. Professor AGASSIZ is not yet well enough to sneak in public.

Saturday afternoon a boy who must have presented a very singular appearance, as the Police report that he was "wrapped in light colored wrapping paper, all sealed up," entered the office Of JAS. M. SHAW, NO. 78 Chathamstreet, and delivered to that gentleman a package that was certainly in the condition that the boy is reported to have bean in.

The trial of WARREN FELLOWS, for the murder of ALEXANDER SWINTON on the 5th of August last, at Port Jervis, commenced to-day. Nearly all of last week was consumed in the effort to impanel a jury, which closed on Friday night with eleven Jurors in the box.

The employes in the machine and other mechanical departments of the Erie Railway Company are pursuinga commendably conservative policy towards their employers. While they are firm in their determination to support the strikers in their action, they seem equally strongly to have made up their minds not to extend the limits of the strike without first having exhausted every resource at their command to effect a compromise.

WASHINGTON, 18.--Virginia still hangs in the Senate. Another day's delay is the consequence of the everlasting propensity of that body to indulge in unbridled debate. The men who say something when they talk, have all been through some days, and listened to the wind-bags to-day with ill-concealed impatience.

It is currently reported that Governor CHAMBERLAIN, of Maine, will pronounce the funeral oration at Portland on the second day after the arrival of the Peabody funeral fleet. The fleet will be due on the 28th inst. The United States double-turroted monitors Terror and Miantonomoh will sail from here to-day to join the funeral fleet and escort it into Portland.

A man giving the name of THOS. MILLNER was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday on a charge of sending a series of indecent, abusive and threatening letters to Mrs. ADELAIDE F. COLBURN and her daughter, at No. 176 Grand-street.

District-Attorney PIERREPONT represented the Government, yesterday, in a suit against the brig Andrew Milliken, held before Commissioner BETTS as referee. The suit originated in the United States District Court, being brought for the purpose of having the vessel condemned on a charge of smuggling on the part of her Captain.

Information which reaches us from Washington warrants the belief that the investigation into the gold-gambling conspiracy of last Autumn will be searching and complete. As the proceedings are conducted secretly, the dispatches published from day to day,
The Canal Convention, to convene at Rochester to-morrow, promses to be one of great importance and weight. Delegations are arriving by every train.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

The Georgia muddle grows thicker and thicker, and it now looks as though it had degenerated into a quarrel between two factions of Republicans-Bullock and anti-Bullock. The feeling here is that it may all be safely left to General TERRY to evolve order out of the apparent legislative chaos. In the meantime both parties are telegraphing to members and Senators very vigorously, imploring them to stand by one side or the other.

Judge VERPLANCK, of the Superior Court, has just decided a novel suit. GEORGE A. DEAKIN, for twenty years past a member of the St. Alphonso Society, a religions benevolent association of thus city, brought a suit to obtain a mandamus to be reinstated to membership of that society, from which he claimed he hand been maliciously expelled for refusing to pay a fine of twenty-five cents unjustly imposed.

GLEES AND MADRIGALS. The concert of glees and madrigals, given last evening at Steinway Hall, attracted to that place a very large audience, and afforded unbounded satisfaction, There is little likelihood that a frequency of such affairs would have as great an influence, for there is a variety in dramatic music that the older compositions do not possess; but an occasional performance, such as occurred yesterday, is interesting and novel in the extreme.

ALBANY, Jan. 18.--The Senate had an Executive Session to-day, and received two nominations from the Governor for the offices of canal Appraisers to supersede Messrs. BROCKWAY and WASSON, Republicans. The nominees were colonel NORTH and GEO. C. GREEN, of Lockport. Colonel NORTH has at least consented to accept the office, and Judge BROOKS, for whose place he was first nominated having withdrawn his resignation, is to be allowed to hold over for the present.

Two boys named PATRICK KNAPP and WALTER WILLIAMS, just about to proceed to Cincinnati, via the Erie Railroad, to which entry they had procured tickets, were arrested in Jersey City Yesterday. Upon the person of KNAPE was found $2,338 38, together with some checks on a New-York bank, which the prisoners acknowledged they had stolen from Mr. TOMAS KNAPP, Collector of the Manhattan Gas Company, the father of Young KNAPP.

A man recently called at the tobacco store of P. LORILLARD, in Chambers-street, and pur chased a quantity of tobacco, requesting that a, check be given him, instead of $50 in currency, which was offered iu change, as he wished to sound It to Yonkers in a letter, This, request having been complied with, he very skillfully altered the $50,to $10,000 and got the chock cortified at the Mechanics' Bank,, on which It was drawn.

The steamship Euterpe, of the consolidated New-York line, which was cleared by her agents, Messrs. T. H. MCOMAHAN Co., on Tuesday last for New-York, with a cargo of 1,012 bales of cotton, and a lot of green salted and dry hides, had been detained in the Roads on account of unfavorable weather, but was endeavoring yesterday and last night to get to sea, a pilot having been on board the day and night.

Steamship Waybosset, Parrish, New-Orleans Jan. 8, with mdse, and passengers to Chas, H. Mallory Co. was detained at S. W. Pass 24 hours, the passage being blocked by steamships Alice and United States; the Alice got over on the 10th, but the United States would probably have to lighten to get off; left at the Pass steamship Concordia, for Boston, wig. for water to cross the Bar.

Prince ARTHUR will leave here on the 20th for New-York. The President of the New-York Central Railway, it is said, has sent his own private car to Montreal to convey him to New-York. parations for the Reception at the Capital by the English Minister.

Massachusetts is making itself heard in Congress in behalf of a large and an immediate reduction of taxation. Mr. SUMNER'S argument in the Senate, though necessarily general in its terms, was direct, clear and conclusive.

The following dispatch and letter show the situation of the Telegraph strike in New-York and this city at this date: NEW-YORK, Jan. 17. To all offiers T. P. L.: I have canvassed the situation and believe it useless to continue this strike. I hereby absolve all Western Union members from their oath, and advise them to return to work.

Rhode Island is now to be added to the list of States which have ratified the Fifteoonth Amendment, its House of Representatives having yesterday voted, 57 to 9, in its favor. The Senate ratified the amendment at its last session, but from local causes there was opposition to it in the House and the matter was postponed until now.
MONTREAL, Jan. 18.--The authorities, having failed to capture CALDWELL, have instituted inquiry into the circumstances connected with the case of his escape from the Montreal Court House.

About 12 o'clock on Monday night the residents in the vicinity of Market and Grand streets, Paterson, were startled by loud cries of "murder, watch," and other language indicative of distress. A man was seen lying on the sidewalk, rising, staggering a short distance and then sinking to the ground again, while two other men, evidently the assailants, were hastening away as fast as their feet would carry them.

Mormondom to-day has been jubilating aud celebrating, for Salt Lake has received its first locomotive with the completion of the line which connects it with the Pacific Road. In the work completed to-day, which gave cause for the celebration just closing, there is much to command admiration.

During the navigable period of 1869, say six months, 126 vessels, having an aggregate tonnage rated by the custom houses at 33,836 tons, wore wrecked, burned, or otherwise totally destroyed upon the great lakes.

ANDREAS.-On Tuesday, Jan. 18, of scarlet fever, MARY DUNHAM, only daughter of John W. and Maria W. Andreas, aged 8 years. Funeral notice in evening papers. ANDERSON.-On Monday, Jan. 17, at the residence of hisson-in-law, Dr. Edwin Lewis, in Jersey City, ALEXANDER ANDER ANDERSON, M. D., late o this City, in the 95th year of his age.

The Board of Manager of the American Colonization Society met this morning at their rooms, Hon. J. LATROBE, of Baltimore, President, and WILLIAM COPPINGER Secretary. There were present an unusually large number of delegates representing the societies in the New-England, Middle and Eastern States, among whom were President LANE, of Princeton; Rev. Dr. PATTON, Rev. Dr. C. H. HALL, formerly of this city; Rev. Dr. SCHENCK, of New-York.

A great demonstration was made on the Boulevard in Paris on Monday night by the friends of ROCHEFORT. The crowd dispersed without a conflict, although the troops occupied the Boulevard until S A. M. The Police made numerous arrest .... Deputy RASPAIL died on Saturday. Deputations from other cites are to attend his funeral, and disorder is feared....

Three three-story brick dwellings being put up in ??vision-avenue, between Rodney and Keep streets, Brooklyn, E. D., tumbled down about 5:30 o'clock last evening from some unknown cause. At the time there were some fifteen workmen in the buildings.

The proprietors of the Oil Works of Hunters Point and Greenpoint have informed the men in their employ that they would not pay any longer the usual rate, $3 per diem, but had determined on reducing it to $2 60 per diem. This the men refused to accede to, and struck.

All that part of the city lying on the levce (new Fourth-street) is completely submerged, and the occupants are engaged in removing their property to safe quarters by means of skiffs. Prowitt's, Ky., was completely destroyed by the storm Saturday night. JOHN MCGOWAN and his oldest daughter were 'killed; another daughter was badly inJured. DOWNER'S stable was blown away, and

The Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Biebierth, representing the Israelites of thirteen States, at a meeting in Nashville, yesterday, expressed regret at the continued persecution of the Israelites in the Province of Romania,

Yesterday morning the seats reserved for spectators in the Court of General Sessions were again compactly filled, the feature of interest being the trial of ELLEN REBECCA UTT, charged with the murder of THOMAS BARRETT, her paramour's brother. Judge BEDFORD presided.

The Circuit Court appointed to be held for the County of Orleans commenced its session at Albion yesterday morning, Judge TALCOTT presiding. A motion was noticed for argument at this Circuit on the part of Messrs. FISK, GOULD Co., in the

The death of FRANCOIS VINCENT RASPAIL, the distinguished French chemist and politician, is announced in our cable dispatches. M. RASPAIL was born at Carpentras, (Vaucluse,) on Jan. 29,1794. He finished his education at the Seminary of Avignon, and when 17 years of ago delivered a course of lectures on philosophy, and the next year one on theology.

The second annual Convention of the Universal Suffrage Association met in this city this morning, at Lincoln Hall, and was called to order by Mrs. ELIZABETII CADY STANTON, President of the Association. The proceedings opened with prayer by Rev. SAMUEL J. MAY, of New-Jersey, after which M rs. STANTON addressed the audience, stating the object of the Convention, which, she said, had assembled to discuss the question of giving to women the right of franchise.
REPORTS. By Mr. MURPHY--Incorporating the Lennox Library. NOTICES OF BILLS. By Mr. THAYER--To amend the Hudson River Bridge charter.

The report published in a morning paper, yesterday, that District-Attorney PIERREPONT has received instructions from Washington to inaugurate proceedings against all wholesale liquor dealers and rectifiers who fail to make certain entries in their books, as required by law, is contradicted by that gentleman.

ORSON A. House, an attorney and counselor at law in this City, for a long time past has been in the habit of advertising his business in one of the New-York journals in the following language: "Absolute divorces obtained in different States; legal separation, desertion, , a sufficient cause; no publicity; no charge until divorce obtained; advice free. M. HOUSE, Attorney, No. Nassau-street."

The Richard B. Connolly Association, named after Comptroller RICHARD B. CONNOLDY, gave its second annual ball at the Academy of Music last evening. The festivities were held under brilliant auspices, being attended by numerous fashionable people.

There was no important change of general character in the gold mining industry of California in 1869, except a slight decline In placer productions, the precise amount of which is not ascertainable, and a slight increase in the yield of the quartz mines. The treasure exports were $37,287,117, and the receipts were $51,226,769, Including about $12,000,000 from Nevada, $4,132,055 imports and $3,042,50 brought by coast steamers, mostly from Oregon and Idabo.

The plans for the new cartage system, approved by Mr. GRINNELL on the 1st of January, were carried into execution yesterday. Tile features of the proposed reform, and the abuses it corrected, have been fully laid before the readers of the TIMES. In brief, it puts a stop to a number of "combinations" to defraud both the Government and the merchant, makes a department where system was deadly needed, and brings order out of confusion.

No one who appreciates the gravity of the present situation in France will dispute the wisdom of the policy that made the impeachment of ROCHEFORT a Cabinet question on whose issue the now Ministry staked their tenure of office.

The Nipsic arrived off the Battery yesterday from Washington. The Guard and Yantic went into commission yesterday. The Saratoga has also been ordered to participate in the expedition to the Isthmus of Darien.

The result ot Collector BAILEY'S faid on several of the wholesale liquor dealers in his district is likely to be announced in a few days. The question whether we shall extend to the Indians the sword or the olive branch is fast narrowing to a practical decision before Congress. The walls of Rome are pasted over with placards of ecclesiastical books lately published, and now with a long circular from the hand of the Pope, laying down the law for schismatics, heretics and all sorts of offenders.

The weather in Central and Upper Italy has been for weeks past worse than has been known in the memory of those of long experience. More than thirty days of continuous rain. has cast a gloom over everything, and in some parts the damage has been considerable.

OFFICIAL MONDAY, Jan. 17, 1870--2 o'clock P. M. The Board met in their Chamber, number sixteen. Present--John Reilly, Esquire, President, in the Chair, and the following members: Assistant Aldermen Lysaght, O'Brien, Galvin, Hill, Hampson, Odell, Rogers, Hoffman, Mulligan, Costello, Gibney, Schlichting, Haughton, Feitner, Soorey, McDonald Fey Shelley--19.

Postmaster-General CRESWELL has made arrangements for an additional weekly dispatch of mails from New-York to Great Britain by the steamers of the Hamburg American Packet Company, thus securing a regular tri-weekly steamship service from New-York on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

The Internal Revenue Office has received an official letter concerning the recent outrages in Spartansburg County, South Carolina. The report is from Deputy Collector WALLACE, of the Third South Carolina District, who, with Assistant Assessor

The annual ball of the Hendrick Hudson Association was held at Irving Hall, last evening. The attendance was very good, and the entertainment was enjoyed with hearty zest. The Association was formed about twelve years ago, being mainly composed of residents of the Eighth Ward.

The United States steam frigate Swatara arrived at the Navy Yard on Tuesday night from the Battery. Forty-eight of her crew were discharged, their time having expired. A draft of a like number will be ordered from the Vermont to-day to fill their places.
A dispatch from Claremont, N. H., announces the death, last evening, of Right Reverend CARLETON CHASE, Bishop of New-Hampshire.

The Court reconvened this morning and the testimony in the case was concluded to-day. Twelve witnesses have been sworn for the prosecution and sixteen for the defence, Throughout the tral the Court room has been crowded continually,

TRAUPMANN, the murderer of the KINCK family, was executed, yesterday, at Paris. The last words he uttered were, "I persist I have accomplices." Great precautions were taken to prevent a disturbance, and consequently the execution passed off without disorder....

BLATCHFORD--HONE.--On Tuesday, Jan. 18, by Rev. Geo. H. Houghton, RICHARD M. BLATCHFORD to KATHARINE HONE, daughter of the late Philip Hone. PERRY--PROUDFOOT.--On Tuesday, Jan. 18, at Calvary Church, by Rev. Dr. Short, Colonel DAVID PERRY, U.S.A., to MARGARET, daughter of the late Laurence Proudfoot, M.D., of this City. No cards.
The steamship Morro Castle, which left Havana on Jan. 15, reached this port yesterday. Purser R.W. ALBERT has our thanks for courtesies.

Vicount de Thurg, of France, and Hon. James M. Marvin, M. C., of Saratoga, are at the New-York Hotel. Judge Noah Davis, of Albion; Hon. J. B. Alley, of Boston; Hon. J. B. Saxe, of Albany; Hon. M. P. Walker, of Maine, Hon. S. R. Van. Deuser, of Newburg;

The case of MICHAEL SPATZ vs. JAMES LYONS came before the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday, INGRAHAM. P. J., and BARNARD and BRADY, JJ. Some of the facts, as well as the questions of law involved, are of interest to the public.

On Monday night a stabbing affray occurred in a saloon in Paterson, in which a young man named HIRAM SPENCER was cut twice in the abdomen and once on the elbow by a man, as alleged, named ALEXANDER McNULTY, who resides at Totowa, a suburb of Paterson.

The following order has just been issued : HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF THE EAST. NEW-YORK CITY, Jan. 17, 1870. By direction of the President of the United States, a funeral escort of United States troops will accompany the remains of the late Mr. GEORGE PEABODY from Portland, Me., to Sonth Danvers, Mass.

The completion of the now building for this dispensary, at the corner of Ninth avenue and Thirty-sixth-street, adds one more to the public charities of New-York, for which the City Is now celebrated. The peremptory and contemptuously brief notification by R. W. PAPE, " G. C. O." of the Telegraphers' League, to the Western Union operators, forms a molanoholy comment upon a transaction which will not soon be forgotten by those concerned. Ho curtly tells them that he has " canvassed the situation" and believes that to continue the strike is "useless."

The Long Island coopers are still on strike, and from the spirit manifested by them It will undoubtedly continue for some time.
