Charleston, S. C., built its now theatre in forty days. Every day a dove visits a fruit stand in Boston, lights upon the shoulder of one of the attendants, and is fed and petted. Ex-Chief Justice THOMAS RUFFIN, Of North Carolina, died on Friday night last, at his residence in Hillsboro.

The following petition has just been laid before the Shipowners' and Captains' and Vessel Owners' and Captains' Association of New-York for signatures. It has been drawn up by members of the Philadelphia Vessel Owners' and Captains' Association: To the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress Assembled:

The regular weekly meeting of the Board of Health was held yesterday, Police Commissioner HENRY SMITH being in tile chair. Fiftysix cases of violations of the Tenement-house law were reported, and the Attorney was ordered to commence suits to enforce the law. Permits to occupy a number of basements as dwellings were granted upon the recommendation of the Sanitary Superintendent.

Among the most notable instances of perseverance under difficulties which has occurred recently was that of Captain TAYLOR, of the ship Dexter, which arrived on Thursday last after a passage of 163 days from New-York. On the 5th of September, while off Rio, the Dexter was found to be leaking badly.
The Ministry have taken up the question of Mr. ARMAND'S mission to Washington. A deduction, if possible, will be obtained in the duty on coal, an object most desired by the people of Nova Scotia....

Tuesday evening the house of H. C. CAPE, No. 461 East Fifty-seventh-street, was entered by thieves while all the family were below stairs at dinner. It is presumed they entered with false keys or by scaling the portico to the second floor window, after the mannrer of the class known as "second story sneaks."

At a meeting of this body yesterday afternoon, Mr. LARREMORE was elected President for the present year. A report from the Executive Committee recommending that a draft be made on the Comptroller for $50,000 for the expenses of the College, was adopted.

In steamship Rapidan, from New-Orleans, Jacate, Mich, Dempsey, Rufino Alloqui, Pedro Unamono, Andrew Jackson, A. E. Spencer, Henry Sherwood Chas. McLeod, Chas. II. Smith J. Hutchinson, Martin F. Tunon, Benj. Titcomb, M. Rionda.

The Lower House of the Legislature reassembled this morning, after a week's adjournment, with a very full attendance of members. Mr. HITCHMAN has entirely recovered from his illness, and resumed his post as Speaker. The organization of the Assembly was completed by the appointment of the reporters, doorkeepers, messengers, pages, , and is now fully equipped for business.

In the Legislature, to-day, Mr. FARWELL. of Augusta, presented the following resolutions, which, after an eloquent eulogy, were unanimously adopted: Resolved, That whereas it has pleased the Disposor of human events to remove from this life EDWIN M. STANTON. in the maturity of his marvelous powers.

The Chronicle has a special dispatch from Jackson, Miss., stating that Governor ALCORN has been elected United States Senator for the term commencing one year from next March, and General AMES for the unexpired term of five years. The same dispatch says:

In steamship Idaho, for Liverpool.--Mr. and Mrs. Mason, Mr. and Mrs. Davis. Jos. Sheldon C, M. Atwood, Mrs. Unsworth, T. L. Enning, Z. W. Enning, Wm. Whitehead, John B. Ebden, Wm. P. Nilmes, Sam. Miss M. Hooper, E. A. Darrah.

We published a statement in yesterday's TIMES denying the truth of statements contained in an article in one of the morning papers of Tuesday last, relating to the liability of wholesale liquor dealers, rectifiers and compounders of liquors, to be punished by fine and imprisonment for not personally making the entries in their books that they are required by law to keep.

M. D. STIVERS, United States Revenue Collector for the Eleventh District, has seized the stock and liquors belonging to the following-named persons, all of the City of Newburg : John Mullen Co., Belfe Rose, Wm. Wilson, Wm. Quaid Brother, L. W. Edwards Co., A. Halnes Co.,

The most inhuman savage of the present generation was put to death yesterday in Paris. Why it should have been thought that the occasion of his execution would be seized 'upon as the pretext for a popular "manifestation."

The coming census Will contain few more interesting and suggestive revelations than those touching the decline of New-England towns. The concentration into cities, the ravages of the late war, the revolutionary work of railroads and factories, the now impulse given to emigration into the South and West, all combined, have lately told upon the rural population of New-England.

The New-York State Canal Convention assembled in Corinthian Hall this morning. After prayer' by Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL, NATHANIEL SANDS, Of New-York was chosen President. He stated briefly the object' for which the Convention had met. Ex-President FILLMORE, and about fifty other gentlemen were chosen Vice-Presidents.

The fund of $100,000 for the benefit of the family of the great War Secretary is already filled up, more than one-half the amount having been raised in this City. The Union League Club Committee, of which Mr. A. T. STEWART IS Chairman, have obtained subscriptions to the amount of $26,000. The following are some of the leading names on their list:

Commissioner BRENNAN sat yesterday, to Investigate charges against derelict policemen, and to his great astonishment there were but three cases upon the calendar. The most Important of these was that of GEORGE W. WINTERS, of the Fifteenth Precinct, who was charged with being off post in a liquor saloon.

The President laid before the Senate a report adopted by the late Louisville Commercial Convention in favor of a Southern Pacific Railroad. Referred. NEW-YORK HARBOR. Mr. CONKLING presented the memorial of the New-York Chamber of Commerce, setting forth that the harbor of Now-York is threatened by a neighboring State with an encroachment, the

Considerable amusement was created in the Tombs Police Court yesterday by the appearance of MARY GILMARTIN, a young Irish woman, who asked for the discharge of her con JOHN, who had been locked up for intoxication.

About a baker's dozen of the familiar faces from Everett Hall were visible last evening in the hall corner of Broadway and Twenty-thirdstreet, where that number of persons held a mass meeting for the purpose, as announced, of forming a new political party.

The delegation which met FISK on Tuesday evening, waited upon General Superintendent RUCKER, to whom they had been referred yesterday morning. RUCKER held views coinciding with those held by FISK. The matter had, he said, been settled on Wednesday last, when the men were paid off and discharged.

Cooper Institute was filled last evening by a mixed audience drawn thither to listen to speeches from Hon. JOHN A. LOAN, of Illinois; Hon. THOMAS FITCH, of Nevada; Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Rev. Dr. SMITH, and Hon. CASSIUS M. CLAY, of Kentucky, who were advertised to speak in behalf of struggling Cuba. Of these only Mr. CLAY was present.

The speech made by Mr. DAWES on the necessity for retrenchment in the various Departments of the Government will doubtless receive careful attention throughout the country. It is another evidence of the feeling which is entertained by a large section of the Republican Party in favor of a great and immediate reduction of taxation. Mr.

The steamship Nevada from Liverpool Jan. 5, via Queenstown 6th, with merchandise and 142 passengers, arrived at this port early this morning. She had westerly gales the entire passage, and Jan. 13, lat. 470 61', lon. 300 40', had a hurricane from the northwest. Made but forty-eight miles to the westward. Her passengers are:

ANDERSON.--At White Plains on Tuesday, Jan. 18, Hon. JOSEPH H. ANDERSON, in the 70th year of his The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral at the village Methodist Church in White Plains, on Friday, the 21st Inst., at 11 A.M. Carriages ill be in waiting on the arrival of the 81/2 o'clock A.M. train from Now-York.

There were no sales at the Exchange Rooms yesterday. To-day JAMES M. MILLER will sell a lot with buildings, on the corner of Firstavenue and Soventeenth-street; and A. J. BLEECKER, SON CO. will dispose of forty nine leases of building lots on Seventy-ninth and Eightieth streets, between First and Second avenues, by order of the Now-York Protestant Episcopal Public School.

The New-York Board of Education met at 4 P. M. yesterday, Mr. LARREMORE in the chair. A communication was received from Mr. J. W. GERARD, in which he spoke of the manner in which comments are made by the Press of this City on the management of the public schools. These comments, he said, are generally made by " ignorant penny-a-liners," and are consequently unworthy of notice.

The representatives of the Republican and Conservative Parties have united in preparations or a public demonstration on the day of the admission of the State. A Joint Committee applied to the Washington authorities for the loan of a cannon for firing salutes, and the application has been granted .... General CANBY to-day directed JAMES

A gentleman named EDWARD W. ?? COMBE applied at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for an order to obtain possession of his ward, AUGUSTA HOLCOMBE, who was now in a house of ill-fame in Eighth-street. He stated that he resided on Long Island, and came to Sweeny's Hotel. in this City.

Our Washington correspondent chronicles one hopeful symptom. The demand for reduced taxation, backed by the people and echoed by the great body of the Republican Press, is not unheeded by the Ways and Means Committee.

TRAUPMANN. the murderer of the Kinck family, was executed at 7 o'clock this morning. Before daylight, HEIDENREICH, the official executioner, tested the scaffold--which had been created during the night on the Place do la Raquette-fastened the ax to the block, and proceeded to the prison.

Warrants were recently issued in the United Sates Commissioner's Office, on application of Collector BAILEY, against several lawyers, liquor Dealers and others, doing business in the Thirty-second Revenue District, charged ith being remiss in paying assessments.

United States District-Attorney PIERREPONT has just been placed in possession of a check for $49,400, representing the total amounts which were recently imposed on about 130 bankers and banking firms in Wall-street and vicinity as penalties for not paying tax on all the moneys used by them in business.

Washington, Jan. 19.--The Senate at last shows symptoms of returning reosan, and of putting an end to debate on the subject of the admission of Virginia. In the long discussion to-day no new points were developed, although Mr. SUMNER made a very labored effort to show that he had procured some additional facts why the State should be retained in bondage some time longer.

A well-known ex-Louisiana Judgo and intimate friend of President GRANT'S father, made a visit to United States Attorney PIERREPONT yesterday, for the purpose of directing his attention to an alleged plot for defrauding the Govment.

The usual North-side crowd gathered at the Police Court room in South First-street, Williamsburg, last night, to witness the conclusion of Coroner WHITEHILL'S inquest on the body of THOMAS KENNEDY, who was kicked to death in the low drinking den No. 136 North Fifth-street, on Monday last, for demurring about the price of a bottle of whisky.

The fourteenth weekly meeting of this Club was held at No. 23 Third--avenue, last evening, and was largely attended by gentlemen interested in the subjects discussed. Mr. WEHLE, the President, in the chair. Mr. MORAN continued his essay on "Darwinianism," and spoke of its adoption by HERBERT SPENCER.

The proposed sale of leases of Trinity School lots at the Exchange yesterday by A. J. BLEECKER, SON CO., was not successful. Leases for three terms of twenty-one years each were offered at a fixed rental, bids being asked for a bonus on each lot. The rents were fixed as follows: One lot southwest corner of Seventy-ninth-street and First-avenue, $350;

The managers of the Northwestern Dispensary met last evening at their new building, corner of West Thirty-sixth-street and Ninthavenue, a description of which was published in yesterday morning's TIMES, to organize the Board and elect its officers.

Some time ago Captain THOMAS STEERS, then of the Twenty-eighth Police Precinct, but now of the Second, was tried by the Commissioners for neglect of duty in failing to ascertain the true character and antecedents of one MATHIAS McCOSKAR, a convicted felon, who was inadvertently appointed a patrolman.

At an early hour yesterday morning a fire broke out in the shoe shop of HENRY FENNER, No. 191 1/2 Laurens-street. The building, a one-story frame, was almost totally destroyed, and the flames spread to similar structures adjoining-one occupied by the grocery of SENA RoTT, and the other by the policy shop of WILLLAM PARSON.

It is now nearly four years since the NowYork gas supply became the subject of loud and earnest complaint. Ever since that time the companies have been continually charged with bad faith in the fulfillment of their contracts, and with a total indifferonce to public comfort and health.

The Inman steamship City of Brooklyn, which loft Liverpool Jan. 6 and Queenstown Jan. 7, arrived at this port last evening, with three days' later news than was at hand by the Weser. The death of Admiral Sir THOMAS HASTINGS is announced. The deceased officer, who was 80 years of ago, entered the navy in 1803.

The Industrial School Association of Brooklyn, E. D., gave a reception in their new home, in South Third-street, near Fourth, last evening. There was. a large land apparently fashionable attendance of ladies and gentlemen, who made themselves unusually industrious in showing that a better place for the poor to find something good to eat would be difficult to find.

During the past week or ton days Macon has been overflowing with burly freedmen "seeking 'ployment" for another year, and there have also been here many gentlemen representin gvarious industries looking for hands. But though there were so many of the employing and the employed classes there were not many contracts made.

Among the clearances from this port yesterday was the bark John Edney, Captain HOPKINS, BETRAM BROTHERS, agents, bound for Hayti, with a strange cargo. The vessel is a rickety affair, and had been lying at Wetmore's Dock, Brooklyn.

A new cable in the interest of the French Company, to connect England and Brest, has been successfully laid. The shore end at Salcombe, Eng., was completed last night .... A few days since it was positively and officially announced that M. RASPAIL, one of the leading members of the Radical Party in the Corps Legislatif, was dead.

Mexican advices by the way of Mazatlan represent the country in an unsettled condition. Revolutions are impending in several States. The Ways and Means Committee is not alone in the "demoralization" occasioned by the demand of the people for reduced taxation. The Tribune shares the perplexity. Until the other day, it insisted that the present rate of taxation might be maintained without producing inconvenience or exciting discontent. Now it talks differently.

Last evening the members of the American Institute met at the Cooper Institute. The opening business was the reading of the report of a Committee of fifteen; appointed two weeks age to nominate candidates for the coming election. It was received and laid on the table.

At 9 o'clock tonight the House adopted the Senate resolution ratifying the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. completing Ohio's ratification thereof. The vote stood-yeas 57, nays 55. Messrs. BATES, HILL, KLEINSCHMIDT and CUNNINGHAM, Reform Republicans, voted in the affirmative.

The debate on the admission of Virginia in the Senate to-day was more diffuse and unimportant in whatever view the subject is regarded, than any discussion which has taken place in that body for a long time. Tired, apparently,

The steamship Idaho has arrived from Honolulu, A Hawaiian Prince and the members of the Austrian Embassy to China, Japan and South America were among the passengers. Sandwich Island advices are to Jan. 4.... The Austrian frigate Donau put Onto Honolulu to repair extensive damage received in a cyclone in the Japan Sea.... His

One swallow does not make a Summer, but we are apt to think of Summer weather when the swallows are in the sky. So when our English friends see FISK and GOULD careering over the financial horizon, we must not be surprised at their apprehensions. Nothing is more conservative than money.

The fact that the streets of this City are in a very filthy condition, is one within the personal knowledge of almost every citizen. It is also matter of general notoriety that their present condition is a consequence of the neglect of the contractors for cleaning the streets, of whom JOHN L. BROWN is chief and "manager," who are paid $498,500 per annum for doing the work, but exhaust, their energies in drawing their pay.

The employee of Mr. STRUMPFLER, who is engaged in the manufacture of boots and shoes at No. 118 Ewen-street, Williamsburg, determined on a strike yesterday morning, in compliance with an order of Lodge No. 130, of the Knights of St. Crispin, of which they were members, but, their demands being at once compiled with, resumed work before the day was over.

The Erie Railway strikers spent most of yesterday in anxiety as to the success of their delegates in securing the cooperation of the Port Jervis men. The delegates called a meeting of the men on Wednesday night, and stated the case to them. When the question as to whether they would sustain the Jersey City men was put to them, they voted strongly in the affirmative.

In the case of Trrus B. ELDRIDGE vs. SAMUEL C. REED, some time since argued in Superior Court, General Term, a decision has just been rendered holding the defendant liable on obligations entered into for the formation of a " pool" in mining stocks, whore those obligations have passed into innocent hands.

The dissensions among the New-York Democracy about the kind of Municipal Government that shall be substituted for the odious "Republican Commissions" still continue, and are growing fiercer every day. From present prospects, it is doubtful whether any legislation with regard to the Commissions car be brought about for weeks to come.

In steamship South America, from Rio Janeiro,--Geo, A. Marshall, Robt. W. Major, Wm. Lerch, L. T. Du Fourcy, Gottfried Malm, Frank Remmel, Albert Williamson, John T. Gerhard, Hon. Jose T. de Paul, Minister Plenipotentiary from Venezuela ; Captain L. Leslie, Captain J. Hancox, G. R. Field, Hon. F. Goding and wife, Emilie Warren, S. C. Hastings, Mr. Barber, Mr. Hickman, Wm. BURNETT--DIXON.--On Thursday, Jan. 20, 1870 by Rev. Dr. W. A. Muhlenberg, WILLIAM BURNETT to Miss KATIE DIXON, at the residence of the bride's uncle, Dr. J. A. Dixon, all of this City. No cards. ?? HAINES, Jr., to MARCIA A., daughter of the late Frederick Finck, all of this City.

For several weeks we have been passing through one of those abnormal seasons which appear to defy all human explanation. Not only at New-York, but throughout the continent, Nature's course seems disturbed.

As we anticipated, Mr. G. L. Fox's performances in "Paul Pry" and in "Robert Macaire" have attracted immense audiences to the Olympic Theatre. We now learn that in a few nights that excellent comedian will act Aminidab Sleek, in "The Serious Family," and dapper Captain Shortcut in "The Spitfire."

The trustees of the German Hospital and Dispensary of this city held their regular monthly meeting at No. 13 Broadway yesterday afternoon. The following officers wee elected for the ensuing year: CHARLES CODFREY GUNTHER, President; H. BARNSTORFF and E. OLDERMANN, Vice Presidents;

The Women's Suffrage Convention reassembled this morning. The hall was crowded. Among those present was Senator WILSON, who, upon being invited to address the Convention, made short speech, in which he stated that whenever he had a vote to give it would be given to remove any burden from the people, and grant the same rights to women that men possess.

Several new warrants were issued by Commissioner BETTS yesterday, for the apprehension of persons charged with omitting to pay the revenue assessments made on their business, as follows: L. Simon, No. 37 Nassau-street, auctioneer and real estate agent; John Ten Brook, No. 12 Pine-street, real estate and insurance agent;

If anything could mako us sympathize with " poor Cuba" more thoroughly than we have hitherto done, it would be the conduct of her avowed champions. They fall upon her neck in pretended friendship, only to give her a secret stab in the back.

The House joint resolution on the subject of the ventilation of the balls of the Senate and House was laid before the Senate by the Chair. The amendment providing for ascertaining the cost of the proposed improvements was concurred in. A STATUE TO GENERAL NATHANIEL GREENE.

Brief mention was made in the TIMES of yesterday of the fact that information had been furnished to the United States DistrictAttorney, by an ex-Louisiana Judge, in regard to certain enormous whisky frauds. The name of the informer was WARWICK MARTIN, formerly a member of the same Church which President GRANT'S father attended, and an intimate friend of the latter.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : I am a constant reader of the TIMES, and acknowledge its right and ability to guide public opinion, but you must allow me to say that in your articles which now and then appear on the subject of rank in the navy, your inclination In favor of the so-called staff side of the question is inconsistent with the conservative character of your paper.

The public ought to be very proud of the journalism of the present day. It has reached an unexampled pitch of perfection. It spares no one, and it, has a finger, to quote the homely adage, in everybody's pie. It tells us all about private affairs, and orders up women for punishment with quite as much boldness and courage as if they were men.

Senator ANTHONY'S paper speaks of Senator "Crogan." O, the types ! The Sisters of Charity of Cincinnati are to send a colony to Colorado. General JOHN BEDEL has written a letter formally accepting the Democratic nomination for Governor of Now-Hampshire.

An interesting case came up at the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday, in which Mrs. CETRINA FRASER and GEORGE C. BINGHAM were plaintiffs against LEMUEL L. FREEMAN, defendant. The suit was brought by Mrs. FRASER and Mr. BINGHAM as administrators of the estate of JAS. L. FRASER, deceased, to recover $5,000 damages for the acts of FREEMAN, which caused the death of FRASER.

A new cable, in the interest of the French Company, has been successfully laid between England and Brest, France. The English shore end was completed on Wednesday night ....The death of Deputy RASPAIL is officially denied....

The steamship South America, which reach ed this port from Rio de Janeiro last night, brought very sad news. LOUIS MOREAU GOTTSCHALK, who intended to revisit this country in the Fall of the present year, died at Tijuca, near Rio, after a three weeks' illness, on the 18th day of December last.

Four pieces of artillery, with officers and men, and ammunition for firing a salute of 100 guns, left here this morning for Richmond. POUGHKIEEPSIE, N. Y., Jan. 20.--ROBERT THORN, the Dutchess County farmer whose house was attacked by burglars on the night of Jan. 5, when he and his housekeepe were badly beaten, died to-day.

The Swatara, which was to have left in a short time for China, is ordered, after she shall have brought drafts of men from Aspinwall, to make another trip to Savannah, and from there to carry a large draft of sailors to San Domingo.

The following is the list of new buildings proposed since the last report, and for the week ending Thursday, Jan. 20, 1870: BROWN-STONE FRONTS. Three first-class dwellings, southwest corner Park-avenue and Fortieth-street, 16.5x60; four stories and basement; BRIEN McKENNY, owner.

The steamship South America, from Rio de Janeiro Dec. 25, and St. Thomas Jan. 16, arrived at this port last night. By the courtesy of the Purser, our South American letter, printed below, was promptly at hand.

A convention of colored people to provide measures for the education and general welfare of that class throughout the State met at Jefferson City, yesterday. Nothing important was done beyond organizing.... A dispatch from Grand Tower, yesterday, says: "The steamer Lady Gay, bound from St. Louis to New-Orleans, was sunk at 1 o'clock this afternoon. No lives were lost.

The Senate met at 10 o'clock A. M., and after the usual routine business Senator J. W. TAYLOR presented a petition from the Rogers Locomotive Works, of Paterson, remonstrating against the enormous charges for freight carried over the Hudson and Paterson Railway by the Erie Railroad Company, and asking for the repeal of tile privileges granted to the Erie Complany or to charter another road.

On Tuesday evening the bands of the different Volunteer battalions in this city serenaded Governor SEWARD. Several thousand people assembled in the street in front of those hotel, and Marte-square was splendidly i1luminated. The officers of the Volunteers and many others entered the hotel, where Colonel ZULUETA delivered a speech of welcome, saying the serenade was a manifestation of the sentiments of the loyal Spaniards for their distinguished guest.

Selections of sacred poetry are not uncommon, but this volume does something more than string together a number of pieces which have been more or less known to the public for years past.

It is said that "Republics are Ungrateful." and the saying would seem to be founded on truth, when we take into consideration the vast number of maimed veterans of the late war who are to-day wandering through the streets of various Northern cities begging for the necessities of life New-York has its full quota of this unfortunate class. has its full quota of this unfortunte class.

The ward of EDWARD V. HOLCOMB, for whom a warrant of arrest was issued on Wednesday for the purpose of rescuing her from a house of ill-fame in Eighth-street, was brought up before Justice COX, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, when it transpired that she was the wife of her guardian, and had deserted him for the bagnio during his absence on business.

The Society of California Pioneers, which proposes to erect a building suitable for the purposes of the association, has petitioned the Legislature for the use of the public square, at present occupied by the Mechanics' Institute Pavillion.... The total fall of. rain for the present season is 8.44 inches, about the average of preceding years....The

The subjoined singular game was contested in the Brooklyn Chess Club Tournament, between Messrs. BAIRD and J. A. DE Cou, in which the latter checkmated his opponent in eleven moves. Mr. DE Cou is celebrated for the brilliancy of his combinations.

COTTON--Receipts to-day, 9,254 bales; exports, to Liverpool, 5,014 bales; to Hamburg, 1,945 bales; to Malaga, 976 bales; coastwise, 520 bales; weekly receipts, net, 46,499 bales; gross, 47,237 bales; exports to Liverpool, 11,995 bales; to Havre, 6,817 bales; to Amsterdam, 3,980 bales: to Hamburg, 1,954 bales; to Genoa, 1,123 bales; to Barcelona, 1,663 bales;

JOHN MCCARTHY, alias William H. Reeves, was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday, at the Tombs, to answer a charge of forgery. It appears that Messrs. WILLIAM V. TOFFEY Co., of No. 54 Broad-avenue, West Washington Market, received a quantity of beef, valued at $1,900, from NELSON MORRIS CO., of Chicago, and were exhibiting it for sale,

BEN. HOLLIDAY, President of the North Pacific Transportation Company, left for Washington yesterday, it is said, for the purpose of obtaining a Goverment subsidy for carrying tile mails between San Francisco and Australia. It is also stated upon reliable authority that the Colomes of New South Wales, New-Zealand and Queensland have offered to grant a subsidy for the establishment of a line of steamers between this point and Australia.

A number of bills of no general importance were introduced and a few passed including that incorporating the Board of Missions of the P. E. Church Diocese; incorporating the trustees of the fund to support infirm clergymen of the P. E. Church Diocese of Albany;

ANNOUNCEMENTS. The representation by which M. PAUL JUIGNET IS to benefit occurs at the Theatre FranoAls this night ... Miss JOHANNA SIMMONS, a lady of musical promise, is to profit bya concert at Apollo Hall this evening. A very excellent programme has been prepared, and will be Interpreoted by Miss SIMMONS and Mr. HENRY C. TIMM,

A German peddler by the name of GEORGE SEEL, who lived at No. 448 Race-street, died about 7 o'clock yesterday morning from the effects of a peculiar mode of medical treatment, advised by a man of the name of OTTO ASCHENBORN, who had recently been employed as porter at Loewen Garden, and Who professed to know all about the disease Which he undertook to cure.

The Erie Railroad strikes were in a despondent mood last evening, as no information whatever from their co laborers along the line was received up to 11 o'clock last night, to which hour the President of the Jersey City organization, Mr. KEASLEY, and a number of the workmen, sat gloomily in No. 7 Engine House, awaiting some news.

The graduating exercises of Grammar School No. 33, in West Twenty-eighth-street, took place yesterday afternoon. The large schoolroom was packed with the scholars and their friends, and presented an attractive sight. Judge DALY delivered the opening address, which was something above the ordinary style of speeches on such occasions.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS--JAN. 21. By Judge Cardozo. Wilcox vs. Treadwell; Morgan vs. Williams; motions granted and reference ordered. In re the application of the Guardian vs. Tilley; upon executing a mortgage upon real estate the order asked for may be made. Wright vs. Keystone Silver Mining Company; motion granted. Biddle vs. Sanford: motion granted on payment of $10 costs.

A man called at the Tombs Police Court yesterday and asked the Magistrate to discharge a prisoner committed for intoxication. Justice DOWLING, for some unknown reason, became somewhat excited, and declared in a loud voice that he "would discharge no one for any drunken politician."

It is now claimed by responsible parties that there is not any truth in the affidavits lately made in regard to extensive whisky frauds alleged to have been committed during 1866 and 1867, at a distillery in West Eighteenth-street. It is said that all the persons who are accused will voluntarily surrender themselves.

The Senate busied itself for a half hour or more, at the opening of the session this morning, in the discussion of a resolution to appoint a stenographer. In the general scramble for offices, large and small, that distinguishes and disgraces the Democratic majority of thisLegislature, the position of stenographer, heretofore regarded as non-political, is entered as one of the prizes.
Ex-Congressman SAMUEL OLDHAM PEYTON, of Kentucky, died at Hartford, in that State, on Monday, aged 70 years. General GID. J. PILLOW, who has been. very ill of pneumonia, at Memphis, is out of danger.

The Postmaster-General did a very good thing the other day when he invited a number of leading Post Office officials to Washington to hold a conference and suggest improvements in the service. Most of their suggestions, or at least those of them on which the outside world is capable of forming an intelligent opinion, were excellent.

The present dullness in wholesale trade naturally renders dealers and salesmen doubly anxious to effect sales of goods, and the fact is some slight explanation of the singular business transactions that culminated yesterday in the arrest of a wholesale buyer. on a charge of fraud and swindling.

Last evening Detective TLLEY, of the Central Police, arrested a noted character variously known as RICE alias William H. Summers alias Charles Cortney, and took him to the office of Inspector DILKS, where he was picked out from a number of persons, by MARTIN LYNCH, of No. 74 Newark-street, Hoboken, as one of two men who robbed him on the 29th of October last, of $200.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 20.--A special dispatch to the Avalanche from Jackson, Miss., to-night, says: "The Legislature has elected Governor ALCORN United States Senator for the long term, beginning March, 1871, and General AMES for the short term. W. H. REVELS, (colored,) a native, and educated in Ohio, at present State Senator from Natchez, was also elected for the term expiring March, 1871, to which Mr. SHARKEY was elected but was not admitted.

The State Canal Convention, held at Rochester on Wednesday, revives the memory of those olden days when the canals were the mainstay of the State, the chiefest source of its prosperity and the strongest support of the commercial supremacy of the State of NewYork. Ex-Governor SEYAMOUR presided,

Several important railway schemes will come up in the New-Jersey Legislature during the present session. Among others the proposed branch of the Central Railway, from Elizabeth to Newark, will be strongly pushed. The proposed road between Newark and Morristown, which passed the Senate during the session of the last Legislature, but which failed in the House, will be again brought forward.

A letter from Fort Laranne states that a band of Imans captured forty head of cattle from a herder named MILLS, on the 14th inst.... Helena papers report the arrival of the agent of the Mountain Crows, from Fort Parker. In the Yellowstone Valley the Indians are all contented. General SULLY has caused the erection of a Bulbstantial mill and farm houses.

The strike of the operatives at La Creuzot still continues, and is creating a " profound sensation." From the number engaged in it fears are entertained that the example thus set will be followed. La Creuzot is one of the greatest iron manufacturing towns in Europe.

Immense quantities of broken ice--probably from the Mohawk River--have accumulated at New-Baltimore. At Hudson the blockade is more impregnable. At Poughkeepsie large quantities have lodged, but navigation is not entirely obstructed.

Messrs. FIELDS, OSGOOD Co. are taking great pams to improve their metamorphosed weekly of Every Saturday. The current number is in some respects a decided advance on previous ones, and the portrait of Mr. LONGFELLOW that embellishes it is worthy of special attention.

Prince Arthur, Colonel Elphinstone, Lieutenants Pickard and Fitzroy, Mr. Thorntoo, the British Minister, and his Secretary, Mr. La Poer French, and Mr. Archibald, the British Consul, are at the Brevoort House.

On the 18th of October last a Convention was held in the City of New-York for the purpose of considering the condition of the canals of the State, and of devising plans to remedy existing evils. Many schemes were suggested and various systems proposed, but to give efficacy to any of these the necessity for a permanent organzation was realized.

Commissioners SMITH and MANIERRE yesterday divided between them a calendar of some eighty eases of charges against policemen for transgressions of the rules and improper conduct. The majority of these cases involved the usual offences of being off post and late at roll call, but some of them were of graver character.

PARIS, Jan. 21--Evening.--The strike of the operatives at La Croeuzot, in the Province of Sarne e t Loir, near Dijon, still continues, and is making a profound sensation throughout the country on account of the large number of workmen concerned in it. It is feared by the Government that the example the strikers have set will be followed elsewhere.

The insurgent forces have at length captured this place, and SALNAVE has fled from tile city, leaving fully one-third of it in ruins. The attack upon Port-au-Prince, by the revolntionists, was commenced on the morning of the 18th of December, at about 4 o'clock. At that hour the rebel steamers, three in number, made their appearance in the harbor of Port-au-Prince and seized SALNAVE'S last vessel, the Terreur, lying at anchor in the harbor.

Prince ARTHUR made his advent in our City yesterday, as was expected, by the Hudson River Railroad, arriving at the depot at 12:45 P. M. He was accompanied in his journey from Montreal by Colonel ELPIIINSTONE and Lieutenants PICKARD and FITZROY, and met at the depot by Sir EDWARD THORNTON, the British Minister, and Mr. ARCHIBALD, the English Consul at this port.

Mr. LORILLARD stated yesterday to our reporter that he had received information by telegraph that his brother, Mr. GEORGE T. LORILLARD, commander and owner of the yacht Meteor, is in Naples. With regard to the loss of the vessel, he said that he believed the story published in the TIMES of yesterday,

The Senate has decided not to be magnanimous. It has denied Virginia the unconditional admission to which literal and unreserved compliance with the Reconstruction acts entitle it, and winch the House generously conceded. At the same time the Senate has refused to be malignant.

The members of Atlas Lodge No. 316, F. A. M., mot at their rooms in Irwin Building, corner Bowery and Bleecker-street, on Thursday evening, and presented to one of their Past Masters - R. W. JOHN BOYD - a very costly jewel as a token of affectionate regard.
PATRICK NOLAN, in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions yesterday, pleaded guilty of grand larceny, having stolen a gold watch and chain from ROBERT T. NELSON. He was remanded for sentence.

At a meeting of the Board or Police commissioners, held yesterday, it was determined, in order to secure a greater efficiency in the service, to have four roundsmen in certain precincts where the territory is large. Accordingly the following patrolmen were to be appointed roundsmen, and assigned for duty to the precincts named.

No one will be surprised at the recommendation of Dr. HARRIS, that a special outlay be incurred for street cleaning. The condition of our thoroughfares is such that some vigorous and speedy action is necessary to accomplish the work that the contractor undertakes to do, but has to a great extent left undone.

There were no public sales of real estate at tile Exchange yesterday. Several important sales are promised, to take place next week, and Tuesday will probably be a pretty busy day at the salesrooms, MULLER CO. LUDLOW CO., and JAMES M. MILLER having announced some Valuable City property to be struck off on that day to the highest bidder.

The Now-York Port Society, organized for the elevation of seamen by moral and religious influences, has steadily prosecuted its work during the last half century. "We are now," say the directors, "doing more than over befor .

DUNHAM-GILL. On Wednesday evening Jan. 19, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Dr. B. L. Agnew, pastor of Westmmster Church, HENRY R. DUNHAM, Jr., of New-York to Miss MARY A., eldest daughter of Captain Wm. H. Gill, U. S. A., commanding officer Schnyikill Arsenal, Philadelphia, Penn.

We briefly noted yesterday the praiseworthy move of the Commissioners of Public Charities, whereby the east wing of the Inebriate Asylum of Ward's Island has been made a permanent home for soldiers who, by reason of wounds and infirmities, have become inmates of various hospitals and almshouses in and around the City.

An order of arrest, granted ex parte by Judge CARDOZO, sitting at the Chambers of the Supreme Court, against Mr. E. J. OAKLEY, the defaulting cashier of the Merchants' National Exchange Bank, has been served upon that individual in a civil suit, and the amount of ball was fixed at the sum of $150,000.

Another meeting in opposition to the Excise law was held by a number of Germans, mostly saloon keepers, at Ocean Hall, on the corner of Nassau and Bridge streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. HENRY C. BADEN acted as Chairman.

ALPHEUS S. BBEBE, aged 26 years, 7 months and 21 days. The funeral will take place from lls late residence, No. 308 West 22d-st., this (Saturday ) morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock. Tile remains will be taken to Stanford, Conn., for interment. Bridgeport papers please copy.

A very largely attended mass meeting of cartmen who feel aggrieved by the recent order of Collector GRINNELL was hold last evening at the corner of Bleecker and Morton streets. Mr. A. G. REYNOLDS presided, and A, J. COLE acted as Secretary. Mr. REYNOLDS made a speech strongly denunciatory of the action of Mr. GRINNELL.

People who are in the habit of reading the English newspapers cannot help noticing in them one remarkable characteristic, which is constantly becoming more and more prominent. We may describe it in a few words as a lack of patriotism.

The services of inauguration of the Temple Israel at the hall of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association, corner of Galatinplace and Fulton-avenue, took place yesterday afternoon. There was a large and fashionable audience. The choir was remarkably efficient, and the services throughout were of au interesting character.

By the last mail Mr. BRENTANO has received a variety of the latest English papers, some of them possessing unusual attractions. The. Graphic, No. 6, surpasses all former numbers, and as a work of art does the highest credit to its publishers.

While the resolution to ratify the proposed Fifteenth Amendment was under discussion in the Ohio House of Representatives on Wednesday evening, the following letter from Chief Justice CHASE was read: WASHINGTON, November, 1869.

An unexpectedly large number of delegates from all parts of New-England appeared this morning to attend the Fat Men's Convention in this City. arge number of persons was also gathered to witness the proceedings.

The steamships Calabria, from Liverpool Jan. 8 and Queenstown Jan. 9, and Holsatia, front Hamburg Jan. 5 and Havre Jan. 9, reeached this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by two days than that at hand by the city of Brooklyn.

To-day has been the most interesting day of all the debate in the Senate on Virginia. The course of the extremists has been so disgraceful for the last few days that it began to be wondered whether the strong men of the Senate, like TRUMBULL, CONKLING, WILLIAMS and others, would sit still and permit tire tirade of abuse and misrepresentation to run on without some effort to cheek it.

Cooperation has not boon fairly tested in the United States. In Great Britain, France, Germany and other European countries it has been thoroughly proved in almost every department of human industry, and has been found practicable and beneficial to those engaged in it.

The pianoforte makers' strike in opposition to a reduction of their wages, and especially their persistent fight with one of the principal firms of the piano manufacturing business, (the STEINWAYS,) continues to be the principal topic of interest, and the men are fully aroused to the importance of the contest in which they are engaged.

WILLIAM F. VELTMAN'S case came before Commissioner SHIELDS yesterday, for examination. The accused is charged with having defrauded the Fourth National Bank of $7,000, by means of false entries while acting as clerk, two other persons being implicated with him in the alleged offence.

A silver mine has becen discovered in Carnavoushire, Wales. The customs receipts for 1868, in Russia, amounted to 143,075,508 francs. The King of Prussia has caused a medal to be struck to commemorate the war of 1866. A movement is on foot for establishing a zoological Society in Liverpool.

APPLEGATE.--At Toledo, Ohio, Friday morning, Jan. 21, ESTHER M. APPLEGATE, wife of Daniel S. Applegate, aged 28 years. Her funeral will take place at Trinity M. E. Church, Jersey City, on Sunday, Jan. 23, at 1 o'clock. All friends of the family, and of her father, Thomas Lacey, Esq., are invited to attend.

The contest of opinion between those who look upon imprisonment as chiefly a reforming agency, and those who see in it a method of punishment only, is very far from ended, although the former have gained increased influence during the last few years.
SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS--JAN. 22 By Judge Sutherland. CASES SETTLED. Gerding vs. Kobbe, Bell vs. Waterbury, Short-land vs. Van Nostland, and Edward Bridges vs. Christopher Rinehardt.

A man named HOTCHKISS who has for several months been a daily passenger on the Morris and Essex Railroad to New-York, noted by his fellow-passengers for his incessant devotion to the columns of a religious newspaper, was severely beaten on Friday evening and kicked off the train at Orange for an insult to a young lady passenger.

GEORGE, DENNISON PRENTICE, the wit, poet and journalist, died yesterday morning at the home of his son, a few miles from Louisville, Ky. He had long been in very poor health, and therefore his death was by no means unexpected. Mr. PRENTICE was one of the best-known litterateurs in the country.

While the train which left Jamaica at 10:05 yesterday morning, on the Long Island Railroad, was crossing the meadow at Hunter's Point, the locomotive ran into a cow just as it was approaching a bridge over a creek. The engine passed in safety,

RODNEY M. POEROY, whose real name is believed to be F. A. TALBOT, was arraigned before Justice DOWLING, yesterday, at the Tombs, to answer a charge of fraud and swindling. The details of POMEROY's arrest and his extensive scheme of operations were fully narrated in yesterday's TIMES.

His Royal Highness, Prince ARTHUR, left the Brevoort House, for Washington, accompanied by his suite, at an early hour yesterday morning. Minister THORNTON also went by the same train. The small pox continues steadily to decline both in the number and virulence of the cases, and the unprincipled efforts which are made in some quarters to create the impression that the City is under the scourge of the dreadful disease are doomed to certain failure. The document which officially attests the death-bed marriage of the late ALBERT D. RICHARDSON, was not filed in the office of the Register of Vital Statistics until yesterday. It is in the hand writing of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, who certifies that on the 30th day of November, he married A. D. RICHARDSON to "Mrs. ABBY SAGE."

Facts reported in the TIMES from day to day since the 1st of January concerning the Wynocke children, their disappearance and the anxious search which has been made for them, were grouped together in an unwarrantable manner by a morning paper yesterday to give color to an accusation of murder against the bereaved parents of the children.

The first weekly service in the new synagogue Temple Israel, at the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, corner of Fulton-avenue and Gallatin-place, was held yesterday forenoon. Rev. R. D'C. LEWIN, the minister of the congregation, conducted the service in English,

He is a close prisoner in his room, and, although the brain power still shines royally and with unabated force, his physical energies are very much prostrated. It will be a pleasure for our readers to know that his second and concluding volume on the War Between the States is very near completion.

The steamship Cleopatra, from Havana Jan. 17, reached this port last night. Our special correspondence, thanks to the courtesy of the Purser, was promptly at hand.

The President of the United States has taken official notice of the death of George Peabody, the philanthropist, by ordering a funeral escort of United States troops to accompany the remains from Portland, Me., to South Danvers, Mass. The escort will be composed of a battalion of the Fifth Artillery, under the command of Brevet Brigadier-General B. H. Hill,

The trial of ROCHEFORT was concluded yesterday and resulted in his conviction. He was sentenced to an imprisonment of six months, a fine of 3,000 francs and a deprivation of his political rights, although he still remains a Deputy.

Three persons, members of the family of Mr. ALBERT BRANDT, a druggist of Newark, N. J., are said to have been poisoned a few days since by eating a piece of ham infected with trichine. They were taken suddenly ill, and the cause of their illness being suspected, an uncooked piece of the ham was taken to Dr. EDGAR HOLDEN, of No. 114 Orange-street.

The House met for general discussion as if in Committee of the Whole. About fifty members were present. Mr. STOKES tools the floor and made a speech on Tennessee politics and as to the standing of Governor SENTER.

By the following order adopted by the Judges of the Supreme Court, (at the suggestion of Judge BRADY, it is understood,) the practice of granting orders and hearing motions by the Judges promiscuously, is to be discontinued. This change will obviate much of the conflict of jurisdiction heretofore so common in that Court,

The Woman's Suffrage Association held a regular meeting yesterday afternoon at No. 956 Broadway, Dr. HALLOCK in the chair. A resolution offered at last meeting, viz.: " That the right of woman to the ballot rests upon her individuality, that she is an integral, and not a fractional part of the Republic, that each woman counts one in the census of the nation," was discussed at some length.

A very daring disregard for an oath was shown yesterday during the examination in the Hester-street distillery case, in which several persons are charged with having run off large quantities of whisky in an illicit manner. Some two thousand oil paintings, collected by Mr. THOMAS THOMPSON, of Boston, deceased, are to be sold on Monday, Feb. 7, at the Leeds Art Gallery, No. 817 Broadway. A few words about the late owner of these pictures will not be uninteresting. It appears that Mr. THOMPSON came of good old Quaker stock.

Yesterday the troubles of the carmen with Collector GRINNELL reached a climax. Having, the evening before, hold a mass meeting for the purpose of denouncing the new cartage system, a delegation of the aggrieved proceeded yesterday to the Custom House, and presented to the Collector a petition, bearing the names of over one hundred merchants, asking for the repeal of the recent order.

ELLIS B. PITCHER, a citizen of Rhode Island and a person of some prominence, committed suicide last night by shooting himself through the head. Family afflictions and the failure yesterday of a firm for which he had indorsed to the amount of $20,000 or $30,000, stripping him of his property, is supposed to have unsettled his mind.

Tho will of Mrs. NANCY CLARKE BACIIE, widow of the late ALEX. DALLAS BACHE, was admitted to probate this afternoon. She bequeaths $5,000 to her nephew, HENRY WOOD BACHE, and in the event of his death unmarried, requests him to bequeath the amount to the National Academy of Sciences at Washington. She also directs that her house.

Rev. Dr. LYMAN has resigned the rectorship of the American Chapel in Rome, and Rev. Mr. NEVIN has taken his place. Rev. Mr. BRIGHAM has been for fifty years pastor of the Congregational Church at Randolph, Mass. Rev. B. EMERSON, D. D., pastor of the South Church, Salem, Mass., was 92 on the 8th of January.

About 7 o'clock last evening, Mr. DAVID EVANS, 65 years of age, residing in HEwesstreet, near Bedford-avenue, committed suicide by cutting his throat. It appears that the old gentleman had been a sufferer from heart disease for several years, and his afflictions were a burden to him, all the, heavier as years were added to his life.

The meeting of the representatives of the Express Companies, which has been in session in this City for some days past, adjourned yesterday afternoon. The American, Merchants' Union and the Adams Express Companies, whose lines were principally involved in the negotiation, have reached a harmonious solution of the questions at issue between them,

The notion appears to be slowly but surely gaining ground that for woman in her conjugal relation to help man is an absurd and exploded fallacy.

The Burns Anniversary, which occurs next Tuesday, will be duly celebrated by the various Soottish societies of this City. The regular Burns Dinner will take place at Delmonico's in the evening, and ladies are understood to be among the invited guests, as was the case last year at the Metropolitan Hotel.

The game of bil1iards last evening between DION and DEERY, for the benefit of the orphan asylums, was largely attended, netting a handsome sum of money for the asylums. DION won the game, the score standing on the fifty-seventh inning, DION 1,500, DEERY 573. DION'S highest run was 129. DEERY'S highest run was 84. Large sums of money changed hands on the result....

Prosperous repetitions furnish little occasion for comment, and the principal theatres have offered their patrons only these and nothing more during the week. Mr. FECHTER'S acting has been the chief theme of discussion in artistic circles, and it seems to be generally agreed that he is destined to win upon the New-York audiences more and more as they grow accustomed to him.

The trial of BOHNER and VAN BORDENBURG, the murderers of the Peightal family, was concluded on Tuesday, and resulted in a verdict of murder in the first degree with regard to both prisoners. The verdict was in strict accordance with the evidence, which fixed the terrible crime unerringly upon the two men.

Such a crowd of negroes, big and little, men and women, including a number of infants, filled the Tennessee depot yesterday afternoon, and thronged all the approaches to it, that access to the train was only to be accomplished by energetic efforts and elbowings.

The annual report of the Prospect Park Commissioners is now ready to be presented to the Common Council. The Commissioners persist in their determination to sell the park land east of Flatbush-avenue. This consists of a tract of 100 acres, and is worth at the present market rates about $3,000,000.

Saturday afternoon a number of prominent citizens of Newark and Elizabeth met at the Waverley Fair Grounds, situated within a mile of the limits of both cities, to decide as to its suitability for the site of a public park.

The treaty concluded by Mr. BURLINGAME between the United States and China has been ratified by the Chinese Government.... Through the negotiations of Secretary J.McLEARY BROWN the term of Mr. BURLINGAME'S mission is extended two years, and the sum of $14,000, in gold, has been appropriated for the expenses of the Embassy....The revised treaty between GreatBritain and China is published.

The cigar makers, to the number of 3,000, now on a strike, held a meeting yesterday, and wore addressed by several members of the International Union who have been attempting to effect a settlement. of the differences.

Rev. Dr. TWING preached last evening at the Trinity Parish Free Chapel, corner .of Seventh-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street, on the subject of "Domestic Missions." The attendance was large, and the sermon was received with marked attention.

About two years ago there arrived in this city a woman named MOLLIE TRUSSELL, who shot and killed in Chicago her lover, GEORGE TRUSSELL, who at one time owned the celebrated horse Dexter. A sensation was created at the time, from the fact that she was acquitted by a Jury after a tedious trial.

DUNHAM--GILL.--On Wednesday evening, Jan. 19, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Dr.B. L. Agnew, pastor of Westmaster Church, HENRY R. DUNHAM, Jr., of New-York, to Miss MARY A., eldest daughter of Captain Wm. H. Gill, U. S. AS., commanding officer Schuylkill Arsenal, philadelphia, Penn.

We recur to the sad record we had occasion to make in reference to our imperiled financial credit, because certain critics seek to break the force of the argument by misrepresentation and invective. We are accused of a desire to injure Governor HOFFMAN and th Democratic' Party, because we censure the Governor for signing the Erie bill, and the party for supporting the act.

Congress has done next to nothing in the two weeks st closed. Virginia was taken up on the first day after reassembling, and the beginning of the third week of the New Year finds the act of admission still incomplete. BINGHAM'S terse and comprehensive proposition comes back to the House so strangled with amendments that the vital provisions of representation which it contains is almost extinguished.

The trials and tribulations of Virginia in its effort to regain admission to the Union do not add to the glory of the reconstruction policy. Their injustice is equaled only by their cruelty,-their harshness only by their folly. The State long ago asked to be restored, and laws were on the statute book providing for its restoration.

MODERN AMERICAN SPIRITUALISM: A TWENTY YEARS' RECORD OF THE COMMUNION BETWEEN EARTH AND THE WOULD OF SPIRITS. By EMMA HARDINGE. New-York: Published by the author, No. 229 East Sixtieth-street. Trade supplied by the American News Company. 1870. The question of "Spiritualism" is not settled yet.

Tho chapalin of the Leavenworth penitentiary is a Sexton, and a woman at that. The fifth annual festival of the Boston Graduates of Yale, is to be held or Monday evening, 31st inst. The Boston gamblers arrested last week paid $2,030 in files, and had about $6,000 worth of property seized.

Mr. BEECHER'S discourse last evening was in the nature of rebuke and advice to the young. The topics he touched upon, he said, many people might think strange, emanating from the pulpit, but they had a grand beating upon the Christian.

JOHN WELSH, with a companion, while passing the trestle work at the Coal Dock in Hoboken yesterday afternoon, became involved in a dispute with a band of rowdies. A fight onsued. During the fight MICHAEL DONNELY drew a penknife from his pocket, and drew it twice over the wrist of JOHN WELSH, severing two arteries.

The United States ship Jamestown, seventy-seven days from the Fiji Islands, via the Mulgrave and Dunham Islands, which she sighted, but had no commnunication with, brings the following intelligence: English settlers are arriving at the Flgi Islands in large numbers from Australia and New-Zealand to engage in the raising of Sea Island cotton, which is said to yield from the highly productive soils of the islands, fabulous returns....

The eighth annual report of the Union Home and School for the Orphans of Soldiers and Sailors has just been issued. This beneficent institution was founded in 1862, and has grown in effciency from year to year under the thoughtful care of the ladles who have it in charge.

Theo news of the annexing humor in which America finds herself, has at last reached the very "corners of the earth," and greatly affected the Fijis. King THACKAMOON makes overtures to be annexed, with all his goods, chattels, real estate, and all his happy subjects. Indeed, those latter have been signing a "petition for a protectorate," which is already on its way to Washingtou.

It is reported that a bill will be brought before the Legislature requiring the fire insurance companies of Brooklyn to contribute a percentage towards the expenses of the Fire Department there; such legislation professedly having reference to the circumstance that one of the companies has recently declared large dividend to its stockholders.

WILLIAM LOGAN, on trial for the murder of WILLIAM MCCARTHY at Standish, recently, was found gailty of manslaughter. POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 23.--The steamboat Norwich is fast in the ice between Catskill and Hudson.

The mail train on the Tennessee Road, which left Lynehburg on Friday last at 5:20 P. M., experienced avariety of misfortunes and disasters. When about six miles from the city some machinery of the engine broke and the train returned to town, This occasioned some delay, and the train did not leave until 8:45 P. M.

The Democrats, it is said, are resolved to do away with the Humane Society and Mr. BERGH. We have been favored with the true reason for this determination. Several Deputy Sheriffs and their friends are much attached to the noble sport of cocklighting, and Mr. BERGH has interfered with their amusements.

J. MCLEAVY BROWN, Chief Secratary of the Burlingune misslon, reached here by the steamer America, enroule to Washington, as hearer of the ratified treatly between the United States and China.... DEERY and DION are to play a match game of billiards, on the 3d of February, for SL,000 side.

There was a review today of 10,000 volunteers. The legion composed of German and American volunteers made Its first appearance on this occasion. It made acreditable appearance, and was universally admired.

The Pastoral Aid Society of the Church of the Holy Trinity celebrated its fourth anniversary yesterday at the church on the corner of Madison-avenue and Forty second-street. Copies of the annual report were found in the, pews, from which it appears that the Society has received from various sources, during the pastryear, $16,327 74,

The labor and capital of Massachusetts are involved in the shoe and leather interests to a greater extent than in any other branch of industry. Boston is the great centre of the shoe trade in this country, and the leather trade employs a capital of $25,000,000, while the two combined represent no less than $100,000,000 of the wealth of the city.

The clipper ship Baltic, formerly the steamer of that name, Captain SHERBURNE, has just arrived at Liverpool from San Francisco, making the passage from port to port in 106 days. Quite a number of clipper ships arrived from San Francisco about the same time, the Baltic beating the fleet from six to twenty days.

The Prospect Park Commissioners have carried their gigantic enterprise through another year. Their work, long ago commenced on a basis no way commensurate with the wants of the population of a great city, has grown naturally into magnificent proportions-so much so as to ?? with fear and alarm the fogies who glory in the slowness of their forefathers and who deem every progressive step a uail forged for their collins.

The Department of State has received from the United States Consul at Amoy a copy of an important order from the Foreign Board at Pekin, which order had not been generally promulgated, but communicated to the Commissioners of Customs of the Treaty ports.

Yesterday morning, as an omnibus was being driven from the depot of the Missouri Valley Railroad, and had commenced crossing the bridge, the horses attached to the vehicle became frightend at a train which was moving above them on the bridge, and atempted to dash off.

The New-Orleans Times, in speaking of a painting on exhinition in that city, entitled the "Heroes of Chancellorsville," and repressenting the interview of Generals LEE and "Stonewall" JACKSON before that battle, prints testimonials from JEFFERSON DAVIS and ROBERT E. LEE. DAVIS writes :

A goodly audience assembled in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, last evening, to listen to the advocates of the temperance cause. Every seat was taken before the meeting opened. The gathering was under the auspices of the Sons of Temperance and " all friends of humanity," according to the programme.

HENRY PLACIDE, comedian, died at Babylon, L. I., yesterday. He was born in Charleston, S. C., Sept. 8, 1799. His father and mother were both performers, the former the manager of a company of actors who traveled through the South, giving dramamatic entertainments.

WILLIAM S. ROCKWELL, of Georgia, once United States District Judge of that State, and Lieutenant Grand Commander of the Supreme Council of Masons for the Southern Jurisdiction of the United States, and Past Grand Master of Georgia, died to-day in HarLford County, Maryland.

Mr. E. T. WALLACE, particulars of whose forgeries have been published, was intercepted at Meadville by a telegraphic dispatch, and on Tuesday afternoon Sheriff FRAZEE went to that place for him. He made no resistance, not even insisting upon a requisition from the Governor of Ohio upon the Pennsylvania authorities.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 5,--In compliance with the third section of the act of Congress of April 10, and the proclamation of the President, of July 15, 1869, an election was held in the State of Texas, on the 30th of November, 1st, 2d and 3d of December, 1869. The result of said election, excepting local officers, is hereby announced as follows:

The Worcester (Mass.) Spy approves of the policy hitherto pursued by Mr. BOUTWELL of reducing the debt as much as possible in order to prepare the way for other financial measures, but emphatically protests against its adoption as a permanent policy. It directs attention to the fact that the country, by doubling its wealth and population, will soon become twice as able to bear taxation;

Bishop LITTLEJOHN, of Long Island, officiated at the new Bethel, foot of Pike-street' yesterday afternoon, and delivered an interesting address on "The Life and Character of Christ." He exhorted those present to rely on Jesus as their compass to direct them on the voyage of life, and to acknowledge him as their captain and guide amidst the storms and shoals .of the world.

In steamship Denmark, from Liverpool--Captain Edenthrough and lady, Edward V. attwood John Scott and family, Rev. T. Hayes and lady, John whittaker and family, Wm. Watson, Walter Lucas, Wm. Sullivan, Miss Sarah Burke, Mr. R. H. Pugh and lady, and 91 in the steerage. In steamship General Barness, from Savannah--J. H. Murray, Chas. Snow, M. Talland, Gec. Cooke, Jno.

The Mormon missionaries, whose advent here a few weeks ago was duly chronicled in these columns, are laboring hard and earnestly on Long Island to spread, as they term it, "the only true Gospel," and to gather into the fold of the Latter Day Saints as many as will hear and believe their doctrines.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent in this morning's issue, under the heading "Steam Boilers and Explosions," referring to the late explosion on board the Parthenia, asserts that the hydrostatic test enjoined by law, under which boilers are submitted to a pressure of cold water "for a low moments," fifty per coal.

It is now announced that Secretary ROBESON has issued orders to Liutenant-Commander EASTMAN, commanding the Nyack, of the Pacific Fleet, to proceed forthwith to the Bay of San Miguel, whore the vessel will act as a supply ship for the Darien Expedition under Commander SELPRIDGE.

As already stated in brief in these columns, KIT BURNS' famous dog-fighting and rat-baiting establishment, in Water-street, has been leased by Rev. WM. H. B00LE, pastor of the South Second-street M. E. Church, Williamsburg, and will be speedily converted into a home for the reformation of the fallen women of that immediate locality.

FEATURES OF TO-NIGHT. The season of opera bouffe commences this evening at the Theatre Franeals. A change of bill is to be effected at the Grand Opera House, whefe " Cool as a Cocumber" and "JOcrisse the Juggler" will hereafter be given. At the New-York circus, several new artists will be introduced, and an entirely fresh programme will be interpreted.

Superintendent KENNEDY some days since received a letter from the United States Consul at San Juan, Porto Rico, stating that a young man named SALVADOR MARTINEZ had sailed from that port as a stowawar in the ship Kcokuk, bound for New-York, via Turk's Island, who had stolen from his aunt a quantity of jewelry, valued at $8,000.

At about 10:30 o'clock last evening afire was discovered in the second story of an L building situated within the quadrangle of the old Wheeler Wilson shop in East Bridgeport. The building had been originally the Japan room, but was used more recently as a drying room,

A third meeting was held by a number of Germans, mostly saloon keepers, in opposition to the Excise law, at Ocean Hall, corner of Nassau and Bridge streets, Brooklyn, Yesterday afternoon, Mr. H. C. BADEN presiding. They adopted the following resolutions, which they intend to circulate for signatures and to send by a Committee to Albany, to be submitted to the delegation from Kings County in the Legislature:

The public sales of real estate during the past week have shown signs of more life in the market than has been observable before for some time. The total amount of auction sales was $32,245. The recorded transactions of the week were 122 in number, and amounted to $1,259,945 in the values involved.

A meeting of the Erie Railway strikers was hold at No. 7 Engine House in Jersey City yesterday morning, at which it was reported that no news had been received from the shops up the road since the last meeting.

The Assembly is tryirg to make up the lost time consequent on the week's adjournment during the Speaker's illnest. A Saturday's session is an unusual event for the first two months of the Legislative term, and a Monday morning session is still more unfrequent; but the Assembly held the first yesterday, and will hold the second to-morrow--provided there be a quorum.

Among the welcome rays which illumine each succeeding Winter are the numerous balls. the proceeds of which are devoted to charitable purposes. Not the least prominent and worthy of these is the Charity Ball, which takes place at the Academy of Music this evening, under the auspices of the Young Men's Association, the Proceeds of which are to be devoted to the Catholic Orphan Asylums.

All the disorder attending the strike of the workmen at Le Creuzot has been repressed by the troops, and the strike is at an end....It is announced that an amnesty for offences against the Press law will soon be issued, and a new law for the regulation of the Press is to be submitted to the Corps Legislatif.

GENERAL: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication including me a commission as Provisional Governor of Mississippi. My failure to have acknowledged the previous letter, in which you informed me of your intention to send me the commission, has arisen from the fact of my absence from home.

Mr. HULAY, late Inspector-General of Customs, has concluded a loan of one million pounds sterling to the Mikado's Government to build a railroad from Yeddo to Kioto. He represents that several English capitalists have effected a loan of two more millions on the pubHe works.

List of Americans registered at the office of BOWLES BROTHERS CO, No. 12 Rue de la Palx, Paris, for the week ending Jan. 6, 1870: New-York--Col. H. Denike, E. M. Jewett, p. Fetridge and family, Mr. and Mrs. G. H. Moller, Miss S. M. Burbank, B. F. Breedon and family, E. J. Morse, Cyrus W. Field, Wm, Orton, Mrs. Rinicutt, J. Shindler and family.

The examination of FISK and GOULD yesterday occupied six hours before the Banking and Currency Committee. FISK was examined first and GOULD afterwards. Much to GOULD's chagrin, he was not permitted to be present when his confederate was examined, and FISKK was served in the same way.

The recognition of the Red River leaders by the Hudson Bay Company as the only legitimate Government in Winnopeg, has excited much comment in this city. ....No force will be attempted against the insurgents but Canada has two Ambassadors at Fort Garry to reconcile the people to the Dominion....

A dispatch from Norton Mills, Vt., says the stoam mills there wore destroyed by fire at 10 o'clock last night. Loss $40,000. Fully insured. WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 23.-The Town Hall In Webster was destroyed by fire last night. Loss $9,000. Insurance $5,000.
At Last! The agony of Virginia is ended. The good sens of the House has averted the delay and the intrigue which any hesitancy in the acceptance of the Senate amendments would have occasioned.

The stabbing affray which occurred in a saloon in Paterson, N. J., on the night of Monday, the 17th inst., resulted, on Sunday might, in the death of the assaulted party, a young man named HIRAM SPENCER. The assailant,

The New-York Cooperative Clothing Manufacturing Company have received their charter and are in full working order. At a meeting last night it was explained that the capital was to be $100,000, to be distributed in shares of $500. Mr. HENRY SCHAFFER is President.

A regular meeting of the Lyceum of Natural History was held last night at the Mott Memorial Library, Madison-avenue, Professor NEWBERRY in the chair. After some regular business, Professor JAY gave a most interesting account of some salt beds at Stossfurtb, Germany.

The remains of the late GEORGE D. PRENTICE were removed from Masonic Temple to Christ's Church, this afternoon, where the solemn and impressive funeral service of the Episcopal Church was performed, after which they were escorted to Cavo Hill Cemetery by the Masonic fraternity, and a large number of citizens.

BRADY.--At his late residence, No. 325 East 14th-st., JOHN BRADY, in the 69th year of his age. Friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from St. Francis Xavier's Church in West 16th.st., on Wednesday next, at 10 A.M. CRAIG.--On Monday, Jan. 24, MARGARET CRAIG, in the 76th year of her age.

About 7 A. M. yesterday a fire broke out on the fifth floor of No. 52 Lispenard-street, occupied, together with the third and fourth floors, by STERNS WEIL, manufacturers of ladies' under garments, whose loss on stock and fixtures is $12,000, which is covered by insurance as follows: Mechanics' and Traders'. $3.000: St. Nicholas.

There is fresh trouble in the ranks of the City Democracy. Some of the leaders have come to theo conclusion that it is extremely desirable to take the advice we have more than once given them, and get rid of the reproach which the government of this City has long been to the whole party.

The East River Association held another meeting yesterday, at No. 40 Burlling-slip, for the purpose of determining what further action, if any, was necessary for pushing forward the movement to prevent the steamers playing on Long Island Sound from occupying any part of the East River below Corlears Hook.

Five small business houses in St. Joseph, Mo., were burned yesterday morning. WM. FOWLER, a brother-in-law of ex-Congressman LOAN, who slept In one of the buildings, was burned to death. While a number of firemen were trying to rescue his remains, the walls fell in upon them.

How often shall we have to repeat the terrible story of a panic in crowded building We all know it by heart. Some malicious or foolish person cries "Fire fire " and there is one general and fatal rush to the doors. In nine cases out of ten it is discovered when the alarm is over that no kind of danger existed.

The Tribune, in a recent article on pig iron, alludes very cheerfully to the condition of the woolen interest under our present taxation. The allusion is creditable to its disposition rather than its intellect, but we fear that tho largo majority of those who have either been engaged in manufacturing or growing wool, will not concur in so airy and cheerful a view of the situation.

It is not much that we have to say of tile late Mr. PRENTICE! He was not an old man when he died, but he had been an editor since the time of the younger ADAMS. His working days numberedforty-five years. It is said that his latter years were clouded by misfortune.

A Kentucky youth was jealous of his own brother, and so killed him. The largest vineyard in California has 306,000 vines, covering 450 acres. Arkansas makes a loud call for school teachers and blacksmiths. Even St. Johns, N. B., reported on the 21st inst., that there was no snow, and the weather was like Spring.

The suit of PETER WEILER against the Paterson and Newark Railroad Company for compensation for land taken by the Company, came up for hearing before Chancellor ZABRISKI, In Jersey City, yesterday. WEILE clanimed that the price of his land, $4,500,

"LA GRANDE DUCHESSE." OFFENBACH'S choicest complication of fun, effrontery, melody and--something else, was revived last night at the French Theatre, under the management of Messrs. BYRNE STARR. The experiment looked on its face somewhat doubtful.

Virginia is at last out of the toils of Congress. Her admission, so far as legislative action is concerned, is complete. The bill will be promptly signed by the President, and before the week is out we may lock for her representatives upon the floor of Congress. There was a rough, sharp,

A two days' session of the New-England Labor Reform League, held here, closed this evening. It was thinly attended. Among the speakers were E. A. Heywood, President of the League, John Orris, Miss Albertson, Cora Symes, Jennie Collins, Mr. Warner, Dr. White, Professor Denton and S. P. Cummings, Chief of the St. Crispin Order.

At about 8 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the second floor front room of No. 9 Worth-street, occupied by DAVID HAURIS, a shoemaker. 'The building is a two.story and attic frame, and contained eight families. The smoke rapidly filled the entire building,

The thirteenth annual ball of the Young Men's Assocination for the benefit of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, took place at the Academy of Music, last evening, under encouraging and brilliant auspices. A largo number of prominent people were present, including the Mayor, Comptroller CONNOLIY,

Only the other day we called attention to some of the "modern improvements" which had found their way into Japan, and now we have by telegraph from San Francisco a fresh catalogue to add to the number. We are told, for example, of a railroad already contracted for from Yeddo to Kioto ;

The regular meeting of the Kings County Supervisors was hold yesterday. It was resolved to increase the fees of the Coroners' for making inquests from $10 to $15 per case. It appeared from a communication from Coroners JONES and WHITEHILL. that their total receipts for inquests in 1869 amounted to $8,930, out of which they paid $2,400 for clerk hire and traveling expenses, leaving them $3,265 each.

Commissioner MANIERRE yesterday conoluded the taking of the testimony in the case of FRANK B. LANE, of the Fifteenth Precinct, charged with improper conduct by the woman LIDA TAYLOR. Sergeant HALBROW, of the fifteenth Precinct, who was the only witness examined, testified that he was in charge of the desk when LANE brought the woman in at 12:45 A. M. She appeared very much excited,

The cartmen to the number of one hundred, met last night at the ?? Buildings, to protest against the projected system of cartage in the Custom House. Mr. A. G. REYNOLDS presided. A report supplementary to that published yesterday was read,

A very full meeting of the Produce Exchange of this City was held yesterday to receive the report of the Committee sent by that organization to the General Convention of the Commercial Union on Canal Affairs at Rochester, held on the 19th inst. Mr. S. D. HARRISON presided, and L. HAZELTINE, Jr., was chosen Secretary.

THE WRECK OF THE LADY GAY.-It is related that a relative of Mr. OWENS. clerk of the steamer Lady Gay, had a dream at 12 o'clock on Wednesday night, in which he saw the boat sink at a certain point in the river. He saw in his dream that no lives were lost, and that the boat was a complete wreck.

During the services at St. Joseph's Chapel, in this city, yesterday, a false alarm of fire was raised. Immediately the usual panic and rush for the doors occurred, and when order was at last restored, it was found that fifteen people had been trampled to death and a great many badly injured.
