NO. III. In our previous articles, the review of the racing season of 1869 was brought down to the close of the Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club at Jerome, to the brilliant success of which the extra day's racing, which included the magnificent steeple chase, materially contributed.
Coroner FLYNN yesterday took the decisive preliminary steps in the investigation of what now seems to be one of the most terrible and heartless crimes upon record.

Yesterday one of the United States Commissioners and one of the Assistant Attorneys were engaged in a private examination for the purpose of ascertaining what degree of credibility attaches to the testimony of the witnesses appearing for the Governmcnt in the Eighteenth-street distillery case.

Yesterday morning the subject of City Evangelization came up in the Methodist dpreachers' meeting, at No. 895 Broadway. It was introduced ;by Rev. Dr. PERRY, and Dev. Drs. W. H. FERRIS, CATTELLE and B. K. PIERCE, and Mr. SHAFFER and others participated in the deabte.

Upon the recommendation of General John A. MCDIONALD supervisor of Internal Revenue for Arkansas and the Internal Revenue for Arkkansas abd the Indian territory. Commissioner Delano has promulgated regulations externding the Internal Revenue laws over the Indian teritory as contempoted by sections 103 and 107 of the net iof JUly 20,

The new National Guard law proposed by Colonel MURPHY contains features which will provoke the liveliest discussion. For example, he proposes to transfer to the Governor the power to appoint brigade commanders, instead of. leaving them to be chosen, as now, by the field officers of the regiments included in the respective brigades.

A PETRIFIED OYSTER.--We have been shown by Mr. EMMETT WOMACK an oyster shell containing a petrified oyster, discovered on the plantation of A. J. WOMACK, in Clay County, at a depth of sixty feet below the surface, in a bed of oysters and other marine shells, fully eighteen inches thick.

Masked balls will be given by German societies, mostly singing societies, of this City and Brooklyn, this senson, as follows: "Schiller Bund," (Schiller Union,) Germania Assembly Rooms, Nos. 291 and 293 Bowery, Feb.7. " Abt Schnicler."

A special meeting of the trustees of the General Thcological Seminary of the Episcopal Church, met last week and transacted important business. A committee had been previously appointed to report on the expediency of removing the Seminary from its present location to another site, and tile Board of Trustees met to act on the report prepared by the committee.

There is scarcely a portion of the habitable globe on which to-day Scotchmen are not preparing to celebrate the anniversary of the birth of ROBERT BURNS. Tho spirit of the peasant bard yet binds by an electric thrill of brotherly sympathy the scattered chlldren of the little nation which he loved so well and interpreted so truly.

A young colored woman named LYDIA ANN GRIFFIN, was arraigned in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, on an indictment for manslaughter, being charged with killing her paramour, HENRY GRANT, also colored. Judge BEDFORD presided, Assistant District-Attorney FELLOWS conducting the case for the prosecution.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Many thanks for the late timely articles on the Lake trade. Allow me to suggest that one cause of the falling off may be the abrogation of the Reciprocity Treaty.

The residence of Dr. H. T. HELMBOLD, No. 156 West Fourteenth-street, was entered by burglars about 6:30 P. M. last Friday while the family was at dinner. The thieves climbed into a second story window, and departed with property valued at $2,000. They had not time to take all the property, owing to the fact that Dr. HELMBOLD went up stairs as they were at their work.

Messrs. GOULD and FISK returned from Washington yesterday morning. Neither of them was willing to say much in reference to the recent investigation. They speak very highly of the urbanity and politeness with which they were received by General GARFIELD and the other members of the Committee.

This being the day designated for the visit of Prince ARTHUR to President GRANT, Secretary FISH came to the Executive Mansion a few minutes before 12 o'clock for the purpose of being present at the interview, and to perform his part of the ceremonies incident to state occasions. About 100 persons, of both sexes.

The Police Commissioners held a meeting yesterday afternoon, during which a number of transfers of patrolmen acting as roundsmen were made. A communication was received from F. S. MASSEY, President of the Fire Departmentof Brooklyn, asking permission to make connections between the fire telegraph and the Police telegraph of that City.

A telegram was yesterday received by the strikers at Long Dock, that the men at Susquehanna had struck at about noon. The men at Port Jervis had not yet taken a like action, but it was thought that some information to that effect would reach them either through telegram or delegate this morning.

The morning train on the Watertown, Rome and Ogdensburg Railroad, duo hero at 12:35 this evening, met with a serious accident a short distance south of Philadelphia Station, caused by a broken rail. Two passenger cars and the smoking car were thrown off the track. J. H. TAYLOR, a traveling agent for a New-York firm, was instantly killed.

News of the final passage of the bill admitting this State was received here after dark. There appeared to be a genearal feeling of relief,
The Senate met at 7:30 P. M. REPORTS. By Mr. PARKER--Amending the charter of the village of Potsdam. By Mr. TWEED--Amending the act chartering Chartitable Societies. BILLS INTRODUCED.

The Seventeenth Assembly District Union Republican Association held its first regular meeting since its new organization at the Wigwam In Forty-ninth-strcet, nearNinth-avenue, last evening. The President, Mr. GEORGEP. BRADFORD. occupied the chair.

Project has been started in London to construct a steamer and railway route from Australia, New-Zealand, , to England,by the way of San Francisco, Cal., Portland, Me., and Milford Haven, Wales. It is thought that the trip can be made in forty days....

On Sunday night the office of WILLIAM R. CUMMINGS, Revenue Assessor of the First District, in Hunter's Point, was entered by thieves, who forced open the outer door of the large Terwilliger safe, but their tools failing them, they did not effectually enter the portion of the safe where the money and stamps were kept. They left behind them a crowbar and sledge hammer, and the following interesting letter:
A French Canadian gentleman in this city, who is intimately acquainted with RIEL, has received letter from him, written at Fort Garry about the beginning of this year.

The steamship Hansa, from Bromen Jan. 8, and Southampton Jan. 11, reached this port yesterday. The steamship Pereire, from Havre Jan. 13, and Brest Jan, 15, arrived last night, The news thus received is later by six days than was received by the Calabria. Captain DAURE, of the Pereire, has our thanks for late Paris papers.
The fourth of the serious of temperance meetings, under the auspices of the National Temperance Society, was held in the Methodist Church at Harlem last night, and was largely attended.

The legislation thus far carried through by the General Assembly of this State bears some resemblance to that body itself-is mixed, some good and some bad. Of the former, the good kind is the act repealing the Township law of last session. The Township law is one of the several instances of New-England legislation for South Carolina.

The Provisional Government has issued a decree outlawing SALNAVE and thirty of his chief partisans, putting at the same time a price of $5,000, gold, on the head of SALNAVE. The decree sets forth that the parties proscribed had been guilty of the most monstrous crimes, organizing pillage, incendiarism and assassination with a system of defence,

Mr. WLNTERS moved that the Committee on Unfinished Business report the Fifteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution on an early day. Adopted ....The Senate limited the time for the introduction of private bills to the 10th of March, and the House added an amendment that the Legislature will adjourn sine die on the 17th day of March....

Very little action was taken., yesterday by Coroner FLYNN in the case of JOHN ALEXANDER, the sea Captain who is alleged to have been murdered by poison,for the: purpose of gaining pessossion of his wealth, th details of which were published in yesterday's TIMES. IRA C.

Two ex-revenue gauges named LOUIS P. WETMORE and EZRA W. FARRINGTON were charged, before Commissioner BETTS, on complaint of Deputy Collector Coop; of the Thirty-second District, with having falsely gauged whisky withdrawn from bond.

The funeral of Right Rev. CARLTON CHASE, Bishop of New-Hampshire, took place in Trinity Church to-day, with solemn and impressive services Among the distinguished clergymen present. were Bishops WILLIAMS, of New-York, HUBBARD, EAMES. PARKER and HERRICK, of New-Hampshire, and others;

Mr. BILLOP SEAMAN, Cashier of the Fourth National Bank, was placed on the witness staud yesterday, for the purpose of giving testimony for the Government concerning the frauds alleged to have been committed on the bank by WILLIAM LEITH, in company with W. F. VELTMAN and ROBERT COPELAND.

The Scoretary of the Navy has addressed a letter to Representative SCOFIELD, Chairman of the Committce on Naval Affairs, informing him that he has transmitted to the House a copy of the record of the proceedings and papers of the Board of Officers, heretofore convened by order of the Navy Department to take into consideration the subject of assimilated rank between the officers of the Marine Corps of the navy.

The Senate discussed Mr. SHERMAN'S Currency bill to-day for three or four hours. Mr. SUMNER called for the reading of his bill offered yesterday as a substitute. The principal speech on the subject was made by Mr. FENTON, who was listened to with uninterrupted attention, and whose views were strongly commended by many of his Senatorial associates.

Justice DOWLING held an examination yesterday in the case of JOHN McCARTHY, who is accused of having forged an order on the freight agent of the Michigan Central Railroad, for the transfer of $2,300 worth of beef. Mr. MORRIS, the owner of the beef, a member of the Union Stock Yard Association in Chicago,
The funeral services of the late Rev. JAMES B. HARDENBURGH, D. D., of whom a full obituary notice appeared in Monday's TIMES, took place yesterday noon, at the Twenty-third-street Reformed Church.

A salute of one hundred guns was fired in the Park at noon today, in honor of the admission of the State. About live thousand persons were present, twothirds of whom were colored. National flags were raised on the Custom House and the Capitol. Governor WALKER spoke a few minutes, congratulating the people on the admission of Virginia and predicting a glorious future for the State.

The Assembly went into Committee of the Whole at the opening of the session to-day, and discussed several bills of minor importance, among them Mr. BERGEN'S bill to prevent the use of old or second-hand barrels for packing sugar, flour or meal. The bill was found to be so loosely drawn as to require a reference back to the Judiciary Committee.

The discovery of a leg-a human log, in an ash-barrel in front of a drugstore at the corner of Willoughby and Prince streets, on Monday afternoon, caused a terrible excitement in the neighborhood of the Court House and City Hall yesterday.

The steamships City of Antwerp, from Liverpool Jan. 13, and Queenstown Jan. 14, and Russia, from Liverpool Jan. 15, and Queenstown Jan. 16, reached this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by one day than was at hand by the Percire. Its features are embodied in letters and extracts given below.

The following seizures have been made by Deputy PUFFER, by order of Collector BAILEY, on information lodged by Assistant Assessor HARVEY: Eleven cases smoking tobacco weight 1,300 pounds value $600, seized at No. 162 Water-street; 52 cases smoking tobacco, weight about 2,800 pounds,

The Board of Overseers of Harvard College has voted to abolish the Junior exhibitions. Virginians are talking about a railroad from Lynchburg which shall lead under the arch of the Natural Bridge. A Boston paper says the people will in-Dawes what Mr. DAWES says.

The proposition to exclude the House of BOURBON from the Spanish throne, came up before the Cortes in Madrid, on Monday, and led to an exciting debate. General PRIM, stated that tho proposition to exclude all the BOURBONS was unjust; declaring, however, at the same time, that " his words were not designed to favor particularlytheDuke of MONTPENSIER, as he should go with the majority whoever might be chosen."

The stockholders of the Little Miami and Columbus and Xenia Railroads to-day ratified, by a unanimous vote, the perpetual lease of those roads to the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad, guaranteed by the Pennsylvania Central Railroad, beginning Dec. 1, 1869, at an annual rental, free of tax and assessments, of $480,000.

The locomotive of tho 12:30 train from New-York on the Now-Jersey Railroad struck a wagon that was crossing the track at Dean Pond, near Monmouth Junction, yesterday, causing fital Injuries to one of the occupants of the wagon and seriously injuring another.

Judging from the demeanor of the strikers at their meetings in Washlugton Hall, Jorsey City, yesterday, the men are beginning to regard their cause as lost, and now attribute the threatcuing failure of their project to tho traitorous acts of the leaders of the various organizatios

ROBERT BURNs, one of the gifted,few who never die, was 111 years old yesterday. Here, as elsewhere, wherever the English language is spoken, the anniversary of his birthday was duly honored, not only by his countrymen, but by men of other races, who claim him as cosmopolitan.

Captain Borr, the commander of a band of loyal guerrillas, lately captured the Insurgent Generals MARCANO, LEIVA and FIGUEREDO, together with the family of the latter, in the vicinity of Bayamo. BOIT and his prisoners have arrived at Santiago .... The insurgent leader, JESUS SANTOs,has surrendered to the Spanish authorities.

BAYLES.--At Matinecock, L. T., on Wednesday, Jan. 19, of congestion of the brain, WARREN, only son of John and Angeline Bayles, aged 15 years, 5 months and 26 days. BLIGH.--At Pau, Basses Pyrenees, France, on Wednesday, Jan. 5, META CAMPBELL, beloved wife of John W. Bligh, of this City. BRADY.--On Monday, Jan. 24, at his late residence, No. 325 East 14th. st., JOHN BRADY, in the 69th year of his age.

There is one duty before Congress which is superior to all official theories or predilections, and the neglect of which nothing will excuse. The relief of the people by the re' duction of taxation is the great necessity of the session.

The following changes have taken place in the Custom House since Jan. 17: Clerk Ninth Division, at $1,200 per annum-W. H. CLARKE, vice J. M. SIZER, resigned. Inspector, at $4 per day-E. A. SHELDON, vice J. H. WESTFALL, resigned. Night Inspeetor, at $3 per day-W. D. URANN, vice S. J. CAMPBELL, resigned.

The New-York Cooperative Building-lot Association held its second annual meeting last evening at No. 214 Bowery. According to the report of the Secretary the society is in a very flourishing condition. The receipts amounted to $34,543, with a balance at bank on the lst January, 1869, of $1,776 31; expenditures, $31,179 28; cash on hand Jan. 1, 1870, $5,145 32; clear profit, $230 39.

We all know that the people of this City submit to endless abuses and impositions with unexampled coolness and fortitude. Most of us go upon the old maxim which tells us that " what can't be cured must be endured." Every one who has a job to accomplish finds us an easy prey.

There was a large increase yesterday in the number of cases of small pox reported, fifteen being verified. They were all found in the infected district heretofore described, and among the emigrant population, that appears to suffer exclusively from the disease. There have been no deaths, however, reported since Monday,

The German Ladies' Annual Charity Concert, in aid of poor widows and orphans, is to take place on Thursday (to-morrow) evening, at Steinway Hall. We earnestly invoke for the occasion the patronage of the benevolent of all nationalities. The purpose in view is a noble one and the affair is injudicious and trustworthy hands.

The Mayor's Marshal has within the last day or two investigated the following eases, and in each has caused the money to be refunded: HENRY S. AUSTIN, Of Chicago, Ill., against the promises No. 416 Broadway; the complainant lost $50 by the envelope game.

Prince ARTHUR today, accompanied by his suite and members of the English Legation, visited Secretary BOUTWELL at his office in the Treasury Department. They were received by Mr. BOUTWELL, and after a few moments passed in conversation, the SecroTary escorted the party through the Printing Bureau of the Department.

Another case of matrimonial infelicities culminating in an attempted murder occurred yesterday in Harlem. It appears that THOMAS TYNAN and his wife separated, and the former went to board in One Hundred and Thirteenth-street, near First-avenue.

The finding of the dead body of DENNIS CRONAN, of Hunter's Point, in Newtown Creek, reported in yesterday's TIMES, seems to be surrounded with more starting ground for suspicion than was at first thought probable.

The sixth annual session of the New-year State Workingmen's Assembly commenced this morning in Iron Moulders' Hall McClure's building. About fifty delegates were present. Mr. WILLIAM. J. JESSUP, President, called the assembly to order, and after calling the roll of officers, delivered his annual address.

The Postmaster General has now completed all the arrangements connected with the carrying of the foreign malls. Contracts have been made with all the new lines engaged, for two years' service. The first arrangement with the Williams Gulon line was merely temporary,

There is a case before United States Commissioner JONES in the Eastern District, which, it is understood, will be likely to call for a decision from the Attorney-General, in order to have a very important question settled, On theo 20th inst. complaint was made before Commissioner JONES, charging JULIUS RAYMOND and MORITZ SCHLISSINGER ith carrying on the business of illicit distillers at Newtown.

Here is the debate: INDIAN CHIEF--"Mr. President, we call hero to-day to offer our fealty to you Aa our recognized guardian and ward, and to pray you, Sir, to continue our good friend and father."

The construction of the new Fire Alarm Telegraph is a work of such magnitude and the contractors are so earnestly striving for perfect excellence that its completion has been somewhat delayed. The work, however, is in rapid progress,

JOHN GUEGNAN, a stranger in this City, and now an inmate of the House of Detention, caused the arrest of JOSEPH DOLLARD, yesterday morning, on a charge of robbery. The complainant met the prisoner and two other men in Roosevelt-street, when they assaulted him in the most unprovoked manner.

The proposition for the exclusion of the House of Bourbon from the Spanish throne came before the Constituent .Cortes yesterday for final action, aud was the occasion of an exciting debate. Gen*oral PRIM participated, and made a personal statement. In the course of his remarks he declared that the proposition was unjust to exclude nll the BOURBONS.

The Democratic accounts from Albany confirm the reports received from our own sources of information relative to the disorganization which exists in the party. There has been an almost unprecedented rush for office, and everybody who has helped to win a Democratic victory expects to be rewarded.

Two things are admitted regarding our wharves and docks-the first that their present condition is disgraceful, and uuworthy even of a second-class city; the second that any improvement of that condition must pot be by patching and botching hero and there, but by thorough reconstruction on a comprehensive plan.

Yesterday there were several important sales of real estate at the Exchange room and considerable interest was exhibited by the large number of gentlemen there assembled. Much the larger portion of the crowd gathered about the stand of MULLER. WILKINS Co., where some valuable business property was disposed of, located on the old down-town streets.

Captain ALFRED BEALS, of the steamer Eastern Queen, was instantly Killed this morning as the boat was going into the dock. He was on the hurricane deck in the act of speaking to the engineer, when he was struck by the walking beam, his head being mangled in a dreadful manner. 'He leaves a wife and three children in Hallowell....

A disastrous railway accident occurred about 1 o'clock this morning at Hankins', a Station, on the Delaware Division, Erie Railway, west of Port Jervis. A regular eastvard-bound freight train, DEWITT, conductor, laden with flour, butter and other products of the West, took the switch at Hankins', to await the passage of the express passenger train East.

We sincerely trust that whenever Congress comes to act on the San Domingo purchase as it must before many days, it will take into serious consideration the position in which our Government now stands with regard to St. Thomas, bought nearly two years, as far as the Executive could buy it, from the Danes.

Mr. HARLAN presented the credentials of his colleague, JAMES B. HOWELL, elected by the Legislature of Iowa to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Senator GRIMES. Senator elect HOWELL then took the usual oath of office. PETITIONS.

At the annual meeting of the American Geographical Society on Tuesday night, Captain HALL, in the remarks made subsequent to the President's address, spoke of the new theory of a thermometric gateway to the Pole. suggested by Captain SILAS BENT, of the Japan expedition under Commodore PERRY.

Tile funeral of Rev. WM. DYMON, rector of St. Paul's Church, Yorkville, took place yesterday afternoon from the Church of the Holy Trinity, in Madison-avenue, with which he was formerly connected. A large assemblage attended the ceremonies, which were at once interesting and affecting.

The Grand Jury of Westehester County have found two hills of indictment against ISAAC VAN WART BUCKOUT, one for killing his wife, and the other for killing Mr. ALFRED RESDALL, at the house of the former, on New Year's day.

Commissioner BOSWORTH sat yesterday to investigate complaints against policemen, and during the session heard forty-five cases. Among the most important was that of JAMES MCGIBNEY, car detective of the Third Precinct, who was arraigned upon the complaint of JOHN LORD, who stated that he went to the Station House and complained that he had been swindled out of $150 at No. 233 Broadway.

The New-Jersey Temperance Convention held its annual meeting in Temperance Hall, Trenton, yesterday. About 200 persons were drawn together, and quite a number of colored brethren were among them. The officers of the Society made their quarterly report...

The Grand Jury yesterday found an indictment against CHRISTIAN HERGER for manslaughter in the second degree, in killing MILTON L' CARPENTER on the night of Jan. 9, by striking him on the head with a wooden mallet. The prisoner was arraigned, and pleaded not guilty.

The region of the Rio Grande is clearly the smuggler's paradise. The Canadian frontier and the Atlantic coast are not, we are sometimes told, absolutely hopeless to theo shrewd smuggler, and strange stories are current of tricks upon revenue officers: But these are exceptional cases, and perhaps go to prove the rule of Custom House fidelity.

The cruel suspense of theo unfortunate nominees of the Governor still continues. Two or three Senators persist in their refusal to confirm theo names sent in until satisfaction is guaranteed them for the future. A motion to go into Executive Session to-day was voted down, the two NORTONS--MICHAEL of New-York, and C. F. of Clinton--refusing to go with their party.

An application was made on Saturday to Judge McKINSTRY, of the Twelfth District Court, for a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of thirty-six Chinese women. The application was made by DUDLEY and HALL, attorneys, on behalf of Chinamen, who claim to have come from China for the purpose of rescuing some forty women, the wives and daughters of respectable men, who were kidnapped and brought by force to this city.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 26.--A young man named FRITZ WERTEMAN WAUWAUTOSA, accidentally fell into a vat of boiling water, at WEINER Co.'s distillery, on Monday, and was scalded to death.

The regular weekly meeting of the Board of Health was hold yesterday afternoon, in the Court Room, at No. 301 Mott-street, Dr. LINCOLN, the President, presiding. Suits were ordered to be commenced in twenty-two cases for non-compliance with the Tenement-house law.

The jury impaneled in the case of Captain JOHN .ALEXANDER, Who is alleged to have been poisoned, wore assembled yesterday at Bellevue Hospital to view the body of the deceased preparatory to the final post-mortem examination. The remains were found to be in an advanced state of decomposition, and quite a mummy in appearance.

When the House took up the Legislative, Executive and Judicial Appropriation bill to-day, General BUTLER got his long-coveted opportunity of replying to the famous speech of Mr. DAWES. He had been preparing for some days, and was quite well supplied with an array of figures to disprove Mr. DAWES' statements. DAWES' statements.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 26.--The House of Representatives organized to-day and elected R. B. MCWHORTEN, Republican, Speaker, over J. E. BRYANT, Conservative, by 24 majority. Three members of the House, Mossrs. DONALDSON, MUNN and TALIAFERRO, have been declared ineligible by the Military Commission.

Mr. CULLOM'S bill for the suppression of polygamy in Utah has evoked from the Mormons a fierce protestation that they will fight sooner than submit to it. The whole temper of BRIGHAM YOUNG and of his people upon the subject is defiant and belligerebt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25.--The British ship Baringer, from Australia, brings the following escaped prisoners, sent from Ireland to the British penal colonies in 1865 and 1867. Their terms of sentence to transportation vary from five years to life: John Kenny, Dennis B. Castman, Dennis Hennessey, Maurice Figenbokin, Patrick Lehy, Thomas Fogarty, David Joyce

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I notice, with surprise, the following in your columns this morning: Mr. CHARLES NORDHOFF, other of New-York Evening Post, says: "My wife will have none but the 'Astral' Oil."--Advertisement.

Some of the papers yesterday contained accounts of a daring street robbery, of which JOHN M. WOOD, of North Adams, Mass., a great of the Metropolitan Hotel, was the alleged victim, it being stated that he had been knocked down in Wall-street and robbed of a check for $13,000.

DE BARY.--On Tuesday morning, Jan. 25, at her residence, JULIA, wife of Frederick De Bary, in the 50th year of her age, after a long and lingering sickness. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from her late residence No. 124 East 27th-st., on Thursday, Jan. 27, at 1 o'clock.

A Rome dispatch says it is possible the Council may be dissolved finally about Easter, owing to the unhealthy nature of the climate of Rome. The Pope, although suffering from a cold, presides daily at the sessions of the Council. A Paris dispatch says the Papal authorities have forbidden the publication of a letter of the Archbishop of Maline

ROME, Jan. 26.--His Holiness the Pope still suffers much from a cold, but he presides over the sessions of the Ecumcnical Council every day. It is said that the Council will suspend, and possibly close altogether about Easter, on account of the insalubrity of Rome.

The services of the sixty workmen discharged from the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Tuesday, and of the one hundred discharged on Monday, were dispensed with by the commandant, Admiral GODON, in accordance with orders from Washington, because of their sympathy with the illicit whisky distillers of the Fifth Ward, Brooklyn. Suits have been commenced

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 26.--Tbe arrival of the squadron with the remains of the late GEO. PEABODY, and the preparations for paying proper tributes of respect to the memory of the great philanthropist, absorb the attention of our population.

A letter was received yesterday for the strikers, from Mr. FIRLEY, of Buffalo, announcing the failure of his efforts to induce the men along the line to sustain their fellow-workers at Jersey City, and advising them to submit quiet. ly and acknowledge themselves beaten. The sympathies of the men are all with the mutinous party, but they cannot afford to sustain them.

By the Russia, Mr. BRENTANO has received his usual budget of first-class foreign publications. The Graphic No. 7, has a page of portraits of French "Irreconcileables," including one of ROCHEFORT. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to ask the use of your columns for putting before the public a plan for renovating our foreign carrying trade, and for giving employment to our vessels and seamen.

At noon yesterday the funeral of HENRY PLACIDE took place at St. Paul's Church, on the corner of Broadway and Fulton-street. Many prominent business men left their offices to spend a solemn' hour in that ancient fane, where the impressive burial service of the Episcopal Church was said over the remains of the veteran actor.

The distribution of semi-annual certificates and prizes at Grammar School No. 29, in Greenwich-street, took place yesterday noon. The exercises were of the usual character, singing, readings, solos, A recitation entitled "Hood's Lost Heir," by MAGGIE CONNERS, was finely rendered, and brought her the applause of the audience.

CINCINATI, Jan. 27.--Colonel DIGBY, of the British army, was married this morning to Miss LILLIE, daughter of W. W. GROESBECK. The ceremony took place at Mr. GROESBECK'S residence, Bishops ROSECRANS, Catholic, and MC-ILVAINE, Protestant, officiating.

A Chille Charles Leonce Victor, Due de Broglie. The Duke of BROGLIE, whose death at Paris on the 26th inst. has just been reported by cable, was born on the 28th of November, 1785, and consequently had attained the age of 85 years. By the death of this nobleman the present generation has lost another of those connecting links which bind it to the transitional epoch of history which followed the first French revolution.

After playing Ruy Blas for twelve nights. Mr. FECHTER chose for his second character in America that of Lugadere, in "The Duke's Motto," and the play was accordingly produced at Nible's Garden on Wednesday evening. The house was crowded to discomfort.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It has transpired that certain eminent capitalists and railroad builders of New-York have recently made arrangements to continue and complete that great line of railroad, terminating at Richmond on the waters of the Chesapeake, and at the month of the Big sandy tributary of the Ohio, a line traversing the States of Virginia and West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.-The question is settled as to who is the leader of the House of Representatives-it is HENRY L. DAWES. His speech to-day was a masterly effort, not because It was an attempt to vindicate his first speech, but because it was a falr, honest, clear statement of the case as it stands;

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.-The ball given at the new Mesonic Hall to-night by the British Minister and Mrs. THORNTON, in honor of Prince ARTHUK, was decidedly recherche, and one of the most magnificent affairs of the kind that bas over taken place at the capital. The hall was profusely decorated with flags and flowers, all of which were arranged with the most artistic taste.

The bold, manly stand taken by Mr. DAWES in behalf of retrenchment and economy in every Department of the Government,will not be weakened by his speech of yesterday. It is frank in the acknowledgment of what, after all, were minor errors, and consistent, clear and effective in the enforcement of the cardinal feature of his first great argument.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.-In compliance with a resolution of the Senate, the Scretary of the Treasury has transmitted to that body the report of Captain CHARLES BRYANT, late Special Agent of the Treasury Department, on the resources and inhabitants of Alaska. The report is very long and elaborate, giving the result of his personal exanmmation of large portions of the Territory, including all the principal islands.

At an early hour yesterday morning exJudge EDMUND L. HEARNE, late of the Marine Court of this City, died at Rockaway, aged 54 years. Deceased was stricken with paralysis

CONREY.--Suddenly, on Wednesday, Jan. 26, ANNA MARIA, wife of Peter Conrey, formerly of New-Orleans, and daughter of the late Daniel Jaudon, in the 76th year of her age. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral services on Saturday morning, Jan. 29, at 10 o'clock, at Zion Church, Madison-av., corner of 38th-st.

The trial of Colonel SAUNDERS D. BRUCE on a charge of publishing a libelous article against GEORGE WILKES in the Turf, Field Farm, was resumed before Judge,BEDFORD in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

At the Exchange Salesrooms yesterday ADRIAN H. MULKER Co. sold three dwelling houses, situated on East Thirtieth, East Fifty-fourth and East Sixty-second streets. That on East Thirtieth, between Lexington and Third avenues, and known as No. 137, is a three-story high-stoop brick house, 20x45, built on a lot 20x08.9. It brought $14,500.

PARIS, Jan. 27.--There was a stormy session of the Corps Legislatif this afternoon, on the France-English Commercial Treaty. M. THEIRS, in a speech, demanded a renunciation of this treaty, and reproached the majority, asserting that they did not truly represent the country or they would overthrow a Ministry having principles the country had repudiated. Great agitation ensued.

The breach of promise case of MARY HARRISON vs. GEO, VREELAND which was held before the Hudson County Court last Winter, came up yesterday in the same Court for a new trial. In the original case Mrs. HARRISON, a widow, aged about 45 years, sued the defendant, a widower of 84, worth $700,000, for damages in the SUM of $10.000 for breach of promise of marriage.

A letter was laid before the Police commissioners yesterday from Mr. GEO. M. VARIAN, tendering to them a piece of the old buttonwood tree which lately stood in Broadway between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh streets. It was stated that the tree was planted between the years 1625 and 1630,

The Yale Alumni Association had its annual dinner at DELMONICO'S, corner of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street, last evening. At 7:30 more than two hundred sons of Yale sat down to dinner, Hon. WILLIAM M. EVARTS, President of the Association, presiding.

There is a lull in the proceedings relative to the Peabody obsequles to-day. The city is crowded with strangers, whose numbers inerease houly, from the back country and from nearly all the cities in New-England.

Judge CARDOZO, holding the Supreme Court Chambers, granted an order of arrest in a suit which has been commenced by EMMA, or EMILY KNICKERBOCKER against the Russian, LEO BALSKY, to recover a large amount of damages sustained by her in consequence of her alleged seduction and a breach of the, marriage promise on the part of the defendant.

There were no sales of real estate at the Exchange Rooms yesterday, and to-day, being Saturday, will be equally quiet. Some important sales are announced for next week, but not enough to indicate any great activity in the market. In fact, the long looked for revival on the trade can hardly be said to have come yet.

Professor J. S. NEWBERRY, of Columbia College, delivered the seventh and last of the American Institute lectures last evening, at the Cooler Institute, on the above subject. The large Hall was well filled.

PRIM has at last succeeded in constituting his new Ministry. Since the dispatch of my last letter, he has been compelled to resort to all sorts of manocuvres to endeavor to retain his former colleagues in the Cabinet, but Senor ZORILLA, the ex-Minister of Justice, and Senor MARTOS, ex-Minister for Foreign Affairs, refused to enter into any Ministerial combination which he was in a position to offer.

The Eighteenth-street distillery case was again postponed yesterday on motion of the Government officers. It appeared that JOHN BOYLE, JOHN FALDEMANN, WM. DOUGHERTY, THOS. DOUGHERTY and EARNEST SMITH were summoned as witness for the prosecution, but that they were reluctant about appearing.

The accident on the Great Western Railroad occurred to the night express train from Detroit. The train consisted of two passenger and two Pullman sleeping cars. The rail which caused the disaster, though new, broke into serveral pieces.

The spacious college building of Otterbein University, at the town of Westerville, in the northeast portion of Franklin County, was burned at an early hour yesterday morning. The University was under the auspices of the United Brethren in Christ. By great exertion and peril of life, most of the chemical apparatus and furniture of several of the lower rooms were saved.

We receive news. by private letters, of a severe earthquake on one of the Ionian Isles, which has not been reported by cable, nor, so far as we. have seen, in any foreign journal, The earthquake resulted in the entire destruction of the town of Santa Maura, on the island of that name, with large loss of life.

An accident occurred on the Sussex Railroad, near Andover, N. J., on Friday, which resulted in the serious injury of several passengers. It is supposed to have been caused by the spreading of the rails. The passenger car was thrown down an embankment fifteen or twenty feet, and completely turned over.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The immense advantages of the extensive water front of New-York City have contributed largely to its great commercial prosperity. There are thousands of stores and warehouses located in the lower part of the City, convenient to the wharves. Probably $2,000,000 of freight per annum are received and sent by the Sound steamers.

JOSEPH H. MARTIN has commenced a suit against F. N. HAMLIN, a well known dry goods dealer, for damages, put at $20,000, for false imprisonment. I came back to Florence for the opening year to find this region also under a gloony cloud. For nearly forty days there has been rain almost without interruption, and the earth has become as suggy with humidity as a wet spongue. The sticks drop mildew, and the weathecock has rasted towards the southeast. It has been vain tolook for consolation in sunlight, for from behind the clouds has hardly gleaned a single beam.

Mandrid, Jan 31.--An exciting discussion occurred in the Constituent Cortes on Saturday, between Senor FIGUERAS, one of the leaders of the Republicans, and General PRIM. The former defended the recent Republican insurrection, and asserted that it was a deliberate act of the people to defend their individual rights, which had been violated by the Government.

JAY GOULD last week gave Princeton College $10,000 for a fellowship in mathematics. Governor REED of Florida, has appointed Major E. C. WEEKS Lieutenant-Governor of that State to fill a vacancy. People in Ohio are again talking about erecting a monument over the remains of President HARRISON.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 31.--A snow-slide from the roof of the Kirk-street Church to-day carried with it a chimney and killed a stranger who was passing on the street.

SOUTH WEST PASS, La., Jan. 31.--Colonel GAZERN, who left Vera Cruz on the 17th inst., arrived here to-day on the schooner Isabella. Colonel GAZERN is Secretary of State of Vera Cruz, and represents that he was compelled to fly to the United States for security. He reports that the revolution is increasing in San Luis Potosi. Orizaba has proclaimed against the Juarez Government.

Commissioner MANIERRE yesterday investigated a complaint against Captain PETTY, of the Fifth Preciuct, made by HENRY WARBERG, of No. 29 North Moore-street. His story was that he had some difficulty with another boarder in the house, and intending to leave, went to his room to pack up his things.

THEODORE S. TRITSCHER, a stranger to this City, now sojourning at Curtls' Hotel, went to Nlbol's Theatre on Thursday evening. After the performance THEODORE met a woman in Broadway, and ws induced to accompany her to No. 50 Crosby-street, where he was robbed of $700 in money.

A temperance meeting was hold last night at the Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church in Thirty-fourth-street. Hon. WILLIAM E. DODGE was in the chair, and was the first to address the audience. He spoke effectively against the evil effects which the public sale of liquors introduced, and deplored the probable reopening of liquor saloons in this City. on Sunday, through the action of the present Legislature.

The Superintendent of Building has caused surveys to be made of the following houses, which have been declared unsafe, and the necessary steps have been taken to render them habitable: Houses Nos. 204 and 206 East Twenty-third-street--Coping on chimney in rear loose; owner, W. BURDON, Brooklyn.

FALKENSTEIN, manufacturer of bootlegs, on the same floor, lost $200, but is insured for $600 in the Bowery. The bulding, owned by SAMUEL LEVY, will require $300 for repairs, and is insured for $8,000. The fire is supposed to have been caused by an overheated stove.

Reduction of the public debt still goes on. The diminution effected during the month Just ended Is $3,933,664-making the aggregate reduction since the 1st of March, 1869, not less than $80,649,971. This is an achievement of which the country as well as the Administr nation may well be proud.

THE PAREPA ENGLISH OPERA TROUPE. Our neighbors of Brooklyn will have an opportunity next Tuesday at their Academy of Music to hear the excellent Parepa English Opera Troupe in WALLACE'S "Maritana." The company afterwards are to continue their travels in the country, and will return to the Metropolis in time to open for a season at the New-York Academy of Music on March 14.

The appointment of General F. A. WALKER as Superintendent of the Census is an important step in the much-vexed census question. It is important, because, as we showed the other day, the key of the whole matter lies in the proper choice of men and the proper assignment of duties to them.

The Senate passed the Currency bill to-day substantially as Indicated in these dispatches last night, namely: Going back to the original proposition to add forty-five millions of dollars to the national currency, and to withdraw from the North and East twenty instead of thirteen millions.

Mr. W. L. ORMSBY, Jr., addressed the Liberal Club last evening on the subject of the "Government and Education of Children." He held that for children as for men, that form of government is best which governs least; that children are not responsible for their faults and should therefore be treated leniently;

Prince ARTHUR arose at his costomary hour yesterday morning, notwithstanding his dissipation of the previous night, and took a morning ride in the Park. Returning at about noon he procceded to thbe residence of Mr. A. T. STEWART, where he was entertained at lunch. He then inspected Mr. STEWART'S new house, and paid a visit to his retail store.
The workmen employed on the BARNARD and McGOWAN'S canal-deepening contract, between this city and the summit, this morning struck for higher wages. They demand $2. The strikers number about 400.

As was yesterday stated, JOHN DIXON, the self-confessed murderer of DAVID SISCO, was arrested on the Sterling Railroad, on Monday night, by two men named AKERS and MORGAN, who, stimulated by the promised reward of $200, had joined the pursuit.

The oral and written examinations, which were commenced on Monday, were continued yesterday. The Senior Class was examined in constitutional law and Greek by Professors HUNTSMAN and SPENCER. The Junior Class was examined by Professor COMPTON in analytical mechanics. The Sophomore Class was examined in drawing by Professor KOERNER.

The death of JAMES MONCRIEF, ex-Judge of the Superior Court, which occurred in this City, Monday, caused by dropsy of the chest, was announced in the Superior Court yesterday. AT the opening of the Court, Chief Justice BARBOUR presiding, Mr.EDWARD F. BROWN arose, and in a few feeling remarks eulogized the late Judge MONCRIEF, and moved that the Court adjourn as a mark of respect to his memory.

FRISBIE--CONNOR.--On Thursday, Feb. 3, 1870, at the residence of the bride's mother, No. 310 West 28th-st., New-York, by Rev. Thos. Street, OSCAR FRISBIE, Esq., of New-York, to ANGIE A., daughter of the late Charles Connor. No cards.

The Mayor and a deputation of the Common Council of Baltimore en route for Massachusetts to attend the funeral of Mr. PEABODY, called at the Mayor's office yesterday, and, in the absence of his Honor, were received by Marshal TOOKER.

A plan of organization adopted binding the members to abide by the rules of the Board. This obligation is as follows:

A terrible accident occurred this morning on the Boston and Albany Railroad, half a mile west of Chatham Village. A large freight train going cast broke the couplings near the centre of the train, and eleven cars ran back down a heavy grade, coming in collision with another freight train, piling the cars all upon each other in a mass of ruins with the engine, and instantly killing MILES PHILLIPS, conductor; CHARLES SPRAGUE, brakeman,

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the chair. A resolution from the other Board was concurred in, imposing a fine of $5 per day, after the 1st of March next, on all persons using awnings the drippings from which fall on the sidewalk. Resolutions for the repairing of various streets were adopted.

At a Radical caucus at Jefferson City, last night, the question of submitting to the people an amendment to the Constitution enfranchizing all those now deprived of suffrage, without respect to race or color, was discussed and carried by a nearly two-thirds vote....In the State Senate, yesterday,

The Swalara has taken a draft of sailors on board and dropped down to the Battery preparatory to starting for Samana Bay, San Domingo, On her return she is to be sent to China. The gunboat Yantic will be ready for duty tomorrow, when she will join the Nipsic and Guard at the Battery, and start for the Isthmus of Darien. The Colorado went to the ordnance dock wednesday to take in her guns.

The sentiment of this community is at last aroused to the alarming fact that as a role with us great criminals go free. While we hear of the execution of murderers in other parts of the country, the gallows appears to be an obsolete institution in New-York City.

A meeting of the Union Republican General Committee was held last evening. Hon. Wm. A. DARLING, as Chairman of special Committee appointed to take proper notice of the death of Hon. EDWIN M. STANTON, reported a series of appropriate resolutions, which were adopted.

The report of the Committee on Canal and Canal Lands, with especial reference to the Illinois and Michigan Canal, was under discussion in Committee of the Whole of the Constitutional Convention on Saturday. The Convention has shown a disposition to discuss this important question thoroughly, and to act upon it with deliberation and caution.

The House has acted promptly in the case of Mississippi, and has taken the only course admissible in the promises. The bill yesterday reported from the Reconstruction Committee and adopted, after a couple of divisions, is identical in its provisions with that under which Virginia has boon restored to the Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--The House made quick work to-day with the bill for the admission of Mississippi. General BUTLER reported from the Reconstruction Committee a bill precisely similar to that admitting Virginia. Mr. BECK, from the minority of the same Committee, reported a substitute, the same that Mr. BINGHAM offered and carried through the House originally in behalf of Virginia.

Opposition is manifested in some quarters to the passage of the measure forbidding the Sound steamers from landing (as now) on the North River side of the City. The ground assigned for this opposition is that trade would be impaired, and that the warehousing interests on the West side would suffer materially if the measure be carried out.

The Board of Indian Commissioners held an adjourned meeting in this City Wednesday, at the office of Commissioner WM. E. DODGE. There were present Messrs BRUNOT, of Pittsburg; CAMPBELL, of St. Louis; TOBEY, of Bos ton; STUART, of Philadelphia, and COLYER, of New-York.

A full and interesting meeting of the Institute was held last evening. Hon. N. C. ELY acted as Chairman. The annual reports of the Trustees, Board of Manager for the Fair, Committees on the Library, Finance, Agriculture, Manufactures and Machinery, were presented and ordered to be placed on file.

Yesterday afternoon the Treasurer of the City of Newark received a call from a boy of 17, who presented a city warrant, drawn in proper form, and signed by Mayor RICORD, for $20,000. The boy demanded payment, and the paper being evidently genuine the Treasurer took it and commenced counting out the money.

An anonymous letter was received by Collector GRINNELL, yesterday, inclosing $125 61, which the writer represented to be about the amount of his indebtedness to the Government on certain goods which he had imported from Europe. He made the discovery that the goods were undervalued by himself after they were passed

LEVY'S FAREWELL CONCERTS. Mr. J. LEVY continues to bid the public farewell. Since Mr. CRUMMULES' assumption of Nicholas Nickleby's privilege of leage taking, there have been few performance more protracted. But as long as the ceremony is productive of good concerts there is no reason to complain of its length.

ALBANY, Feb. 3.--The following bills were reported: By Mr. HUBBARD--For the removal of liens by judgements against persons relieved by the Bankrupt act. By Mr. MURPHY--Amending the act requiring compensation for causing death by carelessness or neglect. MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS.

JOHN EWING. a resident of this place, was killed this afternoon at Waterbury. Vt., by falling from a bridge at which he was at work. FORTRESS MONROE, Feb. 3.--Brevet Lieutenent-Colonel HENRY W. JANES, who for the past three years has been on duty as Depot Quartermaster, has been relieved and ordered to duty at Portland, Oregon.

Libels of information were filed with the Clerk of the District Court yesterday, by Assistant District-Attorney EMERSON, in cases for the forfeiture of large quantities of whisky, recently seized in Collector BAILWAY'S district for non-payment of the revenue tax. The total number of barrels of whiskly which have been reported for legal action is about 2,000,

The Congressional Temperance Society having recommended to the ministers, churches, temperance organizations, and the humane, philanthropic and patriotic throughout the land, to hold simultaneous meetings in their localities on the 22d of February next, the birthday of WASHINGTON, and unite in the organization of temperance societies, based on the simple total abstinence pledge, and adopt means for the promotion of temperance principles;

There seemed to be an increased activity in real estate matters yesterday, if one might judge by the large attendence atthe Exchange Salesroom. It was occasioned by the prospect of the sale of a portion of the estate of the late Colonel JAMES HARRISON.

Rev. WILLIAM HOWELL TAYLOR was duly Installed as Pastor of the Greenpoint Presbyterian Church last evening in presence of a large congregation. The sermon was preached by Rev. J. T. WELLS, D. D., of Williamsburg.
Considerable unpleasant feeling has been created among the residents of Williamsbridge and its immediate vicinity in reference to the name of the place.

At the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday, the resignation of A. GRACIE KING, as a trustee of the Savings Institution for Morchants' Clerks, was accepted, and HENRY K. BOGERT elected to fill his place. BARTHOLD SCHLESINGER was elected a member of theo Chamber, and GEORGE W. LANE, whose time bad expired, was reelected a member of the Arbitration Committee.

RELIEF FOR SEAMEN. Mr. CHANDLER introduced a bill to reorganize the Marine Hospital service ;and to provide for sick and disabled seamen. Referred tod ;the Committee on Commerce.

We are informed that a letter has been received by a former citizen of Chester, who left for New-York a few days ago, from one of the survivors of the wrecked ram Triumph, (formerely the Atlanta,) stating that the vessel struck a rock near the coast of Cuba, and sunk; but that the white persons, officers and others on board, escaped in boats.

The Academy of Music was filled last evening with one of the most fashionable and brilliant assemblages ever congregated within that building, the occasion being the annual ball in aid of the Children's and Nursery Hospital, better known as the Charity Ball.

Mr. CALLAN, member of Parliament for Dundalk, announces his intention of demanding a Parliamentary investigation into the condition of the imprisoned Fenians ....Mr. LEFROY has resigned his seat in Parliament for Dublin University..... The steamer Eagle, which arrived at this port from Havana on Wednesday evening last, contained among its cargo twenty-one large bundles of pine planks or boards, each being marked with the letters M. M. D., the initials of the name of the person to whom they were consigned.

This library is now in the Second year of its existence, and has become a fixed institution. It was organized by a number of residents at Washington Heights in 1868, and started at first on a small scale. By purchase and donations the number of volumes on its shelves has increased to over 1,000, besides having attached to it a small reading room, containing the daily papers and choice periodicals.
A meeting was held yesterday at the office of Mr. ISAAC H. BAILEY to pay proper respect to the memory of the late RICHARD STOUT, one of the old leather and hide merchants of the Swamp.

A mass meeting of piano makers was held last night at No. 10 Stanton-street. The object of the meeting was to discuss the propriety of agreeing to the terms of STEIN WAY SONS, who are willing to pay all branches of the trade, except the bellymen, at a rate only about one per cent less than the old rate.

Those who know NIXON, the murdere of SISCO, at Bloomingdale, N. J., are loud in their denumciation of him and his past life. He is accused of having once, i company with a brother, planned the murder of their father, a plot which the suspicisions of the latter prevented them from carrying into effect.

Yesterday the Convention of delegates from the associations throughout the United States met at 2 o'clock P.M. for the purpose of receiving the report of the Committee on Rules and Regulations. The latter being unprepared to report a postponement until 7:30 P.M. was taken. On reassembling at that hour,

The Senate to-day passed a resolution to go into joint election on the 10th inst. for a Regent of the University, to take the place of Mr. LUCKEY, deceased, and also for a Police Commissioner for New-York, in place of Judge BOSWORTH, whose term expires. Several bills of local importance only were read a third time and passed.

At a cancus of the Plice Justices on Tuesday, at which all were present except Justices DOWLING and BIXBY , a resolution was adopted praying that the Legislature repeal the Special Sessions act. In the interest of a proper administration of criminal justice, we trust that the Legislature will not listen to the recommendation.

American credit has not been so high in England for many years as now. The large amounts of bonds recently purchased are not on speculation, but for permanent investments, and the entire debt could be placed here, and its entire interest paid here, if it were for the interest of America to become tributary to that extent to English capitalists.

MORRIS S. HILL, formerly cashier of the Farmers' and Drovers' Bank, of Somers, Westchester County, appeared in the United States Commissioner's office, yesterday, in custody of a Deputy Marshal. A charge was made against him of having embezzled the funds of the Bank to the amount of at least $30,000 at various times during 1867, 1868 and 1869.

The labor reform members of the Massachusetts Legislature have united in a resolution to confine themselves in tile Legislature solely to matters pertaining to labor reform and not to become involved as a party in the question of woman suffrage or other doubtful measures....

PUEILO'S campaign has turned out a partial failure. The results expected from it have not been obtained, and JORDAN made such a stubborn resistance, that even the official Gaceta is compelled toacknowledge a gret many killed and wounded.

The Convention reassembled yesterday at 12 M., at the Everett House, for the purpose of receiving the report of the committee appointed to draw up the code of rules and regulations for the government of trotting. The President, after calling the meeting to order, inquired if the Committee were prepared to report.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate the resolutions of a recent meeting at the Cooper Institute, New-York, sympathizing with the people of Cuba, and asking that they be accorded belligerent rights; which were referred to the Committee on Federal Relations and ordered to be printed.

An immrnse concource of people attended the turnel servises of ANTHONY, WARREN nand JOHN WYBLE,at the Wynockle Methodist Church, yesterday morning. Every resident for miles around truned out to see the dead children, and testify by their presence their sympathy for the bereaved parents.

At 7:30 o'clock last evening a fire broke out on the fourth floor of No. 94 Bowery, occupied by MEYERS DEMUTH, cigar manufacturers. The whole loss is estimated at $1,000. MORRIS O'BRIEN, dealer in fringes and tassels, who occupied the second and fifth floors, suffered in the same amount;

A project is on foot to establish direct steam communication with New-York.... The schooner Morning Star, formerly the Grapeshot, has been seized on the suit of some New-York merchants. ....The case of the schooner Lehave has been decided.

The following additional changes were made yesterday in the Appraiser's office, in accordance with orders from Washington:- Dr. Headley, appointed Assistant Appraiser, vice Dr. O. S. Bartles, removed; J. R. Vanvechten, appointed Examiner, at $2,500, vice H. M. Graham, removed.

A dispatch from Rome says the Pope will hereafter decline to hold any controversy respecting the dogma of personal infallibility. The death of another Archbishop, and the serious illness of the Archbishop of Lyons, are announced. The Council now consists of 760 members.

At a meeting of the Board of Police Commissionors, yesterday, an order was entered suspending the payment of the pension of IRA C. GARDNER, who is under arrest for alleged complicity in causing the death of JOHN ALEXANDER, the aged sea Captain, which ease is being investigated by Coroner FLYNN.

Policeman SMITH tells us of a singular act porpetrated by a small dog of the common car species, owned by a family on the southside. The dog and a cat had been brought up together and affliated better than cats and dogs generally do, A week ago the cat sickened and died.

The Exchange rooms were very quiet yesterday. A single Supreme Court sale took place, WM. R. ROBERTS acting as auctioneer. The property was situated on Avenue A, between Second and Third streets, and was struck down at $20,500, but the purchaser not being prepared to comply wth the terms of sale, it was again put up and sold for $18.400. The announcements for the coming week indicate an increased activity in the public sales.

This is, undoubtedly, the greatest tournament which has yet taken place in the United States, excepting, of course, the Chess Congress, held in New-York in 1868, in which the celebrated players PAUL MORPHY and L. GILBERY, F. PERRIN and J. MASON.

A young lady of our acquaintance took it into her head the other day that she was a line cook-and particularly apt at making coffee; and she boasted of her accomplishments so far that she presently invited some of her beaux to come and spend the evening.

At the meeting of the National Board on Fire Underwriters at No. 156 Broadway yesterday, Mr. SAVAGE, of this City, made a motion that a Committee of seven be appointed to obtain signatures to the resolutions and obligation adopted Thursday.

Santiago being a Chili town, ought to be a nice burg. "Reddy the Blacksmith" took his punch on the outside of his head and succumbed.--Ex. Dr. CHARLES COTTON, one of the oldest and best physicians of Newport, R. I., died on Wednesday, aged 81 years.

About 7:30 o'clock last evening, as Captain EDWARD CORDELL, of the United States Coast Survey, was walking down Pinc-street from Kearny, he suddenly fell down on the sidewalk, striking upon his face and receiving a cut over the left eye.

But grave Senators set out on a hunt for excuses for continuing it, and continue it they will, probaably, in one shape or another.

The people in all parts of Brooklyn are becoming justly alarmed as to the safety of their property, Thieves are becoming bold in the commission of their nefarious transactions. Speaking operations are coming to be of daily occurrence.
The funeral of ex-Judge JAMES MONCRIEF, of the Superior Court, took place yesterday at the Dutch Reformed Church, Washington-- square, at 10 A. M. The paster, Rev. Dr. HUTTON, officiated.
A collection of books and manuscripts was sold by BANGS, MERWIN Co. yesterday afternoon, which comprised some works not often met with. Among them were a curious book of curicatures

A shoddy factory in Templeton, Mass., owned by J. C. HILL Co., was entirely destroyed by fire last night. The loss was $40,000 which is partially covered by insurance. POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 4.-The steamboat Connecticut was at New-Baltimore at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, with instructions to puch through to Troy. It is thought she will not be able to get through. She is in new ice three inches thick.

Crosby's Opera House, the pride and glory of Chicago, met with a narrow escape from destruction by fire last night. At one time it seemed as if it were really doomed; but, through the energy and prompt action of our noble Fire Brigade, the noble edifice was finally saved to the city.

Two weeks from to-day the third session of the Parliment opens at Ottawa. Lively times are expected. The first two sessions were comparatively name. Important measures, it is true, were under consideration; but to the leading features of these the Opposition were committed equally with the Government.

The annual ladies' reception of the Union League Club is announced for Wednesday evening, the 16th inst. BINNS.--On Thursday, Feb.3, after a severe illness, WILLIAM BINNS, in the 64 the year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 139 East 15th-st., on Monday, 7th inst., at 1 o' clock.

There is to be seen in the shop for the manufacture of agricultural implements, in the State Prison at Jackson, a very rare and ingenious piece of mechanism. It is a turning lathe, which turns sticks of variable thickness and of any degree of crookedness short of a double bow knot.

Judge LEAUMONT, of the Fifth District Court, decided Monday morning that the Legislature could not order the collection of the State taxes and revenues in any other currency than the lawful currency of the United States, and issued an order, directed to the proper officers, directing them hereafter to see that the taxes and revenues are so collected.

Messrs. DEERY and DION last night played their third game at billiards, for a purse of $2,000, game 1,500 points, four ball-carom, on a four-pocket table, push shots and crotch barred. There were eighty-three innings, resulting for DEERY 1,502 points, and for DION 1,044 points. DEERY'S highest run was 231 and DION'S 120 points.

The Prince and his suite left the Brevoort House for a horseback ride yesterday morning. Their route extended to the Central Park, and included Lexington-avenue, Third-avenue and Broadway, among other streets. The party returned shortly after 12 o'clock to take lunch, at which Mr. and Mrs. THORNTON and Mr. AROHIBALD were present.

A riot occurred at Brookville, Miss., on the 29th ult, between negroes and whites, growing out of the shooting and wounding by a youth, named FARMER, of a negro who had assaulted him, which at one time threatened to involve the whole section in strife and bloodshed.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5.--In a street quarrel in St. Joseph, night before last, between several parties, MICHAEL CULLIGAN was shot by H. L. CHURCH, and died soon after. CHURCH, who is a conductor on the St. Joseph and Council Bluffs Railroad, gave himself up and was committed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 5.--The Red River New Nation gives a long account of a meeting held at Fort Garry on Jan. 1, which was addressed by DONALD G. SMITH, who explained his mission and the policy of the Canadian Government.

Internal Revenue Detective COWLAN reports to Commissioner DELANO, under date of Augusta, Jan, 31, having made a very successful raid in the Fourth District of Georgia. The expedition was composed of a number of Assistant Assessors and Deputy Collectors.

The tales that have been told and that might be written about the work and the wages of working women are enough, it would seem, to shake the community to its centre to devise means for the improvement of their social condition.

At a very agreeable entertainment given to the Brooklyn chess amateurs by one of their number, and at which some line classical music was a prominent feature, and lent variety to the proceedings, the following interesting consultation game was played, Messrs. BRENZINGER, MARACHE and RICE being opposed to Messrs. MACKENZIE, DELMAR and BARNET:

Ex-Postmastor-General A. W. Randall and Hon. S. C. Pomeroy, of Washington; Hon. Lyman Klapp, of Providence, and Hon. Samuel Waller, of Seneca Falls, are at the Astor House. Governor John T. Hoffman, of New-York, is at the Clarendon Hotel.

The people of California, since the earthquakes of 1868, have a great dread of recurring shocks, and, as an indication of this wholesome fear and a desire to prevent loss of life, we have intelligence from San Francisco that the Roman Catholics are building there an "earthquakeproof church." This edifice-St. Patrick's

BOSTWICK.-Suddenly, in Brooklyn, on Friday, Feb. 4, OLIVER N. BOSTWICK, aged 54 years, 1 month and 16 days. His remains were interred in Green-Wood Cemetery. BINNEY.--At Philadelphia, on Thursday, Feb. 3, HORACE BINNEY, Jr., aged 61 years. The funeral services will be held at the Church of St. James the Less, on Monday, Feb. 7, at 11 A. M.

Last evening Marion Division No. 34. S. of T., of this City, celebrated its anniversary at Stemway Hall in the presence of an audience of fair proportions. G. W. P. STEPHEN MARRITT, Jr., presided, and the members of the Division--laides and gentlemen--occupied the platform with him, making a creditable appearance.

Prince ARTHUR loft this City for Boston on the 3 o'clock train yesterday afternoon, accompanied by Colonel ELPHISTONE and Lieutenants FITZROY and PICARD. The royal party will be present at the funeral ceremonies of the late Mr. PEABODY, at South Danvers. on Tuesday, after which they are to start for Canada. Yesterday morning the Prince made no visits whatever, his time being altogether taken up with preparations for his intended eastward trip. Mr.

The Turnvereins of this country are associations devoted to the practice of German gymnastics. The members are nearly all Germans. Their exercises are designed to develop the musenlar power of the members to the fullest extent, thus giving a systematic training to the whole body.

CrrY OF MEXICO, Feb. 1, via HAVANA, Feb. 5.-An attempt by the troops to assassinate LERDO DE TEJADA and proclaim SANTA ANNA has been discovered here and frustrated. The ringleaders were arrested and lodged in prison....It is believed that General NEGRETE is concealed in this city working in favor of SANTA ANNA.....Order has been restored in Puebla....The authorities in Michoacan are arming troops.

The experience of the last twenty years has relieved all conductors of the public Press from the burden of discussing the details of any character which the Legislature at Albany takes it into its head to bestow on this City.

The people of Brooklyn, probably in view of the mysterious and bold operations of tile Ring politicians and officials at the City Hall and Court House, appear to be tardy in settling their tax bills. We have received an advance copy of the London Quarterly Review, from Mr. MURRAY, the London publisher, containing the reply to Mrs. STOWE'S Vindication. This gives so much new and strong testimony to prove Mrs. STOWE'S astonishing charges unfounded, that we reproduce the greater portion of it, although indisposed to continue the discussion of this unpleasant topic. The Quarterly article opens:

MARSEILLES, Feb. 5.--Considerable excitement was occasioned in this city this morning by the falling of two houses with a tremendous crash. Twelve persons were buried in the ruins, but it is not thought all were killed.

GENERAL ORDERS NO. 1.-In accordance with General Orders No. 11, dated Headquarters of the Army, Adjutant-General's Office, Jan. 29, 1870, the undersigned hereby assumes command of the Department of Virginia, embracing the States of Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and North Carolina.

BAYARD TAYLOR delivered the fifth of the series of lectures for the benefit of the fund for the relief of disabled soldiers and sailors, last evening, at Irving Hall, before a large and appreciative audience, on the subject of "Life in Europe and in America."
The mystery attending the unprovoked and inhuman murder of Mr. CHARLES ROGERS in Twelfth-street, on the morning of the 30th of December, 1868, has furnished its full share of sensation and doubt.

A popular drama and a novelist of celebrity have recently directed attention to the marvelous obstructiveness of the English Patent system. Although there is less of what is known as red-tape here than in older countries, it must be admitted that we are not without instances of its absurdities.

Decidedly the weekly meetings of the Women's Suffrage Association are losing their attractions and interest. Is it because they are confined too closely to the question, or has the barnlike nature of their place of meeting something to do with the cold chill that has come over the frequenters of former meetings?

PUERTO CABELLO, Jan. 24.--The revolution is spreading, President MONAGNS has taken the field in person....The banished Dominicans have arrived here. SAN DOMINGO, Jan. 20.--The revolutionists, headed by PIMENTAL, are marching northwest. They have captured Guayubin.

The Climate and soil of California are so diversified that every variety of fruit found on the Atlantic shore between Maine and Florida may here be found in our State alone. All the different kinds of apples, plums, cherries, currants and gooseberries peculiar to the North are common here; so also are the almost tropical oranges, olives, flgs, lemons and pomegranates.

The old story comes from Mexico again, "the situation grows worse every day." It has been " growing worse" so long that it seems very much like a chronic affair, whereof the patient is wondrously long in dying.

The Orphans' Home and Asylum of the Protestant Episcopal Church of this City has just published its annual report, and gives a good account of the work done during the past year. This institution, which is located on Forty-ninth-street, between Fourth and Lexington avenues, has been in existence ten years, and has constantly increased in efficiency under the thoughtful management of the ladies who have it in charge.

FEB. 5--In steamship City of London, for Liverpool,--M. Joseph, C. E. Granes, W. E. Harvard, A. H. Kling, Mr. White, Frederick M. Morehead, Joseph Chadwick, L. B. Spencer, Robt. Sedgewick, Mr. Tibbitts, Thos. Irving, S. Lawrent, Wm. C. Davids, John Hayes, Geo. L. Marsden, Rich. Mansfield, Fred. Norman, Geo. Tate, Jas. Clinton, Jas. Ward, Jas. Ritcine.

Last evening three burglars forced their way into the office of JOHN HEITNER, diamond broker, on the second floor of No. 615 Broadway, and proceeded to drill a hole in the safe. They then filled the aperture with powder and affixed a fuse preparatory to blowing the safe open.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. C. ROSENBERG, in a letter published in the TIMES of the 31st ult., says he demurs to my self-sufficient auility. What that may mean I don't know. For a professional critic it is a very vague phrase.

Paris is living in a fever of delicious novelty. Each day has its now political event, its cause celebre, or its opigram. the leaden uniformity of the Empire seems already as old as Louis Quatorze, and with pulses bounding in the new life of freedom, the gay, volatile and good-humored capital revels amid fresh-coming sensations, and from each succeeding day demands its tribute of surprise.

BOSTON, Feb. 5.--The following is the order of exercises arranged for the funeral of the late GEORGE PEABODY, which is to take place on Tuesday next at 11 o'clock: Sacred music by a select chair under Professor WILLCOX.

Wall, Broad and New streets have another sensation, and this time one in which the feeling is unanimous and opinions are not divided. Two women, named respectively Mrs. TENNESSEE CLAFLIN and Mrs. WOODHULL, have leased the offices No. 44 Broad-street, formerly occupied by GRAY, who lately swindled various parties in the street out of $300,000, and have established themselves in business as stock brokers.
No new play and no important revival of an old one has called for notice this week, unless we except the production of "Masantello," on Friday,

An interesting experiment as to the merits of a patent railway safety stove took place at the car factory of Mr. CUMMINGS, in Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. The patentees of the invention are Messrs. E. M. GRANT Co. The experiments was regarded as a very successful one.

The Second Church, Indianapolis, once under H. BEECHER'S care, has built a new house costing over $100,000. A Benedictine monk of Nuremberg, has recently joined the Lutheran Church. The Episcopalians support some twenty-five papers and periodicals, having an aggregate circulation of about 128,000 copies.

There are 350 American families in Dresden. An Englishman has constructed a perfect steam engine so small that it will stand on a threepenny piece. A forty-days' trip from London to Egypt, Suez Canal and Palestine costs forty guineas.

The movement for introducing the teaching of the German language as a branch of our common school education is deserving of support on various grounds. The most obvious argument in its favor is the fact that the German portion of our citizens is a large, an influential and a steadily-increasing one. Furnishing a proportionate share of the

The investigation into the affairs of the life insurance companies, which was to have been commenced in this City yesterday, by the Insurance Committee of the Legislature, was postponed on account of the death of the wife of Mr. MADDOX, one of the members of the Committee.

The steamship Cimbria, which left Hamburg Jan. 19 and Havre Jan. 23, and the Nemesis, from Liverpool Jan. 22 and Queenstown Jan. 23, reached this port yesterday, the Cimbria at an early hour in the morning. The news is later by two days than that already at hand, and for that containing the freshest Continental intelligence we are indebted to the courtesy of Captain HAACK, of the Cimbria.

Commodore JAS. TAFFE has, been detached from the command of the Saugus and placed on waiting orders. Lieutenant-Commander SULLIVAN G. AMES is detached from the Boston Navy Yard and ordered to the Naval Academy. Lieutenant-Commander A . T. KELLOGG is detached from the Hydropathie Office and ordered to the Naval Academy.

An excellent full-length portrait of General Louis Burger, commanding the Second Brigade, is now on exhibition at Browne Spaulding's jewelry store, Broadway. The portrait has been handsomely framed, and is intended as a gift to the Brigadier, from the members of his staff.
The publication of the additional particulars of the alleged frauds on the Newark Treasury, caused a greater excitement, if possible, than the original statement published in these columns on Friday.

THE LAW COURTS FOR FEBRUARY. During tins month an Oyer and Terminer will be held by Judge INGRAHAM in connection with the Supreme Court Circuit, Part I. By order of the presiding Judge, no Circuit Calendar has boon made out for the first Monday, hence the presumption is that for the first days of the term criminal business only will be taken up.
