WASINGTON, Feb. 5.-Only one branch of Congress, the House, was in session to-day, and the proceedings there were purely of the buncombo order, the meeting having been entirely for speechmaking and not for business.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5.--The Golden Gate Iron Works were burned this morning....A slight shock of earthquake at San Francisco and vicinity was felt yesterday....The branch mint at carson City. Nev., commenced operations yesterday, coining only silver dollars... Trouble is threatened at the Ely Silver Mines, Nevada; parties jumped the Panoche Mine.

O come at last, to whom the Spring-tide's hope Looked for through blossoms, what hast thou for me Green grows upon the dewy slope Beneath thy gold-hung, gray-leaved apple tree Moveless, e'n as the Autumn fain would be That shades its sad eyes from the rising be And Weeps at eve because the day is done.
Amongst the many delusions to which young people are subject, that of believing that they can pass by a royal road to artistic eminence is a common and mischievous one.

The Constitutional Convention is making some progress; but there seems to be on the part of the members an inadequate notion of what they were chosen to do. Consequently all sorts of propositions are brought forward, and the action seems more like that of a Board of Supervisors than of a body engaged upon the organic law of a great State.

HALIFAX, Feb. 5.--The papers report that at a meeting held at Merigomisk, in Pietou County, a resolution was passed declaring that the Confederation is a failure, and urging the local Legislature to move for annexation to the United States....A Union Association has been formed in Prince Edward's Island. Hon. T. H.

Yesterday afternoon Dr. JOHN H. GRISCOM lectured at Grammar School No. 47, on "The Relation of the Atmosphere to Life and Health." After giving a brief statement of the uses of air and food in sustaining life, Dr. GRISCOM spoke of the importance of pure air and of the manner in which we breathe, illustrating his statements by models of the lungs.

Yesterday the examination in the case of NORRIS LOZEE, recently arrested on a charge of committing whisky frauds, was adjourned until Tuesday, in consequence of the absence of the Government witnesses.

FEB. 5--In steamship Pennsylvania, from Liverpool.--Mr. Carnelly, Mrs. Jones, Mrs. Oaksmith, Miss. Coyne, Rev. D. O'Brien. FEB. 5--In steamship Cimbria, from Hamburg.--Julius Goetz, E. Milberg, C. Vallmann, H. Pastors, A. Weinberg, George Marous, Dr. Stogmann, Mrs. C. Stedenberg, H. Edye, J. Mendelk, J. F. Rehfeld, R. Frosberg.
DENVER, Col., Feb. 5.--The remaining $1,500,000 of the Denver and Pacific Railroad bonds were sold in London Feb. 3. The sale was reported by cable telegram yesterday, and caused great rejoicing.

The Mining Press says a German scientist. has recently created a considerable sensation by the publication of a pamphlet, in which he takes the ground that the zodiacal light proceeds from a gaseous ring surrounding the earth at a distance of only a few thousand mile from Its surface. BOSTON, Feb. 5.--The large machine shop in Milford, Mass., owned by MACY ELDRIDGE, and occupied by E. A. ALBEE, was burned last night. Loss $30,000; no insurance...SARGENT'S wheel manufactory in West Amesbury was burned last night, with three buildings adjoining. The loss was $40,000, and the insurance $12,000.

A choice collection of oil paintings by native artists, the property of Mr. JOHN P. WATERS, of Brooklyn, is on exhibition at the Art Galleries of LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co., Clinton Hall. Among the paintings we find seven by S. R. Gifford; five by J. F. Kensett, and two by Wm. Whittredge, with examples by Durand Lang, Eastman Johnson, Loop, Yewell, Robbe Troyon, Nebg, Scheeres, Diaz, Ziem, Veyrassat and Geniz.

About 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred in the three-story brick building. No. 25 Walker-street, originating on the top floor, occupied by ASHER REDDICK, manufactures of waterfalls and switches. The fire gamed such headway that before it could be extinguished the entire stock, valued at $3,000, was totally consumed. It was, however, fully insured.

The great hall of the Cooper Union was well filled last evening by a respectable audi ence, for the purpose of hearing the readings and recitations given by members of the Phona Reading Club, under the direction of Professor J. S. FROBISHER. It was one of a series of free enter-

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5.--The bill to regulate the compensation of teachers has been amended by the lower branch of the Legislature so as to give females the same pay as males where equally qualified and performing like duties.

THEODORE NICHLAS was on Friday conwicted in the Cattarangns Court of Oyer and Terminer of the murder of Dr. ANDREW MEAD, in Allegbany, on the 18th of December last. He was sentenced yesterday morning to be hauged on the 18th of next March. This is the second conviction for murder during this term of the Court.

There were numerous fires yesterday evening in various parts of the City, none of which, however, resulted in very serious loss. The first was at 5:30 P. M., in the dwelling No. 9 Mulberrystreet, caused by the soot In the chimney taking fire from a spark; the damage was slight. The next alarm was at 5:?? P. M., for a fire in the rear basement of the tenement house, No.. 706

A descent was made by the Police officers yesterday afternoon on the gambling houses here. Some fifteen places were visited. Owing to the bungling manner in which the affair was conducted only one arrest was made, but considerable property in the shape of roulette tables, , was captured.

Steamship Rhein, (N. G.,) Meyer, Bremen Jan. 22, vin Southampton 25th, with and and 183 passengers to Oelrichs Co. Experienced , during the passage, strong westerly storms until the 4th of February. Steamship Pioneer,(of Liverpool, Shackford, Havana 7 ds., with sugar to Snow Burgess.
The Connecticut Republican State Convention is to be held in Hartford on Wednesday. It pays better to be a Philadelphia Alderman than a Judge of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.

The reassembling of the Virginia Legislature, on the 8th inst., is awaited with much interest. Advices received from Richmond to-night are to the effect that quite a number of members have already arrived. It is learned that Governor WALKER will not send his Message to the Legislature until Wednesday, the 9th.

The steamship Rhcin, which left Bremen Jan. 23, and Southmpton Jan. 25, reached this port yesterday. The news thus at band is later by two days than that received Saturday by the Nemesis. The death is announced of M. MULELER, Bishop of Munster, at the age of 71.

"The Woman's Union Missionary Society of America for Heathen Lands" held its anniversary meeting last evening, at the Reformed Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, which was attended by a very full congregation. This Society is composed of ladies connected with six different Evangelical denominations in this City and Brooklyn, viz.:

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

To the writer's strong sympathy, amounting to enthusiasm, for the character of ALFRED, as well as to a desire to get from the story of his life, its full modern interpretation, we owe this elaborate portrait of one who, perhaps, approached as far as human frailty allows, to the perfect model of a true patriot, a just legislator and a good monarch.

For some time past there has been a discussion quietly going on among a large portion of the leading members of Plymouth Church in regard to the covenants and articles of faith to which all who are admitted to membership are required to subscribe.

The regular monthly meeting of the St. Xavier Alumni Sodality was held yesterday afternoon at their rooms. St. Zavier College, Fifteenth street. The Society was established in 1863, and is a branch of a similar society organized at Rome upwards of three hundred years ago, which has since spread itself over the entire Christian world.

On Saturday the case of NIMMO, the Flashing village Clerk, came before Justices PARCESSES and McKENNA, of Newtown, at the Town Hall, Flushing. It will be remembered that this is the suit growing out of the Flushing contested election case.

The German satirical journal, Kladderadatch, furnishes in a very suggestive drawing a key to the present situation in Austria. The dominion of the Kaiser is personified by a young and buxom damsel, whose left arm is in the grasp of Count BEUST;

On Friday of last week, the Collector of the town of Paris, Oncida County, attempted to attach and hold the morning passenger and mail train on the Utica, Chonango and Susuehanna Valley Railroad, at Clayville, to satisfy an assessment for taxes which the Company refused to pay. The attempt failed, as did a similar one on Friday evening.

The New-Yorker Demokrat (German Republican organ) points out that the choice of the Administration must be made between a tendency to increase and another to diminsh expenditure. It maintains that the Repulican majority cannot fail to adopt the latter course without forfeiting the confidence which the people at present repose in them.

The amendments to the Charter of Jersey City--which, when the act of consolidation goes into effect upon the 1st of April, will comprise the cities of Bergen, Hudson City and Jersey City--have been partially completed by the joint committee appointed by the Common Councils of the three cities.

Since the original purchase of the Hempstead Plain lands by A. T. STEWART, comprising 7,000 acres, he has made an addition thereto of 1,000 acres of private lands adjoining, paying therefore from $250 to $400 per acre, and now owns in one compact and symmetrical tract 8,000 acres of level laud,

There appears to be much more truth in the expression to which the murderer REYNOLDS has given utterance, "Hanging for murder is played out," than one at first is willing to suppose. For example, JAMES SPALLON, in Tremont, charged with brutally murdering PATRICK BROPHY, on the 2d of January last.

Yesterday morning Rev. JOHN J. BROUNER. pastor of the North Baptist Church, in Christopher-street, preached his first annual discourse to his people. A large congregation was present, the galleries being occupied by the Sabbath School.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: For several daysI have noticed in your paper various references to a movement of the Bar of this City, on which you seem to hang a hope ot the reformation not only of the Bench but of the Bar themselves.

To the Editor of he New-York Times: Having read your article headed "Effects of the Bankrupt Act," I Wish to correct some of your statements, which, in the main, are incorrect only because you have no opportunity to judge from experience.

The funeral services of Miss MTAHILDE WHTTMAN, who was fatally burned upon the stage of Mrs. CONWAY'S Park Theatre some weeks ago, were held yesterday afternoon in the Sandsstreet M. E. Church, Brooklyn, with the Sabbath School of which the deceased had been connected.

The exposure made in these columns of the alleged frauds upon the city treasury of Newark, and the false denials of their existence made by the city officials, have become the theme of excited comment throughout that city, and a large portion of the community are disposed to echo the demand of a leading local paper for a prompt and vigorous investigation by the Common Council.

Services were held last evening in the Chanel of St. Chrysostom, corner of Seventh-avenue and Thirty-ninth street, the collection at which was in and of the Free Reading Room (Episcopal,) now being established at No. 1,155 Broadway. The sermon was preached by Rev.

It is estimated that the pension service of the coming fiscal year will demand an appropriation of thirty million dollars. Each succeeding year the rolls have grown in size and expensiveness. With the death of BAKEMAN, last year, the lastRovolutionary pensioner was stricken from the lists;

Last evening Rev. Dr. ALEX. R. THOMPSON preached at the St. Paul's Reformed Datch Church in Forty-second-street, taking for his text the ninth yerse of the fourteenth chapter of Romans: "For to this end Christ both died and rose again, and was revived that he might became the law of the dead and of the living."

The third carnival of the Comus, a German festive organization recently formed, was held last evening in the Germania Assembly Rooms. The hilarity was inagurated by the entrance of a procession costumed as Turks and typical of the opening of the Suez Canal. The members of this procession afterwards directed the festivities, forming a burlesque Ecumenical Council,

"Eternally Lost" was the theme upon which Rev. J. M. PULLMAN discoursed at the Church of Our Saviour, Sixth Universalist, Thirty-fifth-street, near Sixth-aveune, at the morning service yesterday. He took his text from the seventh verse of the 139th Psalm.

Rev. Dr. ELTON died in this city yesterday after a short illness. He graduated at Brown University in 1813, subsequently founded two scholarships in that institution, and for several years was pastor of a Baptist Church in Windsor, Conn. Prince ARTHUR and Minister THORNTON at tended Trinity Church this forenoon.

The Mormon Mission is being pushed forward with all the vigor and energy possessed by its leaders in the vicinity of Freeport, Patehogue, Rockville Centre and Hempstead. During the carller part of the week the most favorable accounts of General BURTON'S work reached the Saints in wiliamsburg, but their later enterprises in the neighborhood of Riverhead have not been crowned with the anticipated success.

The new issues of ten-dollar bills, United States currency, attract very general attention by their resemblance to well gotten up "drug bottle labels." Holding one of these bills up to sunlight there will be perceived running through the tissue of the paper little lines which look like very fine threads.

Never since the commencement of actual secession, ten years age, at which time there were thirty-four states in the American Union, has the Senate Chamber of the United States presented a phalanx so respectable in numbers as at present. There States only remain unrepresented--Georgia, Texas and Mississippi.

The Promoters of the Paris organization for the construction of a canal across the Isthmus of Darien seem to be in earnest. A Cable dispatch tells us that General HEINE started on Saturday with the view of conducting explorations in the interest of the company.

The election of a negro to the Supreme Benell of South Carolina is an event of no ordinary significance. For several weeks it has been settled that the vacancy caused by the election of Judge HOGK to Congress--the vacancy on the bench of the Supreme Court of the State-should be filled by a negro. That race demanded it, and the party had no alternative but to concede it.

Matters are improving slightly in the real estate market, if we may judge from the auction sales and the recorded transfers of the past week. The transfers, of course, have reference to transactions which occurred at a somewhat earlier date. The number reported during the week just past is 178, involving values to the amount of $4,297,741.

Another political speaker, GUSTAVE FLOURENS, is also to be prosecuted for language used at a political meeting. M. LE VERUIER,

On the 2d inst., MAY CARLTON, a native of England, 45 years of age, was committed to the workhouse, Blackwell's Island, for ten days, by Justice SCOTT, of the Essex Market Police Court. Yesterday Coroner KEENAN was notified that she had committed suicide by suffocation, by thrusting two " tallies" down her throat.

Calvary Chapel, being a part of the new wing of the Five Points House of Industry--now Nos. 151 to 159 Worth-street-is to be dedicated to day under the joint auspices of the House of Industry and the City Mission.

Representative HAMILTON, of Florida, has received the following dispatch from Governor REED: TALLAJASSEE, Fla., Feb. 5, 1870.--Impeachment defeated, and my administration sustained by a vote of two-thirds, BILLINGS and MOBLEY, and the entire Federal official force fought to the last upon the side of the Democrats.

A temperance meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the Methodist Protestant Church, in Attorney-street. The body of the house was tilled by an attentive audience. The pastor, Rev. Mr. ELLISON, Colonel WILLIAMSON. Rev. Mr. JONES, of Elizabeth-street Mission, and others addressed the meeting.

A setter announces that he defeated the rebels and captured two pieces of artillery and many priseners 01 age, is among the captured prisioners....Seven, houses and several sugar fields have theen destroyed by inesndaries on the line of the Romcdios, and Caibarien Railroad....

THEODORE GREENWALD and JOSEPH DROLL, who live at No. 14 Rose-Street, were yesterday committed by Justice DOWLING for suspected complicity in a burglary committed on the 5th of November, 1868. During the night of that day ivory goods store of PETER TOTANS, No. 80 Fulton-street, was entered by burglars through a window opening upon the rear yard. and a quantity of billiard balls and checks, valued $606, carried away.

The grand temperance meeting held last evening in the large-hull of the Cooper Union, under the auspices of the Sons of Temperature was well attended. At 9:30 o' clock the proceedings were opened by the Chairman, Rev. STEPHEN MERRITT, Jr., G. W. P. S. T., who introduced the Marion Glee Club, by the whom was sung the "Odo to the Sons of Temperance."

Captain JOURDAN. with a squad of his command, on Saturday night made a foray upon the disreputable saloon No. 63 Leonard-street, kept by JOHN LOFTUS and ANDREW LARKINS, both of whom were arrested, together with a large number of the male and female frequenters and inmates of the don.

The Mamzer Carnival Society held a special session last night at their headquarters, in Orchard-street. This is the oldest carnival society in the United States, and its previous reputaton was fully sustained in last night's carnival. The affair was more democratic than the uptown carnivals. The fun was fast and furious, and nothing occurred to mar the harmony of the evening.

Rev. Dr. THOMPSON preached last evening at the Broadway Tabernacle, corner of Broadway and Thirty-fourth-street, on the subject, "Shall the State be Taxed to Support the Roman Catholic or any Sect?" before one of the largest audiences over assembled within its walls.

The Funding bill reported to the Senate f last week is not the bill drafted by the Secretary of the Treasury, which was in fewer sections and related exclusively to the refunding of Five-twenties; but the bill of the majority of the Finance Committee, embracing other sections not pertinent to funding.

The Tribune, in an editorial on the losses sustained by grain-raising farmers during the past year, says: "They have found partial compensation in the high prices realized for hogs, the receipts from this crop having saved many of them from bankruptcy.

"Masaniello" is to be sung at the Academy of Music to-night. "School" will be given at Wallack's for the first time this season. At the Grand Opera House "The Twelve Temptations" are to be spectacularly represented. A burlesque called "Faust" is advertised for production at Wood's. "Genevieve do Brabant: Succeeds "La Grande Duchesse" at the Theatre Franeais,

We publish in another column a letter from a correspondent who criticises some of our remarks with reference to the Bankruptcy law. He thinks that our statement that assignments with preferences are things of the past, is incorrect, but gives us no facts to show that it is so.

A remarkable serum on this subject was delivered in this church yesterday by the Pastor, Rev, J. McMAHON. After reading a portion of the Gospel for the day, Father McMAHON proceeded to review in no very flattering terms the peculiarly corrupt tendencies of the political officeholders and party leaders of the present Line.

The Arbeiter Union (German Workingmen's Union) of this City held their second entertainment of the season at the Teutonia Assembly Rooms, Nos. 158 and 160 Third-avenue, last night, the large ball being crowded by workmen and their families. The first part of the programme consisted of an address, delivered by Mr. GUILLIAUME DRURY, on "The Present System of Capital and Labor."

A sermon was delivered by Rev. Dr. MORGAN DIX, at Zion Episcopal church, corner of Thirty--eight--street and Madison-avenue, last evening, for the benefit of the Midnight Mission, He said there were plenty of texts which he could take from the Bible for his subject, but he should elite that of the Midnight Mission, as the one most likely to stir the hearts of his hearers.

The forenoon train coming north on the Utica, Chenango and Susquehanna Valley Railroad was uncoupled at Clayville this morning, and two passenger cars were seized by Collector DE GRAFF, of the town of Paris. A special train, carrying the President of the road, LEWIS LAWRENCE, and the Deputy United States Marshal, was also seized.

A bill is before the Legislature of Massachusetts for "fixing the qualifications of persons selling drugs and medicines." Before anybody can be employed in an apothecary's shop to make up prescriptions or sell drugs, he must have proved his qualifications before a Board of Examiners, or be a graduate of some College of Pharmacy.

The new chapel connected with the Five Points House of Industry was dedicated yesterday, with interesting and appropriate services, in the presence of an exceedingly large audience. As a full description of the building was published in the TIMES yesterday morning, it will be unnecessary to repeat the details. At the hour appointed the children marched

JOHN REYNOLDS, who murdered WILLIAM TOWNSEND, the Hudson-street grocer, is now manifesting a better feeling about his terrible crime than he has hither to betrayed. The effects of the liquor he had so constantly and recklessly imbibed the two or three weeks before he stabbed his victim have disappeared,

The sale of the Thompson collection of ancient and modern paintings, which for some weeks past has been on exhibition at the art gallery of Messrs. Henry H. Leeds Minor, No. 817 Broadway, was begun yesterday morning. The attendance was large, but the bidding was not at all spirited, and the price at which the works were disposed of was extremely low.

The World is pleased to see that General SLOCUM, whom it makes haste to announce as a "Democrat," has succeeded in calling the attention of Congress to the discreditable conduct of certain " greedy," but as yet unknown members, who make merchandise of cadetships at the Military Academy, West Point, and the Naval Academy, Annapolis.

A special dispatch to the Tribune gives the particulars of the recent alleged arrest of RIELLE at Red River, which was done by the Canadian loyalists under the influence of the Canadian Government. Fort Garry was garrisoned by a small guard at the time, but his adherents coming in squads,

There were no sales at the Exchange Salesrooms yesterday. Everything was very quiet. To-day, however, a great many houses and lots are advertised to be sold, and the indications of a busy day are numerous. Few people visited the Exchange Rooms yesterday as an anticipated a dull day.

Rev. ALFRED YOUNG delivered a lecture Sunday evening, before the Institute of St. Paul at its rooms, Eighth-avenue and Fifty-fourth-street, to an appreciative audience, the subject being the supposed Literary Observations of a Diamond Ring."

The Marscillaise (HENRI ROCHEFORT'S journal) appears this morning with a characteristic article over the signature of M. ROCHEFORT himself. Relative to the recent notice served upon him ordering him to deliver himself a prisoner, In obedience to the sentence of the Court, he declares boldly that he will not surrender himself, and that if the Ministers want him they must come and take him...

During tile last week or ten days four of the most high-handed highway robberies have been perpetrated in Queens County. They seemed to have cropped out in different sections nearly simultaneously. First we have the robbery and attempted murder of Mr. BERGEN, near the Plains; then the reported attack on a man in Hempstead; third, we find a village Marshal,

The following opinion was delivered in the Supreme Court to-day by Chief Justice CHASE. SUSAN P. HEPBURN and HENRY A. HEPBURN vs. HENRY A. GRISWOLD, in error to the Court of Appeals of the State of Kentucky:

At the opening of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, Judge BEDFORD rendered a decision in regard to a motion made by District-Attorney GARVIN for the transfer of the McFarland murder case to the Court of Oyer and Terminer for trial.

In steamship Henry, Chauncey, for Aspinwall.--For Aspinwall--H. Nathan, J. Brophy, Caxetano de Socarras, Captain W, M. Gampble. Levi Dexter, D. W. Sternberg, Miss Manuelila, Cldena, Captain A. W. McKenzic, Theodore M. Lee, Morris Minella, Thos. Lyons, E. Brophy, Jno. Murphy. For California--Joseph P. Hazard Mary P. Hazard, Gertunde M. Hazard. S. C. Pencoash, Mrs. Lester and 3 children,

The haunt at No. 273 Water-street, known as "Kit Burns' Rat Pit," which has been hired by Rev. WM. H. BOOLE of Mrs. BURNS, who owns the property, for a mission and a home for the reform of abandoned women, was yesterday dedicated to that purpose with religious services and appropriate addresses.

The Committee appointed by the State Assembly to take testimony on the subject of life insurance in this State, with a view to ascertaining whether any additional legislation is necessary thereon, held a session yesterday at the office of Mr. THOS. C. FIELDS, No. 115 Nassau-street.

The project of flanking Hell Gate by cutting a canal through Astoria has been brought before Congress by parties interested in the scheme, and the House of Representatives has passed a resolution asking for full information as to its feasibility,

Yesterday morning, about 11 O'clock, four Americans, ISAAC GREENWALL, HENRY K. FOSSER, HUGH JOHNSON and GARDNER WELLS, all of New-York, were on their way to visit a photograph gallery. The intended to have their pictures taken, and all wore blue neckties. Near the Tacon Theatre they were stopped by a man,

Events in this city and throughout the Territory of Utah for the past two weeks have been more than ordinarily interesting. The fact that Congress has before it two bills for the suppression of polygamy-one introduced into the Senate by Mr. CRAGIN, and one into tile House by Mr. CULLOM-has called forth a most unusual expression of opinion on this special legislation.

GEORGE M. WHARTON, a prominent lawyer of this city, died last evening....The funeral serviced of the late HORACE BINNEY, Jr., took place to-day. At a meeting of the bar this morning, chief justice THOMPSON Presiding, resolutions of respect were passed.

The ball of Manhattan Commandery No. 31, of Knights Templar Masons, of this City, took place last night at the Apollo Rooms in this City. The attendance was very large, and in the early part of the evening the number of guests was so great as to seriously interfere with the movement of the dancers.

A public meeting of citizens of Millburn, N. J., was held on Saturday, at which resolutions were adopted declaring that the condition and location of the Morris and Essex Railroad Station at that place was such as to endanger the lives of passengers and resulted recently in the death of Mr. THEODORE OVERMILLER,

When the Supreme Court affirmed the validity of contracts specifically payable in coin, entered into before the enactment of the Legal-tender law, it was evident that the decision indirectly affected the construction to be put upon all preexisting contracts.

Judge TROY yesterday delivered a charge to the Grand Jury of Kings County in the Court of Sessions. As much as it may be regretted, he said, there is no question that within the last few Winter months crime has increased with unprecedented rapidity. We hear, every day, accounts of burglaries, larcenies, the knife, the pistol.

HANNAH ROBINSON, a young Trenton girl, disappeared nearly two weeks ago under suspicious circumstances. On Sunday the body was found near the "Black Bridge," on the Assanpink River. Suspicions of foul play were excited by the statement of a man who was arrested a few days ago in Phlladelphia,

The following changes in the Custom House have taken place since Feb. 1: Clerk Assistant Collector's office, at $1,200 per annum, J. W. Robertson. Inspectors, at $4 per day--E. C. Dixson, vice R. H. Stoddard, removed; ?? Birdsall, vice J. H. Kellum, removed; Alex. Graham, vice G. W. Creighton, removed; O. M. Clauharty, vice Jno. Alden, removed.

PETER T. WASHBURN, Governor of Vermont, died at his residence in Woodstock at 4 o'clock this morning, after an illness of several weeks. His age was 55 years and 6 months. He was by profession a lawyer, and had been a good deal in public life,

Mr. J. L. A. WARBEN, who arrived per last English steamer from a trip of a year and a half through different portions of Europe, brings with him diplomas as honorary member correspondent of the Societies Entomologique and Malocologique of Belgium to the scientific societies of America.

Petitions favorable to an additional amendment to the Constitution, giving women the right to vote, were presented by Messrs. CONKLING and FENTON. GEORGIA. Mr. MORTON presented resolutions of the Georgia Legislature accepting the conditions recently imposed by Congress by changing the State Constitution, and also ratifying the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.

THE TWELVE TEMITATIONS. The Grand Opera House was densely crowded last night, and the heart of its enterprising owner must have leaped for joy. Rumor has for some time been busy in reporting the unheard-of splendors of the forthcoming spectacle, and really, in some respects, rumor has this time told no lies.

A largely-attended meeting of the parasol and umbrella makers at present on strike was held yesterday afternoon at the shop of Messrs. HALL BLACK, in Walker-street. Representaives from the shops of the manufacturers in which the girls have struck were present, and a very animated discussion of the questions at issue took place.

The German Ladies' Aid Society for indigent widows, orphans and sick persons of this City, held a monthly meeting at St. Mathew's Church, corner of Broome and Elizabeth streets. yesterday afternoon, Mrs. M. LIEBER presiding. Besides the regular business, the report of tile Society of last year was read and received.

The February Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer opened yesterday morning, and the following gentlemen were accepted as Grand Jurors: D. D. MARSHALL, Foreman, Lorenzo Ackerman, Levi Apgar, Joseph Ables, John F. Zebley, David Close, Walter L. Childs, Stephen Cutler, Henry W. Hoops, John P. Huggins, Jaskearney, Edward J. Knapp, Leopold Lithauer.

There was a great deal of perturbation and much confusion at the Capitol to-day at the announcement that a decision had been rendered by the Supreme Court involving the constitutionality of the Legal-tender act. The Court room was crowded; but little satisfaction was obtained in listening to the reading of the decision by the Chief Justice, as he was almost wholly inaudible. The decision will be sent in full;

Mr. BEECHER once said in a sermon, referring to the stages of a noble human life, that it does not reach its altitude by a uniform ascent, but sometimes rises and sometimes falls, though its result shows that the upward force is most powerful. He further declared that oven the saints reach heaven, not by straight lines of advance, but along a series of zig-zags to its very gates.

An adjourned meeting of the New-York Boot and Shoe Board of Trade was held yesterday at the Astor House. A large number of the most extensive dealers and manufacturers in the City were present, and the greatest unanimity marked the proceedings.

The Alta California yesterday discharged the members of the Typographical Union employed as compositors, and reduced the rates to sixty cents per thousand ems. It is understood the Evening Bulletin and Morning Call will also make a reduction as soon as the required number of printers are obtained.

Masked balls were held by two of the German singing societies of this City belonging to the General singers. Union, Mr. BERNARD HUNDT, President, last knight. The Abt Schelars, messrs. M. FUERCHTENICHT. President, and CESAT EMMELMANN, Musical Director, held their ball at the New-York Casino, Nos. 51 to 55 East Houston-street.

Buffalo made last year 153,323 barrels of ale and beer, against 159,247 barrels in 1868. The labor reform men in New-Hampshire advertised the calls for their several conventions in the Democratic papers.

A noble work of benevolence has been recently undertaken at No. 510 Pearl-street, near Centre. It is no less a labor than an attempt to provide, under the title of the "Strangers' Friend," a temporary lodging place for such men as have no homes, but through misfortune or poverty are compelled to wander through our

The residence of Colonel WALTON DWIGHT, formerly occupied by Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, was burned to the ground on Sunday morning. The loss on the building, library, statuary, furniture, , is $70,000. The property was insured for $64,000 in the following offices: The Etna, $13,000; Niagara, of New-York, $10,000; Security, of New-York, $6,000; Home, of New-York, $15,000; International, $10,000; North America, of Philadelphia, $10,000.

Another large meeting, under the auspices of the National Temperance Society, was held at Dr. J. P. THOMPSON'S Church, on the corner of Thirty-fourth-street and Sixth-avenue, last evening. Hon. WM. E. DODGE presided. It had been expected that Rev. Dr. TYNG would take part in the exercises, but his ill-health kept him at home. letter regretting his necessary absence,

The members of the Legislature all arrived to-night, ready for assembling tomorrow. The Governor's Message will declare the opinion that all offices in the State are vacant, and advise the Legislature to appoint a Board or devise some other means of making appointments to fill them until an election can be held.

The inhabitants of this City, and especially those whose unpleasant doom it is to live in Fifth-avenue, will be thrown into no little agitation if they road the report of a lecture recently delivered in England by Professor TYNDALL.

Insteamship General Barnes, from Savannah.--Mr. Poor, A. W. Chapman, R. H. L. Waters, J. W. Carter, Mrs. F. Morgan, H. Veltman, O. Ernest, Captain John Britton, J. S. Mortimer, Mrs. J. S. Mortimer, Thomas Mack, M. Apple, M. Priestly and wife, A. T. Van Ness, O. P. Buel, Mrs. C. Cook and child, C. W. Jones, R. P. Hanson, O. H. Clark, Wm. E. Young, and ?? in the steerage.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associate Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simenton, General Agent. News packages for the Journal of Commerce, Times Tribune. World, Sun, Express, Evening Post. Commercial Advertiser

An explosion of gun cotton occurred yesterday morning in the store of D. D. T. DAVIES, dealer in photograph material, at No. 93 Crosby-street, blowing out the front window and burning Mr. DAVIES seriously about the face. On Thursday evening next a concert will be given in the Park Presbyterian Church in Eighty-fifth-street,

A dispatch received at military headquarters here, from Colonel NELSON, commanding Camp Supply, Indian Territory, announces the return of Major KIDD'S scouting expedition to the Kiowas. Santata, their Chief, has been and is still regarded as threatening hostilities, and Major KIDD was sent down on a tour of observation.

The Vice President laid before the Senate resolutions of the Iowa Legislature, ratifying the Fifteenth Amendment. Mr. SUMNER presented resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, relating to the French spoliation claims. Laid on the table. RAILWAY BILLS INTRODUCED.

The arrest of M. ROCHEFORT in Paris was made early on the evening of the 7th, on his way to a political meeting near Belleville, which was the signal for the gathering of his friends and partisans in great crowds in the streets of that quarter.

At a ball given on the night of the 1st inst. by one TEDDY WILLIAMS, in a saloon in the Eighth Ward, JAMES HEFFERNAN, who keeps a liquor saloon at No. 81 Mercer-street, and is an Inspector of Buildings under Mr. MCGREGOR, had some angry words with a girl named JENNIE COLLINS, which ended in a fight, the latter getting the worst of the combat.

Since the recent disastrous raid made by the detectives of Mr. BERGH among the disreputable frequenters of the cock pits of New-York and Brooklyn, there has boon great excitement, and bitter feeling prevails among all classes of low sporting men, especially in the Seventh Ward, against the author of their trouble;

Mr. JOSEPH P. BRADLEY, of Newark, N. J., whose nomination was sent in to the Senate on Monday for one of the vacancies on the Bench Df the United States Supreme Court, is a legal gentleman ranking among the first of his profession in New-Jersey, and has enjoyed a large practice in the Supreme Court at Washington.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The efforts which you are daily making to direct public attention to the fearful increase of crime in our midst, and to bring to light the apparently hidden causes which have produced such results, is worthy the highest commendation,

Paris has been for the second time within a month on the brink of revolution. The Ministry, supported by an overwhelming majority of the representatives of the people, had resolved to carry the sentence against Deputy ROCHEFORT into execution, while the partisans of ROCHEFORT were equally determined to resist his arrest.

The sale of paintings belonging to the Thompson collection was continued yesterday, at LEEDS' Art Gallery, and the attendance at the morning session, notwithstanding the storm, was large, the rooms being crowded. As a whole the building was perhaps a little more lively than on the day previous, and the prices at which the paintings sold somewhat more generous. On Monday 240 paintings were disposed of,...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent yesterday tells us how the present Manhattan Gas Company organized under the general law for industrial purposes, and that the old Manhattan Gas Company gave up its charter.

A party of half breeds, just in from the Indian campes on the Marias River, report that the Indians are dying at the rate of twenty-five per day, of small-pox, and are begging the whites to spare their lives. The report that Mountain Chiefs band and others had declared war, proves wholly. untrue.

Over two thousand real estate owners of this City have signed a memorial to the Legislature, remonstrating against the proposed alterations of the laws of 1859, chapter 338, "relative to frauds in assessments for local improvements In the City of New-York," on the following grounds:...

The Legislature met at noon to-day. The House. by vote of 109 to 10, adopted a resolution asking Congress to remove all the political disabilities ot the people of Virginia. The colored members voted for the resolution, the negatives being the white members of the extreme faction. The Governor's message was read, and was substantially as given below:

It would be a poor compliment to pay to those members of Congress who have the census question in charge, to predict that after all, they will hopelessly fall back on the laws and schedules of 1850 and 1860. Aud yet this result is the one we have heard spoken of, in several quarters,

The Exchange Salesrooms displayed unusual activity yesterday, sales taking place at three different stands simultaneously. The most important sales were those made by MULLER, WILKINS Co., who disposed of a large amount of City property, including six lots on the south side of Eighty-fourth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues.

The annual ball of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique of this City, was given, with unusual eclat, at Irving Hall, last evening. The ballroom was filled, and the supper room crowded. The great attraction of the affair lay, of course, in the last-named locality. It is safe to say that no more perfect banquet,

The new charter for New-York has not made its appearance on the files of members yet, and it would appear to be giving the printers as much trouble as it did its authors. Mr. WHITE to-day moved that 500 extra copies of the document be furnished to members, which was amended so as to make it 1,000, and carried.

JAMES O'CONNELL, aged 18 years, was killed this morning by a slung shot, during an affray in Warrington-street. Three persons are under arrest on suspicion of committing the homicide.... FREDERICK BARDEN, foreman in the Boston rolling mill at Cambridgeport, was caught in the muchinery to-day and drawn between roolers three inches apart.

In steamship Cimbria, for Hamburg.-- H. G. Ward, D. N. Barney, lady and servant, Miss Bell Barney, Miss Lucy Barney, F. A. Turner, N L. Derby, C. A. Garringues, W. Young, Miss Delia Gurnce, N. D. Turner, W. E. Silsbee., A. V. Tiedemaen, Captain A. F. Voss, Captain H. Keding, M. Mitchell, Lois Landsberger, Chs. M. Schicly, E. F. A. E.

The Metropolitan Board of Health has deemed it necessary to promulgate the following ordinance concerning a kind of contagious disease which has not been seen and known before in this City. Great importance is attached to the prompt and general compliance with the requirements of this ordinance,

The umbrella manufacturers of this City--about a dozen houses--have agreed among themselves upon a uniform scale of prices for their goods, and also upon a uniform scale of wages to be paid to their hands, and have Initiated matters by a reduction of the wages of those hands, all girls, who thereupon struck.

Rev. Bishop JANES, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, has just returned from the South, where he has been attending the North and South Carolina Conferences. He brings very favorable reports regarding the Methodist Church in the South, and says there is a growing cordiality of feeling with their Northern brethren, which, it as hoped, will result ultimately in a reumon.

A heavy fall of snow, accompanied with stormy winds, has sufficed to dispel an illusion which lately was growing rapidly upon us. The mild air, the bright sunshine, the blue skies, almost tempted some persons to believe that we had glided suddenly into a temperate Summer,

Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather about sixty persons attended the first noonday prayer meeting at the former home of "Kit" BURNS, in water-street, yesterday. Among them were two weather-beaten sailors, who united heartily In the services, several women,...

The World which has discussed the new City Charter with conspicuous ability and moderation, is as much averse to the abolition of the Central Park Commission as we are. It says,"the management of the Central Park has been able, honest and efficient.

Under the provisions of tile new cartage system merchants and importers will be permitted to ride their bonded goods, upon application to the general cartage office, No, 71 Broadway, room No. 28. There has been considrable misunderstanding in regard to certain features of the new system.

HENRI ROCHEFORT, the editor of the Marseillaise, was arrested at his residence at Belleville, in the northeastern part of the city, at an early hour this evening. His friends and partisars are assembling in great crowds in that quarter, and serious troubles are expected.

The annual dinner of the Williams College Alumni Association of this City and vicinity will take place at the St. James Hotel, corner of Broadway and Twenty-sixth-street, on the evening of Feb. 22,1870, (the anniversary of the birthday of EPHRAIM WILLIAMS, the founder of the College,) at 6 o'clock.

A man, representing himself to be Doputy Sheriff, called upon a gentleman yesterday with a notice for his attendance as a juror today. It seemed to be a regular order bearing Sheriff O'BRIEN'S signature, and tendered ostensibly by a Sheriffs officer.

WEDNESDAY. For Europe, via Queenstown and Liverpool, by the Nebraska, at 10 A. M. Supplementary mall for paid letters, on Pier No. 46 North River, to 11:30 A. M. THURSDAY. For Havana and West Indies, by the Eagle, at 2 P. M. For Bermuda, W. I., by the Fah Kee, at 2 P. M.

We should be sorry to find that Congress, in concentrating its attention upon fleets, yards and engines, had overlooked a naval subject not a whit less important than any of these, namely the training of our petty officers and seamen.

In steamship Champion, from Charleston.--W.J. Varun, Mrs. Lebby and child, Mr. Mosely, Miss M.J. Gibbs, A.H. Poc, C.H. Sloan, G.H. Oakland, J.B. Curtis, Mrs. C.B. Curtis, Mrs. Smith and child, T.J. Wilkins, W.H. Anderson, Wm. Ryan. A.G. Sage, A. Rose, R. Gilchrist, C. Girken, F. Wells, F. Radcliff, J. L. Howe, L.E. Howe, Miss S.C. Wells and 3 children, Mrs. A.S. Bixby and servant, J. C. Martin,

The Census bill, when mentioned in the Senate now, has the effect of almost emptying the chamber. Such, at least, has been the experience of the last two days. Mr. SUMNER to-day continued his speech, in favor of the House measure and in opposition to the report of the Senate Committee, and to-as Mr. SUMNER styled it--the antediluvian measure of 1850."

Notwithstanding the severe storm, quite a large number of delegates to the Republican State Convention have already assembled. A preliminary caucus for general discussion was held this evening. Hon. DAVID GALLUP presided and remarks were made by General J. R. HAWLEY and others. Many prominent men of the party are present.

We trust that Georgia will not be denied the justice and courtesy of an early decision with regard to its claim for formal restoration. The tantalizing delays inflictedn upon Virgunia were a wrong and a blunder which should not be repeated, A good deed is mended or marred by the manner of doing it;

The declarations of HARRY K. FOSTER, HUGH JOHNSON and GARDNER WELLS, the Americans who were attacked in the street by an unknown man, were taken before the American Consul-General. They all agreed in qualifying the assassination of ISAAC GREENWOLD as most inhuman and without cause. GREENWOLD was buried yesterday, but to-day the body was exhumed for the purpose of embalming it.

The following General Order was promulgated from the Head-quarters of the Army to-day : 1. Under the provisions of the act approved Jan. 21, 1870, General Orders No. 9, all retired officers, who have been assigned to duty, will be considered as relieved from such assignment on the 21st Inst., and will proceed to such homes as they may elect.

The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Cuddy, Reilly, Hughes, Miller, Murray, Welsch, Culin, Gunizer, O'Brien, Woltman, Barker, McKiever, Dimond, Cregier, Crokor, Jackson, Cunningham, Long--20. The minutes of the meeting held February third were read and approved.

To The Editor of the New-York Times: The undersigned, Sandy Hook Pilots, in view of tile friendly motives which induced you to publish in your valuable journal the statistics in relation to the pilots and pilotage of this port, giving us thereby the advantages of your extenive circulation,

Dr. LEE was again called, yesterday, as a witness in behalf of the contestants of the will, and testified that he had read the evidence taken before the Surrogate, or at least those portions bearing upon the sanity or Insanity of the late Dr. CARLTON GATES;

The last resting place of the great philanthropist, GEORGE PEABODY, is called Harmony Grove. It is a cemetery removed just a sufficient distance from the noise, turmoil and bustle of everyday life to afford easy access to such as have friends reposing within its confines; and, from its beauty of location and its appropriate surroundings,...

The Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic of the State of New-York, of which Colonel PELL, of this City, and Colonel McQUADE, of Western New-York, are members, appointed recently to effect an amalgamation of that body with the Union Home and School, whose objects are similar, has succeeded in accomplishing its mission.

In the Essex County Court of Oyer and Terminer, at Newark, yesterday the trial of LEONHARDT SCHUMM for the murder of CORNELIUS STAHL was commenced before Judge DEPUE and Associate Justices THESE, GUILD and ISE. The Court room was crowded with an eager audience, principally composed of Germans, who manifested much interest in the proceedings.

The present Water and Sewerage Board, in Brooklyn, soon after its organization made itself known by what the Commissioners claimed was its legal title--the Permanent Water Board. It was desired by the Commissioners that it should be permanent, but there were thousands of the citizens who regarded it as an oppression which should be as temporary as possible.

AMES.--On Monday, Feb. 7, at the Rectory of the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, GEORGE C. AMES, Esq., late of Washington, D. C. aged 68 years. His friends, and those of his son-in-law, Rev. Nos. St. Hall, D. D., are invited to attend the funeral one views at 3 P. M., on Wednesday, Feb. 3, St, Go Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn Heights.

The Officers and members of the Twenty-second Regiment, in association with the members of their Veteran Corps, gave a reception and hop last evening at the Academy of Music. The affair proved a splendid success, despite the storm prevailing all night.

Mr. ROBERT RAIT, formerly of No. 261 Broadway, died at Ramsgate, England, on the 1st inst., from the effects of a fall. Mr. RAIT was a native of Edinburgh, Scotland. In 1833 he, in conjunction with Mr. COLFAX, set up in this City a manufactory of jewelry, the firm being RAIT COLFAX.

The snow storm which commenced between the hours of 4 and 6 o'clock on Tuesday morning still continued at 10 o'clock on Tuesday evening. A furious gale blew all day. The ferry boats were impeded by the blinding thickness of the storm at sunrise and during portions of the evening. The snow measured in depth at 10 P. M. five and one-quarter inches.

M. J. McETTRICK, the champion pedestrian. is sick in Burligton, Vt. Bucks County, Penn., furnishes most of the cigars smoked in Philadelphia. United States Senator BUCKINGHAM is exDetoed to preside over the Connecticut Republican State Convention in Hartford to-day.

Allusion was made a short time ago to the proposed construction of a new railroad between this Ciy and Brewster's, Putnam County, in this State, to connect at the latter point with the Boston, Hartford and Erie Railroad, and thus form a new route between New-York and Boston.

In a Democratic caucus at Jefferson City, last night, the constitutional amendment recently introduced in the Senate relating to the enfranchisement of all disfranchised persons was discussed, and a resolution adopted declaring it the purpose of the caucus to support such a proposition.

Aside from the combined movement of the cigar manufacturers, cigar makers and tobacco growers, to demand the restoration of the tariff on imported cigars to $3 per pound and fifty per cent. ad valorem, from $3250 per pound and twenty-five per cent, ad valorem, as fixed in the Internal Revenue act,

The kings County Republican General Committee met in Brooklyn last evening, GEORGE C. BENNETT presiding. The Committee on Contested Seats reported In favor of the delegations headed as follows: First Ward, E. A. STUDWELL; Sixth Ward, E. D. WEBSTER, and the Twenty-first Ward, J. ALLEN.

The Ship Neptune, from Liverpool, arrived at this port on the 5th inst., and immediately eight of the crew preferred charges of cruel and inhuman treatment against the captain and first and second mates. This ship is the mate of the James Foster, on board of which so many cruelties were perpetrated some tune since,

The annual reception of the Twelfth Infantry, Company G, came off last evening at the armory, corner of Broadway and Fourthstreet. Notwithstanding the weather, the attendance was as largo as on any previous occasion, and tile festivities were enjoyed to the fullest extent.

Ex-Senator FRELINGHOYSEN, of New-Jersey, appeared before the Committee on Commerce of the Senate the other day, and made an extended argument in opposition to the bill "for the preservation of the harbors of the United States against encroachment."

The Census bill of the House, prepared at so much cost both of money and time, was killed in the Senate to-day, and the admission was made that the body was unable to improve on an old law framed twenty years ago. Mr. SUMNER, Mr. MORRILL and Mr.

Through lack of a quorum the Shipowners' Association held no meeting yesterday afternoon. The members present seemed to think that nothing could be done at Albany to advance the interests of the Association, except, perhaps, a defeat of the bill increasing the rates of pilot-age

Special relief has ones more carried the day in the Senate against general amnesty. Mr. STEWART'S proposition for a swooping removal of political disqualifications, with sundry specified exceptions, was withdrawn at the request of its own advocates, lest it should imperil the bill for individual relief which it was designed to amend.

Senor CASTELLAR was to have presented in yesterday's sitting a project of law for the exclusion of the BOURRONS' rights to the Spanish throne, Several Democrats, desirous of bringing on a rupture between the Liberal Unionists and the Progressists, had come to an understanding with the Republlcans on the subject,

The Chamber of Commerce has protested against the bill before the Legislature reorganizing the Fire Department of this city, has adopted a memorial to Congress, urging the erection of a Government building on Custom Houselblock.

About fifty persons attended the noonday prayer meeting at the reconstructed dog pit of KIT BURNS, in Water-street, yesterday. Most of these came from other neighborhoods to aid in the good work, but there were a number of the denizens of the depraved locality present.

The trial of LRONHARDT SCHUMM for the murder of CORNELIUS STAHL, at Newwark, was continued yesterday in the Essox County Court of Oyer and Terminer. The Court room was more crowded than on the previous day. CHRISTIAN HUMMRL continued his testimony:

In the Supreme Court this morning, the argument in the Schoeppe case was continued by Mr. MILLER, counsel for the prisoner. He was followed by C. E. MCLAUGHLIN, District-Attorney for Carlisle, for the Commonwealth, giving all the facts of the death of Miss STEINEUKE, and defending the chemical testimony brought forward by the prosceution on the trial for murder.

Resolutions were offered and agreed to as follows: By Mr. POMEROY--Requesting the President to communicate information touching the action of any of the Departments relating to the claim of the Central Branch of the Union Pacific Railroad Company to receive lands and boards of the United States in aid of the construction of their road. Also, any recommendation he may see fit to make in the premises.

At a meeting of the Union Cooperative Building Society, last night, about 500 were subseribed. A meeting of the Tailors' Protective and Benevolent Union was held last night, at which the report of the Finance Committee was received, showing about $2,600 to their credit.

The attendance at the Leeds Art Gallery yesterday morning was full as large as it had been for the two days previous, but the price realized for most of the pictures sold was far below their value. The morning sale comprised 128 pictures, catalogued from 482 to 609 inclusive, and the amount realized was $7,809 50, making the sum total received up to last evening $31,083 50.

The Managers of the Wilson Industrial school held a meeting at their building, corner of St. Mark's-place and Avenue A, on Friday, Feb. 4, at which many friends of the institution were present. Rev. Dr. KENDRICK conducted the religions exercises and made a short address.

A hearing on the return to the writ of habeas corpus in the case or Warden STACOM, of the City Prison, was had before Judge INGRAHAM in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. At the opening of the Court, and after the call of the panel of jurors, Judge GARVIN announced to the Judge that there was the case of Warden STACOM, of the City Prison,...

If any one wishes to appreciate the progress of liberal ideas in England, it is only necessary to read the Queen's speech on the opening of Parliament last Tuesday. The ballot is half promised, the land laws in Ireland are to be completely modified, there is to be a bill for the enlargement of the means of national education,

Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD, accompanied by his son and two ladies, arrived at Cardenas on the 28th ult., from Matanzas. The party was met at the depot by a deputation of the volunteer officers of Cardenas, who escorted them to the hotel.

The Governor of Newfoundland has addressed a Message to the Speaker of the House of Assembly, deprecating the action of the House in informally voting no confidence in the Government, and regretting that the House should have adopted the unconstitutional course of naming to him the member for whom he should send to form an

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed in to-day's issue of your valuable sheet an article in regard to the manner in which lodgings are provided for the homeless poor. It has always seemed to me a great wrong, and one which ought long since to have been made right.

At present the Mormons on the Island are under the charge of Bishop ROBERT T. BARTON, who is also Major-General of the Mormon Mintia. He is assisted by Bishop FRANCIS A. HAMMOND and Elders A. M. CANNON, WM. BRONGHURST, WM. W. RITER, BENJAMIN HULSE and RICHARD BROWER, of Utah, and Elders J. M. BENEDICT and AUSTIN PETTIT, of Long Island.

The New-York Liberal Club held its seventeenth regular meeting at its rooms, No. 23 Third-avenue, last evening. Professor POEY read a very interesting paper on the number of books published on the positive philosophy of AUGUST COMPTE--200 in all.

The Connecticut Republicans dispatched their business yesterday with a celerity which betokens energy and harmony. All the present State officers were renominated, with the exception of Lieutenant-Governor WAYLAND, who is in Europe; MORRIS TYLER, of New-Haven, is ?? put forward in his place.

The thirty-first annual reunion of the Eighth Ward Pioneer Clay Club will take place on Thursday evening, the 17th inst., at Apollo Hall, corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth-street, The present officers of this time-honored organization are LUTHER MOREY, President; WM. C.

The severest snow storm of the Winter commenced yesterday afternoon, accompanied by a heavy gale. About eighteen inches of snow fell, drifting seriously and putting an embargo on travel. It cleared up this morning.

The forty days which intervene between the adjournment of Parliament and its reunion in the first week of February give the new Ministry ample time to chalk out a plan of policy. The new men have come into the exercise of power, strictly pledged to economy in the Administration, and where to strike out, pare off, and abolish, is that upon which their ingenuity is now exercised.

A granddaughter of DANIEL WEBSTER, Miss WEBSTER, was married yesterday, at Marsh-field, Mass., to Mr. JAMES GEDDES DAY, of this City. Sir Alexander Mackenzie and Lady Windham are the Clarendon Hotel. Hon. B.F. Coulter, of Tennessee; Hon. H.G. Burleigh,

Rioting continues in Paris, but the "insurrection " proclaimed by the irreconcilable FLOURENS bangs fire. The old revolutionary elan that swept away the Ministry of GUIZOT and the throne of LOUIS PHILIPPE is altogether wanting. In February, 1848,

Yesterday the will of the late General WOOL was presented for probate in the Surrogate's Court of this county. The will is dated March 17, 1868. One of the codicils is dated Nov. 2, 1869, and the other Nov. 5 of the same year.

BILLS REPORTED. By Mr. MURPHY-Extending the term of office of the Collector of Taxes of Kings County. By Mr. GENET-To amend the General Bonding Law, to facilitate the construction of railroads. By Mr. CREAMER-To amend the Public Printing act.

The political disturbances in Paris were renewed at midnight on the 8th mst., but firearms were not resorted to by either side. The Police continued to make arrests and the military wore still hold in readiness. The fresh disturbances occurred nearer the centre of the city, and at considerable distance from the scenes of the first outbreak.

The disorders broke out again at Belleville and in the Rue du Faubourg du Temple at midnight. Several additional barricades have been erected in the narrow streets. The troops fare still in the neighborhood of the scene, but up to this hour have not fired on the rioters.

It is announced that Mr. EDWARD SEYMOUR, who for about two years past has been connected with the well-known house of CHARLES SCRIBNER Co., publishers, of this City, has been admitted as a member of that firm.

This has been a dull day in the Legislature. The Senate transacted little business of interest beyond the passage of the Canal Appropriation bill and making Mr. MURPHY'S Excise bill the special. order for to-morrow. Mr. MURPHY'S bill is similar in its provisions to the Excise law provided for in the new charter for New-York.

Yesterday a considerable amount of property was disposed of at the Exchange Rooms. The most important feature of the day's operations was the sale of lots in Harlem by MULER, WILKINS CO., by order of the administrators of JOHN VANDERPOEL.

It will be remembered that Mr. GEO. T. CHAMBERS, while engaged in shooting at a chick an upon his premises in Astroia, accidentally killed a boy named JOHN MYERS. The father of the boy commenced four civil actions against Mr. CHAMBERS, besides having him arrested three times upon criminal complaints.

The inhabitants of Blue Point, L. I., are considerably excited over the rather mysterious disappearance of Captain JOHN H. ARTHUR, an old resident of that place, who had been doing business in this City, and was living temporarily at No. 238 South Third-street, Brooklyn, E. D.

VALENTINE KLEIN has been arrested on the charge of murdering his own child, a babe seven months old. The testimony before the Coroner was that KLEIN came home drunk, when his wife asked him for money to buy bread, at which he became enraged and took a pot of boiling coffee and poured it over the face and bosom of the child.

CREATION A RECENT WORK OF GOD. By the Rector of St. Mary's Church, New-York. New-York: POTT AMERY. The writer of this remarkable book says that "his aim has been to furnish the sand, mortar and bricks with which some practical geologist may build up a system of geology in harmony with God's written revelation."

The Republican State Convention convened in this city to-day, in Allyn Hall, and accomplished the work of nominating a State ticket, and of presenting a platform for the next campaign, which was done after a shortsession, in which the best of spirit prevailed.

The Post Office Department has just issued the following new schedule of postage rates to Mexico: On letters forwarded to Mexico, ten cents (three cents inland and seven cents sea) per single rate of half ounce or fraction thereof; prepayment compulsory.

The explosion of the liquid gas lamp at 1 o'clock this morning in the cigar store of ADAM KLOHERDANZ, in the front basement of No. 419 Fifth-street, which is a double tenement house, caused a fire doing a damage of $1,000 to stock. and of $ 500 to the building, which is owned by NORDSTROM, BYER VOSS, and is insured for $5,000 in the North American and $3,000 in the Germania.

Governor WALKER'S inaugural address was road in the Virginia Legislature on Tuesday afternoon. After congratulating the members upon the circumstances under which they met, he said: The voice of Virginia is again heard in the national councils. May it be potent for good!

The National Executive Committee, GEORGE T. DOWNING, President, and F. G. BARRODES, Secretary, have issued the following address to the colored people of the United States: Your National Executive Committee, created by you in the National Convention. assembled

In the State Legislature, in the House, this morning, petitions were presented in favor of establishing a public park in Newark, and by the Democratic branch of the Newark Common Council asking for the passage of the bill creating the Fourteenth Ward In that city, so that the deadlock caused by the vote of Mr. CAIN, the bolting Democratic Alderman, in relation to the appointment of city officers might be ended.

Commissioner CHAHOON has been engaged lately in taking depositions to be heard as evidence in the suit of J. M. MADDUX and others against the United States Government. The suit is for the sum of $734,000, the value of 421,000 pounds of manufactured tobacco, which destroyed by the United States Government, at Hamilton's Crossing, on the Richmond.

The regular weekly meeting of the Board of Health was held yesterday, Mr. HENRY SMITH in the chair. Dr. JOHN M. CARNOCHAN, the new Health Officer, who is ex-officio a member of the Board, appeared for the first time and took his seat.

About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a party of burglars forced open the front door of the jewelry store of A. WAILACK CO., No. 72 Spring-street, and immediately upon gaining access to the premises, cut the throat of the watch dog.

The affaire TRAUPMANN and the affaire BONAPARTE are out of my beat, and unless the Atlantic combined telegraph companies have struck, you have known all the facts, possibly somewhat more, as they occurred. There is, however, a speculation about the guillotine which is renewed at every execution.

General ADAM BADEAU, who rendered distinguished services on General GRANT'S staff during the war, was recently United States Secretary of Legation at the Court of St. James, and is new on. duty at the White House, has written an article, which will appear in the March number of Harper's Maugane, entitled "Our Relations With England."

"MARIA DE ROMAN." The performance of "Maria de Rohan," at the Union League Theatre, on Wednesday, was so successful as to deserve marked attention. As we have previously said, the representation was devised by Signor RONCONI. for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged.

Yesterday afternoon a bust of the late JAMES T. BRADY was presented to the Law Institute of this City, by the Committee of the Law Institute, appointed on the 8th of March, 1869, to procure a suitable memorial of the deceased.

Mayor HALL has prepared, and forwarded to the Legislature, the following copy of a proposed act in relation to jurors: AN ACT in relation to Jurors in the Criminal Law Courts of the City and County of New-York. The People of the State of New-York, represented in senate and Assembly, do enact as follows:

The annual report of the Mount Sinai Hospital for the year 1869, just published, sets forth that there were 725 applications for admission to the hospital during the year, 8 born in hospital and 63 remaining Jan. 1, 1869--a total of 684--of whom 510 were discharged cured, 47 died, 71 were discharged improved,7 discharged not improved,3 left before treatment and 46 remained Jan, 1, 1870.

California has 40,000 Indians. The Boston Traveller predicts that Gotham will be crowded with Down East ice next Summer. How to kill time-sleight it. [This joke is old, but it is one of those made not for a day, but for all seasonable times.]

In compliance with a resolution of the House of Representatives, the Secretary of the Treasury has transmitted to that body a copy of the report on Alaska, of special agent G. W. RAYMOND, of the Engineer Corps, United States Army.
Commissioner BRENNAN yesterday investigated charges against policemen as follows: For being off post, ten; conversing on post, three; not attending a fire, five, and three of miscellaneous character.

A private social organization called the New-Yok Masquerade Club, had its third annual ball at Apollo Hall last evening. There was a good attendance, and a large number of fine costumes were worn on the occasion. The festivities were somewhat marred, however, by extremely execrable arrangements. General E.

The excitement in Paris continues. The demonstrations are limited to the collecting of crowds in the streets, which the Police disperse, arresting the turbulent individuals. Armed bodies of police patrol the streets, and the vigilance of the authorities is unabated. A ball announced for Wednesday at the Tuileries, was postponed on account of the disorders.... In Corps

Mennie, Peter McGinniss. Fourth Ward.--Francis Canning, Thos. White, Mathew McCuffrey, Edward Stack, John Drought, Andrew Lindberg, Richard Fitzpatrick, John Gearety, Denis J. Donovan.

The Committee on Commerce has reported without amendment the bill to encourage telegraphic communication between the Eastern and Western Hemispheres, or, in other words, the Pacific Cable bill. The project itself is an old one, antedating the purchase of Alaska, and indeed begun, we believe, before the first Atlantic able was laid.

A glorious national feeling always comes with the census. We come to every decade with a sense of certainty in our gains. We know that we were not much more than 5,000,000 at the beginning of the century; that we crossed its meridian with 23,000,000, and that we entered the great war with 31,000,000!

The fact that the House of Representatives, judged by recent votes, is more liberal than the Ways and Means Committee, is not a reason for assuming that the new Tariff bill, monstrous as it is, will fail as a matter of course. There are the strongest possible reasons why it should fail.

Word was sent from Collector BAILEY'S office to the District-Attorney yesterday, to the effect that there was good ground for commeneing a civil action against the French TransatlanticSubmarine Cable Company, on a charge of non-compliance with the Internal Revenue law.

BURRALL.--Suddenly, on Thursday, Feb. 10, FREDERICK A. BURRALL, in the 75th year of his age. His friends, and those of his son, Dr. Frederick A. Burrall, are invited to attend his funeral from the University-place Church, corner of 10th-st., on Saturday, at 9 1/2 A. M. CARTER.--At New-Canaan, Conn.. on Wednesday morning, Feb. 9, MARTHA W., wife of the late James C. Carter.

It is reported that Governor GEARY has refused to approve the bill passed last week directing the Supreme Court to review the evidence and decide capital eases on their merits. It was passed to cover the case of Dr. SCHOEPPE, now under sentence of death in Carlisle.

A few days since ANDREW D. SMITH, Deputy Insurance Commissioner, received a telegram from Major MURPHY, editor of the Alaska Times, dated Victoria, Jan. 18, conveying to him the sad news that ins brother, Commodore LEON SMITH, was killed by the Indians.

About two hundred bankers and brokers of Wall-street and viomity were recently fined by the Government for noncompliance with the Revenue law relating to the total amount of capital employed in the banking business. It is said that the emoluments which will accrue to different persons in consequence of the payment of these fines, will be extremely large.

JACK REYNOLDS, charged with murdering WILLIAM TOWSEND, the grocer, in Hudsonstreet recently, was arraigned in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge INGRAHAM, yesterday morning and pleaded not guilty. Being without counsel, WILLIAM F. HOWE was assigned to defend him.

The storm of Saturday, Jan. 16, 1870, will long he remembered as one of the most dreadful that has ever occurred in the West. It extended over a great space of country and many people and large quantities of live stock of all descriptions were destroyed by it.

Charlotte, N. C., lights its streets on Sunday nights only. The Wasbington correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette seems to be devoting most of his time to researches in ancient history. And now comes the Sacramento Union asserting that Tahoe means, not grasshopper, but big water.

Rev. WILLIAM. H. PENDLETON last evening delivered the third of his series of lectures concerning his recent, tour through Europe and the Holy Land, the proceeds of which are devoted towards the completion of the new Baptist house of worship, at the Baptist Church, Fifty-third-street and Seventh-avenue.

It is announce that Captain COMMERELL has received permission to take the Monarch to Annapolis, and that she may call at New-York on the way. WASHINGTON, D. C., Feb. 10.-The British Minister called at the Navy Department this afternoon and informed the Scretary that H. B. M.'s ship Monarce would leave Portland on Sinday for Annapolis.

Pursuant to call, the representatives of Life Insurance and Trust Companies met at the rooms of the Board of Fire Underwriters, No. 156 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, to consider what further action should be taken to protect the interest of the companies in securing an open investigation of their affairs by the Legislative Committee lately appointed.

Mr. SCHURZ introduced a joint resolution concerning colleges for the promotion of agriculture and the mechanic arts. It provides that no State that has not received its proportion of the grant of land donated by the United States for agricultural and mechanical colleges shall in future receive such lands, unless the colleges to be established shall provide facilities for instruction for all without regard to race or color. Referred to the Committee on Education.

The Shawmut Flouring Mill, at Brown's Race, owned and occupied by JAMES M. WIIITNEY Co., was completely destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is estimated at $40,000; insured for $18,000, $13,000 on the building and $5,000 on the stock. The adjoining buildings and stocks therein were damaged slightly by water, in the aggregate, perhaps, to the amount of $2,000; fully covered by Insurance.

The drawback frauds still continue to form an animated topic of discussion among official circles in the United States building In Chambers-street, Considerable surprise is felt at the delay in bringing the conspirators to trial, and numerous inquiries are being made as to whether the cases will ever be tried. ACKOR--BRUNI.--On Wednesday, Feb. 9, at the Sixteenth Baptish Church, by Rev. Dr. Mikels PHILIP H. ACKOR to Miss VALENTENIA BRUNI, all of the City. ADAMS--MACY.--At the Church of the Messiah, on Wednesday evening, Feb. 9, by Rev. George K. Hepworth, EDWARD L. ADAMS, of Boston, to EMILY, eldest daughter of John H. Macy, of this City.

A meeting of the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters was, held Wednesday, at which the legal-tender decision of the Supreme Court was considered, and its bearings upon the payment of bonds and mortgages contracted prior to 1862, and also the payment of the interest on the same, was discussed.

Down in Water-street, yesterday, at KIT BURNS' former rat pit, the noon prayer meeting hold for the benefit of the "fallen women" in that immediate neighborhood, was well attended. But it was noticeable that although the room was packed, not one of those for whose benefit the mission was inaugurated were present or to be seen on either side of the glass doors fronting the street.
