In the House today the Regan-Dickey case was decided in favor of the contestant, REGAN, by a vote of 79 to 54. TRENTON, Feb. 10.--In the Senate to-day a bill was introduced to incorporate the Newark Mutual Health Assurance Company, with authority to insure persons against sickness and disease.

Late advices from the Eastern Department have been received. Count VALMASEDA arrived at Manzanllo on the 5th inst., and would leave for Bayamo, but at what time it was uncertain. The Casino Espanol, representing the wealthy and prominent Spaniards of Havana, has issued a document protesting against the vile, unwarrantable and criminal assassination of ISAAC GREENWALDTH.

The trial of LEONILARDT SCHUMM, for the murder of CORNELIUS STAIIL, in Newark, was continued yesterday. The Court room was crowded, as on the preceding days. The prisoner looked more than usually anxious and despondent, the testimony given on Wednesday having been more pointed and positive than that previously given.

The Arion Singing Society of this City held their third carnival "session" of the season at the Germania Assembly Rooms last night. The large hall was again, as on the two former carnival festivals of the Society, crowded with ladies and gentlemen, the latter wearing clowns' caps.

The exporters, refiners and receivers of petroleum, of this City, held a meeting at the Merchant's Exchange. No. 52 Pine-street, yesterday afternoon, Mr. R. C. BURLAGE presiding, which was well attended. The object of the meeting was to adopt a new form of contract between exporters of petroleum on the one part and refiners and receivers of petroleum on the other,

The representation of " Rigoletto," promised for to-night at the Academy, is unavoidably postponed until next week. In its place "Il Ballo in Masehera " is to be given, with Signor LEFRANC, Mme. BRIOL and others; while the baritone part will be sustained--it being his first appearance on the operatic stage, or, we believe, any other-by a well-known amateur, Dr. VALENTINE.

At LEEDS' Art Galleries the sale of paintings belonging to the Thompson collection was continued yesterday. In the morning 125 pictures were disposed of, and the sales finished up about half the catalogue, taking in pictures numbered up to 815. The amount realized was $5,780 50, making the total sum received to the close of the morning sale $42,220.

Mr. MURPHY reported the bill providing for the completion of the Bedford-avenue improvement, Brooklyn. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. CREAMER--Amending the act incorporating the Stuyvesant Safe Deposit Company of the City of New-York.

In the ease of EDWIN PERRY, who has been tried twice for the murder of THOS. HAYES, the night watchman at HARBECK'S stores, and in whose ease the jury failed to agree upon a verdict, before Judge .GILBERT at the Supreme Court yesterday morning, his counsel, CHARLES SPENCER, moved to have him admitted to bail.

Whatever may be the sentiments of adverse cliques, the great body of the people, are as cordially disposed as ever towards President GRANT, and retain an undiminished faith in his willingness and ability to carry on the affairs of the nation in such a way as to promote the "greatest good of the greatest number."

The political contest in this State waxes warm. The Democratic Party will not put any speakers in the field, but will allow all disposed to go over to the Labor Reform Party. A new secret organization, called the Labor League, has been formed, and it is rumored that it is to offset the labor reform movement.

At the Exchange yesterday, MULLER, WILKINS CO. sold a valuable water front property situated in Williamsburg, consisting of twenty-six city lots, partly improved, together with the bulkhead in front, and the north half of the south pier.

A correspondent sends us some particulars of a negotiation, of which he declares he was cognizant, for the sale of a West Point cadetship for $2,000-the usual price, as he was informed, being $3,000. He represents the practice as common, and cites the words of a Major-General, who, when asked what influence would be required to procure the position for the son of our correspondent, answered, "Buy it."

Since the defection and removal of Deputy Collector S. T. BLATCHFORD, the Division of Public Stores has been conducted with uncommon care and exactness. The present Deputy, Mr. DANIEL N. TOMPKINS, was appointed to the position on account of his acknowledged business capacity and integrity, and thus far he has not lost any of the confidence reposed in him.

The third annual ball of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks was held last evening at Irving Hall, and was one of the most successful of the season. As its name indicates, the Order is based upon principles of friendship and

A stated meeting of the Medico-Legal Society of this City was held last evening at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street. The Committee appointed for the revision of the constitution and by-laws reported several changes. Physicians and lawyers.

There is a great deal of speculation as to the chances of the confirmation of Messrs. STRONG and BRADLEY, just nominated for the Supreme Bench. The probability is that both will be confirmed. There is some opposition to Mr. BRADLEY on the ground of locality, but that will be overcome by the fact that he will take up his residence within the circuit to which he is appointed to serve.

Yesterday and on Wednesday the Custom House authorities were busily engaged in removing from the store of the importers, Messrs. WINDMULLER Co., No. 20 Reade-street, a large quantity of merchandise which has been seize by Deputy Collector CLARK, Chief of the Seizure Burenu, in the Custom House.

There was considerable excitement among the people yesterday and last evening. The Police were active, dispersing crowds here and there, but no outbreaks occurred. Many arrests were made. The military was also out in force, but its services were met needed.

An executive meeting of the Gold Board was held at 3 o'clock yesterday to take action in the case of VAN SAUN Co., members of the Board, charged with fraud by SAMUEL C. BARR. Mr. VAN SAUN dented in toto any illegal transaction on the part of the firm, and at his request a Committee of three was appointed to investigate, the case and examine his books,

This morning the puddling furnace In the rolling mill of Messrs. ROWLAND, on Dolaware-avenue, above Poplarstreet, exploded with terrifle force, scattering the molten metal in all directions. Fortunately, however, no one was injured. WOODSTOCK, Vt., Feb. 10.-The funeral of the late Governor WASHBURN took place in this town to-day.

The ferry boat which left the slip at Hoboken for Barclay-street, in this City, at 9:15 last evening, was the scene of a melancholy suicide. When the boat had reached the middle of the river, a woman of more than ordinary beauty, elegantly attired, leaped from the bow of the boat into the river. She was caught in the wheel,

The motion to dismiles the appeal-No. 339, WILLIAM H. GLEASON, Lieutenant-Governor of the State of Florida, vs. the State of Florida ex rel. the Attorney-General, error to the Supreme Court of Florida, was decided In the Supreme Court to-day.

Various and conflicting statements regarding the suspension of the Newark and Paterson Railroad having appeared in the newspapers of late, some of which attached the blame to the local Stockholders, and others to the Directors of the Erie Railway Comp any, who are largely interested in the stock of the Newark and Paterson road,

The city is entirely quiet. There were no disturbances during the night, and the places of business were open as usual. The soldiers have not yet been returned to their barracks. The Police patrolled the streets in force, but did not find it necessary to make any arrests. Over 400 persons have been apprehended for complicity in the rioting during the three days vast.

The Legislature opened yesterday by a speech from the Lieutenant-Governor. His Excellency alluded in warm terms to the general prosperity of the Province. Measures to provide a general system of education and to secure a share of the emigration from England were strongly recommended to the attention of the two Houses.

Yesterday morning the litigation so long pending between JOHN MYERS, Sr., and GEORGE T. CHAMBERS, of Astoria, was brought to a final conclusion, all parties consenting to withdraw their suits. MYERS had brought five civil suits against Mr. CHAMBERS to recover $55,000 for the loss of his son.

The citizens of Freeport and vicinity during the past week have been greatly excited by a series of lectures exposing Mormonism, delivered by Rev. 'F. W. WARE, and also a lecture vindicating their principles by Elders THOMAS JACKSON and WM. W. RITER. Mr. WARE delivered a lecture 'Monday evening at Rockville Centre, Tuesday evening at Baldwinsville, Wednesday evening at Freeport, and last evening at Bald winsville.

In Paris no disturbances occurred on Thursday night, and yesterday the shops were open as usual. About four hundred persons are in prison awaiting examination for complicity in tho insurrection. The troops are still held in readiness for an emergency. FLOURENS is still at large, and is believed to be in Belglum.

Cuban bonds may not appreciate greatly in value, but the Cuban cause evidently gains ground in Congress. Senators MORTON and CARPENTER are strong men to champion what has seemed a losing cause; and now Senator SHERMAN, who cannot be suspected of partiality for filibusterism, adds his voice to theirs in advocacy of recognition.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In noticed the communication from "Fair Play" in the TIMES of Friday, and think I can make even a stronger statement than he did. I was the first person on the line, having waited over an hour for the opening of the ticket office. On inquiring for seats in the parquette, I was informed that they had been sent to the Press;

For months past Brooklyn has been blest with numerous foundlings, the offspring of inhuman parents, who have been cared for as provided by law-not the parents, but the babies. This part of the baby business not proving sufficiently sensational for some barbarous heart, It has developed a new and severer style, as the story about to be related will how. At an early hour yesterday morning,

Additional evidence was taken yesterday before United States Commissioner SHIELDS in the ease of MORRIS S. HILL, charged with embezzling $39,000 from the Farmers' and Drovers' Bank of Somers, Westchester County, by means of false entries.

Our people on the frontiers have been very anxious regarding the probability of Indian troubles the coming Spring. Recently the agent of the Arrapahoes gave that tribe permission to leave their reservation, and visit Fort Dodge, Kan. This was refused by the commanding officer of that post, and the Indians, went into camp near the Canadian River, about forty tiles from Dodge,

From the Port Huron (Mich.) Times. Among the heroes that Port Huron sent to the war was ARCHIBALD P. CAMPBELL, who went from this city as Captain of Company K in the Second Michigan Cavalry, and succeeded PHIL. SHERIDAN in the Coloneley of that famous regiment, though, we believe, the eagle on his shoulder straps was displaced before his death by the General's star.

At 7 o'clock last evening Mrs. MARY LINNETT, wife of JOHN LINNETT, residing at No. 82 Wyckoff-street, attempted to commit suicide by cutting her throat with a razor. Information was immediately conveyed to the Station House of the Forty-third Precinct, and at once Dr. E. G. COLTON, of No. 202 Court-street, was called into service.

For some time past, PATRICK O'HEARN, a native of Ireland, 12 years of age, kept a small liquor store at No.32 Abattoir-place, in Thirty-ninth-street, near North River. Since Wednesday night his saloon has been closed, but the circumstance caused no inquiry, and it was only by accident that a friend forcing his way in yesterday afternoon, found the old man lying under his counter dead.

Late intelligence received from Puerto Principo, is to the effect that General GOYENECHE, with a strong division, left that city on the 5th inst., on a campaign against the insurgents. It was expected that General PUELLO would soon leave that city to again attack the rebel forces.... The steamship Juniata sailed for Philadelphia this evening.

After three days of unusual activity, the Exchange Salesrooms were again quiet yesterday, and no sales of real estate took place. Today there will probably be no business done at the rooms, but next week premises some important sales.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 11.--Dr. CHARLES R. BRICKEN, a well-known physician, theatrical lessee, and a dramatic author of some note, was killed to-day by the discharge of a pistol in his own hands. He was author of the " Cabin and Parlor," a play for a long time performed in the Southern theatres as an offset to "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

The steamship City of Washington, which loft Liverpool Jan. 27, and Queenstown Jan. 28, reached this port last night. Her advice are later by three days than those at hand by the Rhein. On Jan. 26 a public meeting, convened by the Workingmen's National Emigration Association.

During fourteen months Spain has been moving in a circle, and is again precisely in the position she started from in November 1868. The coalition of parties that framed her Constitution laid down the principle that for the reestablishment of public order it was necessary to have a King, and now, after exposing the Crown to a species of Dutch auction, they have ended as they began, by having neither King nor order.

Mr. SHERMAN waked up a drowsy Senate this morning by the introduction of a resolution acknowledging the existence of a state of war in Cuba, and pledging the maintenance of a strict neutrality by the United States. The galleries became excited immediately, and, in a few minutes,

The following game was played Thursday evening in the Brooklyn Chess Club Tourney, between Messrs. F. PERRIN and J. A DE CON. It contains many points of interest and is a favorable specimen of the so-called Petroff's defence to the knight's game:

The Massachusetts Senate has passed the bill to incorporate the Cape Cod Canal Company. Shoo Fly has now got into the Congressional Globe. Of course that finishes it. the expenses of Girard College last year amounted to $163,790. One SMITH is the champion skater in Wisconsin.

The Harvard Club of New-York City, composed of alumni of the Harvard University residing here and in this vicinity, gave its fourth annual dinner at DELMONICO'S last evening. J. C. CARTER, Esq., President of the Club, presided. There were present at the guests' table President ELIOT, of the University;.Hon. WM.

Bristed vs. Brown; judgment for plaintiff on demurrer. Reth vs. Hall; motion granted. Allen vs. The Great American Sanitary Company; motion denied without costs. Price vs. Price, and Rooke vs. Atwood; see memoranda.

The Assembly this morning disposed of the Insuit to its dignity, perpetrated in the arrest of H. RAY, by resolving to summon Judge POTTER, District-Attorney FRENCH and Officer BENEDICT before the bar of the House on Wednesday next to explain or apologize for their conduct and receive such punishment or reprimand as the House may direct.

A sale of a small but choice collection of oil paintings, all by native artists, with three or four eceptions, took place last evening at the art gallery of LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co., in Clinton Hall. The attendance was large and comprised a number of our wealthiest citizens. Mr. J. F. KENSTT was represented by five pictures, which sold as follows: "In, the Meadows," $175;

Mr. CORBETT introduced a bill granting lands to aid in the construction of a canal in Oregon. BILLS REPORTED FROM COMMITTEE. Mr. POMEROY, from the Committee on Public Lands, reported, without amendment, a bill providing for the location of Agricultural College sorip by actual settlers; also, with amendments,

The memorial for relief presented to Congress by Mrs. FRANCES ANN McCAULEY, widow of a former United States Consul-General at Alexandria, Egypt, is one that should appeal very strongly to that body, both on grounds of sympathy and justice.

A mass meeting was called last evening at Walker's Building to ratify the nomination of the ticket in opposition to the orthodox municipal election ticket. An immense crowd was present, and the hall was crammed with orthodox Mormons. Before the hour of meeting no room was left for the opposition.

The following is the list of new buildings proposed since the last report and for the week ending Thursday, Feb. 10, 1870: BRICK AND STONE FRONTS. Two tenement houses, south side of Seventy-fourth-street, 168.8 feet east of Third-avenue, 16.8x55, basement and four stories: F. ROLLINS. owner.

The fact that a work of this kind, treating its subjects, as it does, in the driest possible manner, should in the course of twelve years have reached a fifth edition, is a proof at once of its excellence, and of the need which existed for it.

REPORTS. By Mr. TWEED--Amending the act chartering the New-York Institute for the Blind. By Mr. CAULDWELL--The Yonkers Street bill. By Mr. WOODEN--Authorizing the North American Life Insurance Company to issue scrip to policy holders.

Application was made to the Court of Common Pleas by the distillers of the Second District to restrain Collector DULLAN from collecting by distrait the tax assessed under the rule requiring forty-eight hours for fermentation, instead of seventy-two hours, as heretofore.

The examination in the case of E. W. FA- RINGTON, an ex-United States ganger, jointly arrested with LEWIS P. WETMORE, on a charge of making false returns on a large quantity of whisky, was commenced in the United States Commissioners' Office yesterday.

Captain ENOCH W. PEABODY, of the ship Neptune, concerning whose alleged maltreatment of certain members of his crew so much has lately been said in the newspapers, desires the public to suspend judgment regarding the allegations made against him until the result of the legal investigation now pending shall be made known.

A meeting of real estate owners and grain warehousemen of New-York and Brooklyn, called to consider the question of the changes necessary in the management of the canals, with reference of the general interests of the State and City of New-York, was held at No. 5 Moore-street yesterday. Mr. A. E. MASTER was called to the chair, and Mr. JAS. McCHESNEY appointed Secretary.

On the 23d of November a Committee of " fifteen traveling preachers" made a report upon some alleged frauds in the Methodist Book Concern. They had spent forty days in the investigation, and had examined many witnesses. They reported, inter alia,...

Commissioner BRENNAN yesterday investigated complaints against Policemen as follows: Being off post, seventeen; not patrolling, two; intoxication, one; improper conduct, two. One of the cases of interest was that of GEORGE WHITMAN, of the Twenty-second Precinet, who was charged with making an unwarranted arrest by JAMES ROONEY, of No. 548 West Fifty-second-street.

The steamship Morro Castle, which left Havana Feb. 5, and touched at Nussan, N. P., reached this port last evening. Purser R. W. ALBERT will accept our thanks for the prompt delivery of our Havana correspondence.

A special dispatch from Helena to the Avalanche this morning, from Captain MATT GLASS, of the steamboat Commercial, says: " The steamer Maggie Hays, from New-Orleans for Pittsburg, blow up at "Chute 66," near Helena, yesterday afternoon, killing Captain MARTIN, the second engineer and eight deck hands. The second clerk, Mr. REESE, is badly sealded.but not fatally.

Mr. J. W. HILL, of Jefferson, Williams County, Iowa, has invented a double-shotted projectile, by which he claims a shot can be thrown a distance of eight or ten miles. Messrs. HILL and ROBERTS arrived here on Monday, with permission from Washington to make experiments.

The recent opinion of the majority of the Supreme Court stands in direct hostility to the uniform tenor of that great series of acts and measures which were required to destroy the rebellion, Singularly enough, it is the decision of an unfriendly Court of a State which stood on the brink of disloyalty which has been affirmed, and in effect the numerous decisions made in support of the act throughout the North are reversed.

BUTTLE.--ON Friday morning, Feb. 11, ROBERT BUTTLE aged 78 years. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 521 Grand-st., on Sunday afternoon, at 11/2 o'clock. BURRALL.--Sunddenly, on Thursday, Feb. 10, FREDERICK A. BURRALL, in the 75th year of his age.

The present session of Congress opened with an overclouded sky and numerous squalls. "Bad begins, and worse remains behind." Before Christmas the people's representatives never missed the chance of going into a quarrel. Hard names flew about on all sides.

The new steamer Herald has certain principles introduced in her model, which will render an account of her dimensions and construction, as well as the results of the trials, which took place a few days since, unusually interesting to those familiar with the science of naval architecture.

"IL BALLO IN MASCHERA." AT THE ACADEMY. A performance of " H Ballo " last night calls for notice only in the particulars wherein it differed from late representations of the opera at the same house. Signor LEFRANCO, Mme-BRIOL and Mlle. LAMI sang, respectively, Ricardo, Amelia and Oscar as before-or even better in parts-and as before greatly-to public satisfaction. Poor Mme. CELLINI,

At the morning session of yesterday pictures numbered from 961 to 1,090, inclusive, were sold, realizing $3,930 50, and making the total amount received to the close of the morning sale $48,933.50. The first painting of note disposed of was No. 1,005. A New-England scene entitled "Driving Home." by Biersladt, which was purchased by Mr. Townsend Connelly, of this City, for $425. No. 1,006, by the same artist.

Mr. Baltazzi Effendi, Secretary of the Turkish Legation, is at the Albermarle Hotel. Judge R. S. French, of Wilmington, N. C.; Hon. T. M. Bowen, of Arkansas; Hon. George B. Linderman, of Pennsylvania; General J. E. Peyton, of New-Jersey; Hon. Robert Strange, of North Carolina, and Hon. Charles Dewey,

The report of Quartermaster-General HEWITT has been published. It gives a concise recapitulation of the military condition of the State during the year ending Nov. 30, 1869. In regard to the war claims of Kentucky against the United States, he says that there was, at the date of his last annual report, an unadjusted balance of $1,337,542 55 due the State.

A contemporary points out that a citizen might have all his fortune invested in the stock of the Erie Railway, and yet possess no more control over his property than the man in the moon. The Erie bill passed at the last session of the Legislature is denounced as indefensible, and its repeal is called for in a short but pungent article.

Yesterday we published the fact that the investigations by the Book Committee, of the alleged irregularities said to have occurred in the management of the Methodist Book Concern, had been concluded. The report of the majority was prepared on Thursday evening, and its verdict was as follows:

The following letter from Admiral FARRAGUT to Secretary ROBESON, on the line and staff question in the navy, has been sent to the House Naval Committee, and will be submitted to Congress on Monday. Secretary ROBESON addressed a letter to the Admiral asking his views on the House bill No. 976, and this, as the Admiral observes, is the reason why he enters into the discussion of this embarrassing question:

Thirty-five persons were arrested on Friday and a number yesterday in Paris, supposed to be Implicated in a plot against the life of the Emperor. In all cases arms were found upon the persons of the prisoners. The story of the plot is discredited in London. Seven of the editors of the Paris Reforme have been ordered to appear before the Court for a violation of the Press laws.

The medical profession of New-York has determined to pay a becoming tribute to WM. HARVEY, the celebrated discoverer of the circulation of the blood. Regarded, as he justly has been, as the founder of the science of physiology, it has been long a source of regret to scholars and philanthropists that so few tokens of respect have been paid in any country to his memory.

The Winnepeg New Nation, of Jan. 28, gives the proceedings of the convention of English and French delegates which assembled on the 25th, at Upper Fort Garry, to consider the overtures of Mr. GOULD SMITH,the Canadian Commissioner. Nothing was done on the first day, the delegates not having all arrived.

Thirty-five persons were arrested yesterday on suspicion of complicity in a plot against the State and the life of the Emperor. In all cases arms were found upon the persons of the prisoners. Those arrested were Incarcerated in the Prison Mazas, all secret, on the Boulevard Mazas, and will soon be proceeded against. More arrests are to be made.

The fifth of the series of lectures given under the auspices of " Post Phil. Kearney," No. 8, Grand Army of the Republic for the benefit of the fund for the relief of disabled soldiers and sailors. was delivered at Irving Hall, last evening, by Professor J. W. DRAPER. He gave an account of numerous incidents connected with the late war, and described some of the great battles.

Prince NAPOLEON uses a Russian sledge. The Marquis of WESTMINSTER left $1,000 a year to his election agent. DORE is said to have made 40,000 pictures since he was 14 years old. Queen VICTORIA is 50 years of age; the Empress EUGENIE is 43.

The protracted discussion on the commercial treaties in the French Legislature has produced the usual amount of conflicting facts and irreconcilable theories which are so invariably associated with questions of national finance.

A flag for the National Capital, manufactured entirely of California silk, has been completed and will soon be forwarded to Washington....The Governor has vetoed the bill passed by the Legislature awarding damages to HALL and GARRISON, the publishers of a secession paper in Visalia, which was destroyed by a mob consisting of soldiers and citizens....

and Queenstown Jan. 30, and the Westphalia, from Hamburg Jan. 26 and Havre Jan. 29, both reached this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by two days than that at hand by the City of Washington, Friday night.

A correspondent of the Salem (Oregon) Statesman, writing from Polk County, sends the following interesting statement: "A huge monster was captured last week on Soap Creek, near the south line of Polk County, by two farmers by the names of MILLER and TRIPP. It has the head, feet and ears of a lion;

The Excise troubles of the New-York Democracy have but just begun. Fortune favored them in the political hazard of November last; but they drew an elephant in their lottery, and the question now is how to dispose of him.

A meeting of the umbrella and parasol makers was held last evening at No. 193 Bowery, when they regularly organized by electing Miss LEONARD President of their new protective Union. They have succeeded in their strike and will receive their former wages from the manufacturers.

The case of ROSANNA ROGERS, the girl who is charged with having killed her step brother, JAMES SHERIDAN, at Newark; N. J., on the 10th of November last, came up in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday.

A proclamation appears in to-day's official Gazette, declaring that on and after the 15th of April next American silver shall pass current at rates determined by the Government as follows: Fifty cent pieces at forty cents, twenty-five cent pieces at twenty cents, ten cent pieces at eight cents, five cent pieces at four cents.

Judge GILBERT yesterday rendered his decision in the question of admitting EDWIN PERRY to bail. It is as follows: This is an application on behalf of the prisoner, to admit him to bail. He is under indictment for murder in the first degree; he has been twice tried, and on both occasions the jury were unable to agree upon a verdict.

The Attorney-General has decided that members of the National Guard shall be exempt from jury duty during their term of service, and that a reduction shall be made in the assessment of their real and personal property of $500 each. Cavalrymen, artillerymen and mounted officers are entitled to an additional reduction of $500.

The bill reported by the House Judiciary Committee is intended to change radically the present system of naturalization, under which, owing to the varying laws and practice of the several States, there have been great confusion and opportunities for fraud.

Mr. SHANKS, of Indiana, presented the resolutions of the Louisville Commercial Convention in favor of granting aid to the Mediterranean and Oriental Steam Navigation Company. PETITIONS. Petitions were presented as follows: By Mr. SCHUMAKER, of the Cigar Makors' Union No. 97, of Brooklyn, favoring an incrense of the duties on imported cigars.

The painting numbered 1,375 was the last disposed of yesterday morning, at the sale of the Thompson collection, which has been in progress during the past week. No noticeable pictures were sold during the morning, and a large majority were portraits.

The Connecticut Republicans, in the resolutions adopted at their recent Convention, ask for a tariff "abundant for revenue and as far as possible so devised as to relieve labor, equalize the burdens imposed, oncourago a diversified industry, and avoid strengthening monopolies ;"

It will be a happy day, not for our navy only, but for the country, when the long and bitter quarrel between line and staff is settled by appropriate and just legislation. The last Washington tidings of any importance represented that a basis had been agreed upon whereby the staff should receive positive instead of assimilative rank, while the several grades themselves had not been settled.

The District-Attorney of Kings County makes the following explicit reply to numerous anonymous communications received by him while conducting the prosecution iu the Hayes murder case: DISTRICT-ATTORNEY'S OFFICE, KINGS COUNTY, No. 3 COUNTY COURT HOUSE. BROOKLYN, Feb. 12, 1870. To the River Thieves, Cut Throats and Murderers of New- York and Brooklyb :

The Episcopal Diocese of Illinois, with its cathedral, deaneries, and other organizations, has a total of 5,813 communicants. The Liberal Christian Conference of Michigan, composed of Unitarian and Universalist churches, will meet in Owosso this week. The Chippewa tribe are anxious to have a missionary amongst them.

Thirteen steamers from foreign ports were due in New-York yesterday, only three of which arrived in time to have their cargo invoices pass through the Custom House. For some days past business there has been dull, but an immense rush is expected to-morrow and Tuosday. As an instance of the amount of importing done by New-York merchants,

Burglars, yesterday morning, entered the house of.WM. H. JONES, Quincy-street, near Franklin-avenue, and carried away clothing and silverware to the value of $232. Another set broke into the house of CHARLES BUTTRICK, Bergen-street, near Franklin-avenue, and stole $178 worth of jewelry and silverware.

The tournament at the Brooklyn Chess Club is at present the centre of attraction for chess players of New-York and Brooklyn. Several distinguished chess amateurs from distant cities have honored the Club with a visit, among others one of the strongest players of Chicago, who has broken a lance with a few of our best amateurs, and although not altogether successful, has borne himself like a true Knight.

From the Springfield (Mass.) Republican. There are in the lives of many of us singular experiences which we cannot, account for to ourselves. One such experience persistently haunts at times a young man of this city--the sense of something at his side without noise or substance;

When DE QUINCEY essayed writing up "Murder as one of the Fine Arts," descanting in his own effective fashion upon connoisseurs, amateurs, dilletanti in the science,--in short, "murder-fanciers,"--it is plain he had not yet come to consider the existence and mutual relations of New-York working women and their employers.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Your leading article last Tuesday contains a frightful but not exaggerated picture of the dangers impending over life and property in New-York, in consequence of the new "Democratic" charter.

The killing of CASTANON created a very bitter feeling among the Spaniards, and revived the dormant spirits of the ultras, and the revengeful feelings of those who think that the revolution can be finished by the assassination of private individuals.

United States Commissioner WHITE sat yesterday for the purpose of ascertaining the merits of a charge recently made against a resident of the Eight Ward named SAMUEL L. FENN of having offered a bribe of $50 to Policemen JOHN H. CRAWFORD, of the Sixteenth Precinct, to secure his non-attendance in the alleged Diamond counterfeiting case as a Government witness.

In the midst of some very unpleasant political and social troubles, England has found time to get into a whirl of excitement over a game at billiards. The Prince of WALES was pleased to look on at the match, and a "very large number of the nobility" was also attracted to the scene.

In the case of The United States vs GEORGE JUDSON, before Commissioner JONES, in Brooklyn, yesterday, in which the defendant, a cashier in the Post Office, is accused of embezzling funds of the Department to a considerable extent, Postmaster BOOTH and Special Detective JAMES GAYLOR were examined on the part of the Government.

Few subjects have of late excited more attention from scientific men than the Gulf Stream and its effects on our meteorology. Last Winter in England was most remarkable for its vorual and balmy mildness. But at the very season when the Gulf Stream was exerting the most unusual and paramount influence in intimating the climate of the Isles,

The writer in the International, from whom we lately quoted, furnishes some additional details of the work of Evangelization which is being conducted among the thieves of the English metropolis. These we translate for the benefit of our readers. On the same evening that I accompanied Rev. ARTHUR MURSELL to the thieves' festival, a meeting of a no less extraordinary character was taking place in the New Cat.

GEORGE BARRELL, in the 83d year of his age. Funeral services will take place from his late residence, on Harrison-st., on Tuesday, 15th inst., at 2 o'clock. A train leaves foot of Barclay-st., New-York, at 1 P. M. The remains will be taken to Green-Wood the following day. BUTTLE.--On Friday morning, Feb. 11, ROBERT BUTTLE, aged 78 years.

The following opinion, which explains itself, was rendered by Mr. DORMAN B. EATON, yesterday: No. 2 EAST TWENTY-NINTH-STREET, NEW-YORK, Saturday, Feb. 5, 1870. The Secretary of the Metropolitan Board of Health: SIR: Reference having been made to me, jointly with the Sanitary Committee, of a petition for the removal of the alleged nuisance created on Fifth-avenue by the "Fisk concrete pavement."

At the Convention of Trottiug Associations recently held in this City, there were two delegates from the Far West who expressed an earnest desire to see the world-famous Dexter, the acknowledged "King of the Trotting Turf," and the other renowned fast flyers belonging to Mr. BONNER'S stable, while they were in New-York.

No American citizen, native or adopted, who values the honor and welfare of the Great. Republic, can view with other feelings than those of heartfelt satisfaction the gradual solution of the difficult problem of Reconstruction.

Two of the alleged consolidated bank robbers have been arrested. The Picayune says that special police officers were the ringleaders in the robbery....WILBER, Jr., of the firm of WILBER Co., is reported absconded with $100,000.

The Chamber of Commerce of this city to-day unanimously adopted resolutions declaring That the financial condition of the country requires such a supervision of the tariff by the present Congress as will yield the largest revenue in the least burdensome manner to the manufacturing interests requiring it.

A perfectly groundless charge was made on the part of a farmer, named ROBERT S. HALL, residing at White Plains, in the United States Commissioner's Office, yesterday, against a lawyer, named BENJAMIN LOW, of Monticello, Sullivan County, the brother of Hon. HENRY A. Low.

Five Italian operas have been sung in New-York during the past week-" Masaniello" on Monday, at the Academy; "Maria do Rohan," at the Union League Theatre, on Tuesday; "Linda" at the Academy, on Wednesday, and "Il Ballo in Masechera" and "Fra Diavolo " at the same house on Friday and Saturday. "Masaniello" has not proved so groat a success as we hoped, although Signor LEFRANC sang his part extremely well.

We gave an outline the other day of the route by which it is proposed to conduct the new Pacific cable to the shores of Asia, and thus furnish the last link which will be required to complete the electric chain encircling the world. A writer in the London Times furnishes interesting details of the various projects which are being matured to order to extend existing European lines to the confines to China and Japan.

A ship, supposed the Santee, of Portsmouth, N. H., Captain MAGRAM, from Guanape with guano, Aug. 12. for Liverpool, struck off Skibbereen, south coast of Ireland, recently, and all hands are supposed to have perished. A stove, marked "Jos. SARGENT, Boston, No. 4." had been washed ashore from her. SARGENT,

The closing exercises in the evening schools will take place to-morrow evening. The term commenced Oct. 4 with 11,187 pupils and 316 teachers. The High School opened also at the same time with 1,200 pupils and eighteen teachers; twenty-nine school buildings were used--fifteen for males, eleven for females and three for colored persons.

Aaron Alrensleben, Secretary of the Prussian Legation is at the Albemarle Hotel. Hons. Samuel L. Nickerson, E. E. L. Sweet and P. L. Underwood, of Chicago, and Dr. J. J. Mott, of North Carolina, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Hon. E. C. Banfield, of Washington, Hon C. H. Parkhurst, of Providence, Hon. J. N. Ford,

SPRING's hotel, store and harness shop at Cobden, Ill., were burned on Thursday night. The loss is $30,000, and insurance $12,000. HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 12:-An incendiary fire took place in Stafford last night, at 10:30 o'clock, which in half an hour consumed the entire works of the Stafford Loom Works, involving a loss of $20,000. The insurance is $10,000.

HAVANA, Feb. 12.--The assassin of ISAAC GREENWALDTH was arrested in this city last night. He is a native of the Canary Islands, and a Sergeant in the Fifth Battalion of Volunteers. A Court Martial will be immediately convened for the trial of the murderer....Dispatches from San Miguel have been received.

About noon to-day a young clerk employed by MANNING, HOWLAND Co. was knocked down, choked and robbed of $2,700 in the entry of the First National Bank on State street. An alarm was promptly given and the robber knocked down and captured by a teamster, and all the money recovered.

CONSTANT MAYER'S new picture, "The Witch's Daughter," which has been in this City of late on exhibition for the benefit of the Sisters of the Stranger, is illustrative of a characteristic phase of New-England sentiment in the old time, the days of superstition and bigotry, and the adaptation of the work to its present purposes

The Quarantine Commissioners met at No. 155 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of hearing such suggestions as the merchants and others interested in tile commerce of the port might have to make concerning the conduct of affairs at Quarantine and as to tile need of reforms therein.

The Washington Chronicle publishes the following letter from Chief Justice CHASE, written while Secretary of the Treasury, in 1862, to the Committee of Ways and Means: TREASURY DEPARTMENT, Jan. 29, 1862. SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of a resolution of the Committee of Ways and Means, referring me to House bill No. 240, and requesting my opinion as to the propriety and necessity of its immediate passage by Congress.

The arrival year after year in Italy of Americans practcing art in the Department of Sculpture, suggests an inquiry as to their prospects of success. Italy is found to be an excellent field for the prosecution of art with reference to money profit.

A letter from General HARNEY to General SCHOFIELD, dated Feb. 8, says: Bands of hostile Indians are again roaming off a little to the west of our frontier settlements, which are now at the mercy of the miscreants.

The Chinese new year is not progressing with entire harmony. Yesterday great excitement existed among the rival clans of that people, and a bloody riot seemed at one time imminent. For a long time past the theatre on Jackson-street has been in operation, and enjoyed a large share of the Celestial patronage.
A special meeting of the Gold Board was held yesterday afternoon to bear the report of the Committee of three appointed on Thursday last to investigate the charges against Messrs. VAN SAUN Co.

The attempted suicide of Mrs. MARY SINNETT, of No. 82 Wyckoff-street, Brooklyn, has opened a Pandora's box of secrets as to how the people's money is paid away by reckless officials, and gives some inkling as to why so much out-door poor money is used up every year. The ease was brifly stated in the TIMES yesterday.

Shortly after daylight yesterday morning two suspicious looking men were discovered by Captain EDWARD WALSH and Officers CAMPBELL and CAREW, of the fourteenth Ward Police, as they emerged from the doorway of the premises corner of Baxter and Grand streets.

By a gentleman who arrived by yesterday's stage from the interior of Mexico, and who is well posted regarding existing affairs in Mexico, we have learned the following particulars, which may well be considered a bird's eye view of the present condition of that country:

Officer HELDELBURG, of the Second Ward Police, yesterday arrested THOMAS SICKLES, a boy aged 14, residing at No. 94 Flatbush-avenue, on a charge of larceny. It appears that the prisoner was on Thursday given as certified cheek for $200 on the St. Nicholas Bank by his employers, HENRY LEVY CO., at No. 49 Maidenlane.

The Arion Singing Society, in preparation for the coming masquerade, held a rehearsal at the Germania Assembly Rooms yesterday afternoon. The two main features of the ball will be a representation of a scene on the Pacific Railroad, symbolizing progress, and a representation of the Ecumenical Council, symbolizing reaction.
The House Committee on Public Lands, through their Chairman, Mr. JULLAN, have presented their report with reference to the occupancy of the famous Yosemite Valley.

The Tribune recently accused the Special Commissioner of the Revenue of gross inaccuracy,-alleging that he had stated in his annual report that the wool crop of the United States for 1868 was 177,000,000 pounds, "or four and three-quarters per head for each sheep in the country, when the clip per head in 1860 was only 2.68 pounds."

The new Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents, corner of Broadway and Thirty-seventhstreet, was dedicated yesterday morning. It is built on the site of the old Protestant Episcopal Church, which was purchased some four yearssince of Rev. Mr. ELMENDOFF by the Pastor, Father LARKIN, and converted into a Catholic chapel.

BEN WADE says Cuba must and shall be free. Many of our politicians, though not speechless, are senseless. STERN WHEELER has just joined the staff of the Jackson (Mich.) Citizen. The President smokes, and Congress and Virginia are both interested in the SEGAR case. Iowa has given about one-fifth of its area to aid railroads.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13.--Two slight shocks of earthquake were felt in this city at 3:30 o'clock this morning.... The sale of choice seats for the Camilla Urso Festival, in aid of the Mercantile Library Association, took place last night, and realized $9,000. Mayor SEELY secured the "Grand Box" at $3,200.

Rev. H. W. BEECHER yesterday morning preached upon the subject of the worship of the gods of this world, which blind their votaries. During the course of a long and eloquent sermon he took occasion to say that the gods which the men of the present day are worshiping are pride, selfishness, money, political fame, lust, and sensuality in all its phases.

If the purification of the American judicature is not to be expected until Irishmen are debarred from voting, or until the people give up the direct appointment of public servants, it may be long before the reputation of American Judges recovers itself.

The telegraph brings us the news of a horrible affair at Atchison yesterday morning. It seems that a man named FRANCIS BUTTOMER, who had recently come to that city from Iowa, attended mass with his wife in the morning, and while walking home, deliberately drew a revolver, shot his wife three times,

The efforts which are being made to reform the gas system of this City will be all the more effective if the experience of similar struggles elsewhere be properly understood. For many years prior to 1868 the City of London had been supplied with gas by several great corporations, pretty much in the same way as New-York is now.

The regular monthly meeting of this Society was hold on Friday afternoon last at its rooms, No. 805 Broadway, Rev. CIIAS. H. APPLEGATE, Vice-President, in the chair, JAS. H. PETTON, Secretary. The following is the report of the work accomplished by the missionaries for the past month: Rev. D. L. MARKS, preacher in charge of Missions, New-York Conference, reported: Religious meetings hold.

The quiet town of Lehighton was the scene of much excitement on Tuesday. It was rumored during the day that the Wilkesbarre bank robbers were in the town, but the statement was hardly believed till Constable J. T. WESTON approached four suspicious looking characters, who had been loafing about Mantz's Hotel, with the intention of arresting them.

The first regular Sunday service at the new Water-street Mission and Home for Fallen Women was held yesterday at 3 o'clock P. M. The street presented a very quiet and Sabbathlike appearance, and as the appointed hour drew near, an audience gathered in the low-studded room, now devoted to the regeneration of this degraded locality, which comfortably filled it, and no more.

The following summary of monthly collections of internal revenue or the first half of the current fiscal year, compared with the collections of the first half of the previous fiscal year, presents some Interesting and suggestive facts.

Hon. D. S. BENNETT, member of Congress from this district, will issue a card to the public in the morning papers, stating in substance that he has returned from Washington at the earliest possible moment to vindicate his character

The first Sunday services in the Calvary Chapel, which has just been opened at the Five Points by the City Mission, was held last evening. The neat and commodious edifice was well filled, and in the audience was a goodly number of the residents of that humble locality.

FRANCIS TAYLOR a man about 50 years of age. who resided at No. 73 Chamber-street, Newark, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself with a pistol. He was of very intemperate habits, and is said to have attempted to take his life several times before. During the war he served for some time in the Thirty-ninth Regiment New-Jersey Volunteers.

Dr. GEO. CHRISTIAN STIEBLING lectured on "Vaccination and Smallpox" before the German Freethinkers' Society, at No. 101 Hester-street, last night. He gave a history of vaccination, then spoke on smallpox, its different kinds, phases, contagious character, and finally refuted the objections against vaccination.

CARTER--WELLINGTON.--At Churchill, Kansas, on Wednesday, Jan. 26, 1870. Captain MASON CARTER, 5th Infantry, U. S. A., to LUCY DOWNING, second daughter of Dr. Oliver H. Wellington, formerly of this City.

According to District-Attorney MORRIS the "river thieves, cutthroats and murderors" of New-York and Brooklyn, are to be congratulated on the escape of " EDWIN PERRY, Esq.," who has lately boon subjected to the inconvenience of undergoing a trial for murder.

The tannery of C. H. STURGES and the dwelling house of JAMES H. QUICK, on Caroline-street, were destroyed by fire about 4 o'clock this morning. The lose of Mr. STURGES is about $5,000; insured for $2,500 in the Lancaster Insurance Company.

Last week was by far the most active of the season thus far in the public sales of real estate. the property was of almost every description, and in most cases brought very fair prices. Private sales continue to be negotiated with caution and some difficulty, but there is no indication of any significant fall in prices.

A large encouraging meeting in behalf of African colonization was held under the auspices of the American Colonization Society in the Collegiate Dutch Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, last evening. The venerable Professor SAMUEL F. B. MORSE presided on the occasion.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It may not be amiss to direct the attention of your readers to the experience of the City of London in the matter of gas. When the Corporation of that city, acting on behalf of tbo people, undertook to compel the gas companies to raise their standard from fourteen to eighteen candles, they were baffled for three or four years.

The Holyoke (Mass.) Transcript publishes the following copy of a quaint letter from Rev. JOHN PENDLETON, of Springfield, to AMOS ALLEN, of West Springfield, one of his parishioners, which bears the date of July 6, 1787: HONORED SIR: My kind love to thee and thy wife and dear family hoping these lines will find you well, Dear Sir, I know you love to do good.

A few minutes past 12 o'clock on Wednesday night piercing shricks of "murder" were heard issuing from the yard attached to the Commercial and Farmers' Bank, at the corner of German and Howard streets. Officers McDONALD, CONROY, FITSIMMONS and B. KNIGHT

The Central Park meteorological report for last week sets forth the following facts and figures: Barometer--Mean, 29.752 inches; maximum at 11 A. M., Feb. 7, 30.208 inches; minimum at 6 P. M., Feb. 8, 29,058 inches; range, 1,150 inches. Thermometer--Mean, 32.8??; maximum at 4 P. M., Feb. 12, 45.5??; minimum at 5 A. M., Feb. 11, 22.5??; range, 23??.

A course of free lectures will be delivered at the New-York Port Society's Mariners' Church, in Catharine-street, Rev. E. D. MURPHY, on successive Tuesday evenings as follows The first, next Tuesday evening, the 15th, by Rev. JOHN HENRY BRODT. Subject: "Mexico and its People," with pictorial illustrations.

This is the day on which, according to some writers, in ancient Rome, at the festival of tile Lupercalfa, the names of young women wore' placed in a box, from which they were taken by young men, according as chance directed. The custom still prevails. The box in this latter day and city is attached to. a lamp post, and is big on the 14th of February with the fate of many true hearts.

The Winnepeg New Nation, of Jan. 28, gives the proceedings of the convention of English and French delegates which assembled on the 25th, at Upper Fort Garry, to consider the overtures of Mr. GOULD SMITH,the Canadian Commissionor. Nothing was done on the first day, the delegates not having all arrived. On the third day the Convention was ready for business.

ALLEN.--On Saturday, Feb. 12, Mrs. ELIZA C. ALLEN, relict of the late Andrew Allen. Funeral services from the Church of the Holy Communion, on Tuesday, at 1 o'clock P. M. The friends of her brothers, John W. and Wm. P. Miller, are invited to attend without further notice. BREWSTER.--AT New-Rochelle, on Saturday, Feb. 12, CARRIE H., wife of Frederick W. Brewster.

The link which has connected three of the most remarkable persons in our city for almost a century was broken yesterday by the death of the youngest, MISS BETSY THOMAS, who passed away calmly at noon at the good old age of 96.

A maiden lady, aged 40 years, named JULIA STEBBINS was yesterday found dead in her bed in her room at the American Hotel in Jersey City, under circumstances which gave rise to suspicions of foul play. Coroner BURNS was notified. After having inquired into the facts he directed the arrest of WM. BONIFASSI, alias Charles Mabbechi, on suspicion of having poisoned her.

About 11:30 this forenoon a desperate robbery was attempted by JOHN READ upon the person of WALTER SOUTIIGATE, clerk for HowLAND, MANNING LUCE, of No. 114 Federalstreet, who was at the time going to pay notes to several banks, and had in his possession about $3.700.

The week has been prolific of picture sales. First cane the " Thompson Collection." with its 1,694 specimens of various eras and schools. Then the public were invited to a sale of French and Flemish pictures at BARKER'S Gallery, and on Friday evening a small but remarkably choice collection of works of native artists was sold at the Clinton Hall Gallery.

Genral GOYENECHE again returned to Puerto Principe on the 8th inst. HAVANA, Feb. 12.--The assassin of ISAAC GREENWALDTH was arrested in this city last night. He is a native of the Canary Islands, and a Sergeant in the Fifth Battalion of Volunteers.

The subject of "reorganizing the local government of the City of New-York," as the "Ring" charter terms it, is attracting a good deal of attention outside of the Legislature as well as in, and among the people and the Press of all parts of the State as well as of the Metropolis.

To-day, we believe, woman suffrage becomes an accomplished fact in Utah Territory. Salt Lake tidings tell us that the Morman Legislature have passed the bill giving the elective franchise to the women of the Territory, and that the act has already been signed by Acting Governor MANN, and so has become law.

The Monarch sailed for Annapolis at 10:20 this morning. She was escorted outside the bay by the Leyden with the officers of the monitors, their friends, and a party of ladies on board, by the revenue steamer Mahoning and the steam tugs Cohasset and Uncle Sam. As the Monarch passed the forts she dipped her colors and her marine band played "Auld Lang Syne."

A dispatch from the State Capital, published in our last issue, stated that a proposition for the division of the State, with the Missouri River as the boundary line, is likely to be considered by the General Assembly. The same telegram continued the important intelligence that the people of tile Northwest are almost unanimously in favor of such division.

A new Reformed Presbyterian congregation is about to be organized in the upper part of the City, to be called "The Fourth Reformed Church." It is an offshoot of the Third Church, in Twenty-third-street, recently under Rev. Dr. SLOANE, and now has about 100 regular members, while the attendance at the services, especially on Sunday evenings, has been quite large.

The following is a translation of the extraordinary letter Don ENRIQUE DE BOURBON, cousin of Queen ISABELLA, and brother to her husband, Don FRANCISCO, has addressed to the Regent. It was at first believed to be apocryphal, and its charges against General PRIM considered so serious, that none of the papers would publish it;

The letter of our Paris correspondent onables us to understand the nature and extent of the socialistic plot which the French Government believes it has discovered. It is scarcely necessary to remark that to the official mind all Democratic movements are apt to assume a character of mysterious ubiquity which they do not really possess.

Last evening Rev. GEORGE LANSING TAYLOR preached at the Allen-street M. E. Church on the "Missionary History of Methodism." After referring to the fact that as a Church declined so its missionary enterprise died out, he said that the first methodist missionary society was organized in Leeds, England, Oct. 6, 1813. Long before that time, however, the methodist Church had sent out misionaries to the West Indies, Demerara, Nova Scotia and to this country.

Near midnight of Saturday Mr. DORMAN B. EATON, of No. 2 East Twenty-ninth-street, counsel for the Board of Health, was suddenly assaulted within twenty feet of his residence ly some unknown persons, who struck him on the back of the head with some heavy weapon and rendered him senseless.

Yesterday was the anniversary of this church, and the rector announced to the congregation that at a large and enthusiastic meeting of the gentlemen of the parish, held on the Monday previous, it had been unanimously resolved to raise the necessary funds for the extension of the church building to the Fifthavenue.

Rev. Father YOUNG, of St. Paul's Catholic church, Fifty-ninth-street, preached to a large congregation on the vicious and sensational journalism of the day. A certain class of weeklies, he said, selected tales in which adultery, murder and last formed the basis, together with the most prurient and disgusting details of the Divorce Courts.

The semi-annual exhibition of Columbia College came off on Saturday evening at the Academy of Music. The proceedings opened with the President's address in review of the great political and social events of the year 1869, in which he felicitously adverted to the flourish. ing condition of the College under its present efficient management.

The directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company yesterday ratified the new contract with the Missouri Railroad Company at the rate of $67,500 per annum for twenty years, and Mr. GARRISON, the Acting President, left for Leavenworth to-day to take possession of the road and arrange for through trains to Atchison.

While the congregation at St. Mary's Catholic Church in this city were engaged in worship this morning, a young woman named Miss MARY MAHER entered the church and took a seat. In a few moments thereafter she deliberately took from her pocket a pistol, and shot a young man named THOMAS WISE, who occupied a seat immediately in front of her.

This is the season of the year when that vast multitude of the population of this Metropelis who annually contemplate change ofhabitation, and contemplating, as often as otherwise effect a change of location, begin to look about to see if by moving they can lessen the evils in the form of house rent under which they have been groaning.

A very large audience assembled at the Cooper institute last evening to listen to a lecture by Rev. WILLIAM H. BOOLE, of Williamsburg, on "The Bible in the Schools." Rev. W. H. BUTLER presided. After religious exercises and a few introductory remarks by Mr. BUTLER, Mr. BOOLE was introduced and said that the building of the stately structure of the Republic it was never designed that the stones should be brought without noise and confusion.

The editor of the Paris Marseillaise, FONVIELLE, who is the principal witness in the Bonaparte Noir tragedy, has been liberated, but the other editors of the paper are held in custody. ROCHEFORT is still kept au secret. He sent to the Chamber, to a friendly deputy, last week, a proposition to impeach the Ministry, which the Chamber would not listen to.
Owing to the orders to have repairs on the steamer Ticonderoga finished Immediately, one hundred of the recently-discharged mechanies will be reemployed at the Navy Yard to-morrow.

In steamship Atalanta, from London.-- Richard H. Gill, Arthur Greenwood, Francis D. Gilbert, Martha A. Gilbert, Dorothy Waigle, John C. Waigle, H. Waigle, Elizabeth S. Waigle, Alfred J. Waigle, Estcourt Day. Richard Shandler, Chas. Davis, E. J. Wiclen, Jean Andrean.

Dr. JOHN BEACH proceeded to Ward's Island, yesterday, where he made a post-mortem examination of the body of PATRICK COSKER, the man whose death from injuries was reported in yesterday's TIMES. Death was found to have resulted from rupture of the small intestines.

The naval opinions of so distinguished a sailor as Admiral FARRAGUT cannot fail to have great weight with Congress and the country; and it is, therefore, with much pleasure that we refer to that portion of the Admiral's late letter to Mr. ROBESON which pleads for a Board of Survey.

The anniversary of the Sunday School Missionary Association of the West Presbyterian Church, in Forty-second-street, near Fifth-avenue, was celebrated last evening. The exercises consisted of singing, reading of the Scriptures and prayer.

That intolerable nuisance, the concrete pavement, on Fifth-avenue, is at once to be abated by the City authorities. Saturday noon a body of nearly 200 men were set at work with pickaxes, shovels and other implements, and before night a large quantity was removed between Twenty-third and Nineteenth streets. Portions of it are very hard, and difficult to got up, while other parts are little else than tar and gravel.

Some excellent decisions in the Criminal Courts were again delivered last week. To take the Court of General Sessions alone, we find one man sent to the Pententiary for three years for pretending to find a situation for a young German while he really committed a robbery upon the unsuspecting new-comer.

At about 10:30 o'clock yesterday evening, a difficulty arose between D. S. VORHIES and WILLIAM CHAMBERS, a picture dealer, residing at No. 53 New-Chambers-street, New-York, in the liquor store of PETER FOGARTY, corner of Columbia and Carroll streets. During the melce the latter drew a pistol and shot VORHIES in the head.

The Supervisors of King County yesterday resolved to increase the Coroner's fees to $12 50 per case. The sum of $10,000 due ex-Sheriff CAMPBELL for services rendered, was ordered to be paid. The Law Committee was directed to report the names of all purpose employed as stenographers for the Courts and the compensation they receive.

A post-mortem examination was made yesterday by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH in the case of JOHN MERKLE, who died at No. 459 Tenth-avenue from the effects of wounds sustained on the 1st inst. at the hands of some unknown persons.

Long before the hour named for the meeting of the Common Council yesterday, the halls stairways leading to the chambers of the two Boards were thronged by a most motley and miscellaneous crowd. It appeared that the Committee on Protests, who had under consideration the case of SEGER vs. GUNTZER, having completed their deliberations, were expected to make a report, and that the very large lobby assembled outside were desirous of hearing it.
M. THIERS, in his recent speech to the French Corps Legislatif on the question of a higher tariff on English goods, drew an historical parallel which must have often occurred to students of history,

The St. Thomas and San Domingo treaties hang doubtful in the Senate, and the islanders themselves are still more doubtful "under which King" they would "speak or die." It is now months, and even years, since King CHRISTIAN took formal farewell of his West Indian possessions, after the Seward-Raasloff protocol had been drawn and signed.

The United States vs. KEELER et al. Certificate of division from the Circuit Court for the District of North Carolina. In this case KEELER was Postmaster at Salem, N. C., on the breaking out of the war, and under the Confederate States authority paid over to one CLEUMMENS the moneys of the United States in his possession,

The search for the suspected conspirators continues in France, and many arrests have been made....Another suit against La Marseillaise has been instituted for publishing false news. ROCHEFORT, in a respectful letter to the Prefect of,Police, claims the right to send articles to his paper without submitting them to the keeper of the prison....

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I notice that there is a bill before the Legislature to purchase some seventy acres at the north end corner of Central Park for the use of the First Division, N. Y. S. N. G. Will you not use your efforts to defeat this enormous Jobs If there is not a great change our City militia is likely to become a most costly affair.

A new iron depot for the Third-avenue Railroad Company is about to be erected at One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, Harlem. The work will be commenced March 1. The plans of the Company are to have the building entirely fireproof, and four stories high, the upper floors to be used for a hotel.

The steamship Donau, which left Bremen Jan. 29, and Southampton Feb. 1, arrived at this port last night. The mails, including letters and papers, are later by two days than those at hand by the Java, and were received at the office of the TIMES at 1:40 this A.M.

The Darien expedition which sailed from this port about a week since, wilt probably be beard from towards the latter part of the current month. The naval steamers Nipsic and Guard compose the expedition. Beyond the fact that it is bound for the waters in the neighborhood of the Isthmus, with a view to making surveys and soundings for the proposed Darien Canal, but little is as vet known concerning it.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee held its first meeting for the year last evening, and organized by the election of Mayor MARTIN KALBFLEISCH as Chairman, Messrs. BERGEN and DAYTON as Vice-Presidents, Mr. GEO. G. HERMAN Secretary, and Mr. FREDERICK S. MASSEY as Treasurer.

Coroner KEENAN concluded an investigation yesterday in the case of MORRIS M. PEYSER the merchant from Boston who was accidentally killed on the 2nd inst. at the depot of the Harlem Railroad. Two fresh witnesses were examined, whose evidence was found to he unimportant. Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, who had made the postmortem examination, described the injuries that caused death.

WESLEY HARPER, the third in order of birth of the four brothers, for a whole generation known as HARPER BROTHERS, died early yesterday morning, Ho was born at Newtown, L. I., in 1801, and had thus almost reached the age of threescore and ten. When he was just coming to manhood, his elder brothers, JAMES and JOHN, had fairly established themselves as printers and prospective publishers.

It is announced that Lieutenant-General SHERIDAN and staff will attend the ladies' annual reception of the Union League Club, which takes place to-morrow evening. Invitations have been sent to General GRANT and his Cabinet, to General SHERMAN,

The "Eichenkranz " Singing Society, Mr. CHARLES WILATUS, President, and Mr. CHARLES SAHM, musical director, had a masked ball at Irving Hall last night. The ball was, despite the unfavorable weather, well attended, distinguished by fine fancy dresses and interesting and amusing masks, and a happy affair throughout.

Rev. Dr. MATHIESON, of St. Andrew's Church, died to-day at the advanced age of 75. He came here in 1826, and was much respected. OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 14.--Owing to the snow storm the train with Prince ARTHUR on board did not arrive until 7:30 o' clock P. M.

About 10:30 o'clock on Sunday night, as reported in yesterday's TIMES, a tragedy took place in South Brooklyn, under circumstances which reveal in the plainest manner how the laws are systematically broken by the keepers of drinking saloons. As might be expected, the whole neighborhood in which the tragedy took place was startled, then excited.

In steamship Donau, from Bremen.--Fred. L. Joanvalors and family, F. Derkhein and family, Louis Soumerhoff, Louis Pfeffer, B. N. Silventhal, J. Alexander, J. H. Hersing, C. Y. Strauss, Henry Cochran and wife, V. Wassermann, Alphons Kalischer and family.

GEORGE D. BAYAUD, doing business as an Importer at No. 19 Beaver-street, was arrested by Deputy Revenue Collector KOOP, of the Thirty-second District, yesterday, on a charge of not keeping his books open for inspection for a-period of two years, as required by law.

An interesting insurance ease has just been decided by the law Courts of Maine. The plaintiffs were H. W. LANCEY Co., of Portland, whose store was insured by the Phoenix Insurance Company of New-York, for $8,000. The store was burned in the great fire of 1860. The Company refused payment on the ground that the store was situated upon

The thaw of yesterday melted both ice and skaters' expectations. Sunday's cold snap was of no avail, except to give the City a whiff of bracing atmosphere that it has long been in need of. On Saturday and part of yesterday the Empire Rink presented a tolerable surface, but at McMILLAN'S and in Brooklyn the fun went when the rain came.

"HAMLET" AT THE OLYMPIC. Thanks to the reputation of Mr. G. L. FOX, to the magnetism of a new piece, to the popularity of the Olympic as the abiding place of genuine mirth, and last in enumeration, though by no means least in importance, to the foretaste of merriment in shape of a humorous correspondence between Mr. FOX and his admirers, and due, as usual,

The sale of paintings belonging to this collection was closed yesterday morning. The pictures disposed of were of an inferior grade, and brought merely nominal prices, consisting principally of portraits, crayons, water colors and colored lithographs, a few sketches by BIERSTADT in water colors being the only relieving feature.

In the House of Lords o-day the Earl of CARNARVON moved for copies of e correspondence with Canada and other colonies relative to the recall of troops. He desired that the Colonial Question should have careful consideration. He favored a Confederation of which Albion would be the centre.

MOSBY is in Richmond-not in Cuba. Maine has spent $21,000,000 for its 672 miles of railway. The Republicans of Alabama will hold a State Convention in Selma on the last Tuesday in June next. WENDELL PHILLIPS has declined the invitation to deliver the Phi Beta Kappa oration at Harvard College at the next commencement.

Numerous friendly inquiries were made yesterday in regard to the condition of Mr. DORIAN B. EATON, who was dangerously assaulted, late on Saturday night, near his residence in Twenty-ninth-street. It was ascertained that he was getting along in a very encouraging way. Every precaution has been taken by Dr.

HAVANA, Feb. 14.--Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD has arrived at Matanzas....Several accomplices in the murder of ISAAC GREENWALDTH have been arrested....A schooer with a cargo of arms for the insurgents went ashore dear Gibara during gale from the north. She was discovered by the Spanish officers and seized. Her crew escaped into the interior.

There were no auction sales at the Exchange yesterday. The business of the week will, however, open to-day with considerable activity. MULLER, WILKINS CO, will dispose of several valuable business establishments on down town streets, including the four-story brick store No. 165 Front-Street, four-story brick store No. 205 South-street, and a five-story brown-stone-front store known as No. 33 Cortland-street.

Last Fall the saucy pilot boat A. T. Stewart, having had enough of the ocean wave, one day went to the bottom in the lower harbor. Some wrecker came along and took out her mast and cabin, and that was the last of her until a short time ago the United States surveyors here received instructions to remove the wreck from the channel in which it lay.

The vote of the Vice-President decided in the Senate to-day the questions of talking up the bill for the admission of Mississippi. We are glad to see that the Senate Judiciary Committee has reported favorably on the nominations of Messrs. BRADLEY and STRONG as Associate Justices of the Supreme Court. They are sound and strong men, with personal and professional characters so free from reproach that their elevation to the Bench will win for it increased confidence and respect.

A most brutal murder was committed in Norfolk County a day or two since, at a place called Hickory Ground, the particulars of which are as follows: A negro family named SEGUINE had a boy in their employ, whom they sent to a grocery store to purchase a dollar's worth of pork, giving him a ten-dollar note to pay for the same,

As soon as the sad news of the death of Mr. DOMINICUS S. VOORHEES, the details of whose murder are given in another column; became generally known last evening, the inhabitants of South Brooklyn, as if by common consent, assembled and marched in a body towards Raymond street Jail, with the view of releasing CHAMBERS, the alleged murderer,

A man named JOAN SCHMIDT,' who had been employed at the zinc works at Newark, blow out his brains last evening in an orchard near the place of his employment. He had lost his occupation at the zinc works on Saturday last, and with the money which he received for wages drank freely during all of the night of that day and during all of the following day.

The anthracite coal trade the past week has been quite dull in the Sehuylkill region, showing a considerable falling off in the supply of coal, while in almost every other region the supply has been increased over that of last year. The Reading Road brought down of all kinds for the week 34,965 tons, against 45,870 tons the previous week, and for the fiscal year 503,845 tons, against 438,506 tons to corresponding date last

About noon yesterday, JACOB TROUT, engineer of CHAMBERLAIN, ROE Co., port packers, at No. 517 West Thirty-third-street, was seated in his boiler room eating his lunch. This room is at the northeast corner of the building occupied by the firm, and is not more than five feet square, and contained nothing but a small tubular upright boiler.

A large number of the property holders on One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street, between Third and Sixth avenues, met last night at Washington Hall, corner of One Hundred and Twentysixth-street and Third-avenue, to reorganize an association having for its object the removal of the Fiske concrete pavement. The regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board al Aldermen was held yesterday, President BERGEN presiding. A resolution was adopted appropriating $75 for the celebration of WASHINGTON'S birthday in each of the districts of the city, to be expended in firing 100 guns in honor of the day.

The term of the evening scholls of this City, which began on the 4th of October, closed last evening. These schools are filled up with childern whose circusmstances and employments make it impossible for them to attend the day schools, and hunderds of boys who almost support their parents by "shining" boots or selling papers on the streets, get there a dim and hast gimpse at the " ample page" of science and learning.

The New-York and Ohio Courts having sanctioned the leasing of such portions of the Atlantic and Great Western Railway as are within their respective jurisdictions to the Erie corporation, the parties in interest are now endeavoring to obtain the consent of the Courts of Pennsylvania to the leasing of the remainder of the line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14.-- The President sent to the Senate all the papers in possession of the Secretary of War in relation to proceedings in Georgia, in pursuance of recent acts of Congress, to promote the reconstruction of said State; and in relation to the organization of the Legislature since the passage of the act described.

The Democrats must and will make us feel the practical consequences of their victory at the last election.

The statement purporting to emanate from Minneapolis, to the effect that surveys on the North Pacific Railroadhave been suspended In consequence of a decision of the Secretary of the Treasury, is untrue. General SPAULDING, the engineer in charge, has three surveying parties in the field and all are prosecuting the survey vigorously.

In the Supreme Court this morning Justice READ read an opinion in the case of SCHOEPPE, "error to the Court of Oyer and Terminer of Carlisle," this writ being the last resort of the prisoner for escape from the penalty of death for the crime of murder of which he was convicted.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate various Executive documents, including the report of the Secretary of War upon affairs in Georgia, which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. THE GEORGIA SENATORS. On motion of Mr. TRUMBULL, the credentials of Senators elect HILL and MILLER, of Georgia, were taken from the files and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Two mills at Huntington, the Hampshire Woolen Mill of Messrs. LITTLE STANTON, and the Marseilles Factory of the Huntington Manufacturing Company, were totally destroyed by an accidental fire about 5 o'clock this morning. Total loss $200,000; insurance $60,000, of which $3,000 is in the Fire and Marine Company of this city.

ALLEN.--On Saturday, Feb. 12, Mrs. ELIZA C. ALLEN, relict of the late Andrew Alien. Funeral service from the Church of the Holy Communion, on Tuesday, at 1 o'clock P. M. The friends of her brothers, John W. and Wm. P. Miller, are invited to attend the funeral without further notice.

It is some sixteen hundred years since St. Valentine was beheaded, by order of the Emperor CLAUDIUS. On every anniversary of this gentleman's fate, young people delight pay their homage to his two prominent characteristics of "love and charity," and more particularly do they take an oath of fealty to the first of these his attributes.

Commissioners BOSWORTH and MANIERRE sat yesterday to Investigate complaints against policemen, of which seventeen were for being off post, three for talking on post, three for absence from roil call, and seven for improper conduct.

The following changes have occurred in the Custom House since Feb. 4: Night Inspectors, appointed at $3 per day-A. H. Rogers, vice Warren Carle, removed; Henry Gray, vice Phil. Reilley, removed; Wm. Brosnow, vice Jas. Friel, removed; Geo. Burr, vice E. Wall, removed; S. H. Shangle, vice M. Walker, promoted.

Last evening, a man named JAMES McCARRON, residing at No. 162 Prince-street, while drawing a charge from a loaded revolver, accidentally discharged it, the contents entering the body of his son WILLIAM, a lad about 6 years old, killing him almost instantly.

The spirit and temper of Tennessee Domocracy is fairly illustrated in the proceedings of our Legislature and Constitutional Convention, both now in session at Nashville. If it were not for the wholesome respect and fear the two bodies entertain for the Republican majority in the Congress of the United States, there is no telling to what extremes they would go.

The Teachers' Association of the Baptist Sunday School Union met at the Berean Church, corner of Bedford and Downing streets, last evening. Mr. G. W. HILLMAN presided. The attendance was not as good as was expected. An address was made by Rev. Dr. CHRISTOPHER RHOADES, of the Stanton-street Church, on the subject of the essentials for a Sunday School teacher.
