For some time the attendants at church funerals have been mercilessly fleeced by adroit pickpockets, and the complaints became so frequent that Capt. KELSO of the Central Detectives detailed two of his most efficient officers to the task of circumventing the thieves, if possible.

The war in Paraguay was the subject of an able lecture delivered by General M. T. McMAHON, late United States Minister to that country, for the benefit of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, before a large and respectable audience, at the Cooper Union, last evening.

To-day, at 3 P. M., the Governor-General, in the chamber of the Senate, in presence of the members of the Senate and House of Commons, proceeded to open the third session of the first Parliament of the Dominion of Canada with a speech from the throne.

The cable makes known to us, this morning, that a measure which has often been talked about has at last been adopted by the British Government. All the troops are to be withdrawn from Canada. The visible sign of dependence willthus disappear.

The preliminary sermon before the NewYork and North River Conference, comprising delegates from the Unitarian Churches in this City, Brooklyn, Staten Island and the towns on the North River, was preached, last evening, in the chapel of the Church of the Messiah, (Rev. Mr. HEPWORTH'S,) Thirty-fourth-stret and Parkavenue.

The difficulties of the Board of Health in dealing with the relapsing fever were fully stated yesterday in giving the proceedings of the Board at the secret session hold to consider the subject. The first-class United States steam frigate Colorado, which,las previously announced in the TIMES, went into commission yesterday, preparatory to leaving for the West Indies on a three years' voyage, is now a hive of business. All hands are at work getting everything on board in perfect sea-going order. When she will start on her voyage is not yet known,

Contrary to general expectation last Fall, the price of coal has kept at very low figures during the Winter thus far, and there is a fair prospect of a still further decline, though the rate at which it is now sold in this market is about as low as it can be mined and transported for, and pay a very moderate profit to the producer. The mass of the people never present themselves at Washington to ask for special legislation in their own behalf. They are perfectly willing to bear their proportion of public burdens, provided they are left to the undisturbed pursuit of their respective vocations.

The celebrated Churchill Lind Suit vs. C. M. WOLCOTT, for the right, title, and possession of a large tract of land, including nearly 300 acres, with dwellings, churches, and public buildings, and other improvements erected thereon, is now in course of litigation at Fishkill, Dutchess County.

In the Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge BARNARD, yesterday, the Susquehanna Railroad war was continued. In the case of the Erie Railway Company vs. RAMSEY et al., a motion was made to have Mr. RAMSEY declared to be in contempt for proceeding with his suit against the Erie Company in defiance of the in Junction issued in this suit last December.

There is now open in Brooklyn; corner of Montage and Court streets, a splendid show of rare and high-bred poultry. The collection embraces English, French and Asiatic varieties; also, water fowls and turkeys. Mr. GAVIT'S crested turkey Victor Emmanuel holds the place of honor, and fills it with becoming dignity.

The following is the address of Mr. HOSEA B. PERKINS on the occasion of the presentation of the Kelly medal at Grammar School No. 11, in Seventeenth-street, near Eighth-avenue, to which we made reference yesterday: MR. PRESIDENT: I am at a loss to know why Brother KELLY should select me to perform this pleasant duty, knowing as I do that he has more of the gallantry of modern times than myself.

The examination in the case of GEORGE JUDSON, who is charged with appropriating to his own use money belonging to the Brooklyn Post Office, was resumed before Commissioner JONES yesterday. THOMAS A. KELLY, sworn--Redirect examination by District-Attorney PARRIS.

The condition of Mr. D. B. EATON was more comfortable yesterday. He passed a quiet night, and the absence of fever, which is most to be feared in cases of this character, has to a certain extent relieved the apprehensions of his friends as to a serious result from the dastardly attack which was made upon him on Saturday evening last. The following call for a public meeting of those in favor of a reform of the Tariff has been issued: We, the undersigned, who are opposed to the present unjust and intolerable tariff legislation of the country, and who favor a strictly revenue measure, respectfully invite our fellow-citizens to assemble in the hall of the Open Board of Brokers.

A new candidate for public favor has appeared in England, and is likely to attract great attention from all lovers of art. The work is called the Porlfolio, and is edited by PHILLIP GILBERT HAMERTON, the well-known author of Etching and Etchers, and other books. The object of it is to supply the public with first-rate works of art at a low price.

Some judicial decisions are not judicious. The Rhode Island Republican State Convention is to be hold on the 10th of March. GEORGE WASHINGTON has sued the City of Atlanta, Ga., and the trial of the case is set-down for the 22d of February. A cynical bachelor suggests to us that many of the girls of the period are less facts than figures.

From all parts of the State remonstrances are pouring into the Legislature against giving public money to sectarian schools under the provision smuggled into the City tax levy of 1869. We say "smuggled in," because this is a proper description of the way the obnoxious enactment was foisted upon the people.

BLUMENTHAL.--On Tuesday, Feb. 15, MARTHA J. BLUMENTHAL, wife of Dr. Chas. E. Blumenthal, in the 51st year of her ago. Funeral services onThursdayafternoon, at 3 o'clock, at the house, No. 143 East 27th-st. FIELD.-At Aiken, S. C., on Friday, Feb. 11, FRED. P. FIELD, in the 24th year of his ago.

The Society of Engineers hold a meeting, open to the public, in Room No. 24 Cooper Building, this (Wednesday) evening to discuss the construction of railroads. Professor OSTLER, of London, will read a paper on the peculiarity of the English railroad system.

The Arion masquerade promises this year to be a more than usually pleasant affair. The ball commences at 9 o'clock to-morrow evening, with an overture by tile grand orchestra, after which Prince Carnival escorted by the Lobby Committee in the costume of pages of MARIA ANTOINETTE. ascends the podium, at which time the curtain rises. He enters the gorgeous hall,

WILLIAM WRIGHT, the young man who was hurled into the air and terribly scalded on Monday afternoon, by the explosion of a boiler in the paper hanging manufactory of A. J. DECKER, No. 815 West Thirty-third-street, died yesterday morning at the blount Sinai Hospital from the injuries sustained.

The river is now navigable as far as Hudson, although there is a great deal of broken ice at this point. The channel is free while the shore hugs piles of fragmentary ice. At Crummello the blockade is very formidable. On the Kingston shore large quantities are lodged. At Poughkeepsie the passage of steamers and large sailing vessels is difficult but possible.

On Monday night a fire occurred in a building on the promises adjoining the Union Race Course, formerly owned by JOIN BOTTS. and used as a hotel, which communicated to and destroyed an adjoining building. The building in which the fire originated contained a large quantity of bay and grain, and a valuable pair of mules, all of which were consumed, causing a loss of $4,000.

JOHN CLARK, now residing in Front-street, complained at the Mayor's Office that some time ago he bought a ticket for Europe at No. 146 Liberty-street, and exchanged $870 in greenbacks for gold. On reaching Liverpool he found that he had been swindled out of nearly $800. An officer was sent with CLARK, and $400 were recovered.

The Nassau Oil Works and O'CONNOR's icehouse were destroyed ,by fire this morning, and a man named DORSETT perished in the flames. POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Fev, 15.-FRANK TREMAIN'S carpenter shop, at Wappinger's Falls, was designedly set on fire last night and destroyed. The loss is $2,500; covered by insurance.

Criminal offenders wore dealt with in the mostrigorous manner by Recorder HACKETT in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, the fullest penalty of the law being imposed on each prisoner arraigned for sentence. There were five culprits sent to State Prison for various terms, amounting in the aggregate to fortyfour years and six mouths.

The motions in the Bininger case, which it was supposed would furnish some indication of the position to be taken by the Circuit Court of the United States upon the threatened conflict of jurisdiction between Judge McCUNN and the Courts of the United States, have been decided; but without any such result.

The Senate and House met at 10 o'clock this morning. At 12 o'clock they proceeded in the election of Senators. In the Senate, Mr. BLODGETT, for the term commencing 1871, received 31 votes; present and not voting, 7. Mr. FARROW, for the term ending 1873, received 29 votes;

Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, the steamship Bienville arrived at Pier No. 36 North River, from Havana, having on board the remains of Mr. GREENWALDTH. Mr. GREENWALDTH was one of the three Americans recently shot by the Spanish Volunteers. It was expected that the removal of the remains of Mr. GREENWALDTII from the steamer Bienville would be made the occasion of a public demonstration.

SAMBUEL LAFFIN, who resides in No. 323 West Twentieth-street, was arraigned In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on, a charge of shooting at MICHAEL CLYNE on the previous evening at the corner of Eighteenthstreet and Eighth-avenue.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of War, with an accompanying bill, relative to the acquisition of sites for national coast defences. Referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. CAPTURED ORDNANCE FOR CHICAGO.

The following petition is receiving a great many signatures, and will very soon be presented to Governor HOFFMAN: To His Excellency John t. Hoffman, Governor of the State of New-York: Your attention is called to an unconstitutional tax imposed upon the citizens of the County of New-York.

Does the Mayor propose to offer any roward for the discovery of the ruffian by whom Mr. EATON was attacked on Saturday night Or are the authorities of the City prepared to pass unnoticed an outrage obviously originating in personal malice, and in no manner connected with ordinary street robbery Mr. EATON was not robbed.

The Labor Reform Party held the first campaign meeting last night, at Eagle Hall, which was densely filled, the galleries being occupied by ladies. the Concord brigade band was in attendance. The meeting was called to order by JOHN B. WATSON, of Concord,

Dr. A. W. SHEPARD made a post-mortem examination of the remains of DOMINICUS S. VOORHEES yesterday at his late residence. He was assisted by Drs. COCHRANE and JONES. The ball was discovered as been already described, but the precise description of the case is with-held for the present.

RICHARD DRYDEN ADDINGTON was an insurance agent, and during his life accumulated a little money. The Exchange Salesroom was filled yesterday at 12 o'clock by a crowd attracted thither by the announcement of several important sales of real estate by some of the leading auctioneers who operate at that place. The principal sales were made by MULLER, WILKINS CO., JAMES M. MILLER, ROBERTS ' McGUIRE and A. J. BLEECKER, SON Co.

As stated in Saturday's second edition, the men employed at the iron works in the lower part of the city have decided not to submit the proposed reduction of wages, and consequently work at all these establishments is now suspended. The judges of the Superior Court have rendered their decision in the case involving the question of the exclusion of the Bible from the public schools. The action was to dissolve an injunction heretofore granted to restrain the operation of resolutions of the School Board, declaring that the reading of the Bible and religious exercises should not be permitted in the schools.

A new scheme for defrauding merchants has just been exposed by HAGERTY BROTHERS, doing business at No. 16 Platt-street. It appears that the latter were visited on Monday last by a man giving his name as E. J. BLANCHFIELD, and that they sold him $5 worth of goods. He offered a paper purporting to be a check on the Ocean National Bank for $27 50, signed by W. R.

The regular monthly meeting of the Geographical and Statistical Society of New-York was held last evening at the Cooper Institute, Hon. CHAS. P. DALY presiding. Several new members wore elected, among them lion. CHAS, H. VAN BRUNT, FREDERICK W. LOWE, ROBERT C. HUTCHINGS, and others.

The House of Lords transacted no business of importance to-day, and adjourned at an early hour to enable their lordships to attend the House of Commons, where it was expected that the new Irish Land bill would be introduced.

Some young roughs from the New-York House of Refuge yesterday entered a store in Hoboken, and robbed the till of every cent It contained. They then moved towards Jersey City for the purpose of committing other robberies. When they had reached the Long Dock they fell in with a number of Jersey City boys.

By the arrival of nearly a dozen steamers at once at this port within a day or two, Custom House business has boon made brisk. Yosterday the rotunda fairly hummed with the coming and going of brokers. On Monday tile amount of duties collected was $638,000 in gold; yesterday $854,000-far above the average of daily receipts.

In the lower branch of the Legislature, to-day, a resolution was passed appropriating $39,000 to an Insane Asylum. TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 16.--In the Senate to-day the Newark Police bill came up on its final passage. Mr. J. N. TAYLOR opposed the bill. Mr. LITTLE spoke in favor of it.

The first of the triennial meetings of the Unitarian Churches comprising the New-York and IIudson River Conference, met at the Church of the Mesiah, Thirty-fourth-street and Parkavenue, yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. Rev. Dr. BELLOWS presided, and Rev. Mr. BURR, of Yonkers, acted as Secretary.

The Western Freedmen's Aid Commissioners hold their annual meeting to-day. Reports from various offices indicate that the educational work among the freedmen is progressing encouragingly. Over 300 colored teachers have been furnished the common schools of the South. The Commission had real estate worth more than $200,000.

An Associated Press dispatch has briefly informed you of a terrible tragedy enacted near Ohioville, this county, yesterday. Four miles below Ohioville, and twelve miles from the Hudson River, there resided a wealthy and highly influential farmer named DANIEL A. HASROUCK. He was about 45 years of age.

The City was again the scene of a murder last evening. On this occasion the victim was a woman, the assassin her husband, the cause jealousy. The history of the murder is necessarily incomplete, owing to the fact that one MICHAEL POWERS, the only witness of the crime, who is a totally irresponsible person, was allowed by Captain CAFFREY to leave the Twentieth Precine Station House after the affair,

The Woman's Suffrage Association will hold its regular annual meeting in New-York, beginning on Wednesday, the 11th of May next, and continuing through; Thursday and Friday. The various Woman Suffrage Associations throughout this country and the Old World have been invited to send delegates to this Convention prepared to report the progress of the movement in their respective localities.
The gentlemen of the Union League Club held their annual reception for the entertainment of the ladies last evening at the club House, corner of Twenty-sixth-street and Madison-avenue.

THE EXCISE LAW. After the reading of the journal the Senate went into Committee on the special order-the Excise law. Mr. SCOTT moved an amendment that at the general election of 1870 the question of granting licenses be submitted to the people of the State, which he proceeded to advocate. After debate, this amendment was lost.

Our Washington correspondent foreshadows an angry and protracted contest in Congress in regard to the admission of Georgia. We see nothing in the case that can justify either irritation or delay. It seems idle to discuss the claims to recognition put forward in behalf of the Legislature which elected Messrs. HELL and MILLER to the Senate.

Owing to the fact that Mr. DOMINICUS S. VOORHEES was widely known and much respected by all who knew him, and that his business was such as enabled him to furnish large numbers of laborers and mechanics with employment, there has been much deep feeling of sorrow for his decease, more especially on account of the sudden and unwarrantable manner in which his death was caused.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York. Associate I Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent. News packages for the Journalof Commerce. Times, Tribune. World, Sun, Express, Evening Post, Commercial Advertiser, Staats Zeitung and New-Yorker Demokrat, should also be delivered only to the same parties.

If the respectable citizens and farmers of Western New-York, both Democrats and Republicans, who have recently petitioned the Legislature against granting money to sectarian schools, wish to know how a Tammany Democrat looks on their efforts, let them read Mr. CREAMIER'S speech in the Senate debate of Tuesday.

We have at last reached bottom in the agitation of the census question, and the preparations for the ninth national census, to bo taken for the first day of Juno of the present year, have boon commenced under the law of 1850. Congress has utterly failed in its attempts to enact a new law more in accordance with the wants of the times.

PORTO CABELLO, Jan. 24.--The condition of political matters hero is worse than at last accounts. The prospects of the Government are dismal, and its troops are beaten by the rebels in almost every encounter. The cause of the robels is daily gaining new adherents.

A London telegram of yesterday brings the intelligence of several marine disasters of recent occurrence. Among these is the wreck of the Nova Scotia ship Riva, lost on the Lincolnshire coast with eight of her crew, and the burning of the bark Undine, from New-York, at Rotterdam .... Seven Paris newspapers have received "official warnings."

This is the age of great enterprises. Our columns this morning contain the particulars of the loan of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad Company, who are extending the rails from the summit of the Alleghany ridge, across West Virginia to the Ohio River, at a point not far distant from Cincinnall, Columbus and Lexington.

The National Executive Committee of the Union League of America met in this city, at noon to-day, at Willard's Hotel, Governor JOHN W. GEARY, of Pennsylvania, in the chair. A report was read by THOMAS G. BAKER, the National Secretary.

The funeral of ISAAC GREEN WALDTIH, the American citizen who was killed at Havana by the Spanish Volunteers, the arrival of whose remains in this City was chronicled in the TIMES yesterday, took place yesterday morning. He was of the Jewish faith, and the Society Binai Berith, of which he was a member, took charge of the proceedings. The male relatives of Mr.

We reproduce in another column a very remarkable article from the World on the misgovernment of this City, and the duty which at this particular moment presses upon the reputable section of the Democratic Party. This new manifesto will not surprise any one who has read the World attentively of late.

The other day, during the visit of Prince ARTHUR, apiece of news was invented for the comfort and satisfaction of jaded appetites. It was, however, no sooner set afloat than contradicted, and consequently it could scarcely have done much good to the enterprising journals which published it.

Our wise and virtuous legislators at Albany evidently consider life insurance companies easy and legitimate prey. Not a session is allowed to pass without more than one attempt to force these institutions to terms, either by threatening them with vexatious enactments, or subjecting them to blackmailing investigations.

We regret to announce that Dr. M. B. ANDERSON, President of the Rochester University, and his wife met with a serious accident on Saturday afternoon about 2 o'clock. The Doctor and his wife were driving in a cutter on Andrews-street,
The Judiciary Committee of the Senate again considered the case of Georgia at their meeting to-day, but took no action.

The Nova Scotia ship Riva was lost off the coast of Lincolnshire. She was bound to Boston with a cargo of coal. Eight lives were lost. The bark Undine, from NewYork, caught tire and was destroyed at Rotterdam. The Favorite is reported ashore off Greenock. She will be a total loss.

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 16.--General ESCOBEDO, largely reinforced, faces the insurgents of San Luis Potosi. In a telegram to President JUAREZ he declares the situation reassuring; but he has as yet made no attack. The merchants are fleeing from San Luis to escape continued exactions and robberies.

In steamship Java for Liverpool.--Mrs. M. Livingstone, Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Morgan, infant and servant, Miss Redmond, Mrs. Hoyt, Miss Hoyt, F. Meussing, C. Kessler, Captain Bildering, C. Cook, Mr. and Mrs. John Hart, Captain J. S. Watson, W. Smith, J. M. Durand, J. A. Manning, Robert Lee Dawson, Miss Dawson, Mr. and Mrs. D. King, Jr., P. Tillinghast and two daughters.

The symptoms in the case of Mr. D. B. EATON, who was assaulted by unknown persons a few nights ago, continued favorable yesterday, and although he was suffering considerable pain and quite weak from the shock to his nervous system, ?? physicians are of the opinion that no serious results will follow from the injuries received.

Mrs. MOULD, residing upon Tonnele-avenue, Hudson City, died yesterday at her residence from the effect of poison. She had sent to a drug store near by for medicine. The clerk returned inadvertently a poisonous mixture instead of the preparation which had been sent for. After having taken it, Mrs. MOULD lingered in great agony for a few hours, when she died. Coroner BURNS, who was notified, ordered a postmortem examination of the deceased's remains

The tunnel of the Pneumatic Railway extends at present to a point-half way between Murray and Barelay streets. It is painted white, and lighted with gas. Throughout its length it is of brick, and circular in form, and eight feet in diameter. At the upper end the vault is quite spacious.

The case of JOSEPH C. FOSTER vs. JOHN E. McDONOUGH and WM. E. DEVERNA was before the Supreme Court at Chambers yesterday, Judge BARNARD occupying the bench. The case came up on an order to show cause, granted on Monday last by the Judge named ex parte, at the suit of the plaintiff, JOSEPH C. FOSTER.

Monday night last a fire occurred in the store of MARIA O'HAGAN, No. 314 Fourth-avenue, of such suspicious origin that a charge of arson has been preferred against JOSEPH CAN, her brother, by JEREMIAH SULLIVAN, of No. 32 Spring-street, who alleges that he saw the accused in the act of firing the premises.

Commissioners MANIERRE and BRENNAN eat yesterday to investigate complaints against Policemen. The case occupying the greater portion of the session was that of JAMES S. DYER, of the Tenth Precinct, charged with blackmailing FREDERICK BYER, of No. 37 1/2 Bowery, keeper of one of the concert saloons that are the prevailing nuisances of that part of that thoroughfare.

The steamship Columbia, which left Havana Feb. 12, reached this port yesterday Purser MAGNA is once more entitled to thank for the prompt delivery of our Havana correspondence.

D'WOLF.--On Tuesday, Feb. 15, in the 47th year of his age, JAMES F. D'WOLF, of Rhode Island.

As the principal owner of the Nassau On Works, destroyed by fire Tuesday morning at Astoria, Colonel A. A. DEGRAUW, is out of town, it is impossible to get the names of the companies in which the works were insured. The Superintendent, Mr. BETTS, did not know or would not tell the value of the property destroyed.

To-day is fixed for the trial of REYNOLDS in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. REYNOLDS is under indictment for murder in the first degree, for having killed WM. TOWNSEND, in Hudson-street, under circumstances of peculiar atrocity.

The performance of "Faust" last night was one of those agreeable disappointments that sometimes occur to compensate for occasions when greater things are expected but not forthcoming. There were hazardous indications about the cast which, results being what they were, we prefer not to point out in detail.

The teachers in the public schools of Brooklyn are a poorly paid class, and they have long hoped that the Board of Education would take their case into consideration. The Finance and Teachers' Committees have prepared a resolation which is to be reported at the next regular meeting of the Board. It is as follows:

There was a very fair attendance on the sales of real estate at the Exchange yesterday, considering the amount of property announced for sale. Three lots of property were sold by MULLER, WILKINS CO., and one by BLEECKER Co. The former firm sold first the house and lot, No. 230 Wooster-street, between Bleecker and Amity streets. The lot is 25 feet by 50, and the house a small brick structure, two stories high.

At One Hundredth-street Market, this morning, there was quick sale for horned Cattle. All grades sold to advantage at prices fully 1/2c. ?? 1b. in advance. There were no very inferior animals on sale, and the lots generally finished off with a good top. H. BRYANT'S Ohio Steers were unusually fine, as were T. LINDSAY'S two-year old State Steers.

The work on the grounds at Manhattan square, on which are to be located the Zoological Gardens, is being vigorously prosecuted by the Commissioners, both because public expectation looks for development in this direction, and because of the much-needed accommodations for the rapidly-growing collection of animals that are now insufficiently and unsatisfactorily guarded in and about the old Arsenal building.

It has been some weeks since the residents of Brooklyn have been regaled with a first-class night sensation, but last evening a scene was enacted which reflects the highest credit upon all concerned, as a nest of thieves and blacklegs, long the terror of honest citizens residing in the vicinity of Nassan street and the Navy Yard.

The steamships Hammonia, from Hamburg Feb. , and Havre Feb. 5, City of Baltimore, from Liverpool Feb. 3, and Queenstown Feb. 4, and China, from Liverpool Feb. 5, and Queenstown Feb. 6, reached this port yesterday. The latest news thus received is fresher by five days than that by the Donau, and Captain MEIER, of the Hammonia, has our thanks for much intelligenco contained in recent continental papers.

A message was received from the President announcing his signature to the bill for the relief of the poor of the District of Columbia, and that bill for the relief of J. E. REESIDE had become a law without his signature. RESOLUTIONS FROM STATE LEGISLATURES. Mr. SPENCER presented resolutions of the Alabama Legislature in favor of the establishment of a National Postal Telegraph company, which were laid on the table.

The Committee on Tournaments have appointed the 12th of March as the closing day of the proceedings. As many games have yet to be played to bring the contestants under the threefourths rule lively times may be anticipated. The strongest players have yet to contend together.

The death of MATTHEW D. GREEN, recently recorded in our columns, recalls to mind an incident in his declining years which should not be allowed to pass unnoticed. About two years ago GREEN was stricken by paralysis. He was then residing in Fourteenth-street. During the holidays, between Christmas and New Year's, a small party in which the writer was present, proposed calling upon him.

We are called upon to announce the death of a young and promising merchant of to is City. Mr. ROBERT E. GWYER. Mr. GWYER was for some years connected in business with the South, where he possessed the love and confidence of all with whom he came in contact.

Examinations were held yesterday in the cases of LEWIS P. WETMORE and E. W. FARRINGTON, ex-gaugers, who are charged with making false returns on a large quantity of whisky at the time of its removal from bond. According to a clerk named JOHN S. GRIGGS, letters frequently passed between Mr. COOK, of the firm of GORDON, FELLOWS MCMILLAN, and the defendant.

The Pisciculturist, SETH GREEN, is known throughout tho land for his energy and perseverance in inquiring into and ascertaining the cause of anything that may be new in his little world of interest or nature. For many years Mr. GREEN has been at a loss to account for the enormous destruction of very small trout, but he has now ascertained the cause.

The example of Mr. DAWES is infectious Here we have Hon. DEMAS BARNES declaring, in the first meeting for the year of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, "That in twelve years' residence in Brooklyn he had seen taxes rise from $300,000 to $6,000,000 per annum, and those of New-York from $5,000,000 to $26,000,000, and that without Commissioners, but under boasted Democratic rule."

A bark has sailed from Boston for Cork with 22,473 bushels of Canada peas. A Southern paper called its loading article on Monday" Bosh." The Legislature of Nebraska meets in special session to-day, to take action on the Fifteenth Amendment.

The Assembly occupied most of .its time to-day in tile final disposal of the ease of alleged breach of its privileges perpetrated by Judge POTTER and the District-Attorney and Sheriff of Rensselaer County in the arrest of HENRY RAY, member from Ontario, who had refused to obey a subpoena issuing out of the Court of Oyer and Terminer of Rensselaer County.

Three weeks ago a Woman's Convention was held at Newark, N. J., in the theatre of that famous city. But the audience was by do means a large one, so that the seating capacity of the building was not too severely

The eighteenth meeting of the New-York Liberal Club was held last evening at No. 23 Third-avenue, Mr. HY. WEHLE in the chair. The Secretary read the minutes of the previous meeting and a communication from the Geological Museum, General Land Office, Washington, informing the Club that the Great Western Mining Company have just brought to that office a sample of roofing state taken from beds in Duluth,

A meeting of manufacturers, patentees and jobbers of fruit jars was held yesterday at the Astor House, EDWARD FATANI, of the firm of WHITALL, FATANI Co., of New-York, presiding, and S. R. PINCKNEY, of the Mason Manufacturing Company of New-York, acting as Secretary. The object of the meeting was the better protection of the trade.

The total of tho osses by the fire at Huntington, on Monday, which destroyed the Hampshire Woolen Mills and the Huntington Marseilles Factory, was $225,500. Among the losses are the following: Firemen's Insurance Company, of NewYork, $2,500; Corn Exchange, $5,000; Buffalo Insurance Company, of Buffalo, $2.600;

The House and Senate met this morning at 11 o'clock. At 12 o'clock the Senate proceeded to the hall of the House of Representatives and organized a joint convention for the purpose of comparing the Senatorial vote.

Last night a number of representative Irish Republicans of this City and Brooklyn met at the Clinton-place House, No. 755 Broadway, Colonel T. HANLEY in the chair, to organize an Irish Republican Central Club. Major JAMES HAGGERTY was unanimously elected permanent President.

The report of the Special Committee on Navigation Interests, submitted in the House of Representatives at Washington, yesterday, is a voluminous document. The Committee, in prosecuting its inquiries, have held sessions in the Cities of New-York, Philadelphia, Boston and Portland, receiving the statements of merchants, shipbuilders, shipowners and insurance agents, gentlemen having practical knowledge and experience the relating to the matter under investigation.

The main building of the extensive woolen mills of JOHN P. BRUNER, on Hamilton-street, extending over the whole block between Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth streets, took fire this morning and was entirely destroyed. The fire commenced in the third story of the weaving room, but from what cause is not known.

The all --absorbing topic of conversation of the ?? of the sporting saloons in the Eastern District and around the City Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday, was the arrest of the " flower" of the cock --fighting champions at "PAT" BRENNAN 'S cookpit the before, as exclusively reported in the TIMES.

An organization known as the Christian Workers' Association is now being formed in the eastern portion of the City. The object of this Association is to assist, by means of lay efforts, in the diffusion of Christian instruction in the lower portions of the City, now being loft to a great extent destitute by the removal of the churches up town.

A large and highly-appreciative audience was gathered at the Chapel of the Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, last evening, to listen to the addresses of several distinguished gentlemen of that denomination on the occasion of the centenary of Universalism.

Yesterday the tea brokers and jobbers were greatly exercised over the extraordinary demand that was observed in the market for Japan teas of the new crop. A vessel arrived a few days ago with the first installment, which was promptly disposed of at good prices.
The examination of GEORGE JUDSON, late cashier of the Brooklyn Post Office, who was arrested on a charge of embezzlement, was continued, before United States Commissioner JONES, yesterday.

The following is the list of new buildings proposed since the last report, and for the week ending Thursday, Feb. 17, 1870: BROWN-STONE FRONTS. One store and tenement, No. 50 Rivington-street, 24x60, five stories; L. BOHEN, owner.

The revolutionary Generals TOLEDO and MARTINEZ combined their forces, and threatening ESCOBEDO compelled him to retire to San Felipe, and from that point he fell back yesterday to Guanamato. The insurgent forces in that quarter far outnumber ESCOBEDO'S army.

The Erie Company are already taking defensive measures in anticipation of the threatened attack from the English stockholders. They declare the stamping and taxing of the stock by the so-called Protective Committee to be illegal, and announced that they will not allow shares so stamped to be transferred.

The new Atlantic is lively and fresh, and presents a good many attractive titles. Mr. BAYARD TAYLOR continues his serial; Dr. HOLMES has some characteristic verso, as has also Miss ALICE CAREY; Mr. HENRY JAMES inquires, "Is Marriage Holy ?" and seems to come to theo conclusion that whatever I that institutions may be in theory in practice it too frequently is not holy;

A large and very enthusiastic meeting of our colored citizens was held last evening at Zion Church, Bleecker-street, corner of Tenth, to take measures for an appropriate celebration of the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment. There were represented no less than eighteen union societies, and fully twelve hundred people were present to vote on the questions presented.

The second annual reunion and dinner of the Now-York Alumnt of Hamilton College took place at the Astor House last evening, and although the attendance was not large, numbering about seventy-five graduates, the affair was a thoroughly enjoyable one.

Yesterday a State Convention of druggists was held in Library Hall, Newark. A bill was drafted to be presented to the Legislature, containing the following provisions: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep open a store for the dispensing and compounding of drugs. ,

Governor WALKER, of Virginia, is reported to be preparing an elaborate message upon the finances of that State.

The Government has proof of a plot to assassinate the Emperor and Prince Imperial, and has seized a plan found on one of the prisoners to throw bombs through the Emperor's window at the Tuilleries....France objects to the proposed dogma of infallibility, because, if admitted, the French Bishops would no longer be answerable to the common law.

Yesterday that short figure surmounted by a square stolid face, that on the evening of the 5th inst. achieved an unenviable notoriety, was confronted with he outraged law. JOHN REYNOLDS was to be brought to trial for the Murder of WILLIAM TOWNSEND, all the circumstances of which are too fresh in the public mind to require reiteration now.

JOHN MALLOY, a brakeman employed upon the Erie Railway company, was killed on Wednesday evening at the Prospect-street crossing , in Jersey City. He was engaged in coupling cars and was knocked down and run over by one of them. Coroner BURNS gave a permit for the removed of the remains to south Fourth-street near Grove.

In the universal indignation which has thrilled through all the respectable classes at the attempted assassination of Mr. EATON, there has not been perhaps sufficient consideration of the crimes which this audacious lawyer has committed.

According to the announcement published yesterday, the funeral of DOMINICUS S. VOORHEES took place from his late residence in President-street, Brooklyn, yesterday forenoon. The people of Brooklyn seemed as it turned out en masse to do honor to the memory of the victim of the Sunday night barroom murder at the corner of Columbia and Carroll streets.

CAMPBELL.--On Thursday morning, Feb. 17, MARY, wife of Thomas J. Campbell. Funeral will take place from her late residence, No. 341 West 27th-st., on Saturday, at 1 o'clock P. M. The Senate to-day passed a resolution to adjourn over from Saturday to Wednesday next, and the Assembly passed another to adjourn from Saturday to the 1st of March. As neither House can adjourn more than one day without a joint resolution, and as they are not likely to agree as to time, the chances are that the usual recess of ten days, covering WASHINGTON'S birthday, will be omitted this year.

There was quite a stir in the atmosphere at the Capitol to-day at the announcement that the Ways and Means Committee had voted, by eight to one, that there should be a reduction of internal revenue taxation to the extent of thirty millions of dollars. The first measure of strength between the license men and the Prohibitionists has been had in the Massachusetts Legislature, and the former triumphed by two votes. However, the final decision remains doubtful, as the close vote of 108 to 106 may be reversed by the action of the 25 absent members.

Of course the wiseacres who proposed to excommunicate the TIMES for daring to urge a large and an immediate reduction of taxes, will expend all that remains of their wrath upon General GRANT and the Committee of Ways and Means.

The thirty-first annual reunion of the Eighth Ward Pioneer Clay Club took place at Apollo Hal last evening, under very agreeable auspices. The festivities were attended by a large and select company of ladies and gentlemen.

A large congregation filled the Sandsstreet (Brooklyn) Methodist Episcopal Church, yesterday, to witness the funeral ceremonies of theo late JOSEPH WESLEY HARPER. The coflin containing the body was of oak, covered with black cloth, handsomely mounted with oilver, and lined with white satin. The body appeared in a full suit of black cloth, such as the deceased was in the habit of wearing while alive.

To the Honorable the Board of Education: GENTLEMEN--Your circular relative to "instruction in German French, and Latin in the grammar schools" has been received.

The House of Representatives, some time ago, directed the Secretary of State to furnish the reasons, if any, why the Spanish Government has not paid in coin, according to the treaty of February, 1834, the interest upon the claims of American citizens, secured thereby to be paid in Paris every six months,

The expenses of the office of the General Agent under the new cartage system are to be met by the cartmen employed by importers, by a contribution of ten cents each for the purpose. In fact, unless a cartman pays this ten cents he will be refused a license.

The sales at the Exchange yesterday were very moderate in importance, and no great amount of spirit prevailed. MULLER, WILKINS Co. offered two lots of business property on Hudson and Thomas streets, but, receiving no bids, withdrew it,

In the Superior Court, to-day, the case of the New-England News Company against EDWARD J. JONES, State Constable, was brought up. The jury rendered a verdict in favor of the plaintiffs, for the seizure of 3,200 copies of a paper from the plaintiffs called the Day's Doings. A good deal of interest was manifested during the trial....

The Commissioners of the Central Park have determined to erect and open next Spring a dairy for the supply of pure, wholesome and unadulterated milk for the special use of invalid and delicate ladies and their infant children visiting the Park. The grass grown on the Park yields a return to the Park fund of 84,000 per annum, besides that derived from miscellaneous vegetable substances which grow in abundance from the prolific soil.

The following evidence was given by Mr. DAVID GROESBEOK, yesterday, before the referee appointed to take testimony in the suit of of JOSEPH H. RAMSEY vs. The Erie Railway Company: Question--Do you know whether Mr. RAMSEY owns or has an interest in any claim against the Erie Railway Company Answer--I do. He is the owner of some preferred stock, common stock some sterling bonds and some of its mortgaged bonds.

The Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction met yesterday afternoon. Among the subjects under consideration was that of the late insults offered to ladies at Bellevue Medical Hospital, which was brought to the Board's notice by a communication from Warden BRENNAN. The Commissioners passed a resolution directing the Warden to cause the arrest of any student causing or inciting a breach of the peace,

A permanent organization, called the Citizens' and Taxpayers' Association, has been formed at Hunter's Point. It objects are to protect its members against special legislation; to resist the imposition and collection of unequal and unjust taxes; to secure an equal valuation of property, together with a thorough and impartial collection of all taxes;

Montgomery-street was, last evening, the scene of a serious riot. We reported a few days ago the fact that the bricklayers and plasterers in Hudson County had struck because they could not get the price they wanted for their labor. They had been receiving $5 a day.

The sudden death of Mr. SWEETSER, which occurred at his residence in Twentieth-street yesterday, removes from the Press of New-York one of the most efficient, the most versatile, and less the best known of its younger members. Mr. SWEETSER was born in Brooklyn almost thirty-three years ago.

To find General SLOCUM and Mr. STARKWEATHER on the same side of the Navy Yard question is about equivalent to discovering that the people of Brooklyn ar as willing to have the yard removed from their city as the people of New-London are to receive it in theirs.

When a member of Congress finds that his seat is contested he knows very well that the decision of an impartial tribunal is not within his reach. His case is referred to a Committee, the members of which are nominated by the governing party of the hour.

The players engaged in this tourney visited the club rooms in force yesterday evening. Captain MACKENZIE played two games, the first against Mr. M. MUNOZ, which he won, and the second against Mr. BRENZINGER, which he lost after an animated contest. The latter game is so full of interest that we give it below.

A conference of pastors and leading members of the Congregational Churches of Brooklyn and vicinity was held at the Clinton-avenue Congregational Church, last evening. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, of Plymouth Church, presided and opened the proceedings with prayer. Rev.

The boiler in the Union Railway Car Works of H. M. WOODWARD, in Dekalb-street, in the extreme lowerpart of the city, exploded with terrifle force, about 2 o'clock to-day, FREDERICK KERGIN, FRANK COLLINS, PAUL DE BOW and the engineer, whose name has not been ascertained, were killed,

A large meeting of the property owners opposed to the sale of the easterly portion of Prospect Park, a tract of land embracing some 127 acres, was held at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn, last evening Hon. Our special correspondent at Paris telegraphs that the Government has proofs of a plot to destroy the lives of the Emperor and Prince Imperial, by means of bombs thrown into the apartments of the Emperor in the Tulleries. He has also official information that France objects to the proposed dogma of infallibility, as under it French Bishops would no longer be answerable to the civil laws.

By Mr. MURPHY--To enable the consolidation of the American and Foreign Bible Society with the American Baptist Publication Society. By Mr. PIERCE--Against the act relative to Brook. lyn Schools, and that the same lie on the table. Agreed to.

The annual ball of the Arion Society was given at the Academy of Music last evening, with its wonted success as a pageant and a social reunion. Tile house was filled, and the spirit with which the pleasures of the affair were entered into was maintained until the closing hour. In the Senate to-day the Drigge Land bill came up and was debated at considerable length. It was defeated by a vote of 2 to 6. In the House the Senate amendments to the Newark Police bill were passed. The Air-Line Railroad bill again came up for consideration, the motion being to reconsider the vote by which the adverse report of the Committee was agreed to.

List of Americans registered at the banking house of DREXEL, HARJE Co., No. 3 Rue Scribe, Paris, for the week ending Feb. 2, 1870: Philadelphia--Mr. and Mrs. J. S. Helfrich, Mrs. A. G. Curtain and family, Mrs. E. R. Edwards, Miss E. R. Edwards, Richard S. Edwards, Jos. T. Edwards, Thomas A. Edwards, Benina Smith, Thomas Wood, Dr. W. C. Cattell, Rev. J. W. Claxton, Orlando Crease.

CHARLES CORDEAY was arraigned before Justice DOWLING yesterday to answer a charge of grand larceny. The prisoner and an unknown confederate entered the store of WELLSTEIN MEYER, at No. 55 Leonard-street, on Wednesday afternoon, but Boon disappeared. A few minutes after, Officer BURNS, of the Fifth Precinct, noticed CORDEAY and his companion acting in a suspicious manner, and when they entered a Seventh-avenue car he followed them.

The object of Commissioner DELANO'S visit to this City is said to be, among other things, to inquire into the charges which have been made against Collector BAILEY on account of his action in the recent whisky seizures in his district. He has had several consultations with District-Attorney PIERREPONT, the result of which is partially in favor of the Collector.

The steamship Japan, from Hong Kong Jan. 12, and Yokohama, Japan, on the 24th, arrived at 10:30 o'clock last night. Her list of passengers, which is unusually small, includes M. HENGELMULLER and COLGATE BAKER, for New-York. The merehandise by this steamer to go overland to New-York includes fitty-seven boxes of tea,

Severall sessions of the Council have been held the present week; the last, that of yesterday, of which I have yet heard no report. It is believed that the third so-called public session will be held on the 2d day of next month, in the calendar of the Churoh the day of the purification of the Virgin.

Mr. WILSON, from the Committee of Conference on the West Point Appropriation bill, made a report, which was adopted, that the Senate recede from its amendment striking out the clause for the appointment of two Senators and three Representatives on the Board of Visitors.

Coroner KEENAN yesterday caused a postmortem examination to be held by Dr. SHINE on the body of MARGARET SHERIDAN, who was murdered by her husband on Wednesday at No. 517 West Forty-first-street. The inquest will be held to-day at noon in the West Thirty-fifthstreet Police Station, though it will probably be a very brief one, owing to the scarcity of witnesses.

A grand reunion dinner of the Theta Delta Chi fraternity took place at the Astor House last evening. About seventy-five persons were at the table. The arrangements were excellent, and reflected credit upon those who were immediately concerned in attending to them. The music was furnished by DODWORTH'S band.

Telegraphic dispatches received in the city yesterday afternoon, announced the fact that the steamer Maggic Hayes, of Pittsburg, Captain B. C. MARTIN, master, had exploded a boiler, and afterwards burned to the water's edge, near Island, No. 66, below Helena.

The Assistant Aldermen met yesterday. Resolutions were read directing the Croton Department to make contracts for the laying of the "Stow Foundation" pavement in Fifteenth--street, Twenty-sixth, Twenty-seventh, Twenty-eighth, Thirtieth and Fortieth streets, between Sixth-avenue and the North River.

Hon. HORACE GREELEY delivered his popular lecture on "ABRAHAM LINCOLN" in the Allen-street Methodist Church last evening. The lecture was accompanied by a musical entertainment, under the direction of Professor M. KOSMAN. The whole was gotten up under the auspices of Post Dahigren of the Grand Army of Republic.

Among the changes favored by the Convention of Postmasters at Vashington recently, was the compulsory prepayment of postage on newspapers and publications sent out by publishing establishments. At present it is optional with the publisher whether he shall make prepayment.

A firelast night destroyed the residence of Assistant Postmaster KNOWLTON. The loss is $7,000.... Ten days ago a party of masked marauders went to the residence of Squire WALTON, near Collinsville, Tenn., surrounded the cabin of one of the negroes and ordered him to come out.

Rain has been falling copiously all day. There was a furious thunder storm this evening, and the lightning was very vivid. WASHINGTON, D. C., Feb. 18.-The weather, this morning was warm, but changed in the afternoon, when a heavy rain fell, succeeded by a slight fall of snow. The weather is cold to-might.
Two members of the Ways and Means Committee had some talk last evening with the President, and the remarks made were to be reported to the full Committee.
The funded debt of Philadelphia is $42,4O1,934. The leading Democratic paper in Orleans County is edited by a lady. Baltimore owes twenty-five million dollars.

Mr. SUMNER forwarded to the Clerk's desk and had read a telegram he had received from the Governor of Nebraska announcing the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment by the Legislature of that State with but five dissenting votes.
It began to sprinkle rain at 7:50 o'clock on Thursday evening, accompanied by fitful guts of wind from the south southwest. It rained, however, but seven minutes during that evening.

We have a proof as convincing as it is gratifying that Mr. GLADSTONE'S Irish Land bill is a measure dictated by sound and practical statesmanship, and adapted to the complicated necessities of a deeply-wronged people.

The German Republican Central Committee of this City held their regular monthly meeting at the Steuben House last night, General FRANZ SIGEL presiding, when the Standing Committees of their Executive Committee were appointed. The officers of the Executive Committee are: WILLIAM GRASSE. President; CHARLES SCHWEDLER, Vice-President; ERNEST A. KLIEBE, Secretary.

CHARLES D. KIRK, a well-known editor, fell dead in the street last night from hemorrhage of the lungs. He was aged 37. BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 18.--Hon S. TEACKLE WALLIS delivered to-day, at the Peabody Institute in this city, an oration on the life and character of Mr. PEABODY before a large audience, including the trustees of the Institute, the municipal authorities and many prominent citizens.

JAMES MURPHY, ROBERT BRANIGAN alias MAHONEY, MICHAEL COUGHLIN and JOHN CLARKE were brought up at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, before Judge SCOTT, on a charge of burglary, preferred against them by LOUIS A. COLE, of the canal boat Forrest City.

When President GRANT assured the country that while on all subjects he should have a policy to recommend, he should have "none to enforce against the will of the people," we must suppose that he spoke of and for his Administration as a whole,--not simply for himself.

THE OPERA MATINEE. "Regoletto" so admirably sung at the Academy of music on Monday. is to be performed there at the matinee to-day. Signore RONCONI and LEFRANG, and Miss KELLOGG appears together in VERDI'S very dramatic work.

GEORGE EDGAR FARMER, Commander of Post Phil. KearneyNo. 8, G. A. R., and late Lioutenant-Colonel Sixth New-York Veteran Cavalry, a widely known and esteemed citizen of this City died on the evening of the 16th inst. at his residence No. 138 East Twenty-sixth-street.

Another earthquake visited this city to-day, causing hotels and public buildings to be vacated instanter. The streets were filled with people before the shock had hardly ceased. Fortunately it occurred about the time of recess in the public schools, and many of the children were out playing.

The groat advantages of rapid and cheap transportation are so well understood at the present day that it is unnecessary to explain the Importance of an invention that proposes to transport the malls and products of the country -its grain, fruits, moats, cotton, highwines, oils, minerals, coal, and merchandise generally-to and from all parts of it in a few hours, instead of days, and at a cost far less than by means of railroads.

In the British House of Commons notice was given of an inquiry as to the proposed action of the Government relating to a revised translation of the Bible. It was denied that O'DONOVAN ROSSA had been flogged while a prisoner, since 1868. The Abyssinian war expenses are to form the subject of inquiry by a Committee of the House of Commons.

The regular meeting of the Woman Suffrage Association for New-York was held at No. 140 East Fifteenth-street, yesterday afternoon, Mrs. WILBUR in the chair. Quite a number of ladies assembled, notwithstanding the violent rain storm.

About 1 o'clock yesterday morning burglars were discovered in the store of JAMES ROOSS No. 39 Frankfort-street. Captain DE CAMP, Roundsman ROGERS and Officer HOLMES, all of the Second Precinet, who happened to be near by, were notified by the person making the discovery, and hastened to the place, but before they could enter the store by the front door the burglars had escaped by the rear.

The Mexican Minister of Public Works has sent a letter to the Congress of Mexico, transmitting the original project for concessions for a ship canal through the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. The bill will come up for final action in April next.

The second annual ball of the American Protestant Benevolent Coachmen's association took place at Apollo Hall last evening. Despite the bad weather, the festivities were well attended by the members of the Association, their wives and daughters and numerous friends, and proved to be as enjoyable as any that have occurred this season.

Brad. ley, of Newark, N.J. HADDOCK-PORTER.--On Wednesday, Feb. 16, by Right Rev. Horatio Southgate. D. D., ALONZO R. HADDOCK to LILLIE T., daughter of William V. Porter, all of this City.

The schooner Herald, from Nassan, recently landed a party of thirty-six fillibusters at Gibara, under the command of General GOICOURIA. They were attacked by the volunteers, who killed seven and captured four of the expedition. The prisoners were executed at Holguin on the 14th inst.

Admiral FARRAGUT has given his cordial adhesion to Mr. ROBESON'S bill for staff rank -a bill which, it is understood, Vice-Admiral PORTER and the line in general approve; and now General SHERMAN'S recent letter is cited to support the same bill.

Some of our contemporaries are incredulous as to the sincerity of Democratic repentance wherever they meet with it. Their unbelief is too well warranted by past experience, but we doubt whether it is worth while to throw cold water on the efforts which a section of the Democrats appear to be inclined to make to inaugurate a new epoch in their party.

BIRNIE.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Feb. 17, EDWARD CAMPBELL, eldest son of Edward A. and Jennie Lawrence Birnie, aged 6 years, 4 months and 20 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his parents, No. 44 Hoyt-St., on Saturday, 19th inst., at 2 o' clock P. M.

There is now no bookseller's store in London or Paris which has so large and varied a collection of periodicals and newspapers as Mr. BRENTANO can boast of. The last mails have given him an endless stock. The Fortnightly Review, containing a new poem by ALGERNON SWINBURNE, the Argosy and St. Pauls are among the newest magazine arrivals.

The Legislative Council of British Columbia was opened yesterday' by commission, the Governor, MUSGRAVE, being too ill to be present in person. In the address the Governor announced himself in favor of confederation with Canada, and stated that it was the policy of the Imperial Government.

In the House of Lords to-day the Lord chancellor moved the first reading of the Judges' Jurisdiction bill, and argued at length the necessity for its enactment. Lord CAIRNS questioned the wisdom of some of the details of the bill, but approved of it as a whole.

The fifth of the great fires which have visited this City since the advent of the new year occurred last evening, at Nos. 246 and 248 Cherry-street. This double building, six stories in height, owned by ALANSON J. BRIGGS, was occupied by JOHN FITZGERALD as a rice and feed mill.

A driver of a mail wagon, Who had been purloining letters on an extensive scale for some time, was arrested yesterday, and is now in jail. During the past three months Postmaster EASTMAN has received a great many communications from persons in different parts of the country, complaining that letters containing drafts for money, addressed to them,had not come to hand, and suggesting that some one in the Post Office must know something about them.

This body hold the second meeting last evening at Hibernia Hall. Prince-street, for the purpose of making arrangements for the celebration of St. Patrick's Day. Among the delegates presents was the venerable President of St. Columba's church Temperance Society, Rev. MICHAEL MCALEER.

Tile Bar Association, of which we have more than once spoken is at last fairly organized, and has worthily begun its operations by offering a reward of $5,000 for the conviction of the person who attempted the assassination the other night of Mr. D. B

THOMAS BRENNAN was fully committed to await the action of the Grand Jury, by Justice QUARTERMAN, on Thursday last. It will be remembered that he is one of the parties charged with the robbery of WM. T. JEFFERYS, on the night of Jan. 29, while the latter was proceeding from Flushing to the Bay View House.

The commencement exercises of the Eclectic Medical College of New-York were held at Plimpton Hall last evening. A large auditory was in attendance. and the utmost interest was manifested in the exercises. Prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. EDGCOMB, after which Professor E. FREEMAN, M. D., presented the report of the Faculty for the past session.

Mr. JACOBS, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, offered a resolution, at the opening of the session, this morning, directing the Comptroller to hereafter pay the ante-war debt of the State, principal and interest, in coin.

A small collection of people gathered at the Exchange yesterday, and a single sale of real estate was made. MORRIS WILKINS, auctioneer for E. H. LUDLOW Co., put up the premises No. 525 Washington street, consisting of a lot twenty-five feet by seventy-five, with a threestory brick store thereon, but after using his stentorian voice for sometime in vain, was compelled to withdraw the property.

ROGER BIRCHARD, of Dummerston, a bachelor about 75 years of age, was burned in his store, with the building and all its contents, Saturday night. Mr. BIRCHARD had been in trade full half a century, had always lived alone in his store, and was very eccentric and penurious.

A German named JOHN SCHMIDT, ill Newtown, L. I., who keeps a small store oil Jacksonavenue, about one mile from Hunter's Point, has been for some time confined to his bed by illness. One day last week, while afflicted with a violent paroxysm, he escaped from the house, taking with him a hatchet.

An excursion train from Louisville, consisting of two locomotives and fifteen passenger coaches, containing 2,000 persons, has just arrived, having crossed over the great bridge with perfect safety. The greatest enthusiasm prevails. The strength of the bridge is no longer doubted.

While the Fair of the American Institute was in progress, last Fall, we took occasion to notice, in our reports of the exhibition, the presence of a small electric engine, the power of which was applied to a sewing machine and to a force pump.

In the Essex County Court of Oyer and Terminer at Newark, the prisoners convicted during the Term were brought up yesterday to receive sentence. The Court room was crowded to excess, and the officers had much difficulty in preserving order and keeping the surging crowds within the prescribed limits.

The General Committee of the German American School Association of this City held their regular monthly meeting at Liederkranz Hall, Nos. 31 to 35 East Fourth-street, last evening, Mr. FRANCIS V. EURING Presiding.

The question of subsidizing railroads by land grants in the future, was bitterly fought in the Senate to-day, o the bill to aid in the construction of the road from Portland Oregon. to Astoria and McMinnville, in the same State, and won--so far, at least, as the present Congress is concerned.

A draft of 150 men came last night from Philadelphia, understood to be for the frigate Colorado. The whole force of this ship, including officers, crew and marines, will be 640 men. Fifty new bands wore engaged for work in the Navy Yard. and they will commence their labors to-morrow.

The Episcopalians have now four houses of worship in the township of Morrisania, viz., St. Ann's, at Wilton, (or old Morrisania,) St. Paul's, on Fordham-avenue, near. Eighth-street, St. Mary's, in Mott Haven, and Trinity, in George-street, Eltona, all apparently in a prosperous condition.
A regular meeting of the Quarantine Commissioners was held at No. 155 Broadway, at 3 P. M. yesterday. All the members were present; also, Dr. CARNOCHAN, Health Officer, and the Counsel to the Board.

The steamer City of Boston, which left this port on the 25th of January and cleared at Halifax on the 28th for Liverpool, has not been heard from yet, and naturally some anxiety is felt by parties directly interested with regard to her fate.

There are vague rumors of an organization in this city for the purpose of exterminating the Chinese residents on or before St. Patrick's Day. The attention of the authorities has been called to the matter.

Important changes in the management of the New-York Evangelist are announced. Rev. Mr. CRAIGHEAD, who has been for fourteen years past one of its editors and proprietors, has retired, with the good wishes of all who have been associated with him during this time, and Rev. Dr. ELLINWOOD, formerly of Rochester, a rising man in the Presbyterian Church, has taken his place. The American Presbylerian,

A son of the late Bishop BOONE has gone to China as a missionary. The American Free-will Baptists have a mission in Midnapore, fifty miles southwest of Calcutta. South Australia has 231 recognized ministers, or one to 874 people.

The purchase of the telegraph lines by the British Government was not consummated hastily, or without what seemed ample preparation for their successful management as an adjunct of the postal system. No pains were spared to insure success.

The tone in which some of the Democratic papers discuss the present divisions in their party will be satisfactory chiefly to political cynics These journals are saying to each other, "after this little fuss is over we shall be better friends than ever.

The Adjutant-General has taken a decided and favorable stand on the question of breechloading muskets for the National Guard. The system of tactics at present in use by the Regular and National Guard forces is peculiarly adapted to the use of breech-loaders, and all our first-class regiments should be equipped with them.

It will be remembered that on the arrival of the United States steamer Pawnee from the South Atlantic squadron, last Spring, three of the crew of said vessel preferred charges against an officer of the vessel for gross cruelty in the treatment of them.

All the trouble between the male and female students at Bellevue Hospital appears to have ceased, and the ladies attend the lectures, both clinical and general, without experiencing any annoyance. At the clinics, when delicate subjects have to be demonstrated, the ladies are requested to retire, and of course do so.

It has been for some time the reproach of our State that it has provided no home for the care and maintenance of the disabled soldiers. An institution of the kind existed at Albany a year ago, but the appropriation necessary for Its support was refused by the Legislature, and the doors of the asylum were closed.

Prompt upon the assembling of its Legislature in special session, in compliance with the proclamation of Governor BUTLER, the State of Nebraska has, by an almost unanimous vote, ratified the Fifteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

Dr. MEREDITH CLYMER explained the character of a peculiar disease in this country in 1844; and in a communication to the Medical Record, a few days since, states that he is satisfied that the relapsing fever is the same as that which he observed and described then twenty-five years ago.

The large picture of the battle of Gettysburg by Mr. JAMES WALKER, on which he has been at work for over three years, is now completed and is to be exhibited, we understand, in the principal cities of the Union.

Official information to the Indian Office is to the effect that some little dissatisfaction is felt among a few of the Puebla Indians, of Now-Mexico, owing to the small amount of goods issued to them.

Mr. WM. F. HOWE, the assigned counsel of JACK REYNOLDS, evidently intends to urge strongly the defence of insanity on behalf of his client. He visited the prisoner at the Tombs yesterday, and had a protracted interview with him.

The proposed city on Long Island, for which a charter has been prepared, comprises the following villages situated in the town of Newtown: Hunter's Point, Blissville, Laurel Hill, Astoria, Dutch Kills and Raveuswood. The charter provides for five wards--the First to comprise Hunter's Point;

The amount of proverbial and argumentative philosophy expended upon revolutions is something amazing. Their causes, their course and their finality are carved by the cold steel of logic, and riddled with rhetorical hot shot, until how they happened becomes obscure, what they did is a mystery, and when they ended forms but a chapter of " historic doubts."

It is often worth while to review the initial step in a great undertaking, the small beginnings of a groat fortune or an extensive business, the feeble and comparatively inadequate causes of great results.

The following statement shows the returns made by the various companies mentioned for the month of January. It will be seen that the gross receipts at Booth's Theatre reached the sum of $54,420, on which he paid a tax to the Government of $1,088.

A variety of occurrences tends to bring the subject of insanity prominently before the public. Disordered intellect, it is expected, will be the defence, when the perpetrators of most of the recent murders are brought to trial.

Chicago,Ill.,Feb.19.--A letter received in this city from Fort Abercrombie, says that Friday, the 11th inst., there was the most tempestuous storm on the Plains experienced this Winter. On that day CHARLES WARNER,in company with six soldiers and an Indian scout, left Fort Ransom for Abercrombie.

Of the many oases of death which result from abortions in the City of Brooklyn, as well as elsewhere, very few over come to the public notice. One, however, differing very little from most cases of the same kind has come to the surface through the Coroner's office.

The losses by the great fire in Cherrystreet Friday night, by which the Union Rice Mills of JOHN FITZGERALD were destroyed, were somewhat over estimated, but are still greatly in excess of the insurance. The loss on machinery is $50,000, and on stock $4,000, both of which fall upon Mr. FITZGERALD.

In the lower House of the Missouri Legislature to-day a concurrent resolution was offered looking to Indian suffrage, and instructing the Senators and requesting Representatives in Congress to move in that direction.

Hush I the murmur of the river, And the breeze through oak and pine Flutters to the open casement. Thrills the slender Eglantine: Lo! one comes; I hear the rustle of her garments through the gloom, And her footstep walkes the echo, And her presence fills the room.

The severest gale experienced here for many years occurred yesterday. The wind was furious until late in the night, and it has rained continuously for twenty-four hours. The molting of two feet of snow contributed to swell the flood, which has submerged the culverts and highways.

Mrs. MATHILDA F. WENDT, editor of the Neue Zeit, the German woman's rights paper of this City, delivered an elaborate and interesting lecture on the " Moral Deliverance of Mankind," before the German Reading Club, at No. 200 Third-avenue, last night.

The opera has been numerously attended during the week at the Academy. " Rigoletto" was given on Monday with good results, and there was an unexpectedly satisfactory performance of " Faust " on Wednesday. Miss KELLOGG was better than ever as Margherita, and Signor REYNA surprised the public by his excellent personation of Mephistopheles.
The funeral of Colonel GEORGE E. FARMER, late of the Sixth New-York Cavalry, took place yesterday morning at the residence of his uncle, GEORGE T. JACKSON, Esq., No. 138 East Twenty, sixth-street.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I regretted to see in the last Sunday's number of your excellent paper a fling at the coming era of blue coats and gilt buttons. I consider it a vital innovation on the established fashion-a change, as it were, from death to life.

The question of the annexation of this country to the United States continues to be the all-absorbing topic with the Dominicans, and the feeling in favor of the measure is manifestly on the increase. The verdict in the towns has been already virtually pronounced;

S.John,N.B.Feb.19.--The Government are at a deadlock with the Legislative Council because the former has dismissed Mr. BOTSFORD, who has been for many years Clerk to the Council, and the Council refuse to recognize the right of the Government to dismiss their officers and have retained Mr. BOTSFORD in his position.

Her British Majesty's ship Monarch arrived off Annapolis at 7:30 o'clock last evening and anchored six miles out, where she now lies. At 10:30 o'clock this morning Captain COMMERELL, Governor CHAMBERLAIN, of Maine, and Captains, WOOD and MCFANE at the British, came ashore,

CALVIN C. CLARK, of Bell County, Texas, was murdered in Clark County, Arkansas, on the 9th inst., by the notorious desperado named SAM. HALSEY. CLARK had assisted the Sheriff of Bell County, Texas, In arresting a gang of desperadoes to which HALSEY belonged.

The extraordinary feat of setting 2,064 ems of solid minion type in one hour was accomplished yesterday by Mr. GEORGE ARENSBERG, a TIMES compositor. The trial of speed was the result of a wager that Mr. ARENSBERG could not set four sticks of solid minion in sixty minutes.
The latest news of the Prussian excavations in the Stadium, in Athens, contained in letters from Dr. KARL CURTIUS, were communicated at a recent meeting ot the Archaeological Society of Berlin.

The funeral of Mr. HENRY E. SWEETSER, who has been for some years connected with the New-York Press, and at the time of his death was one of the editors of the World, took place yesterday at 1 o'clock, P. M., at the Madisonavenue Presbyterian Church. Rev. Dr. ADAMS,

A love for beautiful and rare flowers is manifested in every inhabitable part of the globe. Even the savage betrays a reverence for his native flowers, and all modern and ancient languages are full of eloquent passages where flowers are used as a figure of speech to express a sense of beauty or loveliness.

The steamship Main, which left Bremen Feb. 5, and Southampton Feb. 8, reached this port yesterday. Her ad vices are later by two days than were those at hand by the China. The Globe learns that Mr. AUSTIN, an American millionaire, and the representative of an eminent American shipbuilding firm, has agreed to purchase Deptford Dockyard for [Pound]140,000.

The decision of the High Court of France, in the case of Prince BONAPARTE, was published yesterday in Paris, and is more serious than was at first supposed. He is adjudged to have committed homicide on the person of VICTOR NOIR, and to have attempted the homicide of FONVILLE.

Tile other day a lawyer was nearly killed by a dose of medicine which a druggist's assistant mixed for him in this City. Who bared? The druggist was not punished, and a hundred people may since have received a cup of poison instead of the healing draught.

In St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Jersey City, yesterday, the pastor, Rev. Dr. CORRIGAN, preached from the text where the word of God is compared to a mustard seed, and after paraphrasing the Gospel and applying it to the spiritual necessities of his hearers in many of its phases, he took occasion to upbraid those Christians who have no other object

Yesterday morning in the South Congregational Church, Court-street, Brooklyn, of which the late Mr. VOORHERS was a member, the pastor, Rev. Dr. STORRS, delivered a very impressive discourse on the symptoms of social misrnic with special reference to the tragic event of the preceding Sunday. The devotional exercises and lessons of the day bore special reference to the uncertainty of human life.

There has been no material improvement in the real estate market during the week which has just past. An unusual number of auction sales for the present season took place at the Exchange Rooms, and Tuesday, especially, was a comparatively busy day, but this is no reliable criterion of the state of the market.

Postmaster JONES sent, on Saturday. sevoral packages of books and bundles to the Custom House that duties might be collected on them. It appear that the law allows samples of articles to be received from foreign countries by mall free of duty.

Just before the adjournment of the House on Saturday the Speaker laid before that body a communication from the Secretary of State with further correspondence upon the recent assassination of GREENWALDTH and the wounding of his companions in Havana. Amongst the pavers is an affidavit by WELLS, in which, after giving the particulars of the assault, he says:

The statements of our Washington correspondent in regard to the feeling prevalent in Congress towards the Administration, may excite surprise. There have not been want ing indications of captiousness, not to say hostility, on the part of Senators in the matter of appointments.

The heavy rain of Friday night raised the water in the Kennebee and its tributaries to an unprecedented height for this season of the year. The present ice freshet is without a parallel in this section. From the Upper Kennebee every arrival brings intelligence of damages.

It is stated by one of our foreign exchanges that near the City of Medina, in Italy, and about four miles around it, wherever the earth is dug, when the workmen arrive at a distance of sixty-three feet they come to a bed of chalk, which they bore with an auger, five feet deep.

The probability of a compromise between the Democratic factions is said to be Increased by a recent vigorous application of "the screw." It is well known that among the treasures in the District-Attorney's office there is a number of indictments against the class which we may denominate "political criminals."

Yesterday morning, between 3 and 4 o'clock, a somewhat noisy party of roysteres entered an oyster saloon situated corner of Hamilton-avenue and Van Brunt-street, kept by THOMAS McNAMARA. Drinks were, it appears, freely demanded and consumed, but a disposition was manifested to evade their payment.

A Paris dispatch says that an Imperial decree convokes the High Court of Justice to meet at Tours March 21, for the trial of Prince PIERRE BONAPARTE. The members of the Court will be determined by lot. The defence, according to the Gazette des Tribunaux, will be that provocation was given and the killing was in self-defence.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read the letter of "A Line Officer" in the TIMES of the 13th inst., and your editorial of the same date on the line and staff dispute. I am tempted by that communication, and the interest that your paper shows in the question, to ask for space to give your some opinions formed

In our recent article on the legal-tender question, as affected by the decision of the Supreme Court, we stated that during the war with NAPOLEON Great Britain resorted to .the policy of "making the bills of the Bank of England in effect a legal tender."

The meeting to be held at Copper Institute to-night should be such as to convince the Legislature that the great body of the people earnestly desire that the State should make adequate provision at once for the care and maintenance of our sick and disabled soldiers.
