Hon. JOHN WENTWORTH is to lecture on temperance in Chicago, Young people who lisp are requested to say Miss Myth Smith. Indiana has a new post office, to be known as Clear Creek Switch. Williams College is to receive $30,000, payable in three equal annual installments, from ORRIN SAGE, of Ware, Mass.

The chief matter now occupying public attention is the return of the National Guards from Paraguay. 'Preparations have been made to receive them on a grand scale; arches, trophies, flags, illuminations, fireworks and the usual other accompaniments of triumphal marches having been ready for the last week or ten days.

Senator MORTON has just introduced into Congress an exceedingly important resolution, calling upon the President for information as to the number and character of our ironclads, their cost, the list of their dosigners and the present condition of the vessels. This resolution has been agreed to,

The Board met in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present--Assistant Aldermen Healy, Lysaght, O'Brien, Galvin, Robinson, Hill, Hampson, Odell, Rogers, Hoffman, Mulligan, Costello, Gibney, Schlichting, Haughton, Feitner, Scerey, McDonald, Fay, Shelley-20.

On Saturday forenoon Messrs. KOHLER and KAMERA, brewers of Guttenberg, were arrested and arraigned before Commissioner HOFFMAN, of Hoboken, charged by a man named RICHARD DOBBS with violating the Internal revenue laws, by taking from old lager beer kegs revenue stamps which had never been canceled and putting them on new kegs in such a manner that they could be taken off and used again.

Nashville,Tenn.,Feb.20.--The Kossuth House, on Market-street, was burned about 3 o'clock this morning. The fire originated in the dining room on the first floor, and was not discovered until all means of egress, except by the windows of the upper story were cut off. The inmates of the house had to save themselves by jumping from the second floor.

A Building Association, chiefly of German workmen of this City and Brooklyn, has been formed with the object of building a town called Breslau, at Well wood Station, on the Southside Railroad. L. I. One section of the Association, consisting of 500 members, is already fully organized, and a second section is forming.

The Thirteenth, Fourteen tl and Fifteenth Constitutional Amondments have finally passed both Houses. Resolutions recommending the establishment of a general postal telegraph system more presented in the Legislature and tabled.

GENTLEMEN: Your favor of the 14th inst. was received this morning. I have received a telegram from E. H. ROLLINS, Chairman of your state Republican Committee, containing an invitation to canvass your State before the appreaching election, to which I have replied.

In the House of Representatives, on the 16th inst., Mr. BENNETT, of this State, introduced the following bill, and it was road twice, referred to the Committee of Commerce, and ordered to be printed: A BILL to provide for the better protection of the Northern and Northwestern frontier, and to facilitate commerce, and diminish the expense of the exchanges between States.

Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER'S morning discourse yesterday was devoted to a consideration of three conditions of religious life--that in which fear and conserense induce piety, that in which love and hope are the exciting causes, and finally that spiritual state which so few are able to attain here.

In reproducing in America Dr. DICKSON'S translation of MOMMSEN'S Roman History, Messrs. SCRIBNER have done a very important service to the cause of education in the country. This and MAX MULLER'S Chips are the most important philological works issued among us for a long time.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The item which you copied from the Hartford Times in your yesterday's issue, relative to Dr. EWER and the Bishop of Connecticut, oontained two errors, which injustice to both those divines, should be corrected.

On Thursday evening next, Rev. JOHN MURRAY FORBES, D. D., Dean of the Episcopal General Theological Seminary in this City, will be formally inducted into office at the Church of the Transfiguration, Rev. Dr. MORGAN'S. The exercises of the occasion will consist of, 1. Evening prayer.

There now seems less probability of a confliet between Judge McCUNN and the Federal Courts in the Bininger case. Judge BLATCHFORD has decided that Mr.. CLARK, who was the plaintiff in the suit in the Superior Court, must allow the assignee in bankruptcy to conduct that suit in his own name,

Rev. Jos. P. WOODS, Pastor of St. Augustine's Church, Morrisania, lectured last evening in St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Sixth-avenue, in aid of the poor fund of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, connected with that church. The church was filled to repletion, admission being fixed at fifty cents per head.

The masked ball of the Liederkranz Society will take place at the Academy of Music on the 24th inst. The Liederkranz is the largest and wealthiest German singing society of this country, and its masquerade promises to be one of the greatest affairs of the season.

E. P. HUNT, Esq., of Elmira, counsel for DAN NOBLE and MAGGIE DEWITT, has made a motion at a Special Term of the Supreme Court, to be argued the present week at Ithaen, before Judge BOARDMAN, for the unconditional discharge from the indictments pending against them and charging them with complicity in the Royal Insurance Company bond larceny.

During Saturday night the store of PETRY O'HARE. No.399 Third-avenue, was entered by burglars, by a second-story window, which they reached from a rear shed. After ransacking the place, they only found twenty-five pounds of solder and $2 in money which they could make available.

We can never legislate virtue against vice, and any attempt to achieve purely moral results by enactments of Congress will certainly fail. The moral law carries with it its own penalty. We cannot make men good by declaring that all men must be good.

Yesterday afternoon a young man named WILLIAM CLARKE was arrested by Roundsman TEHAN for committing a brutal assault on his wife and her mother in Hudson City. The bruised appearance of the complainants proved the nature of their treatment.

Not long ago Mr. BRIGHT asked the indulgence of the British public for the Government of which he is a member, by stating that it was as impossible to pass in one ses sion all the groat measures that were expected of them as it would be to drive six omnibuses abreast through the narrow gateway of Temple Bar.

The Inman steamship City of Brooklyn. which left Liverpool Feb. 10, and Queenstown Feb. 11, arrived at this port last night. Her advices are later by three days than those at hand by the Main. The letters and papers embodying them were received at this office at 2:15 this A. M. The Queen's address to Parliament was the principal topic of comment in England.

Shortly before midnight of Saturday a party of about twenty were carousing in BAILEY'S saloon, beneath the Darcy Buildings, in Jersey City, when a quarrel arose between several of the crowd, one of whom, named PATRICK EGAN, was struck, as is alleged, a terrible blow on the head with an iron belaying pin, in the hands of a man named JAMES CANFIELD.

BARTOW.--At East Fishkill, N. Y., on Sunday morning, Feb. 20, WILLIAM A. BARTOW, in the 77th year of his age. The funeral will take place at Trinity Church, Fishkill, on Wednesday morning, at 11 1/2 o'clock. The 8 A. m. train on Hudson River Railroad from New-York connects with Dutchess and Columbia Railroad for Fishkill Village.

The announcement that the President favors an immediate reduction of taxation, and that the House Committee of Ways and Means has resolved to report in its favor, is hailed with satisfaction and enthusiastically indorsed by Republican papers throughout the country.

At length it becoming dark, he found it necessary to descend, and the result of his attempt he tells as follows:

At the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, before Judge COX, PETER MAGINNIS aged 23, who resides at No. 124 Tenth-avenue, was arraigned on a charge of complicity in the murder of JOHN MURKLE, who was stabbed to death in front of his house, No. 459 Tenth-avenue, on the night of the 1st of January.

Last evening Rev. WILLIAM BUTLER, D. D., discoursed on the Methodist Missions in India, of which he is the founder, in the Methodist Episcopal Church, Allen-street. He said that on the th of April, 1856, he was commissioned by the American Methodist Missionary Society to proceed to London and take counsel with the Church missionaries there in reference to the

"Rigoletto" is to be sung at the Academy of Music, for the last time, to-night....Mr. FALCONER'S new drama of "Innisfallen; or the Men in the Gap," is to be acted at Niblo's. for the first time in this City, this evening. Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, who have not been heard at Niblo's for five years, fill the leading parts in the play.

GILLET--BREZ.--On Thursday, Feb. 17. at the residence of the bride's parents, by Rev. Francis E. Lawrence, D. D., ETIENNE A. GILLET, of Geneve, Switzerland, to ELISE ALINE, daughter of Paul A. Brez, of New-York.

On Friday night JOHN L. PHIPPS, a farmer, residing near Lincoln, III., while in a fit of frenzy, the cause of which is unknown, shot his wife through the heart with a revolver, inflicting a mortal wound. He then fired a shot into his own brain and expired almost immediately. Mrs. PHIPPS is still alive, but unconscious.

About 4 o'clock yesterday morning, while Officer CONNOLLY was on duty in the vicinity of the Morris Canal basin, his attention was attracted by the cries of some person in danger in that direction. On hastening down he found a night watchman, named JAMES GARVEY, in an exhausted state, just after he had been rescued from drowning.

SAMUEL BREWER, of this city, complained to the Police a day or two ago, that his stepson,GEORGE BILLINGS, had attempted to poison the family by putting something in their tea. No poison was found in the tea not used, and no one was made so sick as to need a physician.

About four hundred persons were assembled in the Hall of the Cooper Institute last evening, at the fourth in the series of temperance meetings which are being held under the auspices of the "Sons of Temperance." After singing and prayer, General CATLIN read an address.

The followers of BRIGHAM YOUNG assembled yesterday at their usual place of worship, No. 145 Grand-street, Williamsburg. A portion of the assemblage appeared to be attracted by curiosity, but during the service listened attentively to the doctrine of Mormonism as preached by the disciples of JOSEPH SMITH.

Paris,Feb.19.--It is reported that the Ministers, in spite of the advice of the Police to the contrary, will permit the procession to pass through the streets on Mardi-gras....The Imperial decree in the Officiel Journal convokes the High Court of Justice, to meet at Tours on the 21st of March.

The ceremony of laying the corner stone of a new Catholic church at Williamsbridge took place about 1 o'clock yesterday, according to announcement. Special trains were run on the Harlem Railroad for the Convenience of those wishing to attend, and the cars inside, platforms and roofs were crowded to the utmost capacity. Captain JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, on Saturday afternoon met in the street WILLIAM MILLER, a notorious butcher cart thief whom he had particularly wanted for some time, and therefore took him into custody. In August last MILLER, with a confederate, picked up a case of silks valued at $300, from in front of No. 211 Broadway, threw it into their cart and drove rapidly away.

Hitherto the Republican policy of Reconstruction has been essentially sectional. It has been the means employed by the major power in the Union to extinguish the last signs of the rebellion, and to reestablish order and authority in the Southern States, in accordance with the principles and purposes which triumphed in the war.

The Joint Committee on Retreuchment made a report to-day. They mention that they visited, during the Summer vacation, the Cities of New-York, Chicago and San Francisco, and carefully inquired into the administration of the public service, and took a large amount of testimony relating to. abuses therein, the most valuable parts of which they submit for the consideration of Congress.

In the French Corps Legislatif yesterday M. JULES FAVRE moved his " iunterpellation " on domestic policy, supporting it in a speech in which he denounced the arrest of ROCHEFORT, and generally assailed the Government and the majority as the instruments of "personal power."

The Geological Section met last evening, Professor NEWBURY in, the chair. Mr. GILBERT stated some interesting facts, the result of soundings on Lake Ontario, which tend to show that the modern lakes have been much larger than at present. After some discussion of this point Professor EDWARDS made some remarks calling attention to recent investigations made in France upon meteorites, their composition and origin.

PATRICK SCANLAN, one of the Erie rioters, before being sentenced, yesterday, in the Hundson County, N. J., Court of Quarter Sessions, was addressed by the Court to the effect that he was found guilty of palticipating in an unlawful assembly.

IRISH DRAMA AT NIBLO'S. Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS reappeared at Niblo's Theatre, last evening, after five years absence from that house. They were the objects of a cordial welcome, and by the applause marking the progress of their performance and the enthusiasm amid which it closed, were afforded unequivocal proofs of their pleasant influence.

In Washington, Dutchess County. resides a man 70 years of ago, named BENJAMIN RYDER. For twenty years he has lived solitary and alone in his dilapidated dwelling, doing his own cooking and subsisting chiefly upon samp, milk and eggs. He owns real and personal property to the amount of $16,000.

An examination was hold in the United States Commissioner's office yesterday in the ease of MARTIN R. COOK, of the firm of GORDON, FELLOWS MOMILLAN, wholesale liquor dealers, charged with having aided and abetted an ox-gauger named EBENEZER W. FARRINGTON in making false returns on a large quantity of whisky at the time of its removal from bond.

La Patrie has an editorial to-day suggested by the anniversary of the birth of WASIIINGTON. "This," It says, "is as much a day for rejoicing for France as for the United States. America owes a great debt to LAFAYFTTE, who contributed so much to the success of the Rovolulion, and without whom there would have been no Union."

However we may talk or hope to the contrary, the assertion of ice companies that the Hudson River crop is a failure is a true one, fully confirmed in fact by all reports from sources outside of the companies. at Poughkeepsie the river has not been closed this season, hence no ice could be gathered for the houses there, and they can hold over 300,000 tons.

Yesterday evening, at 8 o'clock, before Coroner JONES and a jury, an inquest was opened into the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. CASSIDY while under medical treatment, on the 17th inst., in the Dlspensary InFlatbush-avenue, Brooklyn.

As our readers will remember, the ship Neptune, Captain PEABODY, from Liverpool, came into this port about the 10th., soon after which time certain of the crew and passengers made complaints against the officers, it which gross outrages were charged.

Mr. WILLIAMS introduced a joint resolution declaring the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States by the requisite number of States. Referred to the Judiciary Committee. BILLS INTRODUCED. The following bills were introduced: By Mr. CHANDLER-Extending the time for the completion of the Flint and Pere Marquette Railroad, Michigan.

The Indiana Republican State Convention is to be hold in Indianapolis to-day. Cairo has a new paper called the Egytian Sun. This Cairo is n Illinois. St. Louis sends New-Orleans 30,000 tons of Ice under one contract.

The Merrimack and coneord Livers aro very high. Several roads near Lowell were flooded yesterday. Some of the mills stopped to-day on account of the back water. POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 21.-There has been a remarkable change In the weather since 7 o'clock last evening. It is nearly forty degrees colder.

An earlier letter must have prepared you for the deplorable events of which Paris has bcen the theatre for the last forty-eight hours. It is due to the Opposition to say that by the calm and moderate course which it pursued in the Chamber on Monday last it did its best to save the Government from the patent error which it has committed.

The New-York Cooperative Clothing Manufacturing Company hold its regular meeting last night at No. 10 Stanton-street. The regular weekly installments, towards raising the necessary capital for the Company, were paid by the members, and also new members admitted.

The Cadet investigation has resulted in a first-class sensation. As indicated in these dispatches last night, the Military Committee took up the evidence this morning and after a three hours session unanimously resolved to bring the matter before the House for immediate action in one case at least.

SUPREME COURT--CIRCUIT. Part II.--Held by Brady, J. Adjourned to Wednesday on account of Washington's Birthday. The same adjournments for the same reason have been made in all the branches of the Superior Court held by Judges Barbour, monell, McCunn, Jones Spencer and Freedman.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J W. Simonton, General Agent.

TIMOTHY and JAMES DEVINE wore brought up at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, before Judge LEDWITH, charged with breaking into a schooner belonging to Captain HART, now lying at the foot of Twenty-third-street, on Saturday evening, and stealing property to the amount of $75.

Though tardy, the step ' taken last night at the Cooper Institute to house our needy veterans will probably result in freeing the State from a deserved reproach. A National Asylum for disabled soldiers we already have, with its centre in Ohio and its branches in Maine and Wisconsin, and a prospective wing in California.

It is not difficult to be wickedly virtuous, and a thousand contemptuous things are sooner said than one wise one. Certain Senators showed this out very fully, in their rage against the wayward sister Virginia, seeking to return.

On the 15th of last December eleven iron moulders left the employment of GEORGE R. JACKSON, BURNET Co., of the Excelstor Iron Works, by order of the Moulders' Union, and their places were supplied by competent workmen, to whom the highest wages were paid, and the firm has proceeded with the execution of order with entire success, casting very day.

T. G. Tracy. Esq., Editor Austin Daily State Journal: MY DEAR SIR: As a response to the numerous applications to permit the use of my name as a candidate for the United States Senate, I have the honor to request the publication of this note. I am not a candidate for any civil position whatever, and have never authorized the use of my name in such connection.

At no time since the great swill--milk war of 1857 has the public been so inflamed with this disgusting and inhuman traffic as the present. Both the Brooklyn and New--York public have been swindled by milkdealers who. under the guise of dealing out " pure unadulterated Orange and Kings Country milk," have through their nefarious game spread disease and death in their chalk-and -lead admixture called milk.

The Brooklyn Chess Tourney was very numerously attended on Saturday last. Several celebrated players from New-York and Williamsburg, candidates for chess honors, were present, among others Captain MACKENZIE, MASON, Major WERNICK and VON FRANKENBERG.

Chief Justice HINMAN, of the Supreme Court of this State, is in a dying condition at his residence in Cheshire.... The two hundredth anniversary of the organiza,tion of the South Congregational Church of this city will be celebrated Tuesday and Wednesday. NEW-HAVEN, Feb. '21.-The Democratic State Convention meets to-morrow.

Washington,Feb.21.--The United States Supreme Court to-day decided the following case: Benjamin H. Cheever vs. Jesse B. Witson and Annie J. Worcester.--Appeal from the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.--This was an action brought to enforce the provisions of a decree of divorce granted in Indiana, between the plaintiff in error and the defendant. WORCESTER.

The efforts of District-Attorney GARVIN to bring JOHN REYNOLDS to trial for the murder of WILLIAM TOWNSEND have been at last successful. The proceedings in the case began yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge INGRAHAM. Tile expectation that the trial would come on drew together an enormous assemblage of spectators.

Commissioner BOSWORTH sat yesterday morning to investigate charges against policemen. There was the usual variety of oases, the major portion being for neglect of patrol duty. Masked balls were held by the following German societies last night: The singing society " Liederhain," Mr. GODFREY VOGEL, President, and Mr. JOHN RUECKNER, Musical Director, at Dramatic Hall, Nos. 46 and 48 East Houstonstreet. The cold snap which followed close on the heels of the heavy shower of Suuday evening, culminated yesterday in a regular old-fashioned Winter day. A high wind prevailed all day, and the thermometer fell to a point several degrees lower than on any day before this season. From 5 o'clock yesterday morning to midnight wore the coldest nineteen hours experienced this Winter.

Houston, of Philadelphia, and James Roy, Esq., of West Troy, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

The name of those who are at Washington in search of subsidies is Legion. They are there from all quarters, in all disguises, and with all manner of projeots,-but their common end is money. They are patriots, of course, and their schemes are patriotic, and they insist that they are entitled to grow rich at the cost of the Treasury.

The President today transmitted to the House of Representatiues a large mass of documents in reply to a resolution of that body on the subject of Cuban affairs. It gives the letters and telegrams which passed between Minister SICKLES and Secretary FISH In relation to an armistice and purchase of Cuba, , the particulars of which has heretofore been published from documents sent to these Senate.

Havana,Feb.21.--Important news has just been received from Nassau. General QUESADA and five companions arrived at Nassau on the 14th inst. In a small boat. It is reported that the steamer Anna has again been seized on the declaration of one of her crew.

According to announcement, a mass meeting of citizens, without distinction of party, was hold at the Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of approving the proposed passage of a law to establish a Soldiers' Home in this State, as an asylum for the wounded and disabled who fought to put down the rebellion.

The Board of Aldermen met at 2 o'clock P. M. yesterday, Mr. COMAN in the Chair. Resolutions were adopted to fix the salary of the Second Clerk in the Bureau of Street improvements at $3,500 per annum, and that of the General Clark of the Board of Aldermen at the same amount as is now paid the Fourth Assistant Clerk of that Board.

Rev. W. P. CORBITT occupied the floor at the Methodist preachers' meeting, yesterday, in defence of demonstrative Methodism, which, he conceived, had been slandered by Rev. Drs. FOSTER and CATTELLE on previous occasions.

No extended preparations have been made for the celebration of the 138th anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birthday in this City to-day. A parade of the Veterans of 1812 will be a prominent feature of its observance. A full choral service will be held In Trinity Church at 11 A. M., and WASHINGTON'S Farewell Address will be road.

There was very little doing at the Exchange yesterday in the way of disposing of real estate. STANLEY DAY occupied half an hour in selling the house and lot No. 205 West Twenty second street. The bidding started at $11,000, and was worked up by small and apparently reluctant advances, generally of $10 at a true, to $13,000, at whcih figure it was struck down.

Commenting upon the report of Secretary BOUTWELL, we very earnestly dissented from his recommendation that taxes should not be reduced, and said, with a plainness which a true friendship to the Administration demanded, that its policy in that particular was contrary to the wishes of the people and to the interests of the country.

While the sentiment of gratitude exists in a nation, the recurrence of this day will be celebrated with cordiality and rejoicing. No people can ever deem that they are over-burdened with such occasions, since each of them must necessarily be associated with events which not only exalt history, but carry with it a moral that can never lose its import.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your correspondent "Old Soger," in his article headed "Interesting but Dangerous Ordnance Experiments," in your paper of the 18th inst., tries to be witty at my expense. It would be interesting to know if he acquired his wit in the same school in which he learned so much about the "science of grinnery."

The new school building for District No. 10 will be open for inspection to-day, preparatory to the reception of pupils on the day following. Public School No. 10 is a plain three-story and basement brick building, provided with excellent heating apparatus and the most thorough appliances for securing a constant supply of fresh air.

CLARK--ROWE.--In Brooklyn on Saturday, Feb. 19, by Rev. Dr. Barclay, of Toronto, Canada (uncle of the bridegroom,) assisted by Rev. Dr. Drown, Rector of St. Paul's Church, Brooklyn, JAMES B. CLARK, third son of James Clark, Esq., of Crossbasket Castle, Scotland, to MARY T., oldest daughter of Alfred L. ROWE, Esq., of Brooklyn.

The steamer Emma No. 3, which left hero Friday evening tor Cincinnati, while going through Chutte Island, No. 85, struck a snag and careened. The stove in the ladles' cabin upset, setting the boat on fire and totally destroying her, Ten or twelve lives are reported lost but nothing definite is known. A terrible gale prevailed at the time and the water was intensely cold.

We desire to call the attention of Bur readers to the fact that a groat amount of real destitution exists at present among the poor of the Fourteenth Ward, especially in the neighborhood of Broome, Elizabeth and Mott streets.

A disease, fatal in its effects as the Asiatic cholera, has broken out at Albion, in the western part of this county, its first appearance having been made on Saturday last. Five grown persons, each of different families, have died since that time, and others are now prostrated with the terrible disease.

LEWIS MURRAY, one of the porters employed in the Post Office, was charged with embezzlement in the United States Commissioner's office yesterday, on complaint of Special Agent GAYLOR. It was alleged that over one hundred letters were found in his possession at the time of his arrest, and that many of the number contained money.

Mr. J. P. BRACE, one of the Western agents of the Children's Aid Society, left the City yesterday with a large company of homeless and destitute children. The party, which numbered 103, was composed chiefly of orphan boys and girls from 1 to 18 years of age.

Poor TOWNSEND'S murderer, JOHN REYNOLDS, was yesterday found guilty of murder in the first degree, and will this morning be sentenced. The case was so positive that its interest centered in the attempt of the prisoner's counsel to absolve him of moral responsibility for the act.

The fate of this fine vessel of the Inman line is still in suspense. She left this port on the 25th of January, and three days afterwards she passed Halifax, since which time nothing has been heard from her. She was duo in Liverpool on the 6th inst., and is therefore, eighteen days late.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has just been directed to your editorial of this morning on the "Case of Georgia." I noticed especially the following assertions: "That the Legislature, as existing in December last, when the last act of Congress was passed, was unlawfully organized;"

A serious railroad accident occurred near the station at New-Rochelle, on Monday afternoon, which is likely to result in the loss of two lives. Mr. and Mrs. O'ROURKE, who live in the building known as Chatsworth Station, situated about two miles east of New-Rochelle, while under the influence of liquor, proceeded to walk along the railroad on the way home from the village.

The night express freight and passenger train bound north, and a freight train bound south, collided at Tivoli Station early this morning, damaging the engines and the platforms of several cars slightly. Some of the passengers were bruised a little by being thrown from their seats. The accident has caused no delay to other trains.

M. CHEVAUDIER DE VALDROME, Minister of the Interior, has submitted to the' Emporor and to legislative bodies a report favoring the decentralization of the Executive administration. The Corps Legislatif has referred it to a committee consisting of MM. BARROT, GUIZOT and PREVOST-PARADOL.

Yesterday's snow storm blocked up the railroads In every direction, East and West, and the trains are all stopped. Yesterday's and to-day's Western trains are still at Bonaventura Station, and the train due last night, is blocked up at Lachine Junction.
